title: BASEBALL;Before Starting Season, Mets Trade for a Starter
description: When spring training began some seven weeks ago, Mets Manager Dallas Green was asked how he was going to whittle a group of 10 potential starting pitchers into the five spots available in the rotation. "Sometimes those things take care of themselves," Green said, using 41 years of experience in baseball as his guide. "We'll just have to see how it all shakes down."

title: Public Radio Serves Not Just the Affluent
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Division Made Simple: Knicks No Match for Magic
description: When Shaquille O'Neal rose up over Patrick Ewing and force-fed the rim with the basketball late in the game, not one of his teammates went overboard with emotion. When Anfernee Hardaway spotted up over Derek Harper, keeping his elbows in while knocking down a third-quarter 3-pointer, the dueling floor leaders ran back down the court as if it were another day.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the dismissal of an administrator at a Queens social-service agency carried an incorrect byline in some copies. It was written by Alan Finder, not Pam Belluck.

title: In America;Horror Threshold
description: City officials continue to argue that it somehow makes sense -- is somehow in the best interests of the children -- to develop a plan to return three boys to their parents, even though they were savagely abused, and their brother was killed, at the hands of those parents.

title: Essay;The Dole Doctrine
description: Does Bob Dole have a foreign policy? If so, is it more likely to extend freedom and less likely to lead to war than Bill Clinton's?

title: FACING ELECTION, YELTSIN IS HALTING WAR ON CHECHENS
description: Struggling to end the deeply unpopular Chechen war before pivotal elections in June, President Boris N. Yeltsin said today that all major military operations in the secessionist republic in southern Russia would stop at once.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Shifting Patterns, Small Surprises
description: Nancy Meehan makes dances in which everything seems to merge and flow along as inexorably as some age-old natural phenomenon. A good example is Ms. Meehan's new "Glacier Track," presented by the Nancy Meehan Dance Company on Saturday night at St. Mark's Church.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;City Turns to Water Company
description: Jersey City will turn over the management of its municipal Water Department today to the privately owned United Water Company. The city is expected to make a net profit of $38.5 million over the five-year life of the deal, officials of Jersey City and United Water said last week.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Tollbooths End Police Chase
description: The driver of a stolen tractor-trailer truck led the police on a 50-mile chase up the New Jersey Turnpike yesterday until he was arrested after stopping at the George Washington Bridge tollbooths, The Associated Press reported.

title: World News Briefs;Separatists in Kashmir Strike to Protest Slayings
description: A strike called by separatists after the police killed 24 militants near a Muslim shrine on Saturday closed businesses today in Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu and Kashmir state.

title: Treasury Is Selling Only Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week is confined to bills, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and a nine-day cash management bill. On Tuesday, the Treasury will auction a 52-week bill.

title: FINAL FOUR;Unwanted Guard Now Unshakable
description: Early reports from the home front indicated that Kentucky students felt the need to wear their emotions, but not their clothes, after Saturday's 81-74 victory over Massachusetts in the Final Four.

title: Don't Capsize the U.N.
description: The United Nations is in financial straits that are deep, dangerous and only partly deserved. As of the beginning of this year, half its members had not paid last year's dues in full, with the United States leading the pack. The deadbeat total has swelled to $3.1 billion. According to Joseph Connor, the Under Secretary General for Administration, the U.N. faces a cash crisis that could curtail or even shut down its operations by November.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Public Hearings on Welfare
description: Members of the public will also get a chance tomorrow to express their views on Governor Whitman's proposals to overhaul the state's welfare system. The Department of Human Services will hold a series of hearings at three locations: the Hudson County Administration building in Jersey City, Thomas Edison College in Trenton and the Educational Information and Resource Center in Sewell.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Abuse Inquiry at Hospital
description: A five-member panel was named last week to investigate allegations of physical abuse and patient intimidation at the Essex County Hospital Center's psychiatric hospital. The panel will also look into the thefts of towels, sheets, pillow cases and cleaning supplies at the 400-bed hospital, said Joanna Noonan, a spokeswoman for James W. Treffinger, the County Executive.

title: GOLF;A Final-Round Charge Gives Couples Victory
description: America's best and most popular player stopped the bleeding today, both his own and that of his golfing generation. Fred Couples single-handedly put a halt to the PGA Tour youth movement by shooting a near-flawless final round of 64, winning The Players Championship by four strokes and restoring order to the golf world.

title: Abroad at Home;Smears And Facts
description: On Whitewater, it is time to follow Al Smith's advice: "Let's look at the record." For there is a record, the reports of a detailed and dispassionate investigation. And practically no one has read those reports.

title: Where the City Meets Country
description: A cluster of teen-agers stood giggling and squirming in the moonlight on a forested hillside 100 miles northwest of Manhattan, trying their best to be silent. "Just for one minute," implored a naturalist leading them on a nocturnal hike. "Then tell me what you hear."

title: Breaking Ranks, Lab Offers Test To Assess Risk of Breast Cancer
description: In the small world of geneticists in the forefront of studying human disease, the researchers tend to know one another. So last year, after the discovery that as many as 1 percent of Jewish women carry a mutated form of a gene that might predispose them to breast and ovarian cancer, it was easy enough for leading scientists and two major commercial testing labs to agree informally not to offer the test to the general public.

title: His Mission: First Revival For Prodigy, Then Buyout
description: Last spring, as I.B.M. was looking for a new chief executive for Prodigy Services, the stumbling, stodgy on-line service it owns jointly with Sears, Roebuck & Company, the candidates were summoned to I.B.M.'s headquarters in Armonk, N.Y.

title: HOCKEY;Nemchinov Adapts to Put Two on Board for Rangers
description: Sergei Nemchinov looks around the Rangers' locker room and sees a lineup that has changed dramatically in the past few weeks. And when he gets on the ice, he sees linemates who often vary from shift to shift.

title: Corrections
description: A World News Briefs headline yesterday about Indian military action at a mosque in Kashmir misstated the target of the forces' attack. Troops destroyed the headquarters of a separatist group that had occupied the mosque; they did not destroy the mosque itself.

title: Japanese Stocks and the Dollar Are Higher
description: The Nikkei index of 225 issues climbed to a four-year high today on expectations that profits at exporters such as the Toshiba Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation would rise as the dollar hit a two-year high against the Japanese yen.

title: Israeli Technology Concern Gets Offer of $856 Million
description: Davidi Gilo, an Israeli-American deal maker based in Silicon Valley, made a hostile offer yesterday to buy the Scitex Corporation, a troubled manufacturer of digital technology used in printing, in a cash transaction valued at $856 million, or $20 a share.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;A Doctor Who Tried To Shape a Generation
description: Dr. Spock the Baby Doc" is an amiable profile, with contributions from its subject, of the world's most popular child-care advisor in his roles as pediatrician, politician, protester and parent. Interviewed when he was approaching 90 (he is now almost 93), the baby doc seems in good shape, vigorous, clear minded, hard working and as tall as ever. There he is, single-handedly readying his boat for a sail.

title: In St. Louis, Pulitzer Flagship Is in Search of Itself
description: The editor of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, William F. Woo, is one of the country's most prominent journalists. But when it came to getting the news that he was being forced out of his job, Mr. Woo was among the last to know.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Debating Revenue Projections
description: The Legislature will begin its formal budget review process tomorrow, when members of the Senate and Assembly appropriations committees are expected to hear conflicting revenue projections.

title: BASEBALL;After Perez's Shaky Outing, Rogers Will Start, After All
description: Welcome to New York, Kenny Rogers. In a surprise move today, the Yankees returned the $20 million pitcher to their starting rotation today, one day after they had surprisingly turned him into a long reliever.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * U.S. Gold Inc., San Francisco, a subsidiary of Centre Gold P.L.C., to Ciociola & Co., New York, to introduce three video games: Olympic Summer Games, Olympic Soccer and Dream Team Basketball. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Wary Chechens Scorn Plan by Yeltsin
description: The mood in Grozny, the capital of Chechnya, was decidedly somber today even as President Boris N. Yeltsin announced his plan to bring peace to the devastated region.

title: FINAL FOUR;Pressure of Expectations Vs. Pain of Past Failures
description: Someone's time will arrive tonight. The only question that remains in the college basketball season is the degree of surprise at the finish. The Kentucky Wildcats have the chance to turn the overwhelming demand for a sixth national championship into their destiny. The Syracuse Orangemen, a tournament surprise because of an old and basic tactic, a simple but effective 2-3 zone, can win their school's first championship.

title: Prairie Revolt: Sound and Fury but Little Fire
description: The vast, sparsely populated reaches of the Rocky Mountain West, especially Montana, have been a magnet in recent years for an assortment of far-right extremists who hope to inspire a widespread rebellion.

title: Uganda's Christian Rebels Revive War in North
description: Rosalba Acene was running after the guerrillas who had just kidnapped her two nephews from her village near here last week, when the dirt path underneath her erupted in a searing white light. The land mine blew off her right leg above the knee, not only crippling her for life, but leaving her four children without a provider.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Mobile Media Selects Jordan, McGrath
description: Mobile Media Communications Inc. in Ridgefield Park, N.J., which provides paging and personal communications systems like voice mail, has named Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor in New York to handle its account, which had been at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York for a year. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Taking In the Sites;Hey, Does Camp Granada Have a Home Page Yet?
description: If you couldn't get to the summer camp fairs held in February because you were shoveling snow, you can make up for lost time by researching camps on the World Wide Web.

title: Contract Is Expiring for 350 at CBS News
description: The first labor negotiation at CBS News since the Westinghouse Electric Company bought CBS Inc. earlier this year reaches a pivotal moment tonight at midnight, when the company's contract with the Writers Guild of America at CBS's three biggest television and radio stations expires. The union's members have voted to authorize a strike.

title: Media
description: IN a storyline that could have been borrowed from a classic MGM musical, the battered MGM studio has finally emerged from oblivion and gained respect after too many years in the doldrums. Unlike the musicals, though, the ending is bound to be a melancholy one.

title: Public Radio Serves Not Just the Affluent
description: To the Editor:

title: Pension-Fund Group Faces Its Own Governance Battle
description: The Council of Institutional Investors, a collection of large pension funds that has pushed numerous companies to make changes in how they are governed, faces a showdown today over how it governs itself. Corporate members are seeking representation among the group's officers, but union members are vehemently opposed.

title: Challenging A View Of the Holocaust
description: In his immense, angry new book, Daniel Jonah Goldhagen has challenged a fundamental assumption of the Holocaust, that Germans blindly followed orders, or were coerced by their superiors, in murdering Jews. In "Hitler's Willing Executioners: Ordinary Germans and the Holocaust" (Alfred A. Knopf) Mr. Goldhagen argues that thousands of Germans, even though told by their superiors they could refuse orders to kill Jews, eagerly participated in the slaughter, and killed zealously, with unnecessary brutality.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on March 22 about the use of electronic fare cards on New York City's buses misstated the prices. In subway stations, the cards are sold for a minimum of $5. A new $6 card is sold only at selected stores and newsstands, where $15 and $40 cards are also available. The cards can be renewed in dollar amounts up to $80.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Pacers Beat Nets, Await Knicks
description: Butch Beard waved the white flag with 2 minutes 3 seconds to play in the first half. It was obviously his way of saying, "Please, somebody, get me out of here."

title: Corrections
description: A Sports chart yesterday listing major league baseball schedules switched the 1996 playing dates of two teams. The Seattle Mariners' schedule was listed as being that of the Oakland Athletics; Oakland's schedule was under a Seattle headline.

title: Big Tobacco, on the Run
description: The seemingly invincible tobacco industry that has brushed off attacks by everyone from Surgeons General of the United States to individual lung cancer victims is suddenly crouching for cover. It has been battered by lawsuits from a slew of state governments, five Federal grand jury investigations, new revelations by whistle-blowers about internal corporate deceit, a nervous stock market and the surprise defection of one of the tobacco industry's own member companies. Nobody knows where the current swirl of attacks on the industry will end up, but it seems destined to produce a seismic shift in public attitudes toward the companies that market this lethal albeit legal product.

title: Message Screens Planned for 54 Subway Stations
description: As it continues its efforts to make subway announcements sound more like intelligible discourse and less like outtakes from "The Exorcist," the New York City Transit Authority plans to place electronic message screens in 54 stations by the end of next year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Bristol-Myers Shuffles Brands
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company in New York has reassigned several consumer brands among its roster of agencies.

title: POLITICS: IN CONGRESS;The Speaker's Gruff No. 2 Takes Charge in the House
description: When he arrived on Capitol Hill in 1985, the Almanac of American Politics promptly summed up the politically crude, rough-edged and brooding Texan as someone "hardly likely to be a power in the House."

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;An Ambivalent Ear for Elliott Carter
description: The year Elliott Carter was born, Gustav Mahler conducted the premiere of his Seventh Symphony, Erik Satie completed a course in counterpoint, Toscanini made his American debut and Schoenberg's atonal music first alarmed the public. The American President was Roosevelt: Theodore, not Franklin. In other words, it was a long time ago: 87 years. Major composers born around the same time -- Messiaen, Britten, Lutoslawski, Cage -- are all dead.

title: World News Briefs;Cameroon Holds Suspects In Rwanda Mass Killings
description: Cameroon has arrested 11 people accused of having been ringleaders in the mass killings in Rwanda in 1994, including the former director of a radio station that urged on the killers, Foreign Minister Anastase Gasana of Rwanda said today.

title: FINAL FOUR;Kentucky's Pressure Holds No Fear for Hill
description: Otis Hill, Syracuse's beefy 6-foot-8-inch, 255-pound center, has seen Kentucky, in its last two games, swallow up men at his position who have been rated as National Basketball Association lottery picks.

title: Arsonist Is Sought in Blaze That Injured 8
description: A two-alarm fire that burned a six-story building in Washington Heights and injured eight tenants, including five children, on Saturday night was deliberately set, city firefighters said yesterday.

title: Southwest in Accord on Corporate Fares
description: A consortium that represents 25 companies, including Chrysler and Procter & Gamble, has won a commitment from Southwest Airlines to offer simplified fares, based on flight distance, to their employees for business travel.

title: Land Mines End More Lives Than They Save
description: To the Editor: Re Bernard E. Trainor's "Land Mines Saved My Life" (Op-Ed, March 28): The idea that his compelling personal story of tripping a dud antipersonnel land mine in Korea 44 years ago equates with today's land-mine-based genocide is preposterous.

title: Plan for Hughes Is Reported
description: The General Motors Corporation is exploring the possibility of spinning off part of its Hughes Electronics Corporation, an article in The Detroit Free Press said on Saturday. G.M. declined to comment on the report today.

title: Pioneers of Cyberspace Move Into Wider Arena
description: Cyberspace is dead, many of its electronic pioneers said at a conference here this week.

title: Plan for Food Safety Panel Is Criticized
description: A little-noted amendment to the farm bill approved by the Congress last week is causing an uproar among consumer groups and even some producers of meat and poultry. But the framers of the amendment, Republican staff members of the House Agriculture Committee, say they cannot understand what all the furor is about.

title: Habeas Corpus Studies
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising;The business of 'preserving, protecting and insuring' the legacy of Martin Luther King Jr.
description: YES, Einstein's image was used to sell Nikon cameras and Freud's name helped pitch Prime Computers. But historical figures have been enlisted to pitch products less often than have sports and entertainment icons, living or dead -- the Michael Jordans and Marilyn Monroes of the world.

title: Land Mines End More Lives Than They Save
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Baseball Season Marches In
description: The earliest start in baseball history ended with another late-inning victory by the Seattle Mariners.

title: Reviews/Fashion;Designers Inspired by a Spirit of Adventure
description: In hues as rich as the semiprecious gems that inspired them, Han Feng sculptured her improbably beautiful velvet jackets. She proved that with a little imagination, designers need not hoard color for springtime outings.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Going to College, on Line
description: A new program at Thomas Edison State College will allow busy executives to complete a master's degree while sitting at their computers. The college has chosen 11 AT&T employees to try out the on-line program for a Master of Science degree in management. It will offer the two-year program to the public next fall, officials said last week.

title: TENNIS;Ivanisevic Pulls Out; Title Goes To Agassi
description: Goran Ivanisevic, who has predicted it will take a robot -- and another 200 years -- to break his hold on every ace and serving record in the history books, woke up feeling as rigid as a robot this morning.

title: ON BASEBALL;Lowering the Strike Zone Won't Pick Up the Pace
description: The redefinition of the strike zone, new to major league baseball this year, may seem the most intriguing component in the sport's initiatives to speed up games, but players, umpires and managers are greeting this change with a big yawn.

title: Syracuse's Basketball Fans Ready for a Victory Tonight
description: Lest anyone underestimate the ardor that students and citizens around Syracuse maintain for the Syracuse University basketball team, consider what they are willing to ingest.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Texas Lottery Retains GSD & M
description: The Texas Lottery Commission in Austin has retained GSD & M in Austin to handle its account for another two years. Billings were estimated at $25 million to $30 million.

title: PAST DUE -- A special report.;DELAYS BY H.M.O. LEAVING PATIENTS HAUNTED BY BILLS
description: The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, the state's largest and oldest health maintenance organization, routinely fails to pay millions of dollars of its members' medical bills each year, leaving subscribers either to cover the bills themselves or to fight collection agencies and lawsuits from doctors demanding overdue payments.

title: Wood Pulp Prices Off 40% Since Autumn
description: The prices of North American wood pulp have fallen 40 percent since last fall, one of the sharpest price reversals in the history of the industry, and consumers of many paper products, from tissues and paper towels to stationery and envelopes, are expected to find lower prices.

title: New Software For Business By Microsoft
description: The Microsoft Corporation is expected to announce on Tuesday that it has begun shipping its Exchange program, a tool for managing corporate mail that also allows groups of workers to share documents and projects. Electronic Data Systems will announce that it will use the program for its 68,000 employees worldwide.

title: Tenants' Choice: Their Dog or Their Home;Pet Owners Face Eviction in New Rule by Connecticut Housing Project
description: In a housing project where gangs deal drugs and the playgrounds are sprinkled with shattered glass, the risk posed by Teddie, a 3-year-old Pomeranian the size of a football, might not seem to be grounds for eviction.

title: Reviews/Fashion;Making an Elegant U-Turn Toward Indulgence
description: Robert Hughes, in his book of essays on art, "Nothing if Not Critical," takes this swipe at those who would measure the art market in decades: "The inflation of the market, the victory of promotion over connoisseurship, the manufacture of art-related glamour, the poverty of art training, the embattled state of museums -- these will not vanish, as at the touch of a wand, now that 1990 is here."

title: Raphael Blau, Writer, 83, Dies; Did 'Bedtime for Bonzo' Story
description: Raphael David Blau, the son of a rabbi who turned an academic interest in psychology into "Bedtime for Bonzo," the 1951 film in which Ronald Reagan was co-star with a chimpanzee, died on Sunday in Brooklyn. He was 83.

title: Sports of The Times;They're the Oscar and Felix of the Hardwood Set
description: FOR years, Rick Pitino and Jim Boeheim have been telling the story of the obsessive basketball coach who interrupted Pitino's wedding night with the offer of a job -- and how Pitino wangled some extra money out of Boeheim before getting back to his honeymoon.

title: And the Winner Is:
description: South Africa's national rugby team will be allowed to keep the springbok as its symbol, the National Sports Council decided this weekend.

title: Nun Tortured In Guatemala Seeks U.S. Files
description: An American nun who was kidnapped, tortured and raped in Guatemala in 1989 began a protest near the White House today in an effort to prod the Government to release its investigative files involving her case and others like it.

title: C. A. Agemian, 86, Former Executive At Chase Manhattan
description: Charles A. Agemian, a former Chase Manhattan executive whose banking career covered two thirds of a century, died on Friday at a hospital in Neptune, N.J. He was 86 and a resident of Spring Lake.

title: Sri Lankan Boat Is Sunk
description: Rebels sank a Sri Lankan Navy boat as Government troops began a new operation on Saturday against the guerrillas in the north, military officials and newspapers said today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Train Hits Car. Train Sues.
description: A legal twist on the man-bites-dog story: The state is suing the driver of a car that was hit by a New Jersey Transit train in March 1990 for $7,366 in damages to the train. The driver, Nicola McCann of Morristown, was stopped on railroad tracks in Morris Township when her car was struck by the train, said Maureen Sczpanski, a spokeswoman for the Attorney General's office. The suit was filed in Morris County Superior Court.

title: Leadership Debate At Investors' Group
description: The Council of Institutional Investors, a collection of large pension funds that has been a leader in the shareholder rights' movement, faces a showdown today over how it governs itself. Corporate members are seeking representation among the group's officers, but union members are vehemently opposed.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;He Said, She Said, in a Bleak Little Town
description: Guiltrip," a small but powerfully raw Irish film about a tension-filled marriage, confines its scope to one long, eventful day. A bitter all-night argument between Tina (Jasmine Russell) and her husband, Liam (Andrew Connolly), becomes the occasion for examining the events of the preceding hours.

title: FINAL FOUR;Tennessee Rules the S.E.C. And the Whole Country
description: Tennessee was the wise old puncher, Georgia the spirited young boxer. Georgia would fly down the court and fly back, darting, dashing, trying to create chaos. Tennessee would sit back and let Georgia play its little game, then coolly play its more controlled game.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: As China Undercuts Democracy, Hong Kong Scuffles for Passports
description: Inexorably, the clock marched toward midnight, and the last chance to apply for a British overseas passport.

title: Craig Crenshaw, 79; Was Army Scientist
description: Craig M. Crenshaw, a retired physicist and chief scientist of the Army Materiel Command for 12 years, died of a heart attack on March 22 at his home in McLean, Va. He was 79.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;A Portrait of a Legend In Spotlight and Shadow
description: Nestled in a residential neighborhood of Berlin there's a cemetery with a modest marble grave marker reading simply "Marlene." That's all that's needed for the steady trickle of visitors. There, next to her mother's, rest the remains of one of Hollywood's most enduring legends, a German who became an American citizen and entertained United States troops in World War II. Marlene Dietrich's grave has been desecrated at least once by those who still cannot forgive her loathing for Hitler. It's not difficult to imagine her laughing derisively once again at the new generation of thugs.

title: World News Briefs;Israel and Militants Trade Fire in Lebanon
description: Israeli shelling in southern Lebanon that killed two Lebanese civilians on Saturday led to rocket attacks by Islamic militants on northern Israel overnight, but Israelis near the border emerged from bomb shelters today following diplomatic efforts to calm the situation.

title: Congress Plays Doctor
description: When the House took the unprecedented step last week of passing a bill that would outlaw a specific and safe surgical procedure, the so-called partial birth abortion, it set a dangerous precedent by inappropriately intruding into the clinical practice of medicine.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Calloway Stays With Giants
description: The Giants have said all this off season that the most important thing for them is to re-sign their own players. They have taken another significant step in that direction by agreeing to terms with one of their most consistent -- and underrated -- receivers of the last several years, Chris Calloway.

title: Bratton Denies He Was Pushed Out
description: The departing Police Commissioner, William J. Bratton, in an interview broadcast yesterday, denied being "pushed" into leaving sooner than planned by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's public acknowledgment that the Commissioner was job hunting.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Triumph of the Bottom Line;Numbers vs. Words at the Book-of-the-Month Club
description: Correction Appended

title: Report Cites Waste In Pentagon Projects
description: Military budgets may not be rising sharply anymore, but that has not eliminated Pentagon waste, a new study says.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Voter Registration Drives
description: The New Jersey African-American Republican Women's Network plans to hold voter registration drives every weekend until the primary election on June 4, Allie F. B. Stanford, chairwoman of the statewide group, said last week.

title: Reviews/Fashion;2 Soothing Visions Of Clothes for the 90's
description: That it should take two young women to produce the kind of hip stressless sportswear a generation of shoppers is craving should come as no surprise. Cynthia Rowley and Jill Stuart have evolved from humble beginnings to a point this season where their design imprimaturs are becoming significant additions to the style landscape.

title: After Losing Air Base, Plattsburgh Glimpses Brighter Future
description: For more than 180 years, life in Plattsburgh was tied to the military.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Trying On Geisha Gear
description: Dancers often use deliberately distorted or exaggerated movements to make their works emotionally and thematically expressive. Yet "Three," which three choreographers presented on Thursday night at Performance Space 122, remained surprisingly uncommunicative, although it was filled with distortion.

title: FINAL FOUR: NOTEBOOK;St. John's Interviews Kennedy Of F.S.U.
description: Florida State Coach Pat Kennedy confirmed yesterday that he has spoken with the St. John's athletic director, Ed Manetta, about the school's vacant basketball head coaching job, but both he and Manetta denied published reports that Kennedy has been offered the position.

title: Triplets Killed in Accident
description: A tractor-trailer slammed into a family's stalled minivan on Saturday, killing 3-year-old triplets inside.

title: POLITICS: DOLE'S COURSE;Senator Lets Experience Guide Policy on Economy
description: Although Senator Bob Dole avoids the kind of detailed economic policy debates that President Clinton is known to relish, the all-but-official Republican Presidential nominee nonetheless has a loose grouping of economic advisers who are helping to shape his views and sharpen his message.

title: Call to Modify Irish Neutrality Ignites Debate
description: At the quiet urging of American and West European officials, the Government of Prime Minister John Bruton has begun to chip away at Ireland's bedrock policy of military neutrality.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week.

title: CHRONICLE
description: This is the story that asks the question: Can a woman who has endured heartache, death, disease, infidelity and evil not only survive 40 years of virtually unalloyed tsoris but also celebrate it?

title: An Accountability Issue
description: To some proponents of states' rights, a major Supreme Court ruling last week is a welcome reinforcement of a long-term realignment in American politics -- the states' reclaiming of authority from a Federal Government grown too big and too intrusive.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Investors' Council Faces a Challenge The Council of Institutional Investors, a collection of pension funds that has pressured companies to make changes in governance, faces a showdown over how it governs itself. Corporate members are seeking representation among the group's officers, but union members are opposed. [Page D2.]

title: Watson Unit Settles Generic Drug Charge
description: A unit of Watson Pharmaceutical Inc. will pay $2.7 million to settle Federal charges that it sold untested generic drugs to Medicare, Medicaid and other Government health programs.

title: Is Downsizing a Myth? Ask the Downsized
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Finagle a Way To Build Yankee Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Time Warner Swap With Cox
description: Cox Communications Inc. reached an agreement last week with a unit of Time Warner Inc. to trade a South Carolina cable system for Time Warner properties in Virginia.

title: Europe Mustn't Retreat On Single Currency
description: To the Editor:

title: After 12 Years of Delay, New Snag Clouds Coliseum's Future
description: After 12 years of debate and delay in deciding the fate of the New York Coliseum, a new snag has left the project's future as murky as ever as the city and state continue to haggle over whether to set aside part of any new building for trade shows.

title: Police Officer Is Charged In a Shooting
description: An off-duty police officer on the force for less than two weeks was arrested late Saturday for shooting a woman four times with his service weapon, leaving her critically injured and on a respirator, the police said.

title: Virginia Donaldson, Press Agent, 74
description: Virginia Donaldson, the press agent for the New York City Ballet from 1966 to 1982, died on Wednesday at her home in Chicago. She was 74.

title: Critic Calls Anti-Smoking Drive Misdirected
description: Everyone from President Clinton to tobacco companies is preaching these days that teen-agers should be kept from smoking, and that has some anti-tobacco advocates worried.

title: Abortion Pill Advances
description: The New York group holding the American patent rights to the French abortion pill said it was seeking F.D.A. approval. Page A12.

title: Program Creates Community for Foster Care
description: On the grounds of a shuttered Air Force base here, an old-fashioned, close-knit Midwestern neighborhood has been created from scratch, right down to the stay-at-home moms and checkers-playing grandparents.

title: INSIDE
description: New U.S. Peacekeeper Job

title: Chinese Halt a Fund-Raiser By Foreigners for Orphanages
description: It was to be an evening of banqueting, speeches and general celebration of the work of private volunteers in China's state-run orphanages.

title: BASEBALL;A Calming Influence Has Taken Seattle by Storm
description: Lou Piniella has no noticeable scars or gashes on his lower lip, which is surprising considering the punishment he must inflict on it.

title: German Shipbuilder Says Loss Doubles
description: The ailing German shipbuilder Bremer Vulkan A.G. said Friday that its equity capital had been wiped out as a result of write-downs and the planned spinoff of its eastern German shipyards.

title: Metro Matters;Once Again, Giuliani Finds Scapegoat
description: RAUL RODRIGUEZ is caught between wanting to set the record straight and wanting to save his skin.

title: G.I.'s to Provide Security for War Crimes Investigators in Bosnia
description: As many as 200 American peacekeeping troops have been assigned to provide security to international war crimes investigators looking into the suspected massacre of thousands of Muslims in the eastern town of Srebrenica by Bosnian Serb military leaders, American military officials said today.

title: POLITICS: THE ECONOMY;Can the President Capitalize On the Economy's Strength?
description: The conventional wisdom in American politics is that a strong economy greatly helps incumbents, especially incumbent Presidents, and that a weak economy hurts them badly.

title: Muslims and Croats Sign Contract to Aid Federation in Bosnia
description: Muslim and Croatian leaders signed a contract today intended to bring the uneasy allies into a workable federation after months of conflict.

title: F.D.A. Approval Sought For French Abortion Pill
description: The New York nonprofit group holding the patent rights to the French abortion pill in this country announced yesterday that it had filed an application asking the Federal Food and Drug Administration to approve the drug, known as RU-486 in France and mifepristone in this country.

title: Editorial Notebook;Revisiting Marco Polo
description: Did Marco Polo Go to China?" asks the provocative title of a book just out in Britain. The author, Frances Wood, head of the Chinese section of the British Library, contends that Marco Polo's account of his trip to China was probably concocted by the scribe who shared his cell in Genoa, where both were taken prisoner in 1296 during that city's war with Venice.

title: No Headline
description: I don't think of this as banning dogs. I see it as liberating people." FREDERICK L. WALLACE, on new rules for public housing in New London, Conn. [B1:2.]

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;One Town's Mad Crush on an Unknowable Woman
description: JOHN'S WIFE By Robert Coover 428 pages. Simon & Schuster. $24

title: HOCKEY;Gretzky Has Brought Fans, If Not Victories, to the Blues
description: So far, Wayne Gretzky has meant much money for the St. Louis Blues. Before he arrived, according to Coach Mike Keenan, there were 2,000 to 3,000 empty seats for most home games in the big, bright, new Kiel Center. Since Gretzky came from Los Angeles in a trade on Feb. 27, all games have drawn full houses of more than 20,000 customers.

title: Venice Opera's Rebirth: As It Was or Might Be
description: When the 300-foot-high Campanile that dominates Venice's Piazza San Marco collapsed without warning on July 14, 1902, the city fathers immediately decided to build an exact reproduction of the 800-year-old bell tower "dov'era, com'era," where it was, how it was. Ten years later, to the delight of its citizens, Venice's profile once again looked as Canaletto had captured it in the 18th century.

title: Bridge
description: A year ago this department erred slightly when it credited Steve Stanton of Stuart, Fla., with the honor of being the oldest male club director in North America. He is 88, and must give pride of place to Al Perkins of the Bay Ridge Club in Brooklyn, which gathers at 12:30 P.M. each Wednesday at the Church of the Good Shepherd, 74th Street and Fourth Avenue. He has been directing there for 19 years, and on Wednesday, his players honored him on his 90th birthday.

title: BASEBALL;Cone, Set to Go, Knows Yankees' Hopes Rest on His Arm
description: Opening day. The charm and excitement generated by the two simple words still mean something special to David Cone. He is not jaded. His enthusiasm is sincere when he discusses the "privilege" of pitching the hallowed opening game for the Yankees against the American League champion Indians in a stunning ball park that will not have an empty seat this season.

title: Brandfort Journal;For Winnie's Apartheid Days, Why Not a Shrine?
description: Even in the middle of the afternoon on a weekday, Brandfort's dusty little main street is almost deserted.

title: POP REVIEW;Rock Revival With a Country Twang
description: Tim McGraw declared "I'm a renegade" in his first song on Thursday night at the Theater. Faith Hill, the opening act, sang in praise of a woman who was "a wild one." Taken together, they were about as audacious and untamed as the Lipizzaner stallions.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID BOULEY, the renowned chef who has set many a royal repast before the clientele of the four-star Manhattan restaurant that bears his name, is just back from something of a royal visit to Thailand.

title: In Europe, an Ex-Ambassador's New Empires
description: Ronald S. Lauder is not the first American diplomat to turn a political assignment into a subsequent business opportunity. But few people have done it on as grand a scale.

title: Technology: CONNECTIONS;If life on the Web is postmodern, then maybe Foucault really was a Power Ranger.
description: THE bald, mischievous countenance of Michel Foucault no sooner appears on the computer screen than it starts to recede, the left half of his face twisting upward like elastic, the mouth curled into a slightly horrifying grin. A purple haze begins to envelop the skull of the late French philosopher, which is marked with streaks of yellow. The grin pulls upward even further and the head starts to fade. Then, out of the mist some sort of creature comes into focus. As it pulls forward, the figure reveals itself as a blue-masked fighter, his fist coming out at the viewer in a blur of martial arts expertise. Foucault has morphed into a Power Ranger.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A 'Dream' to Reach the Eye and the Funny Bone
description: A notice to ancient Athenian casting agents: Nick Bottom, dismissed for centuries as the saltiest of hams, has it in him to be a first-rate actor.

title: Equity Offerings Set for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:

title: Sports of The Times;Savoring Moments in the Sun Before They Fade Away
description: LONG after Kentucky had defeated Massachusetts on Saturday night, Marcus Camby, the all-America center of UMass, walked across the vacant court. Camby didn't seem to have a particular direction or destination. He was just walking, looking.

title: Internet Shortcut Isn't Prohibitive for Most
description: To the Editor:

title: On Forcing Catholics To Adhere to Doctrine
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents;An air vest that helps avalanche victims breathe (but does nothing to ease the claustrophobia).
description: MORE winter sports enthusiasts are heading into the wilderness in search of uncharted thrills and virgin snow. But the back country can be dangerous. This winter 25 people in the United States -- among them snow boarders, hikers, skiers and snow mobilers -- have died in avalanches.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Talks on Alliance In Telecommunications
description: Singapore Telecom, which is already part of AT&T's World Partners alliance, which sells global telecommunications accounts to multinationals, said yesterday that it was discussing a new partnership with Cable and Wireless P.L.C.

title: Dante Giacosa, 91, Dies; Designed the Fiat 500
description: Dante Giacosa, the auto designer whose career at Fiat spanned nearly half a century and who brought forth such models as the Fiat 500, which motorized Italy in the 1950's, died Sunday in Turin. He was 91.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Duffy Re-signs With Jets
description: ROGER DUFFY had decided to switch to the Dolphins after two seasons as the Jets' left guard. The move would have been part of a general dismantling of the Jets' offensive line.

title: D'Amato Issues a Threat On Whitewater Hearings
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York warned today that he would soon shift the hearings on President and Mrs. Clinton's behavior in connection with the Whitewater real estate deal to the full Banking Committee unless the Democrats agreed to an extension of the special panel that has been conducting the investigation.

title: OUTDOORS;Take Me Out to the Trout Stream on Opening Day
description: A week ago yesterday, along the banks of the Mongaup River, I stood rodless and waderless on a moss-covered rock, staring into tinted waters. I had hoped for at least the flash of a trout, but really just wanted to mark where I would make my first casts of the new season.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A MERGER OF HEALTH INSURERS;Insurance Deal Approved
description: Connecticut's Insurance Department today approved the Aetna Life and Casualty Company's $4 billion sale of its property-casualty business to Travelers Group Inc. The approval was the final regulatory hurdle for the deal, which creates the nation's fourth-largest insurer of buildings, automobiles and businesses. A few finishing touches have to be worked out by the companies, a spokesman for Aetna said. Travelers will form a holding company, based in Hartford, to operate the companies' combined property-casualty operations. As many as 3,300 jobs at the new entity will be eliminated, with half the cuts to be made in Hartford, Travelers has said. The consolidation is expected to result in hundreds of millions of dollars in savings for the new company.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Currency and Charges Cut Sulzer Net by Half
description: Sulzer A.G. said yesterday that its profit fell in 1995 to less than half the previous year's level because of the strength of the Swiss franc and charges. Net income at the Swiss machinery and medical-equipment maker fell to 92 million francs, or $77 million, from 195 million francs. Sulzer's sales fell 5 percent, from 6.04 billion francs.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Make my day. It has not been divulged whether CLINT EASTWOOD said those words on Sunday, but he did say, "I do," as he exchanged vows with DINA RUIZ, an anchor at KSBW-TV in Salinas, Calif. The couple were married in a small ceremony in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Metro-North Workers Can Sue Over Asbestos, Court Rules
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled yesterday that Metro-North workers could sue the railroad for asbestos exposure, even though they are years away from any possible ill health effects.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COOPER CAMERON IN $100 MILLION DEAL FOR INGRAM CACTUS
description: The Cooper Cameron Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the assets of the closely held Ingram Cactus Company in a $100 million deal requiring Cooper Cameron to assume certain liabilities. Ingram Cactus manufactures and sells equipment used primarily for onshore oil and gas production operations. In 1995, Ingram Cactus generated revenue of about $105 million. Cooper Cameron, a Houston-based maker of oil and gas pressure control equipment, lost $500.1 million, or $19.87 a share, on 1995 revenue of $1.14 billion. The latest results included a $441 million write-off of good will. Cooper Cameron shares rose $3 yesterday, to $45, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Solve-Ex Confirms Two Stock Inquiries
description: The chairman of the Solv-Ex Corporation, John Rendall, acknowledged today that at least two Federal inquiries were being conducted into possible manipulation of the company's stock price.

title: World News Briefs;In Reversal, North Korea Asks U.N. for Relief Aid
description: North Korea appealed for international help today for victims of flooding that devastated much of the country's cropland last year.

title: INSIDE
description: Libel Suit Settled

title: After Two Decades, Work Begins On Far Less Ambitious Westway
description: It touched off one of the city's longest and bitterest legal battles, pitting scrappy environmentalists against elected officials who dreamed of a 20th-century project on the scale of that 19th-century uptown wonder, Central Park.

title: New York Life in Partnership Liquidations
description: Seeking to exit a money-losing business and to avoid lengthy and potentially costly lawsuits from investors, the New York Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it planned to liquidate limited energy and real estate partnerships and repay every investor in the partnerships.

title: Trying to Avoid WHX Takeover, Teledyne Selects Another Suitor
description: Teledyne Inc., moving to thwart the hostile-takeover efforts of the WHX Corporation, said yesterday that it had agreed to merge with the Allegheny Ludlum Corporation, the nation's largest producer of stainless steel.

title: Fugitive Since 1970 Fights Extradition
description: After 26 years on the run, Richard Bernard Thomas has decided to keep fighting his return to Philadelphia, where he is accused of murdering a police sergeant during a militant group's attack on a police station in 1970.

title: I.M.F. Head: He Speaks, and Money Talks
description: If Boris N. Yeltsin is re-elected President of Russia in June, he will owe his victory in some part to one of Washington's least-known but most powerful people: Michel Camdessus.

title: Patterns
description: Less Runway Diversity

title: Hicks Muse Hires Smith Barney Man
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., a Dallas investment firm that specializes in leveraged buyouts, hired Michael Levitt today as a managing director and principal.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Bertuzzi Suspended for Three Games
description: Islander forward TODD BERTUZZI was suspended for three games yesterday by the National Hockey League for his conduct during Sunday's game against the Rangers. After getting involved in a third-period fight, Bertuzzi repeatedly tried to toss aside linesman KEVIN COLLINS to get at SHANE CHURLA. After the game, Rangers Coach COLIN CAMPBELL called the incident "disgraceful."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Ford Workers in Mexico Accept Raise of 26%
description: The Ford Motor Company's workers at the Cuautitlan plant on the outskirts of Mexico City have accepted a 26 percent wage increase, averting a strike that was scheduled yesterday, Mexico's Labor Ministry said. The increase, which takes effect immediately, benefits 3,300 union workers. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: To Catch a Snake, Grab the End that Bites
description: HOW do you capture a 17-foot-long, 200-pound snake? Very carefully, as the frighteningly simple method dictates.

title: Newt Gingrich, a Vegetarian? Only in a Prankster's Dream
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich announced that he was becoming a vegetarian, Senator Ben Nighthorse Campbell decided to go back to the Democratic Party and Taco Bell said it was buying the Liberty Bell to help reduce the national debt.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;Sprinter Comes Out of Coma
description: DARRELL ROBINSON, once one of the top sprinters in the world, was alert and communicating yesterday after coming out of a coma. Robinson, 32, was taken to Harborview Medical Center in Seattle on March 25 after police found him unconscious in a car in a parking lot. His sister told The Seattle-Post Intelligencer that Robinson had fallen into the coma after drinking antifreeze in a suicide attempt.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Climbs Against the Yen, And Strength Aids Rise vs. Mark
description: The dollar rose against the Japanese yen yesterday, bolstered by concerns about the Japanese banking system and by expectations that Japanese investors would move more money abroad as their fiscal year began.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the stock market's activity on Friday misstated the closing stock price of the Consolidated Natural Gas Company in some editions. It was $43.50, not $4.50.

title: Blood Test in Coma Rape
description: A judge today told a former nurse's aide to provide blood to determine whether he is the father of a baby born to a woman who has been in a coma for 10 years.

title: 2 Convicted For Fraud Over Dumping
description: Two members of a family that once ran a prominent network of marine-transport companies were convicted last night of Federal fraud charges stemming from the illegal dumping of sewage sludge by the family's barges in waters around New York City and New Jersey.

title: New Directors Named in N.A.S.D. Change
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers today appointed former Government officials and several shareholder advocates as directors, responding to criticism it was dominated by industry insiders.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TRIARC SELLING A TEXTILE UNIT FOR $255 MILLION
description: The Triarc Companies said yesterday that it had a definitive agreement to sell its Graniteville textile business to Avondale Mills Inc. for $255 million. New York-based Triarc, which also owns Arby's restaurants and produces Royal Crown cola, Mistic beverages and liquefied petroleum gas, said it expected to close the sale during the second quarter. Avondale will assume all of Graniteville's liabilities other than income taxes and will pay off its long-term debt. C. H. Patrick & Company, Triarc's dyes and specialty chemical subsidiary, and certain other assets are not part of the sale. Triarc shares rose 50 cents yesterday, to $13.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 2 BELL COMPANIES AGREE TO MERGER WORTH $17 BILLION
description: In the first marriage of two regional Bell telephone companies and one of the largest corporate mergers ever, SBC Communications announced yesterday that it would acquire the Pacific Telesis Group for $17 billion.

title: ROCK REVIEW;Lyrics of Love and Egg-Cream Breath
description: Some of the best albums of Lou Reed's quarter-century solo career have been about falling in love ("The Blue Mask"), city living and politics ("New York") and growing old ("Magic and Loss"). On his latest CD, "Set the Twilight Reeling" (Warner Brothers), Mr. Reed combines these themes and ends up with an album that after many repeated plays, triumphs over its patent silliness (with songs like "Egg Cream," about the Brooklyn restaurants of his youth; "NYC Man," about how he is one, and "Hooky Wooky," about his new love, Laurie Anderson) and holds up to the best recordings he has made since leaving the Velvet Underground in 1970.

title: Jeffrey Lee Pierce, Rock Musician, 37
description: Jeffrey Lee Pierce, the leader of the Gun Club, a trailblazing Los Angeles band that began mixing punk rock with American roots music in 1979, died on Sunday at Utah University Hospital in Salt Lake City. He was 37.

title: Digitized Fragments Help Decipher Dead Sea Scrolls
description: IN the hands of technologically inclined scholars, the story in the Book of Daniel about Shadrach, Meshach and Abednego reads the same as ever. These friends of the prophet Daniel still defy the Babylonian king Nebuchadnezzar's order to worship a golden idol. They are cast into the fiery furnace, and God saves them without so much as a singed hair.

title: Adoptees Don't Always Know Sense of Loss or Incompleteness;Yearning for Closure
description: To the Editor:

title: British in Anti-Bomb Effort
description: The Government said today that it would rush through a bill to give the police new stop-and-search powers in Britain to combat the resumed bombing campaign by the Irish Republican Army.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;A Plan to Fight Breast Cancer
description: With 1,800 deaths a year from breast cancer, New Jersey ranks the third highest among the states in the number of women who die of the disease. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman yesterday announced a series of goals developed by the Department of Health and several cancer research groups.

title: R-Rated Child Abuse
description: The movie blazed with steamy sex scenes, bursts of gunfire and shouted obscenities. But the live drama in the row ahead of me, where a girl no more than 6 or 7 years old sat between her parents, was the real chiller.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Ambient Dirt's Moment Under a Pointillist's Gaze
description: THE SIZE OF THOUGHTS Essays and Other Lumber By Nicholson Baker Illustrated. 355 pages. Random House. $25.

title: Chess
description: In a tournament like the United States Masters Championship early last month in Oak Brook, Ill., every entrant has some special objective, but not necessarily the same one.

title: In Memo, Hambrecht & Quist Discusses Possible Stock Sale
description: After benefiting significantly from the continuing boom in initial public offerings, the investment firm Hambrecht & Quist is discussing the possibility of taking itself public, too.

title: Hope Kindled For Table-Top Accelerators
description: SINCE 1993, when Congress canceled construction of a $10 billion particle smasher that would have girdled most of a Texas county, prospects have virtually vanished for building still larger machines -- accelerators that might glimpse new levels of organization within the building blocks of matter.

title: Asian Immigrants Face Old-Time Bigotry
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Now for an ethical question.

title: Supreme Court Roundup;Justices Say Age Bias Can Occur Even When One Over-40 Worker Replaces Another
description: The Supreme Court today strengthened the Federal law against age discrimination on the job, ruling unanimously that a lawsuit for age discrimination can succeed even if a worker is replaced by someone older than 40, the age at which the law's protections begin to apply.

title: For Helms, His Home State Is Source of Foreign Policy
description: As the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Senator Jesse Helms leaves little doubt how he feels about the Communist leaders of Vietnam.

title: Is It Worth It to Rebuild a Beach? Panel's Answer Is a Tentative Yes
description: EFFORTS to restore eroded beaches by dredging up sand and pumping it onshore have been carried out in the United States since 1922, when New York City enlarged the beach at Coney Island to accommodate a new boardwalk. Arguments about the cost and longevity of the projects have been going on almost as long.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 21 about a memorial service at Carnegie Hall for the composer Morton Gould misidentified the conductor of members of the New York Choral Society in the Gould work "Quotations," and a correction in this space on Thursday misstated his given name. It is Robert DeCormier, not Roger.

title: PERIPHERALS;Spring Cleaning Files
description: THE hard disk in a system running one of the four varieties of Windows gets cluttered fast. The programs themselves are often space hogs, and they scatter little pieces of themselves all over. Even if you delete a program, not all the garbage is taken out.

title: A MERGER OF HEALTH INSURERS;A Big Day for Mergers in the United States
description: Only one day into the second quarter and the mergers business is already on a tear.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WELLS FARGO COMPLETES ACQUISITION OF FIRST INTERSTATE
description: Wells Fargo & Company completed its $11 billion acquisition of First Interstate Bancorp yesterday and said it would reduce its work force by 16 percent by the end of the year. Wells Fargo, which became the nation's eighth-largest banking company, said 1,750 employees were being laid off immediately and another 5,450 would be cut by the end of the year. Before the merger, the two California banks had 45,800 full-time employees. Shares of San Francisco-based Wells Fargo gained $3.25 yesterday, to $264.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF LUCENT TECHNOLOGIES EXPECTED TO REACH $28
description: Lucent Technologies Inc., the telecommunications arm of the AT&T Corporation, is expected to go public tomorrow for as much as $28 a share -- $3 above previous estimates, the lead underwriter, Morgan Stanley Inc., said yesterday. The expected price for Lucent shares has jumped to $25 to $28 a share from $22 to $25, Morgan Stanley said. The stock will trade on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol "LU" and is expected to be one of the biggest initial public offerings. The company, based in Morristown, N.J., was incorporated as a separate entity in September under AT&T's plan to split into three publicly held companies. Lucent plans to offer 111 million shares.

title: BASEBALL;For Pulsipher, the Season Hinges on a Twinge and a Test
description: Bill Pulsipher won't allow himself to think that there is anything wrong with his troublesome left elbow that a little rest won't cure. That's why the Mets pitcher is trying to stay optimistic, despite facing a second magnetic resonance imaging test that could determine his availability for this season.

title: FOOTBALL;Cowboys' Irvin Indicted on Drug Charges
description: Michael Irvin, the All-Pro receiver for the Super Bowl champion Dallas Cowboys, was indicted today on one felony charge of cocaine possession and one misdemeanor charge of marijuana possession.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ASHANTI GOLDFIELDS TO ACQUIRE TORONTO MINING COMPANY
description: The Ashanti Goldfields Company, a gold mining concern in Ghana, agreed yesterday to buy the International Gold Resources Corporation of Toronto for about $100 million. International Gold is a gold mining company whose main asset is the right to acquire a 45 percent operating interest in the proposed Bibiani mine in Ghana. Ashanti said its principal mining operation is near Obuasi, about 110 miles northwest of Accra, Ghana's capital. The site's gold reserves were about 20 million ounces at the end of 1995, Ashanti said.

title: In the Queens Mosaic, A Turkish Inlay;Community Takes Root in Sunnyside
description: Knowing next to no one, Mesut Yaktubay stepped off the plane from Turkey two weeks ago and became an instant regular at Sunny Grocery, a postage-stamp-sized market on an unremarkable corner in Sunnyside, Queens.

title: A MERGER OF HEALTH INSURERS: THE INDUSTRY;Managed Care Empires in the Making
description: Leonard Abramson decided about a year ago that U.S. Healthcare Inc., his enormously successful health maintenance organization, needed a new strategy to keep its profits up. A flock of competing H.M.O.'s, led by Oxford Health Systems, was vying for customers on his home turf, in Philadelphia and New Jersey. Even more threatening, hospitals and doctors were melding into groups big enough to resist when the H.M.O.'s try to squeeze their fees.

title: BIRTH OF A GIANT: A RIVAL'S PROBLEM;New Wireless Service to Use Three Names
description: As SBC Communications Inc. has muscled its way onto the national stage by agreeing to merge with the Pacific Telesis Group, four of the nation's biggest cellular-phone companies have struggled just to name their much-publicized national wireless network. PCS Primeco L.P., an alliance of the Bell Atlantic Corporation, the Nynex Corporation, U S West Inc. and Airtouch Communications Inc., said today that it would operate under three brand names in different parts of the country.

title: Excerpts From Judge Baer's Reversal of Earlier Ruling
description: Following are excerpts from three sections of the ruling yesterday by Judge Harold Baer Jr. in Federal District Court in Manhattan in which he reversed his earlier decision to throw out evidence in a drug case:

title: BASEBALL;Determined Mets Climb Out of a 6-0 Hole to Top Cards
description: If opening day is any indication of what the Mets have in store for themselves and their fans, then those woeful seasons of the early 1990's will be quickly forgotten, replaced by the kind of excitement that has not been seen here in nearly a decade.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Youthful Elan and Technique
description: Talent, technique, stage presence: the Alvin Ailey Repertory Ensemble has all these theatrical virtues in abundance. This group, the second company of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, is a first-rate organization in its own right, as it demonstrated on Friday night when it performed at Davis Hall at City College.

title: Executive Changes
description: AMERICA SERVICE GROUP INC., New Castle, Del., a national provider of correctional health care services, appointed Scott L. Mercy president and chief executive.

title: A MERGER OF HEALTH INSURERS: THE PAYOFF;Once a Pharmacist, Now a Deal Maker
description: Leonard Abramson, a one-time cab driver, walked away yesterday with the biggest tip in his life -- some $492 million in cash.

title: Roderau Journal;Germans in Their Teepees? Naturally
description: This quiet eastern German village is not the place one might expect to hear the mesmerizing rhythm of American Indian chants echoing from a backyard. But there they were, a dozen men and women in full Indian regalia performing a snake dance in front of a full-size teepee decorated with hunting scenes.

title: Opening Day for Biggest Bank in the World
description: After two Japanese banks said a year ago that they would officially merge today, to become the world's biggest bank, the financial community waited excitedly for details.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Safety Device for School Buses
description: Seven-year-old Christelleigh Ostrowski of Trenton was accidentally killed last week when she walked in front of a school bus she had just exited. Her death spurred a bill that would require all new school buses to have a crossing control arm, a device that keeps children at a distance from the bus so that the driver can see them.

title: Modernize A Subway? Not So Fast, Critics Say
description: People here say the most un-Newarklike things about their subway -- that it is clean, that it is crime-free day and night, that it is fast and reliable and can be a great place to flirt. Riders giggle when asked to describe it. They call it cute, historic and quaint.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Snapple looks to humor and Mikey for its comeback ad campaign.
description: A MAKE-OR-BREAK campaign meant to improve sales of Snapple beverages will use offbeat humor and glossy production values to try meeting perhaps the most daunting challenge in consumer marketing: attracting mainstream buyers without alienating devoted fans.

title: Jersey Doesn't Need a New Study of Education;Not 'Equal' Funding
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES WARNS OF LOWER EARNINGS
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc., based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said yesterday its first-quarter earnings would be below analysts' expectations for the third consecutive quarter. Advanced Micro was expected to report earnings of 33 cents a share for the quarter that ended on March 31, based on the average estimate of 23 analysts surveyed by IBES International Inc. The company said the disappointing results were a result of weak demand for all of its PC-related products. Advanced Micro gets about 25 percent of its sales from microprocessors for PC's. The company's shares rose 25 cents yesterday, to $17.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers and Devils Both Eye Playoffs, but Paths Differ
description: Even though the playoffs will not begin for two weeks, the Rangers and Devils are already in playoff mode. But they have different agendas before the regular season ends on April 14, and their struggles will be laid bare at Madison Square Garden tonight, when the two latest winners of the Stanley Cup meet for the first of two times over the next six days.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WOOLWORTH TO CLOSE REMAINING RX PLACE DRUGSTORES
description: The Woolworth Corporation said yesterday that it planned to close its 14 remaining Rx Place Drug Mart stores, all in the New York area, by mid-June, completing the company's exit from the drugstore business. In the last year, the New York-based retailer sold 24 of its larger Rx Place drugstores to the Pharmhouse Corporation, sold its Kids Mart-Little Folks children's apparel chain and shut down two specialty apparel chains in Canada. In February, Woolworth started selling off the smaller Rx Place Drug Mart chain.

title: Leo Shull, 90, Editor and Owner of Show Business
description: Leo Shull, a New York publisher who for five decades recorded the comings and goings and the casting calls on Broadwayand beyond, died on Saturday at Aventura Hospital in Miami. He was 90 and had lived in North Miami since his retirement five years ago.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Turf Wars In Which Hunks Vie For Blood
description: Maybe it was only a matter of time before Aaron Spelling moved from the glamorous, conniving denizens of his usual soapy hits to characters who have truly earned the name bloodsucker. In the newest Spelling-produced series, "Kindred: The Embraced," the heroes are vampires masquerading as drop-dead-gorgeous humans. Five clans of them live in San Francisco, locked in a "Godfather"-style turf war. The most powerful clan is led by a handsome, shadowy businessman named Julian Luna, the Michael Corleone of vampires. There is a clan of young biker vampires. There are even pumped-up vampires with a Schwarzenegger-style leader. When these characters cry their blood-red tears, it's a fashion statement.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Dialing 411 Will Be Costlier
description: Starting July 1, dialing 411 will become a little more expensive for Bell Atlantic customers in New Jersey who call directory assistance more than six times a month from their home phones. Currently, residential users are allowed 10 free calls a month, but that number will drop to 6, Tim Ireland, a company spokesman, said yesterday. Each additional inquiry will cost 20 cents. Bell Atlantic estimated that about 620,000 of its 3.1 million residential users would be affected by the extra charges.

title: Vaccine Stops Tumors in Rats
description: A vaccine from genetically engineered cells eradicates tumors in laboratory rats and may be ready for testing on a human brain cancer by this summer, researchers say.

title: TV SPORTS;CBS Wins on Court And Falls Flat Off It
description: What CBS did well: produce the Final Four and championship games.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING INC., Roseland, N.J., acquired Merrin Financial Inc. of New York, its second purchase in two weeks aimed at bolstering its financial services. Terms were not disclosed.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;French Concern Selling Turkish Bank Interest
description: Turkiye Garanti Bankasi has agreed to pay $245 million for Osmanli Bankasi A.S., which once served as the central bank of the Ottoman Empire. The seller is Compagnie Financiere Ottomane, which is 49.9 percent-owned by the French banking and industrial concern Compagnie Financiere de Paribas S.A.

title: Hear the One About the Awards Writer?
description: His phone has been ringing all week. "The best show in years," said Bruce Vilanch merrily, looking back at the Academy Awards telecast on March 25 and looking ahead to, well, writing just about every awards show in sight.

title: Opera Feud Defused, For Now
description: In a move to ease a feud between artistic partners that threatened to turn tonight's American premiere of "The Dreyfus Affair" into an affair of its own, the New York City Opera said yesterday that the work's composer, Jost Meier, would be invited to take official part in the festivities after all.

title: Stocks Flat in Tokyo
description: Stock prices showed little change here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 39.69 points, at 21,600.08. On Monday, the Nikkei rose 153.54 points, reaching its highest point in four years.

title: A Purchase by I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Wilkerson Group, a pharmaceutical and medical products industry consulting firm. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed. Wilkerson Group, which is based in New York, has a client base that includes international pharmaceutical, biotechnology, supply, device and diagnostic companies.

title: California TV Crews Tape Police Beating
description: A pursuit of a pickup packed with people suspected of being illegal immigrants ended today with deputies being videotaped as they clubbed the driver and swung at a woman.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;Variations On Themes Of Nostalgia
description: Despite their differences, three new recordings share a fascination with Americana. All three take on various forms of American music, and tinker with them, amplifying some parts, hiding others, underscoring sadness or austerity or terror or joy. They are also surprisingly vital, and the built-in nostalgia never turns sour.

title: ON BASEBALL;Before the First Pitch, a Circus
description: The last time there was a major league baseball game in Cleveland, the lingering crowd that had come to see the Indians and Atlanta Braves play Game 5 of the World Series exited Jacobs Field just in time to see the circus arrive.

title: Apple Chief Is Seen Retreating From Price Cuts
description: Apple Computer Inc. may be preparing to extract itself from the computer industry price wars.

title: BASKETBALL;Solution for Cats Was to Let Delk Pull the Trigger
description: They missed 12 of their first 15 shots, and the Kentucky Wildcats seemed to be bothered both by Syracuse's 2-3 zone and their own expectations.

title: Top Anti-Crime Strategist Resigns From Police Dept.
description: The Police Department's top anti-crime strategist, John Maple, said yesterday he would resign, becoming the second top official to leave the force since the appointment of Howard Safir as Commissioner.

title: Sports of The Times;'0' Stands For Ordonez Ovations
description: IN the years when Ozzie Smith was the Oz of Wizardry at shortstop, the Cardinals believed that his artistry with the glove saved about 100 runs a season.

title: Editorial Notebook;The Small World of Grand Juries
description: Halfway through grand jury duty last month I ran into a woman I had met on orientation day. She said her panel was having problems staying awake. "Yesterday we had a case of a stolen pizza," she said. Later my own panel spent two hours deliberating whether to indict a man who was accused of stealing several boxes of plastic trash bags.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Cramer-Krasselt Wins Hyatt Account
description: The Hyatt Hotels Corporation said yesterday that it had named the Chicago office of Cramer-Krasselt to handle its account, which had been at the BBDO New York unit of the Omnicom Group for three years until that agency and Hyatt mutually parted ways in January. The billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million. K.C. Kavanagh, a spokeswoman for Hyatt in Chicago, said that the decision came after a three-month review that had been narrowed to Cramer-Krasselt and two other finalists in Chicago: Rapp Collins Worldwide, which is also owned by Omnicom and continues to handle direct marketing for Hyatt, and Hal Riney & Partners/Heartland.

title: ON COLLEGE BASKETBALL;St. John's Seeking the Right Coach
description: Ed Manetta was here to watch Kentucky win the national championship by beating Syracuse last night. This was a maiden voyage of sorts, his first time watching the championship game as athletic director at St. John's University.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Dresdner Operating Net Increased 22% in 1995
description: Dresdner Bank, Germany's second-largest commercial bank, said yesterday that its operating earnings jumped 22 percent in 1995, rising to 1.99 billion marks, or $1.35 billion, from 1.63 billion marks.

title: BASKETBALL NOTEBOOK;Spurs Have the Talent To Tough It Out in West
description: After the San Antonio Spurs won another game last week, Chuck Person was sitting quietly in the locker room. Person had played a terrible game, shooting 0 for 7 from the field. Suddenly, Coach Bob Hill screamed at the forward from across the room.

title: No Headline
description: I was with some Vietnamese recently, and some of them were smoking two cigarettes at the same time. That's the kind of customers we need! Well, not exactly. -- SENATOR JESSE HELMS, Vietnam's chief obstacle in Washington, on a dinner to promote North Carolina tobacco. [A18:1.]

title: Market Place;Aetna's game plan will be a case for the business school books.
description: TO the uninitiated, it might look like a strategy of sell low and buy high.

title: To Control Mustang Herds, Target Mares
description: To the Editor:

title: Knudsen Sees Loss for '95
description: The Morrison Knudsen Corporation said today that it expected to report a net loss of about $260 million for 1995. The engineering company had a net loss of $349.6 million in 1994.

title: Court Toughens Law Prohibiting Age Bias
description: In a unanimous ruling, the Supreme Court strengthened the Federal law against age discrimination on the job, saying that a lawsuit for age discrimination can succeed even if a worker is replaced by someone older than 40, the age at which the law's protections begin to apply.

title: BIRTH OF A GIANT: A LEADER'S VISION;Gambles, and Successes, at the Top
description: Edward E. Whitacre Jr. is as far from flashy as anyone gets in the communications business: laconic, unflappable and largely uninterested in spinning visions of the future.

title: Britain Asks Europe to Pay Most of Cost of Killing Cows
description: In an effort to rebuild its shattered beef industry, Britain pressed its European partners on Monday to finance 80 percent of the cost of destroying some four million cattle during the next five years, but the European Community today seemed set to offer 70 percent.

title: Media Chain Agrees to Pay In Libel Case
description: Having lost every appeal short of the Supreme Court, the Knight-Ridder company today settled one of the biggest and most closely watched libel suits ever brought against a newspaper, one involving a $24 million award to a former prosecutor over a story printed in the Philadelphia Inquirer in 1973.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Merger of 2 Bells Creates 2d-Largest Phone Company SBC Communications agreed to buy Pacific Telesis for $17 billion. The colossus would provide phone service to 30 million telephone lines in seven states, including Texas and California, and wireless service coast to coast. The company would be the nation's second-largest phone company, after AT&T.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: COMPANY NEWS;HORIZON/CMS AND PACIFIC REHABILITATION END MERGER
description: The Horizon/CMS Healthcare Corporation and Pacific Rehabilitation and Sports Medicine Inc. have agreed to end their merger agreement, Horizon/CMS said yesterday. Details were not disclosed. Horizon/CMS, an operator of nursing homes that is based in Albuquerque, N.M., agreed in November to merge with Pacific Rehabilitation, an operator of outpatient rehabilitation centers that is based in Vancouver, Wash., in a stock swap valued at $62 million. Horizon/CMS shares fell $1 yesterday, to $13.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 2 New Plans Are Prepared For Removing Alarm Boxes
description: Three weeks after the City Council firmly rejected the Giuliani administration's plan to dismantle the city's network of fire alarm boxes, both sides plan to revisit the issue today, introducing separate bills that would leave most of the boxes in place, Council officials said yesterday.

title: On My Mind;Some Ordinary Germans
description: Twice in my life I have felt that until I wrote about what I had just experienced, I would not be able to bring myself to write about anything else. The first time was in 1958, when I first visited Auschwitz.

title: Hollywood and Racism
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Loan Guarantee for Ferry
description: The Federal Government will guarantee a $1.5 million loan so that ferry service between New Jersey and New York City can be improved, Federico F. Pena, the Transportation Secretary, announced yesterday.

title: BASEBALL;Snowfall and Fallout for Yanks
