description: The Yankees woke up to snowflakes cascading by their hotel windows this morning, messy weather symbolic of the manner in which they assembled their starting rotation. Four inches of snow on opening day? Almost as ludicrous as using a $20 million starter as a reliever. But the Yankees did that with Kenny Rogers for 24 wacky hours.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: Peres Vows to Submit Final Pact With Palestinians to Israeli Vote
description: In an apparent effort to win the support of wavering voters in Israel's coming elections, Prime Minister Shimon Peres said today that he would put any final peace agreement with the Palestinians to a referendum.

title: F.C.C. Urged To Strengthen Children's TV
description: With the next round of license renewals for television broadcasters set to begin in June, the Federal Communications Commission is under pressure to finish a yearlong debate about whether to institute new rules requiring more educational programs for children.

title: Yellowstone Wolf Is Killed
description: A 92-pound female gray wolf that was released into Yellowstone National Park last year as part of a plan to reintroduce the species into the northern Rocky Mountains was shot to death over the weekend, Federal officials said today.

title: Council and Mayor at Odds on School Repairs
description: With only a few weeks left before Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is required to submit a budget for next year, the question of how to pay for school reconstruction is emerging as one of the most contentious issues dividing the Giuliani administration and the City Council.

title: BASKETBALL;St. John's Coaching Search Goes On
description: There was lots of speculation but no news yesterday regarding St. John's attempts to hire a new basketball coach. Nor is there likely to be an announcement until later this week.

title: Witness Cites Clinton Allies in Loan Fraud
description: The main prosecution witness in the Whitewater-related loan fraud and conspiracy trial of Gov. Jim Guy Tucker of Arkansas and others testified in Federal court today that he had joined the defendants in lying to obtain hundreds of thousands of dollars in false loans, which he said he was told were being used to bail out Little Rock political figures involved in sagging business deals.

title: Citibank Joins Investment In Masco Home Furnishings
description: The Masco Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its sluggish home furnishings unit for about $1.1 billion to a group of investors that includes Citibank.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Nokia Will Close Down 2 German TV Plants
description: Nokia Oy, the Finnish telecommunications equipment company, said yesterday that it would close its television factory in Bochum, Germany, and the components factory in Ziemetshausen, Germany, as part of its plan to leave that business. Nokia has about 1,200 employees in the television business in Germany.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Serving Their Time in Prison
description: Another dead child's name will be invoked today as lawmakers and victims' advocates seek to drum up support for legislation that would require people convicted of first- or second-degree offenses to serve at least 85 percent of their sentences before being eligible for parole. Many inmates are released after completing only one-third to one-half of their terms.

title: Covering Tobacco: A Cautionary Tale
description: In recent weeks television news and magazine programs have become warriors in the resurgent anticigarette wars, in alliance with whistle-blowers, government officials and legislators, plaintiffs against tobacco companies and antismokers at large.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Scania of Sweden Raises $2.7 Billion in Stock Issue
description: Investor A.B., the main financial arm of the Wallenberg family, raised about 18 billion kronor, or $2.7 billion, through the sale of half of the Swedish truckmaker Scania today, in one of the largest initial stock sales ever.

title: Split of Electronic Data and G.M. Is Set
description: For E.D.S., life after its long-sought parting from General Motors might not be so sweet after all.

title: Sports of The Times;Their Team Has Won, But True Kentuckians Will Check the Tapes
description: FROM the eastern crags of Pippa Passes to the western lowlands of Monkeys Eyebrow, Kentuckians will be reviewing the tape of last night's 76-67 victory over Syracuse for the national college basketball championship.

title: Merger Plans Spur Stocks; Dow Rises 50.58
description: A couple of multibillion-dollar mergers helped drive stock prices upward yesterday, with all three major indicators advancing together for the first time in almost a week.

title: Legislative Rift Imperils Basic Property Insurance
description: A dispute in the Legislature over a state fund that provides basic property insurance is threatening coverage for more than 62,000 homeowners and businesses, most of them in high-crime areas of New York City and storm-buffeted parts of Long Island where such policies are increasingly hard to obtain.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;Love Is Blind. Sometimes That's Good.
description: To Have (or Not)," Laetitia Masson's prickly realist film about a lonely young man and woman who find each other in less-than-glamorous circumstances, could be described as a romantic reality check. In delineating the union of two footloose lovers who bring plenty of quirky baggage to their relationship, it is the antithesis of that quintessentially swoony Gallic romance, "A Man and a Woman," which captivated American audiences 30 years ago. But in its guarded, skeptical way, the superbly acted film is as much on the side of love as is its glossier forerunners.

title: In Pakistan, Coup Trials Mostly Yield Skepticism
description: When the Mughal rulers of India built a fort beside the Indus river here more than 400 years ago, they placed it astride the route that generations of invaders had used when sweeping down on the Indian plains.

title: Weirton Steel To Fix Furnace
description: The Weirton Steel Corporation said today that it had shut down its No. 3 blast furnace for 10 days for a major repair that could wipe out the steelmaker's earnings in the second quarter.

title: How to Fix the Primary Election Mess
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Injury Threatens Fuhr's Streak
description: GRANT FUHR of the St. Louis Blues, who injured his right knee on Sunday, might be unable to build on his N.H.L. record of 76 consecutive starts by a goaltender. Fuhr, the only goalie to start every game this season, sustained a knee strain in the second period of an 8-1 loss to Detroit when SLAVA FETISOV fell on the leg after scoring. Fuhr did not practice yesterday. The team listed his injury as day to day, and there was no word if he would be available tomorrow when the Blues travel to Colorado. (AP)

title: District Attorney Looks Into Accusations of Jury Tampering in Simpson Case
description: The Los Angeles County District Attorney's office, expressing concern over accusations of jury tampering in the O. J. Simpson murder trial, is looking into whether an anonymous letter that resulted in the dismissal of a juror was fabricated.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Panthers Top Whalers Ray Sheppard notched a goal and an assist in the second period to lead the Florida Panthers to a 3-2 victory at home over the Hartford Whalers last night. The Panthers' snapped a four-game losing streak, as Martin Straka notched two assists and John Vanbiesbrouck grabbed 25 saves.

title: Republicans Oppose Retroactive Tax Laws
description: The Republican chairmen of two Congressional committees moved to reassure Wall Street that several tax proposals made by President Clinton would not be applied retroactively should they become law.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Deadline for Disaster Loans
description: The Small Business Administration has approved $576,000 in loans to victims of the Jan. 19 flood, the A.P. said yesterday. Homeowners, renters and business owners who have not already applied for disaster loans have until Friday to do so.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Mixed, But Long End Shows a Gain
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with the long end of the market moderately higher and shorter maturities weaker.

title: G.M.'s Monthly Sales Drop While Chrysler's Increase
description: The General Motors Corporation announced today that its March sales dropped 2.2 percent from levels a year earlier because a long strike interrupted its production. But the Chrysler Corporation reported an 8.1 percent gain for the month.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD;Mad Cow Epidemic Puts Spotlight On Puzzling Human Brain Disease
description: THE epidemic of mad cow disease in England has focused worldwide attention on the human version of the ailment, the fatal malady known as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. It is one of a small group of obscure diseases called spongiform encephalopathies because they produce holes in various areas of the brain, giving it a pitted appearance like Swiss cheese.

title: Jersey Doesn't Need a New Study of Education;Beware of Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Myths About Minorities
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit recently ruled that the affirmative action program at the University of Texas Law School was unconstitutional.

title: U.N. Plans Deep Cuts In Budget For First Time
description: Caught in a financial crisis and constrained by the first no-growth budget in its history, the United Nations expects to cut $250 million from its operating expenses by the end of 1997, the organization's chief administrative officer said today. Of the total, $98 million in savings has already been identified.

title: Ravenswood Aluminum in Pension Accord
description: Ravenswood Aluminum, which is owned by the Century Aluminum Company, has given the Government a lien on its West Virginia mill and promised to pump an extra $40 million into its pension plan in the next four years to get off the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation's list of the 50 most underfunded large pension plans.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Greystone Security Bolstered
description: Responding to incidents of vandalism, state officials have strengthened police security in parking lots at Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital, a spokesman for the State Department of Human Services said yesterday. Four extra patrols have been added daily.

title: NYC;New Season, Old Questions Over Stadium
description: FORGET the rain that sprinkled the Mets at Shea and the snow that whited out the Yankees in Cleveland. Baseball returned to New York yesterday, and that was enough to add bounce to the step of every fan.

title: Russian Military Halts Assault on the Chechen Rebels
description: Responding to the command of President Boris N. Yeltsin, Russian forces today stopped their continuous aerial and ground assault on the mutinous republic of Chechnya.

title: Lessons of a Ruinous War
description: Boris Yeltsin is not the first political leader to discover that it is harder to end a war then to start one, but he is fast learning that painful lesson in Chechnya. Fifteen months after launching a war he assumed Russia would swiftly win, Mr. Yeltsin is desperately trying to untangle his presidency and re-election hopes from a conflict that has gravely damaged both.

title: Observer;Edgar Allan Football
description: Edgar Allan Poe has become the first literary man to break into professional sports. It happened in Baltimore. "Charm City," as some deluded press agent once tried to nickname the Queen of the Chesapeake, recently found itself with Cleveland's old football team on its hands and no name for it.

title: Q&A
description: Lunar Frisbee

title: Gates Acquires Rights To Adams Photo Images
description: William H. Gates, the computer software billionaire, has added to his storehouse of images by acquiring the electronic rights to the works of Ansel Adams, the nature photographer and environmentalist.

title: The Final Sprint to Opening Night
description: The first night that "Big" played to an audience during its recent tryout in Detroit, the creators of the $10 million musical knew something was wrong.

title: Behind the Spin
description: To the Editor:

title: OBITUARY : Dante Giacosa, Fiat 500 Designer, Is Dead
description: Dante Giacosa designed some of Europe's most popular automobiles, but he was best known as the "father of the 500," the chubby little car that symbolized Italy's postwar economic miracle.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Of Communications a la Modem
description: ONCE upon a time, modems were peculiar devices that demanded respect, not to mention long sessions with the baffling manuals that came with them. Now they are essential, typically thrown in with computers like Cracker Jack prizes and configured by software. Modems have largely become commodities, almost indistinguishable from one another.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WEYERHAEUSER DROPS PRICE OF LEADING GRADE OF PULP
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company of Tacoma, Wash., cut the price of its benchmark grade of pulp by 13 percent yesterday, reflecting weaker demand for the processed wood fiber used to make paper. Weyerhaeuser, the world's largest pulp producer, cut the price for northern bleached softwood kraft market pulp to $520 a metric ton, from $600 in March, said Chip Dillon, a forest products analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc. That means the price of pulp has dropped 48 percent from a high of $1,000 a metric ton, reached in the third quarter of last year.

title: Hunting for an Identity In Contemporary Cuba
description: I dream exactly what I live every day," a professor, bored with her mundane life, tells her therapist. But the visual evidence on screen at the start of "Madagascar" suggests that dreams are never that banal. Bicyclists crowd the street, riding to work in slow motion in a haunting, shadowy blue dawn. "Madagascar" is the centerpiece and by far the strongest of three films combined in one program in the New Directors/New Films series and linked by a decidedly noncommercial esthetic. All offer impressionistic views of life in run-down areas of Cuba or Brazil.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The artist formerly known as PRINCE is looking forward to the acquisition of a new name: Dad.

title: 2 Regional Giants Join Forces As Deregulation Takes Hold : U.S. Phone Merger Signals New Trend
description: NEW YORK  Two huge regional telephone companies in California and Texas announced a $16.5 billion merger on Monday, the first and probably not the last among the Baby Bells under new and looser telecommunications laws.

title: Splendor in the Mud: Unraveling the Lives of Anacondas
description: IN one of the murky, hyacinth-choked pools in these vast savannas, whorls of thick spotted coils appear and disappear at the water's surface, hinting at the mass of snake hidden below. Three researchers tensely circle their submerged quarry when suddenly, cornered, the leviathan strikes, her dripping jaws shooting out of the water. Instantly they are upon her, grabbing head and tail, and she upon them, coils tightening around arms, legs, waists. For a moment it seems an even fight as the men, knotted in serpent, struggle even to remain upright. But eventually they manage to extract all 15 feet of her from the muddy lagoon. She is taken, the anaconda, the biggest snake in the world.

title: Investor Group Vote Rebuffs Union Members
description: In a close race, members of the Council of Institutional Investors surprised their leadership yesterday by electing Martin A. Coyle, an executive vice president and general counsel of TRW Inc., as one of its three co-chairmen. They chose him over Michael McGrath, the Treasurer of Minnesota, who was the official nominee.

title: BASKETBALL;Relentless Kentucky Captures Championship
description: No one can touch them now. The Kentucky Wildcats fulfilled the most burdensome demand in college basketball tonight. They overcame a persistent but outnumbered group of Syracuse Orangemen, a team that somehow narrowed a 13-point second-half deficit to 2 and swelled Continental Arena with the hope of one of the most memorable upsets in the history of the national collegiate tournament.

title: Jersey Doesn't Need a New Study of Education
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Japanese Bank In Bond Inquiry
description: American banking authorities are investigating a United States subsidiary of the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan for misreporting bond trades, the bank said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BENNETT FUNDING FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: The Bennett Funding Group Inc. and three affiliates filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Friday and have suspended payments to investors, a lawyer for the company said yesterday. The office-equipment leasing company was sued by the Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday for reportedly defrauding investors. The S.E.C. said the Syracuse-based Bennett Funding ran a "massive Ponzi scheme" involving $570 million of securities. The company and its chief financial officer, Patrick Bennett, have denied the charges. Mr. Bennett also faces criminal charges of securities fraud and perjury. The company is owned by Mr. Bennett's parents, Edmund and Kathleen Bennett, who were not named in the suit.

title: U.S. to Pay for Rights Monitors in Burundi
description: The United States will provide $1.3 million for human rights monitors in Rwanda and Burundi, Brian Atwood, the Agency for International Development administrator, said here today.

title: BASKETBALL;Wallace Falls Short In His Grim Crusade
description: John Wallace, Syracuse's splendid senior forward and team leader, seemed ill-tempered throughout the Final Four. It was as if he had come to a party, didn't like any of the guests, but was compelled to stay.

title: Basketball Finale As Baseball Opens
description: The University of Kentucky captured the national collegiate basketball championship last night, defeating Syracuse, 76-67, at the New Jersey Meadowlands

title: Law Comes to Public Housing
description: The Clinton Administration has offered a new plan to bring a higher level of decency and safety to the nation's public housing projects. It includes the eviction of drug dealers and tougher screening of tenants to keep out criminals. It also threatens the eviction of entire households even if only one member sells drugs. The plan poses civil-liberties risks. But the risks can be averted with due-process protections like those in force in New York City.

title: Austin Center Is Sold
description: The Intercontinental Life Corporation sold the Austin Center office-hotel complex today for $62.7 million to the Khimji family of Dallas and Vancouver, British Columbia. The Austin-based insurance company expects the sale to add $15 million, or $2.78 a share, to its first-quarter results. The company will use the proceeds to reduce its bank debt to $29.9 million from $44.9 million. For the first quarter ended March 31, 1995, Intercontinental Life earned $2.6 million, or 51 cents a share.

title: Columbia Students Begin Hunger Strike for Ethnic Studies
description: Columbia University's student body is becoming more diverse, but its curriculum is lagging behind, according to a coalition of Hispanic, Asian-American and black students who are pressing for a broader program of ethnic studies.

title: BASEBALL;Another Rally for Mariners
description: In baseball's first opening day game in March, the Seattle Mariners defeated the Chicago White Sox, 3-2, Sunday night. They did it with some pretty good hitting by Edgar Martinez in the ninth inning and by Russ Davis and Alex Rodriguez in the 12th.

title: A Trial Revisits Philadelphia's 11-Year-Old Heartbreak
description: The flames of Osage Avenue still rage in Ramona Africa's soul. And its ghosts still haunt and hurt her heart, nearly 11 years after 11 members of her "family," including five children, were killed when the police dropped a bomb on the headquarters of the radical group MOVE.

title: Murdoch May Seek Satellite Deal With TCI
description: The chairman of the News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch, said yesterday that he was prepared to invest hundreds of millions of dollars in a joint venture with Tele-Communications Inc. and John C. Malone, its chief executive, to provide satellite television in the United States.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: MARATHON;Pippig Will Defend Boston Title
description: The two-time defending champion UTA PIPPIG of Germany and 13 other top female runners are among those entered in the Boston Marathon, race officials said yesterday. In the April 15 race, Pippig will try to become the first woman to win three years in a row. The 30-year-old recorded the two fastest times among female marathoners last year, with victories at Boston (2 hours 25 minutes 11 seconds) and Berlin (2:25:36).

title: THEATER REVIEW;They Can Fake a Twang; Do They Sob in the Beer?
description: Scrawled on a blackboard over the bar of a Kansas roadhouse that is the setting for the uproariously silly musical comedy "Cowgirls" is the daily special: "possum pie -- $2.99." As Hank Williams and Patsy Cline twang from the jukebox, a curvaceous, doll-faced waitress named Mickey (Jackie Sanders) with mile-high cotton-candy hair prattles on in a drawl as wide as a gully in Dogpatch.

title: By Design;Color Comes Back to Legs
description: Last year, designers all wanted to see bare legs -- or at least the look of bare legs in sheer hosiery. It was a tad impractical for winter, and all but fashion diehards rejected the whole idea.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Profit at Division Trims Thomson's Loss
description: Thomson S.A. said yesterday that its net loss narrowed in 1995, aided by improved results at its Thomson-CSF unit, which posted its first profit in three years.

title: Under Pressure, Federal Judge Reverses Decision in Drug Case
description: After enduring an avalanche of criticism and calls for his ouster, a Federal judge yesterday reversed his decision suppressing evidence and a videotaped confession in a Washington Heights drug case.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;Chinese Coach Is Hospitalized
description: China's flamboyant and controversial long-distance track coach, MA JUNREN, is hospitalized with a serious intestinal ailment as his team prepares for the Atlanta Olympics. Ma had a blockage of the large intestine, KAN FULING, chief of China's track and field team, said yesterday. During Ma's absence, the assistant coach LIU QI is training the middle- and long-distance runners. (AP)

title: Review/Fashion;Sui's Shades Of Bloomsbury
description: There is a pin-dot-size point of reference on which many designers start and end their collections each season; it is more a notion than an idea. Like the rulers of the tiny planets in Antoine de Saint-Exupery's "Little Prince," they may find their thought for the season big and universal, but it is really just a small idea for a small world.

title: Bosnians Are on Trail Of Missing Kin's Graves
description: He walked the trail of his father, past the snowy hills outside Sarajevo that once hid Serbian snipers and through the torn masonry of the village where his family once lived.

title: Review/Fashion;Into the Evening With Elegance
description: In a season in which fashion has been on a roller-coaster ride, Bill Blass managed to stay up there, with a fall collection of real clothes that were dedicated to the customer and that still managed to pack a wallop.

title: World News Briefs;Talks on Hostages Halted At a Prison in Brazil
description: Inmates holding 23 hostages at a maximum-security prison suspended talks today on ending their uprising after turning down a Government offer of guns, money and getaway cars.

title: Adoptees Don't Always Know Sense of Loss or Incompleteness
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES RISE AFTER PROPOSED DEAL
description: The shares of Republic Industries rose 13 percent yesterday after the company, controlled by the billionaire H. Wayne Huizenga, offered to buy Auto Nation USA, a national used-car company, in a $250 million stock swap. Republic shares jumped $4.125, to $35.50, in Nasdaq trading of three million shares. Republic, a provider of waste collection and electronic security services that it based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., made the offer on Friday. Since Mr. Huizenga resigned in November as vice chairman of Viacom Inc. and chairman of its Blockbuster Entertainment Group, he has bought large stakes in Republic and Auto Nation.

title: BASKETBALL;Little Errors Adding Up To Big Woes for Knicks
description: Charles Oakley sees the warning signs the errant 3-pointer off the break, the forced jumper in traffic and, ultimately, the disturbing blowout loss. He is not saying the Knicks are in immediate danger, but he is concerned.

title: A MERGER OF HEALTH INSURERS: THE REGION;In New York, Aetna Will Be Understudy
description: Even though the Aetna Life and Casualty Company is buying U.S. Healthcare Inc., the impact in the New York metropolitan region will probably make it seem as if the opposite has occurred. The U.S. Healthcare network -- it is both far larger and more successful, with about four times as many managed care patients as Aetna in New York State, for example -- is expected to provide the imprint for how the two companies march forward together.

title: World News Briefs;Revival of Warsaw Pact No Joke in East Europe
description: A Russian news agency found out today that jokes about the old Soviet Union are not so funny to the people of Eastern Europe, even on April Fools' Day.

title: Aetna to Buy U.S. Healthcare In Big Move to Managed Care
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company plans to spend $8.8 billion to buy U.S. Healthcare Inc., a leader in what is known as managed health care, creating the nation's single biggest medical benefits company.

title: Dole's Ideal Vacation: Doing Nothing, or Close to It
description: I've got to go up there and eat a sandwich," Senator Bob Dole said today, gesturing to the condominium 12 floors above. He was talking to a longtime friend sunning in a lounge chair, explaining why he was abandoning the pool deck at the beautiful height of the day.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Hostetler Will Remain With Raiders
description: The injury-plagued quarterback JEFF HOSTETLER will re-sign with the Oakland Raiders today, the team said yesterday. A team spokesman, MIKE TAYLOR, confirmed the agreement, but said the Raiders would not disclose terms of the contract. The signing had been scheduled for yesterday but was postponed because Hostetler was out of town.

title: BASEBALL;Umpire Dies After Collapsing on Field
description: John McSherry, working the first inning of his 26th season as a major league umpire, collapsed and died in Cincinnati yesterday on the opening day of the baseball season. He was believed to be the first person to be stricken fatally on the field during a major league baseball game since 1920.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Spanish Concern Is Sold
description: Mastec Inc. said today that it had bought the engineering and installation subsidiary of Telefonica de Espana S.A., the Spanish telecommunications company, for $39.5 million. The purchase will more than double Mastec's size and give the company, a telecommunications provider based here, access to Spanish and Latin American markets. The Telefonica de Espana subsidiary, which is known as Sintel, also operates in Chile, Venezuela, Peru and Argentina.

title: 2 Law Professors Die In Cape Town Crash
description: Two professors from the City University of New York School of Law were killed yesterday in a highway accident in Cape Town, South Africa, where they were attending a conference on democracy and international law, a university official said.

title: BASEBALL;Old Master: Cone Pitches the Yankees to Victory
description: David Cone treated the baseball like a paintbrush on a belated opening day today, smudging, smearing and blotching the canvas that was the Cleveland Indians. Cone squeezed everything out of the brush and his pitches, and after his abstract effort was finally finished and the game completed, the game he had pitched somehow resembled a masterpiece.

title: Reviews/Fashion;3 Successes, and So American
description: The growing impact of American talent on the international fashion scene raises the age-old issue of whether any country can claim a superior approach to style. Is it the French, the Americans or someone else?

title: A Matter of Ethics
description: To The Living Section:

title: Could It Be? Weather Has Nothing To Do With Your Arthritis Pain?
description: O.K. Maybe sugar does not make children hyperactive. Maybe getting cold and damp does not predispose people to catch a cold. Maybe there is even no such thing as the "hot hand" in basketball. But surely people with arthritis suffer more when the weather changes. Surely all those tales of old people who can feel a storm coming in their bones cannot be wrong?

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Gill Not Ready Yet
description: The Nets' KENDALL GILL, out since breaking a bone in his left hand on Feb. 14, met with team doctors yesterday and was not given clearance to resume playing. Gill was instead instructed to continue rehabilitating the injury until he is re-examined next week. Gill nevertheless participated in a modified practice yesterday. KEVIN EDWARDS, who played in the Nets' first 34 games before going down with knee tendinitis, fully participated in yesterday's practice. KHALID REEVES sat out with an upset stomach.

title: Dominican President Isn't Worst Caudillo
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;49ers Cut a Starter
description: DENNIS BROWN, who started the last three seasons at defensive end, has been waived by the San Francisco 49ers to make salary cap room for the newly signed running back JOHNNY JOHNSON. The signing of Johnson, whose two-year, $3 million contract was filed with the National Football League on Monday, made it mandatory that somebody had to go. (AP)

title: TV NOTES;Not Quite a Hit
description: It may not have lived up to the Marchlong madness of promotion that preceded it, but "Nash Bridges," the new Don Johnson police show on CBS, did demonstrate a pulse in its first two outings last weekend. That's more than can be said for most of the broadcast networks' new offerings this spring.

title: Real Estate;Sony makes a number of moves in Manhattan to put more of its businesses under one roof.
description: CALL it the Sony shuffle. The SonyCorporation of America has doubled its space at 555 Madison Avenue, cut almost in half its space at 711 Fifth Avenue, and terminated its lease at 9 West 57th Street.

title: Theater in Review
description: Gang Thriller in Bay Ridge With a Sassy Cross-Dresser Puerto Rican Traveling Theater 304 West 47th Street

title: Dr. J. Kiffin Penry, 66, Leader In Search for Epilepsy Treatments
description: Dr. J. Kiffin Penry, a neurologist and researcher who was in the forefront of efforts to improve the medical treatment of epileptics, died on Sunday at his home in Winston-Salem, N.C. He was 66 and had been a professor at the Bowman Gray School of Medicine at Wake Forest University.

title: New Custody Rule Harms Fathers' Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Eviction Day Along the Curb Of a Dead Road
description: Work is beginning this week on the West Side Highway, evoking visions of grandeur for city planners and easier travel for many motorists. But to several dozen homeless people, the work brought only disruption and pain yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SCITEX REJECTS $856 MILLION BID BY INVESTOR
description: The Scitex Corporation has rejected a bid of $20 a share in cash from the investor Davidi Gilo, who expressed his disappointment yesterday. The proposal by Mr. Gilo, who owns 3 percent of Scitex, valued the company at $856 million. Shares of Scitex, the maker of computer imaging systems used in printing and graphic arts, fell 25 cents, to $17.625, in Nasdaq trading. The Scitex board said it would seek to increase the value of the company's stock by working with its financial adviser, Alex. Brown & Sons. Mr. Gilo said that he and his advisers would "examine all alternatives." Mr. Gilo is chairman of DSP Communications Inc., a chip maker, but the company has said it has no connection with the bid.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about a contested election at the Council of Institutional Investors, a group of large union and company pension funds, referred incorrectly to the union of which Bill Lucy, an uncontested candidate for secretary, is secretary-treasurer. It is the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, not the Association of Federal, State and Municipal Employees.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Nuclear Reactor Reopening
description: The Salem II nuclear reactor in southern New Jersey will start up again in August, a month sooner than expected, and its twin reactor, Salem I, may also return to service early next year, their operator, the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, said yesterday. Both reactors were shut down by a series of problems last spring. The utility company's announcement drew immediate criticism from environmentalists who would like to see the reactors closed down for good, The Associated Press reported.

title: Treasury Warns Its Agents on Off-Duty Bias
description: The Treasury Department said today that it was imposing rules forbidding its law-enforcement officers to engage in "off-duty manifestations of racial and other forms of bias."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Drug Sweep Yields 32 Arrests
description: About 40 police officers have swept through the area surrounding Martin Luther King Drive and Ocean Avenue as part of a three-day campaign aimed at catching drug dealers, the captain in charge of the operation said yesterday. On Monday, the first day of the sweep, 32 arrests were made and about $4,000 in drug money was seized, said the captain, Kenneth M. French. The police also shut down a crack house where they found 40 bags of heroin, Captain French said.

title: Homage To Chasen's
description: There may never be another Chasen's, the hallowed watering hole in Beverly Hills, Calif., that included among its regulars Ronald Reagan, Dorothy Lamour, Jimmy Stewart and Alfred Hitchcock. It closed a year ago after 59 years and will be replaced, much to the distress of moviedom, by a shopping mall.

title: Dogs Make Life Better For Disabled
description: Forced by multiple sclerosis to use a wheelchair, Lane Phalen struggled for four years to open and close doors, pick up things that fell on the floor or go shopping.

title: Eating Well
description: THIS column is devoted to some bits of interesting information I have come across, as well as follow-ups to previous columns.

title: Devils Cling to Bottom Rung of the Playoff Ladder
description: Time is running out on the Devils.

title: Technology Gap
description: While the Internet's World Wide Web and Microsoft's Windows 95 have increased popular interest in personal computers and in the information superhighway, we Americans who are blind or otherwise visually impaired are being forced onto a side road.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WOOLWORTH'S BOARD OPPOSES SPINOFF PROPOSAL
description: The Woolworth Corporation said yesterday that the board would recommend that shareholders vote against a proposal made by Greenway Partners L.P., an asset management company, that the retailer, which is based in New York, spin off its athletic footwear and apparel division. Greenway Partners proposed the move on Feb. 1, saying that division -- which is mainly the Foot Locker chain -- would be more attractive as a separate company. Greenway holds 8 million shares, or 6 percent, of Woolworth's stock. Woolworth's board said the spinoff would not increase shareholder value. It said that would require the "operational turnaround" of several of its units.

title: Rush to Wed Raises Issues On Freeing Of Baby Bells
description: When SBC Communications and the Pacific Telesis Group announced their $17 billion merger on Monday, the companies said the deal would prep them for the competitive free-for-all promised by deregulation.

title: HORSE RACING;Cobra King And Ide Are Derby Casualties
description: Two of the ranking 3-year-old colts in the country, Cobra King and Ide, were withdrawn from the Kentucky Derby yesterday with leg injuries.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-9

title: Mexico City Journal;Here's Paint in Your Eye, or the Artist's Revenge
description: After a court ordered a prominent artist here to turn over works from his own hand in payment of a debt to his former dealer, he painted 19 stormy canvases spattered with insults against the dealer.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Revised History Standards Disarm the Explosive Issues
description: Proposed standards for teaching history to American schoolchildren, which came under furious attack from conservatives when they were published last year, are being re-issued today in a revised form that omits their most criticized feature: the examples of classroom activities.

title: Business Travel;Security is a growing worry for executives working in some increasingly unsafe overseas areas.
description: EARLIER this year, John Hyden, 41, a British executive visiting St. Petersburg, was having a cup of coffee in the Vienna Cafe of the five-star Nevsky Palace Hotel -- surely a safe place in the new and unruly Russia. Suddenly a gunman burst in and sprayed the room with an AK-47, killing Mr. Hyden along with the intended victim, a Russian industrialist at a nearby table.

title: CHRONICLE
description: TOBY HOFFMAN, 37, a violist, insisted the other day that there was never a trace of sibling rivalry in his family. This is despite the fact that he and his two brothers, JOEL HOFFMAN, 42, a pianist and composer, and GARY HOFFMAN, 39, a cellist, and their sister, DEBORAH HOFFMAN, 35, a harpist, all gravitated early to music.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Airbus Steps Up Effort On Jumbo Jet Project
description: The European airplane consortium Airbus Industrie said yesterday that it was accelerating work on its 70 billion franc ($14 billion) project to develop a jet that would seat more than 500 passengers. The consortium said it had created a division to study the feasibility of building the aircraft, which would compete with a project contemplated by the Boeing Company.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Federal judge's reversal of his ruling in a Manhattan drug case referred incorrectly in some editions to the source of a quotation cited by the judge, Harold Baer Jr., in his new decision. It was Justice Thurgood Marshall, not John Marshall, who said, "Because the strongest advocates of Fourth Amendment rights are frequently criminals, it is easy to forget that our interpretations of such rights apply to the innocent and the guilty alike."

title: White House Responds To Report of Poultry Deal
description: The White House sought today to rebut senior House Republicans about newspaper allegations that President Clinton tried to strike a deal with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia to benefit Arkansas poultry producers.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Finding that LEONA HELMSLEY had disobeyed his order that she answer questions under oath in a breach of contract suit, a Manhattan justice has ordered her to pay a dismissed executive $1.1 million plus interest, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Clinton Discussed '86 Fraud Proposal, Witness Says
description: David Hale, the chief prosecution witness in the Whitewater-related loan fraud trial here, testified today that Bill Clinton participated in a 1986 meeting to discuss a proposed fraudulent loan to some political and business associates from a small-business lending company that Mr. Hale ran.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball Frontier League JOHNSTOWN STEAL -- Signed P Matt Palisin, INF Lenny Sniegowski and OF Thurston Rockmore.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PANAMSAT CONSIDERS SALE, MERGER OR ALLIANCE
description: The Panamsat Corporation said yesterday that it had hired Morgan Stanley & Company to explore its strategic alternatives, including joint ventures, alliances, mergers or the sale of the company. Panamsat also filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a secondary offering of $350 million of common stock. Grupo Televisa S.A., which owns 40.5 million of Panamsat's 100 million shares, said it had not made a decision about Panamsat, based in Greenwich, Conn., or its other assets and could nott promise transactions would result from its review.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : Russian Imperial Style Comes to Mississippi
description: More than 600 priceless treasures of the imperial palaces of St. Petersburg have gone on display in Jackson, Mississippi, including golden thrones, a jewel-studded Bible, and the exquisite five-inch Faberge Gatchina egg.

title: Bones Hamilton, 83, Football Player
description: Robert Alexander (Bones) Hamilton, a standout running back at Stanford from 1933-35, when the university won 25 of 31 games and made three straight Rose Bowl appearances, died at his home in Palm Springs on Monday, Stanford announced today. He was 83.

title: BASEBALL;Mournfully, Reds Defeat the Expos
description: Reds 4, Expos 1

title: BASEBALL;Perez Advised by Yankees To Undergo Elbow Surgery
description: So the Yankees were smart for not trading Scott Kamieniecki, silly for ever removing Kenny Rogers from the starting rotation and suspect for believing Melido Perez could contribute. Why? Because Perez's injury-plagued career took another nasty turn today when the Yankees informed the pitcher that he should have arthroscopic surgery performed on his right elbow.

title: I.R.L. Unveils Its New Rules
description: The Indy Racing League, the series started by the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, announced new rules yesterday for the 1997 Indianapolis 500 aimed at reducing costs for race teams. The rules render the cars now used by the rival Championship Auto Racing Teams series ineligible for the 1997 Indy 500, widening the gulf between the speedway and most of the top Indy-car teams, which are already boycotting the 1996 Indy 500.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Honor for Science Scholar
description: Daniel P. Weitz, a Morristown High School senior, has been thinking about fusion energy since he was 12, according to officials of the State Department of Education. More recently, he built a plasma generator, which creates an electrically charged gas of a type that might one day be the basis of fusion energy, and used it to test some of his theories. The project won him a $15,000 scholarship through the Westinghouse Science Talent Search. Among 40 students across the nation to receive that award, he was the only one from New Jersey. Today, the 17-year-old student will be honored by the State Board of Education.

title: BASKETBALL;Hitting Playoff Stride?
description: Less than a year ago in Game 6 of the Eastern Conference playoffs, Charles Oakley and John Starks sniped at each other on the same Market Square Arena floor, the Knicks won and all was well for the time being.

title: Backing for Teacher-Aide Plan
description: A study of alternative paths into teaching jobs says that some shortages in bilingual and special education classrooms could be solved by expanding the programs that help teachers' aides get their bachelor's degrees and certification.

title: COURT OVERTURNS BAN IN NEW YORK ON AIDED SUICIDES;U.S. COURT CLEARS WAY FOR DOCTORS IN NEW YORK TO AID IN SOME SUICIDES
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled yesterday that doctors in New York State could legally help terminally ill patients commit suicide in certain circumstances, striking down parts of a longstanding state ban on assisted suicide.

title: I.B.M. Jumps and Dow Follows, Adding 33.96
description: The stock market's upward momentum continued yesterday, led by a rally in I.B.M.

title: Hamas Calls for Renewed Suicide Bombings to Counter Crackdown
description: Stung by a tough crackdown by Palestinian and Israeli security forces, the militant Islamic group Hamas called today for a resumption of suicide attacks against Israel.

title: A Mother's Easter Lessons, Cherished and Well Learned
description: BROWN sugar and allspice. Those smells would merge and then waft through my mother's house every Easter as she opened the oven to baste the ham, the centerpiece of our feast.

title: Internet Copyright Protection Isn't Far-Fetched
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Says if Yanks Must Move, West Side Would Be Best
description: With the city ready to present the New York Yankees with a report on the best place to locate the team, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that it would be easier to finance building a new stadium on Manhattan's West Side than at any other site.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHIP MAKER ANNOUNCES CHARGE AND LAYOFFS
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said yesterday that it would cut its worldwide work force by about 400 people and take a related charge of at least $20 million in the current fourth quarter. The chip maker said a slowdown in new orders for computer chips prompted the layoffs, which would involve mainly factory and administrative jobs. National Semiconductor, which employs 21,000 people worldwide, said last month that a slide in its third-quarter earnings was caused by a drop in worldwide orders and bookings, all stemming from the slowdown in PC sales. In the three months ended Feb. 25, the company earned $23 million, or 17 cents a share. National Semiconductor's stock lost 37.5 cents, to $14, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Ready . . . Set . . . Flip: Omelets in Record Time
description: HOWARD HELMER, who looks and often acts remarkably like a wayward Marx Brother, has been a spokesman for the American Egg Board for 20 years. As the national representative for the trade group, he travels the land, talking about eggs and cooking them on television shows, in department stores, in kitchenware shops, at state fairs and, he says, "just about anywhere anyone will have me."

title: Ex-I.B.M. Official Charged in Fraud
description: The former president of IBM Argentina was charged today with fraud in connection with a contract to modernize the state-owned Banco Nacion's computer system.

title: Judge Baer's Mess
description: Federal District Judge Harold Baer Jr. has made a terrible mess. His original ruling that 80 pounds of confiscated drugs and a videotaped confession could not be admitted in a conspiracy trial was bizarrely unfair to police, prosecutors and public safety. But the clumsiness of his reversal provides an ugly picture of a Federal judge caving to politicians and eager to prevent his ruling from becoming a Republican attack issue in the 1996 election campaign.

title: Sybase Expects Loss And Plans Changes
description: Sybase Inc., the struggling data base software maker based in Emeryville, Calif., said yesterday that it expected a loss for its first quarter, which ended last Sunday.

title: A Stealth Attack on Food Safety
description: An 11th-hour amendment, sneaked into the farm bill last week, threatens to complicate and clog the nation's meat and poultry safety system. The White House opposes the amendment but is unlikely to veto the bill, which has many admirable provisions. Given the controversies over possibly contaminated beef in England and the rejection of U.S. chickens in Russia because of high salmonella levels, though, this is no time to trifle with food safety. Congress should correct its own mistake.

title: Must Our CD's, Too, Be Put to Pasture?
description: To the Editor:

title: Diet Books and Programs
description: To The Living Section:

title: Judges Allow New Inquiry Of Agriculture Officials
description: A panel of Federal judges ruled today that the prosecutor investigating bribery allegations against Mike Espy, the former Agriculture Secretary, could look into new evidence that other Department officials may have done favors for industry officials in return for gifts.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MOBIL UNIT ANNOUNCES THAT IT HAS CUT 585 JOBS
description: Mobil Exploration and Producing U.S. Inc., a Dallas-based unit of the Mobil Corporation, said yesterday that it had cut 585 jobs in a reorganization announced in January, which also resulted in the loss of 30 more jobs at Mobil Drilling. Mobil said about 500 employees had left the Dallas-based company voluntarily under an incentive plan. Mobil's major exploration and producing units are in Bakersfield, Calif.; Dallas; Houston; Midland, Tex., and New Orleans.

title: Woman Wounded by Crucifixes in Exorcism
description: As relatives watched and prayed, a man punctured his mother-in-law's esophagus when he jammed two crucifixes down her throat during an exorcism, the police said today.

title: Videotape of Beating by Authorities Jolts Los Angeles
description: A television news crew's videotape of two white sheriff's deputies clubbing two unresisting Mexicans has jarred the Los Angeles area and revived accusations that there is a pattern of police abuse of minorities that law-enforcement authorities have failed to confront.

title: HOCKEY;Kovalev Sizzles, and the Devils Are in Trouble
description: Trades have made the Rangers bigger and maybe a little better. Key injured players have healed and returned. These are among the reasons they defeated the Devils last night by 3-1, their first victory in four games against the Stanley Cup champions this season.

title: 2 Whites Charged With Firing on Blacks
description: Two white teen-age brothers are accused of using a blowgun to shoot two blacks with 3-inch metal darts, the police said today.

title: Teacher Ousted Over Film
description: A school board has dismissed a high school teacher for showing an R-rated Bertolucci movie about Italian fascism to his 17- and 18-year-old students.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Mad Dogs Agency Gains Coors Work
description: The Blue Moon Brewing Company, a unit of the Adolph Coors Company that markets a line of specialty beers meant to compete against microbrewery products, has named Mad Dogs and Englishmen in New York to handle its account, which had been handled on a project basis by Karsh & Hagen in Denver. Billings were not disclosed; Adweek estimated them at $3 million to $5 million.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Teller-Machine Fees on Rise
description: Electronic banking may become more expensive for people who use automatic-teller networks like Cirrus or Plus. Earlier this week, several networks authorized their banks to raise fees for noncustomers to as high as $2.50, from $1.

title: In Bosnia Field, Changes Refuel Talk of Graves
description: As war crimes investigators began their first search of this area for evidence of mass killings, an independent visit today to one of the most important suspected mass graves on their itinerary showed indications of extensive tampering.

title: State Insurance Fund For High-Risk Areas Gets an Extension
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders agreed tonight on a one-year extension of a state fund that provides property insurance in high-risk areas of the state where such policies are difficult to find.

title: World News Briefs;Britain Widens Powers Of Police on Terrorism
description: The Government pushed through a package of tough emergency legislation tonight that hands the police extensive new powers to combat terrorism.

title: Yeltsin's False Truce
description: President Boris Yeltsin's announcement on Sunday of a cease-fire in Chechnya should be met in the United States with the same skepticism that greeted it in Russia. Several cease-fires have preceded it, and all were brief.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Pepsi Introduces a New LookFor Its International Markets
description: Pepsico's Pepsi-Cola unit introduced a $500 million promotion and advertising campaign here today that it hopes will help make up some ground in pursuit of Coca-Cola in world markets.

title: Britain's Daunting Prospect: Killing 15,000 Cows a Week
description: In the last two weeks, the British mad cow scare has humiliated the Government, agonized the $6.5 billon beef industry and turned carnivores into vegetarians.

title: Eye Surgeon Loses Effort To Enforce His Patent
description: A Federal judge has rejected a surgeon's effort to enforce a patent for a type of cataract surgery in a case that has prompted Congress to consider banning such "medical methods patents."

title: In A-Plant's Backyard in Connecticut, Trust Ebbs
description: At the very tip of this town, where Millstone Point forms the eastern shore of Niantic Bay, three nuclear power plants owned by Northeast Utilities sit idle, under intense scrutiny by Federal regulators because of a long record of safety-procedure violations.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Feuding Couple Relies On Hit-Man Diplomacy
description: Early in "Faithful," there's a scene that shows off the comic touch of Paul Mazursky, who can gaze so benignly on the foibles of well-heeled neurotic types. Margaret (Cher) has been wandering about forlornly when she comes across two men (Stephen Spinella and Jeffrey Wright) vocally admiring a Rolls-Royce. "Won't make you happy," she mutters, looking so miserable that one of the men hands her a $20 bill. She takes it, gets into the Rolls-Royce and drives home.

title: BASKETBALL;Those Knicks Just Want To Shout
description: Anthony Mason wheeled his bulky frame from the block on the left baseline with 50.4 seconds left, about to convert an implausible shot on a night of many implausible shots. He moved into the key and lofted a soft jump hook over the elongated frames of 7-foot-4-inch Rik Smits and 6-9 Antonio Davis.

title: Church Faces A New Dispute Involving Race
description: An all-white church that backed down from an effort to have the body of a biracial baby removed from its cemetery is refusing to allow the child's parents to be married there or join the church, the family said today.

title: Extremist Group Suspected in Spokane Bombings
description: Two men wearing ski masks used a pipe bomb in a bank robbery on Monday after setting off another bomb moments earlier at a newspaper office, the authorities said today.

title: Testosterone Injections Work as Contraceptive
description: Weekly injections of testosterone reduce the sperm counts of almost all men to below the threshold needed for conception, according to a study by the World Health Organization.

title: ART REVIEW;From the Heart and Hand of David Hockney
description: There are certain artists who elicit nothing so much as ambivalence, a contradictory state in which both belief and disbelief are suspended. One such artist is David Hockney, the multi-talented painter, draftsman, printmaker and set designer who burst on the English art scene in the early 1960's, carved out a niche for himself at the fringe of the nascent Pop Art movement and made his presence felt soon thereafter in New York.

title: Researching the Enemy: An Old Political Tool Resurfaces in a NewElection
description: When Bob Dole campaigned his way through the Iowa Presidential caucuses in February, he was often shadowed by a young man carrying a compact, broadcast-quality, Hi-8 television camcorder.

title: BASEBALL;Injury Will Likely Keep Mets' Pulsipher Out for Season
description: For most of spring training, a picture of Bill Pulsipher, Jason Isringhausen and Paul Wilson served as the billboard for the Mets' high expectations this season. But the trio has been trimmed to two after a magnetic resonance imaging test conducted yesterday showed that Pulsipher has a torn ligament in his left elbow and will probably need season-ending surgery.

title: Ruby Ridge Lawyer Offers Help in Montana
description: Correction Appended

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Calloway Stays a Giant
description: The Giants re-signed CHRIS CALLOWAY, their leading receiver last year, to a contract reported at $3.6 million over three years yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PENNZOIL TO SELL HALF OF STAKE IN OILFIELD
description: The Pennzoil Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell about half its stake in one of the world's biggest oil development projects, an oilfield in the Caspian Sea, to a unit of the Itochu Corporation in Tokyo for $132 million. The field, off the coast of Azerbaijan, is estimated to contain at least four billion barrels of crude oil. It is being developed by a group that includes oil companies from seven nations. Under the agreement, Itochu would pay Pennzoil $90 million at closing for its 5 percent stake in the Azeri-Chiraq-Gunashli field and the right to receive payments for certain project costs. Additional installments of $22 million and $20 million would be due when oil production started and when the project produced 200,000 barrels a day.

title: Stocks Down in Tokyo
description: Shares traded lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 135.35 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent, at 21,464.73. On Tuesday, the Nikkei rose 39.69 points.

title: Labor Won't Try to Undo Thatcherism, Chief Says
description: The leader of the opposition Labor Party said today that once in power his party would not try to roll back changes wrought by Prime Ministers Margaret Thatcher and John Major in many British institutions, from state-run industries now privatized to once-powerful unions now curbed.

title: Big TV Venture In Luxembourg
description: Bertelsmann A.G. and Audiofina said today that they were forming a 50-50 venture to control the Luxembourg-based television company CLT, creating Europe's biggest broadcast group.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HIBERNIA AGREES TO BUY SECOND BANK COMPANY
description: The Hibernia Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the CM Bank Holding Company for $201.7 million in cash, allowing it to expand into southwestern Louisiana. CM, based in Lake Charles, La., operates in a market that Hibernia, which is based in New Orleans, abandoned in 1992. Hibernia, with $7.20 billion in assets at the end of 1995, is the second-biggest Louisiana-based bank, behind the First Commerce Corporation. Hibernia said it would have 187 branches after buying CM, with 17 percent of the state's deposits. On Monday, Hibernia said it would pay $46 million to buy the St. Bernard Bank and Trust Company in the eastern suburbs of New Orleans. The closely held CM has about $774 million in assets.

title: The Egg: Once Spurned, Now Reclaimed
description: FOR the egg, this is the month, the big break. Sales are rising, science is bowing and religion is waiting.

title: TV NOTES;A Curmudgeon's Fans
description: Hell hath no fury like a curmudgeon scorned, especially if the curmudgeon has access to 22.5 million people. That was about the size of the audience for "60 Minutes" on Sunday night, when Andy Rooney, the program's humorist, asked viewers who appreciate his work to telephone The Associated Press and say so. To expedite matters, Mr. Rooney put the A.P.'s phone number on the screen.

title: BOXING;Another Comeback: This Time It's Douglas
description: Buster Douglas, the only man to beat Mike Tyson, is alive and well, wealthy and slimmed down and preparing to return to the ring 18 months after he nearly died.

title: BASKETBALL;Calipari Is Off St. John's List
description: It looks as though the athletic director of St. John's, Ed Manetta, can cross John Calipari's name off his wish list.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Ciba-Geigy Selling Its Scales Division
description: Ciba-Geigy A.G., based in Basel, Switzerland, said yesterday that it would sell its scales division, Mettler Toledo, to the New York investment firm AEA Investors for 919 million Swiss francs (about $766 million). Ciba decided last year to divest itself of Mettler, which had 1995 sales of one billion francs.

title: In Israel, Two Votes on Peace
description: Israel's Prime Minister, Shimon Peres, has promised to submit any final peace agreement with the Palestinians to a referendum. This was a deft, even necessary move. Public nervousness over the still-to-be-negotiated details of such an agreement threatened to drain support from Mr. Peres's Labor Party in next month's tightly fought Israeli elections.

title: The Art and Science of Easter Dyeing
description: IN answer to a question very few people have thought to ask, the most popular Easter egg color appears to be blue.

title: Hindus Offer Home for Cows
description: A Hindu group in India offered today to shelter British cows threatened with slaughter because of mad cow disease, but denied it planned to ship 12 million of them to sanctuary in India.

title: New Religious Use of Technology: A 'Cyber Seder'
description: To get its messages to the world, organized religion has long sought out new technologies. The first book off Johann Gutenburg's printing press, after all, was a Bible. And soon after broadcasts began at the nation's first radio station in Pittsburgh in 1920, an Episcopal Church started broadcasting its Sunday services.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;An Elegant Chopin in a Modest Place
description: I would like to think that Garrick Ohlsson's choice of Alice Tully Hall for his two-year Chopin series just ended was an artistic, not a business, decision. The combination of a name pianist and a beloved repertory would speak to many in the music business of big spaces and many more seats to sell. This modest 1,100-seat auditorium aligns more precisely with Mr. Ohlsson's elegant sense of proportion: the balance between intimacy and declamation that so marks his playing.

title: Main Charge Against Salomon Analyst Is Dismissed
description: A Federal judge in New York dismissed charges of illegal insider trading yesterday that had been filed against a Salomon Brothers analyst and his father by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Louis B. Flexner, 94, Researcher Into the Biochemistry of Memory
description: Dr. Louis B. Flexner, the founding director of the Institute of Neurological Sciences at the University of Pennsylvania who investigated the biochemistry of memory and the learning process, died on Friday at the university hospital. A resident of Philadelphia, he was 94.

title: When Big Is Good
description: The proposed $8.8 billion megamerger between Aetna and U.S. Healthcare would create a health plan of forbidding size, with over 20 million members in 50 states, including 650,000 members in New York City alone. But in health care, size is probably necessary to create the extended networks and information systems that improve quality. A merged Aetna-U.S. Healthcare would carry the financial strength that is needed in New York to give the likes of Oxford and HIP a run for their customers.

title: Clinton Defends His Criticism of a New York Judge's Ruling
description: President Clinton today vigorously asserted his right to criticize the ruling of a Federal judge, saying the independence of the judiciary did not mean that a judge "should be entitled not only to lifetime tenure but a gag rule on everyone else."

title: Lawsuit Seeks To Bar U.S. From Access To AIDS Files
description: Federal auditors and Boston social services agencies helping people with AIDS are battling over whether it is a grave breach of confidentiality -- or a basic part of auditing Federal programs -- for Federal officials to demand access to records with the names and Social Security numbers of people with AIDS.

title: FILENET STOCK FALLS ON QUARTERLY LOSS FORECAST
description: Shares of the Filenet Corporation fell 21 percent yesterday after the company said late Monday that it would report a loss for its first quarter of about $12 million, or 72 cents a share, because of one-time expenses. The company, a maker of document-imaging software based in Costa Mesa, Calif., also said its quarterly income before the charges -- for merger and reorganization costs and a write-off from the acquisition of International Financial Systems Ltd. in January -- would fall short of Wall Street estimates. Filenet stock fell $12.125, to $45.75 a share, in trading on the Nasdaq.

title: Yet Again, Wall Street Is Charmed by the Internet
description: Once again, the allure of the Internet has proved tempting to Wall Street, as investors looked beyond the immediate financial realities and poured money into another initial public offering.

title: A Top Executive at Lehman Quits One Post
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. said yesterday that its president, T. Christopher Pettit, was stepping down as chief operating officer in a management shake-up.

title: Journal;Hitler's Spin Artist
description: Two Passovers ago American Jews were kvelling over the newly Oscar-anointed Steven Spielberg, whose "Schindler's List" promised to make memory of the Holocaust eternal. This Passover the Spielberg mantle has passed to Daniel Jonah Goldhagen, a Harvard scholar whose just-published book "Hitler's Willing Executioners" brings corrosive literary passion to the proposition that ordinary Germans, not merely Hitler and the SS, willfully, even enthusiastically participated in the slaughter of the Jews.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Sports of The Times;Pitino Ball Leaps Front And Center
description: The telephone was ringing in Andrew (Fuzzy) Levane's Long Island home all morning yesterday, callers asking the obvious: Did you see it? Does it feel good?

title: OPERA REVIEW;Deborah Voigt Steps In as Leonora in 'Forza'
description: Since 1991, when Deborah Voigt made her Metropolitan Opera debut, her performances as Ariadne and Chrysothemis have suggested that she could become the Strauss soprano we've all been waiting for. Her portrayals of some heavier Verdi roles, though less solidly successful, were also encouraging.

title: The Slimy Business Of Roadside Rescues
description: David Fermoile spends the spring's stormier nights along roadways saving a dwindling resource: the amphibians and reptiles of Westchester County. With their numbers declining, Mr. Fermoile posts himself at roadsides before passing cars can run the creatures down.

title: Crown Hts. Youth Acquitted in Attack on Officer
description: Lemrick Nelson Jr., the man facing civil rights charges in the fatal attack on a Hasidic scholar during the Crown Heights racial violence in 1991, was acquitted yesterday on charges that he assaulted a police officer last June, charges that his lawyer had argued were the result of police harassment.

title: World News Briefs;Taiwan Postpones War Games Off China
description: Under pressure from Washington and domestic critics, Taiwan said today that it would postpone for at least three months a live-fire military exercise on Matsu Island, the heavily fortified Taiwanese base that lies less than two miles off mainland China.

title: Theater in Review
description: A Daughter Abandoned, A Prince Unawares 'Life Is a Dream' Pearl Theater

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Adventures of Scooter: Swing and Segregation
description: THE SEVEN LEAGUE BOOTS By Albert Murray 369 pages. Pantheon. $25.

title: Pharmacopeia Pact
description: The Daiichi Pharmaceutical Company will invest $22 million in Pharmacopeia Inc. as part of a drug research agreement, Pharmacopeia said this week. Pharmacopeia, based in Princeton, said that the two companies would collaborate to discover new drugs derived from several undisclosed molecular compounds. Pharmacopeia will also receive license fees and periodic payments as drugs are developed, as well as royalties from sales if any of the drugs are brought to market.

title: City May Cut Its Oversight Of Contractors
description: The New York City Department of Buildings wants to eliminate a requirement that inspectors take a direct role in approving construction projects. The department has proposed instead that the work be done by private engineers.

title: 2 STEELMAKERS PLAN TO RAISE SOME PRICES
description: The USX - U.S. Steel Group and the AK Steel Holding Corporation said yesterday that they would raise sheet-steel prices by 3 percent to 5 percent on July 1, their second increase this year. Other companies are expected to match the move, because orders have remained high since steelmakers raised prices an average of 3 percent in February, the first increases in 13 months. USX-U.S. Steel, the nation's largest steel producer, announced price increases of $15 a ton on hot-rolled sheet steel, $25 a ton on cold-rolled sheet and $35 a ton on coated sheet. AK Steel, of Middletown, Ohio, quickly matched Pittsburgh-based USX-U.S. Steel's spot-market increases.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about trimming the United Nations' 1996-97 budget misstated the method proposed for reducing the staff. The plan is for buyouts, not layoffs; a new system of performance evaluations could lead to dismissals later.

title: ITT, Hilton Are Each Said To Woo Bally
description: The ITT Sheraton Corporation and the Hilton Hotels Corporation are each involved in discussions with the Bally Entertainment Corporation about a possible merger, according to people close to the negotiations.

title: Second Agency Is Added by Amtrak
description: Amtrak has added Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York to its roster by dividing its account, with billings estimated at $40 million, between that agency and DDB Needham New York, the lead Amtrak shop for the last 23 years.

title: Republicans Are Up in Arms At Labor's Political Rebirth
description: Stunned by organized labor's intention to spend more than ever in this year's national elections, Republican campaign committees and business lobbies are crying foul and turning up the heat to blunt labor's impact.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Murdered Archbishop, Lawyers In Armani
description: Back from "First Knight" and the Dark Ages, Richard Gere has a tailor-made role in "Primal Fear," which casts him as a slick Chicago lawyer. Mr. Gere does a solid job of turning Martin Vail, a dashing, self-satisfied legal hotshot, into a character audiences will love to hate. "When your mother says she loves you, ask for a second opinion," Martin tells a reporter who interviews him, smiling seductively as he dresses for a black-tie evening. "This is a cover story, right?"

title: BASEBALL;Stress Was Apparently Factor In On-Field Death of Umpire
description: Severe heart disease killed John McSherry, an autopsy found yesterday, but the National League umpire added to his physical problems with the stressful way in which he approached his job.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Rossini's 'Cenerentola,' With Bartoli
description: Disney it's not. The Cinderella in Rossini's "Cenerentola" has neither a fairy godmother nor a magical pumpkin carriage. In fact, tonight's "Great Performances" presentation of the opera buffa includes dark elements of child abuse and embezzlement. But no matter. Cinderella gets her prince and, equally important, she gets an opportunity to be sung by Cecilia Bartoli, currently the mezzo-soprano darling of the promotional mills in the music business.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Car Phones Tied to Accidents
description: Are cellular phones and cars a dangerous combination? A study by the Rochester Institute of Technology found that the accident rate for drivers with car phones was 34 percent higher than the rate for drivers without phones.

title: U.N. Peacekeeping Is a Quiet Success
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A Chance to Sing at the Met For Nine Young Hopefuls
description: The Metropolitan Opera's National Council Winners Concert is an annual parade of the hopeful and audacious. For the young singers who have passed the company's regional auditions, it cannot be easy to stand on the Met's huge stage, singing into a cavernous space that swallows the sound of more experienced singers, and not knowing whether the audience is more inclined to be demanding or forgiving.

title: Landfill Will Not Be a Tourist Attraction
description: In the "One More Reason to Plan Your New York Vacation Carefully" Department, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday he had disposed of a Department of Sanitation proposal to offer regular tours of the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island, the world's largest garbage dump.

title: No Headline
description: I'm not going to stand up here and say that there was no force used, because you would laugh me out of the room."

title: THEATER REVIEW;Daddy's Miss Subways
description: No show-business father could ask for a better memorial than the one-woman tribute Marga Gomez calls "A Line Around the Block." Affectionate, understanding, tinged with pain and regret but best of all nostalgic and funny, this show is at once a vivid portrait of a lovable but flawed man, a psychic journey into the ineradicable joys and bleak disillusionments of a father-daughter relationship and a striking re-creation of a bygone era of Hispanic variety shows in New York City.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Baby Sitter Charged in Death
description: A 16-year-old Hillside High School senior has been charged with fatally beating a Newark toddler he was baby-sitting for after the child urinated on the floor, prosecutors said yesterday. The 6-foot-3-inch youth is charged with aggravated manslaughter in the death on Saturday of the boy, who would have been 3 today, said Michael J. Lapolla, the first assistant prosecutor for Union County. The teen-ager was arrested after an autopsy determined that the child had suffered a lacerated liver, head trauma and facial bruises, Mr. Lapolla said. He was being held at the county's youth lockup while authorities decided whether to charge him as an adult.

title: Falconbridge Raises Bid for Diamond Fields
description: Falconbridge Ltd. sweetened its offer for Diamond Fields Resources Inc. today in an attempt to avert a bidding war with Inco Ltd. for a huge metals deposit in Newfoundland.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHEVRON AND TEXACO TO REPORT GAINS FROM SALE
description: The Chevron Corporation and Texaco Inc. said yesterday that they would report second-quarter gains from the sale of their Caltex Petroleum Corporation venture's stake in a Japanese refining company. Each received $550 million after Caltex sold its 50 percent interest in the Nippon Petroleum Refining Company to the Nippon Oil Company for $2 billion. Chevron and Texaco jointly own Caltex, a refining and marketing company. Chevron, based in San Francisco, said it would report a second-quarter after-tax gain of $325 million, or an estimated 49 cents a share. Texaco, based in White Plains, expects to post a gain of $275 million after taxes, or about $1.05 a share, based on its 260.3 million shares outstanding.

title: Europe Agrees to Help Pay For Destroying British Cattle
description: After 40 hours of intense negotiation in Luxembourg on the crisis over mad cow disease, Britain agreed early today to destroy millions of head of older cattle during the next five years in return for partial European Union compensation for farmers whose cattle will be incinerated in an effort to eliminate human exposure to the fatal ailment.

title: Great Meatloaf? And the Winner Is . . .
description: IT started innocently enough. Nancy Maher of Southampton, L.I., just happened to mention to her new son-in-law, John Normile, that she made a great meatloaf.

title: At Stanford, a Class-Lab Friendly to Computers
description: All the glowing talk of putting computers in classrooms usually misses a crucial point: most teachers hate working in high-tech laboratories.

title: Wine Talk
description: PEOPLE in the restaurant business come and go at an astonishing rate. It's not uncommon to read about a successful 30-year-old chef who has worked in 10 restaurants. Which makes Joe DeLissio, the wine director at the River Cafe in Brooklyn for 17 years, something of an anomaly.

title: About New York;Small Markets Shopping For Same Deal
description: LUIS SALCEDO waited tables for 11 years, saving tips and paychecks until he could buy a modest coffee shop in Brooklyn. A few years later, he bought a grocery store in the Bronx. Then he put together $1 million through savings and high-interest loans, renovated a dilapidated Harlem storefront and opened up a supermarket with the grand name of Bravo.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Granada Group Forming Unit for Media Ventures
description: Granada Group P.L.C., a British leisure company, announced yesterday that it was forming Granada Media Group, a new unit intended to further the company's television and media interests. Granada named its chief executive, Charles Allen, as chairman of the new group. Duncan Lewis, formerly chief executive of Mercury Communications, was named chief executive. With the new unit, the company intends to be the first British broadcaster to offer a national pay-television channel, beginning this autumn. (Dow Jones)

title: Welcoming Spring With a Warm Salad
description: Maybe it's rushing the season to serve a warm salad for dinner, but after this miserable winter, what could be better?

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BLISS & LAUGHLIN INDUSTRIES, Harvey, Ill., a manufacturer of cold-finish steel bars for the electrical, industrial and automotive industries, completed its merger with a subsidiary of Bar Technologies Inc. Stockholders will receive $9.50 in cash for each outstanding common share of Bliss & Laughlin.

title: ECONOMY SHOWING SIGNS OF REBOUND FROM SLOW WINTER
description: Battered recently by storms and undermined for months by weak sales, the economy has been sluggish for most of the last year. But figures released today gave some tentative signs that business could improve this spring -- and that corporations' strong profits have been relatively unaffected by 1995's weakness.

title: Journalism's Masters
description: To the Editor:

title: More New Bills Could Turn Profit for Treasury
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Baer's Reversal
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Judges Weigh Future Of Giant Cigarette Lawsuit
description: In a tense, high-stakes battle in a Federal appeals court here, lawyers squared off today at a hearing on whether a giant class-action lawsuit against the nation's cigarette makers can continue.

title: Our Towns;In Hoboken, Dreams of Eclipsing the Cooperstown Baseball Legend
description: If Stephen E. Speiser's fondest wish comes true, this baseball season will be different from all other baseball seasons.

title: New Otis Factory in China
description: The Otis Elevator Company said yesterday that it had opened a $30 million factory in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou. The plant, Otis's fourth in China, is expected to produce 3,000 elevators and 500 escalators annually. It will create about 500 jobs, said the company, the elevator-manufacturing unit of the United Technologies Corporation.

title: When a Husband Is a Guest At His Own Dinner Party
