description: I HAVE always admired those masterly men who know how to be the host of a dinner party. They stock the bar, fix the drinks, pass the hors d'oeuvres, advise their wives on the entree, perhaps even drift into the kitchen to casually assemble a trademark salad or to flambe a dessert.

title: Saving Salamanders Is a Roadside Mission
description: A car pulled alongside a white van that was stopped in the middle of a curving dark road in a drenching downpour. "Need any help?" asked the good Samaritan in the car.

title: Reviews/Fashion;Beene Makes It Look Simple
description: Sometimes a designer has to step back a few paces to strip away the pretensions of theatrically staged shows or arty exhibitions and just show the clothes. Show them on live models, not dancers or mannequins, in a way that demonstrates how the clothes fit the body and move in real life -- easily and naturally.

title: Reluctantly, A Theater Troupe Moves Out
description: To outsiders, it might seem like a typical conflict between landlord and tenant, but from the point of view of Woodie King Jr., the New Federal Theater is a victim of its own success.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Marbury to Reveal His Plans Tonight
description: The Georgia Tech freshman point guard STEPHON MARBURY will end the speculation and announce his plans tonight at a restaurant near his home in Brooklyn.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Beuerlein's a Panther
description: STEVE BEUERLEIN, who lost his starting job with the Jacksonville Jaguars, agreed yesterday to a contract with the Carolina Panthers, the National Football League's other expansion team in 1995.

title: Foreign Affairs;House G.O.P. Madness
description: You would think that in the wake of the Oklahoma City and World Trade Center bombings, passing a bill strengthening the F.B.I.'s ability to fight terrorism would be a slam-dunk. But so far the only thing getting dunked is the bill itself. This is a shameful tale -- one that suggests that the soul of the Republican Party, at least in the House of Representatives, has been taken over by lawmakers who despise their own government much more than they fear any foreign terrorists.

title: World News Briefs;U.S. Pressing Libya On Chemical Arms
description: The United States has stepped up its pressure on Libya to halt work on what is believed to be the world's largest underground chemical weapons plant, with Defense Secretary William J. Perry warning today that Libya's chemical weapons program had become "a matter of profound concern to us."

title: HOCKEY;Woeful Isles Are Outnumbered Even When They Aren't
description: At least in football, you have the option of declining a penalty.

title: Reviews/Fashion;Calvin Klein Does the 70's, and Rules
description: The hippest American label in Italy right now is Calvin Klein, said a fashion authority with more than a little insider knowledge, Gianni Versace. Mr. Klein's jeans have become a uniform for the cool, young Milanese; his days of being seen in Italy as creatively in the shadow of Giorgio Armani are over, Mr. Versace said.

title: In Britain, Facing Demands of Beefeaters
description: PETER AND HENRIETTA GREIG -- the owners of Pipers Farm, an organic beef farm in Devon, England, often cited as the producer of the country's finest beef -- are trying to meet the demand for their untainted grass-grazing cattle.

title: Chicken Done to a Golden Rule;Fast-Food Chain Treats Its Employees as Family
description: There is no swagger in S. Truett Cathy, though many people might forgive him if there were. With a hardscrabble childhood and no more than a high school education, he turned a tiny diner with the unlikely name of Dwarf Grill into the nation's third-largest fast-food chicken chain with the even more unlikely name of Chick-fil-A.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Two quick exits from the top at Ayer may be signaling more changes ahead for the agency.
description: THE sudden departure of two of the top three executives at N. W. Ayer & Partners in New York is a likely prelude to further significant changes at the venerable but troubled agency.

title: TV NOTES;Program Notes
description: Bill Moyers will make his first significant appearance on NBC in almost a year (illness forced him to take time off), when he serves as anchor for a Friday-night edition of "Dateline" on April 12. The topic is the survivors of the Oklahoma City bombing a year ago and the families of the 168 people killed. . . . From Presidential candidate to host of "Saturday Night Live" in one whirlwind month: that's Steve Forbes. He quit the Republican campaign trail on March 14; on April 13, he will be the host of the NBC late-night comedy show. The musical performers that night are "Rage Against the Machine." Apparently no connection to Mr. Forbes was intended. L. M.

title: Walesa Back at Shipyard to Work, or Get a Pension
description: Chauffeured in a black Mercedes and wearing a suit, former President Lech Walesa turned up at the shipyard here today, ostensibly to reclaim his old job as an electrician.

title: Food Notes
description: Free-Roaming Chickens in Town

title: Market Place;A big pension fund joins suits to recover payouts by W. R. Grace.
description: IN an unusual move, the California public employee pension fund, known as Calpers, has asked court permission to join in shareholder lawsuits pending in New York State Supreme Court against officers and directors of W. R. Grace & Company. The giant fund's goal, it says, is to recover for Grace some of the millions that were paid to two former top executives who left the company under a cloud.

title: An African Forest Harbors Vast Wealth and Peril
description: The forest grows so thick at the edge of this tiny settlement that even the N'tem River, a sizable Central African waterway, is completely obscured in the riotous greenery. Asked what lies beyond, a Fang villager shrugs and says "nothing."

title: FILM REVIEW;A Lothario and His Homicidal Nemesis
description: The biggest mystery about Martin Lawrence's new film, "A Thin Line Between Love and Hate," is its protagonist's unaccountable appeal to women. About the only thing Mr. Lawrence's character, Darnell Wright, has going for him is sheer nerve. A typical romantic ploy of this socially inept, unhandsome Lothario who works in a Los Angeles nightclub is to sidle up to a pretty woman and slather on banalities like, "Baby, baby, you're so fine."

title: In Syracuse, 'Final Two' Felt Like Championship It Wasn't
description: The banners and balloons may have come down, but the people of this cold city were far from glum today. No matter that Kentucky had won the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship. This city couldn't lose.

title: Dominican President Isn't Worst Caudillo
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs;Public Workers Riot In Bolivian Capital
description: Protests called last month against a Government plan to sell the Government-owned oil company intensified to near riot proportions today, as striking public workers in La Paz shut down public transportation, threw dynamite sticks at police, and looted stores and the offices of the recently privatized state railroad.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Leading Indicators Jump, Pointing to Growth in Spring The index of leading indicators soared in February, suggesting that business could improve this spring after months of sluggish growth. The leading indicators rose 1.3 percent, in their biggest jump in 20 years, the Government said. Inventories appear low enough to encourage companies to lift production soon, and corporate profits have remained relatively firm. [Page A1.]

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Rise On Treasury Securities
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, bolstered by reports that suggested the economy was not growing at a fast enough pace to accelerate inflation.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Daily Briefing column in New Jersey copies on Thursday about a deal by New Jersey Network to lease its excess microwave transmission capacity to Atlantic Microsystems Inc. referred imprecisely to the revenue the arrangement could bring to the network. The deal is expected to produce $3.6 million in revenue over 10 years, not immediately.

title: CS First Boston Registers Record Earnings
description: CS First Boston earned a record $108 million in the first quarter amid rising markets, booming stock and bond sales and a heavy pace of corporate mergers, according to an internal memo sent to employees yesterday.

title: Talk of Bid For Thorn EMI
description: The shares of Thorn EMI P.L.C. soared yesterday on speculation that the Sony Corporation was planning to bid as much as L23 ($35.20) a share for the company, a British music and consumer rentals concern.

title: More New Bills Could Turn Profit for Treasury;Guides for the Blind
description: To the Editor:

title: Portland Journal;Can This Underdog Win The Animal Rights Vote?
description: John Callahan spends his working days making fun of the blind, the old, the overweight, the overly sensitive and the humor-impaired. He is a syndicated cartoonist with a severed spine and is a recovering alcoholic.

title: Football and Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: TV NOTES;Served by Technology
description: For three consecutive Thursdays, PBS will broadcast the second season of "People in Motion," the series produced by WNET/Channel 13 about the ways people with disabilities are using ingenious new technologies, and their own moxie, to overcome obstacles. The new series begins a little differently from last year's, by featuring two relatively famous people.

title: Personal Health
description: YORKTOWN HIGH SCHOOL in Westchester County, N.Y., was having a problem with bullies. Parents told school authorities that older students were extorting lunch money from younger ones, blocking them from getting off the school bus at their stops and threatening them in the school bathrooms. The place where children were supposed to feel safe was increasingly marred by taunting, shoving and out-and-out fighting.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Vote on Needle Exchanges
description: The 35-member Governor's Advisory Council on AIDS will meet today to vote on whether to recommend legislation allowing needle exchanges as a way of curtailing the spread of the AIDS virus. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman opposes permitting drug addicts to exchange used hypodermic needles for clean ones. Most council members indicated at a meeting last month that they favored the exchanges.

title: Drug Case Reversal
description: In January, when Judge Harold Baer Jr. threw out seized drugs as evidence against a confessed drug courier, he said he believed the suspect far more than the police officers who arrested her.

title: ON BASEBALL;New York Shortstops Inspire Sweepstakes
description: After watching Rey Ordonez break into 1996 in a most spectacular way, the great shortstop Ozzie Smith declared that the young Mets emigre from Cuba is the second coming of himself.

title: For Doctors, An Anxiety Is Removed
description: When Howard Grossman was a medical student and a young doctor, nobody ever talked openly about how when they were asked, doctors sometimes helped their terminally ill patients to die.

title: Ross David Siragusa, 89; Founded a Major Maker of Appliances
description: Ross David Siragusa, who founded the Admiral Corporation and led its growth from a small radio manufacturer to one of the country's leading makers of televisions, audio products, refrigerators and other home appliances, died on Saturday at his home in Chicago. He was 89.

title: BASKETBALL;Pitino Has Won it All; Now About Next Year
description: The spin doctor was telling a story on himself. Rick Pitino can do that now that the grass is bluer in Kentucky, now that the painstaking restoration of a championship tradition has been completed. Ultimately, the demands throughout the Commonwealth will not change. Each year, around this time, there are two conclusions to a Kentucky season. There is the satisfaction of a championship, and there is what-went-wrong explanation.

title: INSIDE
description: Another Beating on Tape

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Budget Doubled For Milk Campaign
description: The nation's fluid milk processors voted yesterday to continue what is known as the Fluid Milk Processor Education Program, and to double the budget for a campaign that featurescelebrities sporting milk mustaches.

title: Excerpts From the Ruling on Doctor-Assisted Suicide
description: Following are excerpts from yesterday's decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, written by Justice Roger J. Miner, striking down parts of New York State's law against assisted suicide.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Women's Cup

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Ben Kingsley;The Key to 'Moses' Was 'Schindler's List'
description: WHAT would Gandhi eat? This is perhaps not the right question to ask Ben Kingsley, who won an Academy Award for his portrayal of the ascetic Indian liberator in the 1982 movie "Gandhi." Soon after the film came out, Mr. Kingsley was in an airplane when a flight attendant approached, as excited as if she had spotted Queen Elizabeth in Bloomingdale's underwear department.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Irvin a Candidate for Drug Program
description: MICHAEL IRVIN, the Dallas Cowboy receiver who was indicted Monday on a drug charge, was nearing entrance into the first stage of the National Football League's substance-abuse program, according to a report Tuesday in The Fort Worth Star-Telegram. The report said that in considering whether a player's behavior indicated a drug problem, the league's drug-policy guidelines call for "evaluation and treatment" of the player, and that he can be entered even if a player has not tested positive for drugs. "The first step is evaluation made by independent medical experts, and you can assume, given the circumstances, that will happen here," said GENE UPSHAW, executive director of the N.F.L. Players Association. (AP)

title: A New Proposal to Simplify the Rating of TV Shows
description: In an update on the television industry's effort to develop a ratings system to alert parents to on-screen sex and violence, Jack Valenti said yesterday that television series might be rated categorically for an entire season, with individual episodes singled out for a different rating only if they exceeded certain bounds.

title: Sketches of Some Believed to Be on the Plane: Business Leaders FromAcross the U.S.; Carol Hamilton, Brown's Press Secretary
description: Carol Hamilton is the Secretary's director of public affairs and press secretary. Ms. Hamilton worked for David N. Dinkins before he was the Mayor of New York and the Rev. Jesse Jackson when he ran for President in 1988.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Securities Prices Slump
description: Treasury prices slumped in light trading yesterday after Government data on consumer spending and manufacturers orders pointed to an economic pickup.

title: Tiger's Violent Death Has Texas Town Debating Crime and Punishment
description: Tiger liked to hang out at Koym Field, home of the East Bernard High Brahmas, the back-to-back Class 2A Texas baseball champions. She made friends with the fans, watched the games and cadged some food every now and then.

title: Ford Contracts to ITT
description: ITT Industries' ITT Automotive subsidiary said today that the Ford Motor Company had awarded it two contracts totaling $650 million to produce brakes and other parts for a future vehicle. One contract calls for ITT to provide a completely assembled brake system package, including anti-lock brakes, front calipers, actuation, rear drum brakes and hoses. The second contract includes all brake, fuel and vapor lines as well as the fuel filler pipe for the new vehicle. The $650 million covers the life of the contracts, the company said in a statement.

title: Pataki Announces $445 Million Surplus at End of Fiscal Year
description: New York State finished its fiscal year with a $445 million surplus, largely the result of lower-than-expected spending on social programs and a booming year on Wall Street, Gov. George E. Pataki said today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Lobbying Pays Off in a Raise
description: Lobbyists in New Jersey are spending more, but not for the wining and dining of legislators, the state's Election Law Enforcement Commission said yesterday. Last year, lobbyists reported spending $76,083 on government officials and their staffs, or one-half of 1 percent of their total spending. In 1993 and 1994, they spent 1 percent, the commission said. Frederick M. Herrmann, the commission's executive director, could not explain the decline.

title: Bridge
description: When a close knockout match is over and scores are compared, there is usually a victory shriek from one team and a gloomy silence from the other. When play ended Sunday in a Grand National Team quarterfinal at the Town Club, 6 East 86th Street, there were two gloomy silences. Both teams thought they had lost by one imp, and both were wrong.

title: W.H.O. Seeks Barriers Against Cow Disease
description: Reacting to the epidemic of mad cow disease in Britain, the World Health Organization yesterday recommended a worldwide ban on feeding sheep, goat, cattle and other animal tissues to livestock. The aim is to prevent the infectious agent that causes mad cow disease from expanding further in the animal or human food chain.

title: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: THE EXECUTIVES;A Dozen Companies Await Word
description: Executives at about a dozen companies across the country were missing and presumed dead yesterday after the crash of an airplane that had been carrying a trade mission led by Ronald H. Brown, the United States Commerce Secretary.

title: Sketches of Some Believed to Be on the Plane: Business Leaders FromAcross the U.S.; P. Stuart Tholan, Bechtel Executive, 59
description: P. Stuart Tholan, 59, is a senior vice president of the Bechtel Corporation based in London and is president of the Bechtel unit overseeing Europe, Africa, the Middle East and Southwest Asia.

title: Reviews/Fashion;The Play's the Thing. So Are the Clothes.
description: DESIGNERS, strange hybrids of artists and business people, tend more than most professionals to engage in a constant dialogue with both street life and cultural life. They hope to be inspired or to strike a chord with customers, a necessary precursor to selling clothes.

title: Police to Start Big Offensive Against Drugs
description: Defying the conventional wisdom that drug dealing is an ineradicable plague, the New York City Police Department next week will put up to 3,000 officers and weapons ranging from new computer software to hydraulic battering rams into its biggest assault ever on neighborhood pushers.

title: POP REVIEW;A Phish, 70's Funk And a Band Built to Jam
description: What an odd sight: the Academy Theater full of 20-year-olds listening to a nostalgic mixture of free improvisation, noise and early 70's jazz funk. But that was the scene on Monday night, where the guitarist from the group Phish, Trey Anastasio, had convened a band that included members of the New York downtown vanguard, the Sun Ra orchestra and his own group. Phish is one of the biggest concert draws in the United States; the name has power to draw fans that might not go to hear the original music on its own.

title: Lazard Freres And Its Sisters To Pool Profits For Closer Ties
description: Lazard Freres & Company, the New York investment bank, and its sister firms in Paris and London said yesterday that they would create a new system for sharing profits among their partners and managing directors aimed at promoting greater cooperation among the three firms.

title: ON THE UNABOMBER TRACK: THE OVERVIEW;Ex-Professor Is Seized In Montana as Suspect In the Unabom Attacks
description: Federal agents today raided a remote Montana cabin where they seized a onetime university professor suspected of being the Unabomber, the elusive terrorist who has left a 17-year nationwide trail of mail bombs that have killed 3 people and maimed 23 others.

title: Sketches of Some Believed to Be on the Plane: Business Leaders FromAcross the U.S.; Paul Cushman 3d, Banking Executive, 35
description: Paul Cushman 3d is an executive vice president at Riggs National Bank in Washington and head of its international banking operations. He is 35.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Herald Tribune Appoints Editor
description: Michael Getler, the deputy managing editor of The Washington Post, will become the executive editor of The International Herald Tribune in July, the Paris-based newspaper announced yesterday.

title: Economic Scene;Thinking the unthinkable: Raise the Federal minimum wage.
description: THE ritual pre-election debate over the Federal minimum wage has begun, with Democrats reminding blue-collar workers where their bread is buttered and Republicans countering with tears over the tragedy of pricing inner-city youths out of the job market.

title: Metro Matters;Slowly Moving Down a Road To a Roadway
description: THAT flamboyant display of euphoria the other day, when politicians finally broke ground for a renovated roadway on the western edge of Manhattan, is understandable. New York is a place that is letting one of its most valuable sites (Columbus Circle) go to ruin, that cannot keep its schools or subway stations from crumbling, and that gets hauled into court on almost every move it makes.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Profits Rise 11% At Dutch Monopoly
description: The Dutch postal and telecommunications monopoly Koninklijke PTT Nederland N.V. said yesterday that its profit rose 11 percent last year. Profit totaled 2.26 billion guilders ($1.37 billion), up from 2.04 billion guilders in 1994. Revenue rose 7 percent, to 19.86 billion guilders ($12.03 billion). (AP)

title: Call It Auntie Mame Chinoiserie
description: WHEN Patrick Dennis arrived at his Auntie Mame's, he walked through a door emblazoned with a fire-breathing dragon into incense-scented rooms decorated in a lurid style best described as Chop Suey Moderne.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Criticizing School Financing
description: A majority of New Jersey voters agree with Governor Whitman and the State Supreme Court that financing disparities for rich and poor school districts should be eliminated, according to a poll released yesterday. The poll, conducted independently by the Quinnipiac College Polling Institute, also found that 78 percent of the 908 registered voters questioned believed the state, not local school districts, should set education standards.

title: Arson Halts Amtrak Train
description: Fire destroyed a 154-foot wooden railroad trestle on Sunday afternoon as an Amtrak train with 145 passengers was approaching, and the authorities said on Monday that two boys had confessed to setting the fire accidentally.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Commerce Secretary Lost In Croatian Plane Crash A military plane carrying Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and a delegation of American corporate leaders slammed into a mountainside as it approached the airport at Dubrovnik, on the Adriatic coast of Croatia. Chances that Mr. Brown, a 54-year-old political insider, had survived were "next to zero," a White House official said.

title: Petro-Canada Said to Be Paying $538 Million for Unit of Rival
description: Petro-Canada said today that it would buy Amerada Hess Canada Ltd. from the Amerada Hess Corporation for $731 million (Canadian), or $538 million (United States).

title: Snow Thrower Receives Fine
description: Jeffrey Lange of Readington, N.J., the man photographed taking part in a snowball melee during a Giants game against San Diego at Giants Stadium last Dec. 23, was convicted of improper behavior today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Wright Leaves Psychiatric Hospital
description: The former Seton Hall and Utah Jazz basketball player LUTHER WRIGHT has returned home after being institutionalized for a month as a psychiatric patient. Wright was released Tuesday from the Essex County Hospital Center in Cedar Grove, N.J., where he was being treated for manic depression.

title: CUNY's Battle Should Be Against Budget Cuts
description: To the Editor:

title: Incomes and Spending Advanced in February
description: Americans' incomes rose in February as milder weather let workers put in more hours on the job -- and encouraged them to spend more freely on automobiles and other big-ticket items.

title: Currents;For Olympians Welcoming Tents
description: WHEN AT&T won the right to develop a Global Olympic Village for the athletes at the Olympic Games in Atlanta this summer, it chose to build a 30,000-square-foot tent village. Three soaring white pavilions will be connected by a covered bridge. One arched pavilion is for the athletes and their families (far right in artist's sketch above) and will hold video games, televisions, live entertainment, food, drink and, in general, the possibility of merriment in 197 languages. A circular pavilion (not shown) will be for the public, and will showcase AT&T's Internet service and have several hundred pay telephones. A second arched pavilion (at left above), will be for the news media, with rooms for interviewing and for eating.

title: ON THE UNABOMBER'S TRACK: THE SUSPECT;A Man Known to Few, And a Mystery to Many
description: As a mathematics scholar at several prestigious universities and later as a near-hermit living more than 20 years in a hand-built shack in the wilds of the Continental Divide, Theodore John Kaczynski, the man the authorities believe is the Unabomber, showed himself to be both brilliant and elusive.

title: In Texas Town, Pact Separates Religion and High School Sports
description: A group of high school athletes and parents have won an agreement from the school board of a small town near Austin that its public high school's sports programs will no longer mix religious activities with sports. The parents had complained that prayers were posted on lockers and that religious music was being piped into the locker room.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Pluots, Apriums . . .

title: Dominican Has Acted To Insure Fair Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Penalizes Holtzman Over '92 Campaign Loan
description: Rejecting her assertions of innocence and ignorance, an investigative panel declared yesterday that Elizabeth Holtzman, the former New York City Comptroller, had violated conflict-of-interest laws in obtaining a campaign loan from a bank that coveted city business.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Poe's Baltimore Corner
description: To the Editor:

title: U.A.W. Sets Hard Stance In Bargaining
description: Faced with a renewed emphasis by Detroit's Big Three auto makers on paring costs, leaders of the United Automobile Workers union made clear at a three-day convention ended here today that they were in no mood for concessions.

title: Carl Stokes, 68, Dies; Precedent-Setting Mayor
description: Carl B. Stokes, whose election as the first black mayor of a major city in 1967 became a symbol of a changing America, died early yesterday in Cleveland. He was 68.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Southern Cal's Johnson, Potential Top Pick, Arrives to Eye Jets' Green
description: He was out of uniform, smartly dressed in a blue denim shirt and pants. Still, at almost 6 feet 4 inches and 215 pounds, Keyshawn Johnson cut an imposing figure.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Slip In Ewing's Dungeon Of Bricks
description: When it was announced last night that Shaquille O'Neal would not be playing for the Orlando Magic, a sigh of relief filled Madison Square Garden. But Knick fans expecting a victory were in for a rude awakening.

title: Marbury Leaves Ga. Tech For N.B.A.
description: Less than a year after he graduated from Lincoln High School in Brooklyn, where he became a basketball prodigy, Stephon Marbury was holding court in his hometown again last night. The 6-foot-2-inch point guard from Coney Island announced that he was giving up his final three years of eligibility at Georgia Tech and entering the National Basketball Association draft in June.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Friendship and Desert Sands in Emotional Landscapes
description: Dancemakers, a modern-dance company founded in Toronto in 1974, made a welcome New York debut on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater with two works by its artistic director, Serge Bennathan.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Improvisation has been utterly necessary for the marketers of 'State Fair.'
description: IN the out-of-town tryout, it's usually the show, and not the advertising, that gets road-tested on the way to Broadway. But during the seven-month tour of "State Fair," the marketing message evolved as much as the Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d musical that opened last week at the Music Box Theater in Manhattan.

title: Sketches of Some Believed to Be on the Plane: Business Leaders FromAcross the U.S.; Charles Meissner, Assistant Secretary of Commerce
description: Charles Meissner, Assistant Secretary of Commerce in charge of international economic policy, is one of Mr. Brown's top advisers on export trade policy.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Of Objectivity, Subjectivity and Painful Mishmash
description: DANCE FOR TWO Selected Essays By Alan Lightman 169 pages. Pantheon. Paperback, $12.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about plans by Temple Emanu-El in New York to hold a "cyberseder" on the Internet misspelled the surname of the pioneer European printer whose movable-type Bible was an early example of technology in the service of religion. He was Johann Gutenberg, not Gutenburg.

title: W. Haywood Burns, 55, Dies; Law Dean and Rights Worker
description: W. Haywood Burns, a former dean of the City University of New York School of Law at Queens College and a longtime civil rights advocate who worked with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., represented the black radical Angela Davis against charges of kidnapping and murder, and coordinated the defense for inmates indicted in the Attica prison riot, died on Tuesday in an automobile accident. He was 55 and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Reviews/Fashion;With Spirit, Lower-Priced Labels Make Their Marks
description: THE high-end designers who have traditionally presented their collections in the tents were more than a little worried at the idea that generic lower-priced labels were going to show there, too, this season.

title: How Moscow Plays the 'Ethnic Russian' Card
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Move to Stamp Out Pusher

title: Calendar: Shows, Talks And a Roadster on View
description: Vrooom! Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street; (212) 708-9400.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Daimler-Benz Reports Record Loss for 1995
description: Daimler-Benz A.G. said today that charges for Fokker N.V., its Dutch aircraft unit, and its electrical and engineering unit resulted in a 1995 loss of 5.7 billion German marks, or $3.9 billion, the biggest in German history.

title: Teen-Agers Are More Responsive to Cigarette Ads, Study Says
description: Teen-agers are three times as likely as adults to respond to cigarette advertisements, and 79 percent of teen-age smokers prefer brands depicted by the Marlboro Man, Joe Camel and the fun couples of Newport, a study published today says.

title: Mr. Brown's Mission
description: The plane crash that is feared to have claimed the lives of Commerce Secretary Ron Brown and his traveling companions occurred as Mr. Brown led a mission of faith and hope. This journey into dangerous and disputed territory reflected the highest tradition of American public service. Mr. Brown was carrying the vital message that the United States would not duck the challenge of promoting stability and prosperity in a place racked by four years of war.

title: Biblical Plagues: A Novel Theory
description: THIS is the week when the story of the Exodus from Egypt is being retold in Jewish homes all over the world. Children are typically fascinated by the gory part -- about the 10 plagues that God sent to the Egyptians to pressure them to release their Hebrew slaves.

title: Sketches of Some Believed to Be on the Plane: Business Leaders FromAcross the U.S.; Barry L. Conrad, Hotel Executive, 55
description: Barry L. Conrad is chairman and chief executive of the Barrington Group, a company he formed two years ago. He is 55 and lives in Coral Gables, Fla.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;Regimented, Adolescent, Secretly Gay
description: Even during the stifling conformism of the 1950's, American high school life was never regimented as severely as it is in contemporary Japan. The uniformed adolescent students in Ryosuke Hashiguchi's film "Like Grains of Sand" are portrayed as cold-hearted cookie-cutter products of a system that instills little tolerance for behavior that deviates from rigid bourgeois norms.

title: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: THE OVERVIEW;COMMERCE SECRETARY AMONG 33 LOST IN A CROATIA PLANE CRASH
description: Correction Appended

title: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: THE POLICY;A Role as Nation's Chief Salesman Abroad
description: Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown was in the Balkans in his self-assigned role as the nation's salesman in chief, seeking profitable opportunities for American businesses abroad and making the case that economic power should be a cornerstone of American foreign policy.

title: European Currency Vote
description: Prime Minister John Major, battling to heal serious party rifts, pledged today to fight the next election with a promise of a referendum if his Government decided to join a European single currency.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about mergers in the health care industry misstated terms of two recent acquisitions. Wellpoint Health Networks Inc. bought the group life and health division of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, while Healthsource Inc. bought the medical services business of the Provident Life and Accident Insurance Company. Neither buyer acquired an entire company.

title: Student Dies After Aiding In Research
description: A University of Rochester sophomore from New York City, who was paid $150 to take part in a medical research project on smoking and air pollution, died of a heart attack on Sunday, two days after undergoing a lung procedure related to the research.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Deutsche Telekom Bars Comment on Videotron
description: Deutsche Telekom refused yesterday to comment on a report that it was in talks to buy a majority stake in Videotron Holdings P.L.C., a British cable television operator. "The British market is very interesting for us, but we won't comment on these reports," a spokesman, Ulrich Lissek said.

title: POP REVIEW;Jackson Browne, Gleaning
description: Even comfortable people need consolation sometimes, and Jackson Browne has been there to provide it for more than two decades. In his songs from the 1970's, he grappled with fading idealism and found heroism in holding down a day job, poeticizing "the struggle for the legal tender." More recent songs reveal misgivings about the state of the world: about poverty and desperation, violence and greed. But sincere good intentions, a lover's smile and cozy folk-rock guitars are there to ease both disillusionment and the pangs of conscience.

title: City Cancels More Contracts With Queens Service Agency
description: In its latest move to distance itself from a Queens social services agency at the center of a dispute over city work, the Giuliani administration yesterday canceled two more contracts the agency had recently been awarded to run school programs.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Jardine Buying Stake In Indian Company
description: Jardine Strategic Holdings Ltd. will pay $35 million for a 20 percent stake in Tata Industries Ltd. of India, giving it an investment in some of the subcontinent's fastest-growing industries. Jardine Strategic is one of two core holding companies in the Hong Kong-based Jardine Group, which has interests in property development, engineering and retailing. Tata Industries is a privately owned investment business used by the Tata group of companies to invest in India's new technology industries. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: COMPANY NEWS;SCOTTS TO TAKE CHARGE ON FAILED PROMOTION PLAN
description: The Scotts Company said yesterday that it would take a charge of up to $8 million in the next three quarters to help it recover from a failed promotional plan. The company, which makes lawn- and turf-care products, said excess inventories caused by the plan would hurt sales of high-margin products by up to $60 million in the same period. The failed promotion, which was aimed at retailers instead of consumers, has already led to a first-quarter charge of $2.1 million, the restatement of results for the 1995 fiscal year and the resignation of Theodore Host as chief executive. Scotts shares were down 62.5 cents, at $17.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: OPERA REVIEW;France, Anti-Semitism And an Innocent Man
description: In the end, the composer did show up. Prior reports on Jost Meier's "Dreyfus Affair," which had its American premiere at the New York City Opera on Tuesday night, suggested that the opera's strangely imperious librettist, George Whyte, had barred Mr. Meier from attending. After the disgruntled composer paid his way from Switzerland, a last-minute reconciliation allowed him to take a nervous bow.

title: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: THE RESCUE;A Storm-Swept Mountain's Grim Story
description: Croatian special police officers wrapped in green army ponchos, their faces averted from withering sheets of rain, labored up the steep slope of St. John Mountain tonight in a huge search for the far-flung wreckage that had been the plane carrying Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown and 32 others.

title: Utility Isn't the Point In Ban on Land Mines
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Spain, in Surprise, Cuts Rate to 7.75%
description: Encouraged by slowing inflation, the Bank of Spain jolted financial markets higher yesterday by ordering a surprise cut in its benchmark interest rate to 7.75 percent from 8.25 percent. The cut in the marginal rate on securities repurchase agreements was the fourth since Dec. 22 and brought the rate to its lowest since January 1995. Commercial banks lowered lending rates amid hopes that lower borrowing costs would spur economic growth without causing more inflation, now at a 25-year low. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Wheat Prices Surge on Forecast Of Cold Weekend Temperatures
description: Wheat prices surged yesterday after forecasters said freezing temperatures would reach winter wheat fields this weekend, adding to damage already caused by one of the driest growing seasons on record.

title: POLITICS: IN OHIO;County's Conservative Attitude Liberalizes Treatment of Lawbreakers
description: This is a conservative community where people have strong feelings about law and order. But, it turns out, they have even stronger feelings about holding down their taxes. For years residents voted against a sales tax increase, setting off a fiscal crisis that forced the sheriff to close nearly half the county jail.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Plank Road Brewery, Milwaukee, a division of the Miller Brewing Co. unit of the Philip Morris Cos., to the Leo Burnett Co., Chicago, to introduce Iguana Light beer in test markets including Dallas and Philadelphia. Although this is Burnett's first Plank Road assignment, the agency handles Miller brands like Miller Lite. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Why This Matzoh Is Different From All Others: It's Moscow's
description: Keep calm!" shouted Alla Nazarova as she barred the surging crowed from the door. Her plea meant nothing to the scores of people, all with rubles clenched in their fists, who were standing in line.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the standoff in Montana between Federal officials and members of a tax resisters' group carried an incorrect byline. The article was by David Johnston, not by Dirk Johnson.

title: Injected Drug for Impotence Is Found Effective
description: The first injection treatment approved for relieving impotence works well in most men, allowing sexual intercourse almost every time it is used, a study has found.

title: DANCE REVIEW;A Twilight Realm and Travels Into the Past
description: The breadth of its repertory and the dramatic flair of its dancers help make the Oakland Ballet one of America's most interesting companies. Since its artistic director, Ronn Guidi, founded it in 1965, this California troupe has offered a great variety of new works, as well as exploring dance history through significant revivals.

title: Currents;And Two Gallons Of Butter, Please
description: UNTIL last Friday, the Sony Theaters on Broadway at 84th Street had a simple lobby with murals showing Marilyn Monroe and Clark Gable.

title: Novocherkassk Journal;With Yeltsin's Blessing, the Cossacks Ride Again
description: Wearing his camouflage uniform and black army hat, Slava Ilyin lined up in parade formation.

title: Wise Decisions on the Right to Die
description: Sometimes breakthroughs in individual rights come in a single Supreme Court decision. Sometimes they come in clusters of lower court rulings. That is what has now happened with two momentous decisions from high-ranking Federal appeals courts a continent apart. The two courts have issued humane and sound rulings that would greatly broaden the rights of terminally ill patients to hasten their deaths and strengthen legal protections for doctors who help them. Though they differ in their reasoning, both rulings raise the prospect that the Supreme Court will soon be compelled to consider the right-to-die issue and point the way toward a constitutionally correct result.

title: HOCKEY;Devils Miss Playoffs? Oh, the Shame of It!
description: The fear, desperation and sense of embarrassment that have enveloped the Devils were all evident today at their training facility here. With six games left in the regular season, the defending Stanley Cup champions are in danger of missing the playoffs.

title: Abortion Clinics Report Drop in Harassing Incidents
description: In a state that has been one of the bloodiest battlegrounds in the abortion debate, the anti-abortion pickets outside the office of Dr. Ben Graber, a legislator who sometimes performs the procedure as part of his gynecological practice, would not have been surprising in the past.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Colts' Coryatt Surrenders on Gun Charge
description: Colts linebacker QUENTIN CORYATT was released from custody yesterday after posting a $2,500 bond in connection with a weapons charge in Indianapolis. Coryatt, accused of pointing a handgun at a motorist during a dispute over traffic in a highway construction zone, surrendered at 7:29 A.M. yesterday, said BEVERLY PHILLIPS, a spokeswoman with the Marion County prosecutor's office. An initial hearing was scheduled for next Thursday morning in Marion County Municipal Court, she said.

title: M. Shanara Gilbert, 45, a Law Professor
description: M. Shanara Gilbert, an associate professor of law at the City University of New York Law School at Queens College, was killed on Tuesday in a highway accident in South Africa. She was 45 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: ON THE UNABOMBER'S TRACK: THE TOWN;Among the Junipers, a Loner 'Not That Remarkable'
description: There were no fancy woodworking tools visible in the simple, rustic cabin where Theodore J. Kaczynski spent much of the last 18 or 20 years, nothing that would suggest the exquisite craft that marked the mail bombs that Federal officials say he made.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Currents;A Speak-Easy With Blini
description: KEITH McNALLY, left, has often imagined what an Eastern European speak-easy of the 20's might have looked like. Especially one frequented by Russian Constructivists, whose paintings and designs were inspired by the machine. Pravda, a bar that will open next Thursday at 281 Lafayette Street (near Prince Street), is his fantasy made real (with the help of his partners, Ian McPheely and Ana Opitz).

title: European Topics : Switzerland Targets Book With New Anti-Bias Law
description: In one of its first tests, a new Swiss anti-racism law has been invoked against a book that blames Jews for the outbreak of World War II and denies the existence of the Holocaust.

title: Berkshire Hathaway Files to Offer Shares
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. filed this week with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer 115,000 class B common shares, following up on a promise by the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett to create a new class of shares in the high-priced investment company.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;Will Baseball Make the Call For Umpires?
description: IN the years when baseball was a game instead of an industry, Ford Frick, the National League president who would later be the commissioner, called one of his umpires, Dusty Boggess, to his office.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EXCEL INDUSTRIES COMPLETES ACQUISITION OF ANDERSON
description: Excel Industries said yesterday that it had completed its acquisition of Anderson Industries and disclosed that the deal was valued at $61 million. Terms of the transaction were not announced last month, when the agreement was disclosed. Excel also said it had assumed about $85 million of Anderson Industries' debt. Anderson Industries, which is based in Rockford, Ill., is a holding company whose main asset is Atwood Industries, a maker of gas ranges, water heaters, furnaces, air-conditioners and other equipment for recreational vehicles and manufactured housing. Excel Industries, which is based in Elkhart, Ind., designs, makes and supplies vehicle window and door systems.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Plans for Sports Complex
description: James W. Treffinger, the Essex County Executive, and Mayor Sharpe James of Newark said they would announce plans today for a sports complex in Riverbank Park, which will be part of an economic development zone along the Passaic River, an official involved in the project said yesterday.

title: ON THE UNABOMBER'S TRACK: THE VICTIMS;At the Places Where Bombs Killed, a Day for Memories and Nervous Optimism
description: They are an unusual club, the victims of the Unabomber. Mostly academics, a few corporate executives, and one a secretary who happened to open the wrong package, they are spread at random across the country and linked only by the fact that their lives were damaged or in some cases devastated by a package from someone with a penchant for evil.

title: Panel Says Pap Tests Could Almost End Cervical Cancer Deaths
description: Almost 5,000 American women die of cervical cancer annually and virtually all the deaths could be prevented by routine Pap smears and by safe sex, a National Institutes of Health panel of experts concluded today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Football Player Arrested
description: Todd McNair, a Houston Oilers running back, was arrested Tuesday and charged with 81 offenses involving the mistreatment of 22 pit bulls being trained on his property for dogfights, the police said yesterday. Seventeen dogs were found tied to trees with chains, all had scars and many appeared malnourished, Lieut. Scott Goess of the East Greenwich police said. He described the condition of the dogs as "appalling."

title: Britain Incensed as Europe Keeps Beef Ban
description: Over bitter protests from Britain, the European Union's farm ministers today approved measures to combat mad cow disease that will include the destruction of millions of head of British cattle.

title: Study of 19,000 Finds No 'Gulf War Syndrome'
description: A clinical study of thousands of veterans of the Persian Gulf war has found frequent cases of headaches, fatigue, memory loss and depression but no single cause or mystery ailment to support suspicions about the existence of a gulf war syndrome.

title: Inclusive, in Design and Worship
description: ALL places of worship, from soaring Gothic cathedrals to spare Shinto shrines, speak in their architecture of the beliefs held sacred by those who built them. Few do so as boldly as St. Gregory Nyssen Church, a striking new Episcopal church whose spaces and details express a desire to return to an earlier, more exuberant form of Christian practice.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AVON STOCK JUMPS ON EARNINGS AND PRODUCT PLANS
description: Executives at Avon Products Inc. announced ambitious new product plans yesterday and said the worst appeared to be over for Avon in economically troubled Mexico. Meeting with analysts at Avon's headquarters in Manhattan, the executives also said first-quarter earnings would be in line with analysts' estimates, on modestly higher revenue. The company's stock gained $4.50 a share, to $93, an all-time high. Among the new products announced by Avon is its first hair-care line, Avon Techniques. Late this year, the company will come out with a newly formulated skin-care product and a new fragrance, the company said.

title: Cab Crimes Drop, but Drivers' Fears Remain High
description: Officer Anthony Falconite gazed at the line of battered livery cabs idling in the rain. It looked like robbery weather.

title: ON THE UNABOMBER'S TRACK: THE HUNTERS;With a Family Discovery, a Manhunt Comes to an End
description: Year after year and death after death, investigators looked everywhere, from the checkout records for certain library books to the computer files of known criminals, from the storefronts of scrap metal dealers to the employee lists of companies dealing in artificial human limbs.

title: Dominican Has Acted To Insure Fair Election
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: The Lives Broken Off;Ronald H. Brown, 54, Clinton's Commerce Secretary
description: Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, who was reported missing today in the crash of an Air Force plane near Dubrovnik, Croatia, is one of Washington's most skilled political insiders, a consummate deal maker who helped unify the Democratic Party behind Bill Clinton and then put the creation of American jobs at the center of the nation's foreign policy.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Turnpike Saves $6 Million
description: Using part-time toll collectors on weekends saved the New Jersey Turnpike Authority $6 million in overtime costs in 1995, the agency said yesterday. Overtime was reduced by 37.5 percent because of work-rule changes put into effect last year, said Lynn Fleeger, a spokeswoman for the Turnpike Authority.

title: Life's Thread Stitched Into Quilts
description: EVEN now, seven decades away from her North Carolina girlhood, Virginia Hall has a fondness for Wednesday nights. For it was on fall and winter Wednesdays that Mrs. Hall, a sharecropper's daughter who now lives in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, would gather around the large wooden frame in the living room with her mother and her mother's friends, fortified by laughter, fried chicken and hot buttery cake.

title: U.S. Offers Data to Link Sudan to Plot
description: Pressing a divided Security Council for tough sanctions against the Sudan, the Clinton Administration presented evidence for the first time today that it said directly implicated the Sudanese Government in the attempted assassination of President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt by Islamic militants.

title: Fraud Trial Witness Is Blocked on Testimony on Clinton
description: The prosecution's star witness in the Federal loan-fraud trial here was barred from giving additional testimony today as to whether President Clinton was aware of, or was involved in, a series of questionable loans a decade ago.

title: Sketches of Some Believed to Be on the Plane: Business Leaders FromAcross the U.S.; Claudio Elia, Environmental Executive, 53
description: Claudio Elia is chairman and chief executive of Air and Water Technologies Corporation, an environmental services company based in Branchburg, N.J.. Mr. Elia is 53 years old and lives in Greenwich, Conn.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SANIFILL INC., Houston, an environmental services concern, acquired a number of small waste-services companies with about $29 million in total annual revenues for $18 million in stock and $22 million in cash and notes.

title: POLITICS: ADVERTISING;Attack Ads By Democrats Are Focusing Solely on Dole
description: Senator Bob Dole did not get much of a honeymoon from the Democrats.

title: Lucent's Initial Offering Nets Record $3.025 Billion
description: Lucent Technologies Inc., the AT&T Corporation spinoff, sold 112 million shares at $27 each yesterday, netting it $3.025 billion in the largest initial public offering in American history.

title: Too Close for Comfort?;Inquiry Touches Money Laundering Expert's Backer
description: Charles A. Intriago is one of the nation's most trusted chroniclers of the war on money laundering. Through his Money Laundering Alert, the 54-year-old lawyer has befriended leaders of the crackdown on financial skulduggery by drug lords and tax evaders, citing them in his newsletter, inviting them to speak at his conferences and gossiping with them on the phone.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Siebe Offers to Buy The Rest of Unitech
description: Siebe P.L.C. offered yesterday to buy the 75 percent of Unitech P.L.C. that it did not own for L520 million ($796 million) in a move that would help its growth in Asia. Unitech's board agreed to back the offer. Siebe bought 25 percent of Unitech in mid-March. The new purchase would make Siebe the world's biggest manufacturer of power-supply converters, which are used in electronic equipment, with 6 percent of the market. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Brooklyn Navy Yard Chief, Under Investigation, Is Dismissed
description: The president of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation was dismissed yesterday over concerns that an escalating investigation into her purchase of $30,000 in furniture was undermining her leadership of the nonprofit agency.

title: BASEBALL;Yanks Turn Jacobs Field Into Their House
description: Someone should whisper to Joe Torre that it is really not this easy. Managing the Yankees for George Steinbrenner is not a picnic, especially when a challenging schedule calls for the season to open with a visit to the chilly and rowdy home of the American League Champions.

title: The Whitewater 'Independent' Counsel Isn't
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;HEILEMAN FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY TO SPEED ITS SALE
description: As expected, the G. Heileman Brewing Company filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday as part of its acquisition by the Stroh Brewery Company. Heileman has said that a bankruptcy filing would make its acquisition by Stroh easier by wiping out the litigation risk from Heileman's debt holders. The plan is pre-negotiated, meaning the company believes it has most of the support it needs from creditors for the plan to be legally approved. Stroh announced on Feb. 29 that it planned to buy the company, in which the investment firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst owns a controlling stake, in a complex deal worth an estimated $275 million to $300 million.

title: Richard A. Moody, 84, American-Theater Expert
description: Richard A. Moody, author, theater historian and former director of theater at Indiana University, died on Friday at Bloomington Hospital in Bloomington, Ind. He was 84.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A Student's Skittish, Driving New Work
description: There were several newsworthy angles to the concert by the New York Chamber Symphony on Tuesday night. Gerard Schwarz conducted the premiere of "Flares," a striking work by a prodigiously gifted 21-year-old composer, Vivian Fung. The pianist Lorin Hollander made one of his infrequent appearances in New York, performing Saint-Saens' Piano Concerto No. 5. And with this concert, the New York Chamber Symphony ended its 19-year association with the 92d Street Y. The directors of the Y have asked that the ensemble find another venue. Next season, Mr. Schwarz will be taking his admirable orchestra to Alice Tully Hall.

title: Olympic Profile: Atlanta 1996;For Palestinian Runner, Carrying Flag Is Glory Enough
description: He has no chance of winning a medal at the Summer Olympics. But for Majid abu Maraheel, a distance runner, simply carrying the Palestinian flag at the opening ceremonies in Atlanta will be more than enough glory. Abu Maraheel, 32 and a father of five, is one of three athletes who will represent Palestine at the Olympics this summer, the first Palestinian team to compete at the Games.

title: Dayton Journal;Cleanup Effort Means Fish Are Biting, Again
description: The Great Miami River is a civil engineer's dream, but not a poet's. Flowing slowly between equidistant levees covered with grass mowed short, the river traces a wide curve among the factories of Dayton's south side. The 100-yard-wide expanse of water is a dull brown with dark weeds just below the surface.

title: R-Rating Abuse' Occurs in Flight, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;DSC COMMUNICATIONS REPORTS LOWER EARNINGS
description: Hurt by slower business from its European operations and weak international sales, the DSC Communications Corporation said yesterday that it expected to report first-quarter earnings and revenue below Wall Street's estimates. The Dallas-based telecommunications company said it expected net income to be about 10 cents a share and revenue to be $305 million to $310 million. Wall Street was expecting earnings of 29 cents a share, according to a survey of 14 analysts by Zacks Investment Research. In the first quarter of 1995, DSC posted net income of 36 cents a share on revenue of $318 million. The company's stock was up $1.125 at $26.875.

title: BASEBALL;Mets Fall Inches Short Of a Second Comeback
description: For a moment, time stood still at Shea Stadium yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CALIFORNIA FINANCIAL REJECTS FIRST NATIONWIDE OFFER
description: The California Financial Holding Company said yesterday that it had rejected a $24-a-share takeover offer from First Nationwide Bank in December. California Financial, which operates Stockton Savings Bank, said its board had responded that "it is the longstanding policy of the company to remain independent." California Financial, based in Stockton, Calif., said it issued the statement in response to a Business Week article about First Nationwide's interest. California Financial's stock rose 50 cents to close at $21.50.

title: Release the Inaugural Records
description: Gov. George Pataki must make the financial records for his inauguration public. Assembly Democrats are asking whether as much as $700,000 raised for the inaugural actually went to pay campaign debts, a clear violation of New York law. Mr. Pataki's spokeswoman says no one can criticize the inaugural when "they don't know how much was raised or spent," and adds that no one in the Pataki camp is prepared to offer that information.

title: Sketches of Some Believed to Be on the Plane: Business Leaders FromAcross the U.S.; William Morton, Political Adviser
description: William Morton first became involved in politics in his native Denver, where he worked as a volunteer for Gary Hart's Presidential campaign in 1988. When Mr. Hart's Presidential effort ended, he moved on to the campaign of the Rev. Jesse Jackson. He was originally named political director.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's;Classics And Classic Crossovers
description: Temirkanov's Shostakovich 7th

title: Mayor Names New Head For Agency
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani named Liliam Barrios-Paoli the new Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development yesterday, placing a trusted city administrator in charge of an agency that is trying to shed its responsibility for maintaining much of the city's low-income housing.

title: Sunday News Program Scheduled by Fox
description: The Fox television network will begin offering a weekly Sunday morning news and public-affairs program on April 28, Roger Ailes, chairman and chief executive officer of Fox News, announced yesterday.

title: Judges Set Up Review Panel For Lawsuits On Implants
description: In a rare move that could affect the course of silicone breast implant litigation nationwide, two Federal judges in New York have set up a procedure to create an expert panel to review the scientific issues involved in lawsuits resulting from the health dispute.

title: Gay and Lesbian Officers Suing the Police for Bias
description: Gay and lesbian police officers have filed suit in Federal court against the New York City Police Department, contending that the department had not treated an organization of gay law enforcement workers as an equal of other fraternal organizations.

title: Supply-Side Medicine
description: Imagine that while sitting down to dinner one night your spouse suddenly collapses and is rushed to the hospital in cardiac arrest. In the intensive care unit, the doctor says that a balloon angioplasty is needed as soon as possible. But in order to have the procedure, your loved one will have to be transported overseas -- if the angioplasty is even available.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMDAHL TO BUY TRECOM BUSINESS SYSTEMS
description: The Amdahl Corporation, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said yesterday that it would expand its computer services group by buying Trecom Business Systems Inc. for $145 million. Amdahl, best known for mainframe computers, said it would pay about half the cost now and the other half in the second quarter of 1997. Amdahl, which had sales of $1.5 billion in 1995, is trying to increase its offerings of services, software and maintenance to help companies manage mainframe systems. Trecom is a closely held company with 1,700 employees. Its revenue has grown an average of 40 percent in each of the last three years.

title: Beyond Sun Versus Shade: How to Choose a Color Film
description: BUYING a roll of film should be one of the simplest tasks in photography. But some people find it daunting, and with good reason. Standing in a camera store, faced by a wall of little yellow, green and red boxes with various letters and numbers on them, can make even the most intrepid amateur photographer unsure about what choice to make.

title: Currents;Fake Jewels Add Real Sparkle to Tiles
description: FIVE years ago Coral Bourgeois, an artist and a jewelry designer, began to tire of hand-painting every earring. So Ms. Bourgeois, who lives in Rumford, R.I., decided to combine her talents in a different way. She now designs wall tiles and studs them with plastic jewels to highlight the design.

title: Pakistani Leader Is Committed to Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: AT&T Net Service to Include Compuserve Access
description: AT&T Worldnet Services confirmed yesterday that it would offer its Internet customers access to the Compuserve Information Service at a discount, beginning this summer. The alliance, which was forged last month, is similar to a deal that AT&T struck with America Online on March 11.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Greenberg Goes to South Florida
description: SETH GREENBERG, the Long Beach State basketball coach who made national news in January with critical post-game remarks about New Mexico State after an anti-Semitic epithet was found written in the 49ers' locker room, was named head coach at South Florida on Wednesday.

title: Inquiry on F-14 Looks at Afterburner
description: A Navy investigation into a series of recent crashes of F-14's is focusing on a possible afterburner problem, a military official said on Tuesday.

title: Blue-Chip Stocks Continue Their Upward Roll
description: Blue-chip stocks rose to another record high yesterday, as the market's largest initial public offering to date waited in the wings.

title: The Pop Life
description: Though she hasn't performed much in clubs and her first album was just released this week, Patti Rothberg, a New York singer, guitarist and songwriter, is already worried that she's being stereotyped. One might guess that she is concerned about being written off as a subway musician, since she was discovered busking in the Union Square station in Manhattan and her first album is titled "Between the 1 and the 9" (EMI), after the subway lines that run there. But actually, she's been pegged as the next Alanis Morissette. And this upsets her.

title: HOCKEY;2 Point Edge For Lightning
description: Daren Puppa made 38 saves and Mikael Andersson scored the game-winner at 12 minutes 6 seconds of the third period tonight as the Tampa Bay Lightning boosted their playoff hopes with a 4-2 victory over the Hartford Whalers.

title: Inco Takeover Bid Accepted In Battle for a Huge Mine
description: Inco Ltd.'s takeover bid was selected today in the battle for control of a giant nickel deposit in Labrador, a deal that would solidify Inco's world dominance in the production of nickel, a key component of stainless steel.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the stock market's activity on Tuesday misstated the closing stock price of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group in some editions. It was $143.375, not $43.375.

title: Reviews/Fashion;For Karan and Lauren, Tent-Free Triumphs
description: EVERY New York season there is one story that skulks off the fashion pages and into the mainstream media. Usually it is about a feud, and this time it was Calvin Klein deriding Donna Karan and Ralph Lauren for pulling out of the centralized location for the shows, the tents in Bryant Park.

title: African Immigrants Refusing to Leave France
description: Abdel Kader Wague-Dodo arrived at Charles de Gaulle Airport nine years ago from the Central African Republic with a tourist visa, hoping for work and a better life.

title: Utility Isn't the Point In Ban on Land Mines
description: To the Editor:

title: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: IN WASHINGTON;Jet Crash Casts a Sudden Shadow Over Official Washington
description: At 10:30 this morning, President Clinton's national security adviser, Anthony Lake, walked into the Oval Office with the news: Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown's plane was missing in the Balkans and wreckage had been spotted. The rest was a welter of unconfirmed reports.

title: POLITICS: TIME OUT;New Hampshire Governor Backs Away From Politics
description: After nearly four years as one of New Hampshire's most popular politicians, Gov. Stephen Merrill said today that he was quitting elective politics.

title: Indicted Trader Due in U.S.
description: Victor Gomez, a former trader for Chemical Bank who was indicted on fraud charges and other crimes that caused the bank $70 million in trading losses, has waived extradition from Britain, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Grizzlies End the Futility
description: Vancouver snapped its 23-game losing streak tonight, beating the Minnesota Timberwolves, 105-103, on a last-second basket by Blue Edwards. The victory prevented the Grizzlies from tying the National Basketball Association record for most consecutive losses.

title: Sketches of Some Believed to Be on the Plane: Business Leaders FromAcross the U.S.; Robert A. Whittaker, Energy Executive, 47
description: Robert A. Whittaker is a vice president of Foster Wheeler Corporation in Clinton, N.J., which provides engineering and construction services for industry. He is 47.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Whitman's Counsel Resigns
description: Margaret Foti, who has served as chief counsel to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman since February 1995, has resigned to return to private practice, the Governor's office announced yesterday. She will be replaced by Harriet Derman, Commissioner of the Department of Community Affairs.

title: Harlem Store at Center of Dispute Gets Lease
description: A black record store owner in Harlem whose lease battle with a Jewish businessman prompted protests that led to a deadly arson fire has been offered a new lease in the same building.

title: A Priest Is Accused Of Sexually Abusing A 16-Year-Old Girl
description: A Roman Catholic priest from Nigeria was arrested Tuesday afternoon on charges that he sexually groped a 16-year-old girl and exposed himself to her at a Queens motel room, the police said. The girl made the charges after she and a 21-year-old woman were apprehended for stealing the priest's car.

title: James L. Tullis, 81, Leading Researcher on Blood
description: Dr. James Lyman Tullis, a blood specialist who developed a novel way of freezing and storing human red blood cells for clinical use, died on Sunday at New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 81 and lived in the Boston suburb of Chestnut Hill.

title: U.S. Judge Overturns State Conviction of Keating
description: A Federal judge today overturned the California state court conviction of Charles H. Keating Jr., the leading figure in the 1980's savings-and-loan debacle, ruling that jury instructions by the judge in the state court, Lance A. Ito, had been flawed.

title: U.N. Says Mosquito Netting Could Save 500,000 Lives in Africa
description: Mosquito nets treated with insecticide to fight malaria could save the lives of up to 500,000 African children each year, the World Health Organization said today.

title: Whitman AIDS Panel Urges Needle Exchange Programs
description: Ignoring Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's public opposition to providing clean needles for drug addicts, her own advisory council on AIDS voted today to recommend that New Jersey allow clean-needle exchange programs and the sale of syringes without a prescription at pharmacies.

title: Sketches of Some Believed to Be on the Plane: Business Leaders FromAcross the U.S.; Leonard J. Pieroni, Engineering Executive, 57
description: Leonard J. Pieroni is a chemical engineer who rose to become chairman and chief executive officer of the Parsons Corporation. He is 57 and a resident of La Canada, Calif.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Cold Water for Knicks' Playoff Dreams
description: On a night when Patrick Ewing should have been dominant, he was dreadful. On a night when the Orlando Magic did not have Shaquille O'Neal, the Knicks had no response.

title: BASEBALL;Yanks Are No. 1, but Marlins' and Indians' Payrolls Soar
description: The Yankees, as expected, have the largest payroll in the major leagues, slightly more than $52 million, but the Baltimore Orioles and the Atlanta Braves have higher average salaries. Furthermore, the Florida Marlins and the Cleveland Indians lead the wild swing that has occurred with the payrolls and average salaries of some clubs.

title: BASEBALL;Showalter Proves Selective
description: Always cagey and always coy, Buck Showalter said he did not have time to watch the Yankees play the Indians on opening day. He had to scout a Cuban pitcher whom the Arizona Diamondbacks have signed. He had to finish devising an organizational manual. He had to continue distancing himself from the Yankees.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SUSAN BRADDOCK really wanted a small, two-tiered Regency table that her decorator, Mark Hampton, had donated to an auction benefiting the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Passover, Holy Thursday and Good Friday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: BASEBALL;Pulsipher Looks at Options While Mets Urge Surgery
description: While the Mets have no qualms about Bill Pulsipher's getting a second opinion on his injured left elbow, the club is hoping he will eventually opt for surgery to insure that he will be ready to pitch again by the start of next season.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Swissair Reorganization Produces First Loss
description: Swissair said yesterday that it had its first loss in history last year because of a reorganization charge of 300 million Swiss francs ($251 million). The Swissair Group, which consists of the airline, catering and hotel properties, said it posted a loss of 147 million francs ($123 million), compared with a profit of 23 million francs in 1994.

title: POLITICS: THE AD CAMPAIGN;Taking On Dole in a New Commercial
description: The Democratic National Committee has begun broadcasting a new 30-second television commercial around the country.

title: House Proud
description: I FEEL unsurpassed happiness," Nikos Kazantzakis, the Greek novelist, wrote in 1935 after experiencing a Japanese bath. "I have overcome impatience, nervousness, haste."

title: Correction
description: A March 30 editorial, "The Last Caudillo," stated incorrectly that Joaquin Balaguer, President of the Dominican Republic, had held power without interruption since 1965. Mr. Balaguer was defeated for re-election in 1978 and was out of power for the next eight years.

title: In Ivy League, Yale Is Leader In Labor Unrest;Old Town-Gown Hostility Confers a Dubious Honor
description: Yale always yearns to be No. 1 in the Ivy League, but a walkout by 1,100 service and maintenance workers has cemented Yale's leadership in an area it would prefer not to boast about: strikes.

title: Agency Seeks a Move Because of Air Quality
description: After complaints that the air in its headquarters was making workers sick, the Transportation Department said today that it would ask its landlord to spend $5 million to relocate employees and overhaul the ventilation system this summer.

title: Losing Our Day In Court
description: Do you have the right to take your state to Federal court for putting raw sewage in your drinking water? The United States Supreme Court, it seems, has said no.

title: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: THE PLANE;2 Crashes By 737's Remain Unsolved
description: The Air Force plane that crashed in Croatia today was a modified version of the Boeing 737, a widely used aircraft with one of the best safety records in the air. But two unexplained crashes in the last five years, in Pittsburgh and Colorado Springs, have raised questions about the 737's performance.

title: Liberties;The Body Politic
description: It makes me tense to watch Bob Dole relax.

title: Sketches of Some Believed to Be on the Plane: Business Leaders FromAcross the U.S.; I. Donald Terner, Housing Developer, 56
description: I. Donald Terner is a former director of Housing and Community Development for the State of California and a developer of low-income housing in San Francisco. He is 56 and lives in San Francisco.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Wary Beard Interviews For the Job At St. John's
description: Butch Beard has 10 games remaining in his contract with the Nets after tonight's 100-94 victory over the Los Angels Clippers at Continental Arena, but his job status is hardly secure. And don't think Beard isn't thinking about his future.

title: No Headline
description: Ron Brown walked and ran and flew through life, and he was a magnificent life force. And those of us who loved him will always be grateful for his friendship and his warmth."

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Bertelsmann Deal Spurs a Race for Pay TV
description: With Europe's media giants scrambling to enter the dawning world of digital television, the decision by Bertelsmann A.G. of Germany to form a powerful broadcasting venture with Audiofina of Luxembourg has reinforced the trend toward collaboration over competition.

title: Domestic Sales Rose 4.3% For Auto Makers in March
description: Domestic sales of cars and light trucks rose a combined 4.3 percent last month, the final figures from the auto makers showed today, giving a strong start to the important spring selling season.

title: Perry, in Egypt, Warns Libya to Halt Chemical Weapons Plant
description: Defense Secretary William J. Perry said today that the United States would not allow Libya to complete an underground chemical weapons plant and would not rule out a military attack if Libya does not halt its chemical weapons program.

title: Sketches of Some Believed to Be on the Plane: Business Leaders FromAcross the U.S.; Walter J. Murphy, AT&T Executive, 52
description: Walter J. Murphy, a senior executive at the AT&T Corporation, is a vice president of global sales for AT&T's Submarine Systems division and has spent much of his career building up the company's international business. He is 52 and lives in Fanwood, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday with the continuation of an article about the state of the economy misstated the performance of one component of the index of leading indicators. That component -- the average workweek of production workers in manufacturing -- rose, contributing 0.77 of a percentage point to the index's overall increase; it did not fall by that amount.

title: Market Place;Battle heats up between Morgan Stanley and a fund's investors.
description: THE gloves are coming off in a battle between investors in the Intercapital Global Opportunity Fund, which failed with much fanfare last year, and the Morgan Stanley Group, which was the fund's custodian, registrar and administrator.

title: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: The Lives Broken Off;Nathaniel C. Nash, 44, Reporter for The Times
description: Nathaniel Cushing Nash, the Frankfurt bureau chief of The New York Times, was on board the plane that crashed in Croatia yesterday. The 44-year-old reporter has spent more than half his life at The Times.

title: Stocks Up a Bit in Tokyo
description: Stocks edged up here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 6.43 points at 21,471.16, an advance of less than one-tenth of a percent. On Wednesday, the index lost 135.35 points after comments by a Bank of Japan official suggested that the central bank would soon raise interest rates.

title: U.S. Cites Nations With Big Trade Barriers
description: The Clinton Administration cited Japan, China and 40 other countries and four trading groups for criticism this week in the Administration's annual review of the most onerous trade barriers around the world.

title: War Crimes Aides Say Bodies in Graves May Have Been Moved
description: Many of the hundreds of bodies thought to be buried in two mass graves in this area may have been removed recently, officials close to the International War Crimes Tribunal said today after a preliminary examination of the sites.

title: Recalling Dodgers' Flight, Mayor Makes His Pitch for New Stadium
description: Recalling how New York City lost the Dodgers after a previous mayor refused to help the team build a new baseball stadium in Brooklyn, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has begun to offer the economic justification -- and with it the political one -- for building the Yankees a new home on the West Side of Manhattan.

title: Boyhood Memories of Quilting Time in Alabama
description: EACH fall, after harvest, my grandmother Faith Smith and several of her friends turned to patching quilts and gossiping in her living room in New Brockton, Ala. Outside on the porch the men shelled peanuts.

title: CHRONICLE
description: With a refreshing display of modesty, Sir ALEC GUINNESS unveiled a plaque celebrating his six decades in film on Tuesday, his 82d birthday. He promptly said he wasn't sure he was worthy of such an honor.
