title: South Africans Sentenced
description: A South African judge sentenced five members of a right-wing group to 26-year jail terms today for a series of bombings two years ago in which 20 people died and which were aimed at disrupting the country's first multiracial elections.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MATTEL REACHES AGREEMENT FOR RIGHTS TO DISNEY TOYS
description: The Walt Disney Company's consumer products division said yesterday that it had signed an agreement guaranteeing Mattel Inc. worldwide toy rights for all coming Disney television and film properties. The pact expands the two companies' current relationship, under which Mattel, based in El Segundo, Calif., has provided infant and preschool toys based on Disney characters. The expanded alliance will cover all productions of Walt Disney Pictures, Hollywood Pictures and Touchstone Pictures.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PANAMSAT IN DEAL WITH CHINESE STATE TV
description: China Central Television, or CCTV, and the Panamsat Corporation announced yesterday that they had a satellite delivery agreement that would enable CCTV, a Chinese state broadcaster, to expand its reach to much of the world. The 10-year agreement widened coverage of CCTV broadcasts to include Europe, the Middle East and Africa, an official of CCTV said. Previously, broadcasts covered Asia and North America only. Fredrick Landman, the president and chief executive of Panamsat, which is based in Greenwich, Conn., said the agreement was worth tens of millions of dollars. Panamsat's shares rose $1.125 to $32.125.

title: Suicide Ruling Raises Concern: Who Decides?
description: The decision by a Federal appeals court striking down New York State's ban on physician-assisted suicide has raised an enormous array of thorny questions about how to regulate the practice, and lawyers, medical ethicists and health care providers said today that the State Legislature would have to fill the legal void by establishing clear standards and safeguards.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Florid Style for a Tartar King
description: Last year the Manhattan School of Music committed itself to the task of presenting the 37 Italian operas that Handel composed between 1705 and 1741, only a handful of which can be said to have found a place, though still a tenuous one, in the active repertory. The director and conductor of the school's Handel Project is Will Crutchfield, whose passion for these works was evident not only in his performance of "Tamerlano" on Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, but also in a preconcert lecture in which he presented facts, details and opinions about the music in an assured, rapid-fire patter.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Woolworth Chooses Publicis/Bloom
description: The Woolworth Corporation in New York yesterday named the Publicis/Bloom unit of Publicis S.A. in New York as agency of record for its Woolworth variety chain. The agency will create an image campaign promoting a revamping of the stores that will include redesigned retail space and a more contemporary mix of merchandise. The billings have not been determined.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CHRISTOPHER REEVE, who challenged the audience at the Academy Awards ceremony last week to tackle serious issues, has done just that himself: He has taped a radio advertisement protesting proposed cuts in the New York State Medicaid program. The ad is being carried by five New York City metropolitan area stations through Tuesday.

title: Hung Jury Called Back
description: A judge has taken the unusual step of calling back a hung jury in a murder case after a newspaper reported jurors had acquitted the defendant of the most serious charges. Judge Joseph A. Licari Jr. of State Superior Court declared a mistrial and discharged the 12 jurors Monday after they said they were deadlocked. But now he has asked the jurors to reconvene on April 11 so they can be polled on how they voted on a charge of murder and the lesser charge of manslaughter. The defendant was Reginald Cash, charged in the death of Joseph Woodard, 5, his girlfriend's son. The boy was suffocated March 17, 1995.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Police Shooting Justifiable
description: A Middlesex County grand jury has concluded that two New Jersey state troopers used justifiable force in December when they fatally shot a 19-year-old West Virginia man, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NOWSCO WELL SERVICE DISCLOSES BID
description: Nowsco Well Service Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, said yesterday that the BJ Services Company, a Houston-based oil services concern, intended to make a cash offer to acquire all of Nowsco's common stock at $27 (Canadian) a share. Nowsco said BJ Services had communicated the bid through its Canadian subsidiary but had declined to put it in writing. Nowsco is an international oilfield service company operating in major oil and gas producing regions of the world. The company's shares closed at $20.375 (Canadian), down 12.5 cents, on the Toronto Stock Exchange. At $27 (Canadian) a share, the company has an indicated value of about $560 million (Canadian), the equivalent of about $414 million (United States). The stock also trades on Nasdaq and closed there at $15.375, up 12.5 cents.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Johnson Worldwide Reinforces Agency
description: Johnson Worldwide Associates, a marketer of sporting goods in Sturtevant, Wis., said yesterday that it had further expanded its relationship with Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis by naming that agency to handle advertising for its camping division and its Minn Kota line of trolling motors and marine accessories. Those accounts, in which the billings have not been determined, had been handled by Baxter Advertising in Minneapolis. Carmichael Lynch, which handles several Johnson fishing products brands, was awarded the new assignments without a review.

title: Essay;Presidents vs. Press
description: Here is a story of how politicians and the press use one another, then fall out and savage one another, and finally reap the bitter fruit of negative campaigning.

title: Mexico Tries to Restrict Some Foreign Investments
description: After several years of throwing open its economy, Mexico has recently tried to shut some doors to American and other foreign investors, contending that national interests come before trade agreements.

title: Understanding Holocaust, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: A Compromise Is Put Forth To Detail Risk Of Derivatives
description: Companies would have to shed more light on their use of derivatives, the often enigmatic and occasionally risky financial instruments, under a compromise proposal adopted yesterday by the Financial Accounting Standards Board.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Comegys Shot at Turkish Club
description: The former National Basketball Association player DALLAS COMEGYS was reported in stable condition in a Turkish hospital yesterday after being shot outside a nightclub. The incident left another American player, LARRY SPRIGGS, wounded and an unidentified club patron dead.

title: Court Limits Use Of Monitoring
description: New York's highest court ruled yesterday that judges could require criminal offenders to wear electronic monitoring bracelets in only limited circumstances. It urged the State Legislature to step in and pass a law clarifying when the bracelets could be ordered.

title: Sports of The Times;Paul Wilson Can Unpack His Luggage
description: WHEN the Mets prepared to break camp at the end of spring training, the players brought all their suitcases to be shipped home on a truck. Paul Wilson did not bring his belongings, because he was waiting for the official word he had made the team.

title: TENNIS;Lack of U.S. Headliners Poses Threat in Prague
description: The American Davis Cup team, like so many Americans of late, has come to Prague. To the Czechs, that would normally mean a chance to get a close-up look at Pete Sampras or Andre Agassi, Jim Courier or Michael Chang.

title: Art in Review
description: Kcho Barbara Gladstone Gallery 99 Greene Street, near Spring Street SoHo Through April 20

title: No Medicare Gain From Managed Care
description: To the Editor:

title: TV WEEKEND;Moses as an Outsider, and Uncertain
description: Moses is with us once again on celluloid. He was played staunchly by Charlton Heston in "The Ten Commandments" and stolidly by Burt Lancaster in "Moses -- The Lawgiver." Now in "Moses," a two-part movie on TNT, the Old Testament hero gets an intense workout from the always meticulous Ben Kingsley.

title: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: VICTIMS -- A Banker and 3 Others on Ill-FatedMission; Frank A. Maier, Energy Executive, 50
description: Frank A. Maier was president of Enserch International of Dallas, a worldwide developer of natural-gas power plants. He was 50 and lived in Dallas.

title: BASEBALL;Tigers Overcome A's In 15-Inning Slugfest
description: Tigers 10, Athletics 9

title: Moving Bits, Bytes and Books To the Library of the Future;A New Branch Offers Data in Old Forms and New
description: It was, perhaps, the ultimate illustration of style over substance. Just beyond the glitter of the Seventh on Sixth fashion shows in Bryant Park last week, a more mundane operation was trudging ahead, but one likely to affect New York for far longer.

title: Parole Keeps Abuser From Harming Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Signs Farm Bill Ending Subsidies
description: President Clinton signed today a sweeping farm bill that abandons Depression-era subsidy programs in favor of a system offering guaranteed but gradually declining payments over seven years.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-14

title: Strolling About, Shopping And Celebrating Gardens
description: The 22d Macy's Flower Show runs through April 13 at the Herald Square store, at 34th Street in Manhattan. Special activities, many of them for children, are planned daily, with the exception of Easter Sunday when the store is closed. Events, including music, storytelling and face painting, begin at 10 A.M. Monday through Saturday. All events are free. Information: (212) 494-4495. A listing of other spring flower and garden events follows:

title: ON THE SUSPECT'S TRAIL: THE INVESTIGATION;Long and Twisting Trail Led To Unabom Suspect's Arrest
description: The tip came the way the F.B.I. had long expected, from a family member with misgivings. But the search for the man investigators believe is the Unabomber still had months to go before the suspect was arrested on Wednesday, as his deeply torn family struggled with its loyalties and then as an elite team of agents stood vigil for weeks in the Montana snows.

title: Art in Review
description: James Hill Bill Maynes Contemporary Art 225 Lafayette Street, at Spring Street SoHo Through April 13

title: A Legal Star Is Sentenced For Robbing A Dallas Bank
description: At Wednesday's sentencing of a 30-year-old lawyer who had robbed a bank of $1,430, even the judge was puzzled and saddened.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;ALUMINUM CO. OF AMERICA (AA,N)
description: The Aluminum Company of America reported first-quarter results yesterday that exceeded expectations, even though the company's net income fell 8 percent from the comparable period a year earlier.

title: 2 Young Artists Win Segal Awards
description: The Marvin E. Segal Awards have been presented to Nancy Maultsby, a mezzo-soprano, and Michelle Hurst, an actress. The $4,000 prize is awarded annually to two young artists or ensembles, each chosen by one of the constituent organizations of Lincoln Center.

title: Home Video
description: Waiting for Smaller Disks

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Fast Track to a Doctorate
description: Busy school administrators will have an opportunity to receive a doctorate in two years through a new program at Seton Hall University's College of Education and Human Services, officials have announced. The program is to begin in the spring of 1997. Participants will have to fulfill the same requirements as doctoral candidates in traditional programs, which usually take four or five years, James M. Caulfield, an adjunct professor of education, said this week. A group of 30 students will meet for six weekends each year and for four weeks each July, Mr. Caulfield said.

title: Art in Review
description: David Vestal Robert Mann Gallery 42 East 76th Street Manhattan Through April 27

title: Arson at Brooklyn Video Store Injures Girl, 15
description: A fire that was deliberately set at a video store in Brooklyn severely burned a 15-year-old girl yesterday, the police said.

title: ON THE SUSPECT'S TRAIL: THE FAMILY;Brother Who Tipped Off the Authorities Leads a Quiet, Simple Life
description: David R. Kaczynski, the man who tipped off the authorities that his brother might be the Unabomber, shared his brother's passion for isolation from the modern world.

title: Patient Charged in Assault
description: A Bristol man has been charged with sexually assaulting a fellow patient while she slept at Bristol Hospital.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Passover and Good Friday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Ivy League Plans an Audit to Enforce Its Policy Against AthleticScholarships
description: The Ivy League might be best known for its Nobel laureates and Rhodes scholars, but now, as at colleges and universities with less lofty intellectual ambitions, it is the quarterbacks and goalies who have the most help winning financial aid.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;More Shuffling At D.M.B.& B.
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Inc. in New York, continuing its changes in top management, said yesterday that it had named a new president for North American operations and reassigned the chief creative officer of its New York office. Though the agency has been striving to recover from several large account losses in North America, including the Anheuser-Busch and Amoco accounts, executives said the shifts were unrelated to those losses.

title: NYC;Mass Transit Shows Signs Of Slipping
description: PROVING it with figures is difficult -- indeed, the Transit Authority insists it isn't so -- but New York's subway and bus system strikes many riders as fraying at the edges once more after years of an inspired comeback.

title: FILM REVIEW;An Icelandic Road Movie? Button Up
description: If you don't wear a winter coat to Fridrik Thor Fridriksson's gorgeously eerie comedy "Cold Fever," at least bring a scarf. This film about a Japanese yuppie's pilgrimage across Iceland to perform a ritual that will safeguard the peace of his dead parents' souls has more scenes of wind-whipped snow than any other movie in recent memory. By contrast, even "Fargo" looks balmy.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bulgarian Car Maker Decides to Close
description: Rodacar, Bulgaria's sole car maker, said yesterday that it was closing down because of bureaucratic obstacles and a lack of Government support. Rodacar said it would halt production of its Rover Maestro cars in its factory at the Black Sea port of Varna by the end of May, a move that was seen as a blow to Bulgaria's hopes of attracting sorely needed foreign investment.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;GEC-Marconi in Deal With Thomson-CSF
description: GEC-Marconi of Britain agreed yesterday to form a joint venture with Thomson-CSF of France to make sonar systems for ships, submarines, aircraft and minesweepers. The two companies will pool about 3,500 employees into a company with sales of L360 million ($551 million). Regulators must approve the agreement before the transaction is closed. GEC is a unit of the General Electric Company P.L.C..

title: Scientists Seek Explanation For X-Rays Emitted by Comet
description: When Comet Hyakutake streaked close to Earth last week, a German scientific spacecraft made a discovery that has astonished and puzzled astrophysicists. The comet was emitting X-rays in a crescent pattern on its sunward side.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Wolters Invited to U.S. Tryout
description: Connecticut center KARA WOLTERS will be among six players trying for the final spot on the United States Olympic women's team. The six players, all post players, were invited to a tryout at the United States Olympic training center in Colorado Springs starting Sunday. They will work out with the United States national team Monday through Thursday. Wolters, a 6-foot-7-inch junior, is the only college player in the group. The others are 6-8 HEIDI GILLINGHAM, 6-5 SYLVIA CRAWLEY, 6-4 VENUS LACY, 6-3 VAL WHITING and 6-3 SHANDA BERRY.

title: Ex-Nazi Faces Trial in Italy In Cave Killings
description: Paving the way for what could be Europe's last Nazi war crimes trial, an Italian military judge today ordered Erich Priebke, a former SS captain, to stand trial for his involvement in Italy's most dramatic wartime atrocity.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Suddenly, an Overnight Sensation

title: Jobless Claims Fall By 25,000 in Week
description: The number of Americans filing first-time claims for jobless benefits fell by 25,000 last week as workers affected by the strike at the General Motors Corporation returned to their jobs.

title: ON THE SUSPECT'S TRAIL;Text of Agent's Affidavit on His Search of Unabom Suspect's Cabin
description: Following is the affidavit that Donald J. Sachtleben, a special agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, filed in Federal District Court in Helena, Mont., on a search of the cabin of Theodore J. Kaczynski on Wednesday, as transcribed by The New York Times:

title: Jim Reid, Basketball Coach, 48
description: Jim Reid, the men's basketball coach at Georgetown College for the last 23 seasons and this year's National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics coach of the year, died today after a two-year battle with lung cancer. He was 48.

title: Court Backs Restrictions On Revealing Abuse Claims
description: Affirming a decision by a Federal court, New York's highest court said yesterday that the state could not release the names on a registry of suspected child abusers to adoption and foster-care agencies without conducting a thorough inquiry into the accusations against those listed.

title: Understanding Holocaust, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Shoot Two Suspects in Separate Robberies
description: Police officers shot and wounded suspected robbers in separate incidents in Queens and Staten Island Wednesday and yesterday, officials said.

title: Japanese Stocks Higher
description: Stock prices were higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 224.68 points, or 1.05 percent, at 21,695.84. On Thursday, the index rose 6.43 points.

title: COMMUNISTS LOOK TO THE SOVIET ERA IN THEIR PLATFORM
description: In a stark expression of what they hope to achieve if they take back power, Communist members of Parliament have prepared a draft law that calls for heavy state intervention in the economy.

title: Let Elderly in Public Housing Have Pets
description: To the Editor:

title: HOCKEY;Devils Could Be Left Out After Shutout
description: The prospect of the Devils getting a shot at defending the Stanley Cup grew chancier tonight when a goaltender who had never achieved a shutout in the National Hockey League turned away New Jersey time and again in leading the Hartford Whalers to a 1-0 victory before a jeering crowd at Continental Arena.

title: Art in Review
description: Simon Grennan and Christopher Sperandio American Fine Arts 22 Wooster Street, near Grand Street SoHo Through April 13

title: Restaurants
description: Pelago is clearly a labor of love.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROBERT WHITE, a tenor, is used to the sound of applause, the louder the better, but the sound of a siren is something else.

title: For Children
description: 50th Annual Central Park Easter Eggstravaganza Naumburg Bandshell (72d Street and Fifth Avenue) (800) 201-7275 Recommended for all ages Tomorrow

title: Reporter's Notebook;Dole Wants 'Braveheart.' Prudence Says 'Babe.'
description: Senator Bob Dole knew what he wanted the moment he marched through the door of the local video store.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ADVANCED MICRO-CYPRESS SEMICONDUCTOR SETTLEMENT
description: The Cypress Semiconductor Corporation and Advanced Micro Devices Inc. said yesterday that they had settled two patent infringement lawsuits by mutually accepting a cross-licensing agreement. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed. The settlement, which includes patents filed by each company, allows Cypress and Advanced Micro to continue to produce their own products, eliminating the threat of patent lawsuits by the other company. Advanced Micro had filed a suit against Cypress last June about specialty programmable and memory chips. Cypress had filed a suit against Advanced Micro in November.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: To Die For 1995. Columbia Tri-Star. $100.71. Laser disk, $34.95. 107 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MAY IN ACCORD TO BUY STRAWBRIDGE & CLOTHIER
description: The May Department Stores Company signed an agreement yesterday to buy the Philadelphia department store chain Strawbridge & Clothier for about 4.2 million shares. Before the deal was announced, May's shares closed down 37.5 cents, at $47.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, making the deal worth about $200 million. May plans to buy Strawbridge's 13 stores in the Philadelphia area and assume about $280 million of debt and other liabilities. Shares of Strawbridge fell 37.5 cents, to $18.75. May said the Strawbridge stores would become part of its Hecht's unit but would operate under the Strawbridge name. It said some Hecht's stores would take the Strawbridge name.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF DSC COMMUNICATIONS DOWN ON A FORECAST
description: The stock of the DSC Communications Corporation fell yesterday after the company said late Wednesday that it would post first-quarter earnings and sales below Wall Street estimates. DSC, the maker of phone and cable-TV equipment, said that it expected net income of about 10 cents a share on sales of $305 million to $310 million. Wall Street was expecting earnings of 29 cents a share. A year earlier, DSC earned $41.9 million, or 36 cents a share, on sales of $318 million. DSC's shares were down $2.25, to $24.625, in Nasdaq trading of more than 12.2 million shares.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Mobil Takeover Bid For Ampolex Stalls
description: Ampolex Ltd. won a court order yesterday stalling the Mobil Oil Corporation's hostile attempt to buy the Australian oil company. The decision stops Mobil from sending out takeover documents to Ampolex shareholders and could delay the oil company's effort for at least two weeks. It must either revise its documents or appeal the court's decision.

title: Joys of Easter and Passover in Prayer and Song
description: Here is a sampling of Easter and Passover events in Manhattan and Ellis Island this weekend. Unless otherwise noted, events are free.

title: Prison Riots In Sixth Day In Argentina
description: Riots in prisons across Argentina entered their sixth day today as inmates took dozens of hostages, including a judge and three evangelical pastors. Government officials said the rampage involving more than 10,000 prisoners was one of the worst prison rebellions in the country's history.

title: Utilities Rewrite the Rate Card;Small Users Wary as Big Customers Win Discounts
description: Richard Wilde, along with 1.4 million other residential customers of the Consumers Power Company, is seeing his electric rates rise 8.2 percent this year.

title: Newark, Too, Is Seeking a Stadium of Its Own
description: City officials announced a plan today to build a 6,000-seat stadium downtown in an effort to revive minor league baseball in this city, where the Newark Bears drew huge crowds to Ruppert Stadium in the 1930's and 40's.

title: One Eye on Birds, the Other on Politics
description: Silhouetted against an orange setting sun, chevrons upon chevrons of sandhill cranes descend through a darkening sky, settling on river sandbars, blanketing islands and filling the evening air with a primeval cacophony.

title: BASKETBALL;Wooden Award Goes to Camby
description: And the winner is: Marcus Camby. Again.

title: Thi Cau Journal;Vietnam, a Convert, Pursues Capitalism Devoutly
description: Business has never been better at the "bank of the other world," where Tran Van Binh sells stacks of aluminum-foil gold bars, strings of plastic pearls and wads of photocopied $100 bills from his front porch.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;56,000 Reported Driven From Homes in Burundi
description: Fierce ethnic fighting across Burundi has forced some 56,000 people to flee their homes since the beginning of March, the International Committee of the Red Cross said today.

title: Nervous U.S. Executives in China
description: When sabers rattle, so do the nerves of foreign businessmen.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of former Mayor Carl B. Stokes of Cleveland yesterday misstated the date of his death in some editions.It was Wednesday, not Thursday.

title: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: VICTIMS -- A Banker and 3 Others on Ill-FatedMission; Lee Jackson, Banking Representative, 37
description: Lee Jackson was the United States representative on the board of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development,

title: Chairman Resigns At Cray Research
description: Cray Research Inc. said yesterday that J. Phillip Samper had resigned as chairman and chief executive, in the wake of the plan by Silicon Graphics Inc. to acquire Cray.

title: Students in Limbo
description: Thanks to a university system that provides quality education at an affordable price, New York State ranks near the top in terms of the percentage of high school students who go on to college. But the cuts in student aid proposed by the Pataki administration may already be discouraging the poorest students from even applying to college.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Vampire in Brooklyn 1995. Paramount. $99.12. Laser disk, $39.98. 119 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: THE OVERVIEW;Bad Equipment Tied to Crash, Perry Suggests
description: Defense Secretary William J. Perry suggested today that malfunctioning instruments may have caused the crash of an Air Force jet that took the life of Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and at least 32 others in Croatia on Wednesday.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;South Africa Court Rules Against School Bias
description: South Africa's highest court ruled today that public schools cannot discriminate on the basis of language or religion, a pretext that has often been used to exclude black students.

title: A Warning on Lice Drug
description: Parents must be careful not to overuse a prescription drug for treating lice infestations in children because too much could cause neurological damage, the Food and Drug Administration said on Wednesday.

title: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: THE NEIGHBORHOOD;Harlem Remembers the Heart That Never Left
description: In Washington, Ron Brown will be mourned as the master politician who helped propel Bill Clinton to the Presidency, as the savvy salesman who hawked American goods abroad and as the barrier leaper who soared to national prominence as the first black chairman of the Democratic National Committee and as the first black Secretary of Commerce.

title: BASEBALL;Mets Stage A Comedy Of Errors, Then Prevail
description: The Mets, successfully living on the edge in this very young season, talked about character so much after a 10-9 ninth-inning comeback victory over the St. Louis Cardinals yesterday, you would have thought they were gearing up for a presidential campaign.

title: Barney Ewell, 78, Top Sprinter; Won Gold in Postwar Olympics
description: Barney Ewell, who was one of the world's top-ranked sprinters during and after World War II and who won three medals at the age of 30 when the Olympics were revived in 1948, died yesterday in Lancaster General Hospital in Pennsylvania. He was 78 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;St. Martin's Cancels Book On Goebbels
description: Chastened executives of St. Martin's Press this week halted publication of a controversial new book by David Irving after the company was besieged by angry telephone calls about the historical biography that even the company's chairman concluded was "inescapably anti-Semitic."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Viacom Seeks Stake In Italian Broadcaster
description: Mediaset S.p.A. is in talks that could lead to the sale of a piece of the Italian broadcaster to Viacom Inc., the United States film and television company, Mediaset's chairman, Fedele Confalonieri, said yesterday. Mr. Confalonieri would not confirm the size of any stake Mediaset would sell to Viacom. Italian press reports, citing unidentified sources at Viacom in Los Angeles, said it was interested in acquiring 5 percent.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Ingredients of Artistic Immortality
description: CULTURAL SELECTION By Gary Taylor 325 pages. Basic Books. $26.

title: The Spoken Word
description: "WORD WARS," New York Public Library, Jefferson Market Branch, 425 Avenue of the Americas, at 10th Street, Greenwich Village. An open mike for youngsters, 12 to 18 years old. Some poems will be published in a library booklet. Today and the next two Fridays at 4 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 243-4334.

title: POP REVIEW;On Saxophone: Feel the Heat
description: If the young alto saxophonist Abraham Burton was ever to be drawn in a cartoon, he'd have flames coming out of his saxophone. Mr. Burton is all brash youth, an explosive soloist whose burly, muscular playing is stripped of nuance and dedicated to the heat of improvisation.

title: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: THE SCENE;14 Bodies Are Airlifted To Makeshift Morgue
description: The body believed to be that of Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, along with 13 others from the wreckage of the plane that slammed into a rocky hillside here, was transported tonight by helicopter to a makeshift morgue set up at the airport in Dubrovnik by the United States Army.

title: New York Official Lobbied for Agency Seeking City Business
description: Last April, when a Queens social-services organization was trying to win a multimillion-dollar contract with the city, it sent an unusual salesman to the city agency that was evaluating competing bids. The salesman, it turned out, was a city official himself.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;Life, Lust and Unemployment
description: Jenny, the heroine of the starkly realistic "Work," lives on the borderline of just about everything. In her mid-20's, she is semi-rural and semi-poor. Pale and blonde, she is married to a man but having an affair with the young, black, college-bound woman next door.

title: Study Recommends The Yankees Move To a West Side Site
description: A consulting firm's recommendation that the Yankees move from the Bronx to the West Side of Manhattan was based on the conclusion that a new ball park along the Hudson River would produce a significant increase in attendance, higher prices for luxury seats and an enhanced image for New York City.

title: Metallgesellschaft Reports Talks With Ex-Chief Fail
description: Metallgesellschaft A.G. said today that it had held talks on a settlement with a former chief executive who was ousted after a unit racked up $1.3 billion in trading losses.

title: No Medicare Gain From Managed Care;H.I.P. Backlog
description: To the Editor:

title: Peabody Awards to CBS and Oklahoma Stations
description: CBS News and three Oklahoma City television stations were among the 33 television and radio organizations honored yesterday with a George Foster Peabody Award.

title: British Study Says Brain Patients Had Psychiatric Symptoms
description: Many of the 10 British patients afflicted with a new variant of a fatal brain disease possibly linked to mad cow disease had behavioral and emotional changes that initially fooled doctors into thinking they had psychiatric disorders, according to the first published scientific report about the cases.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Russian Communists Invoke Soviet Era in Their Platform In Russia Communist members of Parliament have prepared a draft law calling for heavy state intervention in the economy. Like the Bolsheviks 70 years ago, the Communists, if returned to power, favor guaranteed employment, cheap apartments and controls on the price of consumer goods.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Angels' Smith Joins the D.L.
description: California Angels reliever LEE SMITH was placed on the 15-day disabled list yesterday with swelling of the right knee. The team's physician, LEWIS YOCUM, drained fluid from Smith's knee during an exam yesterday. To replace Smith on the roster, the Angels will buy the contract of right-hander DENNIS SPRINGER from Class AAA Vancouver, the assistant general manager TIM MEAD said. Smith, 38, underwent surgery Nov. 12 to repair a rupture of the padella tendon in the right knee injured when he slipped during a hunting trip. (AP)

title: Boost the Minimum Wage
description: There is a strong case for raising the minimum wage by a modest amount. Unfortunately, the issue is caught up in election-year politics, making compromise unlikely. Senate Democrats rounded up 55 members last week to force a vote on it, but they needed 60 votes so the effort failed. Few Democrats shed tears, since they could pin the defeat on the majority leader, Bob Dole.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Russia Seeks to Limit An Arms Control Accord
description: The first steps in executing a new international agreement to control trade in conventional weapons have been slowed by Russia, which wants to limit the agreement.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Gains Cited in Camden Patrol
description: State troopers assigned to patrol dangerous neighborhoods in Camden said yesterday that their three-month effort was a success, The Associated Press reported. The police have made 1,069 arrests and have confiscated 86 weapons and 74 stolen cars, said Col. Carl A. Williams, the state police superintendent. Last year, 60 people were killed in Camden. So far this year, the city has recorded five homicides.

title: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: THE ISSUES;Plane Crash in Croatia Silenced A Big Player in Capital Debates
description: When Ronald H. Brown died on a hillside near Dubrovnik, Croatia, on Wednesday, he was in the thick of three battles here that touched the divergent roles he played in Washington.

title: 25 and Under
description: The team of Jean-Claude Iacovelli, the impresario of inexpensive restaurants, and William Prunty, the chef, has struck again. First came Jean-Claude, the little slice of Paris on Sullivan Street, serving inventive bistro fare. Then Caffe Lure, on the other side of Houston Street, where the accent is on seafood. Now comes SoHo Steak, a thoroughly Gallic little restaurant that emphasizes meat but that is no simple steakhouse.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Innocent 1993. Miramax. $100.71. 119 minutes. Closed captioned. R.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Lang Communications in Steps To Survive Under Its Debt Load
description: Dale Lang, chairman of Lang Communications, which publishes Working Woman, Working Mother and Ms. magazines, has spent this week looking for a way to save his financially ailing magazine company.

title: Exchanges Staying Put: First Coffee, Now Cotton
description: In the climax of months of negotiation and an intense rivalry with New Jersey, New York City officials announced yesterday that the Cotton Exchange had agreed to remain in New York.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Mrs. Hart, the recipient of the Handel Medallion, could probably sing the arias herself were she so inclined. She stepped down on Monday as chairwoman of the the New York State Council on the Arts, but has taken up an old career, singing on stage, or, as she put it yesterday, "I'm going back to my night job."

title: A Hard Line In Mideast Gets Harder
description: When the luncheon conversation at Syria's Presidential palace turned to the subject of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the American guest and his Syrian host could not have disagreed more sharply.

title: A Gritty, Ragtag Feminist Too Far Out for Warhol
description: Life in this society being, at best, an utter bore and no aspect of society being at all relevant to women, there remains to civic-minded, responsible, thrill-seeking females only to overthrow the government, eliminate the money system, institute complete automation and destroy the male sex."

title: Real Estate;A warehouse nearly destroyed by fire is rising again as a luxury apartment building in TriBeCa.
description: NEARLY destroyed by fire in 1992, a six-story warehouse in TriBeCa sat charred and vacant for a year and a half. Now it and a smaller adjacent warehouse are being reborn as a luxury condominium.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Overly Fond of Food and Doris Day, for Starters
description: It's all so sad, so painfully familiar and yet so inspiring, the story told by the performance artist Dutch Van Dyke, who can be seen at the Joseph Papp Public Theater these days, in "Nude Nude Totally Nude," a one-woman show by Andrea Martin.

title: Pentagon Spy Agency Bares Some Dusty Secret Papers
description: The National Security Agency, the Pentagon spy service that eavesdrops on global communications, said today that it had declassified more than 1.3 million pages of secret documents, some from before World War I.

title: CRASH IN THE BALKANS;Passengers and Crew
description: Following is the State Department manifest for the United States Air Force plane that crashed on Wednesday near Dubrovnik, Croatia. Entries include place of residence, where available. ALDRICH, Staff Sgt. Gerald, flight mechanic

title: CHRONICLE
description: Former Gov. HUGH L. CAREY, who appointed Mrs. Hart to head the council in 1976, has by contrast never stopped singing since he was at his mother's knee. Mr. Carey, who recently acquired Frank Sinatra's Bosendorfer, is studying piano, the better to be able to accompany himself. "I don't see any accompanist who will hang out with me," he said yesterday. So far, he has taken three lessons with KATHLEEN LANDIS, who performs at the Cafe Pierre of the Hotel Pierre.

title: Explosion In Oregon Indicates Arms Cache
description: Three explosions ripped apart a burning storage shed in a rural area along the Columbia River on Wednesday, sending charred bomb-making literature drifting to the ground, the authorities said.

title: How to Win the War Against Crime
description: Since I became commissioner in 1994, the New York Police Department has been engaged in a full-scale attack on crime. Reported crime continued to decline in the first quarter of 1996 -- 33 percent since 1993. Homicides are down 49 percent.

title: Understanding Holocaust, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;Two agencies are combining in the Southeast, where strong independent shops remain few.
description: TWO relatively small but well-regarded agencies are joining forces to form the biggest independent shop in the Southeast, in a move that is indicative of the consolidations that are remaking the advertising industry to meet changing client needs.

title: Albany Panel Rules Against Two Judges
description: A judicial conduct commission recommended today that an Erie County village justice be removed from office for mishandling funds and that an Ulster County judge be admonished.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Science Times on Tuesday about anacondas in Venezuela carried an incorrect credit. The photographer was Maria Munoz.

title: Corrections
description: Articles yesterday about the airplane crash in Croatia referred incompletely to the death of Nathaniel C. Nash, Frankfurt bureau chief of The New York Times. While he was the first Times correspondent killed on assignment since World War II, a Washington correspondent died in 1949 en route from one. That correspondent, Bertram D. Hulen, was flying from Indonesia to the Netherlands after an inspection tour sponsored by the Dutch Government. The airplane crashed near Bombay.

title: No Headline
description: There is a fascinating paradox in northern Vietnam. You see an urge to recover the past, or the imagined past -- to return to traditions -- at the same time as Vietnam is trying to join modern society." -- PROFESSOR HO HUE TAM-TAI of Harvard. [A4:4.]

title: Inside Art
description: Schiele vs. Restorers

title: BASKETBALL;It's Difficult for Van Gundy To Hide Disappointment
description: The Chicago Bulls are not worried about the Knicks. Neither is the Orlando Magic. However, the Knicks are worried about themselves.

title: Library Honors Writer
description: Tina Rosenberg has received the 1996 New York Public Library Helen Bernstein Award for her book "The Haunted Land: Facing Europe's Ghosts After Communism" (Random House). The $15,000 award is given annually to a writer whose work has heightened public awareness of significant current events, policy issues or social trends. In her book, Ms. Rosenberg examines Germany, Poland and the Czech and Slovak Republics as they attempt to deal with their Communist past. Ms. Rosenberg is also the author of "Children of Cain: Violence and the Violent in Latin America."

title: Abroad at Home;For Public Service
description: When Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown died in the plane crash near Dubrovnik, he was on what even the meanest political critic would have to call a mission of public service. He was trying to involve American businessmen in the reconstruction of Bosnia after its suffering under genocidal assault.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NUTRITION FOR LIFE SHARES FALL ON S.E.C. INQUIRY
description: Nutrition For Life International said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating the way the company distributes its wide range of health products. The company's stock fell $4, or 17 percent, to $19, in Nasdaq trading. The inquiry seems to be focused on the company's "executive-level distributor program," it said. The company develops health products like nutritional supplements and weight-management systems distributed through independent contractors. A distributor may become what the company calls an executive by generating sales volume of $1,000 to $1,500 through his organization. Executive status entitles a distributor to earn commissions on sales generated by other distributors in his organization.

title: Assisted Suicide Poses Threat to Society
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Granada Sets Price For White Hart Sale
description: Granada Group P.L.C., which said last month that it intended to sell 60 White Hart hotels to Regal Hotels Group P.L.C., set the price for the sale at L121.7 million ($185 million) in cash. That is above the price that Regal was planning to pay for the chain in January when it was owned by Forte P.L.C., Britain's largest hotelier. Granada acquired Forte earlier this year in a L3.9 billion takeover.

title: P.& G. Setback In Fraud Case
description: The Procter & Gamble Company must first prove its own investment fraud case against the Bankers Trust Company before trying to demonstrate that the bank has a history of misleading sales practices, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: INSIDE
description: Pact on Drug Prices Blocked

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Reckitt & Colman Sells a U.S. Unit
description: Reckitt & Colman P.L.C., a British household goods maker, said yesterday that it had sold its United States personal products division to J. W. Childs Associates L.P. for $123 million to concentrate on its main business of household products. Reckitt & Colman, based in London, which makes Lysol disinfectant and Woolite fabric wash, said it would receive $108 million in cash and a loan note, payable in seven and a half years, for the remainder.

title: Glitz Isn't Everything, as a U.K. Film Studio Boss Can Verify
description: SHEPPERTON, England  Running a movie studio just ain't what it used to be.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BORG-WARNER SEES LOWER QUARTERLY EARNINGS
description: Borg-Warner Automotive Inc. said yesterday that it expected to post first-quarter earnings that are about 30 percent lower than the 75 cents a share reported for the corresponding period last year. The company said the General Motors Corporation strike and disappointing results in its North American transmission business contributed to the lower profit. G.M. is the company's second-largest customer, accounting for 25 percent of its 1995 sales of $1.33 billion. The company had been expected to report earnings of 73 cents a share. Despite the announcement, Borg-Warner's shares rose 37.5 cents, to $35.50, in New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday.

title: Art in Review
description: Kara Walker Wooster Gardens 558 Broadway, near Prince Street SoHo Through April 13

title: Rapper Is Sentenced To 120 Days in Jail
description: The rapper Tupac Shakur was sentenced today to 120 days in jail for violating probation on his assault and battery conviction in attacking a music video producer.

title: COLLEGE LACROSSE REPORT
description: Top Ten

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Supreme Court Considers Antitrust Case Against N.F.L.
description: An obscure issue of antitrust law that was argued before the Supreme Court last week on behalf of the N.F.L. Players Association could shape labor relations not only in professional football but also in other professional sports and beyond -- anywhere where a relatively small group of employers, who in most other respects are competitors, get together to offer contract terms to their employees.

title: Apple Agrees to Sell a Big Macintosh Plant
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it had agreed to sell its manufacturing plant in Fountain, Colo., to SCI Systems Inc. for an undisclosed amount. SCI, a major contract electronic manufacturer based in Huntsville, Ala., will produce Apple products at the plant.

title: TENNIS;Casals Elected To Tennis Hall
description: Rosie Casals, who earned 12 Grand Slam doubles titles, and the late Dan Maskell, a British champion and longtime BBC commentator known for 40 years as "the voice of Wimbledon," were announced yesterday as the newest inductees into the International Tennis Hall of Fame. The induction ceremony will be July 14 at the organization's headquarters in Newport, R.I., and brings its membership to 165.

title: Executive Changes
description: FIRST UNION MORTGAGE CORP., Charlotte, N.C., a unit of First Union Corp., named John M. Church senior vice president and manager of the commercial mortgage servicing unit. Mr. Church is a former senior manager at GE Capital Asset Management Corp.

title: ON THE SUSPECT'S TRAIL: THE OVERVIEW;Suspect Arraigned on One Bomb Count
description: Theodore J. Kaczynski, the onetime university professor taken into custody on Wednesday as a suspect in the Unabom case, was arraigned here today on a single felony charge of possessing bomb components and was held without bail.

title: BASEBALL;Rainout Puts Rogers In the Bullpen Again
description: The swirling wind, the torrential rain and the seemingly endless delay at Jacobs Field were obvious indicators that today's series finale between the Yankees and Indians would be called off. To Kenny Rogers, the inclement weather was an indication that adjustments in the starting rotation would be necessary and that he would be switched to the bullpen again. Not to worry, this time.

title: A Supervisor Pleads Guilty In Daiwa Case
description: Masahiro Tsuda, the former general manager of the New York branch of Daiwa Bank Ltd., pleaded guilty yesterday to a charge that he had helped to conceal $1.1 billion in trading losses at the bank from Federal authorities last summer.

title: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: VICTIMS -- A Banker and 3 Others on Ill-FatedMission; David L. Ford, Glass Executive, 43
description: David L. Ford was president and chief executive of Interguard, a subsidiary of Guardian Industries Corporation that runs glass-making plants in Europe and the Middle East. He was also the director of sales for another unit of the company, Guardian Europe. He was 43 and lived in Luxembourg.

title: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: THE BOARDROOMS;In Mourning, Companies Confront Future
description: Late Wednesday afternoon, Barbara Allbritton, the wife of the chairman of Riggs National Bank, flew from New York to Washington, where the bank is based, with the parents of Paul Cushman 3d, head of the bank's international banking operation.

title: Hillary Clinton Visits With Protesting Nun
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton met today with an American nun who was kidnapped and raped in Guatemala in 1989 and has been protesting outside the White House since Sunday in an effort to see Government files relating to her case and to other human-rights abuses.

title: Diner's Journal
description: By now the smell of paint may have disappeared. But last week, Butterfield 81 was still so new that it smelled overwhelmingly of paint.

title: ART REVIEW;A Moralist's Landscapes With a Hint of Danger
description: Paradise, they say, is where you make it, and the American artist Ellis Ruley (1882-1959) established his on several acres of land around his home on the outskirts of Norwich, a town in northeastern Connecticut.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Report on Child Abuse
description: More than 9,500 New Jersey children suffered child abuse or neglect in 1994, according to a report released this week by the United States Department of Health and Human Services. The caseload in New Jersey has remained generally constant since 1990, but instances of abuse have become more serious because of increased drug use, according to the research bureau of the New Jersey Division of Youth and Family Services.

title: Medical Examiner Finds Shaking Killed Queens Baby
description: The New York City Medical Examiner said yesterday that violent shaking had caused fatal brain injuries in a 5-month-old Queens baby, Mariah Scoon, whose parents fought to keep her on a ventilator after she had been declared brain-dead.

title: Day of Barbs and Smirks in a Whitewater Trial
description: Beginning their cross-examination of the prosecution's star witness in the Whitewater-related loan fraud trial here, defense lawyers today drew forth admissions that the witness concocted other self-enrichment schemes like those involved in the charges, well before and after the association he said he had had with the defendants.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: FILM REVIEW;If a Guest Is Too Right Wing, He Soon Becomes Fertilizer
description: In "The Last Supper," five hateful liberals hold court at their dinner table, baiting a parade of conservative guests who have been invited only on account of their benighted views.

title: Archer Selecting More Outsiders
description: The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company will nominate at least two outsiders to its board in its September proxy material, company executives told major shareholders this week.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CHAMPION ENTERPRISES INC., Auburn Hills, Mich., a manufactured housing company, said it had acquired Grand Manor Inc., Thomasville, Ga., and that it had a definitive agreement to buy Homes of Legend Inc., Boaz, Ala., at a cost of $33 million for both acquisitions.

title: TV SPORTS;Fox Baseball Coverage Is Sure to Include Some Curveballs
description: Fox's buildup to starting its five-year, $575 million baseball television contract mimics what it did for football and hockey: a blizzard of advertising, the hiring of many new faces to announce the games and the promise of innovation.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Blooms at Farmers' Market
description: Local farmers who have Easter flowers, bulbs and early perennials for sale will be the first to offer their products tomorrow at the new farmers' markets at the Molly Pitcher and James Fenimore Cooper service areas of the New Jersey Turnpike. The markets were organized by the State Department of Agriculture. By midsummer, 15 farmers are expected to take part on a rotating basis at each market, John Specca, a Mount Holly farmer, said yesterday. Until mid-May, the markets will be open on weekends, and after that, they will be open every day. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Dr. Vozcan L. Parsegian, 87, Nuclear Engineer and Historian
description: Dr. Vozcan Lawrence Parsegian, a retired nuclear engineer, the first dean of engineering at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and a chronicler of Armenian architecture throughout history, died on Tuesday at Samaritan Hospital in Troy, N.Y. He was 87 and lived in Troy.

title: Northwest Airlines Cuts Summer Fares
description: The Northwest Airlines Corporation has cut its North American fares by up to 50 percent through April 12 for travel between May 1 and Sept. 9.

title: Union Accepts 5-Year Deal With New York
description: The union representing 1,000 New York City probation officers has agreed to a five-year contract that calls for no layoffs for three years and no wage increases for the first two years, city officials announced yesterday. In the last three years of the contract, workers would receive a 13 percent wage increase, the officials said.

title: U.S. 500 Trophy Has Long History
description: The U.S. 500, the race being run the same day as the Indianapolis 500 by disgruntled Indy-car owners, may not have the traditions and prestige of the Indy 500. But the trophy that will be awarded to the U.S. 500 winner on May 26 certainly has the longer history of race trophies.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * La Casera, Madrid, to Grey Madrid, a unit of Grey Advertising, to handle advertising for the carbonated beverage company, previously handled by Lowe RZR, Madrid, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos. Billings were estimated at $8 million.

title: City Official Helped Group Win Contract
description: Last April, when a Queens social-services organization was trying to gain a multimillion-dollar contract with the city, it sent an unusual salesman to the city agency that was evaluating competing bids.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AFTER EARNINGS WARNING, HYPERION SHARES TUMBLE
description: Shares of the Hyperion Software Corporation plunged yesterday, a day after the company warned of disappointing earnings. The stock tumbled $7.375, or almost 40 percent, to $11.125, in Nasdaq trading of 8.9 million shares. Hyperion, which specializes in financial management software, said late Wednesday that it expected earnings for its third quarter of about 2 cents a share. Among other things, sales were hurt by delays in closings of some sales contracts.

title: HOCKEY;Feisty Flyers Hammer Rangers
description: Before he left the game with a rib injury, Mark Messier was involved in a frantic fistfight. It ended with the Ranger captain without a shirt and shouting and throwing pieces of his equipment at the nearest Philadelphia Flyer players.

title: TRACK AND FIELD;Running and Winning Race Against Anorexia
description: With every stride, Kate Landau, a sophomore runner at Georgetown University, feels a rebirth. With every race, she feels closer to the athlete whose potential seemed unlimited at age 15 when she was rated the No. 1 high school distance runner in the nation.

title: DESIGN REVIEW;Nature and Artifice in Bloom
description: MOVE over, Central Park. The Macy's Flower Show is back in town. For two weeks each year, the world's biggest store is home to New York's most fantastic park: a colorful hybrid of commerce and nature in full and fragrant bloom. For those too old for Santa, the Flower Show is the true miracle on 34th Street. Occupying the grand ground-floor space in Macy's flagship store on Herald Square, the Flower Show, which opened this week and continues through April 13, is one of the great seasonal landmarks of New York City. Like the Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center, or Times Square on New Year's Eve, the Flower Show proves that the city's vitality depends as much on transient events as on the buildings around them.

title: Market Closings
description: The stock and commodity markets in the United States are closed today in observance of Good Friday, but there is limited trading in bonds and currencies. Financial markets in many other countries are also closed.

title: Drug Makers' Settlement Is Blocked
description: A Federal judge today threw out an agreement by 15 drug makers to pay $408.9 million to settle a class-action lawsuit that contends they conspired to fix prices charged to retail pharmacies.

title: Chief Resigns MK Rail Posts
description: The MK Rail Corporation said this week that Michael J. Farrell had resigned as president and chief executive.

title: Protecting Older Workers
description: With clear logic and rare unanimity, the Supreme Court moved this week to strengthen the Federal law that bars employers from discriminating against a worker on account of age. The ruling is all the more refreshing coming from the pen of Justice Antonin Scalia, whose sharp prose is usually reserved for arguments that would weaken civil rights protections.

title: Why a Good Seat Is Hard to Find
description: AUDREY COUGHLAN, a veteran theatergoer from Ardsley, N.Y., was determined to beat the crowds to "The King and I." So last Nov. 4, five months before the musical revival was to open on Broadway, she dialed Ticketmaster, looking for a few good seats.

title: Venezuelan Financiers Indicted in New York
description: Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, said yesterday that a grand jury had returned indictments charging Orlando Castro Llanes, a well-known Venezuelan financier; his son, Orlando Castro Castro, and his grandson, Jorge Castro Barredo, with a scheme to defraud depositors of more than $55 million at Banco Progreso Internacional de Puerto Rico.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Iraqi Aide Casts Doubt On Accord on Oil Sales
description: A top Iraqi official says important differences remain with the United Nations over negotiating an oil-for-food plan, raising doubts about whether a deal can be struck when the talks resume next week.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BOSTON SCIENTIFIC UNIT IS SUED FOR PATENT INFRINGEMENT
description: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that it had filed a patent suit against the Boston Scientific Corporation's Scimed unit for infringement on technology used to install mechanical heart stents. The suit, filed in a Minneapolis court, relates to materials used in balloons made by Scimed for its Bandit brand balloon catheter. Johnson & Johnson said Scimed was infringing five of its patents. In balloon angioplasty, a catheter is snaked through blood vessels until it reaches a clog. At that point, the balloon is inflated to break up and push back the plaque that causes clogs. Such clogs can lead to heart attacks. Boston Scientific shares fell 87.5 cents, to $45.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: ON THE SUSPECT'S TRAIL: LIFE IN MONTANA;Gardening, Bicycling And Reading Exotically
description: The simple, back-to-nature life of the man the Federal authorities believe is the technology-hating Unabomber was plagued by rabbits and deer. They ate his carefully tended organic garden.

title: BASKETBALL;The Search at St. John's Reaching Final Stages
description: The St. John's athletic director, Ed Manetta, said yesterday that the process of selecting a head basketball coach was "moving along." His timetable may be delayed, however, because of the death of the Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, a St. John's alumnus who was a close friend of the university's president, the Rev. Donald Harrington.

title: Yet Another Shift in Mayor's Circle: Deputy Mayor for Finance Leaves
description: Further consolidating his inner circle of trusted aides in top jobs, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that John S. Dyson would step down as Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development and would be replaced by Fran Reiter, a political confidante.

title: Dow Retreats to 5,682.88 In Listless Trading Session
description: In a listless session that ended a holiday-shortened trading week, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 6.86 points from Wednesday's record, to 5,682.88, a close that left it with a surge of 1.7 percent, or 95.74 points, for the week.

title: Burst Main Points to a Wider Pipe Problem
description: A huge water main break in Astoria, Queens, in January was caused by defective pipe, city officials said yesterday, and tests show that the problem extends far beyond the intersection where the main burst. A significant part of the 8,900-foot-long pipe is of equally poor quality, the officials said, and would have to be replaced or repaired at a possible cost of several million dollars.

title: Art in Review
description: Group Show Kaikodo Gallery 164 East 64th Street Manhattan Through April 20

title: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: VICTIMS -- A Banker and 3 Others on Ill-FatedMission; John A. Scoville, Engineering Executive, 64
description: John A. Scoville was chairman of the Harza Companies, a privately held international consulting and engineering firm based in Chicago. He was 64 and lived in Wilmette, Ill.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;A Deal With the Teamsters
description: More than 70 percent of the dealers at Tropworld Casino and Entertainment Resort have signed cards asking to be represented by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, according to officials of the union. If they succeed, they would be the only dealers in the country with union representation, the A.P. reported yesterday. Starting pay for dealers at Tropworld begins at $4 an hour, only 25 cents more than it was in 1981.

title: North Korea Says It Will Cease Respecting Demilitarized Zone
description: North Korea announced today that it would no longer respect the demilitarized zone between the two Koreas, and President Kim Young Sam of South Korea responded by warning Pyongyang against "reckless provocation."

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Oil Prices Rise on Signs That Iraq Isn't Close to Accord With U.N.
description: Crude oil prices rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday on signs that Iraq and the United Nations were far apart on an agreement to allow limited sales of oil.

title: Critic's Choice/Film;Love and a Wistful Song
description: Boy meets girl. Boy loses girl. Boy and girl sing wistful theme song you can't possibly get out of your head. There is no cinematic bauble to match "The Umbrellas of Cherbourg," Jacques Demy's sugar-coated 1964 musical starring a radiant, exquisite 20-year-old Catherine Deneuve as the heroine who is steered by her mother and tearfully betrayed by amour. Mr. Demy's film remains an incredible oddity, from its blazing, audacious color to the fact that its sunny lyrics mention hand grenades and cars needing an oil change. The film, every word, is lip-synched to Michel Legrand's soothing warm bath of a score.

title: DESIGN REVIEW;Where Eyes Meet Skin, and What Comes Between
description: Clothes reveal, clothes conceal. It was ever thus, or almost, as suggested by the latest curatorial effort of Richard Martin and Harold Koda, curator and associate curator, respectively, of the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Bare Witness: Clothing and Nudity" considers more than 200 years of mostly French and American fashion from the vantage point of how much flesh is exposed, and where.

title: ON THE SUSPECT'S TRAIL: THE SUSPECT;Memories of His Brilliance, And Shyness, but Little Else
description: Nearly 30 years later, the young assistant professor still sticks in the minds of colleagues who heard him at a mathematics seminar in Berkeley -- not for what he said, but for how he behaved.

title: Assisted Suicide Poses Threat to Society
description: To the Editor:

title: Utility Entering A New Business
description: The Central and South West Corporation won approval today from the Federal Communications Commission to be the first electric utility to enter the telecommunications business under the new telecommunications law.

title: Deal for Newspaper Sales
description: The American Publishing Company, a unit of Hollinger International Inc., has agreed to buy The Tribune-Democrat in Johnstown, Pa., a 47,000 circulation daily, from Garden State Newspapers. At the same time, American Publishing will sell several of its daily and weekly papers to Garden State. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. The Hollinger dailies being sold to Garden State are The North Adams Transcript in North Adams, Mass.; The Bridgeton Evening News in Bridgeton, N.J.; The Sterling Journal Advocate, The Fort Morgan Times and The Lamar Daily News, all in Colorado; and The Sidney Telegraph, in Sidney, Neb.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: India's Prime Minister Wages Uphill Campaign
description: When Prime Minister P.V. Narasimha Rao opened his campaign to win the support of India's 590 million eligible voters, he began with what many political consultants might consider a gaffe: He apologized for not being somebody else.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Balto 1995. MCA/Universal. $19.98. 78 minutes. Closed captioned. G.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Cadbury Schweppes To Buy Candy Maker
description: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. said yesterday that a subsidiary had agreed to buy the British popcorn and candy maker Craven Keiller Ltd. No purchase price was released for the deal. Craven Keiller's products include toffees, popcorn and chocolates under the brand names Keiller, Barker and Dobson and Craven and Butterkist.

title: Market Place;Emerging markets have begun a comeback from a poor 1995.
description: THE world's emerging stock markets performed a sharp turnaround in the first quarter of this year, while developed stock markets rose at a modest pace when compared with last year.

title: Lucent Opens With a Bang, Jumping 13%
description: The AT&T Corporation took a giant step yesterday toward splitting itself into three companies, rolling out the biggest initial stock offering in history for its $21 billion equipment subsidiary, Lucent Technologies Inc.

title: Texas Agrees to Surgery for a Molester
description: Larry Don McQuay describes himself as "scum of the earth" and claims to have molested young children at least 240 times.

title: Art in Review
description: Jacques Lipchitz 'The Paris Years' Marlborough Gallery 40 West 57th Street Manhattan Through April 13

title: A 3d Connecticut Reactor Is Cited for Design Flaws
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today it has found design deficiencies at the Millstone 3 nuclear power plant in Connecticut, a finding that comes less than a month after it ordered the other two Millstone plants to stay shut until their safety could be assured.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BETHLEHEM STEEL RAISES PRICES TO MATCH COMPETITORS'
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would raise sheet-steel prices by 3 to 5 percent on June 30, matching price increases earlier this week by other steelmakers. The nation's second-largest steel producer raised prices by $15 a ton on hot-rolled sheet steel, $25 a ton on cold-rolled sheet and $35 a ton on coated sheet. Sheet steel is used in a range of products, from automobiles and construction to appliances and garbage cans. The company also said it would raise the price of strip-mill plates by $15 a ton. The USX Corporation's USX-U.S. Steel Group, the nation's largest steelmaker, and AK Steel Holding Corporation announced sheet-steel price increases on Tuesday, and the LTV Corporation matched those prices on Wednesday.

title: Sex Charge for Laureate
description: A Nobel prize-winning scientist at the National Institutes of Health was arrested today on charges of sexually abusing a 15-year-old boy he had brought to the United States from Micronesia, the F.B.I. said.

title: The Nuclear Stockpile America Needs
description: April 26 will mark the 10th anniversary of the explosion at the Chernobyl nuclear plant near Kiev, Ukraine, which sent a radioactive cloud into the atmosphere of Eastern Europe.

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Boniol Signs With the Cowboys
description: The Dallas Cowboys signed the record-setting kicker CHRIS BONIOL yesterday. Terms of the deal weren't released.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Tax Relief for the Elderly
description: Republican lawmakers have introduced a bill that would allow towns to give elderly people and low-income residents a chance to offset property taxes by performing government work. Under the measure, residents would receive vouchers to defray their property tax bills in exchange for taking jobs that become available through resignations or retirements.

title: On My Mind;Believing the Dictators
description: The advantage a democracy has in dealing with dictatorships is that they signal clearly what they intend to do to their victims and enemies. There's just one problem: The democracies keep convincing themselves that the dictators don't really mean it.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Of Monkeys, Reason And the Creation
description: AT long last Tony Randall's National Actors Theater has a production that deserves to be a hit. It's John Tillinger's crisp, handsome, very entertaining revival of Jerome Lawrence and Robert E. Lee's "Inherit the Wind," which opened last night at the Royale Theater with George C. Scott and Charles Durning in the seductively actable leading roles.

title: United Asset to Buy Currency-Trading Firm
description: The United Asset Management Corporation said this week that it would buy OSV Partners, a firm specializing in currency risk management.

title: Art in Review
description: Amy Sillman Casey M. Kaplan 580 Broadway, at Prince Street SoHo Through April 20

title: COMPANY NEWS;GENERAL MAGIC SHARES FALL AS PARTNERS RETHINK PLANS
description: Shares of General Magic Inc. fell 18 percent yesterday, a day after the company disclosed that two of its partners might be pulling back some business. General Magic said that the Sony Corporation had suspended plans to make another hand-held computer based on the company's operating system and that the AT&T Corporation might torpedo its Personalink on-line service carrying the company's Telescript software. Analysts said the pullbacks could undermine the company's ability to grow. General Magic went public a year ago amid much fanfare for its Magic Cap operating system for hand-held computers and its Telescript software for searching in cyberspace. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of General Magic fell $1, to $4.50.

title: Molson Chief Set to Retire
description: The Molson Companies, the Canadian brewing giant, said today that its president and chief executive, Marshall Cohen, plans to retire later this year.

title: How Marco Polo Missed China's Charms
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Gymnasts Flip and Fall for Each Other
description: They first kissed in 1976. She was 14. He was 18. Neither felt a flicker of feeling. To her, he was yet another little blond guy on the circuit. To him, she was a marvelously focused child. The kiss itself was just a photo op. Each had won a silver cup at a Madison Square Garden tuneup for the Montreal Olympics, where she would become a legend, the first perfect princess of gymnastics.

title: Mad Cows and Europe
description: The furore in Britain over mad cow disease -- and its possible link to a rare but similar brain affliction in humans -- has left Britain's $6 billion cattle industry in a shambles. The crisis also gave Britain's neighbors in the European Union a chance to rally constructively behind a shell-shocked neighbor. The Union flunked the test.

title: Art in Review
description: Bill Jensen 'Recent Drawings' Joan T. Washburn 20 West 57th Street Manhattan Through April 13

title: Assisted Suicide Poses Threat to Society
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF NOWSCO RISE ON A TAKEOVER PROPOSAL
description: The stock of Nowsco Well Service Ltd. soared yesterday, a day after the international oilfield service company said the BJ Services Company made a takeover bid worth $27 (Canadian), or $19.88 (United States), a share in cash. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Nowsco rose $6.125, or 39 percent, to $21.50, and in New York Stock Exchange trading, shares of BJ rose $4.125, to $37.375. Nowsco, which is based in Calgary, Alberta, operates in major oil and gas producing regions of the world. BJ said it would meet with Nowsco's board next week to present the acquisition plan and discuss opportunities that would be available to the combined companies. BJ provides oil and gas pressure-pumping and related services to the petroleum industry.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Vote on School Unit's Future
description: A newly formed coalition of parents and other residents in Union County is advocating a "yes" vote to dissolve the state's first regional high school district when the issue goes before voters on May 14. Parents in the district's wealthier towns -- Berkeley Heights, Kenilworth, Springfield and Mountainside -- said that since their property tax base determines their share of the cost, they are forced to pay $16,000 for each high school student.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Women's Coach Resigns
description: PEGGY SELLS, under fire for being abusive to her players, resigned yesterday as Virginia Commonwealth's women's basketball coach after one season on the job.

title: Court Rejects Review In a Bribery Case
description: Federal prosecutors today lost their attempt to have a court review the overturned bribery conviction of the the former Republican Party chairman in Connecticut, Richard Foley Jr.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Retreat On Treasuries Before Report
description: Prices of Treasury securities slipped yesterday as market participants awaited today's report on employment in March.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Scottish School's Gym Will Be Demolished
description: The gymnasium of the Dunblane Primary School in Scotland, where a gunman killed 16 children and a teacher last month before shooting himself, is to be demolished, local officials said today.

title: BASEBALL;From East To West, Promising Reports
description: In a week when injuries removed two of the favorites for the Kentucky Derby, candidates on both coasts yesterday continued to whirl toward Louisville and the Run for the Roses: Unbridled's Song, the top horse in the East, turned in a sensationally fast workout at Aqueduct, and Honour and Glory, the top horse in the West, was made the favorite in the Santa Anita Derby.

title: A Landmark In Detroit May Be Sold
description: The owners of Detroit's landmark Renaissance Center are nearing a sale of the giant office, retail and hotel complex, people involved in the negotiations said today.

title: Company Briefs
description: BAKER HUGHES INC., Houston, a provider of products and services for oil industry, bought Vortoil Separation Systems, for undisclosed terms.

title: About New York;A Cross Borne Not Only At Eastertime
description: FORGIVE your people," echoed the voices of hundreds of people who marched behind two wooden crosses during a Good Friday procession along West 139th Street. As the crowd slowed to a stop, the drug dealers who would be the object of both their forgiveness and their fear looked on with hard faces and smirks.

title: Peeking at Your P.C.
description: As more Americans use electronic mail, buy products over the Internet and keep their most personal records on desktop computers, there is increasing demand for cryptography software that can insure the privacy of personal electronic communication.

title: New Sadness and Memories in Oklahoma
description: Nearly a year after a truck bomb ripped apart the Federal building here, President Clinton, his head bowed and his jaw clenched, helped lay a huge wreath of multicolored flowers today on the empty fenced-in field where the building once stood. He thanked Oklahoma City for being "a testament to the strength of the human spirit" in its effort to rebuild.

title: For Women in Ivory Coast, New Fight for Equality
description: Tomam Constance Yai is on a crusade against polygamy.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TESORO REACHES AN ACCORD WITH DISSIDENT INVESTORS
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with a shareholder group that has tried to remove the company's board for the last two years. The group, the Committee for New Management, agreed not to seek control of the l company or support any outside candidates for its board until 1999. Tesoro, an oil company based in San Antonio, will add three directors to its board, increasing membership to nine. Sanford B. Prater, a partner in the company's largest shareholder, Ardsley Advisory Partners, and Dr. Alan Kaufman, a member of the shareholders group, will join the board. Tesoro's governance committee will select a third member who now has no connection to the company, the shareholders' group or Ardsley.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Bach, Both Biblical And Lithe
description: What is so admirable about Robert Shaw is that he refuses to coast. As the dean of American choral conductors, Mr. Shaw has accumulated a virtual leaf pile of laurels in which he could easily choose to luxuriate as he approaches his 80th birthday.

title: New Leaders in Poland Gaze Intently Westward
description: To mark his first 100 days in office, President Aleksander Kwasniewski recently invited reporters to the living room of his private quarters, held a news conference standing before a handsome wall tapestry and then handed around flutes of champagne.

title: Telling One Typewriter from Another
description: Government officials say they sound two manual typewriters in the home of Theodore J. Kaczynski, a suspect in the Unabom case. They believe one of the typewriters was used to type the Unabomber's manitfesto.

title: It's Not Shameful to Protect Basic Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;Griffith Joyner Leaves Hospital After Seizure
description: The Olympic gold medalist FLORENCE GRIFFITH JOYNER was released from a St. Louis hospital yesterday, a day after suffering a seizure on an airplane en route to a high school track event there. She was discharged about midday, a spokeswoman at Barnes-Jewish Hospital said. The family requested that no other details be released.

title: BASEBALL;Errors Plus Long Ball Equal Trouble for the Mets
description: When the Mets decided to move Jeff Kent from second to third base to make room for Jose Vizcaino, who made room at shortstop for Rey Ordonez, they did so with their fingers crossed. While most people in the organization were confident Ordonez would do well at shortstop, Kent's transition figured to be more difficult.

title: Girl Dies in Video Store Arson; 2 Arrested
description: A 13-year-old girl severely burned in an arson-robbery at a video store in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn on Thursday died last night.

title: Corrections
