description: An article on the Media Business page yesterday, about financial problems at Lang Communications, referred incorrectly to the circulation of one of its magazines, Working Mother. The magazine is indeed audited, by Business Publications Audit of Circulation; it showed a circulation of 929,508 for the six months ended Dec. 31.

title: Beliefs
description: On Holy Saturday, Nietzsche is right for just one day and God is dead." Hans Urs von Balthasar

title: L.I. Man Accused Of Killing Mother
description: A Ronkonkoma teen-ager was charged with murder today after he apparently attacked his mother with a hammer, then stabbed himself, following an argument with her over his drug abuse, the Suffolk police said.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Bank Machine Fees Planned
description: A large New Jersey bank plans to start charging for use of its automatic teller machines by people with accounts at its competitors.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Ear Biter Faces Prison
description: Charles Whitman of Rahway gnawed away most of James Kelly's ear during a bar fight last April, and now, "There is a price that has to be paid," Superior Court Judge John Triarsi said. Judge Triarsi sentenced Mr. Whitman on Thursday to five years in prison. Mr. Whitman had claimed he acted in self-defense, the A.P. said.

title: ISSUE OF HIGH RISK IS RAISED IN CRASH OF BROWN'S PLANE
description: One of the most difficult questions faced by investigators of the jet crash in Croatia that killed Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and everyone else on board is whether the pilots took unnecessary risks to deliver their V.I.P. passengers.

title: U.S. Cash Keeps Children of Poor From Leaving Special Education
description: In the last four years, New York City's Board of Education and the Human Resources Administration have aggressively steered thousands of poor students classified with learning difficulties or emotional problems off municipal welfare and onto Federal disability payments, saving the city and state $5.2 million.

title: Beating Increases Tension on Immigration
description: The videotaped beating of two Mexicans by police officers in California has accentuated the tension that has been growing between the United States and its neighbor over immigration issues.

title: On the Internet, the Unabomber Is a Star
description: The Unabomber, the ultimate technophobe, has a cult following on the World Wide Web that has drafted him for president, given him a mug-shot makeover, and squirreled away countless copies of his mammoth manifesto.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Educators Quizzed on Budget
description: Mayor Doug Palmer sprang a surprise quiz on Trenton school district officials, asking them to answer 42 questions on the new school budget. The budget shows an anticipated $23.4 million shortfall, although the Mayor says that the district hasn't spent millions of dollars appropriated for programs and materials, The Associated Press reported. The answers were due on the Mayor's desk yesterday, when an outside auditor was to begin reviewing the district's records in time for the city to approve the new school budget on Monday. Superintendent Bernice Venable said that she would supply answers to Mayor Palmer's questions, but she added, "Everything is accounted for. I'm not interested in trying to hide any money."

title: 2 Mortgage Rates Inch Up
description: Rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages rose to 7.78 percent this week from 7.69 percent the previous week, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. Rates on 15-year mortgages rose to 7.29 percent from 7.19 percent. Rates on one-year adjustable loans were unchanged at 5.62 percent, after rising for six consecutive weeks. A year ago, 30-year loans averaged 8.41 percent; 15-year loans, 7.99 percent, and one-year adjustable loans stood at 6.41 percent.

title: Nobel Laureate Is Accused of Child Abuse
description: Dr. Daniel Carleton Gajdusek, a Nobel laureate and a leading researcher at the National Institutes of Health, has been charged with abusing one of the dozens of children he brought home from his research trips to the South Pacific and and whose education he paid for in the United States.

title: Coroico Journal;On a Deadly Road in Bolivia, Exciting New Vistas
description: Before setting out on this Andean mountain road, Jaime Machicao, a fruit-truck driver, pours a bit of whisky on the ground, chews a few coca leaves and offers a prayer that he will make the journey alive.

title: Journal;Smoking Out Starrgate
description: For those rooting for the President to end up in the slammer, Tuesday was the biggest Whitewater day yet. At the trial in Little Rock, the felon David Hale testified that Bill Clinton profited knowingly from an illegal loan. And if you turned on CNN that afternoon, there was Kenneth Starr, the independent counsel, at the top of "Headline News," crowing about his case in front of the courthouse.

title: Unfinished Task: Memorial in Oklahoma City
description: Families come from across the nation to stand at Fifth and Hudson Streets, in the heart of downtown, but there is nothing much to see: a chain-link fence, a huge empty lot and the blank wall of an underground parking garage.

title: Busy, Not Busiest Storm Season Is Predicted
description: Eleven named storms, including seven hurricanes, will form during the 1996 Atlantic hurricane season, a forecaster predicted today.

title: No Headline
description: I want to see how he acts with us. I want to see if he is going to act like a man of the people or like a king. We need a real leader. But we also need a man who is one of us."

title: Man Held After Explosion
description: The authorities today filed a Federal firearms charge against the owner of a rural storage shed demolished on Thursday in a series of explosions near Mosier, on the Columbia River east of Portland.

title: Officer Cleared in Shooting Is Dismissed
description: A white police officer who fatally shot a black teen-ager in the back of the head more than a year ago has been dismissed from the Paterson police force, the city's Mayor said today.

title: Two End Fokker Talks
description: The Samsung Group of South Korea and Saab of Sweden, a unit of Investor A.B., dropped out of the running today as potential saviors for the bankrupt Dutch plane maker Fokker N.V., leaving only a Russian consortium as a faint glimmer of hope. "Samsung of Korea and Sweden's Saab have consulted each other but could not come to agreement," Fokker said. "Both parties have therefore decided not to make a bid." Fokker went bankrupt on March 15 after weeks of struggle following a decision in January by its majority owner, Daimler-Benz Aerospace, to cut off financial support. Last week, the Dutch Minister of Economic Affairs, Hans Wijers, said Fokker's administrators were talking to Samsung Aerospace, Saab Aircraft and Tupolev and Yakovlev of Russia.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;17 Killed in Somalia
description: Heavy fighting in the southern part of Somalia's capital caught civilians in a crossfire today, killing 17 people and raising fears that the fighting could spread.

title: New Pressures on Airline Crash-Liability Accord
description: The Warsaw Convention governing the liability of an airline when passengers die in a plane crash is crumbling as airlines try to raise the accord's $75,000 limit on damages.

title: BASEBALL;Gooden's Wait Grows Longer
description: Dwight Gooden's day was growing depressing. He was sitting in a hotel room and more ugly weather was jeopardizing his official return to baseball. He was pondering his father's upcoming heart surgery.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about W. Haywood Burns, a civil rights advocate and former dean of the City University of New York School of Law, referred incorrectly to several survivors. Seth Rubin and Jeremiah Burns were children from the second of his three marriages, to Marilyn Reynolds, not from his first marriage, to Naomi Burns.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 3 about the standoff in Montana between Federal officials and members of a tax resisters group referred incompletely to the writings and philosophy of Walker F. Todd, a lawyer who acted briefly in behalf of relatives of some members of the group. While he has written articles that attracted the attention of Western tax and monetary protesters, he is not an intellectual leader of the tax resister movement.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;The Lot of Beijing's Finest Is Not Happy or Heroic
description: The policemen seen in Ning Ying's "On the Beat" are charged, quite literally, with keeping Beijing from going to the dogs. There is a ban on canine pets, and the police are seen enforcing it with typical dutifulness. Taking notes at their headquarters on each new Government slogan or dictum, they function as petty bureaucrats more than serious crime-stoppers. Dogcatching is about the heaviest responsibility they are asked to shoulder.

title: Uniroyal to Stop Selling Pesticide
description: The Uniroyal Chemical Corporation has agreed to stop selling a pesticide known to have harmful health risks, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Lewis Inquiry Ends
description: There is no evidence that the Boston Celtics captain Reggie Lewis used illegal drugs while he played on the 1986-87 Northeastern University basketball team, an investigating commission reported yesterday. The commission, established last year by JOHN CURRY, the president of Northeastern, found that other members of that team used marijuana and cocaine. Lewis died on July 27, 1993, after he collapsed while shooting baskets. Two doctors said that scarring found on his heart appeared consistent with cocaine use, although an autopsy and subsequent review concluded that an irregular heartbeat caused his death. (AP)

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK Disability Policies Questioned

title: INSIDE
description: Breach at Social Security

title: For First Time, Giuliani Picks Black Deputy Mayor
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appointed Rudy Washington as his Deputy Mayor for Community Relations yesterday, placing a black man for the first time in the highest level of his administration.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Jets Interested in Reich
description: The Jets, impressed with FRANK REICH during his visit Wednesday, are going to talk contract with one of the most noted backup quarterbacks in football. "He's interested; we're interested," FRANK RAMOS, a Jets team spokesman, said yesterday.

title: Decision to Dissolve Implant Panel Is Blocked
description: Negotiations over claims against the Dow Corning Corporation grew murkier today when one Federal judge postponed another judge's decision to dissolve a panel of lawyers representing claimants who say their health was damaged by breast implants manufactured by the company.

title: Market Closings
description: The stock and commodity markets in the United States are closed today in observance of Good Friday, but there was limited trading in bonds and currencies. Financial markets in many other countries were also closed.

title: City Loses Suit on Home-Care Cutbacks
description: A Federal judge has ruled that New York City arbitrarily cut home care for thousands of elderly and disabled people without providing medical or other explicit reasons for doing so. The ruling is a blow to efforts by the Pataki and Giuliani administrations to trim the state and city contributions to Medicaid, which pays the home care costs.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the trail of clues leading to the arrest of Theodore J. Kaczynski, the Unabom suspect, included a law-enforcement official's misstatement of the educational background of the suspect's brother David R. Kaczynski. He graduated from Columbia University, not Harvard.

title: Sports of The Times;The Yanks Will Be Out at Home
description: THE muddy ball came off the metal bat with a thud, skipping along the grass and dying when it reached the saturated infield dirt. The shortstop retrieved it and tossed it back to the pitcher. The next pitch was ripped into the left-center gap, where a kid gave chase and lost his footing in the muck.

title: GROWTH OF JOBS STRONG IN MARCH, CONTINUING TREND
description: Employers added a hefty number of new jobs to their payrolls in March, the Labor Department said today, providing solid evidence that the economy is in better shape than it appeared just a couple months ago.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NESTLE SET TO BUY KOALA SPRINGS INTERNATIONAL
description: Nestle USA Inc., based in Glendale, Calif., said its Nestle Beverage affiliate had agreed to purchase Koala Springs International, a maker of fruit drinks and teas. Terms were not disclosed. Koala, based in Fremont, Calif., makes the Sparklers line of carbonated fruit drinks, lemonades and teas and the Quencher line of noncarbonated fruit drinks. The company will be integrated into the juice division of Nestle Beverage. Nestle USA is a unit of Nestle S.A. of Switzerland.

title: Three Mid-Atlantic States Show A Jump in Jobless Rate to 6.8%
description: Although the national unemployment rate crept up only slightly in March, the rate for New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania moved sharply higher, according to a Federal report issued yesterday. The regional rate jumped to 6.8 percent from the 6 percent level of both February and January.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Victory No. 65 For the Bulls
description: The Chicago Bulls scored the first 20 points of the game and defeated Charlotte, 126-92, last night, giving the Hornets a sobering view of what their future could hold.

title: Ex-Radio Talk Show Host Ordered to Return Money
description: A Federal judge in New York has ordered Irwin H. (Sonny) Bloch, the former financial talk show host; his wife, Hilda Bloch, and six of his companies to return $3.9 million collected from listeners they persuaded to invest in three radio stations in Florida and Connecticut.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Pataki Gains Pick as Court Loses Judge
description: Judge Richard D. Simons is stepping down from New York State's highest court, giving Gov. George E. Pataki his first chance to make his mark on the court, which he has bitterly assailed as overly liberal and soft on crime.

title: Mayor Sees Costly New Stadium as No Burden to Taxpayers
description: The stadium that a consultant has recommended building for the Yankees on the West Side of Manhattan would likely be the most expensive in the nation's history, but Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that it could be built at little or no cost to the city's taxpayers.

title: Bridge
description: Putting old partnerships back together again is almost as difficult as repairing Humpty Dumpty. But it can be done.

title: Streamlining the F.D.A., Safely
description: The Clinton Administration is making it easier for cancer patients to get promising drugs that have not been fully tested. By loosening some of the Food and Drug Administration's rules to accelerate access to experimental drugs, the White House may defuse more sweeping and dangerous reforms under consideration by Congress.

title: Observer;The Family Campaign
description: People who are Bob Dole's age look at Bill Clinton and think, "We are now being governed by the people we used to spank."

title: Cross-Channel Duel
description: The saga of mad cow disease, which only a week ago was the occasion for a touchy-feely show of solidarity among European leaders, has turned into a tale of blame and confusion, isolating Britain from its European Union partners across the English Channel as never before.

title: Consumer Debt Rose Sharply In February
description: Americans' installment debt grew in February at the fastest pace in eight months as each of the major categories of consumer credit posted sharp gains.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Suspect in Sex Case Caught
description: A Gloucester County Jail guard wanted on sexual assault charges was arrested yesterday after leading the police on a chase through South Jersey and Delaware, the A.P. reported. Dozens of police officers from several municipalities participated in the chase, which ended when Andrew W. Trechock's car got stuck in a Logan Township swamp, prosecutors said. The chase began around 1:45 A.M., when the police were called after Mr. Trechock, 32, allegedly sexually assaulted a female relative. He was charged with sexual assault, eluding police and possession of a weapon for an unlawful purpose, prosecutors said.

title: Gene Tests: What You Know Can Hurt You
description: Last year, it was discovered that 1 percent of Ashkenazi Jewish women, those of Central or Eastern European ancestry, carry a mutated form of a gene that might predispose them to breast and ovarian cancer.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Autry Can Make Movies
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association decided yesterday that DARNELL AUTRY, Northwestern's star running back, has the right to appear in a commercial film. The administrative review panel granted Autry, a 19-year-old drama major from Tempe, Ariz., a waiver of an N.C.A.A. rule prohibiting student athletes from appearing in commercial films, clearing the way for him to take part in "The 18th Angel," which is being filmed this summer. (AP)

title: HOCKEY;Playing Without Messier, Rangers Get Payback
description: Coach Colin Campbell has been waiting all season for someone other than Mark Messier to put the puck in the net on a consistent basis. Last night, the Rangers had no choice if they were to win, because Messier was in street clothes with a bruised left rib cage. And because the Philadelphia Flyers were in town on the back end of a home-and-home series.

title: U.S. Workers Stole Data On 11,000, Agency Says
description: In what computer experts say may be one of the biggest breaches of security of personal data held by the Federal Government, several employees of the Social Security Administration passed information on more than 11,000 people to a credit-card fraud ring, according to Federal prosecutors in New York City.

title: News Analysis;In Yale Strike, Power Is the Issue
description: Throughout the 10-day strike by service workers at Yale University, the union and the administration have argued heatedly about management's demand to contract out work and cut retirement benefits. But at the heart of the conflict, both sides agree, is Yale's bid to regain control over its own operations.

title: Historian's Passion is Uniforms That Fit
description: During the late 1950's, the New York City buses that ran uptown and downtown looked different from the ones that ran crosstown; this was useful information for the producers of the film "The Hudsucker Proxy."

title: Protest Leads to 20 Arrests
description: Twenty protesters were arrested after blocking the entrance to a nuclear research laboratory in Manhattan during a Good Friday peace demonstration.

title: Homework Is Keeping Grade-Schoolers Busy
description: It is a busy life for a little boy -- school until almost 3 P.M., day care until 6, then home for two very busy hours before bed at 8.

title: Editorial Notebook;Reflections on a Firestorm
description: Historians caution us to view every era on its own terms. Still, many events become clearer with hindsight, when newer developments have given them context. The MOVE bombing in Philadelphia has reached just that point.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;Faulkner, Set in Malaysia
description: A small boy watches his father set a barn on fire, and it is no exaggeration to say that the child's reaction is universal enough to travel from Mississippi to Malaysia. "The Arsonist" is, in fact, a Malaysian version of William Faulkner's story "Barn Burning." Remarkably, this film is among the most faithful renderings of Faulkner ever brought to screen. Though the characters are transferred to a wildly different time and place, "The Arsonist" is a fluid and beautiful film that captures the essence of Faulkner's story: the boy's largely silent reaction, a tangle of inherited guilt, secrecy and fear.

title: Bodies of 33 Crash Victims To Arrive in the U.S. Today
description: The American Ambassador in Croatia said today that the bodies of 33 Americans killed in the plane crash near Dubrovnik, including that of Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, would be flown back to the United States on Saturday for identification and burial.

title: Booba Barnes Is Dead at 59; Mississippi Juke-Joint Bluesman
description: Roosevelt (Booba) Barnes, a master of Mississippi juke-joint blues, died on Wednesday in a nursing home in Chicago. He was 59 and lived in Chicago.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HARNISCHFEGER INDUSTRIES SELLS ELECTRONICS UNIT
description: Harnischfeger Industries Inc. sold its Elgar Electronics Corporation unit yesterday to the Carlyle Group, GFI Energy Ventures L.L.C. and the senior management of Elgar. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Elgar, based in San Diego, manufactures equipment used in designing and testing electronic products. The company also designs and manufactures power systems used in harsh environments. Harnischfeger is an international holding company. The Washington-based Carlyle Group is a private merchant bank that acquires aerospace, telecommunications, power supply and environmental companies. GFI Energy Ventures is an investor in the power and energy industry.

title: Asian Immigrants Help New York Thrive
description: To the Editor:

title: Asian Immigrants Help New York Thrive;Apology Demanded
description: To the Editor:

title: Case Stirs Fear in France
description: A Frenchman who died in January had brain lesions similar to those of eight Britons whose deaths are believed related to mad cow disease, a Government health official said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;INVESTOR GROUPS PURCHASE BIG STAKE IN MAGIC CINEMAS
description: William E. Simon & Sons and the CIT Group/Equity Investments Inc. have bought an equity stake in Magic Cinemas L.L.C., a closely held operator of movie theaters. The investors paid between $6 million and $10 million for the stake, said Jeffrey Davidson, chief executive of Magic, based in Livingston, N.J. Magic expects to open about 150 screens in the next three years. Currently, it operates 37 screens. The company, formerly known as Movie Entertainment Inc., plans to expand into eastern Pennsylvania and southern Connecticut. Simon, a private investment company, was founded by William E. Simon, a former Treasury Secretary. CIT Group/Equity Investments Inc. is a subsidiary of the CIT Group Holdings Inc. of Livingston, N.J.

title: HOCKEY;Devils Search for Goals in Frantic Playoff Quest
description: Jacques Lemaire put extreme pressure on his players right from opening day to practice the rigid defensive tactics that helped the Devils win the Stanley Cup last year. But with nine days remaining in the regular season, it appears that Lemaire's philosophy may have backfired because the Devils are on the verge of missing the playoffs.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Sequel for 'To Sir With Love'
description: Dangerous Minds," last year's hit movie with Michelle Pfeiffer as a teacher who reforms a classful of tough high school kids, suggested a couple of things about that creaky genre. If you're going to revive it, you'd better have a major movie star and an up-to-the-minute soundtrack. ("Dangerous Minds" was made by its Coolio song.) The standard of the genre, of course, is the 1967 Sidney Poitier movie "To Sir With Love," in which he turns around a class of London toughs.

title: Asian Immigrants Help New York Thrive
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Estranged Husband Kills 9 and Himself in Canada
description: A man estranged from his wife opened fire today on her and her relatives at a wedding party, killing her and eight others, then fleeing to a motel and killing himself, the police said.

title: Damaged Gene Is Linked to Lung Cancer
description: A damaged gene found in many lung cancer tumors appears to play a critical role in developing the disease, say researchers who took part in a new study.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CZECH AIRLINE IN DEAL FOR 10 BOEING JETS
description: CSA A.S., the state-controlled Czech airline, signed a $350 million contract yesterday to buy 10 Boeing jets to replace outdated Russian models. The new planes will allow CSA to improve its fleet, which currently includes seven B-737's and two Airbus A-310's, and expand services. CSA flew 1.5 million passengers last year, up 20 percent from 1994. The airline said it would take delivery of the first three 111-seat Boeing jets in the first half of 1997. The remaining seven will be delivered between 1998 and 2000.

title: Yeltsin Hits Campaign Trail, Telling Voters to Forget Past
description: Traveling on his first campaign trip straight to the Communist-dominated heartland of Russia, President Boris N. Yeltsin wandered from pig farms to metal factories today, delivering the same simple, heartfelt message: the past is over, please don't bring it back.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT UNIT SELLS PROPERTIES
description: The ITT Community Development Corporation said late on Thursday that it had sold several of its properties to Palm Coast Holdings Inc., an affiliate of the Minnesota Power and Light Company, for $34 million. The sale includes properties, retail lots and retail land sales contracts totaling about 13,000 acres of land. Palm Coast is a planned community on Florida's northeast coast. ITT Community, a unit of ITT Industries Inc., also said a Minnesota Powerunit acquired an option to buy Palm Coast Utility Corporation's water and sewer assets. ITT Community said remaining assets expected to be sold include parts of Hammock Dunes, an oceanfront golf community; the River Club, a residential project; and other undeveloped properties.

title: Food Safety Needs More Science, Not Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Bonds Tumble, Sending Interest Rates to 7-Month High
description: Treasury prices tumbled yesterday, driving interest rates to a seven-month high, as the bond market was caught off guard for the second consecutive month by an employment report showing surprising strength.

title: Could It Be True? A New Pavarotti?
description: At times Roberto Alagna feels he is living a fairy tale. In barely a decade, this 32-year-old Frenchman has gone from learning accountancy in the daytime and singing boleros in a Paris pizzeria at night to being acclaimed in Europe as "the new Pavarotti," "the fourth tenor" and "the tenor of the year 2000." Now, preparing for his debut at the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday, he seems rather shocked by the metamorphosis.

title: Witness in Fraud Trial Denies Personal Motive for Implicating Clinton
description: Under stiff defense questioning, the chief prosecution witness in the Whitewater-related fraud trial here denied today that his reason for implicating President Clinton and seeking the help of political conservatives was to get a better plea bargain on the indictments he faced.

title: Newborn Rescued From Park Septic Tank
description: A newborn sealed in a plastic bag and dropped into a septic tank through a toilet was rescued alive on Thursday after an 11-year-old boy heard the infant crying and alerted a sheriff's deputy.

title: Dollar Up in Thin Trading After Report of Rise in Jobs
description: The dollar rose in thin trading yesterday after a report showing strong job growth in the United States convinced currency traders that the Federal Reserve would not cut interest rates anytime soon.

title: It's Not Shameful to Protect Basic Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Pull Their Latest Escape Act
description: There were no orations from Charles Oakley, no internal scuffling and nary a word about Patrick Ewing's overused right arm. The Knicks left the Bradley Center tonight with an uninspiring 86-79 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks, but they'll take it.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on the Chronicle column on Wednesday referred incorrectly the $1.1 million plus interest that a Manhattan justice ordered Leona Helmsley to pay an executive whom she dismissed and who sued for breach of contract. It was a civil judgment, not a fine.

title: COMPANY NEWS;REUNION RESOURCES AGREES TO TRIBO PETROLEUM OFFER
description: The Reunion Resources Company said late on Thursday that it had agreed to sell all of its oil and gas assets to the Tribo Petroleum Corporation for $11.4 million, as it moves to focus on its plastic businesses. Tribo, based in Houston, will pay $9.6 million in cash and $1.7 million in a promissory note due six months after the close of the transaction, expected on May 1. The agreement comes three months after Reunion said the Bargo Energy Company dropped its plan to acquire the assets for $15.1 million in cash.

title: One Man's Windfall, One Industry's Gyration
description: To the Editor:

title: Excel Chairman to Join Billionaires' Club
description: Kenny Troutt, the chairman of Excel Communications Inc., is close to becoming the latest Texas billionaire.

title: Dole Accuses Clinton on Iran Arms for Bosnia
description: Senator Bob Dole, the leading Congressional advocate for lifting the Bosnian arms embargo, accused President Clinton today of duplicity for allowing Iran to supply weapons to the Muslim-led Bosnian Government while fighting Mr. Dole's effort to end the arms ban.

title: COMPANY NEWS;JP REALTY PURCHASES IDAHO MALL FOR $34.4 MILLION
description: JP Realty Inc. of Salt Lake City has acquired the Grand Teton Mall in Idaho Falls, Idaho, for $34.4 million. The real estate investment trust said it had financed the purchase with its $50 million secured revolving credit facility. With the acquisition, the company owns 44 properties, including regional malls, community centers and commercial and business operations.

title: Cigarettes Make the Meal
description: For those victimized by the Draconian law forbidding smoking in New York City restaurants, there is hope for civilized dining. Two bills in the State Legislature would overturn the law. Then maybe the Europeans would stop snickering at us.

title: New U.S. Curbs Sound Alarm for Cuba Investors
description: Bolted to the front of the old phone company headquarters in this city's crumbling center is a bronze plaque commemorating Resolution No. 1 of Cuba's revolutionary Government: the nationalization of the telephone system on Aug. 6, 1960.

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Stumble and Fall, and Then Begin Their Game
description: Leading his Islander teammates onto the ice tonight, defenseman Brent Severyn made a dash across the rink, tripped and, to the amusement of the fans, spilled sidelong into the boards.

title: Not in Michigan Anymore: Spring Visitors From Afar
description: Janice Tysman had never ridden on a subway until the other day, and there she was on an uptown C train dancing between the steel poles and singing. It was springtime in New York City and the 17-year-old high school junior was in love.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Jones Defends Irvin
description: The Dallas Cowboys' owner, JERRY JONES, while criticizing MICHAEL IRVIN's judgment, is confident the All-Pro wide receiver doesn't have a drug problem. "Michael has been in the league since 1988 and has never had any positive tests while he has been under the scrutiny of the N.F.L.," Jones said Thursday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BIRMINGHAM STEEL TO RECORD CHARGES IN 3D QUARTER
description: The Birmingham Steel Corporation will record charges in the range of $18 million to $21 million for the third quarter, which ended Sunday. In the corresponding quarter a year earlier, the company earned $13.3 million, or 45 cents a share, on revenue of $236.9 million. In a statement, the company said the charges included a write-down of older property, plant and equipment; reworking of a contract with Electronic Data Systems; accumulated start-up costs for the new bar mill in Cuyahoga and the new melt shop in Memphis.

title: John McSherry Remembered By Fellow Baseball Umpires
description: It has been said that no one goes to a ball game to watch the umpire. Yesterday, an umpire drew a full house to the church in the Bronx where he was baptized. This time, John McSherry was eulogized there.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AIRGAS SAYS IT HAS ACQUIRED TWO DISTRIBUTORS
description: Airgas Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired Randall-Graw and had bought a Pennsylvania safety supplies distributor. It also said it would buy a Kentucky gas distributor. No terms were disclosed on any of the deals, which are expected to add $85 million to Airgas's annual sales of about $1 billion. Randall-Graw, based in La Crosse, Wis., also distributes industrial and medical gas and has annual sales of about $18 million. Airgas also bought the IPCO Safety Group of Companies of Langhorne, Pa., a distributor of safety, industrial and environmental supplies with annual revenues of about $55 million. Airgas is based in Radnor, Pa.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Churches to Sign Up Voters
description: Organizers of the New Jersey African-American family unity march on May 6 will be handing out voter registration forms during Easter services tomorrow at 104 African Episcopal churches across the state. It is the start of a drive to sign up 75,000 new black voters before the November election.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Giants Seeking Dillard
description: The Giants are close to signing the free agent defensive lineman STACEY DILLARD, who has drawn serious interest from three teams and could sign a multiyear deal this weekend. Dillard played in 15 games for the Giants last season, with three starts, and had 33 tackles and a sack.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;When the Doctor Is a Lady, a Well-Bred One
description: There were many things a well-bred Victorian lady didn't do. Catching head lice from patients at a hospital where she hoped to become a surgeon, not to mention passing those lice on to the servants at home, would have been high on the era's list of social faux pas. To call the fictitious Eleanor Bramwell a Victorian lady doctor is very much to the point, for that combination is the wickedly clever secret behind the latest Masterpiece Theater miniseries. "Bramwell" is "Upstairs, Downstairs" with doctors.

title: Stocks Surge In Japan
description: Stocks ended sharply higher here today, as the market shook off recent worries on interest rates.

title: BASEBALL;News Dashes '96 Hopes for Pulsipher
description: Bill Pulsipher was hoping his 1996 season would be spent helping to pitch the Mets to their first post-season appearance since 1988. Instead, the 22-year-old left-hander will spend the year cheering on his teammates while recuperating from surgery to repair his injured elbow.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Court Upholds Clinton Policy On Gay Troops
description: A Federal appeals court in Richmond today upheld the Clinton Administration's "don't ask, don't tell" policy for homosexuals in the military, saying it was inappropriate for the Federal courts to tell Congress and the President how to deal with such an issue.

title: Appeals Court Overturns A Subpoena For 'Dateline'
description: NBC does not have to turn over unused videotaped interviews from a "Dateline" report that questioned the safety of a combination cradle and baby swing, a Federal appeals court in Manhattan has ruled.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Payrolls Rose in March; Hopes Dashed for Rate Cut Employers added a hefty 140,000 new jobs to their payrolls in March, providing solid evidence that the economy is in better shape than it appeared a couple of months ago. The jobless rate was little changed, edging up one-tenth of a point, to 5.6 percent.

title: Our Crumbling Schools
description: A chunk of Newtown High School's facade fell off this week, right over the main entrance to the Queens school. It attracted no more attention than the classroom ceilings that recently collapsed in elementary schools in Far Rockaway, Brownsville and East New York.

title: Vietnam Will Regret Courting Tobacco
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Beachfront Hotel Is Saved
description: The venerable Flanders Hotel, which last week appeared to be headed for a date with the wrecking ball, has been saved by a Pennsylvania developer, James Dwyer, who agreed this week to purchase the 214-room Boardwalk landmark for an undisclosed price. He said he plans to reopen it this summer, with an extensive renovation starting in the fall in what Mr. Dwyer called "the renaissance of a grand old gal."

title: Mexico Sees a Rate Rebellion;Businesses and Consumers Alike Chafe at Loan Costs
description: Emilio Espana hardly has the makings of a radical. The head of a clan of candy makers, he runs a 94-year-old company that produces mints and lollipops that eager children buy on street corners all across Mexico.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;How Low Can Nets Go? A Season-Low 70 Points
description: Before and after tonight's game, the Nets were a portrait of frustration.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Oldest Passion Play Opens
description: The nation's oldest performance of the Passion Play is to open its 81st season today at 2 P.M. at the Park Performing Arts Center, 560 32d St. The Rev. Kevin Ashe, a Roman Catholic priest who is the director of the nonprofit arts center, said the annual spectacle has been substantially revised over the last 10 years, with a new score and a script that eliminated the anti-Semitic overtones that characterized some traditional Easter plays elsewhere.

title: TENNIS;U.S. Splits With Czechs, Thanks to Martin's Fire
description: Todd Martin has been in difficult Davis Cup situations before. MaliVai Washington has not.

title: New Rochelle Police Officer Charged in Burglary
description: A 26-year-old New Rochelle police officer who was honored in October for rescuing a family from a burning building has been charged with breaking into an apartment here and stealing several hundred dollars in cash.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;North and South Korea At Odds on DMZ Patrols
description: South Korea put its military on a heightened state of alert today after North Korea announced it would "give up its duty" of jointly controlling the demilitarized zone separating the two nations.

title: Nuclear Plants Are Working to Regain Trust
description: To the Editor:

title: Bomber Inquiry Shifts to Tactics For Legal Case
description: As amazed investigators combing the cabin of a Montana recluse continued to haul away what they said was a mountain of evidence tying Theodore J. Kaczynski to the Unabom attacks, the authorities began to turn their attention today to the tactics of building a case against him.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5

title: Brooklyn Cable Fire Cuts Phone Service
description: Two big telephone cables were knocked out in Brooklyn yesterday, disrupting communications among a half-dozen police precincts and making the world a lot smaller for thousands of borough residents for much of the afternoon and evening.

title: Pentagon Plans Major Changes In Maintenance
description: The Defense Department has proposed a plan to save up to $15 billion a year by allowing private contractors to perform more maintenance on weapons and equipment.

title: HOW WE EAT
description: Since returning last summer to the United States from France, where I lived for six years, I have yearned to see an intelligent treatment of American eating habits. Your special issue "How We Eat: An America Divided" (March 10) responded to this, although I would love to have seen an article comparing our behavior with that of other cultures. Of all the paradoxes of modern America (expatriating renders them all the more apparent), binge-and-purge behavior and the morality we've attached to it appall me the most. Just as the V-chip, in my view, treats a symptom (excessive sex and violence on television) without addressing the problem, the low-fat imperative assuages our unhealthy eating habits.

title: CUTTINGS;Preliminary Steps for Rhubarb Pie
description: When my friend Betty, who gardens a mile up the road from our Maryland farm, casually mentioned that she was dividing her rhubarb plants, I was up there quicker than you can say Jack Robinson.

title: SPENDING IT;Life Insurance Trusts Can Help Your Heirs
description: ON his deathbed, Oscar Wilde was offered a sip of champagne. He accepted, saying, "I am dying beyond my means."

title: TENNIS;Many Junior Players Want to Be Pros, Poll Says
description: Ryan Redondo, a 13-year-old competing at this week's Easter Bowl Junior Tennis Championships in Palm Springs, Calif., already knew that most of the competitors want to become professional tennis players.

title: TELEVISION VIEW;Looking Away From DeMille To Find Moses
description: IT IS ALMOST IMPOSSIBLE TO make a good biblical movie. Perhaps it is achievement enough not to make a bad one. Over the last several years, Turner Network Television has produced the first few films in a biblical series, and they are not bad at all.

title: CHOICE TABLES;Ethnic Influences Fuel a Takeoff In Houston Dining
description: HOUSTON is identified by two industries, one undergound (oil), the other high above (space). They fuel the economy -- and civic pride -- in America's fourth largest city, yet something else is happening, this time at street level: a flourishing multi-ethnic restaurant scene.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: SOMEBODY ELSE'S MAMA By David Haynes. Harvest/Harcourt Brace, $13.

title: TELEVISION RATINGS;Multiple-Choice Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Broadway's Producers: A Struggling, Changing, Breed
description: THE PRODUCER ROBERT WHITEHEAD, at 80 one of the grand old men of Broadway, was approached recently by his 23-year-old son, Charlie, with a proposal that both flattered and confounded him.

title: Sifting Sandbox Aptitude Tests;Crayon-Chewing Time for Nursery School Directors
description: One of the rituals of spring in fin de siecle Manhattan is getting a child admitted to a prestigious nursery school, never a task for the fainthearted. The process triggers the usual stories about letters of recommendation written by famous people for 3-year-olds and high-powered mothers in tears because their toddlers are on the waiting list.

title: The Unbeliever
description: INVENTING THE AIDS VIRUS By Peter Duesberg. 722 pp. Washington: Regnery Publishing. $29.95. FOR almost a decade, Peter Duesberg has been publicly arguing that AIDS is not caused by H.I.V. infection. Given his prominence as a professor of molecular and cell biology at the University of California, Berkeley, and his membership in the National Academy of Sciences, his arguments commanded attention. Since he first made this claim, in 1987, many major biomedical research journals have arranged for formal, published debates between Mr. Duesberg and other distinguished scientists. They have disagreed almost uniformly with his increasingly strident contentions, but he has remained undaunted, writing voluminously about his belief.

title: FOOD;No Bones About It
description: LIKE MOST LANDLOCKED AMERICANS RAISED during the 1950's, I was deeply suspicious and a little frightened of any fish that was not square, breaded and deep-fried. Then I moved to Provincetown, Mass., in the mid-70's. The town's ambient aroma of fish and brine seemed romantic, if a little scary. When the fishing fleet docked and heaved its catch onto the town pier, I wasn't sure which distressed me more -- the sound of the fishermen's talk, or the sight of all those glassy-eyed fish.

title: TCI Cable Makes Official Cutback in Public Access
description: TCI CABLE of Westchester's two-month postponement of plans to cut its systemwide public-access channel merely deferred the inevitable. As of May 1, public-access producers will no longer have Channel 8 available for distributing their shows. Citing Federal regulations that it must carry an additional two stations, the cable company said that it had to reassign Channel 8 for other programming.

title: Montana's Quarrel Over Yellowstone Bison Is With Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: 32,000 Panels In Aids Quilt, 32,000 Victims
description: THERE are thousands of stories behind the Names Project AIDS Memorial Quilt, a collection of 32,000 panels, which commemorates the lives of people who have died of AIDS-related complications. But when the three-day display of 500 panels from the quilt opens Thursday in the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College here, at least 20 more people who lived in Westchester will be added.

title: Word for Word/Ronald H. Brown;How to Elect a President: The Campaign Strategy
description: WHEN Ronald H. Brown died in a plane crash in Croatia last week, the nation lost an energetic and successful commerce secretary -- a man who crisscrossed the globe with American business executives, arm-twisting foreign governments to buy anything stamped "Made in U.S.A." But for President Clinton the loss was particularly acute: He called Mr. Brown the single most important strategist in the 1992 Presidential campaign.

title: Easter Walk
description: Easter has not always been the easiest day for me.

title: An Easter Ticket That Can't Be Had by Faith Alone
description: The tickets are free, but for those who want them, they are priceless.

title: WEDDINGS;Susan L. Sewell And Paul Arbor
description: Susan Lynne Sewell and Paul Arbor were married yesterday in the garden of the Grand Oaks Mansion, a historic home in Cartersville, Ga. The Rev. Cuyler Smith, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Courts and Pools At Japanese Hotels
description: A squash court and a wedding chapel are among the lures of two new hotels in Japan, the Imperial Hotel, Osaka, and the Grand Hyatt Fukuoka.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK;Phillips Hopes Ability Outshines Adversity
description: Lawrence Phillips, the talented running back from Nebraska, is working hard to make National Football League teams forget that he assaulted a former girlfriend last season, an incident that led to a six-game suspension and plenty of unwelcome notoriety.

title: A True Mets Spirit
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Preserving the Legacy Of Modernist Design
description: HOLLY GOLIGHTLY looked wistfully on the face of Manhattan as she prepared to depart for Rio. "Years from now, years and years, I'll be back," she declared. "Me and my nine Brazilian brats. I'll bring them back, all right. Because they must see this."

title: FAST FORWARD;Manual Labor
description: GOOD MORNING - DAYLIGHT SAVING time has begun, and you have work to do. Maybe you have already reset your wristwatch and bedside clock, but the odds are that you have neglected one or more of the following timekeeping devices: VCR. Automatic coffeemaker. Telephone answering machine. Camera. Digital thermostat. Television set. Microwave oven. Stereo. Personal computer. Car.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD Lewis Takes the 100

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND;Action Central, at Least in Uniondale
description: ON a Sunday morning the lobby of the Long Island Marriott in Uniondale can turn into the Casbah. The sights and sounds may overwhelm an ordinary mortal, but not Desmond Corsswell of Brooklyn, the "concierge/ bellhop" on duty.

title: Crash Kills 7 Suspected Illegal Aliens After Agents Follow Truck
description: Seven people suspected of being illegal Mexican immigrants were killed today and 18 others were injured when their stolen truck crashed near a United States Border Patrol checkpoint.

title: SPOTLIGHT;Notes on Film
description: Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein were already Broadway legends when Darryl Zanuck coaxed them into the movies with new technologies like Cinemascope and stereo sound. "State Fair" (starring Jeanne Crain and Dana Andrews, above) was made in 1945 on the stipulation that, to keep its homespun quality, the production would not set foot in Hollywood. The pair eventually succumbed to the allure - "The King and I" featured three-acre sets and 40-pound costumes. RODGERS AND HAMMERSTEIN - THE SOUND OF MOVIES is a chronicle of their cinematic legacy. Shirley Jones, Rita Moreno, Nancy Kwan and Julie Andrews take turns sharing inside information about their films - TONIGHT at 8 on A&E.

title: Good Cigars, but a Lot of Smoke
description: THE Culbro Corporation has long been a quiet company.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week. Tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420.

title: BENEFITS
description: Broadway's Bonnets MONDAY and TUESDAY -- The 10th annual Easter Bonnet Competition will be at the Palace Theater, Broadway at 47th Street, at 4 P.M., to benefit Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS. Performers from more than 20 Broadway and Off Broadway shows will sing, dance and show off bonnets they have created. Tickets, $20 at the door. Information: (212) 840-0770.

title: 2 Deaths -- One Then, One Now;On Losing a Father, A Newspaperman
description: JOURNALISM is not just a job. Any reporter who is good at what he does believes this on some level, no matter how he tries to wrap the sentiment in cynicism. I don't know how others came to that conviction, but in my case it was thrust upon me, accepted as part of family lore.

title: WEDDINGS;Jane D. Farkas, Kenneth C. Guarino
description: Jane Darlene Farkas, the daughter of Diana and Robert Farkas of New York, was married on Monday to Kenneth Charles Guarino, a son of Patricia Erwin of Miami and Harold Guarino of Fairburn, Ga. Rabbi Benjamin Feller officiated at Tavern on the Green in Manhattan.

title: Serbs in Bosnia Still Holding 16
description: Bosnian Serbs failed to release prisoners today, as they had agreed to do, but Bosnian Croats and Muslims bowed to pressure and freed their captives, officials said.

title: TENNIS;Czech Doubles Team Has the U.S. in Trouble
description: It took 1 hour 37 minutes for Petr Korda and Daniel Vacek to put the United States Davis Cup team into extremely hot water.

title: DANCE;Far From Ballet's Center, but Still at Its Heart
description: FOR BALLET enthusiasts who know their history, March 10, 1962, is an unforgettable date. On that evening, before a packed house at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, a young Rudolf Nureyev danced for the first time in New York City. The performance was the "Don Quixote" pas de deux, and his partner was Sonia Arova, a Bulgarian-born ballerina with glinting blue-black hair and a bravura style.

title: MUSIC;Offbeat Selections for Noontime
description: SEVERAL Westchester musicians are taking part in concerts this week, starting Tuesday evening at 7:30, when Teresa Echler Wager, Yen Ling Chen, Adam Kent and Marc Wager convene at the New Rochelle Public Library to play music by Faure, Doppler and Chopin for flute, violin, piano and French horn.

title: Is Fashion All Blond? A Spoof Takes Aim
description: ONE of the rituals upended in the film "White Man's Burden," a 1995 satire that depicted a world in which whites were mistreated minorities and blacks the ruling majority, was the fashion show. On the runway were elegant black models wearing clothes by the black designer Tracy Reese, and an all-black audience applauded the finale.

title: POP MUSIC;Songwriters Who Followed Their Literary Muses
description: THE CYBER-LORDS WOULD have us believe that the printed word, if not dying, is hobbling toward retirement and needs its medication three times a day. Well, Rosanne Cash and Bill Morrissey disagree. When the two critically acclaimed singer-songwriters sought new creative challenges, they didn't build a Web page or go CD-ROM. Instead, they set down their guitars, shut their mouths and wrote serious books of fiction. How square.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Merlot Gristina Vineyards, Cutchogue, 1993. About $15.

title: Backtalk;America's Cup Mischief Drives Winner Away
description: Bill Koch recently decided to abandon any further efforts to race for the America's Cup. Koch successfully defended the cup as skipper in 1992 under the America3 banner, and in 1995, he organized an America3 women's team. That group lost the cup defense trials to Dennis Conner and his Stars & Stripes team. The next America's Cup competition is scheduled for 1999-2000 in New Zealand, but Koch will not be there. His America3 Foundation syndicate will continue to sponsor Olympic sailing, but the America's Cup portion of the office has been closed. Here he explains why.

title: Dodger History
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SUNY Budget Bind
description: To the Editor:

title: FUNDS WATCH;Putting Indexing Into Action, in Small Ways
description: The Standard & Poor's 500 stock index has been tough to beat in the last few years. Taking note, investors have been pouring money at a rapid clip into mutual funds that buy the stocks in the index, seeking to match its performance.

title: HOW WE EAT
description: Molly O'Neill's "Tastes Like Chicken" (March 10) reminded me of a day in May 1953. I met my contact in Paris. We went to lunch at one of the very expensive restaurants. Uncle Sam was paying; confidential funds, intelligence stuff. Yevgeny ordered frogs' legs. I grimaced. "Do not make so much a fact of not liking. Act like we belong here. Besides, frogs' legs are very good. They taste like chicken." So I ordered chicken, and now I know what frogs' legs taste like.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE;Kids' Library Cards Rated "R," for Restricted
description: Responding to a flurry of letters from parents and school administrators in Bay Ridge, the Brooklyn Public Library will begin limiting materials available to children next month.

title: Pakistan Is Showing Little Gain on Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: DINING OUT;The Cooking is Down-Home Southern
description: CATFISH, the epitome of Down-Home Southern cooking, has recently found its way onto the menus of fancy French restaurants. The aptly named Catfish Cafe in Lynbrook offers a delicious dish called "catfish named desire" that straddles both worlds. These pan-fried fillets with their lemon-pepper corn flour crust and lush marsala-spiked gravy, a meld of crayfish tails and wild mushrooms are not haute cuisine. But neither are they Friday night, all-you-can-eat fish fry fare.

title: POP VIEW;Young Crooners Learn The Subtle Art of Seduction
description: A QUIET REVOLUTION IS AT hand in urban music. Gone is the boasting about the girl you seduced last night and can't remember today. These days, the come-on of choice for rhythm-and-blues singers is a heated whisper. In recent months albums by Tony Rich, D'Angelo, Omar Lye-Fook and now Maxwell have redefined romance in rhythm-and-blues, putting a hip-hop spin on it.

title: Who Came First?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAYSIDE;'Disneyfort' Joke Was a Panic
description: It didn't match Orson Welles's "War of the Worlds" Halloween hoax, but a Queens weekly newspaper provoked a small panic last week with an article on Disney's ground-breaking ceremony for a theme park at Fort Totten. The date atop the page: April Fool's Day.

title: Boaters at 79th St. Basin Aren't Restricting Access
description: To the Editor:

title: Grim Reaper;Harvesting Evidence in Bosnia's Killing Fields
description: IN a field of mud, in the rain, three men were digging last week. It was a forlorn scene. One man was pulling up chunks of clay out of the short trench they were making. The other two were clearing the dripping clay by hand from their shovels after each bite into the ground. In a small meadow of a remote valley, these workers could easily have been three Bosnian peasants stuck with the task of digging a well.

title: Stunt Plane Crash Kills One Occupant
description: A single-engine stunt plane crashed in an open field here today, killing one person and critically injuring another, the police said.

title: A BOARDROOM OF ONE'S OWN
description: I'd like to think that "A Boardroom of One's Own," by Michael Lewis (The Capitalist, March 17), is a joke. Does the presence of one lone woman on a board make her responsible for its collective action?

title: Of a Mr. Fix-It And a Legacy Of Spending
description: How a Would-Be Mr. Fix-It Left a Company in Ruins" (March 24), by Kurt Eichenwald, examined the rise and recent fall of Paul G. Kahn as chairman of the Ideon Group, formerly Safecard Services. The article, which discussed Mr. Kahn's spending on Ideon projects that were later abandoned, drew reader responses from within and outside the company.

title: Q and A
description: Long-Term Car Lease

title: Shere Hite, Now a German Citizen, Finds Appreciation and Celebrity
description: SHERE HITE is enjoying being feted in Germany, where her March 29 defection from the United States is being celebrated as a political coup.

title: BASEBALL;Jeter Quietly Goes About Business
description: You are 21 years old and starting at shortstop for the Yankees. You are already being mentioned as a Rookie of the Year candidate and you have been the most impressive player on the field when it has not been drenched. You are creeping toward the stardom that has been forecast since 1992. You could behave like a star or you could continue behaving like your modest self. Derek Jeter behaves like himself and that is refreshing. Very refreshing.

title: DANCE;Alumni Step Back in Time to Their Alma Mater
description: ONCE, Princeton University had neither dance nor women. Both arrived in the late 1960's. Before that, Princeton students were supposed to appreciate dance and the arts and, one assumes, women. But they were only supposed to watch. They weren't expected to take part, to do anything.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Testimonial to Education, in Its Richest Sense
description: IF you ask a theatergoer to do a memory search of all-time emotional wringers, is there a cad who wouldn't rank the final moments of "The Miracle Worker" near the top?

title: Inmate Upsets Seizure Policy on Drugs
description: Condemned to live and die behind the blank dun walls of the Federal prison here, Michael L. Montalvo, inmate No. 87224-012, has one great consolation.

title: Habitats/Chatham, N.Y.;A 'Playhouse for Adults'
description: THE game room above the garage is, as the new owner says, a "playhouse for adults," with its huge inlaid billiard table, its wall racks full of cues and its Ping-Pong table and its overstuffed sofas.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE;In Lesbian Archive, Education and Sanctuary
description: You can't get the address of the Lesbian Herstory Archives over the phone, and if you do find its street in Park Slope, the only detail that distinguishes it from other homes on the block of four-story limestones is the wheelchair ramp that, while conspicuous, manages to fade into the building's facade.

title: Alphabet Dancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Man's Quiet Life Shields Turbulent Past
description: None of the regulars at the Maywood Express diner in this faded Chicago suburb knew much about Melvin Taylor's past or, as it turned out, his real name, even though their quiet buddy came in almost every morning for years and ordered the $2.50 special: two pancakes, two sausages and two eggs, over easy.

title: March 31-April 6;Herd Journalism
description: Amazing headline coincidences:

title: PRO BASKETBALL: NOTEBOOK;Bulls Have Little to Fear but Magic
description: It appears that nothing will stop the Chicago Bulls from winning 70 games. So the bigger question becomes: Can anyone stop the Bulls from winning a championship?

title: Who Needs More Evidence of Police Brutality?
description: To the Editor:

title: IN BRIEF;To Market, to MarketIn a Very Big Way
description: Burlington County freeholders envision supermarket trucks pulling into what is now 660 empty acres straddling Burlington and Florence Townships along the Delaware River as they consider authorizing a multimillion-dollar wholesale food market that could serve as a catalyst for revitalizing the aging towns along the Route 130 corridor.

title: Baseball Books in Brief
description: WRIGLEYVILLE A Magical History Tour of the Chicago Cubs. By Peter Golenbock. St. Martin's, $24.95.

title: HOCKEY;Devils Spot Daylight, Then Romp Toward It
description: Tampa Bay left the door ajar Friday night, and the Devils opened it wide this afternoon. The Stanley Cup champions routed the Whalers, 6-3, at the Civic Center to remain very much alive in the playoff race.

title: WEDDINGS;Olexa C. Goldman, Bowen C. Farrell
description: Olexa Celine Goldman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert I. Goldman of New York, was married in New York yesterday to Bowen Cooper Farrell, a son of Haddon B. Montgomery of Santa Barbara, Calif., and Charles F. Farrell Jr. of Newport Beach, Calif. Judge Guido Calabresi of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York officiated at the University Club.

title: THEATER;The Funny Thing Was, How Old Humor Is
description: When the Broadway revival of "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum" opens on April 18 at the St. James Theater, the gods of ancient comedy will once again be invoked. Based on a series of plays that date from the time of the Romans, "Forum" was written by Burt Shevelove and Larry Gelbart, with music and lyrics by Stephen Sondheim. The current production, now in previews, stars Nathan Lane, with Mark Linn-Baker, Lewis J. Stadlen and Ernie Sabella among the cast choreographed by Rob Marshall and directed by Jerry Zaks.

title: Friends of Bull
description: THE LAST HOTEL FOR WOMEN By Vicki Covington. 300 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $23.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 24 about the importance of master classes in the preservation of dance tradition misstated the surname of a dancer with American Ballet Theater. She is Sara Mau, not Moore.

title: A BOARDROOM OF ONE'S OWN
description: Michael Lewis's essay is provoking only in the way that a tirade from Rush Limbaugh, spewing stereotypes and bigotry, wrenches my gut. Lewis may be making a point, while insulting women with his ugly, broad brushstrokes, but I don't get it.

title: The Right to Suicide, Some Worry, Could Evolve Into a Duty to Die
description: Now that two Federal appeals courts have lifted bans on physician-assisted suicide, many in medicine are struggling with a tormenting question: Will the right to die become the duty to die?

title: Capturer of Hearts
description: JOHN'S WIFE By Robert Coover. 428 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $24.

title: Q and A
description: Getting A Variance On Zoning

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;The Sarge Is Back On Maneuvers
description: Oliver and Company Animated, with the voices of Billy Joel, Dom DeLuise, Robert Loggia, Bette Midler, Joey Lawrence, Natalie Gregory Directed by George Scribner G 73 minutes

title: Monet's American Neighbors
description: FOR Claude Monet, the flowers, the waterlilies and the pastoral setting of Giverny, the Norman village on the banks of the Seine where he lived and painted from 1883 until his death in 1926, were always a mixed blessing. They inspired great art, but they also attracted admirers and other painters, and somebody was always dropping in on the artist's paradise, hoping to chat, learn something from the master and perhaps study with him. He welcomed the visitors at first, but they began overwhelming him, and often he had to bar the door.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;And Now, Live From Beverly Hills, a New Museum
description: IT IS BETTER TO BE GOOD THAN original,Mies van der Rohe said, and his words could well apply to Richard Meier. Mr. Meier's architecture -- elegant, utterly refined, modernist to the core -- has not changed in any fundamental way since he made his stunning debut in the 1960's, and he has been both praised and criticized for this. To some he is a bulwark of consistency against an architectural world beset by fashion and trendiness. To others he is a one-trick pony with nothing new to say.

title: Catholic Tastes;How the Church Chose the Best Films Ever
description: IF the Vatican is wired for cable, one might imagine Pope John Paul II settling in tonight to watch "Moses," a four-hour TNT special starring Ben Kingsley.

title: Children's Books
description: RIDDLE RHYMES By Charles Ghigna. Illustrated by Julia Gorton. Unpaged. New York: Hyperion Books for Children. $13.95. (Ages 3 to 7)

title: Girls Are Hardly Doomed To Be Second-Class Citizens
description: To the Editor:

title: Just How American Was It?
description: THE VERACRUZ BLUES By Mark Winegardner. 251 pp. New York: Viking. $22.95.

title: QUICK BITE;A Cheesecake That's Good and Good for You
description: Peggy Skudera of Neptune City has won about 45 ribbons at the Monmouth County Fair for such high-calorie delights as a Grand Marnier cake. But it was a heart-healthy recipe, Miss Peggy's Guilt-Free Cheesecake, that took first prize in the "Eat Right New Jersey" contest sponsored by the American Heart Association and the Jersey Shore Medical Center at Neptune.

title: INVESTING IT;Less Cash, Large Losses: Apple's Dwindling Dollars
description: WILL Apple Computer run out of cash soon? David Dreman, the chairman of Dreman Value Advisors in Jersey City, thinks so. "The company can't continue on as it has for another 60 or 90 days," he said. "The cash drain will cause a crisis. Or force an enormous scaling back or the sale of the company."

title: C. Scoby Stroman, 64, Drummer-Dancer
description: C. Scoby Stroman, a drummer and jazz dancer, died on March 28 at Fort Hamilton Veterans' Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 64 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: High School Offers Honors to Alumni
description: AS one of his alma mater's most ardent sports boosters, and as a longtime junior team coach, Tom Corbo has maintained close ties with Norwalk High School since his graduation in 1950.

title: ART;. . . Complete With Psycho-Thrillers
description: FURTHER PROOF OF THE blossoming romance between artists and film makers today comes in the form of "Spellbound: Art and Film," a multimedia show at the Hayward Gallery, through May 6. Its feature attraction is Damien Hirst's "Hanging Around," a new 20-minute surreal psycho-thriller.

title: Questioning Role Of District Attorney
description: The article "Pirro Assailed Over News Breaks" (March 3) touched a very sore spot. I am one of many people who are angry over the way Randall Forrest, dean of students, was treated when he reported for arraignment at the Greenburgh police station on Feb. 13. The major television networks and the press were there. One might say they were only doing their job.

title: Leipzig Plans to Restore Once-Regal Train Station
description: To step off a train here is to enter, at least momentarily, a splendid lost world.

title: Prosecutors Are Ordered to Show Kevorkian's Intent Was to Kill
description: Prosecutors at the trial of Dr. Jack Kevorkian on assisted-suicide charges will have to prove that he intended to help two women kill themselves, and not merely that he provided them with the means to do so, the Michigan Court of Appeals ruled on Friday.

title: Father of the Blues Is Remembered In Mt. Vernon Show
description: ST. LOUIS BLUES" is one of those songs that seems to have always existed, almost too much an American classic to have been written by one person. Yet there was one -- William Christopher Handy, known as W. C. Handy -- who late in his life lived on the Tuckahoe-Yonkers border.

title: Voices at the Front: 'The Margin for Error Is So Slim'
description: "THE WORST experience I've ever had in my life was the midnight of the opening night of 'Blood Brothers.' Getting those reviews, standing in the middle of Times Square, thinking, 'What have I done?' I went to the Music Box Theater and said, 'I'm going to beat this all the way through.' I say, keep fighting."

title: FARM LIFE -- A special report.;Family Endures as Stewards of the Land
description: IN the light spring wind, something new and fresh was stirring in Bridgehampton: the budding season, part of the yearly ritual of a Long Island farm, a cycle with no beginning and no end.

title: Enemies List
description: THE CAMPAIGN By Marilyn Tucker Quayle and Nancy Tucker Northcott. 478 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers/ Zondervan Publishing House. $22.

title: Sunday April 7, 1996: GOING TO SEED;Ripe With Personality
description: Realizing that sensitive gardeners tend to treat their offshoots as friends, if not downright family, seed companies are cleverly humanizing many of the new varieties they offer every spring. Take the personalized tomato, for instance:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Dangerous Abstractions
description: At first glance, a Ph. D. in mathematics, the subject often called the handmaiden of science and engineering, seems an odd credential for a Luddite. Yet Theodore J. Kaczynski, the suspected Unabomber, received such a degree from the University of Michigan in 1962. What are we to make of this?

title: FOOD;More Inviting Ways to Serve Asparagus
description: IN Italy when the first new vegetables of spring appear, they are often served with pasta. Young fava beans make a delicate sauce for fettuccine when combined with asparagus, prosciutto, cream and leaves of fresh tarragon (the beans are also delicious peeled and eaten raw with pecorino cheese). Asparagus goes well with shrimp, too, served in a more robust sauce made with tomatoes and onions, which goes well with farfalle (pasta shaped like bow ties).

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: BAYSIDE Finding Poetry In Human Rights

title: Barbara McLean, Film Editor At 20th Century-Fox, Dies at 92
description: Barbara McLean, an Oscar-winning Hollywood film editor whose influence at 20th Century-Fox extended far beyond the cutting room, died on March 28 at a convalescent home in Newport Beach, Calif. She was 92 and had lived in Newport Beach since her retirement in 1969 after 20 years as head of the studio's editing division.

title: A Peace Plan for the Cigarette Wars
description: It was a few days before Christmas, and the Massachusetts Attorney General, Scott Harshbarger, was holding forth with the fire-breathing wrath now standard in the national war against smoking. Bay State citizens "have paid too much in staggering human and financial costs for a poisonous product," Harshbarger thundered, before declaring that his state would become the fifth to sue for recovery of the tax dollars it had spent on health care for the customers of predatory cigarette manufacturers. He put the price at more than 10,000 lives and $200 million annually.

title: Divining Russia
description: At a Century's Ending Reflections, 1982-1995. By George F. Kennan. 351 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $27.50.

title: Fielder Belongs
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: DINING OUT;Dishes Influenced by the Pacific Rim
description: THE curious logo of SoNoMa distinguishes a new ownership, different from the last, which chose a more conventional spelling of its name. Unlike the former occupant, this new restaurant is not rigidly tied to the Sonoma Valley, its wines and cuisine. While the new menu does, to some extent, reflect the cooking of the West Coast, the kitchen seems to look beyond, to the Pacific Rim. SoNoMa's cooking is hardly exotic but offers mellow versions of this influence. More familiar dishes like pasta and, at lunch, pizzas are also available.

title: RELIGION;Zoning Battles Erupt as Some Churches Move or Expand
description: Two years ago, an interdenominational church with more than 6,000 member families made plans to move from its cramped quarters here to a much larger property in Sayreville, about 10 miles away. But Sayreville's zoning board fought the move, saying that the area where Faith Fellowship Ministries wanted to build a sprawling complex was zoned for industrial use and the presence of a church would discourage businesses from moving there.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS;Bookshelf
description: THE MIDDLE PASSAGE: White Ships/Black Cargo. Written and illustrated by Tom Feelings. Dial. $45. (All ages) This distinguished American artist spent nearly 20 years studying the Atlantic slave trade and tells the story, wordlessly, in 64 dramatic black-and-white narrative paintings, beginning with capture in Africa. The agony of the death ships is powerfully conveyed. There is a fine map of the African diaspora in the Americas as well as a bibliography. A book for careful study and discussion, both at home and in the classroom. MARRYING MALCOLM MURGATROYD. By Mame Farrell. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14. (Ages 8 to 12) Hannah is convinced her parents want her to marry the son of their best friends, even if Malcolm Murgatroyd is, by sixth-grade standards, a complete dork. Gently amusing.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Memories Are Made of This

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: EASTCHESTER BAY;Bronx Canyons That Aren't Concrete
description: THE cliffs and mansions along the shoreline of Eastchester Bay in the Bronx will be explored by walkers on Saturday, and they are advised to bring along water and good shoes because the tour is a hike of eight or nine miles.

title: Not Zoned for Music in Greenwich
description: MOST of Joyce Newton's neighbors in Greenwich find it quite charming to see her with students at the grand piano in her front window. But at least one reported Ms. Newton to zoning officials for running a "music studio" from her home. The result was a furor among music lovers from as far away as Boston and Vermont.

title: GOOD EATING;For Stylish Dining In the East 60's
description: AUREOLE*** (212) 319-1660; 34 East 61st Street; $$$(c) all major credit cards

title: March 31-April 6;Just a Simple Pap Test
description: Regular Pap tests catch cervical cancer at an early stage when it can easily be cured. But many women fail to get them. As many as 5,000 American women die of cervical cancer yearly. A panel of medical experts convened by the National Institutes of Health last week concluded that virtually every one of those deaths could have been avoided if the women had Pap smears. The group also said that half of the more than 15,000 women who are newly diagnosed with cervical cancer yearly never had the test. GINA KOLATA

title: MANY STATES GIVE POLLUTING FIRMS NEW PROTECTIONS
description: Urged on by a coalition of big industries, one state after another is adopting legislation to protect companies from disclosure or punishment when they discover environmental offenses at their own plants.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;Nothing Seems to Stop the Flow at Stock Funds
description: DESPITE piling one gain upon another in 1995, managers of mutual funds that invest primarily in American stocks did something in the first quarter of this year that they were unable to do most of last year: outperform the market average.

title: Good Grooming Meets Good Groovin' At J. Luv's Hip-Hop Barbershop
description: THERE'S a steady buzz around J. Luv's Spot, and it's not just from the electric hair clippers that seem to mow heads nonstop at this cozy, new midtown Manhattan barbershop.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: WRITING WORKSHOPS

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets Become a Team That Makes the Bucks Look Good
description: This is how bad things are for the Nets: Six weeks after they appeared primed for a serious playoff run, they have sunk to the depths of the Atlantic Division. Worse, they cannot even handle the lowly Bucks, who had lost 16 of their last 17 and had only 9 road victories all season.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Sunday April 7, 1996;A QUESTION FOR: Jacob Lurie
description: An 18-year-old math wizard from Bethesda, Md., he recently won the $40,000 top prize in the annual Westinghouse science competition for a project on surreal numbers.

title: THEATER;'Carousel,' Surviving To Become A Classic
description: ON opening night -- March 22, 1945 -- the performance lasted more than four hours. Agnes De Mille hated the big ballet she had created for the second act. So did the audience. Nor did it cotton to the characters Mr. and Mrs. God. Even The Christian Science Monitor objected. The couple was sitting in the parlor, nobody's idea of Heaven, in judgement of Billy Bigelow, the neer-do-well carnival barker who had killed himself. Pretty glum stuff for a musical.

title: ART;How a Curator Temporarily Turns Into a Judge
description: THE New Jersey Center for Visual Arts has been staging its annual International Juried Show for more than 10 years now, and the ground rules are firmly in place. What goes into the exhibition is up to a single judge with strong credentials in the New York art world. For this year's competition, the judge was Thelma Golden, associate curator of the Whitney Museum of American Art and director of the Whitney's Phillip Morris branch in Manhattan.

title: Safety Note
description: Fire officials recommend changing the batteries in smoke alarms twice a year, when daylight saving time starts and ends. This spring, that is today.

title: Baseball Books in Brief
description: SABR PRESENTS THE HOME RUN ENCYCLOPEDIA The Who, What, and Where of Every Home Run Hit Since 1876. Edited by Bob McConnell and David Vincent. Macmillan, $40.

title: MAKING IT WORK;Devout and Daring
description: THE 11 o'clock hour is still the most segregated hour in America," the Rev. David Dyson says, his words echoing in the cavernous main theatre of the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church. Its walls are covered by a Fort Greene streetscape depicting a random assemblage of local people -- a symbol of Lafayette's multiracial spirit. "That is not true here."

title: Sports of The Times;Hey, George, How About $140 Million?
description: NOW that the Mayor wants to gift-wrap $1.06 billion for the Yankees to star in West Side Story, it is time for George Steinbrenner to put up or shut up.

title: New Poll Finds Strength for Dole On Personal and Political Traits
description: Though Senator Bob Dole was ridiculed by his rivals in the Republican primaries as unelectable in November, he shows considerable strength against President Clinton on many traits, including leadership, personal values and his vision for the country, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: A BOARDROOM OF ONE'S OWN
description: When Michael Lewis "spotted a chilling sign over the desk of a female employee" (saying men should be castrated), the men employed there should have sued the woman for sexual harassment and for creating a hostile work environment.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: REGO PARK;After 2 Stores Open, Business Strolls Back to Queens Blvd.
description: When Alexander's department store closed its doors in 1992, it took with it much of the surrounding foot traffic along Queens Boulevard and left a big void in Rego Park. Without its overflow of shoppers, many long-time merchants followed suit and closed their doors. Those who clung on said sales dropped by 20 percent. Their hopes were all but dashed when Caldor declared bankruptcy in the fall and withdrew its plan to open in the Alexander's building.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: TELEPHONING;Dial 787 for Puerto Rico
description: Puerto Rico, currently covered under the same area code (809) as 18 other Caribbean islands, is getting its own area code: 787.
