Increased demand for telephone service has made the new code necessary. The new and old area codes will both work until January 1997, when 787 (which spells out PUR, the island's Olympic designation) becomes the only code.

title: In Hartford, the River Is Beckoning Once Again
description: ALONG Interstate 91 in Hartford, concrete columns are rising out of the mud, forming the pillars that will support a 1.25-acre landscaped plaza that will allow people to walk from downtown, over the highway, to the edge of the Connecticut River.

title: OFF THE SHELF;Mixing Religion and Capitalism, Sometimes Uneasily
description: IT'S the season of Easter and Passover, of Holy Scripture and Haggadahs -- an apt time to look at some recent books that try to combine religious teachings and business tenets.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FORT GREENE;2 Grieving Women Sue Gun Manufacturers
description: One of the things that Freddie Hamilton remembers most vividly about the funeral of her youngest son is the terror in the eyes of the other mothers who went to pay respect. Caught in a spray of gunfire, Njuzi Hamilton, 17 years old, was killed by a single bullet to the head nearly three years ago. As the Fort Greene neighborhood women -- particularly those trying to rear boys -- went up to the front of the church to embrace her, each whispered, "I am so scared."

title: THE NIGHT;Theater As Rebuff, As Fashion
description: MADELINE KAHN doesn't have fond memories of playing Shakespeare as a Hofstra student.

title: Our Towns;Transforming A New House Into a Home
description: PEARL COLE'S place stands at the end of a tidy row of five two-and three-story town houses with cream-colored vinyl siding, little rectangular lawns and colonial lantern porchlights. It looks like one of the many condominium developments springing up along the highways, yet the street seems as quiet as the deep, green suburbs. Ms. Cole can almost pretend she has moved far away, not just from one housing project to another in Newark's Central Ward.

title: Greer Garson, 92, Actress, Dies; Won Oscar for 'Mrs. Miniver'
description: Greer Garson, the actress who epitomized a noble, wise and courageous wife in some of the sleekest and most sentimental American movies of the 1940's, died yesterday morning at Presbyterian Hospital in Dallas. She was 92.

title: HORSE RACING;Upset Victory by Cavonnier Boosts Rider's Derby Hopes
description: All winter long, the jockey Chris McCarron figured Cobra King was his ticket to the Kentucky Derby. But when that colt ran poorly in last month's Florida Derby, then was found earlier this week to have an injury that will keep him out of the Kentucky Derby, McCarron lost his best chance.

title: CHATTER;The Governor and Her Future
description: Governor Whitman told Bob Dole that she was not interested in the Republican Vice Presidential nomination. Did she make the right decision?

title: Tapestry of Links in the Unabom Inquiry
description: On May 25, 1978, a package was found in a parking lot at the University of Illinois's campus in downtown Chicago. The return address bore the name of a scientist at Northwestern University in nearby Evanston, and the parcel was forwarded to him. But he did not recognize it, so he alerted campus security guards, who opened it. It exploded.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about American poetry misstated the name of the literary organization connected with National Poetry Month. It is the Academy of American Poets, not the American Academy of Poets.

title: Of a Mr. Fix-It And a Legacy Of Spending
description: How a Would-Be Mr. Fix-It Left a Company in Ruins" (March 24), by Kurt Eichenwald, examined the rise and recent fall of Paul G. Kahn as chairman of the Ideon Group, formerly Safecard Services. The article, which discussed Mr. Kahn's spending on Ideon projects that were later abandoned, drew reader responses from within and outside the company.

title: YOUR HOME;Pointers On Co-op Meetings
description: OVER the next several weeks, shareholders in co-ops will engage in a spring ritual that will be frustrating for some, rewarding for others, infuriating for a few and boring for many. It is the annual shareholders' meeting.

title: Baseball Books in Brief
description: THE YANKEE ENCYCLOPEDIA By Mark Gallagher. Sagamore, $39.95.

title: Corrections
description: A foreign exchange listing in the Travel Watch column on page 11 of the Travel section today misstates last year's rate for the Italian lira. One dollar was worth 1,642 lire, not 1,6421.

title: 2 Coaches Ousted as Charges Fly
description: TWO high school coaches have lost their jobs, and complaints about performance and interference are flying. The Jericho School District is investigating one incident, and the Kings Park School District has closed its case in the other.

title: HOCKEY;Wings' Victory March Has a Russian Flavor
description: When Scotty Bowman comes off the ice after practice and stops to chat in Joe Louis Arena, he folds his hands over the end of his hockey stick and leans on it for balance. On his hands, the coach of the Detroit Red Wings wears red and blue gloves that have nothing to do with the uniform of the team.

title: BEST SELLERS: April 7, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;Why Is Alou Smiling? Here's Why
description: Felipe Alou was unexpectedly upbeat. This was a day early in spring training, and the manager of the revenue-poor Montreal Expos was not looking for sympathy. In fact, the constant regeneration the Expos seem to undergo because they shed their highest-priced players had not dampened Alou's outlook at all.

title: In the Air: From Flying Machines to Balloons to Space Capsules
description: THE Bruce Museum's arcade gallery has been transformed into a lighted runway, where aircraft models suspended from beams seem ready for take-off. Viewers are invited to inspect a time line illustrating the history of aviation from Leonardo da Vinci's flying machines to balloons to outer space capsules.

title: Invasion of the Body Snatchers
description: The Demon-Haunted World Science as a Candle in the Dark. By Carl Sagan. 457 pp. New York: Random House. $25.95.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: IN PERSON;Work on the Wild Side
description: If it's Thursday night at Tom Brown's school, it must be time for brain-tanning, the technique of softening raw deerhide with the animal's brains to make it suitable for clothes and moccasins.

title: A Man and His Tower Made Radio Sing
description: Edwin Howard Armstrong loved heights. When he built the 425-foot radio tower on the Palisades here in the late 1930's, he would climb it and swing from its 150-foot arms in a specially rigged deck chair. From the top of the tower, he could see the far tip of Long Island.

title: Baseball Books in Brief
description: NICE GUYS FINISH FIRST By Monte Irvin with James A. Riley. Carroll & Graf, $22.

title: Of a Mr. Fix-It And a Legacy Of Spending
description: How a Would-Be Mr. Fix-It Left a Company in Ruins" (March 24), by Kurt Eichenwald, examined the rise and recent fall of Paul G. Kahn as chairman of the Ideon Group, formerly Safecard Services. The article, which discussed Mr. Kahn's spending on Ideon projects that were later abandoned, drew reader responses from within and outside the company.

title: COPING;Me, an Isle of Tranquillity on Third Avenue
description: THE news that members of the city's Coast Guard contingent are taking up yoga to smooth the waves of change did not stir a ripple at the posture palace where I go several times a week to wring myself out. That's what yoga is really about, twisting your soul back into shape, and it's too bad the Coast Guard didn't find out about it before they had to face the stress of moving from Governors Island, one of the city's least likely neighborhoods.

title: The Tax-Reform Obsession
description: STEVE FORBES'S PRESIDENTIAL CAM-paign may have crashed and burned, but tax reform lives on, and on, and on. Should President Clinton lose in November, a flat tax will become a top priority in Congress. Even if he should win, Republicans will spend the next four years blaming the tax system for all our economic failings. Either way, we will continue to hear a lot about taxes, which raises a question.

title: Foreign Affairs;Politics In the Age Of Nafta
description: I was in Asia a few weeks ago when the Australians held their national election, and I was struck by how much of their campaign revolved around biscuits and bathing suits. Therein lies a revealing tale.

title: Out-of-State Students And What They Add
description: To the Editor:

title: SPOTLIGHT;Songs and Sinners
description: What's this - Sir Laurence Olivier galloping on a horse and singing? Yes, and it's not bad. His pleasant tenor and sauve portrayal of a rogue highwayman (Macheath) add ironic spice to Peter Brook's BEGGAR's OPERA (1953). This is a lively, stylish version of John Gay's raffish, 18th-century operaetta satirizing London low life - THURSDAY at NOON on BRAVO. A game cast shares the sly, period ballads. What you'll miss is the sound of Kurt Weill's devastating, Jazzy music for "Threepenny Opera," the historic 1928 update fo Gay and a 1931 German film. It lurks (like "Mac the Knife"); watch for it.

title: Pakistan Is Showing Little Gain on Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Drop in Crime Slows

title: March 31-April 6;An Infant's Death Provokes New Questions
description: Last week the case of 5-month-old Mariah Scoon turned from one involving parents' insistence on keeping their brain-dead child on a ventilator to a case of parental abuse. The New York City Medical Examiner concluded that violent shaking had caused the brain damage. While on the ventilator, her heart stopped last month. Lois Scoon, a lawyer, and her husband, Malcolm, an anesthesiologist, denied abusing the baby. When Mariah was first hospitalized, the issue was the ambiguity of state laws requiring hospitals to accommodate relatives who objected to taking a brain-dead patient off life support. The Queens District Attorney's office must now decide whether to pursue criminal charges against the parents. DARYL ROYSTER ALEXANDER

title: SOCCER;Wynalda Strikes Late in Opener
description: The latest effort to create a major outdoor pro soccer league in the United States kicked off with fireworks and balloons tonight and, after 87 frustrating minutes, there was even a goal.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Italy Comes to 57th Street By Way of Downtown

title: Streetscapes/The Music Hall at Snug Harbor Cultural Center;A Low-Budget Revival for a Grand 1890 Theater
description: NEW YORK CITY is just now beginning to revive the grand, boxy 1890 Music Hall at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center on Staten Island and when it has finished spending $3 million in the fall of 1997 the walls will be largely raw plaster and brick, the paint will be peeling and the original spiky iron light fixtures will still be broken.

title: Suicide Rates Are Rising for the Unpopular, Harassed Police Force inParis
description: Parisians do not have warm feelings for their police. Older people remember them as collaborating with the German occupiers. Middle-aged Parisians still resent their rough repression of the 1968 student movement.

title: Insurance a Thorn For Coastal Houses
description: A VIEW of the ocean, the Sound, the bay or any other body of water can add tens of thousands of dollars to the value of a Long Island house.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN UP CLOSE;Cable Wars: Liberty Gets New Ally
description: David just got a powerful slingshot in his fight against Goliath. Liberty Cable, the self-styled underdog in competition with giant Time Warner Cable for control of cable service in choice Manhattan apartments, sold 80 percent of itself last week to a unit of Peter Kiewit Sons', a Nebraska conglomerate even larger than Time Warner Cable.

title: You Have Now Entered the Black Hole of American Politics
description: This could be the longest intermission in the history of American political theater.

title: A Reply to Letter On Multi-Culturalism
description: It was with interest and curiosity that I read the letter by Richard F. Welch (March 17] on his views on "Multi-Cultural Education: Immersion Lesson for Students."

title: Montana Standoff Continues; Woman and Daughter Leave
description: Hopes for a peaceful end to the standoff between Federal agents and a tax resisters' group flickered today after a woman and her young daughter left the group's compound overnight.

title: West Side Yankees?
description: In a perfect world, the New York Yankees would not be thinking about leaving the Bronx. Instead, they would seize one of the sensible offers from New York City to renovate Yankee Stadium, improve its transportation links and revive the surrounding neighborhood.

title: ART;Honoring the Grosvenor, Well Ahead of Its Time
description: THE Grosvenor Gallery, which flourished in London from 1877 to 1890, might be thought of as an original alternative space -- it endeavored to show under-represented artists in an original way. Currently, the 19th-century gallery is recalled in an exhibition of 70 paintings, watercolors and other works at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven.

title: IN BRIEF;Children Go to College To Learn to Avert Violence
description: More than 550 schoolchildren from around New Jersey traveled to Richard Stockton College in Pomona last week for an all-day program the college created to prevent racism and violence in public schools.

title: Moye Freymann, 70, Population Scholar
description: Moye Wicks Freymann, who helped to develop more precise measurements in population studies as the director of the Carolina Population Center at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, died at UNC Hospitals in Chapel Hill on March 30. He was 70.

title: Of a Mr. Fix-It And a Legacy Of Spending
description: How a Would-Be Mr. Fix-It Left a Company in Ruins" (March 24), by Kurt Eichenwald, examined the rise and recent fall of Paul G. Kahn as chairman of the Ideon Group, formerly Safecard Services. The article, which discussed Mr. Kahn's spending on Ideon projects that were later abandoned, drew reader responses from within and outside the company.

title: Ideas & Trends;The Justices' Life-or-Death Choices
description: LAST week's decision by a Federal appeals court striking down a 19th century New York criminal law against aiding or abetting suicide has thrust a new question to the top of the nation's legal agenda: Do terminally ill patients have a constitutionally protected right to choose physician-accelerated death?

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST HARLEM;Are Carnivals Good, Clean Fun or Plain Old Nuisance?
description: To many, summer carnivals are a fixture of life in East Harlem, rollicking events with rides, games of chance and other forms of gambling and music and beer sold from legal stands and illegal ice-packed shopping carts. To others, the carnivals are a nuisance, and every year a slew of complaints from residents about public drinking, urination, noise and litter arise from the events.

title: Groups Predict New York Hospital Closings
description: With the managed care revolution steamrolling through New York City, two leading research groups predict that in the next three years it will force at least 15 of the city's 78 hospitals to shut down and more than 12,000 hospital beds and up to 80,000 jobs to be eliminated.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;The Sarge Is Back On Maneuvers
description: Wallace and Gromit: The Best of Aardman Animation A festival of animated shorts, April 10-23 at Film Forum in Manhattan Assorted Claymation figures Directed by Nick Park, Peter Peake and others No rating 77 minutes

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 3/ Facing a possible cash crunch, Apple Computer has already lost its dividend and stretched payments to suppliers. Will that be enough? By Andrea Adelson.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Dr. Terrell Ward Bynum;The Internet: In Need of a Value System
description: TERRELL WARD BYNUM is a professor of philosophy and director of the Research Center on Computing and Society at Southern Connecticut State University in New Haven. Since 1978, Dr. Bynum, has been conducting research in computer ethics. He was a chairman of Ethicomp 95, an international symposium at De Montford University in Leicester, England, and is one of the organizers of a new computer ethics consortium that has brought together scientists from all over the world.

title: How Top-Flight Dance Got to the Shoreline
description: Mariam McGlone likes to say that she did not chose dance -- it chose her. She danced as a girl and then in the 1930's and early 1940's, traveled around the world with professional modern dance companies.

title: THE GREAT OUTDOORS;Nobody's Happy When Autumn's Leaves Are Picked Up in the Spring . . .
description: The trees may not have even begun to bud yet, but foliage enthusiasts should have no trouble finding their fill of leaves this April: they're blanketing the front lawn and lying in heaps in the gutter.

title: ON THE JOB;The Language Barrier as Mount Everest
description: Remember that old song, the one that said little things mean a lot? How true that is, especially in foreign travel. Just when business people hope to be on their best behavior, a word here or a gesture there can turn them into boors or laughingstocks. Read on.

title: The New York Times Business Best Seller
Hjalmar P. Hvam Skier and Inventor, 93
description: Hjalmar P. Hvam, a top United States skier in the 1930's and inventor of the ski safety binding, died of a heart attack on March 30. He was 93.

title: Backtalk;The Cost of Luxury Could Blow Sky-High
description: There is a dirty word in real estate markets that probably won't be uttered by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani or by the Yankees owner George Steinbrenner in the months ahead, as the terms of a new baseball stadium are negotiated. The word is overbuilding.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENWICH VILLAGE;Agonizing Delays for AIDS Drug
description: For the 10 years that he has battled AIDS, Michael M. has relied on the Village Apothecary on Bleecker Street to help keep the cocktail of medicines he takes from causing more harm than good. George Manos, his pharmacist, keeps tabs on prescriptions, bills his insurers directly and offers deep discounts on AIDS drugs. But now Michael -- and hundreds of Village Apothecary customers with AIDS -- must go elsewhere to buy the latest drug, indinavir, which received Food and Drug Administration approval last month.

title: RENT';The Composers Of Our Time
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S DOING IN;Chicago
description: There are times in winter, when wicked cold slices to the bone and face-slapping gales come whipping off Lake Michigan, when almost every Chicagoan shivers in wonder: "Why do I live here?" The answer comes when spring finally breaks, when lovers and loners stroll through Grant Park, white masts of sailboats unfurl against the blue of Belmont Harbor, and the first crack of a Cubs bat gives voice to the hope that maybe, just maybe, this is going to be the year.

title: FILM VIEW;The Right Wing As Punching Bag
description: CONSERVATIVES ARE SIMPLE," says one of the proud-to-be-liberal graduate students in "The Last Supper," Stacy Title's lethally funny black comedy.

title: Like a Colossus
description: THE LAST HERO The Life of Mickey Mantle. By David Falkner. Illustrated. 255 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $24.

title: Former Driver Accuses Deputy Mayor of Bias
description: A former driver for Deputy Mayor Ninfa Segarra has filed a formal notice that he intends to sue New York City for discrimination and wrongful dismissal and has accused Ms. Segarra of using her official car for personal trips, his lawyer and city officials said yesterday.

title: Asian-American Men Use Art to Peel Away Stereotypes
description: WHO they are on the inside is how they want to be seen on the outside, so a group of Asian-American men came together to, in their own words, "peel the banana."

title: Stranger Than Fact
description: One Blood The Death and Resurrection of Charles R. Drew. By Spencie Love. Illustrated. 373 pp. Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press. $29.95.

title: Secularizing a Sacred Symbol
description: IT'S been several seasons since the monastic look hit fashion runways and more than a decade since Madonna first played ring around the rosary. Yet, to the delight of New York retailers, crosses remain brisk sellers. Especially in the category of fine jewelry.

title: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;A Gallery Of Victorians, Proper and Not So
description: ABRAHAM STRANSKY, A Brooklyn-born printer, lived in a cluttered apartment surrounded by magical images of people he had never met and whose names were long forgotten. There were men in funny hats, brides wearing white veils and dark dresses, dead infants, firemen, American Indians, ballet dancers and a group of male athletes with muscles bulging under tight cotton shirts.

title: March 31-April 6;Stopping Teen-Age Smoke
description: About three million teen-agers smoke, and the Government wants to put a dent in that by regulating ads that lure them. But tobacco companies insist their ads aim to get adults to switch brands. "Teens will follow adults," said a Tobacco Institute spokesman.

title: THE GREAT OUTDOOR;. . . But a Summer Fresh Tomato, in Winter, Is Worth Waiting For
description: The United States space program may not have been able to put anyone on Mars. But this week, in a futuristic greenhouse next door to the Burlington County landfill, a team of NASA-financed researchers will make public a scientific advance with even greater potential benefit for mankind: a lustrous, luscious, commercially viable, vine-ripened New Jersey winter tomato.

title: Coalition Opposes McDonald's Site In Port Washington
description: THE McDonald's Corporation wants to open a 104-seat restaurant in Port Washington, but a coalition of 12 civic groups opposes the proposed location.

title: A Merger Of Cellular Companies Is Announced
description: Seeking to plug a territorial gap in its cellular service, Airtouch Communications said yesterday that it would buy the 60 percent of Cellular Communications it does not already own for $1.65 billion.

title: Manhattan Looks to the East For Some Business Catering
description: AT DKNY's annual menswear runway show in an old warehouse on the West Side of Manhattan in February, waiters passed delectable trays of sushi and dim sum to a discerning crowd of 700.

title: WORD & IMAGE;Long Live the Monarchy!
description: THE NEW YORK TIMES HAS EXISTED FOR 145 years, but it is preparing to celebrate a centenary. The first of three commemorative Times Magazines this year will appear next week, to be followed by four major museum exhibitions, a centennial Book Review, a major Times donation to education and a royal feast for staff and friends. Royal indeed, because it's a monarchy we're toasting -- the 100th year of control of this notable enterprise by a single family descended from Adolph S. Ochs.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;New Ways for Fliers To Gather Those Points
description: Several companies are offering new ways to earn frequent traveler awards.

title: No Headline
description: Many of us think there is a ray of hope. I think the epidemic has peaked, and some people would say that it is on its way down."

title: JERSEY;The Militia Movement, Eastern Style
description: IT is difficult to keep it simple when discussing something as weird as the militia movement. Spend time with any typical militia true believer and you will be surprised at how fast a conversation about taxes or legal reform can march off into those dark psychological swamps where the media conspire to discredit bunco artists and check-kiters holed up in a Montana militia compound; where black helicopters swarm with United Nations commandos over the Southwestern desert, and phantom Vietnam M.I.A.'s languish as hostages to the C.I.A. heroin connection, financed by the Trilateral Commission on behalf of the Zionist Occupational Government -- all prophesied (you could look it up) in the Book of Revelation.

title: The Nation;Hiding Out Underneath The Big Sky
description: LAST CHANCE GULCH leads into the old stone buildings of Montana's capital, to Lewis and Clark County Jail, which now holds a man suspected of being one of the most sought-after fugitives of the century. Last Chance is not just a name for a main drag. In Montana, it seems like a state motto.

title: Army Complains of Delays in Plane Search
description: American military officials in charge of the search for the wreckage of Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown's plane say faulty communications and confusion over jurisdiction kept them from reaching the crash site until hours after the plane was found.

title: INVESTING IT;Wild Ride Fails to Sway Many Market Forecasters
description: IF early March seems like a long time ago to investors, no wonder: Ever since the Dow Jones industrial average took a 171-point plunge a month ago tomorrow, it has pumped itself up faster than did certain Presidential candidates in the early primaries. Not only did the Dow recoup much of its dip in a single day -- March 11 -- but as of the market's close on Thursday it had completely erased the drop and then some.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the Sports section last Sunday listing major league baseball schedules reversed the 1996 dates for two teams. The schedule shown for the Seattle Mariners was that of the Oakland Athletics, and vice versa.

title: Whither Bierce?
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Separate but Equal Quarters;2 Brothers Building Twinned Town House
description: Where once a 25-foot-wide town house stood on West 16th Street, a pair of brothers plans to build two residences in a single building split vertically.

title: Radio New Jersey: Is Everyone Listening?
description: TURNPIKE traffic, 10:30 in the morning. There's a car fire at Exit 18, and rubberneckers are backing up in the southbound lanes. The radio pops and snorts, and then, as the signal comes into focus, it begins to snarl.

title: March 31-April 6;Pensions for Ex-Presidents
description: With all the pomp of the national leader he was until last November, former President Lech Walesa of Poland arrived at his old workplace, the Gdansk shipyard, at 6.30 A.M. one day last week to reclaim his old job as an electrician. But he was making a point about his pension -- or the lack of it. Poland's first post-Communist ex-President had discovered he had no pension. His three months' severance pay ended last month.

title: Corrections
description: A table last Sunday with an article about a divorce settlement for the Princess of Wales misstated the data for Frances and Norman Lear. They were married 28 years, not 19; her $100 million award translated into $3.6 million, not $5.3 million, for each year of marriage.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;The Sarge Is Back On Maneuvers
description: Sergeant Bilko Steve Martin, Dan Aykroyd, Phil Hartman, Glenne Headly Directed by Jonathan Lynn PG 92 minutes

title: Why 'To Be Continued' Is Continued
description: AT a time when so much information keeps flooding over us that little from day to day seems to cohere anymore, the words "to be continued" may strike some readers as a luxury berth to a forgotten paradise. Surprisingly enough, those three words appear at the end of Stephen King's latest horror offering, the first installment of his six-part novel "The Green Mile," which is being serialized monthly in paperback. For all their nostalgic promise, the words prompt the question of whether it is possible to return to a literary practice that flourished more than a century ago and had pretty much petered out by the end of World War II.

title: Other Hospitals Offer Bone-Marrow Services
description: I was quite excited to read of the development of bone-marrow transplant services at St. Joseph's Hospital ["In Yonkers, the Cancer Fight Broadens," March 17]. The trend in providing advanced oncology care in community hospitals that was previously only available in large tertiary-care centers has been a positive one. Lower cost, more personalized care and equally positive outcomes are among the benefits.

title: GARDENING;Mystery Behind the Bark: The Surging Sap
description: THE other day while cleaning up winter debris from under a dogwood tree, it seemed some of the lower limbs and part of the trunk were soaking wet. The wetness was sweet to taste, too. This seemed like a curious phenomenon, at first. It sort of begged a return to the lessons of Botany 101.

title: At Car Show, National Identities Blur
description: THE globalization of the auto industry is taking new forms at the New York International Auto Show, which opened this weekend at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. From General Motors mini-vans designed simultaneously for the American and European markets, to Ford executives' proud-parent smiles over the birth of a British-bred luxury convertible, the distance from Detroit to other continents has never seemed shorter. The new G.M. family of mini-vans was designed and engineered with the help of Adam Opel A.G., the company's European subsidiary, and will be built in Georgia for sale in North America and Europe beginning in the fall. Two versions, the Opel and Vauxhall Sintra, will be sold in Europe.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BLACK HISTORY

title: OUT OF ORDER;Give Me Taxes the Old-Fashioned Way
description: THIS will not be a happy week: not just because we are all missing the extra hour of sleep so mysteriously stolen from us this morning, but because we are dreading a much more sophisticated form of robbery. In these last days before April 15, everyone is on edge. People cancel plans and appointments, friends turn down dinner invitations, because they are busy doing a mountain of unpaid clerical drudgery for the I.R.S. The instructions for Form 1040 alone fill a closely printed book of 75 pages. Is all this on the test, professor? You bet it is!

title: Baseball Books in Brief;Game Faces
description: George Brace is the type of photographer and baseball fan who concerns himself less with capturing frantic moments on the diamond than with collecting and sorting vast stores of arcane data and images. In THE GAME THAT WAS: The George Brace Baseball Photo Collection (Contemporary, $35), Richard Cahan and Mark Jacob, two editors at The Chicago Sun-Times, have taken photos from Mr. Brace's collection of hundreds of thousands of negatives (most of them made by Mr. Brace himself) and organized them into the kind of offbeat categories -- sluggers, players wearing glasses, players with funny names -- that card collectors love. The authors chose only black-and-white images taken from 1929 through 1960, and they provide ample baseball lore in their captions. Mr. Brace, who was born in 1913, documented many aspects of baseball, but his portraits and his grand views of the Chicago baseball parks, where he was based, hold the most interest. His best portraits are distinguished by the openness and humor of the players' faces; his images are suggestive of rural America of years past. In his close-ups, the visors of the head-hugging baseball caps serve to frame the faces, drawing the viewer into the animated exchange between photographer and subject. Yogi Berra becomes all grins and ears, Carl Hubbell's intense stare is riveting, and the young Ted Williams radiates self-assurance. When Mr. Brace turned his viewfinder toward Wrigley Field and Comiskey Park, the ball fields were rendered as vast, almost sacred places. Altogether, the book has the feel of a family album -- an intimate and glowing view of a comforting past. Rosemary Ranck

title: DON'T MESS WITH OUR CULTURAL PATRIMONY!'
description: Only part of the imperial collections was transferred to Taiwan by Chiang Kai-shek. Equally extensive imperial collections remain in Beijing, in the Forbidden City, and are examples of the finest quality. And "the greatest exhibition of Chinese art ever mounted in the West" may have been the International Exhibition of Chinese Art, held at the Royal Academy of Arts in London, 1935-36, which included works from imperial collections.

title: Public Affairs Unit Draws Praise for Pirro
description: I read the article about David Hebert's role in the Westchester County District Attorney's office. Jeanine Pirro, our county's very eloquent and competent District Attorney, has once again proven to be aware of our county's needs by hiring Mr. Hebert.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;St. John's Is Still Saying It Hasn't Hired a Coach
description: Amid reports that Manhattan Coach Fran Fraschilla has already been chosen as the St. John's basketball coach, the St. John's athletic director, Ed Manetta, denied yesterday that anything official had taken place.

title: 31 Killed in Sri Lanka
description: Fighting between the army and separatist guerrillas has again intensified in the island's north and east, with 31 people killed on Friday, the military said today.

title: The View From: Westport;Is There a New Lease on Life For Century-Old Toquet Hall?
description: IN the heart of downtown Westport's shopping and business center, renovation is well underway at Toquet Hall, a little-known 103-year-old building where a spacious second floor area has at various times served as Westport's gathering space for town meetings, a dance hall, a machine shop for two inventors and the town's first motion picture theater.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-10

title: A Search Through Time
description: Investigators in the Unabomber case are piecing together events in the life of their suspect, Theodore J. Kaczynski, and finding links to case chronology. Article, page 18.

title: Are Adult Stores Not for Milford?
description: Correction Appended

title: Sports of The Times;No. 42 Knows How to Fight Early Slump
description: NUMBER 42, a rookie, was the sensation of the Mets' training camp this spring, intriguing even opposing players to peek out of the dugout when he took batting practice. He crashed nine home runs, breaking a 21-year-old club record held by Dave Kingman, who used to hit balls over the moon.

title: RESTAURANTS;Good Seats Available
description: SURELY you've been to better-looking restaurants than Restaurant Juniper. What was this place anyway, an International House of Pancakes? A lounge?

title: EVENING HOURS;Bidding, Seeing and Being Seen
description: A gala for City Center, auctions for International House and the Metropolitan Opera Guild and a fashionable exhibition for cars.

title: March 31-April 6;Pursuit With Nightsticks
description: Just as the videotaped beating of Rodney G. King horrified Americans, a film of sheriff's deputies clubbing two unresisting Mexicans in Riverside County, Calif., has provoked outrage.

title: Moral Fiction
description: POETIC JUSTICE The Literary Imagination and Public Life. By Martha C. Nussbaum. 143 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $20.

title: Two Police Officers Hurt
description: Two New York City police officers suffered minor injuries yesterday when they were struck by a candle encased in a glass vase that fell from the roof of a 14-story apartment building in the Spanish Harlem section of Manhattan.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;La Jolla Art Museum Reopens, Restored
description: The La Jolla branch of the Museum of Contemporary Art, San Diego, has reopened after a $9 million expansion and renovation that will enable it to display its permanent collection concurrently with temporary exhibitions.

title: DINING OUT;Ah, Lemon Grass, Coriander and Chili
description: INDOCHINE PAVILION, a restaurant on Chapel Street in New Haven that used to be solely Vietnamese, is now a place for Thai and Laotian fare as well. Common to the three cuisines is an affinity for lemon grass, fresh coriander, noodles, kaffir lime, peanuts and chili.

title: LIVES;There Is Joy in Mudville
description: Mud season is upon us. The great thawing that began with the welcome plink, plink of maple sap dripping into metal sap buckets has now produced a terra infirma. Whole sections of this New Hampshire town are, for the moment, off-limits, the roads impassable wallows. Calls to the road agent are no use. The ruts are bottomless. And so, where there is no pavement, we walk, discovering once again the pleasures of squishing through the black ooze, watching the way it curls up around the sides of rubber boots. It is but a brief few weeks, this transition from frozen ground to a dry one. All too soon we will be caught up in the rush of spring chores. But for now, while we are up to our ankles in it, let us acknowledge the primacy of mud, this union of water and dust.

title: Never Too Rich
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;The Sarge Is Back On Maneuvers
description: Denise Calls Up Alanna Ubach, Tim Daly, Caroleen Feeny, Dan Gunther, Dana Wheeler-Nicholson, Liev Schreiber, Aida Turturro, Sylvia Miles Directed by Hal Salwen PG-13 80 minutes

title: South Korea Raises Alarm After North Enters DMZ
description: South Korea accused North Korea tonight of sending 260 heavily armed soldiers into a sensitive area of the demilitarized zone that divides North and South, creating a state of emergency along the border.

title: PERSPECTIVES;A New Turn in Brooklyn in Housing for the Elderly
description: SHE was 82, widowed, and living alone in a house in Cleveland. No close relatives lived nearby. She went to the hospital for an operation on her lower back. She came home needing full-time nursing care, and got it. But it didn't help her depression.

title: Baseball Books in Brief
description: TOGETHER WE WERE ELEVEN FOOT NINE The Twenty-Year Friendship of Hall of Fame Pitcher Jim Palmer and Orioles Manager Earl Weaver. By Jim Palmer and Jim Dale. Andrews & McMeel, $21.95.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article and picture caption last Sunday about bulkheading to protect oceanfront houses misstated the outcome of a dispute over steel bulkheading at the home of Leonard Holzer in Water Mill. It does not have to come down. A quotation from the Southampton Town Attorney, Lisa Kombrink, about reviewing the permit and its repercussions referred to an unrelated dispute, involving bulkheading at the property of Saul Steinberg in Quogue, not the Holzer property.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Stadiums' First Innings

title: Corrections
description: A map on March 3 in The Sophisticated Traveler, part 2 of The Times Magazine, with an article about the Silk Road, omitted the former Soviet republic of Kyrgyzstan, and a reader's letter dated March 23 pointed out the error. The republic is bounded by Kazakstan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan and China.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Blackboard pages of the special Education Life section last Sunday about Flashpoints, flashcards to help students study for the Scholastic Assessment Test, omitted part of the publisher's name. It is National Academic and Licensing Study Aids.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about problems in celebrity foundations referred incorrectly to the American Institute of Philanthropy. It evaluates nonprofit organizations' financial management; it is not a trade group.

title: Eclectic Santa Barbara
description: WELL-HEELED Easterners seeking health cures made Santa Barbara famous in the 1880's; they were soon followed by robber barons and industrialists tired of New England winters, who in turn attracted artists, spiritualists and exotic hangers-on. A century later, not much has changed: the money now often comes from Hollywood (Kevin Costner just finished building a beach house on Padaro Lane, near Secretary of State Warren Christopher's), but the atmosphere is still a combination of hedonism and spiritual self-improvement.

title: Teterboro and the Man Who Made It Flourish
description: To the Editor:

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;A Revised Amtrak Pass For Spring and Summer
description: Amtrak has revised and renamed its version of the rail pass for this summer. New Explore America fares allow 30 days of travel around one, two or all three regions of the lower 48 states. Unlimited stopovers are permitted -- they must be scheduled in advance -- but passengers generally may not travel twice over the same route in the same direction. The earlier version of this promotion, called All Aboard America, allowed only limited stopovers, although it was about $10 lower across the board.

title: WEDDINGS;Andre C. Houle, Angela T. Lewis
description: Angela Turnham Lewis, the daughter of the mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne of New York and the late Henry Jay Lewis Jr., was married yesterday evening in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., to Andre Charles Houle, a son of Patricia Courtney Houle and Rene Houle of West Chicago, Ill. Rabbi Barry Friedman performed the ceremony at the Inn at Rancho Santa Fe.

title: A BOARDROOM OF ONE'S OWN
description: Yet another example of the "Eve made me do it" syndrome. Call it what you will, it sounds like scapegoating to me.

title: The World;Donors of Foreign Aid Have Second Thoughts
description: THE 1990's have proven a grim time for foreign aid as we know it -- the grants and loans that are the traditional form of international development assistance. Everywhere these days, it seems, support for such aid is dwindling, and once-generous donors are focusing their energies inward.

title: Sex and Glamour a la Judith Krantz
description: SHE'LL be unavailable until 5:30, New York time. Will this be acceptable?"

title: Ex-Officials On Ballot Of Plumbers Cause Outcry
description: In New York City's construction industry, Plumbers Local 2 was once among the most powerful unions.

title: EARNING IT;Your Home Office Is in Order, But How About Your Taxes?
description: JUNE LANGHOFF has a large, bulging folder of receipts in her home office as well as a record of all her 1995 business expenses. But even though tax day is closing in, that is all the tax preparation she had done by late last week.

title: It's a Tough Time for the Democratic Party in Massachusetts
description: These are trying times for state Democratic legislators in Massachusetts. For starters, the Governor, William F. Weld, is a Republican. But last week things got a whole lot worse.

title: Westchester Q&A: Dr. Hesmat Majlessi;Beyond the Cosmetics in Varicose Veins
description: IT is estimated that as many as 80 million people in the United States have varicose veins, 90 percent of whom are women. To many, these twisted, discolored veins are just a cosmetic problem or something that causes a little discomfort. But all varicose veins have the potential for serious complications and, therefore, should be examined by experts, said Dr. Hesmat Majlessi, a vascular surgeon who heads the Rye Vein Care Center in Rye.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;The Sarge Is Back On Maneuvers
description: A Family Thing Robert Duvall, James Earl Jones, Irma P. Hall, Michael Beach Directed by Richard Pearce PG-13 110 minutes

title: From the Icy North, A Tale of Love And Rebellion
description: FOR ONE THING, the sleigh kept turning over. It would travel partly down the valley and then send the "corpse" it was carrying and its other passengers tumbling into the snow.

title: MUSIC;Young Performer, World Premiere
description: YOUTH and experience fuse in the Greater Bridgeport Symphony's final subscription concert of the season, at 8:30 P.M. on Saturday at Klein Memorial Auditorium.

title: Snow for Easter, Anyone? Winter Just Won't Leave
description: At home in Hoboken, N.J., yesterday afternoon, Ignatius Camporeale -- the meteorologist responsible for measuring snowfall in Central Park -- repeatedly tuned his radio to a Federal weather broadcast.

title: JERSEYANA;Coming Soon to Broadway: The Suburb of the Imagination
description: IT looks like a typical New Jersey suburb -- clapboard houses, church steeples, children playing in the street -- but it's on Broadway at the Shubert Theater.

title: March 31-April 6;Yeltsin Tells Russia Peace Is at Hand
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin opened his re-election campaign in Russia last weekend by announcing a unilateral cease-fire and promising that peace, in Chechnya, is at hand. Instead fierce fighting has continued, with more than 60 casualties on the Russian side alone. Shalazhi, a village about 35 miles southwest of Grozny, has been been bombed twice, suggesting that Mr. Yeltsin was either disingenuous or not in full control of the military command.

title: Sunday April 7, 1996: IDENTIFIED FLYING OBJECTS;Eggsotica
description: According to Ukrainian folklore, there's a huge monster chained to a cave wall in the bowels of the earth. For every painted Easter egg, or pysanky, as the beautiful Ukrainian eggs are called, another link in the beast's chain is forged, keeping it from visiting mayhem on the world. Unfortunately, these "eggs" are doing just the opposite, for they are actually embryonic fruit flies of the sort that grow up to plague man and beast alike. Through the miracle of confocal microscopy, scientists at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute in Wisconsin can now "dip" the embryos in dyes and determine genetic patterns, research that has contributed greatly to the study of human genetics. But while a green stripe on a pysanky symbolizes wealth and happiness, on a fruit fly it merely pinpoints a developing body part.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;Keeping Up Appearances
description: ONCE a month, one of the 900 maintenance employees at the Trump Taj Mahal pulls out every artificial plant in the lobby and washes it. Every two months, a team disassembles and cleans each of the casino's 82 enormous chandeliers, usually in the early morning. Once a year, workers drain the outdoor fountains, then steam-clean and repaint every space in the parking garage.

title: DIARY
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

title: Joan Jett Meets Jennifer Rizzotti
description: Who can take the world on with her smile?

title: THE UN-NOMINATED
description: It's no mystery why Jennifer Jason Leigh was snubbed by the academy. She implodes rather than projects her characters, as if the exposition is her own private concern. But, most of all, you can't understand what she's saying -- she mumbles.

title: On the Effects Of Grumman's Exit
description: The article, "Grumman's Exit is a Blow to Bethpage" (March 17), has all the elements of a plot for a movie, reminiscent of the recent film "Other People's Money."

title: ON LANGUAGE;Worth a Thousand Words
description: ONE PICTURE IS WORTH TEN thousand words."

title: A Protest Against 'Parking Lot' Streets
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuba Moves to Silence a Growing Voice of Journalism
description: In the six weeks since Rafael Solano was arrested and taken to the villa that houses Cuba's feared state security compound, the telephone in the journalist's home has rung like clockwork every 27 minutes, day and night, a persistent reminder to his family and his colleagues who gather there that the work they do is considered treason by the Cuban Government.

title: FABERGE AT THE MET;The Dark Side Of the Eggs
description: To the Editor:

title: Keep Affirmative Action
description: To the Editor:

title: BASKETBALL;Van Gundy Has a Pact, But Has No Guarantees
description: He does not have an agent or his own designer, but then, maybe he does not need them. Soon after Jeff Van Gundy was named the Knick coach on March 8, he signed a two-year contract extension worth $1 million a season to coach the team through the 1997-98 season, a team official has confirmed.

title: HOME CLINIC;Repairing Ball and Cartridge Faucets
description: FAUCETS are valves for controlling water. There are four basic faucet designs: compression, ball-type, cartridge and disk. When any faucet starts to drip, the problem is usually a worn seal or component. Fortunately, these parts are readily available and replacing them is simple. You can usually identify a faucet by its body configuration. Knowing the manufacturer can also help.

title: BASEBALL;Unlikely Staff Shuts Down Mets' Hitters
description: The Mets figure that with time, their spotty fielding will improve and their injured starting pitchers will heal. But the problem that could linger is the absence of a reliable power hitter who can rescue the Mets from a miserable hitting day, such as the one they endured yesterday at Shea Stadium.

title: SOAPBOX;Snake Hill, Mountain of Memories
description: ANYONE who drives the New Jersey Turnpike between interchanges 15E and 16E knows Snake Hill, if not by name, at least by sight. You can't miss it. The graffiti-covered crag in the Secaucus Meadowlands is one of the turnpike's most memorable landmarks.

title: ART VIEW;Art, Film and Their Brilliant, Messy Union
description: ONE THING IS CERTAIN ABOUT "Art and Film Since 1945: Hall of Mirrors," the big, ambitious survey at the Museum of Contemporary Art: it could have been a contender. This exhibition, which orchestrates an almost overwhelming mix of the work of 96 film directors and artists -- ranging from Hollywood, foreign and avant-garde film to painting, sculpture, photography and installation art -- seemed supremely blessed with possibility.

title: Pet Trainer's Body Found in Apartment
description: An animal trainer who once appeared on David Letterman's "Stupid Pet Tricks" segment with a Labrador retriever and a monkey was found dead in his Queens apartment, the police said yesterday.

title: THE UN-NOMINATED
description: Not since I saw Marlon Brando in "A Streetcar Named Desire" did I leave a cinema as stunned as after I watched Jennifer Jason Leigh in her role of Sadie Flood in "Georgia." If the Hollywood crowd didn't find this performance worthy of an Oscar nomination, so be it. Janet Maslin's article in your Magazine was, to my mind, worth two Oscars.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPDATE;It's a Whole New Showplace
description: The Pavilion, the historic Art Deco movie house on the southwestern edge of Prospect Park, opened its doors to moviegoers last Wednesday after two years of renovations and a decade of disuse.

title: Police Say Boys Die In a Suicide Pact
description: Two teen-age boys from North Carolina shot themselves to death after a state trooper pulled over their stolen car early today.

title: In Holocaust, Germans Had Willing Helpers
description: To the Editor:

title: Flashbacks
description: THE NAMES OF THE DEAD By Stewart O'Nan. 399 pp. New York: Doubleday. $23.95.

title: A LA CARTE;THe Flavors of American and Caribbean Fare
description: THE Cooke's In serves far more food than anyone has a right to expect for the prices that it charges. Generosity, warmth and smiles are the keynotes at this modest new storefront at 210 Depot Road in Huntington Station (424-2181). The restaurant offers hearty down-home Southern and American heartland dishes, Caribbean concoctions and a few Italian standards.

title: Hopeful East New Yorkers Await Police Drug Sweep
description: It is people like the man in the black beret who make Marisol Colon get off the street by dusk.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;High Noon Over the Hamachi
description: WHEN Angela Chan decided to have a sushi bar in her glatt kosher Chinese and Japanese restaurant near St. John's University in Queens last month, she thought she was ready for the challenge. After all, she already had experience in another glatt kosher Chinese restaurant, on Long Island.

title: Doubting Harolds;Looking Inside a Judge's Mind
description: JUDGES don't like to admit they make mistakes (they prefer to take their chances with a higher court). They do not often apologize for something they said. And rarely, if ever, do they change their mind about a case.

title: How About These Mets!
description: HIGH AND TIGHT The Rise and Fall of Dwight Gooden and Darryl Strawberry. By Bob Klapisch. Illustrated. 236 pp. New York: Villard Books. $22.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: Tuesday

title: Sssssh: A Primer on Sample Sales
description: As a lunch-hour ritual, Chante Oruam dashes across the street to 1410 Broadway in the garment district to Designers Liquidators, to see if new merchandise has arrived. She walks by the man handing out hot pink fliers, standing outside wearing a white cardboard sign saying "Sample Sale, Red Dot Shoe Special, $11," and goes down the steps into the basement.

title: March 31-April 6;Age Is More Than a Number
description: One of the few benefits of turning 40 is entry into the "protected class" of those covered by the Federal law that bars job discrimination on the basis of age.

title: Taster's Tour of the Santa Ynez Valley
description: SANTA BARBARA COUNTY is the Napa Valley of Los Angeles. The beautiful Santa Ynez Valley, just a short drive out Highway 154 from the city of Santa Barbara, is a wine region made to order for short breaks from Southern California smog and urban sprawl.

title: Unsolved Mysteries
description: WHO KILLED GEORGE POLK? The Press Covers Up a Death in the Family. By Elias Vlanton with Zak Mettger. Illustrated. 322 pp. Philadelphia: Temple University Press. $27.95.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;The Rise in Rates Dims the Lights for Utilities
description: UTILITY funds were among the poorest performers in the first quarter, hit by the same surge in interest rates that briefly sent the stock market reeling. Though the broad market more than recovered, the stocks of electric utilities did not, and analysts say fears of another rate increase will probably continue to depress the sector.

title: A Ray of Light in Africa's Struggle With AIDS
description: For the first time since AIDS began killing Ugandans in the early 1980's, there are strong signs that its spread has slowed markedly among young adults and that a new generation is less likely to become infected with the deadly virus because it has adopted safer sexual practices.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: MUSEUM;Dentistry, 3000 B.C.
description: Going to the dentist can be an ordeal. Going to the Dr. Samuel D. Harris National Museum of Dentistry, on the other hand, could be as refreshing as spearmint toothpaste. The museum is to open June 21 at 31 South Greene Street in Baltimore, on the University of Maryland at Baltimore campus. The three floors of displays include the four remaining sets of George Washington's dentures and exhibits on dentistry practices from as far back as 3000 B.C. There are even tributes to amazing dental feats, such as videotape of a water skier in his 80's gripping the towline with his teeth.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;Selling When the Tune Changes
description: WHILE investors hang onto their mutual fund shares for many reasons -- benign neglect is a common one -- most fund purchases are not lifelong commitments.

title: 80 Die in Somalia Fighting
description: Battles between rival warlords in southern Mogadishu have killed more than 80 people in the past two days, Red Cross officials said today. Sporadic gunfire still rang out today, and scores of civilians used the relative lull to flee for safer parts of the city. Most of the fighting has taken place near two major hospitals and around the main highway junction.

title: Despite Nonmusical Jobs, Regina Performers Are Pros
description: To the Editor:

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;When a Storm Cancels a Flight
description: IT was a winter for extremes, including monotonous conversation about the weather and travel difficulties.

title: Outcast Status Worsens Pain of Japan's Disabled
description: He sits back in his wheelchair now and laughs about it, but as a child it was a burden more excruciating than his crippled body and deformed hands: the gradual awareness that what his father felt for him was not love but embarrassment, that even those he lived with regarded him as a monster.

title: HOW WE EAT
description: In "The Morality of Fat," by Molly O'Neill (March 10), one Penny Ettinger is shown sitting on her kitchen floor, dining on rice cakes, while her significant other, perched upon what appears to be a rather uncomfortable stool, chows down on a bowl of cereal. I can understand the desire to live fat-free, but furniture-free living just goes too far. Save some comfort!

title: ON THE STREET;Off-Runway At the Shows
description: While the designer collections were the main event of last week's fall shows at the New York Public Library and in adjoining tents at Bryant Park, members of the audience provided a show of their own. The most interesting outfits were worn by young assistant editors, buyers and stylists, who dressed by mixing pieces rather than staying with one designer's look.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GARMENT DISTRICT;Kosher, and Compassionate
description: It was the first night of Passover and everybody seemed to want something from Eddie Share, the owner of Lou G. Siegel, the 79-year-old glatt kosher restaurant in the Garment District.

title: MARKET WATCH;ITT Gets Gussied Up For a Fling In Casinos
description: Few companies have reflected prevailing Wall Street fashions as consistently as the ITT Corporation. So get ready for the corporate equivalent of bare midriffs and ankle tattoos as ITT spends heavily again to remake itself in the image of the market's latest thing, a gambling-and-leisure behemoth.

title: THE UN-NOMINATED
description: I breathed a sigh of relief as I discovered Janet Maslin's "bravo" to Jennifer Jason Leigh ("The Un-Nominated," March 17). Her Dorothy Parker and more recent Sadie Flood teeter right at the lip of the id and ego. Leigh's haunting honesty is a testimony to truth in drama.

title: INVESTING IT;A Little Off the Top and the Bottom Helps Mid-Cap Stocks
description: CALL it this year's squeeze play. The winning streak that large companies have bragged about for the last two years is causing many portfolio managers to scour smaller stocks for better values. At the same time, managers of small-stock funds who are being flooded with fresh cash have been reaching up to larger stocks.

title: Ideas & Trends;And Now, the Kinder, Gentler Merger
description: PACIFIC TELESIS and SBC Communications made a bit of history last week -- and not just because they became the first of the Baby Bells to grow up and get married. In announcing their $17 billion merger, the two regional Bell telephone companies promised not to dismiss any workers.

title: FILM;That Unhappy Governess, Yet Again
description: THE ACTRESS Charlotte Gainsbourg looked wistfully at a lock of Charlotte Bronte's hair, woven into a mourning bracelet, at the Pierpoint Morgan Library's "Art of the Brontes" exhibition. Ms. Gainsbourg was visiting New York to promote "Jane Eyre," opening on Friday and based, of course, on Bronte's 1847 novel about an impoverished governess who falls tempestuously in love with her brooding employer, Mr. Rochester, played by William Hurt.

title: A World Awash in Chemicals
description: OUR STOLEN FUTURE Are We Threatening Our Fertility, Intelligence, and Survival? -- A Scientific Detective Story. By Theo Colborn, Dianne Dumanoski and John Peterson Myers. Foreword by Vice President Al Gore. Illustrated. 306 pp. New York: Dutton. $24.95.

title: TELEVISION;5 Funny Guys And The Last Laugh
description: WHAT PRICE CULT-STARDOM? For the comedy troupe the Kids in the Hall, the short answer is: $7 million. That is the less-than-stunning sum that a major Hollywood studio allocated to make "Brain Candy," the group's first feature film, which opens on Friday.

title: Cellular Antenna Law Draws Suit on Legality
description: THE increasing popularity of cellular telephones, which in recent years have become essential tools for commuting executives and car-pooling parents, have created a dilemma for municipalities: where to place the antennas, towers and satellite dishes that telecommunications companies need to provide service.

title: Turning an Ear To Other Americas
description: WHEN "AMERICA" IS used as a synonym for the United States, many Latin Americans object, arguing that the term should apply equally from Patagonia to Canada. In this spirit, perhaps, the American Composers Orchestra is presenting "Sonidos de las Americas," an annual series dedicated to music from Latin America, now in its third year.

title: In the Region/Connecticut;15 Synagogues Gain National Landmark Status
description: FIFTEEN historic Connecticut synagogues, chosen for their architectural significance and dating from 1876 to 1943, have been placed on the National Register of Historic Places -- 12 last November and 3 last February.

title: Bread, Tea and Prayer
description: I WENT to Lough Derg, the site of what may be Europe's most rigorous Christian pilgrimage, on a dare -- not the most spiritual of reasons. A college student spending a semester in Dublin in 1979, I asked my teacher, the Irish poet Thomas Kinsella, if he had ever done the three-day pilgrimage on a lake island in County Donegal. "Of course not," he replied with a laugh. "And you'll never do it, either. Americans don't do Lough Derg."

title: Place for Getting Fit That Offers Baby-Sitting
description: FOLLOW the crowd. In order to grow with their maturing baby-boomer members who are buying homes and raising families in Westchester, a market-driven company, Town Sports International, the largest fitness-center operator in the New York City area, recently opened its first New York Sports Club in Westchester. The club, acquired from the All Pro Fitness Center, is in the Vernon Hills Shopping Center here.

title: Diamond in the Rough
description: CREATING THE NATIONAL PASTIME Baseball Transforms Itself, 1903-1953. By G. Edward White. Illustrated. 368 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. $24.95.

title: Crime
description: Two years after the short, bloody reign of Jack the Ripper, a wave of terror rips through Whitechapel in Anne Perry's PENTECOST ALLEY (Fawcett Columbine, $22.95) when a local prostitute is savagely murdered. Thomas Pitt, who heads the Bow Street police command, promises to bring the sadistic killer to justice, "even if he's a gent."

title: ON POLITICS;Can Democrats Break Their Silence on Race?
description: When white Democrats talk among themselves these days, they complain that affirmative action is stealing opportunities from their own families, that young black criminals should be locked up and that women on welfare should go to work.

title: ON HOCKEY;With Messier in a Front-Row Seat, Graves Steps Into a New Role
description: MARK MESSIER sat in the celebrity seats, near the actress Susan Sarandon. The big, balding Ranger captain gleamed in Madison Square Garden's bright light like a jumbo version of her Oscar statuette.

title: WEDDINGS: VOWS;Elaine Greenstein, Brett Kurzweil
description: ELAINE GREENSTEIN, a children's book author and illustrator, is like a character in one of her own books. She likes funny hats, chocolate lace cookies, pranks and sunflowers that grow extra-tall.

title: Correction
description: An illustration credit in some copies last Sunday with an article about a planned skating and hockey complex in Elmsford, N.Y., misstated the surname of an architect. He is Jerome Kerner, not Werner.

title: DON'T MESS WITH OUR CULTURAL PATRIMONY!'
description: It would be a shame if the sensationally spun headline ("The Chinese Masterpiece You Won't See at the Met") that you put on a lovely cover and a superbly reported story kept people away from one of the rarest cultural events of the century (" 'Don't Mess With Our Cultural Patrimony!' " by Andrew Solomon, March 17).

title: Who Needs More Evidence of Police Brutality?
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;An Unsettled House Is Still a Home, for Now
description: WHEN WORKERS BEGAN demolishing a row of houses on Russell Street in London's West End last week, the noise of jackhammers was almost drowned out by loud sighs of relief coming from inside the nearby Royal Opera House. After 18 years of debate and two years of bitter and heated arguments that have badly bruised Covent Garden's public image, a $323 million project to restore, rebuild and expand the 140-year-old opera house has finally begun.

title: Do School Vacations Need Rethinking?
description: WHEN Janis Rehlaender and her husband and children moved to Darien from the Middle West eight years ago, they were surprised to find that schools closed for weeklong vacations in both February and April after already having been closed for more than a week at Christmas.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;Nixon Is Everywhere, It Seems, but in 'China'
description: WHATEVER HAPPENED to "Nixon in China"? John Adams's first opera caused a huge sensation when it appeared a little less than 10 years ago. It made a successful evening's entertainment from familiar and notorious figures in recent world history. It received consecutive premieres in Houston, New York, Washington and Amsterdam. Mr. Adams was hailed as the latest in a distinguished line of composers who were supposed to save or create American opera. Now, inexplicably or inevitably, depending on whom you ask, "Nixon" has dropped from sight. There was a revival at Indiana University a year ago; then nothing. Mr. Adams's publisher, Boosey & Hawkes, says no new productions are in the works.

title: FILM TITLES;'Around the World' In Clever Credits
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Stackhouse Out for Season
description: The rookie Jerry Stackhouse will miss the last eight games of the season with the Philadelphia 76ers because of a broken right thumb. He suffered the injury late in Friday night's 108-87 loss to Detroit. The thumb on his shooting hand is in a cast and he is expected to need six to eight weeks to recover, the team said today.

title: Remembering Ron Brown;So Visible, but From Which Angle?
description: ABRUPT death often deifies people, converting complex personalities infused with character and frailties into paragons of wisdom and grit. So it was with John F. Kennedy, Martin Luther King Jr., and, now, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown. And in America today, the death of a highly visible African-American like Mr. Brown produces another change; the transformation of a living, breathing human being into a larger-than-life symbol, embodying whatever any commentator feels is wrong -- or right -- with the current state of race relations and black progress.

title: THEATHER;A Confection Built on a Novel Built on a Fabrication
description: THE NEW $5.5 MILLION Broadway revival of "The King and I," the 1951 Rodgers and Hammerstein musical that Yul Brynner built a career on, lavishes enormous attention and money on constructing a sumptuous and remarkably authentic stage version of Thailand in the last century.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;At a Highflying Firm, a Fund in the Cellar
description: WHEN it comes to money and finance, Goldman, Sachs has impeccable credentials. The firm is a leading underwriter of stock offerings and fields one of the largest, most respected research teams on Wall Street.

title: INVESTING IT;Buy, Sell, Buy, Sell, Buy: Woes of an Antsy Investor
description: IF investors' portfolios reflect their characters, Ernie Porter is a man with a split personality.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENWICH VILLAGE;House of Yippies: Chicago Convention A Recurring Dream
description: The movement once professed not to trust anyone over 30. But Yippie House -- the Bleecker Street headquarters of the Youth International Party and its offshoots -- is about to pass that dreaded milestone. And after all those years, and all the Yippie breakups and reconfigurations, the three-story storefront building just off the Bowery remains a haven for those taking part in political discussions, pamphleteering and strategy sessions for the effort to legalize marijuana. Some things never change.

title: Facing Cutbacks, Professors Seek Raise
description: WHILE the future of state-supported higher education waits under the ax in New York, Purchase College faculty members here are grappling with a more immediate issue.

title: March 31-April 6;Goebbels Book Is Dropped
description: With the cancellation of David Irving's biography about Joseph Goebbels, the author vowed last week to distribute it via the Internet.

title: Yeltsin's Good Week: He's Back in Race
description: It has been a long time since President Boris N. Yeltsin has had a week this good. He started it last Sunday by announcing a peace plan for Chechnya and he ended it late this afternoon, telling 2,000 core supporters, "We will win in June so that Russia can never be called an evil empire again."

title: ART;Tracking Milestones of the Iron Horse
description: OF all the inventions that propelled the Industrial Revolution, none epitomizes it so well as the railroad. In the United States, the iron horse, with its mournful wail, brought evidence of the revolution to places where it was scarcely more than a rumor. As a subject for art, the railroad has neither an equal nor successor, for it seems now that while industrial objects can be esthetic triumphs they cannot inspire them.

title: TALKING MONEY WITH: MICHAEL CAINE;Appraising Caine, the Businessman
description: WHAT do you do after you have made more than 70 films, opened three restaurants, written one autobiography and won an Oscar?

title: Traffic Alert
description: Fifth Avenue will be closed between 48th and 57th Streets from 11 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. today for the Easter Parade.

title: ON THE MAP;At Rutgers, Making a Difference a Lot More Than One Day
description: In March 1993, when President Clinton came to Rutgers University to announce the Americorps national service program, he challenged students across the United States to help strengthen their communities. Residents at the Community Service House at Rutgers responded by developing a project called Rutgers University Making a Difference, a campus-wide day of service.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Tireless in Toronto: The Knicks Let Loose
description: John Starks hit 3-point bombs with remarkable aplomb and the Knicks ran and ran until the Toronto Raptors were bent over and gasping. Everyone got in the box score. Team records fell. And not a soul complained about bad shot selection, because everything went in.

title: ACADEMIC MUSIC;Students Know Better
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM VIEW;Up Close And Safely Impersonal
description: THE FUNNIEST RUNNING JOKE IN "Denise Calls Up," Hal Salwen's clever new satire about a yuppie social circle that communicates entirely by telephone, computer and fax machine, is the "affair" of two telecommunications workers.

title: Commercial Property/From 410 Park Avenue to 280 Park Avenue;Why the N.F.L. Chose to Keep Playing in Manhattan
description: IT seemed but a typical staged event -- until one realized what was left unsaid.

title: State Warns Indians on Cigarette Tax
description: JAKE J. of Center Moriches bought two cartons of Marlboros for $32 at the Poospatuck Smoke Shop and Trading Company on an Indian reservation near Mastic and walked out with a smile.

title: COVER STORY;Two New Private Eyes, Who Follow Their Instincts and Unfaithful Men
description: BORED by her domestic routine as wife and mother, Dee Tate (Barbara Lynn) decides to go back to work. Her husband, who is a barrister, makes a casual suggestion: "Why can't you just open a flower shop?"

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Prospect Lefferts Gardens;Racial Harmony and Rich Architecture
description: A STORY of racial harmony set against some of the finest residential architecture in Brooklyn resounds from the wide, parking-friendly streets of Prospect Lefferts Gardens.

title: POSTINGS: The White Plains Macy's Is Moving;Downtown Centerpiece Packing Up for the Galleria
description: The Macy's department store that since 1949 has been the retail centerpiece of downtown White Plains is moving to a nearby mall. The store will move from its 336,000-square-foot building at the corner of Mamaroneck Avenue and Main Street and reopen this summer in the Galleria mall space now occupied by Stern's.

title: The View From: White Plains;Where a Giant Toothy Rabbit Holds Court, and Toddlers Too
description: HERE comes Peter Cottontail and he has two toddlers on his lap. Every day last week at The Westchester here, the seven-foot-tall beige plush bunny hugged children with his 10-inch paws, bounced them on his padded knees and gave them the toothy grin fixed permanently on his 30-pound removable head. The costumed rabbit managed to convey a real sense of jovial whimsy and, unlike Santa Claus, he did it without speaking.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN UP CLOSE;Tenants Wanted: Koreans Sought At Empire State
description: The Empire State Building is known throughout the world. Don Dongpil Kim is not. But if all goes according to Mr. Kim's plan, he will be known in certain circles as Mr. Empire State Building. And the landmark tower he is marketing will have fewer "office for rent" signs.

title: Drop in Crime Slows to 9% In the Quarter
description: The double-digit decline in crime that New York City has enjoyed in the last two years is slowing, police statistics show, with an increase in rapes citywide and a growing number of murders, burglaries and robberies in several neighborhoods.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPROT: UPDATE;Marijuana Seller Vows to Aid the Ill
description: After a judge moved to drop the charges against him last week, Johann Moore, arrested for selling marijuana to AIDS and cancer patients, said he would continue to distribute the drug for medicinal purposes.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE;Gym Costs Are Dimming Hoop Dreams
description: Norman Becker, a retired high school teacher, didn't start battling the Board of Education until after he resigned.

title: Surviving Time, Fences And Protests
description: HAWKS circled high above, their cries a faint puncture in the silence. Deer bounded out of the brush and leaped across a meadow. The wind sighed. A few moments passed, then suddenly a tableau of sight and sound emerged that was eerily timeless. A big-tailed creature scooted along the top of a stone wall. Black and tan hounds, with names like Laddie and Jackpot, crossed a field in pursuit. A horn sounded, trailing the hounds' song. Red- and black-coated riders galloped their horses, bringing up the rear.

title: SOAPBOX;Here a Honk, There a Honk . . .
description: YOU don't have to live on West Ninth Street very long before becoming vehemently anti-horn. Three weeks should do it, or just one Saturday in summer. There's something about this street that compels people to honk. It's not particularly trafficky, but the pedestrians crossing the Avenue of the Americas to Balducci's like to take their time, and drivers, unfamiliar perhaps with the anticipatory joy of a $4 Balducci's starfruit, get antsy.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;Municipal Bond Funds May Be Perking Up
description: THE year did not start out well for municipal bond funds. A roller-coaster ride in interest rates -- especially the sudden rate surge in mid-February -- whipsawed them far more than corporate bond funds.

title: SIGNOFF;A Love Of Sports Inspired by The Yankees
description: IT's 8:45 P.M. and college basketball is hanging in the balance.

title: SOCCER;League Starts Out With Measured Hopes
description: Major League Soccer, the American league that is designed to be the legacy of the 1994 World Cup, kicked off its inaugural season last night with reasonable aspirations about the future and a certain amount of skepticism about the product now being put on the field.

title: Clinton Calls Victims 'the Best of America'
description: On a chill military tarmac, on a day as gray as mourning, President Clinton today honored Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and the 32 Americans who perished with him when their plane slammed into a croatian hillside on Wednesday.

title: In Defense Of Dodecaphonism
description: To the Editor:

title: Rockers Are Today's Poets, Forsooth
description: To the Editor:

title: Focus on Travel Of Bomb Suspect
description: Federal agents on the trail of the Unabom suspect have begun an extensive effort to unravel the mystery of Theodore J. Kaczynski's frequent bus travels through the Northwest in recent years and have questioned dozens of employees of bus companies and inexpensive hotels from Montana to California.

title: RELIGION;Returning to the Latin Mass: An Ancient Rite Is New Again
description: Dan Sexton cannot remember the days when every Roman Catholic church offered a Latin Mass. He was born in the 1960's, just as the reforms of the Second Vatican Council required churches to offer Masses in the native language of their congregation.

title: Correction
description: An article on March 10 about the Schonbrunn Palace in Vienna misstated the year in which the actress Katharine Schratt, confidante of the Emperor Franz Joseph, was born. It was 1855.

title: IN BRIEF;A Cape May Landmark Yields to the Future
description: It was a legend on Cape May's famed beachfront, a beacon of the community and a paragon of style. But after many years of decline, the Christian Admiral Hotel was demolished on March 25 in what area residents likened to a funeral for a dear, dear friend.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER EAST SIDE;Needle Center Sounds Alarm On Bad Heroin
description: A heroin addict faces constant peril. Not only are half of New York's 200,000 intravenous drug users H.I.V.-positive, but addicts also run the risk of buying tainted heroin that can lead to overdose or death.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER EAST SIDE;Major 'Head-Rearranging' Caps Board 3's Fractious Year
description: While less bloody than the purging of the Romanovs, a long expected shake-up at Community Board 3 was announced last week as the elected officials who control appointments to the tempestuous board dropped a half-dozen members.

title: March 31-April 6;Too Much of a Good Thing
description: The male hormone testosterone, whose very name evokes thoughts of raw aggression and sexual urges, can render men sterile. Men subjected to weekly injections of the hormone in their buttocks produced so little sperm they were infertile.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: AN awesome, near-forgotten monster thriller; a pair of whodunits, crisp and swank, and a saucy romantic bauble top the menu for movies on television this week.

title: WEDDINGS;Stephanie Russell, Stephen Harper
description: Stephanie Ann Russell and R. Stephen Harper were married yesterday in Wichita, Kan. The Rev. Dr. Robert Meyers performed the ceremony at the University Congregational Church.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: REGO PARK;Asians Protest 'Cheap Shot' In Councilwoman's Remarks
description: Councilwoman Julia Harrison's assertion that Asians are invading Flushing and are responsible for crimes has led some Asian-American New Yorkers to demand that she resign and be censured by the ethics committee of the City Council.

title: Doctor, a Torturer, Is Shot in Argentina
