description: One of the most notorious military doctors of Argentina's brutal military dictatorship was shot 20 times on Friday in an attack outside his home in the Quilmes suburb.

title: Don't Discard Overseas Development Agency
description: To the Editor:

title: Battle Over a Stove Needn't Become a Firestorm
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Care In the Era of Capitalism
description: FOR all the much-discussed emphasis on the need to cut costs, the health care system still is rich enough to excite deal makers. Witness the $8.9 billion agreement last week for the purchase of U.S. Healthcare Inc., one of the country's biggest health maintenance organizations. The would-be buyer, the Aetna Life & Casualty Company, is an even bigger health insurance company.

title: OUTDOORS;Out of the Tackle Box and Into the Art Gallery
description: The first time you see a fly tied by Bob Mead, chances are you will not want to stick it in the fleece band on your favorite fishing hat, or tie it to your tippet. The first thing you will want to do is get away from it, as fast as you can.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;Coast Guard Report Gives Cruise Ships a B+
description: ALMOST a year after the Coast Guard commissioned a study of cruise ship safety, prompted by two groundings and two fires last summer, the task force's recently released report awarded the cruise industry the equivalent of a B plus or possibly an A minus.

title: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;In City Services, Privatize and Beware
description: IT is no surprise that a $43 million contract let by the City of New York to a private organization to enforce the city's welfare rules -- signed last summer and canceled last month -- ran into trouble amid suspicions of cozy dealing. This has been the pattern of privatization efforts stretching back through the 19th century. Privatization has, in fact, been the norm, not the exception, through much of that time in this country -- and equally common has been the need for the government to take over these services after failure by private providers.

title: Who Needs More Evidence of Police Brutality?
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Trail of Disappearing Languages
description: ONE minute Peter Ladefoged was modeling an air flow mask; the next, he was using a small mirror to peer into the mouth of his colleague, Douglas H. Whalen. He was demonstrating a bit of what he does -- on Indian reservations, in African villages and elsewhere -- as he records the sounds of languages that are in great danger of dying.

title: BOOKEND;The Anatomy of Melancholy
description: Peter D. Kramer is the author of "Listening to Prozac" and a clinical professor of psychiatry at Brown University.

title: Classic Hideaways Of The Stars
description: ONLY 90 or so miles from Los Angeles, Santa Barbara and its environs have long been a retreat of choice for movie stars and others; it's easy to imagine, say, Clark Gable and Carole Lombard speeding north on the coast highway in a Cord convertible with its top down. Even today, the town can invoke visions of glamour. Ready for our close-ups, Mr. De Mille.

title: Of a Mr. Fix-It And a Legacy Of Spending
description: How a Would-Be Mr. Fix-It Left a Company in Ruins" (March 24), by Kurt Eichenwald, examined the rise and recent fall of Paul G. Kahn as chairman of the Ideon Group, formerly Safecard Services. The article, which discussed Mr. Kahn's spending on Ideon projects that were later abandoned, drew reader responses from within and outside the company.

title: U.N. Seeking an Accord on a Permanent Court for War Crimes
description: Although progress has been agonizingly slow, legal scholars and diplomats now meeting here are close to agreement on a blueprint for a permanent international criminal court to deal with genocide and other crimes against humanity.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3 Life after Riverside Church. A labor organizer and his congregation in Brooklyn.

title: Program of Workshops To Help the Unemployed
description: MUCH has changed and none of it is good, since the spring of 1988 when A.A.R.P. Works, a career-planning program for out-of-work executives, was first held. The program, a series of seven job workshops sponsored by the American Association of Retired Persons for unemployed people older than 50, has become a barometer reflecting the downsizing taking place in the county, said Claire Watsky, who runs the program.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Datebook chart of the special Education Life section last Sunday, describing summer programs, internships and major tests, misstated eligibility requirements for the summer program at the American University of Paris. It is open to high school sophomores through seniors, not college sophomores through seniors.

title: Sunday April 7, 1996: OFFICIAL POETIC LICENSE;With Both Rhyme And Reason
description: Walt Whitman said, 'To have great poets, there must be great audiences, too,' " explains Bill Wadsworth, executive director of the Academy of American Poets, and so a year ago Wadsworth and a chorus of other true believers set out to really fill the hall. The result is the first-ever National Poetry Month, a celebration involving millions of people through thousands of bookstores, schools, libraries and local literary organizations, from Duluth, Ga., to Ketchikan, Alaska.

title: Sunday April 7, 1996: PACO CAO IS CANNY;But Is He Art?
description: When Paco Cao was living in Oviedo, Spain, he put up a billboard that read "Paco Cao Has Died." In fact, he was feeling fine. Now he's living in New York, and still feeling fine, but rather than killing himself off he's renting himself out -- in his continuing need to express himself in a big way. (This time with the help of Creative Time, a nonprofit arts group.)

title: The Freedom to Marry
description: Chances are that Americans will look back 30 years from now and wonder what all the fuss was about. At the moment, however, the question of opening the institution of marriage to homosexuals is the subject of an emotional national debate taking place at family dinner tables, state legislatures and in the press.

title: Raymond S. Rubinow, 91, Master of Civic Causes
description: Raymond S. Rubinow, a longtime political gadfly and New York civic leader who fought with equal zeal to save Carnegie Hall and demolish Tammany Hall, died on Tuesday at his home in the Esplanade Hotel on West End Avenue in Manhattan. He was 91.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CONEY ISLAND;Ocean Too Small for Warring Ice Swimmers
description: The legendary Coney Island Polar Bears have been evicted from Coney Island, a displacement one hardy winter swimmer likens to Batman's getting the boot from the Bat Cave.

title: STYLE;WOODY'S PICKS: FALL '96
description: Didn't anybody else read the article in The International Herald Tribune about the out-of-control Chinese satellite hurtling toward earth and how the scientists tracking it would be able to give us only two hours' notice about where it was going to crash? Well, I can tell you one thing -- I wasn't ready to die for fashion like all those fanatics sitting there at the shows in Milan who talked about the Gucci collection as if it would change the course of human history. You know, human history could be over after this hunk of scrap metal hits. I told Soon-Yi, "Listen, if ground zero turns out to be the Emporio Armani show, we're going to make a run for it, even if it means missing the evening wear."

title: Media's Weight Bias
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ART;Thumbing the Nose, At Artistic Propriety
description: Gladys Nilsson and Jim Nutt Art Gallery, State University at Stony Brook. To April 13. 632-7240.

title: Next. Next. What's Next?
description: IT'S JUST 36 HOURS BEFORE THE DESIGNER TOM FORD WILL UNVEIL HIS FALL WOMEN'S COLLECTION FOR GUCCI, AND he's standing in a studio in Milan contemplating a Polaroid snapshot. He's impeccably dressed in navy pants and a navy shirt so dark in hue that they appear to be black, but they're precisely not black, they are navy, and he is calm, very cool and yet clearly bothered by this Polaroid. Ford, who is 34, has an open, almost boyish face and even when agitated projects a certain stillness.

title: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;Trading the Mouse For Birds and Tulips
description: WELCOME signs of spring have been slowly emerging where I work -- the grass seems greener, the tulips are up a few inches and buds are visible on a few trees. But perhaps the most striking harbinger of warmer weather on the sprawling I.B.M. campus in Poughkeepsie is the new company I have while out walking at noon.

title: For 360 Years, a Church That Endures
description: When members gather in First Congregational Church here on Easter morning, they do so near the spot where a group of Puritans celebrated their first Easter as a congregation 360 years ago.

title: Riverhead Cinema Is Thriving
description: Congratulations on your very thoughtful piece on Riverhead (March 3, 1996). I do believe, however, that there is one significant omission: Harold and Mary Smith have done fine work for over 10 years in presenting the very best in foreign and vintage films at their mini-cine (The Music Hall) in the heart of Riverhead's downtown. It is purely nonprofit and is done as a labor of lover and service to the community.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: April 7, 1996
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction

title: The Boss From Hell
description: BRAM STOKER A Biography of the Author of "Dracula." By Barbara Belford. Illustrated. 381 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: A Low-Tech Suspect
description: Modern technology has created a brave new criminal world in which drug deals are conducted with stolen cellular phone numbers, would-be terrorists learn bomb-making over the Internet and anti-government renegades keep body and soul together through credit card fraud. But recent developments in the Unabom case suggest that one determined individual might still be able to spread terror across the country for nearly two decades without even the benefit of electricity and indoor plumbing.

title: HOCKEY;Fichaud's First Shutout Ends Isles' 11-Game Skid
description: Eric Fichaud stopped 20 shots for his first National Hockey League shutout to help the Islanders end an 11-game losing streak with a 3-0 victory over the Buffalo Sabres tonight.

title: CAPITOL SKETCHBOOK;Lobbyist Finds Saintly Cause in Gun Control Fight
description: Lobbying can seem so much a task of mammon on Capitol Hill that it is startling to run into John Snyder, the dean of gun lobbyists, and hear him attempt the case for sanctity in firearm rights.

title: Liberties;The Sunshine Boys
description: Strom Thurmond's top aide just bought a motorcycle.

title: Fatal Bleeding Halts Study Of Drug Used In a Surgery
description: A study to determine whether a drug could help protect brain function during open-heart surgery had to be halted because it led to a relatively large number of deaths from bleeding, researchers said last week.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Toyota 4Runner;Another Float in the Off-Road Parade
description: FOR a long time, I wrote a column called "About Cars," and I'm beginning to think it's a good thing the name was changed.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;On the Trail of Jane Austen and Bloomsbury
description: Two new tours offer the chance to visit many of the literary sites linked to some of Britain's best known writers and artists.

title: MEDIA: TELEVISION;Pay TV finds new prospects coming from out of the blue, or at least from satellites.
description: FOR the last several years, the pay-television business, which includes Home Box Office, Showtime and other premium services, has been considered a mature industry with relatively little growth left.

title: The Race for Congress: Texas' 14th District;Under Fire, a G.O.P. Convert Wins Party's Fierce Loyalty
description: From former President George Bush on down, the Republican establishment is working desperately to protect a prized convert, Representative Greg Laughlin, from the rudeness of defeat on Tuesday in his first try for a nomination in his new party.

title: TV Director Makes It To Films On 2d Try
description: For Gregory Hoblit, who is one of television's premier directors, entering the movie business has been a perilous voyage that left him frightened, even scarred. He has not yet fully recovered from the trauma of being abruptly dismissed from his first film, the 1989 thriller "Sea of Love," before he could even begin.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's time for MICHAEL GARIN, the composer, pianist and writer, to move on. Mr. Garin is forsaking one of the city's more glamorous nighttime magnets, the Monkey Bar in the Elysee Hotel on East 54th Street, for Weehawken, N.J.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Stankowski to Masters Paul Stankowski, who did not even know if he would be playing in the BellSouth Classic at the beginning of the week, beat Brandel Chamblee yesterday on the first hole of a playoff for his first PGA Tour victory.

title: Datapoint Is Found Liable in Land Case
description: A Texas state jury has decided that the Datapoint Corporation should be required to pay $16.1 million in damages in a lawsuit asserting fraud against the computer company and two officers, Datapoint said last week.

title: Mr. Pataki's Hospital Plan
description: Gov. George Pataki has made a bold but flawed proposal to throw out New York's system of regulating hospitals. The plan starts off right -- ending price controls that encourage waste. But it would ruin many hospitals that cater to the poor and train medical residents. Mr. Pataki needs to enlarge his plan to subsidize these important functions.

title: Don't Present Israelis With a Fait Accompli;Likud's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Bus Company Owner Missing
description: The local police are working with the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New Jersey and Florida to find Frank L. Black, 58, the owner of a bus company, who has been missing for six weeks. Mr. Black left from Newark International Airport Feb. 24 for West Palm Beach, Fla., to conduct what he had told associates was a business deal, said David Szatkiewicz, an Andover patrolman. But his family and colleagues have not heard from him since then. The police said there were no indications that Mr. Black was abducted.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Traditional Celtic Tunes, With Modern Touches
description: Near the end of Altan's late show on Wednesday night at the Bottom Line, the fiddler Mairead Ni Mhaonaigh quietly announced that she would play a tune she had written for Frankie Kennedy. The stately melody was an elegy for Mr. Kennedy, who played flute with Altan until his death in 1994. The group has weathered his loss and held on to its identity as one of Ireland's best traditional bands, gracefully navigating between purism and modernity. It includes guitar and bouzouki alongside ancient Irish instruments; its drummer, Jimmy Higgins, plays snare drum at times instead of the Irish bodhran. But its Celtic reels, jigs, hornpipes and airs retain their time-tested dignity and their danceable momentum.

title: World News Briefs;Worshipers Inaugurate New Cathedral in France
description: Easter celebrants filled the Resurrection Cathedral today for the inauguration of the first cathedral to be built in France this century.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Hewlett-Packard Narrows Review
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company has narrowed to four finalists its review for the account of its printers and scanners and other peripherals sold in the United States. The account, with billings estimated at $40 million to $45 million, had been handled for the last eight years by the San Francisco office of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C.

title: Ivy League Aid Rules Don't Favor Athletes
description: To the Editor:

title: YACHT RACING;All-Black Crew Finding Its Horizons
description: Responding to a wish from his mother that he take up collegiate sailing, Byron Gully Jr. of Chicago tried out for the team last fall during freshmen orientation at Hampton University.

title: Vice Adm. John D. Bulkeley, 84, Hero of D-Day and Philippines
description: John D. Bulkeley, a retired Navy vice admiral who won the Medal of Honor for his daring torpedo-boat attacks on the overwhelming forces of the Japanese Navy around the Philippines in World War II, died on Saturday in his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 84.

title: World News Briefs;Threats by Guerrillas Put Colombia on Alert
description: The Colombian army and police went on maximum alert today after leftist guerrillas called for a nationwide strike under the threat of violence.

title: DOCTORS MAY GET LEEWAY TO RIVAL LARGE COMPANIES
description: With huge mergers changing the face of the health care industry, the Federal Trade Commission plans to make it easier for doctors to band together, coordinate prices and form networks to compete with insurance companies and health maintenance organizations.

title: Pentagon Hotel Isn't Financed by Taxpayers
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;A Fresh Start For Hitchcock
description: Sterling Hitchcock is happy to be in Seattle and out of New York. He and the Yankees' owner, George Steinbrenner, did not always see eye to eye.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Veteran Drummer in Sync With His Youthful Sidemen
description: The drummer Roy Haynes started his set on Wednesday night at the Village Vanguard by playing the rhythms of the tune "Green Chimneys" on his snare drum. The band joined in, underscoring the composition's accents; melody and rhythm joined together.

title: Hanoi Seeks Western Cash but Not Consequences
description: In Da Nang, the favored paint color seems to be electric blue. Here in the city still popularly known as Saigon it is mostly white. On storefronts and billboards all over the country, neat swatches of paint have recently been applied, under Government orders, to blot out the brand names of foreign consumer products.

title: Some Want to Know Breast Cancer Risks
description: To the Editor:

title: Cardinal's Easter Joy Is Tempered by Court Ruling on Aided Suicide
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, interrupted a joyous Easter celebration with a somber jeremiad yesterday, decrying as "unspeakable" a recent Federal appeals court ruling permitting physician-assisted suicide in New York State.

title: The End of Broadway's Run
description: The playwright William Gibson once remarked that a dramatist can't make a living on Broadway, only a killing. For decades now, serious writers haven't even been able to make a killing.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Seduction and Other Corporate Skills
description: As the public grumbles about issues like downsizing and escalating C.E.O. rewards, big business has more than enough problems to keep its public-relations staffs sweating. Now corporate America has to deal with a new Fox series called, with diabolical simplicity, "Profit." Here in the sleek corridors of the fictional Gracen & Gracen, the world's 15th largest conglomerate, assorted nasties, one of them a genuine psychopath, work feverishly to keep stockholders and themselves healthy, wealthy and insider wise.

title: BASEBALL;Gooden Struggles, Cone Sparkles, Texas Sweeps
description: When Dwight Gooden's once-intimidating and once-magical name was announced, the sparse crowd at the Ballpark in Arlington yawned. Barely a peep was heard. He was treated like just another pitcher trying to prove he belongs. Does he?

title: Books on Tape Inc. Carves Out Quiet Niche Among Big Publishing Houses
description: In 1975, when a former Olympic rower named Duvall Y. Hecht founded Books on Tape Inc., his plan to market audiocassettes containing complete spoken-word versions of printed books was considered foolhardy, even eccentric.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: David A. Bell, chairman at Bozell Worldwide, New York, was named to the additional position of chief executive, succeeding Charles D. Peebler Jr., who continues as president and chief executive of the parent, Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

title: Let's Vote on Giving Yankees a Stadium;What's in a Name?
description: To the Editor:

title: HOCKEY;With Playoffs in Doubt, Devils Needed the Victory More
description: The Devils were fighting for survival. The Rangers, already assured of a spot in the playoffs, were missing both their captain and a sense of urgency.

title: Global Talks Covering Phones Near Deadline
description: Negotiators from 51 countries are racing against the clock at the World Trade Organization in Geneva this month, hoping to meet their self-imposed deadline of April 30 for an agreement on liberalizing trade in telecommunications.

title: Forgotten Cemetery Becomes Two Historians' Battleground
description: For nearly a century, the half-acre here where 100 or more slaves, freed slaves and their descendants were buried was all but forgotten. The patch of earth, next to a swamp, was carpeted by underbrush and shrouded from a winding road by a curtain of oak, ash and elm trees.

title: Arkansas Plan to Promote Election of Black Judges Brings a FamiliarChallenge
description: The first time that Don Glover ran for Circuit Court in this rural corner of southeastern Arkansas, in 1990, he went to bed on election night all but certain he had become the state's first black trial judge. But election officials said they had discovered a miscount of the absentee ballots, and instead of winning by 500 votes, as he expected, Mr. Glover woke up a loser by 50.

title: Patents;A cold cross-country drive is the inspiration for an automated motel-clerk system for tired travelers.
description: A CROSS-COUNTRY drive in subzero weather inspired Carmenina Parkhurst to invent an automatic motel clerk.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Monday about the Book-of-the-Month Club misstated the portion of Bertelsmann A.G.'s revenues that come from its book clubs. In Bertelsmann's most recent fiscal year, book clubs accounted for 18 percent of the company's revenues, not 60 percent. A chart with the article, listing some Book-of-the-Month Club selections through the years, misstated the title of a coming book by E. Annie Proulx. It is "Accordion Crimes."

title: Mediation Expected In CBS-Guild Split
description: A mediator is scheduled to meet Monday with the Writers Guild of America and CBS in an attempt to resolve an impasse that has left about 350 newswriters, graphic artists and others without a contract for almost a week, Variety reported today.

title: Police Gain In Weaponry, Not Diversity
description: Today's police officers are better educated, armed with more sophisticated weapons and more likely to be wearing body armor, the Justice Department said in a report today.

title: The U.S. Must Pay Its Dues
description: The United Nations is on the brink of financial disaster. Americans need to know what's going on, because their country took the lead in creating the organization, and its delinquency in paying arrears is threatening it.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;The Ambivalent Human-Animal Bond
description: Animal lovers, prepare: Tonight's HBO catalogue of cruelties, kindnesses and curiosities in the relationship between what used to be known as man and beast include some of the most grisly scenes that have ever found their way onto the small screen. But however hard to watch, they are not gratuitous. They bring home the extremes of human attitudes toward other species signaled by the title, "To Love or Kill: Man vs. Animal."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Murder Retrial Starts
description: Jury selection is scheduled to begin today in the retrial of Lawrence Simmons, who was convicted and sentenced to life for the 1977 murder and robbery of Dr. David Doktor, 64, outside his Paterson home. Mr. Simmons and two other Paterson men were charged in the case. One of the suspected accomplices received immunity from prosecution in exchange for his testimony; the other was convicted and is serving a life sentence.

title: Ex-Minister Gets Life Term
description: A defrocked Muslim minister who opened fire on a crowd at a university rally nearly two years ago, wounding a Nation of Islam leader and five others, has been sentenced to life in prison.

title: TENNIS;Czech Republic Eliminates a U.S. Davis Cup Team Missing Its Top Players
description: Pete Sampras had already declared that he would be available for the Davis Cup semifinals in September.

title: OPERA REVIEW;A Revolutionary And Noble Poet, Via Pavarotti
description: An opera company does not decide to mount a major new production of Umberto Giordano's "Andrea Chenier" and then search for a tenor to sing the title role. If any opera is a star vehicle, it is this verismo melodrama of the French Revolution, first performed 100 years ago last month. Giordano's hero bears scant resemblance to the historic Chenier, a high-born Parisian poet who championed the causes of the downtrodden but denounced their violent excesses and was executed on trumped-up charges of treason in 1794. No matter. In the opera house, this dashing role has provided some glamour tenors of the past -- Mario Del Monaco, Franco Corelli -- with a chance to exult in virile lyricism and dramatic impetuosity.

title: Hotel Records May Forge Link in Unabom Case
description: Federal law-enforcement officials said today that agents on the trail of the Unabomber had uncovered hotel records placing Theodore J. Kaczynski in Sacramento, Calif., on the same days that some of the Unabomber's package bombs were mailed from the city.

title: A Moment in the Sunset For Heroes of the Slopes
description: To the spring-break college crowd, snowboarders in baggy pants and ski bunnies in pink ear muffs, the sight must have seemed strange: a dozen aging men, wearing white camouflage, descending a ski run in a slow, serpentine formation, making the wide, graceful turns popular in the 1930's.

title: Mix of Rain and Snow Topples a Record
description: Another snowfall record toppled last night in the New York metropolitan area, as a mixture of rain and light snow stuck on Long Island to raise the season's total to 75.3 inches. The old record of 74.9 inches of snow, according to the National Weather Service, was registered in 1966-1967.

title: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;Weighing the downside of taking an Internet-related company public too early.
description: PEOPLE have been tut-tutting about the wacky market for Internet-related initial public stock offerings ever since the Netscape Communications Corporation's I.P.O. last August took the start-up company from nothing to a $2.2 billion valuation overnight.

title: Soroa Journal;Mexican Hide-and-Seek, in a Cuban Playground
description: His bald head and big ears give him an easily recognizable profile. But since Carlos Salinas de Gortari, the former President of Mexico, dropped out of public view more than a year ago, even those few people who claim to have glimpsed him cannot seem to remember exactly what he looked like.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Medical Suppliers Should Be Liable, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: POP REVIEW;Rock Lyrics in Spanish, Not About Lust or Power
description: The band wore black. The lead singer shook his fist and flopped his long hair; he sang about destiny and truth in a vibrato-laden baritone, while two guitarists played booming power chords or pealing, slow arpeggios. Audience members joined in on slower songs and, on faster ones, jumped around, hurled themselves against neighbors and grappled toward the stage.

title: Abroad at Home;Where Would You Hide?
description: It is a glory of America that anyone, however powerless or unpopular, can look to the courts for protection against an overweening government. That feature of our constitutional order has been envied by people around the world -- and widely copied in recent years.

title: Advertising;'Car Talk,' an NPR program, wheels its act onto the Web, and advertising is being accepted.
description: CAR Talk," already a weekly program on National Public Radio and a syndicated column in more than 200 newspapers, is now the subject of a site on the World Wide Web (http://cartalk.com) -- but with a difference. The site, unlike the radio program, will carry advertising.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Town Meeting Is Tomorrow
description: Governor Whitman and her 18 cabinet members are scheduled to answer questions about state government at a town meeting at the County Courthouse tomorrow from 7 to 9 P.M. The session is the first of many planned by the Governor to allow the public to question top officials about state business.

title: On Freewheeling Internet, Addresses Are Up for Grabs
description: Latecomers prospecting for a hip name for a World Wide Web site or E-mail address still have hope. Despite the fact that nearly 250,000 commercial Internet addresses have already been claimed in this decade's great virtual land grab, a vast number of site names remain open for adoption -- including, for starters, hopeless.com.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: F.T.C. Plans to Simplify Rules on Doctor Networks With big mergers changing the face of the health care industry, the Federal Trade Commission plans to make it easier for doctors to band together, coordinate prices and form networks to compete with insurance companies and health maintenance organizations. Doctors contend that such networks might encourage competition by providing alternatives to H.M.O.'s. [Page A1.]

title: World News Briefs;Russians Fight Chechens Despite Peace Approach
description: Russian and rebel forces battled again today over villages in the mutinous republic of Chechnya, despite an announcement by President Boris N. Yeltsin that his troops had halted attacks, the Interfax news agency said.

title: Mtel Plans to Add Jobs
description: The Mobile Telecommunications Technologies Corporation, a paging company known as Mtel, plans to add 400 customer service jobs as it expands its two-way paging network. The jobs will be added in Jackson, Miss., where the company is based and already has 200 customer-service representatives. Most of the new jobs will be full-time, entry-level positions, a representative of Mtel said last week. The announcement came after the company laid off 40 employees, mostly managers, at its headquarters.

title: Ilka Payan, 53, an Actress, Dies; Champion for Anti-AIDS Causes
description: Ilka Tanya Payan, the Dominican-born soap opera star and New York civic leader who played a reluctant but eloquent role in raising AIDS awareness after disclosing that she was infected with the H.I.V. virus, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 53.

title: Man Charged After Explosion Of Arms Cache
description: A reserve deputy sheriff in Washington State has been charged with unlawful possession of a hand grenade after ammunition and explosives blew up in a shed on his property 70 miles east of here last week.

title: How to Turn Around a Magazine for Walkers
description: Everyone loves a success story. Particularly the beleaguered magazine industry, where 7 out of 10 start-ups fail within a decade.

title: Barbara McLean, 92, a Pioneer In Film Editing and Zanuck Guru
description: Barbara McLean, an Oscar-winning Hollywood film editor whose influence at 20th Century-Fox extended far beyond the cutting room, died on March 28 at a convalescent home in Newport Beach, Calif. She was 92 and had lived in Newport Beach since her retirement in 1969 after 20 years as head of the studio's editing division.

title: Armed North Korea Troops Again Violate the DMZ
description: Heavily armed North Korean troops entered the sensitive buffer zone between North and South Korea tonight for the third day in a row, violating the armistice that ended the Korean War, United States and South Korean officials said.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:

title: Giuliani Criticizes Hospital Forecasts
description: Predictions by two leading research groups that at least 15 of the city's 78 hospitals will be forced to shut down in the next three years are probably exaggerated, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday. But he acknowledged that the city's health care landscape will dramatically change by the end of the decade.

title: Treasury to Auction Bills and Notes This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week comprises today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and auctions of two- and five-year notes set for today and tomorrow, respectively.

title: New Abortion Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: Palestinians and Settlers Meet To Pursue Coexistence Quietly
description: Against a backdrop of bitter hostility, a group of prominent Jewish settlers and Palestinian officials have been holding discreet talks on coexistence as Palestinian self-rule has taken hold in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Let's Vote on Giving Yankees a Stadium
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times;On New Jersey Front, Atmospheric Pressure Rises to Danger Level
description: It wasn't necessary for Jacques Lemaire to lecture his New Jersey Devils players on the significance of the hockey game against the Rangers in the Meadowlands yesterday afternoon. It wasn't necessary to lecture them when, after all, they could read.

title: Optometrists Clash With Eye Surgeons Over Laser Process
description: Eager to perform a new eye procedure that experts say could generate as much as $10 billion in revenues, two groups of eye-care specialists are battling each other here and in other capitals over bills that will help to determine which side will control the market.

title: THEATER REVIEW;When Elderly Buddies Take Politics Seriously
description: If P. T. Barnum's law on the ratio of the birth of suckers to time (one per minute) worked for Ross Perot in his 1992 Presidential campaign, the producers of "The Shattering" must have hoped it would apply to theater audiences as well. That's the only apparent reason for the vanity staging of this inept exercise by Mark R. Shapiro at the Players Theater.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Is Humankind Alone in Its Morality?
description: GOOD NATURED The Origins of Right and Wrong in Humans and Other Animals By Frans de Waal Illustrated. 296 pages. Harvard University Press. $24.95.

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Stock prices were lower here today. At the midday break, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 166.10 points, or nearly eight-tenths of 1 percent, at 21,529.74. On Friday, the Nikkei rose 224.68 points.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Girl Dies in Crash at Motel
description: A 16-year-old girl died Saturday when the car she was driving went out of control, crashed through a fence and plunged into a motel swimming pool, the A.P. reported. She was identified as Joh'Nette Gathers, who lived with her mother at the motel, the Econo Lodge. A passer-by rescued three other teen-agers who were passengers in the car.

title: REFORM GONE AWRY -- A special report.;How Haste Made a Shambles Of a Plan to Privatize Welfare
description: For much of the spring and summer of 1995, veteran city workers grew alarmed as the Giuliani administration pushed them relentlessly to award multimillion-dollar contracts to oversee thousands of New Yorkers on welfare.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: Cities Are Digging Deep and Wide as Congress Tightens Purse
description: When Congress began swinging its ax in earnest last fall at the Federal deficit, somebody forgot to tell Amarillo to duck.

title: CUNY, the Vocational University
description: Facing the second year of a financial emergency, many faculty members of the City University of New York are worried about the university's direction.

title: BASKETBALL;St. John's Will Name Fraschilla Today
description: What seemed likely is now official. Fran Fraschilla, the fiery coach of the Manhattan Jaspers, will be named the coach of St. John's at a news conference at 3:30 P.M. today.

title: Argentine Hostages Freed
description: Inmates at a maximum security prison here surrendered 17 hostages today and called off a week-old revolt, clearing the way for copycat rebellions at other jails across Argentina to end.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : A Roosevelt Tells Of Family Secret
description: With his name and appearance, H. Delano Roosevelt already had attracted attention as a candidate for the Long Beach, California, city council. When he told of a family secret, he attracted even more.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;School Vouchers Supported
description: It costs $8,315 a year to provide a public school education in Jersey City, compared with median tuition of $1,775 at private and parochial schools in the city, according to a national study by the Cato Institute, a conservative research group. The study contended that private school education in urban areas like Jersey City was significantly less expensive than most Americans believe, and that government-issued tuition vouchers of $3,000 per pupil would give many families "the clout to bring about a revolution in education."

title: Pope Directs His Easter Prayers to World's War Zones
description: Celebrating Easter Mass before a crowd of about 100,000 outside St. Peter's Basilica, Pope John Paul II prayed for peace in the world's war zones today and for comfort for the victims of violence.

title: No Headline
description: In a period where the inner workings of the Soviet Government and Chinese Government in the cold war are being exposed to view, it's extremely ironic that it's so difficult to get this material out." JOHN LEWIS GADDIS, historian, on declassifying C.I.A. records. [A6:6.]

title: Thousands Flee Fighting in the Liberian Capital
description: Thousands of residents fled homes in Monrovia, the capital, for a second day today as fighting continued between Government soldiers and rebels loyal to a besieged militia leader.

title: Monastery in China Buys TV Time
description: The Yongquan temple has become the first Buddhist monastery in China to buy television advertising time -- to promote tourism to the mountain retreat, the New China News Agency said today.

title: Metro Matters;  Moving Yanks While Hating Steinbrenner
description: TO devoted fans of the House That Ruth Built, to those even vaguely acquainted with the unlovable George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the very idea is heresy. Yet candor impels the question anyway: Why shouldn't the Yankees move from the Bronx to a world-class new stadium in Manhattan?

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Bankers Trust To Fallon McElligott
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation has named Fallon McElligott Berlin in New York to handle its account, with billings estimated at $10 million. The account had been handled by Merkley Newman Harty in New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group, from April 1993 until November, when that agency declined to participate in a review. Fallon McElligott Berlin, an affiliate of Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis, was selected from a field of three finalists; the other two, both of New York, were Graf Bertel Buczek Advertising and Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners.

title: Let's Vote on Giving Yankees a Stadium
description: To the Editor:

title: As a Hospital Is Fixed, A Wound Is Healed
description: For 20 years the old Morrisania Hospital building has loomed grim and vacant over its Bronx neighborhood, sheltering only junkies, homeless people, huge rats, even a family of hawks. With its outlying buildings, the hospital complex occupies an entire city block. When the central structure rose 11 stories above the neighborhood in the booming 1920's, it was a symbol of the borough's ascent. When it was abandoned in 1976, it became an equally potent indicator of decline.

title: Possible Questioning of Philip Morris Staff
description: The Philip Morris Companies has told some Virginia employees that investigators from the Department of Justice may contact them about a Federal investigation of the tobacco company.

title: GOLF;Sweet Mystery And Crenshaw At the Masters
description: For 12 months, every day, it has followed Ben Crenshaw. Wherever he has been, in locker rooms, on practice tees, on the golf course, in his living room, on airplanes, he has been accompanied by the sweet specter of the week that was at Augusta National Golf Club last spring.

title: Serbs Turn Over Files On Captive Suspects
description: Bosnian Serb officials handed over files on 4 Muslims and 12 Croats they suspect of war crimes but refuse to release the prisoners, officials said today.

title: Life Sentences for 3 Men in Racial Attacks
description: Three white men were sentenced to life in prison on Friday for killing one black man and wounding two others in what prosecutors called a hunting trip to start a race war.

title: Raymond S. Rubinow, 91, Master of Civic Causes
description: Raymond S. Rubinow, a longtime political gadfly and New York civic leader who fought with equal zeal to save Carnegie Hall and demolish Tammany Hall, died on Tuesday at his home in the Esplanade Hotel on West End Avenue in Manhattan. He was 91.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about a longtime political gadfly and New York civic leader misstated his first name. He was Raymond S. Rubinow, not David. The obituary is reprinted today on page B12.

title: Sterling McMurrin, Educator, Dies at 82
description: Dr. Sterling M. McMurrin, former United States Commissioner of Education, longtime University of Utah philosophy professor and influential Mormon intellectual, died on Saturday. He was 82.

title: Taking In the Sites;About to Buy a Computer? Here Are a Few Pointers
description: So your favorite Uncle Sam has left you some money this year. Maybe, just maybe, it is time to upgrade your 1984 computer. After all, there have been a few changes in the last 12 years, and even your children use better computers than you use.

title: Sports of The Times;Generation X Must Carry the New Soccer League
description: Tom Liner was born in California, went to school in California, lives in California -- and now he plays professional soccer in California. He stood on the green, green grass of San Jose Stadium and watched 31,683 celebrants, and did not mind admitting he was thrilled.

title: A Fight to Reach Site Of Fatal Plane Crash
description: Challenged by weather and water, rescue crews worked most of today to get to the wreckage of a small plane that crashed Saturday night in a bog near the Barkhamsted Reservoir, killing at least two people.

title: BASKETBALL;For Davis, Getting to Play Is the Thing
description: Hubert Davis could raise a fuss and invoke the unwritten rule regarding a player not losing his starting job to injury. He could offer up as proof his accuracy and his production since coming back from a hyperextended left knee four games ago and say that he, not John Starks, should be introduced before each game.

title: Ready to Test New Cigarette, Maker Fears Tough Rules
description: RJR Tobacco Worldwide plans to begin marketing tests of Eclipse, its nearly smokeless cigarette, late next month but is growing increasingly concerned that regulators may block its commercial release.

title: C.I.A. Is Slow to Tell Early Cold War Secrets
description: The Central Intelligence Agency publicly pledged in 1993 to release its files on its most important covert actions of the cold war -- coups in Iran and Guatemala, the Bay of Pigs fiasco -- in a matter of months. The promise is unfulfilled. The documents remain secret.

title: GOLF;Nicklaus Gets 100th Victory
description: Jack Nicklaus was already one for the ages.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Diversity In World Of Science
description: The faces in "Breakthrough: The Changing Face of Science in America" belong to 20 black, Hispanic and American Indian scientists and engineers who are exploring everything from the ozone layer to the ocean depths to the body's cells; one is building a better rotary engine, while another flies high in theoretical physics.

title: Thailand and Malaysia Magnets For Millions of Poorer Asians : Migrant Workers:Problem and Boon
description: SINGAPORE  Illegal labor immigration has become widespread in Malaysia and Thailand, and government officials are now describing the inflow as a threat to national security.

title: A Day for Bonnets, Umbrella-Sized
description: It rained on the Easter Parade yesterday, but scores of stalwarts braved the drizzle,brightening Fifth Avenue with a potpourri of outrageous hats.

title: Thousands Of Muslims Try to Reach Former Homes
description: They filled the roads leading to this small town for most of the morning -- old women shuffling, peasant farmers with muddy boots and weary stride and a few young, wounded war veterans limping on crutches. There were 3,000 to 4,000 of them, all Muslim refugees walking toward their homes.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Body Parts Dumped in River
description: Police officers on routine patrol in an industrial park yesterday found a person dumping what were described as bags of human body parts into the Passaic River, The Associated Press reported. Divers were seen searching the river yesterday afternoon, but both the East Rutherford police and the Acting Bergen County Prosecutor, Charles Buckley, declined to provide more details.

title: INSIDE
description: Broken Pledge at C.I.A.

title: ON BASEBALLAn Early Lesson on Expectation vs. Reality
description: When the comparison was suggested to him yesterday, Dallas Green laughed and said it probably was fair: Having Zane Smith and Danny Darwin shut out the Mets for a total of 11 innings during the dry part of the weekend was like Green's pitching two successive shutouts when the manager played for the Mets in 1966.

title: Grave Trouble for the Great Writ
description: Members of Congress are exploiting public concerns about terrorism to threaten basic civil liberties. Of these, not one is more precious than the writ of habeas corpus -- the venerable Great Writ devised by English judges to guard against arbitrary imprisonment and, in modern terms, a vital shield against unfair trials.

title: Bridge
description: If one excludes New Zealand and Iceland, both of which have large bridge populations, it is in general true that the world's islands cannot produce high quality teams that are competitive internationally.

title: Essay;The Russian Election
description: Here are the latest poll figures on the Russian election to be held, the world hopes, in June: Gennadi Zyuganov, the Communist leader, 20 percent; Boris Yeltsin, non-conqueror of Chechnya, 15 percent; Grigory Yavlinsky, the democratic reformer, 11 percent. A handful of others, including the nationalist wild man Vladimir Zhirinovsky, are in single digits. That means nearly half the electorate is undecided.

title: M. J. Horowitz, 70, Psychologist
description: Dr. Milton J. Horowitz, a clinical psychologist who was a founding member and former president of the Los Angeles Institute and Society for Psychoanalytic Studies, died on March 31 at his home in Beverly Hills. He was 70.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Valet Parking Weighed
description: Visiting Princeton's trendy business district often entails scrambling for a parking space, or worse (last year, the borough pocketed revenue from more than 50,000 parking tickets). Now a remedy of sorts is being proposed. Tomorrow night, the Borough Council is scheduled to vote on an ordinance that would authorize downtown businesses to offer valet parking on a six-month trial basis.

title: 4 Flee Pennsylvania Jail
description: Four felons broke out of a county jail on Saturday, stripping down to their undershorts to get rid of orange prison jumpsuits, officials said today.

title: The Megacity Summit
description: Our century has witnessed a profound change in living arrangements. In 1900, most people lived as they always did, in rural areas. By 2000, the majority will be city dwellers. This demographic projection is based on the mushrooming growth rates of what are called megacities. Scores of sprawling metropolitan areas already spill over political boundaries and spew pollutants into the air and water, blighting the lives of their own inhabitants as well as millions living elsewhere.

title: One Focus of Inquiry: The Selection of Targets
description: Their lives could hardly have been more distant or more different. One lived in a sprawling confection of a house perched on its own little hillock in a sedate New Jersey cul-de-sac. He had just been promoted to general manager of one of the country's biggest advertising and public relations firms. The other inhabited a tar paper shack in the wilds of Montana with no visible means of support.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Kimberly-Clark Pares Scott Agencies
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation has consolidated its consumer tissue accounts, a move that had been expected since the company acquired the Scott Paper Company. Kimberly-Clark and Scott together spent an estimated $175 million on advertising in the United States in 1995.

title: BASEBALL;Pulsipher Is Prepared For a Long Road Back
description: Subdued and reflective, knowing that his potentially outstanding pitching career could already be over, the Mets' Bill Pulsipher explained yesterday why he was going to have surgery on his troublesome left elbow.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Amnesty on Overdue Books
description: In the last 10 years, officials at the Wayne Public Library estimated that they lost $648,000 in unreturned books. Staff members discovered that 40,500 books were missing when they computerized their card catalogue, said Barbara Pickell, the library's director. But next week, library scofflaws are being given a chance to wipe their slates clean. For six days beginning Sunday, borrowers can return overdue books without paying a fine, Ms. Pickell said. One condition: Overdue books must be accompanied by a can of food to be donated to a local charity. JOE SHARKEY

title: Israel Says Iran Sent Arms to Attack Jews
description: An Iranian ship loaded with advanced arms and explosives that were apparently intended for attacks on Jewish and Israeli targets has been intercepted, Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel said today.

title: Don't Present Israelis With a Fait Accompli
description: To the Editor:

title: Minnesota Provost Is Expected To Take Johns Hopkins Helm
description: After nearly a year without a permanent president, Johns Hopkins University is expected to announce today that William R. Brody, the provost of the University of Minnesota Academic Health Center in Minneapolis, will become its 13th president by Sept. 1.

title: Medical Suppliers Should Be Liable, Too
description: To the Editor: J. Roy Rowland and Louis W. Sullivan (Op-Ed, April 4) engage in scare tactics in arguing that the makers of materials used in medical devices deserve special treatment for product-liability lawsuits.

title: Crew's River Crossings Forge New Mayoral Ties
description: Almost every Monday afternoon since he arrived in New York City last fall, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has traveled across the East River for a standing appointment his predecessor, Ramon C. Cortines, never had: a 60- to 90-minute conversation with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani at City Hall or Gracie Mansion.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week.

title: Go-Between For Family Was in Dark
description: The talks that led Federal authorities to identify Theodore J. Kaczynski as the man they believe is the Unabomber began as a breathless dance in the shadows, the lawyer who served as go-between said today. When he first approached the F.B.I., the lawyer did not know the name of the potential suspect -- or even the name of the client whose suspicions he was reporting.

title: A Compromise Plan to Address Workplace Ergonomics Stays on the Shelf
description: In his Manhattan office, Dr. Emil Pascarelli leafed through the files of a day's worth of patients: a computer programmer, a television producer, a systems engineer, a magazine editor, a help-desk worker at a telephone company and a couple of others.

title: The Young and Restless Audience: Fine Tuning -- A special report;Computers, Cable and Videos Cut Into Children's TV-Watching Time
description: Through the years in TV land, an advertiser seeking the eyes and ears of children knew pretty much where to find them. So Bucky Beaver might pitch Ipana toothpaste during "The Mickey Mouse Club," Maypo could promote porridge on "Captain Kangaroo" and Mattel could send Barbie waltzing through the commercial breaks of "Garfield and Friends."

title: Equity Offerings Set for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: CHRONICLE
description: ISABELLE STEVENSON, president of the American Theater Wing, is fully prepared to take the blame today if any of the 366 producers, directors, actors and playwrights attending the organization's luncheon in the Rainbow Room are displeased with their seats.

title: Jury-Duty Dodgers Tell It to the Judge;After He Hears Their Best Whoppers, a Get-Serious Warning
description: A summons for jury duty in New York State these days arrives with a bunch of tender little carrots dangling from it. Like, say, shorter service. Expanded lists, so that everyone else will be roped in, too. A juror-complaint person. Comfortable chairs. And court employees who have had to attend niceness training seminars. So, nibble, nibble?

title: Quebec's Premier Softens His Stance on Independence
description: He has stopped his furious assaults on the federal Government and hardly mentions Quebec independence. Instead, Premier Lucien Bouchard now speaks of the "shared values" of French- and English-speakers and quotes the Quebec-born, English-language writer Joyce Marshall, who said it is "the rub and bite of difference that keeps us alert and alive."

title: THEATER REVIEW;9-Year-Old's Master Plan For Disaster
description: Out of the mouths of babes come bombs in the implosive world of Roger Vitrac's "Victor, or Children Take Over." This seldom-seen 1928 French comedy, which has been given a smashing (in every sense of the word) revival by the Arden Party troupe, turns a 9-year-old's birthday celebration into a riot of destruction in which that cute childish knack for speaking the unspoken has fatal consequences. You may have been taken to hell by kiddie parties yourself. But yours probably didn't end with a major body count.

title: A New Way to Search for Oil, Via Satellite
description: Like many a deep-sea fisherman, Richard A. Morneau obsesses about the ones that got away. Take, for example, the whopper off the Angolan coast three years ago -- a big deep water oilfield that Mr. Morneau, a geophysicist for the Chevron Corporation, still suspects was down there.

title: For a Czech Film Executive, It's All Business
description: The sprawling Barrandov Film Studios on the edge of Prague has witnessed much of this country's troubled 20th-century history. Founded in the democratic 1930's, the studios were taken over by the Nazis during World War II. Communist apparatchiks then used them to churn out propaganda films between 1948 and 1989. And when Czech movie makers enjoyed a brief "spring" in the 1960's, Soviet troops soon put an end to that.

title: BASKETBALL;As Losses Mount, Knicks Are Piqued for Playoffs
description: For the Knicks, it was another reminder that they have slipped below the National Basketball Association's elite teams. And with the playoffs less than three weeks away, time is running out to build momentum.

title: Proposed Multipurpose Stadium: Bucking Recent Trend
description: On the surface, the argument seems unassailable: A giant dual-purpose sports stadium on Manhattan's West Side as a future home for the Yankees would make more money for the city and for local businesses than a single-function baseball park. It would create more jobs and generate more tax revenue without significantly higher costs. Squeezing every possible use from the space, according to a consultant's report, offers the best hope of paying off the stadium's $1 billion-plus price tag.

title: Every State Should Regulate Physician-Assisted Suicide Now
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: LUCIANO PAVAROTTI, who garnered rave reviews for his performance on Saturday in the Metropolitan Opera's new production of "Andrea Chenier," took a little time off yesterday for art of a different sort. He dropped in at the Hirschl & Adler gallery on East 70th Street for a preview of a show called "Yanks Paint Brits."

title: Arkansas Case Revisits Words Of Star Witness
description: Defense lawyers in the loan fraud and conspiracy trial of Arkansas Gov. Jim Guy Tucker and two others sought today to bring out some inconsistencies with previous testimony by the special Whitewater prosecutor's main witness.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bulgarian Official Says Car Wasn't Competitive
description: Bulgaria's sole car maker, Rodacar, decided to close because its Rover Maestro cars were not competitive and its marketing strategy was faulty, Deputy Prime Minister Roumen Gechev said yesterday. Rodacar announced on Thursday that it would shut its factory in Varna, citing high excise duty on imported diesel engines and a lack of government support. Rodacar had sold just 200 of the 2,100 vehicles it has produced.

title: Raytheon to Buy Chrysler Military Units
description: The Raytheon Company agreed to buy most of the Chrysler Corporation's military electronics and aircraft-upgrading business in a deal worth about $475 million, the companies said today. The transaction continues the consolidation of the nation's military businesses in the face of stagnant spending.

title: No Headline
description: I would rather fight this battle in Congress as an increase in the minimum wage. But I became convinced that if I did not agree to the living wage, we would end up paying out more in food stamps and welfare, and so far the ordinance is not that costly. -- KURT L. SCHMOKE, Mayor of Baltimore

title: Guns Are No. 2 Cause of Death Among the Young, Data Show
description: Gunfire is the second-leading cause of death among Americans ages 10 to 19, the Children's Defense Fund said today in a report. And firearm deaths are increasing faster among that age group than in any other.

title: Yugoslav-Macedonia Ties
description: Yugoslavia established diplomatic ties today with its southern neighbor Macedonia, a long-awaited move that requires it to give up any territorial claim on the former Yugoslav republic.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: United States

title: Surprising Clues Found in Studies Of Virus That Threatens Children
description: TWO studies have provided surprising new information about a common enemy of children all over the world: rotaviruses. Unavoidable even in countries with good sanitation and clean water, rotaviruses infect virtually every child within the first few months or years of life, causing diarrhea and vomiting that go on for days. They are the major cause of such illness in children.

title: 4 States Watching for Brain Disorder
description: Federal health officials said today that they would step up surveillance for a human version of mad cow disease by focusing initially on four states and then expanding their efforts elsewhere if necessary.

title: Strong Ties to Arab Nations Are Key to French Foreign Policy, Chirac Says
description: President Jacques Chirac of France called Monday for a closer partnership between Europe and the countries of the Middle East, including European co-sponsorship of regional peace efforts  a concept once rejected by Israel.

title: TV Agreement Gives Viacom Greater Access To Germany
description: As part of the continuing battle to win control of television viewers in Germany, Europe's largest market, Viacom Inc. and the Kirsch Group of Germany announced yesterday a wide-ranging 10-year agreement that several executives close to Viacom said was worth $1.7 billion.

title: Rating Agency Gives Northeast Utilities Warning on Credit
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission's scrutiny of the three Millstone nuclear plants in Waterford, Conn., prompted Standard & Poor's today to warn the plants' operator that its credit rating was in danger of being downgraded.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ONE CALIFORNIA BANKING COMPANY TO BUY ANOTHER
description: Vallicorp Holdings Inc., a banking company based in Fresno, Calif., said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Sunrise Bancorp of Roseville, Calif., for cash and stock worth $20.6 million. Sunrise has assets of about $120 million and two branches. Vallicorp has 54 branches and $1.3 billion in assets. The transaction is expected to be completed by the end of the year. Sunrise Bancorp stock rose 75 cents yesterday, to $3.75 a share, in Nasdaq trading. Vallicorp stock fell 12.5 cents, to $15.875.

title: ON BASKETBALL;St. John's Expectations Exceeded Its Means
description: They used the word "family" at St. John's yesterday, a word that fit more comfortably when the university's place in the world was more consistent. When Fran Fraschilla was welcomed to the St. John's family as the 15th men's basketball coach in the university's history yesterday afternoon, identified by Ed Manetta, the athletic director and one-man search committee, as "our top choice," the mating dance was complete.

title: Rockwell Agrees to Pay Fine Of $6.5 Million in Explosion
description: The Rockwell International Corporation agreed today to pay a $6.5 million fine in connection with an explosion that killed two men at its rocket engine subsidiary.

title: BASEBALL;Mets Cannot Keep Up With a Generous Jones
description: Bobby Jones was supposed be the cerebral presence that would provide consistency and maturity on a Mets pitching staff in need of both. But instead of being the arm on which the club can lean, the right-hander has emerged as a disappointment.

title: Taiwan's Lobbying in U.S.: Mixing Friendship and Hardball
description: Last spring, a representative of Taiwan got himself invited to a reunion in Dallas of the Flying Tigers, American pilots who fought as volunteers for the Chinese Nationalists, and pledged that his Government would erect a monument to Americans killed in China in World War II.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;Choosing The Solo Alternative
description: Experience doesn't count for much in rock. A familiar face can be taken for granted; new sensations turn into known quantities, and the most loyal fans can be distracted by fresh infatuations. Yet even in alternative rock, with its fixation on novelty, there's a well-mapped career trajectory for a rock songwriter: arrive with a group and stick around after the group dissolves, making solo albums that are likely to be less brash and more considered. The songwriters reviewed below haven't run out of things they want to say.

title: Cash-Poor in New York City
description: New York City ran out of cash to pay its bills 21 years ago, brushing closer to bankruptcy than at any time since the Depression. The city is nowhere near bankruptcy now, but it is certainly short of cash. Companies that do business with the city have been told to expect delays in getting paid, while monthly contributions to employee pension funds have been suspended and property owners are being offered discounts for early tax payments. All these problems are painful signs of chronic fiscal problems from Washington to Albany to City Hall.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Leaders of Jewish organizations responded angrily yesterday to comments made by MARLON BRANDO on Friday charging that Jews "own" Hollywood and are insensitive to the stereotyping of other minorities in movies.

title: Alpharma Gets Approvals
description: Alpharma Inc. said today that it had received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to market treatments for baldness, Minoxidil Topical Solution, and for vaginal yeast infections, Miconazole Nitrate Vaginal Cream. Minoxidil is the generic equivalent of Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc.'s Rogaine, which has annual sales of about $100 million. Miconazole is the generic form of Monistat-7 Vaginal Cream, made by Johnson & Johnson's Ortho unit. It and similar products have annual sales in excess of $100 million.

title: Frank Paice, 82, Trainer for the Rangers
description: Frank William Paice, a longtime trainer for the New York Rangers who over the years became a friend and confidant to many of the team's players, died Saturday in Daytona Beach, Fla. He was 82.

title: By Design;Turtlenecks for All Seasons
description: The one constant in just about every fall collection was the turtleneck, so a trend that started unexpectedly last summer may keep going for a while. Next winter's turtlenecks are snug fitting with long sleeves, but there are a slew of short-sleeved mock turtlenecks for spring and summer.

title: Smoking's Pleasures Pale Next to Lung Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHINA SAID TO DELAY $100 MILLION AIRCRAFT PAYMENT
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said yesterday that it had not received about $100 million in expected payments from Chinese airlines because the Government in Beijing was delaying the formal signing of a contract for McDonnell Douglas aircraft. The company, which is based in St. Louis, was expecting a $50 million payment last summer and another one this month for work on 20 MD-90 jetliners, said Tom Williams, a McDonnell Douglas spokesman. Last month, China's Foreign Trade Minister, Wu Yi, postponed a trade mission to the United States that was to have included the contract signing. "The deal's just delayed," said John Fugh, the president of McDonnell Douglas China. "It's not the repudiation of an approved contract."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Relocating Nesting Geese
description: Geese are not known to be chicken when encountering humans, especially during nesting season, which is now. A Prudential employee recently fell in the company parking lot under an attack from a Canada goose. A few days later, another outraged goose refused to get off a car in the Belle Mead office complex until someone set off a wailing car alarm, Police Chief George Adelmann of Roseland said yesterday. Tomorrow, Department of Agriculture agents will relocate some of the goose nests near the Prudential parking lots, where the company has closed some sections to protect the nesting foul.

title: Film Rating Can't Serve As a Surrogate Parent
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft in an Agreement To Acquire Aha! Software
description: The Microsoft Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire the Aha! Software Corporation, a private company that makes pen-based programs for portable computers. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Stratton Oakmont Is Fined by N.A.S.D.
description: Stratton Oakmont Inc. agreed to pay a fine of $325,000 today, and its head trader agreed to pay $50,000, to settle a case connected with the underwriting of an initial public offering, the National Association of Securities Dealers said.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Judge Finishes Inquiry In Collapse of Banesto
description: A Spanish judge said yesterday that he had ended a preliminary investigation into the collapse of Banco Espanol de Credito S.A., or Banesto. The criminal trial of the bank's former president, Mario Conde, may begin in May. Judge Manuel Garcia-Castellon is expected to formally indict Mr. Conde on charges including misappropriation of funds, falsification of documents and price-fixing after a 17-month inquiry.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Tatham, Revamping Alters Name a Bit
description: Tatham Euro RSCG in Chicago, which is owned by Havas Advertising, said yesterday it had revamped its top management and changed its name to Euro RSCG Tatham.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Turkey Stages Offensive Against Kurdish Rebels
description: Turkish troops, taking advantage of a spring thaw and a unilateral cease-fire by Kurdish rebels, have started a large-scale offensive that has killed 90 rebels and 27 soldiers in three days, the authorities reported today.

title: Stokes Remembered As Unique Product Of the City He Led
description: Ambassador Carl B. Stokes, the first black to be elected mayor of a major American city, was remembered at his funeral today as a ground breaker for minorities in government.

title: Police Scorn Plan to Deny Schooling to Illegal Aliens
description: Some of the nation's largest police organizations are urging Congress to drop a proposal in a House immigration bill that would allow states to deny public education to illegal immigrants, arguing that if enacted it would lead to more crime.

title: State Farm Rebate Order By California
description: California ordered the State Farm Insurance Group today to pay at least $172 million in rebates, rejecting an administrative law judge's ruling that the company has no obligation.

title: Observer;How the Wind Blows
description: Doctor, help me. I am hooked on the Weather Channel. First thing in the morning, still gummy-eyed with sleep, downstairs I race, headed for the T&V. Do I tune to Bryant, Charlie, Harry as in days of old?

title: NYC;New Yorker Dies at 57. World Shrugs.
description: A LITTLE-discussed change is taking place in the auto world that may come as a dagger stab to those who feel the city has already endured its share of slings and arrows. With the 1996 model year soon coming to an end, Chrysler will retire the longest-running American model name: the New Yorker.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the C.I.A.'s unfulfilled promise to release documents about covert actions during the cold war misstated the year of congressional testimony on the issue by R. James Woolsey, who was then the Director of Central Intelligence. It was September 1993, not September 1991.

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow for the seventh day of Passover, Thursday for the eighth day of Passover and Orthodox Holy Thursday, and Friday for Orthodox Good Friday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Siblings in Foster Care
description: Elisa Izquierdo's five siblings have been placed in foster homes, where they seem to be doing as well as could be expected, child-welfare officials said yesterday.

title: Jury Duty Can Renew Faith in Justice System
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;ABBOTT LABORATORIES (ABT,N)
description: Abbott Laboratories Inc. reported yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose 15 percent, partly reflecting better-than-expected results from cutting costs.

title: FOOTBALL;Cardinals Give Esiason a Shot at Starting
description: Describing his three seasons with the Jets as "always in the eye of the storm," Boomer Esiason signed a two-year contract yesterday with the Arizona Cardinals with the likelihood he will be their starting quarterback.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Accountant Admits Guilt
description: Thomas S. Wagner, who worked as an accountant for the former Somerset County Prosecutor, Nicholas L. Bissell, pleaded guilty in Federal court yesterday to a felony charge of helping Mr. Bissell and his wife, Barbara, to falsify business and personal tax returns. Mr. Wagner also agreed to cooperate in the prosecution against the Bissells, who are scheduled to go on trial next week on charges of evading taxes on $143,000 skimmed from cash receipts at gasoline stations they owned. Mr. Bissell is also charged with abusing his office by intimidating a vendor with a threat of planting cocaine in his car, and demanding rebates from a distributor through overstated gasoline sales. After being indicted last September, Mr. Bissell was removed as county prosecutor.

title: Market Place;Labor Desires May Threaten Northwest Air
description: Life is pretty good these days at Northwest Airlines. Of the largest carriers, Northwest faces perhaps the least competition from feisty low-cost airlines. With the help of an industry recovery, Northwest's stock has risen from an initial offering price of $13 in 1994 to yesterday's close of $49.625 a share.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES DROP AFTER VISTA 2000 SAYS CHIEF WILL STEP DOWN
description: The shares of Vista 2000 Inc. plunged yesterday after the company said its chairman and chief executive, Richard P. Smyth, had agreed to a temporary leave pending a review of the company's financial results. The company, a maker of hardware and security equipment that is based in Marietta, Ga., had already announced the review, by the audit committee of the board. The shares of Vista 2000 dropped $2.8125, or 44 percent, to $3.9375 in Nasdaq trading. Arnold E. Johns, who has been Vista's president since February, will replace Mr. Smyth as chief executive during his leave. Vista recently announced that it expected to report a loss of about $5 million for last year because of unspecified adjustments.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Samsung Rules Out Buying Part of Fokker
description: The Samsung Aerospace Industries Company, a unit of the Samsung Group of South Korea, said yesterday that it had ruled out buying part of the bankrupt Dutch aircraft maker Fokker N.V. A Samsung spokesman said the company would continue to negotiate with Fokker on the acquisition of its engineering technology in 100-seat planes.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Cable Group Forms Advertising Bureau
description: The Cabletelevision Advertising Bureau in New York said yesterday that it had formed an independent trade association named the Multichannel Advertising Bureau International, to encourage advertisers to buy commercial time on networks and cable systems around the world owned by members of the cable organization. Robert Alter, 66, a onetime vice chairman and president of the cable television organization, was named to head the new association on a temporary basis until a permanent staff is hired.

title: Q&A;Cold Eyes
description: Q. You see Antarctic explorers swathed from head to toe, except the eyes. Why don't the eyeballs freeze in very cold weather?

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Microsoft Places Account in Review
description: The Microsoft Corporation in Redmond, Wash., said yesterday that it had placed in review its business-to-business direct marketing account, with billings estimated at $10 million. The account had been handled until February by the Anderson & Lembke unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies in San Francisco, which resigned that portion of the account while continuing to handle the advertising and on-line media portions. Microsoft has hired Pickholz Tweedy Cowan in New York, an affiliate of the Cassidy Companies, to help manage the review; a decision is expected by July 1.

title: Report in Wake of Girl's Death Finds Failures in Child Agency
description: The inattention and ineptitude of child welfare workers that led to the death of 6-year-old Elisa Izquierdo was far from unique, but was echoed in hundreds of cases of other abused children in the same period, according to a New York State report released yesterday.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Death Row, A Quandary In Real Life
description: If you haven't seen the movie "Dead Man Walking" or read the 1993 book on which it is based (now near the top of the New York Times paperback best-seller list) or watched its author on talk shows from Charlie Rose to Oprah Winfrey, you can meet her tonight on "Frontline." Whether you grant Sister Helen Prejean the program's title of "Angel on Death Row" will depend on what you think the law ought to demand of murderers like Robert Lee Willie. And that, tonight's even-handed report suggests, might have been influenced by the movie.

title: Man Is Killed in Shootout
description: A man was killed last night in a shootout with several police officers in the East Tremont section of the Bronx, the police said.

title: HOCKEY;Thanks to Isles, Lightning Catches Devils
description: The Islanders flirted with doing the Devils a rare favor.

title: Excerpt From Remarks By Bomb Case Lawyer
description: Following is an excerpt from a news conference held today by Anthony P. Bisceglie, the lawyer for David Kaczynski, whose brother, Theodore J. Kaczynski, is the suspect in the Unabom case, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:

title: BASEBALL;Umpire Gets Leave To Lose Weight
description: One week after John McSherry collapsed in an opening-day game and died, another overweight umpire has been given a leave of absence to begin a weight-loss program, the National League announced yesterday.

title: Moody's Names Ex-President To Head Its Operations Again
description: Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that William O. Dwyer, the ratings agency's former president, would come out of retirement and again be Moody's president.

title: 4 Teamsters Officials Ousted Over Insurance Fraud Charge
description: Medical insurance is often hard for many people to obtain. But relatives and friends of some teamsters' union officials in Brooklyn had no trouble getting it improperly, according to Federal investigators.

title: Opulence Redux (No Apologies)
description: Is greed good again?

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Rexall in Wal-Mart Deal
description: Rexall Sundown Inc. said it had received approval to sell its Sundown brand of vitamins, nutritional supplements and herbal products in more than 2,000 Wal-Mart Stores .

title: SWIMMING;Chinese Women's Team Has New Hopes for '96
description: After 12 months of silence and struggle against drug-taking accusations and acknowledgments, China's female swimmers returned to the water last week with fast times and new faces. The team is likely to challenge top Americans for medals at the Atlanta Olympics.

title: Guilty Plea and Jail Are Said to Be Near For Rostenkowski
description: Former Representative Dan Rostenkowski, once one of the nation's most influential lawmakers, has tentatively agreed to plead guilty to two Federal corruption charges and serve 17 months in prison, a lawyer in the case said today.

title: Stocks Surge in Japan
description: Stocks were trading sharply higher here this morning, with share prices more than recouping their losses from the selloff of the previous session. Analysts said the rise was fueled by optimism that a stronger dollar would raise profits for exporting companies. At the midday break, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 289.79 points, or 1.35 percent, at 21,714.03. On Monday, the Nikkei fell 271.60 points, or 1.25 percent.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ST. JUDE MEDICAL TO BUY MAKER OF NEUROLOGY DEVICES
description: St. Jude Medical Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Cyberonics Inc. for about $72 million, or $7 a share, and invest another $12 million later in newly issued Cyberonics shares for $5.50 each. Cyberonics, based in Webster, Tex., develops devices for the treatment of epilepsy and other neurological disorders.
