The company's products include a pacemaker-like device designed to reduce the incidence of seizures, which is still in the approval process with Federal regulators. St. Jude, which makes cardiovascular devices, is based in St. Paul.

title: The Limits of Openness in Vietnam
description: Vietnam eagerly welcomes foreign investment these days. But the American businessmen who rushed in after Washington finally normalized ties with Hanoi last year are discovering that Communist hard-liners still grip the reins. Tight ideological controls and a maze of bureaucratic regulations make Vietnam a difficult place to do business and imperil its continued economic advance.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Surge in Market Rates Worrisome to Policy Makers Stock and bond prices tumbled as long-term interest rates continued a swift, sharp ascent that is at odds with the Federal Reserve's policy of keeping rates stable. Analysts said the rate surge could endanger the moderate rate of growth expected this year.

title: Health Care Merger Doesn't Serve Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: Fiat's Crown Prince Takes Aim at Old Guard
description: PONTEDERA, Italy  Distancing himself from his powerful family and his country's business establishment, Giovanni Alberto Agnelli, the designated future chairman of the Fiat group, has called for a shake-up of Italy's clubby corporate business practices.

title: South Korea Asks Countries to Press The North on Border
description: The South Korea Government is asking Japan, China and Russia and other countries, to bring pressure to bear on North Korea to prevent further incursions by North Korean troops into its sensitive border area, a spokesman for South Korea's Foreign Ministry said today. He also said that Seoul is considering bringing the matter to the United Nations Security Council.

title: Lawyers Jockey for Role in Unabom Case
description: Lawyers are saying they are eager to defend the suspect in the Unabom case, Theodore J. Kaczynski, but his court-appointed lawyer is seeking a court order to make them stop.

title: Every State Should Regulate Physician-Assisted Suicide Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Calving of Right Whales Faces New Threats
description: NOW, in early springtime, is when female northern right whales and their newborns migrate northward from calving grounds off Florida and Georgia to around Cape Cod, Mass., taking about a month for the journey. It has been a good season for baby making among the northern rights. Scientists have sighted 20 calves, a record after years of falling counts. Only 320 or so of the behemoths now ply the North Atlantic, and a high rate of reproduction is seen as critical to the comeback of these big mammals, once hunted to near extinction and now the most endangered of the great whales.

title: Whitewater Counsel Defends Continuing His Private Practice
description: Responding to critics, the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, today defended maintaining a private legal practice while leading the investigation of the Clintons and others in their Administration.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the French tenor Roberto Alagna misspelled the surname of the soprano who is his fiancee and with whom he will appear in "La Boheme" at the Metropolitan Opera tomorrow night. She is Angela Gheorghiu. The article also referred incorrectly to Mr. Alagna's voice. He is a lyric tenor.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Slice Up a Great Hall and Harvard Gets Testy
description: The architect Charles F. McKim considered the Harvard Union, the sumptuous Georgian building of 1902 that was his first building on the Harvard campus, to be an assertion of the democratic spirit in an increasingly elitist university. He saw it as a clublike place for those Harvard men who could not afford to join the private clubs that were increasingly coming to dominate the university's social life. McKim, the celebrated senior partner of McKim, Mead & White and the architect of such monuments as Pennsylvania Station and the University Club in New York, would doubtless have been puzzled to hear his building described at the end of the century as the ultimate symbol of Harvard's elitism.

title: Ann Taylor To Buy Rest of Joint Venture
description: In an effort to salvage its ailing principal supplier, Ann Taylor Stores said yesterday that it would buy 100 percent of a joint venture it now shares with Cygne Design Inc., as well as another unit of that company.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Sea Kayaker Drowns
description: One man drowned and another was missing in two unrelated boating accidents over the weekend. The State Marine Police at the Point Pleasant Station said yesterday that they were continuing a search for Antonio R. Maduro, who fell from a paddle boat into Barnegat Bay off Chadwick Beach about 1:45 A.M. Sunday. The police said he was in his 20's. In the other boating accident, Charles A. Wagg, 56, drowned after a wave capsized his kayak at sea off Ship Bottom about 2 P.M. Saturday, The Associated Press said.

title: Man Arrested In L.I. Killings Of 5 Prostitutes
description: A 42-year-old postal worker has confessed to killing five prostitutes, dismembering their bodies and disposing of them in garbage bins on Long Island and in Yonkers over the last five years, the police said today.

title: F.D.I.C. Says Risk Is Up at Small Banks
description: A nationwide survey shows that most small banks did not relax their lending standards last year but about 11 percent assumed more risk than usual, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today.

title: Computer Enlists Einstein's Enigmatic Force And Little Mass to Explainthe Universe
description: EVEN their most successful theories and the stunning discoveries by new telescopes on the ground and in space still leave cosmologists with fundamental gaps in the history of the universe they seek to reconstruct. Hard facts are scarce and subject to conflicting interpretations. Cosmologists are left perplexed, but undaunted.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Iraq and U.N. Meet On Issue of Oil Sales
description: Iraqi and United Nations negotiators met for two hours today at the start of the third round of talks to determine whether Baghdad will be allowed to sell oil to buy food and medicine.

title: Freed in Rape Case, Man Is Accused Again
description: A Suffolk County man freed from prison after 11 years because of new DNA evidence in a rape case is now behind bars again, accused of another rape.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Bridging the Mac-Windows Gap
description: THE human race has functioned fairly well for thousands of years despite a large number of operating system incompatibilities. There are different standards for sex, language, race, religion, politics and personal computers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Burger King Changing Its Menu
description: The Burger King Corporation in Miami, a unit of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., is changing its breakfast menu as part of efforts to compete with the McDonald's Corporation.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Family Ties That Bind Growth
description: Take a cab here or a local flight, stay in a hotel, smoke a clove cigarette, watch a private television station, make a cellular phone call, buy a Mercedes or a Kawasaki motorcycle, put sugar in your coffee -- in each case, some of the money lands in a business controlled or owned, in whole or in part, by a relative of President Suharto, Indonesia's longtime strongman. And beyond the first family, Mr. Suharto's closest friends control vast business empires, including monopolies and exclusive concessions conferred by the grace of the President.

title: Patient Wins a Court Ruling Barring Forced Transfusions
description: The State Supreme Court ruled today that Stamford Hospital violated a patient's constitutional rights when it forced her to receive a life-saving blood transfusion two summers ago.

title: Strange Slab Atop Swiss Alps Puzzles Theorists
description: PUZZLING rocks found in the Swiss Alps are shaking up geology and might one day prompt a rush for precious gems and minerals in remote parts of the globe never thought to hide riches.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GENETIC ENGINEERING UNIT TO BE SOLD TO MONSANTO
description: W. R. Grace & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a unit of its Agracetus subsidiary that develops genetically altered products for the agricultural and pharmaceutical industries. The unit, which is based in Middleton, Wis., is to be sold to the Monsanto Company for $150 million in cash. Agracetus's human gene therapy business will remain with W. R. Grace, doing business as Auragen Pharmaceuticals Inc. Monsanto, which is based in St. Louis, makes agricultural and chemical products.

title: Man Details How He Shot a Black Leader
description: The racist acquitted 14 years ago in a sniper attack on Vernon E. Jordan Jr. has detailed for the first time how he indeed ambushed the civil rights leader, two newspapers reported.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Egypt Air to Buy 4 Planes From Airbus
description: Egypt Air said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent with Airbus Industrie to buy four twin-engine A321's. Egypt Air did not say how much it would pay for the four medium-range planes, which are estimated to cost a total of $200 million. Egypt Air has a fleet of 42 aircraft. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Utilities Seek Deal's Approval
description: The Baltimore Gas and Electric Company and the Potomac Electric Power Company said today that they had jointly filed applications with the Public Service Commissions of Maryland and the District of Columbia seeking approval of the $2.9 billion acquisition of Potomac Electric by Baltimore Gas.

title: New Jersey's Senate Race Attracts the Nation's Eyes
description: To reach voters in New Jersey, Richard A. Zimmer, who has already made his pitch in Texas, Florida and New York, will spend the next months seeking support in Illinois, Arizona, Minnesota and California.

title: Stocks Tumble on Jobs Data, and Rates Hit 8-Month High
description: For the second straight month, the stock market fell victim to signs that the economy is growing faster than many on Wall Street had expected -- growth that bond traders fear will result in a revival of inflation and higher interest rates.

title: Smoking's Pleasures Pale Next to Lung Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: Argentine Prison Riot Ends
description: A weeklong revolt in a maximum-security prison on the outskirts of Buenos Aires has left seven inmates missing and presumed dead, judicial officials said today.

title: Planned Jobs Cuts Rise, a Survey Shows
description: The number of planned job cuts announced by employers rose 35 percent in March from the comparable period a year ago, a survey showed today.

title: Some Cities Flexing Fiscal Muscle To Make Employers Raise Wages
description: The pay of 4,000 low-wage workers here office clerks, janitors, ticket takers -- has risen sharply since the city forced companies with city contracts to pay their workers well above the minimum wage. Now more than 30 other cities are also seeking ways to use taxpayer money as a lever to raise the pay of the working poor.

title: U.S. Puzzling Over Motives Of North Korea in the DMZ
description: American officials, while playing down the threat posed by North Korea's sudden round of violations of the military armistice that keeps the peace between the two Koreas, said today that they were baffled by the message Pyongyang was trying to send.

title: BASEBALL;When Pettitte Takes Mound, There Is No Room for Jitters
description: Andy Pettitte pondered the question for a few seconds and could not supply an immediate answer. Asked to remember the last time he was nervous, Pettitte was stumped. He remained silent until someone mentioned his wife giving birth to a son in 1994. Pettitte nodded and called it nerve-racking.

title: Body Parts Are Found in Bags and a Man Is Held
description: A 40-year-old Russian immigrant was ordered held in $1 million bail today on a murder-conspiracy charge after he was spotted on Sunday walking from the Passaic River toward a car loaded with trash bags containing body parts.

title: No Headline
description: The oldest Senator in history is campaigning to serve in two different centuries. Saying he had unfinished business, Senator Strom Thurmond today started his campaign for an eighth term in the seat he has held since 1954.

title: Patterns
description: Return of the Accessory?

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption yesterday about the golfer Ben Crenshaw misidentified the scene. Crenshaw was practicing in Austin, Tex., not playing a tournament in Marietta, Ga.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ELAN ENERGY INC., Calgary, Alberta, an oil and natural-gas concern, has agreed to buy leases to undeveloped oil-containing areas in northern Alberta for $31 million (Canadian), or $22.8 million (United States), from Amerada Hess Corp., New York, also an oil and natural gas company.

title: Music Rarity: One Woman Wielding a Baton
description: When Simone Young stepped onto the podium at the Berlin Staatsoper in 1992, there was hardly any applause at first. This Australian conductor was making her debut with the company in Puccini's "Boheme." She was making history as well, being the first woman ever to conduct there. But to many audience members, this diminutive woman in a black silk suit with her waist-length red hair pulled back in a ponytail must have looked like a violinist or flutist arriving late.

title: Sports of The Times;Michael Irvin's Weakness
description: MICHAEL IRVIN always wanted to be noticed. When he scored a touchdown for the three-time Super Bowl champion Cowboys, he cakewalked through the end zone. When he wasn't being thrown enough passes, he demanded the ball. When he got dressed up, he was as flashy as a pawn-shop window -- gold necklace, diamond bracelet, diamond-studded gold watch, a diamond stud in his left ear.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LABOR DEPARTMENT WON'T INVESTIGATE FLEET UNIT
description: Fleet Bank of New York will not face a Labor Department investigation into charges that it discriminated against seven black employees in its Buffalo office, the department said yesterday. The employees, who filed a $1.8 billion lawsuit in December, accused Fleet of denying them promotions and of discriminating against them. But because they filed a private lawsuit, not a complaint with the Labor Department, the department is not required to investigate, a representative of the department said. James Mahoney, a spokesman for Fleet, said the company was reviewing the charges, though he added, "We would strenuously deny that there's any pattern of discrimination in the company." Fleet Bank of New York is a unit of Fleet Financial Group Inc., which is based in Boston.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Jukebox Radio Link Studied
description: Is the plug going to be pulled on Jukebox Radio? The Federal Communications Commission is investigating a complaint that a Dumont-based company that produces Big Band Era radio programming has improper financial links to a Monticello, N.Y., station, WJUX-FM, that actually broadcasts the programming received in New Jersey. The F.C.C. has notified Gerald A. Turro, the owner of Jukebox Radio Inc., that he has 60 days to end his relationship with WJUX. WJUX receives the Jukebox Radio programming on standard phone lines, then broadcasts it in New York. But the signal is relayed into New Jersey via two devices known as translator stations, which are owned by Jukebox Radio. WJUX's owner is a former business associate of Mr. Turro, Wesley R. Weis. F.C.C. rules prohibit anyone with an FM station interest from also owning a translator station, which can extend coverage.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Drunk Driver Gets 30 Years
description: Michael Homentosky was sentenced yesterday to 30 years in prison for aggravated manslaughter in the death of a 39-year-old Randolph woman in February 1995, when he ran a red traffic light while driving drunk at 82 miles an hour. The accident prompted state legislation requiring prison sentences for drivers who cause a death while drunk. Mr. Homentosky is the first drunk driver in Morris County to be sentenced for aggravated manslaughter, said James M. Porfido, an assistant prosecutor.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SKC OF SOUTH KOREA TO BUILD FILM PLANT IN GEORGIA
description: SKC Ltd., an affiliate of the Sunkyong conglomerate of South Korea, will build a $1.5 billion film plant in Covington, Ga., about 30 miles east of Atlanta, SKC executives and state officials said yesterday. SKC plans to produce materials for audio and video cassettes, packaging and other products at the plant, which will open in 1998 and employ 1,000. Initially, SKC plans to hire about 250 local workers and to bring in about 50 employees from South Korea. The company plans to break ground on the project after the Olympic Games in Atlanta this summer.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Sri Lanka Extends State of Emergency
description: President Chandrika Kumaratunga has extended a state of emergency to the entire country, giving herself sweeping powers in the war against Tamil rebels before June elections.

title: Reasserting Its Identity, Group Picks New Leader
description: Nine months after its last president resigned amid intense debate over the organization's future, the Planned Parenthood Federation of America has chosen its new president, Gloria A. Feldt. Ms. Feldt, 53, who has headed Planned Parenthood's Phoenix affiliate since 1978, has firsthand experience with the group's core issues: raised in small-town Texas, she married at 15 and had her first child nine months later.

title: Zeigler Coal Offers $1 Billion For Cajun Electric Power Plants
description: The Zeigler Coal Holding Company and a unit of the Northern States Power Company said yesterday that they had offered $1 billion in cash for the nonnuclear assets of the bankrupt Cajun Electric Power Cooperative Inc., beating out 11 other bidders.

title: A DEVICE IN CABIN IS SAID TO MATCH THE UNABOMBER'S
description: One of two live bombs found at Theodore J. Kaczynski's Montana cabin was virtually identical to an explosive device used in one of the Unabomber's fatal attacks, Federal law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Russians Attack Chechen Towns As Both Sides Ignore Cease-Fire
description: Russian troops attacked two villages in southeastern Chechnya today in an effort to drive rebel forces out of their mountain strongholds.

title: Fossil May Fill a Gap in Early Primate Evolution
description: The fossil remains of a mouse-sized creature that lived 40 million years ago could be the missing link between the most ancient primates and higher primates, including humans, scientists report.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Black Republican Is Chosen
description: Camden County Republicans yesterday chose Sophia A. Nelson, a 29-year-old lawyer, to challenge incumbent Representative Robert E. Andrews, Democrat of Haddon Heights, this November. Ms. Nelson, who is believed to be the first black Republican to seek the First Congressional District seat, will announce her candidacy on April 16. Mr. Andrews, 38, was elected to Congress in 1990. JOE SHARKEY

title: Spokesman Broke Conflict Law
description: The New York City Conflicts of Interest Board ruled yesterday that David Begel, the spokesman for Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, violated the City Charter when he worked part time for a private educational organization during his first month at the Board of Education last fall.

title: The Landfill Tour Is Canceled, But We Are Offering . . .
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday he had disposed of a Department of Sanitation proposal to offer regular tours of the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island, the world's largest garbage dump." The New York Times, April 3, 1996.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Honda to Offer An Electric Car
description: The Honda Motor Company said yesterday that it would introduce a two-seat electric car in California in the spring of 1997.

title: Texas Frees Child Molester Who Warns of New Crimes
description: Under parole restrictions that Texas officials said were the most severe ever imposed, a convicted child molester who has warned he may rape and murder children in the future obtained his legal due today: release from prison.

title: Hong Kong's Newest Queue
description: The images of tens of thousands of Hong Kong residents lining up last week for a British passport -- one that does not allow them to reside in the United Kingdom without a visa -- reminded the world about the concerns many people in the colony have about their future after China takes over in July next year.

title: Segarra's Chauffeurs Led In Overtime, Records Say
description: As the Giuliani administration continues to investigate allegations that Deputy Mayor Ninfa Segarra used her official car for personal trips, city records show that Ms. Segarra's drivers worked twice as many overtime hours during the last two years as drivers for the other two Deputy Mayors.

title: BASKETBALL;Bulls Finally Lose at Home
description: The Chicago Bulls' 44-game regular-season home winning streak ended tonight as Charlotte, the team they embarrassed four nights earlier, rallied for a 98-97 victory.

title: Havana Journal;25 Years an Exile: An Old Black Panther Sums Up
description: More than a quarter of a century after he sought political asylum in Cuba, William Lee Brent still seems American to the core. He speaks a Spanish tinged with the Louisiana accent of his boyhood, prefers whisky to rum, and continues to focus his attention on many of the same causes he once espoused as a member of the Black Panther Party.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bombay Utility Sets Up Solar Power Plant
description: The Tata Power Company, a generator and supplier of electricity to Bombay, said yesterday that it had set up a 110-megawatt power plant near Bombay that generates electricity from sunlight. The electricity will go into the company's power distribution grids. The project, described as experimental, is expected to last five years. The company said it also planned to set up wind turbines. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: BOXING;Whitaker Hardly Ready To Yield Sport's Summit
description: Speak softly when you ask Pernell Whitaker about Roy Jones Jr.

title: Colombian Legislators Halt Investigation of President
description: The legislative committee investigating President Ernesto Samper announced today that it had suspended its inquiry after other members of the Colombia's Congress accused 12 committee members of impropriety.

title: On My Mind;The Montana Mistake
description: In New York City, police are now under orders to act immediately any time they spot a crime committed -- from drug-peddling to graffiti vandalism. The official attitude about keeping law and order is that there is no crime too minor to bother about. Minor and major, crime has gone down.

title: Hung Jury Declared in Killing Of a Chinatown Tourist in 1991
description: A Manhattan jury was declared deadlocked yesterday on murder charges against a reputed Chinese gang member accused of killing a tourist in Chinatown five years ago.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;DOW JONES & CO. (DJ,N)
description: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings fell nearly 19 percent, a decline greater than analysts had expected, as a result of higher newsprint costs and expenses for new television operations.

title: HORSE RACING;No One Gains Ground On the Derby Favorite
description: Nick Zito, who has won the Kentucky Derby twice in the last five years, conceded some geography yesterday in order to preserve his chances of winning his third Derby, and said: "Unbridled's Song can have center stage in New York."

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Connecticut Weekly on Sunday about opposition to adult video stores in Milford misstated part of the name of a group organized two years ago to protest pornography shops in Waterbury. It is the White Ribbon Against Pornography, not White Women Against Pornography.

title: Coca-Cola Changes Some Fruitopia Flavors
description: The Coca-Cola Company said it was dropping six flavors of its Fruitopia beverages and adding two in a drive to remake the brand.

title: 2 Companies In Asia Venture
description: The General Instrument Corporation of Chicago and the HCL Corporation of India agreed today to a joint venture to make and sell communications equipment in India and other South Asian markets. HCL-General Instrument Ltd. will invest about $50 million to $60 million in the project and will design, manufacture and distribute broadband communications equipment for the growing cable television market, HCL officials said.

title: Cleared of Rape by DNA, Man Is Accused in 2d Case
description: A little over three years ago, a Suffolk County, L.I., man was freed after 11 years in prison when DNA testing seemed to show he had been wrongly convicted of rape. Now he is back behind bars, accused of another rape, and this time DNA testing is the prosecution's weapon.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Tax Offices Extending Hours
description: As the April 15 filing deadline looms, the State Division of Taxation is extending hours at its regional offices in Fair Lawn, Newark, Northfield, Sea Girt, Somerville, Trenton and Turnersville. They will be open from 8:30 A.M. to 6 P.M. today through Friday; 8:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. on Saturday, and 8:30 A.M. to 7 P.M. next Monday. There are also three phone lines for questions and comments: Tax Hotline (609-588-2200), Tax Talk (800-323-4400) and TaxFax (609-588-4500).

title: Phoenix Team To Be Coyotes
description: Say hello to the Phoenix Coyotes, who will take to the ice next season in uniforms of dark green, brick, purple, sand and black.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Electronic Arts Buys South Africa Distributor
description: Electronic Arts Inc., the biggest publisher of video game software, said yesterday that it had bought Vision Software Ltd., a South African software distributor, to expand its reach in Africa. Vision Software, based in Johannesburg, is building import operations in Kenya and four central African countries. Africa "represents a significant opportunity," said David Gardner, managing director of Electronic Arts, based in San Mateo, Calif. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: COMPANY NEWS;RJR WINS SUPPORT AGAINST LEBOW AND ICAHN
description: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation's board has won backing from Institutional Shareholder Services, an influential adviser to large stockholders, in RJR's fight against a slate of nominees to RJR's board that has been proposed by the financiers Bennett S. LeBow and Carl C. Icahn. The advisory firm, based in Washington, has recommended that RJR shareholders re-elect the current directors at the company's annual meeting on April 17. Institutional Shareholders had previously supported Mr. LeBow, the majority owner of Brooke Group Ltd., in the battle to force RJR to spin off its food unit, the Nabisco Holdings Corporation, immediately. RJR has said it does not want to spin off the unit before 1997.

title: Dashing Across Water's Surface: How One Creature Does It
description: BY combining the disciplines of biology and mechanical engineering, researchers say they have deciphered the trick that certain lizards use to run on water.

title: Debating The Language Of Signs;New Jersey Towns Tell Asian-Owned Stores: Advertise in English, Too
description: Hong Gol Kim, owner of Nadri Tour and Travel, says 95 percent of his agency's business comes from Korean customers. So why, he asks, should he have to comply with a local law that requires him to put up a promotional sign with equal-sized letters in both Korean and English?

title: Friends Put Up Cash For Scientist's Bail
description: Dr. Robert Gallo, an AIDS researcher, was among five friends who put up $350,000 for the bail of Dr. Daniel Carleton Gajdusek, the Nobel laureate accused of molesting a boy.

title: Every State Should Regulate Physician-Assisted Suicide Now
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hitachi Plans to Spend $112 Million on Plant
description: Hitachi Ltd. said yesterday that it would invest 12 billion yen, or about $112 million, to build a silicon wafer plant in Japan. The plant will make epitaxial wafers, used to make more powerful semiconductors, Hitachi said. The plant, expected to begin full production in 1999, will be in the Ibaraki prefecture north of Tokyo. (AP)

title: Smoking's Pleasures Pale Next to Lung Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Omit Architects
description: To the Editor:

title: Cat Killing in Texas Deserves Severe Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: Bosnian Men Tell Tale of Survival Deep in Serb Territory
description: Five Muslim men and a teen-age boy have arrived in Bosnian Government territory with an amazing story. They say they managed to escape the suspected killings of hundreds of the men in a town that fell to the Serbs nine months ago and that they have just emerged from hiding in the mountains and forests deep within Bosnian Serb territory.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Looking to Presidents For Signs of Character
description: CHARACTER ABOVE ALL Ten Presidents From F.D.R. to George Bush Edited by Robert A. Wilson 256 pages. Simon & Schuster. $23.

title: Nissan Is Approved For China Venture
description: The Nissan Motor Company announced today that it had received the Chinese Government's approval for the manufacturing and marketing of commercial vehicles in a joint venture in China's Zhengzhou City.

title: Clear Antitrust Rules for Doctors
description: The Federal Trade Commission plans to revise antitrust guidelines that dictate what types of joint ventures doctors will be permitted to create. The chairman, Robert Pitofsky, says the commission, in cooperation with the Justice Department, will not relax the antitrust laws but will simply spell out how existing rules apply to health care. If Mr. Pitofsky delivers on that pledge, the commission will do consumers some good. But if, as some fear, the commission gives doctors special protections, it will do serious harm.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Belfast Protestants Riot At a Blocked Parade
description: Protestant marchers hurled firebombs and bottles today after the police blocked a parade from entering a Roman Catholic area. At least five people were injured.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Few Flaws to Sonics, So Far as Knicks Go
description: What the Knicks have become -- old and ornery -- and what the Seattle SuperSonics are -- fast and furious -- became uncompromisingly clear yesterday when the Knicks couldn't get a rebound and Shawn Kemp couldn't get himself thrown out of the game.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Angotti, a small fish swallowed by a bigger fish, promises not to lose its allure.
description: ANOTHER independent agency has succumbed to the blandishments of a global giant as Angotti, Thomas, Hedge, a New York shop known for stylish, witty creative work for clients like Saab, agreed yesterday to be acquired by the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Dance Notes
description: Stephen Petronio sat on a studio floor the other day watching his young dancers race, spin and idle dreamily through "Drawn That Way," a new piece his company is to perform starting tonight and running though Sunday at the Joyce Theater. He had just turned 40, an event that most dancers would keep to themselves. But Mr. Petronio, a leading choreographer of his generation who is known as a bright, brash, unquenchable enfant terrible, was jubilant. He and his company had, after all, survived. And this watershed birthday had convinced him that now was the time to gamble with new ideas about creating dances.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Your New 1997 PC, or Maybe Not
description: WHAT is wrong with your home computer? Plenty, hints the Microsoft Corporation. It takes too long to start up when you press the on button. It makes connecting peripherals too hard. It insists you pry open the case and confront scary electronic innards if you want to add something as crucial as memory. It needs a bigger screen and better audio and video so that the whole family can gather round the joystick and kill realistic menacing on-screen creatures in an atmosphere of togetherness.

title: Drink-Label Suit Settled
description: Heublein Inc. said yesterday that it had settled a lawsuit against E.& J. Gallo Winery over the labeling on Gallo's Bartles & Jaymes' margarita-flavored coolers -- which do not contain tequila.

title: Delicate Act of Go-Between Behind the Unabom Arrest
description: I felt it important not to get lost in that shuffle," Anthony P. Bisceglie delicately explained, describing his role as skeptical investigator and chief mediator between law enforcement and the anguished family that eventually concluded the Unabomber suspect might be one of its own.

title: HOCKEY;Stick Work Lets Down Rangers At Garden
description: Sure, the Rangers were tired last night. They were playing their fourth game in five nights and their sixth game in nine. That's a lot for even a young team, and nobody ever accuses the Rangers of youth.

title: Help Close Technology Gap for the Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: MARKETS RETREAT AS INTEREST RATES CONTINUE TO CLIMB
description: Stock and bond prices tumbled today as long-term interest rates continued a swift, sharp ascent that is at odds with the Federal Reserve's policy of keeping rates stable and that analysts said could endanger the moderate rate of growth expected this year.

title: Clinton Judicial Nominee Is Focus of G.O.P. Attack
description: Shortly after Bill Clinton was elected President in 1992, Charles (Bud) Stack let the new Administration know what job he yearned to have.

title: BASKETBALL;Botched Play Brings Familiar Nets Finish
description: With 11 seconds remaining and the Nets looking for a 3-point play to force overtime tonight against Philadelphia, Vern Fleming took the inbounds pass from midcourt and looked for his first option, then his second. But he found nothing open except a hole in his teammates' attention span.

title: BASKETBALL;Fraschilla Makes the Jump to St. John's and the Big Time
description: Fran Fraschilla was asked yesterday how difficult it was for him to make the move to the big leagues of college basketball, leaving a successful program at Manhattan College for St. John's, the Big East and all the exposure that the job change will entail.

title: U.S. Ready to Rescue Americans From Fighting in Liberia Capital
description: As intense fighting between rival warlord factions raged through this Liberian capital, the United States Embassy prepared tonight for an airlift rescue of hundreds of Americans and other foreigners trapped in the chaos.

title: COMPANY NEWS;A COMPANY'S STOCK SLIDES AFTER PROCTER ENDS DEAL
description: The shares of Zila Inc. plunged 30 percent yesterday after the company said the Procter & Gamble Company planned to end a marketing agreement for a Zila product used in the diagnosis of oral cancer. The shares of Zila, which is based in Phoenix, fell $2.3125, to $5.875. Zila said on Thursday that Procter & Gamble had given the company a 90-day notice to end the agreement, but stock markets were closed on Friday. Joseph Hines, Zila's president, said the company was seeking new distribution channels for the product, which he said was expected to receive approval soon from the Food and Drug Administration. Zila's product, already marketed in Canada and Britain, is used to determine which sites should be the targets of oral cancer biopsies and surgery and is also used to test patients at high risk for such cancers.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PROVIDER OF HOME NURSING IS SOLD FOR $21 MILLION
description: Premier Medical Services Inc., a provider of home nursing services, said yesterday that it had been acquired by Pediatric Services of America Inc. for about $21 million. Pediatric Services, a provider of home health care for children that is based in Norcross, Ga., said the combined companies would have 95 locations in 26 cities. Premier said it expected annual revenue of the combined company to total about $150 million this year. Premier said it alone had annual revenue of about $40 million. Premier, which is based in Walnut Creek, Calif., also has offices in Maryland, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Virginia and Washington, D.C.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Jolene Sykes was named publisher of Fortune magazine, New York, succeeding Stuart Arnold, who is leaving. Ms. Sykes had been the Southeast regional ad director at Sports Illustrated, Atlanta, which, like Fortune, is owned by Time Warner Inc. Ellen Atkinson was named to the new post of senior vice president for marketing at C/net, San Francisco. She was previously executive director at the Ziff-Davis Magazine Network unit of the Ziff-Davis Publishing Co., New York, which is owned by Softbank.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Tumble As Treasuries Extend Selloff
description: Prices of Treasury securities tumbled yesterday, extending a selloff from Friday, when a stronger-than-expected employment report jolted the market.

title: Chess
description: Four grandmasters, Alexander Ivanov of Brookline, Mass., John Fedorowicz of Manhattan, Sergei Kudrin of Stamford, Conn., and Dmitry Gurevich of Chicago, tied for first place last month in the Mid-America Tournament in Chicago.

title: Jordan Allowing U.S. to Use Its Air Base for Flights Over Iraq
description: For the first time since the Persian Gulf war, American warplanes are preparing to carry out patrols over southern Iraq from neighboring Jordan, a step that could elevate tensions between Baghdad and Amman.

title: BASEBALL;Forecast Is Second Thoughts, With a Chance of Doubleheaders
description: Major league baseball officials, alarmed by the number of snowouts and rainouts in the wake of the sport's earliest start, and concerned about fans and players caught in frigid conditions when games are played, will seek a better way to fit the sport's lengthening schedule into the calendar.

title: Multinet Wins ank Charter
description: The Multinet International Bank, which plans to act as a clearinghouse for multiple currency trades, said yesterday that it had received a charter from New York State.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Honors
description: Barbara Carr, president of Carr & Associates, New York, and Lee Nadler of the Survivors of the Shoah Visual History Foundation, New York, were awarded the Crystal Prism Award by the Advertising Club of New York, which also awarded the American Advertising Federation Silver Medal to Burt Manning, chairman and chief executive of J. Walter Thompson Co., New York, a unit of the WPP Group.

title: Spy Plane Aids in Cleanup
description: A HIGH-ALTITUDE NASA research plane is gathering data to hasten the cleanup of hazardous waste at the California Gulch Superfund site in Leadville, Colo.

title: Nynex and Tribune Company Buy Stakes in Internet Ventures
description: The Nynex Corporation and the Tribune Company each announced separate investments yesterday in companies that provide electronic guides to the Internet's World Wide Web, offering the latest evidence of growing investor interest in such services.

title: No Change In U.S. Policy After Review Of Air Crash
description: The Air Force said today that it is reviewing "every procedure" that might have played a role in the crash of the military plane in Dubrovnik, Croatia, last week that was carrying Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown.

title: INSIDE
description: Computerized Cosmology

title: Executive Changes
description: CAPITAL CITIES/ABC INC., New York, which is owned by the Walt Disney Company, said that Michael P. Mallardi, president of its broadcast group, would retire in June and that his post would be eliminated. And James A. Acara, president of Capital Cities/ABC radio division, would also retire. Robert Callahan succeeds Mr. Acara.

title: Ben Johnson, 75; Won Oscar for 'Picture Show'
description: Ben Johnson, whose past as a rodeo champion lent realism to his portrayal of western characters and his Oscar-winning depiction of Sam the Lion, an aging pool-hall manager in the elegiac 1971 film "The Last Picture Show," died yesterday at Leisure World, a retirement community in Mesa, Ariz., where he had lived since 1988. Mr. Johnson was 75.

title: Stadium Plan Would Scuttle M.T.A. Hopes
description: The proposal to build a baseball stadium on the West Side of Manhattan would kill the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's longstanding plan to develop the site and generate millions of dollars for transit improvements.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A No-Nonsense Teacher Braving the Wilderness
description: A SCHOOLTEACHER IN OLD ALASKA The Story of Hannah Breece Edited by Jane Jacobs Illustrated. 302 pages. Random House. $24.

title: AT WORK WITH: Mason Reese;Part 2 (Hard Part) In the Life Of a Former Child Star
description: LIMELIGHT.

title: Our Towns;A Little Shop Of Condoms (Horrors!)
description: YOU have 30 days to get out of town," hissed the caller, obviously someone who had seen his share of Clint Eastwood movies.

title: North Korea's Puzzling Maneuvers
description: No one can be certain why North Korea suddenly and deliberately violated the 43-year-old armistice on the Korean Peninsula this week, and then just as abruptly stopped. The action could have been an attempt to intimidate South Korea on the eve of its parliamentary elections, or simply a reflection of an internal power struggle involving the military. Whatever the reasons, North Korea's decision to send hundreds of its troops into the Demilitarized Zone has brought an appropriately measured response from the United States. While refusing to be intimidated, the Clinton Administration has also properly avoided exaggerating the dangers.

title: Wine Talk
description: THESE are not days of unalloyed joy in the California wine country. What with grape prices going through the roof, phylloxera-ravaged vineyards to replant, flat sales and many wineries on the block, the wine makers have more crises than a Joan Crawford movie.

title: Disputed Documents Could Be Used in Class-Action Suit Against Tobacco Companies
description: A previously undisclosed collection of what are purported to be confidential documents from the Philip Morris Companies has been turned over to the Federal Bureau of Investigation as potential evidence in Federal investigations of the tobacco industry.

title: 100 DAYS TO ATLANTA 1996;Anxiety for Atlantans, But Officials Are Upbeat
description: The Olympic torch is on its way, but if it arrived today there would be nothing to light. The city is so pockmarked with construction sites that contractors find themselves begging for backhoes. And for the moment, Atlanta's new 21-acre Centennial Park would be usable only if the International Olympic Committee added mud wrestling as a demonstration sport.

title: POP REVIEW;Iggy Pop Flaunts His Energy
description: Anyone can knock over equipment, but only a true punk smashes things in the middle of a set. So that's what Iggy Pop did at Roseland on Monday night. As he sang "Everybody's always trying to tell me what to do," in "Raw Power," he mangled his first microphone stand of the night, pounding it against the floor; then he launched himself at his guitarist's amplifier, knocking a pricey Marshall top off its speaker cabinet. Later he hurled his microphone to the stage, disabling it for part of the next song.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Drug Test Costs Year of Eligibility
description: A Marquette University reserve basketball player lost a year of eligibility because he tested positive for marijuana during the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, the school announced yesterday. ZACK McCALL will keep his scholarship and will practice with the team next season, the university said. (AP)

title: New Corestates President Plans to Resign
description: The Corestates Financial Corporation said yesterday that Samuel A. McCullough, who became its president yesterday, would step down on June 30th, after less than two months on the job. Mr. McCullough had been the chairman of the Meridian Bancorp of Reading, Pa., which Philadelphia-based Corestates agreed to buy in October for $3.1 billion, a deal that was closed yesterday.

title: TV SPORTS;CBS Thrives as a Masters Tradition
description: As CBS Sports prepares for its 41st consecutive Masters this week, is it vulnerable to losing the family golf jewel? Don't bet on it. Not yet.

title: Potassium Iodide Is No Protection From Fallout
description: To the Editor:

title: BASKETBALL;No More Gill, and Not Much of the Nets
description: The Nets' season is all but over. Kendall Gill's season is definitely over. So is Kevin Edwards's.

title: Obesity Is Linked to Birth Defects
description: Obese women are at least twice as likely as thinner women to have babies with debilitating birth defects, two studies have found. And a vitamin known to help prevent such abnormalities appears to offer overweight women no protection, the researchers said.

title: A Racial Study Finds Differences In Jail Sentences
description: A little-noticed study released last fall by the Pataki administration concluded that black and Hispanic people sentenced for minor felonies or misdemeanors in New York were treated more harshly than whites in similar circumstances. Some experts have hailed the study as ground-breaking, but Gov. George E. Pataki's own aides have now disavowed it.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Co-Worker Guilty of Murder
description: William L. Cooper, 37, was convicted yesterday of murdering a co-worker at a construction site in Atlantic City in 1994. The victim, Dennis Bartley, 30, died after being assaulted with a sledgehammer, power drill and circular saw.

title: Croat Handed Over to War Tribunal
description: A Bosnian Croat who was commander of a prison camp was handed over to the Balkan war crimes tribunal today.

title: Scientist's Wife Is Sought in Slaying Investigation
description: The authorities are seeking to question the estranged wife of a molecular biologist who they believe was the victim of a macabre murder last weekend, law enforcement officials said today.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Chip Sales Indicator Falls to 5-Year Low
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator plunged to a new five-year low in March, reflecting the continued slowdown in personal computer sales and rapidly falling prices for memory chips.

title: President Signs Bill For a Line-Item Veto
description: In a move he said would allow Presidents to fight "special interest boondoggles, tax loopholes and pure pork," President Clinton signed into law a bill authorizing a line-item veto. The signing was a legislative triumph for Mr. Clinton, who had long sought authority to cut specific items in spending and tax bills.

title: Fixing the Child Welfare Mess
description: Two new reports examining the death of Elisa Izquierdo confirm the worst suspicions about New York City's child welfare agency. Every one of the systems that failed to save Elisa has been failing other children as well, often on a regular basis.

title: Rostenkowski Pleads Guilty To Mail Fraud
description: Saying he had behaved no differently from most other members of Congress, former Representative Dan Rostenkowski pleaded guilty to two charges of mail fraud today and agreed to begin serving a 17-month prison sentence in 30 days.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;At home on the frontier, Marlboro will cross one, as the first cigarette in the  Marketing Hall of Fame.
description: MARLBORO, the cigarette that Philip Morris and the Leo Burnett Company transformed from an also-ran brand into the world's best-selling smoke -- and perhaps most valuable trademark -- is becoming the first tobacco product to be named to the Marketing Hall of Fame.

title: English Commands Preceded Deputies' Beating of Mexicans
description: An audio recording of conversations between two white sheriff's deputies who beat two Mexican immigrants last week indicates that the officers ordered the Mexicans to get to the ground before striking them. But because the orders were in English, which the Mexicans apparently do not speak, they may not have understood the commands and may have had trouble complying with them.

title: Stocks End Mixed as Dow Drops 33.96 Points
description: The stock market turned mixed yesterday after Monday's sharp decline. The Dow Jones industrial average continued to move downward, but advancing issues outnumbered declining ones on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COLLINS & AIKMAN TO SPIN OFF WALLCOVERING UNIT
description: The Collins & Aikman Corporation said yesterday that it would spin off its Imperial Wallcoverings Inc. subsidiary to shareholders. The company, based in Charlotte, N.C., said the spinoff, which should be completed within four months, would let it focus on its automotive products business. The company said Imperial, a publicly traded company before it was acquired by Collins & Aikman in 1971, had revenue of $205.3 million for the latest fiscal year. Shares of Collins & Aikman, which also makes residential upholstery fabrics and contract carpets, rose 25 cents, to $6.375 yesterday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Holloway Decides Against Duke
description: SHAHEEN HOLLOWAY, one of the nation's most sought-after point guards, crossed Duke off his list yesterday and narrowed his college choices to the University of California and Seton Hall. The prospect of spending next season on the bench behind JEFF CAPEL, Duke's senior point guard, might have influenced Holloway's decision, but the 5-foot-10-inch senior from St. Patrick's in Elizabeth, N.J., did not want to comment on his choice.

title: FOOTBALL;Jets' No. 1 Pick? Phillips a Big Contender
description: Although the Jets say they still haven't decided what to do with the No. 1 pick in the draft, they made it clear today that Lawrence Phillips, the Nebraska running back, is definitely among the players they are considering.

title: Sports of The Times;Seven Runs, Ten Hits, Two Inches
description: The traditional introductory lineup was scrapped in favor of the extended opening day linescore at frigid, snowy Yankee Stadium yesterday, when the sport of statistical purity took measure by runs, hits, errors and inches.

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with a Critic's Notebook article about the battle over the renovation of the Harvard Union carried an erroneous credit. The picture was by The Boston Globe, not by Ed Quinn for The New York Times.

title: Green Decides Not to Run For Mayor
description: In a decision that will help shape the political seasons of both 1997 and 1998, Public Advocate Mark J. Green yesterday removed himself as a candidate for mayor in next year's Democratic primary. Instead, Mr. Green said, he will run for re-election and, if successful, consider challenging his old nemesis, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, in 1998.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NEW JERSEY GRANTS MERGER OF TWO TRUMP CASINOS
description: Donald J. Trump, the developer, received permission yesterday from New Jersey regulators for a $1.4 billion merger of his two biggest casino properties. Regulators also granted Trump a license for his fourth and newest casino, Trump World's Fair Casino, which is to open next month. Trump plans to issue $1.1 billion in new bonds through his Trump Atlantic City Associates to pay off existing debt of Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort and Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino. The two gambling halls will be merged under the Trump Atlantic City Associates umbrella. The deal will decrease their long-term debt by about $65 million, to $1.11 billion, Paul O'Gara, a lawyer for Mr. Trump, told the state Casino Control Commission.

title: Smoking Threatens Alcoholics More Than Drink, Study Says
description: Alcoholics who smoke are more likely to be killed by the cigarettes than by the liquor, a study suggests.

title: At the Nation's Table;From Saloonkeeper To Restaurateur
description: When Ed Moose was about to open his namesake restaurant in San Francisco three and a half years ago, locals were betting he would have to take reservations for his bar stools while his dining tables went begging. As a co-owner of the Washington Square Bar and Grill during the 1970's and 80's, Mr. Moose had won his spurs as the city's reigning saloon lord.

title: Suspect in Serial Killings Is Suicidal, His Lawyers Say
description: Laying the groundwork for a possible insanity defense, lawyers for the postal worker who has confessed to killing five prostitutes in his Hicksville apartment described him today as a man with a history of mental illness who has often threatened suicide.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: COMPANY NEWS;REPLIGEN SAYS TALKS TO SELL UNIT TO GENZYME FAILED
description: The Repligen Corporation said yesterday that talks to sell the assets of its Allegro Biologics unit to the Genzyme Corporation had failed, but did not give an explanation. On Feb. 12, Genzyme said it had agreed to buy the unit's assets for undisclosed terms. Genzyme was to have assumed Repligen's recombinant Protein A business and develop and produce drugs for Repligen. Repligen, based in Cambridge, Mass., develops treatments for chronic and acute inflammation. Genzyme, also of Cambridge, makes drugs and develops treatments for cartilage damage, burns and chronic skin ulcers.

title: Oklahoma City Suspect Wants Secret Documents
description: Lawyers for Timothy J. McVeigh, one of two men charged with bombing the Federal Building in Oklahoma City last year, argued today that they could not defend him without access to classified documents of the Central Intelligence Agency, the Defense Intelligence Agency and the National Security Agency.

title: With Ceremony, Clinton Signs Line-Item Veto Measure
description: In an important shift of power from Congress to the executive, President Clinton today signed into law a bill authorizing a line-item veto, which he said would allow Presidents to fight "special-interest boondoggles, tax loopholes and pure pork."

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: ON BASEBALL;Yankees Hope Fans Warm to New Cast
description: As bizarre as it seemed, as cold and brutally bitter as it was, the Yankees probably made a wise decision in opting to play their Yankee Stadium opener yesterday instead of conceding to the snow and cold and waiting until today or tomorrow. The last time snow interfered with their season, the Yankees filled their idle time by making a trade that marked the beginning of the end of the George Steinbrenner revival of a once-great franchise.

title: 1996 Pulitzer Prizes Form a Snapshot Portrait of Journalists in theWorkaday World
description: A writer who portrayed life on the Lower East Side in a widely acclaimed musical -- only to die on the night of the show's final rehearsal -- was honored with a Pulitzer Prize yesterday.

title: Unabomber Represents Our Anarchist Within;His Brothers' Keeper
description: To the Editor:

title: Petrobras Improves Output
description: The state oil company Petroleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras, said today that it had installed a 440-ton manifold to connect eight offshore oil wells to a new platform. The equipment will increase crude production by 30,000 barrels a day, Petrobras said. The Albacora field, 80 miles off the coast of Rio de Janeiro, produces 57,000 barrels of oil a day.

title: A Girl, 10, Is Raped at Knifepoint in the Bronx
description: A 10-year-old girl was raped at knifepoint in a South Bronx park Monday night by a man who had given her a ride on his bicycle, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report yesterday about the siblings of Elisa Izquierdo, adjoining an article on problems in New York City's child-protection system that contributed to Elisa's death, misstated the criminal charges pending against her stepfather. He is charged with having beaten her several weeks before she died, but is not charged in her death. (Elisa's mother, Awilda Lopez, is charged with having killed her.)

title: Neglect of Manhattan Bridge Takes Toll in Time and Money
description: New York City's effort to shore up the crumbling Manhattan Bridge will take about 10 years longer and almost $300 million more than officials had predicted when the repairs began in 1982.

title: G.E. Unit Teams With Netscape in Business Services Venture
description: Hoping to make computer transactions a common way for companies to conduct business with one another, two leading Internet players, GE Information Services and Netscape Communications, said yesterday that they had formed a new software company.

title: Suit Seeks to Unseal Unabom Documents
description: Three news organizations, including The New York Times, have asked a Federal judge here to open three sealed court documents relating to the investigation of Theodore J. Kaczynski, who officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation believe is the Unabomber.

title: No Headline
description: It's not fair to just take Americans. Why take out only their own citizens while other people are dying? Liberians are angry, yes. They are leaving us to the slaughter."

title: U.S. Mimics Cuba When It Limits Dialogue
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Umpire Makes the Call Behind the Plate: No Coat
description: Derryl Cousins, in his 18th year as an American League umpire, said he was not trying to be macho by working at home plate in a short-sleeved shirt and no jacket yesterday in the cold and snow that buffeted Yankee Stadium.

title: TV Notes;New News for the Morning
description: After decades of finishing third in the morning news-and-talk competition, behind ABC and NBC, CBS News has decided to run a different race. Instead of tinkering with its current vehicle -- "CBS This Morning," with Harry Smith and Paula Zahn as co-hosts -- CBS told its affiliated stations yesterday that it was inventing a new kind of morning broadcast, featuring an expandable partnership with local stations that would enable them to repossess large chunks of morning time.

title: The Pulitzer Prizes
description: ARTS

title: COMPANY NEWS;'DIFFERENCES' SPUR EXIT OF AHMANSON PRESIDENT
description: H. F. Ahmanson & Company said yesterday that its president, Fredric J. Forster, was leaving the company because of "differences on tactics." The company, which operates Home Savings of America, the nation's biggest savings and loan, called the resignation "amicable." Mr. Forster was named chief operating officer in October 1993, succeeding Charles R. Rinehart, who became chief executive.

title: James W. Rouse, 81, Dies; Socially Conscious Developer Built New Townsand Malls
description: James W. Rouse, the visionary developer who built new towns in the countryside, shopping malls in the suburbs and "festival marketplaces," like Faneuil Hall in Boston, in older downtowns, and later used the profits from these ventures to help generate housing for the poor, died yesterday at his home in Columbia, Md. He was 81.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;A Five-Hour Marathon for a TV State of Mind
description: What happens if you sit a baby in front of a black-and-white television and let him watch everything from Jack Benny to monster movies? On the HBO series "Dream On," that baby will grow up to be Martin Tupper, who did not turn out to be functionally illiterate or savagely violent as a result. In fact, the 1950's television baby grew up to be a book editor. O.K., so he's a slightly maladjusted, socially inept, sexually obsessed book editor, but you can't blame television for everything.

title: Personal Health
description: IT makes good sense to lie down when you need to rest your legs, but the legs of millions of Americans do not let them rest. Before they can even fall asleep, many develop "creepy crawly" sensations in their legs, forcing them to get up and walk around for 10 or 20 minutes. Or once asleep, they may be partly aroused by involuntary kicks and jerks of their "restless legs." Other people fall asleep uneventfully, but are often bolted from a sound slumber by a sudden, intensely painful leg cramp like the crippling charley horse that sometimes afflicts swimmers.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;A Top Official Quits Harrisons & Crosfield
description: Harrisons & Crosfield P.L.C. said yesterday that its finance director, Martin Anderson, had resigned, surprising analysts and forcing shares in the British diversified manufacturer down 5.7 percent. William Turcan, the company's chief executive, attributed Mr. Anderson's departure to differences with top management, including himself and the chairman, George Paul. Mr. Anderson, 46, replaced Mr. Turcan as the company's finance director in 1994 after a 16-year career with Hill Samuel Bank. As chief executive, Mr. Turcan sold the company's consumer foods unit and Indonesian plantations business in 1994 to focus on the higher-margin chemicals businesses. Shares in Harrisons, which makes products ranging from chemicals to animal feed, closed down 9 pence at 148 pence after falling as much as 12 pence, or 7.5 percent. The stock has fallen 14 percent since hitting a 52-week high of 172 pence on March 5, dragged down by the company's pessimistic outlook when it posted 1995 results last month. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Tests Show Landing Beacon Functioned in Croatia Crash
description: Officials of the Federal Aviation Administration have tested the Croatian radio beacon that was presumably being used by the plane carrying Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown when it crashed on approach to the Dubrovnik airport and "found the landing beacon signal to be functioning properly during the tests," Air Force said today.

title: Unabomber Represents Our Anarchist Within
description: To the Editor:

title: Gulf War Illness Linked to Fatigue Syndrome
description: To the Editor:

title: A Plasticine Pair Tangled Up With a Cruel Mutton-Maker
description: Rube Goldberg himself couldn't have improved on the elaborate contraptions that Wallace, an eccentric English inventor who is one-half of the Claymation duo, Wallace and Gromit, has devised to make their home a gadget fanatic's dream house. Early in "A Close Shave," the half-hour centerpiece of a program of animated films from the Aardman Studio, a device that propels Wallace's morning porridge across the room into his cereal bowl malfunctions and encrusts an entire wall with muck. That's only the beginning of the problems facing Wallace and his trusty dog, Gromit, a sedentary bookworm who is shown absorbed in "Crime and Punishment" by "Fido Dogstoyevsky."

title: Human Remains Found in Prison Oven After Riot
description: Law enforcement officials said today that they had found human skulls, thigh bones and other body parts in the ovens of a maximum-security prison where seven inmates disappeared in a weeklong, nationwide revolt that ended on Sunday.

title: BOXING;Woman Accuses Tyson
description: Mike Tyson was accused by a 25-year-old Indiana woman of sexual battery in a nightclub on Chicago's South Side over the weekend.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Award for 3 Life-Savers
description: The Plainsboro Police Department will give its Citizen Award for Bravery today to three men who rescued a Princeton University student who fell through ice into a Plainsboro lake in February. Maury Jones of Princeton, Patrick Leonard of Belmar and Michael Shields of Cedar Knolls saved the life of Jiukang Yu, 28, Capt. Timothy L. Matheny said. JOE SHARKEY

title: At the Nation's Table;Beating the Odds Amid the Ashes
description: Before Joseph Thompson moved in, Edmund was the street that time forgot. Abandoned and fire-scarred hulks lined the block. Drug dealers peddled their wares. Most people stayed away.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Antigay Club Law Is Fought
description: Under a 46-year-old law, nightclubs in Jersey City cannot hire or even admit "criminals, prostitutes, pimps, procurers, homosexualists or persons . . . impersonating homosexualists." Dominic Santana, owner of the Hard Grove Cafe in downtown Jersey City, decided to fight when he encountered the obscure ordinance when applying last week for a license to stage live music. In protest, he withdrew his application.

title: Mr. Rostenkowski's Plea Deal
description: There is always a measure of sadness in seeing a skillful legislator brought down, even if by his own corruption. But the plea bargain formally agreed to yesterday by former Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the longtime chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, brings to a satisfactory conclusion an important case involving the abuse of public trust by a powerful official.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Chip Industry Indicator Plunges to 5-Year Low The semiconductor industry's leading indicator, its book-to-bill ratio, plunged to a five-year low of 0.80 for the three-month period ended in March, reflecting a slowdown in personal computer sales and rapidly falling prices for memory chips.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DIGITAL EQUIPMENT CUTS PRICES ON SOME SERVERS
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that effective immediately it was cutting prices on some models of its Alphaserver systems by as much as 33 percent. Digital, based in Maynard, Mass., lowered the price on the 64-bit Alphaserver 400, 1000 and 1000A systems, as well as on system memory options. The decreases stem in part from lower component costs, the company said. The price of the Alphaserver 400, for example, was cut to $5,295 from $7,995. A server is a computer that serves as the host of a network, storing and distributing files to individual work stations.

title: Du Pont Asking for Bail
description: Lawyers for John E. du Pont, the millionaire charged with killing the former Olympic wrestler Dave Schultz, say he should be granted bail so he can check into a psychiatric hospital.

title: In Performance;THEATER
description: Moliere's Pious Hypocrite, With Trusty Hair Shirt 'Tartuffe' Jean Cocteau Repertory

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Taiwan lobby in the United States referred incorrectly to a visit by President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan to Cornell University last year. He attended an alumni reunion and gave a lecture; he did not receive an honorary degree.

title: FOOTBALL;4-Year Deal for Giants' Cross
description: He will be one of the more quiet signings of the Giants' off season, but Howard Cross is nevertheless one of the most important ones. The Giants kept their outstanding tight end by signing him to a multiyear deal yesterday.

title: Stocks Higher in Tokyo
description: Stocks advanced this morning in Tokyo. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 80.69 points, or nearly four-tenths of 1 percent, to 21,824.86. On Tuesday, the Nikkei rose 319.93 points, ending at 21,774.17, its highest close since Feb. 10, 1992. The weakness of the yen has raised hopes of increased earnings for Japanese exporters.

title: 13 Cattle Quarantined in Mad Cow Disease
description: Thirteen head of New York cattle have been placed under quarantine by state agriculture officials because of concerns they could be carrying mad cow disease, although there is no evidence the animals are infected.

title: Pataki Allows Recruiting By Military on Campuses
description: Gov. George E. Pataki signed an executive order today allowing the military to recruit on campuses of the State University of New York, countering a 1993 State Supreme Court ruling that had banned such recruiting on the ground that the military discriminated against homosexuals.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball National League ATLANTA BRAVES -- Placed LHP Pedro Borbon on the 15-day disabled list. Purchased the contract of LHP Tom Thobe from Richmond of the International League. Frontier League JOHNSTOWN STEAL -- Signed OF Thurston Rockmore. SIOUX CITY EXPLORERS -- Signed RHP Jamie Fernandes.

title: For That Essential and Exotic Ingredient
description: SOHO PROVISIONS, an ethnic and organic food merchant, has opened in a no-frills second-floor walkup at 518 Broadway (Spring Street). Douglas Aronson and Hara Viner shed three-piece-suit careers to indulge a passion for food and to help desperate cooks find ingredients for that Lebanese or Bengali recipe.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Thief Returns to Princeton
description: James A. Hogue, banned from Princeton University for posing as a self-educated orphan with a hard-luck story and falsified S.A.T. scores to receive $22,000 in financial aid illegally in 1988, pleaded guilty Monday to returning to the scene of the crime. Prosecutors said Mr. Hogue was seen on campus recently, posing as a graduate student. In 1992, Mr. Hogue pleaded guilty of theft by deception. He served three years of a five-year sentence before being paroled last year on the condition that he stay away from the Princeton campus. He now faces a hearing on the possible revocation of his parole.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Swiss Banks Considering Giant Merger
description: Locked in a ferocious battle for control with an upstart investor, the Union Bank of Switzerland is considering a merger overture from rival CS Holding A.G. that would create one of the world's giant banks.

title: BASEBALL;Players and Fans Left Numb by Yankees' Victory
description: The misty snow turned into a driving snow and then became a blinding snow, and still the frigid Yankees and the chilly Royals played baseball for nine innings on a wet, wild and and wacky day at Yankee Stadium. The summer game had a wintry backdrop for the home opener, and a fan in a Santa Claus costume actually looked appropriate.

title: Benjamin Eisenstadt, 89, a Sweetener of Lives
description: Benjamin Eisenstadt, the innovative Brooklyn businessman who set Americans to shaking their sugar before sweetening their coffee and then shook up the entire sweetener industry as the developer of Sweet 'N Low, died on Monday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 89 and a major benefactor of Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn.

title: In Performance;CABARET
description: The Two Sides of Sammy Cahn, In a Tribute by Sara Zahn 'The Cahn Film Festival' The Triad

title: COMPANY NEWS;PARSONS NAMES A NEW CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: The Parsons Corporation named James F. McNulty as chief executive, succeeding Leonard J. Pieroni, 57, who died last week in the plance crash in Croatia with Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown. Mr. McNulty, who is 53, will also become a director. He joined the corporation in 1988 and has held several senior-level positions, most recently as president of Parsons Infrastructure & Technology Group Inc., one of four global business units of the company, an engineering and construction group based in Pasadena, Calif.

title: A CUNY Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Thousands of Mourners Remember Brown
description: Ronald H. Brown came back to the Commerce Department today in a flag-draped coffin with military honors, and thousands of mourners stood for hours in a driving rain to pay their respects to a man who in the last decade had stood at the center of American politics, trade and diplomacy.

title: Food Notes
description: Taste of the Nation

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Aruba Tourism Authority, Weehawken, N.J., to Fitzgerald & Co., Atlanta, to handle its account in the United States, previously handled by Bates USA, New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: At the Nation's Table;Dining Outdoors On the Waterfront
description: Boston may be burdened by brutal winters, but it is now brightened with the onset of spring. One of the most scenic spots from which to appreciate the balmier days ahead is Cornucopia on the Wharf.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: From Vampires and Batman to the Concert Hall
description: Three years ago, Carl St. Clair, the director of the Pacific Symphony Orchestra in Orange County, Calif., came up with a daunting project for his ensemble. Inspired by a remark by the political columnist Art Buchwald, who said that the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington was "crying out for music," and with the 20th anniversary of the end of the war coming up in April 1995, he was determined to commission a work that would be both monumental and moving. He also sought to address a local need. Orange County has the largest Vietnamese population outside Vietnam, as well as thousands of American veterans. He wanted a work that would reach out to both groups, and, for that matter, to those who had protested the war.

title: TV Notes;A Couple of Pals
description: In a public end to what was once one of television's most public feuds, Arsenio Hall will be the first guest with Jay Leno when NBC's "Tonight" Show visits Chicago for a week starting on April 29.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Russia Allows Tyson Chickens
description: Tyson Foods Inc. said it had received export licenses from Russian officials that would allow it to resume shipments of its poultry.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;The Latest Member of the Coven
description: Television's view of millennium madness generally takes the form of space aliens and futuristic phenomena. But instead of looking forward, Showtime is looking back to the good old days when witches and sitcoms like "Bewitched" tickled prime-time ratings. Starring Melissa Joan Hart ("Clarissa Explains It All") in the title role, "Sabrina the Teen-Age Witch" -- today at 9:40 A.M. and 6:15 P.M. -- could be subtitled "Daughter of Samantha and Serena," characters played by Elizabeth Montgomery in the mid-1960's.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Compagnie de Suez Expected to Post Loss
description: Compagnie de Suez S.A. is expected to post a 1995 loss today of between 4 billion and 7 billion French francs ($784 million to $1.37 billion), analysts said, as unprofitable real estate holdings continue to weigh on its books. The French banking and financial services company had a loss in the first half of 3.98 billion francs. The 1995 loss by Suez would be its second in two years. In 1994, the company posted a loss of 4.78 billion francs as it made huge provisions for losses on risky real estate.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Rape of Children Is Charged
description: Fred Bostic, 32, of Elizabeth, was charged yesterday with sexually assaulting a 3-year-old girl in February 1995 and his girlfriend's 9-year-old daughter a year before that, Edward M. Neafsey, Acting Prosecutor for Union County, said. The older girl's mother was also charged with hindering prosecution and endangering the welfare of a child because she urged her daughter to lie to the police about the assault, Mr. Neafsey said. He declined to identify the mother.

title: Business Travel;Airlines are offering discounts of as much as 50 percent for certain destinations this summer.
description: THE airlines are having their widest and deepest fare sale of the year, with the major carriers offering discounts of as much as 50 percent for travel this summer in the United States, Canada, Mexico and the Caribbean. The carriers vow these will be their lowest fares for summer travel, but that really depends on how many people respond to the sale and how strong summer air travel turn out to be. For now, summer appears to be shaping up well, in part because of interest in the Summer Olympics in Atlanta, which begin 100 days from today.

title: World News Briefs;Clinton Offers to Ease Turkey-Greece Disputes
description: President Clinton met with the Greek Prime Minister today and urged him to refrain from using military force in disputes with Turkey. In a wide-ranging discussion at the White House, Mr. Clinton offered American help in easing tensions between Ankara and Athens.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;School Finance Plan Is Due
description: The Whitman administration said yesterday that it would release district-by-district figures for a new school financing formula in May -- six months after the New Jersey Department of Education first promised to outline how its new curriculum standards would be linked to financing. The announcement came in the face of mounting criticism by both educators and legislators that the state had yet to produce a clear outline of how it would meet a court-ordered September deadline for a plan to equalize the money spent by its richest and poorest districts. The New Jersey income tax cut pushed through by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has put an increased burden on local property taxpayers to underwrite schools.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARLON BRANDO, whose remarks about Jews and Hollywood on the "Larry King Live" show on CNN last week caused a furor, telephoned the head of the Simon Wiesenthal Center on Monday to apologize, Reuters reported yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Stake to Be Sold In Mark Goodson
description: All American Communications Inc., a television syndication company that owns 50 percent of the game-show creator and licensor Mark Goodson Productions, said yesterday that the Interpublic Group of Companies, which owns the other 50 percent of Goodson, had agreed to sell its stake to All American for $25 million. The transaction is expected to be completed by the end of the month.

title: Buzzless Buzzword
description: The fight against bad English is not frivolous," George Orwell wrote in 1946 -- a conviction that has grown ever truer in the intervening half century. Today, a muddled thought or phrase can send the whole globe marching down a cul de sac. This is why Earth Day, April 22, should be spent with dictionaries and thesauruses.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Ex-Trustee Admits Theft
description: A former trustee of a Masonic lodge in Lincoln Park pleaded guilty in Superior Court yesterday to embezzling $164,535 from the lodge, saying he used the money to try to save his printing business. The former trustee, Leland R. Dodd, 62, of Randolph, wrote 23 checks in amounts ranging from $1,000 to $42,000 from 1991 to 1993 to his concern, the American Printing Company, said Susan Bielanowski, an assistant Morris County prosecutor. "What's unusual is that he didn't spend the money on an exotic vacation or a bigger house," she said. "Instead, he put it into his failing business." The theft was discovered during a routine audit.

title: In Letters, Window on Life of the Unabom Suspect
description: In a stream of meticulously handwritten letters to a Mexican farmhand he has never met, Theodore J. Kaczynski, suspected of being the Unabomber, carried on a seven-year correspondence that provides the most detailed portrait yet of his reclusive life in the deep woods of Montana.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;Tuna Takes to Arugula
description: Usually, people plan menus by choosing a main course and then finding other dishes to go with it. But recently I had a marvelous arugula salad at a New York restaurant and thought it was worth recreating.
