The combination of bits of Gorgonzola and nuts (they used peanuts; I chose pine nuts) with the slightly bitter arugula was the perfect combination of crunch and soft, sharp and sweet. The dressing was made with olive oil and white-wine vinegar. This would be a hit as a salad course at any dinner party.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Irvin Denies Having Drug Problem
description: Speaking for the first time since being indicted on drug charges, Dallas Cowboys receiver Michael Irvin told ESPN yesterday he won't be suspended from the National Football League because he doesn't have a drug problem.

title: U.S. IS EVACUATING AMERICANS CAUGHT BY WAR IN LIBERIA
description: United States military commandos tonight began evacuating the first of hundreds of fearful Americans and others from this embattled West African capital, where a tenuous peace erupted Saturday into a new spasm of civil war.

title: Journal;Grand Old Ivy
description: The professor and author David Gelernter may have been maimed by the Unabomber, but he hasn't misplaced either his sense of humor or his loyalty to Yale. In an otherwise somber essay in Time this week about how he bounced back from his tragedy, he drops in a wisecrack about the suspect, Theodore Kaczynski: "I will pass over in silence the fact that he is a Harvard man."

title: It's Coming: Your Pocket Cash on a Plastic Card
description: Citibank, Chase Manhattan, Mastercard and Visa plan to announce today an ambitious joint venture to offer electronic cash loaded on a plastic card that can be used to make small purchases.

title: About New York;In Harlem, Echo of Eloquent Dreams
description: A BIG elegant office sits empty in a big and elegant Harlem town house. A map of Africa hangs on one wall, a globe rests next to a desk covered with legal papers, books and half-written speeches.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Being married to a British prince can be expensive, as both the Princess of Wales and the Duchess of York have said, and even being the girlfriend of a prince can cost a pretty penny.

title: Woman Killed in Crash
description: A woman was killed and three people were injured in a two-car collision in Gravesend, Brooklyn, yesterday. One vehicle apparently ran a stoplight, the police said.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;New Nissan President Seeks Return to Profits
description: The Nissan Motor Company named Yoshikazu Hanawa as its president, in a move analysts say will expand the marketing and planning prowess of Japan's second-largest auto maker. Mr. Hanawa, 62, will succeed Yoshifumi Tsuji, as Nissan focuses on becoming profitable again. In the year to March, Nissan is expected to post its first operating profit since the 1991 fiscal year. Mr. Tsuji, 68, who will become chairman, explained the move as a "return to youth." In the nearly four years Mr. Tsuji was president, analysts credited him with orchestrating the first phase of Nissan's streamlining, including the first plant closings for a Japanese auto maker since World War II. A shareholder vote on the appointments is scheduled for the annual meeting in June. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Concern Grows Over Herb That Promises A Legal High
description: A CHINESE herb that has been used for centuries to treat upper-respiratory problems is becoming increasingly popular with young people, who are using it as an alternative to illegal recreational drugs.

title: Hispanic Nominee in Texas Senate Race; Congressman Loses
description: Texas Democrats set a political milestone tonight by choosing Victor M. Morales, a high school government teacher and political novice who campaigned out of his pick-up truck, as their party's nominee for United States senator. Mr. Morales, who is Hispanic, is the first minority candidate for senator or governor selected by either major party in Texas history.

title: World News Briefs;U.S. Gives $30 Million For Rwanda and Burundi
description: The Clinton Administration has contributed $30 million in new funding to the United Nations refugee agency to be used to aid refugees from Rwanda and Burundi, the State Department announced today.

title: World News Briefs;Yeltsin and Pole Meet; Fail to Heal NATO Split
description: President Aleksander Kwasniewski of Poland met with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia in Moscow today. They said later that they had failed to settle differences over NATO's expansion plans but that they hoped uneasy relations would improve in other areas.

title: BASEBALL;Isringhausen Lifts Mets Out of Slump
description: The sight of Mets pitcher Jason Isringhausen wearing short sleeves in temperatures in the mid-30's must have either psyched out the Cincinnati Reds or provided the Mets with some bizarre source of motivation.

title: Westway's Defeat Yielded Tangible Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SWIMMING;FINA Begins Investigating Foschi
description: JESSICA FOSCHI's battle to clear her name isn't over. Although the American Arbitration Association decided the 15-year-old swimmer from Old Brookville, L.I., was not at fault after testing positive for steroids, swimming's world governing body, FINA, said yesterday it is starting its own investigation.

title: A Ghost of Maoist Fervor Lives On in Disgrace
description: For 10 years, Wang Li worked side by side with Mao and then became one of the most ardent firebrands of the early Cultural Revolution, helping to topple scores of Communist Party elders, some of whom survived to rule again.

title: COMPANY NEWS;KIMBERLY-CLARK TO CUT PRICES FOR PAPER GOODS
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation said yesterday that it would cut prices for its tissues, paper towels and bath tissue, following the lead of its rival, the Procter & Gamble Company. Kimberly-Clark said it would reduce prices for its Kleenex Cottonelle and Scott 1000 bathroom tissue and Kleenex facial tissues an average of about 8.5 percent, effective April 22. Prices for Kleenex Viva and Scott Clean paper towels will be lowered by nearly 5 percent on June 3. The action mirrors price cuts initiated March 27 by P.& G. Kimberly-Clark shares fell $2.375, to $72.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Rehnquist Joins Fray on Rulings, Defending Judicial Independence
description: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, as oblique as some other Federal judges have been direct in response to the recent tide of political criticism of sitting judges and their decisions, said today that the country's history demonstrated how important it was that Federal judges should never be threatened with removal because of their rulings.

title: Excerpt From One Letter
description: Following is an excerpt from a letter Juan Sanchez Arreola, a retired farmworker living in Mexico, said he received from Theodore J. Kaczynski, the suspect in the Unabom case. The letter, dated Nov. 28, 1995, was in Spanish and has been translated by The New York Times:

title: Smokers More Likely to Bear Retarded Babies, Study Says
description: Pregnant women who smoke are 50 percent more likely to have mentally retarded children, according to a study released today.

title: Foreign Affairs;At God's Elbow
description: In the spring of 1982 I was working in the Business Day section of The New York Times and was befriended by a young editor there named Nathaniel Nash. Nathaniel was a gentle soul and a deeply religious Christian. He liked to come by and talk to me about Israel. In April 1982 The Times assigned me to cover the Lebanese civil war, and at my goodbye party Nathaniel whispered to me: "I'm going to pray for your safety." I always considered his prayers my good luck charm, and when I walked out of Beirut in one piece a few years later, one of the first things I did was thank Nathaniel for keeping watch over me. He liked that a lot.

title: Whitewater Witness Admits Error at Prior Hearing
description: As the defense lawyers for the Governor of Arkansas and two co-defendants neared the end of his cross-examination, the prosecution's star witness conceded that he had glossed over details when a judge questioned him in his own loan fraud case.

title: A Mature Housing Market;A Growing Business in Not-Quite-Nursing-Home Care
description: Her body is diminished by age and she needs a walker to get around, but Ida Apperman's voice is as tart as when she upbraided fifth graders acting up in the rear of her Newark classroom a half-century ago.

title: COMPANY NEWS;OLD NATIONAL BANCORP TO BUY WORKINGMENS CAPITAL
description: Old National Bancorp has agreed to acquire Workingmens Capital Holdings Inc. in a stock swap valued at $39.3 million. Old National said late on Monday that it would exchange 0.64 of a share for each share of Workingmens Capital, valuing Workingmens at $21.28 a share. Shares of Workingmens jumped $3.016 yesterday, to $19.266, in Nasdaq trading. Old National, based in Evansville, Ind., has total assets of about $5 billion.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial notebook last Saturday about the 1985 police bombing of the MOVE cult in Philadelphia misidentified Ramona Africa. She is not the mother of the bombing survivor once known as Birdie Africa.

title: OLYMPICS;100 Days To Get Ready For Atlanta
description: ARCHERY

title: KPMG Peat Marwick's Chief Will Not Seek Re-election
description: Jon C. Madonna, the chairman and chief executive of KPMG Peat Marwick L.L.P. who melded the New York accounting firm's diverse domestic operations into a more cohesive whole, said yesterday that he would not seek re-election when his six-year term ends in the fall.

title: BASEBALL;Fan Sues Over '94 Fall
description: A woman from Plano, Tex., who fell 35 feet from the right-field upper deck at The Ballpark in Arlington during its regular-season debut in 1994, has sued the Texas Rangers and the park's architects, alleging negligence.

title: COMPANY NEWS;THREE AIRLINES GIVE BOEING ORDERS FOR 34 PLANES
description: The Boeing Company received about $1.27 billion in orders yesterday from three airlines for 34 jetliners. Western Pacific Airlines, a discount carrier based in Colorado Springs, said it planned to spend $700 million on 20 Boeing 737's; CSA Czech Airlines, based in Prague, ordered 10 Boeing 737-500 twinjets valued at roughly $350 million, and Finland's national carrier, Finnair, said it planned to buy or lease four 757's, valued at about $220 million, its first Boeing planes. Finnair's 56-aircraft fleet now consists mainly of planes from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.

title: Exploring the World of Kimchi, the Spicy Korean Staple
description: INCREASINGLY, I have found myself eating kimchi, the super-spicy Korean pickle dish that is served before and with meals in every Korean restaurant and many Korean homes.

title: A Snowstorm Puts a Coat On Daffodils
description: A late-season northeaster skimmed the New York metropolitan area last night and early today, bringing more than seven inches of snow to parts of Suffolk County, L.I., while coating lawns, car tops and tree limbs elsewhere in the region.

title: If Refrigerators Could Speak, The Stories They'd Tell
description: CAROLYN VERWEYST used to think she knew everything about people and their refrigerators: what they crammed into crispers and shoved onto shelves, how long they foraged for midnight snacks, why they preferred doors that opened to the right instead of to the left.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-11

title: Wilkins's 35 Leads Greeks to the Final
description: Dominique Wilkins scored 35 points today, leading Panathinaikos of Athens into Thursday's European Club Championships final as the Greek club beat CSKA Moscow, 81-71.

title: TV Notes;New, Improved 'Rangers'
description: When last we left the Mighty Morphin Power Rangers, they were on the brink of destruction. Their Zeo Crystal had been shattered, its pieces flung to the winds; their temporary helpmates, the Alien Rangers, had fled Earth; and the Power Rangers' steel-girded command center had exploded, leaving them powerless and fearing that their master, Zordon, had perished.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Miscellany
description: The Publishers Information Bureau, New York, reported that magazine advertising pages in March fell 2.8 percent from March 1995, to 18,449. For the first three months of 1996, total ad pages fell 3.9 percent, to 47,338, from the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: BASKETBALL;Tough Times for Knicks' Offense, But Defensive Effort Saves the Day
description: Just as the Knicks were on the verge of cracking again, their defense slammed the door on the Boston Celtics.

title: In Unabom Case, Pain for Suspect's Family
description: Even as the evidence mounted, David Kaczynski clung to the hope that his older brother, Theodore, was not the Unabomber.

title: Elizabeth Dole Deftly Declines To Steal Show
description: In a North Carolina replay of Senator Bob Dole's visit to his hometown in Kansas two weeks ago, Elizabeth Hanford Dole returned to the place she grew up today for a Republican victory celebration -- a sunny and politically pointed homecoming that ended up being more about Mr. Dole than his wife.

title: Executive Changes
description: BANK OF BOSTON CORP., Boston, appointed Steven Shenfeld as managing director to head a newly formed high-yield sales, trading and research group.

title: Gruntal Agrees To Fraud Fine As U.S. Indicts Former Official
description: A former senior executive at Gruntal & Company, the brokerage firm, was indicted yesterday in the latest charges to come out of an embezzlement scandal that has already led to guilty pleas by two other former Gruntal employees.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Daimler-Benz May Join Digital TV Venture
description: Daimler-Benz Interservices A.G., a unit of Daimler-Benz A.G., confirmed it was in talks to join the digital television venture led by Deutsche Telekom and known as MMBG, and a decision is expected in a few days, Rainer Knubben, the company's spokesman, said.

title: Parents Face Consequences As Children's Misdeeds Rise
description: Frustrated by rising juvenile violence and crime, states and cities around the country are rushing to enact laws making parents responsible for the misbehavior of their children.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BIO-TECHNOLOGY GENERAL SHARES FALL ON COURT RULING
description: Shares of the Bio-Technology General Corporation fell nearly 14 percent yesterday after it said on Monday that a Federal appeals court had upheld an injunction awarded to Genentech Inc., a unit of Roche Holding, preventing Bio-Technology from selling its human growth hormone, Bio-Tropin, in the United States. The court ruled that there was some merit in Genetech's patent-infringement suit, which will now continue at Federal District Court in New York. Bio-Technology shares fell 93.75 cents, to $5.8125. The company sells Bio-Tropin in several markets overseas and the drug accounts for about 90 percent of Bio-Technology General's annual sales. The drug's American market is estimated at $300 million to $400 million a year.

title: Senate Contenders in Boston Fight to a Draw in a Debate
description: Around this time of year in Massachusetts, public attention generally turns to two beloved pastimes, baseball and political campaigns. Alas, the Red Sox began the season losing five of six games on the road, and snow on Monday canceled the team's home opener in Fenway Park.

title: Katzenberg Sues Disney, Seeking Millions in Profits
description: Jeffrey Katzenberg, the former chairman of the Walt Disney Studios, filed a lawsuit today seeking at least $250 million from Disney, contending that the entertainment giant had failed to give him his rightful share of the profits of blockbuster films like "Aladdin," "Beauty and the Beast" and "The Lion King."

title: INSIDE
description: With 100 Days to Olympics, Atlanta's Anxiety Rises

title: About Real Estate;In Virginia, Good Sign For Offices
description: Two office projects are under construction in Fairfax County, Va., the leading suburban office market in the Washington area, providing the first evidence of a return to speculative office development in the county since the real estate recession of 1989.

title: Assessing Gene Tests, Risk and Mastectomy
description: To the Editor:

title: Quayle Gets Cool Welcome in Russia
description: On his first trip to Russia, former Vice President Dan Quayle discovered that the friendship between this country and the United States is beginning to fray.

title: Pazaric Journal;In a World Gone Mad, Mental Home Offers Sanity
description: For four years, Danico Sladoje has played the straight man for a running joke at the Pazaric Social Institution, where, unlike his patients, he has braved shells, starvation and disease by choice.

title: Assistants At Michigan Walk Off Job As Talks Stall
description: More than 1,100 of the University of Michigan's 1,700 graduate students walked off their jobs as teaching assistants this week, protesting what they say has been the university's refusal to negotiate over wage increases and training pay for international students.

title: An Attack On Israel Brings Woe To Peres
description: Political pressure mounted on Prime Minister Shimon Peres today after Shiite Muslim guerrillas in Lebanon fired rockets into northern Israel for the second time in 10 days -- this time wounding at least six people.

title: George Jenkins, 88, Founder Of $9 Billion Grocery Chain
description: George W. Jenkins, founder of Publix Supermarkets, the nation's ninth-largest grocery retailing chain and one of its most innovative, died on Monday at the Lakeland Regional Medical Center, a company spokeswoman said. He was 88.

title: In Performance;JAZZ
description: Minor-Key Laments, a Tinge Of the Hebraic and No Piano John Zorn and Masada The Knitting Factory

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Michigan Suspends Griese
description: Michigan quarterback BRIAN GRIESE was suspended from the team indefinitely and appeared in court yesterday for arraignment on a felony charge stemming from a weekend incident in which he allegedly smashed a bar window. The athletic department spokesman KEITH MOLIN said the matter is being treated as alcohol related, which mandates suspension. Griese, 21, the son of the Hall of Fame quarterback BOB GRIESE, is barred from spring practices. (AP)

title: U.S. Charges Sexual Harassment At a Mitsubishi Plant in Illinois
description: Federal officials accused a Japanese-owned auto maker today of allowing sexual harassment on an "outrageous scale" at an Illinois plant.

title: On-Line Health Information Yields Vast Mountains of Gems and Junk
description: IS the drug your doctor has prescribed the best one for your condition? Do you want to know the benefits and drawbacks of each treatment option that your doctor has given you? How can you challenge your insurance company if it refuses to pay for a therapy that your doctor recommends?

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CAPITAL SAVINGS BANCORP INC., Jefferson City, Mo., said it had authorized its board to buy back as much as 5 percent of its common shares.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Modernism, Not Just Folk Rhythms, From Brazil
description: The third annual "Sonidos de las Americas," a festival of South American music this year focusing on Brazil, was struck by tragedy this weekend. Paulo Braga, a Brazilian pianist who was to participate in Monday night's chamber music program at Weill Recital Hall, rushed back to his country after members of his family were involved in a fatal car accident. Canceling or postponing the concert was impossible, given that so many visiting musicians and composers were involved. With some reshuffling of the program, Monday's concert went on as scheduled, though some of the participants seemed shaken.

title: Nails Polished Here. Surgery, Too.
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs;Slovakia Leader Vetoes Measure to Ban Rallies
description: Under pressure from the United States and the European Union, Slovakia's President vetoed legislation today that critics say would limit free speech and public assemblies.

title: Rematch for DNA in a Rape Case
description: When Kerry Kotler was released from prison in 1992 after more than 11 years of saying he was innocent of rape, he became something of a poster boy for DNA testing. Even the Suffolk County District Attorney acknowledged that DNA tests seemed to show that Mr. Kotler was not a rapist.

title: Market Place;Swiss banking, too, encounters the ethos of the bottom line.
description: THE Swiss have been celebrated and envied for their banking skills for centuries. But even they are not immune from the competitive pressures and lackluster profits that are forcing big banks almost everywhere to consolidate as a way to cut costs and increase revenue.

title: GOLF;Novices Tackle Masters' Course
description: When Michael Campbell, Masters rookie, arrived at the 12th tee at Augusta National this week for his first shot at the meanest little par-3 hole on the planet, he got a quick lesson on why it has been 17 years since a first-time Masters player has won this tournament.

title: HOCKEY;Clinging, Clawing and . . . Clinching
description: The National Hockey League regular season, which overlaps baseball at both ends, is trudging through its 27th and final week. But hockey's division and conference pennant races do not evoke the sweet tension of Yankees-Red Sox in 1978 or Dodgers-Giants in 1951.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SIMON & SCHUSTER ACQUIRES MERGENT TECHNOLOGIES
description: Simon & Schuster said yesterday that it had acquired Mergent Technologies Group, a software company in San Diego, for an undisclosed amount. Mergent will become the Invest Learning Corporation, Simon & Schuster, the publishing arm of Viacom Inc., said, and operate as a division of the company's Computer Curriculum subsidiary. Invest Learning will develop educational software for adult and teen-aged students through 1,600 learning center installations in the United States and Canada, Simon & Schuster said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Ejected Van Exel Shoves a Referee Dale Ellis scored 20 points and LaPhonso Ellis added 17 points and 13 rebounds last night to lead the Nuggets to a 98-91 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers in Denver. Los Angeles guard Nick Van Exel, after being ejected, threw a forearm that shoved Referee Ronnie Garretson onto the scorer's table.

title: Cherokee Investment Deal
description: The company founded by former Treasury Secretary William E. Simon has teamed up with the Chicago-based Cherokee Investment Security L.L.C. to buy and sell contaminated real estate. Through a new company called Cherokee Simon Environmental Realty L.L.C., Mr. Simon and Cherokee plan also to consult with financial institutions, government agencies and corporations on ways to deal with their contaminated real estate. The new company will have offices in Los Angeles, Denver, New Jersey and North Carolina.

title: Martha Stewart Is Said to Seek a Break With Time Warner
description: Martha Stewart, the doyenne of domesticity, is attempting to end her partnership with Time Warner Inc., according to several people close to both parties.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Girl Meets Ghoul, Hit By Cupid's Toxic Arrow
description: Maybe it really is dangerous to invoke the spirits of the nuclear undead. A recent preview of Dana P. Rowe and John Dempsey's "Zombie Prom," a girl-meets-ghoul musical set in the atomic 1950's, was interrupted in its first act by a persistent flapping noise from above that strangely brought to mind the helicopter in "Miss Saigon."

title: Political Scandal, Then
description: To the Editor:

title: Richard Condon, Political Novelist, Dies at 81
description: Richard Condon, the fiendishly inventive novelist and political satirist who wrote "The Manchurian Candidate," "Winter Kills" and "Prizzi's Honor," among other books, died yesterday at Presbyterian Hospital in Dallas. He was 81.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Bond Prices In Rebound
description: Treasury bond prices rebounded yesterday after a four-day decline, as investors showed stronger demand than expected at a $12 billion auction of five-year Treasury notes.

title: Response Time for Police Is Cut but Some Areas Lag
description: Although police response time to 911 emergency calls has been cut sharply in recent years, several neighborhoods on Staten Island and in Queens and Brooklyn have fallen behind the rest of the city, according to a study released yesterday.

title: 31 Students Face Charges in Protest at Yale
description: The Yale University police arrested 31 students who participated in a two-hour demonstration on Monday at the president's office to protest the university's dealings with a striking labor union.

title: I.B.M. and Apple Reported Near Licensing Agreement
description: I.B.M.'s chip-making division and Apple Computer Inc. are said to be close to concluding a licensing deal for Apple's Macintosh software operating system.

title: Preventing Portable Nukes
description: What if the bomb that killed 168 people and blasted the Federal building in Oklahoma City a year ago this month had been nuclear?

title: TV Notes;End Notes
description: The March fund-raising drive on PBS stations around the country reached the highest pledge total in public-television history, $50.2 million, a 13.2 percent increase over the previous high, in March 1995. . . . Today, C-Span will carry live coverage of the funeral of Ronald H. Brown, the Secretary of Commerce, who was killed in a plane crash in Croatia last week. Coverage begins at 7 A.M.; the funeral service in the National Cathedral is scheduled to begin at 1 P.M. L. M.

title: Lower Castes Hold the Key As India Gets Ready to Vote
description: As the setting sun spread a golden hue over the wheatfields that embrace his ancestral village, Ram Ujagar Yadav sat in a grove of eucalyptus trees and mused aloud about the votes that he and tens of millions of other poor, lower-caste Indians will cast in the general election next month.

title: Utility Is Summoned By Nuclear Agency
description: The United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission wants to know why it took Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation more than a year to replace the wrong-size bolts on panels at the Nine Mile Point 1 nuclear plant.

title: New Attack on Race-Based Admissions
description: In the aftermath of recent Federal court rulings that sharply curtailed affirmative action programs, the Attorney General of Georgia has asked the state university system to rescind all its race-based admissions and financial aid policies.

title: At the DMZ, Another Invasion: Tourists
description: The South Korean Government has declared the situation on the North Korean border to be extremely dangerous. Defense officials have held several emergency defense meetings since last Saturday and reminded the nation's soldiers to, in effect, shoot to kill any invaders.

title: Ball, Not Business, for Yanks' Opening
description: On a snowy Opening Day yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani met at Yankee Stadium with the Yankees' principal owner, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, and chatted about baseball. Then they met over dinner last night at Gracie Mansion and discussed the Yankees' future.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Sega Buying Maker Of Slot Machines
description: Sega Enterprises of Japan said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Games Network Ltd., the largest maker of slot machines in Britain, to expand its range of entertainment products in Europe. Sega did not disclose the price it paid. Games Network is a privately owned holding company based in Cardiff, Wales. It consists of JPM International Ltd., Ace Coin Equipment Ltd. and Crystal Leisure Ltd. of Britain and Negocio Internacional de Technologia S.A. of Spain. Games Network generated sales of about $64 million in the fiscal year that ended in September 1995. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Calcium Reduces Risk of Death During Pregnancy
description: Women can substantially lower their risk of high blood pressure during pregnancy and a sometimes deadly condition by adding calcium to their diet, researchers say.

title: G.O.P. Ad Takes Aim At Clinton On Tax Cut
description: Trying to mine taxpayers' misery, the Republican National Committee began assaulting President Clinton in television advertisements today for blocking a tax credit supported by the Republican-controlled Congress.

title: Victims' Kin Sue to Halt Apartheid-Era Inquiry
description: Less than a week before this country's Truth and Reconciliation Commission is to begin its work with a four-day hearing that will see more than a dozen survivors of apartheid-era atrocities tell their stories, the families of some of South Africa's most noted victims have gone to court hoping to halt the proceedings.

title: Goetz II: Race Card, Early And Often
description: The plaintiff's lawyer, the one with the long graying ponytail, addressed the largely nonwhite panel of prospective Bronx jurors yesterday with an easy familiarity. Smiling sympathetically, he asked them whether they thought there should be fewer guns on the street and if they had ever been discriminated against. More often than not, he got the answers he sought: Yes and yes.

title: COMPANY NEWS;VALUJET TO SLOW ITS GROWTH DURING U.S. REVIEW
description: Valujet Airlines plans to slow the growth of its aircraft fleet while Federal regulators review its operations, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The airline, which is based in Atlanta and markets itself as as a low-fare carrier, said it expected to add 13 or 14 aircraft this year and that it expected, subject to regulatory approval, to return to its plan of adding 18 to 24 aircraft each year thereafter. Valujet said the step was in response to increased scrutiny from the Federal Aviation Administration after a string of recent problems involving its planes. Valujet stock closed down $3.875 a share yesterday, to $22, in Nasdaq trading.

title: 3 Letters From the Suspect To Mexican Farmworker
description: Following are three letters that Juan Sanchez Arreola, a retired farmworker living in Mexico, said he received from Theodore J. Kaczynski, the suspect in the Unabom case. The letters were in Spanish and have been translated by The New York Times:

title: U.S. Expels Sudan Envoy Suspected In Bomb Plot
description: The United States announced today the expulsion of a Sudanese diplomat whom it accused of supplying inside information to Islamic terrorists who were convicted last year of plotting the destruction of the United Nations and other New York landmarks after the bombing of the World Trade Center.

title: Immunization Rate Up Sharply, U.S. Says
description: Immunization levels increased significantly in the last three years, to 75 percent of young children from 55 percent, the Clinton Administration said today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, a report in the Dance Notes column on Tuesday about the American Dance Festival at Duke University gave an incomplete E-mail address for a festival official, Rebecca Hix. Her address is rhix

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Cavs Set Back by the Magic
description: Shaquille O'Neal scored 39 points and the Orlando Magic snapped a two-game home losing streak tonight with a 116-104 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Marriott in Talks For Hotels in India
description: Marriott International Inc., the hotel management company based in Bethesda, Md., is talking to developers about opening hotels and resorts in India, a company official said yesterday. Marriott plans to set up a subsidiary to handle such operations, said Samir Daqqaq, the company's international director for sales and marketing for the Middle East, Africa and the Indian subcontinent. He would not give details of the projects, saying the company would make an announcement soon. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: THEATER REVIEW;With a Rabbit Presiding, A Rite of Spring Unfolds
description: In a potent rite of exorcism calculated to banish a never-say-die winter, religious and secular forces have been marshaled in the vast cathedral of entertainment called Radio City Music Hall.

title: Barnard Clerical Staff Renews Strike
description: Clerical workers at Barnard College began their second strike in two months yesterday over differences that both sides said were small.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Being center stage is routine for JIM LEHRER, the PBS news anchor and author of 11 books.

title: No Headline
description: It's Senor Smith goes to Washington. I mean, what greater contrast could you have against incumbency than this schoolteacher out there riding around in a pick-up truck?"

title: On Amtrak, Poetry In Motion
description: Most of the passengers riding the Amtrak Metroliner to Washington today acted like the business people they were. In one car, a woman typed on her laptop while the man across from her talked into his cellular phone. A man in another seat scribbled furiously on a yellow legal pad. Beside him, someone was reading The Wall Street Journal. And then there was Jonathan Oatis, an editor for Reuters news service, seemingly enthralled by a book of poetry.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Distribution Expert Named President of Random House
description: Random House Inc. announced the appointment yesterday of a new president, an outsider highly regarded in the publishing industry for his successful efforts to build a Tennessee company into the biggest book distributor in the nation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Didier Guerin, president of the Conde Nast Asia/Pacific unit of Conde Nast Publications, Sydney, Australia, was named to the added post of chairman of Interculture Communications Ltd., Taipai, Taiwan, which Conde Nast acquired as part of plans to start Conde Nast China and publish Chinese-language editions of GQ and Vogue magazines in Taiwan. Conde Nast is owned by Advance Publications. R. Garrett Mitchell was named West Coast president at Burson-Marsteller, Los Angeles, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., succeeding Ken Rietz, who was named chairman of the United States public affairs practice in Washington and president and chief executive for the Washington region. Mr. Mitchell had been president and chief executive at Yosemite National Institutes, San Francisco.

title: Ethel Butler, 82, Mentor of Top Dancers
description: Ethel Butler, a Martha Graham dancer in the 1930's and early 1940's and a leading teacher in Washington for three decades, died at the Washington Hospice on Tuesday . She was 82 and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: U.N. Dues Get Short Shrift in Budget Process
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Home-Court Edge Is on the Knicks' Minds
description: Their coach is a diminutive, tireless worker; his team is expected not to go very far in the post-season. Together, they badly want home-court advantage in the first round of the Eastern Conference playoffs.

title: Acxiom Stock Up on Deal
description: The shares of the Acxiom Corporation rose 7.6 percent today, a day after the company announced it had bought Pro CD Inc., a producer of reference software, for $47.25 million in stock. The shares of Acxiom, which is based in Conway, closed up 2, at $28.25.

title: Rodgers Is Back in the Race
description: He looks the same as he did when he started college 30 years ago: 5 feet 8 1/2 inches, 130 pounds (up from 128), sandy hair, boyish innocence and enthusiasm. The uniform is the same as always -- sweatshirt, chinos and running shoes. And the self-deprecation is the same, as when he describes himself as an old man "with less muscle and more body fat and a lot slower."

title: COMPANY NEWS;MCKESSON WILL BUY AUTOMATED HEALTHCARE
description: The McKesson Corporation, a drug distributor based in San Francisco, said yesterday that it would buy Automated Healthcare Inc. for about $65 million in cash. Automated Healthcare, a closely held company based in Pittsburgh, makes automated drug dispensing systems that are used in 45 hospitals. The system will be combined with information technology that McKesson is testing to create a more accurate way of dispensing drugs with adjoining inventory control systems, McKesson said.

title: Political Memo;For Giuliani, Baseball May Be a Costly Issue
description: The Mayor who likes to say "no" has whispered a tentative but unmistakable "yes" to the idea of moving Yankee Stadium to the West Side of Manhattan. And in doing so, Rudolph W. Giuliani has allowed his political opponents to feast on what may be one of the defining issues of the 1997 mayoral campaign.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Liberties;His Brother's Keeper
description: We figured that the Unabomber's manifesto would be his downfall.

title: A Pulitzer Winner's Overnight Success of 60 Years
description: A rash of crank calls had been interrupting George Walker at his music since last year, so when the telephone rang on Tuesday afternoon as this 73-year-old composer labored over an organ piece, he snatched it up expecting to hear the maddeningly familiar click of a hangup. Instead, a friendly voice informed him that he had just won the 1996 Pulitzer Prize for music.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;No Action on Hokie Players
description: A grand jury in Blacksburg, Va., decided yesterday there was insufficient evidence to indict two Virginia Tech football players accused by a woman of raping her. The players, ANTONIO MORRISON and JAMES CRAWFORD, remain defendants in a civil lawsuit filed in United States District Court in Roanoke by CHRISTY BRZONKALA. (AP)

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Walsh Leaves Bears To Join Rams
description: STEVE WALSH, who didn't throw a pass for the Chicago Bears last year after carrying them to the playoffs in 1994, will get a chance to become a starter again -- for the St. Louis Rams.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EXECUTONE TO SELL TELEPHONE SALES AND SERVICES UNIT
description: Executone Information Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to sell most of its telephone sales and services unit, including its long-distance reseller business, to Bain Capital Inc. for $66.5 million. Bain, a Boston-based investment firm, will pay $61.5 million in cash and $5 million in notes to Executone, which will retain an 8 percent stake in the unit. The direct sales and services unit, which had sales of $190 million in 1995, will become an independent subsidiary of Bain's acquisition group. Bain said it expected to retain the unit's 1,600 employees. Executone, which is based in Milford, Conn., makes telecommunications equipment for the health care industry and correctional facilities.

title: Europe Isn't Abusing Britain in Mad Cow Affair
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;As on-line stock trading heats up, can bigger and better campaigns for cyberfirms be far behind?
description: PC FINANCIAL NETWORK, one of the pioneering on-line discount brokers, is counting on a humorous ad campaign to increase its share of the hotly competitive electronic investment market.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WANG WILL BUY BELLSOUTH'S DATASERV SUBSIDIARY
description: Wang Laboratories Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the BellSouth Corporation's Dataserv unit -- which provides computer services and develops imaging, document management and network storage software -- for about $30 million. The sale is part of an effort by BellSouth to shed businesses outside of telecommunications in the wake of new legislation that increases competition in the industry.

title: COMPANY NEWS;RITE AID TO END EXTENSION FOR REVCO ACQUISITION
description: The Rite Aid Corporation notified the Federal Trade Commission yesterday that it was ending the rolling 10-day extension of the regulatory waiting period for its planned acquisition of Revco D.S. Inc. The move means that the F.T.C. has 10 days to come to an agreement with Rite-Aid. At that point, the company could proceed with the purchase unless the F.T.C. went to court to stop it. Rite Aid said it was negotiating with the F.T.C. in hopes of reaching an agreement before the waiting period, which is required by the Hart-Scott-Rodino antitrust law, ends on April 19. On that day, Rite Aid's $1.8 billion tender offer for Revco is set to expire. The tender offer has already been extended several times. Revco is based in Twinsburg, Ohio, and Rite Aid is based in Camp Hill, Pa. Both are drugstore chains.

title: Eonomic Scene;No growth, no inflation is fine for bonds but how about people?
description: A CHILLING rise in interest rates has grabbed the financial headlines in recent weeks. But for many Americans who are not shopping for a mortgage or speculating on the price of the 30-year Treasury bond, what matters are the bread and butter issues: economic growth, jobs, consumer prices. And by those criteria, the auguries still look pretty good.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers Fall to the Capitals in Possible Playoff Preview
description: With two games remaining before the Stanley Cup playoffs, the Rangers are reeling. They lost their third consecutive game last night when the Washington Capitals prevailed by 4-1 at Madison Square Garden, and they lost another key player to injury.

title: Giuliani Opens Unit at Bellevue Despite Hospitals' Hazy Future
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani dedicated a new emergency department at Bellevue Hospital Center yesterday in what may well be one of the last major expansions of the public hospital system.

title: China Awards Huge Jet Order To Europeans
description: China's Prime Minister, Li Peng, began a visit to France today by placing an order for an estimated $1.5 billion worth of European-built passenger planes, sending a signal to the Clinton Administration that Beijing can turn to European partners if the United States becomes too intractable on human rights and trade.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's;Building A Low-Cost Collection
description: Classical music is a contingent art: it requires a degree of experience, some prior knowledge, at least casual acquaintance, a little explaining. But the price of experience runs high. Concert tickets become ever more forbiddingly expensive; music education is increasingly confined to the private schools; the audience grows less diverse. Classical music cannot shake its debilitating reputation as rich people's music.

title: F.T.C. Bars Lorillard's Bid for B.A.T. Cigarettes
description: The Federal Trade Commission rejected yesterday the proposed sale of six discount brands of cigarettes by B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. to the Lorillard Tobacco Company, a holding of the Loews Corporation.

title: S.E.C. Proposes Relaxing Rules on Trading
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed relaxing restrictions on trading in stocks and bonds before companies make new issues of the securities available to the public.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Orthodox observance of Holy Thursday and Good Friday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Rev. Edward J. McCarthy, 84, Ex-President of 3 Colleges, Dies
description: The Rev. Edward James McCarthy, an Augustinian friar who was president of three colleges and was briefly held in a Cuban lockup during five decades in higher education, died on Monday at St. Thomas Monastery, a residence on the campus of Villanova University in Villanova, Pa. He was 84 and until last month resided at the Augustinian Monastery at St. Thomas University in Miami.

title: Autodesk Broadens Its Product Line
description: With a flurry of new products and a new stock-ticker symbol, Autodesk Inc. announced plans yesterday to broaden its business with Internet and animation software.

title: A Failing Indicator?
description: On Tuesday, the semiconductor industry's key leading indicator hit its lowest level in the nine-year history of the index. Today, most semiconductor stocks moved up in heavy trading. What gives?

title: Wolfensohn to Ask Donor Countries to Pledge $1.2 Billion : World Bank Will Call For Bosnia Jobs Plan
description: PARIS  The president of the World Bank said Wednesday that he would call for an enormous job creation program to employ former combatants in Bosnia when government officials meet in Brussels this weekend to try to raise $1.2 billion of reconstruction aid

title: Executive Changes
description: CONTINENTAL GRAIN CO., New York, named Michael J. Zimmerman, a senior investment banker at Salomon Brothers Inc., as senior vice president for investments and strategy.

title: Making TV and Internet Safe for Children
description: LIFE'S unpleasantnesses have a nasty way of appearing unexpectedly on television screens or computer monitors. And children have a way of being there when they do.

title: Corrections
description: The main article last Thursday about the plane crash that killed Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and 34 others in Croatia misstated the number of fatal accidents that have involved Boeing 737 aircraft. It is more than 40 worldwide, not 8. (Seven were in the United States.)

title: Reflections and Solace in a Reporter's Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Albany Must Keep Aid for Doctor Training
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of the Times;Orioles: Baubles Or Gems?
description: RANDY MYERS fussed with a fatigue hat and jacket while standing at his locker. He sighed when asked how his 1996 season was progressing.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TV SPORTS;ABC's Swanson Retires
description: DENNIS SWANSON, who succeeded ROONE ARLEDGE as the president of ABC Sports in 1986, retired yesterday, effective May 4. As part of a restructuring, ABC Sports will now report to STEVE BORNSTEIN, the president of ESPN. The restructuring has been expected since last summer when the Walt Disney Company acquired Capital Cities/ABC, which owns 80 percent of ESPN.

title: Menendez Case Nears End
description: The prosecution and defense rested today in the penalty phase of Erik and Lyle Menendez's murder trial. The jury, which will choose whether to recommend that the brothers be put to death or spend their lives in prison for murdering their parents, Jose and Kitty Menendez, is expected to hear closing arguments on Thursday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;JAMES RIVER TO SELL PACKAGING UNIT FOR $365 MILLION
description: The James River Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its plastics-packaging unit to Printpack Inc., a closely held company based in Atlanta, for $365 million. James River, which is based in Richmond, and makes Quilted Northern bathroom tissue, Brawny paper towels and Dixie cups, put the flexible-packaging division up for sale in December to concentrate on its paper businesses. The company expects to record a gain of 25 cents a share when the transaction is complete, probably at midyear. Proceeds will go toward reducing James River's debt. The flexible-packaging group had 1995 sales of $490 million. It has 2,300 employees and 10 manufacturing plants. James River announced the agreement after the close of stock trading.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Israel Counterattacks Guerrillas in Lebanon
description: Israeli helicopters fired rockets today at two Lebanese Army checkpoints in this port city after Israeli jets launched two raids in eastern and southern Lebanon, security sources said.

title: An Alert From the Chief Justice
description: Chief Justice William Rehnquist was defending one of the nation's fundamental strengths when he stressed the importance of judicial independence in his speech this week at the American University law school. This is a subject close to Justice Rehnquist's heart. He has spoken frequently about the issue over the years and, in 1992, even wrote a book on the subject.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;After 5 Years of False Starts, Japan's Economy Is Stirring
description: This winter has lasted five years in Japan, but there is finally talk of an economic spring.

title: 211 Bosnians Free After 8 Months. Why So Long?
description: The smile did not leave her face, but her eyes began to fill with tears as she led her husband down the path to the house where his two young children awaited him.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Sleuths With a Specialty: Spouses Who Stray
description: Dee Tate is a housewife, married 18 years, with two children and a loving barrister husband. Elly Chandler is recently divorced from Dee's brother after a private detective got the goods on his philandering. Elly is in an emotional funk; Dee is a bit bored, what with the kids getting older and everything. What to do? Courtesy of the writer Paula Milne ("The Politician's Wife"), the two fictional women open "Chandler & Company," a detective agency that has a four-week run on PBS's "Mystery" series, beginning tonight.

title: Dow Falls for 4th Session, Declining by 74.43 Points
description: Blue-chip stocks fell yesterday for the fourth consecutive session, hurt by a rise in interest rates driven by concerns about inflation.

title: Bishop's Panel Criticizes Book by Liberal Catholic Theologian
description: A widely used book written by one of the most outspoken liberal Roman Catholic theologians in the United States has come under fire from a committee of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops.

title: 23 Arrested in Columbia Sit-in on Ethnic Issue
description: Twenty-three protesters seeking the creation of an ethnic studies department at Columbia University were arrested yesterday morning after an all-night occupation of Low Library, the university's central administration building.

title: Dole Rejects Rehnquist Criticism on Judges
description: Bob Dole tonight took issue with Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist's upbraiding of politicians for meddling in decisions by Federal judges.

title: Healing Quebec
description: Quebec voted last October by the thinnest of margins to remain a part of Canada. But the emotional campaign and close result left Canada's second-most-populous province bitterly polarized. Six months later a new Quebec Premier, Lucien Bouchard, is trying to heal the divisions. Though a committed separatist, Mr. Bouchard has made reconciliation and recovery his primary concerns. This shift is a welcome development, for Quebec, for Canada and for the United States.

title: DANCE REVIEW;An Eager Collaborator Unwraps New Spectacles
description: With his shaved head and fondness for collaborating with fashionable artists in other media, Stephen Petronio is very much a man of the moment, the bad boy of downtown modern dance. But the program presented by the Stephen Petronio Company on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater called to mind those Christmas table favors with giddy, gaudy outer wrappings and a small explosive pop inside.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Disney Talking To McDonald's About Alliance For Promotions
description: The Walt Disney Company and the McDonald's Corporation, two of the defining forces in American culture, are negotiating exclusive arrangements to cross-promote their products well into the next century, a Disney executive said today.

title: Georgia Tech Lands Another New Yorker
description: Following the path of two of New York City's finest point guards -- Kenny Anderson and Stephon Marbury -- Kevin Morris, a 5-foot-11-inch senior from Martin Luther King High School in Manhattan, announced yesterday that he will attend Georgia Tech next season.

title: Mental Inmate Is Not Liable In a Homicide
description: In a case that focused attention on security weaknesses at psychiatric centers in New York State, a Manhattan jury yesterday found an escaped mental patient not criminally responsible for pushing a woman to her death underneath a subway train last year.

title: A Bridge in Germany Becomes a Post-Cold-War Battleground
description: For there to have been a cold war, there had to be a Glienecke Bridge. It spanned the chasm between two hostile worlds, becoming the backdrop for dramatic spy exchanges in real life and in countless espionage novels.

title: THE AD CAMPAIGN;The Republican National Committee Takes On the President
description: This is a version of a new 30-second television commercial being broadcast in 22 states by the Republican National Committee.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Japan Budget Accord Is Seen
description: The Finance Minister of Japan, Wataru Kubo, said today that the ruling coalition and the main opposition party had an agreement on a budget for the current fiscal year; the budget will include the use of public funds to liquidate seven defunct housing mortgage companies.

title: Princeton and Harvard Are to Return Money
description: Princeton and Harvard Universities have agreed to return money they received from a tax-exempt charitable organization that declared bankruptcy after using money from nonprofit groups for what was called a Ponzi scheme, according to documents filed here today in the Federal Bankruptcy Court.

title: Judge Won't Give Reporters Access to Papers on Suspect
description: A Federal judge has denied a petition by The New York Times and other news organizations to unseal documents that F.B.I. investigators submitted to gain a search warrant for the mountain cabin that the Unabom suspect, Theodore J. Kaczynski, called home.

title: HOCKEY;Listless Devils Now Look Up at Last Playoff Spot
description: Just 10 months after they were sitting atop the National Hockey League, skating in the spotlight with their first Stanley Cup, the Devils are on the outside looking in.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: CHRONICLE
description: When PHILIP JOHNSON, the architect, was first approached about posing for the cover of Out, a monthly gay and lesbian magazine, he had some trepidation.

title: Missouri Man Is Put to Death For '80 Killing
description: An inmate was executed by injection today for killing a man in 1980 to stop him from testifying about the theft of blank prescription pads from a doctor's office.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Tax Preparer Admits Guilt
description: A Paterson tax preparer pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court to filing a fraudulent return that overstated his client's deductions by $15,727. But Kevin McKeon, an Internal Revenue Service spokesman, said, "It's the taxpayer who is liable for the penalties on a false return."

title: U.N. Dues Get Short Shrift in Budget Process
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Honors
description: Alex Stanton, president and chief executive of Stanton & Co., New York, was elected president of the New York chapter of the Public Relations Society of America, succeeding David M. Grant, president of LVM Group, New York.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;School Detectors Find Knives
description: Metal detectors were used for the first time yesterday at a school that enrolls about 900 sixth, seventh and eighth graders. About 10 razor blades and knives were confiscated at the violence-plagued East Camden Middle School, The Associated Press reported. DAVID STOUT

title: F.D.A. Says Use of 'Legal Highs' Is Hazardous
description: The Federal Government has issued a warning to Americans not to buy any of the Chinese herbal products being sold as "legal highs," because they can cause heart attacks, seizures, psychotic episodes or even death.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Cliff Freeman Wins 10 Awards
description: Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York took top honors last night, winning the most awards, at the 1996 Best of New York American Advertising Awards ceremony sponsored by the Advertising Women of New York.

title: Rug Colors That Amaze
description: WHENEVER James Tufenkian, the owner of Tufenkian Tibetan Carpets, a rug manufacturer in Manhattan, looked at design magazines, he was dismayed. "There was nothing on the floors except wood or sisal rugs," he said with slight exaggeration.

title: Early Report on Cell Phone Users Finds No Rise in Death Rates
description: Early studies of the potential health effects of portable cellular telephones show no evidence of an increase in death rates among users, researchers said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ETHYL TO PAY $4.75 MILLION TO SETTLE U.S. CHARGES
description: The Ethyl Corporation and a subsidiary agreed yesterday to pay the United States Government $4.75 million to settle charges that they sold petroleum additives below standards for use in military vehicles. The agreement settles a suit filed in Federal District Court in St. Louis on March 20, 1994, against the two corporate entities by Charles Duchek, a former employee of the subsidiary. He filed under the so-called whistle-blower provision of the False Claims Act, which allows a private individual to sue on behalf of the Government and receive up to 25 percent of any settlement if the Government takes over the case and prosecutes it successfully.

title: U.N. Dues Get Short Shrift in Budget Process
description: To the Editor:

title: European Topics : Even in Unisex Sweden, The War Goes On
description: Equality of the sexes has probably sunk deeper into the Swedish psyche than anywhere else, except perhaps some neighboring Scandinavian countries. But there are still battles to be fought.

title: COMPANY NEWS;VIACOM AND MEDIASET BREAK OFF NEGOTIATIONS
description: Mediaset S.p.A., an Italian broadcaster, said yesterday that negotiations to sell a stake of about 5 percent to Viacom Inc. had broken off. Mediaset's president, Fedele Confalonieri, said last week that the two companies were in talks that could have led to the sale of a stake in the broadcaster to Viacom. Mediaset, which is controlled by former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy, is preparing to sell as much as 2 trillion lire ($1.2 billion) of stock in an initial public offering in June.

title: Mysterious Deaths of Endangered Manatees Are Rising Sharply
description: Less than a month after marine biologists reported finding dozens of dead manetees in Florida's coastal waters, the incidence of deaths has increased sharply and scientists do not understand why.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Wheat Prices Make Steep Climb On Weather and Supply Fears
description: Wheat prices jumped by the daily limit on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday as forecasts for more dry weather caused increased concerns about supply.

title: Excerpts From Clinton's Veto Statement
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's message to the House regarding his veto of a bill outlawing a certain type of abortion procedure:

title: A Chance to Choose In Buying Electricity
description: In a move that mirrors changes in the phone industry, Orange and Rockland Utilities wants to let some of its customers pick their own electric power supplier.

title: Detective Is Slashed as He Stops a Fight
description: A police detective was slashed across the face with a box cutter yesterday while he and his partner were trying to break up a dispute among three men in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Conviction on Clerk's Murder
description: A Superior Court jury has convicted a Paterson man in the stabbing and beating of Tito Merino, 22, a Peruvian who was sent by his mother to relatives in Paterson after his father was killed by the Shining Path guerrilla movement.

title: BASEBALL;A Rookie's Nightmare Comes True for Wilson
description: Since spring training began in mid-February, Paul Wilson has oozed poise and confidence. He has carried himself more like a veteran than a pitcher entering his first year in the big leagues. The National League seemed to be his for the taking.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Du Pont and BASF To Build Asian Plant
description: The Du Pont Company and BASF A.G. said yesterday that they had agreed to form a joint venture to build a $750 million plant, most likely in China, to make nylon ingredients for the Asian market. The companies will each own half of the venture. China is a "leading candidate" for the plant but "sites in other locations in Asia are also being considered," Du Pont said.

title: Male Professors Keep 30% Lead In Pay Over Women, Study Says
description: The salary gap between female and male university professors remained constant last year, with men receiving about 30 percent more than women, said a study released yesterday by the American Association of University Professors.

title: A Lawsuit in Japan Seeks to Ban Noisy Night Flights at U.S. Base
description: More than 3,100 Japanese who live near an American air base filed a lawsuit today against the Japanese and American Governments, demanding a ban on night flights and $30 million in damages.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Banco Santander of Spain Completing Chile Bank Bid
description: Officials of Banco Santander S.A. of Spain were completing plans late last night to acquire Banco Osorno y La Union of Chile in a deal valued at about $400 million, according to a person involved in the talks.

title: Bridge
description: Playing bridge by computer, with three other players geographically scattered, is somewhat unsociable, but it has several advantages. It is economical, you can pick a convenient time and you can arrange a game with players of comparable skill.

title: GOLF: MASTERS;At Augusta, an Early Test of Nerves
description: There are more scenic starting holes. There are more difficult ones, fraught with more peril. For sheer antiquity, there is the first hole at the Old Course at St. Andrews, with the ancient R&A clubhouse standing sentinel behind the tee that leads to a fairway wide enough to accommodate a 747.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Doctor Accused of Groping
description: A 68-year-old osteopath from Mount Laurel accused of groping his female patients was indicted by a Burlington County grand jury on 10 charges of criminal sexual contact, prosecutors announced yesterday.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Home-Repair Scam Charged
description: A Haledon man was indicted by a Morris County grand jury on Tuesday on charges of stealing more than $75,000 for home-repair jobs he never did. Twenty-four people, mostly elderly women, testified they gave down payments of a few hundred to several thousand dollars to Nader Emusov, 38, of Haledon, who promised to make home improvements but failed to return, said Cissy M. Rebich, an assistant prosecutor.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Expels Sudanese Envoy

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Svedala of Sweden Makes Finnish Bid
description: Svedala A.B., a Swedish producer of heavy machinery, offered yesterday to buy Tampella Oy, a Finnish maker of metal and forestry goods, in a stock swap worth 1.8 billion kronor ($269 million). Kvaerner A.S., the largest shipbuilder in Europe, is the largest shareholder in Tampella. Neither Tampella nor Kvaerner took a position on the bid yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Health page yesterday about information available on the Internet misstated the medical condition of Stanley Diamond, a Montreal man who has used on-line news groups to find distant relatives who may carry a gene for beta thalassemia, a blood disorder. He carries a gene for the disease, but does not have the disease itself.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Student Jailed After Ruse
description: In 1988, Alexi Indris-Santana was welcomed at Princeton University. The university was so impressed by how he had overcome an impoverished childhood and scored 1,410 out of a possible 1,600 on his Scholastic Assessment Test that he was granted a $22,000 financial-aid package.

title: Washburn Shot in Foot
description: Chris Washburn, the No. 1 draft pick of the Golden State Warriors in 1986 who was later kicked out of the National Basketball Association for substance abuse, has been shot in the foot. The shooting occurred in a part of Hickory known for drug activity, and Washburn was not seriously injured, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 9 about the new president of Planned Parenthood omitted part of the debate over the Federal Government's main program for financing family planning services, known as Title X. Title X money cannot be used for abortions, and supporters of the program say the money must be separately accounted for and does not subsidize abortions even indirectly. But opponents of the program say that any money given to Planned Parenthood, whose clinics offer abortions, indirectly promotes abortion.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Bankruptcy Filings Upheld For Members of TLC Trio
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge today upheld the bankruptcy filings of three members of TLC, one of the most popular rhythm-and-blues groups in the record industry, whose chart-topping albums have generated more than $100 million in sales for Arista's LaFace record label.

title: Running on Dare, Teacher Wins Senate Primary
description: He is a $36,000-a-year civics teacher at Poteet High School in a suburb of Dallas, running for the United States Senate on a dare from his students. With no staff and almost no money, he campaigns by driving his pickup truck around Texas -- 62,000 miles so far -- talking to voters at gas stations and coffee shops. He calls reporters collect.

title: U.S. Sees Higher Gasoline Demand, and Prices
description: The demand for gasoline, already soaring, is expected to set records this summer, sending prices higher, a Government agency predicted yesterday.

title: Mutual Funds Still Receiving Big Cash Flow
description: While stock and bond markets continued to suffer a rough patch yesterday, evidence mounted that investors were not losing their appetites for stock and bond mutual funds. Far from it: A mutual fund trade group estimated that investors poured more cash into stock and bond funds in the first quarter of 1996 than in the first nine months of last year.

title: Is America Any Place For a Nice Hispanic Girl?
description: FELISA VALETA remembers blowing out the candles on her 13th-birthday cake with the wish, "Please, God, let me remain a virgin until I get married."

title: SOCCER;MetroStars Still Building
description: Roberto Donadoni and Tab Ramos are the top two players for the MetroStars, but they won't be in the lineup Saturday night when the team opens its Major League Soccer season in Los Angeles against the Galaxy.

title: Focus Is Jobs At Expo for 50-Plus Set
description: IN this era of downsizing, what do people 50 and older want most?

title: GOLF;Woods Wows a Pair of Golf Legends
description: The past and the future of the Masters walked the fairways together today. The future walked way out in front.

title: Hawaii Decision on Gay Marriages Should Affect Only Hawaii
description: To the Editor:

title: AT HOME WITH: Christopher Reeve;Will the Insurers Feel His Sting?
description: IN the home gym that was once a two-car garage but is now carpeted and freshly painted, there is a cushioned board known as a tilt table. A quadriplegic can be strapped onto it and swiveled upright to about 75 degrees, to reacquaint his feet with the weight of his dead limbs. "If you don't keep working on your body, muscles atrophy," the man who had the gym built said.

title: Florida Farm a Labor Battleground
description: Daniel Martinez figured he would join the lunchtime demonstration for higher wages and better working conditions, and be back on the job within the hour. Instead, his employer dismissed him and had him arrested for trespassing.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Venezuela to Lift Currency Controls
description: President Rafael Caldera of Venezuela will announce the lifting of all foreign-exchange controls during a national address scheduled for Monday evening, Government officials said yesterday. The Government will adopt a unified exchange rate to be set by the market, said Teodoro Petkoff, Venezuela's Planning Minister. The rate is expected to be between the fixed rate of 290 bolivars to the dollar and the market rate of 470. "It will probably be nearer the latter," Mr. Petkoff said.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Paralyzed Player Goes Home
description: TRAVIS ROY, the paralyzed Boston University hockey player, came home to New England yesterday after two months of rehabilitation for the spinal cord injury he suffered seconds into his first college hockey game.

title: BOXING;The Police Investigate Complaint On Tyson
description: The Chicago Police Department confirmed today that it was investigating a complaint of sexual assault involving Mike Tyson, the heavyweight boxing champion, but a spokesman said no charges had been filed.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: PRESIDENT VETOES MEASURE BANNING TYPE OF ABORTION
description: Aligning himself firmly with abortion-rights advocates in an election year, President Clinton today vetoed a bill that would have outlawed a certain type of late-term abortion, saying the women who need the procedure to safeguard their own health "should not become pawns in a larger debate."

title: COMPANY NEWS;BELL ATLANTIC TO OFFER INTERNET ACCESS
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation jumped on the Internet bandwagon yesterday, saying it would offer access to the global computer network next month. The Baby Bell, which is based in Philadelphia, signed a licensing agreement with the Netscape Communications Corporation for Internet browsing software. It also said it planned to offer a version of the Microsoft Corporation's on-line service, Microsoft Network. Bell Atlantic joins the AT&T Corporation, the MCI Communications Corporation and the Nynex Corporation in establishing an Internet strategy. Bell Atlantic shares rose $1.25 each, to $61.25. Netscape gained $3.25, to $52.50.

title: U.N. Dues Get Short Shrift in Budget Process
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;$20 Million Yankee Pitcher Will Throw in the Minors
description: The twists and turns that have marked Kenny Rogers's brief career track with the Yankees veered back toward Florida yesterday when the $20 million pitcher asked to be sent to extended spring training in order to start two minor league games and strengthen his arm before his Yankee starting debut, which is scheduled for April 23.

title: Warnaco Chief: $10 Million Pay
description: Linda Wachner, the top executive of the Warnaco Group, the apparel maker, was paid about $10 million last year in cash and stock. And she was given stock options that could be worth an additional $10.3 million, assuming the stock appreciates 5 percent annually over the next nine years, the company said yesterday.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;New Pieces Of the Past For 2 Held In Bombing
description: Why did they do it, if they did it? Hints have been emerging since the arrests of Timothy James McVeigh and Terry Lynn Nichols in the bomb explosion that destroyed the Federal Building in Oklahoma City. Now, with the approach of the first anniversary of the worst mass murder in American history, ABC News adds new details from interviews with the accused men's family members and buddies to draw the fullest profiles that television has yet offered.

title: Utility Proposes Choice of Power Supplier
description: The public utility here wants to let its customers pick their own electric power supplier, just as many already do with their long-distance telephone service.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Publicity Stuns Woman in Washington Hts. Drug Case
description: Moments after Judge Harold Baer Jr. reversed his politically unpopular decision last week to suppress drug evidence, Carol Bayless, the person with the most to lose from that decision, remembers thinking, "It's the President's fault."

title: Wild Pitch
description: Even at a time when major league sports have become a cartoon of financial excess, the proposed new home for the Yankees is breathtaking in its audacity. Excluding land value, a multipurpose mausoleum on Manhattan's West Side would cost a billion dollars.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: China Gives Airbus Order, In a Slap at Washington China placed a $1.5 billion order for passenger planes from Airbus Industrie, sending a warning signal to Washington that it can turn to Europe if the United States becomes intractable on human rights and trade. The Chinese ordered 10 short-haul A320 planes from the four-country European consortium, and may buy another 20.

title: Strategist for Bush Joins Dole Camp
description: Mary Matalin, political director of President George Bush's re-election campaign in 1992, is taking a senior role with Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign.

title: Leave the Smoking Ban Alone
description: A year ago this week, the New York City Council passed legislation that banned smoking in most public places in the city. New Yorkers seem happy with the results, and despite predictions of doom, the restaurant industry and tourism business have been thriving.

title: The Korea Divide
description: North Korea's dangerous posturing in the demilitarized zone has dramatized the need to replace the 1953 armistice, which has kept a shaky peace between the two Koreas, with a new system that reflects post-cold-war realignments.

title: Why Trash LP's?
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Finds Smaller Pay Gap For Male and Female Doctors
description: The pay gap between male and female physicians is closing, a study has found.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Troubled-Hospital Hearings
description: A State Senate task force will hold the last of three hearings here Wednesday on problems at Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital, where in recent months a patient committed suicide while staff members slept and four male employees were arrested on charges of sexually assaulting female patients.

title: Closer Watch of Paramilitary Groups Is Urged
description: A leading civil rights figure, Morris Dees, whose organization has spent decades tracking white supremacist and paramilitary groups, has urged Attorney General Janet Reno to establish a joint Federal and state task force to reduce the threat of domestic terrorism.

title: HOCKEY;Messier Iffy on Playoff Status
description: Mark Messier, the Ranger captain with the injured ribs, might not be ready to play when the Rangers open the Stanley Cup playoffs next Tuesday or Wednesday night.

title: Productivity In 1995 Was Best in 3 Years
description: Productivity in the American workplace had its best showing in three years last year but was faltering as the year ended.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day last Thursday, showing March vehicle sales in the United States, misstated the market shares of six auto makers in the car category. General Motors had 30.9 percent of the market; Ford Motor, 20.3 percent; Chrysler, 10.3 percent; Toyota, 10.4 percent; Honda, 10.5 percent, and Nissan Motor, 6.8 percent.

title: Lows Creek Journal;Eureka, Hardly, but for Africans, Specks of Hope
description: Outside their mine, the men had been chatting as they ate a lunch of cornmeal porridge cooked on a nearby fire. But now it was time to examine the morning's samples, and there was total silence.

title: Essay;Oversight Evader
description: For two months, whenever I pressed Muhamed Sacirbey, Bosnia's U.N. delegate, about the presence of Iranian troops in his country, he ducked the question. Finally he said, "You know more about where the Iranians are than we do."

title: With Tears and Remembrances, Ron Brown Is Laid to Rest
description: With his voice breaking and some in his Cabinet dabbing away tears, President Clinton today led the country in a farewell to Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, eulogizing him as "a trailblazer, a builder, a patriot."

title: Americans Fleeing Liberia Tell of New Horrors There
description: Scores of Americans and others fleeing intense fighting by rival militias in Liberia were evacuated today by United States troops and brought to Sierra Leone's main airport here on the first leg of their escape.

title: Need to Cut Costs? Order Out;Outsourcing Saves Money, but Labor Is Frustrated
description: The anti-lock brake systems look out of place as they slide by almost silently on conveyor belts at the ITT Industries factory here. From the spotless white floors to the cool, filtered air to the young workers in white hair nets and white plastic laboratory coats, the factory seems more suited to the production of computer components than auto parts.

title: Ruling: Pacts Are 'Purely Local'
description: Following are excerpts from a decision yesterday by Justice Marylin G. Diamond of State Supreme Court in Manhattan that struck down a law that gave the State Public Employees Relations Board, or PERB, the power to settle contract disputes with the New York City police union:

title: That Upside-Down High Will Be Only a Memory;Monkey Bars Fall to Safety Pressures
description: Monkey bars were once as much a part of New York City playgrounds as water sprinklers, shade trees and bubble gum, and several generations treasure the dizzy memory of hanging upside down from an upper bar. But now they are disappearing.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Disappearing Tulips

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Coca-Cola USA Picks 2 Agencies
description: The Coca-Cola USA division of the Coca-Cola Company has named Highway One Communications in San Francisco, an affiliate of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, and Block & Nardizzi in Stamford, Conn. to handle a variety of promotional marketing campaigns. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Japanese Stocks Ease
description: Japanese stock prices, interrupting recent strength, ebbed this morning. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 34.67 points, or one-sixth of 1 percent, to stand at 21,757.03. On Wednesday, the Nikkei rose rose 47.53 points, or two-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Tsongas Set For Repetition Of Transplant
description: Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts entered a Boston hospital yesterday to undergo a bone marrow transplant for a complication of the cancer therapy he received 10 years ago, the hospital said.

title: The Pop Life
description: Rumors and Responses

title: New Fee Plan for Woodhull Hospital Doctors
description: New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation has signed a new type of agreement with the doctors who work at Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center, one that demands more cost-effective treatment and pays them only for the work they actually perform.

title: An Italian Ex-Premier Tests the Quality of Voters' Mercy
description: Ciriaco De Mita occupies a curious place in recent Italian history.

title: The Hokey Pokey Man Is Dead at 83
description: Larry LaPrise, a singer who wrote the novelty song-and-dance number "The Hokey Pokey" for the apres-ski crowd at an Idaho resort, unwittingly creating a classic for nursery schools and roller-skating rinks, died last Thursday at a Boise hospital.

title: Republican Convert in House Is Ousted in Texas Runoff
description: Despite help from Republican heavyweights like former President George Bush and Speaker Newt Gingrich, a prized convert to the Republican Party has become the first Congressman to be swept from office this year.

title: Boston Chicken Is Purchasing Franchisee
description: Boston Chicken Inc. said today that it would acquire a 93 percent interest in Mid-Atlantic Restaurant Systems L.P., one of its franchisees, in a deal valued at about $79 million.

title: Market Place;Generic drug makers cope with a shift in ingredient supply.
