description: IN 1992, big brand-name drug makers won a victory in Europe over generic drug makers that is just beginning to be felt. A ban was imposed by the European Union on shipments of active ingredients used in drugs on which the patents were about to expire. In a double whammy for generic drug makers, the ban compounded the pharmaceutical industry's earlier success in getting patents extended for years under the GATT trade agreement.

title: A Principled Veto
description: President Clinton's veto yesterday of a bill banning a late-term abortion method not only preserves a woman's constitutional right to use the procedure but protects doctors who perform it from severe criminal penalties, including imprisonment. It also points up the differences in position between Mr. Clinton and Senator Bob Dole.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: South Korean Election: The Issue Is Corruption
description: Being arrested and convicted for taking bribes normally is not healthy for one's political career.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MUSICLAND POSTPONES PUBLIC OFFERING FOR UNIT
description: The Musicland Stores Corporation postponed the planned initial public offering of its Suncoast Motion Picture Company unit yesterday and said it would take a $35 million pretax restructuring charge in the first quarter. Musicland, the nation's largest seller of prerecorded music and videos, also said its banks had agreed to provide more financial flexibility in return for an increase of half a percentage point in the interest rate on its debt. The company said it had decided to put off selling a 30 percent stake in Suncoast because it believed that the unit was worth more than the market wanted to pay. Musicland, which is based in Minneapolis, had said in January that it hoped to sell 3 million of Suncoast's 10 million shares to the public at about $15 a share.

title: War-Crossed Lovers Buried in Sarajevo
description: The couple whose love and death came to symbolize Sarajevo's agony to many people came home in coffins and were buried together here today.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Scots Raze School Gym Where Children Died
description: Workers began today to tear down the Dunblane primary school gym, where a lone gunman killed 16 children, their teacher and himself.

title: HORSE RACING;Unbridled's Song Is No. 1 and Improving
description: Jim Ryerson stood outside Barn 9 at Aqueduct Race Track yesterday morning and considered the good news: He was the trainer of Unbridled's Song, the favorite for the Wood Memorial on Saturday and for the Kentucky Derby three weeks later, and here was the final prep race coming up in his home port, New York, once more the important route to the Derby.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Europe Refuses to Lift Ban on British Beef
description: European Union veterinary experts today turned down Britain's request to relax an export ban on British beef imposed in response to a report that mad cow disease may be transmitted to humans.

title: Bomb Suspect Wrote of Rage At Government
description: Barely two years ago, Theodore J. Kaczynski, the man suspected of being the Unabomber, raged against government officials, portraying them as "either stupid and incompetent, or liars who twist the law to commit any injustice."

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Wilkins Is a Stranger In a Strange Game
description: It's not easy to explain, and back home they would never believe it, but the game Dominique Wilkins plays Thursday night for a Greek club might represent his highest professional achievement. And never mind that he is the eighth-highest scorer in National Basketball Association history.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: THERMO ELECTRON CORP., Waltham, Mass., a maker of health and environmental monitoring products, plans to acquire Sensormedics Corp., a privately held medical equipment manufacturer based in Yorba Linda, Calif. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Metro Matters;Abuse Victims Who Refuse To Be Helped
description: THE public generally hears about domestic violence cases when government fails. That was the case in February, when a Brooklyn woman was killed by her boyfriend soon after his release from jail. But in more than half of the cases that get to court, battered women refuse to cooperate, and the case collapses. This is the story of one reluctant witness.

title: Lee A. Ault, 80, An Art Publisher, Dealer and Collector
description: Lee A. Ault, an art collector and former art dealer and publisher, died on Sunday at his home in Locust Valley, N.Y. He was 80.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Citizen Watch Adds Angotti to Roster
description: The Citizen Watch Company of America in Lyndhurst, N.J., has named Angotti, Thomas, Hedge in New York as the first agency of record for Life, a new brand of watches priced less than the company's flagship Citizen brand. The billings were estimated at $4 million to $5 million. The decision came after a two-month review that had been narrowed to Angotti, which agreed on Monday to be acquired by the Interpublic Group of Companies, and two other agencies in New York: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, which handles advertising for the Citizen brand, and Grace & Rothschild.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Van Exel Receives 7-Game Suspension
description: The wrath of the National Basketball Association and his team descended yesterday on Nick Van Exel, hours after the Los Angeles Lakers' point guard shoved a referee during a game.

title: Military Chiefs Seek $15 Billion Increase
description: The nation's military chiefs have proposed spending an additional $15 billion next year, putting their priorities at odds with those of the White House and in sync with Republicans in Congress, who have promised to spend billions more on the military. The requests focus mainly on new weapons and weapons research.

title: COURT VOIDS LAW AIDING THE POLICE IN WAGE DISPUTES
description: A state judge struck down a state law yesterday that would have helped New York City's police officers and firefighters win larger pay raises, giving Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani a major victory in his battle to control the city's union negotiations.

title: Deal Reached Over the Estate Of Doris Duke
description: A tentative settlement was announced yesterday that would end the war over Doris Duke's $1.2 billion estate and pay Bernard Lafferty, her high-spending, ponytailed butler, millions of dollars to give up his role in overseeing her fortune.

title: Calendar: Workshops, Tours And Auction of Russian Icons
description: Quilt Festival American Craft Museum, 40 West 53d Street; (212) 956-3535.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Seagram Criticized For Possible TV Ads
description: The Coalition for the Prevention of Alcohol Problems, a group of 24 public health and consumer organizations, has accused the Seagram Company of planning "to seduce America's children" because Seagram might be ending its decades-long adherence to a voluntary ban against broadcast advertising among liquor marketers.

title: Toronto-Dominion to Buy Waterhouse Investor Services
description: Toronto-Dominion Bank said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Waterhouse Investor Services, which operates a chain of discount brokerage offices in the United States, in a stock-and-cash deal valued at about $525 million.

title: HOUSE PROUD;The Challenge: Life in 35 Rooms
description: ONE day this winter, Helena C. Doley was noting how her snow-covered view would turn leafy green come spring. Then she winced. Her eyes had wandered from the picturesque scenery outside the Palladian glass doors in the dining room to the wall above, and settled on a seeping white foamy mass that had stained the crimson paint on the wall.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Is an artistic nude too provocative for a wine bottle? Apparently so. Baroness PHILIPPINE de ROTHSCHILD, the owner of Chateau Mouton-Rothschild of Bordeaux, has announced that she will remove the portrait of a naked girl painted by the artist Balthus that was used for the company's 1993 vintage and destined for the United States.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Quill Corp., Lincolnshire, Ill., to Cramer-Krasselt, Chicago, as the first agency to handle branding and marketing for the office-supplies distributor. Billings were estimated at more than $2 million.

title: Judge Releases Man After 13 Years; Says Police Withheld Crucial Facts
description: For 13 years, from a lonely prison cell, Lawrence J. Miller quietly insisted that authorities had convicted the wrong man for a brutal beating of two teen-agers that shook the small city of Danbury, Conn.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Nickelodeon Is Planning Saturday-Morning Assault
description: Inspired by a burst of ratings growth this year that has made Nickelodeon's cable children's programming competitive with those of ABC, CBS and Fox, Nickelodeon has decided to attack Saturday morning, traditionally a stronghold of the broadcast networks.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;The End of Jack, or What Makes a Man Humble
description: LAST ORDERS By Graham Swift 295 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $23.

title: Prodigy Plans Layoffs in Preparation for Sale
description: The Prodigy Services Company announced yesterday that it was laying off 115 of its 680 employees.

title: Small Packages Make Good Things Happen
description: TWO-THIRDS of all New Yorkers live in tight quarters -- four rooms or fewer -- and many more may soon feel the squeeze: small apartments, according to the Real Estate Board of New York, a trade group, are being purchased faster now than in the last three years.

title: Service Chiefs Are Asking For an Extra $15 Billion
description: The nation's military chiefs have proposed spending an additional $15 billion next year, putting their priorities at odds with the Democratic White House and in sync with Congressional Republicans, who have promised to spend billions more on the military.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: A Box- Office Prize

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Too Many School Districts?
description: New Jersey has too many school districts, and the state ought to be more aggressively promoting mergers, officials of the Public Affairs Research Institute of New Jersey said yesterday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Van Exel Apologizes To All But Referee
description: NICK VAN EXEL apologized yesterday to just about everyone with one notable exception: Referee RON GARRETSON.

title: AIDS Virus Delivers a Gene Therapy to Rats
description: A modified, harmless version of the virus that causes AIDS has been successfully used to deliver gene therapy in laboratory experiments, scientists said today.

title: E.P.A. Distorts Goals On Environment Audits
description: To the Editor:

title: Sinclair Buys Radio and TV Stations for $1.2 Billion
description: The Sinclair Broadcast Group of Baltimore announced today that it would pay $1.2 billion to acquire River City Broadcasting, a closely held television and radio broadcasting company based in St. Louis.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Sloppy Digging Leads to Fine
description: The State Board of Public Utilities has made its first settlement with a repeat violator of a law that requires excavators to phone a hotline in advance.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on March 25 from the Bosnian town of Visegrad, about a Bosnian Serb militia leader accused of atrocities, said of the accused man that "beyond Visegrad, his name and story are largely unknown." The article should have noted that the first extensive report of the accusations was published by a London newspaper, The Guardian.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 31 about the involvement of Asian immigrants in New York City politics misstated the percentage of adults of Asian descent in Queens who were registered to vote in 1995. It is 11.6 percent, according to the city's Voter Assistance Commission, not 4 percent.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AIR PRODUCTS TO SELL STAKE IN DISPOSAL VENTURE
description: Air Products and Chemicals Inc. said yesterday that it would sell its stake in an incineration venture, to concentrate on its core gas and chemical operations. The company, which is based in Allentown, Pa., also said it planned to buy back from investors about 10 percent of its 112 million common shares outstanding. Air Products said it planned to sell its 50 percent stake in American Ref-Fuel, the waste-to-energy joint venture with Browning-Ferris Industries. Air Products said the shares to be repurchased, whose value could be more than $600 million. The stock rose $1.875, to $56.50.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Art in Review
description: Cheryl Donegan 'Tent' Basilico Fine Arts 26 Wooster Street SoHo Through April 20

title: Studying Rare Disorder, Scientists Find Gene Affecting Aging
description: After a worldwide search for families with a rare inherited disorder, scientists have discovered for the first time a gene that affects aging in humans. The gene, which was identified among families in Japan and Syria, may shed light on the process of normal aging.

title: ISRAELI AIRCRAFT STRIKE GUERRILLAS IN BEIRUT SUBURBS
description: Charging that Party of God guerrillas in Lebanon had gone too far in their shelling of northern Israel, Israel today sent planes, helicopters and gunships deep into Lebanon to strike at the group. The raids included the first attack on Beirut since the 1982 invasion of Lebanon.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Mixed Signs In Producer Price Index
description: Inflation jitters grew today despite a report that a sizable increase in producer prices in March was confined largely to energy and food.

title: Aide to Dole Denies Summer House Plan
description: A spokeswoman for Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign has denied a report that Mr. Dole or a trust acting on his behalf was buying a summer house in New Hampshire.

title: Minimum Wage Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Another Trial for Andreotti

title: BASEBALL;Key Looks Good But Leaves Early
description: Jimmy Key's shoulder felt stiff all over, and John Wetteland felt something in his side, but oh those flying feet. They are the Yankees' new weapon, something the Yankees either didn't have or Buck Showalter kept well hidden in his four years as manager.

title: Cold-War Archives
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;DIAMOND FIELDS REPORTS BIGGER NICKEL DEPOSIT
description: Diamond Fields Resources Inc., which has agreed to be acquired by Inco Ltd. for $3.2 billion, said yesterday that recent drilling results at its Voisey's nickel find had showed that the lode was larger than previously thought. The company's chief financial officer, Ed Mercaldo, said the latest exploration suggested a part of the Voisey's Bay property known as Eastern Deeps had a surface area three times that of the first deposit discovered there. This "significantly augments the resource potential" of the property, Diamond Fields said. Diamond Fields owns 75 percent of Voisey's Bay, which is in remote Labrador on Canada's northeast coast, while Inco owns 25 percent.

title: Horse Racing;Path Gets Smoother For Star of 3-Year-Olds
description: He is gray, which tradition says is strike one. He was sold for $1.4 million to a Japanese businessman, who sent him back when X-rays detected chips in his left front ankle. His debut at Saratoga last year was postponed three times. He lost at Gulfstream Park last winter to a 143-1 shot. He didn't like crowds, and didn't even like going to the post accompanied by a pony.

title: ART REVIEW;Ivory Saints Reveal a Harmony of East and West
description: Even when the world was wide, art always traveled. European painting was a hit in 18ph-century China. Indian sculpture has turned up in the ashes of Pompeii. Rembrandt collected Islamic miniatures in Amsterdam. The notion of a global culture may be hotly debated today, but it is a central fact of art history.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Oakley Status Is Uncertain
description: Charles Oakley's minimally displaced fracture of the floor of the orbit below his right eye might keep him out of lineup for a week and possibly for the remainder of the regular season and the playoffs.

title: Ford Is Getting Tighter Control Of Its Partner, Mazda Motor
description: The Ford Motor Company agreed today to invest nearly $500 million in the Mazda Motor Corporation in a deal that makes Ford the first American company to take effective control of a Japanese car maker.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Meadowlands Laugher, But Nets Aren't Smiling
description: Some of the Nets thought the Chicago Bulls took them lightly here tonight.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on April 1 about changes at The St. Louis Post-Dispatch omitted a response by William F. Woo, the newspaper's editor, to a stock market analyst's assertion that Mr. Woo had promoted "an extreme liberal view" that limited the paper's acceptability to many suburban readers. Mr. Woo responded: "This paper for generations has been committed to a liberal public philosophy, which I support. I emphatically reject any suggestion that this philosophy has been pushed to an extreme in my tenure."

title: Deutsche Telekom Sights British Utility
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G., the German telecommunications giant, is considering a takeover of Cable and Wireless P.L.C. of Britain and has made unofficial inquiries, a Deutsche Telekom official said today.

title: Critic's Choice/Film;A Storyteller's Wisdom Connects a Boy to the Past
description: The New York African Film Festival remains a landmark event, a rare opportunity to find beautiful and exotic films whose simple integrity transcends formula and cliche. African films remain largely untouched by the conventions of international film making, and that purity accounts for much of their magic.

title: Abroad at Home;Mean and Petty
description: Illegal immigrants are a major political concern in this election year. President Clinton vies with Republicans on who is better at keeping them out. The House has passed an immigration bill, and the Senate debates its version next week.

title: Even Before Deregulation, Cable Rates Are on the Rise
description: For cable-television subscribers across the country, 1996 is starting to look a lot like 1986.

title: CHRONICLE
description: THE DUCHESS OF YORK is turning into a veritable literary juggernaut. As the author of a series of childre"s books about "Budgie the Helicopter," the former Sarah Ferguson will be adding four titles to the collection. The books will be published in the fall by Simon & Schuster. But she is also broadening her interests from helicopters to human beings and has written two books about a pair of 11-year-old girls, one an English princess and the other an American commoner. They look so much alike that they are mistaken for each other.

title: Company Briefs
description: CALTEX PETROLEUM CORP., Manila, an oil refinery joint venture of Chevron Corp., San Francisco, and Texaco Inc., White Plains, will shelve a $620 million refinery expansion in the Philippines.

title: Singapore Ex-Premier Awarded $71,000 in Libel Case Damages
description: A court ordered an American today to pay former Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew $71,000 in libel damages for articles that accused Mr. Lee of using Singapore's courts as a tool of repression.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Stanley Hired at Cal
description: MARIANNE STANLEY, one of the most successful and controversial coaches in college basketball, was hired yesterday to turn around the struggling women's program at California.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Ex-Banker Jailed for Fraud
description: A former bank officer who had access to all the institution's accounts was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to 18 months in prison for defrauding Farmers and Merchants Bank of $200,000 over a seven-year period ending last year.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Horror-Film Shoot With Malaise in the Air
description: Anna Campion's "Loaded" follows a group of pretty, free-spirited young characters to the abandoned English mansion where they plan to make a horror film. The setting brings out the mood-evoking abilities of the writer-director, who is Jane Campion's sister and has two previous short films ("The Audition" and "Broken Skin") to her credit.

title: Sandy Becker, 74, Radio Announcer And TV Show Host
description: Sandy Becker, an announcer on network radio in the 40's and a creator of puppets, characters and skits for children's television shows on which he was the host in the 50's and 60's, died on Tuesday at his home in Remsenburg, L.I. He was 74.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Fortis Considers a Bid For German Insurer
description: The insurance and financial services company Fortis A.G. is weighing a bid for the German insurer Vereinte Versicherung A.G., but it is not in talks yet with its owners, Fortis's chief executive, Maurice Lippens, said yesterday. "We are studying it," Mr. Lippens said at a news conference after Fortis reported that net profit had risen 15 percent last year.

title: Panel Names Group To Expand Airport
description: The Port Authority today named a consortium led by LCOR Incorporated and Schiphol U.S.A. as its first choice to develop a new international arrivals building at Kennedy International Airport, a spokesman for the authority said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MCDONNELL DOUGLAS IS CONSIDERING 400-SEAT JET
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation is considering building a 400-seat long-haul jet to compete with the Boeing 747, The Financial Times reported in today's issue. But the company said late last night that it had no immediate plans to build such a jet and called the newspaper's report "overstated and out of context." The newspaper quoted Michael Sears, who was named president of the Douglas Aircraft Company earlier this week, as saying the new jet could use the fuselage of McDonnell's 300-seat MD-11, while it would need to have new wings. "We know the MD-11 needs a big brother," Mr. Sears told the newspaper. "Over the next six months or so we will define what we would like to do with that big brother." The company said in a statement that "McDonnell is accelerating design and marketing studies of a variety of options to enhance our family of widebody aircraft."

title: No Headline
description: Clearly I would want all my children to die in a state of joy, but not at age 7."

title: Art in Review
description: Eric Wolf Jessica Fredericks Gallery 504 West 22d Street Chelsea Through April 21

title: 60's Drug Is Back, Police Say as They Announce Arrests
description: Phencyclidine, an illegal hallucinogen that first gained notoriety in the late 1960's in its crystalline form as angel dust, has become popular again in the New York area, investigators said yesterday in announcing that they had broken up a large distribution ring for the drug.

title: Prosecutor in Bombings Is Called Unflappable
description: Colleagues and former opponents of Robert J. Cleary, the man appointed to head the Unabom prosecution team, said there were three things a defense lawyer needed to know before facing him.

title: TV SPORTS;Thursday in the Park With Mr. Holy Cow
description: Phil Rizzuto, who retired from sports broadcasting last season but has returned, glided into the WPIX-TV/Channel 11 booth 15 minutes before game time yesterday bundled in a camel's hair coat he did not remove. He wor' shades under his glasses to protect eyes recuperating from cataract surgery.

title: On My Mind;Fighting Female Mutilation
description: It was the most brutal thing I'd ever experienced. It wasn't something you could just let go."

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;When Good Players Behave Very Badly
description: Last night was typical, both for the Chicago Bulls and for Dennis Rodman. The Bulls (67-9) continued their amazing march toward 70 victories, whipping the Nets, 113-100. Meanwhile, Rodman played well (12 rebounds, 6 points), and he picked up a technical foul along the way for shoving Armon Gilliam.

title: Keep Medicare Out of Managed-Care Hands
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Stock prices were lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 33.96 points, or -0.16 percent, at 21660.47. On Thursday, the Nikkei fell 97.27 points.

title: Stock Prices Dragged Down By Interest Rate Concerns
description: A surge of buying at the end of the day left blue-chip stocks little changed yesterday. Over all, however, the market was lower in very active trading, dragged down by concerns over the possibility of higher interest rates.

title: Dan Wolf, 80, a Village Voice Founder, Dies
description: Dan Wolf, a founding editor of The Village Voice and a longtime adviser to Edward I. Koch, died yesterday at New York University Medical Center. Mr. Wolf, who lived in Greenwich Village, was 80.

title: Man Is Sentenced to 50 Years in Sex Crimes
description: Calling a defendant "a devil incarnate," a Manhattan judge gave a 50- to-100-year sentence yesterday to a man who brutalized and sexually assaulted three female victims in Greenwich Village, including an 11-year-old girl whose orthodontic braces he broke when he punched her in the mouth.

title: U.S. Agrees to Move Some Troops Off Okinawa
description: The United States and Japan are expected to announce an agreement on Monday to move a small number of American troops from Okinawa to other parts of Japan and to return more land used by the American military to Okinawan owners, Pentagon officials said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Time Warner To Charge for Web Service
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it would begin charging users a monthly subscription fee for a new personalized news delivery system on the World Wide Web, saying advertising revenues alone were not enough to support the high start-up costs of Internet-based publishing.

title: Experts Say Stadium Plan Would Cut Yankees' Take
description: Ticket sales, luxury suites and other revenue will not raise enough cash to pay for the $1 billion West Side stadium envisioned by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani without cutting deeply into the profits of the Yankees or any other sports tenant, experts familiar with the financing of stadiums in other cities said.

title: J. P. Morgan Earnings Rise; First Union Shows Decline
description: J. P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that earnings rose 72 percent in the first quarter as trading profits surged.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;WPP Group Plans Consulting Network
description: The WPP Group in New York said yesterday that it would combine five units to form a worldwide network of companies specializing in corporate-identity consulting services.

title: ART REVIEW;From Ashcan to Pluralism, With No Pollock in Between
description: An American Story," the Whitney Museum of American Art's latest display of works from its permanent collection, does everything except jump through hoops. The museum's designers have filled its yawning fourth floor with walls that twist and turn, and have punched new doorways in the only long, straight wall. The result is a labyrinth of galleries and acres of new hanging space, as well as a weird, disorienting swirl when you first look upward from the angled walls to the fixed grid of the ceiling. Barbara Haskell, a curator, has filled these nawly contrived spaces to the brim, mixing media at will, with an overall effect of rather neat and elegantly detailed open storage.

title: Developer Buys the Rights to Build a Times Square Tower
description: A Manhattan developer has acquired the right to construct a large office tower at the northeast corner of 42d Street and Broadway in Times Square, taking over part of a vast development proposal that has been stalled for 15 years.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Unstrung Heroes 1995. Hollywood. $100.71. Laser disk, $39.99. 93 minutes. Closed captioned. PG.

title: Andreotti Is Back in Court, This Time on Murder Charge
description: Former Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti, already on trial in Sicily on charges of association with the Mafia, went on trial a second time today, this time in Perugia on charges that he ordered the 1979 killing of an Italian journalist.

title: Restaurants
description: Walking into Jo Jo can be a nightmare. Take, for instance, one Saturday evening last month. Too many people were crowded into the tiny bar area in the front of the long narrow restaurant, struggling to get rid of their coats. Meanwhile, a man was whining, "But I did confirm!" to a hostess, who told him, in great detail, of her many attempts to find him during the day.

title: TV WEEKEND;On the Chicano Awakening
description: Chicano!," a four-hour tribute to the Mexican-American civil rights movement, begins in the 1960's with the campaign for the return of lands in New Mexico that leaders like Reies Lopez Tijerina claimed had been guaranteed to Chicanos after the Mexican-American War. His Alianza movement, participants recall, fostered an ethnic solidarity that soon broadened into demands for economic justice and political power.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Orthodox observance of Good Friday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Court Hears 2 States Claim a Piece of History;The Winner of a Battle Over Who Owns Ellis Island Gets to Tax Tourists
description: For 200 years, the states of New Jersey and New York have cast their eyes just off shore to an oddly shaped but expanding bit of rock and dirt and have thought, "That's mine." For 200 years, neither side prevailed completely.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: NYC;One Question That Matters In Goetz Case
description: BERNHARD H. GOETZ skipped the subway when he went to the Bronx yesterday morning. No surprise there. Instead, he had a hired car pick him up at his apartment near Union Square.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Scarlet Letter 1995. Hollywood. $100.71. Laser disk, $49.99. 135 minutes. Closed captioned. R.

title: Market Place;Time of Testing In Love Affair With Wall St.
description: While the rest of New York enjoyed a beautiful spring day, it was drizzling yesterday on Wall Street, where spirits are being dampened by the nasty suspicion that maybe, just maybe, the stock market will not continue to go up forever.

title: FILM REVIEW;Cross-Dressing and Happiness Pills
description: Kids in the Hall: Brain Candy," the drag-and-drug comedy from the television-skit troupe Kids in the Hall, offers America yet another chance to continue its platonic love affair with men in dresses. This group's specialty is, quite literally, wiggy humor, since each of the five Kids plays multiple roles and four of them cross-dress with goofy abandon.

title: A Bomb in Buenos Aires
description: Explosives experts found a bomb today outside a naval hospital where a former military doctor in Argentina's so-called dirty war remained in critical condition after being riddled with bullets in an attack by a leftist guerrilla group last week.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Cutthroat Island 1995. Live. $99.98. Laser disk, $39.95. 118 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Westward I Go Free'
description: It may seem mere coincidence that the arrest of Theodore Kaczynski, the alleged Unabomber, and the standoff between Federal authorities and the Freemen, the right-wing militia group, have both occurred in Montana.

title: Diner's Journal
description: What do New Yorkers like best?" the owners of Sullivan's must have asked themselves. Given that they were opening right under the marquee of the landmark Ed Sullivan Theater (where David Letterman tapes his show), it was a reasonable question. They came up with the following answers.

title: Art in Review
description: Meyer Vaisman 303 Gallery 89 Greene Street SoHo Through April 20

title: Clinton Adviser Rules Out Taking Commerce Post
description: Thomas F. McLarty 3d, a top White House adviser, has withdrawn as a possible replacement for Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, leaving a wide-open field.

title: FILM REVIEW;Plain but Smart, Jane Gets Her Prince
description: Franco Zeffirelli's handsome but chilly film version of "Jane Eyre" is right in step with the cinematic vogue for high-toned 19th-century romances in which smart gals finish first and noble suffering is rewarded with happily-ever-after wedded bliss. In an era overrun with preening supermodels and "Baywatch" babes, daydreams about those dear old golden-rule days of feminine propriety can be as consoling as a bowl of lumpy oatmeal on a dank morning.

title: A Calculation in Tears
description: President Clinton's decision to dramatize his veto of a bill banning a type of late-term abortion with tearful testimony from women who had undergone the procedure represented a calculation by the White House that it needed to put a human face on a potentially damaging issue.

title: Big Swiss Bank Rejects Merger Appeal by Rival
description: The Union Bank of Switzerland declined today to pursue merger discussions with rival CS Holding, the financial-services company that operates Credit Suisse and CS First Boston, saying that such a combination into one of the largest banks in the world would strain financial and management resources.

title: FILM REVIEW;He's Lonely, but the Wine Is Older Than She Is
description: Monsieur Arnaud (Michel Serrault) is an elegant phite-haired gentleman, solitary in his habits and accustomed to watching the world with a quiet detachment. He is not one to let his feelings show. "He's a strange guy," remarks Jacqueline (Claire Nadeau), who was once his lover without having had much effect on him. "Delicate. Civilized. But did you see his eyes? He doesn't miss a thing."

title: Tokyo Journal;Dance Naked? Why Not, It's Cherry Blossom Time
description: It was chilly and the rain poured from the dark sky. But with a tent in hand, his feet sinking in the muddy grass, Hiroshi Watanabe pushed on with his task: to find a perfect picnic site with a view.

title: New Jersey Court Says 12-Year-Old Must Register as a Sexual Offender
description: When New Jersey lawmakers moved to protect the state's children from sexual predators by passing the package of community notification measures known as Megan's Law in 1994, they provided no exemptions: not even, an appellate court has ruled, for offenders who are themselves children.

title: BOXING;Probation Officials Restrict Tyson to Ohio
description: Mike Tyson was restricted yesterday to the state of Ohio, where he makes his home, while the police in Chicago investigate a complaint of sexual misconduct allegedly committed by the fighter early Monday morning.

title: Yahoo! Offering Is Set for Today
description: Investors' infatuation with Internet stocks will be tested again today when Yahoo! Inc. makes its initial public offering at $13 a share.

title: Congress Ties Its Own Hands
description: The House plans to vote soon on a misguided bill, co-sponsored by over 200 representatives, that would remove from the Federal budget four transportation trust funds. These accounts, which are supplied by fuel taxes, provide money to build and repair highways, mass-transit systems, waterways and airports. The bill is designed to insulate these funds and make it harder for Congress to switch spending from transportation to programs it values more highly.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Wednesday showing weekly United States petroleum data was outdated. The figures were for the week ended March 29. A chart for the most recent week, which ended on April 5, appears today on page D13.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the Tribune Company's $7 million investment in Excite! Inc., an Internet company, misstated the stock market's reaction to the disclosure, around midday Tuesday. Excite!'s stock price showed little change when the Tribune investment was disclosed, although it had fallen sharply earlier in the day; the disclosure did not depress Excite!'s stock price.

title: BASEBALL;Green Delivers a Warning As Pitching Woes Continue
description: Dallas Green preached patience and perspective last season when his young Mets staggered to a terrible start that effectively ended their post-season hopes. Youth coupled with the short spring training had made the early season troubles inevitable, the manager reasoned. His big leaguers weren't quite ready to perform like big leaguers.

title: FILM REVIEW;What's a Professor to Do When a Nazi Lives Next Door?
description: In "Getting Away With Murder," Dan Aykroyd stands none too convincingly before a blackboard that reads "Hegel's dialectic." He is pretending to be Jack Lambert, an ethics professor with a moral problem on his hands.

title: Mass Weapons Are Spreading, Pentagon Warns
description: The spread of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons represents a threat nearly as big as the specter of global conflict between Moscow and Washington during the cold war, Pentagon officials said today.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Deploying a Huge Force To Celebrate a War's End
description: On paper, the idea of Elliot Goldenthal's "Fire Water Paper: A Vietnam Oratorio," looks dangerously overblown. The Brooklyn-born composer wrote this hourlong work for the 20th anniversary of the formal conclusion of the Vietnam War. Scored for huge orchestra, chorus, children's chorus, solo cello and two vocal soloists, the piece sets an unwieldy assemblage of texts that touches all the politically sensitive bases: passages from the Requiem liturgy of the Roman Catholic Church in Latin, French and Greek; poems by Buddhist monks and a Vietnamese nun who immolated herself as a protest against the killings; quotes from writers ancient and contemporary; biblical passages, and dispatches from the Pentagon Papers.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;From a Soviet Magazine That Made a Revolution Of Its Own in Design
description: In the 1920's, photography's persuasive potential was harnessed to advertising in the West and to governmental propaganda in the Soviet Union. When the Soviets decreed that all art was required to hew to the Socialist Realist line and carry the promise of the revolution to the masses, political leaders already had a sense that photography could do this particularly effectively. No one needed an art education (or any other kind) to read photographs. The images were inherently credible, and photomontage provided a vivid means of combining fact and ideology: modern machinery dwarfed by heroic workers, happy masses presided over by gigantic Stalins or Lenins.

title: Cocaine Seized in Bronx
description: Police officers investigating a reported robbery at a Bronx parking garage came across a minivan filled with 660 pounds of cocaine worth about $6 million, investigators said.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Dream Team Invitations
description: CHARLES BARKLEY and MITCH RICHMOND will be asked to fill the last two spots on the United States Olympic men's basketball team, a source told The Associated Press last night.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CULBRO MEETING IS QUIET, DESPITE LEGAL WOES
description: Questions, but no new answers, arose at the annual shareholder meeting yesterday of the Culbro Corporation, the diversified holding company whose booming cigar sales in 1995 have been clouded by legal troubles disclosed last month. The problems, range from drug smuggling incident at a company cigar warehouse to a former employee's lawsuit accusing the company of bribery, illegal insider trading and violating Federal election rules. Two of the several dozen shareholders at the meeting expressed concern about the legal problems, especially a fraudulent invoicing scheme discovered by company lawyers who were investigating the drug smuggling. Edgar M. Cullman, Culbro's chairman, said auditors had missed the invoices because they were submitted over a long period and each was small. The Alabama grand jury investigations are continuing. Also, generous stock-option awards to Culbro executives were approved despite opposition by Mario Gabelli, the investment manager who holds a 20 percent stake in the company and is the largest shareholder after the Cullman family.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Bridge Jumper Tries Again
description: A homeless man who was hospitalized last September after he tried to jump off an overpass above Route 495 was persuaded yesterday to climb down from the ledge of a nearby bridge, said a spokeswoman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: A Safer Smoke Or Just Another Smokescreen?;Reynold Courts Support for a New Product
description: Once a company designs an innovative product, figures out how to make it profitably and determines consumers are anxious to try it, it can count on smooth sailing toward a big payoff, right? Not for the increasingly reviled tobacco industry.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PFIZER REACHES AGREEMENT TO ACQUIRE CORVITA
description: Pfizer Inc., the diversified drug and health care company, has agreed to acquire the Corvita Corporation for $85 million, the companies said yesterday. Corvita, which is based in Miami, develops synthetic vascular grafts that are used to treat severely diseased arteries. It has also been testing devices to improve blood flow in arteries. Pfizer will begin a cash tender offer of $10.25 for each Corvita share within five business days, the companies said, and shareholders owning about 20 percent of Corvita's stock have agreed to tender their shares.

title: Fidelity to Buy Bank Back-Office Provider
description: In an aggressive diversification move away from usual mutual fund business, Fidelity Investments agreed yesterday to acquire a Broadway & Seymour Inc. unit that provides back-office operations to bank trust departments.

title: New York Charges Suspect With Murder of Biologist
description: The 40-year-old Russian emigre held in New Jersey in the weekend killing and dismembering of a Russian-born molecular biologist was formally charged yesterday by New York State with murdering the scientist.

title: Race Is Dominant Theme As 2d Goetz Trial Begins
description: Like a half-remembered dream, the case against Bernhard H. Goetz began its second run-through in a New York courtroom yesterday. This time, there were none of the side elements that marked Mr. Goetz's 1987 trial and its buildup as a quintessential fragment of the era: demonstrators outside the courtroom, heavy security inside, impassioned debate about whether Mr. Goetz was justified in shooting four young black men who surrounded him on a subway train in December 1984.

title: Cases of Fatal Virus Are Edging Up, Mostly in West, Agency Says
description: Nearly three years after an outbreak of lung disease caused by hantavirus on a Navajo reservation in the Southwest brought the disease to the attention of scientists, Federal statistics show that the number of cases is rising slowly and remaining largely in the West.

title: U.S. Enlists Rich Nations in Move to End Business Bribes
description: Under intense pressure from the United States, the world's richest nations today took an important step to fight corruption in international business dealings by agreeing that bribes paid to foreign officials, often listed as commissions or fees, should no longer be tax deductible.

title: Serbs Refuse to Join Other Bosnians at Conference
description: The Bosnian Serbs are refusing to attend an international conference on raising money for rebuilding Bosnia, an official helping oversee the peace accord said today.

title: In Unabomber Case, Don't Blame Mathematics
description: To the Editor:

title: Letting the City Control Its Cops
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan has ruled that the state should not interfere in collective bargaining between New York City and its police and fire unions. The decision was an important victory for the Giuliani administration, and for the principle of local autonomy.

title: Whitman Says State Will Sue Tobacco Makers on Illnesses
description: While the newsstand in the basement of the State House was ringing up cigarette sales as usual today, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman was upstairs announcing that the State of New Jersey would file a lawsuit against the tobacco industry. Following the lead of five other states that have recently taken similar action, New Jersey officials said they would seek to recover money the state spends to treat tobacco-related illnesses.

title: Clinton Backs Consolidation Of Proposals On Pensions
description: President Clinton today repackaged a batch of proposals for expanding access to pensions and retirement savings accounts into a broad new bill that has little chance of passage but could be a popular manifesto in the Presidential campaign.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Wall Street Begins to Fear Market May Continue Slide After five days of declines, Wall Street's spirits are being dampened by a nasty suspicion that the stock market may not always rise. Worries about inflation are probably the chief culprit. Commodity prices are hitting new highs, and bond yields are climbing quite close to 7 percent. Market Place. [Page A1.]

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Sales of U.S. Autos Up 50% in Japan Since Trade Accord
description: Ten months after the United States reached a high-stakes accord with Japan over automobile trade, President Clinton is set to announce that sales of American cars in the Japanese market have surged 50 percent and that Japanese auto makers have begun buying far larger quantities of American parts.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Midshipmen Are Indicted in a Scheme to Steal and Resell Autos
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted two current and three former midshipmen at the United States Naval Academy here in what officials said was a scheme to steal and sell automobiles.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;No Charges in Baby's Death
description: No charges will be filed against the parents of a 2-week-old girl who was accidentally smothered by the couple as they slept in their bed, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Iran's Party of God Puts Deep Roots in Lebanon
description: Through more than a decade of confrontation with Israel, the Iranian-backed Party of God has waged war against both soldiers and civilians in a relentless campaign to drive Israeli occupiers out of southern Lebanon.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Who Needs Scores?
description: Don't expect out-of-town updates on the Riverfront Stadium scoreboard. They have been missing at most Cincinnati Reds games this season, thanks to a cost-cutting move by MARGE SCHOTT, the owner. The Reds have canceled a $350-a-month service that supplies updates for the scoreboard. "Why do they care about one game when they're watching another?" Schott said. She suggested that scores could be obtained elsewhere. "They can get it off the radio, can't they?" (AP)

title: Defying Polls, Gingrich Raises Big Money
description: The setting was a lunch at the Bismarck Hotel, where Mayor Richard J. Daley once held court and cut some of his biggest political deals. But the 200 guests had not paid at least $250 each to hear about the last of the Democratic bosses. They came to see Newt Gingrich, the Republican Speaker of the House.

title: OPERA REVIEW;New Faces at the Metropolitan
description: GOOD marketing creates anticipation. Inspired marketing can even induce product satisfaction. Ill-considered marketing -- and poor Roberto Alagna was its victim on Wednesday night -- inflates expectations to the bursting point and then hands the consumer a sharp pin.

title: Switzerland's Top Bank Spurns Merger Bid From Arch-Rival
description: LONDON  Union Bank of Switzerland gave an emphatic thumbs down late Thursday to the idea of a merger that would have created the world's largest bank outside Japan.

title: FILM REVIEW;In Projects, Deejay Calls The Tune
description: The slinky, nasty-mouthed title character of Clement Virgo's film "Rude" certainly lives up to her name. Broadcasting to the residents of an urban housing project on a pirate radio station, this Jamaican-Canadian disk jockey addresses her listeners in language that varies from X-rated sex talk to apocalyptic mumbo jumbo.

title: Petals on a Wet Spring Snowbank
description: To the Editor:

title: Creed of Hate Called Christian Identity Is the Heart of the Freemen's Beliefs
description: A few weeks before Federal agents shut down access to the ranch near here occupied by a militant anti-government group that calls itself the Freemen, its leaders invited the Rev. Helen Young to come hear them out.

title: Kmart Plans New Scrutiny For Managers and Vendors
description: After spending three months on an investigation that is almost certain to result in disciplinary actions against some employees, the Kmart Corporation said yesterday that it would require all its managers and vendors to sign an "integrity pledge."

title: Tennessean Leaving House; Son Seeks Seat
description: Representative Harold Ford, Democrat of Tennessee, announced today that he was leaving Congress after 22 years, clearing the way for his son, a law-student, to seek his seat.

title: Inside Art
description: More German Treasures in Russia

title: COMPANY NEWS;EQUITY RESIDENTIAL BID FOR BALCOR PROPERTIES
description: Equity Residential Properties Trust, the nation's largest public owner of apartments, has made an offer to buy 30 to 35 properties from partnerships run by the Balcor Company in a transaction that could exceed $350 million, according to Balcor officials and filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Chicago-based Equity Residential, which is controlled by the investor Sam Zell, and the Balcor partnerships are close to reaching an agreement, according to the executives and the filings. Officials at Equity Residential, which owns or controls 59,044 apartment units in 30 states, were not immediately available for comment. Balcor is based in Bannockburn, Ill.

title: AT THE MET AND THE MODERN WITH: Jacob Lawrence;An Invigorating Homecoming
description: IN the 1930's, when he was a teen-ager, Jacob Lawrence liked to walk the 50-odd blocks from his Harlem apartment to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where he'd go straight to early Italian Renaissance paintings. Some 60 years later, having come to town from Seattle, where he now lives, he heads first for the same galleries.

title: Mother and Son in Standoff Surrender
description: Two members of the Freemen, a militant anti-government group that has held off law-enforcement officials near here for almost three weeks, turned themselves into Federal Bureau of Investigation agents late this afternoon.

title: Widow in L.I.R.R. Massacre Considers Race for Congress on Gun Ban
description: Hers was a public face of grief and rage after a gunman stalked the aisles of a Long Island Rail Road car in December 1993, killing her husband of 28 years and gravely injuring their only child. The next year, she appeared in campaign commercials for the state's Democratic Governor --showing she was no slick politician as she mispronounced his name "Coh-mo" in praising his work to ban assault weapons.

title: In America;The Stadium Fantasy
description: I stood on the corner of 12th Avenue and 30th Street, with a cold, harsh wind blowing in from the Hudson River, which is right across the avenue, and tried to imagine a stadium there.

title: In Unabomber Case, Don't Blame Mathematics
description: To the Editor:

title: Sidney Weinberg, 72, a Mentor To a Generation of Pathologists
description: Dr. Sidney B. Weinberg, the forensic pathologist who created the Suffolk County Medical Examiner's office in 1960 and turned it into a national showcase, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian hospital. He was 72 and lived in Huntington Station, L.I.

title: BASEBALL;Being Busybody Has Its Down Side
description: George Steinbrenner sounded tired. Passionate discussions about whether the Yankees should stay in the Bronx or relocate are percolating. A $20 million free agent is pitching in the minor leagues while a pitcher who has not won a game in 22 months is in the rotation. The Olympics in Atlanta are three months away. Maybe he should sound tired.

title: GOLF;Norman's Opening Round Is the Stuff of Dreams
description: The Masters has always taunted Greg Norman. Whether he admits it or not, his favorite tournament in the world has always baited him, like a cruel mistress, seducing him and then slapping his face, drawing him near and pushing him away.

title: Memorial for Cherkassky
description: A memorial service for the pianist Shura Cherkassky is to be held today at 12:15 P.M. at Weill Recital Hall. Mr. Cherkassky, who died on Dec. 27 at 84, was one of the last of the great Russian Romantic pianists. Speakers are to include Judith Arron, executive director of Carnegie Hall, and Harold Shaw, Mr. Cherkassky's North American manager. Doors open at 11:45 A.M.

title: Moral Censure Acts as a Judicial Check
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Wunderman Cato Scales Back an Office
description: Wunderman Cato Johnson, the direct response and sales promotion unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., will reduce its presence in Los Angeles from a full-service office to a field office.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;China and France Will Study Developing a 100-Seat Jet
description: China and France signed a preliminary agreement today to study joint development of a 100-seat jet, dealing a blow to American companies that were also seeking to team up with the Chinese to build a new plane.

title: Johns Hopkins Student Held in Fatal Shooting
description: A Johns Hopkins sophomore from Port Washington, L.I., was shot to death late Wednesday night at the university in Baltimore, shortly after he was elected president of the College Republicans club.

title: Art in Review
description: Charles LeDray Jay Gorney Modern Art 100 Greene Street, near Prince Street SoHo Through May 11

title: South Korea's Ruling Party Trips But Does Not Fall in Elections
description: President Kim Young Sam's ruling party lost its majority in South Korea's legislature in voting on Thursday, but it averted a setback that would have robbed the unpopular President of his mandate nearly two years before the end of his term.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Art in Review
description: Krzysztof Wodiczko 'Xenology: Immigrant Instruments, 1992-1996' Galerie LeLong 20 West 57th Street Manhattan Through April 27

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about repetitive stress injuries omitted a response from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration to Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, who had endorsed a proposed task force to combat such injuries. The response, from Joseph A. Dear, the Assistant Secretary of Labor who heads OSHA, said, "I am afraid that the task force you propose would currently be viewed as an action not consistent with Congressional intent regarding OSHA's activities."

title: Moral Censure Acts as a Judicial Check;Let Voters Choose
description: To the Editor:

title: BOXING;No Title Fight Is Complete Without Palm Trees
description: Pernell Whitaker, bored with yet another opponent he says he has never seen fight, will put his welterweight title at risk Friday night in this unlikely setting.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Gains on Outlook for Rise In U.S. Rates and Fall in Bonn's
description: The dollar rose against most leading currencies yesterday, bolstered by expectations that United States interest rates would remain steady, while German rates would fall.

title: Saudis Bar Nigeria Pilgrims
description: Saudi Arabia, citing epidemics sweeping West Africa, has banned all Nigerians from entering the kingdom to make the annual pilgrimage to the Islamic world's two holiest shrines.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;From Swamp to Brawny Big City
description: CITY OF THE CENTURY The Epic of Chicago and the Making of America By Donald L. Miller Illustrated. 704 pages. Simon & Schuster. $35.

title: UNABOMBER CASE GIVEN PROSECUTOR FROM NEW JERSEY
description: The Justice Department named a New Jersey Federal prosecutor today to lead a team of six Government lawyers who will prosecute the Unabom case, suggesting that the case is rapidly shifting from the Montana wilderness to a courtroom.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Poor Little Boy Befriended by Bugs
description: As mainstream movies for adults go dumb and dumber, children's films inversely take the high road. And the new sophistication of fairy-tale entertainment has become so acute that its fairy-tale qualities may actually pale by comparison. So "James and the Giant Peach," the latest animated film from Disney, is a technological marvel, arch and innovative with a daringly offbeat visual conception. But it's also a strenuously artful film with a macabre edge that may scare small children. And beyond that, it lacks a clear idea of who its audience might be.

title: A Common Past
description: A decade ago, the Kaczynski brothers led similar, solitary lives: Theodore, in a Montana cabin, and David, in a Texas desert. Page A20.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Once Again, The Taming Of a Despot
description: TAKING the story of Anna Leonowens, the adventurous yet very Victorian English governess who tamed the exotic King of Siam, Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d created a musical play as joyously all-American as anything they ever wrote. It's beside the point that "The King and I" is set in the Far East and has nothing to do with America. As expressed by its charming score, the show's spirit is that of an idealized 19th-century America far removed from the Civil War, robber barons, the Industrial Revolution and the winning of the West through the expropriation of other people's property.

title: Home Video
description: An Unscheduled Release

title: FILM REVIEW;A Palace Servant's Daughter Awakens to Harsh Truths
description: The Silences of the Palace" was shown as part of the 1994 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Caryn James's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 30, 1994. The film opens today at Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street, in Greenwich Village.

title: The Brothers Kaczynski: How 2 Paths Diverged
description: He was a bearded nature lover, living in a tiny wilderness cabin, traveling by bicycle and shunning electricity, telephones, and running water.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Santander Buys Stake In Chile's Banco Osorno
description: Banco Santander S.A., Spain's largest commercial bank, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a 51 percent stake in Banco Osorno y La Union for $495 million in a merger that would create Chile's largest private bank. Santander plans to merge the bank, Chile's fourth largest, with Banco Santander-Chile, creating a financial institution with $7.9 billion in assets and a combined market value of $1.7 billion, the banks said in a joint statement. On Wednesday, the banks had said they were completing an agreement.

title: HOCKEY;Devils Glimpse Into Abyss, and Turn Back
description: The ressure was enormous, and it mounted even more when the Devils fell behind by two goals tonight, looking possible playoff elimination squarely in the eye. But the defending Stanley Cup champions did not blink, and in a fashion reminiscent of last year, they stormed back to beat the Washington Capitals, 3-2, and remain in the playoff hunt.

title: What Civics Lesson In Rostenkowski Case?
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANNE TRUITT proposed a toast "to fidelity" Wednesday evening as she looked back on her 40-year friendship with KATHARINE GRAHAM, the chairwoman of the executive committee of The Washington Post Company.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS -- Advertising;In an ambitious expansion plan, a British agency is opening a full-service office in San Francisco.
description: A BRITISH agency celebrated for its creative prowess is crossing an ocean -- and a continent -- in an ambitious, and risky, bid to expand.

title: In Unabomber Case, Don't Blame Mathematics;Harvard vs. Stanford
description: To the Editor:

title: Retail Sales Increase In March on Easter Effect
description: Like tulips, retail sales seem to pop up in the spring, but after the positive effect of Easter on March sales, which were reported yesterday, the retail bloom could come off in April.

title: For Children
description: 'The Cicadas Are Coming! The Cicadas Are Coming!' Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences 75 Stuyvesant Place, near Wall Street St. George (718) 727-1135 Recommended ages: 5 and up Through July 7

title: Columbia Students Stage Overnight Sit-In
description: About 200 Columbia University students staged a sit-in at the school's Hamilton Hall yesterday, demanding again that the administration create a department of ethnic studies.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AT&T SIGNS 5 CONTRACTS FOR LOCAL SERVICE
description: The AT&T Corporation signed agreements with five companies yesterday to offer local telephone service to businesses in 70 American cities. AT&T had said it planned to enter local markets, a $90-billion-a-year business. The company said the agreements do not involve an equity investment from AT&T. The companies that will carry AT&T calls to businesses from the point where AT&T's lines stop are American Communications Services Inc., Brooks Fiber Properties, Hyperion Telecommunications, Intelcom Group Inc. and the Time Warner Communications unit of Time Warner Inc. AT&T is also talking with the seven Baby Bell phone companies and with the GTE Corporation about connecting with the local phone networks.

title: About Real Estate;Rental Apartments Try A Comeback in Suburbs
description: In suburban markets, developers who say they are responding to a lag in condominium and cooperative sales are increasingly turning to rentals. They say they are doing so in order to keep building and to serve a growing number of people who are unwilling or unable to commit to a purchase.

title: Airplane's Design Presents Challenges for Young Pilot
description: Jessica Dubroff may have been too small to climb into a pilot's seat unassisted. And she had to sit on a booster seat to see out of the windshield. But what exactly does it mean to "fly" an airplane?

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;BET Quick to Reject Higher Bid by Rentokil
description: Rentokil Group P.L.C., the British provider of pest control and other services, increased its bid yesterday for BET P.L.C., but BET quickly rejected the richer offer. The new bid values BET, which also provides a variety of services, at L2.1 billion (about $3.23 billion), up from Rentokil's previous offer of L1.8 billion.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Ferry and Cavaliers Shoot Down Knicks
description: His proficient long-range shooting brought the Cavaliers within one game of the Knicks in the race for the Eastern Conference's fourth playoff spot, and New York fans caught a sobering glimpse of what could be an intense first-round playoff matchup.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Senator Attacks School Plan
description: A Democratic lawmaker urged Education Commissioner Leo Klagholz yesterday to withdraw part of the Whitman administration's plan to improve curriculum standards.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Loose Wheel Injures Worker
description: A construction worker was listed in critical condition yesterday after a 200-pound wheel that had come loose from a passing tractor-trailer struck him while he was working on the center divider of Route 195, the State Police said.

title: 25 and Under
description: Selecting a restaurant is sometimes an exercise in terminal negotiations.

title: U.S. Calls Off Risky Daylight Rescue Flights in Liberia
description: As fighting by rival militia groups raged on in Monrovia, the Liberian capital, United States officials today called off daytime evacuations of foreigners for fear that rescue helicopters based here would come under attack.

title: Jets Sign Reich as Backup
description: The Jets continued to show their serious intentions yesterday by signing one of football's n'ted backup quarterbacks, Frank Reich, to a two-year contract. The 34-year-old Reich, whose package is believed to be worth about $1 million, would give the Jets a proven quarterback if their $25 million man, Neil O'Donnell, were sidelined. Even though Coach Rich Kotite has had only praise for the inexperienced Glenn Foley, the fact that he is recuperating from serious shoulder surgery put pressure on the team to acquire a quality backup.

title: Girl, 7, Seeking U.S. Flight Record, Dies in Crash
description: A 7-year-old California girl on a quest to become the youngest cross-country pilot was killed today when her single-engine plane crashed shortly after take-off in thunder and driving sleet. Her father and a flight instructor were also killed.

title: Ashanti Goldfields to Buy Australian Miner
description: Ashanti Goldfields Ltd. of Ghana, a gold miner that has made a number of acquisitions in the last year, said today that it had agreed to buy Golden Shamrock Mines Ltd., an Australian company, for about $290 million in stock.

title: Keep Medicare Out of Managed-Care Hands
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;DELPHI PLANS TO SELL 3 PLANTS AND SHUT ONE
description: The General Motors Corporation's parts subsidiary, Delphi Automotive Systems, said yesterday that it would sell three North American plants and close a fourth in an effort to become more profitable. Delphi plans to sell its electrical and lighting plants in Livonia, Mich.; and Oshawa and Windsor, Ontario, and close a generator plant in Albany, Ga., that employs about 500 workers. They will be offered transfers to another plant in Flint, Mich., that will take over the Albany plant's work, Delphi said. Delphi also said it would seek a partner for a plant in Flint. The company has said that it plans to increase its business outside North America, and with customers other than General Motors. On Tuesday, Delphi Packard Electric Systems said it would build a $17 million plant and service center in Guangzhou, China, to make automotive electronics for export to Europe and for Chinese car makers.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on March 31 about Kenneth Starr, the independent counsel in the Whitewater investigation, said incorrectly that a conservative women's organization for which Mr. Starr did legal consultation in 1994 was involved in a lawsuit against President Clinton. The organization, the Independent Women's Forum, was considering entering the litigation but did not. The editorial also said Mr. Starr had represented a conservative foundation in a school-voucher case before the Wisconsin Supreme Court. In fact he represented the state, which paid him from a grant to the voucher program from the Bradley Foundation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: UN Rights Report Flays France for Its 'Racist' Immigration Laws
description: PARIS  A United Nations report sharply rebuked France on Thursday for "a wave of xenophobia and racism" that it said was sweeping the country.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FEDERAL INVESTIGATION OF CABLE CHANNEL ENDS
description: The Home Shopping Network Inc. said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had ended a three-year investigation without comment and without taking action against the company, Home Shopping said, after the markets closed. The investigation, which began in 1993, was initiated following shareholder lawsuits and accusations against the company's founder and former chairman, Roy M. Speer. In 1994, a Federal grand jury in Tampa, Fla., closed its investigation into accusations that Mr. Speer had engaged in bribery, soliciting kickbacks, and holding secret interests in company vendors. That Federal investigation ended two months after Home Shopping agreed to settle a dozen shareholder lawsuits. The company, based in Clearwater, Fla., is now a unit of Silver King Communications.

title: TV WEEKEND;Slavery as Experienced By a Mixed-Race Couple
description: Offered by CBS as "an epic drama in the tradition of 'Roots,' " "Captive Heart: The James Mink Story" is really a modest production recounting an unusual family story based on historical records. Living in Toronto in 1852, James Mink (Louis Gossett Jr.), son of a freed slave, is the millionaire owner of a hotel and livery business.

title: Sports of The Times;'I Never Remember 5-Putting'
description: WHEN Tom Watson phoned his Kansas City office the other day, he asked his administrative assistant, Kelly Fray, "What's new?"

title: Japan Budget Bill Passes Lower House
description: After a three-week sit-in protest by the opposition party, the lower house of the Japanese Parliament passed a national budget today that includes funds to liquidate crippled lending institutions.

title: In Beirut Suburbs, Attack Brings Back Old Memories
description: When Israeli warplanes fired their rockets into the southern outskirts of the capital today, it was the last thing most civilians expected.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: 16 Killed in a Blaze at Dusseldorf Airport
description: At least 16 people were killed today as waves of smoke from an unexplained fire carried lethal fumes into elevators, ventilation ducts and lounges at the Dusseldorf airport, police and fire officials said.

title: FILM REVIEW;For Daddy, A Boyfriend From Hell
description: Surprise, surprise. Mark Wahlberg, the pug-faced actor formerly known as Marky Mark, could be on the verge of full-fledged movie stardom, embodying every father's worst nightmare of a boyfriend for his darling daughter. In "Fear," he plays David McCall, a young Seattle roustabout with a shady past who becomes involved with 16-year-old Nicole Walker (Reese Witherspoon), a restless teen-ager who looks like Alicia Silverstone's sulky younger sister.

title: Israel's Answer to Terror
description: As Israel's elections approach, Prime Minister Shimon Peres may be tempted to unleash Israeli force against terrorist targets to demonstrate that his Government is unyielding in its defense of the nation's security. Given the recent terrorist attacks in Israel, Mr. Peres has every reason to be resolute. But he should not strike out in anger. It is important that Israel's response to terrorism be dispassionate and proportional to the threat.

title: Bronx House Fire Kills 3 Children and Injures 5 Tenants
description: Three children were killed yesterday when a fast-moving blaze trapped them on the top floor of a Bronx apartment house, forcing other tenants to jump out their third-floor windows and sending firefighters scurrying back outside only seconds before the house's roof collapsed.

title: In Bronx, Spring Rings Too Loudly
description: It started as a morning filled with promise for Mohammed Ahamed, manager of the Price is Right -- Mostly Under $10 clothing store on Third Avenue in the Bronx. On the first shirt-sleeve day in a long-awaited spring, his avenue was abuzz with shoppers, and bouncy rock music wafted from his storefront.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Thursday with an article about increases in the immunizing of children in the United States in the last three years mislabeled two states. Minnesota and Wisconsin were reversed.

title: Sports of The Times;A Hometown Hero, Always At Home
description: BY 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, the playground at 25th and Diamond was bustling with activity. Six Nike representatives and the staff at the Hank Gathers Recreation Center were busy putting last-minute touches on the biggest activity of the spring. Dawn Staley was coming home.

title: Religion Journal;Getting Below Surface Of U.S. Catholics' Beliefs
description: A basic religious question that pollsters tend to ask Americans is, "Do you believe in God?"

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption in some copies yesterday about the Knicks-Cavaliers game misidentified the Knick player being defended. He was Anthony Mason, not Derek Harper.

title: India's Fiscal Woe Was Forged in Britain
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Dream Teamers Picked
description: The surprise selection of CHARLES BARKLEY means five members of the 1992 United States Olympic basketball team have been invited to join the 1996 squad.

title: Ford, in Mazda Investment, Is Revered as Well as Feared
description: The Ford Motor Company's decision to take effective control of the Mazda Motor Corporation represents a judgment that the ailing Japanese car maker, with its sales falling, can no longer make it by itself in an increasingly global and combative auto industry, executives and analysts said yesterday.

title: HOCKEY;Red Wings Set Victory Record
description: The Detroit Red Wings became the 'irst National Hockey League team to win 61 games in a season tonight with a 5-3 victory over the Chicago Blackhawks.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Abortion Doctor Wins Ruling
description: A physician accused of botching abortions should be allowed to resume practicing, an administrative law judge recommended yesterday.

title: G.O.P. Has Tentative Deal on Terrorism Bill
description: Republicans in the House and Senate have struck a tentative deal on legislation bolstering Federal powers to fight terrorism and hope to pass a finished version by next Friday, the anniversary of the Oklahoma City bombing, Republican officials said today.

title: Retail Sales Rise Slightly; Consumer Prices Up 0.4%
description: Retail sales eked out a small gain in March as inflation edged higher, Government figures showed today, indicating that a rebound seen earlier this year may be moderating.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Creed of Big Yet Simple
description: Mary Anthony, whose company celebrates its 40th anniversary this year, believes in the power of big, dramatic, lyrical movement performed wholeheartedly and with compelling simplicity. All were in evidence in a program on Thursday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Russian Planes Continue Attacks on Chechnya
description: While Kremlin mediators tried to arrange a meeting with the Chechen rebel leader, Dzhokhar M. Dudayev, Russian aircraft and artillery continued attacks today on a village in southwestern Chechnya.

title: INSIDE
description: Talks on Price-Fixing Inquiry

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Pentagon warnings of the spread of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons misspelled the surname of the Assistant Secretary of Defense for international security policy in some copies. He is Ashton B. Carter, not Cater.

title: POLITICAL BRIEFS;THE CAMPAIGN FOR CONGRESS
description: North Carolina A Bit Early, Helms Opens Fire

title: COMPANY NEWS;INTERNATIONAL UNIT TO SELL STAKE IN BRAKE MAKER
description: The Allied Signal International Finance Corporation, a unit of Allied Signal Inc., said yesterday that it would sell its 80 percent stake in the Turkish brake maker Transturk Fren Donanim Endustrisi A.S. to Robert Bosch G.m.b.H. of Stuttgart, Germany, which makes automotive and electronics products, for $21 million. Also, Allied Signal completed the sale of its wholly owned hydraulic- and anti-lock-braking businesses to Robert Bosch for $1.5 billion. That sale was cleared by European regulators earlier this week. The businesses that were sold to Bosch accounted for about $2.1 billion of Allied Signal's 1995 sales of $14.3 billion.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Blast Hits East Jerusalem Hotel, Raising Fears of More Bombings
description: An explosion ripped through a hotel room on the main street of Arab East Jerusalem today, seriously wounding a guest who the police said had apparently been handling a bomb.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Mickey Kantor Is Named To Head Commerce Agency President Clinton named Mickey Kantor, who has been the trade representative, to succeed Ronald H. Brown as Commerce Secretary. Mr. Kantor, shown at left, used extraordinary pressure tactics to force Europe, Japan, Mexico and China to open their markets, a style much different from Mr. Brown's.

title: Commerce and Diplomacy
description: Mickey Kantor, President Clinton's choice to succeed Ronald Brown as Commerce Secretary, can be expected to keep American overseas business interests in the forefront of Washington's foreign policy agenda.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BIG OIL COMPANIES NAMED IN PRICE-FIXING SUIT
description: The Amoco Corporation, the Amerada Hess Corporation, Texaco Inc. and 23 other oil companies have been accused of cheating royalty owners through price-fixing in a proposed class action filed in Federal court in Houston. The lawsuit, filed by the McMahon Foundation of Oklahoma and J. Tom Poyner, a Texas resident, seeks unspecified damages on behalf of royalty owners throughout the continental United States. The lawsuit says the oil companies engaged in a conspiracy to depress the "posted price" they use to calculate royalties paid to landowners.

title: Spring Tonic in a Surge of Income Tax Refunds
description: An early surge in income tax refunds is giving Americans billions of extra dollars to spend this spring, which helps to explain the revival in the economy now in progress.

title: Amid Jokes and Bagpipes, Bratton Departs
description: It was not exactly the parade that he envisioned a year ago, but in the end, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton got a send-off from Police Headquarters complete with an honor guard wielding carbines and a bagpipe company wailing "Give My Regards to Broadway" and "God Bless America."

title: CUNY 'Vocational' Friction Has National Echo
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 in Militant Montana Group Plead Not Guilty on All Counts
description: One day after surrendering to the authorities, two members of the militant anti-government group known as the Freemen pleaded not guilty today to charges that included mail fraud and bank robbery.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Lightening Loads in Newark
description: Travelers' astonishment at not finding rental baggage carts in Newark International Airport is soon to end. Passengers using Terminal C can now rent baggage carts for $1.50. By the summer, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the airport, plans to make the carts available in all three terminals.

title: New Jersey Offers Yankees Stadium Plans
description: The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority has given the New York Yankees' principal owner, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, plans for a stadium in New Jersey to house the team after the lease for its current home in the Bronx expires in 2002, according to officials of the state and the Yankees organization.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about an audio recording of sheriff's deputies in Riverside County, Calif., just before they beat Mexican immigrants who had entered the United States illegally in a pickup truck referred incorrectly to one immigrant, Enrique Funes Flores, also known as Adrian Flores Martinez. While the Sheriff's Department originally suspected Mr. Funes Flores of being the truck's driver, it later declared that he was not.
