title: Official Charged in Anti-Semitic Vandalism
description: A 39-year-old employee of the Village of Larchmont has been charged with inscribing anti-Semitic phrases and Nazi swastikas in the village Municipal Building, and the authorities said they were investigating his possible involvement in similar incidents elsewhere.

title: Keep On Walking
description: To the Editor:

title: IN PERFORMANCE;DANCE
description: The Lessons of Love's Pain, Without Solace in Pentitence Companhia Paulo Ribeiro St. Mark's Church

title: Mayor Woos Civic Leaders on Stadium Plan
description: Even as he insists that no decision has been made on a proposal to build a new stadium for the New York Yankees on the West Side of Manhattan, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has begun a campaign to rally the city's business leaders behind the idea.

title: Police Brutality in Mexico, Echoing California Case, Puts Zedillo onthe Spot
description: As Mexico continues its sharp criticism of the United States for the recent beating of illegal immigrants by police officers in California, the Mexican Government itself is being condemned for a brutal attack against peasants by its police.

title: CABARET REVIEW;Age Has Not Withered Her
description: At 80, Hadda Brooks can sing the most innocuous line and turn it into an innuendo more salacious than the blatant sexual come-ons of most contemporary rhythm-and-blues singers. On Thursday night in the Oak Room at the Algonquin Hotel, as part of a five-night stand that ends with two shows tonight, Ms. Brooks was sometimes a sexual dynamo, slinking around the room and massaging the muscles of various men as she sang the brazen "Need a Little Sugar in My Bowl." At other times, she exuded misery instead of charm, sitting down at the piano to imbue "I'm a Fool to Want You" with all the self-punishment the slow, wrenching song could contain.

title: Dismissing Defense Effort, Judge Stays on Drug Case
description: Judge Harold Baer Jr. rejected a defense request yesterday that he remove himself from a Washington Heights drug case, strongly denying that political pressure had led him to change his mind and admit disputed evidence.

title: Liberian Civilian Hostages Are Trapped in Mortar Attack
description: Several thousand Liberians held hostage in a barracks here by one of the country's warring militias came under mortar attack today by another faction for the second day. While the fighting continued, a United States evacuation effort focused on pulling out stranded Americans and other foreigners from isolated hiding places here.

title: GOLF;Augusta Shows Its Claws, but Norman Isn't Fazed
description: Playing with a calm resolve that sliced through the gusting winds and glided over the concrete greens of Augusta National, Greg Norman today added a 69 to his stunning opening round of 63 and widened his lead to four strokes after two rounds of the Masters.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SCITEX Corp., Herzlia, Israel, a computer imaging systems company, said an Israeli investment group had raised its stake in it to 24.33 percent of the company's outstanding ordinary shares. The group, which includes IDB Development Corp. Ltd., PEC Israel Economic Corp. and Recanati family members, purchased 225,000 shares at $18.38 to $19.12 a share.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;10-Year Sentence for Mobster
description: A member of the Lucchese crime family in New Jersey who admitted conspiring to commit nine murders was sentenced in Federal court yesterday to 10 years in prison. Thomas Ricciardi, 44, of Lakewood, could have received a harsher sentence, but Judge Alfred J. Lechner Jr. noted that he had cooperated with Federal authorities in prosecuting members of other crime families. Mr. Ricciardi's testimony helped solve murders that had occurred between 1972 and 1990, said Colette R. Buchanan, an assistant United States attorney.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about New Jersey's decision to file a lawsuit against the tobacco industry to recover money spent by the state on tobacco-related illnesses misstated the number of states that have already filed such lawsuits. It is seven, not five. (In recent weeks, Minnesota and Texas have joined Florida, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Mississippi and West Virginia.)

title: COMPANY NEWS;BELL & HOWELL TO USE THE INTERNET FOR ITS MEETING
description: Bell & Howell Company said yesterday that it would supplement its first annual shareholders meeting in Ann Arbor, Mich. with a first-of-its-kind session on the Internet. The Skokie, Ill., supplier of information-access products will provide a live interactive audio feed of the meeting on May 16 to shareholders who connect electronically through its site on the World Wide Web (http://www.bellhowell.com).

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Hope Old Logo Wins Back Fans
description: The Rangers are preparing for the playoffs, and the Devils are trying to squeak into the post-season. The Islanders? With 50 defeats this season, they have a far different task -- win back their fans.

title: New York's First World's Fair, Oft Forgot
description: To the Editor:

title: Martin R. Kaufman, Theater Producer, 35
description: Martin R. Kaufman, a producer and the founder of the Kaufman Theater on West 42d Street in Manhattan, died on Thursday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 35.

title: Navy Blames Showing Off For Jet Crash
description: The Navy said today that a pilot was probably showing off for his parents when he crashed an F-14A jet fighter in Nashville in January, killing himself, a fellow officer and three people on the ground.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-6

title: Don't Let Politics Destroy Welfare Agency's Good Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Critics Exaggerate Pakistani Rights Abuses
description: To the Editor:

title: New York City Can't Afford This Tax
description: Every three months, I make out a check to New York City for, well, never mind the exact number -- suffice to say it's 4 percent of my quarterly earnings.

title: Safety Mistake Cited in Crash Of Girl's Plane
description: An investigator from the National Transportation Safety Board said this evening that the single-engine plane that crashed on Thursday, killing 7-year-old Jessica Dubroff, her father, Lloyd, and her flight instructor, was overweight when it left the airport at Cheyenne, Wyo., in a thunderstorm.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;French and Russians, Warring Once Again
description: Somewhere this side of kneejerk thematic programming, it ought to be possible at least to keep works on a program from warring with one another.

title: Bridge
description: The laws of bridge require players to reveal their signaling methods to the opponents. But years ago this columnist pointed out a curious exception. The declarer is entitled to signal secretly to the dummy when he has something to say that he does not wish the opposition to hear. If dummy has an A-K combination, for example, the partnership may agree in advance that the play of the ace will advise dummy to hold his cards up on subsequent deals because one opponent has periscopic eyes.

title: Minimum-Wage Raise Still Causes Job Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;B.U.M. INTERNATIONAL SEEKING CHAPTER 11 PROTECTION
description: B.U.M. International Inc. has filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act and will liquidate its 41 retail outlet stores. The maker of casual clothing said it expected to post a loss of $9 million to $16 million for 1995. The company also said it would report a first-quarter loss from operations of more than $1.7 million. The planned liquidation of the company's retail outlets is part of a restructuring program. B.U.M. said late Thursday that it planned to continue as a licensing and marketing company. The company filed Wednesday in a Los Angeles bankruptcy court.

title: 55-Nation Conference on Fund-Raising for Bosnia Is Split Over theSerbs
description: Representatives of 55 countries began a two-day meeting today intended to raise $1.2 billion more in foreign economic aid for Bosnia and Herzegovina this year. American and European officials disagreed about whether the discredited Bosnian Serb leadership should get any of the money yet.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Tales of Stolen Babies And Lost Identities;A Greek Scandal Echoes in New York
description: The baby girl, swaddled in rags, was abandoned on the steps of an orphanage in Patras, Greece, with a simple note giving her name (Maria Ioannou), date of birth (Aug. 15, 1955) and a plea that she be fed.

title: Relatives and Dignitaries Gather To Honor Margaret Rockefeller
description: The bell of St. James Episcopal Church in Manhattan tolled 80 times yesterday as 2,000 family members and friends stood in tribute at a memorial service for Margaret Rockefeller. Mrs. Rockefeller, a philanthropist and the wife of David Rockefeller, the former chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died on March 26 at the age of 80. Five generations of the Rockefeller family occupied the first 16 rows of the church.

title: Herbal Dangers
description: The Food and Drug Administration has issued a warning to consumers that an herb being marketed as a safe alternative to illegal recreational drugs may cause serious health problems, from dizziness to death. The warning is welcome, but more regulatory or Congressional action may be needed.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;French Companies In Deals With China
description: French companies including Elf Aquitaine and Framatome signed new contracts worth $160 million with China. France's biggest oil company, Elf Aquitaine won a 650 million franc ($130 million) contract from Sinochem, a Chinese chemical concern, to export oil to China.

title: Giulianis Earned $303,889
description: Donna Hanover was the principal breadwinner in Gracie Mansion last year, earning substantially more than her husband, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, because of her television and theatrical work.

title: IN PERFORMANCE;CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: New Voices in the Tale Of the Suffering Jester 'Rigoletto' New York City Opera

title: U.S. WILL RETURN BASE IN OKINAWA
description: In a landmark move to scale back the intrusiveness of the American military presence in Japan, the United States agreed tonight to return a major American air base to Japan in five to seven years.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Robert Brustein on April 8 about a plan to provide subsidies to Broadway theaters misattributed a quotation. It was the playwright Robert Anderson who wrote, "You can make a killing in the theater, but not a living."

title: Don't Let Politics Destroy Welfare Agency's Good Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture in Weekend yesterday showing Thomas Hovenden's painting "The Last Moments of John Brown," with an interview with the artist Jacob Lawrence, was reproduced in mirror image. In the painting, John Brown is standing at the right.

title: CUNY 'Vocational' Friction Has National Echo
description: To the Editor:

title: China Reassures Hong Kong's Many Holders of Foreign Passports
description: HONG KONG  Moving on Friday to allay serious concerns about Beijing's stance on nationality laws and residency rights in Hong Kong after July 1, 1997, a senior Chinese official ruled out unequal treatment for local residents holding foreign passports.

title: IN PERFORMANCE;JAZZ
description: A Drummer's Be-Bop Band Sounds Like an Orchestra Paul Motian Sweet Basil

title: COMPANY NEWS;DOCUMENTS FILED WITH S.E.C. FOR REFINANCING
description: Apple Computer, struggling to avoid a financial crisis, announced one step yesterday that would give it additional breathing room. The company said that it had filed documents with the Securities and Exchange Commission reporting that it had successfully extended and refinanced $400 million of short-term loans to its subsidiaries in Japan and the Netherlands. The debt included a $187 million note, due in March, and a $203 million note that was due this month. The computer maker, based in Cupertino, Calif., said that it had extended the loans with new maturity rates ranging from June 28, 1996, to Sept. 29, 1996.

title: Disciples Pay Homage To a Guru of Gumshoes
description: Philip Marlowe was a private eye who operated with the basics: a gun, a bottle of rye and a wisecrack. But how would he fare today, half a century after walking the mean streets of Los Angeles in the novels of Raymond Chandler?

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;State Wants Canadians Back
description: Come to New Jersey, eh? State tourism officials said yesterday they would travel to Canada next week to try to drum up tour business from travel agents, bus tour companies and tour planners in Toronto and Montreal. "It's our largest market, it's easily accessible and it's one that the industry finds it easy to market," said the state tourism director, Linda Mysliwy Conlin. For decades, Canadians, mostly from Quebec, have flocked to Cape May County and the Wildwoods, but the weak buying power of the Canadian dollar has curtailed their travels during the last two years, state officials said. JOE SHARKEY

title: Historian Wins Long Battle To Hear More Nixon Tapes
description: A determined historian won a legal victory today that will lead to the slow but steady release of more than 3,000 hours of secretly recorded Nixon White House tapes.

title: Anne Klein to Close Designer Collection Unit
description: Anne Klein & Company, one of the first American design houses run by a woman to achieve world-class respectability, said yesterday that it would terminate its designer collection division.

title: Richard J. McSorley, a Times Editor, 67
description: Richard J. McSorley, a former deputy makeup editor of The New York Times, died on Thursday at Methodist Medical Center of Oak Ridge, Tenn. He was 67 and lived in Norris, Tenn., since retiring in 1992.

title: Trade Representative Picked As New Commerce Secretary
description: Moving swiftly to fill a Cabinet vacancy created by the death of Ronald H. Brown, President Clinton today appointed one of his most loyal political strategists, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, to fill out Mr. Brown's term as Commerce Secretary.

title: COMPANY NEWS;REYNOLDS METALS TO CLOSE CAN PLANT IN HOUSTON
description: The Reynolds Metals Company, the nation's second-largest aluminum company, said yesterday that it would close its Houston aluminum beverage can manufacturing plant within 12 months, affecting about 200 workers. The Houston-based company will take an after-tax restructuring charge of $23 million in the first quarter, mostly to cover costs for the closing, when it reports earnings on Monday. "Regretfully, we must close the Houston plant because of overcapacity in the U.S. can industry and an anticipated slowdown in the average annual growth rate for aluminum cans from 5 percent to 2 percent," said William Leahey Jr., Reynolds Can division vice president and general manager.

title: Executive Changes
description: SHATTAN GROUP, New York, a newly created private equity firm, will be headed by Thomas S. Shattan, Gregory E. Mendel and G. Kevin Fechtmeyer. The three executives resigned from Prudential Securities Inc., where they had founded and managed the firm's private equities financing business for emerging growth companies. Mr. Shattan had been managing director and group head at Prudential, while Mr. Mendel had been a managing director and Mr. Fechtmeyer a director.

title: Bankruptcy Pressed For Commodity Firm
description: Lehman Brothers Inc., Merrill Lynch & Company and other broker-dealers are trying to force the AIOC Corporation, a New York-based commodities trading group, into Chapter 11 bankruptcy.

title: Two Clinton Loyalists
description: Mickey Kantor moves from his Trade Representative post while Franklin Raines returns to White House duty from a lucrative career on Wall Street. Articles, page 8.

title: Man in the News: Michael Kantor;Always the Hard-Edged Deal Maker
description: Just an hour or so after he landed in Geneva last June for a final showdown with Japan over automobile trade, Mickey Kantor stood in the middle of a vacant United States Government office, swishing a bamboo sword through the air.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Bomb Threat Snarls Air Base
description: A telephoned bomb threat shut down air traffic on both runways at McGuire Air Force Base for several hours yesterday morning. Access to the base was partly restricted as security guards with dogs searched for explosives, the A.P. reported. About 6,000 people work on the base, home to a fleet of C-141 cargo transport aircraft and KC-10 aerial refueling planes. No bomb was found.

title: GOLF;Saturday's Showdown Echoes '90 British Open
description: For the first time since their Saturday showdown in the 1990 British Open, Nick Faldo and Greg Norman will be together in the final pairing of the day in a major championship in Saturday's third round of the Masters.

title: Europe Jobless Rate Rises
description: The European Union said today that its unemployment rate rose to 11 percent in February after being stable in the two previous months. Some 18.3 million people are out of work in the 15-nation bloc.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Daewoo Takes Issue With Polish Duty
description: A dispute over customs duties on car parts imported for assembly in Poland could prompt South Korea's Daewoo Group to pull out of a $1 billion joint venture, a Polish official said yesterday.

title: Helmut Krone, 70, a Creator of Ad Campaigns
description: Helmut Krone, a pioneer of modern advertising, died yesterday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 70.

title: Dow Surges to a 45.52 Gain, Easing Big Losses for Week
description: Stocks broke out of a weeklong slump to end sharply higher yesterday, as a rally in the bond market eased worries about higher interest rates.

title: Horse Racing;3 Final Stepping Stones On Path to the Derby
description: The $500,000 Wood Memorial at Aqueduct, where Unbridled's Song is the early 2-5 favorite in a field of six, will be one of three final dress rehearsals today for the 122d Kentucky Derby on May 4 at Churchill Downs.

title: On Ponies, in Planes, Girl Was Taught to Follow Her Dreams
description: The small buzzing dot in the sky over the gentle green hills circled round and round the farm until Kelly McKnight realized that it was his 7-year-old pony-riding pupil practicing flying a Cessna. "We said, 'That's Jess,' and waved," Mr. McKnight recalled.

title: Once Again, No Safety In Lebanon
description: Before Israeli rockets fell on Beirut today, reproducing the familiar black smoke spirals and sirens of 14 years ago, Mohammed Nasur stood in the deserted streets of his neighborhood in the southern suburbs and peered into the overcast sky.

title: Making Sense of Jessica's Death
description: The death of 7-year-old Jessica Dubroff has obsessed America. There were few park bench conversations, lunchroom discussions or even telephone calls yesterday that did not include an exchange of opinions about the little girl who crashed her plane while trying to become the youngest cross-country pilot ever.

title: Journal;A Falling Starr?
description: In the endless saga of Whitewater, this may be remembered as the week Kenneth Starr blinked.

title: Mary Matalin Pulls Out of Dole Campaign
description: Mary Matalin, the television commentator and Republican operative, withdrew yesterday as a volunteer adviser to Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign after some Republican leaders raised questions about her loyalty because she is married to James Carville, the Clinton political adviser.

title: L.I. Police Find Wife Of Slain Biologist
description: The missing wife of a prominent biologist whose body was bludgeoned and hacked to pieces was found wandering on the grounds of a Long Island research laboratory yesterday, the authorities said.

title: A Gunman's Tale of Fear, Hatred and Drugs
description: An unrepentant Bernhard H. Goetz testified in court for the first time yesterday, coolly describing the events 12 years ago that put him at the center of an international debate over how far an ordinary citizen could go in fighting back against crime.

title: China's Europe Card
description: Prime Minister Li Peng of China and his Trade Minister, Wu Yi, flew to France last week to sign a $1.5 billion deal to buy 10 passenger planes from Airbus Industrie. The purchase, the largest yet for Airbus, a European consortium, follows Ms. Wu's postponement last month of a trip to the United States, where she was expected to announce a $4 billion order from Boeing and McDonnell-Douglas.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LORAL TO SPIN OFF SPACE AND COMMUNICATIONS UNIT
description: The Loral Corporation said yesterday that it would spin off Loral Space and Communications Ltd. on the expiration date of the Lockheed Martin Corporation's $9.1 billion offer to acquire most of Loral. Investors will get one share of Loral Space for every share of Loral they hold before April 22, the company said. The distribution of Loral Space shares is subject to the completed purchase by Lockheed Martin of two-thirds of Loral's 180 million outstanding shares for $38 a share. Lockheed Martin will also pay $344 million, or $7.50 a share, for a 20 percent stake in Loral Space, which will be traded on the New York Stock Exchange beginning April 20.

title: State Dept. Budget Is Vetoed; Clinton Protests Planned Cuts
description: Complaining that the Republican-led Congress was trying to undermine the White House's foreign policy authority, President Clinton today vetoed a $13 billion State Department authorization bill that would have required substantial spending cuts and would have forced Washington to give more political support to Taiwan.

title: Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet Dies; Paris Advertising Giant Was 89
description: Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet, the grade-school dropout who gave France its first advertising agency, its first radio news programs and its first opinion polls before capping his visionary business career with the startling invention of Le Drugstore, died on Thursday at his home in Paris.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Daimler Group Wins Singapore Rail Pact
description: ABB Daimler-Benz Transportation and its partners won a $202.1 million contract yesterday to build Singapore's first light-rail commuter line, opening the door to a possible $850 million of further business.

title: Molecules From Before Birth of Solar System?
description: Cage-like carbon molecules recovered in Canada may have been created before the birth of the solar system, eventually finding their way into a huge meteorite that hit the earth 1.85 billion years ago. Somehow, a team of scientists surmises, these complex molecules survived not only the hostile conditions of interstellar space but also a searing ride to earth.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page contents entry on Wednesday about President Clinton's signing of a bill authorizing a line-item veto referred incompletely to the political significance. Besides being a triumph for Mr. Clinton, the signing was a victory for many Congressional Republicans.

title: POP REVIEW;Some Things Change; Not Besotted Abandon
description: A Pogues concert is a lesson in entropy. On Thursday night at the Supper Club, as the Celtic- and punk-influenced rock band's set progressed, disorder began to reign as energy dwindled. By the end of the show, James McNally was walking around the stage with his accordion balanced on his head, Darryl Hunt was rapping on a beer bottle instead of playing the bass and Spider Stacy was haranguing audience members and omitting entire verses from songs.

title: Fans Campaign to Keep Whalers in Hartford
description: This February, Mike Seaver had the best month ever at his downtown Hartford restaurant, Chuck's Steak House. Events at the Hartford Civic Center included a flower show, a University of Connecticut basketball game, a Rod Stewart concert and five Hartford Whalers hockey games.

title: Library Treasures Rarely Out of Dresden
description: On May 3, 1849, Robert Schumann was working at his home in Dresden on a piece of music set to a poem by Frederick Schiller when he put down his pen because, as he wrote across the bottom of the score, he had been "interrupted by alarm bells."

title: COMPANY NEWS;JUDGE ENTERS $211.2 MILLION JUDGMENT AGAINST FLEMING
description: A judge in Cleburne, Tex., entered a $211.2 million judgment against the Fleming Companies yesterday after court-ordered mediation failed to produce a settlement with a former customer, David's Supermarkets Inc. Judge C. C. Cooke entered the judgment in state court against the Oklahoma City-based supermarket supplier two weeks after a jury found Fleming defrauded the closely held David's by overstating its costs in a cost-plus supply contract. Fleming immediately posted a $230 million bond to cover the cost of the judgment and a year's interest.

title: Walesa May Get Pension
description: Former President Lech Walesa, who says money problems drove him back to his old job at the Gdansk shipyard, may finally be granted a pension by the Polish Government.

title: Leasing Of Schools Is Focus Of Inquiry
description: A grand jury is expected soon to begin hearing evidence of possible profiteering by landlords and conflicts of interest in a $170 million school-leasing program by the New York City Board of Education, investigators said yesterday.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Adds to a Week of Gains As a Firm U.S. Economy Is Seen
description: The dollar rose against the German mark and Swiss franc, helped by perceptions that the United States economy remains strong relative to its European rivals.

title: Life of Seclusion Continues, Under Watch
description: Theodore J. Kaczynski, the Unabom suspect who embraced isolation in his tiny mountain cabin, now spends his days reading and writing in a 7-by-10 foot cell at the Lewis and Clark County Jail, watched round the clock through bulletproof glass.

title: About New York;How Sexual Crimes Ripple Outward
description: JOSEPH SMALLS doesn't work at Saks Fifth Avenue anymore. He used to be a plainclothes security guard there, keeping an eye on suspicious types who might try to sneak out with fancy clothes.

title: Archer Said To Be in Talks On U.S. Case
description: The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company has entered into substantive negotiations with the Justice Department to settle potential criminal charges of price-fixing, people involved in the case said yesterday.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Texas Instruments Has Steep Drop in Profit
description: Hurt by falling prices for memory chips and lower royalty payments, Texas Instruments Inc. reported a sharp drop in first-quarter earnings yesterday.

title: Weicker Declines Bid for Presidency
description: Former Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut, who had been considering running for the Presidency as an independent, has decided not to enter the race.

title: Man in the News: Franklin Delano Raines;Moving From Big Money to Politics
description: When Franklin D. Raines was asked by the Boeing Company to join its board last year, he answered that it would be a great honor -- and that by the way, he had a personal connection to the giant aircraft company: his mother had worked for years cleaning its offices in Seattle.

title: Environmentalists Fault Mutual Funds
description: Flush with cash, mutual funds are seeing green, but Co-op America, a Washington group that promotes socially conscious investing, contends that they are not investing green.

title: A Mall by Any Other NameCan Good Vibes Sell Elvis Busts and CubanFood?
description: Shaheen Sadeghi owns a shopping strip here, where he makes a sweet living providing space to hip stores that cater to shoppers in their 20's.

title: HOCKEY;The Rangers' Loss Could Be the Devils' Demise
description: The Devils and their fans can't accuse the Rangers of tanking it last night at Madison Square Garden. Many of their injured players returned and it wouldn't be fair to criticize the effort of the home team, which put forth its best effort of the week.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Van Gundy Remembers Lessons In Loyalty
description: He is on the other side now, which is why he expects neither a pre-game handshake nor a polite yet hollow discourse moments before tip-off in a cramped Miami Arena corridor. You coach under Pat Riley for four seasons, you know the rules.

title: Yahoo Gets Big Welcome On Wall Street
description: Yahoo Inc., named to celebrate the rowdy culture of the Internet, found a warm welcome on staid Wall Street yesterday. Investors, undaunted by Yahoo's lack of profits and formidable array of competitors, gave the young company a first-day market valuation of nearly $1 billion.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Hanoi-Conoco Oil Pact Reopens Island Dispute
description: Vietnam and China restated competing claims to the Spratley Islands today, after Hanoi announced a deal with Conoco Inc. to explore for oil in the area.

title: Facing Split Over China, Dole Delays Asia Policy Speech
description: When Senator Bob Dole was invited weeks ago to give the keynote address at a dinner at the Richard Nixon Library in Yorba Linda, Calif., it looked like a made-to-order occasion for him to unveil his Asia policy.

title: Observer;Down And Out
description: The upmounting volume of outsourcing in ongoing downsizing circles has Mr. Barton V. fuming. "Where do they get these words?" he asks, referring to "outsourcing" in a letter I have culled from the incoming mail.

title: Top Editor Will Leave Magazine
description: Andrew Sullivan, the editor of The New Republic, announced yesterday that he would step down from his post at the end of May.

title: BOMBER MANIFESTO AMID ITEMS FOUND, LAW OFFICIALS SAY
description: Federal law-enforcement officials said today that agents searching Theodore J. Kaczynski's Montana cabin had found the original typewritten manuscript of the Unabomber's 35,000-word manifesto, a powerful piece of evidence that has convinced the authorities that they have the long-sought serial terrorist.

title: 17.4 Million in Grants To Save Fragile Books
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities has awarded 90 grants totaling $17.4 million to help libraries preserve and microfilm brittle books. A grant of $1 million went to the New York Public Library to preserve, repair and microfilm more than 8,000 books on the societies of the Americas.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Puckett's Vision Woes
description: KIRBY PUCKETT still hopes to play this year, although his doctor said yesterday that it could be weeks or months before the Minnesota Twins' 36-year-old outfielder fully regains vision in his ailing right eye.

title: No Headline
description: I have never turned down anything this President has asked me to do."

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: In his column yesterday, A. M. Rosenthal misspelled the surname of the winner of the 1996 Pulitzer Prize for feature photography. Her name is Stephanie Welsh.

title: Assembly Leaders Block Transit Spending Plan
description: In a struggle over the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's long-term spending plans, including whether to rebuild the Franklin Avenue Shuttle, State Assembly leaders yesterday blocked $300 million in changes that the M.T.A. wants to make in its capital-spending program.

title: Amoco Oil Discovery
description: An unit of the Amoco Corporation in Trinidad said today that an exploratory well was producing 3,700 barrels of oil and oil products a day and about 64 million cubic feet of natural gas. The Trinidad Oil Company said it had drilled its East Mayoro 5X exploration well off the Caribbean island's east coast to 15,163 feet. The well encountered 1,700 feet of hydrocarbon-bearing sands.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;For Princeton, Valet Parking
description: Now somebody will locate that elusive downtown parking space for you -- for a fee. Public valet parking is coming to Princeton after the town passed legislation this week setting aside a curbside valet-parking zone in front of Lahiere's restaurant on Witherspoon Street. During a six-month trial period, any licensed valet service can solicit cars in the zone, provided the service is first-come, first-served, without preference for any restaurant or shop. The system is expected to begin operating within two weeks.

title: BOXING;Whitaker Keeps Title With a Split Decision
description: He tried clowning when boxing would not work, but Pernell Whitaker still managed, barely, to hold onto his welterweight championship tonight against a cautious Wilfredo Rivera -- who fooled him by switching to a southpaw style.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Faust's Old Biergarten Now a Big Wine Boite
description: A 16th-century tavern made famous by Goethe's classic work, Faust, reopened today as an upscale restaurant.

title: CUNY 'Vocational' Friction Has National Echo
description: To the Editor:

title: Labor Deals Major's Tories A New Blow In Local Vote
description: Trimming the Conservative Party majority to a single seat, the Labor Party scored an unexpectedly large victory in a parliamentary election on Thursday, snatching a seat in the Staffordshire South-East local election.

title: BASEBALL: YANKEES NOTEBOOK;Good News for Key and Wetteland
description: The uneasiness over Jimmy Key's left shoulder that had hovered over the Yankees after he left Thursday's game in the sixth inning with stiffness dissipated somewhat yesterday as Key breezed through his exercise routine and declared himself ready to make his next start, on Tuesday in Milwaukee.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EL PASO NATURAL GAS SET TO REALIGN ITS BUSINESSES
description: The El Paso Natural Gas Company said yesterday that it would realign its operations into three businesses and change its name to the El Paso Energy Corporation. El Paso Natural Gas said its Natural Gas Transmission business unit would retain the name El Paso Natural Gas Company and be responsible for all regulated pipeline assets and activities including the EPG Mainline, the Mojave Pipeline and the company's interest in the Trans-Colorado pipeline project. A new company, with headquarters in Houston, will be formed to oversee the company's field and merchant services activities under the names El Paso Field Services and El Paso Merchant Services Group. The third business unit will be the El Paso Energy International Company.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Invitations to Passion of a Certain Kind
description: Sex symbols and would-be sex symbols proffered four hours of come-ons at Nassau Coliseum tonight. R. Kelly, LL Cool J, Xscape and Solo all promised satisfaction and demonstrated their know-how with swiveling hips. Now and then, they were willing to vow undying love.

title: Make Brooklyn a World-Class Seaport
description: The Port of New York and New Jersey has a lemon on its hands. Millions of cubic yards of riverborne mud contaminated by toxins are clogging New York Harbor's channels and docks. Some large ships cannot enter fully loaded and must put part of their cargo on barges first.

title: Israel and Militants Trade Blows As Fighting Spreads in Lebanon
description: The war of attrition between Israel and Lebanese guerrillas swelled today as Lebanese Islamic militants showered Katyusha rockets on northern Israel and Israeli guns and gunships struck anew across Lebanon.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Judge Warns Irvin
description: The judge in MICHAEL IRVIN's drug possession case has said the Dallas Cowboys receiver is close to violating a gag order. Judge MANNY ALVAREZ said Irvin is "getting very close" to causing more trouble for himself by speaking generally about the case in several recent interviews.

title: Tirana Journal;Dictator Liked Bunkers. My, They Mushroomed!
description: There is paranoia. And then there was Enver Hoxha's brand of paranoia.

title: BASEBALL;9th-Inning Comeback Falls Short For Mets
description: If Coors Field is a hitter's park, then somebody forgot to tell the Mets until it was too late. While the Colorado Rockies used back-to-back home runs by Larry Walker and Andres Galarraga to fuel their offense, the Mets waited until the ninth inning to put a decent rally together and suffered a 6-5 loss for their sixth defeat in their last seven games.

title: Three Lawyers Start a Fund To Assist an Embattled Judge
description: Even as a state commission continues to investigate a Brooklyn Criminal Court judge for his handling of domestic violence cases, a group of lawyers has established a fund to help raise money for the judge's defense.

title: BASEBALL;Yankees Turn Cone's Gem Into Nail-Biter
description: David Cone acted like an indomitable and indestructible toy placed inside a room with inferior and ineffective toys who quickly started looking for somewhere to hide. Wind Cone up, watch him march confidently to the mound and observe as he dominated the hitters.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;State Sells Its Health Plan
description: The Whitman administration will sell New Jersey's Garden State Health Plan to the AmeriChoice Corporation for $15 million, officials said yesterday.

title: Treasury Prices Surge as Inflation Fear Ebbs
description: Treasury prices staged their biggest rally in nearly 10 months yesterday after economic reports suggested the economy was growing at a pace too slow to cause inflation to accelerate.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Scores Return
description: Out-of-town baseball updates were back on the Riverfront Stadium scoreboard yesterday after the Cincinnati Reds renewed their Sports Ticker service.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CONCERNS VOICED ON UNION PACIFIC ACQUISITION
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that the Union Pacific Corporation's proposed $3.9 billion acquisition of the Southern Pacific Rail Corporation raised "significant competitive concerns." The department, in comments filed with the Surface Transportation Board, said the proposed deal would hurt a large number of markets throughout the West, where the number of rail carrier competitors would decline and could result in price increases of roughly $800 million for shippers and consumers. The volume of commerce affected is more than $6 billion. The department said the railways' plan to grant more than 3,800 miles of track rights to the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corporation "appears to be inadequate to prevent rate increases."

title: 2 Marines Who Refused to Comply With Genetic-Testing Order Face aCourt-Martial
description: Two marines are to be court-martialed in Hawaii on Monday for refusing to comply with the military's program of mandatory genetic testing, the first major test of a practice that experts say is growing rapidly in the private sector as well.

title: New Jersey Has Plan To Lure the Yankees
description: The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority has given the New York Yankees' principal owner, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, plans for a stadium in New Jersey to house the team after the lease for its current home in the Bronx expires in 2002, according to officials of the state and the Yankees organization.

title: Federal Appeals Court Rejects A Challenge to 'Megan's Law'
description: The first Federal appeals court to consider a New Jersey law calling for community notification about paroled sex offenders rejected an offender's challenge to the law yesterday. But the ruling was so limited that it failed to resolve the debate over the constitutionality of the law.

title: Cellstar Shares Tumble
description: The stock of the Cellstar Corporation tumbled today, a day after the company, a wholesale distributor and retailer of cellular telephones, said it might post a first-quarter loss. The stock fell $2.50, to $6.125, on the Nasdaq. The company, based here, said Thursday that its earnings would be signicantly below analysts' consensus estimate of $6.122 million, or 32 cents a share, for the quarter ended Feb. 29.

title: 1970's: Jan 22, 1978;A Dissident's Place, East and West
description: Unless a synthesis, so to speak, of Marx and Jefferson can be achieved, Communism may solidify permanently into the greatest prison of the mind the world has ever seen, far more oppressive than the so-called Dark Ages of medieval Europe. Bad as clerical repression was, there was more debate and diversity then, especially in the 12th century, than in the Soviet Union or China today. . . .

title: 1950's: Feb. 26, 1956;Would It Still Be Brooklyn?
description: The tactless remark that New York can spare the Dodgers as easily as it can the Third Avenue El represents a school of thought that has always associated the Brooks with declasse phenomena like El lines, cobblestones and walk-up rooming houses. It has its source in the 1920's, when the Dodgers were undeniably a squalid lot, who instinctively finished sixth each season. But the counsels of adversity built up strong, useful, loving qualities in Brooklyn fans: patience, eloquence, resourcefulness, patriotism, hero-worship.

title: Swirling Around Unabom Suspect, an Environmental Dispute
description: In the last half-dozen years that Theodore J. Kaczynski has lived his solitary, lonely life just outside this rugged mountain hamlet, a plan to gouge out one of the biggest open-pit gold mines has bitterly divided the people here.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;Transfer Point Becomes Flash Point
description: Subway travel is about to become a lot more complicated for the 56,000 people each day who make the East Side transfer between the No. 6 train and the E or F trains. For many, it could become more expensive as well.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Wyoming plane crash that killed a 7-year-old pilot misattributed comments that legislation to prohibit children from flying planes was a bad idea. That position was taken by Phil Boyer of the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association, who said that "the rules that the F.A.A. has set up adequately covered this flight," not David R. Hinson, the Federal Aviation Administrator.

title: LESSONS;Hate and How To Counter It
description: In December 1993, a stone crashed through the window of Isaac Schnitzer's bedroom in Billings, Mont. A menorah had been in the window, and the stone sent a powerful message: Jews aren't welcome here.

title: Rent-Free Village Space May End for Gallery
description: THERE have been no pointed fingers, bitter accusations or angry outbursts, but a separation still looms between the Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson and the village here.

title: Sports of The Times;Owners Display New York Colors
description: IT is a long way from East Third Street and Beverly Road to Churchill Downs. Straight out of Kings County, with a stopover in Queens, Ernie Paragallo heads for Louisville now as the overwhelming favorite for horse racing's crowning moment.

title: The Early Years: Aug. 15, 1897;The Newport Of Long Island
description: Into the peaceful hamlet of Southampton, "hallowed by pure lives and peaceful deaths," there came one Summer day over a quarter of a century ago, in search of rest and cool ocean breezes, Dr. T. Gaillard Thomas of New York . . . The little village with its old-time charm had fascinations for the physician . . . , but greater fascinations he found in the purity of the air, the dry and healthy soil, and the perennial breezes which blew continually, and, no matter from which quarter they came, brought coolness and health with them. Dr. Thomas studied the conditions of the atmosphere of the place, and before another year had come planned the erection of a Summer home about the centre of the east bank of Agawam Lake.

title: April 7-13;The Power of No
description: President Clinton, who waited more than 29 months in office before vetoing his first bill, has learned to say no. Last week he blocked a bill, backed by the Republican-controlled Congress, that would have banned a form of late-term abortion. The procedure involves partly extracting the fetus from the birth canal and then collapsing its skull with suction. Abortion opponents contend it is infanticide; abortion rights advocates say it is only used in rare cases of severe fetal abnormalities, or to protect the life of the mother.

title: 1950's: Aug. 8, 1954;The Cold War at Home and Abroad
description: Certainly it is apparent to all that the very foundation of American assistance in Indochina rested upon a miscalculation of the military program of the French Union forces and the success of the Navarre Plan. Certainly it is apparent to all that our State Department, under both Democratic and Republican leadership, failed to recognize the nature and significance of the independence movement in Indochina, and consistently misled the American people -- although not the people of Indochina -- as to the degree of freedom granted by the French.

title: DANCE;An American Approach to the Steps of Old Ireland
description: YOU COULD FIND Donald Golden's School of Irish Dance with your eyes closed. From the corner of 76th Street and Fifth Avenue in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, you hear the raucous rhythms of Irish "hard shoes" battering a floor somewhere. This beat leads to the door of Bay Ridge Manor, a banquet center, then downstairs to a mirrored dining room with sparkling ceilings and huge chandeliers. What you see underfoot, at first, is flowered carpeting, but what you hear is the loud tapping.

title: SPENDING IT;Simpler Times Had A Simpler Form
description: The tax wasn't exactly flat, and the required form wasn't exactly a postcard, but that was the general shape of things when the income tax was first levied in this country. This original tax form, for 1913, looks like what some proponents of tax reform would like to see today.

title: WOMEN: May 23, 1993;Is Hillary Clinton Running The White House?
description: There actually is, as the mists of New Age mysticism slip away, a clear line to Mrs. Clinton's message. It is, fundamentally, an old and very American message, one that goes purposely beyond the normal boundaries of politics into the territory of religion. It is concerned not just with how government should behave but with how people should. It is the message of values, not programs. It is the message of the preacher. . . .

title: When Trains Stop, Work Begins
description: The subway cleaner pushed a ragged mop across the car's filthy threshold, a weary gesture that might have had symbolic value if anyone had been on the dim platform to see it.

title: Clinton Challenges Congress to Pass Terrorism Bill He'd Approve
description: President Clinton called on Congress today to pass an anti-terrorist bill that has languished for a year despite a promise of quick action after the Oklahoma City bombing.

title: COPING;A Postcard From Morgan's Twilight World
description: MORGAN GELBLUM, pale and pretty, lies slackly in her father's arms, smiling up into his beard. Is she smiling at his loving prattle or at something only she can hear? He begins to croon and she croons back, which delights him. Morgan is responding; Morgan is finding pleasure in her narrow, twilight world.

title: WOMEN: Aug. 26, 1923;The Amazonian Revival
description: You have the ballot," said mere man back in 1920. "Now what?" Three years have passed. The net results of suffrage are three or four Congresswomen, most of them recalled after a single term; one Senator who held office for a day, and Mrs. Belmont, the Twentieth Century Amazon, whose slogan is "Down With the Men." To quote her:

title: F.Y.I.
description: Lions on Guard

title: WEDDINGS;Emily Hartman, Kevin V. Cox
description: Emily Ames Hartman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerard K. Hartman of Larchmont, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Kevin Vandernoot Cox, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis M. Cox 3d, also of Larchmont. The Rev. Joseph DeSanto performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Augustine.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: EARNING IT;Going for the Green: The New Jobs of Summer '96
description: IF you are a college student who has put off finding a summer job, you would often be out of luck this late -- especially if your goal is interesting work. This year, though, some procrastinators may be off the hook, thanks to a few one-of-a-kind opportunities.

title: The Nation;Your Tax Cut Is in the Mail . . .
description: INCOME taxes are due tomorrow, and tonight many of you will labor at the dining-room table, awash in old mortgage statements, pecking at the calculator, cursing silently at the insatiable Federal maw. Then you'll write us a check.

title: Race and Rights: Aug. 31, 1986;Hiding the Stress of Black Success
description: There are a bunch of us black men between the ages of 39 and 45 who share the bond of being in the first generation that took full advantage of the civil rights laws of 1963-65.

title: 1990's: Aug. 15, 1993;The Anguished Politics Of Breast Cancer
description: How many angry women does it take to make a revolution? Inspired by AIDS activists in the 1980's, women with breast cancer are turning scores of support groups into a national political advocacy movement. . . . The energy that drives them is anger. They say they've had it with politicians and physicians and scientists who "there, there" them with studies and statistics and treatments that suggest the disease is under control.

title: A Fordham Student Is Raped and Beaten
description: A 21-year-old woman was beaten, raped and left critically injured in the Fordham section of the Bronx early Saturday, the police said.

title: Marlboro Man Doesn't Deserve Honor;Secondhand Smoke
description: To the Editor:

title: Money Arriving Soon for Summer Job Programs
description: Cities and towns trying to set up summer jobs programs for poor youths will have to scramble because the $625 million from the Federal Government to pay for them are just becoming available after being held up by the budget fight.

title: 59th Victim of Bombings
description: An Israeli man died today of wounds suffered in one of four recent attacks by Islamic suicide bombers directed against Israelis.

title: New Releases
description: CHARLIE HADEN AND QUARTET WEST: 'NOW IS THE HOUR' Verve/Gitanes Jazz

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Giants Linebackers: Glory Is Gone
description: There was a time, not so long ago, when teams were simply scared to play the Giants. They looked at their linebackers, they saw people like Harry Carson and Lawrence Taylor, and they stayed up late finding ways to stop them. But in a lot of instances, calling the psychic hot line might have worked just as well.

title: ATLANTA 1996: Olympic Profile;Love Conquers All, Eventually
description: Hello."

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: April 14, 1996
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction

title: Hispanic Rights Chief Quits Clinton Panel
description: A leading Hispanic civil rights advocate has resigned from a Presidential commission on Hispanic education, declaring that it had become too entangled in partisan politics and had lost its independence.

title: SIGNOFF;No Supers, No Sign-Offs, No Changes
description: IT has been two years now since one Charles replaced another on "Sunday Morning" on CBS, two years since Charles Osgood's bow-tied staccato supplanted Charles Kuralt's folksy Carolina cadences. The show still opens with the same vaguely classical trumpet music and still closes with a one- to three-minute nature segment: woods, fields or streams presented without narration from the Charles in the studio. And the easel that serves as the anchor desk is still tilted at the same almost-perpendicular angle as when Mr. Kuralt filled the tall chair next to it.

title: Improper Bostonian
description: THE WHITE BLACKBIRD A Life of the Painter Margarett Sargent by Her Granddaughter. By Honor Moore. Illustrated. 371 pp. New York: Viking. $29.95.

title: 1990's: Dec. 1, 1991;Grady's Gift
description: GRADY SHOWED UP ONE DAY at our house at 1409 Fifth Avenue West in Birmingham, and by and by she changed the way I saw the world. I was 7 when she came to iron and clean and cook for $18 a week, and she stayed for seven years. . . .

title: WOMEN: July 5, 1936;Is Eleanor Roosevelt Running The White House?
description: Whatever the outcome of this year's Presidential campaign it will probably not shake the poise of a certain lady who is one of Franklin D. Roosevelt's most ardent admirers, and who has herself made no small contribution to history during the past three years.

title: Israel and Guerrillas Joined Again in Deadly Dance
description: If there was anything surprising about Israel's offensive against Shiite Muslim guerrillas in Lebanon, it was only the timing. Otherwise, the operation has been a dance whose steps are sadly familiar.

title: ON THE STREET;Making Heads Turn
description: Come springtime, the creative force of milliners is a sight to see in New York and Paris. On Fifth Avenue, women saved their finest for Easter Sunday and families wore their flowered hats to church, but they were nearly eclipsed by the carnival-like headdresses that dominated the parade. Two girls (above) appeared in a hat contest at Tavern on the Green. Earlier, during New York fashion week, two women (near left and top right) showed off hats by the London designer Philip Treacy while another (near right) preferred something from the 1940's. In Paris, hats are also worn to grab attention, like the doll-size, feathered one (far left) from the late 1930's and the fedora (top left), which was draped with yarn that resembled spaghetti and was secured on the side with a knife and fork.

title: Tongues Untied
description: THE DEATH OF DISCOURSE By Ronald K. L. Collins and David M. Skover. 294 pp. Boulder, Colo.: Westview Press/ HarperCollins Publishers. Cloth, $49.95. Paper, $16.95. WE'VE all heard people casually invoke the First Amendment, usually when they're restricted in some way they don't like -- and usually in technical ignorance of what the amendment actually covers (as in, "Today I told my boss he's a jerk. But I'm protected, because I was exercising my rights under the First Amendment, you know, free speech").

title: A Town Learns Tragedy Knows No Borders
description: EVERY day now, the family of Police Officer Michael Frey and residents here struggle to make sense of something they may never understand. It has been three and a half weeks since the 29-year-old policeman was gunned down by a crazed resident in what started out as a routine call and ended as a tragedy.

title: No Exit
description: LIVE GIRLS By Beth Nugent. 198 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.

title: 1990's: Aug. 22, 1993;The Devil in Long Island
description: What the hell happened? What happened to the incredibly boring place I grew up in, where I swear nothing ever happened? What happened to turn it into this charnel house of sensational spouse slayings; fatally attracted judges posing as lowlife, blackmailing private eyes sending condoms to mistresses' daughters; cold-blooded, steroid-juiced young killers; kidnappers with dungeons; horticultural serial killers? A veritable Babylon and not the colorless stop on the L.I.R.R. right after Amityville, Copiague and Lindenhurst, but a Babylon out of the Book of Revelation, the blood-drenched Mother of Abominations.

title: A Modern Stone Age Family
description: Francine Prose's most recent novel is "Hunters and Gatherers." Two novellas will be published next fall as "Guided Tours of Hell."

title: Michael Werboff, 99, Portraitist Whose Subjects Included Kings
description: Michael A. Werboff, a Russian-born portraitist whose subjects included royalty and captains of industry as well as writers and artists, died on April 4 at his home in Manhattan. He was 99.

title: Key Mandela Aide to Join Group Promoting Investment by Blacks
description: Cyril Ramaphosa, widely considered a possible successor to President Nelson Mandela, said today that he would be leaving the South African Government to become a senior executive in a business conglomerate.

title: Vietnam: Nov. 4, 1962, Saigon;The Yankee Invasion
description: In the mountainous territory north of here, where the brush seems to grow in three thick levels -- foot-level brush, shoulder-level brush and tree-level brush -- there is a tendency for Communist guerillas to consider the terrain their own and a tendency for Vietnamese officers to agree. It is nightmare country, a scenic, brutal haven for the irregulars, but hated by government regulars who sense ambushes all around them. Recently American and Vietnamese officials, in an attempt to change the pattern of the war in the north, designed a new tactic: The idea was to strike quickly into the heart of the mountains, defy the laws of guerilla warfare (the laws say you don't attack the enemy unless you have a 7-to-1 manpower edge, but here it should be more like 10-to-1), hit a larger enemy force by surprise, tear him up -- and run like hell. . . .

title: 1940's: March 9, 1941 Washington;Roosevelt on the Way to War
description: In the crowded Oval Room in the White House where the President works, talks and relaxes in the hours he does not spend in the executive offices, there is a long shelf holding an odd and interesting assortment of unpublished volumes. They are books written for him within the past eight years and consist for the most part of studies, surveys and blueprints of projects he has considered or hoped to realize. In a general way they may be said to represent the unfinished business of the New Deal.

title: 1940's: May 25, 1947;On Americans
description: In the United States one is always concerned to find out what an individual does, and not what he is; one takes it for granted that he is nothing but what he has done or may do; his purely inner reality is regarded with indifference, if, indeed, any note is taken of it. A man to be respected is one who has done things that have value.

title: Lilco Under Fire for Warnings on Rate Increases
description: OFFICIALS and private groups are attacking statements by Lilco that an immediate cut in electric rates could undermine its finances and force higher rates next year.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Security Flaws Found At Athens Airport
description: Security measures at Hellenikon International Airport in Athens do not meet international standards, the United States Department of Transportation said last month.

title: 1950's: Oct. 4, 1953;What Every Budding Architect Should Know
description: The proposed new building for the Guggenheim Museum, which you see in my drawing at the top of the page, is the latest sense of organic architecture. Here we are not building a cellular composition of compartments, but one where all is one great space on a single continuous floor.

title: A Chinese Herb And Vested Interests
description: To the Editor:

title: INVESTING IT;On-Line Trading Takes Off
description: CALL your broker! For clients of discount brokerage houses, that phrase may become as old-fashioned as button your shoes.

title: An April Day. 51 Years Ago. War in Italy.
description: For Bob Dole, April 14, 1945, is a date which will in infamy.

title: Make Big Hollywood $$ in the Comfort of Your Home
description: IN Hollywood's jargon, Susan Gardner's home was discovered. A film scout scouring the neighborhood for the ideal crime scene knocked on her door and asked if she wanted to transform her home into a stage set and reap a few thousand dollars for the bother.

title: INSIDE
description: An Insurer to Benefit

title: NEW JERSEY & CO.;Dairy Strike Drags On: There's Milk but Definitely No Honey
description: At the beginning of the year, Lisa Grouoig was wearing a gray uniform and a white apron as a housekeeper at a Manhattan hotel. Now she wears a technician's white laboratory coat as she tests milk samples for bacteria and fat at Farmland Dairies.

title: Vietnam: Nov. 5, 1967, Rachkien, South Vietnam;THE MEN OF THIRD SQUAD, SECOND PLATOON, C COMPANY, THIRD BATTALION
description: Maska's squad got in from the field at 7:30 on a Sunday morning. They had been out for three days and their uniforms were coated with gray paddy mud. The first thing they did after breakfast was take showers. The water was cold. They read their mail. Richie Hill's wife kept asking for a pair of Vietnamese sandals. "My old lady wonders why I can't send her no shoes home." he said. "Where the hell I'm gonna get them? She must think I'm in Saigon."

title: CLASSICAL VIEW;A Prophet Finds Honor At Home
description: EXPLOSION MARKED THE PROGRESS OF American Symphony Orchestras in the 1960's and 70's. Implosion may get them as far as the 21st century. The hand-wringing over shrinking audiences, alienated communities and philanthropic resistance has been recited often in these pages. From the National Endowment for the Arts, however, trickles better news: that specific solutions for specific places may exist.

title: ON PRO FOOTBALL;Looking Out for No. 1: For Jets, Real Riches May Lie in Making a Deal
description: The Jets, by virtue of their failings ast season, own the No. 1 pick in the National Football League draft next Saturday. Here is an opportunity for a team that has operated under a rain cloud for the past 25 years to strike a bold blow for a bright future.

title: Turning 50, Songwriter Sings About Life
description: Loudon Wainwright 3d is turning 50 this year.

title: 1990's: Nov. 28, 1993;Whatever Happened to AIDS?
description: I have come to the realization that I will almost certainly die of AIDS. I have wavered on that point. When the disease was first diagnosed in early 1991, I was sure I would die -- and soon. I was facing brain surgery; the surgeons discovered an infection often fatal in four months. I would shortly develop pneumonia, then blood clots. I was hospitalized four times over five months. But by the end of that year, I thought differently. My health rebounded, almost certainly because of AZT. I was doing so well; I really might beat it. Now, it is clear I will not. You can beat the statistics only so long. My T-cell count, which was only 2 when I got my diagnosis, has never gone above 30 -- a dangerously low level. I have lived longer than the median survival time by 10 months. The treatments simply are not there. They are not even in the pipeline. A miracle is possible, of course. And for a long time, I thought one would happen. But let's face it, a miracle isn't going to happen. One day soon I will simply become one of the 90 people in America to die that day of AIDS. It's like knowing I will be killed by a speeding car, but not knowing when or where.

title: Race and Rights: Nov. 8, 1992;If Welfare Doesn't Work, Then How Did I Get Here?
description: When I walk down the streets of my Harlem neighborhood, I see women like my mother, hustling, struggling, walking their children to school and walking them back home. And I also see women who have lost both energy and faith, talking loud, hanging out. I see the shadow men of a new generation, floating by with a few dollars and a toy, then drifting away to the shelters they call home. And I see, a dozen times a day, the little girls my sister and I used to be, the little boys my brothers once were.

title: No Headline
description: You could hurt someone if you didn't know what you were doing. You've got to be esthetically perfect to be an octopus thrower."

title: Ideas & Trends;Like Revenue All Over Again
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has said that even though a new stadium on the West Side of Manhattan would likely be the most expensive in the nation's history, it could nevertheless be built at little or no cost to the city's taxpayers. Money could be raised, he said, through ticket sales and advertising revenue, among other things. Because such promises have at times proved difficult to keep, here are some suggestions to make up for any shortfall. ADAM BRYANT * Have the ushers play "squeegee men" at new stadium. After wiping down your seat, they don't go away until you give them $2. City gets 50 percent.

title: At Calexico, U.S.A., 'Drugs Flow Through Here All the Time'
description: Nearly every day, before and since President Clinton certified on March 1 that Mexico was a cooperative partner in the fight against drugs, smugglers cross the border around here, through miles of desert scrub and onto isolated highways, with load upon load of narcotics.

title: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;O.K., Save the Whales, But Spare My Mailbox
description: OUR accountant liked to think he was as jaded as any of his colleagues; he prided himself on having "seen it all." It was thus with a bit of satisfaction that I showed him our charity list for last year and watched his eyes bulge. Where in past years he had seen only a lump sum, he could now behold in precise detail our contributions to almost a hundred different organizations devoted to the betterment of man, the relief of misery and the preservation of the better parts of this planet as we know it.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Skies Now Friendlier Between U.S., Germany
description: The United States and Germany have signed an agreement to drop restrictions on air travel between and within the two countries. When finalized, the open-skies agreement will give any United States or German airline freedom to serve any route in either country. There will be no government control over fares, capacity or frequency of service.

title: 1970's: July 22, 1973;The Story So Far
description: It was late spring 1973; a special Watergate prosecutor was named, Senate hearings were beginning and Richard Nixon's Presidency was doomed.

title: Broadway: May 17, 1992;Gray's Anatomy
description: This originally appeared in the Magazine as a work in progress and formed the basis for "Gray's Anatomy," which opened in 1993 at the Vivian Beaumonth Theater.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Exhibit on Centennial Of Film in Rome
description: The 100th anniversary of film is being celebrated in Rome with an exhibition that will run until Dec. 31. Named "The City of Cinema; the First 100 Years of Italian Cinema," the exhibition is at Rome's Cinecitta, a leading European movie studio from the mid-50's to the mid-60's.

title: WEDDINGS;Andrea Pomerantz, Matthew Lustig
description: Andrea Gayle Pomerantz, a magazine editor, and Matthew Joseph Lustig, an investment banker, are to be married today in New York. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein is to perform the ceremony at the Hotel Pierre.

title: 1990's: Aug. 6, 1995;They Were a Happy Family in Sarajevo. Then Came War.
description: The Sarajevo mortuary is unrefrigerated this fourth summer of the siege because there is no electricity in the city, so the stench of bodies is often pungent. The smell seeps out of the tiled morgue into the small room of peeling paint and sagging plants where the records of the dead are kept. The names -- 3,060 in 1992, 3,091 in 1993 and 1,797 in 1994 -- are written in a spidery script across page after page of frayed ledgers: a dry chronicle of a European war and a city's dismemberment.

title: April 7-13;The Unabomber's Pen Pal?
description: Last week, as a New Jersey prosecutor was named to coordinate the Unabomber case, a Mexican farmhand opened a window into the mind of Theodore Kaczynski, the Harvard-trained mathematician who is suspected of being the Unabomber and who was the farmhand's pen pal.

title: Lost Character
description: To the Editor:

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;Rutgers Grads Give a Lesson
description: Rutgers's football team met its past and learned how far it has to go.

title: Martha Keehn Social Worker, 73
description: Martha Keehn, a social worker in India and Africa, died on April 5 at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. She was 73 and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Ritual Encounters
description: THE BRAZEN SERPENT By Eilean Ni Chuilleanain. 47 pp. Winston-Salem, N.C.: Wake Forest University Press. Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $7.95.

title: April 7-13;A Small Pilot Dies
description: The girl was 7 years old, she just loved to pilot airplanes from atop her red booster seat, and she pulled at the nation's heart when she died Thursday in a Wyoming plane crash while she attempted to set a record as the youngest person to fly an airplane across the United States.

title: Loyalty Betrayed
description: Through ethnic discrimination tacitly approved by its Muslim-dominated Government, the Bosnian Army has "cleansed" its officer corps of almost all non-Muslims. This is a profound injustice to the Serbian and Croatian officers who defended Bosnia, and the situation raises questions about American support for the Bosnian military.

title: Whodunit? That Under-40 Crowd
description: WITHOUT so much as a blueprint for fighting crime or a news conference for publicity-hungry politicians to elbow each other out of the limelight, one town's murder rate is all but guaranteed to plunge next month. And sure enough, the credit -- or blame -- rests with high-level decision-makers at an organization with three initials.

title: Between Two Worlds
description: ON GRIEF AND REASON Essays. By Joseph Brodsky. 484 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $24.

title: MARKET WATCH;Big Profits At Banks: A House Of Cards
description: Don't worry, the bankers said in 1988. Any losses from real estate loans will be "modest" and "manageable." They weren't.

title: BASEBALL;For Jones, a Spring Snowstorm and More Spring Training
description: Everybody has been pounding Bobby Jones these days, so why not Mot'er Nature?

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION;The Great Escapist
description: Best known of all the Pre-Raphaelite painters, Dante Gabriel Rossetti (1828-82) was the London-born son of a political refugee and the sister of Byron's doctor, as well as the brother of the poet Christina Rossetti. In DANTE GABRIEL ROSSETTI (Abrams, $29.95), Russell Ash, the author of numerous books on art, including volumes on Edward Burne-Jones and Toulouse-Lautrec, portrays Rossetti as an undisciplined youth whose florid personal style eventually took him to the center of the Victorian artistic world. Along with his fellow painters William Holman Hunt, John Everett Millais and others, Rossetti founded the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, a movement Mr. Ash characterizes as having an "idealized and escapist view of an imaginary 'golden age' rooted in the medieval world, with its traditions of courtly love and chivalric duty." Others in Rossetti's circle included the art critic John Ruskin, Burne-Jones, William Morris and the poets Algernon Charles Swinburne and George Meredith. Rossetti, who was also a poet, married his model Elizabeth Siddal in 1855; in 1862 she died from an overdose of laudanum. Racked with guilt that he had ignored her for his work, Rossetti buried the only complete set of his poems with her, and then ordererd her body exhumed seven years later so that the poems could be retrieved and published. Because of frequent bitter criticism of his work, the artist rarely exhibited publicly, and his final years were marked by insomnia, drug abuse and doomed love affairs, including one with another of his models, William Morris's wife, Jane. While Mr. Ash's account of Rossetti's colorful life is cursory, his commentary on each of the 40 full-color plates reproduced offers valuable insight and information. Robin Lippincott

title: April 7-13;Chaos Envelops Liberia; U.S. Evacuates Foreigners
description: Last weekend, Liberia's seven-year-old civil war suddenly exploded again, this time with a fury nobody had foreseen. By the end of the week, bodies littered the streets and several thousand Liberians were coming under mortar fire as they were being held hostage by one warring militia in a barracks that another militia was trying to capture.

title: HOCKEY;The Devils' Playoff Chase Ends With a Whimper
description: Just one season after the greatest moment in Devils history -- their one and only Stanley Cup championship -- the team sank to an embarrassing low today by becoming the first in 26 years to miss the playoffs just a season after becoming the National Hockey League's champions.

title: WOMEN: April 15, 1990;Who Says We Haven't Made a Revolution?
description: It is now 1990. The swirl and excitement of the 70's has, of necessity, abated. (After all, how many times can original insight make headlines?) Countless women and men experienced those years as crucial -- feminism gave them an inner clarity that continues to sustain -- but for most people the task of life is overwhelming, and without the compelling factor of daily activism, hard truths become blurred, difficult to hold onto. People fall back on the familiar, on that which gives ready comfort. As feminism appears to lose ground, quietude and inertia fill the vacuum. Quiet brings on anxiety, and anxiety makes anyone lose his or her nerve. On the right, the loss of nerve is greeted with relief; on the left, it's an occasion for panic. Orwellian phrases develop quickly to assure an end to the radical impulse: post-feminism, second stage, a different voice. The words indicate progress but the meaning is regression. Sociologists write books about the longing for connection, and novels wink at marriage. Activists wring their hands -- "Everybody's having babies!" -- and journalists rush to announce it's all over, folks.

title: A LA CARTE;Candles and Music, Yet Informally Unpretentious
description: TONY'S Ristorante in Cedarhurst looks exactly like a place with an unpretentious informal name like Tony's should. This small, plain, white-tablecloth spot on a quiet corner of an older residential neighborhood at 331 Washington Avenue (239-0935), where Babyface and before it a candy store had been in operation since mid-January.

title: A Gandhi Bows Out of Election, and Indians Grieve
description: Only a few months ago, when Rajiv Gandhi's widow traveled from New Delhi to address a throng on the grassy common behind the bazaar here, this dusty town bubbled with excitement. But now there is a deep sadness blowing in the hot spring winds, as though something has slipped away and can never be replaced.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;Chinese Restaurant May Help Public Plaza to Shine
description: The cold winter aside, the public plaza at the Bel Canto condominium building, at 68th Street and Broadway, has not looked inviting in recent years. Sparsely furnished, dimly lighted, unkempt and at times a magnet for homeless people, the plaza seemed to provide another example of the flaws in the city program that granted developers zoning variances in exchange for public spaces.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: MIDTOWN Bargains Galore, For a Good Cause

title: GOLF;Norman, at Long Last, Is on Brink of a Masters
description: Greg Norman is on the precipice again, right where he likes to be. Peering down from the top of the Masters leader board, the wind in his hair, all alone after three high-wire rounds of golf, the man who loves to live his life on the edge is right on the verge of the biggest victory of his life.

title: 1970's: July 16, 1978;The Private World of Truman Capote
description: Capote tells me he has never picked up anybody for a one-night stand. "I'd sooner," he says, "jump off the Brooklyn Bridge." He tells me, too, that he has been to bed with women whose names I'd know, that they were always the aggressors and that he doesn't pretend to be bisexual and that he doesn't think there is such a thing. In this bar, we are voyeurs, both of us, just as Capote is a voyeur, I now understand, at a place like Studio 54 where he goes maybe twice a month. He watches, dancing, enchanting when he must, but mostly content to look. Looking, he is a lot of fun. He sees everything and can make stories out of everyone. After a few days together, he says: "I know a lot more about other people than I know about myself."

title: FACING THE FUTURE
description: IN THE BEGINNING was the icon, but the beginning was only a dozen years ago. In 1984, the Apple Macintosh brought the first accessible computer interface - the controls of a computer, the equivalen of a steering wheel and dashboard - to the average person. Called a graphic user interface, or GUI (pronounced GOO-ey), it was based on the use of a mouse and on-screen pointer. The key controls were icons: small symbols, such as a pen that stood for writing program, a paintbrush for a drawing one, a trash can or spinning black hole for deleting files, all arranged on a computer "desktop."

title: DINING OUT;Rustic Elegance and Lively French Fare
description: THE car's headlights picked out the sign for Flippers as we headed down the hill through a pelting rain. Inside the restaurant, a different kind of storm was brewing.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;FUNDS WATCH
description: How I.R.A.'s Gather Dust

title: FOOD;Parsley Takes a More Assertive Role
description: PARSLEY is the herb taken for granted. A few sprigs solve the garnish problem. A scattering of chopped leaves enlivens almost any dish with a bright bit of green.

title: MAKING IT WORK;Late-Night Bowling's Fab Four -- Mush, Max, Paul and Sandro
description: BOWLING is not for the weak of heart. You will need a strong wrist and a strong will. A strong liver can also be an asset. And if you want to bowl after midnight, there is one place to do it, Whitestone Lanes in Queens, New York City's only 24-hour, 7-day-a-week bowling alley. Your master of the house will be Mush, the manager of the graveyard shift.

title: 1950's: Nov. 15, 1959;Anger Is Not Enough
description: Every dissenter who is worth his salt -- better, every dissenter who wants to be numbered among the salt of the earth -- is primarily concerned about some positive value that he wants not only to assert for himself but to recommend to others. . . . Angry men, young or old -- assertive nonconformists, although not of Hitler's stripe -- have no great value to themselves, much less to society, if they are merely angry, merely objectors to the dominant institutions and idea of their time.

title: WEDDINGS;Pamela Reif, Alistair Phillips
description: Dr. Pamela Reif, the daughter of Judith Mistry of Haverford, Pa., and Max Reif of Bala Cynwyd, Pa., was married last evening to Dr. Alistair Phillips, a son of Deirdre and David Phillips of Boston. Rabbi Julie Greenberg performed the ceremony with the Rev. Stephen Jacobson, an Episcopal minister, at the Hotel Atop the Bellevue in Philadelphia.

title: WOMEN: March 15, 1970;Sisterhood Is Powerful
description: The women's movement is a story without an end, because it has just begun. The goals of liberation go beyond a simple concept of equality. Looking through my notebook, I see them expressed simply and directly. (itals)Betty Friedan: "We're going to redefine the sex roles." Anne Koedt: "We're going to be redefining politics."(end itals) Brave words for a new movement, and braver still for a movement that has been met with laughter and hostility. Each time a man sloughs off the women's movement with the comment, "They're nothing but a bunch of lesbians and frustrated bitches," we quiver with collective rage. . . .

title: The 1980's: Sept. 7, 1980;An Artist's Solitude
