description: Most often in Hopper's paintings there is that famous single figure -- often a female, nude or partially undressed -- that has imposed on his work so many associations with "loneliness." Hopper complained that, in discussions of his work, the "loneliness thing was overdone." What obviously obsessed him was not "loneliness" but the taut surface of some deeply engrained solitude.

title: Streetscapes/56 Beaver Street;On the Menu at 1891 Delmonico's: 40 Apartments
description: IF there is a race on now to be first in converting Wall Street's empty offices to residential space, then Francis Greenburger will probably win, even though his company, Time Equities, bought the old Delmonico's Building at 56 Beaver Street only last November, well after other would-be converters. Although other projects are at least a year away from completion, Mr. Greenburger expects to be offering finished apartments in May -- but then he does have a two-decade head start.

title: Ideas & Trends;It Was the Pits. It'll Be Missed.
description: ON April 1, no fooling, they closed the last seven porn shops on The Block, that stretch of Sodom that lies between Seventh and Eighth Avenues on 42d Street, the basest bottom line of the X-rated intersection known as Times Square. Nimble Video, Neptune Video, Nugget Video and Courageous Books -- purveyors of exotic goods and services -- all went out of business to make way for the redevelopment of Times Square.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS;Housing May Replace Barren Lot
description: On the eastern edge of Brooklyn, in what was once a part of Jamaica Bay and then a city dump for construction debris, a developer is proposing to erect a new neighborhood, including the largest housing development to be built in Brooklyn in the last 20 years.

title: BASEBALL;Yanks' Faith in Gooden Takes Another Big Hit
description: The Yankees continued mouthing polite and pleasant words about Dwight Gooden, but they already sound hollow and the emptiness could get worse if he does not improve soon. Despite showing snippets of his old ability for three innings and despite being slightly betrayed by his defense, Gooden has still not validated his presence in the rotation after floundering in his debut at Yankee Stadium yesterday.

title: 2 Firefighters Are Disciplined for Handling of Fatal Fire
description: A Queens fire captain and lieutenant on whose watch a firefighter died in a Far Rockaway blaze in January have been disciplined after an internal report found that they had not adequately supervised their subordinates.

title: School Districts Ready Budgets for Voters
description: DESPITE lack of action on state and Federal budgets, the county's 34 noncity school districts have had to do their homework in order to be on time with their proposed budgets for the 1996-97 school year. Voters in 30 of those 34 districts will vote on May 8. Tuckahoe, Bronxville, Eastchester and Briarcliff Manor will present their budgets variously between May 1 and May 23. The cities of Mount Vernon, Peekskill, New Rochelle, Rye, White Plains and Yonkers do not need voter approval because their school expenses are included in their municipal budgets.

title: New Releases
description: JESUS ALEMANY: 'CUBANISMO!' Rykodisc/Hannibal

title: Race and Rights: Jan. 10, 1965, Weissenfels, East Germany;You Can't Go Back to Weissenfels
description: I had last seen Weissenfels at the age of 8 from the rear of a green Gestapo passenger van that carried a small group of our town's Jews from the police prison in the old Saxon castle up on the hill toward a sudden, unexplained exile from which even the few who survived had never come back.

title: ART;Still Packaging Culture for the Multitudes
description: IN THE POWER-CRAZED PRECINCTS OF Washington, where those out of office are presumed either dead or in Florida, J. Carter Brown is still in everyone's Rolodex. Although he stepped down three and a half years ago as director of the National Gallery of Art (with the title director emeritus, proudly proclaimed on his business stationery), he has by no means lost his status as a Washington institution. He remains the Presidentially appointed chairman of the powerful Commission of Fine Arts, which oversees the District of Columbia's public art and architectural endeavors; vice chairman of the Pennsylvania Avenue Development Corporation; a trustee of the Kennedy Center and a regular on the dinner-party circuit in Washington and New York.

title: Redefining Fairness
description: In Defense of Affirmative Action By Barbara R. Bergmann. 213 pp. New York: A New Republic Book/ Basic Books. $23.

title: Essences of Ease
description: POETS HAVE ALWAYS UNDERSTOOD THE INTRICATE RELAtionship between mood and place: how subtle events in design - the rippling of a drapery as it catches a breeze, the reassuring thunk of a solid wooden door as it closes - leave an indelible impression. In an age obsessed with image, it is easy to forget that rooms are more than the display of furnishings; they are also the accumulation of experiences, the locus of memories.

title: South Africa;The Arithmetic Of Apartheid
description: To understand the peculiarities of South Africa -- the laws and attitudes -- one must begin with arithmetic, the arithmetic of population. The last official estimate, for mid-1974, put the country's total at just under 25 million. The estimate broke that down by race as follows: whites, 4,160,000; Asians, 709,000; Coloreds, 2,306,000; Africans 17,745,000.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN;Naples
description: Naples is wet laundry flapping in the sea breeze over teeming, alley-like streets. It is a million once-elegant french doors opening onto wrought-iron balconies slowly rusting into oblivion. It's two grimy restorers dodging cars under the weight of a glittering 18th-century crystal chandelier.

title: South Africa: July 7, 1985;A Rare Talk With Mandela
description: I was ushered into the carpeted first-floor office of a major in South Africa's correctional service, and had waited there only a few moments when Mandela hurried in, welcoming me graciously. He is a tall, slim, handsome man who looks far younger than his 66 years. Dressed in his own well-fitted khaki shirt and trousers, rather than a regulation blue denim prison uniform, he appeared vigorous and healthy, with a calm, confident manner and dignified bearing that seemed incongruous in our prison surroundings. Indeed, throughout our meeting, I felt that I was in the presence not of a guerrilla fighter or radical ideologue, but of a head of state. . . .

title: Coming of Age in Sri Lanka
description: FUNNY BOY By Shyam Selvadurai. 310 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $23.

title: 1940's: May 6, 1945 With American Forces in Germany (By Wireless);The World Must Not Forget
description: We have been traveling in these latter days through some of the most beautiful country in the world. The war has passed over it so swiftly that most of its placid villages clustered about their quaint Baroque churches are quite unmarked. Lilacs and magnolias are blooming. Apple and cherry trees which line the rolling fields are in full blossom and touch a smiling landscape with spring glory.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;Disabled Access To Inns at Issue
description: DAYS INNS OF AMERICA and the Justice Department are going to court over the Americans With Disabilities Act, signed by President Bush almost six years ago.

title: WOMEN: Sept. 10, 1967;An Interview with a Cheerful First Lady
description: When did you meet the President?

title: The Great Outdoors: June 22, 1958;Road Map for a Trip to the Moon
description: Let us examine the prelimiary steps, as we now foresee them, the must be taken before any man can reach the lunar surface and return home.

title: HOCKEY;Bruised but Still Unbowed, Rangers Gird for Playoffs
description: His right hand was bandaged, but Pat Verbeek said it was not a serious injury, just sore from a stick slash. The Ranger right wing talked more of his recovery from his back problems, saying his spine was "back in whack."

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;The 'Modern' Gives the Modern A New Gleam
description: THE MODERN IS MOLDERING": that's as close as you can get in English to Otto Klemperer's punning swipe at the "modern," which in German overlaps with the verb "to decay." Modernity is not as fashionable as it once was; the new has given way to the neo, audacity to authenticity. "Modern" gives off a dull, cold gleam, like the metal surface of an International Style skyscraper covered by 40 years of grime. In music, composers have fled the geometries of modernism en masse: the halls of academia echo with recantations, and graph paper is swept under the rug.

title: WEDDINGS;Anne M. Coudert, P.D. Schreckinger
description: Anne Marie Coudert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Raphael Coudert Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter David Schreckinger, a son of Demetra Daniels Schreckinger of New York and the late Neil Jay Schreckinger. The Rev. Joseph Kelly performed the ceremony at St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: SOAPBOX;A Home for Betsy
description: RUTH was trembling. I could tell over the phone. She told me that she had done the unthinkable: she had refused to pick Betsy up from her temporary group home. When the social worker tried to drop Betsy off at her house, Ruth was purposely not at home. She simply could not go on for another day with Betsy in her house. She had abandoned her 26-year-old daughter to the state.

title: POSTINGS: 6-Story Building on E. 60th Street;Chaplaincy's New Home
description: The Healthcare Chaplaincy, a multidenominational organization that trains and supervises professional chaplains in Manhattan hospitals, has moved from a cluster of ground-floor studio apartments on East 70th Street to a rehabilitated six-story building near the Queensboro Bridge.

title: 1940's: Aug. 1, 1948;Family Life, '1948 A.T.' (After Television)
description: The American household is on the threshold of a revolution. The wife scarcely knows where the kitchen is, let alone her place in it. Junior scorns the late-afternoon sunlight for the glamour of the darkened living room. Father's briefcase lies unopened in the foyer.

title: A Fiddler Unfazed by the Brightest of Spotlights
description: THE 38TH ANNUAL Grammy Awards, which were presented in February, hardly lacked media attention. But one aspect of the televised ceremony was curiously overlooked: the appearance of the 21-year-old violinist Maxim Vengerov, whose Teldec recording of Shostakovich and Prokofiev concertos had been nominated for a Grammy. For four minutes, Mr. Vengerov's scorching performance of the concluding Burlesque of Shostakovich's First Violin Concerto reached a global television audience estimated at more than a billion people -- probably more than have ever heard any classical musician, except, of course, for those three tenors.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: THE STEVENSONS A Biography of an American Family. By Jean H. Baker. Norton, $30.

title: INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3 Meet Mush, master of the graveyard shift at Whitestone Lanes.

title: Race and Rights: Oct. 5, 1969;The Yogi and the Commissar
description: It takes a great deal of money to keep Bapu living in poverty. . . . "

title: BASEBALL;Yankees Still Waiting For Martinez to Strike
description: Bernie Williams entered the game against Texas batting .185 and proceeded to go 0 for 3. Joe Girardi had the pleasure of hearing boos and chants of "Stanley, Stanley, Stanley" before he made a throwing error. Dwight Gooden, 0 for 1996, including spring training, was rocked for six runs in five and a third innings.

title: The Iranian Connection
description: It has been public knowledge for some time that Iran's Islamic regime supplied beleaguered Bosnian forces with arms when the West would not. But it now turns out that in 1994 while the Clinton Administration was publicly defending the United Nations arms embargo against Bosnia, it secretly approved the Iranian arms shipments.

title: WOMEN: April 11, 1976;Who's Afraid of the E.R.A.?
description: On Nov. 4, 1975, New York voters defeated the E.R.A.

title: Slain Woman Was Warned of Package Bomb
description: After having been warned by the police not to open unexpected packages delivered to her home, a 37-year-old woman whose former husband had reportedly threatened to blow her up was killed as she opened a package bomb on her kitchen table.

title: WEDDINGS;Sharon Weinstock, Jacques Steinberg
description: Sharon Leslie Weinstock, a daughter of Marilyn and Leonard Weinstock of Jamaica Estates, Queens, is to be married today in Mamaroneck, N.Y., to Jacques Paul Steinberg, a son of Edythe Steinberg and Dr. Barry Steinberg of Somerset, Mass. Rabbi Michael Paley is to perform the ceremony at the Mamaroneck Beach and Yacht Club.

title: Broadway: May 1, 1988;Carlotta and the Master
description: As I opened the gilded elevator door I saw Mrs. O'Neill, standing in the doorway of her apartment. She was then 68, and one of the most beautiful women I had ever seen. ... She wore an unadorned dress of black silk and no jewelry except for a pair of creamy pearl earrings, which gave her face an added glow. ...

title: Tough Job, Hard Times
description: WHETHER she is cruising the aisles of Kilroy's Wonder Market, dashing into the video store or ambling down Rock Road on a lazy Saturday, Elizabeth Mulholland can expect a tug on her elbow. It might be a parent, a teacher or, heaven help her, a fuming taxpayer. The topic could be rising enrollment, the high school's discipline policy, the leak in the middle school roof. Maybe it's a complaint about the math curriculum or the senior class trip.

title: Essences of Ease;PASSAGES
description: THERE ARE ROOMS, and there are the spaces that connect them to each other and to the outside world. These in-between passages - be they porches or wide halls, verandas or widow's walks - have always occupies a special place in American regional architecture. They preserve an almost archaic connection with nature and with the hierarchy of the interior. Traditionally, porches were transitional areas that were neither indoors nor out, where families might see neighbors and be seen without having to welcome everyone into the privacy of the interior; they also helped ventilate houses in the age before air-conditioners. Wide halls, on the other hand, pace one's arrival, sometimes even delaying it with a show of portraits or photographs. Today, such seemingly impractical in-between spaces speak of an era when people had the time to linger, to look and to enjoy the company of others or simply the sound of the wind. You might say they work on a higher plane than function.

title: Test of Breasts By Ultrasound Gets Approval
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved a powerful ultrasound device today to help doctors determine when lumps in women's breasts are noncancerous so the women can avoid a common surgical test.

title: Leader as Hard as Nails Is Taking Reins at N.R.A.
description: The gray-haired little grandmother behind the big desk would stand 5 feet tall, if she was standing uphill. Pictures of grinning grandchildren decorate her warm and tidy office. Her ashtray holds a single, half-smoked cigarette. The filter is ringed with pink lipstick.

title: Sports of The Times;Golf's Bobby Jones Revival
description: IN 1947, two refugees from the New England chill were watching one of the sweet-swinging golfers of that era, Henry Picard, loft an iron shot in the Masters tournament that Bobby Jones had founded in 1934 on the Augusta National course that he had helped design.

title: DINING OUT;A Cozy Little Spot Where Two Can Talk
description: THE fieldstone and pink mortar exterior of Cafe Allegre in Canton evokes an image of Hansel and Gretel. But once through a narrow hall, past food cases and food aromas, bathroom and kitchen, the tiny dining room projects a completely different image: softly lighted, sophisticated dining that is as romantic as all get-out.

title: MUSIC OF 'RENT';The World Doesn't Need More Pop
description: To the Editor:

title: The Great Outdoors: May 3, 1936;Zeppelin vs. Airplane
description: The airplane, like the skimming stone the boy throws out over the water, stays up only as long as it has flying speed - energy to push it forward. It is dynamic. You must not have an engine failure if you are flying oceans. ...

title: COVER STORY;The Negro Leagues, Paving the Way
description: Kevin Rodney Sullivan, a 36-year-old black film maker, knows that he would not be where he is today without the efforts of those who preceded him. "My grandfather was a sharecropper in Albama," he says. "My father was a municipal worker in San Francisco for 40 years. I get to make movies."

title: Who's Who
description: NAMES ARE MISSING!!!

title: 1990's: Nov. 5, 1995;Making Microsoft Safe for Capitalism
description: In a historical eye blink, as the technologies of computing have come to pervade the world's economic life, Microsoft has turned 20 years old. When Ronald Reagan became President, Bill Gates's new company was an unincorporated partnership with accounts kept in handwritten ledgers. Apple was a big new personal-computer company, worth $3 billion; I.B.M., the mainframe giant, was cobbling together its first personal computer out of parts from outside suppliers. By 1990, just a decade later, Microsoft had become the world's richest software company, though it had no leading product in any important category but operating systems. Today nearly half of the world's total PC software revenue now goes directly to Microsoft.

title: 1940's: Sept. 25, 1949;On Germans
description: They desire neither to hear nor to know anything about the atrocities of the Nazi regime, which they declare to be propaganda lies and exaggerations. They exhibit an ostentatious indifference toward court cases dealing with such atrocities. They are equally indifferent to the havoc which Hitler's war wrought in other countries. When they are told that the British are worse off than they, they reply, "Perhaps, but only a little."

title: Harrowing Time For a College Grad
description: To the Editor:

title: Women: March 7, 1915;Let The Vote?
description: Over the early years, the Magazine has invited correspondents with opposing views to lock horns on its pages. Questions involving women's rights have frequently provoked spirited debates.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperpacks
description: LET'S FALL IN LOVE By Carol Hill. Norton, $11.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHINATOWN;Living With the Fishes on Mott Street
description: Peter Eng's apartment smells like a fish market. So do most of the apartments at 135 Mott Street, which houses two seafood stores on the ground floor. "When I get home, I have to pick fish scales out of my sneakers," said Mr. Eng, 47, a screenwriter who grew up on the block.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;Rescuing a Heroine From the Clutches of Obscurity
description: A gilded heroine bravely guards the Maine monument on Columbus Circle. Down the street, at Grand Army Plaza, there she is again, this time as the seductive Pomona, Roman goddess of fertility, pouring her coquettish charms into the Pulitzer Fountain. And standing high above the Municipal Building, she is Civic Fame, proclaiming New York as the world's greatest metropolis.

title: The Early Years: Dec. 24, 1922;Give Them Their Land
description: Poor Indian, dear Indian! Why all America ought to belong to him! Why look you now at the injustice that has been done to him! . . . Not only has all America been snatched from him, but even his four square leagues are invaded by vile white men, greedy white men, hateful white men!"

title: 1940's: April 15, 1945 Moscow (By Wireless);Moscow Rallies to Survive
description: I The first time I saw Moscow was in July 1941, when the sprawling metropolis was girding itself for war. Miles of railway sidings just outside the big Kievskaya station were burdened with troop trains and supply trains, and trains bulging with artillery shells and tanks. Sleeping cars with big red crosses painted on their sides were shunted to subsidiary lines and the walking wounded cadged cigarettes from each other, limping about the platforms and handing smokes to the serious cases lying in their berths behind curtained windows.

title: New Releases
description: VARIOUS ARTISTS: 'BEFORE THE BLUES,' VOLS. 1-3 Yazoo

title: Defenders of Mrs. Clinton Dig In for the Long Haul
description: Oh yeah, Al D'Amato," Lynn Cutler said warily in summoning up the New York Republican Senator as a kind of virtual Nemesis from an endless video game. The Whitewater hearings run so determinedly by the Senator have haunted her in what she once imagined would be the simple task of defending the reputation of Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: SLOW DANCING ON DINOSAUR BONES By Lana Witt. Scribner, $22.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: THIS SIDE OF COOPERSTOWN An Oral History of Major League Baseball in the 1950s. By Larry Moffi. University of Iowa, $24.95.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Kings Point, L.I.;Where Gatsby Could Still Be Comfortable
description: IN the 1920's, the lush village of Kings Point with its rolling hills and the opulent life style of its wealthy inhabitants became the inspiration for West Egg in F. Scott Fitzgerald's novel, "The Great Gatsby."

title: 1990's: July 9, 1995;'Does Anyone Here Think This Baby Can Live?'
description: Half-past midnight, 12 hours after the Brigham doctors consulted with Jennifer and Kevin DeCosta about the fate of their child, the high-risk delivery bell went off in the NICU and the receptionist called out to the triage team, "23-weeker, delivery room 9!" Dylan DeCosta was on his way.

title: Port Can't Be Held Hostage To Environmental Demands
description: To the Editor:

title: Bleak House
description: The Manikin By Joanna Scott. 276 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $22.50.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: ON the week's movie menu, suspense plays a major role - in an upstate house, in a Mexican border town and in the London stage orbit - and one of history's great sea disasters reappears.

title: Kurdish Disunity
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;Can Gwynn Hit .500? Probably Not, but .400 Would Be Fine
description: The prospect of a full season generated talk this spring about the prospect of a home run record. If hitters like Matt Williams, Albert Belle and Ken Griffey Jr. could hit the number of home runs they slugged in shortened seasons, think of what they might do in 162 games.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Hearty Diner Fare With a Thai Twist

title: TELEVISION;The Man Behind the Chutzpah Of Master Sgt. Ernest Bilko
description: PERCEPTIONS OF the new film "Sergeant Bilko" are likely to diverge somewhere along the age-40 line. For moviegoers under 40, "Sergeant Bilko" is primarily another Steve Martin movie. For those over 40, the film's title alone conjures up memories of a classic 1950's sitcom.

title: Broadway: June 12, 1960;What's The Theater For?
description: EDWARD ALBEE: I would submit that the Theater of the Absurd, in the sense that it is truly the contemporary theater facing as it does man's condition as it is, is the Realistic theater of our time; ... the supposed Realistic theater - the term used here to mean most of what is done on Broadway - in the sense that it panders to the public need for self-congratulation and reassurance and presents a false picture of ourselves to ourselves is with an occasional very lovely exception, really and truly The Theater of the Absurd. ...

title: Authors Lunch to Cite the Progress of Libraries
description: THE fifth yearly Book and Author Luncheon of the Westchester Library System, to be held Tuesday at noon at Abigail Kirsch's Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, has an especially full menu this year.

title: The World;In British Race, Blair Fits Bill
description: POLITICIANS in Britain sometimes look to the United States the way New Yorkers look to California -- to peer into the possible future. With a mixture of fascination and dread, they train their telescopes on the horizon and wonder which trends of public fickledom will blow their way and which newfangled techniques can be lifted for their own campaigns.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHINATOWN;In Demographic Ebb and Flow, Chinatown Surges and Neighbors Fade
description: Depending on whom you talk to, the Lower East Side is either booming or fading away.

title: Race and Rights: Feb. 23, 1969, San Francisco;She Is What She Feels
description: She put down her drink and pointed to a newspaper clipping on her kitchen wall, her answer to a reporter who stopped her one day to ask, "What are you doing with life?" "Getting stoned, staying happy and having a good time," her answer read. "I'm doing just what I want with my life, enjoying it. I don't think you can ask more of life than that."

title: 1950's: Aug. 11, 1957;On Frisbees and Other Wacky Toys
description: Under the influence of an itch, whim or dry martini the adult male or female with a loose dollar will often buy a crazy, mixed-up toy such as a rubber Goo-Goo Doll, a set of walking false teeth or a plastic chicken which, when pressed will ring a bell and lay five eggs. Marbles. Nearly every month something new and goofy in the toy market pops up to capture the attention of adults as well as children and sometimes the item catches on and becomes a national fad. Of course, nobody in the toy business has any idea ahead of time which plaything will become a bonanza, since in past years magnificent fads have sprouted from the disparate likes of Bubble Wands, teddy bears, coonskin caps, Ouija boards, Fli-back paddles, Pickup sticks, non-flying spaceships and various small gewgaws that talked, walked on the ceiling, opened beer cans and did everything but cheat at cards. And now we have the Frisbee. . . .

title: 1950's: Nov. 16, 1952;This Is the Beat Generation
description: The wild boys of today are not lost. Their flushed, often scoffing, always intent faces elude the word, and it would sound phony to them. For this generation conspicuously lacks that eloquent air of bereavement which made so many of the exploits of the Lost Generation symbolic actions. Furthermore, the repeated inventory of shattered ideals, and the laments about the mud in moral currents, which so obsessed the Lost Generation does not concern young people today. They take it frighteningly for granted. They were brought up in these ruins and no longer notice them. They drink to "come down" or "get high," not to illustrate anything. Their excursions into drugs or primiscuity come out of curiosity, not disillusionment.

title: BACKTALK;From 'K.V. Switzer' to Girl to Woman in the Span of 4 1/2 Hours
description: For 29 years I've told time by the Boston Marathon. The 1967 race changed my life and dictated my direction. Now, I remember other day-to-day occurrences -- jobs, degrees, marriages -- in the context of the corresponding years on the 26-mile run from Hopkinton to Boston. (Divorce? Oh . . . '73, hot, no wind.)

title: BEST SELLERS: April 14, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction

title: FILM;Seeing Box-Office Magic in Children's Books
description: WHEN WALT DISNEY PICTURES turns to Victor Hugo for the source of its annual summer mega-release (the animated "Hunchback of Notre Dame" will succeed "Pocahontas" at a theater near you this June) and sinks $40 million into a live-action recycling of its animated 1961 classic "101 Dalmatians" (slated to scamper across hundreds of screens at Thanksgiving), is it safe to conclude every great children's book has already been made as a movie?

title: Vietnam: Oct. 22, 1967;Where Johnson Ends and McNamara Begins
description: In Robert S. McNamara there has been a unique meeting of a man and his times. In a period of vast social and technological change, with vast domestic and international problems arising from this change, Robert S. McNamara is the managerial type par excellence. He has mastered the technique of the statistical approach, the careful analysis of the available options, the ability to qualify the disparate elements of a complex situation. He also has arrived at a time when the United States is at the height of its power, with crisis after crisis flowing through the operations room of the White House. For two Presidents, eager to make today's multitude of decisions and go on to tomorrow's, McNamara has provided the ready answers.

title: 1.23 Billion Is Pledged In New Aid For Bosnia
description: Cash-strapped governments and international institutions around the world promised $1.23 billion more in aid today to help rebuild shattered roads, power grids and homes in Bosnia and Herzegovina, bringing the total pledged this year to more than $1.8 billion.

title: Family Center Brings Fun Into the 21st Century
description: FORGET old-time family entertainment. Backyard tag, frozen pond ice-skating and games of make-believe are passe. Fun in the 90's means very high-tech, capitalizing on the best of technology driven activities. Laser tag, virtual reality, interactive 3-D theaters are now musts on American -- and Long Island -- amusement agendas.

title: A Very Long Line Of Basketball Stars
description: MARCUS CAMBY, Butch Lee, Jeff Ruland, Super John Williamson, Michael Adams, Scott Burrell, Mike O'Koren, Dean Meminger, Wes Matthews, Ricky Mahorn.

title: Race and Rights: Nov. 28, 1965;The Absent Father Haunts the Negro Family
description: About 25 percent of Negro families are headed by women who have no husbands. These are families where the male is absent because of divorce, separation or desertion, and do not include families with illegitimate children which have never included a male parent.

title: Dole Assails Clinton for 'Crunch' of Low Wages and High Taxes
description: With tax-filing day fast approaching, Bob Dole today lambasted what he called "the Clinton crunch," which he said had squeezed most Americans between higher taxes and lower wages.

title: Vietnam: Sept. 5, 1965, Saigon;HO CHI MINH ON THE MOVE
description: On March 15, 1954, on top of Hill Gabrielle overlooking the valley of Dienbienphu, M. Sgt. Bensalem Abderrhaman of First Company, Fifth Battalion, Seventh Algerian Rifles, had spent his last ammunition and the small-boned but tough North Vietnamese regulars of Regiment 88, 308th People's Army Division, were now all around him in their green fatigues. They wore short, quilted jackets to protect them against the morning cold of the mountains, palm-leaf pith helmets covered with camouflage netting in which they had stuck leaves and branches from the surrounding foliage, rubber-soled sneakers with broad cleats, and cheap-looking, thin web belts and pouches in which they carried spare ammunition, grenades and perhaps a fist-sized ball of cooked rice as an emergency ration.

title: Writer on Nature (and Life) Deserves a Wider Audience
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about opposition to adult video stores in Milford misstated part of the name of a group organized two years ago to protest pornography shops in Waterbury. It is the White Ribbon Against Pornography, not White Women Against Pornography.

title: Habitats/245 Echo Place;The Bronx, Yes, Thonx
description: WHEN Cordelia Leacock turns on the television set to watch "Days of Our Lives," her favorite soap opera, she sits alert and ready to change the channel if things start getting, as she says, "a little tacky."

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-13

title: John E. Nafe, 81; Physicist Studied The Earth's Crust
description: Dr. John Elliott Nafe, a physicist who originated significant seismological concepts over nearly three decades as a teacher and researcher at Columbia University, died on April 6 at his home in Vancouver, British Columbia. He was 81 and had lived at the university's earth sciences campus in Palisades, N.Y., until his retirement in 1980.

title: Correction
description: The Perspectives column last Sunday, about conversion of a Brooklyn nursing home into a residence for the elderly, misstated the building number on Prospect Park West. It is No. 1.

title: WEDDINGS;Joseph J. Jaeger, Laraine P. Collier
description: Laraine Petrow Collier, the sales manager for L'Oreal Cosmetics in Atlanta, and Joseph J. Jaeger, the company's vice president of finance in New York, were married yesterday at the White Hart Inn in Salisbury, Conn. The Rev. Judith Johnson, a nondenominational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Visa for India
description: To the Editor: I am writing about difficulties obtaining a visa at the New York City office of the Consulate General of India, 3 East 64th Street.

title: 1970's: April 20, 1975;Moment by Moment With President Ford
description: 12:07 P.M. He stands at a lectern on a podium in the East Room of the residence, alongside Secretary-Designate Hills. . . . The room is murmurous with standing guests. Television lights are on. The President places his speech on the lectern and a respectful silence falls.

title: WEDDINGS;Jacqueline Parkes, Brian D. Hendrix
description: Jacqueline Dale Parkes, a daughter of Margaret Parkes and Dr. James C. Parkes 2d of New York, was married yesterday to Brian Dean Hendrix, the son of Kenneth Dean Hendrix of Springfield, N.J., and the late Dorothy Hendrix. The Rev. Robert B. O'Connor performed the ceremony at Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: WEDDINGS;Sally Perkins, Peter F. Hewitt
description: Sara Spear Perkins, a writer in Stonington, Conn., was married there yesterday to Peter Fraser Hewitt, the director of the junior department at the Royal College of Music in London. The Rev. Mark Robinson performed the ceremony at Calvary Episcopal Church.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE;Lube for the Car, Java for the Driver
description: When coffee bars started appearing in bookstores, it seemed as natural as putting books on coffee tables. But what Ehud Cafri and David Winer have done at First Avenue and 92d Street has a touch of the mad scientist about it: they put a coffee bar in a carwash.

title: Race and Rights: Sept. 16, 1984;Manchild in Harlem
description: Manchild 1984 is the product of a society so rife with violence that killing a mugging or robbery victim is now fashionable.

title: Commercial Property/Rent-Increase Pass-Alongs;Tenants Find It's Easier to Switch Than Fight
description: LIKE most brokers, Michael Myers, chairman of Corporate Realty Partners, used to dig in his heels if a landlord wanted to tie annual rent increases to raises in the porters' wage package.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Deadline Tomorrow For Regency Claims
description: Tomorrow is the last date for claims to be filed with bankruptcy court by passengers who paid for Regency cruises that were canceled when the company shut down Oct. 29. Lawyers in the case estimate that 20,000 people may be entitled to a refund; 10,000 had filed claims by the end of March.

title: SPENDING IT;Compensation and the I.R.S.: It's Not the 'Good' Old Days
description: For those who grumble about high taxes and hark back to "the good old days," remember: it used to be worse, at least for the very rich. In fact, 55 years ago, the top marginal rate was 81 percent, nearly double today's top effective tax rate of 39.6 percent at the Federal level.

title: JAZZ MASTERS;Of Course It's Jazz
description: To the Editor:

title: DINING OUT;Trattoria-Style Specialties in Rye Brook
description: OUR recent visits to Provare reminded us of attending a long-run Broadway show playing with a third or fourth cast. The words and music might not change, but . . . . And so this stylish restaurant has lost some of its freshness. It seems as though every hamlet in the county now has the formula trattoria with its antipasto center and exposed pizza station. Yet Provare's audience -- mainly hotel guests -- will be beguiled by the big city pizazz of the place, and county residents will continue to find this dining room a reliable (within its culinary limitations), pretty yet informal spot to meet friends.

title: MUSIC;Westchester Joining Nationwide Organ Recital
description: AT 6 o'clock tonight here in the East, the American Guild of Organists celebrates its 100th birthday with what it has proclaimed "the world's largest organ recital." More than 160 players from coast to coast will simultaneously play Bach's most famous organ piece, Toccata and Fugue in D minor.

title: Race and Rights: April 16, 1961;The Jackson Pollock Market Soars
description: No other American artist, not even Whistler (if we consider him an American artist), has created such a furor in the world as the late Jackson Pollock.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Ace Instructor

title: As Revenues Drop, Hospitals Talk of Forsaking Charity Care
description: With managed care driving down their revenues, many hospitals around the country say they can no longer afford to provide free medical care to the growing number of uninsured who have come through their doors seeking treatment for everything from the flu to heart disease.

title: EVENING HOURS;For Writers, Scholarships And Riders
description: Playwrights Horizons, Pratt Institute and Horse Show Foundation benefits; a book signing, and a new way to get around.

title: The 1980's: Feb. 17, 1985;Power, Greed and Glory on Wall Street
description: Traders are often depicted in banker cartoons as poorly educated drones with digital minds, robots hunched over Quotron and Telerate screens, barking orders, thinking of the moment, not the long term.

title: From Stony Brook, a New Way to Examine Colons, Externally
description: FLYING through a virtual colon, Dr. Ari Kaufman said, is a lot like playing a "Star Wars" video game.

title: Praise Bellevue Hospital, and Don't Sell It
description: To the Editor:

title: The World;Pulling for Yeltsin, but Gingerly
description: IT'S no secret inside the White House that President Clinton would like to see not just himself but Boris Yeltsin turn out to be the Comeback Kid of 1996. But with Russia's elections fast approaching and its public in a nationalist mood these days, that still leaves open the question of just how closely Bill should embrace Boris when the two meet in Moscow this week.

title: BOOKEND;'Animal Farm' at 50
description: Arthur C. Danto's most recent books are "Playing With the Edge: The Photographic Achievement of Robert Mapplethorpe" and "After the End of Art: Contemporary Art and the Pale of History."

title: 100 Years of The New York Times: About Men - March 30, 1986;A Brother's Murder
description: From June 1983 until January 1996, the About Men column offered a place for personal essays about male roles - father, son, weekend athlete, breadwinner and, as in this example, mourner.

title: The Nation;Taking States Seriously
description: FOR much of his nearly quarter century on the Supreme Court, William H. Rehnquist was the outrider. Often in dissent, he traveled far from the pack, tracing a singular path across a constitutional landscape that in his view was strewn with monuments to the modern Court's errors. Prominent among these were the Court's precedents elevating the power of the Federal Government at the expense of the individual states.

title: Liberties;The Dream Machine
description: It's a familiar story. The Dream becomes a Nightmare. Television logos shifted seamlessly from the Jessica Dubroff Adventure to the Jessica Dubroff Tragedy. Newspaper headlines went from a little girl with a big dream to the death of a little girl and her big dream.

title: The Future Home of Yankee Stadium? It's All in the Traffic Patterns
description: In looking at four possible new homes for the Yankees in New York City, consultants concluded that a site west of Pennsylvania Station has the best transportation access. But traffic experts, mass-transit advocates, environmentalists and community groups say that finding is based on faulty reasoning and a large dose of hopelessly optimistic guesswork.

title: 1950's: Dec. 28, 1952;Joe Docks, Forgotten Man
description: Joe Docks, bottled up in his cramped cold-water flat or his waterfront bar, doesn't get much chance to tell us about his life. But he doesn't like it. Hard-drinking, two-fisted, high-strung, a rabid sports fan, an all-out friend, a dangerous enemy, he's also a loyal, religious, hard-working, responsible family man concerned about getting his kids through school and seeing them get a better break than their old man. He lives for the day when his job will be systematized through some plan of work rotation based on an adequate, annual wage. He'd like some advance notice of where and when he's going to work. Today there is not even a central information service on shipping traffic, and the men pick up their information as to job chances in the same haphazard, chaotic way they did a hundred years ago.

title: The View From: Hartsdale;Priest-Auctioneer Who Raises the Spirit and Lowers the Gavel
description: THE Rev. Rayner (Rusty) Hesse likes to tell people he is bivocational -- and he gets even more of a kick out of their reactions when they learn the two vocations are Episcopal priest and dealer of antiques and collectibles.

title: THEATER;Marketing Broadway as a Cool Spot
description: MTV PLUGS. WEB SITES that print out theater tickets. Fliers posted in laundromats. Productions at 10 A.M. These are a few of the ideas, high tech and low, of theater producers and marketers determined to bring young and minority audiences into the ever-graying, implacably white precincts of Broadway.

title: The 1980's: April 8, 1984;Trump, Expanding
description: It is not yet 9 A.M. Spending a day with Donald Trump is like driving a Ferrari without the windshield. It's exhilarating; he gets a few bugs in his teeth.

title: Direct to Midtown, 21 Times a Day
description: Direct rail service to Manhattan from North Jersey is only two months away.

title: One Pilot Program's Concerted Effort
description: ISRAEL CRUZ of Bridgeport said one of the saddest days of his life occurred last year when his now 17-year-old daughter Alisha left school before earning her high school diploma.

title: THEATER;Ibsen, a Century Later
description: THE consequences of a compromised existence, of constant evasions, of clutching "old dead ideas, dead beliefs, dead opinions" -- all these are the enemies of truth and fulfillment, the ghosts that wreck lives.

title: INVESTING IT;Litigation Law Creates Work for Disclaimer Writers
description: THE Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 had a difficult birth. Only after frenetic lobbying and Democrats' joining with Republicans to overturn President Clinton's veto did the act become law in December. But so far, the measure does not seem to have been worth all the fuss.

title: Dentist-Anesthesiologists Are Pushing for Formal Recognition
description: IT was not front-line combat as a marine in the Vietnam War that undid Michael Arms. Nor the time he was mugged and stabbed in the Bronx.

title: Keep the Traffic Moving' Is Not Be-All and End-All
description: To the Editor:

title: House to Vote on a Constitutional Amendment on Taxes
description: House Republicans will celebrate income tax day on Monday by voting on a constitutional amendment that would require a two-thirds vote by both Houses of Congress to raise Federal taxes.

title: ISRAELIS BLOCKADE PORTS IN LEBANON AND SHELL SOUTH
description: Israeli gunboats blockaded Beirut and other Lebanese ports today and Israeli guns rained shells on southern Lebanon as Israel steadily raised the heat of its operation against Islamic guerrillas.

title: 1970's: March 22, 1973;A Dissident's Place, East and West
description: Stalinism as a method of governing a state, in my opinion, has no future. Therefore, it is all the stranger to see [Stalin's] features in a bookstore window near the London School of Economics, in the Latin Quarter in Paris or in a shop on some American campus, where they decorate the shelves beside Lenin, Trotsky, Che Guevara, Mao, etc. -- all the small-time and big-time murderers who, apart from the difference in their ideals, have one common characteristic: They all committed murder. No matter what their numerator is, their denominator is common; and the sum of these fractions would produce a number that would confuse even a computer. I don't know what all the young people are looking for in these books, but if they really can find something there for themselves, it means only one thing: that the process of moral castration of Homo sapiens, begun by force, is continuing voluntarily, and that Stalinism, as a system of thinking, is conquering.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE;Even a Film Star Can Be in the Dark On Street Lights
description: Patricia Neal, the Oscar-winning actress and until recently reticent private citizen, is hot under the collar.

title: SPENDING IT;Need Tax Help? So Do the Experts in Washington
description: IT is estimated that about half the Americans who file Form 1040 income-tax returns do the work themselves, spending an average of 12 hours trying to understand the complex laws of the tax system. Many of these 59 million taxpayers will be stuck inside today, trying to complete their returns before tomorrow's filing deadline.

title: April 7-13;Pickup Candidate
description: Last week Texas saw some strange upsets. Its Republicans rejected the prized convert to the G.O.P., Representative Greg Laughlin, in his bid for a nomination. And Texas Democrats, choosing a U.S. Senate candidate, rejected John Bryant, a veteran Dallas Congressman, in favor of an unknown.

title: 1940's: Feb. 8, 1948;Notes on Talking Dogs
description: Most of the talking dogs confine themselves to sentences of from three to five words, and since these articulate canines are popping up all over the country, people are going to have to learn to take them in their stride. If a strange dog accosts you on the street and asks you what time it is, there is no reason to quit drinking or consult a psychiatrist. Just tell him what time it is and go on about your business.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;To Wings! To Wings! A Chicken War Rages
description: Call it the battle of the Upper West Side chicken joints.

title: WEDDINGS;Eric S. Richter, Lori R. Gross
description: Lori Robyn Gross, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Elliot Gross of Melville, L.I., was married last evening to Eric Shawn Richter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Barry Richter of Sands Point, L.I. Rabbi Marc A. Gellman performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York.

title: Race and Rights: Nov. 3, 1974;Harlem Has Three Faces
description: The black middle class, a beleaguered group that has been much maligned by trendy black and white writers, has for some time now been under attack for its inability to "do something" about the marauding bands of black underclass men who, for whatever social reasons, make life in the cities of this country one of unbearable apprehension. The black middle class can do very little, however, about this group, since its language of exchange is different, its values are different, its priorities are different. These black men and women of achievement stand in terror of an underclass that cannot see methodical achievement on its horizon and despises it in others.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE: UPDATE;Snags Won't Delay Work at Station
description: Despite cracks in new tiles and recent water backups at the IRT subway station at Grand Army Plaza, the Transit Authority expects the renovation of the 75-year-old station to be completed on schedule.

title: What Separates Hate and Civil Disobedience?;The Waco Difference
description: To the Editor:

title: 1970's: January 10, 1971;A Short Educational Dictionary
description: Identity One of the main concerns of education, and the main concern of concerned students, is to seek, establish, etc. their identity. Methods include (a) becoming unconscious through hallucinatory drugs; (b) joining an organization all of whose members accept identical opinions, etc. At an early age, children may be taught their identity, or one better suited to them than the original, by progressive and concerned teachers.

title: Ideas & Trends;The $1 Billion Cure For Civic Insecurity
description: THE nation's cities are desperate in their courtship of baseball and football teams. Downtown revival, tourism, tradition, civic pride -- whatever the reasons, they have pleaded and wheedled and offered the owners the world to make themselves at home.

title: 1940's: Sept. 3, 1989 (50 Years Later);When the Air Raid Sirens Began Their Wail
description: The day on which Western Europe took the final step into the most disastrous war in history was a fine one in London. The sun was bright and warm on Sept. 3, 1939, and the sky that Sunday morning was cloudless. But the news from Poland was bad. As I ate my eggs and bacon, I read that German panzers were knifing through the Polish defenses. Then the telephone rang. "Better get in here, Chamberlain's broadcasting at 11," an Associated Press colleague reported. "This may be it." Outside, Foulis Terrace was almost deserted, except for two elderly ladies who descended in stately fashion from a house farther down the road.

title: As Trucks Shun Turnpike, Small Towns Are Run Over
description: To the Editor:

title: Women: June 11, 1989;Last Year Oprah Winfrey Made $25 Million
description: When she walks from room to room in her large apartment, which receives cool light from Lake Michigan, Oprah Winfrey talks to herself, little purring, self-approving speeches - as if to reproach the silence, as if silence were a form of inactivity, a vacuum that called out to be filled.

title: WEDDINGS;Stacy Miller, T.J. Mahoney Jr.
description: Stacy Ann Miller, a daughter of Sue Grousd and a stepdaughter of Dr. Michael H. Grousd of Lake Forest, Ill., was married yesterday to Timothy J. Mahoney Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mahoney of Chatham, N.J. The Rev. George J. Rassas officiated at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Lake Forest.

title: The Fall of Communism: March 11, 1990;Poland's Return To Europe
description: It was in Poland where the Soviet Empire began to crumble - and where a post-Communist Central Europe began to emerge. Herewith, notes on that revolution from a Times correspondent, a leading Polish dissident and a world-renowned poet

title: Face-Off;North Korea Wouldn't Invade the South, Would It?
description: EVERY evening, South Korean soldiers rake some beautiful white beaches, smoothing out the sand from one end to the other. It is not to make it prettier, for no one is allowed in the area at night: the point is to be able to check for footprints in the morning to see if a new Korean War is breaking out.

title: Race and Rights: July 9, 1972, Chicago;Jesse Jackson: 'I Am . . . ' Audience: 'I Am . . . ' Jesse: 'Somebody' Audience: 'Somebody'
description: The service has been going on for almost two hours.

title: Q and A
description: Horse Racing in England

title: The Early Years: Aug. 2, 1908;The Growing Menace of the Use of Cocaine
description: The 'coke-peddler,' said an expert on the drug, "is a familiar figure in the back rooms of salooon dives throughout the country and every 'red-light district' has a drug store which caters especially to the 'coke' is probably much more widely spread among Negroes than among whites. 'Heaven dust' they call it..."

title: Future of Wainwright House in Doubt Despite Trust Fund
description: THE seasons present a shifting tableau along the waterfront at Wainwright House Inc. here, but the 44-year-old, nonprofit organization has traditionally focused on more timeless concerns.

title: WEDDINGS;Jennifer Sheppard, Michael Freitag
description: Jennifer Lynn Sheppard, an associate at White & Case, the New York law firm, was married yesterday to Michael Louis Freitag, a partner in Kekst & Company, the financial public relations firm in New York. Judge Joseph I. Dever of the Lynn District Court in Massachusetts , officiated at the Lyman Estate, a historic house in Waltham, Mass.

title: Our Towns;12-Year Fight For Justice Forges a Bond
description: IT has reached the point where Larry Miller and Richard Emanuel finish each other's sentences. While one tells a story about The Case, the other chimes in, cracks wise, wells up with tears.

title: Essences of Ease;REPOSE
description: MORE THAN ANY OTHER PIECE of furniture, the chair serves a multitude of functions: dining, working, dressing, entertaining. Histroically, one of its main purposes, starting with thrones and continuing down to the lowly stool, was to indicate rank. Today, however, providing a place of uninterrupted comfort is perhaps the chair's most significant role. Luckily, there are as many styles and types of seating to choose from as there are personalities to match. Whether sitting upright to read, or slouched and cosseted by the deep fluff of downy cushions, or supported by just enough padding to feel suspended above daily cares, we all devise our own way to enjoy a favorite chair. Ultimately, in the embrace of good seating, finding true relaxation is a process of discovery.

title: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;After 50 Years, Still Coaxing Secrets Out of Clay
description: The potter Peter Voulkos has traveled far from what he called the "mud shop" in Bozeman, Mont., where he made and sold dishes and bowls as dinnerware nearly 50 years ago. Nobody eats from his plates any more: they are too large, too roughly surfaced and, most of all, too costly. Today his ceramics are art. Some are cracked, full of holes or as charred as burned steak. His sack-shaped buckets and the large, bulbous, narrow-necked forms he calls stacks are considered sculpture.

title: Long Island Q&A: Harriet Marion Fulbright;A Life Devoted to Carrying the Torch for Sharing Knowledge
description: HARRIET MARION FULBRIGHT'S life has been devoted to education, first as a teacher and then through her involvement with the Fulbright Scholarship Program begun by her husband, Senator J. William Fulbright of Arkansas, who died last year.

title: April 7-13;DNA Cuts Both Ways
description: At a time when DNA fingerprinting has become commonplace, the announcement last week that a DNA test had linked Kerry Kotler, a 37-year-old man, to a rape on Long Island last summer, was still extraordinary. Why? Only four years ago, a DNA test had cleared the same man of another rape, for which he had served 11 years in prison.

title: Mayor Downplays Rival Stadium Plan
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he was not overly concerned that New Jersey officials had drafted plans for a baseball stadium to house the New York Yankees once the lease on the team's Bronx home expires in 2002.

title: Fighting for Turf: Sotheby's vs. Christie's
description: WHEN Christie's, the auction house, last year bought Great Estates, the real estate marketing company, a handful of Manhattan brokerage firms competed to be anointed as the New York City affiliate, vying to pay a $100,000 annual fee for the privilege of using Christie's venerable name and all the business referrals that go with it.

title: The World;Giving War a Chance
description: A scant two months ago, the war between fundamentalist Islamic guerrillas and Israel in southern Lebanon was a minor smudge in an otherwise hopeful picture for the Israelis. The peace with the Palestinians was moving along well, the Syrians were at the peace table in Washington, and if the Party of God guerrillas were still harassing Israeli troops in their buffer zone in southern Lebanon, the clashes were limited. Anyway, the entire conflict would go away once there was peace with Syria.

title: Marlboro Man Doesn't Deserve Honor;Cold Comfort
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping Children Off the Streets
description: THE supervisor of the New Haven Police Department's juvenile services, Lieut. Douglas MacDonald, placed his hands on the shoulders of a 12-year-old boy standing in front of him. The boy, just under 4 feet tall and weighing about 50 pounds, fixed his eyes on the floor and said nothing. He had just been arrested for car theft, and this was not the first time.

title: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;Human Capital, Unmasked
description: IMAGINE yourself the manager of a team of five engineers. The team is experienced, well-knit and highly effective. The team members have paid their dues and know their subject area better than anyone else on earth. Their project is on track. And now, to your dismay, one of the five announces that she will be leaving at the end of the month. What a disaster. You call Personnel. "Louise is leaving on the 31st," you tell them. "Send me another Louise."

title: 1970's: March 7, 1971;Fighting the Good Fights
description: And there are millions of people who want Ali to win. Most of them have no feeling at all about the bright, decent Frazier. Ali is the only character on stage. For some of them he is the Third World or the Noble Savage or the Child Who Will Show Us The Way. For others he is the man who stood firm, who was willing to suffer for his convictions. . . . There are those who see him as youth and light and magic, a Technicolor genie in a bottle-green world. And there are those who simply see him as the man who told the Establishment to stuff itself.

title: THE PRICE OF RELAXATION
description: 55 and Under

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: TRAIN;Stubs for Passes
description: Amtrak does not show movies on its trains, but it's offering the next best thing. Customers who buy Northeast Direct tickets (a service that links 44 cities from Boston to Newport News, Va.) worth $35 or more in April or May can get two free tickets to a movie at United Artists and Sony/ Loews theaters in the Northeast. To get the movie passes passengers must mail in a form, available at Amtrak stations, and their train-ticket stubs. Information: (800) 872-7245.

title: Race and Rights: Sept. 10, 1961;Is It Finally Time for Freedom?
description: On a chill morning in the autumn of 1956, an elderly, toil-worn Negro woman in Montgomery, Ala., began her slow, painful four-mile walk to her job. It was the tenth month of the Montgomery bus boycott, which had begun with a life expectancy of one week. The old woman's difficult progress led a passer-by to inquire sympathetically if her feet were tired. Her simple answer became the boycotters' watchword. "Yes, friend, my feet is real tired, but my soul is rested."

title: Whimsical Street Clock Has Imprint of Modernists
description: To the Editor:

title: GARDENING;A Time to Ponder Amid Shoots and Buds
description: APRIL is the month of new beginnings, when the landscape starts to come alive. The earliest bulbs have bloomed; others are up, waiting their turn. Buds on the maple trees, elms and oaks are getting fatter, ready to burst. In some places there are even patches of new grass.

title: The Great Outdoors: July 13, 1969;The Moon is Green
description: The Moon Is Green. We have spent something like $33 billion on space so far. We should have spent it on cleaning up our filthy colonies here on earth. There is no urgency whatsoever about getting somewhere in space, much as Arthur C. Clarke wants to. ... Brilliant space enthusiasts like Arthur C. Clarke are treasurers, of course, to the thousands of persons in the enormously profitable spaceship trade. ... "The discovery that Jupiter is quite warm and has precisely the type of atmosphere in which life is believed to have arisen on Earth may be the prelude to the most significant biological findings of this century," he wrote recently. ... Somewhere cash registers ring. By KURT VONNEGUT JR., from "Excelsior! We're Going to the Moon! Excelsior," JULY 13, 1969

title: The Early Years: May 30, 1937;At Home With the Fuhrer
description: As a rule official business is out of the way by lunch time. It is well known that Hitler is a vegetarian and does not drink or smoke. His lunch and dinner consist, therefore, for the most part of soup, eggs, vegetables and mineral water, although he occasionally relishes a slice of ham and relieves the tediousness of his diet with such delicacies as caviar, luscious fruits and similar tidbits. He is outspoken about having a sweet tooth and loves confectionery, especially chocolates. However, regular meals are served for guests. . . .

title: In the Region/Westchester;Downsized Kraft Checking Out of White Plains
description: LATE last month Kraft Foods announced that it would be vacating 623,700 square feet of office space at its signature red-brick building on North Street here. This time, however, brokers seem almost sanguine about the news of yet another downsizing.

title: WEDDINGS;Caren Levy, Jonathan Greenhouse
description: Caren Elizabeth Levy, a daughter of Leslie and James Levy of White Plains, was married last evening to Jonathan David Greenhouse, the son of Eileen Greenhouse Genet of Short Hills, N.J., and the late Randy Greenhouse. Rabbi Andre Unger officiated at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Broadway: Feb 1, 1953;Broadway Is Dead. Long Live Broadway
description: BROOKS ATKINSON: As usual, the theater is dying. No new theater has been built since 1927. ... From an economic point of view, the legitimate theater is like its buildings: it is obsolete. But as usual, the theater continues. ... Broadway is the magic land that attracts young people from everywhere. From "Theater: Culture and Carnival," FEB. 1, 1953

title: ON THE MAP;In Manalapan, Bargain-Hunters Show Up Early and Often
description: For three generations, the family of Steven J. Sobechko has owned and run Englishtown Auction Sales, a market for discounted and used merchandise on Englishtown-Old Bridge Road in Manalapan Township.

title: College Bills and Rewards
description: To the Editor:

title: The 1980's: May 3, 1987;I Dare You
description: Follow me around. I don't care," Gary Hart says firmly, about the womanizing question. "I'm serious. If anybody wants to put a tail on me, go ahead. They'd be very bored."

title: 1940's: June 1, 1941;From Shaw To Us
description: Citizens of the United States of America, the whole 130 millions of you, I am sending you my old plays, just as you are sending us your old destroyers. Our Government has very kindly thrown in a few naval bases as well; it makes a bargain perhaps more welcome to you. Now, the German humorist, I think his name is Dr. Goebbels, he has got a great deal of innocent fun out of that. He tells us -- or rather he tells the rest of the world -- that England has sold her colonies for scrap iron. Well, why shouldn't we? We are in very great need of scrap iron. We are collecting iron from door to door. Our women are bringing out their old saucepans. . . .

title: In the Region/Long Island;For Sale: Glen Cove Estate, With All Approvals
description: THE 47-acre Pembroke estate overlooking Long Island Sound, once owned by the Loew family, which bought it in 1920, has come on the market as an approved 46-house subdivision.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;The Composer Was Courageous, But Not as Much as in Myth
description: NINETEEN FORTY-EIGHT was the worst year of Dmitri Shostakovich's life. The crisis surfaced on Feb. 10, with the infamous resolution of the Central Committee of the Communist Party indicting Shostakovich and other leading Soviet composers as "formalists," enemies of the people. Official displeasure over a new opera by the sycophantic hack Vano Muradeli quickly escalated into wholesale intervention by the party into all aspects of musical life, directed by Stalin's cultural henchman Andrei Zhdanov.

title: Broadway: Feb. 13, 1994;Broadway Is Dead. Long Live Broadway
description: FRANK RICH: What did change in the late 1980's and early 1990's was the quality and texture of American playwriting, which became more diverse. ... Yet, for all this creative flowering, the mood in the New York theater continued to turn sour. ... Rising costs and ticket prices continued to erode Broadway. ... "Sometimes you see death everywhere," went a totemic line in John Guare's brilliant theatrical summation of the 1980's in New York, "Six Degrees of Separation." From "Exit the Critic," FEB. 13, 1994

title: ART REVIEW;When the West Embraced a Japanese Sensibility
description: THERE are birds and bees, along with rabbits, frogs and seemingly mice enough to keep a researcher busy for a week, at the Zimmerli Museum here. They are all to be found in the roughly 100 prints and watercolors making up "Flora and Fauna: The Japanese Influence on the Depiction of Nature in Western Art, 1875-1925." (Snappy title.)

title: ART;Overcoming the Image-Reversal Problem With Woodcuts
description: THAT prints reverse the images from which they are pulled is a fact of life, and few if any printmakers give it a second thought. But when he began to produce woodcuts, in the 1950's, Alvin Most gave reversal many thoughts, for he found it constricting to work on a block and not know the results until he saw the impression. The way Mr. Most described it in a recent conversation, the experience was like backing and filling without the aid of a rearview mirror.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;Gym Suspect: Little Exercise
description: In the 20th Precinct, where serious crime has dropped by 50 percent in the last three years and the crime rate is among the lowest in the city, four health-club locker break-ins in a month constitute a crime wave. Two such thefts were recently reported at the Equinox Fitness Club on Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street, and two were reported at the Reebok Sports Club, Columbus Avenue and 60th Street.

title: Race and Rights: March 16, 1969, Guaymas, Mexico;Yossarian Is Alive and Well in the Mexican Desert
description: It is a moment of intense concentration. Mike Nichols, the director of the film, is sitting in a blue director's chair, his face contorted, his hands clenched, his eyes squeezed shut. He finally opens his mouth to speak. "Bladder," he says. "Whimsy. Dailies. Rumble. Barren. Crystal. Pastry."

title: The Early Years: Jan. 8, 1928;Henry Ford: The Mussolini of Highland Park
description: Probably Henry Ford would resent being called a despot -- even a beneficent despot. For all that, he is an industrial Fascist -- the Mussolini of Highland Park, Fordson and Dearborn, not to mention works in Europe and agencies in every part of the world. No man in contemporary industry wields such dictatorial power. Since he and his son own the stock in the many Ford companies, he is responsible only to himself for dividends and for the success or failure of policies that affect the happiness of more than 125,000 employees. He dominates everywhere.

title: IN BRIEFS;This Is a Recording: Tax Lines Are Very Busy
description: For taxpayers desperate for last-minute information, the state's Tax Hotline may not seem so hot. In fact, the Hotline and the related Tax Talk line are probably lukewarm at best, judging from the volume of busy signals and the time a caller spends on hold. Here's a sampling of calls last week. TAX HOTLINE (609-588-2200) Tuesday, 5 P.M.: Busy. 5:05 P.M.: Busy. 5:30 P.M.: It's ringing! A recorded voice answers: "You have reached the New Jersey Tax Hotline. Please hold the line, and the next available assistant will assist you," followed by a schedule of the division's extended office hours, followed by music. 5:32 P.M.: Still holding. The music is interrupted by another recorded message: "Remember, your call will be answered in the order it was received. So please, don't hang up and redial. That will only further delay your call." More music. 5:34 P.M.: Still holding. Then, another recording. Music. 5:35 P.M.: Holding. Another recording. 5:36 P.M.: Music, followed by a disorienting sound -- the live voice of a woman asking how she can help. She answers three questions in a casual but knowing tone, inspiring confidence that her information is correct; her answers also match an accountant's.

title: Broadway: June 25, 1967;Broadway Is Dead. Long Live Broadway
description: WALTER KERR: Broadway's patterns are transparently stock: everyone knows that. ... But if, as we move away from the despised commercial center to the hoped-for excitements of ... Absurdist nihilism, Brechtian-inspired alienation or any other sort of nose-thumbing, we discover that we are mainly pouring old hat into new hat boxes ... how are we to escape the overpowering conviction that the theater as such is stale? ... From "The Theater Is the Victim of a Plot," JUNE 25, 1967

title: The Early Years: Nov. 9, 1930;The Mystic
description: From the study of history, one is inclined to regard religion and science as irreconcilable antagonists. . . . But . . . I assert that the cosmic religious experience is the strongest force and the noblest driving force behind scientific research.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;University of Miami Football Player and Woman Killed
description: Just nine months after Marlin Barnes helped start a Right Track Program in North Miami to help steer youngsters away from trouble, the University of Miami junior linebacker was found stabbed to death today.

title: A Tiny District Defends the Right to Be Small
description: FOR as long as anyone in this button-sized town can remember, children have filed into a single, beloved building each morning. Since they oversee only one school, members of the Cranbury Board of Education have fewer topics than most to debate around budget time. But for districts this small -- and in New Jersey, there are dozens -- board members are especially vulnerable to a prospect that tends to make their skin crawl.

title: South Africa: Sept. 8, 1985;Guarding Paradise
description: The police dogs are guarding the gates of paradise. Keep away from roads that pass where the blacks and the police-army are contained in their vortex of violence, and life can go on as usual. One can turn one's attention to matters that affect one directly and can be dealt with without bloodying one's hands: lobbying all over the world against disinvestment and sports boycotts. These are areas where sophisticated people understand one another in economic and leisure self-interests: for many, the only brotherhood that transcends nation and race.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;Hot Heads On Hairdresser Lane
description: STROLL along Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, anytime, any day of the week, and in the hubbub of commerce you'll find people getting their hair permed, weaved, braided, blow-dried, curled, wrapped or set.

title: April 7-13;Rostenkowski's Mean Ways
description: For years, he was one of the nation's most influential politicians, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. He was an oversized, swaggering Democrat who dominated the writing of tax laws. At the snap of his fingers, half of the lobbyists in Washington would have backed up Brinks trucks to his office to unload money bags.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;Dollar Outlook Brighter After Last Year's Slide
description: WITH the possible exception of the weather, no single variable in planning for international travel is more subject to uncertainty than the value of the dollar. Just consider last year. The dollar was hitting new lows against its Japanese, German and French counterparts in the spring, and it seemed unclear when the slide would end.

title: The 1980's: December 14, 1980;Looking Back at 80
description: Since my boyhood I have been vain of having been born just before the end of 1900 and, at every birthday, thinking of myself as pretty well as old as the century. It was at ease with its assumptions for 14 years: after that, two dreadful wars, huge serial changes, technological revolution, the disappearance of British power, the rise of the welfare state, a decade or two of "peace" in the world abroad, dramatic upheaval once more. Now that I am 80, I see I have been shaken up like dice in a box, if not as painfully as people born 10 years earlier than myself. Many are still alive and in voice. I am abashed by my survival, rather than proud of it; there is no merit in it. The credit goes to those secretive gamblers we call the genes. I come of long-lived forebears among whom there were few defaulters on the Yorkshire side. Also, because of the great advances of medical science and hygiene, the average expectation of life in Great Britain has enormously increased in the last 50 years or more. The old are no longer revered curiosities: on the contrary, often a social problem. We swarm in cities and resorts, ancient mariners who square our shoulders as we pick one another out at a glance in the pubs, the shops, the park seats, the planes and the tourist buses. Our skins do not yet give off the eerie smell of dotard. That glance of ours is often frisky, conspiratorial and threatening, warning the world at large that we could a tale unfold if we should happen to get a grip on your wrist. Not a day's illness -- we boast -- except a winter cough or a twinge of arthritis or gout -- we speak of these twitches as medals we have won. Smoke like fish (we go on), drink like a chimney, pity people who do not work a 12-hour day, who have not ducked their heads through two world wars or known the good old hard times. And as for this new thing called sex -- what we could tell you about that! Only last night . . .

title: The 1980's: March 11, 1984;Return to the Crime
description: I had tried not to think about it; I had put it off. But I knew that one day, like an automaton, so I would not feel emotion or panic, I would have to look for the clandestine prison called Puesto Vasco. I would have to enter that tiny cell without a number, close that steel door behind me, put my right eye up to that peephole and look at the cell across the way. I would have to relive that night when another eye looked back at me through the peephole in the opposite cell, an eye I never saw again but have carried with me as an integral part of my body, of my very nature, so that something of the owner of that eye will continue to live, the prisoner who was surely murdered and thrown into a mass grave.

title: PUBLIC INTEREST;Community Board Meetings in Manhattan and Queens
description: MANHATTAN

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: BOOK;Small-Screen Landmarks
description: Homes of famous Americans have long been tourist destinations, from Jefferson's Monticello to Hearst's San Simeon. Now there is a book that points out Ralph Kramden's Brooklyn apartment house. "TVacations" (Pocket Books, $12), by Fran Wenograd Golden, is a 352-page paperback that lists buildings and other sites used as locations in television series past and present. Fans of the old "Batman" series, for example, can visit the cave in Griffith Park in Los Angeles that was the Batcave. To order, call (800) 223-2336.

title: Race and Rights: Aug. 24, 1969;Chicago, Where All America Was Radicalized
description: One afternoon during the 1968 Democratic National Convention, I came out of the air-conditioned Tribune Tower in Chicago to find a long line of demonstrators marching past on the sun-blistered sidewalk of Michigan Avenue. The New York Times was using rented office space in the Tower as its center for convention coverage and I was on my way to an early session at the Stockyards Amphitheater.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 16 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the film "August," and a film listing on page 39 in some editions, misstate the given name of an actor. He is Gawn Grainger, not Dawn.

title: East German Is Hailed for a Scathing Appraisal of Unification
description: With a passionate warning that German leaders are squandering the promise of unification, an outspoken engineer-turned-legislator named Eckhardt Rehberg has emerged as a hero in eastern Germany.

title: 1940's: Sept. 27, 1981;The Horror of Babi Yar
description: Bruised and bloodied, numbed by the incomprehensibility of their fate, the Jews emerged onto a grassy clearing. They had arrived at Babi Yar; ahead of them lay a ravine. The ground was strewn with clothing. Ukranian militiamen, supervised by Germans, ordered the Jews to undress. Those who balked, who resisted, were assaulted, their clothes ripped off. Naked bleeding people were everywhere. Screams and hysterical laughter filled the air. Some people's hair turned gray on the spot. Others went mad in moments.

title: Rhode Island Doors Open to Visitors
description: As intriguing as the grand mansions of Newport may be, visitors to Rhode Island can, in the months ahead, get a broader view of the state's homes and gardens.

title: CHATTER;New Jersey, New and Improved
description: If you could be queen (or king) of New Jersey for a day, with unlimited power, what one thing would you change in the state?

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS;Mourning a Cherished Chapel
description: There isn't much to the red-brick chapel on the corner of Bergen and Bond Streets, only four oscillating fans affixed to the cream-painted walls, 24 pews on the thin blue carpet, and a humble wood organ. Yet for the aging Hispanic congregants who worshiped there for some 30 years, it was more than enough.

title: ART;In Stamford, a Decorous Annual
description: NO waves are made, few waters churned. The "New Art Annual '96" at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center is a pleasant, decorous affair, on the conservative side. That is, conservative by 20th-century standards, and this has certainly been a ground-breaking century.

title: An Old-Fashioned Catholic School Finds New Success
description: FOR anyone who ever attended a Catholic school, a few minutes at St. John School in Old Saybrook will stir up a lot of memories. Orderly lines of little people, girls in plaid skirts, boys in shirts and ties, file quietly along the corridors to their classrooms, past the religious pictures and statuary, past Sister Marie Alberta, the principal.

title: Vietnam: Jan. 20, 1980;THE DEATH AND LIFE OF DITH PRAN
description: After a breakfast of Pepsi-Cola at a restaurant whose French proprietor is glad for company but who has no other food, we walk back to the hotel and decide it is still safe to move around. So we drive to the biggest civilian hospital -- Preah Keth Mealea -- to get some idea of casualties. People are bleeding to death on the corridor floors. . . .

title: JERSEY;Filling a Niche in the Movie Market
description: MY wife hates it when I grab the paper on Friday mornings and fish out the section with the reviews of all the movies we're not going to see, not in New Jersey.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION;Perfecting the Art of Psychosis
description: In his clever and incisive novel, NAMING THE JUNGLE (New Press, $18.95), the French writer Antoine Volodine follows the remembered and invented lives of Fabian Golpiez, a man "rich in cowardice," as he struggles to get by in the post-revolutionary society of Puesto Libertad, a prototypical Latin American city surrounded by jungle and mystery. Since his survival strategy involves feigning mental illness, Fabian must undergo a unique therapy at the not-too-gentle hands of Dr. Gonalves, a combination shaman and psychiatrist who practices in the requisitioned office of a "disappeared" dentist.
