Sitting in the dental chair, surrounded by drills and other implements of the trade, the patient spins out tales that are part memory and part contrivance, all designed to maintain his status as "a psychotic with severe and intractable disabilities." It is not easy work, for the doctor demands quality stories: "These standard hallucinations! Vibrating canoes, anacondas! Old hat! Rivers fermenting beneath their cargo of leaves. . . . Always the same junk! Sexual symbolism for half-wits!" Obediently, Fabian digs deeper, inventing and reinventing himself, winding his way through love affairs, shootouts and voyages of exploration and discovery until finally, traveling upriver toward the source of his imaginings, he appears to invent Dr. Gonalves himself. In Linda Coverdale's spirited translation, "Naming the Jungle" (which is the first of Mr. Volodine's books to be published in English) emphasizes the uncertainties of the characters and their jumbled lives by placing them in an especially well-defined world. The therapy Fabian goes through to maintain his supposed craziness involves establishing an Indian identity by naming the plants and creatures of the jungle. Only the people remain hard to pin down. But that uncertainty, that refusal to locate themselves, Mr. Volodine suggests, is precisely what makes them worth caring about. James Polk

title: Race and Rights: Nov. 3, 1963;A Waif in Schnook's Clothing
description: Woody Allen, a slight young man of 27 who recently moved out of the East Side's Blue Angel and into Greenwich Village's Bitter End, is a "new" young comedian who differs greatly from his fellow performers in demeanor, delivery and total effect. Allen does not have Mort Sahl's brassy expansiveness, or Shelley Berman's ferrety persuasiveness; nor does he indulge in the shock-for-shock's-sake approach practiced by Lenny Bruce. What Allen projects -- and his work has been called "fresh," "bright," "individual" -- is wistful futility. He is a waif in schnook's clothing -- bedeviled always by the world and by society.

title: Race and Rights: Nov. 17, 1901 - Dec. 15, 1901 (a six-part series);The Black North: A Social Study
description: The North, and especially great cities like New York, has much more than an academic interest in the Southern Negro problem. Unless the race conflict there is so adjusted as to leave the Negroes a contented, industrious people, they are going to migrate here and there. And into the large cities will pour in increasing numbers the competent and the incompetent, the industrious and the lazy, the law abiding and the criminal. Moreover, the conditions under which these new immigrants are now received are of such a nature that very frequently the good are made bad and the bad made professional criminals.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE;Fight to Regain School Board Voice
description: For 8 of the 20 candidates running for Community School Board 2, there is a missionary fervor: winning representation for the Upper East Side on the board.

title: ROAD AND RAIL;A Terminal Re-emerges From Years of Grime
description: Of all the signs and placards that have gone up in the Hoboken Terminal over the last few months, the most poignant may be the temporary one labeled "Lost and Found." The three words sum up New Jersey Transit's efforts to rediscover what has been lost for many years: the terminal's historic grandeur and tantalizing potential.

title: Logical Loopholes
description: To think of taxes is to think of loopholes, and to think of loopholes is to sneer. Even as we use them, we bristle at how inept, corrupt lawmakers just can't seem to keep the tax code free of them. There wouldn't be any loopholes, we grumble, if only Congress would do its job right.

title: In the Region/New Jersey;The Hills of Watchung Are Alive With Housing
description: AS the first half of The Hills, a huge housing community that has risen over the last 14 years within the folds of the Watchung Hills in Bedminster Township, is nearing completion, activity is churning here on its second half on the other side of the hill.

title: 1950's: March 8, 1959;An Intimate Lunch With Fidel
description: I had spoken to him three times in the wild, exultant first days of his victory. Six weeks had since passed. The excitement was over. The dreams had turned into harsh realities. For four afternoon hours, sometimes surrounded by his barbudos (the bearded ones who fought with him in the Sierra) and by the women who were looking after him, but mostly alone with me indoors or strolling around the grounds of his house, he talked and occasionally listened.

title: The Fall of Communism: Jan. 14, 1990;Poland's Return To Europe
description: It was in Poland where the Soviet Empire began to crumble - and where a post-Communist Central Europe began to emerge. Herewith, notes on that revolution from a Times correspondent, a leading Polish dissident and a world-renowned poet

title: For Many Older Gay People, A Life History Is Ignored
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLUSHING;Councilwoman Loses Backing
description: Senator Leonard Stavisky, center, joined in rebuking Julia Harrison. Julia Harrison, the Flushing Councilwoman whose criticism of Asian immigrants stirred a storm of protest in recent weeks, has lost whatever support she had from the Queens Democratic establishment.

title: Walter R. Harding, 79, Professor Whose Life's Work Was Thoreau
description: Dr. Walter R. Harding, a leading scholar of the life and works of Henry David Thoreau and emeritus professor of English at the State University of New York College at Geneseo, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Dansville, N.Y. He was 79.

title: ON POLITICS;The Grim Reality of AIDS, The Grim Reality of Politics
description: David W. Troast is hardly a wild-eyed radical. A lifelong Republican, Mr. Troast is a soft-spoken, successful businessman from Hunterdon County. He lives about three miles from Governor Whitman and they sometimes run into each other at social events.

title: Insurance Discounts for Daytime Lights
description: New York State now requires that auto insurance companies reduce their premiums by 2.5 to 3 percent for residents who own cars with factory-installed daytime running lights, which have been shown to reduce head-on and side-impact collisions.

title: Some Fifth Graders Are Starting To Date Early
description: THE flirtatious glances and giggling whispers that punctuate lunchroom chatter at the Ardsley Middle School would be unremarkable for seventh- and eighth-grade students practicing dating skills.

title: Race and Rights: Aug. 1, 1965;Nature Shock
description: The model for our right relation to nature should be that of the good trainer of animals. It seems obvious to me, for instance, that a well-trained sheep dog has more realized its "dog nature" than a wild one, just as a spoiled lap dog or one terrified by ill usage has had its "dogginess" debased. This means, of course, reintroducing the notion of teleology. . . . Our world will be a safer and healthier place when we can admit that every time we make an atomic bomb we corrupt the morals of a host of innocent neutrons below the age of consent.

title: DRIVING;Trouble Spots on the Road To Avoid This Week
description: A look at trouble spots you may encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of Transcom, an interstate transportation agency.

title: Race and Rights: Dec. 27, 1964;A Stranger In Philadelphia, Miss.
description: The kindly old man, a wholesale grocer near retirement, was sitting by the window in his store, picking his way down one of the tangled paths of this community's exclusive topics of conversation -- race and murder.

title: THEATER;A Courtroom by Day, but a Stage by Night
description: TIME: 8 P.M. last Monday.

title: April 7-13;Mr. and Ms. Doctor
description: Last week two separate studies -- one of professors and one of doctors -- concluded that men and women are still paid different salaries for the same work.

title: Broadway: June 12, 1960;What's The Theater For?
description: TENNESSEE WILLIAMS: My mother ... says to me so often, "Son, when there is so much unpleasantness in the world, why is it necessary to put it on the stage?" ... The nervous system of any age or nation is its creative workers, its artists. And if that nervous system is profoundly disturbed by its environment, the work it produces will inescapably reflect the disturbance, sometimes obliquely and sometimes with violent directness. ...

title: The Early Years: Sept. 11, 1932, Munich;Hitler and the Mob
description: Adolf Hitler. What would he be like? What is the secret of his strange power? I wondered, vaguely, as I wandered in the streets of Munich. . . .

title: Cold War Heroes
description: ON THE BRINK The Dramatic, Behind-the-Scenes Saga of the Reagan Era and the Men and Women Who Won the Cold War. By Jay Winik. Illustrated. 672 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $30.

title: The 1980's: April 3, 1983;My Mother Eleni
description: In 1980 Nicholas Gage, then 41, left his job as a New York Times correspondent in Athens and began to hunt for his mother's killers. He found - but spared the life of - the man who prosecuted and sentenced his mother to death.

title: 1940's: March 4, 1945 Iwo Island (By Wireless);The Road to Tokyo: Red Epic of Iwo
description: Nine o'clock is H-hour. The first wave misses it by just two minutes and is reported ashore at 0902. Six waves come in by L.V.T. (landing vehicle tracked) or armored "alligator," which is a light tank and side-wheel boat combined.

title: Commendable Restraint by the F.B.I.
description: Determined not to repeat the mistakes of Ruby Ridge and Waco, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has adopted a creative, restrained strategy for dealing with members of the Freemen separatist group wanted on criminal charges. This strange, sometimes threatening band of religious bigots and tax scofflaws is hunkered down in farmhouses they have commandeered in rural Montana.

title: So What Will You Have, Hon?"
description: AT the Hilltop Diner, 164-02 Union Turnpike in Fresh Meadows, Queens, you can find a man who for five years now has eaten two meals a day there, seven days a week. You can find out why The Lunch Bunch became The Big Three. You can find out why it's better for management if someone has a few Cokes rather than a swordfish steak. You can find out what it means to order a Greek salad "Deborah's way."

title: ENCOUNTERS;A Sculptor Whose Model Is History
description: IN a lonesome meadow in Orient, a buffalo made of great planes of copper seems to roam. The sculptor and monument maker Robert Berks explains how to make three-dimensional shapes hold their lighting, even at a great distance, even when the sun's direction changes.

title: The Great Outdoors: March 10, 1985;John J. Audubon, Predator
description: Audubon had an advantage not shared by ... his predecessors who drew birds with such archaic stiffness. ... Audubon gave them the illusion of life. His method was to wire freshly killed specimens into lifelike positions on a gridded board. He describes the first time he tried this. "One morning I leapt out of bed ... went to the river, took a bath and returning to town inquired for wire of different sizes, bought some and was soon again at Mill Grove. I shot the first kingfisher I met, pierced the body with wire, fixed it to the board, another wire held the head, smaller ones fixed the feet ... there stood before me the real kingfisher. I outlined the bird, colored it. This was my first drawing actually from nature." ...

title: CUTTINGS;Preparing the Garden to Serve as Your Salad Bar
description: Every spring I like to write a little ode to the salad garden, especially for those beginners who may be fearful of lettuce.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAY RIDGE;Merchants Fear Cuts to Fairs
description: In a move to rein in street festivals, especially those car-clogging fairs that gobble up Manhattan avenues weekend after weekend, the Mayor's Office has imposed regulations that go into effect this month just as the festival season gets under way.

title: Corrections
description: The Frugal Traveler column on March 31, about Philadelphia, referred incorrectly to a change in William Penn's religious affiliation. Baptized an Anglican as an infant, he joined the Society of Friends at age 23. He did not convert from the Society of Friends to the Anglican church.

title: Race and Rights: Feb. 11, 1968;Memoirs of a 'Cold Warrior'
description: I find it more than a little odd that I -- and others like me -- should be denounced as an "obsessive" anti-Communist and an "incorrigible cold warrior." But, then, I must admit that I find many things odd about the new radicalism in American intellectual and literary circles. I am confused by middle-aged radicals who insist, in one and the same breath, that the present distribution of income is horribly inequitable and that you can't live decently in New York on less than $50,000 a year. I am bewildered by a highbrow left-wing magazine which proudly advertises that it is "cliquish" and "snobbish." I don't comprehend the merger that seems to have taken place between the literary left and cafe society, or the calm assumption that writers are and ought to be "celebrities."

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: GREENWICH VILLAGE;Lessons in How to Keep Your Planet Clean
description: FOR the second time in two years, hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers are expected to gather in Greenwich Village on Saturday to take part in activities celebrating Earth Day, to help create a greater awareness of the environment and the need to do more to save it.

title: RELIGION;Is Bad Counseling by Clergy A Proper Issue for Courts?
description: For all kinds of professionals, from doctors to lawyers to therapists, malpractice suits have become an increasingly common fact of life. Clergy members, however, have always been presumed to answer to an authority higher than the courts.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: TELEVISION VIEW;A Not So Grand Old Show
description: THE SHOW STARTED OUT WITH GREAT promise. The cast list, though made up of only Republicans, was long. And it was filled with some of American politics' quirkier character actors.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: GOING THE DISTANCE One Man's Journey to the End of His Life. By George Sheehan. Villard, $22.

title: THE QUEST FOR COMFORT
description: EVER since human beings learned to walk on their feet, it seems they've been trying to get off them. Apparently believing that rest couldn't be eternal without a place to recline, the anicent Egyptians filled their tombs with elegant chairs and beds. Chinese aristocrats of the Ming dynasty (1368-1644) could end an evening of revelry by falling into a portable reclining armchair: the zuiwengyi, or "drunken lord's chair." In Western culture, the English Knole settee, circa 1620, featured a cushioned headrest attached to each arm with hinges. If the occupant wanted a snooze, he just racheted a pillow into position.

title: WEDDINGS;Martha Chowning, Jonathan Groff
description: Martha Blakeley Chowning, the special assistant to the chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities in Washington, and Jonathan Carr Groff, the head writer for "Late Night With Conan O'Brien" on NBC-TV, were married yesterday in New Orleans.

title: Future Shock
description: THE FUTURE OF CAPITALISM How Today's Economic Forces Shape Tomorrow's World. By Lester C. Thurow. 385 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $25.

title: 5000 Sundays;Letter From the Editor
description: Why doesn't The New York Times print Sunday comics? It's a question people have been asking since 1896, when Adolph S. Ochs, a successful young publisher from Chattanooga, bought the newspaper. The Times then was struggling to stay alive and the obvious thing to do was offer what the giant newspapers of the era did: Sunday comic supplements. Ochs, however, had something else in mind. Just three weeks after taking over, he introduced an illustrated Sunday section with feature articles intended to appeal to intelligent readers and printed on coated paper for good reproduction of photographs: The New York Times Sunday Magazine Supplement.

title: Sensory Perception
description: Prospect The Journal of an Artist. By Anne Truitt. 221 pp. New York: Scribner. $22.

title: YOUR HOME;For Info On Co-ops, Type http://
description: AN increasing number of sites on the Internet's World Wide Web are providing valuable information and services for shareholders and board members of co-ops and condominiums. But to find them, you need to know where to look.

title: WEDDINGS;Miss Kozlowski, Mr. Magnano
description: Kimberly Sue Kozlowski, the daughter of Darlene and Dennis Kozlowski of Columbus, Ohio, was married yesterday to Robert Joseph Magnano, a son of Sheila Magnano of Norwalk, Conn., and the late Joseph P. Magnano. The Rev. David Blanchfield performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of Our Lady of Victory in New York.

title: EARNING IT;Can You See What's in Your Personnel File? It Depends
description: EVERY few weeks, Jon Howard Rosen, a labor lawyer in Seattle, gets a call from a client who wants to know if he has a right to see his personnel file.

title: What Separates Hate and Civil Disobedience?
description: To the Editor:

title: WEDDINGS: VOWS;Janice Lee and Joseph Bae
description: JANICE LEE and Joseph Bae, both 24, met at Harvard University, and in many ways they are still like college students.

title: Conversations/Kwame Ture;Formerly Stokely Carmichael And Still Ready for the Revolution
description: Kwame Ture, better known to most Americans as Stokely Carmichael, black power advocate, racial separatist and troublemaker (not necessarily in that order), is the unrepentant voice of the 60's. While most of the radical left of a generation ago has moved on, sold out or gone on to that great proletarian paradise in the sky, Mr. Ture continues to proselyte.

title: BOXING;Whitaker's Greatest Challenger: Motivation
description: Only after he was surrounded by those he knows best just after midnight today, Pernell Whitaker made the admission:

title: Foreign Affairs;Foreign Policy Wonk
description: There was a time a couple of years ago, somewhere between the debacles in Somalia and Bosnia, when the notion of President Clinton running for re-election trumpeting his foreign policy record would have seemed ludicrous. Foreign policy looked to be a sure loser for the President, something best left unspoken. But in the wake of recent successes from Bosnia to Haiti to trade, Bill Clinton definitely is not planning to run away from foreign policy in '96. To the contrary. He's planning to put it right in the Republicans' face -- and proud of it.

title: When Octopuses Are Flying in Detroit It's . . .
description: The secret to throwing a large octopus onto an ice hockey rink is to boil it first for 20 minutes on high heat with a little lemon juice and white wine to mask the odor.

title: FRUGAL TRAVELER;Deco and Deals In Miami's South Beach
description: RECENTLY I started reading mystery novels set in and around Miami by such writers as Elmore Leonard, Carl Hiaasen and Edna Buchanan -- page-turners full of fecund moons and firearms, Palm Beach palaces and shabby hotels, sad-sack victims and charismatic thugs. I found myself yearning to visit. So in February, I bought a round-trip ticket to Miami on Tower Airlines for $168 and flew south.

title: Whalers In Need of a Few (More) Good Fans
description: THE Mayor of Hartford, Michael P. Peters, says that if the Whalers decide to leave his city, "I'll be the guy lying down in front of the moving trucks."

title: The Great Outdoors: Oct. 10, 1909;Wilbur Wright Explains His Aeroplane
description: Our machine is superior to all others," Wright said. ... "The biplanes of Voisin and Farman are about the same size as ours. It is noticeable, however, that they use double the power and travel at less speed. In flight, the Voisin and Farman are sluggish, slow and lacking in precision of movement, while the Wright is the 'true bird,' quick in its action, maneuvring with promptness. ...

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ORGANS GALORE

title: 1970's: May 11, 1975;A Step in the Right Direction
description: The discotheques are at . . . full decibel. But there seem to be indications of a revival of more gracious forms. The dancers look at one another slightly more than they did 10 years ago. They occasionally touch, as in the hand-holding hustle. Even our young seem to sense something has been missing.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 6/ Some new, and some old, ways for investors to play foreign countries. By Doreen Hemlock.

title: Nast Show Is Only Part Of a Trove in Morristown
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: WHAT THEY TELL YOU TO FORGET A Novella and Stories. By Fred Pfeil. Pushcart, $25.

title: A CELEBRATION OF ONE HUNDRED YEARS
description: In the first of three centennial issues this year, The New York Times Magazine revisits the world as it has looked over the last 5,000 Sundays since the magazine's establishment by Adolph S. Ochs. This special retrospective number encompasses houses in the Hamptons (1897) and a family in Bosnia (1995), the rise of Broadway and the fall of Communism, civil rights and women's rights.

title: World News Briefs;Colombian Leader Faces A Renewed Graft Inquiry
description: The congressional committee that had been looking into charges that President Ernesto Samper used money from drug cartels in his election campaign in 1994 has decided to resume its investigation, even though most of the members of the committee have themselves been accused of improprieties.

title: FILM;With Video, 'Cut!' Needn't Be the Director's Final Word
description: FOR DIRECTORS, ONE NICE thing about video is the chance it gives them to go back and tinker with their old movies. "It's a subjective business and your perception changes," Oliver Stone said the other day. "Years go by, and you want to recut and change things."

title: YOUNG NEW JERSEY;Until Voices Mature, a Place for Boys to Grow
description: The adult male soprano, or castrato, has gone the way of the mutilating operation that made his range possible. For boys, the high voice remains their domain, if only till puberty. For that window in time, some join choirs that showcase their peculiarly clear, penetrating sweep of tone.

title: Body Parts Found on S.I.
description: A severed hand and torso were found Friday afternoon by children playing on a beach on eastern Staten Island, the police said.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;Pious Whimsy for the Keyboard
description: THE "BIBLICAL" SONATAS, Johann Kuhnau's little monument to what he called the "stylus phantasticus," were published in 1700. Along with the somewhat invidious fact that Kuhnau was Bach's immediate predecessor as the musical director for the town of Leipzig, they have kept his name a little bit alive in history books and on disk. I've never actually heard any of these "Musical Representations of Several Biblical Stories" in live performance, but there have been quite a few recordings; an ancient LP by Albert Fuller at the harpsichord, with a narrator to read the subtitles and occasional blow-by-blows, remains a treasured memory. Given a properly deadpan rendition, these assemblages of minuscule chorale preludes, fugues, toccatas and wordless recitatives can be somehow hilarious and touching at the same time.

title: Ariel Allen, Advertising Executive, 58
description: Ariel Allen, a senior advertising executive for the Colgate-Palmolive Company, died on April 7 in New York. She was 58.

title: South Africa: Sept. 19, 1976, Durban, South Africa;'Must Everything Be Destroyed?'
description: I write not to express my detestation of the policies of apartheid, not because my Government has cruelly and ruthlessly treated its more articulate opponents, including many of my friends, but because I fear for the future of Afrikanerdom. I fear it is going to be destroyed and I fear that the process of destruction has actually begun. . . .

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS;Special Today: Home Design/Magazine Part 2
description: The Essences of Ease: Elements that make rooms places of memorable experience: light, flow, repose and passages.

title: A Little Brooklyn Job With Lots of Influence
description: It is an election about which the average Brooklyn voter is likely to know little or nothing.

title: DINING OUT;French With Lineage
description: WHEN the server at La Petite Rose tells you that the sorrel in the special salmon appetizer is from the chef's own garden, don't you have to try it?

title: 1980's: Feb. 10, 1985;Andy and Jean-Michel
description: Their friendship seems symbiotic. As the elder statesman of the avantgarde, Warhol stamps the newcomer Basquiat with approval and has probably been able to give him excellent business advice.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: KNICKS NOTEBOOK;After Outburst, Starks Starts on the Bench
description: On Friday after practice, Jeff Van Gundy said his decision to start John Starks over Hubert Davis for the rest of the season might be tentative, adding, "that could change at any time."

title: Needle Center Could Find Better Ways to Spend Time
description: To the Editor:

title: SPOTLIGHT;Tough Love
description: Three out of 10 teen-agers are involved in dating violence. Aisha, who was physically beaten by her last boyfriend, admits that she was in love and says, "I never thought he would kill me - until the end." Kelly describes how her relationship slid from "sweet' to explosive, and how difficult it was to find a means of escape, which she finally did through a domestic-violence counselor. Michael appears with Tamara, his girlfriend, to talk about their continuing abusive relationship, which Michael attributes to his "Patriarchal background." The pair hold hands throughout the conversation. "When I do hit her," he says, "it's out of compassion. I do it to get her attention."

title: Race and Rights: Aug. 9, 1959;Southern Blacks: A Middle Class
description: To keep the Negroes in their place" still means, to most people who use the phrase, keeping them behind sledgehammers and mattocks, brooms and axes and plows, in the jobs requiring the most muscle for the least money.

title: Workers to Spruce Up Houses for Neighbors
description: SPRING is the season for home repairs and refurbishing. On May 4, about 10,000 Home Front volunteers in New York and Connecticut will wield hammers and paintbrushes, install windows and weed backyards for their less affluent neighbors.

title: A Man Whose Life Is One With Plants
description: LYNDHURST, 63 acres of dark, thick green carpeting on the bank of the Hudson River here, has been home to the wealthy since it was built in 1838. Jay Gould lived here; its last private owner was Anna, Duchess de Talleyrand-Perigord. For the last 25 years it has also been the home of Ralph Indivere, real name Raphael, nickname Ralphie. Mr. Indivere, a horticulturist for the National Trust for Historic Preservation property, until recently worked an eight-hour day, five days a week. He is 80 and seems to be on speaking terms with every tree and plant on the grounds.

title: Costa Rica
description: To the Editor: I am glad Francesca Lyman enjoyed the Corcovado Tent Camp ("Life at the Top in Costa Rica," Feb. 18). But as the camp's own literature states, potential visitors should "prudently judge whether or not they are suited for this type of experience."

title: The 1980's: May 17, 1981;How a Sit-in Turned Into a Siege
description: A little before noon on the drizzly Sunday of Nov. 4, some 400 students broke away from one of Teheran's frequent revolutionary demonstrations; this one was to commemorate Ayatollah Khomeini's exile 15 years before and to honor those who had died -- the score of "martyrs," as they are always called -- during the previous year's revolutionary protests at Teheran University. Now the students stormed down Takht-e-Jamshid Avenue and, with bolt-cutting shears, snipped through the chains holding the big iron gates in front of the American Embassy and swarmed into the manicured compound. Marine security guards, firing tear gas, in accordance with standing instructions, held them back for a time as the diplomats frantically tried to shred documents. Soon, the students had rushed through the buildings, rounding up the Americans along with 100 Iranians, most of them seeking visas to the United States. Several of the hostages remember being told not to worry, that it was merely a sit-in; others recall the students excitedly making calls from the embassy and recounting their adventures to their friends. A banner was strung up across the gates: "Khomeini struggles, Carter trembles." The occupation of the American Embassy in Iran had begun.

title: The Safir Agenda: Seeking Continuity Instead of Changes
description: In two weeks of private briefings that may reveal the first hints of his priorities, New York City's incoming Police Commissioner has focused on efforts to improve the department's corruption controls, coordinate police activities with Federal law enforcement and ease tensions with the police union, senior officials say.

title: 1950's: May 17, 1951;The Cold War at Home and Abroad
description: If our handling of the problem of Communist influence in our midst is not carefully moderated -- if we permit it, that is to become an emotional preoccuption and to blind us to the more important positive tasks before us -- we can do a damage to our national purpose beyond comparison greater than anything that threatens us today from the Communist side. . . . Something may occur in our own minds and souls which will make us no longer like the persons by whose efforts this republic was founded and held together, but rather like the representatives of that very power we are trying to combat; intolerant, secretive, suspicious, cruel and terrified of internal dissension because we have lost our own belief in ourselves and in the power of our ideals. The worst thing that our Communists could do to us, and the thing we have most to fear from their activities, is that we should become like them.

title: 1950's: April 15, 1956;The Monroe Doctrine
description: None of the customary reasons for an actress's success and fame explain very much when applied to Miss Monroe. . . .

title: BOOKSHELF;Reading, Writing and Riddling About Libraries
description: To celebrate National Library Week, which is April 14 to 20, the Fairview Free Public Library sponsored a poetry contest. Here is what some children had to say about their library, the smallest in Bergen County, according to its director, Arlene Sahraia.

title: Connecticut Q&A: George C. Springer;Speaking Out for Teachers in the Cities
description: GEORGE C. SPRINGER has led the 20,000-member Connecticut State Federation of Teachers for 17 years. He is troubled by a change in the way education is supported. "I think what people want for their kids is different than what they want for other people's kids," he said as he delineated some of the reasons that school support is declining.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;Transsexuals' Dual Risk of AIDS
description: By day, Terry Garcia attends Fordham University, studying to be a lab technician. But at night, the 44-year-old Vietnam veteran takes to the streets to earn a living as a transsexual prostitute, to pay for monthly estrogen injections and, eventually, surgery to become a woman.

title: Q and A
description: Broker's Fee Right Contested

title: THE NIGHT;A Peach, A Laugh, A Blessing
description: THE storm hitting the city on April 9 felt like a cartoon version of bad weather. Snow -- big, wet, overproduced blobs of it -- was dropping over the big peach on the roof of the Sony Imax theater at Broadway and West 68th Street.

title: The Early Years: June 14, 1936;His Strength Is in His Wallop
description: Joe Louis avoids meeting people, hates conversation (even fight talk) and says less than any man in sports history, including Dummy Taylor, the Giant pitcher, who was a mute. Dr. William Walker, who examined Louis before the Carner fight a year ago, was amazed at the man's silence. "Closest thing to a wooden Indian I ever saw," swore the doctor. And that creates a perfect picture of Louis -- outside the ring.

title: The Peacock Preens Again
description: AT the Capital Cities/ABC annual management meeting in February, in what amounted to his farewell address after the company merged with Walt Disney, Tom Murphy, the chairman of Cap Cities, had a message for his troops:

title: SOAPBOX;Late Winter Song
description: Spring was mugged while hitching a ride on Routes One and Nine; Going north with his bags of seed and his famous smile. But I understand that he never made it past the part where the road twists around Rahway prison. No one knows if it was some guys with multiple earrings in one ear who were responsible, or if it was that site of so much misery that did him in. But with his pockets empty he's been reported as appearing febrile and wandering sheepishly through the Meadowlands, maybe unable to decide which was the Starting Gate, or whether it was worth the starting after all; but then he got shacked, not knowing better, at the Swann Motel; And there are those that claim he's still there. Can anybody spare a dime to get him sprung? It's cold out there.

title: South Africa: May 4, 1986;Nothing Prepares You for Apartheid
description: I sprawled out in the back seat of the car, put a jazz tape in my cassette player and tuned my mind to another planet as two black South African journalists and I headed toward Johannesburg along a highway in the Orange Free State, a rarely compromising bastion of South African conservatism. We had spent most of the day covering the funeral of a former leader of the African National Congress, working under a pitiless sun in a patch of desolation that is part of the so-called black homeland of Bophuthatswana.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;Cutting to the Chase
description: Michael Barker, an Atlantic City lawyer, is in a quandary. He wants to do the right thing and is willing to make certain sacrifices to that end. He wants, he says, to take his "show on the road." The problem is how.

title: NONTONAL MUSIC;Another Emperor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation;Private Groups Lead Charge in War on Far Right
description: IN the year since the worst terrorist act on American soil, the bombing of a Federal building in Oklahoma City that killed 168 people, the number of right-wing groups harboring anti-government sentiments has been estimated at more than 800, by some counts, and they now operate in every state.

title: A Superhero in the Cartoon World
description: THREE Easy Steps to Drawing Joe Kubert: 1. Sketch square jaw, deep furrows in forehead. 2. Add large pulpy nose, thick gray hair, painfully firm handshake (OOOUUUCCCHHH!). 3. Pencil in background: Kubert drawings of Sergeant Rock, Tor the Caveman, and a nearly life-size Tarzan rescuing Jane from leaping, wide-mouthed crocodiles.

title: A Hospital Worries About 'People Who Fall Through the Cracks'
description: For most of his life, William Logan worked in heavy construction, and he was always able to get decent health insurance through the union. Then the heart problems started. He lost his job, and a succession of other jobs didn't pay well and didn't come with health benefits.

description: SHOWDOWN The Struggle Between the Gingrich Congress and the Clinton White House. By Elizabeth Drew. 398 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $25.

description: THOUGH the charm of Holly Springs, Miss., lies in its impressive assemblage of 19th-century houses, people in the area consider the hamburgers and catfish sandwiches at Phillips Grocery a more than adequate reason to visit the town.

title: Details
description: THE SIZE OF THOUGHTS Essays and Other Lumber. By Nicholson Baker. 355 pp. New York: Random House. $25.

title: Costa Rica
description: To the Editor: While I agree with Beth A. Brombert's "Inviting Lodgings, Luxuriant Land" (Feb. 18) about both accommodations and the countryside of Costa Rica, I feel compelled to warn about the dangers of food and water there, particularly during the rainy season.

title: The Fall of Communism: June 14, 1981;Poland's Return To Europe

description: LAST May, traveling in Spain's dramatic snowcapped Catalan Pyrenees, I found an extraordinary cache of Romanesque structures, unaltered for 10 centuries.

title: Vietnam: Sept. 24, 1989;RETURN TO THE KILLING FIELDS
description: At 8 A.M., we take an Air Kampuchea flight to the provincial town of Siem Reap, where I was born and raised. About 140 miles northwest of Phnom Penh, Siem Reap has long prospered from its proximity to the Great Lake and the ruins of Angkor Wat. We stop at the nearby killing field, which I had last seen in early 1979, when the Vietnamese, as punishment, ordered their Khmer Rouge prisoners to dig up the bones and skulls buried in the trenches. . . .

title: BOWLING;4 Victories Give Title To Williams
description: For Walter Ray Williams Jr., starting the final round of a professional bowling tournament from the No. 4 spot is nothing new. During a career that has already landed him in the P.B.A. Hall of Fame, the 36-year-old Williams had twice won from there. Until today, though, he had never survived four straight head-to-head matches in an arena.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a listing on March 31 of lodgings and places to hike in County Down, Northern Ireland, misstated the currency used there. It is the British pound, not the Irish punt. The exchange rates of the two currencies are similar, so the difference between the actual prices and those given is insignificant.

title: THEATER;An Eccentric Ringmaster Creates His Own Circus
description: THE FIRST THING YOU NOTICE walking into the theater to see Suzan-Lori Parks's new play, "Venus," is a mysterious red light blinking at the top of the proscenium at center stage. It doesn't stop until the show is over and everybody goes home. The next thing you notice about the play, which begins previews at the Joseph Papp Public Theater on Tuesday, is the network of strings crisscrossing the stage overhead, instantly establishing that this production has been directed by Richard Foreman.

title: 1970's: APRIL 23, 1972;An 18-Year-Old Looks Back on Life
description: Every generation thinks it's special -- my grandparents because they remember horses and buggies, my parents because of the Depression. . . .

title: The 1980's: Sept. 19, 1982;Toxic Shock
description: In June 1980 the Centers for Disease Control linked toxic shock syndrome to tampon use, resulting in widespread publicity about the ailment.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Look in Mirror, Loathe What They See
description: When their former coach was combing their sideline instead of South Beach, there were always certainties: Down the stretch, in the final minutes, they would be there, positioning themselves under the basket with their cocked limbs, battling for everything that came off the rim, staying close and believing. Always believing.

title: The Fall of Communism: Dec. 17, 1989;The Other Side of The Wall: An East Berliner's Diary
description: Thursday evening, Nov. 9. At home, I turn on the late-night news. Every channel on television is showing a huge celebration that's apparently happening in West Berlin. . . . The wall has been opened. One of the most insurmountable borders in Europe has become a German dance floor. . . .

title: Fatal Abuse
description: THE BOOK OF DAVID How Preserving Families Can Cost Children's Lives. By Richard J. Gelles. 200 pp. New York: Basic Books. $23.

title: THEATER;Last-Ditch Comedy of Despair
description: WHEN first overheard by Josh, his nephew who's drifted in uninvited, Uncle Bob is rambling, but brilliantly. Call it reflecting. Which means he's speaking the usually unspoken, having nothing to lose.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: SPENDING IT;Death or Taxes: Choose One. By Tomorrow
description: In case you are among the millions of Americans for whom the term Low nday has a new meaning, as you rush to finish your taxes today, here are a few tips from tax practitioners and the Internal Revenue Service.

title: SPENDING IT;Where the I.R.S. Aims the Prosecution Ax
description: AS you slip your tax return in the mail just ahead of tomorrow night's filing deadline, perhaps a bit nervous that the Internal Revenue Service might decide to make a Federal case out of something amiss on your forms, take a deep breath and check your return address.

title: A Familiar Mideast Pattern
description: Israel's offensive against Islamic guerrillas in Southern Lebanon is a dance whose steps are sadly familiar. News analysis, page 10.

title: MUSIC;Strings In Recital, Steel Bands On Stage
description: THE rush toward graduation is on, with a resultant increase of concerts at schools and conservatories around the state. In West Hartford, the Hartt School, still awash in 75th-anniversary celebrations, has a pair of free programs in Millard Auditorium this week: a chamber recital today at 3, and a session 8 P.M. Saturday with the Hartt Steel Band. Appearing this afternoon are 10 members of the string faculty, their performances of works by Bruch, Weber, Rossini, Schumann and Bartok accomplished in partnership with their clarinet and piano colleagues, Ronald Krentzman and Anne Kan.

title: WOMEN: Jan. 29, 1956;Let Them Work?
description: YES. The man is carrying too big a burden and carrying it all alone. Male and female created He them -- that they might be able to enrich one another. "It is not good for man to be alone. Let us make him a help like unto himself." Eve -- like (itals) Adam and different (itals) from Adam. Sure, let's vive la difference. But also, let's vive la similarity. Let the woman, the keeper of the hearth, get in there and pitch by her man's side for a few years in order to be sure that there's a hearth to keep. . . .

title: WEDDINGS;Deborah Berch, William C. F. Kurz
description: Deborah Berch and William Charles Frederick Kurz were married in New York yesterday. Dr. Matthew Ies Spetter, leader emeritus of the Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture, officiated at the Carlyle Hotel.

title: Canceled Trip
description: To the Editor: Many years ago, we read an article in the Travel section that spoke highly of Moment's Notice in New York. I kept the name, but we never used the company until recently.

title: WEDDINGS;Kathleen Murphy, John F. Nittolo
description: Kathleen Elna Murphy, a daughter of Linda Piccininno of Bayville, N.J., and Donald B. Murphy of New York, was married yesterday to John Francis Nittolo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Nittolo Sr. of Millburn, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Warren H. Bouton performed the ceremony at the Community Congregational Church in Short Hills, N.J. Mrs. Nittolo, 28, graduated from the University of Richmond. Her father is a partner in Brown Brothers, Harriman & Company, the private bank in New York. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce. Mr. Nittolo, 30, and his father are owners of an electrical contracting company in Millburn.

title: War Wounds Shape Life, and Politics, for Dole
description: When Bob Dole was to give a speech on affirmative action last month in California, he ended up delivering just one sentence on the subject. It turned out, he said later, that he had been given a lectern with a slanted top, and his notes kept slipping off. Because of hand injuries he sustained in World War II, Mr. Dole could not hold his notes and a microphone at the same time. So he decided to ad-lib, giving short shrift to his main topic.

title: Marlboro Man Doesn't Deserve Honor
description: To the Editor:

title: Broadway: Feb. 4, 1979;Before the Accents
description: She's in three major movies coming out this year: "The Senator," Woody Allen's "Manhattan" and "Kramer vs. Kramer." ... Currently, she is at Joseph Papp's Public Theater in Thomas Babe's new play, "Taken inMarriage."

title: 1970's: Sept. 26, 1976;The Search for Jimmy Carter
description: Maybe Carter was one of the few people in the world who could look good under fluorescent light. Wearing a pale blue button-down shirt open at the neck -- pale blue was certainly his color -- Carter's presence had a quintessential American cleanliness, that silvery light of a finely tuned and supple rectitude that produces our best ministers and generals alike, responsible for both the bogs of Vietnam and the vision of a nobler justice. But then it was not hard to see that if Carter got elected, there would be cliques of Carter-watchers among the press, for his personality had delicate shifts that suggested much. Last night, on the charter flight coming back to Georgia from West Virginia, Mailer had been conducted to the front of the press plane to meet the candidate and his wife Rosalynn (pronounced ROSE-lyn) and that had been an agreeable adrenaline, as if one had moved into a new suburban neighborhood and been invited to one's first barbecue and the host was Jimmy Carter -- "I've been looking forward to meeting you," he says -- a friendly fellow you couldn't size up instantly. He had to have ability because he was running the biggest corporate operation in town, yet there he was, as ordinary as yourself, except for a keenness of response, an alertness in his attention that was not at all ordinary, yes, somebody you instantly wanted to know better. . . .

title: Race and Rights: Sept. 14, 1969;The New Reformation
description: In the end it is religion that constitutes the strength of this generation, and not, as I used to think, their morality, political will and common sense. Except for a few, like the young people of the Resistance, I am not impressed by their moral courage or even honesty. For all their eccentricity they are singularly lacking in personality. They do not have enough world to have much character. And they are not especially attractive as animals. But they keep pouring out a kind of metaphysical vitality.

title: Everyone's A Centrist For Election In Italy
description: For all the confusion that marks this year's parliamentary elections in Italy, a certain balance has entered the political equation. Next Sunday, for the first time, voters will face a choice between a left-leaning coalition and a right-leaning one, each with even chances of capturing the great core of Italy's centrist voters.

title: General Custer in the Corporate Archives
description: THE Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company would have been 150 years old this year. But it was not to be. Insurance companies, once considered bulwarks of American business, are an endangered species today, rapidly disappearing in takeovers. Connecticut Mutual, born in 1846 as the first mutual insurance company in the state, is dead in 1996, merged into the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, which has headquarters in Springfield, Mass.

title: The 1980's: June 25, 1989;The Education of Dan Quayle
description: Dan Quayle has been brushing up on his leaders. He has read William Manchester's biographies of Douglas MacArthur and Winston Churchill. He has finished "Leaders," Richard Nixon's memoir of meetings with Konrad Adenauer, Nikita Khrushchev, David Ben-Gurion, Zhou Enlai and other heads of state. He enjoyed Paul Johnson's "Modern Times," with its sketches of such "gangster-statesmen" as Mussolini, Stalin, Hitler and Mao Zedong.

title: Let's Meet, People!
description: No grand idea was ever born in a conference," wrote F. Scott Fitzgerald, "but a lot of foolish ideas have died there." Maybe he was right, but when it comes to business meetings, many people would arch their eyebrows at even this qualified praise. Do you have a tale of these workplace fixtures, from the flimsy reasons for conducting them to those precious tricks for enduring them? Send it to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: WOMEN: Jan. 15, 1956;Let Them Work?
description: NO. I know hardly any junior misses who want to grow up to be wives and these few are treated condescendingly by their teachers. . . . Young girls should be told that there is more to being a housewife than eternal scrubbing and vacuum-cleaning.

title: ART;Shades of Nature as Reflected in Flowers
description: "Botanical Artists of the East End" East End Arts Council, 133 E. Main St., Riverhead. Through Apr. 21. 727-0900.

title: April 7-13;An End to Graft Deductions
description: The Clinton administration got the world's industrialized countries to agree last week that they would no longer subsidize bribery. To be sure, Washington's victory is not solely a moral one. American business executives have long complained that they are at a disadvantage because they are barred from paying bribes to secure foreign business. Most of their international rivals are not only permitted to bribe foreign officials but can also deduct these payoffs from their taxes as a business expense.

title: Boston Braces for a Colossal 100th Marathon
description: For its 100th running on Monday, the Boston Marathon will stretch like a pair of Spandex tights, with a field four times its normal size. The last of the runners may not reach the starting line for an hour. By then, Cosmas Ndeti, the three-time men's champion from Kenya, should be approaching the midway point.

title: WEDDINGS;Alicia vonSchaumburg, Brian Aslami
description: Alicia vonSchaumburg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth vonSchaumburg of Bloomfield, N.J., was married there yesterday to Dr. Brian Azim Aslami, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Azim Aslami of Jacksonville, Fla. The Rev. John D. Gabriel performed the ceremony at St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church.

title: Computer Speak;World, Wide, Web: 3 English Words
description: THE Internet has been pretty universally viewed as one of the great democratic advances of the late 20th century. Nothing in human history has ever made more information more readily available to more people at lower cost.

title: Vietnam: Sept. 4, 1966;LIFE AND DEATH OF A VIETNAMESE VILLAGE
description: Under the heavy clouds of the monsoon season the paddy fields undulate blue-green, like the bottom of an aquarium. Between the gentle curves of the dikes they flow toward the horizon, eddying now and then around red-tiled roofs and copses of coconuts and bananas. From our helicopter, the land looks sculptured by a history as constant as the motion of water. Across its face, the asphalt road runs straight for nearly two miles out from town. Where the road breaks off into a red gash of dirt track, there is a hamlet -- a line of thatched huts, a naked lot, wooden houses with patches of tin roofing, a confused area of rubble in front of which a new whitewashed building flies the red and yellow flag of the Republic of Vietnam. Away to the east, two more hamlets trail along the dirt road; even less substantial, they are no more than double rows of palm-leaf huts laid out between tumbled barriers of earth and barbed wire. Beyond them the road disappears in the swamp that forms the boundary of the village of Duc Lap.

title: G.O.P. Plan Would Profit Insurer With Ties to Party
description: A health insurance company with close political and financial ties to Republican leaders stands to benefit substantially from a proposal that conservative Republicans want to add to a major health insurance bill scheduled for debate next week on the Senate floor.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;3 Attractions, 1 Ticket In Orlando
description: Three family attractions in Orlando -- Universal Studios, Sea World of Florida and Wet 'n' Wild -- are offering a new combination pass that allows unlimited admission for five days. The price, $95.35, or $77.33 for children 3 to 9 years old, is less than the combined cost of one day's admission to each of the three sites. (Children under 3 enter free; all prices include tax.)

title: THEATER;'True West' in Westchester Debut
description: SUCH is the rear view of the Broadway theater that a 1979 Pulitzer Prize-winning play by Sam Shepard is to go down in theater annals as the playwright's Broadway debut.

title: In Hiring Aliens, Companies Face Hurdles
description: WHEN Colin Service Systems in White Plains was recently fined $1.5 million, the largest amount ever imposed by the Immigration and Naturalization Service for hiring illegal aliens, the whole subject of immigration, legal and illegal, hit close to home.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLUSHING: UPDATE;Subway Work Is Under Way
description: Renovation of the Main Street subway station began last Monday, nearly half a year after a judge dismissed a lawsuit seeking to block the construction.

title: 1940's: Sept. 5, 1943;What Is a New Dealer?
description: A New Dealer regrets poverty and deplores the fact that it is necessary for society to slough off its misfits as an individual sheds his impurities and his diseases. But New Dealers believe that human want and human distress should be prevented or at least ameliorated as much as possible. Here again there are in agreement millions who would object to being called New Dealers, but who might not approach the problem quite as objectively as do New Dealers. Above all things, we believe in self-help.

title: What Separates Hate and Civil Disobedience?
description: To the Editor:

title: Farm Road Now a Shoppers' Link
description: EVEN up to five years ago open spaces were frequent along Route 347.

title: Race and Rights: April 29, 1962;Ben-Gurion on Buddhism
description: He abused me, he defeated me, he robbed me" -- in those who harbor such thoughts hatred will never cease. For never does hatred cease by hatred here below. Hatred ceases by love; this is an eternal law.

title: Tel Aviv Museum
description: To the Editor: The Tel Aviv Museum, mentioned in "Israel's Second City" (Feb. 18), has just received the donation of a sizable collection from the family of the legendary pianist Felicja Blumental. It is made up of 60 works by such artists as Braque, Dubuffet and Klimt. A Felicja Blumental Music Series has also been initiated, with the Israeli pianist Chaim Freiberg, who teaches in New York, invited to give a recital at the museum on April 28 in honor of Felicja Blumental, who died in January 1992.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week. Tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420.

title: WOMEN: Jan. 3, 1937;Oh Mr. Bartender...
description: Sherman Billingsley is a leading disciple of the new era. His Stork Club, which catches the cream of the dinner and supper club trade, is designed for women. He was the first to put carpet down. He was the first to make grandmother welcome, and he has now gone so far as to deep milk in stock, just in case the folks bring the children along.

title: The 1980's: Aug. 2, 1987;Voices From the Barbie Trial
description: Along with Nuremberg, which took place only a year after the Allied victory, and the Adolph Eichmann case of 26 years ago, this was one of the three great war-crime trials in the West. It differed from the others because Klaus Barbie had done more than sign papers and give orders. He had personally tortured victims. He had liked his work, deriving satisfaction from the brutal extraction of information. But even so, Barbie's character was not the most significant difference. What was most amazing was that, after 40 years, the details of what happened could still be told with such vigor by people who had been there and back. . . .

title: WEDDINGS;Melissa M. Bullen, Sargent S. Johnson
description: Melissa Marie Bullen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Bullen of Locust Valley, L.I., and Hobe Sound, Fla., was married yesterday to Sargent Snyder Johnson, a son of Helen S. Johnson of Wayzata, Minn., and Dr. Harry A. Johnson Jr. of Minneapolis. The Rev. Seymour St. John performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Chapel in Hobe Sound.

title: Correction
description: A table last Sunday with an article about the recent performance of municipal bond funds included an incorrect listing for the funds with the highest returns for the 12 months ended March 29. The fund shown in first place, Smith Barney B Muni Bond Florida, should not have appeared on the list. Smith Barney said the fund's return for the period was 8.09 percent, not the 38.60 percent reported by Morningstar Inc., which provided the data for the table.

title: POP MUSIC;As in His Song, He's Been to Hell and Back
description: Steve Earle sips a double latte spiked with a shot of caramel and three sugars. He stubs out one cigarette and fires up another. At 41, Mr. Earle may one day tame his two-plus-pack-a-day habit, but nobody around him seems worried. Everyone is just grateful that he is alive and sitting in his tour bus instead of out buying the drugs that all but killed him.

title: It Must Be Spring
description: MY husband, David, and I are supervising 25 American college students on a study-abroad program in London. I called one of their dormitories to try to find a babysitter for Saturday night. "Sorry, Mrs. Lubin," Andrew apologized. "I'll be in Barcelona on Saturday. Let me ask Trang." Trang lives down the hall. "Sorry again," he reported back. "Trang says she'll be in Paris."

title: 100 Years of The New York Times: On Language - May 27, 1979;'I Led the Pigeons to the Flag'
description: William Safire has written On Language for the Magazine since 1979. He selected the column adapted here as a favorite.

title: College Bills and Rewards
description: To the Editor:

title: A Political Move Into The Movies
description: THE LAST SUPPER," A new film about murderous graduate students and the ridiculous conservatives they poison at dinner, has been described by reviewers as evenhandedly nasty to both ends of the political spectrum. But its author, a 32-year-old named Dan Rosen, is an unabashed liberal.

title: WEDDINGS;Grace Hackmeier, James Blakemore
description: Grace E. Hackmeier, a research associate in the development department of the New York Public Library, was married yesterday to James C. Blakemore, an associate at Thacher Proffitt & Wood, a law firm in New York. The Rev. Mary H. Naegeli officiated at the Moraga Valley (Calif.) Presbyterian Church.

title: BENEFITS
description: Chefs Against Hunger MONDAY -- Share Our Strength, the anti-hunger organization, will hold its ninth-annual "Taste of the Nation" event at the Marriott Marquis from 7:30 to 10:30 P.M. Fifty New York chefs will prepare their signature dishes; among them will be Michael Romano of the Union Square Cafe and Diane Forley of Verbena. Tickets, $125, from (800) 233-3123.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: PRIVILEGED CONVERSATION By Evan Hunter. Warner, $22.95.

title: Marlboro Man Doesn't Deserve Honor;Secondhand Smoke
description: To the Editor:

title: The 1980's: June 5, 1988;The Battle of the Books
description: Canon formation, canon revision, canonicity: the mysterious, often indecipherable language of critical theory had yielded up a whole new terminology. What was this canon? The books that constituted the intellectual heritage of educated Americans, that had officially been defined as great. The kind of books you read, say, in Columbia's famed lit. hum. course, virtually unchanged since 1937: Homer, Plato, Dante, Milton. . . . The masterpieces of Western civilization. The Big Boys. . . .

title: The Early Years: Jan. 17, 1915, 'SOMEWHERE' IN FRANCE;The Germans' Secret Weapon
description: Being a motoring guest of the Kaiser has . . . certain obvious advantages. . . . You become ipso facto a ranking honorary Major General of the German Army, and spend most of your time acknowledging salutes. . . . Motoring, you discover, if you did not already know it, the psychological secret of the Germans' so far successful fight against odds. The "open secret" is German discipline and German sentimentality -- a hard combination to beat.

title: The Great Outdoors: May 28, 1989;Why Mow?
description: I bought a lawn mower, a Toro, and started mowing. At first I tried for a kind of Zen approach, immersing myself in the lawn-mowing here-and-now. ... I noticed that where rain collected white clover flourished, that it was on the drier rises that crab grass thrived. After a few weekends I had a map of the lawn in my head as precise and comprehensive as the mental map one has to the back of his hand. The finished product pleased me too, the fine scent and the sense of order restored that a new-cut lawn exhales. My house abuts woods on two sides, and mowing the lawn is, in both a real and metaphorical sense, how I keep the forest at bay and preserve my place in this landscape. ...

title: New Releases
description: TOWERING INFERNO: 'KADDISH' Island

title: HOME CLINIC;Fixing the Portable Electric Drill
description: THE portable electric drill is the most useful and versatile of all the power tools. With it you can drill holes, drive screws, sand wood, polish metal and mix paint -- provided, of course, that the drill is in good working order. What do you do, however, when your drill is not working properly? Some people assume that it is not worth fixing; they drop the tool in the trash and buy a new one. There are times when repairs can cost as much as a new drill, but often a little maintenance and a few inexpensive parts may be enough to restore the tool.

title: HORSE RACING;Unbridled's Song Keeps the Role of Kentucky Derby Favorite
description: Unbridled's Song coasted to a length-and-a-half victory in the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct yesterday, and clinched the role of favorite for the Kentucky Derby, a role that has produced no winner in 17 years.

title: Race and Rights: June 2, 1968;The Torch Is Passed
description: The four horsemen of Robert Kennedy's race for the Presidency of the United States are a ghost, a shadow, an image and a specter. The ghost is the idealized memory of his brother, President John F. Kennedy. The shadow, cast by the ghost, is what gets in the way of the voter trying to see Robert as a man rather than as a Kennedy. The image of Robert's ruthlessness is at least partly a legacy of his service to his brother. And the specter is of a Kennedy dynasty.

title: WEDDINGS;Amanda Kalb, Lawrence Anderson
description: Amanda Lannon Ward Kalb, a daughter of Elizabeth Ward Kalb of Pittsford, N.Y., and Barrett Franklin Kalb of Morristown, N.J., was married yesterday to Lawrence John Anderson, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Lawrence Anderson of Rockville, Md. The Rev. James Schwartz performed the ceremony at St. Louis Roman Catholic Church in Pittsford.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;Buy Britain! Sell Sweden! Hold Hong Kong!
description: WANT to bet on a recovering economy in another country? Think Germany will soon cut interest rates and drive up that country's stock market? Some new investments make it particularly easy to speculate on just such matters.

title: The Odd Couple
description: A DISGRACEFUL AFFAIR Simone de Beauvoir, Jean-Paul Sartre, & Bianca Lamblin. By Bianca Lamblin. Translated by Julie Plovnick. Illustrated. 184 pp. Boston: Northeastern University Press. $24.95.

title: Sydney Howe, 67, Environmentalist, Is Dead
description: Sydney Howe, an early fighter for clean soil, water and air who was one of the first to balance the needs of the environment with those of poor people in the cities, died on Monday at his home in Holderness, N.H. He was 67.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;INVESTING WITH: Robert W. Bissell
description: WHEN stock investors look for safety, they flock to companies that are paying high dividends. For whatever the ups and downs of the stock market, these holdings produce a steady stream of income. The comparable investment in mutual funds is the equity-income category. Its funds invest in just such high-yielding stocks. With volatility increasing and talk persistent about how long it has been since a 10 percent decline in the broad stock market, these funds make sense for the conservative.

title: The Kaffenion Connection: How the Greek Diner Evolved
description: WHEREVER Greeks gather, a kaffenion can usually be found. It's a rough place where men gather to talk and down cups of coffee and shots of ouzo.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;Workmanlike Efforts for Society's Nuts and Bolts
description: THERE'S SOMETHING perverse about presenting a show on public architecture in a place that has a hard time drawing crowds. A visitor can spend a lonely half-hour or so at "Civics Lessons," a survey of recent public buildings in New York City now on view in the rotunda of the Customs House at the tip of Manhattan. The off-the-beaten-track location is not the only reason that this show has failed to attract the audience it addresses. There's also little magnetism coming from the work on view.

title: Broadway: Oct. 13, 1968;The Living Theater Presents: Revolution! Joy! Protest! Shock! Etc.!
description: I demand everything - total love, the end to all forms of violence and cruelty such as money, hunger, prisons, people doing work they hate," says Judith Malina, clenching her small fist. "We can have tractors and food and joy. I demand it now!"

title: World News Briefs;Gorbachev Wins Place On Presidential Ballot
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev qualified today to be listed on the ballot for Russia's presidential election in June.

title: The 1980's: June 16, 1985;On Boxing
description: How can you enjoy so brutal a sport, people ask. Or don't ask.

title: Liberian Truce Fails to Hold; Anarchy Rules
description: Hopes that a hastily arranged cease-fire would hold in this war-gutted city were dashed by late this morning, when gunfire rang out anew and sporadic shelling resumed near a diplomatic enclave where thousands of Liberian refugees had sought shelter.

title: 100 Years of The New York Times: Hers - Nov. 20, 1988;Children of Choice
description: The Hers column was published in the Magainze from 1988 until January of this year. It provided a forum for women to explore public and private issues - like this appraisal of proabably the most divisive one of all.

title: NOTICED;Stickpins: The Subtlest of Status Symbols
description: THE tiny but telling chieftain's sword stickpin sported by Mel Gibson as he accepted his Oscars for "Braveheart" was one detail the cleavage-doting fashion press somehow neglected to pinpoint that night. But Mr. Gibson's accessory may well be part of an intriguing sartorial trend.

title: Vietnam: Jan. 14, 1951, Saigon;WHEN VIETNAM WAS FRANCE'S PROBLEM
description: Nerve center of a ruthless war between the Vietminh and the French, Vietnam's capital wears a prosperous, bustling facade which serves as a thin disguise for danger and insecurity.

title: Broadway: June 5, 1960;How to Curry Favor With the Critics
description: This is not as difficult as it may seem. Critics are skittish and undependable creatures - that is, their idea of what constitutes a good performance is remarkably fluid and their standards change alarmingly from season to season. This year's favorite is next year's whipping boy, the reason being, of course, that they are notoriously unable to divorce the actor from the part he is playing. ...

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: READINGS FROM WORKS

title: RUNWAYS;An Equation Where Angles + Cutouts = Fashion
description: TOGA-SLICED shoulders, cutouts and graphic prints all figure in fashion's new geometry. As part of linear modern clothing, designers are opening up windows on the body, using the twirl of a compass or the angle of a T square to create inserts of fabric or views of flesh.

title: 100 Years of The New York Times: Sunday Observer - May 18, 1975;Spaced Out
description: From 1973 to 1987, Russell Baker wrote Sunday Observer for the Magazine. He selected the column adapted here as a favorite.

title: ON HOCKEY;Devils Failed on Ice And in the Front Office
description: Do the Devils advance to the playoffs to defend their Stanley Cup? Well, no, they won't go, the first champions since the 1969-70 Montreal Canadiens to not even qualify for the following tournament.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE;Brooklyn's Girl Next Door?
description: Ask her fans to associate Mary Tyler Moore with a city and they'll likely conjure up images of her tossing her hat in the air in snowbound Minneapolis or twirling around in capri pants in New Rochelle.

title: Strangers in the Next Pew;Churches Troubled, or Revitalized, by Immigrants
description: As the Rev. John Cole looked out recently over his 80-member congregation of blacks, whites, natives and immigrants in Jamaica, Queens, he offered what he hoped was a healing instruction: write your name and telephone number on a piece of paper, he said, pass it to someone across the aisle, and call that person during the week and ask if he or she needs a prayer.

title: Women: April 22, 1945;Wanton Wife
description: Most war wives fall into four general categories: the Weeper, the Waster, the Wanton, and the Wonder Girl. . . . The Wanton, the unfaithful wife, is going to find it at least as hard to live with herself after her husband comes home as to take up life with him where it left off.

title: 1970's: January 17, 1971;What It Means to Be a Homosexual
description: The late Otto Kahn, I think it was, said, "A kike is a Jewish gentleman who has just left the room." Is a fag a homosexual gentleman who has just stepped out? Me?

title: Another Dirty Trick
description: THE LAST PUMPKIN PAPER By Bob Oeste. 267 pp. New York: Random House. $23.

title: Why Pay Retail? Someone's Got to
description: WOMEN -- and men -- may love designer clothes, but a growing number may love one thing even more.

title: INVESTING IT;If Wall St. Zigs, Find Markets That Zag
description: WITH the American stock market becoming more and more skittish, many investors may look abroad for safety. For while overseas investments are often seen as chancy and lucrative, they can also help to lower risk, like any other method of diversifying a portfolio.

title: WOMEN: January 6, 1985;Having, Getting, Earning, Eating
description: Karen Valenstein is the highest-ranking woman in the public-finance department of E. F. Hutton & Company and one of the preeminent women in investment banking. While the number of women working on Wall Street has increased dramatically in the last 10 years, few have risen as high as Mrs. Valenstein. Of the 29 first vice presidents in deal-making roles at Hutton, just six are women. . . .

title: Racial Motive Seen in Mississippi Shooting
description: From neo-Nazi notes that a white supremacist left in his house before he died in a fire he had set at a shopping center in a largely black neighborhood after spraying it with gunfire, the police concluded today that racial hatred had led to the deadly shooting.

title: 1950's: Aug. 31, 1958;There is No News From Auschwitz
description: For every visitor, there is one particular bit of horror that he knows he will never forget. For some it is seeing the rebuilt gas chamber at Oswiecim and being told that this is the "small one." For others it is the fact that at Brzesinka, in the ruins of the gas chambers and the crematoria the Germans blew up when they retreated, there are daisies growing. . . .

title: 1970's: June 2, 1974;The Patty Hearst Syndrome
description: When I first learned of the kidnapping, I remembered that as a young girl, I often had dreams of being kidnapped and falling in love with one of my captors. I also remembered Temple Drake, the heroine of William Faulkner's "Sanctuary," who chose to live with her abductor, a hood named Popeye, in a Memphis whorehouse before being "saved" and returned to a decaying social order.

title: 1940's: Nov. 21, 1948;My First Thanksgiving
description: I have been asked to recall my first Thanksgiving, which with me is hard to do, as I've seen many.

title: Innocence and Experience
description: BLAKE By Peter Ackroyd. Illustrated. 399 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

title: WEDDINGS;Susan Monahan, James Parkinson 4th
description: Susan Louise Monahan, a daughter of Susan Maxwell Monahan of Scottsdale, Ariz., and the late Thomas Redmond Monahan, was married yesterday to James Thomas Parkinson 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Parkinson 3d of New York. The Rev. Clarke Oler, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Paradise Valley (Ariz.) Country Club.

title: Robert Anderson, Ambassador And Kissinger Aide, Dies at 74
description: Robert Anderson, a career Foreign Service officer best known as Henry A. Kissinger's spokesman on marathon diplomatic shuttles during the 1970's, died on April 5 at Fairfax Hospital in Virginia. He was 74 and lived in the Georgetown section of Washington.

title: WEDDINGS;Barbara Reid, Chaplin Barnes
description: Barbara Trowbridge Reid and Chaplin Bradford Barnes were married yesterday in Stonington, Conn. The Rev. Mark K. J. Robinson performed the Episcopal ceremony at Calvary Church.

title: DIARY
description: THE STOCK MARKET What Goes Up Goes Where? It was the battle of the cliches last week on Wall Street: "What goes up must come down" vs. "You can't miss with stocks." The "can't miss" theory got a resounding vote on word that we keep pouring staggering sums into mutual funds. Watch the superlatives pile up: the first quarter's $80 billion take shattered the previous record, with the $72 billion that went into stock funds exceeding the total for 1995's first seven months. Still, come down the market did, relentlessly -- with no big next-day bouncebacks, like soothing hot chocolate, to make it all better. What's happening? "Inflation!" cried the doomsayers, while optimists pointed, yet again, at the aging-baby-boomer savings juggernaut. Irresistible force, meet immovable object.

title: SOAPBOX;A Test of Determination
description: I'M lucky. I found out before I got sick, before the virus hijacks so many of the helper cells in my immune system that it lets some dormant infection wake up and clobber me. Even though women have become the fastest-growing population of people with AIDS in the United States (18 percent of the total cases in 1994, up from 7 percent in 1985, according to the Centers for Disease Control), doctors don't routinely offer the H.I.V. test to their female patients.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Eagle Vision TSi, Honda Civic HX;Testing a Shifty Character And a Shiftless Wonder
description: AUTOMOBILE transmissions come in two flavors, manual or automatic. Check that: they used to come in just two flavors. Now Honda and Chrysler, seeking to add pizazz to some plain-vanilla products, are offering exotic variations. Each works splendidly.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: TO SLEEP WITH THE ANGELS The Story of a Fire. By David Cowan and John Kuenster. Ivan R. Dee, $25.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: Monday

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: BUT I LOVE YOU ANYWAY By Sara Lewis. Harcourt Brace. $22.

title: Essences of Ease;Light
description: LIGHT IS THE CRUCIAL VARIABLE in good design for the home. In a moment, it can transform a nondescript corner into a radiant place of comfort. And yet people still underestimate light's complexity by assuming that more is always better. A great opportunity to explore the play between light and shadow, the natural and the artificial, can be lost in the blast of too much sun or the glare of track lighting. Whether it is the precise grid of a floor-to-ceiling glass window, shafts of light pouring through a small, square skylight, or even the circular halo created by a lamp shade, it is the definition and the shaping of light that make it so intriguing.

title: WOMEN: April 18, 1993;In These Girls, Hope Is a Muscle
description: When the bus finally pulls in front of the Centrum and it is time to leap off, the girls have faces like masks. To the world, they are a bunch of teen-age girls; inside their heads, they are commandos. To the world, these teen-agers have pretty names: Patri, Kristin, Jen, Kathleen, Kim, Jamila, Sophie, Jade, Emily J., Emily S., Jan, Lucia, Carrie, Rita, Jessi, Julie. But as far as the girls are concerned, they (itals)are the codes that encapsulate their rare and superb skills, their specialty plays, their personal styles. They are Cloudy and Cougar and Jonesbones and Gumby and Grace and Skippy and Predator. They are warriors. . . .

title: The 1980's: Jan. 29, 1989;Embattled Infidel
description: Two weeks after this article appeared, the Ayatollah Ruholla Khomeini issued a fatwa, calling for Salman Rushdie's death for writing "The Satanic Verses," and urged all "zealous Muslims" to execute him quickly. Rushdie immediately went into hiding.

title: FILM VIEW;Ruining the Stories of One's Dreams
description: OF MAKING BOOKS there is no end," according to Ecclesiastes, and of making movies out of books there seems no end either. I get edgy whenever I hear of yet another one being remodeled for film, especially a book I treasured as a child. Edgy not so much over what they will do to it, but rather over what I will do.

title: Flood Is Called Right Tonic for Grand Canyon
description: An effort to help restore the Grand Canyon to a more natural state by inundating it with water released from an upstream dam "worked brilliantly," Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt said on Thursday.

title: World News Briefs;American Boxer May Sue Toronto Police for Arrest
description: Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, who spent 19 years in prison for a murder he did not commit, says he is considering legal action against the Toronto police after he was detained for half an hour during a drug sweep.

title: A Chinese Herb And Vested Interests
description: To the Editor:

title: Sister Act
description: WHATEVER HAPPENED TO MARGO? By Margaret Durrell. Illustrated. 226 pp. North Pomfret, Vt.: Andr Deutsch/ Trafalgar Square. $29.95.

title: Judge Jails Estranged Wife of Slain Biologist After Travel InformationIs Found
description: After learning that the estranged wife of a murdered and mutilated biologist was found with travel books, flight information for Switzerland and a stolen license plate, Judge Claire Weinberg of Nassau County ordered her jailed without bail yesterday.

title: Narration on Wheels
description: A WHITE MERC WITH FINS By James Hawes. 289 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $22. IN his debut novel, James Hawes starts off with a flurry of nervous aggression, like a stand-up comic trying to hide the first-night jitters. The book's narrator (who remains nameless throughout) is much given to buttonholing the reader in a voice that feels close to the edge of hysteria -- but then he will tell us that he has plenty to feel hysterical about. A one-time heroin user, part-time office flunky and full-time slacker, he senses his life running away from him. He lives in a shed at the bottom of his sister's garden in West London, from which he ponders the misery of having a receding hairline and being 28 years old:

title: STEEPED IN SIMPLICITY
