description: ALTHOUGH the Japanese teahouse is a deeply spiritual, profoundly Eastern place, what came most vividly to my mind on a recent visit to one were the words of Diani Vreeland, the legendary, worldly-wise former editor of Vogue magazine: "Elegance is refusal."

title: April 7-13;Manatees Succumb to Odd Ailment
description: The manatee death toll rose sharply this week, making this year the worst on record for the endangered sea mammals that live in Florida's coastal waters. So far this year, 224 manatees have been found dead, and more than half of them have been killed by a mysterious ailment that has struck Florida's southwest coast.

title: WHERE THE HERETICS FOUGHT AND LOST
description: AT the last gasp of the Pyrenean foothills in France, overlooking the plains of Toulouse, the village of Fanjeau is as peaceful as its history is sinister. In 1217 a monk, Dominic Guzman, founded his Order of Dominican Friars here, poor men who lived on charity and preached the faith among ordinary people. Fanjeau still has a flavor of solemnity and self-denial: narrow streets around the church, a girdling wall, magnificent views. Its sole cafe sits not in the square, as you would expect, but instead rather shyly at its foot.

title: Essences of Ease;FLOW
description: CONSIDER CURVES IN design to be the physical equivalent of the soothing sound of water. Modern architecture has often been described as adamantly rectilinear, but, in fact, it has frequently employed the curve within the square for sheet dramatic effect, as seen in Le Corbusier's famous Villa Savoie in Poissy, France. The flow created by curved elements - as large as a spiraling staircase or as small as a molded object on a table - sets up a dynamic of motion that is essential in creating a sense of vitality, as well as sensuality, in the home.

title: New Releases
description: CELINE DION: 'FALLING INTO YOU' Epic/550 Music

title: QUICK BITE;A Louisiana Treat on Route 4 West
description: Technically, they're probably not good for you. But as far as tasting good, the oysters en brochette at Jose Tejas on Route 4 West in Paramus are worth their wages in sin.

title: Ruling in Price-Fixing Case Provides a Look at Drug Industry
description: Providing a look at rarely publicized internal discussions in the pharmaceutical industry, a Federal judge has quoted from sealed industry documents that compare the industry to a cartel, or "kind of an OPEC," which, the judge said, shared information on pricing and competition.

title: Trotsky Defended
description: To the Editor:

title: 1990's: Jan. 8, 1995;Off the Grid
description: A warming morning late in October, and James (Bo) Gritz stands on a mountaintop in north-central Idaho, addressing the faggot press. His words. Still, look at them: a Brit with blond hair fringing his round head -- The London Times calling; a reporter from People with long hair and a goatee; the neo-beat novelist William T. Vollmann, on assignment from Spin magazine and accompanied by a friend, a birdlike woman with bright red lipstick and purple gloves. And there are three or four others, including a photographer from this magazine who has slipped his earring into his pocket to get under the faggot radar.

title: GOLF;A Six-Stroke Lead Looks Formidable
description: Now that Greg Norman is 13 under par, the 41-year-old Australian golfer will go into Sunday's final round of the Masters with a six-stroke lead on Nick Faldo and a seven-stroke lead on Phil Mickelson.

title: As Full-Size Cars Vanish, Police Pay
description: The full-size police cruiser, like the old-fashioned family station wagon, is becoming a thing of the past, and many police departments say the change in automotive tastes is costing them money.

title: Race and Rights: April 9, 1967;Negroes Are Anti-Semitic Because They're Anti-White
description: In the American context, the most ironical thing about Negro anti-Semitism is that the Negro is really condemning the Jew for having become an American white man -- for having become, in effect, a Christian. The Jew profits from his status in America, and he must expect Negroes to distrust him for it. The Jew does not realize that the credential he offers, the fact that he has been despised and slaughtered, does not increase the Negro's understanding. It increases the Negro's rage.

title: N.J. LAW;With Burglars on the Prowl, Asians' Homes Become Prisons
description: It was supposed to be a big day for Cherry Hill residents who are graduates of National Taiwan University, Taiwan's most prestigious university. Alumni from Delaware, Pennsylvania and South Jersey were having a reunion near Wilmington, Del., complete with dinner, dancing and karaoke, and 20 from Cherry Hill had reserved two tables, two months in advance.

title: Operation Desert Hoops
description: HANG TIME By Zev Chafets. 305 pp. New York: Warner Books. $21.95.

title: The View From: Clinton;From Fine Wood and Fine Art, Fine Music
description: FOR 18 years, Lawrence Wilke has turned pieces of wood into beautiful, resonant musical instruments. "I started when I was 16," he said. And although he occasionally did other things -- like finish high school -- he never really stopped. "I couldn't get away from it," he said. "I knew it was what I had to do."

title: Three Childhood Treasures
description: EVER SINCE "The Prince and the Pauper" was made into a movie in 1909, children's books have been a ready source for films, sometimes over and over. Lassie, for one, has come home at least five times. In "Gypsy Colt" (1954), the collie was even turned into a horse. Ten years later, Robinson Crusoe journeyed to outer space in "Robinson Crusoe on Mars." Of Tarzans, there are many. And Mark Twain's Tom and Huck have whitewashed a lot of fences and gone down many a river.

title: 1970's: May 19, 1974;Let Us Begin
description: Elon: Isn't it amazing, Sana, that after 25 years of bloodshed and terror, here we find ourselves engaged in a public dialogue? Even now we live in what still seems only a temporary lull in the hostilities. Let's aim at more than just a discussion. Let's forget about scoring points. Rather, let's meet as two humans equally enmeshed in a terrible tragedy and equally aware of it. If you like, in a mutual exercise of self-awareness.

title: NONTONAL MUSIC;A Puzzling Attack
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: BAD ANGEL By Helen Benedict. Dutton, $22.95.

title: POSTINGS: Protests Filed on 51,000 Parcels in New York City;Commission Begins Hearings On Property-Tax Assessments
description: It's tax protest season in New York City. The months-long period of hearings before the New York City Tax Commission on assessments tentatively levied by the Finance Department for the fiscal year 1996-97, which begins July 1, is on. And it turns out that there have been fewer protests this year than last.

title: Race and Rights: Sept. 7, 1969;How on Earth Did Woodstock Work?
description: By late July, Woodstock and John Roberts were in a mud slide of trouble. Even with 1,000 paid employees, the stage was never finished -- it had no roof. Two trailor trucks crammed with lighting equipment were parked alongside the stage, but their doors never opened. The New York Police Department ordered 350 officers hired as security guards not to work at Bethel. Although some cops ignored the order (festival officials swear the patrolmen who came were perpetually high on marijuana or whisky), the chief security forces were 50 teen-age ushers from the Fillmore East, a Manhattan rock club, and 100 members of the Hog Farm, a New Mexico commune flown East in an airliner chartered for $16,000.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: AMBIVALENT ZEN A Memoir. By Lawrence Shainberg. Pantheon, $24.

title: 1970's: Dec. 16, 1979;AN ENCOUNTER WITH COLONEL QADDAFI
description: FALLACI: Now, I'd like to put together a profile of you, Colonel. And I'd like to do it by conducting a kind of trial, a little indictment to help you understand why you are so little liked in the world. By the way, did you know, do you know, you are so unloved and so unliked?

title: 1950's: April 30, 1967 (A Decade Later);The Most Gifted Demagogue Ever
description: He was probably the first American ever to be feared and actively hated on every continent. What he stood for -- or was thought to stand for -- seemed so ominous to Europeans that Winston Churchill felt constrained to work an anti-McCarthy passage into Elizabeth II's Coronation speech, and The Times of London observed that "the fears and suspicions which center around the personality of Senator McCarthy are now real enough to count as an essential factor in policy making for the West."

title: Race and Rights: June 7, 1964;The 'Black Psyche'
description: I shall never forget an evening I spent in a movie house in Hollywood, watching a closed-circuit television broadcast of the first Patterson-Johansson fight, and the great shame I felt for my white countrymen that night, as they began to smell a possible victory for the white foreigner over the black American. Forgotten entirely was the fact that soft-hearted Floyd Patterson was a fellow-countryman. Color superseded patriotism. As I sat there hearing shouted exhortations like, "Kill the nigger!" I felt that Patterson and I were aliens in a strange and hostile country, and Ingemar was home amongst his people.

title: Westchester Q&A: Charley D. Ewen;Missionary of the Microbrewery
description: IT happened with wine, with coffee and now, said Charley D. Ewen, a Scarsdale resident, it is happening with beer. People, no longer content with the tastes that satisfied their parents and grandparents, want a choice in what they drink.

title: Tying OSHA's Hands On Ergonomic Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Pretending to Be Poor
description: Washington and Albany are threatening to crack down on Medicaid spending for the poor. But there is one part of the health insurance program that neither wants to touch -- the blatant and often unethical misuse of the program by well-to-do patients in nursing homes.

title: Case Against Ex-Congressman Is Narrowed
description: A Federal district judge has dismissed two of five charges in an embezzlement case against former Representative Joseph P. Kolter of Pennsylvania.

title: GOOD EATING;SoHo's Charms As a Dining Mecca
description: ALISON ON DOMINICK STREET * (212) 727-1188; 38 Dominick Street (Varick Street); $$(c) all major credit cards

title: Lester Aronson, 84, Animal Behavior Researcher
description: Dr. Lester R. Aronson, a biologist who spent more than half a century studying the sexual and other behavior of fish, frogs and cats for the American Museum of Natural History, died April 7 at a nursing home in Old Tappan, N.J. He was 84 and lived in Hillsdale, N.J.

title: MUSIC;A Loser? That Depends
description: WHEN Frederic Chiu did not make the finals of the 1993 Van Cliburn International Piano Competition, one article about him was headlined "A Loss Launches a Career." The iconoclastic virtuoso's provocative repertory and adventurous style made headlines hot enough to be used as calling cards: "Rebel Pianist Wins Van Cliburn Audience but Scandalizes Jury." "A Poorer Field of Finalists for His Absence." "Spiritual Son of Glenn Gould."

title: The Early Years: Jan 22, 1911;Senator Roosevelt, Insurgent
description: Senator Roosevelt is less than 30. He is tall and lithe. With his handsome face and his form of supple strength he could make a fortune on the stage and set the matinee girl's heart throbbing with subtle and happy emotion. But no one would suspect behind that highly polished exterior the quiet force and determination that now are sending cold shivers down the spine of Tammany's striped mascot.

title: Slimmed Down, The Post Returns to Sundays
description: For the third time in its history, The New York Post published a Sunday newspaper, a slimmed-down issue selling today for half the cost of a previous, unsuccessful version.

title: Correction
description: An article on April 6 about health care financing misstated the surname of a health care securities analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. He is Kenneth S. Abramowitz, not Bernstein.

title: BACKTALK;100 Races Later, It's Still Boston
description: The first Boston Marathon was run in 1897, which makes this year's race the 100th. My first was in 1969, and I've run it several times since. You never forget Boston, especially not your first. Back then, for me and my running friends it was the main event, our personal Super Bowl, World Series and Final Four combined.

title: INVESTING IT;It Keeps Your Pants On. But Can It Fatten Your Wallet?
description: WHEN a product is so common that it is used as a prop in a television show stunt, is it a sign that its potential for new uses has been played out?

title: The Great Outdoors: May 2, 1909;How to Kill a Lion
description: Nothing causes the East African colonist more genuine concern than that his guest should not have been provided with a lion. The knowledge preys upon his mind until it becomes a veritable obsession. He feels some deep reproach is laid upon his own hospitality and the reputation of his adopted country. How to find and, having found, to kill a lion is the unvarying theme of conversation; and every place and every journey is judged by a simple standard - "Lions or no lions."

title: The Road to Extermination
description: Hitler's Willing Executioners Ordinary Germans and the Holocaust. By Daniel Jonah Goldhagen. Illustrated. 622 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: 28 Women Emerge From Shadows of History
description: NOTABLE women in business, education and the professions are in the spotlight in "Extraordinary Yankees: Business and Professional Women of the Connecticut River Valley" at the Connecticut River Museum in Essex. The show includes profiles of 28 women whose occupations ranged from pharmacists, healers and physicians to dressmakers and department store executives, architects, scholars and educators.

title: The Fall of Communism: Aug. 18, 1968;The Inevitable End
description: Traditional Communism . . . is a dead end. . . . Sooner or later, to put it briefly, its methods ossify into dogma and its rulers degenerate into a blinkered incompetence so that necessary change cannot be undertaken or even conceived. . . . Crisis is not an accidental but a necessary result.

title: WOMEN: Nov. 8, 1964;Hosed
description: How to account for the present success of the textured? For one thing, it is certainly part of the international "yeah, yeah" (or "ye, ye") look, born with the Twist and the Frug and the Monkey. With the very short skirt, the high boot, the cut-out shoe, the emphasis is on the leg. . . .

title: Stiff Anti-Drug Policy Adopted
description: The world's stiffest anti-doping program and a new code of conduct for America's Olympic athletes were adopted unanimously by the United States Olympic Committee today.

title: The 1980's: November 16, 1980;China's True Face
description: This account was written secretly by Wei Jingsheng, a former Red Guard, before his arrest in 1979 and was later smuggled out of China. He was sentenced to 15 years for "counterrevolutionary activity."

title: Mules Were Heroes of the Slopes, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: In Developing Nations, Buzzwords Fall Flat;Why Not 'Humility'?
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Tale of Tobacco, Pleasure, Profits and Death
description: ASHES TO ASHES America's Hundred-Year Cigarette War, the Public Health and the Unabashed Triumph of Philip Morris By Richard Kluger 807 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

title: Treasure Island: A Landfill Full of Possibilities
description: It has been described as an Atlantis rising out of the Pacific.

title: MEDIA: TELEVISION;The latest ruling in a long-running court battle takes NBC's side in wage dispute.
description: ARE journalists professionals? Or are they trained laborers?

title: Howard Chandross, Bridge Master, 50
description: Howard Chandross, one of America's top-ranked bridge players, died yesterday in Long Beach, L.I., where he lived. He was 50 years old.

title: Taiwan Is Said to Buy 300 More U.S. Tanks
description: Taiwan plans to buy 300 more M60-A3 tanks from the United States to strengthen its defenses, a leading Taiwan newspaper reported today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Wieden & Kennedy, Take a Bow
description: For the second time since 1992, Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., has been named the National Agency of the Year by the trade publication Adweek.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Nomo Is Back in Form
description: The phrase "sophomore jinx" doesn't translate into Japanese, at least not for HIDEO NOMO.

title: Senate G.O.P. Seeks Tax Cuts In Stalled Talks On State Budget
description: In the surest sign yet that slow-moving talks over the New York State budget are finally turning serious, the Republican leadership of the State Senate plans to unveil an ambitious proposal this week to cut an array of business taxes by $75 million this year and much more in future years.

title: James C. Turner, 79, Laborer Who Rose to Union Presidency
description: James Castle Turner, a former laborer and college boxer who became president of the International Union of Operating Engineers and championed racial integration in the union movement, died on Saturday at the Day Shore Convalescent Center in North Miami Beach, Fla. He was 79.

title: From Albany Senate Leader to Lucrative Job as Bottlers' Lobbyist
description: Two days before he announced his retirement from the State Senate in 1995, Ralph J. Marino, the former Senate majority leader, signed a contract for $100,000 a year to help the beer and soda industries try to reduce state beverage-container taxes and repeal the state's bottle-deposit law.

title: Thousands March to Battle New Right
description: Nearly 13,000 young feminists, old leftists, concerned immigrants and even "Angry White Guys for Affirmative Action" joined forces today for a national "Fight the Right" march along the bay.

title: Children at Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Can TCI's Leader Walk His Talk, at Last?
description: John C. Malone has been perceived by supporters and critics alike as a man with the vision to see from the mountaintop -- and the power, when necessary, to move the mountain.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Hokie Charged
description: Virginia Tech quarterback JIM DRUCKENMILLER was charged with malicious wounding Saturday by police investigating a fight that took place outside a Blacksburg, Va., bar last month.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: SOCCER;MetroStars Post Loss As League Triumphs
description: They do not even need Pele.

title: Chief Executive to Leave T. Rowe Price
description: George J. Collins, who helped build T. Rowe Price Associates into one of the nation's biggest mutual fund groups, is stepping down by next April, the company said on Friday at the shareholders meeting.

title: Martin Braine, 69, Cognitive Psychologist
description: Dr. Martin D. S. Braine, a professor of cognitive psychology at New York University who researched the acquisition of language by children as well as the thinking and reasoning of children and adults, died on April 6 at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 69 and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LUISE RAINER, the film star and first wife of Clifford Odets, and WALT WHITMAN ODETS, his son with his second wife, Betty Grayson, met for the first time last week at an art show. But a bond between them was instantly forged.

title: Kosher for Passover' Unkosher in Quebec
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Money Can't Buy Everything, Just in Case You Didn't Know
description: The news tonight is that John Stossel, like lots of rich and famous people, is not particularly happy. But the ABC News reporter gets to spend a peppy hour looking into what makes some human animals happier than others, just the sort of occupation, he learns, that produces happiness.

title: Tight Security Gets Tighter As a Sad Anniversary Nears
description: Across Ohio recently, police chiefs and sheriffs received a letter from Ted A. Almay, superintendent of the state's Bureau of Criminal Identification and Investigation. The Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Tex., went up in flames on April 19, 1993, Mr. Almay reminded them, and the Federal Building in Oklahoma City was blown up on the same date two years later.

title: New York Area Is Forging Ahead In New Media
description: The new-media industry in New York has more than doubled in the last three years to become a $3.8 billion-a-year business and a mainstay of the metropolitan economy, according to a study to be released today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When she was first approached last year by Pocket Books about writing a cookbook, David Letterman's mother, DOROTHY MENGERING, hesitated.

title: Taking In the Sites;Covering Those 26.2 Miles Without Getting Winded
description: When John J. McDermott won the first Boston Marathon, he could hardly have guessed that 99 races later the marathon would be one of the world's premier sporting events and that it would be covered by more than half a dozen sites on the Internet.

title: U.S. Troops Wrap Up Evacuation Operation in Liberia
description: After six days of hectic operations, an American evacuation effort from this embattled and badly looted city to neighboring countries wound down today with a final trickle of traumatized foreigners being flown out of Liberia.

title: A Celebration of the Urge to Unplug
description: Nearly two centuries ago, the Luddites of England smashed machines and burned factories in their rebellion against the Industrial Revolution, and were then relegated to history books as dunderheads and barbarians.

title: Crime Show Leads to Arrest
description: An 18-year-old man wanted in the shooting deaths of his parents last month was captured in Texas just minutes after his case was portrayed on a television crime show, the authorities said today.

title: The Bitter Winds of Liberia
description: Few countries are as tormented as Liberia. Anarchy and civil war have swept like a bitter wind through this West African country for seven years, claiming more than 150,000 lives and displacing half of Liberia's three million people. A peace agreement reached last August offered hope that the country's six guerrilla armies might be disarmed under a transitional regime. Sadly, the shared interest in peace proved weaker than the distrust, greed and ambition of rival warlords, whose forces resumed fighting earlier this month in Monrovia.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Resumes Are in the Mail: Struggling Nets Lose Again
description: Their coach may not be back. Their general manager may not be back, at least in that capacity. And many of the players on their roster may not be back. So the Nets are simply trying to finish the last week of their season before the off-season changes begin.

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with an obituary of Robert Anderson, a career Foreign Service officer, was published in error. It showed Robert B. Anderson, a former Treasury Secretary, who died in 1989.

title: Frances Frenaye Is Dead at 88; Translated European Literature
description: Frances Frenaye, a veteran American translator of French and Italian literary works into English, died on Friday at her apartment in Miami Beach. She was 88.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;3 Guitarists, 2 Generations
description: Great Guitars," a Highlights in Jazz show at Pace Downtown Theater on Thursday night, began calmly. The three guitarists, Charlie Byrd, Howard Alden and Russell Malone, played a set of standards, often gently. By the end of the concert, as they cruised through a set of tunes associated with Charlie Christian, the temperature had risen substantially, and Mr. Byrd, who is some four decades older than Mr. Malone, was in no mood to be upstaged by the young guitarist. The music sparkled with competition, borne out in ideas and wit.

title: Abortion Foe Is Charged
description: A Fairfield man has been charged with attacking a woman as she and an escort tried to enter a health clinic where abortions are performed.

title: Hans Blumenberg, Philosopher, 75; Studied Modernity
description: Hans Blumenberg, a wide-ranging German intellectual known for his writings on modernity, died on March 28 in Altenberge near the northwest German city of Munster. He was 75 and lived in Altenberge.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Roseanne And Forbes, Both on TV With Men In Bug Suits
description: If there's one thing Roseanne knows how to do, it's generate hype. For weeks, she has been flogging the idea that "Saturday Night Special," the limited-run sketch-comedy show that she is producing, would be radically different from its aging competition, "Saturday Night Live." (A less similar title might have helped, for starters.)

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Veteran Saxophonists Show More Than Age
description: Against the blank canvas of a neutral rhythm section, eight of the better improvisers in jazz grappled in a cutting contest at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday. Called "Battle Royale: Trumpets and Tenors 2," it was the public face of what the writer Albert Murray has named "antagonistic cooperation," where musicians, challenged by their peers, ape pushed into further excellence. For the audience at the sold-out concert, few situations offered a better environment to investigate the differe'ces among great improvisers.

title: Northrop Grumman Stock
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation said on Friday that it planned to sell seven million shares of stock, using the proceeds to repay debt it took on for its $3 billion purchase of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's defense electronics unit.

title: NATO Says It Didn't Allow Grave Site to Be Disturbed
description: Aerial intelligence photographs show that a field thought to be the grave of hundreds of Muslim civilians was not tampered with while NATO was responsible for monitoring the site, alliance officials said today.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Kansas Utility Makes Hostile Bid Western Resources, a utility based in Kansas, made a hostile bid of $1.7 billion yesterday to take over Kansas City Power and Light, which already has agreed to merge with another Kansas City utility, Utilicorp. Though hostile takeovers of utilities are rare, companies have been scrambling to find merger partners as they seek to adapt to meet demands for lower rates and deregulation. [Page D2.]

title: Another Top Disney Executive to Leave
description: The Walt Disney Company said today that Dennis Hightower, the president of its television and telecommunications operations, would retire on June 1.

title: Metro Matters;Trying to Lift Secrecy's Veil From Abuse
description: HOW is "Elisa's Law" working?

title: Growth Hormone Fails to Reverse Effects of Aging, Researchers Say
description: Human growth hormone, a drug once hailed as something able to make old men feel young again, has proved far more likely to cause puffy ankles and sore joints than to restore youth, according to a study being published today.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:

title: MUSIC REVIEW;To Scots, Folklore And Tango
description: The four works performed in Friday night's concert by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center at Alice Tully Hall could not have been more different. Yet each piece was indebted to some kind of folk music for inspiration (and sometimes sourae materials), giving the program an effective thematic link.

title: TECHNOLOGY: CONNECTIONS;A fascination with the Unabomber, and the suspect, run deep on the Internet.
description: MAN, is this ever weird," reads a posting on a Usenet news group that is called "alt.fan.unabomber." "There is now a news group about the guy who despises technology."

title: In America;Freedom Birds
description: Nearly three years ago, in the pre-dawn darkness of June 6, 1993, a tramp steamer called the Golden Venture ran aground in the rough surf off the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens.

title: The Call of the Wildlife Show
description: Across the broadcast industry, they're dancing with wolves, partying with bears, swimming with sharks and generally having a fine time of it with wildlife, offering more and more nature programs to viewers.

title: Cashing In on Gotham's Culture-Hungry Guests
description: Thirty weary-looking Volkswagen salesmen, just in from Stuttgart, Germany, sat in the first few rows of the Palace Theater on Broadway one recent evening, having a post-performance chat with cast members of "Beauty and the Beast." It was 5 A.M. Stuttgart time, and the group had been up for 25 hours, so they were bleary-eyed, but still attentive. Ina Lee Selden, president of Manhattan Passport, one of an increasing number of companies marketing cultural tourism in New York City, was translating, and Patrick Quinn, the actor who plays Lumiere, the candelabrum in the show, was explaining how he lights himself up every night.

title: Essay;Thrift Is Back!
description: Fear itself that nameless, unreasoning, unjustified terror of a poverty-stricken old age -- has done a wonderful thing this year. Politicians are competing to stimulate a value that had all but disappeared in a blizzard of credit cards: thrift.

title: The 100th Boston Marathon
description: While the rest of the country toils today, Bostonians and their neighbors will be celebrating the 100th running of the Boston Marathon. This year's race will be a gargantuan affair, featuring 38,500 registered runners, thousands of support people and as many as one million spectators. There will also be a blizzard of advertising and commercial hype.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;UConn Loses Assistant
description: HOWIE DICKENMAN, an assistant basketball coach at Connecticut, has reportedly agreed to become head coach at Central Connecticut State, his alma mater.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;$7 Million Due in Heat Aid
description: New Jersey will receive nearly $7 million in Federal emergency heating assistance intended to soften the financial effects of this year's brutal winter, Federal officials said.

title: At the End of the Tunnel, a Home;Forced to Leave Shanties, Dwellers Try Out Life Above Ground
description: As a spring snowfall turns to chill rain outside his window, Robert Kalinski stubs out yet another cigarette and savors some of the things most people take for granted: a set of keys, a bathroom sink and silence.

title: Soap and Substance for Arabic TV
description: Abdelwahab had it all. Almost. A poor shopkeeper who became one of Egypt's richest men, he lived in a grand apartment in posh Zamalek that was filled with gilded furniture. He had a Mercedes, an adoring wife and four daughters. But the son whom he educated at Egypt's most expensive university was giving him no end of trouble.

title: Witness Put on the Defensive In the Trial of Clintons' Allies
description: The Federal loan fraud trial of Gov. Jim Guy Tucker and two former business partners of Bill and Hillary Clinton seemed in recent days more like a trial of the main prosecution witness, David Hale.

title: New Stadium Isn't Feasible, but Revamping Yankees' Old One Is;Westway's Promise
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A review of the Broadway musical "The King and I" in Weekend on Friday misstated the nationality of its director, Christopher Renshaw. He is British, not Australian.

title: In San Francisco, Print Books Are Still in Style
description: Perhaps Kenneth E. Dowlin, San Francisco's head librarian, can be forgiven for being a little prickly.

title: Refugees Jam Road to Sidon, Trying to Flee Israeli Rockets
description: The coastal road from southern Lebanon to Sidon ran one way today: north.

title: Fear of a Communist Comeback Has Many in Russia Packing Bags
description: At the age of 22, Galina Mardoyan has seen enough turmoil to last a lifetime. By the time she was done with high school, the Soviet Union had collapsed. As an Armenian living in Georgia, she felt despised, so she moved to a resort on the Black Sea, where she hoped to live quietly with her grandmother.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Former Prosecutor's Trial Set
description: Jury selection is to begin tomorrow in the trial of Nicholas L. Bissell, the former Prosecutor of Somerset County, who was accused in a Federal indictment last September of a variety of misdeeds, including tax evasion, mail fraud, perjury and forging documents so that his son could receive financial aid for college.

title: Tax Deadline Is Midnight
description: Today, April 15, is the last day to file income tax returns for 1995. All tax returns have to be postmarked by midnight tonight to avoid penalties.

title: City Tries Again to Set Up Manhattan Concrete Plant
description: Ten years ago, in a novel plan to lower construction costs and damage the Mafia, the city began subsidizing a private concrete company in Manhattan. But the plan dissolved last year after the company, $4 million in debt and beset by managerial disputes, collapsed in bankruptcy.

title: Jury Finds for Time Inc.
description: A Federal jury decided on Friday against a Georgia man who filed a $26 million lawsuit against Time magazine after it mistakenly published his photograph and said he played a role in the 1988 bombing of a Pan American flight over Lockerbie, Scotland. After two days of deliberations, jurors rejected accusations by Michael Schafer that he was defamed and his privacy invaded when Time ran his photograph in its issue of April 27, 1992, and identified him as an international terrorist who used the name David Lovejoy. The magazine, owned by Time Warner Inc., published a correction four weeks later, saying Mr. Schafer's photograph was used in error.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Needham Hires Chief For Digital Account
description: Steve Norcia, a managing partner at Earle Palmer Brown who was brought in to head that agency's New York office in November 1994, has joined DDB Needham Worldwide in New York as the worldwide account director on the Digital Equipment Corporation account.

title: On Broadway, Audience Still Reigns;High Ticket Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs;Safety Lapses Cited In German Airport Fire
description: Officials at the airport here where 16 people died in a fire last week have admitted that there were serious lapses in safety procedures before and during the blaze.

title: Camilla de Leon, 80, Dance Composer
description: Camilla de Leon, a dance composer and accompanist in the 1930's and 40's, died on April 3 at Middlesex Hospital in Middletown, Conn. She was 80, and lived in Middletown.

title: HORSE RACING;Unbridled's Song Favored, But So Is the Derby's Jinx
description: With three weeks to go to the Kentucky Derby, there is Unbridled's Song alone in front of everybody else on the road to Louisville. Now, all he has to do is outrun the jinx that says few favorites win the Kentucky Derby.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 1 about a meeting of students from New York City and communities around the city's upstate reservoirs misstated the stance of the Rosendale Town Board on a recommendation by students that the town build a storage shed for road salt. The board took the proposal under advisement; it did not vote approval.

title: Toying With the Constitution
description: House Republican leaders have chosen today, tax day, to stage a vote on an irresponsible measure that would amend the Constitution to require two-thirds majorities in both houses of Congress to raise taxes. The Republican sponsors know they lack the votes to approve the amendment. They simply want to trap the Democrats into opposing an anti-tax measure during an election year.

title: F.B.I. Agent Dies in Crash
description: An F.B.I. agent was killed in a car accident today near the remote Montana ranch where anti-Government militants are holed up, the first fatality in the three-week armed standoff between the Freemen and Federal officers.

title: BASEBALL;In With the New: Martinez Shrugs Off Ghost of Mattingly
description: Wade Boggs had a slightly strained hamstring and Tino Martinez had an anemic bat. The combination prompted Joe Torre to change the Yankees' lineup twice yesterday, and the results were just what the manager would have ordered if he had the ability to order whatever he wanted.

title: Bridge
description: Study the West hand shown in the diagram, and plan your opening lead against four spades doubled. The North hand has bid the minor suits, and South has bid strongly in spades. Then consider the full diagram, and ask yourself whether you could have done better in double-dummy.

title: Woman's Plea for Asylum Puts Tribal Ritual on Trial
description: Fauziya Kasinga says she fled her homeland of Togo at age 17 to avoid the tribal rite of female genital mutilation and an arranged marriage as the fourth wife of a man nearly three times her age. When she arrived at Newark International Airport, she felt sure that she would find sanctuary in a country that "believed in justice."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Car Pins and Kills Child, 7
description: A 7-year-old boy was killed Saturday when he was run over as he tried to stop the station wagon he had been playing in from rolling down a driveway, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Unequal Sentencing
description: A study by the New York Division of Criminal Justice Services has arrived at provisional but nonetheless alarming conclusions about discrimination in the courts. The study finds that members of minority groups are substantially more likely than whites to be jailed -- even when they commit the same crimes and have similar criminal histories. The study warrants close examination by criminal justice officials and, ideally, a more detailed sequel.

title: As Rockets Rain Down, Israeli Holdouts on the Border Vow to Stay
description: A thunderous crash of Katyusha rockets broke the silence of a nearly deserted neighborhood in this border town today, sending Katy Bar-Yosef and her neighbors charging into their bomb shelter.

title: Corrections
description: A caption with a painting of the judges of the Book-of-the Month Club in Business Day on April 1 omitted the name of the artist. Joseph Hirsch painted the picture in 1944.

title: New Stadium Isn't Feasible, but Revamping Yankees' Old One Is
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Harnisch's First Game Back Is a Met Rout
description: Pete Harnisch's journey back from shoulder surgery was filled with more peaks and valleys than the Rocky Mountains that frame Coors Field.

title: New Police Leader Wants to Improve Ties to Minorities
description: On the eve of ceremonies that will give him command of the nation's largest police force, Howard Safir, the incoming New York City Police Commissioner, said yesterday that one of his first goals would be to improve police relations with the city's black and Hispanic residents.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Schott Takes the Field To Say She's Sorry
description: The Cincinnati Reds owner, MARGE SCHOTT, walked onto the field yesterday just as a game with the Houston Astros was about to begin to apologize to the umpires for her comments about John McSherry's collapse on opening day.

title: MARATHON;Blast of Bravado Is Felt From Ndeti in Boston
description: He held up the running bib inscribed with No. 1, pointed to the bib and then to himself, and lifted a finger aloft. And with that haughty gesture from Cosmas Ndeti of Kenya, a new strain of personality virus emerged in the modern athlete: the born-again Christian trash talker.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Seats Up on School Boards
description: Voters across New Jersey will go to the polls tomorrow to choose members of their local school boards and determine how funds should be spent. This year, 2,385 candidates are vying for 1,585 positions and about $6.5 billion worth of school budget questions will be decided, said Frank Belluscio, a spokesman for the New Jersey School Boards Association.

title: Tudor and S.E.C. In Talks on a Trade
description: Paul Tudor Jones, head of the Tudor Investment Corporation of New York, is in talks with the Securities and Exchange Commission over allegations that the firm violated a stock trading rule, the company said Friday.

title: Student, 21, At Fordham Is in Coma After Attack
description: It was late by the time the three college women started home to the Bronx after a night at the Wetlands, a Manhattan club. They got off the D train just after 4 A.M. Saturday and hailed a gypsy cab, which would take them close enough to home, they thought, to avoid trouble.

title: As Clinton Visits Changing Asia, Military Concerns Gain Urgency
description: After his last trip to Japan three years ago, one dominated by vicious disputes over trade, President Clinton returns on Tuesday to a changed strategic landscape, with Japan seeming a reduced economic threat, and China seeming a larger military one.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Oakley to See Doctor
description: The swelling around CHARLES OAKLEY's right eye has begun to subside, but his team is still hurting as it heads for the post-season.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Residents to Chat on Budget
description: Hudson County's delegation to the State Legislature all nine of whom are Democrats -- want to make sure that their constituents have a say in the current state budget process, even if they cannot make the trip to Trenton.

title: Major Faldo Stands Tall After Norman's Grand Collapse;Six-Stroke Lead Disappears Into the Depths of Augusta
description: As he so often has done, Nick Faldo saved his best golf for the last day of the Masters. And as he so often has done, Greg Norman saved his worst. So today, on a hot, sultry afternoon at Augusta National, Faldo left with his third green jacket and Norman le't with the most crushing defeat in a career that has seen many.

title: Sports of The Times;Does This Not-So-Great Shark Care?
description: WHEN Greg Norman's tee shot on the 12th hole splashed into Rae's Creek, the ball could be seen in the blue-dyed water, but his dorsal fin had disappeared.

title: Dr. George Kelsey, Baptist Minister, 85
description: The Rev. Dr. George D. Kelsey, a theologian and educator who was largely responsible for the young Martin Luther King Jr.'s decision to dedicate his life to the ministry, died on April 3 at the King James Care Center in Chatham Township, N.J. He was 85 and a resident of Madison, N.J.

title: Abroad at Home;Stand Up For Liberty
description: In one significant respect, Bill Clinton's Presidency has been a surprising disappointment and a grievous one. That is in his record on civil liberties.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Ancient African Legend Confirms Music's Power
description: Les Ballets Africains, the National Dance Company of Guinea, has been presenting music and dance based on Guinean cultural traditions for more than four decades. And so it was not surprising that the eveninglong "Heritage," presented by the company on Saturday night at City Center, wove together traditional music and da'ce so smoothly and with such sophistication.

title: ON BASEBALL;A Fill-In Shows Off His Range
description: All through spring training, the Yankees had a ticket punched for Andy Fox. It did not say Penn Station, but rather Columbus, Ohio.

title: POP REVIEW;Atmospheric Feedback From Self-Styled Creeps
description: The world is caving in on Thom Yorke. He has no real friends, he loses his faith in everything every day, and he thinks he'd be better off dead. At least, that's what he sang on Friday night at Roseland during a sold-out concert by the band he leads, Radiohead. The English quintet has made a career out of wielding self-loathing as a weapon to push back against the pressures of socialization. As the catch phrase of "Creep," the 1993 hit that put the band on the pop-music map goes, "I wish I was special/But I'm a creep."

title: An Era Passes at One Place That Fed the Civil Rights Struggle
description: They will still be serving Mister Robert's famous fried chicken. Miss Sherman, the one and only Orah Belle Sherman, will still show customers to their tables. And waitresses named Ophelia and Alma and Shirley will continue to call them honey and darling while pouring more tea.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Liz Claiborne gets set to pitch a curve to the youth market and hopes it will throw a strike.
description: LIZ CLAIBORNE wants to throw consumers a curve, but they may well be knocked for a loop.

title: TENNIS;Milbury Sees Promise In Ashes of Poor Season
description: Mike Milbury likes to point to the future. He really doesn't have much of a choice.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Johnson Becomes Latest To Bump Into a Peferee
description: Magic Johnson has had a lot to say -- and none of it nice -- about the increase in player-official confrontations in the National Basketball Association. Now the future Hall of Famer has a lot of explaining to do after bumping a referee during yesterday's 118-114 home victory over Phoenix.

title: Japanese Stocks Higher
description: Stock prices were trading higher here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 204.88 points, or 0.95 percent, at 21,865.35. On Friday, the Nikkei fell 33.96 points.

title: POP REVIEW;Dancing and Politics by Way of Martinique
description: The party and politics merge easily in the music of the singer and banjoist Kali, from Martinique by way of Paris. At S.O.B.'s on Friday night, Kali (Jean-Marc Monnerville) sang about political stasis in Martinique, about Rastafarianism, and racism in Paris. One tune used the words "Island for sale" as a passing riff. And everything he and his band played had the profound groove of the best dance music of the African diaspora, secure and unhurried.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;An Institution Is Threatened
description: The Student Cooperative Bookstore at Rutgers University has earned high marks from students for its reasonable prices and quaint atmosphere. But the 59-year-old store has long needed a facelift, and no money is available to modernize the institution.

title: Clintons Pay $75,437 in Tax
description: A booming stock market and an old appearance on late-night television helped increase the income of Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton by more than $50,000 last year. They paid $75,437 of Federal tax on income of $316,074.

title: INSIDE
description: No Shadows in Silicon Alley

title: In Developing Nations, Buzzwords Fall Flat
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A Solitary Spirituality And Absurdist Humor
description: Simply put, there is no musical organization in New York that produces more intellectually enticing or more viscerally satisfying programs than Continuum. Cheryl Seltzer and Joel Sachs founded the group 30 years ago, and it long ago became one of New York's unheralded glories. Year after year, its explorations in 20th-century repertory prove to be not only unusual and unexpected but also important and enduring.

title: Hostile Bid Made for Kansas City Power
description: A hostile takeover bid, unusual in the utilities industry, was made yesterday for the Kansas City Power and Light Company, which already had agreed to merge with another utility.

title: U.S. Should Share Its Data on Managed Care
description: To the Editor:

title: How Settled Is Law On Marriage Issue?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Divers to Search for Body
description: A state police emergency unit plans to don scuba diving gear today to search the Millstone River in Somerset County for the body of a man who drowned in a canoeing accident while trying to rescue a friend, the state police said.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Sad Second Chance To Know Her Mother
description: Doctors kill you," Selma Griswald tells her daughter Kate as they sit in the waiting room. "Show me a person who has just died, and I'll show you a doctor 10 feet away."

title: Lifting Liberia Out of Chaos
description: George Boley stood in a clearing deep in a Liberian rain forest and said that he was misunderstood. "I am not a warlord," he told me in late 1994. "I don't know why they use this term to describe me."

title: HOCKEY;Campbell Names Names After Frustrating Finish
description: The Rangers finished their regular season today with their fifth straight loss, a 5-1 embarrassment at the hands of the Florida Panthers. When it was all over, the dismal finish finally got to Rangers Coach Colin Campbell.

title: New Leader at Helm of the Microsoft Network
description: Russell Siegelman, who guided the Microsoft Network, or MSN, on-line service from its inception to a subscriber base of more than a million users, said on Friday that he was stepping down to pursue other interests within the Microsoft Corporation.

title: ROWING;Impressive U.S. Team Is Complete
description: Rowing with what she suspects is a cracked rib the 11th of her career -- Ruth Davidon, a medical student, sped away from the field of single scullers in her 2,000-meter race today to win a spot on the United States Olympic team.

title: World News Briefs;Nigerian Tribal Clashes Reported to Kill 80
description: Tribal clashes in eastern Nigeria that began about a week ago have killed about 80 people, and thousands have fled their homes, the national news agency reported today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: I.B.M. Disk Is Said to Break Billion-Bit Barrier
description: The International Business Machines Corporation is expected to announce today that it has broken the magnetic disk-drive storage barrier of one billion bits of data a square inch.

title: Equity and Convertible Debt Offerings This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: NBC Hopes to Woo Affiliates With Old-Fangled Technology
description: A few decades ago, before the age of cheap satellite communication, the television networks distributed programming to their affiliated stations around the country over telephone lines. Now, with the help of the latest digital technology, NBC is hoping that it can lift its ratings and improve its affiliate relations by reviving that old model.

title: Market Place;For Netcom, Its Fans Say Being Down Is Not Out
description: The fast-growing Internet business is often compared with the PC business a decade ago. And it is for just that reason that investors seem to be growing wary of the Internet and its wealth of too-good-to-be-true success stories.

title: Clinton Veto On Abortion Is Criticized By O'Connor
description: Equating a controversial type of late-term abortion with outright infanticide, John Cardinal O'Connor, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, yesterday sharply criticized President Clinton's veto of a bill that would have outlawed the practice.

title: Patents;Yet another award to the scientists who cloned DNA and gave birth to the biotechnology industry.
description: A LATE-NIGHT chat in a Hawaiian deli between Herbert Boyer and Stanley Cohen is now the stuff of legend. That conversation almost 25 years ago sparked a frenetic collaboration, and within three months the two scientists had demonstrated that DNA cloning was possible. Their research began the industry of biotechnology.

title: World News Briefs;Latvia-Estonia Dispute On Sea Border Is Defused
description: The Baltic states of Latvia and Estonia said today that they had reached a short-term agreement to defuse an increasingly bitter dispute over their sea border.

title: Brooklyn Woman Shot by an Early Visitor
description: A Brooklyn woman was rousted from her apartment and shot in the face early yesterday by a gunman who was hunting for a teen-ager related to the woman, the police said.

title: Bond Offerings Tentatively Set for Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills.

title: Farrakhan Speaks of Plot
description: Louis Farrakhan says he thinks the Government wants to "silence" him because of his visits this year to countries accused of having ties to terrorism, the Nation of Islam leader said in an interview broadcast tonight. Mr. Farrakhan told CBS's "60 Minutes" that officials want him "silenced or muzzled" because he appears "to be interfering with America's foreign policy objectives in Africa and the Middle East."

title: A Technological Overhaul Of I.R.S. Is Called a Fiasco
description: As taxpayers rush to meet Monday's midnight filing deadline, the Internal Revenue Service is scrambling itself, trying to salvage a multibillion-dollar program to overhaul its computer system and eliminate paperwork.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Co-Chief Adds Title At BBDO New York
description: BBDO Worldwide in New York, in another transitional change in top management, has promoted Tom Carey, the co-chief executive of BBDO New York, to the additional position of president of North American operations. Mr. Carey, 51, assumes responsibilities from Tom Clark, 59, who has served as chairman of BBDO North America. Mr. Clark continues as a vice chairman at BBDO Worldwide and chairman of the Southfield, Mich., office, and continues to manage all aspects of the agency's Chrysler Corporation accounts. BBDO is owned by the Omnicom Group.

title: New Stadium Isn't Feasible, but Revamping Yankees' Old One Is
description: To the Editor:

title: Tapping the Power of Satellite TV;3 Broadcasters Aim for Arabic Speakers Around the World
description: Karim Abdallah, who was working as an executive at the Cable News Network during the Persian Gulf war, remembers vividly the thirst of the Arab world for the kind of minute-by-minute news coverage that CNN provided during that conflict. He remembers, too, how eagerly local broadcasters in Egypt and Bahrain agreed, when given the chance in the early days of the war, to pass the network's satellite feed to their viewers.

title: Government Dexterity Eases Misery for Iraqis
description: All of a sudden, Bala Abdullah Khalil, a mother of seven, can afford to heap rice on her children's plates in quantities she could not conceive of a few months ago.

title: Pope Spends a Day in Tunisia, And Offers Words of Tolerance
description: Pope John Paul II made a one-day trip across the Mediterranean to Tunisia today, bearing a message of religious tolerance that he hopes to beam to the rest of the Islamic world.

title: Miller Out at Least 3 Weeks
description: The Indiana Pacers, eliminated in the seventh game of the Eastern Conference finals the past two years, will go into the playoffs this year without Reggie Miller, their leading scorer.

title: Canada Eases Rules On Broadcast Stakes
description: Canada has raised the maximum allowable share a foreigner can hold in a broadcast company.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: PANIC IN LEBANON SPREADS AS ISRAEL KEEPS UP ATTACKS
description: Hundreds of thousands more Lebanese refugees fled in panic today after Israel warned people in southern Lebanon and other areas to leave their homes.

title: Senate Is Weighing Overhaul of Job-Visa Program
description: In corporate boardrooms, labor-union halls and on Capitol Hill, a fight is under way over an unlikely group of Polish physical therapists, Indian computer programmers, French fashion models and thousands of other specialized foreign workers in this country.

title: Bomb Injures U.S. Worker
description: A Federal labor office received a death threat hours before a bomb exploded in the truck of one of its workers, injuring him and his wife, the authorities said today.

title: No Headline
description: Have you guys locked the dean in his office?" STEVEN J. ROSS, Columbia '68, encouraging a new generation of protesters. [B3:1.]

title: Rufus Miles Jr., 85, Aide to 3 Presidents
description: Rufus E. Miles Jr., an author and Federal administrator who served as an assistant secretary under three presidents, died on Tuesday at Ithaca Hospital. He was 85.

title: The I.R.S. Scrambles To Meet a Deadline
description: While millions of taxpayers rush to meet the filing deadline, the Internal Revenue Service is scrambling to meet demands that it reduce its paperwork and modernize its computers -- a multi-billion dollar project.

title: On Broadway, Audience Still Reigns
description: To the Editor:

title: Hong Kong Journal;In Its Takeover Overture, China Calls the Tune
description: At 9 o'clock this morning, Ivy Chan, representing the Hong Kong Federation of Students, was ushered into a thickly carpeted room in the chandeliered Grand Hyatt Hotel here to tell a Beijing-appointed committee what local university students think of China's takeover of the British colony next year.

title: Protesters at Columbia Signal Spring
description: It's April. The trees in Central Park sprout buds. Baseball is back. And students at Columbia University occupy a building.

title: Vermont Candidate Suffers Hemorrhage
description: Vermont's Lieutenant Governor, Barbara Snelling, suffered a cerebral hemorrhage on Saturday and remained hospitalized today in critical condition after emerging from a coma, said a spokeswoman at the hospital in New Hampshire where Mrs. Snelling was taken.

title: Hospital Blast In Pakistan; Political Feud Is Heating Up
description: A bomb exploded in Pakistan's only cancer hospital today, killing at least 6 people, wounding more than 30 and adding a grim twist to a personal and political feud that many Pakistanis say could have a profound impact on the country's future.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;TRW INC. (TRW,N)
description: TRW Inc. reported yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose just 2 percent, below Wall Street's expectations, as a strike at the General Motors Corporation cut into the profits of the company's automotive parts business.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Into Camp Season, Not Necessarily With Kayaks
description: Pick a nun, any nun, who has captured the overcrowded imagination of American pop culture in the last 35 years. The Flying Nun? Maria, the novitiate from "The Sound of Music"? The Blue Nun on the wine bott'e label? Mother Teresa? You'll find them all inside one unhappy Belgian convent, Our Lady of the Pernicious and Pestilent Wounds, in Blair Fell's "Tragic and Horrible Life of the Singing Nun," at the Grove Street Playhouse.

title: BILL ON TERRORISM GAINS MOMENTUM ON CAPITOL HILL
description: Broad counterterrorism legislation moved closer today to becoming law as Republican leaders in Congress predicted final passage of the measure by Friday while senior Administration officials said President Clinton was unlikely to veto it.

title: Chief Leaves At Vista 2000
description: Vista 2000 Inc. said today that Richard P. Smyth was retiring as chairman and chief executive and had resigned from the board.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Time Warner Plans Buyback of Shares
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy back about 15 million shares, or 5 percent of its outstanding shares.

title: D'Amato Plan Would Keep Whitewater On Agenda
description: Expressing frustration over the inability to reach agreement with Democrats on extending the life of his special Whitewater committee, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato set in motion today a plan to hold wide-ranging hearings on the Clintons' Arkansas business ventures and related matters before the Senate Banking Committee.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar at Recent High vs. Mark On Comment by German Banker
description: The dollar rose to a 14-month high against the mark yesterday after the president of the German central bank, Hans Tietmeyer, said he would welcome a further decline in the exchange value of his nation's currency.

title: A Defeat for Business Bribery Abroad
description: The United States has successfully pressured its allies to stop subsidizing corruption. Western European governments routinely allow companies that pay bribes to win business contracts from foreign officials to deduct those kickbacks from their taxable income. Last week the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a group of 26 major industrialized countries, agreed to end tax-deductible bribes. That does not go nearly as far as America, which outlaws foreign bribery altogether, would like, but it is a big first step.

title: BALLET REVIEW;'Swan Lake,' With a Classic Spirit, as a Showcase
description: It isn't every day that a first-class "Sqan Lake" floats into town. But Sonia Arova and Thor Sutowski offered nothing less in their striking staging for Ballet South on Sunday afternoon.

title: After Genetic Engineering, a Weed Gobbles Up Mercury
description: Scientists have used gene-splicing to turn a weed into a possible tool for cleaning up mercury, a dangerous contaminant from pesticides, gold mining and textile and paper making.

title: Jury Finds Publisher of Amsterdam News Diverted Funds
description: Siding with an angry shareholder in a long-running battle for control of the city's largest weekly newspaper aimed at black readers, a jury in Manhattan has ruled against the longtime publisher of The Amsterdam News, Wilbert A. Tatum.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Pacers' Miller Leaves Hospital
description: REGGIE MILLER, progressing well a day after reconstructive surgery on his right eye socket, was released from St. Vincent Hospital yesterday in Indianapolis. Indiana will be without Miller, their leading scorer, at least three weeks, which would be well into the start of the National Basketball Association playoffs, and they could be without him a lot longer than that if his double vision has not cleared completely. JOHN ABRAMS, an ophthalmologist, said after Miller's surgery on Sunday that the double vision, caused by his two eyes not focusing exactly in the same direction, could take up to two months to clear. Last night, Abrams said there had been a marked improvement, but Miller was still seeing double when he turned his eyes in certain directions.

title: Students at Columbia End Battle for Ethnic Studies
description: Columbia University students demanding the creation of an ethnic studies department ended a rancorous two-week battle, with the administration pledging last night to hire more minority faculty members and to give students a role in the selections.

title: CHRONICLE
description: OMAR SHARIF is a legend with two hats: the one he wears as a screen idol and the one he wears as an inveterate bridge player.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;Manifestoes Shrieked And Sung
description: In 1848, Richard Wagner wrote, "I will destroy the existing order of things, which parts this one mankind into hostile nations, into powerful and weak, privileged and outcast, rich and poor: for it makes unhappy men of all." He didn't succeed, of course, but musicians are still trying to use music to stir up revolution. Though the music charts are dominated by songs about romance and angst, here are four new albums by popular musicians for whom political commentary and musical expression are inseparable.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Breach of Promise Suit Is Filed
description: When a bypass operation last January failed to mend Frank Borino's heart, his doctors arranged for him to get an assisting device installed while he waited for a heart transplant. Mr. Borino, of Jersey City, contended in a lawsuit filed last month that Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey agreed to pay for the transplant but reneged. Today, two Assembly Democrats, Loretta Weinberg of Teaneck and William J. Pascrell of Paterson, planned to ask the State Insurance Department to examine whether policies like Mr. Bodino's provide adequate coverage.

title: Scrap Steel Venture Is Formed in Trinidad
description: Cleveland-Cliffs Inc. and the LTV Corporation said today that they had agreed to form a $150 million joint venture to make scrap steel in Trinidad for the steel industry.

title: Death of an Emigre;A Macabre Ending to a 26-Year Marriage
description: There was a time, back in their vigorous and innocent youth, when she would do anything for him, even endure a hunger strike. He would stifle his dreams of science and settle for hammering bookshelves together to be with her.

title: Israel Lets an Old Foe Enter West Bank
description: Israel agreed today to allow a Palestinian guerrilla leader who was once one of its most wanted enemies to enter Palestinian-ruled areas, officials said.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Resounding in 300 Sites Nationwide
description: There was great pressure on everyone involved to get the organ recital started at exactly 6 P.M. on Sunday at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church. The free concert, part of an event billed as the "World's Largest Organ Recital," was being presented to commemorate the centennial of the American Guild of Organists. Some 300 organists in churches and concert halls across the country were each to begin a recital at exactly the same time with exactly the same piece: Bach's Toccata and Fugue in D minor.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Growing Pains Indeed: One Troubled Family
description: Back in the mid-1980's, Joanna Kerns eased nicely into the role of Maggie Seaver, the "Growing Pains" mother who juggled a lovable family and a journalism career with enviable spunk. We're not in sitcom land anymore, Toto. Tonight, on Fox's "Terror in the Family," Ms. Kerns is Cynthia, whose abusive 15-year-old daughter, Deena (Hilary Swank), has left her mother's lip bloodied more than once. And that's not the half of it. Cynthia's 13-year-old son, Adam (Adam Hendershott), is swilling vodka in his bedroom, and her husband, Todd (Dan Luria), looks as if he's trapped in a perpetual migraine. Where are Alan Thicke and Kirk Cameron now that Ms. Kerns really needs them?

title: Seagate Invests in Ulster
description: Seagate Technology Inc. said today that it would make a $75 million investment -- the fourth in three years -- in its Northern Ireland computer disk-drive factory. Seagate Technology, based in Scotts Valley, Calif., said the move brought its total investment in Northern Ireland to more than $260 million. Seagate said it currently employs 750 workers at the plant, and the investment will create 300 new jobs in the next two years.

title: A French-Fry Cooker That Feigns Grease
description: It may seem like one of the more mundane accomplishments of the microprocessor revolution, but the Middleby Corporation and a German partner think that they have come up with a commercial-size cooker to make french fries that taste greasy but are not.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Can't Conceal What Oakley's Loss Means
description: The game was easy for the Knicks; the status of Charles Oakley remained far more troubling.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Banks Report Quarterly Rise In Earnings
description: The Nationsbank Corporation and several smaller banking companies said yesterday that lending and fees increased first-quarter earnings. However, lower profits from currency trading hurt the quarterly results at First Chicago NBD Corporation.

title: New York's Dynamic New Media
description: New York City is justly proud of its world-class television, book publishing and newspaper industries, which are mainstays of the regional economy. But according to a study released yesterday by a state development agency, these traditional businesses are not the largest media industries in the region. That honor belongs to the new-media industry, the typically small businesses that sell interactive software and on-line computer services.

title: Some in Southern Lebanon Remain, to Defy Israel
description: Alone in their neighborhood, Mohammed Ruman and his children stood in a doorway and watched the center of their hometown under fire in the distance. The air resonated with the rumble of Israeli rocket blasts, and a mile away the hillsides burned.

title: Journalist Is Out of a Havana Jail but May Have to Leave Cuba
description: A Cuban journalist who was held in a Havana prison for six weeks as an enemy of the state has been allowed to go home but must now decide whether to leave Cuba or face up to three years in prison.

title: Computer Security Concern Agrees to Be Sold for Stock
description: RSA Data Security Inc., which makes cryptography software that is a key component of secure transactions on the Internet and corporate computer networks, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Security Dynamics Technologies Inc. for four million shares of stock.

title: GOLF;Norman Is Master Of Losing Gracefully
description: It has been said that we learn far more about the character of athletes in defeat than in victory. If this were true, then we would know just about everything there is to know about Greg Norman by now. Because this is a man who has undergone more torturous losses in major championships than most golfers can even imagine.

title: The Forest That Stopped Growing: Trail Is Traced to Acid Rain
description: IN the first long-term study of its kind, researchers have found that a New England forest whose soil chemistry has been altered by acid rain essentially stopped growing nearly a decade ago and will probably be a long time in recovering.

title: Kennedy Introduces Measures To Cut Layoffs From Mergers
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy introduced tax legislation today intended to discourage layoffs resulting from corporate mergers, as part of a package of proposals designed to help workers.

title: Chess
description: The Chess-in-the-Schools International Tournament, from March 21 to April 2, celebrated 10 years of chess instruction for inner city children under the sponsorship of the American Chess Foundation.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;A Tale of Two Late Filers . . .
description: Like many other taxpayers, Governor Whitman and her husband, John, have not finished their tax returns and have filed for an extension. They have estimated their Federal gross adjusted income at $1.3 million, the Governor's office said, and have paid Federal taxes of $225,942 and state taxes of $112,891.

title: Vitamin C: Is Anyone Right On Dose?
description: HOW much vitamin C is enough? Is it the 60 milligrams a day -- the amount in half a cup of fresh orange juice -- that is the current Recommended Dietary Allowance (R.D.A.), the 30 to 40 milligrams that some nutritional biochemists think it should be, the hundreds of milligrams that millions of Americans now take as a daily supplement or the thousands of milligrams that Dr. Linus Pauling believed would protect against serious illnesses, including cancer?

title: COMPANY REPORTS;REYNOLDS METALS CO. (RLM,N)
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said yesterday that its earnings fell sharply in the first quarter, coming in lower than Wall Street's expectations, as a result of lower aluminum prices, weaker demand, higher raw-material costs and some operating problems.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID W. LEEBRON, a professor at the Columbia University School of Law, has been named the 12th dean of the school, it was announced yesterday by GEORGE RUPP, president of the university.

title: Answer to Dubroff Tragedy Is Common Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: George Mackay Brown, 74, Dies; Poet Steeped in Orkneys Lore
description: George Mackay Brown, a poet, novelist and short story writer whose work evoked the rugged life and the history and culture of the remote Orkney Islands in Scotland, died on Saturday in a hospital in Kirkwall in the Orkneys. He was 74.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers' Hopes Hinge on Messier's Health
description: Mark Messier skated well today while the Rangers prepared for the Stanley Cup playoffs. He smiled a lot, and he whooped and hollered, too, during drills at Playland Ice Casino. As is usually the case, the captain was patient, polite, verbose and optimistic in post-practice conversations.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HARDY OIL PLANS TO SELL UNITED STATES UNIT
description: Hardy Oil and Gas P.L.C., a British exploration company, said yesterday that it would sell its United States subsidiary to the unit's managers for $179 million in a transaction financed by the Enron Corporation. Hardy Oil and Gas said it would use the cash to reduce debt and pay its share of the cost of developing new fields in the North Sea and in waters between Australia and Indonesia. The sale of Hardy Oil and Gas USA Inc. to its management, led by a Hardy director, Robert Henderson, will result in a charge of $11.6 million.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Fictional Fiction Writer Demonstrates His Magic
description: CROSS CHANNEL Stories By Julian Barnes 211 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $21.

title: Rabbi Arthur J. Lelyveld, 83, Rights Crusader
description: Rabbi Arthur J. Lelyveld, a leader of Reform Judaism who was active in social causes, died yesterday at the Montefiore Nursing Home in Beachwood, Ohio, near Cleveland. Rabbi Lelyveld, who lived in Cleveland, was 83.

title: BASEBALL;Franco Is Closing In on a Milestone
description: If baseball historians will not embrace John Franco, they must at least accept him. Years from now when Franco's name comes up for Hall of Fame consideration, the first recollection may be of a career of style more than substance. But baseball is all about numbers, and Franco's are beginning to rank where few relievers and certainly no left-handers have ever gone before.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;England to Try Russian For War Crimes
description: An 85-year-old Soviet refugee was ordered today to stand trial on charges of murdering unidentified Jews in Belarus during World War II.

title: Jugglers Now Juggle Numbers to Compute New Tricks for Ancient Art
description: STRUNG together, the numbers sound like a numerologist's incantation. "Six, six, six, seven, one," Bruce Tiemann intones as he rhythmically tosses juggling balls toward the ceiling of a Portland squash court. "Seven, seven, seven, one, six, one."

title: POP REVIEW;Pausing From His Trek, Art Garfunkel Performs
description: After Simon and Garfunkel split up in 1970, Paul Simon went on to record 13 top-40 hits; experiment with South African, Peruvian, zydeco and gospel music; write a screenplay, and win numerous Grammy Awards. Art Garfunkel walked. For 11 years, Mr. Garfunkel has been trekking across America, working his way westward a week or so at a time, by shuttling back and forth between his Manhattan apartment and the town where he left off.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Agency Trims Summer Jobs
description: The United States Labor Department's summer jobs program will employ 533 fewer New Jersey youths this year than in 1995, the department announced last week. The state is receiving $18.4 million to hire 15,880 youths in local communities to work in places like libraries and hospitals. New Jersey received $23.7 million for the program last year. Under a tentative agreement in Congress, the jobs program is being cut about 28 percent nationally, from $867 million to $625 million.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Sorting Out Mixed Media Signals
description: Twelve-year-old Daniel Shanklin is confused. "The media kept saying, 'She's so brave and courageous,' " he said, referring to the breathless news coverage leading up to 7-year-old Jessica Dubroff's fatal crash last week. "Then right after she died, they said, 'Oh, the poor little girl -- she should never have done that.' "

title: Unions Cancel Their Effort To Elect a Director at Kmart
description: Just a few weeks after saying they would ask shareholders of the Kmart Corporation to press the company to elect a new director, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and another union said yesterday that they had withdrawn their nomination and were satisfied for now with the board's current configuration.

title: Dole and Ethanol Industry Count on Each Other
description: Last September, just as the House was set to gut the billion-dollar subsidy that supports the ethanol industry, Senator Bob Dole paid a call on Speaker Newt Gingrich.

title: Microsoft Buys Game Company
description: The Microsoft Corporation said today that it had acquired Exos Inc., a maker of personal computer video game control devices that enable users to feel effects like race-car crashes, flight turbulence and gun recoils more realistically.

title: How the Bottom Line Ended Anne Klein's Top Line
description: In Tomio Taki and Frank Mori, Seventh Avenue seemed to have the quintessential back-court team. Seasoned fashion players, the two gave moral support and business advice to designers looking for backers. Mr. Taki, Takiyho Inc.'s chairman, and Mr. Mori, its president, also provided financial succor to Anne Klein, which it owns, and the Donna Karan Company, where its stake is half.

title: Answer to Dubroff Tragedy Is Common Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: Threat Prompts University To Hold Tests a Week Early
description: The University of South Florida announced today that it would hold final examinations a week early at its main campus in Tampa in response to a letter threatening to blow up an administration building and kill a white female professor on Monday April 29.

title: Big Steelmakers Shape Up;U.S. Mills Win Back Business at Home and Abroad
description: Richard Moore was laid off from the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's sprawling mill here in 1981, one of tens of thousands of workers shed by the American steel industry as it fought to cut bloated costs and fend off surging imports.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, Va., is celebrating a gift that is a legal historian's dream: the lifetime professional and personal papers and memorabilia of the late Supreme Court Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, who served as chancellor of the school from 1986 to 1993.

title: Pratt & Whitney Contract
description: Pratt & Whitney said today that it had received an order to supply 24 engines to Delta Air Lines Inc. for $170 million. Pratt & Whitney, a unit of the United Technologies Corporation, said the air carrier would use the PW4060 engines in its Boeing 767-300ER planes. The aircraft, with the new engines installed, are scheduled to be delivered between early 1997 and mid-1998. Delta, based in Atlanta, plans to use the planes to replace L-1011 aircraft on international routes.

title: COMPANY NEWS;KANSAS CITY POWER TO REVIEW WESTERN RESOURCES' BID
description: The Kansas City Power and Light Company said yesterday that it would promptly review an unsolicited takeover proposal by Western Resources Inc. worth $1.7 billion. On Sunday, Western Resources offered to acquire all of Kansas City Power's outstanding shares for $28 apiece in a stock swap. In January Kansas City Power agreed to merge with Utilicorp in a $3 billion stock deal that would create one of the nation's largest electric and gas utilities, with operations in eight states. Shares of Kansas City Power rose $2.125, to $26, yesterday, while shares of Western Resources fell 25 cents, to $28.875.

title: Target in New York
description: Target Stores, the Minneapolis-based discount retail chain, will move into New York State with four stores opening this fall, company officials announced today.
