The stores, all with 96,000 square feet of floor space, will be in Buffalo, Williamsville, Cheektowaga and Niagara Falls. Target is a division of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, which also operates Hudson's, Marshall Fields, Dayton's and Mervyn's department stores. Target has 688 stores in 34 states across the nation and plans to open 70 to 80 more this year.

title: U.S. and Japan Agree on Plan To Cut Back Okinawa Bases
description: The United States and Japan agreed today on a far-reaching plan that may sharply reduce the friction caused by the American bases in Okinawa. But the plan also raises new questions about the Japanese-American relationship in the years ahead.

title: Wildcat Strike Shuts Down a G.M. Plant
description: A wildcat strike shut down a factory in Lordstown, Ohio, today that makes some of the General Motors Corporation's most popular cars, the latest sign of continued labor problems at the world's largest auto maker.

title: Greg Norman's Terrible Sunday
description: Anyone who has ever flubbed a job interview, gone blank in the middle of delivering a speech, whiffed with the bases loaded or double-faulted to lose a set can identify with Greg Norman. On Sunday he squandered a commanding six-stroke lead in the final round of the Masters golf tournament, falling like a rock to finish a distant second to the winner, Nick Faldo. The difference between Norman's collapse and the day-to-day humiliations experienced by most of his fellow human beings was a matter of scale and visibility. Rarely has a world-class athlete so thoroughly and publicly embarrassed himself.

title: Fund Linked to N.R.A. Gave $20,000 for Goetz's Defense
description: A legal group founded by the National Rifle Association gave $20,000 for the defense of Bernhard H. Goetz, who is being sued by a man who was left paralyzed after Mr. Goetz shot him in a Manhattan subway 12 years ago.

title: In High Ceremony, Safir Is Sworn In to Lead Police
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani swore in his new Police Commissioner yesterday with pageantry worthy of a mayoral inauguration -- and indeed it was the Mayor, in his favorite role as the city's premier crimefighter, who was the focus of the bunting-wrapped event on the City Hall steps.

title: Q&A
description: Flu and Headache

title: Sports of the Times;A Bandit Runs Free To Boston
description: ON this of all holidays, Bob Sykes knew a compatriot when he saw one. He climbed aboard a bus at the intersection of Interstate 495 and Route 135, and his eyes soon fixed on Bob Mueller of Randolph, Mass.

title: Family Bids Sad Farewell to a Young Flier
description: Strangers gathered with family and friends today under gray skies to remember Jessica Dubroff, the 7-year-old pilot who died trying to become the youngest person to fly across the United States.

title: Executive Changes
description: BANKERS TRUST NEW YORK CORP., New York, said that Frank N. Newman, its president and chief executive, would become chairman, succeeding Charles S. Sanford Jr., who is to retire by mid-1996.

title: Texas Dismantling Scholarship Intended for Minority Students
description: Broadening its reaction to a recent Federal court ruling that struck down race-based preferences in admissions at the University of Texas Law School, Texas plans to dismantle a statewide minority scholarship program that it had created under a Federal desegregation order.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Ferris Wheel Will Look Down on Big Ben
description: Deciding to roll in the millennium in a big way, London is preparing to construct a 500-foot-tall Ferris wheel -- the largest in the world -- that would rotate continuously on the south bank of the Thames and provide nearly 1,400 presumably non-acrophobic riders with spectacular views of the city's landmarks.

title: E.P.A. Plans Radical Change In Calculation of Cancer Risk
description: In a long-awaited move that will ripple across the nation's pollution-control programs, the Environmental Protection Agency is proposing major changes in how it determines which chemicals and pollutants cause cancer, relying less on animal tests and more on new techniques of microbiology.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Inmet Sells Stake In Australian Company
description: The Inmet Mining Corporation of Toronto said yesterday that it had sold its 5.3 percent stake in MIM Holdings of Australia for about $150 million (Canadian), or $111 million (United States). Inmet sold all of its 75 million MIM Holdings shares and acquired options to buy 25 million MIM shares for $1.3 million (Canadian) to cover options previously written.

title: William K. Everson, Historian And Film Preservationist, 67
description: William K. Everson, a film historian, teacher and preservationist whose extensive film archive helped educate many critics and film makers, died Sunday at his apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 67. The cause was prost'te cancer, said a family spokesman.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Museum's Future Is in Doubt
description: The New Jersey Museum of Agriculture, which opened in 1990 on the Cook College campus of Rutgers University, received $265,000 in state financing for the current fiscal year. But Gov. Christine Todd Whitman decided that the museum did not merit that level of support and eliminated it from her proposed 1997 budget.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Kurd in Washington Said to Be Rebel Leader
description: The head of the Kurdish Information Office has been arrested for passport fraud, and American authorities said they believe he is a leader of the rebel Kurdistan Workers' Party, which the State Department lists as a terrorist group.

title: Effort to Make Raising Taxes Harder Fails
description: Rejecting the symbolism of an anti-tax vote on the day Americans file their tax returns, the House of Representatives tonight defeated a proposed constitutional amendment to require two-thirds majorities in both houses of Congress before Federal taxes could be raised.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Daily Briefing column in New Jersey copies on Thursday about James A. Hogue, who was an undergraduate at Princeton for a short time several years ago before admitting that he had falsified his name and lied about his background to obtain financial aid, referred incorrectly to his recent status at Princeton. The university said Mr. Hogue, who pleaded guilty on April 8 to trespassing on the campus last winter, was not enrolled as a graduate student.

title: Suspect Is Arrested In Rape of Girl ,10
description: After a five-day investigation and a 10-block chase involving squad cars and a bicycle, detectives arrested a man on Sunday in the knifepoint rape of a 10-year-old girl in a South Bronx park last Tuesday, the police said.

title: NYC;Memories Of Holocaust, And Debate
description: THIS is the Jewish season of bitter memory, centered on Yom Hashoah today, Holocaust Remembrance Day. In New York, ceremonies in the last few days have honored and mourned the six million Jews killed by the Nazis, as ever with twin admonitions: "never forget" and "never again."

title: INSIDE
description: End to Immigrant Dreams

title: No Headline
description: Is it corruption to induce a candidate to support certain philosophical principles by making a contribution? It's called party discipline! I've never considered it to be corruption. I thought it was good old-fashioned democratic politics."

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Saudis Bar Some Africans As Health Risk to Mecca
description: Saudi Arabia has banned Muslims from four African countries from making this year's pilgrimage to Mecca because of an outbreak of meningitis in Nigeria, Mali, Niger and Burkina Faso.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;2 Free Agents on Defense Come to Terms With Giants
description: Even as the Giants' draft microscope focuses on the Illinois linebacker Simeon Rice, the team continues to take care of other business by signing its own free agents. The Giants have come to terms with defensive end Stacey Dillard and linebacker Marcus Buckley.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NATIONWIDE ACCUSED OF ILLEGAL ACTIVITY IN MARKETING
description: Florida regulators accused Nationwide Insurance yesterday of pressuring its agents in the state to discriminate against consumers based on age, sex, marital status, employment and other personal information. In an order sent to the company, the state's insurance commissioner, Bill Nelson, said Nationwide created a marketing program to sell unnecessary policies, exclude consumers from coverage based on where they lived and deny policies because customers were unwilling to buy additional coverage. Mr. Nelson said the marketing program was "an illegal system of operation." The state's move resulted from complaints from some Nationwide agents. Nationwide officials declined to comment on the order, saying they had not yet reviewed it. "Nationwide has a firm corporate policy to comply with all laws and regulations," a company spokesman, Lou Fabro, said. "It is committed to pursue that policy of compliance." Nationwide has 688,000 automobile, homeowners and commercial policies in Florida.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SFX BROADCASTING TO PURCHASE MULTI-MARKET RADIO
description: SFX Broadcasting Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Multi-Market Radio Inc. in a transaction valued at more than $100 million. Multi-Market currently owns, services or has agreed to acquire 14 radio stations. Under the agreement, SFX will retain 12 stations that were supposed to go to Multi-Market in a swap with Liberty Broadcasting Inc., which is also being taken over by SFX. SFX will exchange stock valued at $11.50 a share for Multi-Market's class A shares, plus other considerations. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Multi-Market fell 75 cents, to $10.50. Shares of SFX rose 62.5 cents, to $34.50. Multi-Market had revenue of $18.3 million last year, while SFX had revenue of $76.8 million.

title: Hospitals Sue New Jersey to Recover Millions Spent to Treat the Poor
description: The New Jersey Hospital Association, a trade organization that represents most of the state's hospitals, filed a lawsuit against the state today, seeking payment for free medical treatment to the uninsured.

title: AT&T Makes Stadium Offer
description: AT&T Corporation is proposing to put up about $600 million for a new domed stadium for the next Cleveland Browns team, a television station reported today.

title: Benefits From Transit Spending Said to Outweigh Costs by 5 to 1
description: For every dollar that local officials spend on mass transit in the New York region, residents get back about five dollars in economic benefits, a Federal report states.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Smith Barney Helps Increase Travelers Profit
description: Travelers Group Inc. said yesterday that its earnings jumped 42 percent in the first quarter as profits more than doubled at the company's brokerage unit, Smith Barney Inc.

title: Union Pacific Says It Will Push Merger
description: The Union Pacific Corporation said today that it hoped to continue working with the Department of Justice and to persuade the department to modify its criticism of Union Pacific's proposed merger with the Southern Pacific Rail Corporation.

title: Texas Utilities to Acquire Pipeline Owner
description: The Texas Utilities Company has agreed to acquire the Enserch Corporation, which owns one of the largest natural-gas pipelines in the nation, in a deal valued at about $1.7 billion, Texas Utilities said yesterday.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Intel and Sun Post Earnings Over Wall St. Expectations
description: Despite reports of a broad slowdown in sales of personal computers and related chips, the Intel Corporation reported first-quarter earnings today that exceeded estimates by Wall Street analysts.

title: MetroStars Ready for Crowd
description: Encouraged by the huge crowd that attended Major League Soccer's first game in Los Angeles and their own early returns, the MetroStars have decided to double the number of tickets on sale for Saturday's home opener at Giants Stadium.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PARACELSUS HEALTHCARE TO BUY CHAMPION HEALTHCARE
description: The Paracelsus Healthcare Corporation, a privately held operator of hospitals and nursing homes, agreed yesterday to buy the Champion Healthcare Corporation, also a hospital owner. Financial terms were not disclosed, but the deal will exchange all of Champion's stock for Paracelsus shares. After the merger, Paracelsus's chairman, Manfred George Krukemeyer, and members of Paracelsus management will own about 60 percent of the company, with Champion Healthcare holders owning the remainder. The new company will trade on the American Stock Exchange. In American Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of Champion rose 50 cents, to $11.

title: Acclaim Takes a Charge as It Refocuses
description: Acclaim Entertainment Inc. said today that it would get out of the cartridge video game business to focus on personal computer games and that it had taken a related charge of $51.2 million.

title: By Design;Once More for White Jeans
description: Jeans have been stone-washed, bleached, unbleached and shredded. They've come 'n every shade of blue, plus black, red, green, yellow, orange and pink. They've come in leather, suede, velvet, corduroy and cotton shirting. Now, look for white denim jeans, which are what many members of the fashion flock were wearing at the fall collections. White jeans had a miniflurry a few years ago and, like many fashions of the past, are having a revival.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Goodby, Silverstein Splits with Sega
description: Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco and the video game marketer Sega of America, owned by Sega Enterprises, have mutually agreed to part company over differences on the creative direction of the company's 1996 campaign. Goodby, Silverstein had handled the creative portion of the Sega national broadcast account, with billings estimated at $20 million to $30 million, for the last five years.

title: Dole Campaigns as Guardian of Youth
description: Senator Bob Dole today offered a novel reason to vote for him for President: he said he would be a better guardian for children than Bill Clinton would be.

title: Answer to Dubroff Tragedy Is Common Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: Justices Take Up Question of Party Donations to Candidates
description: After 20 years of examining the intricacies of Federal campaign finance law, the Supreme Court turned for the first time today to the role of political parties, considering whether they have a constitutional right to spend unlimited amounts of money to get across their candidates' messages.

title: 2 Are Charged in Brooklyn In Beating Death of Infant
description: A Brooklyn mother and her boyfriend were charged in the beating death of the woman's 9-month-old daughter and the abuse of her three other children, whose bodies were covered with bruises and possibly cigarette burns, the police said late yesterday.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Major League Soccer

title: A Modest Proposal on Assisted Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE REVIEW;The Powers of a Deceptively Innocent Apple
description: Complex movements of human bodies symbolized the ambiguities of spiritual experience in the program of works by Michael Yasenak that the Human Dance Company presented on Saturday night at the Washington Square Church.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Evergreen Sells 3 Buffalo Radio Stations
description: The Evergreen Media Corporation said today that it had sold three radio stations in Buffalo for a total of $32 million in two separate transactions.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Lakers' Johnson Is Banned, Fined And Apologetic
description: A week ago, Magic Johnson, the Los Angeles Lakers' revered star, had harsh words for Nick Van Exel. His young teammate had shoved a referee onto the scorer's table, and the National Basketball Association suspended him for seven games and fined him $25,000.

title: USAir Chairman Says Carrier's Solution Will Come From Outside
description: USAir's future lies in buying another airline, being acquired itself, or forming some partnership with another carrier, Stephen M. Wolf, the airline's new chairman, has told employees in the last few weeks.

title: South Africans Revisit Apartheid's Horrors
description: Nohle Mohapi's husband had been in detention -- she didn't know where -- when someone came to her workplace to deliver two letters he smuggled from jail. They were written on toilet paper and said "the situation was bad" but that her politically active young husband, Mapetla, was all right. The letters said she must take care of the children until they would all be together again.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Gain On Treasuries For 3d Session
description: Prices of Treasury securities were higher yesterday despite a lack of new economic data.

title: Observer;George in Heaven
description: A billion here, a billion there, and pretty soon you're talking about real money." I quote Senator Everett Dirksen a generation ago warning the Senate that money does not grow on trees, even for the Federal Government.

title: Philip Morris Sharply Cuts Prices on Post and Nabisco Cereals
description: In a bid to take market share from its larger competitors, the Post cereals division of the Kraft Foods unit of the Philip Morris Companies announced an immediate 20 percent reduction yesterday in the retail prices of its Post and Nabisco breakfast cereals.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CASTLE HARLAN TO BUY FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS INSURANCE
description: Castle Harlan Inc. and the chief executive of Financial Institutions Insurance Group Ltd., John Dore, agreed yesterday to buy Financial Institutions for $54 million. Castle Harlan, a New York-based merchant bank, and Mr. Dore signed a definitive agreement to pay $16 for each common share of Financial Institutions, an insurance holding company based in Wilmington, Del. Financial Institutions has offices in Chicago and Avon, Conn., and assets of more than $94 million. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Financial Institutions rose 75 cents, to $16. The agreement is the latest step in the effort by Castle Harlan to build its specialty insurance business.

title: Ticks and Moths, Not Just Oaks, Linked to Acorns
description: A TANGLED cycle of events in northeastern forests that gives a reason for both Lyme disease epidemics and outbreaks of gypsy moths has been unraveled by ecologists. They have traced both events to the bumper crops of acorns that are produced every three or four years and to the white-footed mice that feed on them.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;CORNING INC. (GLW,N)
description: Corning Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings fell 13 percent as lower profit from its clinical laboratories business more than offset higher profit from its pharmaceutical services and fiber optic businesses. Still, the company's results exceeded Wall Street's expectations.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: E.P.A. Proposes Changes In Regulating Carcinogens The Environmental Protection Agency is proposing major changes in how it determines which chemicals and pollutants cause cancer, relying less on animal tests and more on new techniques of microbiology.

title: Hospital Ousts Psychologist in Abuse Case
description: One psychologist at a city-run hospital has been dismissed and another suspended for altering hospital records about Elisa Izquierdo, the 6-year-old girl whose death from abuse prompted widespread criticism of New York's child-protection system, city officials said yesterday.

title: PERIPHERALS;A Repair Kit for Windows Software
description: MICROSOFT WINDOWS users need all the help they can get, Mac mavens like to say. That may be a bit unfair, but it is not entirely untrue. But the Macintosh itself has become more complicated over the years, and it is a brave soul who does not have Norton Utilities or a similar fix-it program at hand. Still, those programs concentrate on hardware. Here we are talking about software, Windows software.

title: On My Mind;The Winner in Lebanon
description: The man sits there in Damascus, watching Lebanese and Israelis killing each other, saying not much but knowing a great deal.

title: Foreign Aid Makes A Visible Difference
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Camden Judge Dies in Crash
description: David A. Keyko, the Camden municipal judge who sentenced a Garden State Parkway driver to 15 days in jail for tailgating, was killed on Sunday in a plane crash near a Florida airport, the police said yesterday. Judge Keyko's companion, Teresa Dougherty, of Voorhees, was injured. The police said they believed she was flying the single-engine plane.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: ART REVIEW;Trojan Gold, Lost and Found, on View in Moscow
description: After decades of intense mystery and speculation as to its whereabouts, the storied gold of ancient Troy is back on view. And its exhibition here at the Pushkin Museum has inflamed tensions between Russians and Germans over who should own it.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Net Fell 1% At Eli Lilly In Quarter
description: Eli Lilly & Company showed modest growth in the first quarter, despite strong sales of the antidepressant Prozac.

title: Ozarks Twister Hits Arkansas And Kills 7
description: Seven people were killed and at least 30 injured on Sunday night when a tornado hopscotched for 45 miles along the hilly terrain of northern Arkansas.

title: New York Needs a State Smoking Law
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;And One for Very Late Filers
description: After one month, the state's heavily promoted tax amnesty program has taken in $9.5 million from more than 15,000 residents and businesses, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The state is spending $10 million on the program. The Whitman administration has predicted that it will have collected $70 million by the time the program expires on June 30. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about Dan Wolf, a founder of The Village Voice, misstated the role of Edward I. Koch in the fall of the Tammany Hall leader Carmine G. De Sapio. Mr. Koch's victory in a contest for Democratic district leadership in Greenwich Village in 1963 thwarted Mr. De Sapio's comeback attempt. Mr. De Sapio had already lost the leadership -- in 1961, to James S. Lanigan.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;The Jets and Johnson Are Talking Contract
description: The Jets, who hold the No. 1 pick in the National Football League draft on Saturday, have started contract negotiations with receiver Keyshawn Johnson of Southern California and have apparently decided that he's their man if they can sign him ahead of the selection process.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Company Is Sued for Fraud
description: A Delaware company tried to defraud a Morris County woman out of some of her $1.4 million in winnings from a 1987 state lottery, the State Attorney General contended in a lawsuit filed on Friday.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;SmithKline Eliminates Dual Share Structure
description: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. said yesterday that it had eliminated a dual share structure in effect since the 1989 merger of the SmithKline Beckman Corporation of the United States and Beecham Group P.L.C. of Britain. SmithKline announced the share structure change on Feb. 20. SmithKline's class A and class B shares are being merged into one class of common shares. Preference shares are being redeemed at a total cost of about $295 million.

title: ON BASEBALL;A Healthy 17-Game Winner Winds Up in Yankee Limbo
description: Their $20 million insurance policy accompanied the Yankees to Milwaukee yesterday on his way to Florida. The Yankees want him with them tonight just in case -- "if for some reason Jimmy Key is tight and can't loosen up because it's a night game in Milwaukee," Joe Torr' said.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Comments, Not Losses, May Finish Nets' Beard
description: Bickering is one of the few things the Nets have excelled at in recent years, so perhaps it shouldn't be surprising that the team's coach and president are now going public with their unhappiness with one another.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Nutmeg Mills, Tampa, Fla., a unit of the VF Corp. that markets licensed sports apparel, to Sass & Associates in Annapolis, Md., to handle advertising for the Lee Sport brand and to introduce Lee Sport Genuine Casualwear. The billings were estimated at $9 million to $11 million. The Lee Sport brand had been handled for the last year by the lead VF agency, Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis. Sass also handles a line of Nascar apparel for Nutmeg under the Nutmeg Racing brand.

title: Market Place;Utility shareholders face a new hurdle as deregulation nears.
description: HOLDERS of utility stocks, already skittish from cuts in dividends and drives to make electricity pricing more competitive, can now begin to worry about what the industry calls stranded costs.

title: Trading House In Chapter 11
description: The AIOC Corporation, a New York metals trading house, has entered into Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, a clerk from the Federal bankruptcy court in Manhattan said yesterday.

title: In Study, Freezing Saves Infants' Sight
description: A treatment in which the eyes are partly frozen has helped save the sight of some premature babies, according to a follow-up study published today.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday about the activity in the financial markets last week included an erroneous figure supplied by Salomon Brothers for the price-earnings ratio of the Dow Jones industrial average. The Dow ended the week with a price-earnings ratio of 17.65, not 2.03.

title: A New Japan Policy?
description: President Clinton arrives in Tokyo today on a mission to repair the United States' strained relations with Japan. Fortunately, the Administration has indicated he will jettison his longstanding trade-first focus and concentrate for now on the strategic relationship between the countries.

title: Capital Delegate Seeks Tax Cut to Lure People
description: In a bold effort to entice people to live in the District of Columbia, Eleanor Holmes Norton, the District's delegate to Congress, introduced legislation today that would cut the top rate of Federal income tax to 15 percent for District residents. Low-income residents would pay nothing.

title: Answer to Dubroff Tragedy Is Common Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite Cold War's End, Russia Keeps Building a Secret Complex
description: In a secret project reminiscent of the chilliest days of the cold war, Russia is building a mammoth underground military complex in the Ural Mountains, Western officials and Russian witnesses say.

title: Battered Women Rightly Fear Lack of Support
description: To the Editor:

title: CABIN'S INVENTORY PROVIDES INSIGHT
description: An F.B.I. inventory unsealed today by a Federal judge in Montana said that agents searching Theodore J. Kaczynski's Montana cabin found a wealth of potential evidence, including the addresses of corporate executives, explosive devices, five guns, street maps of San Francisco and hundreds of books.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INTERLAKE CORP., Lisle, Ill., which makes material handling, automotive and aerospace products, said it planned to sell its packaging business to closely held A. J. Gerrard & Co. of Des PLaines, Ill., for an undisclosed amount.

title: Nikkei Hits 4-Year High
description: Stocks continued their surge today, trading above the 22,000 barrier for the first time since February 1992. After climbing as high as 22,077.87 in early trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 14.87 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, at 21,868.17. On Monday, the Nikkei closed at 21,883.04, the highest close since 22,107.12 on Feb. 7, 1992.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Marina Construction to Begin
description: Construction is to begin today on a marina complex in the Morris Canal basin at Liberty State Park, the project's developer said. The complex will include 60 slips for craft up to 100 feet long, restaurants, and a public boardwalk, said Steve Park, a partner of Dimeling, Schreiber & Park of Philadelphia, which will lease the site from the Liberty State Park Development Corporation.

title: Patterns
description: Fashion's Off Broadway

title: School Disparities Cited in Gifted Programs
description: Charging that school officials practice the educational equivalent of redlining, a Brooklyn-based community organization sent volunteers posing as parents into schools and found that the black and Hispanic volunteers were much less likely than whites to be allowed to speak to school administrators and obtain information about gifted programs for their children.

title: The C.I.A.'s Cuban Cover-Up
description: Thirty-five years after the failed Bay of Pigs invasion, the Central Intelligence Agency's internal record of the disaster remains hidden in its secret archives -- unavailable for historical research and, more importantly, public debate over United States policy toward Cuba.

title: Comptroller Approves Shift Of State Jobs From Albany
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall today approved a scaled-down version of Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to move thousands of state-financed workers from heavily Democratic areas to Republican districts, ending a bitter political standoff with the Governor.

title: Battered Fordham Student Begins to Emerge From Coma
description: A Fordham University junior began emerging from a coma yesterday, two days after she was attacked in her off-campus apartment building. The school offered a $10,000 reward for information leading to the conviction of a suspect.

title: Ex-Harlem Officer Draws 8 Years for Corruption
description: In the harshest sentence yet handed down in Harlem's 30th Precinct corruption scandal, a former police officer who admitted stealing drugs and then selling them was sentenced yesterday to eight years and one month in Federal prison.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Singapore Video Accord
description: Singapore Telecommunications Ltd., the national telephone operator of Singapore, said today that it had signed an agreement with Time Warner Cable, a subsidiary of Time Warner Inc., to form a partnership for video-on-demand projects.

title: G.O.P. Backer Hired Governor's Wife
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and his wife, Libby, made $209,011 last year, including $47,929 that Mrs. Pataki received for doing consulting work for Ronald Lauder, the wealthy businessman and Republican campaign contributor, according to tax returns the couple made available today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ACX TECHNOLOGIES MAY SELL GOLDEN ALUMINUM COMPANY
description: Shares of ACX Technologies Inc. rose 5 percent yesterday after the company said it had hired Dillon, Read & Company to explore the possible sale of all or part of the Golden Aluminum Company. Joe Coors Jr., chief executive of ACX, said the San Antonio-based aluminum can unit was a small, but significant, player in the aluminum can sheet industry. Shares of ACX rose 87.5 cents, to $18.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. ACX, based in Golden, Colo., was spun off by the Adolph Coors Company in 1992.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Personal Organizer as Pocket Pet
description: GADGETEERS, rejoice! A handsome little device called the Pilot is almost certainly the cutest $300 pocket organizer ever produced.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Rams Battle for Lyght
description: The St. Louis Rams say they have taken advantage of a technicality to match an offer by the Jacksonville Jaguars to cornerback TODD LYGHT. The 6-foot, 186-pound Lyght was designated a transition player by the Rams, giving St. Louis a week to match Jacksonville's offer.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;The WPP Group cautiously re-enters the acquisition arena.
description: THE world's largest agency company, the WPP Group, is cautiously putting expansion back on its agenda -- including additional investments in new media ventures in the United States -- after returning from the brink of extinction.

title: U.S. Helps to Start Negotiations To End the Fighting in Lebanon
description: Israeli planes and artillery hammered Lebanon for the fifth day today, but Israeli and American officials said intensive contacts had begun in an effort to end the fighting, possibly by week's end.

title: The Conscious Mind Is Still Baffling to Experts of All Stripes
description: LIKE the proverbial blind men trying to identify by sense of touch a large, thick-hided animal with a trunk at one end and a tail at the other, some the world's top scientists, philosophers and far-out thinkers gathered here last week to contribute their different perspectives on the elephant of consciousness.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Balloons, Toy Pistols and a Fish for Fidgety People
description: Vera Mantero, a Lisbon-based choreographer, created vivid portraits of fidgety people on Sunday night at the Kitchen. Her program was part of Nova Danca Portugal '96, a festival that suggests Portuguese modern dance is thriving.

title: Optometrists Deserve Trust on Laser Procedure
description: To the Editor:

title: F.D.A. Backs Treatment Designed to Cure Ulcers
description: Correction Appended

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Tyson Case Open
description: The police in Chicago yesterday questioned an Indiana woman who last week accused the boxer MIKE TYSON of sexually assaulting her in a nightclub. The Chicago police said the woman was questioned for two hours at the South Side precinct, where she filed her complaint against the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion on April 9. The police said the woman, a 25-year-old beautician from Gary, Ind., told the police enough to keep the investigation open. Tyson has not been charged. (AP)

title: Anti-Tax Move Stalls
description: A proposal for a Constitutional amendment that would make it harder to raise Federal taxes was defeated in the House. Page A18.

title: Courts to Get More Computer Data to Handle Custody Cases
description: In the wake of criticism of a Brooklyn Family Court judge's decision to award custody of 6-year-old Elisa Izquierdo to her mother before the child's beating death, the state's top judge announced plans yesterday to strengthen the hand of any family court judge who presides over difficult child custody cases.

title: Mammal Bones Found in Amber for First Time
description: SOME of the most vivid remains of past life are preserved in amber: frogs and flowers, insects and lizards from millions of years ago. But scientists had never found any well-identified traces of ancient mammals in these solidified forms of tree resin until they recently examined an amber sample from the Dominican Republic.

title: Clinton Visits Korea and New Peace Talks Are Proposed
description: Against the backdrop of recent North Korean military incursions into the demilitarized zone between the two Koreas, President Clinton and President Kim Young Sam of South Korea today proposed four-party talks intended to bring about a permanent peace agreement that would replace the 1953 armistice that ended the Korean War.

title: TV SPORTS;Some Words Get Stuck in the Throat
description: On a day when Greg Norman played as if he were tutored by Leslie Nielsen, CBS's announcers discovered many ways to avoid saying that he was collapsing until Jim Nantz finally uttered that dreaded "C" word. The harsher version -- choke -- was never mentioned.

title: Time to Stop in Lebanon
description: Israel's strategy in Lebanon now seems clear. By attacking targets in Beirut and other communities, and blockading port cities, Israel hopes to produce enough turmoil and refugees to force Lebanese and Syrian authorities to crack down on Hezbollah terrorists.

title: Williams Holdings Deal
description: Williams Holdings P.L.C. said today that it had acquired Nighthawk Systems Inc., a maker of carbon monoxide detectors, for $19.6 million in cash and debt. Nighthawk, based in Colorado Springs, had sales last year of $32 million.

title: Unions Sue City on Hospital Financing
description: A coalition of the largest municipal labor unions filed suit yesterday against the Giuliani administration, charging that city budget cuts were illegally shortchanging the public hospital system.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: MARATHON;Pippig Comeback Keeps Kenyans From a Sweep
description: Her countrymen ran unchallenged for a 1-2-3 finish, and Tegla Loroupe pulled far ahead of the women's field today as Kenya prepared for a clean sweep of the 100th Boston Marathon. The crowd kept urging on the defending champion, Uta Pippig, screaming "you can catch her," but Pippig did not believe she could win as waves of apparently futile encouragement washed over her.

title: Dow Rises 60.33 on Strong Profits and Bonds
description: The stock market soared yesterday for the second consecutive session, in reaction to higher-than-expected corporate earnings and a rising bond market.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A Dramatist and a Purist
description: What perhaps most separates the two German masters of the Baroque is their sense of audience. Handel composed as if he were a listener, calculating the space, the occasion and the musical forces in order to create the clearest impression. The four Anthems for the Coronation of King George II, written in 1727 and performed by the Bach Choir of London on Sunday afternoon, were meant to be heard in a great space by a public with more on its mind than music.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;U.S. Issues Strong Warning To China About Copyrights
description: The Clinton Administration has delivered a sharp warning in private to Chinese leaders that China's failure to comply with a 1995 agreement on copyright piracy of American products is undercutting the Administration's credibility in Congress and will force tariff sanctions on up to $2 billion in Chinese imports sometime next month, Westerners who were briefed by the Administration said.

title: Knudsen Weighs A Bankruptcy Plan
description: The Morrison Knudsen Corporation, the troubled engineering and construction company, is planning to talk to its creditors about filing a prepackaged bankruptcy plan. The disclosure came yesterday in the annual report for 1995 that Morrison Knudsen filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Approval Is Given For Fleet Acquisition
description: Fleet Financial Group Inc. of Boston received regulatory approval today to buy the United States unit of National Westminster Bank P.L.C. for $3.26 billion.

title: HOCKEY;Devils Start Their Long Off Season
description: The Devils gathered at the rink one last time today for a team picture and a little more soul-searching over a season that ended two months sooner than they had expected.

title: New York Needs a State Smoking Law;Reason for Quitting
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK N.R.A. Affiliate Gave to Goetz

title: Pullout From Chechnya
description: Russia pulled out two battalions from the mutinous republic of Chechnya today as a part of President Boris N. Yeltsin's latest peace plan, but fighting continued and the rebels shot down a helicopter, killing four Russian soldiers.

title: Changes Today in Financial Tables
description: The tables, provided by The Associated Press, replace versions from Tribune Media Services.

title: HOCKEY;PLAYOFF MATCHUPS
description: EASTERN CONFERENCE

title: Rivals Bicker In Monrovia As Cease-Fire Holds, Barely
description: Liberian leaders tried to shore up a tenuous truce today even as sporadic sniper fire rang out in Monrovia and young thugs raced through the streets brandishing assault rifles.

title: Sports of The Times;N.B.A. Lets Magic Off Much Too Easy
description: THE look on Magic Johnson's expressive face when his Laker teammate, Nick Van Exel, ran over to Referee Ron Garretson and knocked him across the scorer's table two weeks ago, within a foot or so of Magic Johnson, was the look many of us had watching from the stands or on television. The look on Magic's face was one of amazement, of incredulity, of shock: What, players don't physically attack a referee!

title: The Apple' Closes
description: The Apple Doesn't Fall . . .," a comedy by Trish Vradenburg, closed on Sunday after one performance at the Lyceum Theater, 149 West 45th Street. Directed by Leonard Nimoy and starring Margaret Whitton and Florence Stanley, it had 19 previews.

title: Hospital Disciplines 2 in Case of Abuse
description: One psychologist at a city-run hospital has been dismissed and another suspended for altering hospital records about Elisa Izquierdo, the six-year-old girl who was beaten to death in November. The actions against the psychologists at Gouverneur Hospital were the most serious disciplinary moves taken so far against any of the dozens of officials who came in contact with Elisa before her death.

title: Clinton Veto Threat On Immigration Bill
description: The Clinton Administration is vowing to veto any immigration bill the Senate approves if it authorizes additional visas for thousands of new temporary farm workers or permits states to deny public education to illegal aliens.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bank of Ireland to Buy British Building Society
description: The Bank of Ireland agreed yesterday to buy the Bristol and West Building Society for L600 million ($906 million) in cash to create the largest bank in Ireland and establish a British mortgage business. The Bank of Ireland, now the second-biggest Irish bank after the Allied Irish Bank, said the acquisition would create a company with assets of L29 billion and 650 branches. Bristol and West is Britain's ninth-largest building society.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ALLING & CORY SOLD FOR $88 MILLION TO UNION CAMP
description: The Union Camp Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire Alling & Cory Company, a distributor of paper and packaging products, for about $88 million. Alling & Cory, based in Rochester, operates 15 distribution centers and 20 retail paper shops in New York, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Ohio and West Virginia, and an envelope-converting operation in Hamburg, N.Y. Alling & Cory had sales of $773 million last year. Shareholders of Alling & Cory may choose Union Camp common stock or cash in exchange for their shares. Union Camp, a maker of paper, packaging, chemicals and wood products, had sales of $4.21 billion in 1995.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Dontae' Jones Signs Out
description: DONTAE' JONES, the Mississippi State junior forward who helped the Bulldogs reach their first Final Four, has left school and will probably enter the N.B.A. draft. (AP)

title: COMPANY NEWS;FORD SWEETENS TAURUS DEAL TO FIGHT CHALLENGE
description: Moving to protect the Taurus's title as the "best-selling car in America" from a challenge by the Honda Accord, the Ford Motor Company sweetened financing terms yesterday for the vehicle. Ford cut the financing costs for the Taurus and the Contour, offering loans with an interest rate of 2.9 percent instead of 4.8 percent. The average lease payment on a Taurus will drop to about $240 a month from about $270. The Taurus, which has held the top United States sales position for the last three years, has had sales of 91,828 cars this year -- just 486 more than the Accord. Ford also said it was introducing a new base model for its redesigned Escort, which goes on sale May 23. The new model will start at $11,430, about $500 less than the old base model.

title: McAfee Associates Rebuffed In Bid for Cheyenne Software
description: Cheyenne Software Inc. said today that its board had unanimously rejected an unsolicited takeover bid from McAfee Associates Inc., calling the rival software company's offer of $27.50 a share in stock inadequate.

title: Apple, With Losses Rising, Loses Its Head of Research
description: Apple Computer Inc., in the midst of a corporate make-over, announced the resignation yesterday of its longtime head of research and development.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COMPAQ IN CLOSER TIE WITH INTERNET SECURITY CONCERN
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation will incorporate network security software by Raptor Systems Inc. into its computers, the companies said yesterday. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Raptor rose $3.375, to $32.625. Financial terms of the arrangement, which builds on an existing relationship, were not disclosed. But Raptor stands to grow rapidly if Compaq deploys its software broadly. Raptor lost $2.6 million on $3.9 million in sales last year. Compaq intends to use Raptor's EagleNT software in machines that companies want to work with both internal corporate networks and the Internet.

title: Nairobi Journal;Take (On) the Minibuses, if You Dare
description: Forget this country's flagging economy and rampant corruption. The hottest political issue in Kenya these days is what to do about the local version of mass transit: those speeding, overloaded, exhaust-belching minibuses and minivans known as matatus.

title: Why Should Elderly Go Bankrupt Over Care?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Honk if You Want a New Stadium Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: CONGRESS IS DENIED REPORT ON BOSNIA
description: The White House will assert executive privilege and refuse to give Congress a secret internal report on President Clinton's 1994 decision to do nothing about weapons shipments from Iran to Bosnian Muslims, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Arafat Aide Hopeful on Adopting New Charter
description: A senior official of the Palestine Liberation Organization predicted today that it would adopt a new charter to replace the current document that calls for Israel's destruction.

title: Bremen Journal;The Sinking Shipyard That Carries Many Fates
description: Birgit and Michael Grohe were finally married last August and were looking for a bigger apartment for themselves and their two children when, quite suddenly, their lives were turned into a question mark.

title: Feasting on Crumbs of America's Love Affair With Bread
description: TRADING up from squishy white bread to artisanal loaves has had an unforeseen consequence in many kitchens. All over America, stale hunks of crusty bread are being tucked away in bakery bags or thrown in the back of the refrigerator, growing older and harder by the day. Handmade loaves are superior to sliced white bread in every respect but one -- staying power.

title: LEBANON ROCKED AS ISRAEL'S RAIDS ENTER SIXTH DAY
description: As Israel pounded targets in Lebanon for the sixth straight day, this capital staggered today under the social and economic strain of an assault that has all but closed the country's seaports, damaged three power stations and sent hundreds of thousands of refugees fleeing their homes.

title: Man Held in Threat to Howard Stern
description: A Buffalo man was arrested early yesterday after he shouted threats and ran toward Howard Stern, the radio talk show host, as Mr. Stern was arriving at work in a limousine in midtown Manhattan, the police said.

title: Engineering School Offers 4 Years of Free Tuition
description: The Rowan College School of Engineering in southern New Jersey has no building, no accreditation and will not even open until the fall, but yesterday it made a bold move to entice a bright class of freshmen: it has offered all entering undergraduates four years of free tuition.

title: No Headline
description: We've been climbing the ladder for five years now, trying to accomplish something. And now in the last six days, it's as if everything has broken down."

title: School Board, Overcharged, Will Examine All Its Leases
description: Responding to criticism of the Board of Education's handling of a $170 million building-leasing program, the board president, Carol A. Gresser, said yesterday that she would direct Chancellor Rudy Crew to re-examine all school leases .

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: AUTO RACING;Andretti Placed on Probation
description: MICHAEL ANDRETTI was placed on probation yesterday by IndyCar Racing, which also assessed fines to the driver CHRISTIAN FITTIPALDI and two racing teams. The penalties were issued by WALLY DALLENBACH, IndyCar's chief steward.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Drug Makers Raise Profits 20% or More
description: Spurred by strong sales of relatively new products, Johnson & Johnson and Pfizer Inc. both reported earnings spurts yesterday that exceeded 20 percent in the first quarter. Both companies were expected to outpace the rest of the pharmaceutical industry.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Language Lapse Cited In Colombia Air Crash
description: The air traffic controller who handled the American Airlines plane that crashed in Colombia on Dec. 20 thought that the crew's request for routing made no sense, but his English was not good enough to tell them, a report released today by the National Transportation Safety Board and Colombian authorities said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Y.& R. and Dentsu Alter a Joint Venture
description: Dentsu Inc. and Young & Rubicam Inc. will dissolve part of their joint venture agency, Lord, Dentsu & Partners, as Dentsu takes control of the Los Angeles office. Operations in New York will continue unchanged.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Shadowy Face and Murder in the Midnight Sun
description: BLACKWATER By Kerstin Ekman Translated by Joan Tate. 434 pages. Doubleday. $23.95.

title: U.S. Urges Lebanese To Disarm Islamic Group
description: The United States, working to broker a new cease-fire agreement in southern Lebanon, handed the Lebanese Government an initial proposal today that reportedly called on Lebanon and Syria to disarm Hezbollah guerrillas in exchange for a possible Israeli pullout from its buffer zone in nine months.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;McSherry's Successor Is Named
description: Two weeks after he was asked to fill in for the late John McSherry on the National League umpiring staff, RICHARD RIEKER was named to it permanently yesterday by the league president, LEONARD COLEMAN. Rieker, 34 years old, has put in 296 days in the major leagues over the last three seasons and has been a professional umpire since 1983.

title: Paging Network Is Leading Bidder
description: Paging Network Inc. of Plano, Tex., was the top bidder in a Federal auction of more than a thousand licenses for dispatch, paging and wireless telephone services.

title: Korea Convergence
description: With their proposal for peace talks with North Korea today, President Clinton and his South Korean counterpart, Kim Young Sam, have broken new ground and raised a spark of hope that the last front of the cold war will finally see what Mr. Clinton called "an ultimate reconciliation."

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Shift on Insurance Inquiries
description: The State Insurance Commissioner, Elizabeth Randall, announced new regulations yesterday barring health and life insurance companies from inquiring whether applicants have ever been victims of domestic violence. The new rules will also prohibit companies from limiting or excluding benefits when a loss results from battering. The regulations were inspired by reports that at least two companies included questions about domestic violence on applications, Ms. Randall said.

title: 1996 N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;Thibault Takes On Rangers and History
description: Jocelyn Thibault once idolized Patrick Roy, a goaltender who turned himself into something irreplaceable when he guided the Montreal Canadiens to a Stanley Cup at 21. With 43 saves in the Canadiens' 3-2 overtime victory against the chastened Rangers in the series opener last night, Thibault indicated he's prepared to imitate his idol.

title: Amex's Profits Rise to Record
description: The American Stock Exchange said yesterday that its first-quarter profits tripled to a record $3.9 million, fueled by higher stock trading volume and demand for market data.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BRENDLE'S SEEKS BANKRUPTCY COURT PROTECTION
description: Brendle's Inc. said yesterday that it had closed the doors of 18 stores and filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Brendle's, known for its jewelry, housewares and gifts, said it would shed some merchandise lines and focus on five categories: party goods, crafts, personal health care, fitness and outdoor products. The Foothill Capital Corporation, the company's secured lender, is providing a $25 million revolving credit line, Brendle's said. The company, based in Elkin, N.C., said its lease liabilities and the investment needed for a reorganization had forced the decision to file for bankruptcy. Brendle's plans to continue to sell jewelry. It sells party goods under the Party Universe name.

title: LeBow Says He Lost Fight On RJR Slate
description: In a surprising capitulation on the day before the annual meeting of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, Bennett S. LeBow conceded defeat yesterday on his slate of 10 company directors.

title: Executive Changes
description: KMART CORP., Troy, Mich., named Stephen Ross senior vice president and general manager of apparel and other products.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;CATERPILLAR INC. (CAT,N)
description: Caterpillar Inc.'s first-quarter earnings fell 1.3 percent, to $296 million, from $300 million in the corresponding quarter of 1995, though per share earnings rose to $1.53 a share, from $1.50, as the company bought back shares through the quarter.

title: Report Shows Newsrooms Inching Toward Diversity
description: Minority employment in the country's newsrooms increased for the 19th year in a row last year, but the increase was small, according to an annual survey by the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Libyan Jet Breaks Rule On Air Ban
description: A Libyan passenger jet flew Islamic pilgrims to Saudi Arabia today, in violation of a United Nations ban on Libyan international air travel.

title: Pataki Weighs Alterations For Workers' Insurance
description: Gov. George E. Pataki proposed legislation today to revamp the state's troubled workers' compensation system, saying his plan would reduce soaring insurance costs at least 30 percent.

title: Sports of The Times;Circus Lull Might Be Temporary
description: PERFORMANCES Canceled!

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Principal Charged in Sex Case
description: The principal of an elementary school here was charged on Monday with sexual assault against a 15-year-old boy, Charles R. Buckley, the Acting Prosecutor for Bergen County announced yesterday. The suspect, John T. Mangan, taught in Ringwood 15 years. He became principal of Peter Cooper Elementary School a decade ago. Mr. Mangan is a resident of Wyckoff, in Bergen County. Mr. Buckley said the assaults took place there over the last year.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Colombian Rebels Kill 31 Soldiers in Ambush
description: Colombian rebels ambushed a military convoy near the border with Ecuador late Monday, killing 31 soldiers and wounding 18, officials said today.

title: Journal;The New Republic
description: If there's one trait that all minorities have in common in America, it's the habit of chalking up "firsts" -- from the first black general to the first Jew on the Supreme Court. In the history of gay America, Andrew Sullivan joins that club: He was the first openly gay editor of The New Republic -- or of any influential American periodical aimed at a general audience.

title: Puerto Rico Joins U.S. in Plan to Fight Island Drug Runners
description: The smuggling is old-fashioned but effective. Under cover of night, airplanes drop large bales of cocaine and marijuana into the sea for retrieval by fast boats that deliver them ashore. Or yachts and other pleasure craft stuffed with illegal drugs in the quaint islands of the Lesser Antilles sail into the harbors of Puerto Rico.

title: Elway Signs 5-Year Deal
description: John Elway, the master of the miracle comeback, signed a new five-year, $29.5 million contract today, guaranteeing that he will end his career with the Denver Broncos.

title: Israel Must Halt Devastation in Lebanon
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA REVIEW;A 'Walkure' With Domingo at the Met
description: It is only in the politically charged world of modern Wagnerians that a straightforward, traditional and comparatively staid production can occasion as vehement a debate as an eccentric one. Ever since the Metropolitan Opera introduced its grandly Romantic, naturalistic staging of "Die Walkure," a decade ago -- with the other "Ring" operas quickly following -- some have praised the company for having the sense to stage the work on Wagner's own terms, and others have derided it for lacking the imagination and fortitpde to offer a fresh approach.

title: Forbes Back at Magazine
description: Forbes Inc. said this week that Steve Forbes, 48, had resumed duties as chief executive and president and as editor in chief of Forbes magazine after ending his unsuccessful quest for the Republican Presidential nomination. At the same time, the acting chief executive, Timothy Forbes, Mr. Forbes's brother, was named to the new position of chief operating officer. Forbes Inc., a privately held company, produces Forbes and American Heritage magazines, and other publications.

title: Sports of The Times;Life on the Other Side of the Whistle
description: THE reaction to the news that John Starks would be officiating a basketball game yesterday afternoon was mixed.

title: Dole Pulls Bill On Immigration Over Side Issues
description: Senator Bob Dole suddenly pulled the immigration bill from the Senate floor today, angered by Democratic attempts to force votes on amendments dealing with the minimum wage and Social Security, two issues that would put the presumptive Republican Presidential nominee and his party on the spot politically.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HELLMAN & FRIEDMAN TO ACQUIRE ADVANSTAR
description: Hellman & Friedman Capital Partners III L.P. said yesterday that it would buy Advanstar Holdings Inc., a publisher of business trade magazines, for $237 million. Advanstar, based in Cleveland, publishes 55 magazines and professional journals for the health care, pharmaceutical, computer, retail and service industries. Its titles include Managed Healthcare, PC Graphics & Video and Hotel & Motel Management. The company also produces trade shows and sells data base, direct-marketing and reference products. Advanstar, which is 49 percent owned by Goldman, Sachs & Company, put itself on the market early this year. Hellman & Friedman, based in San Francisco, is an investment partnership with $1.5 billion in capital.

title: Foreign Affairs;Gardening With Beijing
description: In an interview with President Clinton last week he related to me a revealing exchange he had with China's President, Jiang Zemin, at their brief summit meeting five months ago. Said Mr. Clinton: "I had a fascinating conversation with Jiang Zemin in New York when he said: 'Are you trying to contain China or not?' I said, 'No, no, I'm trying to engage, I don't want to contain you.' But I said, 'It might surprise you to know what I think the greatest threat to our security you present is.' And I said, 'The greatest threat to our security that you present is that all of your people will want to get rich in exactly the same way we got rich. And unless we try to triple the automobile mileage and to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, if you all get rich in that way we won't be breathing very well.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Tyson Investigation to Continue
description: The Chicago Police Department's investigation into alleged sexual misconduct by MIKE TYSON will probably continue for days or weeks, a spokesman said yesterday, but no charge has been filed against the heavyweight boxing champion. The accuser, LaDONNA AUGUST, a 25-year-old beautician from Gary, Ind., met with Chicago detectives for more than two hours Monday night. She has said that Tyson bit her on the face and made other inappropriate advances at a Chicago nightclub on April 7. PAUL JENKINS, the police department spokesman, said, "We're reaching out and trying to talk to people who were there, eyewitnesses or secondhand witnesses. Tyson has made himself available to us."

title: TV Notes;Keeping Numbers Up
description: Last year at this time, the O. J. Simpson trial was an obsession with many American television viewers, and because several basic-cable channels were carrying it live, they reaped the benefits in higher Nielsen ratings. Broadcast network executives dismissed the high cable numbers, saying they would drop off dramatically once the trial was over.

title: About New York;Finding Truth At the Point Of a Camera
description: WILLIAM KLEIN may live in Paris, but he's really at home in your face. Unlike photographers long on lens and short on creativity, he schmoozes, cajoles and shoots.

title: Octopus Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: 1996 N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;Hartford To Detroit?
description: If the Hartford Whalers don't sell 11,000 season tickets by May 1, they may move. One location under consideration is a northern suburb of Detroit, which already has the Red Wings in a downtown arena.

title: 2 Executives to Share the Duties of Disney's Departing TV Chief
description: The Walt Disney Company announced changes at its entertainment operations yesterday, expanding the duties of two top executives, Joe Roth and Robert A. Iger.

title: Home-Grown Courts Spring Up As Judicial Arm of the Far Right
description: In the trailer where he lives alone here in the hills of northern Arkansas, Tom Prahl reads law books and the Bible, taking prodigious notes.

title: Grand Jury Indicts Suspect in Shooting Death of Officer
description: A Bronx grand jury indicted a 28-year-old man on first-degree murder charges yesterday in the shooting death of a police officer, and the State Attorney General said that his investigators had strong grounds for seeking the death penalty in the case.

title: Handcuffing Campaign Reform
description: As irate voters lash out at politicians who are unwilling to end the corrupting influence of money on politics, they should realize that another obstacle blocks genuine reform: Buckley v. Valeo, a 20-year-old Supreme Court decision that prohibits campaign spending caps and other measures necessary to reform campaign financing.

title: Retarded Defendants Gain More Protection
description: The Supreme Court today raised the level of constitutional protection for criminal defendants with mental illness or retardation, ruling unanimously that it would violate the fundamental right to a fair trial for a state to proceed against any defendant who, more likely than not, was mentally incompetent.

title: BASEBALL;After Isringhausen's Brief Struggle, Mets Can't Recover
description: His rise was so dramatic, from the 44th round of the free-agent draft to a 9-2 rookie record, that Jason Isringhausen made it easy to forget there could be nights like this.

title: Doles Pay Almost $137,000 in Taxes
description: Senator Bob Dole and his wife, Elizabeth Hanford Dole, paid nearly $137,000 in Federal income taxes for 1995 and reported an adjusted gross income of $533,415, their tax forms show. Mrs. Dole's work as president of the American Red Cross paid more than her husband's job as Senate majority leader.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: HOCKEY;Game 1 Gives Rangers a New Playoff Curse: Damphousse
description: The Rangers' playoff opener last night included the drama of Mark Messier's return from injury, the excitement of a 77-shot shootout and the tension of an overtime decision.

title: BASEBALL;The Brewers Batter Key And Cruise to Victory
description: It is still too premature to know whether Jimmy Key will experience additional pain in his left shoulder after pitching sluggishly in frigid weather against the Milwaukee Brewers tonight. But it is definitely not too early to deduce how painful this performance was for the perfectionist in Key to accept. Even if he tried playing it down.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HEXCEL BIDS $135 MILLION FOR HERCULES UNIT
description: The Hexcel Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the composite products division of Hercules Inc. for about $135 million. The unit makes fabrics and carbon fiber for the commercial and military aerospace markets. The Hercules division has facilities in Magna, Utah; Decatur, Ala., and Madrid. Hexcel said that it had received a commitment from Credit Suisse for a $300 million line of credit, which it plans to use to buy the Hercules division and to refinance debt. Hexcel, based in Pleasanton, Calif., makes materials for aerospace, military and industrial markets. Hercules, based in Wilmington, Del., is a specialty chemicals concern.

title: Wine Talk
description: THE modern history of Austrian wines reads like the plot of a Viennese operetta, with outsize villains, innocent victims, bumbling bureaucrats and, finally, what appears to be a happy ending.

title: Effort to Derail Anti-Terrorism Bill Fails
description: The Senate tonight narrowly defeated an attempt to derail counterterrorism legislation, clearing the way for a final vote this week.

title: Tough Script Signals End To Buchanan Trip to Sidelines
description: After almost three weeks of uncharacteristic shyness, Patrick J. Buchanan is hoping to recapture the spotlight on Wednesday by attacking President Clinton for "abject appeasement" of China.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Amid the Fury, Strains of a Polka Beat
description: Ministry's show at Roseland on Sunday night was part concert, part massage. Even for those outside the mosh pit, the music kneaded and pummeled the whole body, from ear-jabbing high guitar lines to sustained bass tones that vibrated the pelvis. Ministry, like its fellow industrial bands, is in the business of delivering ominous tidings with elemental force, but there's finesse to concentrate the fury.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Nomura Posts Loss From Write-Down
description: The Nomura Securities Company, Japan's largest securities house, announced yesterday that its writedown of marketable securities for the year ended March 31 resulted in a valuation loss of 3.2 billion yen, or $29.5 million. The loss comes to 16 percent of its net income of 20.02 billion yen in the fiscal year ended March 1995.

title: Yogurt Claims
description: To The Living Section:

title: Chain Agrees to Revamp Movie Theaters
description: United Artists Theatre Circuit Inc. agreed today to make its cinemas more accessible to the handicapped, ending a Federal investigation into accusations that moviegoers with disabilities could not go into some theaters or were segregated to the back rows, the Justice Department said.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;2 Haitian Ex-Leaders Arrested by Dominicans
description: Two of Haiti's most wanted former officials have been arrested in the Dominican Republic, Dominican officials said.

title: A Taste for 'Tough Art' Becomes a $5 Million Gift
description: Seventy-five works by some of the most fashionable artists of the last few decades, a collection valued at more than $5 million, have been given to the Museum of Modern Art by Elaine Dannheisser.

title: Court Reverses Convictions Of 4 Real Estate Executives
description: An appeals court today reversed the convictions of four former executives of the General Development Corporation. They were jailed for two years after being convicted of cheating home buyers out of $117 million.

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Japanese stocks traded lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 51.95 points, or 0.24 percent, to stand at 21,816.22. On Tuesday, the Nikkei closed down 14.87 points.

title: Unexpected Dangers Found in Low Levels of Lead
description: LEAD may be even more dangerous than previously thought, causing high blood pressure and kidney impairment at unexpectedly low levels, according to two studies of adult men published today. The authors of the reports, in The Journal of the American Medical Association, suggested that current safety standards for lead exposure in both adults and children, which have considerably reduced the incidence of lead poisoning in this country, may need to be tightened even further.

title: Real Estate;A consolidation of offices for the Gay Men's Health Crisis in a new lease on West 24th Street.
description: THE Gay Men's Health Crisis, the country's oldest and largest AIDS service organization, has leased a 150,000-square-foot building at 119 West 24th Street, between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue.

title: Replacing Kenneth Starr
description: With a Presidential election only six months away, the public needs to have confidence in the fairness, good judgment and unselfish civic purpose of the independent counsel on Whitewater. It is also important that the months of work by a large, expensive staff not be squandered. After listening to Kenneth Starr's narrow, legalistic reasons for his continued representation of wealthy, politically active clients while serving as independent counsel, we have concluded that Mr. Starr is not the person to deliver on those two goals. It is time for him to step aside and let the investigation go forward under a replacement from the senior staff.

title: Why Marry?
description: Thursday morning, and it's my turn to move our cars for street cleaning. Gene has already bribed the cats into silence with food.

title: Cardinals Condemn Clinton Abortion Veto
description: In an unusual joint statement that carried a scarcely veiled political threat, the nation's Roman Catholic cardinals yesterday condemned President Clinton's veto last week of a bill that would have barred a certain late-term abortion procedure.

title: New Police Commissioner: A Bureaucrat Who's 'All Cop'
description: Long after he had reached the level when most law enforcement bureaucrats stop carrying even one gun in a shoulder holster, Howard Safir sometimes carried a second one at his ankle.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;New Chairman Elected By Union Bank Holders
description: The shareholders of the Union Bank of Switzerland have elected a former chief executive, Robert Studer, as chairman, it was announced yesterday. The election was seen as a defeat for the large shareholder Martin Ebner and a vote of confidence for management.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;The State of Sleeplessness
description: If you think you aren't getting enough rest, you probably aren't. New Jerseyans sleep one hour less on average than people in other states, and one in four residents has difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep, according to a University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey/Eagleton Poll made public yesterday. Researchers cited stress of high-pressure jobs, commuting and rotating shifts as factors that cause sleep loss. About 45 percent of New Jerseyans snore, but less than 10 percent seek help, researchers found.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Prime Pick Of Jets Remains Up in Air
description: The Jets are willing to give up their No. 1 draft pick for the right deal, Dick Haley conceded yesterday. But no one has made them a worthwhile offer, he added, sounding as if he wished he had one.

title: Is North Korea Turning to Counterfeiting?
description: With North Korea so poor that people are going hungry, some experts are worried that the Government there may be turning to a novel approach to raising hard currency: peddling counterfeit American money.

title: Food Notes
description: From the Organic Farm

title: COMPANY REPORTS;WEYERHAEUSER CO. (WY,N)
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company reported yesterday that its first-quarter earnings fell 31.3 percent from the corresponding period a year ago, reflecting rapidly declining prices for the company's pulp, paper and packaging products as well as lower prices for its wood products.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Reuters Sales Up 14% in Quarter
description: Reuters Holdings P.L.C., the world's largest financial information distributor, said yesterday that its first-quarter revenue rose 14 percent from a year earlier as sales of transaction products offset slower growth in information products.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Growth Is Planned By ARCO Chemical
description: The ARCO Chemical Company said today that it would build a new chemicals plant in the Netherlands to produce plastic materials and upgrade its plastic raw materials plant in Channelview, Tex.

title: Wildcat Walkout Is Ended At Big G.M. Assembly Plant
description: Striking workers returned to their jobs at a General Motors Corporation assembly plant tonight hours after G.M. once again displayed its aggressive new approach to labor relations, obtaining a Federal court order for an immediate end to the wildcat strike.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ERICSSON, Stockholm, the telecommunications equipment maker, signed a contract with Omnipoint Corp. of Arlington, Va., a communications technology company, that could be worth up to $350 million in equipment orders over the next five years.

title: Child Agency Under Scrutiny in Death of a 9-Month-Old
description: A 9-month-old baby whose death was apparently a case of child abuse had been removed from her mother's care last year, but was returned less than a month later when child welfare workers found no proof of abuse, officials familiar with the case said yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PRONET TO BUY TELETOUCH COMMUNICATIONS
description: Pronet Inc., a wireless communications company, said yesterday that it would acquire Teletouch Communications Inc. for common stock worth about $75 million and the assumption of about $91 million in Teletouch debt. Pronet also would buy about $15 million of the company's preferred stock. Shareholders of Teletouch, based in Tyler, Tex., will receive about $5.50 in Pronet stock for each share of stock held. Pronet said the acquisition would create the fourth-largest public paging company in the United States, with about 1.4 million subscribers. Pronet, based in Plano, Tex., plans to manage the Teletouch operations through its Houston and Charlotte, N.C., centers. Pronet stock fell $1, to $27.625, and Teletouch rose 43.8 cents, to $5.125.

title: Troubles at Naval Academy Result in Restricted Privileges
description: The superintendent of a troubled Naval Academy took the unusual step today of canceling off-campus privileges for upperclassmen for a week to encourage them to discuss arrests and other recent problems on their campus, in Annapolis, Md.

title: Atlanta 1996: Olympic Profile;Shcherbo in a Long Climb From Desperation to Hope
description: The man who nearly matched Mark Spitz was nothing more than a pale face in the crowd of pale gymnasts seated on the shuttle bus at the world championships, which began here today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There is something special about the relationship between an aunt and a niece who go to the theater together, or so says WENDY WASSERSTEIN, and therein lies the theme of her first children's book.

title: Maryland Elects Democrat
description: A Democrat, Elijah Cummings, became Maryland's newest Congressman today, winning a special election to fill the unexpired term of Representative Kweisi Mfume.

title: Personal Health
description: I KNOW, you have known how to walk since infancy. But when you walk for fitness two or three miles a day three or more times a week, your walking technique can make a big difference in the benefits you derive, how soon you tire and your chances of developing discouraging aches and pains. During my own daily fitness excursions in a local park, I have seen all kinds of walkers, many of whom could get a lot more from their activity with some minor adjustments in how they walk. Think of fitness walking as a sport: every participant can benefit from a little coaching. This is National Walk for Health and Fitness Month, so there is no better time than now to review your reasons for walking and your style.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Suzan-Lori Parks;From A Planet Closer To the Sun
description: Suzan-Lori Parks had just returned from vacation. With another offbeat play, "Venus," about to open at the Public Theater in New York and the first film she's ever written, Spike Lee's "Girl 6," now in cineplexes, she needed time to relax and let down her dreadlocks.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Bulls Measure Greatness by a New Number: 70
description: Their chartered bus made its way north on I-94 and pulled into the Bradley Center parking lot at 6 P.M. Enraptured fans tried to make out the figures behind the tinted windows, the way people try to make out the figures in a limousine outside a Hollywood premiere.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Italian G.D.P. Data Offer Mixed Picture
description: Italy's gross domestic product expanded 2.3 percent in the third quarter compared with the similar period a year earlier, though the country's economy contracted nine-tenths of 1 percent in 1995's final quarter from the third quarter, the state statistical institute, Istat, said yesterday. Italy's G.D.P. grew by 3 percent for the full year, compared with 2.1 percent in 1994. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Senator Is Still Planning to Push Amendment on Raising Taxes
description: The Senate's chief supporter of a constitutional amendment to require two-thirds majorities in both houses before Federal taxes could be raised said today that he planned to push ahead for Senate action despite Monday night's defeat of the plan in the House.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Fake Mute Convicted of Fraud
description: A Union Beach man who prosecutors said dodged a 1987 Federal conspiracy indictment by faking a head injury was convicted yesterday of defrauding his insurance company and Social Security of nearly $300,000.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Quarterly Net Is Up 20% At Times Co.
description: rose nearly 20 percent, slightly exceeding the expectations of most Wall Street analysts.

title: Let the Sentencing Debate Begin
description: One of the few positive things about the dawdling in Albany over the New York State budget is that it creates an opportunity for the Legislature to take a hard look at the significant and expensive changes in the criminal justice system wrapped in Gov. George Pataki's proposed budget.

title: George J. Balbach, 86, Justice Active in Queens Civic Affairs
description: George J. Balbach, a retired New York State Supreme Court justice who was long active in the civic affairs of Queens, died on Monday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 86 and lived in Jackson Heights, Queens, and Oakdale, L.I.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on April 4 and 5 about the late Commerce Secretary, Ronald H. Brown, referred incorrectly to his membership in a fraternity at Middlebury College. Though he was the first black to be admitted to Sigma Epsilon at Middlebury, he was not the first black to be admitted to any fraternity at the Vermont school; that milestone was passed in 1948, a decade before Mr. Brown attended.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Who Will Back Up the Giants' Brown?
description: At the N.F.L. Quarterback Challenge this past weekend, an event where quarterbacks work on their tans and test their passing skills against each other, the New York representatives did just fine.
