The Giants' Dave Brown threw for fun, but next season will he be throwing deep for the Giants?

title: Business Travel;Three companies introduce electronic systems that could take the pain out of filing expenses.
description: THE tedium of filling out expense reports could soon be just an unhappy memory, thanks to American Express, Carlson Wagonlit and Rosenbluth International. These travel management companies are introducing electronic expense reporting systems designed to make this aggravating chore less onerous.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in Business Day yesterday about a joint venture of Cleveland-Cliffs Inc. and the LTV Corporation misidentified the new plant's product. The venture will produce a scrap steel substitute, reduced-iron briquettes; not scrap steel.

title: Nassau to Ban Sale of Herbal Stimulant Linked to a Death
description: Nassau County officials said today that they would ban the sale of herbal stimulant pills suspected of killing 15 people nationally, including a college student from Long Island. The ban is one of the first in the nation.

title: The Diet Wheel Again Spins To Protein
description: FRAN McCULLOUGH, a book editor in Manhattan who has lost 60 pounds in the last year, is relishing the response of people who haven't seen her for a while ("Is that really you, Fran?"). Friends of Janet Pope, a decorative artist in Baltimore, shake their heads in awe at her weight loss -- 56 pounds in 13 months -- accomplished, like Ms. McCullough's, by cutting down on carbohydrates and concentrating on protein.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ORACLE AND SUN MICROSYSTEMS TO COOPERATE
description: The chief executive of the Oracle Corporation, Lawrence J. Ellison, said yesterday that his company and Sun Microsystems Inc. would cooperate on basic design ideas for the software that runs less expensive computers. The companies have been talking about computers that could access the Internet and other data networks but with less processing and memory power than PC's. "We're going to compete, but we're also going to cooperate because the industry is in desperate need of an alternative to the Microsoft monopoly," Mr. Ellison said. Both companies are designing software to perform the basic functions of such machines, which Oracle calls a network computer, or NC. A Sun spokeswoman said she could not confirm the arrangement.

title: Mathematics Remains Remote From Crimes
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMGEN BUYS THREE MILLION SHARES OF REGENERON
description: Amgen Inc. said yesterday that it had bought three million shares of Regeneron Pharmaceuticals Inc. for $48 million, increasing its stake in the biotechnology company to 17.7 percent from 6 percent. The two companies are working together to develop a treatment for Lou Gehrig's disease and a treatment for nerve pain in diabetics. The purchase price also includes warrants to buy an additional 700,000 Regeneron shares at $16 each. Exercise of the warrants, for an additional $11.2 million, would raise Amgen's stake to nearly 20 percent. Shares of Amgen, based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., fell 6.25 cents, to $54.50. Regeneron, based in Tarrytown, N.Y., rose 87.5 cents, to $13.625.

title: Chelsea to Add a 24-Hour Food Market
description: NEW YORKERS who have been craving lobster at midnight or steak at 6 A.M. will soon have a huge warehouse market to satisfy their desires.

title: Researchers Say Chemicals May Have Led To War Illness
description: Researchers from two universities suggested yesterday that gulf war syndrome might have been caused by exposure to ordinarily harmless doses of two or more chemicals that together might cause nerve damage.

title: CHRONICLE
description: After a four-year separation, the Duke and Duchess of York -- PRINCE ANDREW and the former SARAH FERGUSON -- have agreed to end their marriage and will be pursuing a swift divorce, Buckingham Palace announced yesterday.

title: College Matchmakers;Consultants Plot Ways to Impress the 'Right' School
description: In an era when consultants are retained for anything from dressing for power to picking the right dog, it was maybe inevitable that parents begin hiring professionals to guide their children through the anxiety-ridden ritual of applying to colleges.

title: Defining a World Court
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Here's to You, Mr. Robinson
description: Every baseball fan knows that Jackie Robinson broke the major league color barrier in 1947 as a Brooklyn Dodger. But another watershed event occurred 50 years ago today at Roosevelt Stadium here. That's when Robinson -- as a member of the Montreal Royals, the Dodgers farm team -- became the first black athlete to play in any previously all-white professional baseball league. Local officials will dedicate a bronze plaque tomorrow at the former site of Roosevelt Stadium, now the Society Hill condominium complex. TERRY PRISTIN

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;The High Cost of a Fine Smoke
description: The fall of the Soviet Union and rising American animus toward one of Marxism's last bulwarks are taking a sharp toll on an illicit pleasure: the consumption of Cuban cigars.

title: Israel Must Halt Devastation in Lebanon;No Security Neurosis
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Sendek to Coach North Carolina State
description: HERB SENDEK, who coached Miami of Ohio to a post-season berth in each of his three seasons at the school, is the new coach at North Carolina State. The school said yesterday that it would announce the appointment at a news conference today. Sendek succeeds LES ROBINSON, who resigned on March 22 after six seasons. At 33, Sendek, a former assistant to RICK PITINO at Kentucky, will be the youngest coach in the Atlantic Coast Conference. (AP)

title: N.Y. Restaurant Study
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Missing Jews and Polish Anti-Semites
description: Hidden in a Roman Catholic orphanage in Warsaw, the young Marian Marzynski survived the German occupation of Poland, when most of his family was killed in death camps. After the war, he worked as a broadcast journalist in Warsaw, and in 1969 he immigrated to the United States. In 1991, he returned to Poland with an American-born friend, Nathan Kaplan, who was searching for his parents' past in the town of Bransk, about 100 miles east of Warsaw. There they met Zbyszek Romaniuk, a young Pole with a fascination for his town's history, which overlaps an era of Jewish history.

title: Swastikas and Similar Graffiti Spread in the Nation's Capital
description: A problem that has long plagued downtown Washington, the defacement of newspaper boxes and trash bins by spray-painted swastikas and SS logos, appears to be spreading into residential communities where many of the city's Jews live.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MCAFEE CONFIRMS THAT CHEYENNE REJECTED ITS BID
description: The software maker McAfee Associates Inc. confirmed yesterday that it had offered $1 billion for Cheyenne Software Inc. on Saturday and expressed surprise that Cheyenne had publicly announced its rejection of the offer of $27.50 a share on Monday. Usually such rejections are announced by the potential buyer. Shares of Cheyenne, based in Roslyn Heights, L.I., fell 12.5 cents, to $21.625, on the American Stock Exchange; McAfee fell $1, to $57.75, in Nasdaq trading. McAfee, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it first got in touch with Cheyenne last November and made a formal offer in February.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dole Pulls Bill to Avert Vote on the Minimum Wage Democrats tried to force votes on the minimum wage and Social Security, causing Senator Bob Dole to pull a bill on immigration from the Senate floor. He appeared flustered by how to deal with the issue of raising the minimum wage to $5.15 from $4.25.

title: Liberia Faction Begins New Raid on Barracks
description: A major faction in Liberia attacked a barracks complex today that was held by a rival group, thus continuing to threaten the 10,000 people who have taken refuge in the buildings and are now trapped there.

title: Angry Britain Rejects Mass Slaughter of Cattle
description: LONDON  Buoyed by signs of rising consumer confidence in the safety of British cattle, the government defiantly ruled out Tuesday any mass slaughter and said it would challenge the European Union's four-week-old ban on British beef exports in the European Court of Justice.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Panels Clash on Needle Trade
description: Two of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's advisory panels have taken contrary positions on whether to endorse a plan to allow drug addicts to exchange dirty needles for clean ones. Yesterday, the Council on Alcoholism and Drug Abuse sided with the Governor and voted to oppose the needle-exchange proposal, The Associated Press reported. Two weeks ago, the Governor's Advisory Council on AIDS defied Mrs. Whitman by strongly recommending that the State Department of Health establish regulations for voluntary, community-based exchange programs.

title: New York Council to Ask Voters To Postpone Limits on Its Terms
description: Two and a half years after voters imposed term limits on all of New York City's elected officials, leaders of the City Council announced yesterday that they would place a referendum on the ballot in November asking voters to put off the limits for six to eight years.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NATIONAL DATA AGREES TO BUY CIS TECHNOLOGIES
description: The National Data Corporation plans to buy CIS Technologies Inc., another health care management company, in a stock deal valued at about $97 million, the companies said yesterday. Under the agreement, Atlanta-based National Data will offer 0.08682 share of its common stock for each CIS share, or a total of 2.8 million National Data shares, in a tax-free pooling of interests. Shares of CIS rose 68.8 cents, to $2.688; National Data fell 37.5 cents, to $34.375. CIS, based in Tulsa, Okla., manages health care reimbursement and business offices.

title: Judge Refuses Bail for Wife of Slain Scientist
description: Rejecting claims that she was being detained illegally, a judge today refused to set bail for the estranged wife of the Russian scientist whose dismembered body was thrown into the Passaic River 10 days ago.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Mavericks Are Reportedly Sold
description: The Dallas Mavericks have been sold to a group led by ROSS PEROT JR., 'ccording to news reports yesterday. KDFW-TV and radio station KLIF, both flagship stations for Mavericks broadcasts, reported that the Mavericks' owner, DON CARTER, had agreed to sell the club to the Dallas developer. (AP)

title: Market Place;For Bank Stocks, Bigger Appears Better
description: The bigger the better appears to be the rule for bank stock investors these days.

title: Surfing the Food Network: Notes of an Armchair Cook
description: When I was 7, I won first prize in a scavenger hunt. Actually, I didn't really win. I just got the prize. The real winners, two brothers from the neighborhood and my tomboy sister, rejected the award -- a cookbook for kids. I don't know why. As I saw it, any book subtitled "Yum! I Eat It" couldn't be so bad.

title: Charles Anderson Dies at 89; Trainer of Tuskegee Airmen
description: Charles A. Anderson, who dreamed as a boy of soaring into the clouds and later helped to smash racial barriers by training a famed unit of black fighter pilots in World War II, died on Saturday at his home in Tuskegee, Ala. He was 89.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: G.M. Strike Drags Down Industrial Output
description: Weighed down by a 17-day strike at the General Motors Corporation, industrial output slumped five-tenths of 1 percent in March to match the biggest declines since the final stages of the 1990-91 recession, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: Eating Well
description: IN an effort to produce dairy products without any fat, manufacturers have instead produced dairy products without any taste. Even worse, they have sometimes created products that don't taste like food. They taste more like, well, paste.

title: Kevorkian Faces Suicide Prosecution Without a Law Being Cited
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian's latest assisted suicide trial began today, as his lawyers asked jurors to "strike a blow against tyranny" and prosecutors urged a conviction based on an unusual Michigan Supreme Court ruling that assisted suicide can be prosecuted as a felony under the traditions of common law even though there is no written statute against it.

title: TV Notes;Resurrecting a Report
description: With major newspapers, magazines and television networks eager to outdo each other in investigating the evils of Big Tobacco, and cigarette companies ready to fight back with huge lawsuits, any journalistic development can flare up into conflict.

title: American to Make Reservations System a Separate Unit
description: The parent company of American Airlines is expected to announce today that it is making its technology division, Sabre, a separate subsidiary.

title: Prosecutor to Take Death of Baby to Grand Jury
description: The Queens District Attorney's office said yesterday that it would present to a grand jury the case of Mariah Scoons, the 5-month-old girl whose parents fought to keep her on life support and whose death was later ruled a homicide.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Federal Agents Search Mourning's Home
description: Federal agents searched the Potomac, Md., home of ALONZO MOURNING and seized boxes of records, but an F.B.I. spokeswoman said the Miami Heat star was not the target of the operation.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Twins' Puckett to Have Eye Surgery
description: Minnesota Twins outfielder KIRBY PUCKETT is expected to have laser surgery to try to lower the pressure in his right eye. Puckett was placed on the disabled list before the season after he experienced blurred central vision in his right eye because of a partial blockage of the blood vessels feeding the retina.

title: Premature Births Tied to a B Vitamin Deficiency
description: Researchers say they have the first evidence that a diet low in folic acid during pregnancy increases the chances of giving birth to a premature baby of lower than normal birth weight.

title: Honk if You Want a New Stadium Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Enron Pipeline Deal
description: Enron Global Power and Pipelines L.L.C. has agreed to acquire a 50 percent interest in the Centragas natural gas pipeline in Colombia from Enron's parent company, the Enron Corporation, for about $40 million in stock. The 357-mile Centragas pipeline has a capacity of 100 million cubic feet of gas a day. In the deal announced this week, Enron Global will exchange 1.6 million newly issued shares for the pipeline stake. The Enron Corporation, based in Houston, owns 52 percent of Enron Global and the stake will be 55 percent once the transaction is completed.

title: Mother of Man Goetz Shot Depicts Her Ordeal
description: In a voice so soft she could have been talking to herself, the mother of the man paralyzed by Bernhard H. Goetz's gunshot 12 years ago told a Bronx courtroom yesterday of a life in which the simplest daily routine has become an arduous chore.

title: Sprint, GTE and Ameritech Show Phone Profit Is Strong
description: Three of the nation's biggest phone companies reported strong gains in first-quarter earnings yesterday, as customers demanded more lines to hook up to the Internet, fax machines and home offices.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HARRIS BANK TO BUY 54 CHICAGO BANK BRANCHES
description: Harris Bank, a unit of the Bank of Montreal, said yesterday that it planned to buy 54 Chicago-area branches of Household International Inc.'s banks for $277 million. The deal would expand the number of Harris sites to 140. Harris said it expects to close a few sites and plans to transfer affected employees as the bank continues to expand. Household is the nation's seventh-largest issuer of credit cards. The company, based in Prospect Heights, Ill., has been shedding units to focus on core businesses such as credit cards, home-equity and student loans and automobile financing. The Household deal would give Harris an additional $2.9 billion in deposits and $300 million in loans. The bank had $18.7 billion in assets as of March 31.

title: Finally, New York Takes to Brew Pubs
description: IN the last decade, the lust for better beers has given rise to hundreds of small breweries throughout the country. Many of them took root on the West Coast.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Kodak Stock Rises as Profit Meets Outlook
description: The shares of the Eastman Kodak Company increased $3.25 yesterday to close at $73 as the company announced earnings that were in line with the expectations of analysts and said it would buy back an additional $2 billion worth of common stock.

title: TV Notes;More to Discover
description: Discovery Networks announced its fall lineup yesterday with more hours of original programming than Discovery Channel and its sister, the Learning Channel, have ever offered: 952 hours on Discovery, 773 hours on Learning.

title: TV Notes;The Doctor Is In
description: When you hear the medical reporter on local television news called "Doctor," does that mean you can ask him or her about your nagging back pain?

title: Britain Says Beef Sales Are Recovering After Health Scare
description: Four weeks after setting off a public scare about the safety of British beef because of mad cow disease, the Government said today that beef sales in Britain were recovering.

title: Israel Must Halt Devastation in Lebanon
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Fumes Lead to an Evacuation
description: A chemical reaction at a laboratory forced the evacuation of some 200 workers yesterday after fumes were released into the air, environmental officials said. No one at the Nickstadt-Moeller laboratory on Edgewater Avenue was injured, said Keith Lewandosky, a senior environmental specialist with the Bergen County Department of Health Services.

title: Gasoline Rises 6 Cents a Gallon
description: Gasoline prices continued to soar in April as self-serve regular rose 6 cents a gallon, to an average of $1.24, a survey by the American Automobile Association showed yesterday.

title: Mother Who Publicized Sick Daughter Made Her Ill, Police Report
description: A woman who got national publicity for her sick daughter is now accused of making her ill. The authorities say the mother duped doctors into ordering 200 hospitalizations and 40 surgical operations and even injected the girl, now 8 years old, with fecal bacteria.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hanson Sells Plant In South Africa
description: Hanson P.L.C. has sold its Eveready battery factory in Durban, South Africa, to the Duracell Inc. subsidary of Duracell International for 525 million rand, or $123.5 million. Hanson had kept the South African Eveready business after it sold the British battery company Ever Ready Ltd. to Ralston Purina in 1992. Ralston bought the United States-based Eveready Battery Company from Union Carbide in 1989.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Market Chain Has 15% Profit Gain
description: Tesco P.L.C., Britain's biggest supermarket operator, yesterday reported a 15 percent increase in pretax profit for the year ended Feb. 25. Tesco said its pretax profit before charges was L681 million, or $1.02 billion, compared with L595 million in the previous year. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Sinopoli Leaves Imprint On the Old Dresden
description: The removal of the Iron Curtain has opened up fresh territory for Western music-business operatives while freeing central and eastern European orchestras from a provincialism forced on them by years of communism. The ride has been both exhilarating and dangerous, and it has created strange bedfellows, none stranger than Giuseppe Sinopoli's directorship of the Dresden Staatskapelle.

title: Cab Owners Fight Order To Get Costly New Cars
description: It might be called "The Case of the Vanishing Taxi Fare Increase." Ask passengers about the 20 percent rise in fares in March, and they will say they certainly feel the difference. But thousands of independent taxi owners who drive their own cars or lease them out say the bonanza they were promised by the Taxi and Limousine Commission has disappeared. And they say it doesn't take a Sherlock Holmes to figure out where it went.

title: U.S. MILITARY ROLE IN EAST ASIA GETS SUPPORT IN TOKYO
description: Defying anti-American sentiment fanned by the rape of an Okinawa girl by American servicemen last fall, President Clinton and Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan today reaffirmed the United States' military presence in the Far East as "essential for preserving peace and stability" in the region.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Oakley Should Be Back In Time for the Playoffs
description: Charles Oakley's facial injury will not require surgery, meaning that the power forward is expected to be ready when the Knicks start the playoffs next week.

title: Natural' Substance Safety
description: To The Living Section:

title: In a Recount, Cyber Census Still Confounds
description: Millions of Internet users have vanished without a trace since last summer. Millions more have reappeared since December. And a couple of million disappeared again just yesterday, when Nielsen Media Research revised its estimates of Internet use among adults in the United States.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Profits Double At Chrysler As Sales Rise
description: The Chrysler Corporation's earnings doubled in the first quarter, surprising Wall Street.

title: Federal Reserve Turns Aside Criticism in G.A.O. Report
description: The Federal Reserve Board dismissed most of the criticisms of its management today that had been included in a recent report to Congress, and said that it ran itself as efficiently as any company or Government agency.

title: Liberal Arts Are Alive and Well at CUNY
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Upholds School's Ban on Backpacks
description: Her views on Thoreau and justifiable disobedience aside, an eighth-grade New Jersey girl has no constitutional right to defy a ban on backpacks in her school's classrooms and halls, a state administrative law judge ruled yesterday.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;A Meat Sauce With a Greek Touch
description: This recipe for meat sauce was inspired by the mixture of spices in a traditional Greek dish that was covered with cheese and baked in the oven. It uses fennel, which provides a wonderful, slightly sweet licorice flavor that marries happily with caraway, ground coriander, cloves and bay leaf. (Don't forget to remove the bay leaf before serving.) Toss the sauce with some linguine, and on the side, consider serving a mesclun salad dressed with olive oil, balsamic vinegar and reduced-sodium soy sauce.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Creepy Side of Noir: A Bumpkin Gang
description: Floating around the HBO schedule these days is one of those feature films that, like "The Last Seduction" starring Linda Fiorentino, can be seen on pay television before being released, if ever, to theaters. This one, written by the brothers Jonas and Josh Pate, is "The Grave." As a creepy comedy, it's less black than red, as in neck.

title: A Mint Julep Toast for Edna Lewis's 80th
description: EDNA LEWIS, the doyenne of Southern chefs, celebrated her 80th birthday Sunday at Bulloch Hall in Roswell, Ga., which was the home of Theodore Roosevelt's mother, Mittie Bulloch. More than 75 friends and colleagues, including Marion Cunningham and Jean-Claude Baker, celebrated with her, at a dinner that included mint juleps, barbecued pig and buttermilk biscuits. At the party, Ms. Lewis was resplendent in black and gold.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Mechanics of Marriage And a Bit of Ambiguity
description: It would seem to be a situation all too familiar from the headlines of the last two years: a pretty, blond Hollywood wife is tatooed with bruises she says came from her husband, a virile good guy of a public idol. Yes, the police have been summoned, she says, but have administered nothing more than a slap on the wrists.

title: INSIDE
description: Agony Over China Trade

title: Tomas Gutierrez Alea, Cuban Film Maker, 69
description: Tomas Gutierrez Alea, the celebrated Cuban director of "Memories of Underdevelopment," "Strawberry and Chocolate" and other films, died yesterday in Havana. He was 69.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;For the debut of a Virgin Megastore, everything's on a grand scale.
description: THE Virgin Megastore that opens next week in Times Square, with 75,000 square feet on three levels, is being aggressively promoted as the world's largest purveyor of music, movies, books and multimedia products. One reason the self-styled "entertainment retail complex" is as big as a warehouse is the big task it seeks to accomplish: helping to build Virgin into a megabrand in the United States.

title: Technology Issues Lead Gains in Market
description: Stocks, led by technology issues, rose strongly, lifting the Nasdaq composite index, which had been lagging recently, to a record high.

title: COMPANY NEWS;RITE AID PURCHASE OF REVCO MIGHT FACE LAWSUIT
description: The Federal Trade Commission and several states are preparing a legal challenge to the Rite Aid Corporation's $1.8 billion acquisition of Revco D.S. Inc., its biggest competitor, officials at antitrust agencies investigating the purchase said yesterday. Any move is expected to come by Friday, when Rite Aid's $27.50-a-share tender offer expires, the officials said. Executives of Rite Aid, the nation's largest drugstore chain, met yesterday with F.T.C. officials in Washington. The company has already extended the period for antitrust review five times to prolong negotiations with the commision. When the commision challenges a merger or acquisition, the agency usually asks a Federal judge for a court order to delay the transaction until antitrust questions are resolved.

title: Gunmen Rob City College Bank And Make Off With $600,000
description: Two gunmen robbed a part-time bank on the City College campus in Harlem yesterday morning, fleeing with about $600,000 that the bank had on hand to cash student aid checks.

title: Doctor's Specialty Turns Out to Be Masquerade
description: Colleagues remember him as witty and charming, a crisp professional with a confident bedside manner, a flair for storytelling and a generosity of spirit that led him on risky overseas trips to provide free medical care for the poor.

title: Retired Professor Teaches History to Those Who Lived It
description: After teaching American history to undergraduates at Williams College for 44 years, Prof. Robert Scott adjusted his classroom methods for his new students at Kimball Farms, a retirement community here. Most of them are octogenarians.

title: Crash Prompts Pentagon To Install Safety Devices
description: The Secretary of Defense has ordered that new recording devices and safety equipment be installed on military aircraft that carry passengers, after investigators found no sign so far that major components failed on the plane that crashed in Croatia on April 3, killing Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and 34 others, a senior Air Force official said today.

title: Ferry's Shot Buries Hawks
description: Danny Ferry hit a 3-pointer with 41 seconds left and Cleveland overcame a 20-point deficit to beat Atlanta, 80-77, tonight, breaking a three-way tie for fifth place in the Eastern Conference playoff race.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Philip Morris Posts a Sharp Income Climb
description: The Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that earnings in the first quarter surged 17.2 percent on continued strong demand for cigarettes.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;U.S. Bonds In the Shadow Of Inflation
description: Treasury prices ended slightly lower in moderate trading yesterday, despite a drop in commodity prices that eased some inflation concerns.

title: Scott Leaves Stage During 'Inherit'; Randall Steps In
description: George C. Scott, saying he felt faint, walked off stage last night during a performance of the National Actors Theater production of "Inherit the Wind" at the Royale Theater on West 45th Street. But before a member of the theater staff could call for a brief pause in the show, Tony Randall dashed from his mezzanine seat to replace Mr. Scott.

title: Now Legal Immigrants, Too, Become the Target
description: To the Editor:

title: A Survey Finds Bias on the Front Page
description: Although women make up 52 percent of the nation's population, they are the subject of only 15 percent of front-page newspaper articles, a new survey has found.

title: Dole Wavers On Extending Trade Rights For China
description: In the first indication that Washington's dealing with China could become a major campaign-year argument in Congress, Senator Bob Dole appeared to back away today from years of support for extending broad trade privileges to Beijing, saying he had not decided whether to oppose the Clinton Administration's efforts to renew those trade rights this spring.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Prices Reverse as Corn and Oil Plunge and Gold Follows Drop
description: Corn and crude oil prices plunged yesterday on indications that low inventories of both commodities would be replenished in coming months.

title: 20,000 Fine For Campaign
description: The Presidential campaign of Patrick J. Buchanan has agreed to pay a $20,000 fine to the Federal Election Commission for improper contributions to his 1992 campaign, the commission said today.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Unhappy Endings for the Nets and Beard
description: The end is near, not only to another dismal campaign by the Nets but also for Butch Beard's reign as head coach.

title: Rowlands Release Bare Bones Of Their Income Tax Return
description: Gov. John G. Rowland had total income of $111,417 last year, but only $27,717 was subject to Federal taxes, according to a summary of the Governor's tax returns.

title: Tony Award Telecast Packs More In 2 Hours
description: And the winner of the Tony for best director of a musical is . . . prerecorded.

title: Mr. Clinton's New Agenda in Asia
description: When President Clinton first visited Japan in 1993, acrimonious trade issues dominated the agenda. Mr. Clinton is back in Tokyo this week, but the subject has changed. This time, both sides are stressing efforts to reinforce the United States security alliance with Japan. The shift is appropriate, given new military tensions in the region, and it promises to produce more harmonious relations between Washington and its leading Asian ally.

title: Fleet Chairman to Resign In Wake of Banks' Merger
description: Joel A. Alvord, the chairman of the Fleet Financial Group, announced late last night that he would step down at the end of the year.

title: New Boat People Exodus: Back to Vietnam
description: Two decades after the fall of Saigon, the biggest flood of Vietnamese boat people in years is under way. But this time the flow is being reversed, as refugee camps around Southeast Asia begin closing down and tens of thousands of asylum-seekers are sent back to the country they fled.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK;Modell Toys With the Idea of Moving Up in Draft
description: Art Modell, the Baltimore Ravens' owner, had turned over much of the college draft responsibility to Coach Bill Belichick in recent years. But now that Belichick is no longer the coach, Modell is weighing in on the draft.

title: Ex-Judge Cleared of Raping Court Reporter
description: A former state judge accused of rape, threatening and sexual harassment by his court reporter has been cleared of criminal conduct, law enforcement officials said.

title: In Bomb Case, Defense Team Challenges Government
description: With a Federal grand jury scheduled to begin considering evidence on Wednesday against Theodore J. Kaczynski, the Unabom suspect, the two court-appointed lawyers who represent him have lost no time in waging an aggressive defense.

title: Gulf Canada to Buy Some Pennzoil Assets
description: Gulf Canada Resources Ltd. said today that it planned to buy most of the Pennzoil Company's Canadian oil and natural-gas assets for about $184 million (United States).

title: Mayor Wants Stadium Both Ways
description: When it comes to building a new stadium for the New York Yankees, Rudolph W. Giuliani is apparently of two minds.

title: Essay;Iran-Bosnia Blunder
description: As forecast here last week, President Clinton has drawn the curtain of "executive privilege" around the Iran-Bosnia blunder. He is determined to keep from public scrutiny the secret green light he gave to a terrorist state to supply and penetrate the Muslims of Bosnia.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Used-Car Chain Names Finalists
description: Driver's Mart Worldwide Inc. in Grand Rapids, Mich., a new company that plans to open a national chain of used-car stores this year, has named three finalists in a review for its account.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Earnings of 2 Big Brokers Surpass Expectations
description: Two securities houses, the Bear Stearns Companies and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, reported quarterly earnings yesterday that exceeded analysts' expectations.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Next to Brazil's Pop Scene, A Niche for the Classical
description: A few seasons ago, Dennis Russell Davies expanded the mandate of the @merican Composers Orchestra by adopting a broad definition of America for the sake of an annual Sonidos de las Americas festival. This year's installment, which ended with a panel discussion and concert at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon, focused on the music of Brazil.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Economies of Europe Eroding Amid Gains Elsewhere
description: While the United States remains on a path of stable if moderate growth, the condition of the big West European economies has significantly deteriorated over the last six months. And Japan is showing increasing signs of strength, the International Monetary Fund reported today.

title: No Herbal Connection
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Kelly's Outlook Uncertain As Shoulder Pain Persists
description: The pain in Pat Kelly's right shoulder persists and the possibility is getting stronger that the Yankee second baseman will remain a Yankee spectator this season. An examination will be made of Kelly's shoulder in New York by team doctors on Thursday or Friday to determine if he needs surgery for the second time in six months.

title: Immigration Case Exposes Cultural Ignorance
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about the growth of nature programs on television misidentified the outlets for many of the programs. "Wild America," "Nature," "Eyewitness" and "Survival" all appear on the Public Broadcasting Service, not on the Discovery Channel; "The Secret Life of Plants" appeared on the Turner Broadcasting System, not Discovery.

title: Housing Construction At Slower Pace in March
description: Housing construction slowed in March, partly because of a sharp drop in new apartments, as rising mortgage rates threatened to weaken the housing market in coming months.

title: West London Hit by Bomb; No One Hurt
description: An explosion rocked an expensive residential district of west London tonight after a warning call attributed to the Irish Republican Army, police and fire officials said.

title: BASEBALL;Wilson Keeps Cool While Losing Control
description: The potential is not in dispute, not for Paul Wilson, and not for the young pitchers who created so much hope before the start of this Mets season. The immediate question relates to the pitch often considered the most important in their game -- strike one, or ball one -- and the consequences of each subtle success or failure.

title: Bill Lengthens Hospitalization After Births
description: A Senate committee today approved a bill that would require health plans to cover at least 48 hours of hospital care for mothers and their newborn infants.

title: Medicaid Loopholes Are for Good Reason;Dubious Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: Bob Grant Is Off Air Following Remarks On Brown's Death
description: Bob Grant, the radio talk show host who for more than 25 years has provoked outrage with his derogatory comments about black and Hispanic people, was abruptly taken off the air yesterday after facing criticism for a remark he made following the death of Ronald H. Brown, the Commerce Secretary.

title: Making Liberty His Business;Ex-Political Prisoner Turns Freedom's Icon Into a Career
description: On a sweltering August afternoon in 1958, Ovidiu Colea stepped off the train from Bucharest in a town hard by Romania's western border. The young man clambered over the bank of the Danube and lay on his belly in a cornfield, waiting for nightfall and a chance to escape to the United States through Yugoslavia. As he was gripping a bag containing the snorkel and mask that would have taken him across the river, he suddenly felt the cool barrel of a soldier's rifle against his head.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the settlement of a student protest at Columbia University demanding the creation of an ethnic studies department described two aspects of the settlement incorrectly. While Columbia does plan to fill more faculty positions in Asian-American and Hispanic studies, it did not agree to hire professors with specific racial or ethnic backgrounds. In addition, the university said students who barricaded Hamilton Hall could be placed on probation; it did not agree not to take any disciplinary action against them.

title: In Summit Silences, a Truce In U.S.-Japanese Trade Wars
description: What is striking about the summit meeting this week between President Clinton and Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto is what is not being heard or seen.

title: 1996 N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;Damphousse Lurks, And Rangers Cringe
description: Unlike Mark Messier, Vincent Damphousse does not have a Stanley Cup ring for nearly every finger. Unlike Messier, Damphousse is not nursing tender ribs that sometimes puts a telltale hitch in his glide.

title: Senate Easily Passes Counterterrorism Bill
description: The Senate tonight overwhelmingly approved counterterrorism legislation that would significantly accelerate executions of death-row inmates around the country and make it more difficult for all Federal and state prisoners to appeal their convictions.

title: Scott Returns to Show
description: George C. Scott, who walked off in midperformance of "Inherit the Wind" on Tuesday night, complaining that he felt faint, returned to the show yesterday evening. A spokesman, Gary Springer, said that Mr. Scott had by prearrangement missed the matinee performance. Mr. Scott has intermittently missed performances of the revival, scheduled to run until May 5 at the Royale Theater. Representatives of the show say he has been ill, but have not disclosed the exact nature of the malady.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Profit Rises At SGS-Thomson
description: SGS-Thomson Microelectronics N.V., Europe's biggest independent semiconductor maker, said yesterday that its first-quarter net income rose 64 percent as specialized computer chips kept raising profit margins. The French-Italian company said its profit was $175 million, up from $106.9 million a year earlier. SGS-Thomson's sales rose 32 percent, to $1.03 billion, from $779 million in the 1995 quarter.

title: Young Vanguard Has Seen TV-Less Future, and It Works
description: THE children were shocked. The teachers had to be out of their minds. Why else would they propose such an outlandish idea: a whole week without television?

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Jets' Poker Face Keeps Rest of the First Round a Mystery
description: Keyshawn Johnson was on yet another business trip to New York yesterday -- he has been spending more time here than the recently signed Neil O'Donnell -- but claiming he still doesn't know if the Jets will make him the first pick in the draft.

title: Sports of the Times;50 Years Ago: Robinson's Jersey Debut
description: ONCE known as Droyer's Pointe, the area is now called Society Hill, the name of the fashionable condo complex where Roosevelt Stadium stood, where Jackie Robinson wore a minor league Montreal Royals uniform 50 years ago today as the first black player in organized baseball.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICA'S FAVORITE CHICKEN SELLS A MAJORITY STAKE
description: The America's Favorite Chicken Company of Atlanta, the nation's second largest chain of chicken restaurants, sold a 58 percent stake yesterday to Freeman Spogli & Company for $320 million, raising money for acquisitions. The sale to Freeman, a Los Angeles investment firm, will enable America's Favorite to offer shares to the public in a couple of years, said Frank Belatti, the chief executive. The company, which operates about 2,250 Popeye's Chicken and Biscuits and Church's Chicken restaurants, will use $70 million to pay off debt. The company emerged from bankruptcy in 1992.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's;Folk Songs Embraced By Masters
description: Britten's Appropriations

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;A Pair of Moves In Graphic Design
description: The Leap Partnership in Chicago has agreed to acquire a graphic design company, and BBDO South in Atlanta has formed a graphic design unit.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Honoring the Radish

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Times Co. Appoints a Senior Vice President
description: to the new position of senior vice president for corporate development, new ventures and electronic businesses. The appointment is effective immediately.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Hackensack River Is Rated
description: An environmental group has ranked the Hackensack River as the 15th most threatened river of 30 rivers in the country. American Rivers, a nonprofit watchdog organization, said that extensive development along the Hackensack is a danger to the 200 species of resident and migratory birds in the area.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Nathan's Famous Rehires an Agency
description: Nathan's Famous Inc., the restaurant chain, has rehired the Manhattan Marketing Ensemble in New York to handle its account, which had been at Jerry & Ketchum in New York, a joint venture of Jerry Della Femina and Ketchum Communications, for the last year. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Text on Race via Dynamics and Space
description: Bebe Miller always commands attention as a dancer. And she can do so quietly. She certainly can burst into rage when the choreographic occasion demands. But she can also move gently, almost diffidently, off in a corner while other people let their steps thunder at center stage. No matter where she is and how strongly or delicately she is moving, she draws the audience to her.

title: COLLEGE LACROSSE REPORT
description: Princeton

title: Banc One Plans Buyback
description: The board of the Banc One Corporation has approved the repurchase of as many as 10 million of the company's common shares. The stock closed today at $33.875, down 62.5 cents a share. Banc One, which is based here, has bought back more than 40 million shares since 1994, of which 23.6 million were used in the acquisition of Premier Bancorp Inc., with the remaining 16.5 million reissued as part of a 10 percent stock dividend paid in February. In January, the company had about 410.6 million common shares outstanding.

title: COMPANY NEWS;A HIGHER OFFER IS MADE FOR INTERNATIONAL JENSEN
description: The Emerson Radio Corporation said yesterday that it had offered to buy International Jensen Inc. for about $57 million, topping a previous $51 million bid by the Recoton Corporation. Emerson is offering $9.90 in cash for each of Jensen's 5.7 million outstanding shares. The company said it would also assume some Jensen debt, bringing the total consideration to about $100 million. Jensen, based in Lincolnshire, Ill., is a maker of speakers and other audio products. In January, Recoton offered $8.90 in cash and stock for Jensen's shares. Under both proposals, Jensen's automobile speaker manufacturing business would be sold to its chairman, Robert G. Shaw, for $15 million.

title: South Africa Murders Soar
description: An average of 52 people are murdered each day in South Africa, making the murder rate nearly 10 times that of the United States, according to police figures released today.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: REPUBLICANS TOLD TO BRACE FOR VOTE ON MINIMUM WAGE
description: The wall of Republican opposition to raising the minimum wage cracked today when Speaker Newt Gingrich told House Republicans that they should prepare themselves to face a vote on the issue -- a vote that would almost surely lead to an increase.

title: Lawyer Says Client Is Guilty In Klaas Case
description: The lawyer for the defendant in the Polly Klaas trial told jurors today that his client was guilty of kidnapping and killing the girl and that he would not try to make excuses for it.

title: Medicaid Loopholes Are for Good Reason
description: To the Editor:

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: CLOSE TO HOME;A House, Too, Can Be a Lifelong Companion
description: I AM amazed at the irony that my deepest relationship is with a house.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Partners & Simons, Boston, was awarded three accounts, with combined billings estimated at $5.5 million: Saville Systems, Burlington, Mass., as the first agency to handle its account; Process Software, Framingham, Mass., previously at Harpell Martins, Concord, Mass., and Cayenne Software Inc., being formed by a merger of Bachman Information Systems, Burlington, and Cadre Technologies, Providence, R.I., to handle advertising.

title: Goetz Defense Opens, Calls Jimmy Breslin and a Psychiatrist, ThenCloses
description: After being attacked in court for nearly a week, portrayed as a bilious aggressor who opened fire in a subway 12 years ago, Bernhard H. Goetz opened his defense in a lawsuit at midmorning yesterday.

title: The Perils of the Press in Indonesia Include Jail
description: The clang of a steel door slamming echoed against the concrete walls as Eko Maryadi waited for his friends, a computer disk clutched in his fingers. At the massive wooden gate of the central prison, a guard yanked on the door's iron ring, directing the visitors toward the holding cage.

title: Clinton Urges Broad Global Role for Japan
description: Bringing a state visit to an end, President Clinton today urged Japan to forge an alliance with the United States for the next century, with a growing commitment to free trade and to an expanding international leadership role that "flows from its place as a great nation."

title: Justices Express Skepticism On U.S. Policy of Seizures
description: The Supreme Court appeared distinctly troubled today by the Federal Government's strategy of both prosecuting drug dealers and seizing their property. But it was evident during a fast-paced argument that the Justices were even more troubled by the implications of ruling that the widely used prosecution-and-forfeiture combination is an unconstitutional form of double jeopardy.

title: Dole Meets A Setback
description: Senator Bob Dole returned from his Florida vacation last week with a tan and a clear idea of how he would run for President: Campaign from the Senate floor by getting legislation passed to contrast himself with President Clinton, and deliver speeches to distance himself from unpopular Republicans in Congress.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Hasbro to Choose From Five Agencies
description: Hasbro Inc. has narrowed a review of the broadcast advertising portion of the account of its Playskool line of toys, which has been handled by Griffin Bacal in New York. Though the billings were not disclosed, trade publications estimated them at $30 million.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;AT&T Profit Is Up 14% For Quarter
description: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that profit from long-distance telephone and wireless services climbed nearly 14 percent in the first quarter, to $1.4 billion, but that sales growth in its long-distance business was appreciably slower than that of its competitors, the Sprint Corporation and MCI Communications.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;A Hayseed in the Groves of Academe
description: The time slot following "Friends" is foolproof, and sure enough, NBC has filled it with a fool. Boyd, the country-boy hero of "Boston Common," drove his younger sister to college in Boston and stayed because he fell for a sweet graduate student named Joy. "If you say it really fast, it sounds like you're a pogo stick," he say dreamily about her name. "Joy-joy-joy." We're not talking about debonair sophistication here. Monica from "Friends" wouldn't give a bumpkin like Boyd a second glance.

title: Ralph Marino, Lucky Guy
description: Ralph Marino, the former New York State Senate majority leader, was a sad sight after the last gubernatorial election. Having failed to show the proper enthusiasm for George Pataki's candidacy, Mr. Marino was stripped of his leadership post, his staff and his prime office space. In a world where even the humblest legislator has some stipend-paying additional assignment, Mr. Marino moped around the corridors with barely a perk to his name.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICA WEST MECHANICS VOTE IN FAVOR OF UNION
description: Mechanics at America West Airlines have voted in favor of being represented by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the second group to seek union representation since the carrier emerged from bankruptcy in 1994. The teamsters said yesterday that 82 percent of the mechanics at America West maintenance bases in Phoenix; Las Vegas, Nev., and Columbus, Ohio, voted in favor of representation. America West, the nation's ninth-largest airline, said it planned to file a lawsuit in Phoenix today asking a Federal judge to review the election. America West questioned why Federal officials overseeing the election allowed about 400 mechanics, dismissed by the airline in December, to vote. Shortly after the company emerged from bankruptcy, its flight attendants voted in favor of union representation.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SANDY SPRING BANCORP INC., Olney, Md., said it would acquire Annapolis Bancshares in a stock swap valued at $18 million.

title: AT HOME AND WORK WITH: Robert Isabell;Coming to the Aid Of the Party
description: ROBERT ISABELL hates the word "lavish." Especially when it is used to describe his work. New York's reigning florist and party designer, whose celebrity-clogged, gala-studded resume includes the wedding of Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg and the funeral of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, prefers "understated."

title: Bell Atlantic And Nynex Are Said to Be Close to a Deal
description: Bell Atlantic and Nynex may consummate their long and highly publicized courtship as early as this weekend, according to executives familiar with the negotiations. But the protracted and public nature of the talks could make a merger more difficult for both Bell companies to sell to investors, regulators and their own employees -- all of whom have had months to find fault with the potential alliance.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;MERCK & CO. (MRK,N)
description: Merck & Company said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose 14 percent, propelled by sales of its cholesterol-lowering drug Zocor and the addition of newer products including Fosamax, a treatment for osteoporosis.

title: BASEBALL;Rod Carew's Daughter Dies
description: For seven months, 18-year-old Michelle Carew battled against leukemia. Her doctors said she needed a bone-marrow transplant. There were 70,000 volunteers, but none had marrow to match hers.

title: And They All Came Tumbling Down;Short-Seller Levels a Wall St. Institution
description: For years, the promoters of small public companies have complained about "bear raids" by short-sellers, investors who strive to profit from declining stock prices. But despite tales of bears who go even further, illegally conspiring to drive prices down, actual evidence of such misbehavior has been scarce.

title: Wrong Way to Recall the Bombing
description: To mark the first anniversary of the Oklahoma City bombing tomorrow, Congress vows to pass, and President Clinton is expected to sign, a bill that threatens civil liberties under the guise of fighting terrorism.

title: Mobil to Buy Big Stake in Kazakh Field
description: The Mobil Corporation said today that as expected it had agreed to buy 25 percent of one of the world's biggest oil projects, a $10 billion venture led by the Chevron Corporation in the central Asian republic of Kazakhstan.

title: 1996 N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;Despite Opening Loss, Rangers Stay Upbeat
description: Teams that lose their playoff opener aren't always this optimistic. When that defeat is the sixth in succession, it is rare to hear so much confidence.

title: BASEBALL;Deep Sleep For Yanks After Cone Is Hit Hard
description: The signs that it would be an annoying day for the Yankees were littered across the barren expanse of County Stadium today, telltale signals that this listless bunch would struggle, fall down and never bother getting up against the Milwaukee Brewers. Sure enough, the Yankees snoozed through an 8-4 defeat in unsightly fashion today.

title: Theater in Review
description: Keeping 'Richard III' In the Womb 20 Months 'A Kingdom for My Horse' La Mama Annex Theater

title: SENIOR CLASS;Alcohol Lures the Old
description: HE'S a hearty 72-year-old Manhattan entrepreneur who retired to Florida. She's a no-nonsense 75-year-old former factory worker who lives in a federally subsidized apartment and has never left New Jersey. What they have in common, along with three million other Americans age 60 and over, is a drinking problem.

title: Pataki Curbs Unmarked Cars' Use
description: Gov. George E. Pataki ordered the state police today to stop using unmarked cars to pull over speeding drivers, citing what he called a growing number of cases around the country in which criminals trap their victims by posing as police officers.

title: 2 Wells Are Closed in Area With Concerned Over Cancer
description: Two wells have been closed in a water system serving 85,000 people in southern New Jersey as public health officials try to solve a 15-year-old riddle involving the environment and what appears to be a high rate of cancer in children.

title: Simpson's Friend Invokes 5th Amendment
description: Al Cowlings has refused to testify about what his longtime friend O. J. Simpson did in the days immediately after Mr. Simpson's former wife, Nicole, and her friend Ronald L. Goldman were killed on June 12, 1994.

title: States Are Arenas on Minimum Wage
description: At a time when both major political parties are trying to speak to people's fears about the economy, Democrats here and in other state capitals across the country are using proposals to increase state minimum wages to try to reclaim their mantle as the defender of working people.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Irvin Trial Date Set
description: A trial for Dallas Cowboys receiver MICHAEL IRVIN on drug charges was set for June 24, but State District Judge MANNY ALVAREZ took no action yesterday on several media organizations' requests to lift a gag order, ordering the lawyers to reach their own agreement in a week.

title: Philip B. Kurland, 74, Scholar Who Ruled on Nixon Tapes
description: Philip B. Kurland, a constitutional scholar who concluded from a lengthy transcript of White House tape recordings in May 1974 that there was "substantial evidence" of perjury and obstruction of justice by President Richard M. Nixon in the Watergate affair, died on Tuesday at Bernard Mitchell Hospital in Chicago. He was 74 and lived in Chicago.

title: 6-Month Term For Immigrant Who Shot Son
description: When Konstantinos Papadopoulos emigrated from Greece to Astoria, Queens, 10 years ago, he dreamed of a better life for his family as he sold coffee and doughnuts from a pushcart.

title: Officials Had Improp Use of Vehicles
description: Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers has been using a four-wheel-drive vehicle that had been paid for with Federal drug forfeiture funds and was supposed to be used exclusively for law-enforcement purposes, city officials acknowledged yesterday, though they faulted the Police Department for the error.

title: Company at Fulton Market Under Federal Investigation
description: The company that won a prized city contract last year to unload supplies at the Fulton Fish Market is being investigated by Federal authorities on suspicion of altering a document to qualify as a bidder for a $12 million contract.

title: Treasures Under Ralph Ellison's Dining Table
description: When Ralph Ellison died in 1994, it was known that his papers included an ambitious novel in progress. No one knew, however, that he also left behind a half-dozen short stories, all apparently written before "Invisible Man," his best-known work. Two of the stories, "Boy on a Train" and "I Did Not Learn Their Names," will be published on Monday by The New Yorker in a double issue of the magazine devoted to the subject "Black in America."

title: COMPANY REPORTS;I.B.M. Stock Falls Despite Strong Profit
description: I.B.M. posted better-than-expected first-quarter operating earnings and raised its dividend for the first time in three years yesterday, but its stock plunged nearly 9 percent after the company's chief financial officer worried analysts and investors about its performance in the months ahead.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COMMONWEALTH EDISON TO SELL TWO PLANTS IN MIDWEST
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company agreed yesterday to sell two coal-fired power plants in the Midwest. Southern Electric International, a unit of the Southern Company of Atlanta, will pay $64.2 million for the State Line Generating Station in Hammond, Ind. Dominion Energy Inc., the independent power and natural gas unit of Dominion Resources Inc. of Richmond, Va., will pay $186.2 million for the Kincaid Generating Station in Kincaid, Ill. Under the deal, Commonwealth Edison, a unit of the Unicom Corporation of Chicago, will remain the sole purchaser of output from the plants for 15 years.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Break Out the Scotch
description: An additional 35 million bottles of Scotch whisky were sold in 1995, a trade association said today, cheering an industry that has stumbled badly over the last decade and a half. Scotch distillers sold the equivalent of 935 million bottles last year, an increase of 3.8 percent from 1994 and approaching record sales from the peak years of 1978-79. A drop in consumption in the 1980's hit the Scotch whisky industry hard. Since 1979, the industry's employment has fallen to 14,000 people from 26,000. There are slightly fewer than 100 distilleries in business, compared with 130 in the late 1970's.

title: Tokyo Stocks Fall Slightly
description: Stocks traded lower here today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 3.72 points, or two-tenths of 1 percent, at 21,812.50. On Wednesday, the Nikkei fell 51.95 points, or two-tenths of 1 percent, to close at 21,816.22.

title: Theater in Review
description: A Jazz Artist and Father Turns Out to Be a Woman 'The Slow Drag' American Place Theater

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Hearing on Sex Offender Law
description: Judge John W. Bissell of Federal District Court will hear arguments tomorrow as to whether he should extend his March 13 order barring prosecutors in the state from notifying residents if a dangerous sex offender lives nearby.

title: Jury Decides to Spare Menendezes the Death Penalty
description: A jury decided today that Erik and Lyle Menendez should not be put to death for killing their parents and that instead they should spend the rest of their lives in prison.

title: Pataki Finds Lottery Ads Too Rich for Good Taste
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today urged state lottery officials to shift the focus of their advertising campaign, by playing down the lure of great wealth and emphasizing instead the lottery's stated goal of raising money for education.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;AMR CORP. (AMR,N)
description: AMR Corp., the parent of American Airlines, reported the biggest first-quarter profit in its history yesterday, benefiting from higher ticket prices and fuller flights.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SOCCER;U.S. Coach Recovering
description: STEVE SAMPSON, coach of the United States national team, was listed in satisfactory condition yesterday after undergoing emergency surgery for acute appendicitis, according to an announcement from the United States Soccer Federation.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Thomson Plans Sale Of Credit Lyonnais Stake
description: The French military and electronics company Thomson S.A. said yesterday that it would sell its stake in the troubled bank Credit Lyonnais to the state by Dec. 20. Thomson said the price for the stake of nearly 20 percent would be set by an authority selected by the two companies.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UTILICORP WILL NOT INCREASE ITS MERGER OFFER
description: Utilicorp United Inc. said yesterday that it would not increase its offer to merge with the Kansas City Power and Light Company, despite a higher bid from Western Resources Inc. Utilicorp and Kansas City Power, both based in Kansas City, Mo., agreed in January to a $1.35 billion deal that values Kansas City Power at $26.77 a share. Western Resources, another Kansas-based utility, is offering Kansas City Power shareholders a $1.7 billion stock-for-stock transaction valued at $28 per share. Kansas City Power has said that it is reviewing the Western Resources offer. A Utilicorp spokesman, Jerry Cosley, said yesterday, "There's no need to change our agreement." But many analysts said the Western Resources offer may be too good to refuse.

title: Clinton Announce? Most Unlikely Now.
description: President Clinton may never formally announce that he is running for re-election, a top Clinton-Gore campaign official said today.

title: BASEBALL;Puckett Has Eye Surgery
description: Minnesota Twins outfielder Kirby Puckett has undergone the first of what may be a series of operations to stave off the effects of glaucoma.

title: Bulling Ahead
description: It was not pretty and the team's stars lacked their usual luster, but the Chicago Bulls' ragged victory over the Milwaukee Bucks Tuesday night gave them their 70th regular-season victory, the most ever won by a National Basketball Association team. This has been a phenomenal year for a team that some say might just be the best of all time.

title: Plans Approved for New Central Park Children's Zoo
description: The Art Commission unanimously approved plans yesterday for a new children's zoo in Central Park, providing the final regulatory go-ahead for the $6 million project. But the long battle between the city and preservationists wanting to save the old zoo's fanciful structures may not be over.

title: Sports of The Times;Beard Is the Fall Guy for a Failing Franchise
description: BACK home in Washington, the coach's youngest child deals with the cruelty of the standings and the insensitivity of his classmates. The standings say that the New Jersey Nets are a bad professional basketball team. The classmates call his father a lousy coach.

title: Senate Accord Revives Whitewater Committee
description: Senate Republicans reached a compromise with their Democratic counterparts today to extend the life of the special Whitewater committee, an outcome that means the Republican-dominated panel will continue public hearings into mid-June on the Arkansas business dealings of Bill and Hillary Clinton.

title: Leroy Doggett, 54, Expert in Astronomy
description: Dr. Leroy Elsworth Doggett, an astronomer who headed the nautical almanac office at the United States Naval Observatory, died on Tuesday at George Washington University Hospital. He was 54 and lived in Washington.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Fallon McElligott Gains Ad Age Honor
description: Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis has been named the United States Agency of the Year for 1995 by the trade publication Advertising Age in its 52d annual Agency Report issue.

title: U.S. and Israel Await Answer From Syrians
description: Intensive diplomatic contacts continued today as Israel and the United States awaited a response to their cease-fire proposals from Syria, the country they believe holds the key to ending the latest flare-up in the 11-year conflict between Israel and Islamic guerrillas in southern Lebanon.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Torricelli Aide Is Reassigned
description: The press secretary for United States Representative Robert Torricelli was reassigned yesterday after a weekly newspaper suggested that the spokesman had blurred the line between the Englewood Democrat's Senate campaign and his official duties.

title: Liberties;Been There, Done That
description: When I heard that Mary Matalin was joining the Dole campaign, where she could throw poison darts and blow kisses to James Carville over at the Clinton campaign, I muttered darkly, "Not that again."

title: Oklahoma Blast Case Puts Denver on Edge
description: To the west, the sun sets over Bear Creek Lake Park, silhouetting the jagged Rocky Mountains. To the north, golfers tee off on the manicured greens of the Foothills Golf Course.

title: WITH HELP FADING, GIULIANI MAY CUT 12,000 CITY JOBS
description: With his budget proposal fraying and prospects of help from Albany fading fast, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he now planned to eliminate as many as 12,000 employees from New York City's payroll in the coming fiscal year, only weeks after proposing a more modest reduction of 2,750.

title: New Jersey Seaport Serves Region Just Fine
description: To the Editor:

title: World Bank Gets Bosnia Aid Role
description: As they embark in earnest on efforts to rebuild Bosnia, the United States and the European Union have handed over much of the job to the World Bank, an institution widely criticized for its slow-moving bureaucracy and its spotty record in similar programs.

title: Academy Head Defends Ethics Of Midshipmen
description: The superintendent of the United States Naval Academy said today that the recent series of criminal charges against midshipmen were isolated incidents and did not reflect more deep-seated problems at the academy.

title: Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin
description: President Clinton arrives in Russia today facing issues that will severely test his diplomatic mettle. Mr. Clinton's primary purpose is to join other world leaders in a weekend summit meeting on nuclear safety and security that seems primarily designed to burnish Boris Yeltsin's prestige as he campaigns for re-election as Russian President. But with the war in Chechnya still going on, the security of Russia's nuclear materials in doubt and new concerns being raised about a secretive Russian military construction project, Mr. Clinton should not be content just to flatter Mr. Yeltsin.

title: Court Stays Ruling on Suicide
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan yesterday temporarily suspended its decision striking down a state law against doctor-aided suicide, to give lawyers time to file an appeal with the United States Supreme Court.

title: Immigration Case Exposes Cultural Ignorance
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Mine in Bosnia Kills 2 NATO Peacekeepers
description: Two NATO peacekeepers were killed today and two others were wounded when their vehicle hit a land mine near here. NATO said the troops were part of a brigade that has soldiers from northern Europe. The names and nationalities of the victims were temporarily withheld.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Federal Farm Credit Banks is selling $50 million of medium-term notes due in 1999 through Nationsbanc Capital Markets. The notes are callable in one year, carry an interest rate of 6.500 percent semiannually and are priced at par.

title: Buchanan Backing Off With Curt Nod To Opponent
description: Declaring that he did not want to "injure" Senator Bob Dole, Patrick J. Buchanan said today that he still had no plans for a third-party campaign for the Presidency and would stop campaigning at least temporarily in the remaining Republican primaries.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Crude Oil Prices Settle Higher Despite Speculation on Iraq Deal
description: Crude oil prices settled higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, after plunging early in the day, as traders bet that stockpiles are so low that even a limited oil sale by Iraq would be absorbed by the world market.

title: Blue Chips Plunge, Dragged Down by I.B.M.
description: The Dow Jones industrial average plummeted 70.09 points, or 1.25 percent, yesterday to close at 5,549.93, dragged down by a plunge in I.B.M.'s stock that accounted for nearly 50 percent of the Dow's decline.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;L'Oreal's Net Profit Rose 8.3% in 1995
description: L'Oreal, the world's largest cosmetics company, said yesterday that its net income before items rose 8.3 percent in 1995, despite higher French taxes and a strong franc. Net earnings totaled 3.38 billion French francs, or $676 million, up from 3.12 billion in 1994. Pretax profit before employee profit-sharing and capital gains and losses totaled 5.88 billion francs in 1995, a 10 percent increase from the previous year.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-14

title: Rift Over Health Bill
description: Senator Bob Dole said he would try to amend a bipartisan health insurance bill to encourage medical savings accounts as an alternative to standard health insurance. The proposal, strongly backed by conservative Republicans, puts him squarely at odds with President Clinton.

title: DLB Oil and Gas Purchase
description: DLB Oil and Gas Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire most of the Amerada Hess Corporation's Oklahoma oil- and gas-producing properties for about $35 million. The purchase includes ownership in 44 fields, nine of which DLB plans to operate, and 1,196 wells. Proven reserves total about 7.22 million barrels of oil.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Hunting for Baseball's Essence at Its Extremities
description: THE HEART OF THE GAME The Education of a Minor League Ballplayer By Paul Hemphill 284 pages. Simon & Schuster. $23.

title: Arabs Pledge $100 Million to Train Bosnia Army
description: The White House said today that Arab allies had pledged about $100 million for its plan to train and arm Bosnia's military.

title: POP REVIEW;Knowing Just How Hard It Is to Be a Teen-Ager
description: No Doubt decided to spend its day off as an opening act on the British band Bush's arena tour to perform at the club Tramps on Sunday night. It was a choice emblematic of the kind of dedication and perseverance, which after eight years of performing and overcoming the suicide of its lead singer and neglect from its record company, has turned No Doubt from a little known California band mixing ska, punk and new wave to national pop darlings with a top-40 album.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Ford Earnings Fall 58 Percent, but Less Than Expectations
description: The Ford Motor Company announced today that its earnings fell 58 percent in the first quarter, but the drop was smaller than securities analysts had anticipated as the American and European car markets proved unexpectedly strong.

title: Another Prize for 'Independence Day'
description: Independence Day," by Richard Ford, has won the 1996 PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction. It was the second major award in a week for the novel, published by Alfred A. Knopf, which last week won the Pulitzer Prize in fiction.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Indictment on Gun Arsenal
description: Russell G. Fauver told the authorities that he needed the cache of arms found at his home in Evesham Township because he had a civic duty to protect the country from forces controlled by the United Nations, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Water Wells to 85,000 Are Shut in New Jersey
description: Two wells have been closed in a water system serving 85,000 people in southern New Jersey as public health officials try to solve a 15-year-old riddle involving what appears to be a high rate of cancer in children.

title: Rome Rabbi Asks Leniency for Ex-Nazi Accused of '44 Atrocity
description: Two unusual appeals for leniency for an 82-year-old former SS captain by the chief rabbi of Rome and a distinguished Italian journalist have set off an impassioned debate. The former captain, Erich Priebke, is to stand trial in May for his role in Italy's worst wartime atrocity, the killing of Italian civilians in 1944 outside Rome.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Plunges 70.09, Dragged Down by I.B.M. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 70.09 points, or 1.2 percent, to 5,549.93, dragged down by a slide of $10.25, to $105.25, in I.B.M., which reported better-than-expected earnings, but saw narrower profit margins ahead.

title: Monkey Killing Begins
description: Health officials today began killing 48 monkeys at a primate breeding center that may have been exposed to a deadly strain of the Ebola virus, a spokesman for the Texas Health Department said.

title: From Humble Sources, Earthy Elegance Springs
description: THE Bryants had lived for 50 years in this hamlet in western Alabama in a leaky shed of worn-out boards and rusty tin patched with tar paper, with no indoor plumbing. This is where they raised six children and are helping to raise three grandchildren. Mr. Bryant once tried to build the family a better house, but it collapsed when he added the roof.

title: In Lebanon Strikes, Israel Acts Defensively
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Coca-Cola's First-Quarter Net Rose 12% on 9% Revenue Gain
description: The Coca-Cola Company reported a 12 percent increase in first-quarter earnings today, but sluggish sales increases in Latin America and Africa continued to be a drag on its international profits.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Drop On Treasuries For a 2d Day
description: Prices of Treasury securities dropped for a second straight day yesterday, despite a Government report that housing starts fell 3.9 percent last month. Much like the weak manufacturing report earlier this week, it failed to ease investor concern that the economy might be poised for an inflationary rebound.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Claims From Winter Cut Allstate's Profit
description: The Allstate Corporation said yesterday that earnings fell 22 percent in the first quarter, pulled down by insurance claims filed as a result of the severe winter.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Weapons Scheme Admitted
description: Y.S. Yoon, a Norwood businessman who sold at least $1 million worth of weapons parts to the Republic of Korea in 1992 pleaded guilty in Federal court yesterday to misleading customs officials as to where the hardware came from, Federal prosecutors said.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Lawyer Denies Theft Charges
description: A Northfield lawyer, accused of faking a client's signature on a $115,000 check for settlement on an accident claim and of keeping the money, pleaded not guilty yesterday to theft and forgery charges, the Atlantic County Prosecutor's office said.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;SBC COMMUNICATIONS INC. (SBC,N)
description: SBC Communications Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter profit rose more than 17 percent, paced by a record increase in phone lines and a 48 percent increase in cellular customers.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Last G.I.'s With U.N. In Haiti Are Leaving
description: The last 82 American soldiers with the United Nations peacekeeping mission left Haiti today, military officials said.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: MARATHON;Pippig Feeling Better
description: UTA PIPPIG, who captured her third straight Boston Marathon after being slowed by diarrhea and menstrual cramps, was released from the hospital yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Calendar column in The Home Section last Thursday about self-guided tours of mansions in Fairmont Park in Philadelphia tomorrow through Sunday, sponsored by the Philadelphia Museum of Art, misstated the telephone number for information. It is (215) 684-7922.

title: Marines Convicted In DNA Dispute
description: Two marines who refused to give blood samples for a DNA registry have been found guilty of disobeying a lawful order but have been spared the stockade and bad-conduct discharges.

title: Currents;Wall Designs To Upset a Colonial Image
description: WHO would have thought Colonial wallpapers could be funky? But from the 1920's to the 50's, a leading New York decorator and writer, Nancy V. McClelland, embraced historical designs that were a far cry from the era's usual safe chintzlike florals.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: WOMEN'S BASKETBALL;Tall Honor for Rizzotti
description: The all-American JENNIFER RIZZOTTI, whose hustle and drive pushed Connecticut into the Final Four for a second straight year, was picked as outstanding women's college player under 5 feet 6 inches.

title: Immigration Case Exposes Cultural Ignorance
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctor to Get Life in Killing of Her Children
description: A doctor accused of killing two of her children in an arson fire and trying to poison her husband pleaded no contest today in exchange for a life prison sentence.

title: Stavros Niarchos, Greek Shipping Magnate And the Archrival of Onassis,Is Dead at 86
description: Stavros S. Niarchos, the shadowy Greek shipping magnate who spent much of his life battling his archrival Aristotle Onassis for supremacy on the high seas, in conspicuous consumption and at the altar, died on Monday at a hospital in Zurich. He was 86.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;From Ancient Rome to Little Bo Peep
description: Forming an ambitious project that would use broadcasting, computers, the Internet and virtual-reality technology, Atlantic Productions, a television-documentary company, is joining with Sun Microsystems and Industrial Light and Magic to develop multimedia re-creations of great civilizations of the past.

title: Mute in an English-Only World
description: When I read of the troubles in Palisades Park, N.J., over the proliferation of Korean-language signs along its main commercial strip, I unexpectedly sympathized with the frustrations, resentments and fears of the longtime residents. They clearly felt alienated and even unwelcome in a vital part of their community. The town, like seven others in New Jersey, has passed laws requiring that half of any commercial sign in a foreign language be in English.

title: Fighting Affirmative Action, He Finds His Race an Issue
description: Sometimes Ward Connerly feels alone, exposed, out there on his own. And sometimes he feels just a bit scared.

title: Clinton to Allow Arms Transfer to Pakistan
description: President Clinton has decided to proceed with the transfer to Pakistan of $368 million in military equipment that had been held up because of Pakistan's nuclear weapons program, it was disclosed today.

title: Inducing Labor In Childbirth is Challenged
