description: Challenging a long-held view, a new study concludes that doctors do not always need to induce labor when a woman's water breaks after a full-term pregnancy.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TOWER AUTOMOTIVE TO ACQUIRE A MASCOTECH UNIT
description: Tower Automotive Inc. signed a letter of intent yesterday to acquire Mascotech Inc.'s Stamping Technologies Inc. unit for about $80 million, the companies said yesterday. Mascotech expects to receive about $55 million in cash and the remainder in stock and notes. The Mascotech unit, which is based in Rochester Hills, Mich., has annual sales of about $190 million. Tower Automotive, based in Grand Rapids, Mich., makes engineered metal stampings and assemblies for light vehicle manufacturers in North America. Mascotech is an affiliate of the Masco Corporation of Taylor, Mich.

title: SOCER;MetroStars Mania: Team Opens All 76,000 Seats
description: The MetroStars are now preparing for the possibility of a huge crowd for their Major League Soccer home opener here Saturday night. With an advance sale of about 25,000 tickets, they announced today that they would open the upper deck at Giants Stadium, making all 76,000 seats available.

title: The Fine Art Of Teapots (Hold the Tea)
description: HARD as it tries to compete, tea just doesn't have the same cachet for Americans as espresso or cappuccino. Despite the efforts of a national tea council and a Federal tea tasting board (now extinct), and despite the heralded promotional visits of scions of famous tea companies, tea has never taken off here.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: MEN'S BASKETBALL;Syracuse Aid Leaves
description: WAYNE MORGAN, an assistant to JIM BOEHEIM at Syracuse for 12 years, was hired as head basketball coach at Long Beach State yesterday.

title: BASEBALL;Pulsipher Undergoes Surgery
description: Bill Pulsipher, who underwent reconstructive surgery yesterday to repair a torn medial collateral ligament in his left elbow, could begin throwing again by July if the pitcher's recovery progresses as expected. Fred Hina, the Mets' head trainer, said he spoke to Dr. James Andrews after the surgery was completed in Birmingham, Ala., and that Andrews had told him that the wrisp tendon used to strengthen the ligament was thick and pliable.

title: The Pop Life
description: A Wiser Lionel Richie

title: Crew Will Investigate Charges Of Racial Steering in Schools
description: Saying he is "exceedingly distressed" by a report that accuses school officials of racial steering, the New York City Schools Chancellor, Dr. Rudy Crew, formed a committee yesterday to investigate the charges raised in the report and recommend ways to stop any discriminatory practices.

title: City Pledges To Enhance Home Care For Elderly
description: New York City has agreed to increase home-attendant care for about 1,000 elderly and disabled people who were given personal-alarm buttons after deep reductions were made in the amount of time that home-care workers spent with them.

title: First Michigan Bank
description: The First Michigan Bank Corporation acquired the Arcadia Financial Corporation of Kalamazoo, Mich., this week in a stock swap valued at about $20 million. Arcadia Financial owns Arcadia Bank and Trust, which has offices in Kalamazoo and Portage, Mich. Arcadia Bank and Trust, with $108 million in assets, will be known as FMB-Arcadia Bank.

title: Immigration Case Exposes Cultural Ignorance;Asian Prostitution
description: To the Editor:

title: Bertelsmann Acquisition
description: Bertelsmann A.G.'s Nice Man merchandising company said today that it had bought the Brockum Group, which sells goods endorsed by rock-and-roll groups like the Rolling Stones and Pink Floyd. BMG Entertainment, the North American music unit of Bertelsmann, did not disclose the terms.

title: Dole Plan on Health Bill May Encounter Resistance
description: Senator Bob Dole, the likely Republican nominee for President, has told other senators that he will try to amend a bipartisan health insurance bill to encourage medical savings accounts, a proposal that puts him squarely at odds with President Clinton.

title: Currents;Prince Has Right Tools: His Own
description: WOULD a gardening prince use just any old tools? Prince Louis-Albert de Broglie (pronounced duh-BROY), known in France as le Prince Jardinier -- the Gardening Prince -- has designed his own line, which is now available at Bergdorf Goodman. He has festooned all with a waggish coat of arms -- a crossed spade and fork under a jaunty coronet, the whole confection topped with a rakish farmer's straw hat. His offerings include handmade brass stakes, in two sizes, with space for labels (above, left) at $25 and $45 each; an old-fashioned jute apron, $195, and a tool bag, $125.

title: Calendar: Gardening, Bidding and Listening
description: Plants and Antiques New York Botanical Garden, Southern Boulevard and 200th Street, the Bronx; (718) 817-8747.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF DATA DIMENSIONS RISE, AGAIN
description: The shares of Data Dimensions Inc. rose yesterday for a second day after the billionaire investor George Soros and his affiliates bought an 8.08 percent stake in the computer consulting company. Shares of the company, based in Bellevue, Wash., rose $5.625, to $39.25, in Nasdaq trading. The shares are up 40 percent since Monday. Data Dimensions is working on a solution to the so-called millennium crisis. Many of the world's mainframe computers are not prepared to recognize dates after Dec. 31, 1999.

title: Bridge
description: The quiet 50-year-old man who died Sunday of a heart attack as he left his Long Beach, L.I., home headed for a tournament was a familiar figure to enthusiasts, in part because he would circle playing areas in a mechanized scooter. But few knew that he served the Nassau-Suffolk Bridge Association in many ways, currently as president; that he owned 18,000 master points, more than anyone else in the New York area; that he had twice nearly won national titles, and that he had battled physical problems all his life. He had spent eight years in hospitals in which surgeons sought to correct problems with his hands and feet, and these were aggravated when he was involved in a 1988 car accident.

title: GOLF;Support From Around the World Overwhelms Norman
description: The fairway before him was green, freshly mown, crisp, almost shimmering in the sun. It was all Greg Norman could see today, that and his golf ball, first hanging against the sky and then piercing the middle of it all.

title: Economic Scene;The drive to put cost limits on regulatory benefits isn't dead yet.
description: REGULATORY reform, shorthand for the Republican push to require regulators to take account of economic costs as well as benefits in rule-making, crashed and burned in the Senate last summer. But there is a glimmer of hope that a coalition of Republicans and moderate Democrats can fashion a compromise -- reform lite, if you will -- before it is hopelessly mired in election year politicking.

title: INSIDE
description: Shipping Magnate Dies

title: THEATER REVIEW;Having Fun With Care For the Old
description: The old woman seen on stage as the audience enters the Intar Theater doesn't appear at all happy to be there. Seated rigidly in a wheelchair, she is isolated by a spotlight and wearing a festively printed dress that has nothing to do with the affronted expression on her face. Her head erect, her eyes blinking abruptly, she evokes the thwarted dignity of a falcon in a cage. She is visibly, painfully uncomfortable, and your first instinct may be to pretend she isn't there.

title: Immigration Case Exposes Cultural Ignorance;Making Asylum Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;More Job Cuts Set at Apple As Loss Exceeds Estimates
description: Burdened by its own internal turmoil and a broad slowdown in personal computer sales, Apple Computer Inc. reported a $740 million loss for the second quarter, somewhat larger than it had predicted a month ago. The company also said that it would eliminate another 1,500 jobs in the next 12 months, in addition to the 1,300 job cuts previously announced.

title: Don Clayton, 70, Driven Man Who Putted His Way to Riches
description: When Don Clayton was 28, he felt such pressure selling insurance in his hometown of Fayetteville, N.C., that his doctor feared he was on the verge of a nervous breakdown and ordered him to take a month's vacation -- but neglected to tell him not to engage in any formal relaxation.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Expansion Raptors Pull Nets Out of Doldrums for a Night
description: The Nets gave Butch Beard a reason to smile tonight -- one of the few he will probably enjoy in the last days of his tenure as the team's coach.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ALCO STANDARD TO SPLIT INTO TWO COMPANIES
description: The board of the Alco Standard Corporation approved a plan yesterday to split into two publicly traded companies: one to sell and lease office equipment and the other to distribute paper products. The company, based in Wayne, Pa., also said its second-quarter earnings rose 45 percent. Since early February, Alco has been considering a plan to split its Ikon Office Solutions unit and its Unisource paper products division. Alco shares rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $54.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Suit Over Restrictions on Encryption Software Clears Early Hurdle
description: Ruling that software code is speech that deserves First Amendment protection, a Federal judge has refused a request by the Government to dismiss a mathematician's lawsuit accusing it of wrongly blocking him from freely publishing and exporting his computer program.

title: No Headline
description: I equally dislike both sides!"

title: Voters Approved More Than Two-Thirds of School Budgets
description: For the second year in a row, more than two-thirds of New Jersey's local school budgets were approved Tuesday, suggesting that voters generally are in a mellow mood about education spending and the property taxes that help finance it.

title: Market Place;From Donna Karan this year, a second effort to go public.
description: HERE she goes again.

title: Currents;Where Words Are Precious
description: DESIGN fanatics anticipating healthy tax refunds should drop by the 36th annual New York Antiquarian Book Fair. The show -- books, celebrity autographs, rare maps and more -- opens its three-day run tomorrow at the Seventh Regiment Armory, at Park Avenue and 67th Street. Among the rarities is a 1789 copy of "The Cabinet-Maker and Upholsterer's Guide" by Alice Hepplewhite (George's widow), offered for $4,500 by the Heritage Book Shop. Its furniture designs (candle stands, below) inspired woodworkers throughout the Georgian world. Modernists can covet Howard Schickler's 1923 illustrated edition of "Pro Eto" ($5,500), a love poem by Mayakovsky with brooding, baffling photomontages by Aleksandr Rodchenko (right).

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Mexico Set to Issue New 30-Year Bonds
description: Mexico said today that it was issuing up to $2.5 billion of new bonds that it would swap for United States-backed Brady bonds in a sign that the country's status had improved in financial markets.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Southern Seeking British Power Concern
description: The Southern Company, the Atlanta-based utility holding company that entered the British electricity market last year by taking over a regional utility, said yesterday it hoped to combine that business with National Power P.L.C., one of Britain's two electricity generators. Southern said it would wait to see whether the British Government would allow combinations of power-generating companies and regional utilities that distribute power.

title: Inquiry Faults Trustees' Acts At Adelphi U.
description: The trustees of Adelphi University may have violated several state laws by financing "extraordinary personal spending" by its president, Peter Diamandopoulos, the New York State Attorney General charged yesterday in papers seeking to compel Adelphi to comply with subpoenas.

title: Metro Matters;Abuse Victim: Taking Action If She Won't
description: THE young woman is pacing back and forth, punching her fist in her hand, talking to herself. "I'm going to tell him," she mutters. "I'm going tell him this time."

title: Hanoi Journal;A Vietnamese Uprising, to Keep Out High-Rises
description: Battered by war, crumbling from poverty and neglect, this faded, tree-lined capital remains one of the last beautiful cities in Asia, a relic of French colonial elegance surrounded by the raucous new mega-cities of the region's economic boom.

title: NBC Outlines Programs For Cable News Channel
description: Tom Brokaw, Katie Couric and Bill Moyers are to be rotating hosts of a live, nightly news and talk program on MSNBC, the 24-hour news cable channel that will start in July. The program, which will also include regular NBC correspondents, is one of three nightly prime-time programs announced yesterday by Andrew Lack, president of NBC News. MSNBC is run jointly by NBC and the Microsoft Corporation.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Ex-Prosecutor in Mexico Assassinated in Tijuana
description: A former federal prosecutor was shot to death today as he jogged on a public running track in Tijuana.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AFTER REJECTING BID, CHEYENNE ASSERTS IT IS NOT FOR SALE
description: Cheyenne Software Inc. emphasized yesterday that it was not for sale, after publicly rejecting a $1 billion takeover offer from McAfee Associates Inc. on Monday. Earlier, McAfee said it would rally shareholder support to press for the merger, which would create the world's fifth largest software company. Bill Larson, McAfee's president and chief executive, would not say whether McAfee would raise its $27.50 a share offer for Cheyenne, a maker of network management software that is based in Roslyn Heights, L.I. Shares of Cheyenne rose $1.375 yesterday, to $23, on the American Stock Exchange. McAfee, of Santa Clara, Calif., is the leading seller of anti-virus software.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about proposed changes in Federal guidelines for assessing the cancer risks of chemicals misspelled the surname of a staff member at the National Academy of Sciences who commented on the changes. She is Gail Charnley, not Charmley. The article also referred incorrectly to her position at the academy. She is on loan from the academy to serve as executive director of the Commission on Risk Assessment and Risk Management, an independent organization created by Congress; she is not a member of the environmental studies and toxicology board established by the academy and the National Research Council.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: RJR Nabisco Re-elects Board and Rejects a Spinoff
description: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, besieged outside the company's annual meeting today by antitobacco protesters and inside by dissidents supporting a spinoff of its food business, announced an across-the-board victory in its proxy battle with the financier Bennett S. LeBow.

title: Medicaid Loopholes Are for Good Reason
description: To the Editor:

title: Yeltsin Promises Voters Chechen War Will End
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin, campaigning today at the site of one of the deadliest incidents of the Chechen conflict, pledged to crush "terrorism" in Chechnya with a mixture of force and negotiation.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Graf's Father Charged
description: STEFFI GRAF's father was charged yesterday with evading $13 million in taxes by failing to report as much as $28 million in his daughter's income.

title: U.S. Has Plan to Ban Land Mines, but Not Yet
description: In response to a growing sentiment in Congress and among allied nations to ban the use of land mines, the Clinton Administration is circulating a proposal that would eliminate their use by United States forces, but not until the year 2010.

title: Whispers of a Successor Echo in the IMF's Halls
description: PARIS  When Michel Camdessus opens the annual spring meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank next week in Washington, the hidden item on the agenda, and perhaps the hottest, will be  Michel Camdessus.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Police Question Mason On a Day of Distraction
description: It has been a problem-filled season for the Knicks, so in that respect, today was typical.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HAYES MICROCOMPUTER EMERGES FROM BANKRUPTCY
description: Hayes Microcomputer Products Inc. said yesterday that it had received approval from Federal Bankruptcy Court in Atlanta to emerge from Chapter 11 protection, with somewhat different financing than anticipated. The company told a bankruptcy judge on Monday that the financing initially arranged from an equity investor, the Northern Telecom Ltd. unit of BCE Inc., fell through in early April. Northern Telecom had planned to team with Acma Ltd. of Singapore to buy a 49 percent stake in Hayes for $35 million. Instead, the Atlanta-based Hayes arranged for two Hong Kong concerns -- Kaifa Holdings Ltd. and Rolling Profits Holdings Ltd., a unit of Wongs Ltd. -- to split a 16.3 percent stake for $5.8 million each. Quek Sim Pin, the Acma chairman, also agreed to acquire a 12.3 percent stake for $8.8 million, through companies he controls. Acma had already agreed to pay $17.5 million for a 24.5 percent stake.

title: Kmart Files Suit Against Real Estate Associate
description: In what it said was almost certainly the tip of an investigative iceberg, the Kmart Corporation filed a civil suit yesterday against one of its real estate associates for fraudulent business dealings.

title: F.T.C. to Fight Rite Aid-Revco Drugstore Merger
description: The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that it would seek to block the Rite Aid Corporation's planned $1.8 billion takeover of Revco D.S. Inc., holding that the merger of the nation's biggest drugstore chains would raise drug prices for consumers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;A Texas agency is being recognized nationally, but don't expect it to move to New York or Chicago.
description: ROY M. SPENCE JR., the president of GSD& M, likes to talk about fighting the "bigness disease." He sneers at what he calls the bloated bureaucrats of many advertising agencies, then reminisces about how his own shop grew up from small beginnings when it was founded by six college friends.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Coalition Fights Resort Plans
description: A citizens group filed a petition yesterday that seeks to block Atlantic City from giving away land to Steve Wynn, a Las Vegas-based developer, so that he can build a 2,000-room hotel and casino. Last month, the City Council approved a deal giving Mr. Wynn's Mirage Resorts Inc. the land in exchange for cleaning up the site, a former landfill, and employing 2,000 city residents.

title: FILM REVIEW;F for Deportment But an A for Effort
description: The Substitute" proposes a remedy for crime in inner-city high schools that only Hollywood, in a fit of exploitative zeal, could have cooked up. Why not plunk a battle-scarred soldier of fortune inside a chaotic Miami classroom and give him free rein to strong-arm unruly students into obedience?

title: NOTEBOOK;The Minimum Wage: A Portrait
description: Advocates of legislation to raise the minimum wage by 90 cents an hour over the next two years, mostly Democrats, argue that it would provide a critical lift for low-wage workers. Opponents, mostly Republicans, say that the increase would lead to a loss of jobs and that the benefits would primarily be enjoyed by teen-agers and others who do not really need the raise. Economists disagree over which position is right. Both sides offer data to bolster their position. Unless otherwise indicated, the source of the figures here is the Labor Department.

title: HOCKEY;New York Experiences an Outage on Power Play
description: The Rangers' special-team play was abysmal last night, and it cost them severely although they came back from a three-goal deficit against the Montreal Canadiens.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Directing male actors during her student days at Sarah Lawrence College was no easy task, says JANE ALEXANDER, the chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: INSIDE
description: Early Camp by Amazon

title: Columbia's Ethnic Studies Protest Isn't Over
description: To the Editor:

title: Colleges Feel Cost of Shunning Recuiters Over Gay Rights Issue
description: In a process repeated at institutions from Maine to Oregon over recent months, City College of San Francisco has had to consider the classic ethical dilemma of whether a principle is worth its price.

title: Drug Company Stocks Rise As 3 Post Higher Earnings
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation, the Warner-Lambert Company and SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. posted higher first-quarter earnings yesterday, helping to touch off a rally in drug stocks.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Mason Says Being Nice Caused His Latest Jam
description: Saying the only thing he is guilty of is "being a personable person," Anthony Mason attempted today to give his side of the story about his public misadventures, portraying himself as an everyday guy locked in the restrictive world of a professional athlete.

title: Tonight's 'Muppet' Episode Withdrawn
description: ABC has removed "Muppets Tonight!" from the show's normal 8:30 time slot tonight, because the show included a comedy skit about a bomb and today is the one-year anniversary of the Oklahoma City bombing.

title: Poll Finds Ruth's House Way Ahead of Giuliani's
description: As Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani discusses the possibility of building the New York Yankees a new stadium in Manhattan, a vast majority of New Yorkers would rather that the team stay in the Bronx, according to a poll released yesterday.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Sooner Than Expected, Germans Cut Key Rates
description: The central bank of Germany, faced with a stagnant national economy, unexpectedly cut official interest rates half a percentage point yesterday.

title: BASEBALL;Gooden's Time Is Running Out On His Ineffective Sales Pitch
description: Sometames, Dwight Gooden has sounded more like a salesman than a starting pitcher. Believe me, his rapid-fire voice seemingly pleads, this product really works. Simply give it time and you will see.

title: Abroad at Home;Slamming the Door
description: The case of 19-year-old Fauziya Kasinga, who says she fled her native Togo to avoid the rite of female genital mutilation, has aroused much sympathy. She arrived at Newark Airport in 1994, told officials she was using someone else's passport, sought asylum, was turned down and has been held in prison ever since. The Board of Immigration Appeals will hear her appeal on May 2.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Art in Review
description: Caio Fonseca Charles Cowles Gallery 420 West Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo Through April 27

title: Utah Couple Playing Out Family Saga
description: Family values" was the flag that Joseph Waldholtz tirelessly waved in 1994 to help elect his wife, Enid Greene Waldholtz, to Congress in the most expensive campaign of the season.

title: After 151 Years, Dance Ban Ends at Baylor
description: For the first time in the 151-year history of Baylor University, dancing has been allowed on campus at the Southern Baptist school.

title: Art in Review
description: Agnes Martin 'New Drawings and Watercolors' Pace Wildenstein Gallery 32 East 57th Street Through April 27

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;W. H. Smith to Sell Office Supplies Unit
description: W. H. Smith Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it would sell its office stationery unit to Guilbert S.A. for L142 million ($216 million). Guilbert, based in Senlis, France, distributes office and business machine supplies.

title: Inside Art
description: Olmec Art From Mexico

title: New Planet Seen Outside Solar System
description: Two astronomers say they have discovered another planet that is outside the solar system and orbiting a star 40 light-years from Earth.

title: Air France Loss Narrows
description: Air France disclosed this week that its loss narrowed to about $240 million, in the year that ended on March 31. (AP)

title: Senate Defeats Dole Revision To Health Bill
description: The Senate cleared the way tonight for passage of legislation that would make health insurance more accessible, narrowly defeating an amendment by Senator Bob Dole that opponents charged would have killed the bill.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Airbus to Step Up Its Delivery Schedule
description: The European plane-making consortium Airbus Industrie said yesterday that it was increasing its delivery schedule to meet demand. It said it would deliver 135 planes in 1996 and a record 185 in 1997. Last year it made 124 deliveries.

title: Deregulation Of Phones: The Hard Part
description: Nobody ever said deregulation would be simple, especially when it comes to knocking down barriers to competition in the communications industry.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Ex-Lawmaker to Face Judge
description: A former Congressman who was forced to resign more than two decades ago after being convicted of income tax evasion is scheduled to be sentenced in Federal court today on more recent fraud charges.

title: Group Goes To Networks About Air Time
description: A nonpartisan organization that is seeking free network television air time for Presidential candidates carried its fight today to the networks' corporate parents.

title: Corrections
description: A letter to the editor in The Living Section on Wednesday from Richard A. Friedman, director of the Psychopharmacology Clinic at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, about the toxic effects of herbal products like ephedra, omitted part of his title. He is an M.D.

title: Connie Mack Jr. Son of Athletics Owner, 83
description: Connie Mack Jr., the father of the Senator from Florida and a son of the Hall of Fame baseball manager, both named Connie Mack, died of cancer of the esophagus on Wednesday. He was 83.

title: Art in Review
description: Jonathan Lasker Sperone-Westwater Gallery 142 Greene Street, SoHo Through April 27

title: Campaign Finance Restrictions Don't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Has $16 Million on Hand for Campaign, Report Says
description: President Clinton has more than $16 million in cash on hand to spend on his re-election campaign between now and the Democratic convention in August, according to reports filed today with the Federal Election Commission.

title: DESIGN REVIEW;When a Car Is More Than a Car
description: The Museum of Modern Art has acquired a gorgeous new object for its design collection. The museum has also passed up a golden opportunity to enrich the vocabulary for the discussion of design. The new addition is the Jaguar E-type roadster, the legendarily sexy car known in the United States as the XK-E. Too bad the show organized to celebrate this acquisition fails to address the cultural forces that propelled this glorious hunk of metal into legend.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Subdued Realm Of Cowboy Junkies
description: I've been told the Cowboy Junkies don't have any happy songs," Margo Timmins complained genially during the band's set at the Beacon Theater on Tuesday night. Actually, the set included one or two. But most of the concert, and most of the Cowboy Junkies' repertory, lives up to titles like "Lonely Sinking Feeling" and "A Common Disaster."

title: FILM REVIEW;A New Level of Devotion From a Pair of Celtics Fans
description: There is more hysterical screaming in "Celtic Pride" than you will find in a dozen horror movies, but not an ax murderer in sight. The screamers in this stridently unfunny comedy about sports obsession are Boston Celtic fans whose rabid devotion to the basketball team amounts to a self-destructive addiction.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Early Dynastic China' J. J. Lally & Company 41 East 57th Street Through April 26

title: F.T.C. Approves Lockheed-Loral Merger
description: The Federal Trade Commission approved the $9.1 billion merger today of the Lockheed Martin Corporation and the Loral Corporation, a move that will create a military behemoth.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: * Lonny Strum was named chief executive of Rosanio, Bailets & Talamo, Cherry Hill, N.J., succeeding Linda Rosanio, who continues as chairwoman and president. Mr. Strum had been president of Earle Palmer Brown, Philadelphia. * Len Fogge was named to the new post of executive vice president for creative/marketing services at the Showtime Networks unit of Viacom Inc., New York. He had been president at Franklin Spier Inc., New York. * Donna-Ann Hayden was named to the new post of president at Arnold Public Relations, Boston, a division of Arnold Communications. She had been senior vice president for consumer marketing at Bozell Public Relations, Boston, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt. * Judy Carpenito was named to the new post of senior vice president and managing director of the New York office of the Martin Agency, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos. She had been executive vice president and managing director of Saatchi & Saatchi Direct, San Francisco, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C.

title: In a Corruption Inquiry, Giuliani Suspends 42 Elevator Inspectors
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani suspended nearly three-quarters of New York City's elevator inspectors yesterday, in what Federal investigators described as a broad investigation into a bribery conspiracy.

title: Woman Denies Romance With Unabomber Suspect
description: Unwillingly thrust into the Unabom case, an exasperated Ellen Tarmichael came forward today to say that she was never romantically involved with Theodore J. Kaczynski, her subordinate at a foam factory in a suburb of Chicago nearly 20 years ago.

title: Grant Gets Job Offer, as Cuomo and Others Back His Right to Offend
description: Radio listeners of assorted political stripes, including former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, came to the defense of Bob Grant's right to speak his mind yesterday, the day after Mr. Grant's popular afternoon program on WABC-AM was canceled.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It won't be the biggest role she's ever played, but when KATHY NAJIMY steps into the spotlight at the Bottom Line tonight, she will say with fervor, "Here's Betty!"

title: Researchers Link Income Disparity to Higher Rates of Death
description: Poor people have long been known to have more medical problems than affluent people of the same age, but a new study suggests that greater inequality in the distribution of income contributes to higher overall mortality rates and deaths from heart disease, cancer and homicide.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Traditional Art From Tanzania' Sonnabend Gallery 420 West Broadway, near Spring Street, SoHo Through April 27

title: FILM REVIEW;Dumb Meets Dumber: Italy's Own Jim Carrey
description: If it's true, as the saying goes, that all men are little boys, then comic superstars like Jim Carrey and his Italian counterpart Roberto Benigni embody the puerile id skidding gleefully into box-office history. The two actors may have wildly divergent styles, but both deliver a similar message with the same maniacal glint in their eyes: to be a hellion in perpetuity is the ultimate men's liberation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;H & R Block Taps Young & Rubicam
description: H & R Block said yesterday that it had named the Chicago office of Young & Rubicam Inc. to its corporate advertising account, which was handled for 12 years by Bernstein-Rein in Kansas City, Mo. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;TIMES MIRROR CO. (TMC,N)
description: The Times Mirror Company reported yesterday that first-quarter earnings from its continuing operations rose 84 percent, as it trimmed expenses at its newspapers, although its net income plunged more than 98 percent.

title: Britain, Facing Setback in Court, Won't Deport Saudi Dissident
description: Facing an embarrassing reversal by the courts, the British Government today dropped its efforts to deport a leading Saudi dissident whose activities here angered the Saudi royal family and raised fears that lucrative British military sales could be lost.

title: GUNMEN IN EGYPT KILL 18 IN ATTACK AT TOURIST HOTEL
description: Gunmen with automatic rifles and pistols opened fire early today on Greek tourists outside their hotel, killing 18 people and wounding at least 17 others in the most violent attack on foreigners since tourists became targets here in 1992.

title: New Mitsubishi U.S Plant
description: The Mitsubishi Materials Corporation of Japan will build a $130 million plant in Mobile, Ala., to make polysilicon, a material used to manufacture computer chips. Mitsubishi, a leading maker of metals and ceramics, said that the plant would supply primarily the United States market. The factory is expected to be completed in October 1997 and will eventually employ 150 workers.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Sister, A Brother And Mother
description: THREE decades and several lifetimes separate the flawless young Catherine Deneuve of "The Umbrellas of Cherbourg" from the more real and sorrowful woman she plays in Andre Techine's "Ma Saison Preferee." And as she is thrown startlingly off-balance, photographed in unkind natural light and forced to confront the troubling emotions of Mr. Techine's story, this habitually reserved actress shows her spontaneity, giving a performance of touching complexity and candor. She seems reborn. So does Mr. Techine, the onetime film critic whose more formal earlier work (the 1976 "Barocco," the 1986 "Scene of the Crime") now gives way to an intimate, less composed style. Made in 1993, just before his equally acute "Wild Reeds," "Ma Saison Preferee" ("My Favorite Season") finds the director probing believable troubles with honesty, intelligence and tact.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Hotel and Casino Going Up
description: Ground will be broken today for two projects: a new 500-room hotel in a blighted area at the entrance to Atlantic City, and a Bally's Park Place casino built around a Western theme. The $87 million Doubletree Convention Center Headquarters Hotel is a joint venture between the Casino Reinvestment and Development Authority and private developers. Bally Entertainment said it expected to open its new $100 million Western casino, entertainment complex and shopping area by the summer of 1997.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Teacher Quits After Arrest
description: A Lodi High School math teacher resigned yesterday after he was arrested for abusing his position by photographing the nude torsos of male students, the authorities said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Microsoft Profit Rises 42%, Topping Analysts' Forecasts Microsoft reported a 42 percent earnings rise to $562 million, beating analyst estimates and belying reports of a slump in the personal computer industry.

title: Marshall Goes Home To Retire as a Giant
description: Leonard Marshall was a crucial member of the Giants' 1986 and 1990 Super Bowl teams, and after one season with the Jets and another with the Washington Redskins, he returned home yesterday.

title: ART REVIEW;As an Alternative, but an Alternative to What?
description: Bronx Spaces" at the Bronx Museum of the Arts gathers under one roof -- in spirit, if not exactly in fact -- four of the borough's hard-working nonprofit alternative art spaces: the Bronx River Art Center and Gallery, En Foco, Lehman College Art Gallery and Longwood Arts Project.

title: Spoiled Juice Suspected in School Illness
description: Sixty-one pupils at an Upper West Side elementary school became ill early yesterday afternoon, and the authorities think spoiled pineapple juice might have been the reason.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Triumph for Renee Fleming in 'Armida'
description: Rossini's "Armida," first performed in Naples in 1817, is inexplicably neglected. The daunting title role demands a charismatic and tireless soprano. Eve Queler and her Opera Orchestra of New York had such a soprano for their concert performance at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night: Renee Fleming, who scored a triumph in the role.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ACME-CLEVELAND TO ALLOW DANAHER TO BID WITH OTHERS
description: The Acme-Cleveland Corporation, which rejected an unsolicited $186 million takeover bid by the Danaher Corporation last month, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement that would allow Danaher to participate in a friendly bidding process with other potential suitors. Acme-Cleveland, which makes electronics and telecommunications products, agreed to supply certain nonpublic information about the company to Danaher. Acme-Cleveland said other potential buyers, which it would not name, had received such information and had interviewed managers and visited company operations. Acme-Cleveland will also postpone a shareholder meeting scheduled for Thursday, at which the company had planned to discuss the bid from Danaher, which is based in Washington. Acme-Cleveland is based in Cleveland.

title: New Zealand Bank Is Target of Takeover
description: The Westpac Banking Corporation of Australia has made a takeover bid of $1.27 billion (New Zealand), or $868 million (United States), for Trust Bank New Zealand Ltd. If the bid is successful, it will create New Zealand's largest banking company.

title: BOXING;3 Friends Qualify for U.S. Boxing Team
description: They followed one another into the ring tonight, friends for years in Philadelphia gyms, all carrying the same fistic dream, all determined to make it to the Olympics. One after the other, in unprecedented fashion, they did.

title: Yankees and New York Near Accord on Team's Back Fees
description: As the Yankees consider a proposal to build a $1 billion stadium on the West Side of Manhattan, the team is close to settling its longstanding dispute with the city over how much it owes in back rent and cable television fees.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;U.S. Bonds Still Plagued By Inflation
description: Treasury prices ended lower for a third consecutive session yesterday, retreating from early gains, as inflation worries revived following a stronger-than-expected regional manufacturing survey.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Japanese Make Key Arrest in Debt Crisis
description: Japanese authorities arrested a property magnate today in an apparent move to begin pinning responsibility for the nation's debt crisis.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Dead Whale Found in River
description: A dead whale found floating in the Delaware River yesterday was towed by tugboat to a United States Army base for an autopsy, officials said.

title: SPORTS BUSINESS;Nets' Owners Are Facing a $96 Million Question
description: Will the New Jersey Nets' seven owners sell out? Maybe. Maybe today. Maybe next week. Maybe when Yinka Dare knocks down a triple double.

title: FILM REVIEW;Vanya, This Time In Wales
description: Directed and scored by Anthony Hopkins, "August" transposes "Uncle Vanya" to a pastoral Welsh setting, a leafy estate where its Victorian characters grapple with the same spiritual crises that fuel Chekhov's play.

title: The Spoken Word
description: "ALLIES AND ENEMIES: THE DILEMMA OF ASIAN-AMERICANS DURING WORLD WAR II," Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, Manhattan. A day of discussions and film screenings, with film makers, scholars and critics. Tomorrow, noon to 6 P.M. Sponsored by the Museum of Chinese in the Americas, 70 Mulberry Street, Chinatown. Contribution: $10; $7 for museum members; $5 for students and the elderly. Information: (212) 517-2741.

title: Anyone Can Become a Star in Astoria
description: I MOVE a track ball across a computer screen, clicking on "Jurassic Park," and a video monitor fills with rampaging dinosaurs hunting humans cowering in a kitchen. But it's eerily silent at points. It's up to me to add the sound effects. A ladle drops, and I insert a frightening clang. But what sound for a rapacious raptor? I choose a kitten's "meow." Changed the scene, that did.

title: A New Jersey Report Shows an Increase in Birth Defects
description: The number of reported birth defects rose statewide in New Jersey from about 24 per thousand in 1985 to 35 per thousand in 1993, which state public health officials attributed largely to an increase in improved reporting from the state's hospitals.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Generale des Eaux Posts First-Ever Loss
description: Compagnie Generale des Eaux S.A. said yesterday that it had posted a net loss of 3.7 billion francs ($730 million) as charges on real estate and construction outweighed gains from asset sales. The loss, the first in the 142-year history of France's biggest water-supply and construction company, compares with a profit of 3.3 billion francs of 1994. Operating profit dropped to 1.7 billion francs, from 3.7 billion francs in 1994.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BURLINGTON NORTHERN TO BUY A RAILROAD IN WASHINGTON
description: The Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the Washington Central Railroad Company, which operates two stretches of track in Washington state, for about $40 million in stock and cash. One of the lines connects the 234 miles of track between Kennewick and Cle Elum, and an 85-mile segment connects Connell to Moses Lake. In a second deal, Burlington Northern, which is based in Fort Worth, said it would buy 150 new locomotives from the General Electric Company for about $200 million. Burlington Northern will use the engines to replace less efficient ones. Burlington Northern stock rose $2, to $84.50, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Art in Review
description: Mark Morrisroe Pat Hearn Gallery 530 West 22d Street, Chelsea Through April 28

title: DEATH IN LEBANON: ISRAEL;Voicing Regret, Israeli Leader Offers a Cease-Fire
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres expressed regret today over the deaths of at least 75 Lebanese civilians in an Israeli artillery strike and said Israel was prepared to accept an immediate cease-fire if its Islamic guerrilla opponents did too.

title: Serb Village Sees Only the Flowers
description: Spring is trying to poke its way into the high mountain valleys here. Its slowly warming air brings the small flowers and young grass now growing through the remains of human bodies stretching in a line up a hill.

title: Tickets and Tows in Parking Crackdown
description: Announcing a new commitment to control double-parking and ease traffic in midtown and lower Manhattan, the New York City Police Department completed a two-day ticket-writing blitz yesterday during which officers handed out several thousand more parking summonses than usual.

title: Compuserve and Planet Hollywood Price Their Public Offerings
description: Compuserve Inc. and Planet Hollywood International Inc. priced their initial public offerings late yesterday, becoming the latest companies to enter the sizzling market for new stocks.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers Face 0-2 Mountain They've Never Scaled
description: When they took the ice at Madison Square Garden last night, the Rangers appeared from within a plume of artificial smoke. On the scoreboard above, their best moments of the season were mirrored on a large video screen.

title: No Headline
description: I never thought I would see a massacre like this. It's bad enough when it takes place in a Lebanese village, but to see it in a United Nations camp is truly a tragedy."

title: A YEAR OF SORROW -- A special report.;Blast Toll Is No Longer in Deaths, but in Shattered Lives
description: The shark-nosed 1968 Plymouth Road Runner is alive again. Rick Tomlin, a middle-aged civil servant, had been working in his spare time to help his son restore it, but that project was cut short when a truck bomb tore through the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building, killing Mr. Tomlin and 167 others one year ago.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Caterpillar Toys Deal
description: Caterpillar Inc. said today that it had reached a deal for Mattel Inc. to produce a line of Caterpillar toys, ranging from simple miniatures to remote-controlled models and others big enough for children to ride. Mattel will produce at least 20 toys.

title: Kevorkian Is Excused From Attending Trial
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian's latest assisted suicide trial took an unexpected turn today when the retired pathologist suddenly asked the judge to allow him to leave the courtroom and not attend his own trial.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Friday with an article about the beliefs of a militant anti-government group that calls itself the Freemen referred incorrectly to the views about the group expressed by a minister, the Rev. Helen Young. Ms. Young, who has visited members of the group at the ranch they are occupying near Jordan, Mont., disagrees with the group's racist and anti-Semitic beliefs, but did not use the term "disgusting" in referring to them.

title: Boat People Embark on Sad Voyage Home
description: Sullen and defeated, 317 Vietnamese boat people shuffled down a gangplank into the hold of a Malaysian Navy landing craft this morning, the first to be sent back home by ship as refugee camps in Southeast Asia begin to close down for good.

title: Bronx Fire at Rush Hour Halts a Metro-North Line
description: A brush fire in the Bronx forced the Metro-North Commuter Railroad to shut down service on the busy New Haven line for nearly three hours last night, stranding 40,000 commuters at the height of rush hour. Service on the Harlem line was also disrupted.

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows:

title: Disney Rejects Time Shares In Times Square Hotel Rooms
description: Despite a flurry of theater renovation projects and store openings around Times Square, one of the more offbeat ideas for 42d Street -- time-share condominiums to be operated by the Disney Company -- has been shelved.

title: Elusive Salinas Turns Up in New York
description: He was supposed to be in Cuba, or Canada, or Costa Rica, or a resort on Paradise Island, or a walled compound in central Mexico.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Jersey City's Grim AIDS Toll
description: A grim distinction for Jersey City: It is now second only to Washington in numbers of AIDS cases per 100,000 population, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. Jersey City's rate in 1995 was 138.1 cases, down from 148.7 in 1994. Most of the cases resulted from drug abuse, Irene Hunt, the city's AIDS coordinator, said yesterday.

title: F. Lee Bailey Strikes Deal In Effort to Get Out of Jail
description: If F. Lee Bailey is to get out of jail any time soon, he must convince a Federal district judge that he can be trusted. Toward that goal, Mr. Bailey, the famed defense lawyer, offered today to get court approval before spending more than $10,000 for any purpose.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pearson Shares Rise On Report of Job Cuts
description: The shares of Pearson P.L.C. rose yesterday after its newspaper, The Financial Times, said it planned to cut 51 jobs as part of an "efficiency and rationalization" plan. The newspaper's cuts include 9 percent of the 265-member editorial and writing staff and six members of its photography department. Another 21 positions will go in other departments and through the closing of advertising offices in Bristol and Birmingham. Bloomberg Business News

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;Bodies Doubled: The Art of Being Horst P. Horst
description: In 1946, the photographer Horst P. Horst took a picture of Gertrude Stein and himself. In the picture, one of his hands is resting, proprietarily, on the chair where Stein is sitting with her hands in her lap and with her fuzzy white poodle, Basket, at her feet. On the wall behind them is a portrait of Basket by Marie Laurencin. And in front of them, almost out of the frame, is the drawing hand of Carl Erickson, the artist who developed Vogue's illustration style in the 1930's, only to be outmoded by fashion photographers like Horst.

title: North Korea Says It's Weighing a Proposal for 4-Party Peace Talks
description: North Korea said today that it was considering President Clinton's proposal for four-party peace talks, lending hope that it may be possible to begin a dialogue to reduce the threat of war on the Korean Peninsula.

title: Japanese Stocks Decline
description: Stocks were trading lower here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues stood at 21,774.92, down 37.58 points, or 0.17 percent. On Thursday, the index fell 3.72 points.

title: School Board Hopefuls and Parents Clash at Forum
description: Despite corruption allegations against him, Carmelo Saez Jr. made a campaign stop last night at a high school auditorium in the South Bronx, but "Meet the Candidates Night" in Community School District 9 quickly erupted into a chaotic shouting match between the candidates and the voters.

title: Interlopers And the Men Who Love Them
description: Formerly a barrel of fun in her "Hairspray" days, Ricki Lake tries morphing into an earnest romantic heroine for "Mrs. Winterbourne." Looking variously compassionate, perplexed, alarmed or smitten, she shows off four more emotional shadings than this story actually demands.

title: Norman Shoots Solid Round
description: Just days after his Masters cave-in, Greg Norman pulled his psyche and his golf game together to land in contention yesterday in the MCI Heritage Classic.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;From Zaire to Ann Arbor to the N.F.L.
description: Tshimanga Biakabutuka was on his way out of Zaire. Out of Africa. It was 1980, he was 6, and his family was about to be terribly fragmented. He, four siblings and his parents were moving to Montreal where his father would capitalize on a scholarship to earn a Ph.D. in psychology. Three other siblings, sadly, would have to be left behind with relatives. His family's sparse dollars could take only a few so far.

title: Therapist Recruiters Aren't Visa Police
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Dreadful Performance Leaves Knicks With No Answers
description: In the past, there would be a grand answer for what happened tonight at Gund Arena. Someone would point a finger, or storm out of the locker room stone-faced, blame the coach, the offense, the All-Star, anything.

title: District Attorney Sues Pataki Over Ouster From Case
description: Accusing Gov. George E. Pataki of improperly trying to force his pro-death-penalty views on the state's prosecutors, District Attorney Robert T. Johnson of the Bronx went to court yesterday to sue the Governor for removing him from a case involving the murder of a police officer.

title: News Analysis;New Limits on Prisoner Appeals: Major Shift of Power From U.S. to States
description: Once President Clinton signs the legislation approved today by the House restricting appeals by death-row inmates and other prisoners, he will be imposing the most vigorous constraints on the constitutional right to seek Federal review of convictions since Lincoln suspended the writ of habeas corpus in the Civil War.

title: Iran-to-Bosnia Arms Transfer Is Old News
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;GAS CONTRACT RULING HELPS TESORO AND 2 OTHERS
description: The Texas Supreme Court yesterday reversed a decision issued in August 1995 that would have limited the amount of natural gas that the Tennessee Gas Pipeline Company was required to buy from the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation and two other suppliers under a 1979 contract. The reversal is significant to Tesoro and the two other producers -- KCS Energy Inc., based in Edison, N.J., and the Coastal Corporation, based in Houston -- because it means that Tennessee Gas, a unit of Tenneco Inc., must buy gas from the three companies under terms of the 1979 contract, which sets prices much higher than current ones. Tesoro's stock jumped $1.125, to $10.75; KCS was up $4.25, to $21.875, and Coastal was up 12.5 cents, to $39. Tenneco said it would ask the court to rehear the case.

title: Group Asserts U.S. Workers Are Better Off Than Thought
description: Injecting its voice into the debate over economic insecurity, a lobbying group representing the nation's manufacturers issued an analysis today that it said rebutted "the conventional wisdom that wage stagnation and job loss represent reality for American workers."

title: Gay Student Clubs In Utah Face a Ban
description: The Utah Legislature voted today to ban clubs for gay students in high schools.

title: William J. Flanagan, 76, Head Of New Jersey Turnpike Agency
description: William J. Flanagan, the longest-serving executive director of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority, died on Wednesday at his home here. He was 76.

title: Ex-Rep. Tucker Draws Prison For Extortion
description: Continuing to maintain that he had been set up by Government prosecutors bent on imprisoning black officeholders, former Representative Walter R. Tucker 3d was sentenced on Wednesday to 27 months in prison for extortion and income tax fraud.

title: Columbia's Ethnic Studies Protest Isn't Over
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Show and Auction
description: An exhibition of photographs to be sold at a benefit silent auction will go on view tomorrow at noon at the Kent Gallery, 67 Prince Street, in SoHo. Among the more than 90 photographers represented are Eve Arnold, Henri Cartier-Bresson, Larry Burrows, Annie Leibovitz and Mary Ellen Mark. The photographs will be auctioned at a gala on Thursday at 6:30 P.M. at the Madison, 29 East 32d Street, Manhattan. Tickets to the gala, with food and dancing, are $45 a person. Proceeds benefit the Domestic Abuse Awareness Project, a New York City organization founded in 1991. The photographs are on view tomorrow through Tuesday, noon to 8 P.M. Information: (212) 353-1755.

title: A Rivalry Between East and West Grows In New Media
description: The new-media business may be a fledgling industry, but it has already generated a big-time fight for bragging rights that pits New York against the West Coast.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Bridges of Madison County 1995. Warner. $103.91. Laser disk, $39.98. 135 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Treasury Chief Seeks World Bank Funds
description: Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin appealed to Congress today for funds for the World Bank and other international financial institutions, saying United States participation in the lending agencies was at a crossroads.

title: New York to Pay $40,000 to Inmate In Brutality Case
description: A Federal magistrate has awarded $40,000 to a prison inmate who complained of brutality by guards at the Clinton Correctional Facility in Dannemora, N.Y.

title: Mazda Raises Some Prices
description: Mazda Motor of America has raised the suggested retail price of its 1996 models an average of $248. The increases are for cars shipped to dealers beginning this month, the company said. The increases affect virtually the entire line of sedans, convertibles, vans, trucks and sport utility vehicles, but not the base Millenia and Miata M Edition models.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Rise in Profit At McDonnell Shows Strength
description: With impressive performances by all three of its operating segments, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation turned in strong first-quarter results yesterday, leading some Wall Street analysts to expect higher earnings for 1996 and beyond.

title: FILM REVIEW;Flyboys and Farm Girls on a War's Edge
description: In the gorgeous opening scene of "For the Moment," two carefree young aviators hoot and holler as they glide their World War II aircraft over lush Canadian farmland in the province of Manitoba. It is early summer of 1942, and Lachlan (Russell Crowe), a young Australian adventurer, and his Canadian pal Johnny (Peter Outerbridge) are deliriously frisking in the sky to the ethereal strains on the soundtrack of Pachelbel's Kanon.

title: Provision in Terrorism Bill Cuts Rights of Illegal Aliens
description: A little-noticed provision in the counterterrorism bill approved by Congress would drastically reduce the rights and protections of aliens with claims to remain in the United States, civil rights advocates said today.

title: William T. French, 83, Head Of Merchandising Companies
description: William T. French, a marketing executive who was chairman of two major merchandising companies, died on Wednesday at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital Center in New York. He was 83 and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: On My Mind;Relaying Warning To Libya
description: Deep inside a mountain, Libya is building the world's largest underground poison gas plant. Short of a bombing raid, which the United States is preparing for if it comes to that, the Clinton Administration is doing everything it can to deliver a message to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi: Stop while you have the chance.

title: Reporter's Notebook;Clinton Takes Glad Hand to the Land of the Bow
description: To underscore their friendship during this week's summit meeting, President Clinton has been calling his Japanese counterpart Ryu.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Last U.N. Troops Leave, Ending Rwanda Mission
description: The last United Nations peacekeepers in Rwanda left today, ending a mission that was widely criticized for failing to prevent bloodshed.

title: Anniversary Is Bittersweet
description: Daina Bradley Bruce lost her mother, son, daughter and a leg in the Oklahoma City bombing. But one year later, as others mark the deaths, she celebrates life -- that of her newborn son.

title: Political Memo;Giuliani and Garth Are Back on Speaking Terms
description: The breezes around City Hall are suddenly warm, the political pollen count is causing itchy throats, and two former allies have ended a yearlong winter's chill to refashion a partnership with important implications for the 1997 mayoral race.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Cleanup Planned in Camden
description: The Mayor of New Jersey's poorest city announced a plan yesterday to clean up more than a dozen contaminated sites in the hope of attracting developers to Camden. Mayor Arnold Webster said the city will use $1.3 million in state grants to target 14 sites that are currently unusable because of ground contamination from hazardous waste, The Associated Press reported.

title: Geography of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: COLLEGES;Husker Rebuff For Phillips's Assault Victim
description: Kate McEwen, the woman assaulted by the former University of Nebraska running back Lawrence Phillips last September, has been informed that the university does not plan to renew her basketball scholarship for another season.

title: Maker of an AIDS Vaccine Says Test Found No Benefit
description: The end came today for a highly touted AIDS vaccine in a carefully worded announcement by the small company that produced it saying a study of the vaccine "did not demonstrate statistically significant clinical benefit."

title: THEATER REVIEW;Nathan Lane In Sondheim's Roman Romp
description: FOR whatever reasons, the time seems ripe for a smart, cheeky, buoyant revival of "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum," and the spiffy new Jerry Zaks production, which opened last night at the St. James Theater, is it.

title: NYC;At Sotheby's, A Yard Sale Like No Other
description: IF this were pro football, they would be talking about getting pumped up for the big one. Instead, it is the more rarefied, if no less commercial, world of auction houses, where they note in reserved fashion that the excitement is palpable. It amounts, however, to the same thing.

title: Exit Bob Grant
description: Bob Grant, the radio talk-show host, was booted off WABC-AM this week, apparently for telling his listeners that he hoped Commerce Secretary Ronald Brown had been killed in the crash of his plane in Croatia. "My hunch," Mr. Grant said, "is that he is one of the survivors . . . maybe it's because at heart, I'm a pessimist."

title: Diner's Journal
description: New Seasonal Dishes

title: COMPANY REPORTS;American Express Earnings Rise Despite Charge Card Unit Loss
description: The American Express Company reported yesterday that first-quarter earnings rose 12 percent, led by its travel services and financial units, even though loan losses in its credit and charge card business surged.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Why the Allied Victory Was Not a Sure Thing
description: WHY THE ALLIES WON By Richard Overy Illustrated. 396 pages. W. W. Norton. $29.95.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: COMPANY NEWS;FORMER S.E.C. CHAIRMAN TO HEAD BENNETT FUNDING
description: Richard C. Breeden, a former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was appointed yesterday to take over the financially troubled Bennett Funding Group, which stands accused of swindling investors out of millions of dollars. Mr. Breeden was appointed S.E.C. chairman by President George Bush; he served from 1989 until 1993. The Securities and Exchange Commission has accused Bennett Funding, based in Syracuse, and its subsidiaries of selling earlier this decade $570 million of fraudulent securities to investors in what it says might be the largest pyramid scheme in history. Bennett Funding has filed for bankruptcy protection.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * Liberty Bank, Middletown, Conn., to Decker Advertising, Glastonbury, Conn., to handle its account, previously at Marquardt & Roche, Stamford, Conn. Billings were estimated at more that $1 million. * House Beautiful magazine, New York, a publication of Hearst Corp., to Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners, New York, to handle its account, which had been inactive. Billings have not been determined. * Claridge Casino Hotel, Atlantic City, a unit of the Claridge Hotel and Casino Corp., to Rapp Collins Worldwide, New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group, to handle advertising, direct marketing, promotion and event marketing, which had been handled in-house or assigned out on a project basis. Billings were not disclosed, but Advertising Age estimated them at $4 million. * Palace Brands Co., Hartford, part of the Heublein unit of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., to Hamon & Stern Advertising, Los Angeles, as the first agency to handle advertising for the wine brand Varietals by Baron Philippe de Rothschild S.A. Billings were not disclosed.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MAKER OF ALUMINUM SIGNS CHARGED IN PRICE-FIXING CASE
description: The Justice Department yesterday charged Wrisco Industries, an aluminum company, and its president, Agostino James Monastra, with conspiring to raise and fix prices on aluminum signs. Another company, Alliance Metals Inc. of West Chester, Pa., and its president, Bradley B. Evans, previously pleaded guilty in the case. Prosecutors would not say how much Wrisco and Monastra are accused of making off what they say was a scheme that started in January 1995 and lasted until July 1995, when the F.B.I. searched Wrisco and Alliance offices. The telephone was not answered late yesterday at Wrisco's offices or at Mr. Monastra's home.

title: DEATH IN LEBANON: LEBANON;ISRAELI BARRAGE HITS U.N. CAMP IN LEBANON, KILLING AT LEAST 75
description: The Israeli Army fired an artillery barrage into a United Nations peacekeeping camp today, killing at least 75 Lebanese civilians and wounding more than 100. The attack, which Israel said came in response to rocket and mortar fire by guerrillas near the base, was by far the deadliest yet in the eight-day-old offensive in southern Lebanon.

title: Arnold Neustadter Dies at 85; Orderly Mind Behind Rolodex
description: Arnold Neustadter, whose invention of the Rolodex card file helped so many millions of people organize their professional and private lives that it became a lasting symbol of the art of networking, died on Wednesday at New York University Hospital in Manhattan. He was 85 and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: HOCKEY;Canadiens Make Studies Pay Off
description: Mario Tremblay, the rookie coach of the Montreal Canadiens, knew just what to do when his rookie-crammed squad began to panic after a feverish Ranger charge tied last night's score at 3-3 deep in the final period. He called a timeout and gave an instant pep talk.

title: FOOTBALL;Nebraska's Berringer Killed in Plane Crash
description: Brook Berringer, the Nebraska quarterback who overcame two collapsed lungs to become an essential part of the 1994 Cornhusker championship season, was killed yesterday afternoon in the crash of a private plane in an alfalfa field in Raymond, Neb. He was 22.

title: Jets Obtain Help For Defensive Line
description: After acquiring seven offensive players in the off season, the Jets made their first deal for a defender yesterday when they signed lineman Mike Chalenski of the Eagles.

title: Natural' Doesn't Mean Safe
description: In banning the sale of the herbal stimulant ephedra, which has been linked to 15 deaths nationwide, Nassau County this week not only took on the multimillion-dollar dietary supplement industry but also issued a challenge to Congress.

title: For Children
description: 'From Nudnik to Nightingale' 'A Tribute to Rembrandt Films and Gene Deitch' Museum of Modern Art 11 West 53d Street (212) 708-9400 Recommended ages: 6 and up Tonight through Sunday

title: Delilah' Clips and Tells About Unabom Suspect
description: A canning jar on a windowsill in Dundee Warden's one-chair barbershop holds an unusual souvenir: tangled hair clippings, dark brown and shot through with gray, that she clipped from the shaggy head of Theodore J. Kaczynski, the Unabom suspect.

title: In an Amazon Cave, Light Is Shed on Early Americans
description: Digging in a cave near the Amazon River in Brazil, archeologists have found stone weapons, rock paintings and other traces of what may have been one of the earliest human cultures in the Americas. The discovery could revise thinking -- and stir more controversy -- about the lives and migrations of the first Americans.

title: Sports of The Times;How Many Chances Left For Gooden?
description: HE is living on borrowed time already, what with the fast cars and the guns and the beer and the illegal substances in his recent past. Maybe Dwight Gooden has finally learned to take it one day at a time, which is the only way it works for the seriously addicted.

title: The Clack of the Tracks, With Free Verse
description: To the Editor:

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;A Subversive's Luminous Hybrids
description: An exhibition now at Ubu Gallery introduces to this country the rarely seen photographic work of Stefan Themerson (1910-1988), a Polish artist who produced some of the most important avant-garde films of the 1930's, usually in collaboration with his wife, Franciszka (1907-1988). Both Themersons seem to have defied classification. Her interests included painting, drawing, book illustration and book design. Starting with his early success as a writer of children's books, his talents included several forms of writing, as well as collage, photography and film.

title: Rival Gangs of Workers Brawl Over Jobs
description: Members of two labor organizations representing members of minority groups clashed yesterday morning at a Chelsea intersection, the latest battle in a tug-of-war for jobs at construction sites.

title: About Real Estate;Residents Getting Action At an Embattled Building
description: Apartment life has not always been easy at the Chatsworth. On and off for the last three decades, the rent-stabilized building on the West Side of Manhattan has been the scene of major landlord-tenant battles, pushing it into financial and physical decline and since the late 1980's into the hands of a court-appointed receiver.

title: 25 and Under
description: Up From Takeout

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Now and Then 1995. New Line. $102.65. Laser disk, $39.99. 102 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ATLAS VAN LINES PARENT TO BUY ANOTHER MOVER, RED BALL
description: Atlas World Group Inc., the parent company of Atlas Van Lines, will buy a competing mover, the Red Ball Corporation, for an undisclosed amount, the companies announced yesterday. Red Ball will continue to operate separately, under its own name. Its chief executive, Walter E. Saubert, will continue in that role but will join the board of Atlas, which is based in Evansville, Ind. Atlas, which is privately held, reported revenue of $316 million last year. Red Ball reported revenue of $80 million.

title: Market Place;Nynex may need a quick conclusion to a merger deal more than Bell Atlantic does.
description: BELL ATLANTIC and Nynex are both eager to resolve their merger talks, which have gone on longer than a Manhattan telephone directory. But for reasons both tactical and strategic, Nynex may have more incentive to seal the deal quickly, according to people familiar with the negotiations.

title: DEATH IN LEBANON;The Peacekeepers With No Peace to Keep
description: Scattered across the rolling, rocky hills of southern Lebanon is a network of 169 checkpoints and observation posts and some two dozen bases -- like the one that was shelled by Israeli troops yesterday -- manned by soldiers from nine countries wearing the distinctive blue berets of United Nations peacekeepers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CENTURA BANKS INC., Rocky Mount, N.C., has agreed to acquire First South Bank, Burlington, N.C., in a stock swap valued at about $36.6 million.

title: Public Is Protected, Officials Say
description: Every elevator in New York City must undergo five safety inspections every two years: three by city inspectors, two by private inspectors certified by the city.

title: Rail Link Proposed From Penn Station to Kennedy Airport
description: The Port Authority, which has tried for decades to build a direct connection between Manhattan and Kennedy International Airport, is proposing a new $1 billion plan for a rail link between Pennsylvania Station and the airport.

title: BASEBALL;Strike Zone Is Elusive For Mets' Pitchers
description: Don Baylor, whose Colorado Rockies reached the playoffs last year as a 3-year-old, was talking about the heightened expectations that resulted from the team's surprisingly early success.

title: Art in Review
description: Gregory Green Max Protetch Gallery 560 Broadway, at Prince Street SoHo Through April 27

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Executives Form Consulting Company
description: Four longtime industry executives are forming a consulting company named the Advertising Partnership, with offices in New York and London, that will use interactive technology to help agencies and advertisers improve their relationships.

title: Offer to Hemophiliacs With H.I.V. Is Set
description: Four producers of blood-clotting products that are said to have infected thousands of hemophiliacs in the United States with the virus that causes AIDS said yesterday that they planned to offer $600 million to affected individuals and their families in a bid to resolve litigation against the companies.

title: Youthful Pawns With Dreams Of Royalty;Chess's Popularity Booms In New York Public Schools With Regular Lessons
description: On Tuesday morning, in Maureen Coleman's third-grade classroom at Public School 19 in the Bronx, 25 or so 8-year-olds stood up to take an oath. They were enthusiastic about what they perceived to be a ritual, though it seems fair to say they didn't know what they were about to swear to.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHINA-U.S. FRICTION SEEN HURTING BOEING'S BUSINESS
description: The troubled relations between China and the United States are threatening the Boeing Company's business in China, Ronald B. Woodard, president of the company's Commercial Airplane Group, said in Beijing yesterday. Relations between Washington and Beijing, which have been strained by disputes over trade, copyright issues and human rights, influenced China's recent decision to order 33 jetliners from Airbus Industrie instead of Boeing, Mr. Woodard said at a conference of business leaders. "The relations between our two countries made a Boeing decision impractical," Mr. Woodard said. He said that Boeing, which in the past has had a majority of China's aviation market, supported a renewal of Beijing's most-favored-nation status, which provides for ordinary trading rights with the United States.

title: Restaurants
description: Did you notice the woman with the cigarette?

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;A Rainbow Coalition of sorts can be found in a wider range of campaigns than ever before.
description: MARKETERS who have long painted portraits of consumers in shades of white are adding colors to their palettes as campaigns increasingly present multiracial, multi-ethnic images -- and even interracial couples.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;National Power Rejects Talks With Southern
description: National Power P.L.C., Britain's largest utility, has rejected meeting with the Southern Company to discuss a merger, saying National Power was not for sale and questioning whether the United States company could offer a fair price. The rebuff came in a letter from John Baker, the British company's chairman, to the head of Southern's international unit, Tom Boren. Southern announced on Wednesday that it might bid for National Power.

title: In America;G.O.P. Hit Men
description: You couldn't make these guys up -- the exterminator, the undertaker and the big-game hunter who are leading the charge by House Republicans to trample the nation's environmental laws.

title: Ethanol's Contributions Pay Off
description: Ethanol, long oversold as a source of cheap, clean energy, has been the beneficiary of generous subsidies provided by politicians whose favor has been bought at bargain prices by Archer Daniels Midland, ethanol's leading American manufacturer. Ethanol has been an excellent investment for the company, but a rotten investment for the taxpayers.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Media column in Business Day on Monday, about a court ruling that denied overtime payments to certain writers and producers at NBC News, misstated the number of employees affected by the ruling in some copies. It was the 3 employees who brought the lawsuit, not 149.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BRISTOL-MYERS IN ANOTHER BIOTECHNOLOGY INVESTMENT
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that it planned to make a $10 million investment in the Somatix Therapy Corporation, a biotechnology company, bringing its total investment in the company to $20 million. In exchange, Bristol-Myers, the pharmaceutical concern, has first rights to collaborate with Somatix on any cancer products it develops. Somatix, which is based in Alameda, Calif., is developing gene-therapy products to treat cancer and Parkinson's disease. Bristol-Myers, which is based in New York, made an initial investment of $10 million in Somatix last August. Somatix's stock fell 50 cents yesterday, to close at $7.625 a share on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Stripped of Themes, Yeltsin Wraps Himself in Flag
description: In his embattled bid for re-election, President Boris N. Yeltsin has raised the red flag. Literally.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a dispute over an Internet survey by Nielsen Media Research misattributed an estimate that there were fewer than 10 million Internet users in the United States and Canada. The estimate came from a number of similar surveys conducted by Internet companies and market research companies, not from Professor Donna L. Hoffman of Vanderbilt University. In an analysis in December challenging Nielsen's numbers, Professor Hoffman said that based on preliminary data, which she confirmed last week, the Nielsen numbers were overstated "perhaps by millions."

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Microsoft's Net Rises 42%, Belying Idea of a PC Slump
description: Belying reports of a slump in the personal computer industry, the Microsoft Corporation reported today a 42 percent rise in earnings for its fiscal third quarter, beating the consensus of analysts' earnings estimates by a few cents.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICA WEST TO LINK SERVICE WITH FLIGHTS FROM BRITAIN
description: British Airways P.L.C. has formed an alliance with the regional airline America West Airlines Inc. that will connect America West's network of United States routes with the British carrier's trans-Atlantic flights to Phoenix. British Airways is starting daily nonstop service from Gatwick Airport near London to Phoenix, where America West is based, on July 1. The airlines intend to share flight codes, a marketing technique that will combine the networks of British Airways and America West in reservation systems. Code-sharing allows passengers to travel on flights of separate airlines with one ticket.

title: Home Video
description: Very long movies that come on two cassettes have been anathema in video stores. "Customers always say, 'Oh, no,' when they see it's a double," said Rich Thorward, a video dealer in Glen Rock, N.J.

title: Diet Alone May Not Provide Enough Vitamin C
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on April 11, about the supply problems of generic drug makers, misstated the home country of Galena, a drug manufacturer recently acquired by the Ivax Corporation. Galena is based in the Czech Republic, not Hungary.

title: China Cautions U.S. and Japan on Security Pact
description: For the first time since the end of the cold war, the Chinese Government expressed public concern today that the United States-Japan security alliance that served to contain the former Soviet Union might now shift its focus toward China.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Fallon McElligott's New York Office
description: Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis said yesterday that it would expand to New York by forming a creative team to be based there headed by two creative group directors.

title: Friends and Relatives Mourn 14-Year-Old Victim of Knifing
description: Naomi Lugo was "one of the most optimistic kids" at Susan Wagner High School in Staten Island, one of her classmates said. She sang in the school chorus, spent many of her free hours with a church youth group and frequently helped other students with their class work.

title: Scientist's Estranged Wife Is Charged In His Killing
description: The estranged wife of a Russian scientist was charged yesterday with helping her cousin hack him to death in the victim's apartment, where the authorities said the killers waited in the dark, wearing rubber gloves and armed with axes and a knife.

title: Lucille Bremer, 79, Actress and Dancer
description: Lucille Bremer, an actress and dancer who was Fred Astaire's partner in "Yolanda and the Thief" and "Ziegfe'd Follies" during her brief film career in the 1940's, died on Tuesday at Scripps Memorial Hospital in La Jolla, Calif. She was 79 and lived in

title: Fire Stalls Commuters On Metro-North Line
description: More than 40,000 Metro-North commuters were delayed last night when a brush fire in the Bronx caused the railway to shut off service on the New Haven line. The problem also caused major delays on the Harlem line.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Separatist In Italy May Play Kingmaker
