description: Umberto Bossi, the irascible leader of Italy's separatist-minded Northern League, has few kinds words to say about other Italian politicians: They are either Mafiosi or cretins, thieves or colonialists, a list of invectives that sum up his feelings about the Government in Rome.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;DEAN WITTER, DISCOVER & CO. (DWD,N)
description: Dean Witter, Discover & Company said yesterday that first-quarter earnings rose 10.7 percent, bolstered by strong results in its credit services and securities operations. The financial services company posted net income of $245.8 million, or $1.41 a share, compared with $222.1 million, or $1.28 a share, in the 1995 quarter. Analysts had expected earnings of $1.38 a share in the latest quarter, according to First Call.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about John C. Malone's leadership of Tele-Communications Inc. misstated the performance of the company's stock price in the last two years. It declined 9 percent; it did not increase 24 percent. As noted elsewhere in the article, the overall value of a stake in the company would have increased 24 percent in the last two years because such a valuation would include shares of Liberty Media, which were given to Tele-Communications shareholders when Liberty Media was spun off last August.

title: Stephen Wright, 85; Led in Education for Blacks
description: Dr. Stephen J. Wright, a former president of Fisk University who spent his life broadening educational opportunities for black America, died on Tuesday at Johns Hopkins Medical Center in Baltimore. He was 85 and a resident of Hampton, Va.

title: A Deadly Day in Lebanon
description: Israel's campaign of military retaliation in Lebanon moved to a new plane of violence yesterday with the accidental shelling of a United Nations base in Lebanon that killed at least 75 Lebanese civilians and wounded more than 100 others. All had fled to the compound in recent days seeking shelter from Israeli attacks against Hezbollah targets in Lebanon.

title: A Season of Opening Days;Companies Make New Issues a Big Event on Wall St.
description: Down on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, a lot of high-priced talent is just standing around in the frenzy. Henry B. Schacht, the chairman of Lucent Technologies, is part of the crowd, and so are Richard A. Grasso, the exchange chairman, and President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro of Italy, who is at the exchange to give a speech. Messengers push through the gawkers to deliver buy or sell orders to Michael La Branche, the specialist at Post 7-N.

title: Profit Data Help Lift Stock Prices
description: Stock prices rose narrowly yesterday, while the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index set a high for the 12th time this year.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Waiting to Exhale 1995. Fox. $19.98. Laser disk, $39.98. 121 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ROCHE TO GAIN ACCESS TO GENETIC RESEARCH DATA BASES
description: Incyte Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that it would provide access to its genetic research data bases to the Swiss drug company Roche Holding. Roche will have access to Incyte data bases dealing with D.N.A. sequencing, gene expression, gene mapping, cloning technology and other subjects. Such data assist in the identification of so-called disease genes and in the search for new therapies. Specific terms were not disclosed, but Incyte, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., will receive annual subscription fees, royalties on sales of products that are developed with the help of the technology, and other payments. Incyte stock was up $2, or 8 percent, at $27.25 a share, on Nasdaq.

title: Jobless Claims Rise by 10,000
description: The number of new claims for jobless benefits rose by 10,000 last week -- the first increase in three weeks.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;NORTHWEST AIRLINES CORP. (NWAC,NNM)
description: The Northwest Airlines Corporation said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings soared as it attracted more passengers and charged higher fares.

title: An Admission Of Corruption Probably Isn't Chicago's Last
description: Politicians love parades in this town, except for the one that was staged again today from a Federal courtroom high above the city: the parade from politics to disgrace.

title: Elyse Should Pack It In
description: Elyse Meredith, a spunky 14-year-old from New Jersey, has lost her fight to prove that teen-agers have a constitutional right to wear backpacks in school. A state judge has decreed that even though officials at Annin Middle School in Bernards Township seem to have gotten a little carried away in their anti-backpack crusade, they still have the right to make the rules.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;NBC Gains Help G.E. Profit, Up 11% for Quarter
description: The General Electric Company reported yesterday that first-quarter earnings rose 11 percent, fueled for the fifth consecutive quarter by strong profit increases at its NBC television and plastics units.

title: FILM REVIEW;Of Goofy Mad Scientists And Aliens in Bad Wigs
description: Couch-potato comedy can't get any lazier than "Mystery Science Theater 3000: The Movie," but that counts for most of this film's slender charm. All that's here is "This Island Earth," a nicely lame 1954 science-fiction film featuring aliens with bad wigs and big foreheads, along with running commentary from one man and a couple of robots watching the show. "O.K., let's see, Shatner, Shatner . . . no, it doesn't look like he's in this one," says a voice over the opening credits. "We're safe."

title: On Stage, and Off
description: More Pain From That Broken Foot

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Cable and Wireless Posts One-Time Charge
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C. said yesterday that it would post a one-time expense of L120 million, or about $181.2 million, primarily related to its operations in Central and Eastern Europe. The British telecommunications operator said the expense would not have any impact on the company's cash position. The company said the charge would be more than offset by a one-time earnings gain from the sale for L199 million of the company's stake in Mannesmann Mobilfunk, a German cellular-telephone network operator.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Brooklyn Enclave Feverish With Love and the Lottery
description: Lotto Land," John Rubino's ode to a Brooklyn neighborhood, is a movie whose fondness for its characters makes up for some of its failures, but not enough for this no-budget film to hold together as more than a shaky exercise in good will. Shot in only 19 days in a working-class neighborhood at the fringe of Park Slope, the movie is a shambling pop-blues suite, in which a group of songs by the Holmes Brothers, a New York blues trio, is crudely woven through the film's two interlocking love stories.

title: The Trillion-Dollar Solution
description: Now that the flat tax has faded, at least momentarily, from the center stage of politics, free-market ideologues have geared up for another crusade. This time their banners say, "Privatize Social Security!"

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;U.S. Official Dismissed; Opposed All Land Mines
description: In a speech today at Georgetown University, Defense Secretary William J. Perry said the United States military relies on thousands of land mines to defend against attack from North Korea. That means it will be years before the United States abolishes them, he added. In the meantime, the Pentagon plans to use land mines that are designed to self-destruct after a certain period.

title: DEATH IN LEBANON: REACTION;In the Face Of Horror, Diplomacy Stays Muted
description: The Israeli attack on a United Nations camp in southern Lebanon has created a quandary for both the United States and its Arab allies: how to react strongly enough to an action with unintended consequences that killed at least 75 Lebanese civilians, but not too strongly to hurt Prime Minister Shimon Peres in Israel's upcoming election.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Peugeot Citroen Says Profits Fell 45%
description: The French car maker PSA Peugeot Citroen said yesterday that its profits slumped 45 percent last year as it fell victim to currency shifts, sluggish car sales in Europe and stiff price competition. It said net income fell to 1.7 billion French francs ($332 million) for 1995 from 3.1 billion the previous year. The figure was slightly worse than forecast.

title: Peres and Arafat, After Talks, Agree to Revive Peace Efforts
description: Under the shadow of the fighting in Lebanon, Prime Minister Shimon Peres and the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat agreed today to revive their peace efforts, which had been suspended after a spate of suicide bombings in Israel by Palestinian militants.

title: Campaign Finance Restrictions Don't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: TV WEEKEND;Amish Twist Changes A Standard Mystery
description: Harvest of Fire," a Hallmark Hall of Fame presentation on CBS on Sunday night, starts out like a standard mystery. Fires are destroying barns in an Amish community in Iowa. An F.B.I. agent, Sally Russell, is sent to catch the arsonist.

title: Mortgage Rates Fall
description: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.95 percent this week, down from 8.05 percent last week, according to a national survey issued today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.75 percent, down from 5.8 percent last week. Fifteen-year mortgages averaged 7.48 percent this week, down from 7.56 percent a week earlier.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Fighting Ebbs in Liberia But Cholera Is Spreading
description: International mediators urged Liberia's warring factions today to accept a truce. The appeal came during a lull in 12 days of factional fighting that have cleared Monrovia's streets of all but swaggering combatants and people scavenging for food.

title: GYMNASTICS;Separate Missions for 2 Americans
description: For Dominique Dawes, the road to success in Atlanta may begin here at the world gymnastics championships. For Chris LaMorte, the road ends here. But even though Dawes and LaMorte will not be Olympic teammates this summer, they are both wearing red, white and blue in San Juan, and in today's first session, both Americans qualified for Friday's eight-gymnast finals.

title: Expect Gas Prices To Keep Going Up
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Panel Backs Over-Counter Sale of 2 Nicotine Patches
description: Smokers should be able to buy two nicotine patches without a prescription to help them quit, a committee of scientific advisers told the Food and Drug Administration today.

title: Many Already Use Medical Savings Accounts
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Board and the Amex Report Rises in Uncovered Short Sales
description: Open positions of short sales reached a record level for the third consecutive month on the New York Stock Exchange in the latest period. On the American Stock Exchange, short interest was at its highest level since its record high in October 1994.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Arnold Neustadter, the inventor of the Rolodex, misstated the residence of a surviving brother, Morton. He lives in West Palm Beach, Fla., not New York.

title: U.S. Ruling May Speed Drug Dealers' Evictions
description: A Federal judge made it far easier for authorities to evict drug dealers from New York City public housing projects, saying that drug-related crime poses a more urgent threat to tenants now than when the eviction procedures were established in 1971.

title: COMPANY NEWS;QUESTOR PARTNERS MAKES $34 MILLION BID FOR ANACOMP
description: Questor Partners Fund has offered to pay as much as $34 million for a 44 percent stake in Anacomp Inc., which is scheduled to emerge from bankruptcy protection next month. Questor, a private partnership, has issued a tender offer of $7.75 a share for up to 4.4 million of Anacomp's when-issued shares. Anacomp, a manufacturer of microfilm and microfiche based in Carmel, Ind., reached an agreement with its major creditors earlier this year and is expected to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection in May. Questor, based in Southfield, Mich., focuses on acquiring and turning around troubled companies.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about Federal approval of a combination of two drugs, clarithromycin and omeprazole, for treating ulcers over a 28-day period misstated the time during which a patient would take two 20-milligram capsules of omeprazole daily. It is the first 14 days of the 28, not the first 24.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Giants' Scouts Keep Eye On Rice for No. 5 Pick
description: Ask just about anyone in football whom the Giants will draft with their No. 5 pick, and he will say Illinois defensive end Simeon Rice. Ask people in the Giants organization and they will say Simeon Rice. Ask Simeon Rice himself and, well, you get the picture.

title: Tiff Over Intellectual Property;Should Columbia Own Fruit of Economist's Labor?
description: Did Columbia University convince Geoffrey H. Moore, a world-renowned pioneer in business cycle forecasting, to sign over the rights to his life's work, then callously evict him from his office? Or did the university walk the last mile with Dr. Moore, an 82-year-old economist, absorbing his deficits for a decade and arranging for a wealthy alumnus to underwrite his money-losing research center before cutting off his paycheck?

title: Archer-Daniels Settlement May Be Low, a Judge Says
description: A Federal judge cast doubt today on the proposed $45 million settlement of a class-action lawsuit accusing the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company and its competitors of price-fixing, saying the company's $25 million share may be too low.

title: Journal;Stealth Attack On the Y
description: No one can say that the 92d Street Y, New York's foremost retailer of all things Jewish-American, isn't polite. Almost to a fault. On Tuesday night the Y played host to a man who is trying to take the bread out of its mouth -- Ralph Reed, executive director of the Christian Coalition, the religious-right organization campaigning to kill the National Endowment for the Arts, which helps underwrite the Y's classical music and literary reading programs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Smaller Stocks Rise, As Dow Average Falls 16.26 Smaller issues took the leadership role in a mixed stock market. The Nasdaq composite index rose 2.40 points, to 1,138.70, establishing its third new record of the week. And the American Stock Exchange market value index climbed 2.80 points, to 585.88, marking its fourth consecutive record and its 18th high this year.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MEREDITH AND NEW HERITAGE SELLING CABLE SYSTEMS
description: A joint venture of the Meredith Corporation and New Heritage Associates agreed to sell its interest in several suburban Minneapolis-St. Paul cable systems to Continental Cablevision Inc. for $125 million in cash, Meredith said yesterday. The joint venture, called Meredith/New Heritage Partnership, owns a majority interest, while Continental owns a minority stake in the systems, which are valued at $262.5 million. Meredith, based in Des Moines, is a diversified media concern with magazines including Better Homes and Gardens and The Ladies' Home Journal. In addition to the cash, Continental will also assume about $90 million of the debt of the Meredith/New Heritage venture.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hong Kong Banker Dies After Losses in Bonds
description: The Yasuda Trust and Banking Corporation's managing director in Hong Kong fell to his death this week, shortly before the bank reported losses in bond trades totaling 37 million yen (about $370,000). Masayoshi Kashiwagi, acting director of Yasuda Trust Asia Pacific Ltd. died on Tuesday, said Masashi Doi, a general manager in Yasuda's head office in Tokyo. Mr. Doi would not confirm news reports that Mr. Kashiwagi had committed suicide at his high-rise home in Hong Kong. "Hong Kong police are still investigating why he died," he said.

title: Thrill of the Hunt Is Key to an Auction of Old Masters
description: LONDON  There is a hidden hunter in every art lover and the best opportunities for those dying to buy a gem that no one else paid attention to are still to be found in lightweight auctions halfway through the season.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;The Shostakovich 4th: Like Him, a Survivor
description: If Faulkner was right, then endurance has a nobility all its own. Survivors -- Dmitri Shostakovich, for one -- gain an aura just for showing up, for staying alive and in place even when history discourages them from doing so. Shostakovich paid a terrible price for survival: terror and abject capitulation before Stalinist politics, stealth in order to safeguard private values, a willingness to cower publicly when the Politburo so ordained.

title: Cost of Holding Bosnian Vote Is Estimated at $153 Million
description: An international team in charge of conducting elections in Bosnia by mid-September said today that the electoral process would cost $153 million beyond the $1.2 billion in foreign aid already pledged toward reconstruction and other civilian needs.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: NUCLEAR INSECURITY -- A special report.;Russia Struggles in Long Race To Prevent an Atomic Theft
description: When scientists from the Kurchatov Institute go to work at Building 116, getting in the door is no simple matter.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TALKS WITH TSINGTAO BREWERY OF CHINA SUSPENDED
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies, the world's biggest brewer, and the Tsingtao Brewery Company of China have suspended two-year-old talks about Anheuser-Busch's increasing its 5 percent equity stake in the Chinese company. The companies confirmed that talks broke down after the maker of Budweiser and Bud Light opened a joint venture producing Budweiser beer last May at the Zhongde brewery in Wuhan, China. Anheuser-Busch and Tsingtao were negotiating a $230 million joint venture to produce 200,000 tons of Tsingtao beer a year, raising the company's output by almost a third. Tsingtao's general manager, Shao Ruiqi, said his company was not happy with Anheuser-Busch's financing proposals and would turn instead to Chinese Government support.

title: Oklahoma City, a Year Later
description: The mangled building has been demolished and the rubble removed. Two suspects await trial, and the world has moved on. But yesterday the people of Oklahoma City paused to remember the bombing that changed their city and their lives a year ago, and the rest of America could not help but wonder at their pain and their courage.

title: Unabom Suspect Loses Motion That No Charges Be Brought
description: A Federal district judge today denied defense lawyers' motion that no charges be considered against the Unabom suspect Theodore J. Kaczynski.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LANDRY'S SEAFOOD TO BUY BAYPORT RESTAURANT GROUP
description: Landry's Seafood Restaurants Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Bayport Restaurant Group Inc. for $45 million in stock and the assumption of about $20 million of Bayport's debt. Bayport, based in Hollywood, Fla., operates 17 Crab House restaurants. Seven additional restaurants are scheduled to open in 1996. Landry's Seafood, based in Houston, operates 48 seafood restaurants. In 1995, Landry's reported sales of $104 million. Also, Landry's said it planned to offer an additional four million shares for sale to the public. The company said it would use the proceeds for restaurant expansion and repayment of debt. Landry's currently has about 18.25 million shares outstanding.

title: Lucille Bremer, 79, Actress and Dancer
description: Lucille Bremer, an actress and dancer who was Fred Astaire's partner in "Yolanda and the Thief" and "Ziegfeld Follies" during her brief film career in the 1940's, died on Tuesday at Scripps Memorial Hospital in La Jolla, Calif. She was 79 and lived in La Jolla and in Las Cruces, Baja California, Mexico.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Mexico Brighter, But the Cheering Isn't by Leaders
description: The Mexican stock exchange hit record highs four days this week, interest rates dropped to their lowest point in seven months, and the once-wobbly peso traded at its strongest level since January.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Prices of Wheat Increase Again As Wet Ground Delays Planting
description: Wheat prices jumped again yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as wet soil conditions in the northern Plains states delayed plantings of the spring wheat crop.

title: Bridge
description: Four decades ago a race horse named Silky Sullivan had a reputation for falling behind in the early going and then surging to victory in the later stages. There is now a Silky Sullivan bridge team, consisting of John Boyer, Ellyn Plato, Bob Factor, Eric Mach, Al Lewis and Bruce Gardner, all of Manhattan.

title: Contractors Are Implicated In Bribe Case
description: It was wrongdoing by employees of private elevator inspection and repair companies, not by city inspectors, that prompted the investigation that led this week to the suspension of nearly three-quarters of the inspectors, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about recently discovered short stories by Ralph Ellison misidentified the journal that intended to publish the story "Hymie's Bull" in the 1930's, but went out of business before it could. It was New Challenge, not the Negro Quarterly.

title: Love: A Furry, Long-Tailed Thing;Dispensing With Stereotypes by Keeping Rats as Pets
description: Raquel Cintron learned the hard way that it does not pay to tell the men she goes out with that she has rats in her apartment. She did that once, and it ruined the romance.

title: In Performance;POP
description: Restless, and Making Fun Of Just About Everything Bad Religion Roseland

title: Here's a Stadium Plan That Will Work
description: Faced with shrinking revenues and cuts in services, New York City has to find ways to grow. Done a little differently, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's proposal to build a ball park over the Long Island Rail Road yards in the West 30's offers this chance -- without dislocating residents or businesses.

title: Dole, Citing 'Crisis' in the Courts, Attacks Appointments by Clinton
description: Senator Bob Dole said today that President Clinton's judicial appointments had caused a "crisis" in the courts and in a move eagerly sought by conservatives, he promised to expel the American Bar Association from the judicial screening process.

title: In Performance;JAZZ
description: How a Drummer Turns a Night Into One Connected Suite Max Roach Quartet Iridium

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Team Seeks Money for Coach
description: Coachless but undaunted, the Princeton University women's rugby team finished up a 24-hour "run-a-thon" last night. The event was held to raise money to hire a new coach. The team's volunteer coach left the university after it won the national women's collegiate rugby championship last year. More than 50 players took place in the fund-raiser, said Ashley Kline, a senior who is one of the team members sharing coaching duties to prepare the team for the 1996 national championship games next month.

title: A Revamp of 1556 Edict : France Reforms Auction System
description: PARIS  Within two years, the Paris auction market will have changed beyond recognition.A government official announced last fall that France was, in effect, ready to drop the century-old rule that reserves the right to hold auctions on French territory as the exclusive monopoly of judiciary officers called commissaires-priseurs.

title: Jury Urges Death for Slaying of 2 Students
description: A Superior Court jury recommended the death penalty today for a 20-year-old gang member who shot and killed two college students from Japan during a carjacking two years ago.

title: Brook Berringer, 22, Substitute Who Helped Nebraska to a Title
description: Brook Berringer, the Nebraska quarterback who overcame two collapsed lungs to become an essential part of the 1994 Cornhusker championship season, was killed Thursday afternoon in the crash of a private plane in an alfalfa field in Raymond, Neb. He was 22.

title: Health Legislation: Gradualism Wins the Day, for Now, but DoubtsPersist
description: As a relatively modest piece of health insurance legislation moves through Congress, it seems to be producing an unexpected turnabout among people who lived through the agonizing debate over the same issue in the first two years of the Clinton Administration.

title: Appeals Court Backs Dismissal of Smoking Suit
description: A judge was correct to dismiss a lawsuit by the family of a heavy smoker who died of throat cancer because it was filed too late and the risks of smoking are widely known, an appeals court ruled.

title: U.S.-China Talks: A Big Agenda, Little Progress
description: A much anticipated meeting between senior Chinese and United States officials to discuss disputes over the spread of nuclear weapons, trade, Taiwan, human rights and the piracy of American software and music produced little today except atmospherics and promises to continue to discuss differences.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Blast Anniversary Marked
description: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg and Charles Marciante, president of the New Jersey A.F.L.-C.I.O., are to meet this morning with local union leaders to mark the first anniversary of the Napp chemical plant explosion. They plan to call for more stringent worker-safety regulations, especially those requiring manufacturers to notify local and Federal officials about any dangerous chemicals being stored on site.

title: Westinghouse Says It Weighs Separate Broadcasting Stock
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that it was weighing the idea of separate stocks for its broadcasting and industrial operations.

title: World News Briefs;Not Selected as Lamas, Boys Get Other Rewards
description: Two boys who were not named by China to serve as a Buddhist leader have received other high positions, an official report said today.

title: York Journal;God Works in Mysterious Plays, Doesn't She?
description: The cast members of the traditional York Mystery Plays were warming up in a freezing rehearsal room here when God, standing in front of Pontius Pilate and the Virgin Mary, began to giggle conspiratorially during the shoulder exercises.

title: COMPANY NEWS;KIMBERLY CLARK TO SELL ALL MIDWEST EXPRESS SHARES
description: The Kimberly Clark Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its remaining shares in Midwest Express Airlines Inc. Kimberly Clark, the airline's largest shareholder, divested itself of 80 percent of its shares in the Milwaukee-based Midwest in 1995. It will sell its nearly 1.3 million remaining shares in a public offering. The company has been selling off Midwest stock to focus on its core business, a spokeswoman, Wendi Strong, said. Kimberly Clark, which bought Scott Paper in a $6.8 billion purchase last year, has since focused on integrating Scott's operations into its own.

title: Charles Shannon, An Art Instructor And Painter, 81
description: Charles Shannon, a painter and teacher who discovered the artist Bill Traylor, died on April 5 at his home in Montgomery, Ala. He was 81.

title: In Oklahoma City, Silence For Each of the Victims
description: The sun shone in a cloudless sky this morning, just as it did a year ago today, when more than 1,000 people were at work or play or running an errand at the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building, never expecting the massive truck bomb that ended 168 lives and changed other lives forever.

title: World News Briefs;French Troops Support Central African Republic
description: French soldiers took control of major installations in Bangui today, joining troops loyal to the Government in trying to crush an army revolt. The mutiny, over back pay, began Thursday and grew to include about 400 soldiers, who commandeered private vehicles and clashed with loyalist troops.

title: Group Tries to Halt Selling of Racist Novel
description: A human rights group that monitors right-wing fringe groups is conducting a letter-writing campaign to persuade bookstore chains and distributors to shun a race-war novel that is an underground classic among white supremacists and survivalist cults as well as the chief suspect in the Oklahoma City bombing, Timothy J. McVeigh.

title: 1996 N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;Rangers' Big Adjustment Is to Avoid Adjustments
description: The Rangers plan to make a stand by standing pat.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Ex-Union Leaders Fined
description: The Election Law Enforcement Commission issued $36,000 in fines Thursday against the Newark Teachers Union and its former president and treasurer for failing to file quarterly reports about political contributions between 1991 and 1995.

title: Ascent Is Planning To Acquire Assets of Its Rival Spectravision
description: Ascent Entertainment Group Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire the assets of a rival company in pay-per-view television, Spectravision Inc., which has been operating under bankruptcy-law protection.

title: About New York;Lobbying For Markets (And Himself)
description: RICHARD LIPSKY looks out for the little guy. He relentlessly lobbies city officials on behalf of small business owners whose livelihoods and neighborhoods are threatened by the invasion of sprawling supermarkets and megastores. He kept Pathmark out of Astoria and has rallied hundreds of small supermarket owners opposed to the Fairway Market's opening in West Harlem in violation of zoning laws.

title: Golf Is Cruel, but Shark Shall Rise Again
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Johnson Looks Like Good Fit For the Jets
description: The one player on whom virtually everyone with the Jets agrees, wide receiver Keyshawn Johnson of Southern California, is expected to be chosen today as their No. 1 pick of the National Football League draft -- if. As in, if the two parties could get together on money.

title: In Hindsight, Ousted Host Would Alter His Remark
description: Reflective but hardly repentant, the recently ousted talk-show host Bob Grant returned to radio yesterday, this time as a guest, and said that if he had it to do over again he might have leashed his tongue a bit.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Big Investor in BET Rejects Rentokil's Bid
description: M&G Investment Management, the largest shareholder in BET P.L.C., said yesterday that it had rejected the Rentokil Group's bid of L2 billion ($3.04 billion) for BET, a British business services company, in a blow to the takeover attempt. M&G, a British fund manager that holds a 7.5 percent stake in BET, informed BET's chairman, Christopher Harding, that it had rejected the offer and praised BET's management team. Nigel Morrison, an M&G fund manager, said Rentokil's bid was too low.

title: Traitor, Now in Russia, Wins in British Court
description: The High Court ruled today that George Blake, one of the most notorious Soviet spies ever to betray the British secret service, was entitled to the proceeds from his autobiography, "No Other Choice," published here in 1990.

title: GOLF;Watson Hopes to Kick His Sunday Blues
description: Tom Watson has come so tantalizingly close, so many times. It was just last year, right here at the MCI Classic, that he was one stroke behind going into the final round. He finished seventh. Twice this year, at Bay Hill and at New Orleans, he was there on Saturday, gone on Sunday, closing both times with rounds of 74.

title: He Said It, Sisters, but It's Not What He Meant
description: To the Editor:

title: Alan Barwiolek, 43, Is Dead; An Actor, Despite Deafness
description: Alan Barwiolek, who helped found the New York Deaf Theater as part of a lifelong campaign to improve things for those in the silent world he was consigned to at birth, died on Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 43 and had been associate professor of sign language studies at Union College in Plainfield, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about the growing popularity of chess in New York City schools misidentified a girl from Public School 19 who was shown at a demonstration board. She was Melissa Fortunato, not Lisa Mahoney.

title: In Performance;DANCE
description: Talking, Singing and Moving In a Fantasy About Imagination Stephan Koplowitz and Company Creative Club House Bessie Schonberg Theater

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Ex-Lawmaker Attacks F.B.I.
description: At his sentencing yesterday for income tax evasion, a former United States Representative, Cornelius E. Gallagher, blamed "the undying enmity" of Federal agencies dating back to the late J. Edgar Hoover for his troubles with the law. "J. Edgar Hoover is not on trial here, you are," replied Judge Harold Ackerman of Federal District Court, who sentenced Mr. Gallagher, 75, to 10 months in prison. Mr. Gallagher served in Congress for nearly 14 years until a 1973 conviction on tax evasion charges, for which he spent 17 months in prison.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: COMPANY NEWS;STUART ENTERTAINMENT TO ACQUIRE TRADE PRODUCTS
description: Stuart Entertainment Inc., the world's largest maker of bingo cards and accessories, agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Trade Products Inc. for $38 million. The Seattle-based Trade Products makes gaming tickets for carnivals and fund-raising. The combination of the companies will provide more opportunities for product development and help Stuart Entertainment develop business in emerging markets, Stuart said. Stuart is based in Council Bluffs, Iowa.

title: Jose Luis Lopez Aranguren, 86, Professor Who Opposed Franco
description: Jose Luis Lopez Aranguren, a philosopher of ethics whose opposition to the Franco dictatorship cost him a university teaching position, died at a hospital here on Wednesday at the age of 86.

title: Edward J. Keating, Sports Agent, 59
description: Edward J. Keating, a sports agent who negotiated the contract that made Frank Robinson the first black manager in major league baseball, died of cancer Thursday in Sagamore Hills, Ohio. He was 59.

title: Small Stocks Lift Nasdaq; Dow Declines 16.26 Points
description: Smaller issues took the leadership role yesterday in a mixed stock market.

title: Suspect in Fordham Rape Surrenders to the Police
description: An 18-year-old recent immigrant from the former Yugoslavia has been charged with attempted murder and rape after confessing to an attack on a Fordham University junior a week ago, the police said.

title: Young Singers Receive Prizes of $15,000 Each
description: The second annual Aria awards, a series of cash prizes for young singers, have been awarded to Christine Goerke, a soprano, Stephanie Blythe, a mezzo-soprano, and Frank Hernandez, a baritone. The three singers, each of whom received a cash stipend of $15,000, were chosan by a jury of which Speight Jenkins, the general manager of the Seattle Opera, was the chairman. The winners did not know that they were being considered for the prize.

title: In Performance;POP
description: In a Conversational Baritone That Can Dive Even Deeper Bill Morrissey Bottom Line

title: COMPANY NEWS;SUNBEAM CHAIRMAN AND TWO DIRECTORS RESIGN
description: The Sunbeam Corporation's chairman and chief executive, Roger W. Schipke, will be leaving the struggling maker of blenders and other small appliances. Mr. Schipke was seen as not being able to lift Sunbeam to the heights many had expected, and the company is headed for its fourth straight quarter of lower earnings. Two directors also resigned: Roderick M. Hills, the former head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and Paul W. Van Orden, executive director of the Chazen Institute of International Business at Columbia University Business School. Shares of Sunbeam, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., fell 50 cents yesterday, to $16.50.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks See Another One Slip From Their Hands
description: The Knicks have lived and died by Patrick Ewing's hands for a decade. Sometimes nimble. Sometimes unnerving.

title: Lebanese, Under Fire, Direct Fury at the U.S.
description: The Friday morning market opened almost as usual today as dawn brought hopes that the shelling of a United Nations camp on Thursday might bring an immediate end to the rain of fire that has fallen on this town almost every day since Israel's assault on southern Lebanon began.

title: On Anniversary, Sect's Members Commemorate Fatal Fire
description: The crackly tape-recorded sounds of David Koresh's voice and guitar drifted across a dry, windy stretch of Texas prairie today as surviving members of the Branch Davidian sect commemorated the fire in which Mr. Koresh and nearly 80 of his followers perished exactly three years ago.

title: Could We Be Importing the Ebola Virus?
description: Once again, the Ebola virus has appeared in monkeys in the United States. This time, monkeys imported from the Philippines for medical research were found to be infected with Ebola-Reston, a strain that is not dangerous to humans, at a primate center in Alice, Tex.

title: Suspect in Drug Case Rejects Plea Offer
description: The politically charged case of a confessed drug courier will most likely go to trial next month, after the defendant rejected a Government plea offer yesterday that would have sent her to Federal prison for at least nine years.

title: In Russia, Clinton Focuses on Past
description: He said barely a word about the fevered electoral struggle over Russia's future. Instead, President Clinton, as if seeking sanctuary from the volatility of Russia's political scene, resolutely focused today on the glory, the tragedy and the heroism of Russia's past.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY MORE THAN DOUBLES STOCK SALE
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. more than doubled the size of its coming stock sale, suggesting strong demand for shares in the company, which is run by Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire investor. Berkshire now plans to sell 250,000 shares of its class B common stock, up from an initial projection of 100,000 shares, according to an amended registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company plans to set the price of class B shares at one-thirtieth of the price of Berkshire common shares, which closed yesterday at $33,300, up $300. Berkshire Hathaway, based in Omaha, is an insurance holding company.

title: Egyptian Police, in Sweep, Seize Suspects in Killing of Greeks
description: Security forces swept through three shantytown areas of Cairo today, arresting Muslim fundamentalists as potential suspects in the massacre of 18 Greek tourists at a hotel near the Pyramids.

title: LEBANON FIGHTING DEFIES DIPLOMACY AFTER DEATH OF 75
description: Despite a flurry of diplomatic efforts to end the fighting, and despite the global outcry over the fiery killing of at least 75 Lebanese civilians by Israeli guns on Thursday, exchanges of shells and rockets in southern Lebanon continued unabated for the ninth day today.

title: America's Cold-War Secrets
description: It has been six months since President Clinton instructed the Federal Government to move more swiftly to declassify millions of secret documents. Three years have passed since James Woolsey, as Director of Central Intelligence, promised that his agency would review and release files on covert intelligence operations of the cold war.

title: Washington Spat Threatens to Halt Disposal of North Korean NuclearFuel
description: In one of the world's stranger partnerships, a team of North Korean technicians and a Georgia company under contract to the Energy Department are one step away from safely storing 8,000 nuclear fuel rods that were used in a North Korean reactor and whose fate prompted a confrontation between the United States and the North two years ago.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column on Thursday about Jackie Robinson's debut as a minor league player in 1946 incorrectly described the site in Jersey City where it took place. There is indeed a plaque there honoring Robinson. It was erected on Wednesday.

title: Scientist's Wife Arraigned on Federal Charge
description: Rita Gluzman was arraigned in Federal District Court here this morning on charges that she and her cousin killed her husband, a Russian scientist, then hacked up his body and disposed of it in the Passaic River.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Conviction in Carjacking
description: Randolph Dixon, 43, an East Orange man who was stopped in the midst of a robbery last July by bystanders coming to the victims' aid, was convicted yesterday of robbery and carjacking, prosecutors said. Passers-by intervened when a driver and his mother were robbed and attacked in their car by Mr. Dixon and an accomplice, who fled. JOE SHARKEY

title: CAPITOL SKETCHBOOK;Behind the Drive for Free TV Time for Candidates
description: After 25 years as a newspaper reporter, Paul Taylor approaches his latest news conferences from the far side, stepping gingerly into the television lights as a person trying to create news, not report it.

title: Sheik Defines Path to Heaven
description: The Sheik of Al Azhar, the spiritual guide for hundreds of millions of Muslims, said in an interview published today that he considered those who blow up Israeli troops in suicide operations to be martyrs.

title: Matchmakers' Stack College Admissions Deck
description: To the Editor: Having accepted a $2,500 consulting fee to advise a high school sophomore on her college application process (news article, April 17), a consultant subsequently writes Dartmouth's dean of admissions a letter of recommendation for this student. Conflict of interest? It would seem so, unless the consultant makes clear the financial relationship, in which case the admissions office probably ignores the letter.

title: Matchmakers' Stack College Admissions Deck
description: To the Editor:

title: For Ancient Bolivian Tribe, Time Is Running Out
description: It is harvest season on this barren, windswept plateau, some 13,000 feet above sea level in the Andes Mountains, but Juan Condori Mauani can barely find enough grain to fill his poncho.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Across the Color Line With Satchel Paige
description: No showboating!" When the catcher Josh Gibson yells that warning at his teammate Satchel Paige, he had better be joking. In 1945, Paige was the most famous and dazzling pitcher in the Negro Leagues, and telling him not to showboat was like telling him not to breathe. Paige responds with a broad, mischievous smile, then gives a swift-footed little dance on the mound, a dramatically huge windup, a quick strike.

title: F. Lee Bailey Freed From Jail In Dispute Over Drug Money
description: F. Lee Bailey was released from a Federal jail here today after serving six weeks for contempt of court. The lawyer has a year to pay the Government $700,000, but he said today that he intended to get it back, and more, through the courts.

title: Perot Party Makes Ballot
description: The Reform Party of Ross Perot today won a spot on Ohio's Presidential ballot, bringing to nine the number of states where the party has won certification.

title: Small Agency Does Battle With the City Budget Office
description: Offering a glimpse of the internal wrangling behind New York City's budget, the director of the agency that investigates potential conflicts of interest among public officials has warned the Giuliani administration that its latest spending cuts would have a devastating impact on the agency's mission.

title: The Conceit of Progress
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-6

title: Tightrope for Clinton
description: Aware of the delicacy of being in Russia not long before its presidential election, President Clinton averted his eyes from politics. Page 4.

title: The U.S. Deficit Fell in March
description: The United States budget deficit fell to $47.28 billion in March from $50.54 billion in March 1995, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Fans Throng to See Mrs. Onassis' Items Shown at Sotheby's
description: One moment it was, look at the desk where John F. Kennedy signed the Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. The next moment it was, there may be a bomb right here, head for the exits.

title: Planet Wall Street Embraces Planet Hollywood
description: Does 75 times earnings sound like too much to pay for a restaurant company?

title: Sports of The Times;The Choice Comes Down To Greatness
description: FINALLY, the great day has arrived. Nearly four months after a disheartening loss to New Orleans ended another miserable season, Jets fans, Jets officials and Jets players can wake up this morning without cursing the sun. Draft day is here, and with it comes the promise of a new era for a beleaguered franchise.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Mercedes Plans to Build Small Cars in Brazil
description: Mercedes-Benz A.G. said yesterday that it planned to invest $400 million to build small autos in Brazil. Mercedes said it would produce around 70,000 A-Class cars annually in a factory in Juiz de Fora, between Rio de Janeiro and Belo Horizonte, beginning at the end of 1998. That is in addition to the 200,000 A-class cars to be made annually in Rastatt, Germany, starting next year.

title: Search for Cause of a Cancer Cluster Yields Fear and Doubt
description: People are worried along parts of the New Jersey shore, even on a bright spring day when the sky reflects the water like a mirror. Some are even concerned enough to buy bottled water, call their doctors or scan the real estate pages.

title: In Performance;JAZZ
description: A Band Rules Its Realm With a Powerful Swing Christian McBride Village Vanguard

title: No Headline
description: Jacqueline Kennedy was a national icon. If we could, we'd like to take something back to Wisconsin."

title: BALLET REVIEW;Straitjackets, And Speaking With the Feet
description: Ever since 1992, an organization called New Choreographers on Point has presented "Ballet Builders," evenings of new works in the balletic idiom by choreographers and dancers of varied backgrounds. One never knows what will be featured in such choreographic showcases. Often, the offerings are both fascinating and exasperating.

title: Mr. Pataki's Principled Stand
description: Gov. George Pataki commendably ignored some of his conservative supporters last week when he reissued an executive order prohibiting discrimination against homosexuals in New York State employment and their access to state services. His willingness to do so is especially refreshing in a Presidential election year where anti-gay bigotry has emerged as a troubling theme in national Republican politics.

title: Matchmakers' Stack College Admissions Deck
description: To the Editor:

title: MetroStars Are Expecting 60,000 at Home Opener
description: The MetroStars are expecting a festive crowd of about 60,000 for tonight's home opener at Giants Stadium against the New England Revolution.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Demolition of Towers Set
description: Packed with 1,500 pounds of dynamite, three vacant high-rises at the Otto Kretchmer housing project are scheduled to come tumbling down Monday. The demolition was originally scheduled for tomorrow, but was delayed a day after state Labor Department officials argued that a weekday explosion would draw fewer spectators. The Newark Housing Authority is blowing up the high-rises to build town houses, said Harry Robinson, a spokesman for the authority. Buses and a shelter are available for nearby residents who want to leave the area during the demolition, which is scheduled for 11 A.M.

title: Beliefs
description: The idea of doctors taking an active role in ending people's lives cannot but have ominous overtones for Jews, even for those who feel that such action might sometimes be justified.

title: Excerpts From Speech: On the Judiciary
description: The following are excerpts from an address by Senator Bob Dole to the American Society of Newspaper Editors, as recorded by by the Federal News Service, a transcription service.

title: ASSEMBLY LEADERS YIELD ON WELFARE
description: The Democrats who control the State Assembly said today that they had dropped their opposition to time limits on welfare, clearing the way for the state to impose the first significant cuts in the program's history.

title: Kalim Siddiqui, 62; Led British Muslims
description: Kalim Siddiqui, a prominent British Muslim who backed Iran's call for the assassination of the writer Salman Rushdie, died of a heart attack on Thursday while on a visit to Pretoria, South Africa. He was 62.

title: BASEBALL;This Tame, No Magic In the 9th For Mets
description: The Mets had the Colorado Rockies right where they wanted them. Though they trailed by two runs entering the ninth inning, the Mets seemed poised for one of their familiar late-game comebacks.

title: THEATER REVIEW;An Apocalyptic, Life-and-Death Men's Car Pool
description: Casualties run high in the Darwinian world of "Car Pool," a deceptively modest-seeming new play by Laura Hembree at the Theater Off Park. Like the old bomber crew movies of World War II, this smart, neatly tailored work assembles an archetypal assortment of men in one vehicle, then waits suspensefully to see which ones get it and which ones survive. The battlefield has shifted to corporate America, but mortality waits just as patiently to claim its own.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Let's Begin Work on the Hudson River Park
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NUCO2 INC., Stuart, Fla., which supplies carbon dioxide systems for use in fountian beverages, agreed to buy the carbon dioxide supply operation of Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of New York Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Wider Beach Badges Studied
description: Mayor Kenneth Pringle wants to establish a "regional beach-badge" system to allow neighboring beach towns to provide reciprocal access and share the revenues. But he acknowledged yesterday that the idea was unpopular with some mayors in other beach communities because they feared losing money and worried about increased public access to their beaches. Mr. Pringle said a survey to gauge support for his idea would be conducted this summer in shore towns in Monmouth, Ocean, Atlantic and Cape May Counties, most of which restrict beach use to those who buy a municipal pass. The only free public beaches on the New Jersey shore are in Atlantic City and the Wildwoods.

title: Body of Young Boy Is Found Behind Bronx Housing Project
description: The badly decomposed body of a young boy was found yesterday in a plastic garbage bag behind a South Bronx public housing project, a few hours after a couple there had been charged with mistreating four other children and the police learned that a fifth child was missing.

title: 2 Baby Bells Said to Settle A Final Issue
description: Bell Atlantic and Nynex resolved the remaining management issues yesterday that stood in the way of their merger, an executive familiar with the talks said.

title: To Long-Starved Soccer Fans, a Game Feels Like a Banquet
description: It has been almost two years since Kevin McAllister put down $150 as a deposit on season tickets for a team without a name, uniform or player.

title: Memorial Service For Michelle Carew
description: Friends abd family said goodbye to Michelle Carew at a memorial service today.

title: CUNY's Problem Is Based in Albany
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO BASKETBALL;End Is Near for Nets' Frustrating Season
description: As if the Nets had not suffered enough this season, there was another bit of indignity tonight: The team's charter broke down and the players had to wait until morning to fly to Atlanta for Saturday night's season finale.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pirelli Chief Retiring After Years at the Helm
description: Pirelli S.p.A. said yesterday that its 70-year-old chairman, Leopoldo Pirelli, would retire from the company. The Italian tire and cable concern was founded by Mr. Pirelli's grandfather, Giovanni Battista Pirelli, in 1872. After spending almost a half-century at the helm of Italy's 10th-largest industrial company, Mr. Pirelli will be replaced by the chief executive, Marco Tronchetti Provera, 48. Mr. Pirelli's son, Alberto, was named deputy chairman.

title: Olympic Torch Relay Will Skip Atlanta Suburb That Condemned Gay Life
description: Starting next week, the Olympic torch will travel by relay through 42 states on its way to the opening ceremonies of the Summer Games here. But on its 15,000-mile, 84-day journey, it will not pass through the Atlanta suburb of Cobb County, Olympics organizers said today, because the county has refused to repeal its 1993 resolution condemning the homosexual "life style."

title: Buses Crash in Paterson; Dozens of Students Hurt
description: A novice school bus driver being trained to follow a new route apparently ran a stop sign in a residential neighborhood today, colliding with a New Jersey Transit bus and sending about 40 people, most of them high school students, to the hospital for treatment.

title: Columbia Defeats the P.C. Separatists
description: Some of my fellow students at Columbia staged a two-week protest this month to try to force the university to establish an ethnic studies department. Such a department would be wrong. Twenty-two students were arrested after more than 150 occupied Low Library, the main administrative building. About 100 blocked the central classroom building for four days to protest the school's "hegemonic and white supremacist" curriculum.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LE GROUPE VIDEOTRON OF CANADA PLANS OFFER
description: Le Groupe Videotron Ltd. of Canada said yesterday that it would make an offer of $498 million in cash and debt for CFCF Inc., a Montreal-based telecommunications company. CFCF also terminated an agreement it reached with Videotron in November 1995. Under that deal, Videotron, also a Montreal-based telecommunication concern, would have purchased CFCF's cable TV operations and CFCF would have purchased Tele-Metropole Inc., a broadcasting company controlled by Videotron. Videotron's bid includes $367 million (Canadian) in cash and the assumption of more than $300 million in debt. Videotron is offering $21.50 (Canadian) a share for CFCF, besting a recent rival offer from Cogeco Cable Inc. of $20 (Canadian) a share.

title: French Radio Quota Hasn't Alienated Fans : Listeners Stick With 'le Rock'
description: PARIS  It has been three-and-a-half months since the government demanded at least 40 percent French-language programming by most private music-oriented radio stations, and so far, the worst fears of station managers and on-air personalities have yet to materialize.

title: COMPANY NEWS;J. BAKER'S STOCK RISES ON ACCORD TO SELL UNIT
description: Shares of J. Baker Inc. rose nearly 16 percent yesterday after the company agreed to sell its Shoe Corporation of America division to a group formed by management and Bain Capital Inc., a private investment firm. J. Baker, a footwear and apparel retailer based in Canton, Mass., said the transaction was subject to certain conditions, including a final agreement. The Shoe Corporation operates licensed shoe departments in small department-store chains.

title: More Budget Pain for the City
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's budget plans, as announced at the beginning of the year, contained a cluster of unrealistic assumptions. Now the New York City Mayor acknowledges that his earlier hopes for windfalls from the state and Federal governments will not be fulfilled soon and that his own spending reductions are falling short of expectations. He warns that he will have to cut thousands more jobs and related city services in the next year. Mr. Giuliani's tough new approach is commendable, but his own delays in dealing with pressing problems will make their solution all the more difficult.

title: Ban Retained On Naming Of Offenders
description: A Federal judge today continued his order barring New Jersey authorities from notifying schools, day-care centers, women's shelters and, in some cases, residents about paroled sex offenders living in their neighborhoods.

title: World News Briefs;Haitians Arrest Brother Of Leader of 1991 Coup
description: The police have arrested the brother of the man who organized the 1991 overthrow of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, a week after the coup leader was arrested in the Dominican Republic.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: BASEBALL;Gooden Experiment Is Like Mad Science
description: Carefully walking on George Steinbrenner's tightrope between being acceptable and becoming expendable, Dwight Gooden might have finally plummeted over the edge tonight. Gooden lost his footing once more, and there was no net to catch him. He would have needed an extra-large net.

title: Trial Date Is Set in Fight Over Ellis Island
description: New Jersey's lawsuit against New York to claim control over portions of Ellis Island warrants a full trial, a special master for the United States Supreme Court has ruled.

title: World News Briefs;Rebel Group Accepts Cease-Fire in Liberia
description: A rebel faction whose showdown with rival groups plunged the capital into chaos agreed today to a cease-fire and freed 78 foreigners trapped by the fighting.

title: Derby in Doubt For El Amante
description: El Amante, who won the Flamingo Stakes at Hialeah two weeks ago and was considered a candidate for the Kentucky Derby, came down with a fever after reaching Churchill Downs this week and may not be ready to run in the Derby two weeks from today.

title: 2 Girls Arrested in Mailed Threats to Clinton
description: Two 13-year-old girls have been arrested and ordered held without bond at a juvenile detention center, accused of sending President Clinton letters that threatened him and his family.

title: 90's Revival: Positive Power of Thinking
description: Few legends haunt the imagination of New Yorkers of a certain intellectual or literary bent more than tales of the circles, salons and other highbrow hobnobbings that were once a feature of city life.

title: BOXING;A Plodder Outpoints A Dancer In Box-Off
description: Zabdiel Judah of Brooklyn planned to fight from long distance tonight in the light welterweight division at the Olympic box-offs. He would keep moving against the awkward, ever-charging David Diaz of Chicago and deftly avoid the pushing and shoving. But the 18-year-old Judah did so much dancing that he hardly bothered to throw a punch.

title: Observer;The Demon Success
description: The death last week of Jessica Dubroff, the 7-year-old flier, produced a spate of un-American criticism of parents who push their children too hard too soon. This outburst resulted not from a sudden public onset of good sense, but only because of the melodramatic way Jessica died.

title: INSIDE
description: Andean Tribe Threatened

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;As Piracy Grows in Mexico, U.S. Companies Shout Foul
description: Luis is proud of his work, and he backs it up with a personal guarantee. From his stall in a teeming Mexico City market, Luis peddles the latest in pirated videotapes of American movies. Recently his prize item was Walt Disney's "Toy Story," which is not even out on video yet in the United States.

title: Process Eased For Evicting Drug Dealers
description: A Federal judge made it far easier for authorities to evict drug dealers from New York City public housing projects yesterday, saying that drug-related crime poses a more urgent threat to tenants now than when the original eviction procedures were established 25 years ago.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : Want That 15 Minutes of Fame? There's Rent-A-Fan Club
description: These days you do not have to wait for your 15 minutes of fame. Instead, you can buy them, the Los Angeles Times reports.

title: Delaware Executes Man Who Killed His Parents
description: A man who spent most of his life behind bars was executed by injection today for killing his adoptive parents in May 1994, a month after getting out of prison early for good behavior.

title: Bond Prices Gain After 3 Days of Losses
description: Prices of Treasury securities turned higher yesterday, ending a three-day slump.

title: In the Region/New Jersey;For West New York, a $650 Million Hudson Enclave
description: EXCEPT for a golf driving range, West New York's nearly mile-long Hudson River waterfront remains the industrial wasteland left behind when shipping and rail operations there ceased more than 20 years ago. But that may soon change.

title: WEDDINGS;Jessica Jacobson, John E. Sorkin
description: Dr. Jessica Lynn Jacobson, a pathology resident at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, was married last evening to John Eric Sorkin, an associate at Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, a New York law firm. Rabbi Roberto Graetz performed the ceremony at the Sheraton Palace Hotel in San Francisco.

title: April 14-20;The Minimum Wage Gets Costly for Dole . . .
description: In their drive to increase the Federal minimum wage from $4.25 to $5.15 an hour, Democrats in Congress received a bonus last week. They found a good way to portray Senator Bob Dole as Scrooge.

title: Timeless Values
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD;The Swell Morel
description: Morels look like mushrooms a la Disney. Wringled, honeycombed, druidlike and cap-shaped, they push through the barely thawed earth of Italy, France, Switzerland and the northern parts of the American Midwest, paying a certain homage to winter, yet presaging gentler days. Because they are hollow little huts, they deliver only a hint of the woodsy flavor of their late-autumn cousins; their taste hints variously of hazelnuts and nutmeg, even more vaguely of smoke. They bring to a dish an elusive flavor that is no longer winter but not quite spring.

title: Israeli Shelling of Coast Road Cuts Aid to Lebanese Villages
description: Israeli gunboats stepped up their shelling of Lebanon's coastal highway today, trapping residents in southern Lebanon and all but cutting supply lines to villages there, even as diplomats met in Syria to try to put an end to the violence.

title: GARDENING;Thinking of Bulbs? Think Big, Think Color
description: THE marvelous parade of bloom from hardy bulbs has begun. Anyone who gardens knows well that these bright greeters of the new season are just about the easiest form of planting.

title: WEDDINGS;Kerry Yeager And Jed Stevens
description: Kathryn Gow Yeager, the daughter of Barbara and George Yeager of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Wells Stevens, a son of Jill and George Stevens of New Canaan, Conn. Canon Peter Daley performed the Anglican ceremony at St. Phillips Church on Antigua.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;When Life Is a Downer, He Takes Off in a Peach
description: Fear Mark Wahlberg (formerly known as Marky Mark), Reese Witherspoon, Alyssa Milano, William Petersen, Amy Brenneman Directed by James Foley R 95 minutes

title: IN BRIEFS;Victim's Mother to Speak On Sentencing Bill
description: Karen Wengert of Manalapan Township, whose 6-year-old daughter was abducted from her home and killed in 1994 by a neighbor with a history of sexual offenses, is to be among the advocates of victims' rights testifying on Wednesday for a bill that would require those convicted of violent crimes to serve at least 85 percent of their sentences.

title: Are Annapolis's Problems Systemic?
description: The shelves at Peppers here on Main Street are filled with blue-and-yellow Naval Academy merchandise, and if prospective customers are less eager to be identified with the Academy these days, sales do not show it. Business is good.

title: The Passion of Anna
description: THE BURGERMEISTER'S DAUGHTER Scandal in a Sixteenth-Century German Town. By Steven Ozment. Illustrated. 227 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $23.95.

title: WEDDINGS;Marjorie Miller, James Laughlin
description: Marjorie Lynn Miller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Owen Miller 2d of Metairie, La., was married yesterday to James Young Laughlin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Ben Laughlin of Blawenburg, N.J. The Rev. Ophelia Laughlin, the sister of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in New Orleans.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: STUYVESANT TOWN/MADISON SQUARE;Housing Complex Charges Misuse of Official Parking Permits
description: Stuyvesant Town, with its private security force and quiet location on First Avenue, would seem to be a haven both for its 20,000 residents and their cars. But, like many New York buildings that went up in the 1940's, the complex was not built with automobiles in mind, and residents have found it more and more difficult to find parking spaces.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Agreement to Increase South African Flights
description: The United States and South Africa agreed last month to loosen restrictions on flights between the two countries.

title: GOLF;The Curse of the Front-Runner: It's Real
description: Even for the toughest competitor in sport, the challenge presented to Greg Norman at the Masters last weekend was monumental.

title: Nile in Style
description: To the Editor: I know that it's almost heretical to suggest a luxury trip to Egypt without the four-day Nile cruise, but after research, my husband and I decided to pass on the cruise. We learned that all Nile cruises visit the same three sites. Next we found that taking the cruise would leave us only a day or two in Luxor, and because the archeology was at the top of our agenda, that just didn't seem like enough. Finally, we discovered that we could leave Luxor in the morning with a car and driver, visit all three sites, and be at the hotel in Aswan for a late lunch and a dip in the pool.

title: Climate Changes as Overseas Selling Rises
description: WESTCHESTER is well known for a lot of things, but international trade is not one of them. Yes, the county has long been home to Fortune 500 companies doing business overseas, and now as more mid-size companies enter global markets, the county is emerging as an international trade center.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION;Notes From Underground
description: What was it like to be an insider in Andy Warhol's Factory? You'll get only a vague idea from Mary Woronov in SWIMMING UNDERGROUND: My Years in the Warhol Factory (Journey Editions, $19.95), her account of the years she spent as a dancer with the Exploding Plastic Inevitable and an actress in movies like "The Chelsea Girls." This is no how-it-was memoir seen from sober, reflective middle age. Ms. Woronov writes as if she had been in a perpetual amphetamine haze, too high to notice much of what was going on besides drugs. In her Factory, there was no music, except for a mention that the Velvet Underground's Lou Reed "had two iron mistresses, music and heroin," and no art but for the night Warhol was seen sketching noses. There was a lot of crawling on bathroom floors and hanging out with drag queens at Max's Kansas City. Ms. Woronov recalls filming "The Chelsea Girls," and possibly another movie, but she wasn't sure if the camera was on. This Factory alumna offers few insights into the famous-for-being-famous people around her. THE VELVET YEARS: Warhol's Factory 1965-67 (Thunder's Mouth/Publishers Group West, $24.95) brings the Factory into focus, and not just because the book consists principally of photographs. Stephen Shore, who had the run of the loft, took enigmatic, posed but casual portraits of the Factory's denizens: Edie Sedgwick, Lou Reed, International Velvet, Ondine, Ingrid Superstar, Billy Name, Ultra Violet, Mary Woronov. In accompanying interviews by the novelist Lynne Tillman, we hear about Warhol's dedication to his work, and about the critical reaction. Paul Morrissey describes the artist as dependent on others to do things for him, and claims there were no wild parties, while Jonas Mekas remembers great parties with guests like Montgomery Clift and Tennessee Williams. And Billy Name recalls the day Warhol was shot by Valerie Solanas and nearly died. Andy Warhol remains elusive, but it's clear his acolytes loved him -- even though they agree he wasn't much of a talker and was cheap. Carol Peace Robins

title: GOLF;Roberts Ices Par; Caddie Ices Heckler
description: Well, it was just another humdrum day on the PGA Tour today in the third round of the MCI Classic. Loren Roberts, bouncing shots off trees and making putts from every corner of the Low Country, merely shot a round of 63 to charge into the lead and tie a tournament record of 15-under-par 198 after three rounds.

title: WEDDINGS;Susan D. Peters, Walter Durniak Jr.
description: Susan Drullard Peters, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Peters Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Walter Durniak Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Durniak of Millbrook, N.Y. Canon Sydney Woodd-Cahusac officiated at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: BASEBALL;Clark Pitches Eight Strong Innings and Vizcaino Delivers the Victory for the Mets
description: Superstitious baseball players have been known to duplicate nearly every move they made before a game that ended in victory. They'll wear the same clothes, eat the same food, drive the same roads to work. Being a creature of habit can be a comforting thing in sports. But sometimes it's not always possible.

title: Once Upon a Time, and More
description: AS a child, Barbara Craigie of Darien told stories to make life interesting. "Actually, I told lies," admitted Mrs. Craigie, who said she often tried to pass off made-up, exotic adventures as the truth. "Living in a very conventional home, I guess I thought I was honor bound to make life more interesting than it really was."

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;Air Ticket Theft: Steering Clear
description: RECENT thefts of blank airline tickets from travel agencies in Illinois and Dallas have raised anxieties among travelers about being stuck with a bad ticket. Those who are dealing with their usual travel agencies, or with ones recommended by friends, are in little danger. But people pursuing a fabulous bargain from an unknown seller, particularly one available only by phone, may be dealing with a thief, or an associate selling the thief's loot.

title: DIARY
description: MARKET ZIGZAGS

title: Streetscapes/Station Square, Forest Hills, Queens;A Medieval Design That Works in Modern Times
description: BUILT in 1912 in Forest Hills, Queens, Station Square is what almost every New York neighborhood lacks: a village center. A ring of unusual, medieval-style buildings, connected by arched overpasses, encloses a brick-paved square.

title: Study Says Babies in Child Care Keep Secure Bonds to Mothers
description: The most far-reaching and comprehensive study to date has found that using day-care centers or baby sitters does not affect infants' trust in their mothers.

title: Lebanon Fighters Gain Stature, but for How Long?
description: By any available measure, Hezbollah represents only a minority even of Lebanon's Shiite Muslims. Its core fighting force probably numbers just a few hundred men, and it depends heavily on support from Iran, which gave it birth after Israel invaded Lebanon 14 years ago.

title: Europe's Reborn Right
description: A PAGE OF HISTORY HAS TURNED: FOR THE FIRST TIME SINCE World War II a wave of aggressively nationalist, extreme-right parties have swept into municipal, regional, national and European parliament offices from the English Channel to the edge of the former Soviet empire. When they won a few scattered elections in the mid-1980's, they were taken for a passing phenomenon. But in election after election, this hard right -- which calls the traditional right "soft" -- is proving its power to survive and grow, pushing its roots deeper and deeper.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: AUTHORS, AUTHORS

title: ART VIEW;The Stylish Small Change Of a Paris Rich in Talent
description: THERE ARE MUSEUMS that jump about every which way in hopes of giving a new spin to their exhibitions pro grams.

title: Women at Midlife Exploring Choices 'Of This New Stage'
description: AT 50, Colette Dowling decided to leave a 16-year relationship with a man -- "not because it was bad," she said, "but because it was not good enough."

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHELSEA;Many Are Called But Few Chosen For Dance Spot
description: Michael Ault, wearing gray Versace pants and a pale yellow T-shirt, stood in front of silver metallic doors, guarding the entrance from the onslaught of more than 3,000 people, as his partner, David Sarner, wearing jeans and a navy baseball cap, stood on top of a giant Dumpster two Friday nights ago, trying to monitor the crowd for V.I.P.'s.

title: Sunday April 21, 1996: TASTE TEST;Interior Motives
description: My life has stopped because of this test," wails Lia Laurino, an experienced interior designer in New York, who nevertheless spent last weekend suffering through the two-day ordeal offered by the National Council for Interior Design Qualification. In 80 locations throughout the United States and Canada, some 1,500 designers were tested on very un-decoratorish topics like building codes and three-dimensional planning. Last year, only 17 percent passed the exam to become state-certified. "There's such a fear factor that interior designers are afraid to take it," says Todd Bostick of the qualification council. "But they do, in line with the other professions."

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Heat Ready for the Bulls
description: A late-season surge propelled the Miami Heat into the playoffs, and Alonzo Mourning said the team's momentum could carry them past the Chicago Bulls in the first round.

title: Angkor Wat
description: To the Editor: It was an eerie feeling to be seated at sunset on Feb. 4 at Angkor Wat watching a classical Cambodian dance performance and while perusing Barbara Crossette's article, "Angkor Emerges From the Jungle" (Jan. 28), courtesy of a nice couple from New York next to us.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Metuchen, N.J.;Battling to Retain Its Small-Town Identity
description: SURROUNDED by Edison Township and within five miles of two major malls, the tiny, 2.8-square-mile Borough of Metuchen is struggling to preserve its small-town ambiance and commercial viability.

title: ART;Exhibitions Highlight the Influence and Variety in Indian Art
description: 'Affinities and Influences: Native American Art and American Modernism" Parrish Art Museum, 25 Job's Lane, Southampton. To May 5. 283-2118.

title: Travels With an Omnivore
description: JOURNEY TO THE LAND OF THE FLIES And Other Travels. By Aldo Buzzi. Translated by Ann Goldstein. 147 pp. New York: Random House. $23.

title: Concert for a Community, By the Community
description: HARTFORD regional leaders, who want to bridge economic, cultural and ethnic barriers among communities around the capital, have turned to musicians for help.

title: Commercial Property/Drugstores;The Rite Aid Chain Takes Manhattan, the Bronx . . .
description: WALK past the Rite Aid drugstore at 84th Street and Lexington Avenue, turn east on 86th Street, and there it is, another Rite Aid. Walk east one more block, Rite Aid again.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: THE VISITING PHYSICIAN By Susan Richards Shreve. Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $23.95.

title: Hubert Opperman, A Champion Cyclist And Politician, 91
description: Hubert Opperman, one of the world's leading cyclists in the 1920's and 1930's and later a member of the Australian Parliament and Cabinet, collapsed and died in Melbourne on Thursday night while riding his exercise bicycle. He was 91.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 3/ Minority investors are getting badly beat up buying into public companies controlled by Dr. Douglas R. Colkitt. By Kurt Eichenwald.

title: Ronald N. Davies, 91, Who Issued Little Rock Order, Is Dead
description: Ronald N. Davies, who as a Federal judge in 1957 ordered the schools of Little Rock, Ark., to integrate and prevailed over Gov. Orval E. Faubus, died on Thursday in Fargo, N.D. He was 91.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Rental Car Thefts: Warning in San Diego
description: Travelers renting cars in the San Diego area should be cautious about the models they choose and where they park. According to the San Diego Police Department, 1,300 cars a month are being stolen there, and 10 percent of them are being driven to Mexico and resold.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAY RIDGE;Movie Complex Is Not a Hit
description: With Brooklyn's relative dearth of movie houses, plans for a new eight-screen multiplex would have seemed a welcome announcement. At least, that's what United Artists thought when it broke ground two weeks ago on a new theater complex.

title: Jack Wyrtzen, 82, a Christian EvangelistDTL>GLENS FALLS, N.Y., April 19
description: Jack Wyrtzen, an evangelist and founder of the Word of Life Christian organization, died on Tuesday at Glens Falls Hospital.

title: Italians Cast Votes Today, Questioning The Point
description: When polls open on Sunday for Italy's third parliamentary election in four years, there will be nagging questions in the minds of many voters: Are these elections really necessary, and what will they prove?

title: Movable Feasts
description: The Debt to Pleasure By John Lanchester. 251 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $20.

title: BASEBALL;Three Starts and He's Out: Gooden Heads for the Bullpen
description: Dwight Gooden was mercifully removed from the starting rotation and switched to the bullpen tonight as the Yankees unveiled their latest strategy for trying to discover if he can still pitch competently in the major leagues. About the only thing this marriage has shown so far is how desperately the Yankees want Gooden to succeed.

title: CUTTINGS;At Long Last Daffodils (Now It Must Be Spring!)
description: Snowdrops bloom in the snow, but when the daffodils open you know spring is here. And a river of yellow and white from 30,000 bulbs planted on the grassy slopes of the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx will be peaking for the next two weeks. If you love daffodils -- and who doesn't? -- this is the best time to wallow in the wonderful excess of hundreds of the same kind blooming in masses. It's also the best way to see which you like the best.

title: In Southampton Clinic, Spanish Is Spoken
description: In discussing the increasing Hispanic population on the South Fork ["Hispanic Population Making Inroads on the South Fork," Feb. 25] a speaker commented, "The area has a dire need for additional Spanish-speaking health practitioners . . . and Southampton has no bilingual social workers or public health nurses."

title: Architects Scaling Down High-Rise Dreams
description: After 29 years as a successful architect, Roger C. Fitzgerald folded up his drafting table two years ago and opened Breadsmith, a bakery in Haddonfield, N.J. Charlotte Hitchcock, whose architecture practice bustled with historic preservation work in the 1980's, now teaches geometry and algebra at Miss Porter's School in Farmington, Conn. And Steven M. Grotell, a former Manhattan architect, is now designing on a smaller scale, having traded retail spaces for watch faces.

title: Now, Iran-Bosnia;Who Knew What and When?
