description: IT'S an election year, so perhaps it should come as no surprise that, suddenly, the Clinton Administration has its very own scandal involving Iranian ayatollahs and secret arms shipments.

title: No Headline
description: The wonderful charm of New York is that when the regulations are old-fashioned or don't make sense, you just charge ahead."

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN: UPDATE;Actress's View Finally Brightens
description: The lights on the East River esplanade are burning again. The 14 dark or flickering street lamps that the actress Patricia Neal once saw from her apartment overlooking the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in the East 80's were repaired Monday morning in the teeming rain. Ms. Neal worried that the defective lamps created dark zones that were hazards for pedestrians and joggers.

title: Feeling Rotten
description: OSLER'S WEB Inside the Labyrinth of the Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Epidemic. By Hillary Johnson. 720 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $30.

title: BOXING;For Tarver, A Flawless Final Stop To Atlanta
description: He says that he mentally enters the ring long before he enters it physically. The light heavyweight Antonio Tarver likes to lay out a fight in his mind, spreading it out before him like a set of new clothes. This is what he had always envisioned, the perfect fight. A shutout.

title: Correction
description: A map on March 17 with an article about Columbia University's new building program misstated the location of three buildings. The Law Review building will be on the south side of 116th Street between Amsterdam Avenue and Morningside Drive, not the north; the Kraft Center for Jewish Student Life will be on the south side of 115th Street between Riverside Drive and Broadway, not the north, and the Business and Law School annex will be on the northeast corner of Amsterdam Avenue and 115th Street, not the northwest.

title: Correction
description: An article on April 7 about the heresy trial of an Episcopal bishop who ordained a gay man as a deacon misspelled the surname of the director of Integrity, an organization of gay Episcopalians. She is Kim Byham, not Bynum.

title: Once More Without the Vigor: Acura Plays the Numbers Game
description: A decade after revolutionizing the luxury care market, the Acura division of the American Honda Motor Company is reinventing itself, revamping its product line and plugging vehicles into nearly every conceivable niche. It is also renaming its models with letter-number combinations that represent the type of vehicle and the engine size. Acura says it research indicates that affluent customers associate luxury with numbers, not word.

title: From an Airliner's Black Box, Next-to-Last Words
description: FEW offices have as little privacy as an airliner cockpit, where a microphone picks up a pilot's every word, chuckle and yawn. A recorder, housed in a so-called black box, continually erases all but the last 30 minutes of conversation. It stops when the plane's power is off and, on much rarer occasions, in a crash. If the recorder is recovered, the tape is analyzed by investigators. It is then transcribed and, as with details released last week on the crash in December in Cali, Colombia, it is made public.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLUSHING;Science Hall's 30-Year Project
description: A greatly enlarged New York Hall of Science will open its doors this week, three decades after plans for the expansion were first made.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;On a Day of Celebration, The Cornhuskers Grieve
description: No. 18 had already been reassigned. That is not a heartless reality of the football business at the University of Nebraska, it is just the way things are. A career ends, the time comes to move on, and for all but the elite, someone else wears your shirt.

title: Backtalk;Kasparov, Major-League Knight
description: Garry Kasparov, as always ruthlessly engaged, watched Greg Norman, humanly distracted, come apart in the final round of the Masters last Sunday. The 33-year-old world champion of chess was only mildly interested; he had just flown into New York and happened to flick on the TV in his hotel room. What was the fuss about? Golf is no sport, a man on a lawn hitting a little white ball with no one attacking him. Now chess, cruel, in-your-face, animalistic chess . . . ahhhh.

title: WEDDINGS;Sawa Yamamoto, David Saenger
description: Sawa Yamamoto, a computer artist, and David Saenger, a medical student, are to be married today in Loma Mar, Calif. David Pomerenk, a commissioner in the criminal division of the Northern Municipal Court of San Mateo County, is to officiate in the Huckleberry Grove of San Mateo County Memorial Park.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;From Kerouac to Kmart
description: WHAT'S a 15-year-old schoolgirl doing on Eighth Street at noon on a Wednesday? "Cutting class and looking for shoes," confessed Rosa Velez, an ninth-grader from Jersey City, who along with two truant friends, was simply heeding the tradition of nonconformity that has been played out on Greenwich Village's main crosstown thoroughfare for generations.

title: Violence Growing in Battle Over Brazilian Land
description: A confrontation in northern Brazil between families seeking land to farm and the police ended in bloodshed this week, when the police opened fire and killed 19 people.

title: The Long-Lost Art of Ellis Ruley
description: ELLIS RULEY lived on a farm outside Norwich from the 1930's to the 1950's, and when he wasn't out in the garden amid the pumpkins, the yellow squash and the tangled vines of the tomatoes, he was a construction worker.

title: Travel Advisory: Deals and Discounts;TURNBERRY PACKAGE
description: Mother's Day, Father's Day and Memorial Day are marked with special packages at the 350-room Turnberry Isle Resort and Club in Aventura, Fla., between Fort Lauderdale and Miami International Airport. The Mother's Day package, which starts at $149.50 a person nightly, based on double occupancy, includes accommodations, American breakfast, a holiday brunch or barbecue, greens fees for one day, one-day admission to the spa, an hour of tennis and other extras. It is available May 10 to 13. All the packages require a two-night minimum. The Father's Day package, June 14 to 19, is similar and starts at $109.50 a person. The Memorial Day package, May 24 to 28, includes a holiday dinner instead of the brunch or barbecue. Tax and service are included in all packages. Telephone: (305) 932-6200 or (800) 327-7028. JANET PIORKO

title: Price of Winter at The Pump
description: THE price of gasoline in Connecticut is flirting with the record highs set just after the Gulf War.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: April 21, 1996
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction

title: A Green Refuge From Hanoi's Bustle
description: NOT far from bustling Hanoi, with its flocks of construction cranes and packs of buzzing motor scooters, is a lovely sanctuary that offers a respite from the exciting but cacophonous Vietnamese capital. Cuc Phuong, the country's first and oldest national park, is a tropical forest rich in exotic birds, towering trees, brilliant flowers, rare monkeys and other endangered species. Created in 1962 under the leadership of Ho Chi Minh, it is the cornerstone of a fledgling nine-park network the Government is developing in an effort to ride the big tourism wave now sweeping across Vietnam.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;Homeless Say Public Plaza Is Harassing
description: For Perry, a homeless man who sleeps in Central Park or midtown doorways, the public plaza of the Sony Building lobby at 56th Street and Madison Avenue was a welcome retreat with tables and chairs. But in January, he and other homeless people say, they noticed a change.

title: The Wild Child
description: To the Editor:

title: Mormons Pick Harrison as Site for Temple
description: THE saints may be marching, or driving, into Harrison.

title: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;We Need a Ron Brown Award for Business
description: COMMERCE Secretary Ronald H. Brown was an extraordinarily effective ambassador for our country's business community, and he will be missed.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Different Nets, Same Dreadful Season
description: A quick look at the standing would suggest that there was not much of a difference between this season's version of the Nets and last season's.

title: Foreign Affairs;No More Carrots For Assad
description: The best way to understand what the fighting between Israel and the pro-Iranian guerrillas in south Lebanon is all about is to think of it like this: Israel is about to have an election (May 29) and the whole Middle East is trying to take part in the campaign.

title: Basic Instincts
description: LEGACIES Stories. By Starling Lawrence. 243 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.

title: STREET SMARTS;Stay Clear of the Jungle That Dr. Colkitt Grew
description: FOR a moment, let's pretend that a disturbing conflict of interest is a tree. Now, let's go visit the lush, overgrown forest of Douglas R. Colkitt.

title: Pace Offering Lawyers An Internet Database
description: AS the result of worldwide academic collaboration, the Pace University School of Law in White Plains has begun an Internet database on international trade law.

title: April 14-20;A Plea from the Pope
description: It took Pope John Paul II less than two hours to fly from Rome to Tunisia last week for a daylong visit, but he came bearing a message of religious tolerance that he clearly hoped would travel even farther, across the border to Algeria and on to other Muslim countries where fanaticism continues to claim its victims.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN;Tokyo
description: Spring is glorious in Japan. By now, the cherry blossoms that bathe the parks in pink and fill them with picnickers have already bloomed and disappeared. But azaleas follow in May, and irises in June. And many temples hold festivals in which portable shrines career through the streets carried on the shoulders of chanting, often inebriated, revelers.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: TIGER's TAIL By Gus Lee. Knopf, $24.

title: The Battle Cry 'Reform!' Rocks the House of Lords
description: From time to time something goes wrong with the clock that rings Big Ben, perhaps some humidity that slows the aging mechanism or a spasm of wind that speeds it up. Then a workman appears with a pocket full of thick one-penny copper coins. He deftly dangles from a railing and carefully adds or subtracts a penny from a tiny pile on top of the 13-foot pendulum, thereby gaining or losing two-fifths of a second over the course of 24 hours.

title: Rehabilitating Sade
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Achieve Remembrance of Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: Bob Grant's Listeners Got a Different View
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Harvest: One Farm, One Life
description: SHE'S coming back?" said Brian Goode, executive sous-chef of Union Square Cafe in Manhattan. "That's good news for us. Last year she was saying: 'This is it. I'm selling the farm. I'm retiring.' "

title: A FUNNY THING';Before Rome There Was Athens
description: To the Editor:

title: Worlds Apart
description: THE TEMPLE BOMBING By Melissa Fay Greene. Illustrated. 502 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley Publishing Company. $25. ATLANTA: burned to ashes and skeletons during the Civil War, the town where Coca-Cola was invented in 1886, where Joel Chandler Harris wrote his Uncle Remus stories, where the usherettes wore hoop skirts at the premiere of "Gone With the Wind" in 1939. Martin Luther King Jr. was born and buried there; Atlanta was called the headquarters of the civil rights movement in the late 1950's, when he founded the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. Black students who organized the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee desegregated the lunch counters in the early 60's. Atlanta was famous for good manners even when Lester Maddox brandished an ax handle at blacks who tried to enter his fried chicken restaurant (the publicity enabled him to become Governor of Georgia in 1966).

title: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;A World of Asian Art in New York
description: IN RECENT WEEKS, NEW YORK HAS been awash in Asian art. The blockbuster exhibition "Splendors of Imperia' China" at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is drawing bigger crowds than its current Russian art extravaganza "Faberge in America." Around town there have also been 10 auctions, four gallery shows and the first International Asian Art Fair, in which hundreds of Asian artworks were sold for an estimated $55 million.

title: Decomposed Body Found
description: A group of campers discovered the decomposing body of a man on a small island about a mile from the Norwalk shore, the police said.

title: PREGNANCY, UNSEATED
description: It is ironic that Lisa Schiffren blames feminism for the rudeness of those who, on seeing her pregnant condition, remain seated (Lives: "Pregnancy, Unseated," March 24). Feminism does, indeed, have a history of rudeness. Susan B. Anthony was frequently censured for disrupting public meetings because she presumed women were entitled to have certain rights. And while men of that era may have looked sweetly upon pregnant matrons, feminists won women the right to be guardians of their own children.

title: Race an Issue for Democrats In Primary Opposite Helms
description: It did not happen in the expected way. But once again, race has become a central feature of a campaign to determine whether Jesse Helms returns to the United States Senate.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Wright's Work

title: Imagine L.I. Without Families Like Halseys
description: After reading "Family Endures as Stewards of the Land" [April 7], I now know why apples don't fall far from their trees.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3 On welfare, trying to get off: a park worker's tale of job loss, life crisis and new hope.

title: ART VIEW;A Mongolian Legacy, In War and Peace
description: THE VERY NAME MONGOLIA HAS A CHILL, lunar feel, the sense of a place uncharted and sparsely populated, somewhere beyond beyond. In reality, this vast territory in east central Asia has an ancient history and a vibrant, hybrid art. And that art is the subject of a remarkable if problematic exhibition titled "Mongolia: The Legacy of Genghis Khan," organized by the Asian Art Museum in San Francisco and ensconced at the National Geographic Society in Washington.

title: A Season Winds Down
description: PRODUCERS of what's left of the theater season are counting on the lure of novelties and the value of names.

title: Crime
description: Even if you don't buy the creepy and totally loony serial killer in Lynda La Plante's COLD SHOULDER (Random House, $24), you have to admire the magnificent wreck of a woman who tracks him down and delivers him to justice. Ms. La Plante, who wrote "Prime Suspect," the Emmy Award-winning British television series that starred Helen Mirren as an obsessive police detective, brings the same emotional intensity to this harrowing story about a California police lieutenant who bottoms out when her partner is killed, and drunkenly shoots to death an innocent boy.

title: Clinton Tiptoes Around Russian Vote Except to Say He's for It
description: A day before his one-on-one meeting with Boris N. Yeltsin, President Clinton today urged Russia to stay on the path of democratic and economic reform. But he declined to state his preference in the Russian presidential election, which could return a resurgent Communist Party to power.

title: Below Stairs
description: To the Editor: I have visited most of the National Trust mansions and palaces, and have found the "downstairs" most interesting. R. V. Denenberg's article is well written, but contains a common factual error.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;Gay Support Sought in School Races
description: Jill Harris remembers the nasty scuffles over the Children of the Rainbow curriculum, the 1992 multicultural guide that encouraged respect for families headed by gay men and lesbians. "You couldn't be a gay man or a lesbian in New York City and not feel personally attacked when that was stuff was happening," she recalled.

title: INVESTING IT;Nothing Ventured, Less Gain
description: LOOKING for the next Netscape? So is everybody else, but one clue to discovering the next hot initial public offering could be as simple as finding out which company has had the benefit of venture capital and which has not. A recent study shows that of the companies that have gone public since 1986, the ones that were backed by venture capitalists had the biggest rise in their stocks. The Securities Data Company, a financial information company based in Newark, reported that offerings backed by venture capital rose an average of 135.1 percent during the period, while offerings without venture capital rose an average 35.5 percent.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-13

title: Connecticut Q&A: Kenneth O. Decko;How Business Sees the State's Economy
description: FOR more than 20 years Kenneth O. Decko, a lawyer, has been involved with the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, which, with more than 9,500 members, is the state's largest business organization.

title: The View From: Larchmont;Kept Secrets That Kept Jews Alive
description: IF someone came to your door asking you to hide a Jewish family, and this was during the Nazi occupation, and you would be killed if you were discovered, would you do it?

title: Glint of Hope For a Grove Of Redwoods
description: The corporate baron wants his millions. The environmentalists want to protect the trees. The loggers want jobs. The politician wants to placate all sides. And the lawyers want to litigate.

title: Sports of The Times;Soccer Comes Home To Giants Stadium
description: IT took 11 years for the great Melting Pot to finally cook up another team, and then it took 89 minutes to botch the taste. The New York/ New Jersey MetroStars disappointed their instant fans last night when Nicola Caricola put the ball into his own goal with 12 seconds left in the game.

title: CHOOSING MY RELIGION
description: Stephen J. Dubner's "Choosing My Religion" (March 31) was a courageous and beautifully written article.

title: L.I. VINES
description: Red Table Wine Eastend Select, Pellegrini Vineyards, Cutchogue, 1993. About $10.

title: WEDDINGS;Betsy Gleick and Jim W. Parham
description: Elizabeth Gleick, a senior writer at Time magazine in New York, was married yesterday to Jim W. Parham, the director of sales at Tommy Boy Music Inc., a recording company in New York. Justice Burton S. Sherman, who is retired from State Supreme Court in Manhattan, officiated at the James Burden Mansion in New York.

title: April 14-20;Bob Grant Unplugged
description: There are those who think Bob Grant is brutally bigoted and believe many of his comments are offensive, and there are those who consider him admirably candid and believe his comments are misinterpreted. But on both sides there are those who were troubled that Mr. Grant's talk show on WABC-AM radio in New York was silenced by the Walt Disney Company and Capital Cities/ABC.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;Gadfly With a Bite
description: ASKED why his morning talk show on WFPG-AM portrays Atlantic City's government as a "hotbed of crimes against humanity," Harry Hurley, a slight, energetic man with a high voice and an acerbic manner uncommon among broadcasters, said, "You can't put perfume on a pig."

title: LESSONS;The Holocaust's Message, in Graphic Detail
description: Arie Galles stood in his studio in Madison, giving a tour of the field of gray rectangles and white stripes and squiggles before him.

title: April 14-20;You Know What You Paid. Here's What THEY Paid.
description: April brings forth cherry blossoms and the income tax returns of elected public officials.

title: CHOICE TABLES;Kyobento: Box Lunch, Kyoto Style
description: KYOTO is famous for its refined cuisine, more delicately seasoned than Tokyo's robust cooking. Most of Kyoto's better restaurants have only private tatami-matted dining rooms, and the cost for such an exclusive eating experience is steep: $500 a person for dinner is not unusual. If you would like to sample extraordinary Kyoto cuisine at a less alarming price, $50 or less, I recommend lunch, especially the elegant, affordable kyobento boxed meals that many of the top restaurants offer at noontime.

title: April 14-20;The Swastikas Stay
description: Spray-painted swastikas have begun spreading from downtown Washington to outlying neighborhoods, and Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. was not about to stand for that. Rag and solvent in hand, he wiped one away as a stand against hatred and bigotry.

title: Westchester Q&A: Warren Lehrer;Biographies of Those Less Famous
description: THE fine line between eccentricity and craziness is one of the many themes explored by Warren Lehrer, an associate professor of visual arts at Purchase College, in a collection of biographies of people he calls "stoop philosophers, sit-down comedians and off-the-cuff bards."

title: Americans, and Their Pets, Redeeming U.S. Debt at the U.N.
description: It may not seem like much, but when the United States alone owes you $1.6 billion in unpaid dues, or roughly half the $3 billion your overall membership should have come up with up by now but hasn't, even $11,665.11 can be a help.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week. Tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420.

title: WEDDINGS;Katherine Ross, Joel Whitebook
description: Katherine Ball Ross, the literary editor of Victoria magazine in New York, and Dr. Joel Whitebook, a psychoanalyst in New York, were married last evening by Acting Justice Mary Davis of State Supreme Court in Manhattan. The ceremony was performed in New York at the house of Judith Thurman and Peter Miller, friends of the couple.

title: Lucidity
description: This Page: The pavilion of mirrored glass on top of the Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea was designed by Dan Graham to be both reflective and transparent, and the result is an ever changing play of light.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLATBUSH: UPDATE;Library Is On Line
description: The Brooklyn Public Library took a fledgling step onto the information superhighway last week when its Flatbush branch began offering Internet access to the public.

title: ASIA-PACIFIC ISSUE;A WORLD OF CHOICES: Phnom Penh
description: As struggling Cambodia pulls itself out of decades of war and turmoil, it is beginning to look for ways to have a good time, and the handful of hardy foreign tourists are welcome to join in.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAY RIDGE;Anchor for More Than Boats
description: John Hall's pale-brick apartment building overlooking the mouth of Sheepshead Bay is a conspicuously modern feat, wedged along the shore in a niche of modest, wood-framed houses that are home to the area's four yacht clubs.

title: IN PERSON;Visual Voyages
description: PERHAPS the true artist never takes a vacation; the perceiving eye and the connecting mind refuse to rest. By this standard, Carol Rosen, best known as a sculptor, rates as a typical artistic obsessive. The proof lies in her new photo-collages, on view through Friday with a few earlier sculptures at the Elizabeth B. McGraw Arts Center at Newark Academy here. They are composed mostly of photographs Mrs. Rosen took on her European travels in recent summers; Italy, France and Spain leave their traces.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Smaller Trade Group Replaces Government's
description: The 35-year-old U.S. Travel and Tourism Administration, which promoted foreign tourism in the United States, closed on Monday, a casualty of government budgetary battles. On the same day a privately financed interim organization opened to take its place, and is expected to function for at least a year.

title: April 14-20;A Big Wheel to Rival Big Ben
description: By day it will have a fine gossamer appearance. By night, it will be gently lit, sparkling and magical, drawing attention to the River Thames." That was the way the architects, David Marks and Julia Barfield, described a new landmark they hope to build by 1998 in London -- the world's biggest ferris wheel, some 500 feet in diameter. The scheme, to mark the millenium, is depicted in this photo illustration. British Airways contributed $900,000 in start-up money last week; $13.3 million more is needed. JOHN DARNTON

title: There's No People Like Show People
description: LOVE, AGAIN By Doris Lessing. 352 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $24.

title: Below Stairs

For example, the reasons for the renaissance at American Ballet Theater could be read in 'ne graceful gesture offered to the company by its premier danseur Julio Bocca in the final moment of the 1995 New York season.

title: SOMETHING'S GOT TO GIVE
description: Darcy Frey's article "Something's Got to Give" (March 24) was superb, with all the elements of an exciting adventure novel -- beautifully delineated characters, high-speed action, scary moments and comic relief. I couldn't put it down.

title: Sunday April 21, 1996: FLOSSING;The Milkweed Factor
description: Most farmers in Nebraska (and everywhere else) try to kill off the milkweed in their fields, but not those cornhuskers around the Natural Fibers Corporation. The little company in Ogallala blends milkweed floss -- the shiny fibers exposed when the pods crack open in the spring -- with goose down to create batting for comforters and pillows. Insulation aside, the floss's biggest selling point is that it's hypoallergenic. "The hollow fibers of the milkweed trap and suppress the dust and dander in down," explains Herb Knudsen, the president of Natural Fibers.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;Eloquent Champion of the Vernacular Landscape
description: NEW YORKERS HAVE THREE more days to catch "A Sense of Place, a Sense of Time," the Municipal Art Society's small, delightful show of drawings by J. B. Jackson. But those who miss the show at the Urban Center (451 Madison Avenue, at 50st Street) can catch it at the Rhode Island School of Design in Providence, where it will run from April 29 through May 25. And those who hop on a train to see Jackson's drawings will not regret the journey. They will have the chance to travel through Jackson's subject: the American landscape in all its battered, democratic glory.

title: With G.O.P. Congress the Issue, 'Gender Gap' Is Growing Wider

title: To Market, to Market All Over New Jersey

Here in the land of Jersey Fresh, he had trouble finding supremely fresh corn on the cob, or green beans that snapped rather than stretched. He actually had to drive to the Greenmarket at Union Square in Manhattan for the freshest selection of fruits and vegetables.

description: For M & T Pretzel, the hot-dog kings of Central Park, it is another clean sweep. For the Harlem concessionaires who have been selling hot dogs and ice cream at Riverbank State Park, it is a slap in the face.

description: There is an eerie calm in the headquarters of American Atheists Inc. here. The desk calendar in one office remains open to Aug. 19. Down the hall, a handful of workers quietly sort videotapes and prepare literature. The empty offices appear as though the staff has just gone to lunch.

title: Rte. 25A a Problem for Local and State Planners
description: IN 1790 George Washington followed parts of Route 25A, or Main Street in Setauket, on a Presidential tour. Maps dating as early as 1797 show the street as a bustling commercial route.

description: JUDGING from early returns, the 1996 Presidential campaign does not promise to be one of the more riveting in the nation's history.

title: THEATER;Placing Big Bets on 'Big,' the Musical
description: EVERY SO OFTEN, AN IDEA comes along that's so simple it's a license to print money. Imagine a heartwarming musical with lots of adorable children and funny adults. The kids sing and dance. So do the adults. The musical becomes a must-see for young and old alike and, as a result, it runs for what seems forever.

title: Another Country
description: Cross Channel By Julian Barnes. 211 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $21. WE live, Julian Barnes suggests in an earlier book, in "a pragmatic and knowing century"; we are also, he says in another, "modern and ignorant." Can we really be all these things? Of course. Knowingness is not knowledge, and pragmatism and modernity are two of our favorite boasts about ourselves. But who is making this diagnosis? In the first case it is Geoffrey Braithwaite, the grieving, widowed doctor and ardent Flaubert fan who tells the story of "Flaubert's Parrot"; in the second, it is the deviser of the brilliant exploration of Gricault's "Raft of the Medusa" in "A History of the World in 10 Chapters." These characters are not exempt from the condition they describe, they are symptoms of it: wry, witty, belated, supposedly practical, often helpless. Behind them hovers the shadowy figure of Julian Barnes himself, who is just as wry, witty and belated, maybe as practical, and presumably quite a bit less helpless. I'm not so sure, though. Style and intelligence, which Mr. Barnes has in abundance, can focus helplessness and allow us to think about something else, but they can scarcely make it go away. Would we want it to go away, in all cases? "How do we seize the past? How do we seize the foreign past? We read, we learn, we ask, we remember, we are humble; and then a casual detail shifts everything." This is Braithwaite, and "the foreign past," for him, as for Barnes and for us, is delicately weighted with a double meaning: the past of a foreign scene or a foreign writer, and the past of our own life or marriage or love, which, as L. P. Hartley famously said, is a foreign country. Braithwaite's answer is more than modest, but his initial metaphor is surely too greedy, full of the promise of failure. We don't seize the past. At best we get a picture of it, and a couple of chances to revise the picture. And the past, in Mr. Barnes's fiction, becomes a figure for a whole series of separations and gaps, places where the mind or the memory can't quite reach the other side, as if the ferry were becalmed, or the tunnel not complete: between then and now, of course, but also between there and here, between them and us, between her and him, between any event and the chance of our understanding it.

title: Corrections

With help from seasoned troupers like Arthur Treacher, Mady Christians, Mary Nash, Helen Westley and Sidney Blackmer, young Shirley gracefully sets the tone and pace. Especially appealing are Jean Hersholt (above with Miss Temple) as her stern but humane grandfather and Marcia Mae Jones as a wistful, crippled youngster and Heidi's chum. title: Asia-Pacific Issue;An Island Of Serenity Near Bali

When children began appearing by the roadside to greet us with a chorus of hellos, my sister, who had traveled with me to the neighboring (and more exalted) island of Bali eight years ago, was charmed.

title: FILM;Now It's the Cars That Make the Characters Go
description: THE CADILLAC OF MINIVANS," John Travolta calls the Oldsmobile Silhouette he drives in the film "Get Shorty." As smooth talking as a car salesman, by the end of the movie he has convinced a big Hollywood star, played by Danny DeVito, that a vehicle lambasted by Consumer Reports for its technical mediocrity and derided in car magazines for "Dustbuster styling" has its own virtues. The punch line: The Hollywood star ends up buying one.

title: WEDDINGS;Nora K. Lee, Geoffrey Kanter
description: Nora Katherine Lee, a daughter of Alice and William Lee of Palm City, Fla., was married last evening to Geoffrey Elliot Kanter, the son of Joy and Richard Kanter of Rydal, Pa. Rabbi George Stern performed the ceremony at the Penn Club in New York.

title: How to Achieve Remembrance of Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: MARKET WATCH;Inflation Is Dead Forever, They Hope
description: There are a lot of ways for a company to increase sales. One is to offer customers a deal so good they will leap at it in droves. Of course, if the deal is that good, the company may come to regret offering it.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAYSIDE;From the Lawn Police Files
description: The lawn police watched as gardener Robert Ciampa tended to the lawn at the home of a regular client last Monday.

title: Virginia Law Gives Some Immunity From Laws
description: An archaic legal defense is suddenly in vogue in Virginia's capital, provoking citizens to demand the repeal of a law they never knew they had.

title: HOME CLINIC;How to Look for Quality in Wicker
description: THE term "wicker" refers to a particular style of ornamental, woven furniture and not to a specific material. Wicker furniture uses the techniques of basket weaving through supporting spokes. It may be made of a variety of materials like cane, willow, reed, rattan, rush, raffia, or Oriental sea grass. The term "'wicker" derives from the Swedish words "vikker," meaning willow, and "wiker," to bend.

title: BASEBALL;Puckett, Facing Life Outside Baseball, Keeps Fighting
description: Kirby Puckett, the one player in the game who can make almost anyone smile just by stepping onto the field, looked around the Metrodome today, his hazel eyes dancing, clear, bright and as shiny as his personality.

title: SOMETHING'S GOT TO GIVE
description: Obviously, it's those of us who don't have a fear of flying who need a psychiatrist!

title: UP AND COMING: Tea Leoni;Playing Golf, Wearing Pearls, Taking Pratfalls
description: SHE HAS THE FRESH-FACED look of a 1950's Radcliffe grad: good bone structure, great shoulders, a natural athlete. Someone a fellow could go skiing with who wouldn't complain about the cold. Both gorgeous and game, Tea Leoni is the kind of girl a Philip Roth character would go crazy for.

title: FOOD;Salmon, Asparagus, Strawberries and Spring
description: EVEN though you can get them year round, salmon, asparagus and strawberries still make me think of spring. So on a recent weekend, as the crocuses were making a valiant effort to show their heads in the garden under yet another covering of snow, a group of friends and I ushered in the season.

title: Proficient in English But Trying to Lose Their Accents
description: GUIDO MASSOLA is holding his hand in front of his face and staring intently at Arlene Corcoran's eyes and mouth. The two of them are slowly and rhythmically intoning the words, "doe, toe" over and over again. As Ms. Corcoran repeats the words, she asks Mr. Massola if he can feel his breath on his hand.

title: Rehabilitating Sade
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times;The Corn In Nebraska Is Rotten
description: LAWRENCE PHILLIPS was conspicuous by his absence, just as the University of Nebraska was conspicuous by its callousness in not renewing the basketball scholarship of the woman he assaulted.

title: Bell Atlantic's Board Approves Nynex Merger to Create Colossus
description: Bell Atlantic's directors voted yesterday to merge with Nynex, according to several people familiar with the discussions. The combination of the two regional Bell operating companies would create the nation's second-largest telephone company after AT&T.

title: Earned Millions
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WEDDINGS;Sarah Merians and Marc Silverstein
description: Sarah Melinda Merians, a photographer, and Marc Stuart Silverstein, a lawyer, were married on Thursday at the Puck Building in New York. Cantor Richard Botton performed the ceremony.

title: Rare Class
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Supermodels: Hot as Ever Or on Ice?;... but Fashion May Be Fed Up
description: THE models of the moment all look about 16. They are, uniformly, white, branch-thin as Twiggy, with blond locks cropped prison-camp short. Their names do not matter to much of anyone besides their bookers.

title: Stephen Meyers, 53, Legal Innovator, Dies
description: Stephen Z. Meyers, the visionary legal practitioner who helped revolutionize the practice of law as a founder of Jacoby & Meyers, the nation's first mass-market law firm, was killed Friday night when the car he was driving collided with a delivery truck on a winding country road in New Fairfield, Conn. He was 53.

title: DESIGNER NIHILISM
description: I work as a movie-theater projectionist (Culture Zone: "Designer Nihilism," by Michiko Kakutani, March 24). Maybe two films a year are good. Last year one of the two was "Leaving Las Vegas." It does not explain how its characters arrived where they are. Do we really need to hear about their terrible childhoods or lost loves to make us care about them? Is there something wrong with feeling sadness or pain? The Greeks created both comedy and tragedy because they fulfill basic human needs. Perhaps the popularity of "Leaving Las Vegas" has less to do with a new esthetic posturing than with the need of audiences to feel something other than just "good." FRANK HUDEC New York

title: Sunday April 21, 1996: HOLTSVILLE, L.I.;Many Happy Returns
description: Early last week, seven million taxpayers in New York and New Jersey dropped their Federal returns in the mail. A few days later, an enormous wave hit the I.R.S. Service Center in Holtsville, L.I., just south of Exit 62 on the Long Island Expressway. Holtsville, named after an unmemorable 19th-century Postmaster General from Kentucky, is a nondescript village of 10,000. It is an address that many know but few visit, so we paid a call on a few residents to find out what tax time was like. HARALD AUKLAND, postmaster: "On an average day we receive about 1,500 to 2,000 pieces of certified mail. Last week, we received about 20,000 to 30,000 pieces a day. If it weren't for the I.R.S., our certified mail would be about 20 to 30 pieces." DAVID CENG, owner of Tung Hoi II Chinese Take Out: "Fridays are the busiest days. Sometimes they order 20 or 30 lunches. The most popular dish is sesame chicken." JOE COTICCHIO, chief of the volunteer fire department: "The town owns the building and the I.R.S. rents it, but they pay no taxes. We go there three to four times a month because they have a lot of disabled people there who are sick and have to be taken to the hospital. We had a couple of big fires, but never around tax time." RICK KNOWLDEN, night-shift supervisor of the error-correction unit in the I.R.S. document-perfection branch: "In the minds of most people, the 15th will climax the season, but ours won't peak until the end of May." STEVE PRISCO, proprietor of the Holtsville Sports Deli: "They're big eaters. I.R.S. employees get to work at 8 in the morning and start thinking about lunch at 8:05."

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;Levine Can't Let Go of Mozart. Or the Met.
description: ON A RECENT WEEKEND at the Metropolitan Opera, a string of "Cosi Fan Tutte" performances ended, and the Mozart cast prepared to head in all directions: Carol Vaness to Houston to sing Norma, Dwayne Croft to Paris to sing Eugene Onegin, Cecilia Bartoli to Singapore to give recitals.

title: SIGNOFF;Prissy Teachers, Jell-O And Baby-Sitter Jokes
description: IT's Saturday night, and we're kicking back with big bowls of Spider-Man cereal with its marshmallowy spider symbols and watching "All That" on Snick, which is Saturday Night Nick, short for Nickelodeon.

title: The Company He Keeps
description: PETER MARTINS, BALLET master in chief of the New York City Ballet, sits on a red leather couch in his office, wearing jeans and a denim jacket. Just outside the doorway hangs a stage bill from a 1976 tour: George Balanchine, ballet master; Jerome Robbins, the company's other great choreographer; Lincoln Kirstein, general manager. The list of principals includes Martins, whose dancing embodied the brilliant, self-effacing technique that fueled Balanchine's ballets.

title: In the Region/Long Island;Designers' Showcase, With Option to Buy a Condo
description: VISITORS to a Designers' Showcase that opened here today at a 50,000-square-foot Tudor-style mansion overlooking Christopher Morley Park can do more than see how 40 designers have decorated its 60 or so rooms and 26 bathrooms. They can also shop for a new home.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Pipe Down and Hope for Best
description: There are many worse predicaments to be in. Patrick Ewing could be planning a parasailing adventure the first week of May, his locker-room cubicle already cleaned out. Derek Harper could be wearing a "Will Work for Minutes" sign around his neck, facing a free-agent market with only so many three-year deals to go around. The picture of Anthony Mason posting up in an Eastern European country, surviving on $200,000 and no shoe contract, is not a pretty one.

title: POSTINGS: It's the Time of Year for House and Garden Tours;A New Historic District And a Civil War Campsite
description: Self-guided house and garden tours this spring will offer close-up looks at the city's oldest and most recently designated historic districts -- Brooklyn Heights (1965) and St. George/New Brighton on Staten Island (1995) -- as well as Civil War drama: a re-enactment of an encampment of the 14th Regiment on the streets of Fort Greene in Brooklyn. Here is a sampling:

title: SPENDING IT;Nanny-Tax Tally of '95: Who Paid, Who Lied?
description: LAST Monday, a New York City couple met with their accountant to file their 1995 taxes. They had an income of $100,000, a hefty mortgage and a nanny the Internal Revenue Service knew nothing about. And they kept it that way.

title: BOOKEND;Books Without Voices
description: The subject is not esoteric or obscure nor are the means of expression ungraspable. These books aren't even sculpted. They are real, and so are the ropes, hooks, nails and wires. Pfeiffer's eloquence lies in his unambiguous candor. With blunt ingenuousness he has conceived an image for the descent of intolerance into brutality, for the murderous resentment that is inspired by heterogeneous intellect and unruly imagination -- an image that embodies the authoritarian impulse to prohibit the access of mind to mind.

title: ASIA-PACIFIC ISSUE;A WORLD OF CHOICES: Bangkok
description: Tourism is perhaps the highest art form of modern Thailand, proof of the nation's energy and ingenuity. The more thoroughly traditional culture is crushed under the steamroller of modernization, the more its gems are preserved and polished for foreign visitors.

title: World News Briefs;Marines Land in Liberia To Guard U.S. Embassy
description: Marines arrived in Monrovia today to take over security at the American Embassy and dozens more foreigners trapped in factional fighting were flown to safety.

title: BENDING THE RULES -- A special report.;Where a Zoning Law Failed, Seeds of a New York Revival
description: In a moment of panic in 1974, as manufacturing jobs were disappearing by the tens of thousands in New York, the city tried to lock in its past as a burly, blue-collar colossus. A new planning blueprint was imposed, severely limiting uses for anything but manufacturing across nearly 14 percent of the city's land area, more than 20,000 acres.

title: Word for Word: Chernobyl Witnesses;After Meltdown, Unsung Heroes Talk of Rads, Duty and Vodka
description: NUCLEAR safeguards were at the top of the agenda last week as President Clinton and other leaders gathered in Moscow for a nuclear summit conference. The meeting coincided with 10th-anniversary commemorations of the explosion and fire at the Chernobyl reactor complex in Ukraine, which killed untold numbers of people and spewed radiation across much of Europe.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE;1908 Bathhouse in Search of Its Past and a Future as a Gym
description: The tiny, plastic-coated sign is a mysterious invitation, fastened to the fence surrounding the abandoned hulk of an old gym and bathhouse at Fourth Avenue and President Street. The new owner, Eric Richmond, hopes the marker will help him dredge up clues to the bathhouse's heyday, now nearly forgotten.

title: It's Lonely for the U.S.;Walking Loudly, Carrying Trade Rules
description: THE arsenal of the economic age is trade sanctions, and these days it sometimes seems as if President Clinton's advisers can think of nothing else.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Wainwright House in Rye misstated the amount that a donor has offered to keep the property from being sold. It is $100,000 a year for 10 years, not $10,000 a year.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: Monday

title: Lodgings in Miami
description: To the Editor: I was dismayed to read a recommendation of the Mermaid Guest House in Miami Beach ("What's Doing in Miami," Jan. 21).

title: WEDDINGS;Allison D. Dettra, T.N. Taravella
description: Allison Denise Dettra, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Dettra of Fort Montgomery, N.Y., was married yesterday in the Cadet Chapel of the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., to Timothy Nathaniel Taravella, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Taravella of Newburgh, N.Y. The Rev. Wayne Conrad, an uncle of the bride who is a United Methodist minister, officiated. The Rev. Owen Mullen, a Roman Cath'lic priest, took part in the service.

title: WEDDINGS;Didi L. Bender, Frederick Romley
description: Didi Lynn Bender, the daughter of Carol and William Bender 3d of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Frederick Michael Romley, a son of Mary Romley of Glendale, Calif., and the late Fred Romley. The Rev. Charles Temple, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Transfiguration in New York.

title: SPOTLIGHT;Race to Safety
description: In Carol Reed's NIGHT TRAIN TO MUNICH (1940), a bold Briton (Rex Harrison) rescues an abducted scientist (Felix Aylmer) and his daughter (Margaret Lockwood, above) from Nazi headquarters. Next to the these three sits a sharp-eyed Nazi officer (Paul Von Hernried - he changed his name in Hollywood). And up pops that sporty duo, Basil Radford and Naunton Wayne, from Hitchcock's "Lady Vanishes." Did they switch trains? This brisk thriller has the same screenwriters, the same heroine, the same edgy flavor and a nifty cable-care cligghanger. Good stuff. Move over, Hitch - TUES. at 8 P.M. on CHANNGEL 31; and THUR. at 2 P.M. and THURS.-FRI. at 3 A.M. on CHANNEL 55.

title: ART;32 Pictures That Are Show's Guests, Eclectic and Transcending Borders
description: INCONGRUITIES at the old Paramount Theater here begin with the Pop-style marquee that projects from a half-timbered facade, which, in size if not craftsmanship, would have dazzled the medieval inventors of the style. They continue inside with an upstairs corridor that is hung not with photographs of the stars but with an exhibition of paintings.

title: SOAPBOX;'Take Our Daughters'? Always Have
description: IN the Virgin Islands, my mother worked as a maid for Mr. Sebastian, the European proprietor of a white-owned store on Main Street. As a small boy, I'd come to work with her each day; I remember that she once slapped my face after I'd used his bathroom. (I later understood that I shouldn't have flushed: water was scarce on the island. But how was I to know? We blacks didn't have indoor plumbing at all.)

title: Those Young Faces in the Cockpit
description: The boys, ages 12 to 14, peered intensely at their instructor, their red textbooks open to Lesson 23: "Emergency Procedures, Wind Shear, Turbulence." The instructor, John Calla, began. "What are some types of emergencies?," he asked. "Engine failure," one student said. "Electrical fire," said another. "Ice," someone else piped in.

title: PREGNANCY, UNSEATED
description: Offering one's seat has less to do with gender issues and everything to do with empathy, awareness and a respect for the physical needs of others. Schiffren raises important issues, then obscures them with a heavy ideological brush.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;Jewish History Museum Opening in Los Angeles
description: WALKING through the Skirball Cultural Center, a new Los Angeles museum and sprawling complex celebrating the American-Jewish experience, Dr. Uri D. Herscher, the founder and president, paused at a multiscreen exhibit depicting the way Jews and other groups arrived in the United States at the turn of the century.

title: THEATER;'Jerusalem' at the Schoolhouse
description: THE new play at the Schoolhouse could do for tourism in Jerusalem what Alfred Hitchcock and Janet Leigh did for taking showers in shabby motels.

title: ART;The Artist, in Personal as Well as Commercial Mode
description: TYPICALLY, artists who don't live off their creative work support themselves by waiting tables or in construction jobs. It's a lucky one indeed who doesn't have to make much of a switch between art and livelihood. That is the case with six New England photographers in "Camera Work" in Akus Gallery at Eastern Connecticut State University in Willimantic. They make what the curator, Peter Barr, calls art photography, but then they take a short step into the more lucrative realm of commercial photography.

title: WEDDINGS;Randy J. Kass, Glenn R. Reiser
description: Randy Jill Kass, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Kass of Atlantic Beach, L.I., is to be married today to Glenn Richard Reiser, a son of Harriet Reiser of Boca Raton, Fla., and the late Erwin Reiser. Rabbi Brooks Sussman is to perform the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: WEDDINGS;Lucinda F. Ryan, William Stewart
description: Lucinda Fortune Ryan, a daughter of Ann McNamara of Far Hills, N.J., and the late Clendenin J. Ryan, was married yesterday to William Loughridge Stewart, the son of the late Mp. and Mrs. H. Dorn Stewart Jr. The Rev. Rod Brown performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church of the Holy Trinity in Oxford, Md.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Finding Colorful Characters in a Search for Self
description: ONE summer day in 1950, 19-year-old Mack was watching a game of "kick the can" when his left eye got in the way of the can. What was the young man, forevermore to be called One-Eyed Mack, to do about his dream of becoming a state highway patrolman, just like his dad. Or a cross-country bus driver?

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;European Cafe of Pre-Cappuccino Era Is Brewing Changes
description: It is one of a handful of businesses on West 72d Street that have not had a makeover in decades. But not even Eclair, the "Russian Tea Room of the Upper West Side," is immune to change.

title: Nile in Style
description: To the Editor "The Nile in High Style" (Feb. 25) brought back memories of the trip my wife and I took several years ago, which was the same, including a stay at the Mena House with a view of the pyramids.

title: April 14-20;Mercy, L.A. Style
description: If there was ever a crime that invited the death penalty, parricide is probably it, or so many people thought when Erik and Lyle Menendez were convicted of murdering their parents.

title: A Compulsion for Music
description: ALEC WILDER IN SPITE OF HIMSELF A Life of the Composer. By Desmond Stone. Illustrated. 244 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $30. ALEC WILDER spent his life looking for cracks to fall through. Though he wrote three songs that became standards ("I'll Be Around," "While We're Young" and "It's So Peaceful in the Country"), most of his "popular" music was too delicate and introspective to please a mass audience; though he composed hundreds of works for some of America's greatest instrumentalists, these "classical" pieces were too strongly colored by jazz and popular music to win critical acceptance. Today, he is mainly remembered for his groundbreaking book "American Popular Song: The Great Innovators, 1900-1950," surely the wittiest work of musical analysis ever written -- and one that characteristically has nothing whatsoever to say about Wilder's own songs, even such miniature masterpieces as "I See It Now" and "Did You Ever Cross Over to Sneden's?"

title: Legends. Champions?
description: HE COACH WAS A WATCHFUL MAN, AND HE'D sensed the trouble coming. Even as his Chicago Bulls skimmed through the N.B.A.'s marathon grind at a record-winning pace, even as they loomed as a team for the ages, Phil Jackson could feel the ions in the air long before the storm touched down in East Rutherford, N.J., on March 19.

title: ON THE STREET;When the Woman Wears the Dress (Not Vice Versa)
description: A woman, far right, rushing along Madison Avenue last week presented a terrific example of the customer as the final arbiter of how designer clothes can be personalized and adapted to each customer's sense of style.

title: WORD & IMAGE;Intellectual Popcorn for the Net
description: THANKS TO ESTHER DYSON, I'VE BEEN reviewing the assets of The New York Times, and I find them seriously but fortunately undervalued -- not in any legal way that would offend the authorities, but in an analytical sense that bears on the future of news purveyors in the digital age. As we hurtle into cyberspace, we peddlers of information had better learn to reassess the worth of our intellectual capital.

title: GEORGE BURNS;Good-Natured Mortal
description: To the Editor:

title: WEDDINGS;Susan L. Loring, Hugh G. Crane
description: Susan Lynn Loring, a daughter of Barbara Loring and Dr. Robert Loring of St. George, S.I., was married yesterday to Hugh Geoffrey Crane, a son of Jeanne and John Crane of Ann Arbor, Mich. A justice of the peace in St. Kitts, British West Indies, performed the ceremony at Ottley's Plantation Inn.

title: Sculptor's Work for School Reflects an Enduring Kinship
description: Alton Tobey had been standing in his studio for an hour, discussing the impetus for his life-size cement sculpture of Mentor and Telemachus. Responding to a suggestion to sit down while talking, the 81-year-old artist declined. "I don't need to sit down," he said, bristling only slightly.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: RUNNERS' DERBY

title: RESTAURANTS;Right at Home
description: IN case you're wondering if the painting that you're admiring at Nadia is the original "Pique-Nique" by Ferdinand Botero, it is.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE AGE OF EXTREMES: A History of the World, 1914-1991 By Eric Hobsbawm. Vintage, $16.

title: ASIA-PACIFIC ISSUE;A WORLD OF CHOICES: Taipei
description: Taipei lacks both charm and beauty, a rather damning assessment on the face of it. But beneath the gray, polluted skies, the monotonous low-rise buildings and the mad scooter drivers who swarm the roads, it remains the most vital and vibrant city in the Chinese-speaking world. The back lanes of every neighborhood (just walk behind whatever hotel you stay in) are crammed with cafes, tea houses, restaurants, herbal medicine stalls and pocket temples. The city is changing daily, adding buildings, restaurants, shopping centers. Nonetheless, visitors tend to come to Taiwan primarily for what is older, enduring, traditional.

title: Stonewalling on Iran
description: When the Clinton Administration secretly approved Iranian arming of Bosnia in violation of a United Nations embargo two years ago, it made a policy blunder and slighted its constitutional responsibility to keep Congress and the American people informed. Now it compounds the offense by suppressing the report of a White House agency that investigated the legality of the episode.

title: The View From: Westport;A Hunt Club Setting, Antiques Rampant
description: IT'S a springtime shot in the arm. Attracting 5,000 to 6,000 dedicated collectors -- as well as those who attend just for the joy of looking -- the 32d annual Southport-Westport Antiques Show will open at the Fairfield County Hunt Club, on Long Lots Road in Westport, on Thursday.

title: OLYMPICS;Competitors Keeping Olympic Test in Mind
description: Dominique Dawes had just made a mess of her uneven bars routine Friday night, and she doubled over, covered her eyes with both hands and sobbed. Nearby, Svetlana Chorkina's face was also streaked with mascara and tears, but Chorkina was on her way to victory.

title: Pataki's Dream Ads: Pick 6 for Education
description: Taking their cue from Gov. George E. Pataki's new criterium for the lottery ad campaign -- that it emphasize social benefits -- several advertising agencies and designers imagined how they might fashion such a pitch. The current campaign, "Hey, You Never Know," appeals, the Governor said, to humankind's thirst for "instant riches" -- mansions and yachts, for instance. He urged it be balanced with a new campaign stressing that the lottery raises money for schools. Here, solicited by The New York Times, are some possible campaigns that the Governor may not have had in mind.

title: LIVES;Outer City Blues
description: People think we're joking when my husband and I say that after almost two decades in the country we've just moved back to the city to improve our quality of life. Perhaps it's because our move runs counter to the popular fantasy of leaving the stressful, dirty city for a place where daily existence still retains a few charms from an earlier era: trees, pure air, safe neighborhoods, decent public schools.

title: 2 Opinions On Parking On Roads At Beaches
description: IN the summer the North Fork expects waves of tourists. But with the trend of wineries and farm stands to remain open after Labor Day and anglers finding that the bluefish are biting, the busy season has been expanding to November.

title: Route 6 Uproar In the Quiet Corner
description: DEAD corn stalks poke out from a farmer's field along the roadside, under the flickering embers of a late afternoon sun. The rolling landscape of Coventry seems to stretch on forever, and the sight of angular clapboard homes spread far apart among the hillocks suggests a Connecticut before the age of the automobile, perhaps even rail.

title: Chinatown Friction Involves Law, Not Ethnic Differences
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOOLS;Caught in the Middle, a School District Tries to Survive a Budget Squeeze
description: With a per capita income of $15,024 and a declining tax base, this Middlesex County town is not in a position to overhaul its lackluster schools. Businesses are moving to more promising locales, and residents stand firm against tax increases. So the schools crumble, the textbooks fade and the chance for improvement shrinks with each budget cycle.

title: Security at Fordham
description: To the Editor:

title: Not So Easy
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: DRAWN WITH THE SWORD Reflections on the American Civil War. By James M. McPherson. Oxford University, $25.

title: Black Like Them
description: The Future of the Race By Henry Louis Gates Jr. and Cornel West. 196 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $21.

title: And Miles to Go
description: THE older I get, the more I love to travel. I've always wanted to see the world, but never so urgently as since I turned 50 and faced up to the mathematical discrepancy between the years I have left to live and the places I have left to see.

title: Late-Blooming Novelist and the Picaresque
description: MORE than a dozen years ago, Alan Isler began to write his first novel for his own amusement.

title: Eccentric Circles
description: PECULIAR PEOPLE The Story of My Life. By Augustus Hare. Edited by Anita Miller and James Papp. Illustrated. 303 pp. Chicago: Academy Chicago Publishers. $26.95.

title: Death Penalty Spurs Readiness for Lawyers
description: THE first defendant in a crime that could lead to the death penalty will find that lawyers in Westchester have been preparing long and hard to prosecute or defend him. There is no doubt that District Attorney Jeanine Pirro will seek the death penalty where she feels it is appropriate.

title: Sour Spring for Mr. Dole
description: The return of Congress after its spring recess was planned by Republicans as a season made for the leadership talents of Bob Dole. But it has not worked out that way. Instead of running the Senate like a fine machine, churning out legislative accomplishments, Mr. Dole stumbled last week through a series of fiascos that betrayed confusion and uncertainty about the direction he intends to lead his party and, if elected, the country.

title: PREGNANCY, UNSEATED
description: I recently offered my seat on a Madison Avenue bus to a well-dressed, briefcase-carrying, very pregnant woman. Her response: "I don't want your seat. I'm pregnant, not disabled." Rather than give offense, I may keep my seat next time.

title: New Blood for the Big Three's Plants
description: JUST over a year ago, Tammy M. Nedzweckas quit her $10,000-a-year job as a restaurant cook and started working the night shift at a Ford Motor Company plant here, earning $31,000 a year. Every minute and 15 seconds, she twists an air-conditioning valve cap on a Bronco or a pickup, slams the hood shut and clambers up behind the wheel to drive the truck around the corner. Then she hurries back on foot to tighten the next cap.

title: COPING;Why My Art Dealer Moved to 57th Street
description: MY art dealer, Franklin Parrasch, recently moved from SoHo, which was reminding him of his native New Jersey, to West 57th Street, which is again "the center of the art scene." He says.

title: Poetic Anger
description: DARK FIELDS OF THE REPUBLIC Poems 1991-1995. By Adrienne Rich. 79 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. Cloth, $25. Paper, $10.

title: Mr. Speaker
description: BALANCE OF POWER Presidents and Congress From the Era of McCarthy to the Age of Gingrich. By Jim Wright. Illustrated. 528 pp. Atlanta: Turner Publishing. $25.95.

title: Federal Budget Knife May Cut Aquaculture
description: A FEDERAL aquaculture laboratory that helped make Connecticut a leading producer of oysters -- and is poised to revive the state's scallop industry -- may be eliminated in the 1996-97 Federal budget.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;3 Madrid Shows Mark Goya's 250th Birthday
description: An extensive exhibition of Francisco de Goya's paintings at the Prado in Madrid recently opened, marking the 250th anniversary of the artist's birth in the northeastern village of Fuendetodos.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;Door Slams on Bailey House's Bid for a New Building
description: Bailey House thought it had a deal. The second oldest AIDS organization in the city, one that provides housing with health and other services for homeless people with AIDS, was well on its way to opening a 30-unit program for families headed by mothers with AIDS in East Harlem. The community board supported the project, and so did the surrounding neighbors. Everything was falling into place.

title: SOMETHING'S GOT TO GIVE
description: Frey's article misses the point and creates an unfair impression of America's air traffic controllers and the Federal Aviation Administration. United States controllers are first-rate professionals whose hallmark is excellence. They are at the core of the world's safest and most efficient aviation system.

title: Until Convention, Dole Faces A Budget Squeeze of His Own
description: Having spent $5.3 million last month, Bob Dole now has only $2 million left to spend on his Presidential campaign between now and the Republican convention in August, according to his financial report filed today with the Federal Election Commission.

title: Ken Doherty, 90, Longtime Penn Relays Director
description: Ken Doherty, a track and field athlete, coach and author and the longtime director of the Penn Relays, died Friday in Lancaster, Pa. He was 90.

title: ON LANGUAGE;Presumptives and Presumptions
description: THE FINANCIAL Times and just about every other news publication refer to Senator Bob Dole as "the presumptive Republican Presidential nominee." Likely and probable (not certain enough) and all-but-certain (too many words) have fallen by the wayside of campaign coverage. "Presumptive nominee" has assumed the status of bogus title, appearing before, rather than after, the person's name.

title: The World;Finally, Japan May Have a Future in the Military
description: FOR the last 50 years, Japan has sat out Asia's disputes, its armed forces limited strictly to self-defense. Now, that may be changing. The Japanese-American summit meeting in Tokyo last week may be remembered as a milestone -- the occasion when Japan took the first steps on a long journey to exorcise the ghosts of war and take up a role in international security.

title: BASEBALL;Yankees Lose a Lead, but Then Steal It Back
description: Sweating and smiling as he stood in front of his locker, John Wetteland explained how he finally wriggled through a tense ninth inning in a tense game by stranding two runners and giving the Yankees a 7-6 victory over the Twins at the Metrodome tonight.

title: Abortion Bill's Veto Assailed by Vatican
description: In an unusually severe attack, the Vatican has condemned as "shameful" President Clinton's veto of a bill that would have banned a kind of late-term abortion procedure.

title: Modern Holocaust Memorial: Thesis of Victim on Internet
description: Ela-Chaim Cunzer died in the winter of 1944, far from his family, without a tombstone, without even a grave. His life was truncated before its vivid promise could be realized, his mathematical work and dreams reduced to a single digit among the digits that added up to the six million Jews who died in the Holocaust.

title: Leaves Piling Up in Street? Why Not Compost Them?
description: To the Editor:

title: Redoing Cyrano, This Time With a Twist

title: DINING OUT;Where the Props Are Misleading
description: THE visual symbols of the interior might discourage one from dining here, and that, alas! would be a mistake. For their theme restaurant, the owners of Laredo have chosen props straight from a "B" western of the 1950's. But once the food arrives, diners will not cavil about the fake cactus or the mounted animal skull and will find that Laredo is not a run-of-the-mill Tex-Mex eatery.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;It's Their Album. They'll Cry if They Want To.
description: IT'S OFFICIAL: AMERICA'S NEW national pastime is self-pity. There's so much to sulk about -- economic insecurity, social disorder, frustrating jobs, romances going wrong and, for baby boomers, the inevitable responsibilities and disappointments of aging. And now, self-pity no longer means suffering in silence. In the 1990's, it's a proud, gutsy misery, strong enough to shape a whole identity. Politicians cater to it, offering scapegoats and palliatives; talk shows parade self-styled victims. And popular music, always the vent for troubled feelings, has groaned and whined its way through the decade.

title: Turning Up the Temperature On the Way to . . . Carmen?

So it speaks volumes that Anne Sofie von Otter, the Swedish mezzo-soprano who makes her long-awaited New York recital debut at Alice Tully Hall this afternoon, cites her vast choral experience as the foundation for the rock-solid vocal technique and immaculate musicianship that have propelled her to the top ranks of today's classical vocalists.

title: WEDDINGS;Lynda Montgomery, Mikkael Sekeres

title: STYLE;Barneys Bashing
description: The announcement, in January, that Barneys New York was filing for bankruptcy has prompted an outcry so gleeful and vindictive that it seems out of all proportion to the event itself, when you consider that the event is the financial collapse of a mere store. "The tyranny of fabulousness" is the term one gloating pundit used to describe the power that Barneys seems to have wielded over innocent, upstanding citizens who wanted nothing more than to go about their business, oblivious to fashion. In magazines and in newspapers (including this one), writers claim to have been oppressed by style in general and by Barneys in particular to such an extent that one begins to suspect some underlying grudge of long standing. They talk as if the store were staffed by that clique of cool kids in junior high who wouldn't let the rest of us sit at their table in the cafeteria.

Two giant Oscar cut-outs survey the dance floor like flat, sexless totems, and tropical flowers and trees on the bandstand, the tables, and the bar of this retro-glam supper club on West 43d street, welcome guests in from the cruel cold outside. There's even a replica of those arid Western hills and the famous outsized letters that rise before them, except something's not quite right here: instead of Hollywood, the sign reads, "Mollywood".

title: Fun at the Gym: On the Balance Beam, Doing Cartwheels
description: FAIRFIELD COUNTY GYMNASTICS, in Fairfield, has been in existence for 14 years and has a membership of 375. The owner and founder, Elaine Audy, has seen her youngsters achieve goals, gain self-confidence and have fun, which is the real point. "Gymnastics should enhance their lives, not kick everything else out," she said. "You don't have to be a star." To her, the Olympics has become too focused on the individual and the gymnasts are portrayed badly when they fail. "I highlight the kids' successes," she said, "and not the things they can't do."

title: All Germans Look Alike

IT is a part of the legacy of the Holocaust that 50 years on, many commonly held views of Germany are tainted by the very qualities that are being criticized. In other words, the critical point of view may itself be entrenched in prejudice. Intolerance is indeed to be found in Germany -- lots of it -- but no less in the eye of the beholder who is unable or unwilling to differentiate between individual Germans.

title: TELEVISION;So Famous, Such Clout, She Could Interview Herself

Simpson's former lawyer, who sits opposite her in uneasy anticipation of an interview that will be shown on the ABC news-magazine program "20/20." Mr. Shapiro is promoting his circumspect new book on the Simpson trial; Ms. Walters needs him to say something more interesting, and new. A nice tension fills the air. "Sit up straight," Ms. Walters tells Mr. Shapiro. And then, intensely: "I know you don't want to trash anybody. On the other hand, you don't want to do an interview that's so bland that nobody cares."

title: Books in Brief: FICTION;Furtive Glances
description: Mori Ogai's novel THE WILD GOOSE (Center for Japanese Studies, University of Michigan, cloth, $28.95; paper, $14.95) is a small book that gives immense pleasure. Eloquently understated, it provides a lyrical account of the thwarted romance between a Tokyo medical student and a young woman who is the mistress of a dull middle-aged moneylender. Written early in this century and translated here with an insightful introduction by Burton Watson, the narrative illuminates the rigid social order of Japan in the 1880's, an era when that country's rapid Westernization was just beginning. Okada, the story's protagonist, is noted for his good looks and virtue. Yet despite his heroic nature, he can't rescue Otama from her fate. The relationship of Okada and Otama consists of furtive glances, a smile, the tip of a hat -- and Okada's rescue of a pet bird from a snake. The novel's disarming power grows from its minimal plot, its muted descriptions of the two main characters and its narrative viewpoint (the action is seen in flashback through the eyes of one of Okada's schoolmates, a technique that provides esthetic distance). Spare, symbolic imagery reinforces our understanding of all the characters, particularly the women, whose only available responses to disappointment are silent suffering and dissembling. Mr. Watson's introduction outlines the autobiographical elements in the story, and a careful reader may discern Ogai's intimations that he is writing a new kind of fiction. Certainly he was influenced by his substantial reading of European writers, and he ranks as one of the key innovators of modern Japanese literature -- but the success of "The Wild Goose" rests on its timeless portrayal of the clash between social caste and romantic love. Gardner McFall

description: A gorgeous Bay Area Rapid Transit station recently opened in this town just south of San Francisco, but most of the people of Colma will not be using it to go anywhere.

title: In the Region/Connecticut;Nailing Jobs for Women in the Construction Industry
description: IN a good, hard-working year, Jo Ann Paradis, a grandmother from North Stonington, can make around $100,000 driving her $130,000 Kenworth tri-axle 14-wheeler to and from construction sites all over Connecticut, loading and dumping dirt and gravel.

title: Reporter's Notebook;Yeltsin Serves Visitors A Big Plateful of Politics
description: If the leaders of the world's richest countries had the slightest doubts about what has been on President Boris N. Yeltsin's mind lately, they disappeared Friday night at a sumptuous private dinner at the Kremlin Grand Palace.

title: WEDDINGS;Debra Scherer, Marcantonio Pinci
description: Debra Scherer, an editor at French Vogue in Paris, was married in New York last evening to Marcantonio Pinci, a partner in Dobson & Pinci, a law firm in Milan. Dr. Ronald Sobel, who is the senior rabbi at Temple Emanu-El in New York, performed the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel.

title: DINING OUT;Chinese Food With Flair and Flavor
description: WE first reviewed Hunan Gourmet in Greenwich in 1983 and found it very good indeed. But times change, and kitchens in Chinese restaurants are known for their revolving doors, with chefs moving in and out with alacrity.

title: Travel Advisory: Deals and Discounts;SAVINGS TO SAVANNAH
description: An air fare of $59 from Newark to Savannah, Ga., has been announced by Jet Express, a public charter service based in Smyrna, Ga. That price is good for every seat on every flight from May 16, when the Savannah service begins, to June 16. (Regular fares after June 16 will also start at $59 but range up to $129.) The line will fly daily except Tuesday using a Prestige Airways Boeing 727-200. There are no advance-purchase or Saturday-night-stay requirements. Tickets are nonrefundable but may be changed for a $25 fee. Information: (800) 386-2786.

title: Economics of Caring for the Aged
description: CLORINDA MORELLI turned 106 last week, celebrating the occasion quietly with her 80-year-old daughter, friends at the nursing home where she resides and, if not as many candles on the cake as years, then at least memories of a life well lived.

title: Planning an Insurance Trust
description: To the Editor:

title: ON PRO FOOTBALL;For the Draft Picks, Mother's Day Is Early
description: Draft day is for the fans. Especially the New York fans. They come to the Theater at the Garden and they cheer, they boo, they wear green and they wear blue.

title: Asia-Pacific Issue;Journey to a Sacred Mount
description: ALTHOUGH Mount Kailas, at 22,028 feet, is not one of the highest Himalayan peaks, it is among the world's most beautiful mountains. A delicately curved pyramid with a rounded top, its most striking feature is concentric bands of dark rock on which snow accumulates, forming stripes of black and white.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A Civil Night

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER EAST SIDE;2d Avenue's Case of Shakes
description: John Kolombos has never experienced an earthquake. But Mr. Kolombos swears he feels the earth move all the time at the Cooper Square Restaurant, his coffee shop on Second Avenue at Fifth Street.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 7 about life insurance trusts referred incorrectly to the tax consequences of failing to issue annual Crummey notices, which inform beneficiaries that they are entitled to dip into the trusts. Failure to issue such notices can make insurance premium payments subject to the unified gift and estate tax, not income tax.

title: Next Profession
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CLASSICAL VIEW;Words, Words, Words
description: LIBRETTISTS STARTED GETTING THEIR revenge with the advent of supertitles. The operatic singing voice had become so big and blowsy, and the opera house so large, that no one understood the words writers had so carefully put in singers' mouths. Increasingly, listeners were requesting specific knowledge. Texts electronically inscribed at the tops of prosceniums and, more recently, on the backs of seats offered at least crude answers. People had to read, not just listen.

title: Man Gets Death Sentences
description: An Air Force sergeant has been sentenced to die in the electric chair for hacking his wife and two children to death with a machete.

title: Q. and A.
description: Different Kinds of Air Rights

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Acura 3.5RL;Impersonating a Lexus: Exhibit A
description: I STOOD in the vegetable aisle of the supermarket, comparing a can of Green Giant Niblets with a can of the store-brand corn. The generic variety cost 39 cents, the Green Giant 73 cents. Assuming the quality is virtually the same, why the big difference in price?

title: Travel Advisory: Deals and Discounts;RIDING THE RAILS
description: Britrail has introduced a Kid's Pass program that allows each adult buying a Britrail Pass to receive a free pass of the same type and duration for a child aged 5 to 15. (Additional children's passes may be purchased for half the price of a regular adult pass, and children under the age of 5 travel free.)

title: DINING OUT;Part Family, Part Club, Part Restaurant
description: PICCOLO in Huntington may be the toughest reservation on the Island. Calling a week and a half in advance for a Saturday night resulted in a choice of 5:30 or 9 P.M. Even on a midweek evening there were diners waiting for a table at 9 P.M.

title: CHRISTOPHER SEES SYRIA CHIEF IN BID
description: Saying he expects "difficult discussions" during the next two days, Secretary of State Warren Christopher met tonight with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria on an emergency mission of shuttle diplomacy to try to establish a cease-fire in southern Lebanon and to "stop the killing" there.

title: INSIDE
description: Yet Another Vote in Italy

title: It's Not a Wage Gap But an Age Gap
description: Congress appears bent on raising the minimum wage in an attempt to accomplish by legislative fiat what many claim the economy can no longer do on its own: give low-income workers a bigger piece of the pie. What legislators perhaps don't understand is that if poor Americans can gain entry into the work force, even at low wages, they usually move up the economic ladder.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;When Life Is a Downer, He Takes Off in a Peach
description: Mystery Sciene Theater 3000: The Movie Trace Beaulieu, Michael J. Nelson, Jim Mallon, Kevin Murphy Directed by Jim Mallon PG 80 minutes

title: An Athlete's Dream, Only Half Realized
description: APRIL 12 should have been the culmination of a dream for Konstantine Starikovitch. On that Friday, almost five years after he arrived at Kennedy International Airport alone, with $136 in his pocket, unable to speak English and with no place to stay, the native of Podolsk, Russia, drove to Albany with his wife and was sworn in as an American citizen.

title: A FUNNY THING';Comedic Legacies
description: To the Editor:

title: MAKING IT WORK;Jim Gainey's Step Up
description: JAMES GAINEY will talk your ear off, and the point is he knows a thing or two.
