He has sat in the cab of an 18-wheeler on a rainy night thinking mainly about a cup of coffee 50 miles down the road, but also musing about why black people have had to put up with so much in this 220-year-old country. He has been in homeless shelters so bad he suspects prisons must be better. He has learned enough to reduce the lessons of a hard life to aphorisms, ones that rattle around in your mind for awhile.

title: PICTURING THE DYING;Some Want To Be Sustained
description: To the Editor:

title: April 14-20;. . . as Tinkering Forges Ahead
description: Republicans who opposed President Clinton's sweeping health care plan in 1994 kept saying that all the system needed was a little tinkering. Congress is on the verge of keeping their promise.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Napoleon's Suite at Fontainebleau Reopens
description: After 18 years of research and restoration by museum staff, the private apartments of Napoleon I at the Chateau de Fontainebleau opened to the public last month. The 800-year-old chateau reflects a variety of exterior styles, especially of the 16th century, and is famous for its 17th-century "horseshoe" exterior staircase. The palace is set in formal gardens and surrounded by forest.

title: The Conscious Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: FRANK J. MACCHIAROLA has had numerous titles in academia, Chancellor, vice president and dean among them. Now he will add "president." Now the dean of Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law at Yeshiva University, he has been named to the presidency of St. Francis College in Brooklyn, his alma mater.

title: Boy was Decoy in Slaying, the Police Say
description: Saying that his 4-year-old son needed to use the bathroom, a Bronx man won his way into another man's apartment yesterday, and then stabbed the resident to death during a robbery, the police said.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Vows Are Exchanged, Then Domestic Violence Rears Its Head
description: Donald Byrd is not only choreographically intelligent and imaginative, but unpredictable as well. Unlike choreographers who express all their ideas in a single style, Mr. Byrd lets the ideas he wishes to explore determine the manner in which he presents them. As a result, his dances are surprises.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;National Geographic To Martin Agency
description: The National Geographic Society in Washington has named the Martin Agency in Richmond, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle an assignment to create a national branding and membership development program, which will run in test markets. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million. Martin was selected after a brief review that also included two other finalists: Cliff Freeman & Partners, New York, which is owned by Cordiant P.L.C., and the Ogilvy & Mather Chicago unit of the WPP Group. Two other agencies continue on the National Geographic roster: Arnold Communications in McLean, Va., and Goldberg Marchesano Kohlman in Washington.

title: Vassar Helps 2-Year College Students Transfer Up
description: Willa Panvini, 28, was working in a series of dead-end clerical jobs, but she really wanted to become a pop singer. Elva Adams, 51, was ending a career at I.B.M. Bernetta Parson, 29, was determined to move beyond a frustrating receptionist's job.

title: The Fairfield Store Bows Out at 75
description: Finally the bargain hunters have found the Fairfield Store. It took the lurid orange "Going Out of Business Sale" signs in the windows fronting the Post Road here, because for 75 years the Manasevit family relied on traditional values to attract customers: high quality and personal service. When shoppers wanted less, the Manasevits decided this year that it was time to go.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Iva Silver was named creative director at Shepardson Stern & Kaminsky, New York, succeeding David McCall, who continues as chairman. Ms. Silver had been a group creative director at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about war victims buried in Sarajevo misstated the year in which the Winter Olympics were held there in some editions. It was 1984, not 1986.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Debate Over Area Codes
description: Sooner than expected, New Jersey's area codes are running out of numbers, and the telecommunications industry is divided over how to alleviate the overcrowding.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A New Phone Merger Creates a Giant in the East The merger of Bell Atlantic and Nynex, to be announced today, will create the second-largest telephone company in the United States after AT&T -- with $27 billion in sales, 127,600 employees and 36 million customers in 12 states. The impact on consumers is far from certain, since the two companies do not compete directly. [Page A1.]

title: Report on Jet Program
description: The investigative agency of Congress has recommended that the Pentagon consider canceling its most expensive weapons program, the $81 billion FA-18 Super Hornet, the next generation of the Navy's top fighter jet, a magazine reports.

title: THEATER REVIEW;An Albee Horror Story, Set in a Drawing Room
description: You may think you know the work of Edward Albee, but the chances are that you don't if you haven't seen the Lincoln Center Theater's immaculate, showy, very fine new production of "A Delicate Balance," which opened last night at the Plymouth Theater.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;New Scrutiny on Schools
description: A monitoring team appointed by the State Department of Education will begin a two-week review today to find out whether Atlantic City's public schools are taking the steps recommended last year after the district failed to meet standards for recertification.

title: Albert Beich, 77, Writer for Stage and Film
description: Albert Beich, a screenwriter and playwright who was a co-writer of the 1958 Broadway play "The Man in the Dog Suit," died on March 30 in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 77 and lived in Scottsdale.

title: This Time, Atlanta Finds College Crowd More Orderly
description: The movable street party that is the Atlanta black college student spring break, or Freaknik, was markedly less rowdy this year, judging by official arrest counts and the unofficial estimates of those attending the annual event.

title: The Strange Competition With China's News Agency
description: When the official New China News Agency announced three months ago that it would start supervising international agencies that sell financial information in China, that decision was widely interpreted as an effort by the Communist Party to protect itself from the swelling pool of information available here.

title: FOOTBALL;War Room Stayed Calm Despite Giant Changes
description: As the National Football League draft began to take unexpected twists and turns on Saturday and the Giants were left holding a first-round pick that was suddenly devalued, two things happened that made the team's draft different from last year's and even those of recent years.

title: O'Connor Backs Criticism Of Clinton Abortion Veto
description: Responding to accusations that the Roman Catholic Church was interfering in a Presidential election, John Cardinal O'Connor, the Archbishop of New York, yesterday defended the church's right to criticize President Clinton's veto of a bill outlawing some late-term abortions.

title: Abroad at Home;The Old Dole
description: The first time Bob Dole ran for national office, as Gerald Ford's Vice-Presidential candidate in 1976, he came on as a snarling heavy who denounced "Democrat wars." His nastiness helped to sink the Republican ticket.

title: Olympics Gets Atlanta Job Market Off to Fast Start and Surging Toward Wire
description: A predicted surge in temporary employment for the 1996 Summer Olympic Games here is beginning to show as job fairs sprout like crocuses and employers strive in a tight job market to fill the tens of thousands of jobs that are expected to pump nearly $2 billion in wages into the local economy.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bulls Finish 72-10 The Chicago Bulls wrapped up the best regular season in National Basketball Association history yesterday in Landover, Md., with their 72d victory, getting 26 points from Michael Jordan in a 103-93 thumping of the Washington Bullets.

title: BASEBALL;Franco Loses Lead And Hears About It
description: From the time it takes to make the long walk from the mound in the middle of Shea Stadium to the Mets' dugout, many in the crowd of 22,737 let John Franco know just how they felt about his ninth-inning collapse against the Colorado Rockies yesterday afternoon.

title: High Technology, Not Huddled Masses;U.S. Brokers Help Cutting-Edge Foreign Companies Come to Wall Street
description: Jo A. Lernout and his partner, Pol Hauspie, found new ways to allow computers to recognize speech and turn written text into the spoken word a few years ago. After starting a company in Belgium in 1987 to research and develop these products, they found customers ranging from AT&T to Samsung. By the middle of last year, they had decided to go public so that investors could discover them.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: MUSIC
description: Indian Classical Music, And the Audience Gasped Bismillah Khan and Vilayat Khan Town Hall

title: Brave New Ball Game
description: Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, Democrat of Scarsdale, has offered the quintessential New York solution to keeping the Yankees in the Bronx. If George Steinbrenner tries to flee to New Jersey, invoke eminent domain and have the state take over the team.

title: Sports of The Times;Graves's 2 'Ugly' Goals Save Day for Rangers
description: ADAM GRAVES thought the puck was still down there near his skates, but it wasn't. It had ricocheted to Mark Messier, who swooped down the ice and flipped it past Jocelyn Thibault for what appeared to be a 1-0 lead for the Rangers.

title: THE TELEPHONE COLOSSUS: THE NEGOTIATIONS;NYNEX AND BELL ATLANTIC REACH ACCORD ON MERGER; LINKS 36 MILLION CUSTOMERS
description: Ending a prolonged public courtship, the Bell Atlantic and Nynex Corporations agreed yesterday to one of the largest corporate mergers in American history, people involved in the negotiations said.

title: Treasury Auctions Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and two- and five-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and Wednesday. On Thursday a 52-week bill will be auctioned.

title: Defunding Mother Nature
description: The television networks and cable channels are falling over each other to satisfy a growing public appetite for nature programming. An article in The Times last week noted that wildlife programs, once the preserve of the Public Broadcasting Service, have spread like mangroves to NBC, Turner Broadcasting, the Discovery Channel and Disney, among others. This is welcome news. Quite apart from the fact that such programming is of a higher order than most television fare, its popularity is further evidence of what the polls have already told us. Americans care about what is left of their natural resources and the threatened creatures who inhabit them.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: IN PERFORMANCE: THEATER
description: A Married Man's Womanhood, With Dented Psyches in Tow 'The Boar's Carcass' Theater at St. Peter's Church

title: Giuliani Says He Is Open to Scaling Down Stadium Proposal
description: After weeks of touting the creation of a $1 billion multipurpose Yankee Stadium on the West Side of Manhattan, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he was open to other possibilities, even to the construction of a smaller, cheaper baseball-only ball park.

title: Irwin Takes Seniors Event
description: Hale Irwin, a rookie on the PGA Senior Tour, turned back a huge foreign challenge today to win the PGA Seniors' Championship. Irwin fired a closing round one-under-par 71.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Juno would be delighted to handle your E-mail free, but she would like something in return.
description: JUNO, the principal Roman goddess, wants to extend her hegemony into cyberspace. But even her husband, Jupiter, might evoke another mythological figure by describing her task as Herculean.

title: FOOTBALL;Phillips Appears in St. Louis
description: With his media coach standing behind him, Lawrence Phillips made his first public appearance since being picked No. 6 in the draft by the St. Louis Rams on Saturday. Phillips, who had stayed in the Los Angeles area rather than come to New York for the draft, flew into St. Louis yesterday, smiled for the cameras and made no excuses for his past behavior.

title: In America;Poison Numbers
description: The Cato Institute, a conservative think tank, released a study last fall that made the provocative claim that welfare families typically received a benefits package equivalent to $17,500 in income, and thus were doing much better than many working families.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Friday about the Bell Atlantic and Nynex Corporations misstated the debt listed on Nynex's balance sheet. As of the end of 1995, the company had $506 million in short-term debt and $9.3 billion in long-term debt.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: Mendelssohn's Exuberance, In the Cause of Symmetry Michael Mao Dance Kaye Playhouse

title: THE TELEPHONE COLOSSUS: STRATEGIES AND VISIONS;In This Marriage, Opposites Attract
description: Message to New York and New England residents: get ready for your telephone company to play hardball. Very hard.

title: ON BASEBALL;Amid Flaws, 2 Mets Stand as a Picture of Grace
description: Jason Isringh'usen, looking young enough to evoke images of Opie Taylor, stood in the Mets' clubhouse and spoke words of wisdom usually expected from a veteran:

title: Perot Suggests G.O.P. Sought Cash for Tricks
description: Ross Perot suggested today that Republican Party operatives had once asked him for $1 million to finance a political dirty tricks campaign.

title: Telekom Begins to Feel the Winds of Change
description: BERLIN  It was hardly a ringing endorsement for Deutsche Telekom AG and its hopes for a static-free privatization later this year when the German parliament voted to drop its high-priced domestic telephone carrier in favor of a U.S. competitor known as Worldcom.

title: Students Still Sweat, They Just Don't Shower
description: They might wear nose rings, shave their heads or sport tattoos on their who-knows-where. But among most American high school students these days, one thing is considered way too strange: showering with classmates after gym period.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Premiere Technologies Inc., Atlanta, to the Fitzgerald & Co. division of the Fitzgerald Cos., Atlanta, to handle the account of the telecommunications provider, which had been handled in-house. Another Fitzgerald unit, Julie Davis Associates, Atlanta, will handle public relations for the Premiere Worldlink Card. Total billings were estimated at more than $4 million. Quantel, Newbury, Berkshire, England, to Farago Advertising, New York, as first American agency of record for the digital equipment manufacturer. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million. The European portion of the account is handled by the CSA Partnership Ltd., London.

title: Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder, 76, Is Dead; a Sports Oddsmaker
description: Jimmy Snyder, known as "Jimmy the Greek," an oddsmaker and football personality who brought gambling to the forefront of televised sports but was fired by CBS Sports for saying that black Americans were better athletes than whites because of physical traits dating back to slavery, died yesterday in a Las Vegas, Nev., hospital. He was 76.

title: FOOTBALL;Jets Match Their Draftees to Their Needs
description: The Jets, who needed so much, continued to cull collegians in the exact order they needed them today, finishing their draft by taking two defensive backs and a defensive lineman.

title: Why Gay Couples Should Rally for Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay;Don't Gamble With Gamblers
description: Sometimes the good guys get so taken with the justice of their cause that -- as they approach their goal -- they blow the whole thing.

title: Murmur of Gore's Ambition Becomes Louder
description: Vice President Al Gore and his coterie of advisers have long had an unspoken pact that they would not directly talk about the delicate subject of his Presidential aspirations for 2000.

title: A Debacle For Israel
description: Whatever arrangements are made to stop the fighting in southern Lebanon, it is already apparent that Israel's military operation has been a painful failure and a diplomatic disaster.

title: MEDIA: WEEKLIES;With free distribution, The Village Voice echoes its owner's strategy in California.
description: The Village Voice's announcement in February that it would give away rather than sell much of its circulation surprised many people. But Stern Publishing Inc., which owns The Voice, has been auditioning that show out of town for more than a year.

title: Unearthing the Tales Of a Lost Settlement;Glimpses of Black History in a Place That Faded From Maps and Memory
description: They are easy to overlook, these four woodframe houses, simple and spare, the paint peeling from their facades.

title: Pennsylvania Is Ready to Give Dole a Victory, and Reason to Worry
description: When Bob Dole campaigned at an outdoor rally here last week and declared that "if Bob Dole carries Pennsylvania, Bob Dole will be the President of the United States come January," no one disagreed.

title: School Courtyard Holds Promise as Place of Peace
description: Loss is one subject that most of the students at Du Sable High School are forced to study long before starting the ninth grade. Situated in a weary section of the South Side, the school is surrounded by gangs, guns and ghosts of family and friends snatched away by violence in the streets.

title: Tobacco Documentary Died After a Lawsuit
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Trapped in a Nightmare World of Evil
description: A SINGLE SHOT By Matthew F. Jones 248 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.

title: G-7 Officials Hail Strong Dollar But Voice Concerns Over Europe
description: Officials from the seven largest industrial nations today welcomed the strengthening of the dollar over the last year, but they expressed concern about slow economic growth in Europe and pushed for debt relief for the world's poorest nations.

title: A Veto, a Condemnation and Possible Political Fallout
description: The Clinton Administration has found a happy alliance with the Roman Catholic Church on much of its social welfare agenda, from universal health insurance to preserving the basic safety net programs for the poor. But abortion has always been the great divider, and in recent days it has reasserted itself with a vengeance as a result of President Clinton's veto of a bill outlawing a form of late-term abortion.

title: INSIDE
description: Price of Crime Calculated

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;It's All Part of a Cycle, But Wheels Are Loose
description: When yesterday's Knicks-Celtics game mercifully ended, the Knicks (47-35) were headed to their lowest playoff seeding since 1991. The Boston Celtics (33-49) were headed for vacation.

title: World News Briefs;Australia Investigates Envoys and Pedophilia
description: The Minister of Foreign Affairs, Alexander Downer, said today that he would open an independent inquiry into reports supposedly connecting Australian diplomats in Asian countries to pedophilia.

title: Bernard Edwards, 43, Musician In Disco Band and Pop Producer
description: Bernard Edwards, the pop producer and member of one of disco's most popular bands, Chic, died on Friday in Tokyo. He was 43 years old and lived in Connecticut.

title: FOOTBALL NOTEBOOK;Passers Get Passed Up
description: Good quarterbacks are always the marquee players in the National Football League draft. Two went in the first five picks last year: Steve McNair, at No. 3, was taken by Houston and Kerry Collins, at No. 5, went to Carolina.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Imation Account To Ketchum Unit
description: Imation, the imaging systems and data storage company that will be spun off in July from the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, has chosen the Ketchum Advertising Pittsburgh unit of Ketchum Communications as its first agency of record. Billings were estimated at $14 million.

title: ON PRO FOOTBALL;Internet Lets Fans Ask Why
description: Gil Brandt, the former chief scout for the Dallas Cowboys, manned the National Football League's Internet connection for the draft this past weekend. Brandt said the majority of the E-mail questions he received were from Jets fans wondering why the team had taken receiver Alex Van Dyke of the University of Nevada with the first pick in the second round, No. 31 over all.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Broadcast Networks Losing Ad Dollars
description: Marketers will continue to shift advertising dollars from the broadcast television networks to other media as those networks continue losing viewers, according to an annual survey by DeWitt Media Inc., the media services agency in New York.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Parable of Lovers' Quest In Today's South Africa
description: Back in the 1960's, the choir Ladysmith Black Mambazo had a hit in South Africa with "Nomathemba," which means "hope" in Zulu. In it a girl named Hope leaves her village and her fiance; he seeks her in vain in the city and returns to the village brokenhearted, only to find her under a favorite tree. Given South Africa's history, no song about home is a simple love song. "Nomathemba," a new musical by Ntozake Shange, Eric Simonson and Ladysmith Black Mambazo's leader, Joseph Shabalala, brings the lovers' parable to post-apartheid South Africa, where new-found freedom runs up against poverty, desperation and bitter memories. It is being performed through May 19 at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts here.

title: Whom to Trust: Government or Stockbrokers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert J. Shaw, 79, TV Writer Known for 'Who Shot J. R.?'
description: Robert J. Shaw, who wrote the "Who Shot J. R.?" episode of "Dallas," which attracted the biggest television audience in history at the time, died on March 30 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 79.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHN CHAMBERLAIN will have the chance to see his work on the faces of hundreds of people tomorrow at a rally in Bryant Park. For the Victim Services organization, he has created a mask that depicts emotions of a victim of violence. The mask has been reproduced for the rally. People at the rally may wear it to symbolize the way they hide their feelings if they have been crime victims, or to symbolize a false sense of immunity, if they have not.

title: Communications Trade Pact Eludes the Big Economies
description: Trade ministers from four of the world's major economies said today that they had made some progress toward an agreement to liberalize trade in telecommunications. But the officials, who met over the weekend in the Japanese port of Kobe, said it was still questionable whether a global accord could be forged by the self-imposed deadline of April 30.

title: BASKETBALL;The Knicks' First Round, and Last Chance, Will Be in Cleveland
description: The Knicks earned the right today to return to the scene of their greatest regular-season crime, perpetrated last Thursday in Cleveland. Patrick, Oak, Mase and the gang will meet the Cavaliers in the first round of the playoffs, an event that will signify either the last great post-season run by this group of core players or merely a quiet burial of an era.

title: No Headline
description: These guys don't want to undress in front of each other. I just don't get it. When I started in '74, nobody even thought about things like this. The whole thing is just hard for me to accept."

title: World News Briefs;U.S. Hails Missile Talks With the North Koreans
description: United States officials today hailed two days of talks here with North Korea on its missile program as "a good beginning" and said the two sides planned more discussions at a later date.

title: Gift Saves an Unusual Journal
description: Double Take magazine, a critically acclaimed new journal of literature, reporting and photojournalism, edited by Robert Coles, the Harvard child psychiatrist, and Alex Harris, a Duke University documentary photographer, has received a $10 million grant from the Lyndhurst Foundation of Chattanooga, Tenn.

title: After Primaries, Districts Could Be a Family Affair
description: Across the open lands of central Pennsylvania, a father and son are hoping to ride the highways and byways of the Alleghenies to Capitol Hill.

title: After Imus Spoke, More and More Radio Affiliates Started Listening
description: Don Imus, the radio talk show host, is reaping the rewards of rudeness. Since his remarks about President and Mrs. Clinton, made to their faces at the Radio and Television Correspondents annual dinner last month, the "Imus in the Morning" show has been picked up by 10 additional stations.

title: Why Gay Couples Should Rally for Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;I.R.S. Indicts Consultant
description: The president of an Iselin-based computer consulting company was indicted last week in Federal court on charges that he failed to pay the Internal Revenue Service $320,000 that he withheld from his employees' paychecks from 1989 to 1991, the United States Attorney's office said.

title: First-Person Dole
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking In the Sites;Government Regulations, In Their Electronic Form
description: The newly hired chief executive at the Acme Widget Company, Betty Boss, wants to make sure that her business is in compliance with Federal regulations. Acme, a mythical manufacturing company with 432 employees that makes widgets, is subject to rules and regulations on safety, environmental practices, labor laws and trade. So, Ms. Boss turns to the World Wide Web to start her research.

title: HOCKEY;Lightning Tops Flyers Again
description: Aleksandr Selivanov's feet were as important as his stick.

title: BASEBALL;Better Late Than Never, Rogers Debuts
description: Why did the Yankees inexplicably wait before finally displaying Kenny Rogers? Why did they inexplicably tamper with their $20 million investment? The questions have existed since spring training and they reverberated throughout the Metrodome again today because Rogers looked dynamic in throwing a no-hitter for five and one-third innings. He made the Yankees look like dunces for a ludicrous delay in using him.

title: Patents;Beyond 'lather, rinse, repeat': formal steps to take the guesswork out of the application of cosmetics.
description: PUTTING on makeup is a personal action based on vague, universal principles. Now Justine Reynolds of Chester, N.J., has won a patent for a method of applying cosmetics.

title: New Questions On PAC Led By Gingrich
description: The political action committee once headed by Speaker Newt Gingrich, Gopac, worked on behalf of Republican state and local candidates without submitting required reports in some states.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;A Sharper Image For Sharper Image
description: The Sharper Image Corporation, the retail and catalogue merchant, has named the Goodby, Silverstein & Partners unit of the Omnicom Group in San Francisco as the first agency to create a corporate image campaign. Billings have not been determined.

title: OPERA REVIEW;Figaro and the Count in 1930's Spain
description: Give Frank Corsaro the benefit of the doubt, and assume that his decision to transport Mozart's "Nozze di Figaro" to Spain in the 1930's was not a random whimsy. Then the question becomes, does he actually hear jackbooted fascists clomping through Mozart's exquisite score, or espy them between the lines of Lorenzo da Ponte's subtle libretto?

title: Editorial Notebook: Hostility Toward the Gifted;The Life and Times Of P.S. 308
description: With its bunker-style design and slit windows gated in mesh, Public School 308 in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn is the essence of a fortress. The metaphor is right for a school that shelters children against drug dealers, gangs and hopelessness.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week.

title: Kashmiri Separatists Claim Delhi Bomb That Killed 17
description: Two separatist groups seeking to halt elections in Indian-ruled Kashmir took responsibility today for an explosion in central Delhi on Saturday night that killed at least 17 people, including 8 foreigners. At least 30 other people were injured in the blast.

title: Metro Matters;Local Politics Of 'Terror': New Curbs
description: WHAT does the new counterterrorism bill have to do with New York politics?

title: Schedule of Equity Offerings Set for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Bridge
description: If you double an expert in a part-score on the strength of a good trump holding, you must be resigned to the fact that the declarer will probably save a trick because he will know the position. On the diagramed deal from the Cavendish Invitational Pairs in Manhattan last May, the declarer was Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla., an expert's expert, and he was able to lay a clever trap when doubled in three diamonds.

title: Pooh's Playmate Dies
description: Christopher Robin Milne, immortalized as the young friend of Winnie-the-Pooh in the children's stories of his father, A. A. Milne, died on Saturday at 75. Page B12.

title: GOLF;Roberts Putts His Way to a Record and a Victory
description: The first whiff of salt air hit Loren Roberts flush in the face as he walked from the 17th green to the 18th tee today, carried on a freshening breeze off Calibogue Sound. It was an appropriate wind and a fitting odor, because after what Roberts had done to Mark O'Meara, to the rest of the field in the MCI Classic and to the Harbour Town Links golf course on this shiny afternoon, some smelling salts were in order.

title: Israel Eases Blockade on Assault's 11th Day
description: Israel has lifted its blockade on the port of Beirut, Lebanese officials said today, but it continued its air and artillery assaults on targets across southern Lebanon for the 11th straight day.

title: The City's New Fire Boss: From the Ladders to the Limousine
description: As his black Crown Victoria raced across the Brooklyn Bridge, Thomas J. Von Essen, the city's new Fire Commissioner, was already five minutes late for his first meeting with his new boss, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: HOCKEY;Relieved Rangers Are Back In Business
description: This was a delightful game on several levels, especially for the Rangers, who finally won one. By beating the Montreal Canadiens by 2-1 today, they ended their playoff losing streak at two games and their overall losing streak at seven.

title: Two Arrested in Machete Killing
description: A man and a woman from Coney Island were arrested on Friday in the killing of a 21-year-old Brooklyn man whose torso washed ashore near the boardwalk early Tuesday, the police said.

title: Do as They Say, Not as They Park
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC REVIEW;It's Funky And Jazzy, But Still Classical
description: If the New Juilliard Ensemble's program at Alice Tully Hall on Friday night had had a theme, it might have been the subtle, unstoppable influx of nonclassical material into contemporary classical music. Louis Andriessen's "Zilver" had more than a trace of funk; Sofia Gubaidulina's "Rubayat" and Jacqueline Fontyn's "Sul cuor della terra" carried a minor tinge of jazz, and Jerome Kitzke's "We Need to Dream All This Again" drew liberally on pop innovations and American Indian tradition. Milton Babbitt's "Arie Da Capo" might seem the odd work out in this regard, but its effortless conversational flow also had a jazzy feel.

title: Italian Vote Cheers the Left, but the Future Is Murky
description: A center-left coalition claimed a historic victory tonight in Italy's parliamentary elections, based on partial returns indicating that it would control the Senate and that it was close to winning a majority in the Chamber of Deputies.

title: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;Adapt karaoke for CD-ROM and what do you have? A copyright problem, it seems.
description: AS they careen into the information age, the media are increasingly becoming the butts of their own jokes.

title: SYRIA AND ISRAEL ARE STILL BALKING OVER A CEASE-FIRE
description: Hopes for a quick cease-fire in southern Lebanon and northern Israel dwindled today as both Syria and Israel insisted on a broader memorandum of understanding that would stop the fighting for longer than a few days, senior American officials said.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Insect Threatens Hemlocks
description: State forestry officials say they are now able to measure the threat posed by a tiny insect that has been sucking food reserves from Eastern hemlock trees in northern New Jersey. About 80 percent of the state's hemlock population is under attack from the hemlock woolly adelgid, an exotic insect that originates in the Far East, the State Division of Parks and Forestry reported last week.

title: Shuttle Found Lost Sections of Great Wall in '94
description: Segments of the Great Wall of China that have been lost in centuries of desert sand were discovered in radar images taken from the space shuttle Endeavour in April 1994, says a scientist with the space agency.

title: Memoirs Reveal Awe of Germany and Anger at U.S. : Mitterrand Views, for the Record
description: Francois Mitterrand's memoirs, to be published Monday, reveal that the former French president was an extraordinary admirer of Germany but also that he had no clear strategy for France during German reunification.

title: Whom to Trust: Government or Stockbrokers?
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Japanese Music of Today And a Posthumous Degree
description: The concert of contemporary Japanese music presented by Continuum on Saturday evening at the Miller Theater was part of a weekendlong commemoration of Kobo Abe, sponsored by the Donald Keene Center of Japanese Culture at Columbia University. Abe, who died in 1993, was associated with several of Japan's best-'nown composers, some of whom wrote scores for films made of his works. He also composed an appealingly tactile electronic score for one of his plays, "The Little Elephant." A tape was played before the concert and during the intermission.

title: As Cheyenne Fends Off a Bid, a War of Words Escalates
description: After last week's nasty battle between McAfee Associates and Cheyenne Software, the only clear thing so far is that there is no clear winner.

title: THE TELEPHONE COLOSSUS: THE CONSUMERS' CHOICES;Deal Produces Divided View Of Effects on Phone Service
description: Consumer advocates and regulators were sharply divided on the likely effects of a Nynex-Bell Atlantic merger on communications customers in the New York metropolitan area, but the two companies have carved out far different reputations when it comes to service.

title: Clinton and Yeltsin Accentuate The Positive at Summit Meeting
description: President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin emerged from a meeting in the Kremlin today effusively celebrating the American-Russian partnership even as they glossed over a host of policy differences.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-7

title: I.N.S. Detains African Woman Despite Lack of Security Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks Increase in Japan
description: Stocks rose here early today. In morning trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 135.45 points, or about six-tenths of 1 percent, to 22,019.29. On Friday, the Nikkei rose 71.34 points.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Baby Killed in House Fire
description: A 16-month-old girl was killed yesterday morning when fire broke out at a wood-frame house on Bryan Place, a few blocks from the PATH station, the authorities said. Firefighters battling the intense blaze were unable to reach the baby, Hoyane Samb, whose body was found on the second floor of the multiple-family dwelling, said Officer George Everett of the Jersey City Police Department.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Earth Day in a Canoe
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has often been photographed riding her bicycle. But today, in one of several Earth Day events on her schedule, the Governor will travel by canoe along the Rancocas Creek. She will also visit Stow Creek in Salem County to view bald eagles, an endangered species that was reintroduced to the area by the Department of Environmental Protection and wildlife groups.

title: Help New York's Media Entrepreneurs Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Both Sides Question Value of Unification : East-West Gap Looms Ever Wider
description: IN November 1989, when peaceful demonstrations in Communist East Germany triggered the opening of the Berlin Wall, the slogan was:"We Are The People."Soon the message of demonstrators changed to "We Are One People," leading to Germany's reunification in October 1990.Today, half a decade after those events, there are no demonstrations.But if there were, the signs would probably read:"We Are Two Peoples."

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Fasten Your Seat Belt And Gulp Your Valium
description: Now and then in the shaky flight of "Why Planes Go Down," mention is made of the high odds against being killed in an air crash (about three million to one), but reality is instantly ignored as the program jets on with its mission of scaring you out of your seat, if not your pants. Viewers are welcomed aboard this way, "Any number of things can go wrong when you fly, and when something does, there may be no worse way to die." If that isn't deterrent enough, you are put on notice that you might also catch the flu.

title: Dole Concedes Wage Increase Will Win Vote
description: Bowing to political reality, Bob Dole, who has strongly opposed increasing the minimum wage, said today that he expected the Senate to pass an increase but refused to say how he would vote.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: Scenes of Gossamer Unfurled Over the Top or Underneath Keely Garfield's Sinister Slapstick Dia Center for the Arts

title: Not So Harsh on Refugees
description: The ordeal of a young woman from Togo who came to America to avoid the practice of female genital mutilation should give members of Congress pause before they approve any further limitations on the rights of refugees seeking sanctuary in the United States. As detailed last week by Celia Dugger of The Times, Fauziya Kasinga was detained for months before she obtained a hearing, and she was strip-searched and held with convicted criminals. Shamefully, the anti-terrorism bill just passed by Congress and immigration bills still pending could subject many more refugees to similar treatment.

title: Militants in Egypt Threaten Americans With Retaliation
description: Two militant Islamic groups threatened today to kidnap American citizens and to target American and Israeli interests around the world with bombings and sabotage.

title: Survey Finds That Crimes Cost $450 Billion a Year
description: Crime costs Americans at least $450 billion a year, according to the most comprehensive survey ever done on the price of violence.

title: Christopher Robin Milne, 75, Pooh's Companion
description: Christopher Robin Milne, immortalized as the young friend of Winnie-the-Pooh in the children's stories of his father, A. A. Milne, has died, The Times of London reported today. He was 75.

title: Lexis-Nexis to Carry Bloomberg Services
description: Lexis-Nexis, one of the world's largest providers of on-line information, and Bloomberg L.P. are expected to announce today an alliance that will provide Bloomberg's business news and daily market summaries to more than 750,000 Lexis-Nexis subscribers, beginning in the second half of this year.

title: BASEBALL;Belle's Latest Target Is a Photographer
description: Albert Belle, the temperamental outfielder, threw a baseball that hit a photographer before a game two weeks ago, the Cleveland Indians confirmed today.

title: Paris Journal;Hot on His Trail: World's Police and an Ex-Wife
description: This town of weathered fieldstone houses, burnished church spires and flowering river walks likes to call itself the prettiest in Canada.

title: A Newspaper War, Texas Style, Grips a Suburb
description: Amon Carter disdained Dallas so much that every time he traveled there from his offices in Fort Worth, he conspicuously carried his lunch in a little paper sack, to let people know he would not spend a dime of his millions in Dallas County.

title: The Attack of the Summer Movies
description: It's the spring of Hollywood's discontent. And the summer doesn't look any happier.

title: SENIOR GAMES;'World's Greatest' Neither Floats Nor Gloats
description: While the two-day, 10-event competition at the recent International Senior Games was promoted as "The World's Greatest Athlete," it turned out to be something less than that, and, in a curious way, something more.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PAUL ROBESON JR. is not a musician himself, but his ties to music through his father run so deep that he is often asked to present awards to accomplished musicians.

title: Judge Wants Suburbs to Get Some Housing For the Poor
description: In the latest twist in an 11-year-old public housing desegregation suit, a Federal judge has issued an order intended to force the mostly white suburbs of Dallas to accept public housing. Should the suburbs resist, the ruling would require the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development to investigate whether the refusals violated civil rights laws.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Contract for Rail Station
description: The Board of Directors for New Jersey Transit has approved an $80 million contract for the continued construction of its Secaucus Transfer complex. The project will allow commuters on the old Erie Lackawanna Lines from Bergen, Passaic and Rockland counties to get off at a new station in Secaucus and transfer to Amtrak's Northeast Corridor Line, which goes directly to Manhattan.

title: Gunman Shoots 2 Brothers, Killing One, at Bronx Barber Shop
description: A feud between a man and two brothers erupted in gunfire yesterday morning at a barber shop in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx, leaving one sibling fatally wounded and the other critically injured, the police said.

title: SOCCER;With Top Players Still Out, So Is Verdict on MetroStars
description: The Giants Stadium crowd of 46,826 that watched the MetroStars lose by 1-0 to New England on Saturday night was a little smaller than the team expected for its home opener. But it was still a high number for a team that was missing its three top players -- and is clearly going nowhere without them.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Dr. Ronald Boyce Mackenzie, an epidemiologist, misspelled the name of the institute where he once worked. It is the Centinela Hospital Fitness Institute, not Centinella.

title: Violence Flares as Bosnians Try to Regain Prewar Homes
description: NATO troops in the sector of Bosnia under the control of American peacekeepers fired warning shots today to stop Bosnian Serbs from attacking Muslims trying to visit homes from which they were expelled during the war. NATO military officers and refugee workers said that the confrontation is likely to be one of many as Bosnian refugees -- Serbs, Muslims and Croats alike -- try to return home.

title: C. W. Petersmeyer, 77, Early Investor in TV
description: Charles Wrede Petersmeyer, who saw the financial potential in television when the medium was commercially introduced in the 1940's and was part of what became one of the nation's largest publishing and marketing concerns, died on Thursday at his home in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 77, and had been a longtime resident of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Whom to Trust: Government or Stockbrokers?
description: To the Editor:

title: HOCKEY;Hot Goalie Stymies Red Wings
description: The Winnipeg Jets rode the goaltending of Nikolai Khabibulin and a balanced scoring attack to shock the Detroit Red Wings, 4-1, yesterday after dropping the first two games of their first-round playoff series.

title: World News Briefs;Peacekeepers in Liberia Assert Control in Capital
description: Peacekeepers from West African countries asserted control over central Monrovia today, allowing residents to emerge into the capital's streets to search for food and clean water after two weeks of fighting.

title: Clinton Is Served Watered-Down Communism
description: Bill Clinton got a taste of Communism Lite today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;I.M.F. Moves to Diminish Surprise Element of Crises
description: Saying it had learned from the 1994 economic crisis in Mexico, the International Monetary Fund began pressing developing nations today to disclose more and better information about their financial condition and warned investors that they should not count on internationally financed bailouts in the future.

title: TV SPORTS;An Announcer Knows Her Game
description: Suzyn Waldman arrived in her Kansas City hotel room late Sunday night, flipped on ESPN and absentmindedly watched "SportsCenter" until she heard her voice, as if from another dimension, call a play from that day's Yankees-Twins game. "I looked up and I could hear myself!" she said. She called her mother, then watched the replay several more times yesterday morning.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PHYSICIANS RESOURCE GROUP INC., Dallas, said it had agreed to buy 10 eye-care practices in Texas, Ohio, California and South Carolina for a total of $23.5 million in cash and stock.

title: Summitry and Politics in Moscow
description: Bill Clinton and Boris Yeltsin proved again over the weekend that it is impossible to separate diplomacy from domestic politics, especially in an election year. In a series of stage-managed meetings in Moscow, the two Presidents nudged relations a bit closer, but left a queasy feeling they were both shaving differences to give the other a political assist.

title: Poland's Ex-Premier Cleared in Spy Case
description: An investigation into whether former Prime Minister Jozef Oleksy spied for Moscow has been closed because of insufficient evidence, a military prosecutor said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;British Utility Parrying a Bid by Southern
description: National Power P.L.C. sought today to fend off a hostile takeover bid from the Southern Company of Atlanta by agreeing to buy a British utility for L2.5 billion, or $3.78 billion.

title: Many Tourists Delay Trips to Israel and Egypt, but Few Cancel
description: Egyptian and Israeli officials in the United States said yesterday that many would-be tourists to their countries had delayed scheduled departures after the killing of 18 Greek tourists in Cairo on Thursday and the Israeli Army's killing of at least 75 civilians in Lebanon on the same day. But so far, they said, there have been relatively few cancellations.

title: Safety Board Warns of Failure in Jet Part
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said today that a component of 5,400 jet engines on large airplanes could develop cracks capable of destroying the engines in flight.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SETTLEMENT ACCEPTED ON LOUISIANA-PACIFIC HOME SIDING
description: A Federal judge accepted the settlement yesterday of a class-action lawsuit that had accused the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation of producing defective siding for homes. After chastising lawyers last week for a proposal he said inadequately compensated homeowners, Judge Robert Jones of the Federal District Court in Portland, Ore., approved a modified deal. Louisiana-Pacific agreed to pay $275 million, and has an option to add $50 million more to the fund in each of years six and seven of the settlement. The company agreed to pay administrative costs and arbitrators' awards from funds outside the settlement pool. The siding in question, known as Inner Seal, resembles cedar, but it can soak up moisture, resulting in swelling and cracking. It was installed on an estimated 800,000 homes nationwide. Louisiana-Pacific has maintained that up to 90 percent of the problems with the siding can be traced to improper installation and maintenance.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;The Joys of Mac Color Scanning
description: EVEN without opening the box, one can guess that the new Apple color scanner is not flawless. If it were, someone at Apple Computer Inc. might have used it to scan in a bunch of $20's and $50's (the new $100 bills are harder to counterfeit) and then send them to a color laser printer to help offset the company's financial losses.

title: Cosmetics Can't Mask Our Economic Inequality
description: To the Editor:

title: A Report Tries To Counteract Job-Loss Fears
description: The Council of Economic Advisers will report Tuesday that more than two-thirds of the new jobs created in the United States in 1994 and 1995 paid better than the average job, Administration officials said today, and that despite waves of corporate layoffs, the length of time most workers spent unemployed in recent years has actually declined.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Anna C. Roosevelt;Sharp and To the Point In Amazonia
description: THE mouth of the cave opens wide and arches high, like a lithic bandshell cut into the hillside. From a rock pedestal where the conductor might stand, the view beyond encompasses miles of tropical forest much as it was when some of the earliest Americans dwelled here 11,000 years ago. To the south, sunlight glints off shallow lakes on the floodplain of the Amazon River six miles away. From these waters and through the dense foliage, the ancient people would arrive and climb a steep trail to the cave, their lofty sanctuary of vaulted sandstone.

title: Poll Suggests Ferraro Could Beat Giuliani in Race
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro, the former Vice-Presidential candidate, is the only Democrat who would defeat Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani if the mayoral election were held today, according to a new poll.

title: Conduct Panel Plans Charges Against Judge
description: The New York State commission that investigates judicial misconduct said today that it planned to file administrative charges against Lorin Duckman, the Brooklyn Criminal Court judge accused of mishandling domestic violence cases and being unfair to prosecutors. The charges could lead to the judge's censure or removal from the bench.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;NABISCO HOLDINGS CORP. (NA,N)
description: The Nabisco Holdings Corporation of Parsippany, N.J., said yesterday that its earnings rose about 10 percent in the first quarter, mostly because of lower interest expenses and a lower tax rate.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LAIDLAW TO ACQUIRE SCOTT'S HOSPITALITY
description: Laidlaw Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Scott's Hospitality Inc. in a transaction valued at $836 million (Canadian), or about $613 million (United States). The purchase would raise Laidlaw's share of the private school-bus market, adding Scott's 6,000 buses to Laidlaw's 29,000. As part of the deal, Scott's, based in Toronto, would also shed its restaurant-franchise and food-service operations. Laidlaw, based in Burlington, Ontario, said A& W Food Services of Canada Inc., a closely held restaurant concern, would buy the 400 Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurants of Scott's in Canada and 51 highway rest-stop franchises. The rest of the food services of Scott's, which A& W has agreed to manage until they are sold, include 245 Manchu Wok restaurants in North America and 205 Perfect Pizza outlets in Britain.

title: F& M to Acquire a Bank
description: The F& M National Corporation said today that it would acquire the Allegiance Banc Corporation of Bethesda, Md., for about $15 a share in stock, or about $29 million over all. Allegiance is the parent of Allegiance Bank, which operates seven branches in Maryland and has assets of about $138 million. F& M, based here, is a holding company for several banks, with total assets of more than $2 billion.

title: Group Sues New Jersey Over Aid to Education
description: A group that has been the biggest force for changing New Jersey's system of paying for education has filed suit to force the Whitman administration to spend $141 million more on schools next year to equalize educational disparities.

title: New York Weeklies Stage a Free-for-All;Voice and Press in Give-Away Battle
description: In the weeks surrounding the reincarnation of The Village Voice -- from aging alternative weekly to Manhattan's newest and most ubiquitous free paper -- the metropolis has been awash with mysterious rumors.

title: Corrections
description: Two historical photographs yesterday with an article about efforts to preserve remnants of the Brooklyn black settlement known as Weeksville carried an outdated credit. The organization that supplied the photos is the Brooklyn Historical Society; it is no longer the Long Island Historical Society.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;What's Hard About Hardware? Software Is the Hard Part
description: ALL I wanted to do was keep the files on my laptop computer in sync and up to date with the ones on my desktop machine. How hard could it be?

title: COMPANY REPORTS;K-III to Acquire Westcott After Twice Raising Its Bid
description: After a last-minute bidding war, the K-III Communications Corporation has won the right to acquire Westcott Communications Inc. for $422 million, or $21.50 a share in cash, outbidding a consortium led by the Texas leveraged buyout firm of Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc.

title: Rite Aid Agrees To Store Sales
description: The Rite Aid Corporation agreed today to divest itself of 10 stores to settle Pennsylvania's antitrust concerns about its proposed acquisition of a competing drugstore operator, Revco DS Inc., for $1.8 billion.

title: Goetz's Attorney Sums Up, Ruefully
description: Bernhard Goetz's lawyer told a Bronx jury his client was "a jerk" and that "someone should punch him in the mouth" for uttering racist epithets. But he argued that Mr. Goetz's flawed character should not obscure that he was justified in shooting four teen-agers he thought were about to rob him on the subway a decade ago.

title: A Family Museum to Sell Off Cherished Art
description: The Shelburne Museum in Shelburne, Vt., which has one of the most esteemed art collections in the country, has decided to sell $25 million worth of art at Sotheby's this fall, in an effort to dig its way out of a financial mess.

title: Corrections
description: An entry yesterday in the Business Day listing of dividend meetings for the week carried an outdated reference to the Signet Banking Corporation. Signet has changed its meeting to May 28 from today.

title: ON COLLEGES;Small-School Talent in Big Time
description: There was a time when high school coaches, looking to cheer up senior players, would tell them not to worry about receiving offers from so-called "small-time programs." If you've got talent, they said, the pros will find you.

title: BASKETBALL;In Swift Move, Nets Drop Beard (and a Few Names)
description: The worst-kept secret in New Jersey became official yesterday when the Nets announced they will not exercise the option on Butch Beard's contract as head coach for next season.

title: Liz Claiborne Chairman
description: Liz Claiborne Inc. said yesterday that Jerome A. Chazen, 68, would retire as chairman of the company, a women's apparel concern, effective May 16 and become chairman emeritus. As expected, the president and chief executive, Paul R. Charron, will take on the additional post of chairman.

title: COMPANY NEWS;THERMADYNE SELLING FLOOR MAINTENANCE UNIT
description: The Thermadyne Holdings Corporation signed an agreement yesterday to sell its floor maintenance business to Incentive A/S of Denmark for $115 million. The unit makes commercial and industrial janitorial equipment under the Clarke, A. L. Cook and American-Lincoln brand names. Thermadyne, based in St. Louis, said the sale would allow it to focus on its core cutting, welding and wear resistance businesses. Its stock rose $1.125, to $22.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: BASEBALL;Strawberry Will Pay Up
description: Darryl Strawberry agreed today to pay nearly $300,000 in overdue child and spousal support by June 24 to avoid criminal prosecution.

title: Race Issue Rattles Celebrity Haven
description: One summer afternoon in 1994, Richard Hill was on his way to pick up his wife at a doctor's office here when his car was stopped by two white police officers. Guns drawn, they frisked and interrogated Mr. Hill, who is black. Then, without provocation, he says, one of the officers grabbed him by the genitals and squeezed hard enough to send him to a hospital emergency room for treatment.

title: Apple Shows New Computers
description: Apple Computer Inc. introduced four new Power PC personal computers today with faster processors as the troubled computer maker tries to spur more interest in its products.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Bond Issue Is Ballot Bound
description: The Assembly Housing Committee approved legislation yesterday that would authorize a $290 million bond issue for affordable housing to be placed on the November ballot.

title: Chess
description: Despite a first round loss to Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria, Garry Kasparov climbed up to a first place tie with him in the Max Euwe Memorial Tournament three weeks ago in Amsterdam. Both turned in scintillating 6 1/2-2 1/2 scores in the 10th and last running of the elite all-grandmaster competition.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;2 Major Challengers to Telmex Agree to Merge
description: Even though Mexico's telecommunications market has not yet opened to competition, two of the leading companies waiting to enter, each of them including an American partner, have already decided to merge.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Continental Airlines Posted A Profit in the First Quarter
description: Continental Airlines reported a strong profit for the first quarter today, and said it was becoming a "normal company."

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Major League Soccer

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;State Lottery Top Rated
description: Money magazine has rated New Jersey's lottery the most efficient in the nation. Out of $1.57 billion in ticket sales, $647.8 million was netted by the lottery, a return of 41 percent, the consumer magazine reports in its May issue. Proceeds from the lottery are used for public schools, higher education and programs for the mentally ill and the mentally disabled.

title: Nutritional Supplements Need Study, Not Federal Regulation
description: To the Editor:

title: A HUD Strikeout
description: A woman I will call Mrs. Hardy arrived at Bronx Legal Services at the 11th hour. Her story was a familiar one. Her landlord wanted to evict her because her estranged crack-addicted husband had been arrested for a drug offense just blocks away from her city-owned apartment. Although he had been drifting through New York City shelters for two years, he gave the police his wife's address as his residence. Later, he confessed he had done so "out of spite."

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Greek Coast Guard Fires On Turkish Fishing Boat
description: A Greek coast guard patrol boat fired on a Turkish fishing boat today, trying to stop it after the Turkish boat smuggled illegal migrants onto a Greek islet, officials said.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Sears of Britain Sells Dutch Shoe Retail Unit
description: Sears P.L.C., a British retailer, agreed yesterday to sell Hoogenbosch Beheer B.V., its Dutch shoe retailing subsidiary, to a management-led team for L46.6 million (about $70 million). The sale completes Sears's plans to reorganize European operations, which consist of Wallis in Germany, Miss Selfridge and Adams in the Netherlands and Adams in Spain.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY U.S. Defeats Austria

title: CHRONICLE
description: For the last few years BLAINE TRUMP has been gathering furniture and equipment for the new headquarters of God's Love We Deliver, the organization that provides hot meals daily to more than 900 homebound people with AIDS. "One day I said, 'David, how about something for our new home?' " she recalled yesterday. "Make me some furniture."

title: Four Confess On Saudi TV To Bombing Of U.S. Center
description: Four Saudis confessed on television today to the car bombing last year of an American-run military training center that killed seven people, and they said they had been planning further attacks.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Greenwich Air Reduces Offer
description: Greenwich Air Services Inc. said today that it had reduced the amount it would pay for its planned acquisition of Aviall Inc.'s engine service division to about $250 million.

title: Robert Hersant, 76, the Owner Of France's Leading Press Group
description: Robert Hersant, France's leading newspaper and magazine publisher, whose best-known property was the conservative daily Le Figaro, died on Sunday at his home in the Paris suburb of St.-Cloud. He was 76. The cause of death was not given.

title: Executive Changes
description: AMERICAN SKANDIA LIFE ASSURANCE CO., Shelton, Conn., named Lawrence Kudlow chief economist.

title: 2 Small Competitors in New Giant's Path
description: Two huge holes can be found on a map of the 13-state region from Maine to Virginia that will be dominated by the proposed merger of Bell Atlantic and Nynex. One is virtually all of Connecticut, which is served by the 118-year-old Southern New England Telephone Company; the other is a swatch of western New York around Rochester served by the Frontier Corporation.

title: Walk, Yes, but Don't Expect New Bones
description: To the Editor:

title: HOCKEY;Turgeon in the Center Of Montreal Crucible
description: A little more than a year ago, when he was traded to the Canadiens from the Islanders, Pierre Turgeon sat in an alumni room in the old Forum surrounded by pictures of former leaders of this ancient, gloried hockey team.

title: Xoma in Pact With Genentech
description: Genentech Inc. and the Xoma Corporation said today that they had agreed to develop jointly Genentech's treatment for psoriasis and other inflammatory disorders, a product that is also used to help prevent the rejection of organ transplants.

title: A Phone Merger Calling for Inquiry
description: The proposed merger between two regional telephone giants, Bell Atlantic and Nynex, could prove helpful or harmful to residents in the Mid-Atlantic and New England states, depending on factors yet to be evaluated. The merger would likely reduce the number of phone companies that will compete for local phone customers, thus lessening the incentive to offer lower prices or better service. But the two companies might be able to show that the merger will create large savings that can be passed along to customers. The Justice Department and Federal regulators owe consumers a probing investigation before they grant approval.

title: BASKETBALL;Seton Hall's Griffin Honored
description: Adrian Griffin of Seton Hall, who led the Pirates with a 19.5-point scoring average this past season, was named the local area's men's Division I player of the year tonight by the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on April 10 about Jack Miles, the winner of the Pulitzer Prize for biography for his book "God: A Biography," misstated his current employment. He is now director of the Humanities Center at the Claremont Graduate School, near Los Angeles, no longer a book columnist for The Los Angeles Times.

title: Dole Has Led Senate to Legislative Success
description: To the Editor:

title: Record Catch Of Lobsters Raises Fears Of Overfishing
description: It should have been cause for celebration.

title: WITH CHARLIE COMPANY: Fighting Boredom;For G.I.'s in Bosnia, There's More Action on TV
description: As his fellow soldiers sat on guard duty or loped through training exercises outside, Sgt. 1st Class Amos L. Hardy, a veteran of the Persian Gulf war, settled himself in for what now defines excitement for the boys of Charlie Company.

title: BASKETBALL;Knicks Are Looking To Oakley For a Lift
description: Charles Oakley rumbled up the steps to Purchase Gymnasium today, beads of sweat glistening on his fore'ead. He brought two basketballs to shoot and one assistant coach to rebound.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Germans Mix Varese and Zappa in Their Debut
description: I liked the reed dude," a casually dressed young man sitting near me remarked after the Ensemble Modern's concert on Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall. I think he meant the bassoonist. It was a different audience from the usual crowd that attends New York contemporary-music concerts. The likely explanation was the presence of four short classical compositions by Frank Zappa. The late rocker's fans were out in force, delivering a huge roar of approval when the manically clever "G-Spot Tornado" closed the concert with a stroke of a giant gong.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Eurotunnel Loss in '95 Was Double That of '94
description: Eurotunnel, the British-French company that operates the tunnel under the English Channel, reported yesterday that its losses had more than doubled in 1995. The performance was worse than experts had predicted. Eurotunnel's British co-chairman, Sir Alastair Morton, said business was picking up for the company, which went into default on bank interest payments last year.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TRAVELERS/AETNA OFFERING SEEN RAISING $875 MILLION
description: The Travelers/Aetna Property Casualty Corporation priced its initial public offering yesterday at $25 a share, which would raise $875 million over all. The company is selling 35 million shares, or 8.8 percent of its 396 million shares outstanding. At the offering price, the company has a total market value of $9.9 billion. Travelers Group Inc. formed the company this year by buying the Aetna Life and Casualty Company's property and casualty unit for $4 billion and combining it with its own such business. The shares of Travelers/Aetna begin trading today on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol TAP.

title: Nutritional Supplements Need Study, Not Federal Regulation
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Ministers Ask For Arson Inquiry
description: A group of black ministers, supported by the Christian Coalition, called today for a more aggressive Federal investigation into a rash of suspicious fires at Southern black churches that are reminiscent of the anti-civil rights attacks of the 1950's and 60's.

title: INSIDE
description: Judge Faces Formal Charges

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Euro Disney Says Loss Narrowed in Winter
description: Euro Disney said yesterday that it had cut its losses during the slow winter season as higher attendance at its Disneyland Paris theme park and hotels more than offset an increase in debt charges. The company, a French theme park operator that is 39 percent owned by the Walt Disney Company, said its loss for the six months that ended on March 31 had fallen to 169 million French francs ($33 million) from 241 million francs in the period a year earlier.

title: Cisco Agrees to Acquire Stratacom In a Stock Swap Worth $4 Billion
description: Cisco Systems Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire Stratacom Inc. in a stock swap valued at about $4 billion. The deal will create a networking giant whose technologies and customer base will spread across many diverse market segments.

title: In Charge of the Trendy Youth Movement at Lauder
description: When MAC cosmetics introduced its second spokesperson last month, adding the sly androgyny of the rock singer K. D. Lang to the tongue-in-cheek glamour of the drag queen RuPaul, the event was considered so noteworthy by those who court the 25- to 39-year-old market that VH1 broadcast a news segment about it.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LONE STAR STOCK UP ON WORD OF POSSIBLE OFFERS
description: The shares of Lone Star Industries jumped 7.8 percent yesterday after the company said several concerns were interested in a business combination, including a possible takeover or merger. The stock was up $2.50, at $34.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. The company, a producer of cement, ready-mixed concrete, sand and gravel, said that it would explore the opportunities but that no decisions had been made on whether a transaction would be in the best interests of shareholders. Lone Star, based in Stamford, Conn., has a market capitalization of about $425 million.

title: Allegations Listed Against Bronx School Board President
description: As school investigators see it, School District 9 in the central Bronx continues to be the personal domain of Carmelo Saez Jr.

title: Gene Jumps To Spread A Toxin In Meat
description: WHEN Dr. David Acheson and Dr. Gerald Keusch at Tufts New England Medical Center sent their laboratory assistants out to the grocery store to buy hamburger one day last summer, it was not for a lab cookout.

title: 85 Achille Lauro Killing 'a Mistake'
description: To many Americans, the killing of Leon Klinghoffer, a disabled passenger, by Palestinian hijackers of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro in 1985 stands as a uniquely brutal episode in the history of terrorism. To Mohammed Abbas, the leader of the band that committed the crime, it was a regrettable mistake.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Indian Police Doubt Bombing in Collapse
description: Indian police said today that they could not explain the collapse of a guest house in New Delhi on Saturday in which 17 people were killed, including eight foreigners, saying no trace of explosive material was found in the debris.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;In Shift, Viacom Is Said to Let Former Executive Join MCA
description: Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman of Viacom Inc., has dropped his efforts to prevent Frank J. Biondi Jr., whom Mr. Redstone ousted as president and chief executive in January, from taking the top job at rival MCA Inc., according to executives close to the talks. An announcement of Mr. Biondi's appointment is expected today.

title: Quest for Fusion Power Is Slowed by Cutbacks
description: ON Nov. 1, 1952, when a thermonuclear bomb equivalent to 10 million tons of TNT was detonated at Eniwetok atoll in the Pacific, an apocalyptic nightmare was born, but also a great dream: the possibility of generating cheap and abundant electricity by fusing together hydrogen nuclei.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Jazz CD's;Capturing The Vitality Of Live Jazz
description: Over the last few years, there has been a discrepancy between the precocious abilities of younger jazz musicians and their recordings. The CD's often seem lifeless, rarely capturing either the playfulness or the sense of experimentation that audiences find during club performances. This sorry state is changing slowly, and the following albums, the second for the bassist Christian McBride and the trumpeter Nicholas Payton, and the third American release for the pianist Cyrus Chestnut, capture some of the vitality they bring to their live music.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Haitian Aides Accept Asylum in Honduras
description: Two former Haitian officials, including a leader of the coup against former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide in 1991, were sent today to Honduras, which offered them political asylum.

title: New I.B.M. Software To Hear Commands
description: Hoping to increase sales of its troubled OS/2 operating system for personal computers, I.B.M. is including voice recognition capabilities in the next version of OS/2, known as Merlin, that will enable users to perform many routine tasks with simple oral commands.

title: By Design;Slides for the Summer
description: Spring's successor to the square-toed pump that made fashion news this winter is the open-toed mule, sometimes called the slide. It most often sits on a chunky heel no more than two inches high, just like the pump.

title: THE FINE PRINT: Renewing Excise Taxes;With Budget Bills in Limbo, a Lapsed Airline Tax Adds to a Growing Deficit
description: As Republicans and Democrats have skirmished this spring over reducing the Federal deficit, they have neglected to renew a handful of excise taxes that expired last December, in the fog of an earlier budget fight.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ROCKWELL WINS SATELLITE DEAL FROM THE AIR FORCE
description: The Rockwell International Corporation has received a $382.2 million order from the Air Force for six satellites that will become part of the Global Positioning System, the Air Force said yesterday. The order also includes options that would have the company provide a variety of support services for the satellites. If all the options were exercised, the contract could be worth as much as $1.3 billion for 33 satellites, said Rockwell, which is based in Seal Beach, Calif. The satellites will replace some global positioning satellites now in orbit, which Rockwell also built. The satellites emit signals that hand-held receivers translate into information for navigation purposes.

title: Chechnya War as Fierce as Ever Despite Yeltsin's Pledge of Peace
description: The people of the Chechen flatlands have developed a routine in the weeks since President Boris N. Yeltsin announced his initiative to end the war in this secessionist region in southern Russia.

title: Abbot Moffat, 94, Lawmaker And Then a Diplomat in Asia
description: Abbot Low Moffat, a powerful New York State legislator during the Depression who in a second career as a diplomat warned against American involvement in Vietnam, died on Wednesday at a retirement home in Hightstown, N.J. He was 94.

title: Syria's Battle on All Fronts
description: Two months ago, the carnage was on the streets of Israeli cities, where suicide attacks by fundamentalist Palestinians left more than 60 dead and hundreds wounded. This month, it has been in southern Lebanon, where Israeli bombing -- retaliation for rocket attacks by Hezbollah fighters -- has killed at least 100 civilians and displaced hundreds of thousands.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Boy Sentenced in Gun Death
description: A 13-year-old boy was sentenced to up to three years for shooting a playmate to death as the two played with a gun in a friend's garage. Desmond Carberry of Dover Township had pleaded guilty to second-degree manslaughter in the death last November of Noel Daroja, 10, of Berkeley Township, the A.P. reported.

title: BASEBALL;Cone Relishes a Victory Over Royals
description: David Cone always has special feelings when he throws baseballs at Kauffman Stadium. It was called Royals Stadium when Cone chased autographs as a kid two decades ago and when he realized a dream by making his debut with the hometown team in 1986. After his years with the Mets, he returned to win the Cy Young award with Kansas City in 1994.

title: Harland Says It Will Eliminate 2,500 Jobs
description: The John H. Harland Company said today that it would cut about 2,500 jobs, or 36 percent of its work force, in the next two years as part of a strategic reorganization.

title: Utility Rejects A Hostile Bid In Kansas City
description: The Kansas City Power and Light Company today rejected a hostile takeover bid from Western Resources Inc., calling it a last-minute attempt to thwart "the formation of a formidable competitor."

title: BASKETBALL;Malone Fired After a Season
description: Citing philosophical differences, General Manager Isiah Thomas of the Toronto Raptors fired his he'd coach, Brendan Malone, today. Malone will be replaced by the assistant coach Darrell Walker.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Wheat Prices Continue to Surge As Weekend Rains Miss Kansas
description: Wheat prices surged yesterday for a fourth consecutive session, reaching a record high, after weekend rains missed most of the Kansas crop, leaving little chance for a recovery from a six-month drought.

title: No Headline
description: We desperately need people. Most of these farms used to have a husband, wife, a son or two and a ranch hand, but now they're all getting down to just one or two people. It takes twice as much land and twice as many cows now to make the same living you did 10 years ago."

title: Dutch Re-Create a 1936 Anti-Nazi Art Show
description: As part of the Nazis' plan to make the 1936 Summer Olympics in Berlin a showcase of their ideological and racial superiority, Josef Goebbels, the regime's propaganda chief, excluded Jews, leftists and purveyors of "degenerate" art from an Art Olympiad organized to coincide with the games.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Madison Avenue girds itself for Z-Day today, as a prescription drug goes over the counter.
description: ON a conventional calendar, today is Tuesday. But on the fanciful calendar followed along Madison Avenue, today is Z-Day as another popular drug previously sold only by prescription becomes available in an over-the-counter version.

title: Nanjing Journal;China's Campus Model for the 90's: Earnest Patriot
description: His manner was friendly, but his words had a hard, metallic edge to them.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Meadowlands Deal Is Struck
description: The Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission and a private developer have agreed to eliminate 5,600 housing units from the Town Center project in Carlstadt, officials announced yesterday. The units originally were included in the mixed-use project, approved as part of the commission's blueprint for the development of the Meadowlands.

title: Findings Intrigue Sickle Cell Experts
description: THE recent finding that hemoglobin in the blood carries nitric oxide as well as oxygen has researchers studying sickle cell disease scrambling to find out how to put this information to good use.

title: Tornadoes Leave 4 Dead in Western Arkansas
description: A day after tornadoes in this area of western Arkansas killed four people, including two young children, firefighters went from house to demolished house today, searching for more victims.

title: In Backpack Case, Student Won No Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: Afghan Toll In Flooding Put Over 100
description: Heavy flooding has killed more than 100 people across Afghanistan, relief workers said today as a Red Cross official warned of an ecological disaster in the war-devastated country.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EL PASO ENERGY BEGINS TENDER FOR CORNERSTONE
description: The El Paso Energy Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Cornerstone Natural Gas Inc. in a deal worth $115 million. Under the agreement, El Paso Energy, based in El Paso, would begin a cash tender for outstanding shares of Cornerstone, based in Dallas, at $6 a share. Cornerstone's operations consist of approximately 700 miles of gathering and transportation systems and seven natural gas processing and treating facilities principally in East Texas and Louisiana.
