The company also markets natural gas and gas liquids. El Paso Energy, through the El Paso Natural Gas Company, owns and operates one of the nation's largest transmission systems serving the Southwest.

title: Sports of The Times;It Started With Two Free Throws
description: THE name of the team in Connecticut was the Pride. As in: Swallow your pride, young man, you're in the basketball bush leagues now.

title: Board: Passive or Efficient?
description: The 11-member panel of lawyers, judges and laymen that will weigh the fate of Judge Lorin Duckman has been criticized by some legal experts as too passive, while others say it does the best it can with limited money and staff.

title: Lapsed Airline Taxes Leave Hole in Budget
description: As Republicans and Democrats have fought this spring over cutting the Federal deficit, they have neglected to renew a handful of excise taxes that expired last December. So far, the lapse, principally involving levees on the aviation industry, has added $1.7 billion back to the same deficit the parties are trying to cut.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Car-Chase Policy Is Reversed
description: Reversing a four-year-old policy limiting when the police can pursue suspected car thieves, Mayor Sharpe James said yesterday that officers would be allowed more discretion in deciding when to give chase. The old policy required the police to have knowledge that the car had been used in a crime before engaging in pursuit and was intended to protect bystanders and drivers.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;WPP Says Gross Profit Rose 13% in First Period
description: WPP Group P.L.C. said yesterday that its first-quarter revenue and gross profit both rose by more than 13 percent. WPP, the world's largest advertising company, said first-quarter revenue climbed to L390.4 million ($590 million). It did not disclose the amount of its profit in the quarter. WPP is the London-based parent of the advertising agencies J. Walter Thompson Company and Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide. WPP's revenue grew 8 percent in 1995, to L1.55 billion ($2.27 billion). The chief executive, Martin Sorrell, said last week that he would be disappointed if WPP did not do better than that in 1996. He said advertising would be bolstered by the Olympic Games in Atlanta and the Presidential campaign in the United States. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Research Yields Underused Source of Food in Africa: Grains
description: SUB-SAHARAN Africa often evokes images of famine, drought, starvation and malnutrition. Yet, researchers say, this area is the home of more than 2,000 grains, vegetables, roots, fruits and other foods that potentially could feed the continent and even other parts of the world.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CASCADE COMMUNICATIONS PLANS TO BUY ARRIS NETWORKS
description: The Cascade Communications Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Arris Networks Inc., a provider of technology for communications companies, for $145.3 million in common stock. Cascade said the purchase would extend its product offerings. The company, based in Westford, Mass., mainly provides switching systems used to distribute data at high speeds over telephone networks. Arris, a private company also based in Westford, would expand Cascade's product line to allow users to gain access to high-speed networks from remote locations. Cascade's shares gained $1.50, to $86.50, in Nasdaq trading. The acquisition is expected to be completed in May.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Belligerent Poet in a Gentler Light
description: ROBERT FROST A Biography By Jeffrey Meyers Illustrated. 424 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $30.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Aliens in Ohio, Afraid of Jell-O (But No Coneheads in Sight)
description: Some think it's idiotic. Others find it brilliant. Actually, "Third Rock From the Sun" is brilliantly idiotic, a daffy pastiche of farce, burlesque and satire. And confounding most of the television industry, this NBC series (it was rejected by ABC) has steadily evolved into a full-fledged hit since its premiere in early January. Once again, most prime-time experts are reduced to fidgety mumbling.

title: Mother Is Charged in Fatal Fall Of 7-Month-Old Girl in Bronx
description: A 7-month-old girl fell four stories to her death yesterday afternoon from the fire escape outside the window of her apartment house in the Bronx, and her mother has been charged with dropping her, the police said.

title: A Sticking-to-Their-Knitting Deal;Nynex and Bell Atlantic Decide They Are Truly Made for Each Other
description: It may be less New Age this time, but it may make better business sense.

title: Market Place;Bell Atlantic's chief has guessed wrong about deals in the past.
description: RAYMOND W. SMITH gives Wall Street the deals it loves, and when he announces a big merger, Bell Atlantic's stock price goes up. It happened again yesterday, when his company announced its merger plans with Nynex, to form a local telephone giant with visions of getting into long-distance.

title: Tokyo Stocks Fall
description: Stocks fell slightly here today. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 4.01 points, at 22,119.88. The Nikkei closed Monday at 22,123.89, its highest finish since Feb. 7, 1992.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES SELLING A FINANCE UNIT
description: Fleetwood Enterprises Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its recreational-vehicle finance unit, the Fleetwood Credit Corporation, for $157 million to the Associates First Capital Corporation. Fleetwood Enterprises, a recreational vehicle maker based in Riverside, Calif., said Fleetwood Credit had assets of $400 million and serviced a total receivables portfolio of about $1.1 billion. The financing arm contributed $47.8 million in revenue in the fiscal year that ended on April 30, 1995. Associates First, a finance company based in Dallas, is part of the Ford Motor Company's financial services group.

title: Whitman Administration Is Sued on School Spending
description: Adding another element to the battle over spending on public education in New Jersey, the Education Law Center announced today that it had filed suit in State Supreme Court to force the Whitman administration to add over $141 million to education spending next year to close the gap between the richest and poorest districts.

title: The Senate Is Smarter on Health Care
description: The bipartisan health-reform bill that the Senate is expected to pass today, like a companion bill already passed by the House, helps workers who quit or change jobs keep their medical coverage. But the House version would also raise insurance costs for chronically ill people and would almost surely be vetoed by the President. If the Republicans are to lay claim to health care reform, they will have to stick close to the Senate version.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALEXANDER LIBERMAN, the former editorial director of Conde Nast and a painter, sculptor and photographer, will receive the National Arts Club's Gold Medal Award for Photography tomorrow at a black-tie dinner at the club, on Gramercy Park South. But don't try to tell Mr. Liberman that photography is a lofty form of art comparable to painting or sculpture.

title: Ex-Plumbers' Union Officials Guilty in Extortion
description: Four former officials of Plumbers Local 2, a powerful construction union in the New York City area, pleaded guilty yesterday to state charges of extorting payoffs from contractors for sweetheart deals.

title: Clinton Says the Protection of Sterling Forest Is a Priority
description: The Clinton Administration today threw its full weight behind proposals to block development at Sterling Forest, the privately owned woodland mostly in New York that is also a major source of drinking water in the electorally important state of New Jersey.

title: Court Upholds Laws Requiring AIDS Tests in Sex-Assault Cases
description: A New Jersey appeals court has upheld two state statutes requiring defendants in sexual-assault cases to be tested for the AIDS virus if the victim so chooses.

title: Oneok Adds to Properties
description: The Oneok Resources Company said today that it had bought all of Scana Petroleum Resource Inc.'s oil and gas properties in Oklahoma for $46.7 million. The purchase includes more than 500 producing oil and natural gas sites, according to Oneok Resources, which is a wholly owned subsidiary of Oneok Inc., which is based in Tulsa. Scana Petroleum's parent company, the Scana Corporation, is based in Columbia, S.C. The purchase was financed by cash on hand and proceeds from a recent sale of oil and gas reserves in Alabama and Mississippi.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Redstone Drops Opposition To Biondi's Joining MCA Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman of Viacom, has dropped his efforts to prevent Frank J. Biondi Jr., whom Mr. Redstone ousted as president and chief executive in January, from taking the top job at rival MCA Inc., according to executives close to the talks. An announcement is expected today.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;U.S. HEALTHCARE INC. (USHC,NNM)
description: U.S. Healthcare Inc., which is being acquired by the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, reported lower first-quarter earnings yesterday after accounting for the $8.9 billion transaction. Without those charges, the company said, earnings for the quarter would have been up 12 percent on a per-share basis.

title: Erma Bombeck Dies at 69; Put Howls Into Humdrum
description: Erma Bombeck, who mined the everyday lives of housewives and parents for the mother lode of humor that transformed her into one of the country's most popular newspaper columnists and a best-selling author, died yesterday at the University of California at San Francisco Medical Center. Mrs. Bombeck, who made her home in Paradise Valley, Ariz., a suburb of Phoenix, was 69.

title: New Scrutiny for Sellers of Herbal Highs
description: Sean Shayan, who says he is 20, is the chief executive of a company with a mind-boggling growth record: in barely four years, his Global World Media Corporation says it has sold nearly $300 million of its prime product, Herbal Ecstacy.

title: An Award for 'Dancing After Hours'
description: Andre Dubus has been named this year's winner of the Rea Award for the Short Story. The prize, which carries a cash award of $30,000, was awarded to Mr. Dubus for his collection "Dancing After Hours."

title: ITALIAN LEFT WINS BIG BREAKTHROUGH IN NATIONAL VOTE
description: By taking a step to the center, Italy's former Communists broke through a last barrier in national elections on Sunday, sharing with their centrist partners a victory in both houses of Parliament and winning for the first time a chance to form an Italian government.

title: Lebanon Pauses to Mourn As Attacks Enter 12th Day
description: Israeli warplanes rocketed Palestinian guerrilla targets in the hills south of Beirut this afternoon even as much of Lebanon stopped to mourn victims of Israel's 12-day-old military campaign.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Daily Mail Gets Stake In British TV Operation
description: The Daily Mail and General Trust P.L.C. of Britain has bought a 20 percent stake in Independent Television News for L20.4 million ($30.9 million). Granada Group and Carlton Communications said jointly yesterday that they had each sold 10 percent of I.T.N. for L10.2 million, giving I.T.N. a total value of L102.5 million ($155.2 million).

title: Nutritional Supplements Need Study, Not Federal Regulation
description: To the Editor:

title: Observer;The Charisma Chasm
description: Bob Dole stops me on the street. "Bob Dole feels your pain," he says. I want to cry.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Stephen Z. Meyers, a founder of the Jacoby & Meyers law firm, misstated his father's surname in some editions. The name is Frederick Meyers, not Harmon.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasuries Continue Their Rally
description: Prices of Treasury securities climbed yesterday, extending their rally from Friday.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Dutch Investor to Make a Bid for Fokker
description: Fokker N.V. welcomed a new potential savior today when Jaap Rosen Jacobson, a Dutch investor, said he would make an offer for the aircraft manufacturing arm of the bankrupt company.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Grab Bag of Characters And a Big Challenge
description: If every actor were the master of every role, theater would be a more predictable and less interesting art. So it is understandable that when a performer accepts the challenge of a show that demands a range of roles -- from the perplexed 8-year-old daughter of "a lapsed Catholic and a cultural Jew" to a retired guy named Joe, from a Sephardic wife and mother in Turkey to the Last of the Red-Hot Mamas -- the risks mount. Toss in the need to sing, to dance, to put across punch lines, to weave tales in the plain language of prose and the poetry of lyrics, and the challenge is compounded.

title: Theater in Review
description: A Bronte Sister's Life As Mixed-Media Pastiche 'Do Something With Yourself: The Life of Charlotte Bronte' Invisible Theater

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Tikhonov Fired as Central Army Coach
description: VIKTOR TIKHONOV, whose lengthy reign as the virtual czar of Soviet and Russian hockey produced three Olympic and eight world titles, has been fired as coach of Russia's flagship Central Army team. Tikhonov, 66, had lost the other half of his dual job two years ago when he was removed as national team coach.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Is Higher Against Mark In Side Effect of Italian Election
description: The dollar rose yesterday against the German mark, which weakened against the Italian lira and other European currencies after a center-left coalition won a majority in both houses of the Italian Parliament.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Providence Journal Files to Offer Stock
description: The Providence Journal Company, which owns nine television stations and publishes The Providence Journal-Bulletin, Rhode Island's leading newspaper, filed today to sell class A common stock through an initial public offering.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Prelude to an Anniversary for the Met Orchestra
description: This week the Metropolitan Opera is celebrating the 25th anniversary of the debut of its artistic director, James Levine, and the concert of the Met Orchestra on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall seemed an apt prelude. The present lofty state of the orchestra is, after all, one of Mr. Levine's prime achievements in the house, and the players sounded every bit the fine symphonic ensemble they aspire to be in their odd moments.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: COMPANY NEWS;ENGELHARD AGREES TO BUY MEARL FOR $272.7 MILLION
description: The Engelhard Corporation reached an agreement in principle yesterday to buy the Mearl Corporation, a privately held company whose products include pigments and additives for automotive finishes and cosmetics. Engelhard's chairman, Orin R. Smith, said he expected the acquisition, for $272.7 million in cash, to close in June. Mearl, based in Ossining, N.Y., had sales of about $134 million in 1995, Engelhard said. The shares of Engelhard, which is based in Iselin, N.J., were up 25 cents yesterday at $23.50. The company also makes pigments, as well as chemicals and other materials for a variety of industries.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: GOLF;Kite Wants to Stay Off Senior Tour
description: TOM KITE, golf's career leading money winner, said yesterday that he may bypass the lucrative Senior Tour when he hits age 50 if he remains competitive on the PGA Tour.

title: Transactions
description: Hockey National Hockey League PITTSBURGH PENGUINS -- Recalled C Richard Park from Belleville of the OHL. Tennis Western Tennis Association WTA -- Named Mark Saunders executive director. College NCAA -- Named Ronald Stratten group executive director for education services. CONNECTICUT -- Announced G Ray Allen will forego his remaining eligibility and enter the NBA draft.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Elisabeth Badinter, vice president of the supervisory board at Publicis S.A., Paris, was promoted to chairwoman, succeeding Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet, her father, the founder of the agency company who died on April 11. Maurice Levy was reaffirmed as chairman, chief executive and president of the Publicis management board. John F. Varty was named senior vice president and group management supervisor heading the retail automotive division at Campbell-Ewald Advertising, Warren, Mich., a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., succeeding Nicholas Popely, who left. Mr. Varty had held a similar post at Foote, Cone & Belding, Santa Ana, Calif., a unit of True North Communications.

title: Pinnacle Banc Group Bid
description: Pinnacle Banc Group Inc. agreed today to acquire the Financial Security Corporation for $47 million. The companies said Financial Security common stockholders would get $28.50 a share in cash, Pinnacle common stock or a combination. Financial Security is to merge into Pinnacle, and Financial Security's Security Federal unit is to become a separate Pinnacle unit.

title: Dole Faults Clinton Choice for Federal Bench
description: Bob Dole took to the Senate floor today to urge President Clinton to withdraw the nomination of a Miami trial lawyer to a Federal appeals court, saying the lawyer was unqualified and had been nominated only because he had helped raise "millions and millions of dollars" for the Clinton campaign.

title: Suspect Arraigned In Serial Killings
description: A 42-year-old postal worker who confessed to killing five prostitutes was arraigned on murder charges today, but prosecutors said his history of mental problems might prevent them from seeking the death penalty.

title: Cosmetics Can't Mask Our Economic Inequality
description: To the Editor:

title: Democratic Air War Hits Michigan
description: Like the Oldsmobiles they make in Lansing, President Clinton has been a regular presence in television commercials here for months, part of a nationwide advertising campaign by the Democratic Party that began extraordinarily early, last August, and has cost at least $20 million so far.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Hurt by Strike, G.M.'s Profits Are Off by Half
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that its earnings dropped by half in the first quarter, dragged down mostly by the 17-day brake-factory strike last month in Dayton, Ohio, that cost the company $900 million in after-tax profits.

title: Patterns
description: Tents May Return to Park

title: Tobacco Chemicals Linger in Babies
description: Women who smoke during pregnancy, or even breathe other people's tobacco fumes, pass cancer-causing chemicals into their fetuses' blood, where they linger for months, scientists say.

title: Sri Lanka Reports Gains Against Rebels
description: As part of a major campaign against separatist rebels, Sri Lankan Army units have pushed into two towns deep in rebel territory on the Jaffna Peninsula, military officials and rebel radio said today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Hammond Loses Job in World League
description: BOBBY HAMMOND was fired as coach of the London Monarchs of the World League of American Football yesterday and replaced by the former Denver Broncos wide receiver LIONEL TAYLOR. Hammond, a former running back with the Giants and Washington Redskins, was dismissed two days after the Monarchs (0-2) lost, 37-3, to the Frankfurt Galaxy. Taylor, 59, moves up from offensive coordinator. (AP)

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Parental Expectations: How Much Is Enough?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;UNION CARBIDE CORP. (UK,N)
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday that its earnings fell 31.7 percent in the first quarter, reflecting higher costs of raw materials and lower prices for some major products.

title: Justices to Decide Municipal Liability Issue
description: Accepting a case that could revive debate over whether local governments are responsible for misbehavior by their employees, the Supreme Court today agreed to hear an Oklahoma county's appeal of a ruling that it was liable under Federal law for a deputy sheriff's violent behavior because it had disregarded the man's own police record and tendency toward violence when it hired him.

title: Theater in Review
description: Set After World War I, But at War With the Nazis 'Don Juan Comes Back From the War' Classic Stage Company

title: BASEBALL;The Mets' Wilson Finally Asserts Himself
description: The presumption was that altered mechanics were behind what Paul Wilson finally achieved last night, his first major league victory after two confidence-shaking starts. Perhaps the notion is left over 'rom the years of success Tom Seaver earned at Shea Stadium and the extensive explanations he would offer afterward, the legacy Wilson inherited because of his talent, his potential and his business address.

title: DANCE REVIEW;A Visit to a Strange Land Of Children Not Yet Born
description: If awards were given for the most bizarrely compelling dance event of the year, Bebe Miller's "Tiny Sisters in the Enormous Land" would certainly be a strong contender.

title: Ethiopia Tries Former Rulers In 70's Deaths
description: As the leaders of the Marxist Government that once held this nation in an iron grip filed quietly into court, Hiwet Teklu could barely stand to look at them from her seat in the back of the cavernous room.

title: NYC;Forswearing Dolts and Knaves and Their Ilk
description: IT'S time for a quiz about life on the sidewalks of New York.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Jets Sign Six College Free Agents
description: One day after the draft ended, the Jets remained busy yesterday, re-signing their oldest player and picking up six college free agents, including two area players and the running back who initially replaced LAWRENCE PHILLIPS at Nebraska.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Berringer Is Memorialized
description: Nebraska Coach TOM OSBORNE eulogized the former Cornhuskers quarterback Brook Berringer yesterday as a man who made a difference in the short time he had on earth.

title: Palestinians Meet to Rethink Calls for Israel's Destruction
description: The Palestine National Council, the Palestinian parliament-in-exile whose roster of members reads like a who's who of Israel's old enemies, convened today in Gaza to hear Yasir Arafat say that the time had come to formally take Israel's destruction off the Palestinian agenda.

title: On My Mind;The Mideast Mirage
description: Working closely together, the American Administration and the Israeli Government have created several important and lasting results out of the fighting in Lebanon. These results, every one of them, have been damaging to the military, political and just plain human interests of all three countries.

title: BASKETBALL;Allen Will Enter Draft After 3 Years at UConn
description: After three glorious seasons with the University of Connecticut, Ray Allen said today that he was ending his college career with one year of eligibility remaining to make himself available for the pro draft in June.

title: Bill Seeks to Protect Inmates From Guards Who Seek Sex
description: What woke her in the predawn of Aug. 8, 1995, was the urgent tapping on her shoulder. Felita Dobbins, a prisoner at the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, said she opened her eyes to find a guard, Selbourne Reid, stepping out of the pants of his crisp blue uniform.

title: New Ethics Complaints Filed Against Gingrich
description: Representative George Miller of California filed new ethics complaints against Speaker Newt Gingrich today, asking for the reopening of an investigation into volunteer work done in Mr. Gingrich's office by a telecommunications entrepreneur.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: CUC to Buy Ideon in $375 Million Deal
description: Moving to add the names of millions of credit card holders to its already huge consumer data base, CUC International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Ideon Group, a credit card registry service, in a stock swap valued at some $375 million.

title: Robbers Planned Ambush of Officer Killed at Sears, Officials Say
description: The two robbers who killed a Teaneck police officer moonlighting as a Sears, Roebuck & Company security guard on Friday night apparently operated with a well-planned ambush, investigators said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Poppe Tyson Buys Marshall Jaccoma
description: Poppe Tyson in New York, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt that offers services like advertising and interactive marketing, said yesterday that it had acquired Marshall Jaccoma Mitchell in New York. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Peres, Assailed on All Sides, Says Pact Will End Fight
description: Heckled by Israeli Arab lawmakers but pressed by the Likud opposition to continue attacks against Hezbollah, Prime Minister Shimon Peres told Parliament today that he would reject any agreement in Lebanon that merely restored conditions that prevailed before the operation.

title: New Medicare Trust Fund Data Show an Unexpected Shortfall
description: Medicare's Hospital Insurance Trust Fund lost $4.2 billion in the first half of the current fiscal year, according to new Government data, which suggest that the financial condition of the program is worse than projected by Administration officials last year.

title: Big Oil Companies Report Strong Gains in Earnings
description: Buoyed by higher prices for crude oil and strong demand for natural gas and gasoline, most of the nation's major oil companies reported higher earnings yesterday for the first quarter, generally exceeding analysts' forecasts.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Two European Singers Give New York Debut Recitals
description: Young tenors and sopranos who promise to tear up the vocal world are in short supply just now, but first-rate new mezzo-sopranos and baritones seem to be plentiful. This surfeit of mezzos and baritones may be of limited help to opera directors searching for the dream casts of the future. But in recent years, it has been a boon to the world of the art-song recital, and in time it may enrich the opera world as well.

title: A Former Premier And a Mussolini Also Win in Italy
description: Although the biggest victory in Italy's elections was for the political left, there were some other winners.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Less than a month after he turned 80 and also won a special Pulitzer Prize, HERB CAEN, the San Francisco Chronicle columnist, has married, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Q&A
description: Circular Breathing

title: Cosmetics Can't Mask Our Economic Inequality
description: To the Editor:

title: Theater in Review
description: Two Couples, Two Generations In a Two-Family House 'Checkmates' Henry De Jur Playhouse

title: Keycorp in Talks
description: Keycorp is in talks to acquire Carleton, McCreary, Holmes & Company, a Cleveland investment banking firm, for an undisclosed price, the two companies said today. The Cleveland-based bank started Key Capital Markets Inc. in February to provide investment banking services to its corporate and government clients.

title: Siege Is Subplot in Town's Survival Drama
description: For a town that has barely a tumbleweed's toehold in the high plains of Eastern Montana, life has not lacked for drama around here -- even before arrival of the anti-government fugitives known as the Freemen.

title: Inventor Loses Suit Against Ford Motor
description: Jerome H. Lemelson, an inventor who contends that he pioneered VCR's and fax machines, has lost a case against the Ford Motor Company involving bar coding.

title: ON BASEBALL;Boston Has No Defense For Poor Start This Year
description: If this were a television program, the interview subject would be seated behind a screen, silhouetted on camera, and his voice would be distorted, the better to not be able to identify him.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;London International Buying Aladan of U.S.
description: London International Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Aladan Corporation, an American maker of medical gloves and condoms, for $69.5 million. London International, which also makes consumer latex products including Durex and Ramses condoms, said the purchase should help its earnings within a year. Aladan, based in Norcross, Ga., posted sales of $86 million last year. (Dow Jones)

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Center for Child Victims
description: Figures of cats and dogs adorn the wallpaper downstairs and toys are stacked everywhere. The idea behind the new child advocacy center opening today is to make the court system less traumatic for the child victims who are forced to deal with it.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Investors Worry About Bell Atlantic-Nynex Deal
description: One day after Bell Atlantic and Nynex announced their corporate connection, the deal began getting static yesterday on Wall Street.

title: Japan Girds for Trial of Sect Leader in Nerve-Gas Attack
description: With more than 2,000 police officers enforcing rigid security, Japan braced itself this morning for the beginning of what is billed here as the "trial of the century" as Shoko Asahara entered a courtroom to face charges of ordering the nerve gas attack in the Tokyo subway system last year.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Steps That Are Treasures
description: Dance in America," once such a vibrant presence on the public-television schedule, trickles along these days with an occasional special beneath the "Great Performances" umbrella. Dance experts can debate whether the fault is attributable to PBS or to an increasingly lackluster dance scene in general. Gone, certainly, are the days of unending astonishments from the likes of Balanchine, Nureyev and Fonteyn.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Escapades With a Hilarious Corpse
description: Michael Mayer, the director of the Vineyard Theater's production of Janusz Glowacki's 1993 play "Antigone in New York," explores what "homeless" really means as the word applies to the characters, and with this direct approach he -- and actors who know the value of restraint -- gives the play a unity that has eluded previous productions.

title: Executive Changes
description: BANTAM DOUBLEDAY DELL PUBLISHING GROUP, New York, a division of the Bertelsmann Book Group North America unit of Bertelsmann A.G., promoted Erik Engstrom, its executive vice president and chief operating officer, to president.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Mark Schwatka was named to the new position of senior vice president and senior creative director at Grey Advertising, New York. He had been an executive vice president and executive creative director at Bates USA, New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C.

title: China Outflanks U.S. to Avoid Scrutiny of Its Human Rights
description: Outmaneuvered, outspent and outlobbied by Beijing, the United States lost a battle today to subject China to the scrutiny of the United Nations Human Rights Commission, which had been gaining strength since the end of the cold war.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Tyson Told to Avoid Strip Clubs and Bars
description: Ohio probation officials have ordered MIKE TYSON to stay out of bars and strip clubs after a woman contended that the boxer assaulted her in Chicago. "In other words, he couldn't figure it out before," said GEORGE WALKER, chief probation officer for Marion Superior Court. Tyson, who is on probation for a rape conviction, has agreed to abide by the restrictions, although he disputes the woman's version of events, in which she said he groped her and tried to bite her face at a Chicago nightclub. (AP)

title: COMPANY NEWS;PETERSEN PUBLISHING SAYS IT IS CONSIDERING A SALE
description: The Petersen Publishing Company, a magazine publisher, said yesterday that it was considering putting itself up for sale, a move that is expected to draw bids from some of the biggest names in publishing. Petersen, known for such varied titles as Motor Trend, Hot Rod, Guns & Ammo, 'Teen, Sport and Skin Diver, said it had hired Goldman, Sachs & Company to help "explore strategic alternatives." Petersen also said it would consider a "possible business combination," a public offering or other similar transaction. Publishing executives said they expected the auction to begin at $300 million to $400 million, based on a multiple of 10 times Petersen's estimated annual operating profit. Petersen, which has 24 monthly titles and 57 titles published with varied frequencies, has annual revenue of about $275 million. The company, which is closely held, is based in Los Angeles.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Forget Libido. Check the Radiator!
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRISTOPHER GETS SNUB FROM ASSAD IN MIDEAST TALKS
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria abruptly canceled a meeting this afternoon with Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who had flown to Damascus especially to meet him. Mr. Assad's stated reason was that the Americans had arrived 20 minutes later than expected and that he had a state dinner planned for the Pakistani Prime Minister, American officials said.

title: THEATER REVIEW;An Erotic Memoir of a Golden Boy Drunk on Illicit Sex
description: Virgins and Other Myths," initially produced by Primary Stages, has reopened in a Primary Stages production at the Atlantic Theater, 336 West 20th Street, Chelsea. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Feb. 2.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Salomon's Earnings Soared In First-Quarter Rebound
description: Salomon Inc., recovering from a difficult 1995, said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings more than tripled, to $276 million, from $81 million in the first quarter of last year, thanks to robust securities trading and investment banking revenues.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hypo Bank Says Operating Profit Rose
description: Bayerische Hypotheken und Wechsel Bank A.G.. informally known as Hypo Bank, said yesterday that its operating profit before risk provisions rose 30.5 percent in the first quarter of 1996. Operating profit rose to 639.5 million marks ($426.3 million), the bank said without providing a reason for the increase.

title: Manufacturers See Slow Growth
description: Small manufacturers predict continued slow growth in their businesses this year on several fronts, including jobs, wages, sales and profits, the National Association of Manufacturers said today.

title: Japanese Stocks Rise
description: Japanese stocks rose today. At the close of trading, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 162.17 points, or 0.73 percent, to 22,282.05. On Tuesday, the Nikkei lost 4.01 points.

title: Dole Isn't Alone In Exploiting Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;METROCALL IN DEALS TO ADD 520,000 PAGING SUBSCRIBERS
description: Metrocall Inc. of Alexandria, Va., said yesterday that it had agreed to two acquisitions that would add about 520,000 paging subscribers to its customer base. The company will buy Page America Group Inc., of Hackensack, N.J., in a deal that will add about 220,000 subscribers, primarily in the New York and Chicago areas. The price consists of $55 million in cash and $23.5 million in Metrocall stock, subject to adjustment. Metrocall will also buy the Midwest assets of Chicago-based Source One Wireless Inc., adding about 300,000 subscribers. The price has not been determined.

title: POP REVIEW;Les Paul Has a New Home And Time for a Little Chat
description: When Fat Tuesday's closed last year, the guitarist Les Paul ended a 12-year residency of Monday-night appearances with his trio. Now he's back in another basement club, Iridium (44 West 63d Street, Manhattan), where he started a new series on Monday night.

title: Class Notes;A teacher who told her students to 'write dialogue that's natural' finds herself out of a job.
description: Cecilia Lacks is white and every student she taught at Berkeley High School in St. Louis was black, but failure to connect with her students was not why the school board dismissed her. Nor was it the quality of her work in the classroom, for she had once won an award as one of the nation's 15 best teachers. Even for a veteran English teacher with 25 years of experience in St. Louis schools, the cause of her troubles is hard to explain.

title: Accountants to Pay $10 Million To Victims of Real Estate Fraud
description: In the aftermath of the largest real estate fraud in state history, the accounting firm of Arthur Andersen & Company has agreed to pay $10.3 million to investors in partnerships with the failed Colonial Realty Company, to settle an investigation into its work for the company, Federal authorities announced today.

title: Pennsylvania State Senator Wins Primary For Congress
description: A state senator won a Congressional primary in central Pennsylvania today, outpacing three other Republicans, including the son of Representative Bud Shuster.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets' President Says Search For a Coach Is Continuing
description: Michael Rowe, the Nets' president, who is heading the team's search for a new head coach, said yesterday that 'o one has been offered the job yet.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Securities Prices Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, as a surprisingly strong Treasury auction pulled bonds off their lows of the day.

title: Food Notes
description: Starbucks Chills Out

title: INSIDE
description: Court Rules on Patent Trials

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Rutgers Raising Tuition
description: Faced with a $15.6 million cut in state aid, Rutgers University officials say they would need to raise tuition by 10 percent to close the financing gap. A double-digit increase is unlikely, said Nancy Winterbauer, vice president of budgeting for the university, but students are bracing themselves for a rise in tuition well above this year's 4 percent increase. Tuition now stands at $3,786 a year.

title: Correction
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on Friday, about the appointment of Donna-Ann Hayden as president of Arnold Public Relations, misidentified the city where she previously worked for Bozell Public Relations. It was New York, not Boston.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Dolphins Sign Marino Through 1998
description: The Miami Dolphins signed quarterback DAN MARINO to a three-year contract reportedly worth $17.73 million. The deal will pay Marino an average of $5.91 million per season. Denver quarterback JOHN ELWAY last week signed a five-year, $29.5 million contract ($5.90 million per season). (AP)

title: Sports of The Times;To Richter, Every Move Is Explosive
description: THE stakes were higher. So were the sticks. And so were Mike Richter's reactions, even when he wasn't looking.

title: Loss for U.S. on Rights
description: Outmaneuvering Washington, China blocked an effort to subject it to scrutiny by the United Nations Human Rights Commission. Page A12.

title: Reader's Digest Deal To Settle a Lawsuit
description: Reader's Digest Association Inc. said it would pay $40 million to settle a class-action lawsuit accusing the publisher of unfairly monopolizing the distribution of magazines for school fund-raisers.

title: HOCKEY;Montreal Has Lost Its Old Mystique
description: Just who was visiting whom tonight at the $230 million Molson Center, that charmless but expensive home of Les Habitants, a team that still doesn't seem to feel empowered by its grand new, brand new headquarters?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Job-to-Job Health Bill Gains, Covering Mental Illness The Senate passed legislation to make health insurance coverage portable from job to job, on a 100-to-0 vote. The bill faces a difficult conference with the House, but appears to have irresistible political momentum.

title: An Immediate Bonding With Beckett: An Actress's Memoirs
description: Whether she is acting in a play by Samuel Beckett or facing a personal crisis, Billie Whitelaw is fearless in her determination. "If it is necessary, I will walk through brick walls," she said in a recent interview. "Later, I will collapse with broken bones, but if I've got to do it, I will do it. Sam knew that I would turn myself inside out to give him what he wanted."

title: For Secretaries, E-Mail Beats Typing Pool
description: For many, the image of secretaries seems frozen in time, locked somewhere in black-and-white 1930's films in which prim young women are forever taking dictation or pecking away at their keyboards.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Suspects in Tourist Deaths Battle Egypt Police; 6 Die
description: Egyptian police fought a gun battle today with Islamic militants they said were responsible for killing 18 Greek tourists last week.

title: The Camelot Auction Begins, With the Prices Fit for Kings
description: It was the night of the $574,500 humidor, the $442,500 rocking chair and the $167,500 grand piano. Not to mention the $48,875 tape measure and the $33,350 footstool with the cover that was faded, stained and torn.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on March 10 described the work of the Maryland Homeless Veterans Center in Baltimore and included interviews with veterans who are undergoing counseling there. James Metts, a drug abuser, said that before his tour of duty ended in 1972, he had killed thousands of Vietnamese, including "babies, old people, the whole nine yards," in search-and-destroy missions with a small unit.

title: Keeping the Local Lines Open
description: The merger of Nynex and Bell Atlantic is raising new worries about where deregulation is taking us, when media mega-mergers are common and the Telecommunications Act of 1996 gives companies more latitude to team up and enter new markets. Are we moving toward a new national monopoly -- like the old Bell system, before it was broken up -- with control over cable TV and other media?

title: Beard House: Promoting Culinary Arts And Itself
description: JAMES BEARD would have loved all this, said Caroline Stuart, the onetime assistant to the cooking legend and now the vice president of the James Beard Foundation.

title: FILM REVIEW;Two Buddies Whose Family Life Is the Nemesis
description: As we recall our youths, many of us can remember moments when a well-intentioned parental "no" sealed off avenues of opportunity in ways that changed our lives far more than we could have realized at the time. "Two Friends," Jane Campion's sad, minutely observed story of a dissolving friendship between two 15-year-old girls, imagines such a turning point with an astonishing clarity and feel for the texture of drab middle-class life on the outskirts of Sydney, Australia.

title: Molly Keane, 91, a Novelist; Portrayed the Anglo-Irish Gentry
description: Molly Keane, an Anglo-Irish novelist who had ridden to enough hounds, attended enough hunt balls and listened to enough below-stairs gossip by the time she was 17 to sustain two literary careers three decades apart, died on Monday at her cliffside home in Ardmore, County Waterford, Ireland. She was 91.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;Chinese Dish With Sesame Flavor
description: Here is a one-dish Chinese dinner that you may want to start with a bowl of soup or a flour tortilla that has been brushed with oil, sprinkled with sesame seeds and toasted in the oven.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Netscape Exceeds Wall Street Expectations
description: Driven by the rapid deployment of private corporate intranets and the continued expansion of the global Internet, the Netscape Communications Corporation reported first-quarter earnings today that were double Wall Street's expectations, as well as a tenfold increase in revenue.

title: Welfare Study Offered Fair Assessment on Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Yields On Removal Of Fire Boxes
description: Stymied in his efforts to remove all the city's fire-alarm boxes, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani retreated yesterday and agreed to a City Council plan that would keep in place almost two-thirds of the city's fire boxes.

title: New Gene Bomb Aims to Kill Cancers
description: Scientists fighting cancer said today that they had engineered what they call the first genetic time bomb, set to go off inside tumor cells when they produce telltale proteins.

title: Bronx Jury Orders Goetz to Pay Man He Paralyzed $43 Million
description: Nine years after a criminal jury accepted Bernhard H. Goetz's argument that he fired his famous shots in self-defense, a civil jury in the Bronx rejected that claim yesterday and ordered him to pay $43 million to the man he left paralyzed by gunfire on a downtown Manhattan subway train.

title: More PC's Are Found in American Homes
description: The number of American homes with personal computers increased slightly last year, but the percentage of households with PC's remained unchanged, a trade group said this week.

title: Zora Arkus-Duntov, 86, Who Made Corvette a Classic, Dies
description: Zora Arkus-Duntov, the Russian engineer and race car driver who turned the Chevrolet Corvette into one of the most popular muscle cars in the United States, died on Sunday at St. John Hospital here. He was 86.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: BASEBALL;Belle Incident Brings League Investigation
description: Announcing an investigation into the latest incident involving Albert Belle, Gene Budig, president of the American League, yesterday summoned the Cleveland Indians' troubled star to an investigatory meeting at his office today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Fatal Shooting From Bicycle
description: A 21-year-old Elizabeth man died Monday night after being shot over the weekend by a man who approached him on a bicycle, fired and pedaled away from the scene, the authorities said yesterday. The dead man, Freddie Carbajal, and a 19-year-old youth who was wounded in the ride-by attack were part of a group that had left a bar early Sunday and became involved in a fight with another group outside the Pioneer Homes public housing complex, said Robert O'Leary, the assistant prosecutor for Union County.

title: National Magazine Award to Business Week
description: Business Week won the National Magazine Award for general excellence yesterday, in the category for publications with a circulation of more than one million. At the ceremony at the Waldorf-Astoria, the magazine's editor in chief, Stephen B. Shepard, spoke of its successful fight against a Federal judge's attempt to stop it from publishing an article unfavorable to Bankers Trust Company. He called the court case "a classic First Amendment battle." It was the second time in three years that Business Week won for general excellence.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Apartheid From Under: One Man's Long Life
description: THE SEED IS MINE The Life of Kas Maine, a South African Sharecropper, 1894-1985 By Charles van Onselen Illustrated. 649 pages. Hill & Wang. $35

title: Specialist Testifies Depression Was Issue in Kevorkian Cases
description: A nationally recognized specialist on suicide testified today that two patients of Dr. Jack Kevorkian might not have wanted to take their own lives if they had been treated for clinical depression.

title: Arthur P. Davis, 91; Encouraged Generations of Black Writers
description: Dr. Arthur P. Davis, whose long career as a teacher, author, editor and custodian of black literature helped inspire generations of young black American writers, died on Sunday at Washington Hospital Center. He was 91 and lived in Washington.

title: Business Travel;Law firms in four states file suits challenging the port charges assessed by cruise lines.
description: CONTENDING that port charges assessed by cruise lines typically increase advertised cruise fares by at least $100 to $150, law firms in New York, Florida, California and Washington State filed class action lawsuits in state courts yesterday and Monday against seven of the cruise industry's largest lines.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;BRISTOL-MYERS SQUIBB CO. (BMY,N)
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that its earnings rose 11.1 percent in the first quarter, helped by strong sales gains for some of its cholesterol-lowering and cancer-fighting drugs.

title: A Grill With a New Risotto Every Hour
description: ROBERTO RUGGERI, an owner of the Bice chain of restaurants, was looking to expand. Mario Sbarro, whose family founded the Sbarro fast-food chain, wanted a new niche. The result, Med Grill, a joint venture, has made its debut on the lower level of Trump Tower, 725 Fifth Avenue (56th Street). A cafeteria-style area, with a coffee bar, sandwiches, salads, pastas and a different risotto every hour, offers tables with the waterfall as backdrop. Nearby is a new bar and a moderately priced restaurant.

title: Drogheda Journal;New Curse, They Say, From the Land of Cromwell
description: Since 1649, when Oliver Cromwell and his Roundheads massacred more than 1,000 Irishmen, there has been a suspicion of English actions here in this hilly town on the River Boyne, three miles from the Irish Sea.

title: Vote Blocks Term-Limit Bill; Political Echoes May Linger
description: A proposed constitutional amendment to limit Congress members' years in office was blocked in the Senate today by a Democratic filibuster, and Republicans served notice that they would make a political issue of it.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: GOLF;Ben Wright in Betty Ford Clinic
description: BEN WRIGHT, the veteran CBS Sports golf commentator, has checked into the Betty Ford Center in Rancho Mirage, Calif., for undisclosed treatment, persons familiar with the situation said yesterday. Wright is serving a four-year paid suspension for remarks he made last year about lesbianism on the LPGA Tour and about the newspaper reporter who disclosed them.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Disney Loses $25 Million, As Creative Division Falters
description: The Walt Disney Company reported a $25 million loss for its second quarter yesterday, reflecting the costs of acquiring Capital Cities/ ABC Inc. and accounting changes that required it to write down the value of its theme parks.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Babcock International Sees Lower Earnings
description: The Babcock International Group, a British engineering and power-plant manufacturing company, said yesterday that profit for its fiscal year would be significantly below market forecasts. As a result, shares fell as much as 20.5 pence, to 108, a low for the stock, before recovering to 113 pence.

title: Service for Carol Hamilton
description: A memorial service for Carol Hamilton, press secretary to Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, will be held at 3 P.M. on Friday in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University. Among the scheduled speakers are former Mayor David N. Dinkins, Representative Charles B. Rangel, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and George Stephanopoulos, senior adviser to President Clinton.

title: TV Notes;Program Notes
description: *Bill Cosby's television wife for eight years on "The Cosby Show," Phylicia Rashad, will play his wife again on Mr. Cosby's new sitcom for CBS, which is based on the British series "One Foot in the Grave." The show, set to begin in the fall, is still untitled.

title: Workplace Fears Disputed In Politically Delicate Study
description: In a politically delicate effort to show that it is helping to create jobs that pay well, the Clinton Administration issued a study today that disputes one of the most prevalent stereotypes about the economy, concluding that most new jobs created in the service industries are relatively high-paying executive and management positions.

title: Metro Matters;Judge Wins This Round By Losing
description: In that muddy way the political system has of softening the rough edges with improbable compromise, the Criminal Court judge accused of mishandling domestic violence cases just won a round in his fight to stay on the bench -- by losing. And the Commission on Judicial Conduct asserted its quasi-independence from Gov. George E. Pataki by almost doing as he asked.

title: No Headline
description: Above all, it is proof positive that progress is again possible on health reform, and that the ghosts of gridlock for the 1994 debate no longer haunt our work on health care."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Volkswagen Profits Soared in First Quarter
description: Volkswagen A.G., Europe's largest car maker, said yesterday that its profit soared to 116 million marks ($76.3 million) in the first quarter of the year from only 13 million marks a year earlier. The company's sales climbed 15 percent, to 24.47 billion marks ($16.1 billion).

title: Texas Drilling Acquisition
description: Patterson Energy Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy the Tucker Drilling Company for about $23 million in stock. Patterson Energy, based here, and Tucker Drilling, of Angelo, Tex., both provide contract drilling, exploration and development of oil and natural gas.

title: White House Seeks Release Of Intelligence Budget Total
description: What had once been one of the Government's best-kept secrets, the annual budget of the Central Intelligence Agency and its sister spy agencies, would no longer be so secret under a proposal announced today by the White House.

title: Don't Turn Back on Affirmative Action
description: To the Editor:

title: Times Square Heralds Megastore
description: Good glitz," said Charles Millard, president of the New York City Economic Development Commission, looking somewhat sheepish yesterday, his pants legs soaked with champagne, amid a crush of shoppers and curiosity seekers at the opening of the Virgin Megastore Times Square.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;False Theft Claim Is Charged
description: A 32-year-old Hammonton man was charged yesterday in Philadelphia with falsely claiming he had been carjacked in that city at knifepoint and forced to drive his attacker to Atlantic City, the police said. After the man, Dennis J. Pittman, contacted the police in Atlantic City on Monday, he was driven to his home, where the Philadelphia police picked him up for further questioning.

title: Ex-Principal Pleads Guilty to School Theft
description: The former principal of a Brooklyn elementary school interrupted his week-old trial yesterday to plead guilty to stealing $20,000 from the Board of Education through false work claims and theft of supplies.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Swiss Bank Buys Private Banking Units
description: The Swiss Bank Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the international private-banking arm of Standard Chartered P.L.C. in an effort to increase its international asset management business. The unit has more than $5 billion in assets. Swiss Bank also said it had bought a private portfolio of international assets worth $1 billion from the Chase Manhattan Private Bank, a move that would beef up the Swiss bank's United States private-banking business.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Grant for Veterans Home
description: The United States Department of Veterans Affairs has awarded an $8.3 million grant to be used for the completion of a nursing home for veterans in central New Jersey, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SPIEGEL INC., Downers Grove, Ill., sold Cara Corp., its information technology consulting unit, to Cara Acquisition Corp., a new company owned by William Blair Capital Partners L.L.C. and Cara's management. Terms were not disclosed.

title: TV Notes;Fighting an Injunction
description: The syndicated tabloid news magazine "Inside Edition" will include a report on Friday (at 7:30 P.M. on Channel 4 in New York) that has led to a precedent-setting injunction against its producers, citing invasion of privacy.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Leader of Reign of Terror Is Dying, Cambodia Says
description: The Cambodian Government says Pol Pot, the Khmer Rouge leader whose reign of terror left possibly more than one million people dead in the mid-1970's, may be terminally ill and near death.

title: BASEBALL;Kamieniecki Is Ready To Be a Yankee Again
description: There were lonesome moments when Scott Kamieniecki did not feel like a member of the Yankees. There were reflective moments when he wondered why he had been nudged aside once again. There were distressing moments when the major leaguer could not believe he was pitching another game at the Class A level.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICAN SPORTING GOODS TO ACQUIRE AVIA BRAND
description: Reebok International Ltd. signed a letter of intent yesterday that calls for the American Sporting Goods Corporation to buy nearly all the operating assets and business of Reebok's Avia Group International Inc. The purchase price was not disclosed. Reebok, based in Stoughton, Mass., said in January that it intended to sell Avia to focus on its Reebok and Rockport brands. The deal is expected to close by the end of May. American Sporting Goods, based in Irvine, Calif., owns the Turntec and Nevados brands and holds the United States license for Ocean Pacific footwear.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Bristow Is Out as Hornets Coach
description: Nearly six months after ALONZO MOURNING left the Charlotte Hornets, the fallout continued yesterday with the dismissal of Coach ALLAN BRISTOW.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Agency Goes East; A Second Goes West
description: Two agencies are making plans to expand.

title: U.S. Checks Phoenix Company For Lapses in Handling Blood
description: The Government is investigating whether anyone received tainted blood from a Phoenix company. But officials said the blood supply is safe and getting safer every year.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;RJR Nabisco Improved in First Quarter
description: Lifted by better-than-expected sales in its premium cigarette brands and by worldwide volume and sales growth in its tobacco and food businesses, the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation reported improved first-quarter results yesterday, a week after it had beaten back a proxy challenge by the investors Bennett S. LeBow and Carl C. Icahn.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Kraft Foods Shifts Agencies for Cereals
description: The Kraft Foods unit of the Philip Morris Companies is realigning its agency roster by returning the account of its Post Grape-Nuts cereal brand to Grey Advertising in New York after a year at FCB/Leber Katz Partners in New York; it is also reassigning Nabisco Shredded Wheat cereals to Grey after 10 years at FCB/Leber Katz. Though total billings were not disclosed, the Grape-Nuts account was estimated at $25 million.

title: At the Nation's Table: Williamston, Mich.;You Think Water Grows on Trees?
description: Branch water is to bourbon as Coca-Cola is to rum. But what exactly is branch water?

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Kemp Is Out for One Playoff Game
description: SHAWN KEMP, the Seattle SuperSonics' leading scorer and rebounder, was suspended for his team's first game in the playoffs and fined $7,500 for his fight with Denver's TOM HAMMONDS, the National Basketball Association announced yesterday. Hammonds was also suspended and fined $7,500. Since his team missed the playoffs, he will miss the first game of next season.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Remy Cointreau Profit Hurt by Cognac Slump
description: The French liquor and wine company Remy Cointreau said yesterday that its revenue in the year that ended on March 31 rose 1.2 percent, but the company said it expected to report lower profit for the year. Remy Cointreau attributed the profit drop to a 13.5 percent decline in cognac sales. In the 1995 fiscal year, the company earned 276 million francs (about $54 million).

title: A Naval Academy in Need of Help
description: Is the United States Naval Academy suffering from deep ethical decay, or just a few bad students who slipped through the screening process? In the last year, midshipmen have been charged with rape, drug use and running a car-theft ring. There have been enough such embarrassments to suggest that the problem is systemic and that fundamental reform of the academy is in order.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Mexico Ex-Governor Tied To Cover-Up of Killings
description: An investigation by the Mexican Supreme Court released today found that the former Governor and several officials of the state of Guerrero tried to cover up the killing of 17 poor farmers by police last June.

title: Subway Service on 6 Lines Is Halted By Brooklyn Electrical Explosion
description: An electrical cable explosion in downtown Brooklyn caused a power failure in the subway system yesterday evening, forcing throngs of people to flee up dim station stairs and immobilizing trains that carry tens of thousands of people between Manhattan and Brooklyn.

title: Internet Software Developer in an Acquisition
description: Spyglass Inc., one of the two leading developers of Internet browser software plans to announce on Wednesday that it has acquired Surfwatch Software Inc., a maker of technology for filtering content available on the World Wide Web, several people familiar with the agreement said today.

title: Stock Posts Decline At St. John Knits
description: The stock of St. John Knits Inc. fell 7 percent yesterday in the wake of news that the founders' daughter had been named president.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Digital Stock Soars on Rise In Earnings
description: After warning investors last month that its personal computer business had experienced an unexpected downturn, the Digital Equipment Corporation reported a 68 percent increase in earnings yesterday for its fiscal third quarter.

title: Journal;Grant's Unquiet Tomb
description: Bob Grant, the popular New York radio talk-show host canned at WABC, has a voice so mean he could make your blood run cold even when he wasn't wishing aloud that Magic Johnson would contract full-blown AIDS or that Ron Brown wouldn't survive his plane crash. But the way he was abruptly yanked from the airwaves last week -- in an opaque two-sentence statement, by one of the world's largest media goliaths -- also induces the chills. This is an ugly story all the way around.

title: Workers in Love, With the Boss's Blessing
description: FOR about a year, Cynthia Jacobs and Scott LaRue had seen each other around. At coed volleyball games, they eyed each other through the net. Many evenings, they could be found at the health club, chatting tentatively between the Stairmaster and the stationary bicycle. Then Mr. LaRue made his move.

title: Mistakes Charged in Schools Construction
description: The agency that builds public schools in New York City has repeatedly botched projects, endangering children and causing delays with mistakes that included building a $300,000 wheelchair ramp under the hoop on a basketball court, a State Senate committee charged today.

title: Yeltsin's Visit to China: Asians Cast a Wary Eye
description: SINGAPORE  While Asian countries regard reconciliation between China and Russia as an immediate plus for regional stability, they also worry that Russian arms and friendship might embolden Beijing to use force to pursue its territorial claims to Taiwan and other parts of Asia.

title: CHRONICLE
description: H. DALE HEMMERDINGER, the president of Atco Properties and Management, a real estate company, wanted to do something to honor the first person he ever hired, 25 years ago, for the firm, PETER L. DiCAPUA, now a senior vice president. "But I didn't want to give him a vacation or golf clubs," he said yesterday. "That's not his style."

title: Vatican Takes the News of a Left-Leaning Italian Government Calmly
description: The Roman Catholic Church in Italy accepted with good grace on Tuesday the inevitability of a government dependent on the support of former and present Communists.

title: Real Estate;On the Delaware River, once the haunts of heavy industry, a company finds a beauty spot for a plant.
description: A COMPANY that makes bathroom cabinets and shower rods is building a manufacturing plant along the Delaware River here, providing a stark contrast to the chemical plants of the early 20th century that still operate nearby.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Certainly, It's No Way To Treat a Champion
description: Pity the poor Houston Rockets, the defending National Basketball Association champions. Hobbled by injuries, jeered for their unimpressive regular-season record (48-34), the Rockets are a team stumbling into the Western Conference playoffs.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Capriati Joins Fed Cup Team
description: JENNIFER CAPRIATI was added to the United States Fed Cup team yesterday, replacing LINDSAY DAVENPORT, who has an injured left wrist. Capriati joins GIGI FERNANDEZ and MARY JOE FERNANDEZ on the team, which plays at Austria on Saturday and Sunday. (AP)

title: Our Towns;Little House on the Market: Homes for Everyman?
description: EVEN Dennis Davey has to admit the house he designed for posterity hides its charms well.

title: CHRONICLE
description: FERN MALLIS, the executive director of the Council of Fashion Designers of America, never sat down to compute how much money she has raised for worthy causes, like fighting AIDS and breast cancer, until the other day. When she did, she was surprised. "It was something like $30 million over the last 12 years," she said, running down a list of causes that have generated contributions from the design and fashion worlds.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;N.B.A. PLAYOFFS
description: N.B.A. EASTERN CONFERENCE PLAYOFFS

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Commuters Gain 3 Minutes
description: Three minutes may not seem like a lotunless, of course, you are late for work. That is how much time commuters will save on the new express PATH trains that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will begin operating next Monday morning from Newark's Pennsylvania Station to the World Trade Center in Manhattan, a spokeswoman for the authority said yesterday. The trains will operate during the morning rush only, at 7:30, 8 and 8:43, and are expected to cut the trip to 19 minutes from 22, said the spokeswoman, D. Joy Faber.

title: TV Notes;Touched by the Ratings
description: If a couple of last weekend's programming experiments are any indication, the next big prime-time battleground is shaping up to be Sunday night.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Training Foreign Doctors
description: Nearly half of the 2,900 students enrolled in medical schools in New Jersey come from other countries -- a relatively high proportion, compared with other states -- and yesterday, some members of the Assembly Budget Committee wondered whether taxpayers should be shouldering the expense of training them.

title: COMPANY NEWS;REPORT BY BAUSCH & LOMB COMMITTEE CLEARS EXECUTIVES
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. said yesterday that a special committee had found no evidence that any company executive participated in or knew about irregularities that required the company to restate its 1993 and 1994 financial results. The committee of independent directors was convened in October to review management practices after Business Week published an article that said the Bausch & Lomb had shipped unsold products and faked invoices to inflate sales figures. The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether the Rochester-based company inflated 1993 sales of contact lenses. The company's board said "appropriate steps" had been taken to strengthen control practices.

title: In a Calm of Sorts, Liberians Venture Out in Shattered Capital
description: After two weeks of bloodshed and panic brought on by the sudden renewal of Liberia's civil war in the streets of this crowded capital, a sort of calm filled the air today as many shell-shocked and destitute citizens came out of hiding, hoping to rebuild their lives.

title: F.B.I. Arrests Navy Machinist On Charges of Military Spying
description: A Navy machinist's mate who once served on nuclear-powered missile submarines was arrested on Monday on charges of military espionage, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: City Faces Big Regents-Diploma Hurdle
description: If all New York City students are required to earn an academically demanding Regents diploma to graduate, schools like Grover Cleveland High School face a formidable, if not hopeless, challenge.

title: Justice For All, Twice
description: It took two trials to do justice in the serial story of Bernhard Goetz.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Paraguay's Army Chief Steps Down, Easing Crisis
description: Paraguay's army commander, who had openly defied a presidential order to step down, relinquished his post today. His action eased a tense standoff with the civilian Government that raised fears that the country was on the verge of a coup.

title: COCKTAILS WITH: Catherine Deneuve;Woman, Actress, Ice Queen And Icon
description: To be absolutely frank, it takes a few minutes to get over the fact that it really is Catherine Deneuve who is sitting just three feet away, sipping a bourbon sour in the lounge of a Left Bank hotel and chatting away as if she were, well, just a middle-aged woman having a pre-dinner cocktail.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Enticing Europe's Shoppers
description: For Christie Wright, shopping at the Gap is not really about buying T-shirts or jeans, though she likes to talk about getting "good quality for relatively cheap prices." It's about her 10-year-old daughter, Charlotte, growing up, watching Gap ads on MTV, and getting a dose of America and its styles, all while shopping near home on Oxford Street. So these days Mrs. Wright bypasses the nearby Stefanel boutique and ventures into the Gap.

title: Cumin and Coriander: Exotic Spices With Familiar Faces
description: CUMIN and coriander are like the Burns and Allen of spices -- approachable, easy to like and always entertaining.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;Oakley Returns to Knicks Practice With a Visor and a Vengeance
description: Worrying about Charles Oakley's physical condition has become old. It is like parents rushing to their fallen but barely scratched child and inquiring "Are you O.K.?" when they should be asking about the welfare of the pavement.

title: U.S. Is Enlisting Doctors In Campaign Against Smoking
description: Doctors should routinely ask patients about their tobacco use and actively work to get those who smoke, chew or sniff tobacco to quit, according to new guidelines released today by the United States Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, an arm of the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Capital Plan For M.T.A. Is Revised
description: In a tacit bow to criticism of its $7.3 billion plan for new trains, buses and stations, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has reduced its borrowing plans by $1 billion, easing pressure to eventually increase fares to repay these debts, M.T.A. and state officials said yesterday.

title: Employee Surveys Put Boorish Bosses on Notice
description: LONDON  Have you been asked lately about your job, your feelings toward your boss or the direction your company has taken? If not, don't despair. Your time is coming. Around the world, companies are embracing employee polls as the latest must-have tool for good managers.

title: Mr. Gingrich and His Volunteer
description: Representative George Miller has filed a new ethics complaint against House Speaker Newt Gingrich. The California Democrat seeks to reopen an investigation into volunteer work done in Mr. Gingrich's office by a telecommunications entrepreneur named Donald Jones while Congress was completing a major overhaul of telecommunications laws.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THE PLACE: A Bergdorf Goodman elevator. I enter on the fourth floor. A couple, late 20's, are the only other passengers until the third floor, when two middle-aged women, in loud conversation and carrying mink coats, come aboard. I don't intentionally listen to them, but it is just about impossible to do otherwise.

title: Sex and the Survival of the Fittest: Calamities Are a Disaster for Men
description: WOMEN have long known that they are not the "weaker sex," but a University of Washington anthropologist says he has proved it. It is not just that women live longer when the going is good. Women are also more likely than men to survive when conditions are at their worst, says the researcher, Dr. Donald K. Grayson.

title: SENATE PASSES HEALTH BILL WITH JOB-TO-JOB COVERAGE;Dole Prods Clinton to Meet on Budget -- VOTE IS UNANIMOUS
description: The Senate today passed legislation to make health insurance coverage portable from job to job in a 100-to-0 vote that masked months of uncertainties, compromises and difficult persuasion.

title: Export Boom In Services Cuts Growth in U.S. Trade Deficit
description: Erasing about half of a huge January increase, the nation's trade deficit shrank to $8.2 billion in February as sales of American services abroad rose to records, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: 2 Ivy League Schools Shun the Matchmakers
description: To the Editor:

title: Ditch the Libya Option
description: To the Editor:

title: Streetcar Named Desire' and 'Gatsby' to Be Operas
description: The Metropolitan Opera and the San Franscisco Opera both announced commissions for new works yesterday, and although the announcements were unrelated, both works are to be based on classics of American literature. The Met has commissioned the composer John Harbison to write "The Great Gatsby," based on the F. Scott Fitzgerald novel. The San Francisco Opera has commissioned Andre Previn to turn "A Streetcar Named Desire," the Tennessee Williams play, into an opera.

title: Mississippi's Latest Equality Issue
description: A decision to mandate equal admission standards for black and white state universities in Mississippi is threatening a dramatic reduction in the number of black college students in the state.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Frazier Says He Won't Play This Year
description: TOMMIE FRAZIER, the quarterback who led Nebraska to consecutive national titles but went undrafted by the National Football League, told the Lincoln, Neb., television station KOLN last night that he will follow his physician's advice and sit out for a year before giving the N.F.L. a shot as a free agent.

title: Megastore in Times Square
description: Times Square's redevelopment took a concrete step forward with the opening of a Virgin megastore on Broadway. Page B2.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Sweden Cuts Rate; More Trims Expected
description: Sweden's central bank cut its chief money-market rate for the ninth time this year, to 6.9 percent from 7.15 percent, in a move to bolster the economy. The rate-cutting is expected to continue, with some forecasting a low of 4.5 percent this year. At the same time, the krona, which would theoretically be weakened by the rate cuts, is continuing a three-year climb.

title: The Victor in Italy's Vote: Low-Key but Confident
description: Romano Prodi, the soft-spoken 56-year-old economics professor now in line to be Italy's next Prime Minister, has been in politics all of a year, much of which he spent on a bus meandering over the backroads of the Italian peninsula.

title: Bahrain Jails 11 in Protest
description: Bahrain has imprisoned 11 people for taking part in anti-government protests, newspapers said today.

title: No Right to Offend
description: To the Editor:

title: Laborers Leave Hall
description: A group of laborers who refused to give up control of their union hall last month have peacefully relinquished the building after losing a battle in Federal court.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Don't Turn Back on Affirmative Action
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Defends Its Silence on Teheran's Arms Smuggling to Bosnia
description: The Clinton Administration today defended its 1994 decision not to block Iranian arms shipments to Bosnia but failed to shed light on how the decision was made or why Congress was not formally informed.

title: Foreign Affairs;Exit Strategy
description: Ever since the Clinton Administration dispatched 20,000 troops to Bosnia to implement the security provisions of the Dayton peace accord, it has never been clear what the U.S. exit strategy was. Yes, there was a clear exit strategy if Serbs, Croats and Muslims all lived up to the provisions of the Dayton agreement and essentially unified Bosnia. If that happened, U.S. troops could easily withdraw after President Clinton's one-year deadline, without Bosnia's collapsing back into war. But that best-case scenario never seemed likely and still doesn't. So the real question has always been how the U.S. will get out of Bosnia after a year without the situation there returning to war, even if the political settlement prescribed by Dayton is not yet in place.

title: U.S. and Britain Object to Iraq Oil Plan
description: The United States and Britain announced today that they want extensive changes in a draft plan to allow Iraq to sell up to $2 billion worth of oil every six months to buy food and medicine for its suffering civilians.

title: Invalid G.M. Shares Re-emerge in Europe
description: A batch of invalidated General Motors stock certificates, which were supposed to have been destroyed four years ago, have emerged again in Europe.

title: Is the Chechen Rebel Leader Dead? All Russia Is Wondering
description: The fate of the leader of the rebellion in Chechnya became an urgent riddle tonight after a senior Chechen official said that he had been killed earlier this week in a Russian rocket attack.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TRUSTCO DECIDES NOT TO PURSUE ACQUISITION OF ALBANK
description: The Trustco Bank Corporation said yesterday that it would not pursue a proposed $460 million acquisition of the Albank Financial Corporation. Last month, Trustco, a banking company based in Schenectady, N.Y., offered cash and stock totaling $40 for each of Albank's shares, or $33.33 a share after accounting for Albank's recent 6-for-5 stock split. Albank, the Albany-based parent of Albank F.S.B., rejected the offer, saying the bank was not for sale. Albank shares fell $2.25 yesterday, to $27.125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: G.O.P. Moderates in House Face Dilemma on Wildlife Bill
description: Moderate Republicans, who hold a crucial bloc of votes on sensitive environmental issues, are in an uncomfortable position as the House prepares to take up a bill making it harder for the Fish and Wildlife Service to limit recreation and hunting on Federal wildlife refuges.

title: Grumman's Past Is Auctioned, Too
description: Although there were industrial diamonds in the drill bits and gold and platinum in some of the computer-driven tools, none of the bidders at the auction in Northrop Grumman's machine shop here, where workers once built jet fighter planes, were looking for jewelry today.

title: Judge Reinstates Board Accused of Corruption
description: Saying Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew acted too hastily in suspending a South Bronx school board, a state judge returned control of District 7 to the nine-member board.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;MONSANTO CO. (MTC,N)
description: The Monsanto Company said yesterday that its earnings rose 13 percent in the first quarter, pushed up by strong profits in its agricultural and pharmaceutical businesses. Still, the results were lower than Wall Street had forecast.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Saudi Petrochemicals Show 32% Profit Drop
