description: The Saudi Basic Industries Corporation, the Middle East's largest producer of petrochemicals, said yesterday that its profit plunged 32 percent in the first quarter on weaker prices for its products. Profit fell to 1.14 billion riyals ($304 million) from 1.68 billion a year earlier. Ibrahim ibn Salamah, the company's managing director, attributed the profit decline to weaker petrochemical prices on the world market. Revenue fell 17 percent, to 4.9 billion riyals, even as the company's total production rose to 5.6 million tons from 5.2 million tons. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Judge Gives Ousted Board Its School District Again
description: Accusing Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew of acting rashly when he suspended a South Bronx school board in February, the morning after a televised report of corruption, a state judge returned control of School District 7 yesterday to the nine-member board.

title: At the Met, the Artists Backstage
description: By Saturday afternoon, the Metropolitan Opera will have presented "La Boheme" 16 times this season. During the string of performances, which started in December, there have been five Mimis, three Rodolfos, three Marcellos and two conductors. Six of these artists were making their company debuts, from the much-touted lyric tenor Roberto Alagna, two weeks ago, who is to sing again tonight , to the little-known Chilean soprano Cristina Gallardo-Domas on Wednesday.

title: Dole Isn't Alone In Exploiting Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: Appeals Court Halts Takeover
description: Regulators who allowed MAC, the nation's largest automated teller machine network, to grow should have given opponents a chance to fight, an appeals court panel ruled today.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;UAL and Southwest Post Earnings Results
description: The parent of United Airlines said yesterday that operating earnings soared in the first quarter as the number of its passengers increased despite relatively high fares.

title: No Headline
description: SNORING is no joke, certainly not to the snorer's sleepless companion and often not to the snorer, either. Roommates have moved out of snorers' bedrooms, spouses have filed for divorce and at least one man -- a notorious gunfighter named John Wesley Hardin -- committed murder when he could no longer take the incessant noise.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;America Not So Hospitable
description: The trans-Atlantic retail traffic, of course, goes both ways, and Europeans can receive a harsh welcome in the United States. One European who learned the hard knocks of American retailing was Luciano Benetton.

title: BASEBALL;Key Shoulders the Load, But Yanks Drop the Ball
description: Joe Vitiello flicked the baseball off the end of his bat and it sailed lazily into medium center field. The ball stayed in the air long enough to be caught, but what looked like a third out turned into a devastating hit because Bernie Williams was playing deep in center and because Paul O'Neill slowed down in right after figuring that Williams would corral it.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NOWSCO SEEKS ALTERNATIVES TO BJ SERVICES BID
description: Nowsco Well Service Ltd. said yesterday that it would recommend that shareholders reject a takeover offer from the BJ Services Company worth $403 million (Canadian), or $296 million (United States). Nowsco, an oil service company in Calgary, Alberta, said the offer was inadequate. The company added that it was pursuing alternatives and that it had entered into confidentiality agreements with a number of parties, which it did not identify. BJ Services, a Houston-based provider of oil and gas services, made its offer of $27 (Canadian) a share earlier this month. It is to expire May 17.

title: Passing of Regents' Exams To Be Required for Diploma
description: The New York State Board of Regents intends to approve a plan on Wednesday that will require every public school student in the state to pass rigorous Regents examinations to earn a high school diploma, a plan widely considered to be the most significant change in state education policy in more than a decade.

title: At the Nation's Table: Rutherford, Calif.;Like Squeezing Oil From a Grape
description: Bob Pestoni is known as the trashman of Napa Valley. For 30 years, his family has run Upper Valley Disposal and Recycling, collecting household, commercial and agricultural waste products, including huge amounts of pomace produced by 42 Napa Valley wineries after grapes have been crushed.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Three Marketers Name Agencies
description: Three consumer marketers have named agencies already on their rosters to help market new products.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NORTHWEST AIRLINES PLACES ORDER FOR 20 AIRCRAFT
description: Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft consortium, said yesterday that the Northwest Airlines Corporation had ordered 20 additional aircraft valued at $1 billion, making Northwest its biggest airline customer of A320's. Airbus said the order, which completes the carrier's previously announced intentions, brings the number of Northwest's A320's to 70. Northwest will take delivery of 13 aircraft in 1998 and 7 in 1999. The A320's, which can seat 150 passengers, will replace older planes.

title: CHRONICLE
description: STEFANIE POWERS, the film and television actress, has won a libel suit against The Sun, a London newspaper. The Evening Standard reported yesterday that Miss Powers settled out of court for about $105,000, plus $45,000 in legal fees. In addition, she received an apology in court for the newspaper's allegations that she had sexually abused an assistant.

title: Opening Housing to Hispanic Chicagoans
description: Living in a cramped apartment above a North Side tavern, Raquel Gonzalez-Sypien, 60, puts up with the noise and the mice because the $450 rent is all she can afford. She had applied for federally subsidized housing as far back as 1978, but lost her spot on a waiting list for failing to submit some follow-up paperwork.

title: Virtual Ethics
description: When is it all right to copy software or an image from the Internet? As more and more students build their own pages on the World Wide Web, educators face the challenge of teaching ethics that have yet to be formulated by adults concerning copyright and other intellectual property issues in cyberspace.

title: Ethiopia Trial Masks the Withering of a Nation
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Nation's Table: Chicago;Haute Cuisine, The Thai Way
description: When Arun Sampanthavivat opened Arun's Restaurant in a storefront on Chicago's North Side, the decor was bare-bones, but its Thai food was extravagant. Eleven years and one move later, Arun's (pronounced ah-ROONS) is in a home that matches its food.

title: Panel Finds Bias in Connecticut Courts
description: The state court system is biased against minorities, with black and Hispanic people largely absent from top judicial positions, minority defendants subject to harsher treatment than white defendants for similar crimes, and juries that are disproportionately white, a special state task force reported today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Botha Loses Appeal; Moorer-Schulz Is On
description: A Federal court in Philadelphia yesterday refused to hear an appeal from FRANCOIS BOTHA, who lost his International Boxing Federation heavyweight belt in March after being disqualified for steroid use following his last fight. The ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit removes the final legal obstacle to a heavyweight title bout between MICHAEL MOORER and AXEL SCHULZ, who had lost to Botha before Botha's positive steroid test. The Moorer-Schulz bout is set for June 22 in Germany. (AP)

title: Dole Isn't Alone In Exploiting Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: A Secret Arms Deal Between Iran and Croatia Comes to Light
description: Iran and Croatia signed a secret military cooperation agreement last December that included an Iranian proposal to deliver surface-to-surface missiles to Sarajevo and Zagreb as well as a plan to exchange Croatian and Iranian military personnel, senior Croatian officials and Western diplomats said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Talks Continuing on Viacom Cable Channel
description: Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman of Viacom Inc., and Edgar Bronfman Jr., the chief executive of the Seagram Corporation, met again yesterday in an effort to resolve their differences over the introduction of Viacom's new cable channel, TVLand, according to several executives close to the talks.

title: HOCKEY;Mission Accomplished: Rangers Even the Series
description: Now it is the Rangers with the momentum in this tense, unorthodox and highly entertaining first-round series of the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Wine Talk
description: YOU know those oddballs who go up and down the beach early in the morning with metal detectors, looking for coins? Well, they probably have better luck than people out looking for reasonably priced Burgundy.

title: COMPANY NEWS;VENTURE SEEKS TO DEVELOP SKIN TREATMENTS
description: Pfizer Inc., Oncogene Science Inc. and New York University said yesterday that they had agreed to form a company to develop products to treat skin conditions like baldness, wrinkles and pigmentation disorders. Pfizer, a New York-based pharmaceutical company, will hold 82 percent of the venture. Oncogene, a biopharmaceutical concern in Uniondale, L.I., will hold 14 percent. New York University will have the option to acquire 4 percent. The new company, called the Anaderm Research Corporation, will seek to develop drugs that target biological mechanisms underlying various skin conditions, some of which New York University has already identified.

title: The Goetz Verdict
description: The trial of the subway shooter Bernhard Goetz that ended yesterday was a mirror image of the one that polarized New York in 1987. Then, Mr. Goetz was acquitted of attempted murder in the shooting of four black youths who asked him for $5. This time a civil jury awarded one of those youths, Darrell Cabey, $43 million in damages.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Stores Destroyed in Blaze
description: A fire that broke out Monday night at the Acme Shopping Center burned for more than seven hours yesterday, destroying a supermarket and four other stores.

title: Leading Computer Hacker Strikes a Plea Agreement
description: Kevin Mitnick, the country's most notorious computer hacker until he was tracked down in an electronic manhunt and arrested last year, has reached a plea bargain in which he has admitted possessing stolen cellular telephone devices and violating terms of probation that resulted from a previous computer break-in.

title: COMPANY NEWS;STERLING CHEMICALS REJECTS HUNTSMAN'S OFFER
description: The Huntsman Corporation, the nation's largest privately held chemical company, said yesterday that it offered on April 15 to pay $12 a share for Sterling Chemicals Inc. but that Sterling rejected the bid. The offer totaled $780 million, including $113 million in debt that Huntsman would have assumed. Shares in Sterling rose 50 cents yesterday, to $12.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. In January, Houston-based Sterling said it had hired Lazard Freres & Company to help explore ways to increase shareholder value, and that it was discussing a possible sale with several parties. Sterling shares rose 35 percent, to $12.50, on that day.

title: Disputed Issue In Senate Bill: Mental Care
description: The health insurance bill passed by the Senate today would make an immense change in national health policy by requiring insurers to provide coverage for mental illnesses that is equivalent to the coverage provided "for other conditions" like heart disease, diabetes and cancer.

title: BASEBALL;Jones Crushes Late-Night Homer to Propel Mets
description: By the time the ball left Chris Jones's bat, the night had turned soggy then wacky, and then the night turned into morning. Beyond midnight and beyond reason, with a soaked crowd reduced to friends and family, the Mets played a game that had interminable written all over it.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF TRAVELERS/AETNA RISE ON FIRST DAY
description: Shares of the Travelers/Aetna Property Casualty Corporation rose $2.50 yesterday, to close at $27.50 in their first day of trading. In the fourth-largest offering this year, Travelers/Aetna, which is based in Hartford, sold an 8.8 percent stake to raise $875 million. The company, the nation's fourth-largest property and casualty insurer, sold 35 million shares at $25. About 14.4 million shares were traded yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. At current prices, Travelers/Aetna has a market value of $10.8 billion. Travelers Group Inc. of New York formed Travelers/Aetna by merging its insurance subsidiary with the Aetna Life and Casualty Company's property and casualty unit, which Travelers bought this month for $4 billion.

title: Ruling Curbs Jury's Role On Patents
description: In one of the most important patent decisions in years, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that in a patent infringement suit it was up to judges, rather than juries, to resolve the crucial issue of what a patent means.

title: TV Notes;A Cartoon Winner
description: Soon after the Cartoon Network started in 1992, its creators began a companion project to generate new cartoons. Word went out to animators, both established and new, inviting them to submit seven-minute cartoon pilots. Those judged best are then developed at the Hanna-Barbera studio and shown on the 24-hour Cartoon Network in a series called "World Premiere Toons." The lure is that the most popular ones may get a full-time slot.

title: Beef, Beef, Everywhere, But Hardly a Nibble to Eat
description: I KNOW how to cook three things: chili with ground beef, spaghetti with ground beef, and chicken. Thanks to the mad cow scare in Britain, it's down to chicken.

title: Closing an Era of Enmity
description: An improbable but vitally important political drama is unfolding in Gaza this week. The Palestine National Council, for years a kind of parliament in exile of the Palestine Liberation Organization, has convened on Palestinian-administered territory to debate and vote on changes in the P.L.O. charter that would remove all calls for Israel's destruction.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK Jury Says Goetz Must Pay

title: PRO FOOTBALL;With No Offer for Mitchell, Jets Cut Him
description: The Jets' disenchantment with Johnny Mitchell, once acclaimed as a potential star tight end, ended yesterday when they simply dropped him, unable to get even a low-round draft choice for the former No. 1 dpaft pick.

title: Grandeur and Modernity in New Library
description: There are no Corinthian columns, no ornate coffered ceilings, and the grand staircase is of stainless steel and terrazzo rather than marble. No lions guard the door. But the new Science, Industry and Business Library of the New York Public Library, which is to be dedicated this morning at Madison Avenue and 34th Street, is every bit as grand, in its way, as the library's great main building at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street.

title: More Preschoolers Cared For By Nonrelatives, Report Says
description: When mothers go back to jobs, the task of caring for preschoolers most often falls to caretakers outside the family, and a growing number of them are in day-care and preschool centers, according to a Census Bureau report made public today.

title: Boy Found In Trash Bag Had Been In Foster Care
description: The 22-month-old boy whose body was found in a plastic garbage bag last week was one of four children child welfare officials had removed from their mother nearly two years ago, but the children were returned to her last September, according to child welfare agency records.

title: Clinton Chooses Gore Aide to Run the Campaign
description: Ending a long search and months of speculation, President Clinton is expected to name Peter S. Knight, a lawyer and longtime aide to Vice President Gore, to head the day-to-day operations of their re-election campaign, White House officials said tonight. The appointment could be announced as soon as Wednesday.

title: Market Place;A Not-So-Bulletproof Stock Deal From Oliver North
description: Oliver North wants you -- and your money.

title: SOCCER;MetroStars Sign Goal Scorer
description: The MetroStars, desperate for goal scorers, believe they have found their man.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;After Ford takes a greater hand, Mazda consolidates its ad account in Japan.
description: IN a departure from the usual practice in Japan, the Mazda Motor Corporation has chosen to concentrate all its advertising with Hakuhodo Inc., Japan's No. 2 agency behind Dentsu Inc.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Increase in Compaq's Earnings a Surprise
description: After warning Wall Street that its profits would be weak in the first quarter, the Compaq Computer Corporation reported a surprising 8 percent increase in earnings yesterday, belying worries that the personal computer market was weakening.

title: U.S. Agency Clears Merger For Hospitals
description: Federal regulators have given permission to St. Barnabas Medical Center and seven other hospitals in northern and central New Jersey to merge as the wave of hospital consolidations that has been taking place in much of the country begins to be felt in the state.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TENNECO SOLICITS BUYERS FOR NATURAL GAS UNIT
description: Tenneco Inc. is seeking at least $4 billion for its natural gas unit, Dana G. Mead, the company's chairman and chief executive, said yesterday in an interview. Tenneco, based in Greenwich, Conn., wants to sell or spin off Tenneco Energy to shareholders. The company has reviewed offers and is preparing presentations for at least three finalist bidders, Mr. Mead said. The company expects to sell Tenneco Energy and spin off Newport News Shipbuilding by the end of 1996, he said.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Conviction in Carjacking
description: A 26-year-old Irvington man was convicted yesterday in the 1994 murder of a woman who was carjacked while unloading groceries in front of her East Orange home. The defendant, Alonzo Hill, admitted abducting Sandra McKnight, but said that he had not intended to kill her and had not known that an accomplice had a gun.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Airport Losing Passengers
description: Newark International Airport is gaining passengers on international flights but losing a far greater number of domestic travelers, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday. Last year, 22.8 million passengers traveling within the United States used the airport, 6.5 percent fewer than in 1994.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARGOT KIDDER, the actress best known for playing Lois Lane opposite Christopher Reeve in the "Superman" films, has been hospitalized in Los Angeles, Calif., for psychiatric observation, The Associated Press reported yesterday. She was found on Tuesday in the backyard of a Glendale, Calif., home, disheveled and disoriented, claiming she had been stalked and assaulted, the police department said.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bank of Scotland Has Higher Profit
description: The Bank of Scotland said yesterday that its pretax profit rose a higher-than-expected 21 percent in the year that ended on Feb. 29. Profit before taxes rose to L545 million ($828.4 million), from L449.7 million the previous year.

title: Nasdaq Posts Slight Rise In Short Sales Outstanding
description: The number of open positions on short sales in the Nasdaq market rose slightly in the month ended April 15, the National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday.

title: SORTING IT OUT;House and Senate House Bills: Similar at Core, but Conflict Lurks
description: Both the House and Senate versions of the health bill contain popular provisions that help people keep their health coverage when they take a new job. But each chamber of Congress added some provisions that are more controversial, and the difference must be resolved by a committee of legislators from both the House and Senate.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Reuters in Business Day yesterday about the first- quarter earnings of the ITT Corporation included some outdated references to the company's businesses. The ITT Corporation owns hotels, casinos and professional sports operations; its insurance businesses were spun off into the ITT Hartford Group in December, and its auto products and electronics operations were spun off into ITT Industries at the same time.

title: 1996 N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;The Rangers Heat Up Series But Keep Cool
description: It was no surprise to see Kevin Lowe of the Rangers and Donald Brashear of the Canadiens glowering and growling along the boards Tuesday night during Game 4 of the Eastern Conference quarterfinals at the Molson Center in Montreal.

title: No Headline
description: It bothers me when companies where all the high officers are men say they're making it Take Our Children Day because they don't want to discriminate against boys. Executives with glass ceilings shouldn't throw stones. I think people are afraid to stand up for girls, or they think some affirmative-action bogeyman's going to get them."

title: New York City Council Postures on Term Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: USF&G CORP., Baltimore, an insurance company, said its board had authorized management to buy back as many as 5 million shares, or about 4 percent of its 119.7 million common shares outstanding.

title: As Whitewater Hearings Resume, Clinton Aides Hope Threat Is Fading
description: From an Arkansas courtroom to a Senate hearing room, Whitewater inquiries suddenly seem more manageable to the Clinton Administration, which just months ago was constantly consumed by them.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;King Supports Capriati
description: JENNIFER CAPRIATI, a surprise, last-minute choice for Federation Cup play against Austria this weekend -- should have a chance to defend her Olympic title, the United States team captain, BILLIE JEAN KING, said yesterday. King said she would push for International Tennis Federation support to take Capriati's case to the International Olympic Committee and allow her to enter "as an exception."

title: Clinton Signs Measure on Terrorism and Death Penalty Appeals
description: President Clinton today signed broad legislation that provides new tools and penalties for Federal law-enforcement officials to use in fighting terrorism and also sharply restricts the ability of death row inmates and other prisoners to appeal their sentences.

title: Essay;Cradle of Terror
description: From the Bekaa Valley in Syrian-occupied Lebanon, the dictator Hafez al-Assad mounts two separate terrorist wars.

title: Crackdown at Naval Academy
description: Expanding its response to a string of embarrassing incidents, the United States Naval Academy cracked down today on privileges for midshipmen, shortening weekend leave, ordering upperclassmen to wear their uniforms off the academy grounds and rolling back the weeknight curfew.

title: Don't Criticize the Israelis Alone for the Crisis in Lebanon;No Peace to Come
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Charles W. Bray was named to the new position of president and chief executive of NIMA International, Washington, an infomercial industry association. He had been senior vice president and chief financial officer of the Food Marketing Institute, Washington.

title: AT HOME WITH: Sarah Jessica Parker and Matthew Broderick;Too Cute for Words?
description: IN the public mind, celebrity couples tend to take on qualities as a unit, often as a result of the projects they made famous together. Think of the weathered passion of Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton, so brutally caricatured (or maybe not) in "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" Or the crusty affection of Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TYSON SEEKS TO SELL 4 BEEF PLANTS AND PORK PLANT
description: Tyson Foods Inc. said yesterday that it wanted to get out of the pork and beef business and would try to sell five plants that employ about 1,600 people. Tyson, the nation's leading poultry processor, said that if buyers could not be found, the company would keep operating the plants. Tyson's chairman and chief executive, Leland E. Tollett, said the company would have to invest enormous amounts to become a major competitor in the pork and beef business. The beef plants are in Harlingen and Garland, Tex., and Sioux Center and Orange City, Iowa. The pork plant is in Holland, Mich.

title: Another G.O.P. Environmental Folly
description: For various reasons, few of them honorable and most of them political, members of the House of Representatives approved a bill yesterday called the National Wildlife Refuge Improvement Act. The bill is grotesquely misnamed. It will in fact weaken the refuge system. The nation will be well served if the Senate -- which has no companion measure on the table -- does nothing, thus consigning the House action to the annals of legislative trivia where it belongs.

title: Serial Killer Auction Is Set
description: Property belonging to the serial killer Jeffrey L. Dahmer, including the tools he used to murder and often dismember 17 young men and boys, will be auctioned to raise money for the families of his victims, a lawyer said today. The lawyer, Robert Steuer, said a Wisconsin judge on Tuesday had cleared the way for the sale. No date was set for the auction. The judge ordered the sale of a sledge hammer, hatchet, hypodermic needle and other property over the objection of prosecutors, who said it might glorify Mr. Dahmer, who was killed in prison in 1994.

title: WHAT ROOMS MAY BE WEARING NEXT YEAR;Give Me That Old-Time Millennium
description: On Day 3 of the International Home Furnishings Market, the world's largest retail furniture expo, buyers hurrying between showroom buildings paused while the skies darkened and the temperature dropped. A funnel cloud that someone reported at the city limits never did touch down, but weather remained on everyone's mind.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Wit Capital Corp., New York, to Mezzina/Brown Inc., and M/B Interactive, New York, to handle advertising and marketing and develop World Wide Web programming for the investment bank and brokerage firm, in exchange for Mezzina/ Brown's receiving an undisclosed equity stake in Wit. The billings were not disclosed.

title: Mandate That H.I.V. Troops Be Discharged Is Set for Repeal
description: Congressional leaders agreed today to repeal legislation that would have forced the Defense Department to oust members of the military who tested positive for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Italy's Center-Left Coalition
description: The churning and reshaping of Italian politics that began with the spectacular corruption scandals of 1991 crossed a significant threshold this week. The surprising electoral success of the center-left Olive Tree coalition brought Italian Communists, under a new name and platform, into office for the first time since World War II.

title: Tran Van Tra of Vietnam, 77; Commander in Tet Offensive
description: Gen. Tran Van Tra, who commanded Vietnamese Communist raids on Saigon during the Tet offensive of 1968 and directed the final assault on the city when it fell in 1975, died on Saturday, Vietnamese newspapers reported this week. He was 77.

title: Developer Declares Against Thurmond
description: Elliott Close, a wealthy real estate developer, formally announced today that he would seek the Democratic nomination for the Senate seat of South Carolina's popular 93-year-old Republican incumbent, Strom Thurmond.

title: Take Our Goldfish to Work Day
description: Now, don't get me wrong. I love my goldfish. There are three of them, standard issue to some but very special to me. Yet it bothered me that they spent their day doing traditional goldfish-type things. Not that swimming and gliding and eating and kissing me through the glass bowl aren't good things -- they are. I just felt the fish were capable of more. All that energy spent to-ing and fro-ing could be poured into more productive channels, if you will.

title: Defendant in Bosnian War-Crime Case Is Sent Home, Gravely Ill
description: A Bosnian Serb general charged with crimes against humanity was released today from United Nations custody in The Netherlands after doctors concluded that he is terminally ill.

title: COLLEGE LACROSSE REPORT
description: Harvard

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Torricelli Reveals Tax Return
description: For the first time since he was elected to Congress in 1982, Representative Robert G. Torricelli made his tax return public yesterday, saying his 1995 income taxes totaled $64,006. His earnings, $254,274, included $126,648 from the sale of assets in a blind trust, said his campaign manager, David Plouffe. Mr. Torricelli's likely Republican opponent for a Senate seat, Representative Richard Zimmer of Delaware Township, reported 1995 earnings of $133,603 with taxes of $23,097.

title: Hevesi to Have Surgery
description: City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi told reporters yesterday that he has prostate cancer and will undergo surgery next week to remove his prostate. He said his doctors have told him that the surgery should remove all traces of the cancer.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Schedule Blesses the Jets With Some Weak Foes
description: There is something to be said for finishing with the worst record in the National Football League. The Jets have realized part of that by getting the No. 1 overall selection in the college draft. And with the release of the N.F.L.'s 1996 schedule, they are about to realize the other benefit -- a weak schedule.

title: The Pop Life
description: A Good Week for Blowfish

title: The Regressive Skies
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Philips Electronics Profit Falls 31 Percent
description: Philips Electronics N.V. said yesterday that its first-quarter profit before special items fell 31 percent as semiconductor sales slipped and weak demand hurt the consumer electronics unit. Philips, Europe's largest electronics maker, said its net income fell to 377 million guilders ($221 million) from 544 million a year earlier.

title: 1996 N.H.L. PLAYOFFS: RANGERS NOTEBOOK;McSorley Practices With No Pain
description: Marty McSorley was twisting and turning in an optional practice for the Rangers here this afternoon, and said afterward that he felt no pain from the groin injury that has kept him out of the series with the Canadiens.

title: Spreckels Sells Sugar Unit
description: Spreckels Industries completed the sale of its sugar unit on Monday to the Imperial Holly Corporation for about $28 million and changed its name to Yale International Inc. Spreckels said on Jan. 9 that it would sell the unit, Spreckels Sugar. The company, based here, makes hoists, actuators, jacks and other material-handling equipment and specialized industrial products. Imperial Holly refines sugar.

title: Israel's Wrath, Iran's Sweet Grapes
description: The fighting in northern Israel and Lebanon that's still raging after two weeks started because Iran wants to destroy the peace process and because Syria -- at least as long as President Hafez al-Assad's dictated peace is rejected by Israel -- backs Iran.

title: Executive Changes
description: MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO., St. Louis, named John Dunham executive vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Sports of The Times;N.B.A. Name Game Keeps Coming Up Flat
description: IN New York, expectations are high and not always realistic.

title: American Express Executive Resigns
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that its chief financial officer, Michael P. Monaco, had resigned after a dispute with his boss, the chairman and chief executive, Harvey Golub, over the assignments of "a number of senior people."

title: The Plumber With Spring in His Toolbox
description: It was just before noon yesterday, and the sun was transforming a breezy day into something nicer. Above in a tree, a migrating scarlet tanager chirped. Joggers huffed, Rollerbladers glided and smiling mothers pushed strollers. Just one thing was wrong, and Bob Zuber, the plumber of Central Park had arrived to fix it.

title: TRACK AND FIELD;15,000 Athletes Competing In This Pear's Penn Relays
description: Bob Hayes, Eamonn Coghlan, Sonia O'Sullivan and Vicki Huber ran here. Jesse Owens and Carl Lewis sprinted and long-jumped here. Edwin Moses and Renaldo Nehemiah hurdled here.

title: Sports of the Times;Baseball's Self-Destruct Artist
description: KIRBY PUCKETT may be all but blind in one eye. Darren Daulton may never be able to hit another single, let alone a home run. Rod Carew will never hug his daughter again.

title: Optometrists Voted New Powers But Lose Bid to Do Laser Surgery
description: Optometrists in Connecticut would gain new authority to treat some forms of glaucoma, to prescribe medication and to perform other minor procedures under legislation that won final passage in the State Senate on Tuesday.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's;Concepts Complete And Not So
description: Sibelius Unfinished

title: Indonesia Newsmen Face Harsher Prison
description: To the Editor:

title: CONGRESS AND WHITE HOUSE FINALLY AGREE ON BUDGET, 7 MONTHS INTO FISCALYEAR
description: After two days of intense negotiations and seven months of living with stopgap spending measures and partial Government shutdowns -- negotiators for Congress and the White House agreed late this afternoon on a permanent budget for the fiscal year that began on Oct. 1.

title: Boston to Give Victim's Widow $1 Million in Wrongful Death Suit
description: The widow of a black minister who died of a heart ailment during a mistaken police raid on his apartment has agreed to a $1 million settlement with the city.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Doom, Gloom and Some Insults
description: Paul Ehrlich and the Population Bomb," on Channel 13 tomorrow night, is an admiring profile of the environmental Cassandra who has been issuing warnings for three decades about overpopulation in the poorest countries and overconsumption in the richest countries. Despite improvements in farming and health that have given ammunition to critics of his famous 1968 polemic, "The Population Bomb," his predictions of famine and revolution remain as dire as ever.

title: Britannica Layoffs Set as House Calls End
description: Encyclopaedia Britannica Inc. said today that it would lay off all 140 sales representatives who make house calls in the United States and Canada and disband a similar sales network of 300 independent contractors.

title: Inherited Damage Is Found In Chernobyl Area Children
description: Ten years after the disastrous nuclear accident at the Chernobyl power plant in the Ukraine, scientists report that they have found inherited genetic damage in people exposed to the fallout.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Mathematicians Say Asteroid May Hit Earth in a Million Years
description: Some bad news from European mathematicians: there seems to be a significant chance that within the next 1.14 million years, an asteroid named 433 Eros could hit Earth, with dire results for the human race and most other species.

title: Mitsubishi Wants Settlement Of U.S. Sexual Harassment Suit
description: Mitsubishi Motor Manufacturing of America, which is facing potentially the biggest Federal sexual harassment lawsuit in history, wants to settle the case, the top executive at the company said today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Allen Is Staying With the Chiefs
description: MARCUS ALLEN, the Kansas City Chiefs' most productive offensive player for three seasons, signed a three-year contract yesterday. Allen, 36, signed with the Chiefs in June 1993 a'ter 11 seasons with the Raiders.

title: Bahrain Curbs Clerics
description: Bahrain's Emir today decreed the establishment of a Government council to screen mosque preachers and to issue rulings on religious issues, a measure apparently aimed at muzzling the Shiite Muslim opposition in the small Persian Gulf state.

title: On Day 2, the Tug of Romance Outweighs the Price of History
description: Kaye Bowles-Durnell of Louisville, Ky., the co-publisher of Pizza Today magazine and co-promoter of the World Pizza Games, spent $9,200 for a watercolor-and-ink drawing by the artist Eugene Berman and $16,200 for a Louis XV style giltwood mirror yesterday. And yet her voice betrayed an almost imperceptible disappointment, not at the notion of staggeringly high prices, but at the fact that she did not get to take home more.

title: P.L.O. ENDS CALL FOR DESTRUCTION OF JEWISH STATE
description: Bowing to the insistent demands of Yasir Arafat, the main assembly of the Palestine Liberation Organization voted today to revoke the clauses in its 32-year-old charter that called for an armed struggle to destroy the Jewish state.

title: Telegraph Publisher to Take Paper Private
description: Conrad Black, the Canadian newspaper owner, took steps to remove his company Telegraph P.L.C. from the London stock market with an offer of L280 million ($420 million) for the 36 percent of the company that he does not already control.

title: At Trial in Tokyo, Guru Says Aim Was to Give 'Ultimate Joy'
description: With the nation glued to television coverage of the event, the leader of a Japanese religious cult refused to enter a plea today as he went on trial on charges of organizing the nerve gas attack on the Tokyo subway system last year, and he defended his activities as an attempt to bring people "ultimate happiness."

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS: Getting a Second Shot and Nailing It;After More Downs Than Ups, the Cavs' Ferry Finally Fits In
description: In the dark of night, a tall man and a woman, both in casual dress, appeared at the security entrance of Gund Arena. It was about 10:30. A guard looked them over, then let them pass.

title: BASEBALL;Again, Mets Burned by the Bullpen
description: Maybe it was a mild case of jet lag or just a tired team in need of a good night's rest. If the problem were that simple, then the Mets could dismiss their lethargic 9-4 loss to the St. Louis Cardinals tonight and rest up for the final game of the two-game series Thursday afternoon at Busch Stadium.

title: AUTO RACING: NOTEBOOK;At Indy, Young Drivers in Old Cars
description: The Indianapolis Motor Speedway announced the entry list for the 1996 Indianapolis 500 last week, and it reflected the upside-down nature of things in this year of the boycott: youthfulness where it is the biggest problem (among the drivers) and years of experience where it does the least good (in the cars).

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Earnings at Nomura Reach 5-Year High
description: Japan's largest securities house, the Nomura Securities Company, announced yesterday that it had its biggest annual profit in five years last year, saying it had been helped by a recovery of Japan's stock market and lower interest rates. Nomura's earnings of 91.49 billion yen ($863 million) for the business year that ended on March 31 were well above the 6.8 billion yen ($64.1 million) it earned a year earlier, but slightly below analysts' forecasts. The figures are for parent current profit, which is a pretax profit including gains and losses made on securities investments and other nonoperating activities. (Reuters)

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Patriots Release Pick
description: Claiming that they failed to do their homework, the New England Patriots yesterday released the draft rights to CHRISTIAN PETER, a Nebraska defensive tackle with a criminal record who was selected in the fifth round last week'nd. "Unfortunately, we did not have information regarding Christian Peter's record at the time we made our draft selection," said BOBBY GRIER, the Patriots' player personnel director.

title: A Methodist First Lady Addresses Her Church
description: Methodist residents of the White House have been a rarity in the 20th century. Ulysses S. Grant was a Methodist, as was his successor, Rutherford B. Hayes. But President William McKinley and his wife, Ida, more than 90 years ago, were the last members of the faith to occupy the Executive Mansion until Hillary Rodham Clinton became First Lady in 1993.

title: WHAT ROOMS MAY BE WEARING NEXT YEAR;Upstart Spirits Tickle Kips Bay
description: IT wasn't the typical show house moment. But then, this isn't the typical Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club Decorapor Show House.

title: Baby Hurt in Theft
description: A 4-week-old baby was critically injured by three elementary school boys who were stealing a tricycle from his home on Monday, the police said today. The infant, Ignacio Bermudez, remained in extremely critical condition at Children's Hospital in Oakland. The child, who was on life support, suffered two skull fractures and internal bleeding. The three boys, two of them 8 and the other 6, were not identified because of their ages. On Tuesday morning they were booked for investigation of attempted murder, Capt. Ray Howard of the Martinez police said.

title: Going, Going, Gone: The Garage Sale Of the Century?
description: This week, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis' children are selling more than 4,000 of her meticulously catalogued personal belongings in a four-day auction at Sotheby's.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Siemens Profits Rise On Overseas Sales
description: The German electronics maker Siemens A.G. said yesterday that its profit rose 15 percent in the six months that ended on March 31 with help from the weaker German mark and expansion in foreign markets. Siemens earned 1.08 billion marks (about $710 million) in the latest half- year. A year earlier the company earned 939 million marks.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Frito-Lay Wins New Product Award
description: Frito-Lay Inc. in Plano, Tex., took top honors last night at the 10th annual Edison New Product Awards ceremony, sponsored by the American Marketing Association.

title: Florida Facing Crisis in Insurance
description: Sarah Anderson says that after Hurricane Opal last year, her street in this small Gulf of Mexico town in the Florida Panhandle "looked like a combat zone," with roof shingles strewn about, chimneys blown down and waterfront houses flooded.

title: Stocks Flat in Tokyo
description: Stock prices were stagnant here this morning, after a Wednesday session that pushed the market to a four-year high for the second time this week. At the midday break today, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 1.30 points at 22,280.75. On Wednesday, the Nikkei rose 162.17 points.

title: In France, Socialized Medicine Meets Gallic Version of H.M.O.
description: The French Government today announced sweeping changes in the national health care system that are intended to curb spending and help tame the budget deficit. The new measures, among other things, will use computers to monitor every patient's costs and penalize doctors who surpass budgets for the care and prescriptions they provide.

title: U.N. and Iraq Suspend Talks on Limited Oil Sales
description: Iraq and the United Nations temporarily suspended talks today on a plan that would allow Iraq to sell a limited amount of oil in order to buy food and supplies for civilians.

title: Why Not Link All Three Airports to Midtown?
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: Treasury Yield Curve
Fulton Market Fish Deliverer Is Kicked Out
description: Citing a case of purloined scallops and other misdeeds, city officials yesterday ousted from the Fulton Fish Market a major seafood delivery company that prosecutors said had once been linked to the Mafia.

title: BASEBALL;Belle Gives His Side of Story
description: Albert Belle, mired in another controversial incident, met yesterday with baseball officials in the hope of producing a quick end to his latest problem.

title: Republicans Seeking to Counter Democrats Over Minimum Wage
description: Republican leaders in the House of Representatives sought today to counter Democratic demands for an increase in the minimum wage by pledging to pass a sheaf of other measures that they said would give low-wage workers better jobs and fatter paychecks.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about this year's National Magazine Awards misstated the given name of the writer of the articles that have won feature-writing awards for GQ two years in a row. He is Tom Junod, not Philip.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Muster Extends Streak

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Big Chinese Securities Firm To Acquire Troubled Rival
description: In a final chapter to the most riveting drama in China's emerging securities markets, directors at Shenyin Securities signed an agreement today to acquire the firm's longtime rival, Shanghai International Securities.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Slide After Auction Of Treasuries
description: The prices of Treasury securities ended lower yesterday, retreating from highs that were reached during the session after an auction of five-year notes was stronger than expected.

title: Bringing Flame to the U.S.
description: The plane that will carry the Olympic flame to Los Angeles, where it will start an 84-day relay across the United States, departed today for Greece.

title: Board Begins Inquiry Into All School Leases
description: Voicing dismay over allegations of mismanagement and profiteering by landlords who lease buildings to the school system, Board of Education officials said yesterday that they were beginning an investigation into all of the city's 193 school leases.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Round 1 to the Knicks, Then Wish 'Em Well
description: To fully appreciate what meager playoff rewards the Knicks have been reduced to shooting for, let us return to the bowels of the Continental Arena, to Mike Fratello's explaining one December night why his Cleveland Cavaliers had no choice but to trade off John Williams and Mark Price, the last two starters from a onetime contender.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Arbor Day Advice

title: U.S. Frees African Fleeing Ritual Mutilation
description: Fauziya Kasinga, who sought sanctuary in the United States in 1994, saying she was escaping her African tribe's custom of mutilating the genitals of young women, was released by Federal immigration authorities yesterday after more than a year of sometimes harsh confinement in a detention center in New Jersey and prisons in Pennsylvania.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Bizarre Behavior, but It's in the Script
description: The reunion of John Barrymore and Nicol Williamson is, if nothing else, a press agent's dream. It was only five years ago that Mr. Williamson played Broadway as the ghost of the stormy and unpredictable Barrymore, in Paul Rudnick's "I Hate Hamlet." That stormy and unpredictable performance included bizarre extemporaneous speeches, unscripted entrances and exits and, most notoriously, Mr. Williamson whacking a fellow actor for real during an onstage sword fight.

title: Christopher's Shuttle Route Stretches to South Lebanon
description: After meeting with the Syrian President, Hafez al-Assad, in Damascus and with Lebanese leaders in southern Lebanon, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said this evening that while an agreement on ending the fighting in the Middle East is closer, significant differences persist between Israel and Syria.

title: 52-Story Comeback Is So Very Trump;Columbus Circle Tower Proclaims That Modesty Is an Overrated Virtue
description: Maybe he slipped under your radar over the last few years. Maybe you came to think of him as a real estate also-ran, or a chewed-over chunk of tabloid fodder.

title: BASEBALL;Hitters Give Kamieniecki A Big Boost
description: Yankee Manager Joe Torre did not know what to expect from Scott Kamieniecki, his new fifth starter by default, now that Dwight Gooden has been relegated to bullpen duty.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: The Metro Matters column yesterday, about the controversy over Judge Lorin Duckman's handling of a domestic-violence case, referred incorrectly to the prosecution's record. Before Judge Duckman released the defendant on bail, the prosecution had asked for more time to prepare for trial only once; it had not been unprepared repeatedly.

title: Chechen Rebels Say Leader Died in Russian Air Attack
description: Chechen rebels mourned their fallen leader today and vowed to carry on the fight against Russian forces for independence for Chechnya, the secessionist republic in southern Russia.

title: Denver Lawyer, Suspect in Killing of His Wife, Commits Suicide
description: A lawyer suspected of killing his estranged wife and a bystander here shot himself to death on Tuesday after being stopped for a traffic violation near Barstow, Calif.

title: 5 Bronx School Officials Are Indicted in Absentee Ballot Fraud
description: Prosecutors charged yesterday that high-ranking officials of a school district in the Bronx conspired to file hundreds of fraudulent absentee ballots in the 1993 school board election to assure victory for candidates they believed would help them keep their jobs.

title: 3M Sets Plant Closing
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said today that it was phasing out a medical and graphic arts imaging business here and laying off 335 employees over the next 15 months. The transfer of operations to Medford, Ore., and Ferrania, Italy, is part of a restructuring of 3M's data storage and imaging system businesses being spun off in July as an independent company called Imation.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Consumer Savings Likely From Order to Utilities The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission ordered electric utilities to open their transmission systems to outside energy providers, which could eventually save consumers billions of dollars a year.

title: Goetz Verdict Clears Injured Son, Mother Says
description: Shirley Cabey performs a little mental trick when she is with her paralyzed, brain-damaged son, Darrell: she refuses to see the wheelchair he will spend the rest of his life in. She just imagines he is a normal 30-year-old, sitting in a chair.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COGECO RAISES BID FOR BROADCASTING COMPANY
description: Cogeco Cable Inc. of Montreal said yesterday that it was raising its offer for the Montreal-based broadcasting company CFCF Inc., to top a competing bid by cable company Group Videotron. In a statement, Cogeco said it was offering $19 (Canadian) and half of a subordinate voting share of Cogeco Cable for each share of CFCF. Cogeco values the offer at more than $23 a share and its previous offer at $20 a share. The new bid values CFCF at about $700 million. Videotron has made a cash takeover offer of a $21.50 a share for CFCF.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on April 16 about Federal approval of a combination of two drugs, clarithromycin and omeprazole, for treating ulcers misstated the affiliation of Dr. David A. Peura. He is chairman of the Ulcer Education Campaign, not president of the American Gastroenterological Association.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MAKER OF ARIZONA TEA TO ADD A BEER
description: Ferolito, Vultaggio & Sons, the maker of the fast-growing Arizona line of teas, announced yesterday that it would introduce a beer, Mississippi Mud Black and Tan. The beer, to be brewed by the Stroh Brewery Company of Detroit, will be a blend of a continental pilsener and a porter, and will be sold in 32-ounce jugs. Don Vultaggio, the chairman of Ferolito, Vultaggio, which is based in Lake Success, L.I., also announced five new Arizona teas, a 20-ounce nonalcoholic Arizona Pina Colada, and a malt-based margarita called Palm Beach.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Honors
description: Frank Lalli, managing editor of Money magazine, New York, was named president of the American Society of Magazine Editors, New York, succeeding Ellen Levine, editor in chief of Good Housekeeping, New York.

title: A Summer of Jazz and Soul All-Stars
description: Both the JVC Festival and the Knitting Factory announced their summer festival plans yesterday. The JVC Jazz Festival's schedule is notable for its low-key line up and its attempt to incorporate some of the city's rich club life by offering special discounts at clubs for JVC ticket holders.

title: Watch Those Costs of Plugging In
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York;Vaudevillian Is Honored, Con Amor
description: THE actor inside Johnny Castro stirs restlessly at the sound of laughter and applause. Never mind that four decades have passed since he last trod the boards in skits about mad monks, Latin lovers and grouchy grandfathers.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;British Reject 2 Power-Industry Takeovers
description: The British Government blocked two big mergers in the electricity industry today, stunning the stock market here.

title: Calendar: Tours, Talk And Auction
description: Blossoming Brooklyn Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, off Eastern Parkway; (718) 622-4433.

title: Female Sterilization Not Foolproof, Study Says
description: Female sterilization is still a highly effective method of contraception, but it is not quite as foolproof as once thought, a new Government study says. The study concluded that 1 in 50 sterilized women could become pregnant during a 10-year span.

title: The Housemother of the Show House
description: THE New York Public Library has its lions. But who needs lions when you have Rella MacDougall?

title: Yeltsin, Grasping at International Coattails, Takes Re-electionCampaign to Beijing
description: Just days after welcoming leaders from major industrial nations to Moscow, President Boris N. Yeltsin arrived in Beijing today for three days of high-profile meetings that both he and President Jiang Zemin of China appear to view as a chance to play to important constituencies at home.

title: Detroit Newspaper Declares Impasse in Strike
description: Declaring an impasse in the 10-month-old strike of its editorial employees, the management of The Detroit Free Press put its final contract offer into effect yesterday, in the process ending the special status of the journalists' union by removing the obligation that all eligible employees join it.

title: Map of Yeast Genes Promises Clues to Diseases of Humans
description: Leaders of an international team involving more than 70 laboratories announced yesterday that they had deciphered the complete genetic blueprint of baker's yeast.

title: Plan Edges L.I.R.R. Closer To a Grand Central Link
description: A Long Island Rail Road link to Grand Central Terminal, long dreamed of by transportation planners, moved a step closer to reality yesterday when the Metropolitan Transportation Authority approved a revised capital plan that included a $50 million down payment on the project.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Korean Challenges Sign Law
description: The owner of a Korean-American advertising agency has challenged the constitutionality of laws here and in six neighboring towns that require foreign-language commercial signs to include English lettering of equal size. The businessman, John Park, contended in a Federal lawsuit filed on April 19 that the requirement discriminates against non-English-speaking people on the basis of national origin.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Out to Save the World With Hope and Guitars
description: WHEN WE WERE GOOD The Folk Revival By Robert Cantwell Illustrated. 412 pages. Harvard University Press. $24.95.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TEXTRON REPORTED TO BE IN TALKS ABOUT UNIT'S SALE
description: Textron Inc. is considering selling its disability insurance unit, the Paul Revere Corporation, to the Provident Companies for about $1 billion, a person familiar with the talks, who insisted on anonymity, said yesterday. Textron, based in Providence, R.I., is trying to shed its financial-services units to focus on core manufacturing businesses, which include making Cessna aircraft and Bell helicopters. For Provident, based in Chattanooga, Tenn., the acquisition would be the latest step in the company's effort to expand. Textron's chief financial officer, Stephen Key, declined to comment on the likelihood of selling Paul Revere. The talks were reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Turner Appearing In Food Courts
description: Turner Private Networks in Atlanta, a unit of Turner Broadcasting System Inc., has signed a two-year, $6 million agreement with the Food Court Entertainment Network in Astoria, Queens, to expand Cafe USA, the network of television monitors Food Court is establishing in shopping malls.

title: Rite Aid Drops Revco Bid After Regulatory Opposition
description: The Rite Aid Corporation abandoned its effort to acquire Revco D. S. Inc. yesterday by withdrawing its $1.8 billion offer, bowing to stern Government resistance.

title: Liberties;Camelot 144
description: Sure, I had aspirations.

title: COMPANY NEWS;QUAKER STATE SAYS IT WILL ACQUIRE BLUE CORAL
description: The Quaker State Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire Blue Coral Inc., which makes car-cleaning products, for more than $100 million in cash and stock. Dallas-based Quaker State produces motor oil and lubricants and markets automotive products and services. Quaker will also assume some of Blue Coral's outstanding debt. Blue Coral, a privately held company in Cleveland, had sales of about $100 million last year. Its leading brands include the Blue Coral line of car-care products: Westley's Bleche-Wite, Black Magic Protectant and Tire Dressing and Touchless Acrylic Restoration Coating.

title: Paraguay Averts a Military Coup, but the Deal Outrages Many
description: Overnight, the shadow of another coup in Paraguay was swept away, but the relief of the people here is tempered by outrage over the compromise the civilian Government made to escape the threat.

title: Methodists Keep Rule Against Homosexuality
description: Coming to grips with an issue that has divided Protestant churches for years, the nation's second-largest Protestant denomination, the United Methodist Church, decisively rejected an attempt today to strike a declaration against homosexuality from the church's official teachings.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;USAir Reports Its Deficit Narrowed From '95 Quarter
description: USAir Group Inc. reported today that its first-quarter loss was considerably smaller than in the comparable 1995 quarter, even though a harsh winter reduced airline travel and revenue in January and February.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Deere Deal With Ukraine
description: Deere & Company completed a $187 million sale of agricultural equipment this week to Ukraine, which it said was the largest farm equipment sale it had ever made. The deal included the sale of 1,049 agricultural combine harvesters and related equipment to Ukragroprombirzha of Kiev. The company said the combines would be produced at the John Deere Harvester Works in East Moline, Ill.

title: Mitsubishi Overture In Harassment Case
description: Mitsubishi Motor Manufacturing of America wants to settle what could become the biggest Federal sexual harassment lawsuit, the company's chairman said, indicating that Mitsubishi was softening its hard line in the case.

title: Tape of Clinton Testimony Is Ordered Sealed
description: A Federal district judge today ordered that all copies of President Clinton's videotaped testimony in a Whitewater-related case be surrendered to the court and placed under seal.

title: 1996 N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;Panthers Put Bruins TO Wall
description: The Florida Panthers moved within a victory of sweeping the first playoff series in their three-year history tonight as John Vanbiesbrouck shut down the Boston Bruins, 4-2.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Clinton to Speak at Princeton
description: President Clinton is to deliver the commencement address at Princeton University, which is celebrating its 250th anniversary, officials said yesterday. Princeton does not usually ask outsiders to speak at graduation, but decided to invite the President because of the anniversary, said Justin Harmon, a university spokesman. The date, June 4, happens to coincide with state primary elections.

title: An Edge for Sun As Microsoft Embraces Java
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., a stock market favorite lately on the strength of its Internet products, has secured a significant endorsement from the Microsoft Corporation and will announce next week that Microsoft is to incorporate Sun's Java software programming language into the Windows 95 personal computer operating system.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Rethinking Unmarked Cars
description: New Jersey, unlike New York and other states, has had no problems with criminals impersonating state troopers and pulling people over on the highway, State Police Superintendent Carl A. Williams Jr. said yesterday. That may be because only 1 percent of the unmarked cars in the state police fleet are used in traffic enforcement, a police spokesman said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMTROL ANNOUNCES DIVIDEND AND POSSIBLE SALE
description: The shares of Amtrol Inc. jumped yesterday after the company said it might put itself up for sale. Amtrol, based in West Warwick, R.I., a maker of flow-control products, said it had hired Smith Barney Inc. and HSBC Securities Inc. as financial advisers to help it explore strategies that could include the sale of all or part of the company. The company also declared a special cash dividend of 70 cents a share that will be paid in addition to its regular quarterly dividend of 5 cents a share. Both dividends will be paid May 15 to shareholders of record as of May 6. Amtrol stock gained $2.75 to close at $19.25 in Nasdaq trading, after hitting $22.25 earlier in the day.

title: G.O.P. Acts to Protect Drinking Water
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Whitman Revises Cost Cuts
description: The Whitman administration has agreed to hold off on two cost-cutting measures proposed in the 1997 budget, State Attorney General Deborah T. Poritz told the Senate Appropriations Committee yesterday. Ms. Poritz said that four state police forensic laboratories would stay open for at least another year and that 39 marine police officers who were due to be laid off would remain on the job for now.

title: Bonn Journal;Germans, Jews and Blame: New Book, New Pain
description: In the half-century since the end of World War II, Germany has undergone cycles of agonized self-interrogation over the Holocaust, focused perhaps on the most overpowering question of all: why was it the Germans who systematically killed six million Jews?

title: Market Place;The S.E.C. chief wades into the battle over accounting rules.
description: THE battle over accounting rules is on, and Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is demanding a bigger role than ever in deciding who picks the people who write the rules.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Europe Blocks Platinum Deal
description: The European Commission rejected a $1.9 billion merger of the platinum units of Lonrho P.L.C. of Britain and Gencor Ltd. of South Africa today and said that it would oppose any other move that would lead to a loss of competition.

title: COMPANY NEWS;360degrees COMMUNICATIONS TO BUY CELLULAR COMPANY
description: The 360degrees Communications Company, the former Sprint cellular division, said yesterday that it was buying the Independent Cellular Network in a deal worth more than $500 million. 360degrees Communications, based in Chicago, said it would assume $362 million in debt from the privately owned Independent Cellular and give the owners, the Crown family of Chicago, 6.5 million shares of 360degrees Communications common stock. At its current value, the stock would be worth $156 million. Shares of 360degrees Communications rose 25 cents, to $24.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. That would make the deal worth a combined $518 million in stock and debt assumption. The takeover would give 360 Communications 3.2 million potential new customers in Pennsylvania, Ohio, Kentucky and West Virginia.

title: Turkey to Investigate Ciller
description: Turkey's Parliament dealt a serious blow to the political prospects of former Prime Minister Tansu Ciller, backing an Islamist motion to investigate allegations of corruption during her years in power.

title: On Coastal Road in Lebanon, Tempting Fate (and Shells)
description: By its 14th day today, the war had a rhythm.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;CIRRUS LOGIC INC. (CRUS,NNM)
description: Cirrus Logic Inc. reported a larger-than-expected loss for its fiscal fourth quarter yesterday, as restructuring charges and a slowdown in demand for PC chips hurt profits and sales.

title: On Daughters-at-Work Day, Some Are Including the Sons
description: On the fourth annual Take Our Daughters to Work Day today there is a lot less talk about discrimination against girls and a lot more about the evils of excluding boys.

title: Judge Barred From Moving His Chambers To California
description: A Federal judge whose rulings have become a political issue cannot move his offices from Newark to California, his colleagues on the bench have decreed. But one judge insisted yesterday that the decision had nothing to do with ideology and everything to do with office space.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Wheat Prices Jump on Concern Of Shortages Before Spring Crop
description: Wheat for delivery before the spring harvest jumped to record highs yesterday as concerns grew that low stockpiles left over from last year's harvest could cause shortages before the spring crop arrives.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about the bond market's activity on Tuesday included erroneous data supplied by Technical Data for the most recent yield curve of selected Treasury securities. A corrected chart appears today on page D18.

title: A Maharajah on the Hustings in India's Elections
description: Among India's maharajahs, Madhavrao Scindia's name is legendary. Seventy-five years ago, he led the Prince of Wales, later King Edward VIII, on a tiger hunt so elaborate that it entered Indian folklore. At a banquet, liqueurs and cigars were served from a solid silver electric train that circled the table, pausing by each guest.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: A Second Career: Getting the Arts Into the Schools
description: She had slipped into the makeshift auditorium of the Oakwood Avenue School in Orange, N.J., with no fuss and joined warm-up exercises with the children before the dance instructor introduced her. "This is Celeste Holm," he said. "She's an actress."

title: P. L. Travers, Creator of the Magical and Beloved Nanny Mary Poppins, Is Dead at 96
description: P. L. Travers, who insisted she had never meant to write for children when the magical nanny Mary Poppins leaped from her pen, died on Tuesday at her home in London. She was 96.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CIGNA TO BUY BACK ABOUT 4.6 MILLION SHARES
description: The Cigna Corporation, the big insurance concern, said yesterday that it planned to buy back as much as $500 million of its stock from investors. Based on Cigna's current stock price, the buyback would represent about 4.64 million shares, or about 6 percent of its 76.5 million outstanding shares. Cigna stock rose $4.375, to $112.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. Philadelphia-based Cigna said that it planned to use internal resources to finance the buyback.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Doctor's Suspension Asked
description: The State Department of Human Services has recommended that a psychiatrist at Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital be suspended for 60 days without pay for making false statements about a 64-year-old patient who suffered a broken neck and died last November after orderlies tried to lift her into a wheelchair, hospital officials said yesterday.

title: Bridge
description: Each year the American Contract Bridge League tracks the best performances in various categories. The Rookie winner for 1995, starting with fewer than 5 master points, broke an 18-year-old record by earning 457 points. This total would have made John Kobuko of Royal Oak, Mich., the winner in three higher categories, Junior Master, Club Master and Sectional Master.

title: Clinton-Dole Fight on Health Bill Is Preview of Campaign to Come
description: President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole started scrapping today over health insurance and it was clear that they saw a major Presidential campaign confrontation in the making.

title: G.O.P. Acts to Protect Drinking Water
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;MCI COMMUNICATIONS CORP. (MCIC,NNM)
description: MCI Communications said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings jumped 21 percent, buoyed by increases in long-distance calling.

title: Don't Criticize the Israelis Alone for the Crisis in Lebanon
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;For Schools and Business: Radio Hookup to Internet
description: In a move that could sharply cut the cost of hooking up schools and companies to the Internet, the Federal Communications Commission plans to announce on Thursday a proposal to set aside a portion of the airwaves for free and unlicensed high-speed communications over short distances.

title: Gingrich, Like the President, Calls for a 'New Environmentalism'
description: In a speech striking for its echoes of environmental themes often voiced by the Clinton Administration, Speaker Newt Gingrich called today for a "new environmentalism" that would achieve higher levels of protection, while moving more quickly and costing less than the regulatory approaches of the last generation.

title: Bosnia Hunting Enemies Down, Diplomats Say
description: The Muslim-led Bosnian Government has dispatched small Iranian-trained commando units to kill or capture enemies it has branded as war criminals, senior Croatian officials and Western diplomats say.

title: Firefighter Kills Wife and 4 Officials
description: A firefighter killed his wife at home, then went to a firehouse and opened fire on his supervisors today, killing four department officials before being wounded in a shootout, the police said.

title: Giuliani's Deal With M.T.A. Is Criticized by Fiscal Monitors
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's agreement to borrow money to pay for improvements in New York City's subways and buses over four years, and receive an immediate cash payment from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, ran into criticism yesterday from the city's fiscal monitors.

title: GARDEN NOTEBOOK;Reading Charleston A Garden at a Time
description: THE time's gonna kill us, Miz Whaley's gonna kill us," said Anna Lou Marvin as she churned down Church Street in her sensible blue flats. She was dressed nicely, as one does in Charleston, in a blue skirt and matching jacket and blue clip-on earrings. And at 75, she was hard to keep up with.

title: SUNY Trustees Name Presidents At 4 Colleges and Universities
description: In an unusual spate of appointments, the trustees of the State University of New York named four college and university presidents yesterday, including two who had been acting in an interim capacity.

title: INSIDE
description: Whitewater Respite Seen

title: An Updated View of Downsizing
description: The Council of Economic Advisers has issued a report that aims to reduce anxieties over the politically charged issue of "downsizing," the widespread layoffs of workers for no fault of their own. The report puts the recent wave of corporate layoffs into a broader perspective of economic change and growth, but whether it will help President Clinton allay fears about job security is uncertain.

title: Durable Orders Rise 1.4%, Swollen by Military Goods
description: Orders for big-ticket manufactured goods posted a surprising rise in March as strong demand for new aircraft more than made up for weaker new-car orders, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Progress on Mass Transit
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has amended the flawed borrowing plan it proposed last year. From the M.T.A.'s perspective, the new proposal is a big improvement. But it includes a deal with New York City that appears to allow the Giuliani administration to balance its upcoming budget with long-term debt.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The toque is passed: JOEL ROBUCHON, considered one of France's greatest chefs, announced yesterday that he would retire from the three-star restaurant that bears his name in Paris. He anointed his successor: ALAIN DUCASSE, the chef of another Michelin three-star restaurant, Louis XV, in Monte Carlo, Monaco.

title: ELECTRIC UTILITIES TO PROVIDE ACCESS FOR COMPETITORS
description: In a move that could eventually save American consumers billions of dollars a year in electricity bills, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission ordered electric utilities today to open up their transmission systems to outside energy providers.

title: Economic Scene;Good news for the down and out, or are the data misleading?
description: WHAT'S all this fuss about income inequality? Sure, the richer are richer and the poor are eating Doritos. But not to worry, says W. Michael Cox and Richard Alm, researchers at the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas: Most Americans struggling to make ends meet are on the fast track to affluence.

title: Why Not Link All Three Airports to Midtown?
description: To the Editor:

title: New Teeth at the F.T.C. (Fangs to Some);Commissioner Steps Up Antitrust Work and Broadens the Agency's Role
description: About a month after William Baer handed the Justice Department a humiliating courtroom defeat, deflating its effort to prove that the General Electric Company had rigged the prices of industrial diamonds, the antitrust lawyer was approached about a new job.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Constructing Both the Musical Language and the Music
description: A remarkable new community of composers appeared after World War II. It was a little like an orphanage, for here were men and women forcibly severed from their past yet trying to find some altered connection with it. Tradition lay in ruins along with Europe itself. Before, methods of making music had been passed on from one generation to the next and undergone change in the process. Now, for many, the transactions of inheritance had been interrupted if not destroyed.

title: Officer Is Accused of Working as a Drug Courier
description: A police officer was arrested yesterday on charges that he worked off duty as an armed drug courier for a Brooklyn cocaine dealer, police officials said.

title: Spy Suspect May Have Sought Out Russians
description: The Navy machinist's mate arrested in Orlando, Fla., this week on charges of military espionage had approached Russian officials in an effort to sell classified submarine information, officials said today.

title: Yale Workers End Walkout
description: Yale University employees returned to work today after a monthlong strike that closed campus dining halls and left students fending for themselves at mealtimes.

title: Frustration Over Contract Talks at Rutgers Erupts Into Protest
description: Longstanding contract disputes between Rutgers University and four of its faculty and staff unions flared into the open today with a noisy demonstration outside the president's office and barbed comments at a hearing on proposed tuition increases.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SPYGLASS TO BUY 2 INTERNET BROWSER COMPANIES
description: Spyglass Inc. said yesterday that it was buying Surfwatch Software and the OS Technologies Corporation, bolstering its position as a leading developer of Internet browser software. Spyglass, based in Naperville, Ill., confirmed it had a definitive agreement to acquire Surfwatch for $12.6 million. Surfwatch, which sells software that allows PC users to block out undesirable Internet sites, is a privately held company based in Los Altos, Calif. Privately held OS Technologies develops and licenses World Wide Web conferencing technologies. Terms of that deal were not disclosed. Surfwatch will become the core of the Spyglass West Coast research and development organization. OS, based in Townsend, Mass., will become part of Spyglass's East Coast unit.

title: 1996 N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;Blackhawks Sweep Flames
description: It took just short of five games, but the Chicago Blackhawks completed a four-game sweep of the Calgary Flames.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;One More Push for Knicks' Old Crew
description: The dark sunglasses and the brisk walk were the first signs. Then came the comments, terse and curt.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;As agency bosses meet, an emphasis on marketing brand names and the growth of new media.
description: THE agenda of the 1996 annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies looks much like those of the last four meetings. But that does not concern the executives who planned the meeting because, as K. C. and the Sunshine Band might proclaim, that's the way -- uh-huh, uh-huh -- they like it.

title: Watch Those Costs of Plugging In
description: To the Editor:

title: Schwab to Offer Insurance
description: Charles Schwab & Company, the nation's largest discount brokerage firm and a mutual fund middleman, said this week that it would offer consumers life insurance. Schwab said consumers would be able to get quotes on premiums from employees not working on commissions in a matter of minutes over a toll-free telephone number.

title: Marvin Davis Ends Effort to Oust Pickens
description: Marvin Davis, a Beverly Hills billionaire, admitted to a rare defeat today as he formally abandoned a campaign to unseat T. Boone Pickens as chief executive of Mesa Inc.

title: Not All Mideast Woes Belong to Syria
description: To the Editor:

title: Boeing Foresees Hiring This Year
description: For the first time in five years, the Boeing Company plans to expand its work force.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NATIONAL POWER UNIT TO PURCHASE ENRON POWER PLANT
description: National Power P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that its American National Power unit had agreed to buy a natural gas-fired plant in Milford, Mass., from the Enron Corporation and the Jones Capital Corporation for $163.5 million. National Power said that more than half of the plant's output is sold to the New England Power Company, a unit of New England Electric System. The company said the acquisition was subject to approvals from the Town of Milford.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Developer Is Convicted
description: One victim of a Clifton developer's real estate scam, prosecutors say, was a bus boy whose wife left him after he lost his down payment. Another victim stopped buying her children toys and other frills to save for her down payment.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DANAHER EXTENDS ACME-CLEVELAND TENDER OFFER, AGAIN
description: The Danaher Corporation said yesterday that it had extended until May 8 its tender offer to acquire the Acme-Cleveland Corporation for $27 a share, or $186 million. It is the second time that Danaher has extended the bid. Danaher, a maker of tools and equipment for the transportation industry, said about 35,000 Acme-Cleveland shares had been tendered as of Wednesday.
