Last week, Acme-Cleveland agreed to share financial information with Danaher less than a month after it rejected the takeover bid as inadequate. Acme-Cleveland is a maker of communications, motion-control and measurement products.

title: Tragedy Strikes a Police Family Twice
description: Two months ago, officers at the 63d Precinct mourned with their commander, Deputy Inspector John W. Fahy, over the death of his wife, Capt. Margaret Fahy, who had succumbed to liver cancer.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR ISSUES EARNINGS WARNING
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said yesterday that its year-to-year sales growth and earnings per share for the company's fourth quarter ending May 26 might be substantially below analysts' expectations. The mean estimate compiled by First Call has been for National Semiconductor to post a fourth-quarter net income of 33 cents a share, including a 13-cent-a-share charge, compared with 59 cents for the corresponding period last year. National Semiconductor said it expected fourth-quarter sales to improve over third-quarter levels, but fourth-quarter sales are still likely to be lower than sales for the corresponding period last year. Despite the forecast, the company's stock rose 12.5 cents a share, to $16.75, yesterday.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;Nets' Hunt For Coach On Hold
description: The Nets' president, Michael Rowe, said yesterday that his search for a new head coach is on hold for now. Its resumption, he said, depends on the team's seven owners -- and whether those seven still own the team tomorrow morning.

title: Agassi Faces Hoots After Monaco Loss
description: Andre Agassi made a quick exit to jeers and whistles today, while Boris Becker made a more expected departure from the Monte Carlo Open.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Comcast Deal With Phillies
description: The Comcast Corporation announced yesterday that it had formed a joint venture in cable television with the Philadelphia Phillies. Together, Comcast and the Phillies plan to start a regional sports network that will eventually show the games of three major Philadelphia professional sports franchises: the Phillies, the Flyers and the 76ers.

title: Arts Backed as Aid For Troubled Youths
description: In a high-level plug for community arts programs for young people, a White House panel has prepared a report documenting how such programs can foster creative enrichment and academic improvement. The report, "Coming Up Taller," by the President's Committee on the Arts and the Huma'ities, says that "safe havens" of music, theater, dance and visual arts programs have proved "particularly potent" in stemming violence and drug abuse and in keeping students from dropping out of school. It is to be ceremonially released this afternoon at the White House by Hillary Rodham Clinton, the actor Richard Dreyfuss and Jane Alexander, chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Arts, among others.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Business Digest on April 13, referring to an article about Anne Klein & Company's decision to end the designer collection division, misidentified the owner of Anne Klein. It is Takihyo Inc., a privately held company based in the United States, not the Takihyo Company, a publicly traded Japanese company; the two companies are not affiliated.

title: OLYMPICS;Top U.S. Diver Is Back, With Mixed Emotions
description: After he won a gold medal on the 3-meter springboard at the 1992 Summer Olympics, Mark Lenzi made appearances on the "Tonight Show" and "Good Morning America." He joined the banquet circuit, but soon his celebrity faded. One day, everyone seemed to know his name, the next day he was nobody.

title: About Real Estate;Dutchess County Revives After I.B.M. Downsizing
description: After being hit hard by job cuts at I.B.M., the residential construction market in Dutchess County, N.Y., is showing signs of a rebound.

title: ART REVIEW;Of 60's Self-Awareness And the Human Figure
description: Sixty drawings from the female figure by Richard Diebenkorn (1922-93) are now on view at Acquavella Contemporary Art. They were made at a particular time and for a particular reason, and they make an intense and concentrated effect.

title: Brother Accused of Helping Dump L.I. Bodies
description: The younger brother of Robert Shulman, the postal worker who has confessed to killing and dismembering five prostitutes, was charged today with helping to dispose of two of the bodies.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SMITH'S FOOD BEGINS OFFER TO BUY ITS SHARES
description: Smith's Food and Drug Centers Inc., a supermarket operator in Salt Lake City, began an offer yesterday to purchase 50 percent of its class A common stock and class B common stock at $36 a share in cash. The offer will expire on May 22. Smith's, which operates 140 supermarkets in eight states, said it has 11.4 million class A shares and 13.7 million class B shares. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of Smith's rose 50 cents, to $25.125. The offer is being made in connection with a previously announced recapitalization agreement and plan of merger. Under the plan, a subsidiary of Smith's will complete a merger with Smitty's Supermarkets Inc. Smitty's is controlled by the Yucaipa Companies.

title: Higher Standards From Mr. Mills
description: New York's Education Commissioner said six months ago that he planned to tighten graduation requirements for the state's 2.7 million high school students. This page embraced the proposal but said that the Commissioner, Richard Mills, would need to provide both a clear plan and the resources for achieving it. This week Mr. Mills unveiled the plan, but some education officials suspect that he may have trouble finding the money.

title: U.S. Extends Deadline for Bosnia Pullout
description: The Defense Department said today that American and other peacekeeping troops would remain in Bosnia for at least a month after the original pullout deadline of Dec. 20 -- a deadline once described by the Clinton Administration as absolutely unextendable.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;American Portable Selects Korey Kay
description: American Portable Telecom in Chicago, a wireless communications company owned by Telephone and Data Systems Inc., said yesterday that it had selected Korey Kay & Partners in New York as the first agency to handle its brand and retail advertising account. The billings were estimated at $12 million to $15 million.

title: Helen Keane, 73, a Manager Of Jazz Artists and Producer
description: Helen Keane, a manager and producer who was one of the few women on the business side of jazz, died at Cabrini Hospice in New York on Monday. She was 73 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column last Friday about a benefit reading at Sarah Lawrence College included a misidentification provided by the school for an alumna's father. The alumna, Penelope Wesley Gill, is the daughter of the late Tom I. Gill. (Two daughters of the writer Brendan Gill are Sarah Lawrence alumnae, but Penelope Gill is not related to him.)

title: COMPANY NEWS;CABOT SAFETY AGREES TO BUY PELTOR HOLDING
description: The Cabot Safety Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Peltor Holding A.B. of Varnamo, Sweden, a subsidiary of Active I Malmoe A.B., for $90 million. Peltor makes earmuff-style hearing-protection devices and had sales of about $41 million for last year, Cabot said. Cabot, a Boston-based maker of personal protection equipment, said it expected to complete the deal by the end of June. Cabot also said it was contemplating an initial public offering of its stock to raise funds for future acquisitions and general corporate purposes.

title: Paraguay's Leader Backtracks on Naming General to Cabinet
description: Reversing a decision that averted a coup but prompted outrage among Paraguayans, President Juan Carlos Wasmosy said today that he would not appoint the rebel army commander as Defense Minister.

title: Celebrating the Shad
description: A tribute to the shad, a stalwart inhabitant of the Hudson River, is planned tomorrow at the St. Charles A.M.E. Zion Church, 432 Valentine Avenue (Route 340), off Route 9W, Sparkill, N.Y. The Sixth Hudson River Festival and Shad Bake is to feature shad dinners and dishes, crafts, storytelling and music. Hours: noon to 4 P.M., rain or shine. Free admission. Information: (914) 359-3509.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;Cavaliers React Slowly To Knicks' Hot Hands
description: Michael Cage, the Cleveland Cavaliers' center both on the court and in metaphysical basketball discussions, was trying to explain in his team's locker room tonight how the Knicks managed to blow out his team in the first game of their Eastern Conference opening-round playoff game, 106-83.

title: OLYMPICS;Johnson's Season Opens In the 400 Tomorrow
description: Three months before he attempts to become the first man to win the 200-and 400-meter sprints at the Summer Olympics, Michael Johnson will open his outdoor season on Saturday amid great anticipation and curiosity.

title: On My Mind;What Clinton Wrought
description: In just one secret move, President Clinton did the following things:

title: Justice Dept. to Ease 1956 I.B.M. Decree
description: The Justice Department has agreed this week with I.B.M. that another portion of the 1956 consent decree restricting the company's operations should be terminated.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Abortion Foes Win Ruling
description: Anti-abortion activists should be allowed to stand on the sidewalk in front of abortion clinics to counsel women who are going inside, a state appeals court ruled yesterday.

title: 25 and Under
description: Memo to anybody who thinks of 9 Jones as a pleasant, beige-toned restaurant where the menu ranged from Asia to Europe to North Africa: Forget it.

title: In a Record Recall, Ford Is Set to Repair 8 Million Vehicles
description: Yielding to public pressure and a series of class-action lawsuits, the Ford Motor Company today announced the largest recall by a single auto maker, asking that the owners of 8.7 million cars and trucks bring them to dealers for replacement of ignition switches that might cause fires.

title: Senate Bars Plans to Cut Immigration
description: Raising serious doubt that Congress will make any meaningful changes in legal immigration this year, the Senate today resoundingly rejected two measures to reduce the number of foreigners entering this country legally.

title: THE BUDGET TRUCE: THE OVERVIEW;HOUSE AND SENATE VOTE TO APPROVE '96 SPENDING BILL
description: Congress passed a $160 billion spending bill today, assuring that vast swaths of Government that had closed, reopened, closed again and reopened again during the long budget wars will stay open the remainder of fiscal 1996, now a bare five months.

title: INSIDE
description: Boy, 6, Charged in Beating

title: Reporter's Notebook;Oohs, Aahs and Millions In Frenzy to Buy Camelot
description: And yesterday, the fake pearls sold for $211,500.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about first reports of the death of Dzhokhar M. Dudayev, the leader of a rebellion in the southern Russian region of Chechnya, referred incorrectly in some copies to a Chechen commander who corroborated them. The commander, Shamil Basayev, did not lead a raid on Kizlyar, a village outside Chechnya, and was not a close relative of Mr. Dudayev.

title: Failed Bosnia Plan Raised Policy Alarm
description: In late 1994, Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke began searching for ways to circumvent the international arms embargo against Bosnia. With the approval of his superiors, he put together a proposal to urge friendly third countries to ship weapons to Bosnia's beleaguered army. The proposal was ultimately rejected, but Mr. Holbrooke's activities had an unintended consequence: They helped raise suspicions within the C.I.A. that an illegal covert operation was under way.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: White Man's Burden 1995. HBO. $100.71. 89 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday

title: U.S. Wins Liberians' Pledge to Back Truce
description: When an American delegation left Liberia today after a visit aimed at helping to restore peace to a city battered by two weeks of brutal fighting, the diplomats had made two significant steps .

title: TRACK & FIELD;Georgetown Women True to Form
description: It was one of those moments that defines track and field or any other sport, a moment that can steal a deserved victory or turn a sure loss into a how-do-you-figure-this. But this time, Georgetown, the relay team that should have won, did, and Villanova, a perennial winner but in a downslide this year, did not.

title: Friend of Ex-Cravath Lawyer Guilty of Insider Trading
description: An insurance salesman from Las Vegas, Nev., pleaded guilty yesterday to one count of conspiracy to commit securities fraud, admitting to insider trading based on information from a former lawyer at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, the New York law firm.

title: ART REVIEW;Anguish of Many Colors in Paintings by Odets
description: Talented, tormented Clifford Odets (1906-1963) never lived up to his early promise. Plays like "Waiting for Lefty" and "Awake and Sing" brought their young author instant success and, briefly, the mantle of Eugene O'Neill as the great white hope of Broadway. Thereafter followed a long, painful decline dotted by increasingly infrequent, poorly received plays, and, as his journal and biography have revealed, infused with burning ambition, esthetic longing, countless love affairs and quite a bit of high-living.

title: Sonat Offers $1.5 Billion for Transocean
description: The Sonat Offshore Drilling Company of Houston offered yesterday to buy Transocean A.S. of Norway in a $1.5 billion transaction that would form the world's second-largest operator of offshore rigs.

title: Aid to Bosnia: A Secret U.S. Plan and Its Repercussions
description: In late 1994, shortly after he became Assistant Secretary of State, Richard C. Holbrooke began searching for ways to circumvent the international arms embargo against Bosnia, according to White House officials.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Singing, Dancing and Sinning
description: IN a fuzzy sense, the Hollywood musical hasn't vanished; it has simply moved music to the background, where it remains a driving force. The soundtrack to "Waiting to Exhale" was released weeks before the film, which built on the success of Whitney Houston's title song. Coolio's song "Gangsta's Paradise," a late addition to "Dangerous Minds," turned a preachy Michelle Pfeiffer film about an inner-city teacher into a hit that sounded fresher than it really was. The Pfeiffer-Coolio video didn't hurt either; music videos are an indispensable part of movie advertising.

title: Art in Review
description: Rosemarie Trockel Drawings and Photographs Nolan Eckman Gallery 560 Broadway, at Prince Street SoHo Through May 4

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Business Digest yesterday referring to an article about the Compaq Computer Corporation's first-quarter financial results misstated the company's closing stock price on Wednesday. The stock closed at $47, up $3.125 for the day. In addition, the entry misstated the percentage increase in Compaq's revenues in the quarter. They rose 42 percent, not 45.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Swiss Re Says Profit Rose 17.4% Last Year
description: The Swiss Reinsurance Company said yesterday that its net income rose 17.4 percent in 1995 as investment income rose, claims payouts fell and a one-time gain helped earnings. Profit of the company rose to 1.095 billion Swiss francs ($887 million), the highest in its history, from 932 million francs a year earlier.

title: TV WEEKEND;Go Back Into the Water? You Think It's Safe?
description: If you loved the big shark, you may very well hate the giant squid. On the other hand, "Peter Benchley's 'The Beast,' " as the official television title would have it, is at heart meant to be little more than the kind of nail-biting entertainment that boosts consumption of pizzas and colas. With an eye on the sweeps ratings that determine ad prices, NBC is hoping that what worked smashingly for moviegoers in Mr. Benchley's "Jaws" can be recycled successfully in this carbon-copy thriller. Only the names and locations have been changed to fend off blushes of embarrassment.

title: Unabom Request Rejected
description: A Federal appeals court has refused a request by defense lawyers to bar prosecution of the suspect in the Unabom case, Theodore J. Kaczynski, because of Government leaks to news organizations. Without hearing arguments, a three-judge panel from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, said that, with rare exception, it had no jurisdiction over someone who has not yet been indicted.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;Olajuwon and Rockets In Post-Season Form
description: No one needed a chest protector.

title: BASEBALL;O'Neill Unsettled Over Being Taken Out of Game
description: Paul O'Neill was the picture of confusion as he slouched back in his chair yesterday afternoon, struggled to produce answers about being replaced on defense in the ninth inning of Wednesday's 10-8 victory over Cleveland and even wondered if a reporter thought that Manager Joe Torre was being critical of his effort.

title: COMPANY NEWS;STERLING CHEMICALS AGREES TO BE ACQUIRED
description: Sterling Chemicals Inc. agreed yesterday to be acquired by an investment group formed by the Sterling Group Inc. and Unicorn Group in a transaction valued at as much as $780 million, including debt. The Houston-based Sterling Group formed Sterling Chemicals in 1986. Under the agreement, shareholders of the Houston-based maker of basic chemicals can choose to receive $12 a share in cash or retain part or all of their shares in the company. Those shares will not be listed on the New York Stock Exchange. On Sunday, Sterling turned down a $12-a-share bid from the Huntsman Corporation of Houston. Huntsman expressed disappointment in yesterday's announcement and said it might have raised its offer, had it been allowed to examine the company's books.

title: When County Politics Is a Family Business;Westchester Feels the Spanos' Presence
description: There are moments when government in Westchester County seems like a family business, the Spano family business.

title: OPERA REVIEW;Comic Rarities by a Young Donizetti
description: In his 50 years, Donizetti composed more than 60 operas. Only a handful of them are produced regularly. It would be easy to assume that many of his unknown operas deserve their neglect.

title: German Shipbuilder Complied With Contracts
description: To the Editor:

title: London Bombs Were Huge, Police Say
description: Two bombs that partly detonated beneath the Hammersmith Bridge together contained one of the largest amounts of explosive material planted in Britain by the I.R.A., Scotland Yard said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Daimler Sees Profit In 1998 of $4 Billion
description: Daimler-Benz A.G. said yesterday that it expected operating profit of 6 billion marks ($4 billion) in 1998, compared with a loss of 5.7 billion marks in 1995. Sales at Germany's largest company are expected to be 132 billion marks in 1998, Daimler said, a 21 percent rise from 1995. The company made the forecasts in a statement on merging the remaining parts of AEG A.G. with the parent, Daimler.

title: Is U.S. Too Generous In Immigration Policy?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Delta Reports Record Operating Profit, but Has Net Loss After Charges
description: Delta Air Lines reported a fourfold increase in operating profits yesterday for the quarter ended in March, and announced new programs to share with employees both stock options and seats in boardroom meetings.

title: Bosnians See A California In Balkans
description: As the people in this valley emerge, battered by war and winter, two men are waiting for them. They intend to grab everyone -- widows, refugees and demobilized soldiers alike -- by their collars, shake them soundly, then point them toward a vision.

title: THE BUDGET TRUCE: STATUS REPORT;Battles in the Budget War
description: The spending bill Congress approved yesterday ends one battle of the Congress-White House budget war that began when Republicans won control of both houses in 1994.

title: Article 1996042600000080926 -- No Title
description: Max Wohlberg, a liturgical scholar and composer who set Judaism to music for millions of worshipers and taught a generation of cantors how to lead their congregations in song, died on Friday at his son's home in Washington. He was 89 and had been a professor at the cantorial school of the Jewish Theological Seminary in Manhattan since he helped found the school in 1952.

title: Seek Not Martyrdom
description: To the Editor:

title: 6-Year-Old Charged With Trying to Kill Baby
description: County prosecutors charged a 6-year-old boy with attempted murder today, accusing him of dumping a neighbor's newborn baby out of its bassinet and beating it nearly to death in an act that appeared likely to brand him the country's youngest would-be killer.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Money Train 1995. Columbia Tri-Star. $102.32. Laser disk, $34.95. 110 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: West Williamston Journal;And Still the Birds Die, Out in the Poisoned Sea
description: The first casualties of the worst oil spill in Welsh history began to arrive almost immediately: hundreds of listless seabirds covered in oil, brought in by volunteers. That was two months ago.

title: Nike Unit to Open Factory
description: Nike Inc. said today that its Tetra Plastics Inc. subsidiary would open a factory in June that would employ 150 people in Tigard, Ore. The 117,000-square-foot factory, which the company would be leasing, would be a branch of Tetra's headquarters in St. Charles, Mo., where 475 people are employed.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Earhart as Brave, Careless, Marooned and in Love
description: I WAS AMELIA EARHART By Jane Mendelsohn 146 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.

title: FILM REVIEW;If Beauty Is Skin Deep, Some Are Thick-Skinned
description: There's no wondering whether the screenplay for "The Truth About Cats and Dogs" is the work of a man or a woman: not after the writer (Audrey Wells, once a jazz disk jockey) concocts a dead-on scene at a cosmetics counter for Abby (Janeane Garofalo), the film's irresistible heroine. Abby knows she's no raving beauty, and she also knows that's why the department store's makeup saleswoman is pulling up a big mirror for a closer look.

title: World News Briefs;Local Court Drops Case Against Polish Ex-Leader
description: A provincial court in Gdansk, saying it lacked jurisdiction, dropped proceedings today against Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski over the shooting deaths of 44 protesters by security forces in 1970, when General Jaruzelski was Defense Minister.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: How to Make an American Quilt 1995. MCA/Universal. $100.71. Laser disk, $39.98. 117 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Mutual Funds Are Cutting Cash Reserves
description: As rapidly as cash has flooded into mutual funds that invest in American stocks this year, the fund managers have put the money to work even faster, cutting their cash reserves in an attempt to keep up with a red-hot stock market.

title: Correction
description: An April 24 editorial, "The Goetz Verdict," erred when it said that Darrell Cabey was sitting bleeding when Bernhard Goetz fired a second bullet into his spine. Mr. Cabey had not been previously wounded.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Starting Place 1993. Interama. $39.95. 80 minutes. English and Vietnamese with English subtitles. No rating.

title: Biotech Counterattack On Resistant Bacteria;Small Companies Leading in Research
description: Drug makers thought they had a batch of miracle drugs that would provide tidy profits off into the horizon, but nature -- in the form of ever-changing bacteria -- had a different idea.

title: THE BUDGET TRUCE: NEWS ANALYSIS;Ammunition For the Fall
description: In many respects, the battle over this year's budget ended with a whimper.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HORSE RACING;Jockey Is Suspended
description: WILLIAM OTERO, an apprentice jockey, will sit out 20 days of racing, if stewards at Aqueduct have their way.

title: Separatist Is Not a Word for Ethnic Studies
description: To the Editor:

title: Teachers' Pension Fund Votes To Cut Back Tobacco Holdings
description: Saying that uncertainty surrounding tobacco stocks had undermined their investment value, the board of the New York Teachers' Retirement System voted yesterday to reduce the tobacco holdings in one of its stock index funds by as much as 25 percent, a move that could lead the system to sell up to $100 million in tobacco-related investments.

title: Florida Bans Lethal Herb
description: Florida today became the first state to ban sales of herbal products that mimic the illegal drug ecstasy. The products contain the stimulant ephedrine, a dietary supplement that the Food and Drug Administration warns can cause heart attacks, seizures and psychosis.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Is everything perfect?" our waitress asks in her charming French accent.

title: Nothing From the White House, but There's a Degas
description: Wath all the commotion over the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis sale, it was easy this week to forget that Sotheby's and Christie's are still in the business of selling art.

title: Sports of the Times;This Time, Better Than 'Old' Knicks
description: IF the Knicks could save time in a bottle, it would be 5 minutes and 29 seconds of the fourth quarter here last night, when they not only were the vintage, Pat Riley, in-your-face, out-of-my-sight Knicks, but were even better than we remember them at their very best.

title: Who Won the Budget War?
description: After 13 stopgap measures, 2 Government shutdowns, several vetoes and seven months of bickering, the White House and Congress have finally agreed to a budget. The political victory belongs to President Clinton, who was clearly on the defensive after the G.O.P.'s midterm triumphs in 1994 but in the end won major concessions from Republicans on the environment and other issues like abortion and homosexuals in the military. He also won the public relations war. Even though Republicans achieved big cuts in total spending, the President persuaded them to pump $5 billion into a few high-profile programs popular with voters.

title: 1st Amendment Protection For a Restaurant's Critic
description: Yes, Aaron Chess Lichtman says he has tried the chicken at Kenny Rogers Roasters. And, indeed, he does not like it. But that is largely beside the point.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;5-Year-Old Is Held Hostage
description: A man brandishing a revolver ran into a Broad Street laundromat yesterday and held a 5-year-old boy hostage for more than two hours, police said.

title: Mortgage Rates Dip
description: Mortgage rates inched down this week, with 30-year fixed-rate loans at 7.92 percent, compared with 7.95 percent last week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today. The average interest rate for 15-year fixed-rate loans also fell, to 7.43 percent from 7.48 percent. The average adjustable-rate loan inched down to to 5.74 percent from 5.75 percent.

title: A Fair and Impartial Inquiry
description: Recent criticism of Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, for purported conflicts of interest in his representation of private clients is fundamentally wrong. It ignores the mandates of the independent counsel law, the realities of any investigative process and Mr. Starr's own role as aspecial prosecutor and private lawyer. Perhaps most significantly, it fails to appreciate Mr. Starr himself.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: When the Moon Is in the 7th House

title: DANCE REVIEW;Stylish Limb-Flinging And Taffyish Stretching
description: Things got off to a stylish, snappy start in a performance by ODC/San Francisco, a major West Coast modern dance troupe, on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. Moments after the curtain rose on "Part of a Longer Story," choreographed by the company director, Brenda Way, to the Mozart Clarinet Concerto in A, a line of women in sleek black costumes made its way slowly across the front of the stage, to be followed by men in white at the back crossing in the opposite direction. It was a strong image, and the subsequent solos for the five women all had interestingly quirky movement, from limb-flinging to spidery, and oozy to deft. One dancer resembled taffy stretching slowly and then snapping.

title: Nasdaq Climbs to a Sixth Consecutive High
description: Wall Street staged a late rebound yesterday, sending the Nasdaq composite index to a sixth consecutive high. Computer and paper stocks fueled the advance.

title: ART REVIEW;Picasso Again, Still Surprising
description: FIRST came the mammoth Picasso retrospective in 1980. Then seven years ago was the memorably exhaustive and exhausting "Picasso and Braque: Pioneering Cubism." It might seem that by now William Rubin, the Museum of Modern Art's longtime head of painting and sculpture, who organized both shows, would have had enough of Picasso marathons. But Mr. Rubin is back, out of retirement for yet another Picasso swan song. To him, more is always more, with Picasso at least.

title: Margaret L. P. Burden, 86, Philanthropist
description: Margaret Livingston Partridge Burden, a Manhattan philanthropist long associated with the Community Service Society, died yesterday at her home on the Upper East Side. She was 86.

title: Duckman Is Returning, but to Civil Court
description: Lorin Duckman, the embattled Brooklyn judge who has been on voluntary leave for two months amid furious criticism over his handling of domestic-violence cases, will return to the bench next Wednesday, but in a new assignment: hearing civil cases, instead of criminal ones.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;10 Charged in Fraternity Rite
description: Summonses were issued Tuesday to 10 Rutgers students who required minors to drink liquor as part of the hazing ritual at Alpha Delta Epsilon, a coed fraternity that is not recognized on campus, Anthony Murphy, the chief of police, said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-18

title: Spanish Premier Reported Clear in Basque Deaths
description: A Supreme Court judge investigating charges that Spanish death squads carried out assassinations of Basque separatists in the 1980's has found nothing to link the squads to outgoing Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, Spanish newspapers reported today.

title: THE BUDGET TRUCE: MINIMUM WAGE;House Republicans Again Avert Vote on Minimum Wage
description: House Republicans narrowly fought off a Democratic effort today to vote on an increase in the minimum wage, even though 13 of them deserted their leaders and voted with the Democrats.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: JOHNSON & JOHNSON New Brunswick, N.J., said its board had approved a 2-for-1 stock split and raised its quarterly dividend 15 percent, to 38 cents a share, from 33 cents previously. Both the dividend and the stock split will be for shareholders of record as of May 21.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Muslim holiday Eid al-Adha, the feast of sacrifice, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City Sunday, Monday and Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;TCI Wins a Round in Running Satellite TV Feud
description: Three months ago, it looked as if Rupert Murdoch and MCI Communications Inc. had outmaneuvered and outmuscled John C. Malone in snatching the last unclaimed license for direct-broadcast satellite television service in the United States.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Mandarich Joins Colts
description: Seven years after he entered the National Football League as the second overall pick in the draft, TONY MANDARICH is ready to compete for a job with the Indianapolis Colts after a five-year absence from the league.

title: Beijing Announces Hot Line to Moscow, as Ties With U.S. Cool
description: President Jiang Zemin of China announced today that he was establishing a hot line with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, while letting his circuits cool with President Clinton.

title: Editorial Notebook;Chernobyl Reconsidered
description: The first Government bulletin, circulated by the Tass news agency, was deceptively innocuous.

title: Few at Mitsubishi Are Silent Over Accusations
description: As the gray sky brightened this morning and Kelli M. Harrison hurried to work, she paused to give her views about accusations that hundreds of women here at Mitsubishi's automobile assembly plant had been sexually harassed.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SOCCER;Ramos Set for Debut
description: TAB RAMOS, the first player signed by Major League Soccer, practiced with the MetroStars for the first time yesterday and will make his league debut tomorrow night when the team plays Columbus at Giants Stadium.

title: Republicans Fighting Over Seat in Brooklyn
description: At a recent gala political dinner, an elegantly dressed Arthur Bramwell, chairman of the Kings County Republican Party, reflected to a guest on the turbulent relationships within the Grand Old Party in Brooklyn and, specifically, his duels with his archrival, State Senator Robert J. DiCarlo.

title: Separatist Is Not a Word for Ethnic Studies;No Surrender
description: To the Editor:

title: Deloitte & Touche Agrees to a Settlement
description: The accounting and consulting firm of Deloitte & Touche has agreed to pay $65 million to settle claims it contributed to the collapse of Bonneville Pacific.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Evening Hours column in the Styles pages last Sunday, with a report about the celebration of the Graham-Windham child-welfare agency's 190th year, misidentified a guest. He was Jemel Williams, not Michael Conroy.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Giants Sign Three, Including a Punter
description: Giants punter MIKE HORAN will have some competition for the starting job this summer.

title: India's Have-Nots Swamp the Party System
description: This tiny settlement astride a railway line in Bihar state is typical of India's 850,000 villages, except that it is quite a bit poorer than most. Life here has not changed much since Mohandas K. Gandhi walked India's hinterland, proclaiming the most downtrodden of the poor, the so-called untouchables, to be "the children of God."

title: Art in Review
description: Suzanne McClelland Paul Kasmin Gallery 74 Grand Street SoHo Through May 11

title: Goldman-Rockefeller Merger Is Delayed
description: Rockefeller Center Properties Inc. and a group of investors led by Goldman, Sachs & Company and David Rockefeller agreed to extend by one month to May 31 the closing of their $1.2 billion merger.

title: Albany's Health Care Lobby Courts Clout With Dollars
description: Just three years ago, the Medical Society of the State of New York, a trade group that represents nearly 30,000 doctors, gave a total of $13,250 to the campaign committees run by the Republicans and the Democrats in the State Legislature. Last year, the society contributed $165,650.

title: THE BUDGET TRUCE: THE FRESHMEN;Compromise Is a Relief For Even the Most Rigid
description: The freshmen House Republicans, the firebrands who stood rigidly on principle last year and helped shut down the Federal Government twice rather than compromise, today lauded the new budget accord -- even though it contains elements they dislike.

title: Abroad at Home;'A Public Charge'
description: Imagine that 2-year-old Irina Dovsky comes to America with her parents as legal immigrants. A year later her father dies. Her impoverished mother manages to get Irina into the Head Start program. She does wonderfully there over the next two years, and goes on to success in school and college.

title: Morgan Stanley Invests in Insurer
description: The Morgan Stanley Group said yesterday that its merchant banking arm had invested $215 million in the Direct Response Corporation, a consumer auto insurance company.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;France Lowers Ceiling On Money Market Rates
description: The French central bank lowered the ceiling for money market rates yesterday while leaving the floor rate unchanged, keeping alive expectations for further cuts. The bank cut its ceiling interest rate, the 5-to-10-day securities repurchase rate, by 60 basis points, to 4.9 percent from 5.5. It unexpectedly left its floor intervention rate unchanged at 3.7 percent.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Flying Feet Electrify The Sweep Of History
description: IT'S a strange and mighty force that is connecting the audience and the performers at the Ambassador Theater. People watching the show there seem to find themselves yelping, whooping and sobbing without even being aware of it. And when the dancers onstage conclude a number with a jubilant roar, the audience roars right back.

title: In America;The Real Welfare Cheats
description: The unconscionable assault on welfare recipients by officials at all levels of government is taking place in an atmosphere of extraordinary dishonesty.

title: Market Place;Good days for the American steel business, as the orders stream in.
description: THIS is a good time to be in the steel business, even if that is not obvious from first-quarter earnings -- which are down, in some cases sharply, from last year's levels.

title: THE BUDGET TRUCE: THE DETAILS;Both Congress and Clinton Find Cause for Cheer in the Final Budget Deal
description: Both Congressional Republicans and the White House can find something to crow about in the $159.4 billion budget agreement that Congress passed today, and each side has eagerly trumpeted its gains.

title: Clinton Swipes at the Whitewater Prosecutor
description: President Clinton took a veiled swipe today at the special Whitewater prosecutor, Kenneth W. Starr, hinting that he agreed with Mr. Starr's critics that the prosecutor's private legal work presents potential conflicts of interest for his inquiry into the Clintons.

title: At Montana Standoff, F.B.I. Spurns Aid of Far-Right Groups
description: Posturing for television cameras, three visiting media stars of the far right protested angrily today when agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation turned them back at a checkpoint here, rebuffing their offer to negotiate the surrender of about 20 members of the Freemen.

title: For Children
description: 58th Annual Science and Technology Expo New York Information Technology Center 55 Broad Street Lower Manhattan (212) 838-0230, extension 422 Recommended ages: 6 and up Tomorrow

title: Pact on Lebanon Cease-Fire Is Very Near, Officials Report
description: Israel, Syria and Lebanon are very close to an agreement on a cease-fire and a set of rules for military behavior that should put an end to two weeks of rocketing and shelling in northern Israel and southern Lebanon, officials close to the negotiations said on Thursday.

title: Mechanics Accused of Bogus Auto Repairs
description: Eleven auto mechanics at seven Manhattan garages have been arrested and charged with performing bogus repairs on motorists' cars, sometimes at costs of thousands of dollars, the Manhattan District Attorney's office announced yesterday.

title: Separatist Is Not a Word for Ethnic Studies
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Mets' Victory Supplies A Variety of Heroes
description: When asked to pinpoint the most impressive thing about the Mets' 9-3 drubbing of the Cardinals this afternoon at Busch Stadium, Manager Dallas Green had to ponder just a bit. There was plenty to choose from.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Israeli Labor Party, in Switch, Lends Support to Palestinian State
description: Departing from its previous position, Prime Minister Shimon Peres's Labor Party approved an election platform today that does not rule out a Palestinian state.

title: Wisconsin Acts to End Welfare Entirely
description: Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin today signed legislation to abolish welfare payments in that state by the fall of 1997 and replace them with a system of work programs, child care and subsidies to private employers who hire the poor.

title: Penney's Wandering Eye Puts Wall St. on Watch
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation, the country's fourth-largest retailer, was courted for a takeover by the J. C. Penney Company but swiftly refused the offer, both companies said yesterday.

title: BASEBALL;Belle and McDowell Are Cast as Villains Against Yanks
description: Albert Belle extended his arms to hit the outside sinker that did not sink and drilled it deep enough to find a new home in the barren right-field seats, deep enough to etch a blank look across Andy Pettitte's face and deep enough to frustrate the Yankees in the eighth inning of an already frustrating game.

title: Big Board's Profit Rises
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that its net income for the first quarter rose 40 percent, to $21.4 million, from $15.3 million a year ago. The Big Board, the world's largest stock exchange, said its revenue rose 14 percent, to $134.9 million, from $118.2 million a year ago. The Big Board's expenses rose 6.4 percent, to $97.1 million, from $91.3 million a year ago. The exchange said an average of 427.5 million shares were traded a day in the first three months of the year, up 28 percent from the 333.3 million shares traded in the first three months of 1995.

title: BASEBALL;Gooden Gets to Start Again
description: The Yankees' Dwight Gooden will get another opportunity to start because David Cone has a blister on his middle right finger and is skipping tomorrow's game against the Minnesota Twins. While Gooden receives another chance to prove he belongs, the durable Cone will be missing his first start since 1987.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;A Downpour of Knick 3-Pointers Sinks Cavaliers
description: Anthony Mason and Patrick Ewing were standing at the free-throw line, impatiently waiting for Cleveland to bring the ball up and start the second half. The All-Star center suddenly offered his clenched fist to his teammate, and Mason obliged, tapping Ewing's fist with his own. They shared a few words.

title: Tap Ensemble Benefit
description: The Manhattan Tap Ensemble is to perform tonight and tomorrow night at 7 P.M. at the Harlem School of the Arts, 645 St. Nicholas Avenue, at 143d Street in Manhattan. Tonight's performance, a benefit for the tap company, will be f'llowed by a party at Well's Restaurant in Harlem. The company will also present a daylong series of workshops on Sunday. For ticket prices and information: (212) 787-7181.

title: Lebanese Cope With a Smashed Country
description: Until this morning, the road from here wound south and east through hills and villages just inland from the southern port of Tyre. Now the pavement ends in rubble and a bomb crater 30 feet deep.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Securities Close Higher
description: Prices of Treasury securities ended higher yesterday on late bargain hunting and short-covering by investors in a quiet but choppy trading session.

title: No Headline
description: No one actually knows what to do with 6 and 8-year-olds you're detaining for such a serious crime. This is quite different than the petty theft of candy that kids this age might do periodically."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Imperial Chemicals Says Earnings Fell in Quarter
description: The British chemical giant Imperial Chemicals Industries P.L.C. reported a fall in first-quarter profits yesterday and warned that the next three months' results would also be lower. Pretax profit before exceptional items fell to L202 million ($305 million), from L221 million a year ago, when the chemical cycle was at the peak of a boom. The results were at the lower end of analysts' expectations.

title: Mix-Up on Leases Costs New York City Schools $30 Million in State Aid
description: State officials said yesterday that the New York City public school system would lose at least $30 million in state aid because the Board of Education had signed leases for school buildings without state approval.

title: 1996 N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;Rangers Need Killer Instinct in Indefinable Series
description: Momentum has been juggled like a hot potato in this deadlocked playoff series between the Rangers, who entered it as the logical favorites, and the Canadiens, who entered it as underdogs with ample attitude. Things got confusing right off the bat: the Rangers failed to declare themselves in the first two games, then the Canadiens backed off in the next two.

title: CHRONICLE
description: If it's not one role that TONY RANDALL is playing in "Inherit the Wind," it's another, and sometimes he takes to the stage with no notice whatsoever.

title: KNICKS NOTEBOOK;Riley's Advice to Van Gundy: Relax
description: The mentor called his protege on Wednesday night and offered him one last bit of advice before he coached his first playoff game.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;Rediscovering South America in Its Self-Images
description: The textbook history of photography has long been the record of European and North American eyes looking at the world. That vantage is changing. The camera, invented in Europe, has found its way into the hands of other cultures, which are increasingly using it -- with a full sense of its potential for truth and manipulation, ugliness and beauty -- to shape a self-image.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;B.A.T. Doesn't Expect To Match 26% '95 Gain
description: B.A.T. Industries P.L.C., the British conglomerate, does not expect its profit growth in the current year to match the exceptional 26 percent jump seen in 1995, its chairman, Lord Cairns, said at the annual meeting yesterday. Lord Cairns said the company would make steady progress in the current year, predicting that there would be "swings and roundabouts" in the tobacco business. He said favorable trends in B.A.T.'s Allied Dunbar financial services unit and Farmers insurance unit in the United States should continue. (Reuters)

title: Clinton Aide Sees Double Standard on Gifts
description: The Senate special Whitewater committee, now cruising into its final round of hearings, was the scene of a jousting match today between Republicans on the panel and one of President Clinton's most spirited longtime political associates, Betsey Wright.

title: Hitachi Gearing Up for big-Memory Chip
description: Hitachi Ltd. plans to spend $1 billion on cementing its position as a leader in the market for the next generation of computer chip memory devices.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bayer Says Profits Rose 13.7% in Quarter
description: The German chemical giant Bayer A.G. said yesterday that recent acquisitions had helped it increase first-quarter sales and earnings, putting the company on track to post a second consecutive record profit this year. Bayer said pretax profits climbed 13.7 percent, to 1.16 billion marks ($762 million), while sales rose 4.2 percent, to 12.17 billion marks ($7.9 billion), in the first quarter.

title: Significant but Spotty Gains Found for Science and Math in U.S.Schools, Report Says
description: Despite a persistent gloom about the nation's schools, a comprehensive assessment of science and mathematics education, from elementary to graduate levels, finds significant progress in test scores, curriculum and academic preparation.

title: World News Briefs;Zulu King's Wife Wounded in Attack
description: An armed gang attacked a house belonging to King Goodwill Zwelithini of the Zulus tonight, wounding one of his wives and their daughter, the police said. The King was not at the house, in the KwaMashu township outside Durban.

title: Stiff Penalties Could Drive L.I. Broker Out of Business
description: Regulators have quietly moved to drive a stake through the heart of what some of them call the most incorrigible penny-stock operator around, Stratton Oakmont Inc. of Lake Success, L.I.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When Dr. NEIL deGRASSE TYSON was a boy of 8 or 9, his parents would take him to the Hayden Planetarium, and he knew almost immediately that he "wanted to study the universe as an adult," he said the other day.

title: What Chinese Nationalists Are Telling World
description: To the Editor:

title: TV WEEKEND;A Court TV for Teen-Agers
description: Tomorrow morning, Court TV inaugurates "Teen Court TV," a weekly set of programs aimed at introducing teen-agers to the workings of the justice system. The idea is to deliver information about trial procedures and the people who carry them out in ways that may attract youngsters to the screen and keep them there for as long as three hours.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Kodak's chief executive urges advertising agencies to exploit the advantages of  the new media.
description: SPIRITED discussion and debate about the prospects and pitfalls of the media new and old -- particularly their money-making abilities -- dominated the general session yesterday of the 78th annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

title: Critic's Choice/Film;2 Views of Iran's Quake
description: When the earth moves in the films of Abbas Kiarostami, don't look for a romantic metaphor; expect the real thing. The Iranian director, whose work forms the heart of a series of recent Iranian movies that opens today at the Walter Reade Theater, is best known in the United States for two movies that contemplate the aftereffects of an earthquake in northern Iran in 1990.

title: Restaurants
description: These are the best things in the whole world," I said impulsively as the waiter set a bamboo tray on the table. Fragrant steam rose invitingly and we all leaned forward to peer in.

title: Let's Not Be Finicky About Coarse Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: In Germany, 3-Star Dining Can Bring On a 4-Star Guilt Attack
description: Will enjoyment ever be officially allowed in Germany?" asked Hermann Bareiss, a German innkeeper and restaurateur in this Black Forest resort, complaining that the Germans' love of comfort is matched only by their sense of guilt.

title: Jug McSpaden, 87, a Top Golfer Known for Finishing in Second
description: Harold (Jug) McSpaden, who won 17 tournaments on the professional golf tour in the 1930's and 1940's against such stars as Byron Nelson, Ben Hogan, Sam Snead and Gene Sarazen but was better known for finishing second, was found dead on Monday with his wife, Betsy. He was 87 and she was believed to be 73.

title: Flu Shots Changing To Fight New Strains
description: Federal health officials said today that they would change the influenza vaccine to be given out later this year to protect against new flu strains recently seen in Asia, Europe and North America.

title: Tokyo Stocks Up Slightly
description: Stocks were trading slightly higher here this morning. At the midday break, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 33.77 points, or less than two-tenths of 1 percent, to 22,263.87. On Thurs day, the Nikkei fell 51.95 points.

title: FILM REVIEW;How an Unlikely Coach Inspires Her Basketball Team
description: Could a feisty middle-aged white woman who knows nothing about sports mold a losing black basketball team into high school champions? "Sunset Park," a sentimental comedy that shows a genuine fondness for its characters, would like to think so.

title: U.N. Council Criticizes Israel, But Half Its Members Abstain
description: Recovering some of the diplomatic ground they lost last week in the Security Council, Arab nations forced a resolution through an emergency session of the General Assembly today condemning Israel's continuing assault on southern Lebanon.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Documenting Marcel' Reinhold-Brown Gallery 26 East 78th Street Through May 5

title: Lower Rates Raise Resales Of Single-Family Homes
description: Sales of previously owned homes jumped 6.9 percent in March to the highest level in more than two years as buyers responded to low mortgage rates.

title: The Spoken Word
description: "GREAT NARRATIONS," Carnegie Hall. An evening of readings and music to benefit Music for All Seasons, an organization that presents live performances in residential institutions like schools, prisons and nursing homes. Works to be presented include Aaron Copland's "Lincoln Portrait," Saint-Saens's "Carnival of the Animals" and Leonard Bernstein's "Candide Overture." Participants include Lynn Redgrave, Tony Randall, Ted Koppel, Dudley Moore and the New Jersey Symphony. Today at 8 P.M. Tickets: $15 to $75; patrons' tickets: $150 to $500. Information: (212) 247-7800 or for patrons' tickets, (908) 755-5753. "WOMEN AND THE THEATER," 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, Manhattan. A discussion with Wendy Wasserstein, the playwright; Anna Deavere Smith, the author and actress, and Graciela Daniele, the director and choreographer. Sunday at 8 P.M. Tickets: $18. Information: (212) 996-1100.

title: FILM REVIEW;High-Test Swagger by Burly Buddies
description: Lee Tamahori, the New Zealand-born director who made such a ferocious first impression with "Once Were Warriors," has his thrill thermostat set so high that Melanie Griffith plays his new film's most straitlaced character. That character is the sultry wife of a police detective, Max Hoover (Nick Nolte), a vamp who greets her husband with one very hot hello each time he returns from work.

title: Pepsico to Sell Burmese Stake
description: Pepsico Inc. plans to sell its 40 percent stake in a joint bottling venture in Myanmar, formerly Burma, yielding to critics of its business activities in the military dictatorship.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Surging Grain Prices Raise Fears of Inflation Corn and wheat prices have climbed to records this month, because of bad weather, dwindling supply and strong demand at home and abroad.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;All Beethoven, With a Message and a Birthday
description: Whether it wanted to be or not, Wednesday night's concert by the Israel Philharmonic was as much a political as a musical event. Cultural roots set down 60 years ago produced this orchestra; and when the Israel Philharmonic is on the road -- here, it was at Carnegie Hall for the first of two evenings -- it travels in the name of a country frequently embattled and currently embattled once again. The music was all Beethoven but seemed all-Israel as well. A musical identity, the message went, defends a country, too.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Congressman Is Challenged
description: A lawyer from Orange said yesterday that he would run against United States Representative Donald M. Payne in the June 4 Democratic primary. The challenger, Cecil J. Banks, who is black, accused Mr. Payne, the chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus, of spending too much time on foreign affairs and black issues and neglecting the concerns of the district.

title: OLYMPICS;More Tickets Are Available
description: More than 240,000 tickets for 211 previously sold-out Olympic sessions will go on sale Saturday morning by phone and the Internet.

title: FILM REVIEW;Zombie-Bashing and Necrophilia
description: Enough hollow-eyed zombies explode out of the ground in Michele Soavi's leaden comic satire "Cemetery Man" to populate several horror movies. Preventing them from going on a ghoulish rampage requires that Francesco Dellamorte (Rupert Everett), the dedicated watchman at the Buffalora Cemetery, split their heads open with a shovel. As more and more corpses pop out of the earth, Francesco resorts to gunfire, all the while fretting about whether to file an official report. If he does, he worries, he may lose his job.

title: Is U.S. Too Generous In Immigration Policy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Wrigley Plant in Russia
description: The Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company, the world's largest maker of chewing gum, said today that it expected to break ground next month on a $25 million factory in St. Petersburg, Russia. The plant, when completed, will make products to be sold in Russia and other countries in the Commonwealth of Independent States.

title: Pakistani Calls for Reform
description: Imran Khan, Pakistan's former cricket hero and a critic of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, announced today that he was forming a movement to fight corruption and injustice. He said at a news conference here that he would turn his Justice Movement into a political party if it won enough support.

title: Kennedy Says Dole Is Trying To Sabotage Insurance Bill
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy today accused Senator Bob Dole, the presumptive Republican Presidential nominee, of trying to "sink the bill" approved by the Senate this week that would make health insurance more accessible.

title: Secretary Brown Recalled as a Son of Harlem
description: In an emotional ceremony that brought together public officials and everyday workers from businesses along 125th Street to remember a son of Harlem, New York City paid tribute yesterday to Ronald H. Brown, the Commerce Secretary who was killed with 34 other people in a plane crash in Croatia three weeks ago.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Sugar Mountain' White Columns 154 Christopher Street West Village Through May 12

title: Art in Review
description: William Klein 'New New York, 1954-55' Howard Greenberg Gallery 120 Wooster Street SoHo Through May 11

title: CHRONICLE
description: Yes, it is true," HUME CRONYN said, enunciating each syllable, "I am af-fi-anced." Mr. Cronyn will be married to SUSAN COOPER, a close friend of 22 years to him and his late wife, Jessica Tandy, who died in 1994.

title: 2 Arrests Made in Queens In New Child Abuse Cases
description: In a month in which three children in New York City have died of alleged child abuse, the police last night were grappling with two new, unrelated, cases of abuse that left a 4-week-old and a 10-month-old hospitalized with critical injuries.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Separatist Is Not a Word for Ethnic Studies
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS MEDIA;Rehearsing Answers Before the Questions
description: When Lawrence Phillips showed up to discuss being the sixth selection in the National Football League draft, it was on Sunday, one day after the Rams chose him. The former Nebraska running back appeared in St. Louis before a tamer, smaller press horde than the unwieldy one that would have sliced and diced him Saturday at the theater at Madison Square Garden. He was flanked by Rich Brooks, the Ram coach, as well as by Andrea Kirby, his media coach.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ALLIED SIGNAL RECEIVES $1.1 BILLION IN CONTRACTS
description: Allied Signal Inc. said yesterday that its aerospace business had received $1.1 billion in contracts to supply aircraft parts and avionics. The largest pact, valued at $700 million, came from GE Capital Aviations Services, a subsidiary of the General Electric Company. Under the deal, Allied Signal Aerospace will supply auxiliary power units, wheels, brakes and avionics for as many as 254 Boeing 737 aircraft GE Capital plans to buy. Allied Signal said it also received a contract, valued at $250 million, from Singapore Airlines to supply air turbine starters, wheels, brakes, and avionics equipment for as many as 61 Boeing 777 aircraft. Malaysia Airlines' order was for more than $100 million to supply components for up to 17 Boeing 777 and up to 13 Boeing 747-400 aircraft. And Allied Signal also agreed to supply TPE331-12 turboprop engines to Construcciones Aeronauticas S.A., a unit of Northrop Grumman, for about $54 million. The Spanish company will use the engines to power its 212-400 aircraft.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PHILIP MORRIS TO INVEST MORE IN U.S. TOBACCO UNIT
description: The Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that it would double capital spending on its United States tobacco unit in particular this year to increase production of cigarettes for sale in the United States and abroad. The company would not disclose how much capital spending for its United States tobacco production was last year. Its total capital expenditures for the year were $1.62 billion.

title: World News Briefs;At Nervous Chernobyl, Another Accident
description: A worker at the Chernobyl nuclear plant disposed of some radioactive material today in a container that was not completely sealed, raising new fears of contamination 10 years after the world's worst commericial nuclear disaster.

title: Home Video
description: Writing Songs for Disney

title: 1996 N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;All the Stops Were Pulled
description: Night had long ago turned to early morning, and only a few thousand fans from the sellout crowd remained, waiting more than three hours to see someone put the puck into the net.

title: Honoring the Poetry Of Jane Kenyon
description: A memorial service for the poet Jane Kenyon is to be held on Tuesday at 6 P.M. at the Friends Meeting House, 15 Rutherford Place, at East 15th Street, Manhattan. Ms. Kenyon died a year ago at the age of 47.

title: California Civil Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;WORLD COLOR PRESS TO PURCHASE RINGIER AMERICA
description: World Color Press Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Ringier America for $415 million in cash and debt, moving it into the business of printing soft-cover books and bolstering its magazine and catalogue operations. The nation's No. 3 printer and a unit of Printing Holdings L.P. will acquire Ringier's six printing and production facilities and its prepress facility. Ringier, based in Chicago, is owned by the Swiss publishing company Ringier A.G. As part of the transaction, World Color will assume about $285 million in debt.

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan gallery shows:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Man Indicted in Attack
description: A man who prosecutors said assaulted an F.B.I. employee so severely that her arm was shattered and she needed hundred of stitches was indicted on Federal charges late Wednesday, the United States Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: FILM REVIEW;Van Damme as Auteur
description: Jean-Claude Van Damme makes his directorial debut with "The Quest," showing off his fascination with all forms of two-fisted fighting and proving himself at least a more viable actor-auteur than Steven Seagal. Beyond that, Mr. Van Damme's studiously hokey action-adventure is interesting only for being so totally familiar, even if you've never seen another film about a Ghan-Gheng martial-arts match in an ancient Lost City in Tibet.

title: U.S. Budget Deal Provides No Windfall for New York
description: New York State officials said today that the Federal budget agreement between President Clinton and Congressional leaders provided no new aid that might help Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature end their impasse over the state budget, which is now a month overdue.

title: Rowland Picks Nominee to Head Top Court
description: In a return to tradition, Gov. John G. Rowland has nominated Justice Robert J. Callahan, the State Supreme Court's senior justice, to head the state's highest court.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UNISYS SHAREHOLDERS REJECT PLAN TO SPLIT COMPANY
description: Shareholders of the Unisys Corporation yesterday rejected a plan by a dissident investor to split the company into three. About 68 percent of the shareholders voted against the plan while 30.2 percent voted in favor, Unisys said. The proposal was modeled after the AT&T Corporation's recent split-up and was intended to staunch the company's losses. The biggest proponent of the splitting plan, Greenway Partners L.P., a New York investment firm. disputed the vote count. Greenway owns about 4 percent of Unisys, which has struggled to shift its focus to computer management and consulting services from the manufacture of mainframe systems. James Unruh, Unisys's chief executive, said the plan would have failed because the new companies would have been unable to stand on their own.

title: NYC;Comrades Are Whistling A Happy Tune
description: FROM Gdansk to Tbilisi, statues of Lenin have been pulled down in Eastern Europe, but that form of perestroika has not quite made it to West 23d Street. A bust of the old boy sits there in unreconstructed solemnity, peering north across New York rooftops from an office bookshelf at the headquarters of the Communist Party, U.S.A.

title: Fertility Clinics in Chile: A Tale of a Doctor Fleeing U.S. Law
description: On any weekday, a steady stream of well-dressed couples, many driving Mercedes-Benzes and BMW's, can be seen pulling into the parking lot of Clinica Las Condes, one of Chile's most prominent medical centers, nestled near the verdant Andes.

title: Clinton Friend's Case Ends
description: The Justice Department has dropped its investigation of the role played by Harry Thomason, a Hollywood filmmaker, in the dismissal of employees in the White House travel office, Mr. Thomason's lawyer said today.

title: 13 Charged as Balkan Crime Ring Members
description: Federal authorities today announced charges against 13 men from Yonkers and the Bronx who are believed to be members of a nationwide crime ring involving more than 400 Balkan refugees.

title: Group at Adelphi Asks Regents to Remove the Trustees
description: Faculty members and alumni of Adelphi University petitioned the state today to remove the university's board of trustees, charging that its "divisive, destructive and costly actions" threatened the survival of the 100-year-old institution.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;2 Accused of Bilking Banks
description: The owner of a communications company and his co-conspirator used counterfeit checks to defraud companies and banks, including New Jersey's First Union National Bank, out of about $250,000 during March, Federal authorities said yesterday.

title: GRAIN PRICES SOAR ON POOR WEATHER AND LOW SUPPLIES
description: As the nation's farmers head into their fields for spring planting, economists are paying more attention than usual to how the work is going.

title: Bally Reported to Pull Out of Talks on Sale
description: Convinced that it is worth more than potential suitors have been willing to pay, the Bally Entertainment Corporation has taken itself off the auction block, people with knowledge of the sale talks said yesterday.

title: For Japan's Women, a Lesser Work Role
description: It would be safe to assume that there is little sexual harassment on the assembly lines of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation in Japan. That is because there are virtually no women on the assembly lines of Mitsubishi and other automobile manufacturers.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;Rest of Pack Looks for Ways to Prevent Inevitable
description: Leaving the Chicago Bulls' locker room several weeks ago, Michael Jordan was asked if he saw anything that could throw the Bulls off course in their pursuit of a championship.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Northwest Announces Air China Agreement
description: The Northwest Airlines Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to an alliance with Air China to steer passengers to each other's flights. In December, the United States and China agreed to allow their countries' airlines to promote flights together. Northwest said its Air China venture was the first alliance between major United States and Chinese airlines.

title: Battered Lebanon Must Recover Again
description: The effects of the more than 24,000 Israeli shells and nearly 600 air raids that pounded Lebanon over the last 16 days will be felt long after the guns fall silent early today.

title: New Case Reported in Britain Of Illness Tied to Mad Cows
description: A neurologist treating three new patients with suspected cases of a fatal neurological disorder said today that at least one is suffering from the variant that scientists suspect is linked to the so-called mad cow disease.

title: 3 Million G.O.P. Fund Raiser Believed to Set a State Record
description: State Republican officials said today that a fund-raiser held for Gov. George E. Pataki on Thursday night in Manhattan brought in more than $3 million, making it by many accounts the most lucrative campaign event in New York State history.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;U.S.-Backed Pact Puts Japan In New Role in Asian Finance
description: Japan has concluded a currency pact with seven neighboring countries in an effort to expand its role in guarding against turmoil in the currency markets in Asia.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Money Laundering at Casino
description: Stephen McClintock, 43, a former vice president for marketing at the TropWorld casino in Atlantic City, admitted yesterday that he had schemed to launder nearly $125,000 by buying betting chips and then cashing them in, officials said. Mr. McClintock was approached in 1994 by an undercover Internal Revenue Service agent posing as a gambler who wanted to shield winnings from tax reporting laws, said Kevin McKeon, a spokesman for the agency. Mr. McClintock used the undercover agent's cash to buy more than $54,000 in chips from six casinos, and a month later bought $70,000 more from eight more casinos, according to the United States Attorney's office.

title: Stirling Silliphant, 78, Writer; Won 'Heat of the Night' Oscar
description: Stirling Silliphant, the highly prolific and successful screenwriter who won an Academy Award for writing "In the Heat of the Night" in 1967, died yesterday in Bangkok at the age of 78. In 1988, after three decades of writing for movies and television, Mr. Silliphant left California and moved to Thailand.

title: BASKETBALL;Nets to Settle Ownership
description: The National Basketball Association commissioner, David Stern, said yesterday that he expected the Nets to resolve their murky ownership situation early next week.

title: World News Briefs;One Italian Is Corrupt, One Is Not, Court Finds
description: A court acquitted the former Prime Minister Bettino Craxi of a graft charge today, but it issued a guilty verdict to the younger brother of another ex-Prime Minister, the media mogul Silvio Berlusconi. Mr. Craxi and the younger Mr. Berlusconi had been charged in a bribery case involving property deals.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GRUMA OF MEXICO TO SELL STAKE TO ARCHER-DANIELS
description: Gruma S.A. of Mexico said yesterday that it was in talks to sell a 20 percent stake valued at about $200 million to the Archer-Daniels Midland Company. The two companies are waiting for United States Government approval of their plans, said Eduardo Livas Cantu, chief executive of Gruma. The company makes corn flour, much of which is used to make tortillas. The price of the transaction has not been determined, Mr. Livas said. If completed, the Mexico City-based company will issue new shares worth 20 percent of its capital. The company has a market capitalization of 7.6 billion pesos (about $1.03 billion). Archer Daniels, one of the world's largest agricultural companies, is based in Decatur, Ill.

title: Religion Journal;132 Years Later, Methodists Repent Forebear's Sin
description: Both Judaism and Christianity demand that believers acknowledge their transgressions before God and seek forgiveness. What Roman Catholics do in confession and Jews do on Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, is to undergo a searching personal accounting, a task that also carries the inwardly renewing promise that those who repent of their wrongs can begin anew.

title: Blame Group Phobia for Empty Showers and Student Skunks
description: To the Editor:

title: Oldest Mummy 'Found' on Museum Shelf
description: Anthropologists at the Nevada State Museum said today that they had unearthed the oldest known mummy in North America -- and they found it right on their own shelves.

title: Big Labor Can Take On Wall Street
description: Hoping to elect a more worker-friendly Congress, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. will spend $35 million on voter education this year. But if big labor really wants to stop companies from slashing jobs and relocating overseas, it would use its war chest to educate middle-class investors.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Fatigue and Love's Accordion
description: Clara Andermatt has the curious choreographic ability to make dancers look excited and weary at the same time. She displayed it in the two works performed by her Companhia Clara Andermatt Thursday night at Dance Theater Workshop as the final attraction of Nova Danca Portugal '96, a stimulating modern-dance festival featuring troupes from Lisbon.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Germany Now Expects Slower Economic Growth
description: The German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, said yesterday that the Government now expects the economy to grow by only three-quarters of 1 percent this year, down from the 1.5 percent it had been predicting. "But," Mr. Kohl said in a speech prepared for delivery in Parliament, "we do not expect a recession in Germany."

title: School Board Defends Handling of Lease Reimbursement
description: Still stinging from accusations that the New York City Board of Education had squandered the opportunity to receive $30 million in state aid for building leases, top city school officials asserted yesterday that two years ago they tried to follow state reimbursement guidelines but were thwarted by state officials.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SERV-TECH IN PACT TO MERGE WITH HYDROCHEM INDUSTRIAL
description: Serv-Tech Inc. agreed to merge with Hydrochem Industrial Services Inc. in a transaction that would create a specialty maintenance services company with annual revenue of more than $400 million. Under a letter of intent, shareholders of both Houston-based companies would exchange their stock for shares of a new publicly traded company in a tax-free transaction. Investors in closely held Hydrochem will receive 55 percent of the new company, and Serv-Tech holders will get 45 percent. The companies expect to reach a definitive agreement by July 1.

title: Kohl Offers Plan for Big Cuts In the German Welfare State
description: With Europe in the throes of a widespread debate over its economic future, Chancellor Helmut Kohl announced a plan today for long-heralded cuts in Germany's vaunted and well-padded welfare state that threaten social benefits that his compatriots have come to regard as virtually sacrosanct.

title: In Protecting Principals, A History of Problems
description: If he succeeds in abolishing tenure for New York City's principals, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew will bring about a historic change in how the school system is run.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Germany Cuts Welfare; Lean Times for Europe? With Europeans voicing widespread anxiety about whether they can remain competitive in the global economy, Chancellor Helmut Kohl announced long-heralded cuts in Germany's well-padded welfare state that are intended to reduce Bonn's budget deficit by $33 billion.

title: Chinese Seek Atom Option To Fend Off Asteroids
description: When President Boris N. Yeltsin declared on Thursday, somewhat prematurely as it turned out, that he had persuaded China to sign a treaty banning nuclear weapons testing forever, he was unaware of China's position on the "asteroid threat" and the need for "peaceful nuclear explosions" to combat it.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;College or University?
description: The State Commission on Higher Education agreed yesterday to begin changing the way colleges earn the right to call themselves universities, a move that should help William Paterson College and Rowan College, among others, to burnish their prestige nationally. The changes would bring New Jersey's regulations into line with those of 47 other states. Currently, a New Jersey college must have 20 percent of its students enrolled in graduate studies and must offer doctoral degrees to call itself a university. Under the proposal, consultants would evaluate a college's academic standards to make a recommendation about a change in status. JOE SHARKEY

title: COMPANY NEWS;BORG-WARNER TO BUY THREE COLTEC BUSINESSES
description: Borg-Warner Automotive Inc. said yesterday that it would buy three automotive businesses from New York-based Coltec Industries Inc. for $283 million in cash. Borg-Warner, a Chicago-based maker of automotive drive trains, said it would buy Holley Automotive, based in Water Valley, Miss.; Coltec Automotive, based in Sallisaw, Okla., and Performance Friction Products of Longview, Tex. Borg-Warner Automotive shares rose $2.875, to $38.625, and Coltec's shares rose 62.5 cents, to $13.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. The three companies being acquired make air and oil pumps and parts for transmissions, brakes and suspensions.

title: POP REVIEW;Across the Border Into a Blur of New Styles
description: Los Lobos prowled through the back alleyways of American music in their first set on Thursday night at the Mercury Lounge. They picked up electric Chicago blues and syncopated New Orleans drumming, a norteno (Tex-Mex) polka from San Antonio and steadfast soul from Memphis, a Puerto Rican bomba and a Cajun two-step.

title: I.R.A. Says It Set Bombs
description: The Irish Republican Army took responsibility today for two large bombs planted under a Thames River bridge.

title: New Faces for MetroStars
description: With Tab Ramos and Ruben Dario Hernandez making their Major League Soccer debut, the MetroStars should present a decidedly different picture when they play the Columbus Crew tonight at Giants Stadium in their attempt to end a two-game losing streak.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Man Charged with Fraud
description: A man who Federal Bureau of Investigation agents said posed as a priest to swindle relatives of people who had recently died was charged yesterday with wire fraud. Special Agent Ann Todd said that the suspect had been tentatively identified as Adrian Rodriguez, 38, but that he had been "uncooperative" and had used more than a dozen aliases. Mr. Rodriguez had called people in Puerto Rico and informed them they were the beneficiaries of dead relatives' life insurance policies, but needed to wire a "processing fee" to get the proceeds, according to the complaint filed by the F.B.I. He collected about $40,000 this way, Agent Todd said.

title: Cheap Gas vs. Stiff Upper Lips;So Far, Deregulation Is Leaving Most Britons Cold
description: You might think that American and other foreign energy companies would have an easy time stealing British Gas's residential customers, now that the Government is ending the giant utility's monopoly on home deliveries of natural gas.

title: Zimbabwe's Leader Scoffs at Critics of Iron Rule
description: Zimbabwe is at a crossroads.

title: Gov. Engler's G.O.P. Ticket Potential Puts Past Under Scrutiny
description: One drawback to starring on lists of potential Vice-Presidential candidates, Gov. John M. Engler of Michigan is discovering, is that columnists start calling you things like "the Rotund One" in print.

title: BASEBALL;Good Victory But Bad News For the Yanks
description: When the hot-hitting Minnesota Twins came to town on the same day that the Yankees decided to shelve their top pitcher, David Cone, until his health problems can be figured out, it was hard to imagine that things could get any more bleak in the Bronx.
