title: Nature Notes From Route 22
description: It is nearly impossible to think about nature without thinking about time. For almost anyone living in the country, time is not the fourth dimension. Time is the only dimension, and it tugs at one in an ancestral way that has nothing to do with clocks or calendars or the frenetic inner pulse of one's humming computer. Time in nature is both an axis and a cycle. But it is also a jumble, a collision, especially in the way it works on human feelings.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-8

title: PLAYOFFS;Starks Stays Irrepressible, As Always
description: When Charlie Ward made a critical 3-pointer in the fourth quarter of Game 1 against Cleveland on Thursday night, the Knicks' reserve point guard was met by a demonstrative teammate on his way back to the bench for a timeout. He did not mind the screaming and the encouragement, but John Starks kept blocking Ward's path, not letting him go anywhere until his words were heard.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DIVIDEND TO BE RAISED BY 9% ALONG WITH STOCK SPLIT
description: The Monsanto Company said yesterday that it would raise its dividend nearly 9 percent and planned to split its stock five-for-one. The company, an agricultural biotechnology and chemical concern, will now pay a quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share, up from 69 cents. The new dividend will be paid June 12 to shareholders of record May 15. After the stock split, in which the company will issue five shares for every one share held, the quarterly dividend rate will drop to 15 cents a share. St. Louis-based Monsanto also said it would provide stock-option grants to about 27,000 employees who do not currently receive options.

title: No Headline
description: It's different, but everywhere in the world a jerk is a jerk, and the regular people can use a little help."

title: About New York;S.I. Shuns Debating Death Penalty
description: LAW and order matter in Staten Island.

title: Observer;Take A Parent To Work
description: We have just had Take Your Children to Work Day. I didn't take mine. Never do. It's supposed to help children understand their parents' work. I tried it once, and it was a bust.

title: Music in Review
description: A Woodstock Amalgam With an Italian Accent Zucchero Beacon Theater

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Fuji Bank Chief Steps Down but Denies Reason Is Losses
description: The president of the Fuji Bank, one of the nation's largest financial institutions, announced his resignation today, but denied that his decision was a result of huge loan losses at the company.

title: BOXING;No Charges Planned for Tyson
description: The Chicago police said today that there was no evidence to support a woman's contention that Mike Tyson had spoken to her inappropriately and groped her at a nightclub.

title: Bridge
description: Identifying the most expensive bidding decision ever made used to be difficult, but in purely financial terms there is now a clear answer. It occurred recently in a Manhattan rubber bridge game at which the stake is, apparently, the world's highest.

title: Free-Range Canines;Dog Owners Claim Run of the Parks
description: It has come to this: 14,000 years after the domestication of dogs, 371 years after Europeans settled Manhattan Island and 123 years after the completion of Central Park, this town is not big enough for humans and their best friends.

title: Soulful Vulnerabilaty Makes a Killer Special
description: Halfway through "The Killer," a smoldering chunk of Hong Kong noir, the dragnet tightens around a hit man who has left a pile of bodies in his path. "He looks determined without being ruthless," a police detective tells his sketch artist. "There's something heroic in his manner. He comes across so calm. Acts like he has a dream, eyes full of passion."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Pinelands Housing Rejected
description: Acting to restrict large-scale development in the Pine Barrens, the State Department of Environmental Protection rejected a plan yesterday that could have led to the construction of 5,500 homes on 4,000 acres at the edge of the Federally protected Pinelands National Reserve. The decision was welcomed by environmentalists determined to discourage more development in the sprawling pine forests and adjacent wetlands, and by neighbors already complaining about heavy congestion in Manchester Township.

title: Zelina Journal;A New York Cop's New Beat: Bosnia
description: Two months ago Charlie Hayes's profile read like this: New York Police Department, 21 years, retired. Last assignment: Patrol, Upper East Side.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column yesterday about the engagement of the actor Hume Cronyn to Susan Cooper, a children's book writer, misspelled the name of an award she has received. It is the Newbery Medal, not Newberry.

title: Gambling in the Sunlight
description: Just a few weeks ago, Representative Frank Wolf's proposal to create a commission on the social and economic impact of the nation's gambling explosion seemed just the sort of virtuous idea that everyone in this partisan Congress could support. In early March the House approved the nine-member study panel without dissent. But the Virginia Republican's proposal is in trouble in the Senate and may die there unless the majority leader, Bob Dole, exerts leadership to rescue it.

title: CMS and Asea In Joint Venture
description: The CMS Energy Corporation and ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd. said yesterday that they would buy one of Morocco's largest power plants and double its size, a project worth an estimated $1.3 billion. CMS Energy, based in Dearborn, Mich., said its independent power unit, CMS Generation, and Zurich-based ABB Asea Brown Boveri's Energy Ventures had reached an agreement with Morocco's national utility.

title: Queens Grocer Robbed, and Robbed Again
description: Lee's Grocery Store in Queens was busy Thursday night -- it was just one holdup after another.

title: Music in Review
description: Musically Peeling Away The Generational Layers Cracker Roseland

title: MIDEAST ACCORD;Restricting the Violence in Lebanon
description: Following is the text of the understanding reached today between Israel and Lebanon, in consultation with Syria: The United States understands that after discussions with the Governments of Israel and Lebanon, and in consultation with Syria, Lebanon and Israel will insure the following:

title: Three in Oklahoma Guilty in Bomb Plot
description: Three people who prosecutors said believed in an imminent foreign invasion of the United States have been convicted of plotting to bomb civil rights centers, gay bars and abortion clinics.

title: Dobbs Ferry Gambles And Wins On Grants
description: Last year, a small foundation created to raise money for the public schools here took a big gamble. It spent $60,000, nearly half of what it raised the previous year, to hire a full-time fund raiser.

title: It Was Zoning That Allowed SoHo to Be SoHo
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about a United Nations resolution on the fighting in Lebanon misidentified the body that approved the resolution. It was the General Assembly, not the Security Council.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Life Span Dips For Men Born In New York
description: For the first time in this century, the average life expectancy of males born in New York City has begun to decline, a reversal that researchers attribute largely to the city's AIDS epidemic.

title: F.A.A. Terminates Wilcox Contract
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it had terminated its $475 million contract for air-navigation equipment with Wilcox Electric Inc., a part of the Thomson-CSF unit of Thomson S.A. of France.

title: Correction: The Dow Thursday, Minute by Minute
Agency Stripped of Welfare Contracts Sues City to Keep Other Jobs
description: The Queens-based private agency at the center of an investigation into the awarding of two city welfare contracts worth $43 million went to court yesterday, trying to block efforts by the Giuliani administration to cancel six other contracts that it had with the city.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Softbank Profits Soar On Japanese Demand
description: The Softbank Corporation's profit nearly tripled in the fiscal year that ended on March 31, as a surge in Japanese demand for computers, software, network services and computer peripheral devices lifted sales. The company, Japan's largest computer software wholesaler, said yesterday that profit jumped to 13.8 billion yen ($122.62 million). Sales rose 45 percent, to 140.28 billion yen.

title: Cost of Immigrants Is State's, Court Says
description: A Federal appeals court has rejected an effort by New York State lawmakers and county executives to make the Federal Government reimburse the state for the cost of providing social services to illegal immigrants, officials said today.

title: 1996 N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;Next Stop on Rangers' Express Could Be Clincher
description: Finally, the home team won a game in this scintillating first-round Stanley Cup playoff series. It wasn't easy, but it certainly was a welcome turn of events for the Rangers, who can advance to the Eastern Conference semifinals tomorrow with a victory at Montreal.

title: Model Corporate Citizen Finds Its Trust in Doubt Over a Zoning Issue
description: It came down to whether they could still trust Hoover, their local corporation. Was Hoover still Hoover? Or had the 1990's turned the Hoover Company, America's leading vacuum cleaner manufacturer, into just another subsidiary controlled by a faraway corporation? That is what North Canton's 15,000 residents have struggled to figure out these last two years.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Sprint Gets Final Payment From Partners
description: The Sprint Corporation said today that it had received the final payment of $660 million in its sale of a 20 percent stake to France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom.

title: Mitsubishi Motors Plans Rescue of Embattled U.S. Unit
description: The American manufacturing subsidiary of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, already the target of a potentially huge Federal sexual harassment lawsuit, is also facing serious financial problems that will force a reorganization and a huge capital infusion, the parent company announced today.

title: MIDEAST ACCORD: IN ISRAEL;Peres's View: Modest Boon
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres, evidently relieved at being extracted by the American-brokered deal from a military operation that had gone awry, declared today that "Israel comes out of this with more quiet and more strength."

title: U.S. Seizes 2 Georgia Men With Ties to Paramilitary Group
description: Federal agents today arrested two Georgia men linked to a small right-wing paramilitary group who the agents said had bomb-making materials that they were fabricating into pipe bombs and detonating on property that they owned 80 miles south of here.

title: PASSENGER PLANES IN MILITARY FLEET GET SAFETY HELP
description: Responding to the crash of an Air Force passenger plane that killed Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and 34 other people, the Pentagon announced today that it would immediately begin adding better navigation equipment to all 2,800 passenger planes in its fleet.

title: The Last Battle For Troy
description: Moscow's Pushkin Museum has restored to world view, for the first time in more than 50 years, the ancient and fabled artifacts known as the Trojan Gold. But the artistic importance and romantic history of the treasure were overshadowed at the exhibit's opening when Russian and German officials squabbled over the custody of the trove, which was removed from Berlin by Soviet troops in 1945.

title: PLAYOFFS;Riley and Heat Unravel As Bulls Take Control
description: The Miami Heat discovered, as so many of Chicago's opponents have this season, that one half does not make a game against the Bulls.

title: Critic's Notebook;The World Is an Orderly Place, on CBS
description: When Della Reese sits down with a man who is cheating on his wife, she's not coy about her purpose. "You don't have to be an angel to see what's going on around here, but that's what I am, an angel sent by God," she says. As Tess, a sometimes acerbic, no-nonsense senior angel, she warns him, "God is not pleased." In a different kind of show, the man might say, "There's no such thing as an angel," or "Get outta here!" But this is "Touched by an Angel," so he decides to fix up his life. There are several wonders surrounding this show: it is an unlikely hit that has re-energized Saturday night for CBS, and, thanks to

title: When Police Aren't Told Of Stolen Cars' Recovery
description: Just where the bullet shattered the bone, a metal plate now sits in Lebert Folkes Jr.'s head, to hold the right eyeball in place. Robert K. Graham had a finger amputated after his left hand was pierced by a bullet.

title: Schools Head Urges Abolishing Tenure for New York Principals
description: The New York City Schools Chancellor, Dr. Rudy Crew, urged abolishing tenure for the city's 1,160 principals yesterday, saying the school system needs the power to remove principals to improve its many underachieving schools.

title: It Was Zoning That Allowed SoHo to Be SoHo
description: To the Editor:

title: Music in Review
description: In an Eclectic Songfest, A Soprano Is Her Own Critic Christine Brewer Alice Tully Hall

title: Lesson From Holocaust Avoids Parallel to Assisted Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: Journal;Sotheby's Sneak Preview
description: Forget those headline items -- the $211,500 faux pearls Jackie wore in a magazine photo or the $1.43 million desk on which J.F.K. signed the Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;No Word From Camby
description: MARCUS CAMBY did not reveal yesterday if he would stay at Massachusetts for his senior season. "Probably the most aggravating part is people asking, 'what are you going to do?' " Camby said in an interview with New England Cable News. "And you don't have an answer at this point." Several newspapers have reported that he plans to enter the N.B.A. draft. (AP)

title: Three Are Charged in Murder Of Actor From 'Killing Fields'
description: Three men were charged by the Los Angeles police today with the murder of Haing S. Ngor, a Cambodian physician who won an Academy Award for his performance in the 1984 film "The Killing Fields."

title: World News Briefs;10th Anniversary of Blast Is Marked at Chernobyl
description: Tens of thousands of people wept, prayed and marched today to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster, which unleashed a lethal radioactive cloud over Europe and blighted millions of lives.

title: Company Briefs
description: PRONET INC., Dallas, a provider of wireless communications, agreed to buy the paging operation of Pac-West TelecommInc. and Strategic Products Corp., both based in Stockton, Calif., for about $19 million.

title: Chemical Bank Ex-Trader Returns to U.S.
description: A former currency trader for the Chemical Banking Corporation has been brought back to the United States from Britain to face charges that he concealed a $70 million trading loss while working in the bank's New York office.

title: Hate Graffiti Is Cleaned Up
description: About 50 volunteers with spray bottles and rags turned out today to help remove swastikas and other hate graffiti around the capital.

title: MIDEAST ACCORD: IN LEBANON;Pact Raises Few Hopes Among Those Long Schooled in Chaos
description: This country has been pounded by more than 24,000 Israeli shells and nearly 600 air raids in the last 16 days, and their effect will be felt long after the guns fall silent early Saturday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about videotaped testimony to be given by President Clinton in the Arkansas criminal trial of his former business partners in the Whitewater real estate development referred incorrectly to the investigation by the Whitewater independent counsel into that venture and the collapse of Madison Guaranty Savings and Loan.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Giants Think They Have Complete Player in Jones
description: Last season, toward the end of a game against Kansas, Oklahoma defensive end Cedric Jones was hit below the knees by a player trying to block him. He knew he was hurt, he just didn't know how badly. So he played on. As long as he could. As hard as he could.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FAIRCHILD AIRCRAFT IN TALKS TO ADD DORNIER LUFTFAHRT
description: Fairchild Aircraft Inc. said yesterday that it was negotiating to take over Dornier Luftfahrt G.m.b.H. from Daimler-Benz A.G. of Germany. The Texas-based company provided no purchase price for Dornier, an unprofitable German maker of turboprop airplanes. Fairchild Aircraft said the talks "are expected to lead to Fairchild taking over control" of Dornier, whose main product is the Dornier 328, a 30-to-40-seat turboprop. A Daimler spokesman, Eckhard Zanger, confirmed that Dornier's parent company, Daimler-Benz Aerospace A.G., was in talks with Fairchild, among other potential buyers.

title: Dangerous Flaws In Tracking Stolen Cars
description: Just where the bullet shattered the bone, a metal plate now sits in Lebert Folkes Jr.'s head. Robert K. Graham had a finger amputated after his hand was pierced by a bullet. The two motorists were shot by the police in separate incidents in February after being mistaken for car thieves. Prosecutors will investigate. But the investigators will not ask why the Police Department's system for tracking stolen automobiles led officers to think that they were confronting car thieves.

title: SUNY Trustees and Leader Try to Resolve Differences
description: Responding to a report that the Chancellor of the State University of New York, Thomas A. Bartlett, might resign as early as Monday because of differences with the Board of Trustees, board members and others close to him sought yesterday to express optimism about the relationship and to say they were trying to find ways to work together better.

title: Edward W. Carter, 84, Retailer And a Pioneer of Shopping Malls
description: Edward W. Carter, a retailing executive who was one of the first to see the potential of shopping malls and was a founder of the Carter Hawley Hale Stores empire, died on Thursday at his home in Bel Air, Calif. He was 84.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the competition in Arlington, Tex., between The Fort Worth Star-Telegram and The Dallas Morning News misstated the year of the death of Amon Carter, founder of The Star-Telegram. It was 1955; his son, Amon Jr., died in 1982.

title: Blame Group Phobia for Empty Showers and Student Skunks
description: To the Editor:

title: At Miss Porter's School, Miss Bouvier Is Just Not for Sale
description: You have to wonder what that stuffed elephant would have gone for at Sotheby's.

title: 4 Agency Workers Questioned On Death of a Boy in the Bronx
description: Four workers for the city's child-welfare agency appeared yesterday before a new review panel investigating the agency's handling of the case of a 22-month-old Bronx boy whose decomposed body was found in a garbage bag outside his parents' apartment last week.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PRIME MEDICAL SERVICES PURCHASES LITHOTRIPTERS
description: Prime Medical Services Inc. said yesterday that it had bought the privately held Lithotripters Inc. for $88 million in cash and stock. Lithotripters, based in Fayetteville, N.C., and Prime Medical of Austin, Tex., both specialize in lithotripsy, a medical procedure that uses shock waves to treat kidney stones. With the purchase, Prime Medical now serves about 32,000 lithotripsy patients a year through contracts with 400 hospitals. Prime Medical said its annual revenues are expected to jump to $90 million from the $23.2 million it reported last year. The purchase price includes $70 million in cash and 1.6 million common shares.

title: Quality College Prep
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Isringhausen And Mets Get Chilly Reception
description: Jason Isringhausen usually thrives in chilly temperatures. The colder the better, as far as he is concerned. So when the thermometer read 50 degrees for the start of tonight's game against the Pirates, it figured to be just the climate in which he could thrive.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WIRELESS ONE IN AGREEMENT TO ACQUIRE TRUVISION
description: Wireless One Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Truvision Wireless Inc. in a stock swap valued at $45 million. Wireless One, an operator of wireless pay-television systems, will exchange 3.4 million shares for all of Truvision's shares. Truvision, based in Jackson, Miss., operates four wireless pay-television systems in and around Mississippi. Wireless One, which operates 14 systems, will have about 34,000 subscribers when the deal is completed.

title: Urohealth-Galileo Pact
description: Urohealth Systems Inc. signed a letter of intent today to enter a joint distribution agreement with the Galileo Electro-Optics Corporation. Urohealth will have exclusive rights to offer Galileo's rigid and flexible endoscopes for all urological and gynecological applications. Galileo Electro-Optics makes fiber optic and electro-optic components, which transmit, sense or intensify light or images. Urohealth's stock was up 62.5 cents, to $14.75, and Galileo gained $2.50, to $23.625. Both stocks hit new 52-week highs during the day.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COPLEY PHARMACEUTICAL SAYS LOSSES ARE WIDENING
description: Copley Pharmaceutical Inc., beset by legal woes, said yesterday that its losses were widening as the company, a drug maker, cuts prices to maintain the market share of its two best-selling products. Copley, which is 51 percent owned by Hoechst Marion Roussel Inc., said it expected to lose more than 9 cents a share but less than 18 cents a share in the first quarter, which ended on March 31. Wall Street analysts had expected the company to earn money in the quarter even though they knew of the price competition. Copley lost $1.7 million, or 9 cents, in the quarter that ended Dec. 31. In the first quarter of 1995, the company earned $2.92 million, or 15 cents a share.

title: Jury Calls for Execution of Ex-Policeman
description: A former New Orleans police officer who ordered a woman murdered the day after she filed a brutality complaint against him should be executed, a jury ruled today.

title: A Surgical Strike That Could Backfire
description: Since the Persian Gulf war, American military leaders have argued that strategic bombing can kill, overthrow or paralyze enemy leaders -- making wars winnable within a matter of days. Like the Texas Ranger slogan, "One riot, one Ranger," such targeted bombing promises "one war, one raid."

title: Lesson From Holocaust Avoids Parallel to Assisted Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Muslim holiday Eid al-Adha, the feast of sacrifice, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City tomorrow, Monday and Tuesday.

title: The Cease-Fire in Lebanon
description: Thanks to the tireless and skillful mediation of Secretary of State Warren Christopher, two weeks of warfare and upheaval in Lebanon and northern Israel are ending. No party emerged a clear-cut winner from the fighting, but all can claim some benefit from the diplomacy that ended it.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;2 Decisions in Mexico May Aid U.S. Companies
description: American companies that compete in telecommunications and the managment of pension funds in Mexico stand to gain from two important regulatory decisions in Mexico, although not as much as they want.

title: Lesson From Holocaust Avoids Parallel to Assisted Suicide;Don't Demonize Dissent
description: To the Editor:

title: Mild Sanctions on the Sudan Approved by U.N. Council
description: The Security Council agreed today to impose mild sanctions on the Sudan unless it hands over three men accused of trying to assassinate President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt last June.

title: Canada Close To Elimination
description: Valery Karpov scored the tie-breaking goal as Russia beat Canada, 6-4, today, putting the Canadians on the verge of elimination from the world hockey championships.

title: Saul Bass, 75, Designer, Dies; Made Art Out of Movie Titles
description: Saul Bass, the minimalist auteur who put a jagged arm in motion in 1955 and created an entire film genre, died on Thursday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 75.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;2 Admit Damaging Graves
description: Two teen-agers admitted in Federal court yesterday that they spray-painted Nazi swastikas and other anti-Semitic graffiti on grave markers in a Jewish cemetery in Saddle Brook the night before last Halloween, and said they were sorry they did it. Christopher Talbot, 19, of Lodi and Kevin Coombs, 18, of Garfield each pleaded guilty to violating Federal civil rights laws. The vandalism came under Federal law because it was intended to hurt, intimidate and oppress people because of their religious beliefs, said Lisa Russell-Charles, an assistant United States attorney.

title: AN AMERICAN PLACE;Corporate Neighbor Becomes a Stranger
description: It boiled down to whether the people of North Canton could still trust Hoover, their local corporation. Was Hoover still Hoover? Or had the 1990's turned the Hoover Company, America's leading vacuum cleaner manufacturer, into just another subsidiary controlled by a faraway corporation?

title: Two Held in Death of Officer At Hackensack Sears Store
description: Two men have been arrested in the April 19 slaying of an off-duty Teaneck police officer, and one has also been charged with the earlier killing of a Paramus gas station attendant during a robbery, the authorities said today.

title: Blame Group Phobia for Empty Showers and Student Skunks
description: To the Editor:

title: Music in Review
description: Choosing Updated Offenbach Over Outdated Innuendoes 'La Belle Helene' Alice Tully Hall

title: It Was Zoning That Allowed SoHo to Be SoHo;Tax Inhibits Growth
description: To the Editor:

title: George Margolis, 81, Who Pioneered Early Studies on Alzheimer's
description: Dr. George Margolis, a Dartmouth College neuropathologist who did some of the early research into Alzheimer's disease, died on Thursday at his home in Ridgefield, Conn. He was 81.

title: Look at the Cost of White-Collar Crime, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: MIDEAST ACCORD: THE OVERVIEW;ISRAEL AND LEBANON AGREE TO HALT BORDER SHELLINGS; A SAFEGUARD FOR CIVILIANS
description: Israel, Syria and Lebanon agreed today on a written set of understandings to stop 16 days of rocketing and shelling in northern Israel and southern Lebanon. The attacks have killed more than 150 Lebanese, forced hundreds of thousands of people in both countries to flee their homes and caused millions of dollars of damage.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;A Spring of Possibility For New, Improved Jets
description: Is it always this windy here?" Neil O'Donnell asked, laughing, after his first exposure to his new teammates and the unpredictable elements at the Jets' practice field, even in springtime.

title: Bank Lobbying Blocks a Bill On S.& L.'s
description: After months of maneuvering, the nation's big commercial banks succeeded this week in blocking legislation -- supported by both the Clinton Administration and the Republican leadership -- that would have forced them to pay a big share of the cleanup bill from the savings and loan crisis.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: GYMNASTICS;Comaneci, Conner Wed
description: NADIA COMANECI, 34, who dazzled the world with her perfect 10's at the 1976 Olympics, married a former United States gold medalist, BART CONNER, 38, yesterday in Bucharest, Romania. Outside, about 2,000 fans watched the proceedings on a giant screen. The couple live in Oklahoma, training young gymnasts. (AP)

title: Dole Urges Repeal of 1993 Gas Tax Increase
description: Senator Bob Dole today called for the repeal of a 4.3-cent gas tax that a Democratic Congress passed in 1993 as part of President Clinton's plan to reduce the budget deficit.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMERITECH AND I.B.M. IN MULTIBILLION-DOLLAR DEAL
description: The Ameritech Corporation and the systems integration unit of the International Business Machines Corporation entered into a multibillion-dollar, 10-year agreement yesterday for information technology services. The deal, involving I.B.M.'s Integrated Systems Solutions Corporation, is one of the largest ever in terms of the amount of mainframe computing capacity involved, the companies said. Under the agreement, Integrated Systems will manage Ameritech's data center operations and ongoing consolidation efforts.

title: Ending Sexual Abuse in Prison
description: The relationship between prison guards and the inmates they control clearly presents opportunities for abuse. That is why a proposed bill to criminalize all sex between guards and prisoners -- coercive or consensual -- deserves approval by New York's State Legislature.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Daytime Curfew for Youths
description: Starting May 15, youths between the ages of 6 and 17 will be stopped by the police if they are found on the city streets during school hours. The City Council on Thursday approved a weekday curfew to "help prevent truancy, juvenile delinquency and crime in the city." Those with valid excuses for not being in school will be exempt. The measure provides penalties of fines, community service and jail terms for parents of offenders, as well as for store owners who allow truant students to gather in their businesses.

title: So What to Do With Souvenirs of Camelot? Use Them, if You Dare
description: Alexandra Grzesik has plans for the shiny, silvery mint julep cup with the golden lining that she bought for slightly less than $1,200 at the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis estate auction yesterday. Never mind what the paragon of good taste and elegant simplicity might say: Ms. Grzesik is going to use it as a toothbrush holder.

title: Spanish Leader Wins Support Needed for Majority
description: The conservative Popular Party announced a long-sought agreement tonight with a coalition of Catalan nationalists, paving the way for the party's leader, Jose Maria Aznar, to become Spain's next Prime Minister.

title: INSIDE
description: Banks Help Derail S.& L. Bill

title: Yankee Who Captured Savannah Is Its Hero
description: Not since William Tecumseh Sherman spared Savannah from the torch has this city been so indebted to a Yankee.

title: World News Briefs;Chess Match Moved From Iraq to Russia
description: The world chess federation has dropped its plans to stage its championship in Iraq and will hold the match in southern Russia, the federation's president, Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Rentokil Succeeds In Hostile Takeover
description: Rentokil P.L.C. said yesterday that the business services company BET P.L.C. had accepted its hostile takeover offer of L2.1 billion ($3.17 billion) in cash and shares for control of a 59.8 percent stake in BET. Market analysts had predicted a narrow Rentokil victory, believing institutional shareholders would put their trust in Rentokil's record of at least 20 percent growth for 14 consecutive years.

title: 1,000 Friends Help Cheer Up Mrs. Clinton
description: More than 1,000 Democratic women rallied in defense of Hillary Rodham Clinton today and heard her predict that Republicans would soon be launching "a relentless attack" of negative advertising and misinformation in their effort to defeat her husband.

title: F.A.A., Citing Problems, Drops Contract for Navigation System
description: Citing cost overruns and schedule delays because of mismanagement, the Federal Aviation Administration today canceled a $475 million contract that was intended to help the airlines get extremely precise navigational data from satellites.

title: Music in Review
description: The Cincinnati Plays Weber, Schumann and Shostakovich Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra Carnegie Hall

title: Venezuela Joins The Latin Trend To Free Markets
description: After reversing several years of stalwart resistance to free-market changes, Venezuela is under heavy pressure at home and abroad to produce results.

title: With New Budget, Domestic Spending Is Cut $24 Million
description: The budget bill signed today by President Clinton, combined with other actions taken by Congress in the last year, will cut domestic spending by $24 billion, and most of the savings will come from housing, labor, education and Commerce Department programs.

title: Sports of the Times;A Threat That Is Not So Empty
description: ATHLETES stretched and warmed up on the Franklin Field infield yesterday afternoon, oblivious to the chill of intermittent rains that soaked Day 2 of the Penn Relays. Athletes are vulnerable like this -- open to the elements, to criticism, to the vagaries of success and failure.

title: PLAYOFFS;Canadiens' Thibault: Nightmare In the Nets
description: When Jocelyn Thibault, Montreal's top goalie, went through his customary visualization routine before taking his pre-game nap, he probably didn't envision himself facing 34 pucks in only two periods and stopping all but one. Nor did he anticipate a playoff outing in which his Canadiens were outshot by 6-0 during five fruitless power plays.

title: PLAYOFFS;Score One for Kurri, and He'll Take It
description: The scowl said more than his words ever could. Jari Kurri listened to a question from a friendly face, a witness to his brilliance throughout the Edmonton years that have suddenly seemed so long ago. For all the goals Kurri has scored in the Stanley Cup playoffs, enough to guarantee a place in the Hall of Fame, is it possible to reach a point where he feels he can't score anymore?

title: COMPANY NEWS;HERMAN'S SPORTING GOODS FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: Herman's Sporting Goods Inc., which operates 117 stores in the Northeast, said yesterday that it had again filed for bankruptcy. The filing of the voluntary Chapter 11 petition in the United States Bankruptcy Court in Trenton was the second time the retailer, based in Carteret, N.J., had applied for protection from its creditors. It previously filed in 1993. As of March 30, Herman's had $127.8 million in assets and $160.5 million in liabilities, according to the filing. Among the top unsecured creditors the company listed were Reebok International, Rollerblade Inc., Authentic Fitness, Russell, Nike and Prince Sports Group. All of the company's stores will remain open for business, Herman's said.

title: TRACK & FIELD;Wind Tames George Mason's Medley
description: The midday wind at Franklin Field was awful today and the gusts were worse. On a day that turned chilly and drizzly, the wind blew at 22 miles an hour and the gusts reached 40. The wind tore into runners and made them feel as if they were wearing weights around their waists.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Holloway Can Sign
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday restored the eligibility of SHAHEEN HOLLOWAY, one of the nation's top recruits, to sign a letter of intent with Seton Hall University if he so chooses. He will announce his decision on Monday.

title: Music in Review
description: A Variety of Moods Spiced With a Hint of New Orleans Jane Ira Bloom Sweet Basil

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the Market Indicators charts in Business Day yesterday omitted the daily graph showing the position of the Dow Jones industrial average at 30-second intervals during the previous day. The omitted chart appears today on page 38.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Football

title: STYLE;Fade Out
description: Myth expresses in a concise and symbolic way some truth of human experience, possibly even some fact. Nico, a German model who became the lead singer of the Velvet Underground and died eight years ago of a brain hemorrhage, was a particular myth of the downtown, bohemian, Andy-Warhol-factory, cool-beyond-cool 1960's. As it turns out, however, Nico is not very mythic at all. The idea of her may be interesting, but she is barely an instrument of expression. She has the blankness, the emptiness of a mirror.

title: April 21-27;Japan's Trial of the Century
description: The guru of the Aum Shinrikyo religious cult was thinner but no more contrite after spending nearly a year in jail. On the first day of his trial for ordering last year's nerve gas attack on the Tokyo subway system, Shoko Asahara declined to enter a plea and instead gave the judges a brief lecture about his religious ideas.

title: BENEFITS
description: Writers Read for Literacy MONDAY -- Barbara Bush, the former First Lady, will speak briefly at an evening of readings by authors, including Richard Ford, Nikki Giovanni and Stephen King. The evening will benefit Literacy Partnerp. The readings begin at 7 P.M. at the Juilliard Theater, 155 West 65th Street, followed by a black-tie dinner and dance at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center. Gerald M. Levin, the chairman of Time Warner, and his wife, Barbara, will be honored. Tickets, $500, or $175 for the readings alone, from (212) 921-9070. Kips Bay Preview MONDAY -- The Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club will hold a preview of its 24th annual Decorator Show House, at 603 Park Avenue (64th Street). The evening, from 6 to 8, will begin with cocktails at the Americas Society, at 680 Park Avenue (68th Street). Mariette Himes Gomez, Samuel Botero and other designers will be on hand. Tickets, $125, from (718) 893-8600.

title: Upheaval and Calm as Big Dig Transforms Boston
description: Its construction has been likened by people here to that of the Pyramids, the Hoover Dam and the Panama Canal. It has been called "a wonder of the world," by the United States Transportation Secretary.

title: What Is the Answer to Free, Odious Speech?
description: To the Editor:

title: COPING;From Franco to Imus: An Activist's Long View
description: I was less depressed during the Depression," said Ruth K. Goldberg, who is 84. "Maybe it's because I was younger then. Old age is not so wonderful. I keep crossing out names of friends in my address book. But there's something else, too.

title: April 21-27;Ethiopia's Marxist Rulers Go on Trial
description: Prosecutors finally got down to business earlier this month in the trial of 46 former leaders in the Marxist military junta that ruled Ethiopia for nearly 17 years. After more than a year of delays, the first witnesses were called in what the new Ethiopian Government says will be the largest judgment of genocide and crimes against humanity since the Nuremburg trials.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHELSEA;Company in AIDS Dispute Pays a Price for Its Prices
description: When employees of Stadtlanders Pharmacy and Wellness Center arrived at their store at Eighth Avenue and 16th Street 10 days ago, they found its plate-glass windows papered with the words "Profiteers" and "Price Gougers."

title: Stamford Shapes Up to Hold Off Lean Years;After a Decade of Malaise, the City Takes Steps to Tame Its Bureaucracy
description: In the sleek corporate office building called Government Center here, the chief diversion of city workers these days is looking out the window to watch the swift progress of the construction of the Swiss Bank Corporation's new headquarters.

title: ART;From Trees and Animals to an African-American Burial Ground
description: THE Homer Babbidge Library at the University of Connecticut in Storrs is far from a work of art. Its cantilevered design has long been plagued by structural problems making the library a permanent construction site.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY;She Must Be Crazy
description: At a cliffside restaurant in a swanky Caribbean resort, wealthy vacationers pause between spoonfuls of passion-fruit sorbet to monitor the progress of a lone swimmer as she sidestrokes out to sea, faithfully escorted by her three Irish setters. Is she crazy? the diners ask one another with a mix of fascination and horror. Doesn't she know about sharks? The swimmer's name is Adele, and by some standards she must be crazy: not so long ago, she turned her back on a pampered, privileged life in the Connecticut countryside to fly off to India and worship at the feet of a tyrannical guru. Narrated in part by one of Adele's acquaintances, THE WOMAN WHO WALKED ON WATER (Riverhead, $21) unfolds in brief, elegantly written chapters, keeping its distance as it traces this restless, enigmatic woman's attempts to lose herself in something greater. Seen from the narrator's detached perspective, Adele's headlong pursuit of enlightenment proceeds inexorably, like a 10-car pileup viewed in slow motion far in the distance. As she steadily recedes from her earthly existence, Adele sacrifices not only her autonomy and her material possessions but also a chorus of bewildered family and friends. She loses weight, her hair becomes streaked with gray, she suffers from mysterious illnesses. But could she be exchanging these mundane measures of health for a deeper spiritual well-being? Is Adele's flight from her former life transcendent or tragic? As it explores these questions, Lily Tuck's second novel emerges as a haunting, strangely perplexing meditation on the quest for higher meaning -- and the steep price that seekers (not to mention those around them) must pay. Sarah Ferguson

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a restaurant review last Sunday about Nadia, in Maplewood, referred incorrectly to two appetizers. House-cured duck with green lentils is one dish; foie gras is another. They are not served together.

title: POP VIEW;Can Rock Play to the Broadway Crowd?
description: WHEN "RENT" OPENS tomorrow night at the Nederlander Theater on Broadway, it will arrive with all the accolades a show could hope for, from rave Off Broadway reviews to a Pulitzer Prize. That should be enough, its producers and fans hope, to make a success of a musical-theater work that is not a revival, a movie adaptation, a Stephen Sondheim opus or an Andrew Lloyd Webber spectacular. "Rent," as a rock opera, also carries a different set of aspirations -- that Broadway can find common ground with composers and fans of the world's most popular music.

title: WEDDINGS;McKenzie Reed, Kees van Meel
description: Virginia McKenzie Reed, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Larus Reed Jr. of Richmond, was married yesterday to Cornelis Hendricus Adrianus van Meel, a son of Mrs. Cornelis J. A. van Meel of Bolsward, the Netherlands, and the late Mr. van Meel. The Rev. Dr. Robert R. Laha Jr., a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Proposals for More Visitors to Alaska Parks
description: The National Park Service recently announced proposals for increasing the number of visitors at two national parks in Alaska.

title: Alexander D'Arcy Film Actor, 87
description: Alexander D'Arcy, who appeared in such films as "Prisoner of Zenda" and "How to Marry a Millionaire" in an acting career that reached from the 1920's to the 70's, died on April 20. He was 87.

title: West Side Is Best
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Sunday April 28, 1996: ON THEIR TOES;The Patter of Aching Feet
description: When the New York City Ballet begins its spring season at the State Theater Tuesday night, the audience will marvel at the revolutions of a pirouette, the height of a jete, the fluidity of an adagio. But if all the balletomanes knew what another first-nighter in their midst knows, they'd be marveling that some of the dancers were dancing at all. For it is to this man, an orthopedic surgeon named William G. Hamilton, that dancers from the New York City Ballet, the American Ballet Theater and many other companies go with their potentially career-ending injuries. He has ministered to the soles of Baryshnikov, Martins and Farrell, among hundreds of others.

title: A PEACE PLAN FOR THE CIGARETTE WARS
description: Richard Kluger's "Peace Plan for the Cigarette Wars" (April 7) is more like a unilateral surrender. However selfish the motives of personal injury lawyers, the lawsuits they have filed have been the single most powerful weapon in the war against smoking. To prohibit all future actions would be to capitulate to an enemy that is finally running scared.

title: How a Little School Handily Competes
description: IT would take a good-sized piece of paper to enumerate the amenities that Union School does not have.

title: MUSIC;Twin Cloud Marks 10th Birthday
description: REFLECTING on the last 10 years, the impresario Thom Wolke, 37, founder-director of Twin Cloud Concerts, which marks its 10th anniversary today at a folk summit in the Tarrytown Music Hall, said: "I didn't know I would last this long. I felt that there was a cultural hole that needed filling in the community, that there was no place for people my age and other baby boomers to enjoy quality folk music and jazz in comfortable surroundings. Well, things have come a long way since then, so we will be celebrating with some of my favorite artists."

title: WHO'S ON TRIAL - THE HERETIC OR THE CHURCH?
description: As one of the bishops involved in the "irregular" ordination of women in the Episcopal Church, in 1974, I applaud your selection of Bruce Bawer to report on the current controversy over the ordination of homosexual people ("Who's on Trial -- the Heretic or the Church?," April 7).

title: WEDDINGS;Gina Marie Neri, Robert Hayes
description: Gina Marie Neri, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Neri of Franklin Lakes, N.J., was married there yesterday to Robert Kyle Hayes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard T. Hayes of Rotonda West, Fla. Msgr. Carl Hendrickson performed the ceremony at the Most Blessed Sacrament Church.

title: GOOD EATING;Elegant Dining At Midtown Oases
description: AKBAR* (212) 838-1717; 475 Park Avenue, near 57th Street; all major credit cards

title: Effects of Downsizing Just Keep on Going
description: NINE years and counting, and the downsizing will just not let up in Westchester.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Chevrolet Corvette Grand Sport;0 to Springtime in 4.8 Seconds
description: FINALLY there is a car in my driveway that no one really needs.

title: ON THE MAP;In the Gritty Underworld of the Tunnel, He's There for You
description: Day after day, when Richard Cravello goes to work, he gets stuck in the Lincoln Tunnel.

title: Edward Lea Marsh Jr. Legislator and Livestock Breeder, 86
description: Edward Lea Marsh Jr., a country lawyer, civic leader, legislator and breeder of show-quality cattle and poultry, died last Sunday at his home in Old Lyme, Conn., where his ancestors settled in the 1600's. He was 86.

title: In the Region/Long Island;A Pendulum Swings, From Youngsters to the Aged
description: FOR more than a decade, the Larkfield Elementary School on Cheshire Place, once part of the Northport-East Northport School District, stood empty, a casualtyof declining school enrollment.

title: Italy's New Politics;Barricades in the Middle of the Road
description: LAST week, a coalition of center-left parties won national elections in Italy, promising an administration in which the left and moderates will work hand in hand. Four days later, the hardy Marxists of the Communist Refounding party -- who ran as allies but not members of the victorious coalition -- called the faithful to annual rallies celebrating Italy's liberation in 1945. "The fascists sometimes come back," was the dark warning spelled out on posters plastered all over central Rome, "We can stop them -- hope is reborn."

title: Feeling the Earth Move
description: California fault Searching for the Spirit of a State Along the San Andreas. By Thurston Clarke. 417 pp. New York: Ballantine Books. $24.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption in the Arts and Leisure section today, about the artist who painted the icon "The Trinity," reverses his names in some copies. He was Andrei Rublev.

title: In the Region/New Jersey;Fade Out a Flea Market, Fade In a Multiplex Theater
description: FOR 20 years, a 20-acre tract off Route 1 here was home to the U.S. 1 Flea Market, where some 100 merchants sold their wares at bargain prices in a 175,000-square-foot building that now is vacant and forlorn.

title: At Naval Academy, Ethics Lapses Go Back Years
description: To the Editor:

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;Imitation That Doesn't Flatter
description: HOW DELICATE IS great architecture, that it must be protected not only from its enemies, but also from its friends. Almost everyone who has ever seen Louis Kahn's Salk Institute for Biological Studies admires it as one of the exalted buildings of American architecture. Dr. Jonas Salk, who founded the institute, was so proud of this structure that he came to see himself not merely as the client who had commissioned it but almost as Kahn's collaborator. And he believed the building, completed in 1965 on a bluff overlooking the Pacific Ocean, to be one of his finest accomplishments.

title: The View From: Bedford Hills Correctional Facility;Keeping Families Intact, From Prison
description: CATHY MIGLIORE says her children keep her going. Ms. Migliore is a 36-year-old inmate at the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility here, serving a 25-year sentence on a drug-related conviction. She is articulate, friendly and determined that her 15- and 17-year-old sons get the kind of upbringing that will help them develop into decent, mature adults.

title: ART NOTES;Artist Explains His Indian Inspiration
description: WHEN Will Barnet, who has works in the Whitney Museum of American Art, the Philips Collection in Washington and the Vatican Museum, was growing up in Beverly, Mass., he developed a strong attraction for the Indian art and artifacts that he saw in museums in the Boston region.

title: Homeless Center Says Its Bad Days Are Over
description: As officials review its request for nearly $2 million a year in city funds, New York City's largest drop-in center for the homeless has become the focus of a debate over its troubled history and whether conditions there have improved.

title: End of 53d St. Transfer Shows M.T.A.'s Contempt
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;Woody Allen's Gigs: Blowing Westward
description: Though Michael's Pub has featured some of the biggest names in jazz, to most New Yorkers, the name is synonymous with Woody Allen, who has regularly used the Monday night sessions to pick up his clarinet and blow some New Orleans jazz from his Manhattan soul.

title: Credit Check;Happy Days Are Here Again! Right, Voters?
description: BILL CLINTON wrote the book on how to run against the economy in 1992, when the country was in a recessionary funk and the now-famous "It's the Economy, Stupid" sign hung in his campaign headquarters.

title: Chain Gangs For Women Cause Furor
description: The Prison Commissioner of Alabama, who had drawn national attention for steps that included reinstituting chain gangs for male prisoners, resigned on Friday after the Governor squashed his suggestion that female prisoners ought to be put on chain gangs as well.

title: A PEACE PLAN FOR THE CIGARETTE WARS
description: Kluger had some good comments, especially those debunking myths about smoking and his thoughts on changing cigarette advertising. However, he didn't address the growing discrimination against smokers and some of the social toll it's taking.

title: Joy and Order as India's Voting Starts
description: As the daughter of tea pickers who have worked for generations in the plunging green hillsides around this idyllic village in southern India, Bha-geshwari went to the polls every election day with her parents, watching as they joined millions of other Indians in choosing a government.

title: MANUAL LABOR
description: James Gleick's "Manual Labor" (Fast Forward, April 7) scratched the surface of a problem that only seems to stem from 20th-century technology. Describing simple functions in plain language has been difficult for a much longer time. Here is an example, from "Beadle's Dime Hand-Book of Pedestrianism," published in 1867:

title: GARDENING;Dividing Perennials Multiplies Neighborliness
description: TRADITION holds that spring-blooming perennials are divided in the fall, while fall-blooming perennials are divided in the spring. This theory is essentially correct, but sometimes gardens do not work out this way.

title: Correction
description: A brief report on the Travel Advisory page on April 14 about movie passes for Amtrak passengers misstated the status of movies on the company's trains. Several Amtrak trains do indeed offer movies in lounges, at individual seats or in sleeper cars, depending on the route.

title: WEDDINGS;Nathalie Lagesse, Francis deWolf 3d
description: Nathalie Blore Lagesse, the daughter of Guy Lagesse of Chazay d'Azergues, France, and Tessa Blore of London, was married yesterday to Francis Colt deWolf 3d, the son of Doda deWolf of Washington and the late Mr. deWolf Jr. Msgr. Joshua Mundell performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Washington.

title: Project's Calm Brings No Peace
description: For more than three weeks now, the mothers in Eastman Towers, a 140-unit public housing project here, have let their children play outdoors with little fear that they'll be felled by bullets. The elderly no longer worry about being accosted by menacing drug dealers as soon as they step outside, and some even crack their doors to cool overheated apartments.

title: FRUGAL TRAVELER;The Right Guidebook Earns Its Ticket
description: WHEN I was in Sofia a year and a half ago, I mislaid my "Rough Guide to Bulgaria," and panicked. It wasn't in my handbag or at my rooming house -- and it was the only guide I'd brought. Eventually, I found it at a little restaurant off Vitosha Boulevard where I had eaten lunch. But I can still remember the awful feeling of being alone in a foreign city without a guidebook. I've come to rely on those practical, trusty little travel compendiums, and don't hold with the notion that if you carry one around while touring it's like wearing a scarlet T.

title: MY INNER SHRIMP
description: I was delighted by Garry Trudeau's Lives column, "My Inner Shrimp" (March 31). Although I am of average height (5 foot 9), I have a relevant tidbit.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;That Empty Feeling Swallowing Cleveland
description: It was another empty day for the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: April 21-27;Day of Taking Daughters To Work Includes Some Sons
description: It's a sign of the times: in an era when anything that hints of affirmative action is viewed with suspicion, Take Our Daughters to Work Day was an obvious target for criticism. This year, almost a third of the employers taking part in the fourth annual Daughters Day -- an event started by the Ms. Foundation for Women to counter the loss of self-esteem that plagues many girls approaching adolescence -- included sons as well.

title: Lafayette Avenue Church Reaches Out Musically, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Library Awards for Writers Who Challenge the Young
description: SOME invent their stories; others travel as far as Australia for material, while many bury themselves in months of research at public libraries. Writing for the young, children's authors say, is as complex and challenging as any task they can imagine.

title: DINING OUT;Garlic Knots Excel in Now-Plush Decor
description: CALL them pizza knots, garlic knots or warm rolls. Those tiny twists of baked pizza dough, glistening with garlic butter, were love at first bite when I tasted them at Franina in Syosset more than a decade ago.

title: TELEVISION;A Church Resurges, Bearing Music
description: IF REPRESSION CAN BE HEARD TO CRUMBLE, it is in the brittle peal and cascading play of Russian church bells. More, it is in the sinuous, subtle lines, the rooted, resonant tones and the close, colliding harmonies spun out in majesty by the church choir; in the sturdy syllables of Old Slavonic, a language kept alive by the Russian Orthodox Church.

title: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;Using Old Masters To Shed Light On Turkish Rugs
description: WHEN MOST PEOPLE look at an old Turkish rug, they count the knots on the back. (The more the better, they think.) But when Michael Franses, a 47-year-old London textile dealer, looks at one, he studies the dyes and images on the front. What he sees are some of the same glorious images of stars, arabesques and mythological creatures that inspired Renaissance painters like Holbein, Lorenzo Lotto and Mantegna to depict the rugs in their works.

title: Picasso's Family Album
description: THERE IS NO SINGLE, true version of Pablo Picasso. He painted, again and again, his friends, lovers, wives and children. And likewise, they and others have had their own different versions of him. Almost a quarter of a century since his death at 91, in 1973, people still fight over his history and reputation, the way they once fought for his affection.

title: ART;Complementary Artists, Separate Spaces
description: VINCENT BALDASSANO uses every color in the spectrum -- at full throttle and often in the same painting. Carol Brown is a sculptor who never deviates from black, her modeling medium having been impregnated with graphite.

title: WEDDINGS;Karen L. Miller, Zev W. Abraham
description: Karen Lynne Miller, a daughter of Barbara Miller of New Rochelle, N.Y., and the late David Miller, was married last evening to Zev Warren Abraham, the son of Harriet Abrahami, also of New Rochelle, and Kenneth Abrahami of New York. Rabbi David Greenberg officiated at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Americo Alberi Aerospace Engineer, 82
description: Americo Alberi, an aerospace engineer who played a role in the ill-starred Apollo 13 lunar mission in 1970, died on April 9 at his home in Southold, L.I. He was 82.

title: POP MUSIC;Electric Guitars Along the Great White Way
description: IT'S A LONG WAY FROM THE AGE OF Aquarius to the decade of downsizing. Ever since the rock musical "Hair" appeared in the late 60's, many people have tried to duplicate its success. "Rent," which opens on Broadway tomorrow night, has already inspired comparisons to the classic rock operas of the past. PAULA SCHWARTZ

title: Police Chief's Success in Charleston, S.C., Is What's Raising EyebrowsNow
description: Mary Ader remembers her husband's reaction when he first learned that Reuben Greenberg had been appointed the police chief of this city where the Civil War began. "Don't tell me," he said incredulously, "that they picked a black chief?"

title: Pulp Means Periodicals, Not Paperback Books
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: LONG MARCH TO FREEDOM Tom Hargrove's Own Story of His Kidnapping by Colombian Narco-Guerrillas. By Thomas R. Hargrove. Ballantine, $23.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;Backstage With Pavarotti
description: IN the concert halls of Manhattan and Philadelphia, a performance by the tenor Luciano Pavarotti is almost taken for granted. But when he comes to Atlantic City, it's "the event of the decade."

title: Isadore Gold, 80, Army Doctor Who Helped to Keep Tojo Alive
description: Dr. Isadore Roy Gold, who was part of the Army medical team that kept Gen. Hideki Tojo alive after the Japanese military dictator attempted suicide in 1945, died on April 19 at New York Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 80.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on April 14 about "True West" by Sam Shepard, at the Chappaqua Library Theater, reversed the descriptions of two characters. Lee is a "beer-guzzling vagrant" and Austin writes screenplays.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: 2 Locked in Trunk; Parents Are Arrested
description: A couple were charged with endangering the welfare of two of their children today after locking them in the trunk of a car as punishment and then going for a ride, the police said.

title: Holocaust Center Gives Assistance to Teachers
description: TO insure that awareness of the Holocaust extends beyond commemorative services at synagogues, temples and interfaith events, the Westchester Holocaust Commission's Holocaust and Human Rights Study Center opened last Tuesday to serve as a research library, which, while open to all members of the community, is primarily aimed at teachers and students.

title: SPENDING IT;Lose Your Hotel Room? You Still Can Win
description: WHEN Richard Sequerth arrived at the Adam's Mark Hotel in Tulsa, Okla., late one Wednesday in February, he wanted to go straight to bed, he recalled recently. But he made it only after a detour.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the Holocaust Art and Education Fund of the Bergen Museum of Art and Science misidentified the work shown. It is Arie Galles's charcoal drawing of the Majdanek concentration camp in Poland, not Bergen-Belsen.

title: Goetz's Attackers Should Have Known Risks
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;Apollo Bronze Gone
description: Perhaps it was a crazed souvenir hunter. Or perhaps a scavenger eager to deal 100 pounds of bronze. Whoever it was, officials at the Apollo Theater are outraged at the theft of the 30-by-42 inch plaque proclaiming the theater a Federal, state and city landmark. The plaque had been bolted to the wall at the West 125th Street entrance. "I cannot understand why anyone would want to hurt us in this way," said Grace Blake, executive director of the Apollo Theater Foundation. SHARON CHETTY

title: John J. O'Connor, Food Marketer And Educator, 65
description: John Joseph O'Connor, who created the nation's first Academy of Food Marketing in 1960 and helped to develop nutrition programs in Latin America and India, died on April 19 at Arlington Hospital in Virginia. He was 65 and lived in Arlington.

title: INVESTING IT;Company's Systems Know the Way to San Jose
description: IN centuries past, navigators used the stars and magnetized needles dangling from strings to find their way. It's not that way anymore.

title: Sunday April 28, 1996: GIVE ART A CHANCE;Starting From Scratch
description: Got an itch to help a worthy cause? Thread Waxing Space, a multi-discipline gallery in SoHo, has concocted a novel way to scratch it. "Scratch," in fact, is the name of Thread Waxing Space's game, an unusual union of art, benefit and gamble. It is the brainchild of Mel Chin, who is internationally recognized for his public art projects. Here's how it works: Chin designed a gold frame and printed 1,200 copies. Next, 175 artists filled in the blank space within 175 of those frames. The rest were filled with aphorisms or cash awards (up to $500). All were then varnished and covered with silver scratch-off ink, instant-lottery-like.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: WEDDINGS;Mary A. Hossfeld, Tracy A. Urdan
description: Mary Agnete Hossfeld, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Hossfeld Jr. of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Tracy Adair Urdan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Urdan of Berkeley, Calif. The Rev. Churchill Pinder performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: CHOOSING MY RELIGION
description: As a priest, I found Dubner's article to be very stimulating. This is a great age for us to experience and to keep searching, following that star.

title: Fred Sullivan, 50, Dies; Made Films Set in the Adirondacks
description: Fred G. Sullivan Jr., an independent film maker who used the Adirondacks as his movie lot, died on April 18. He was 50 and lived in Saranac Lake, N.Y.

title: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;A Widow's Walk On the Wild Side
description: A WIDOW and her money are soon parted -- unless she is careful and wise. I am not talking about a street scam or a swindle. Most of us are too cool for that. There are other ways, and I have tried them all.

title: Giuliani Seeks Tax Break for Early Payers
description: New York City's budget problems have produced at least one benefit for property owners: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the city planned to offer discounts to people who pay their property taxes early.

title: Perspective;The Urban Myth of Baseball as Savior
description: Sit in the spare, cramped owner's box at Milwaukee's County Stadium, and it's actually possible to feel sorry for the owner; the box has the comfort and charm of a Formica booth in a greasy diner off a bypassed old highway. Even on the crisply glorious afternoon two weeks ago when the Brewers were beating the Yankees, what was the point of belonging to the league of loathsome richies if you didn't even have a condo wet bar to entertain politicians, objects of desire and the kids who snubbed you in high school?

title: CRAFTY COMMUTER;This Week's Trouble Spots
description: A look at trouble spots you may encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of Transcom, an interstate transportation agency.

title: WEDDINGS;Lauren Tuchin, David Cheng
description: Lauren Nicole Tuchin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Terry A. Tuchin of Allendale, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. David Cheng, the son of Dr. Jui Chang of New Rochelle, N.Y., and the late Dr. Chun J. Cheng. Dr. Joseph Chuman, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society of Bergen County, performed the ceremony at Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: DRIVING;Trouble Spots to Avoid if You Can
description: A look at trouble spots you may encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of Transcom, an interstate transportation agency.

title: wit's end: Coping With E-Mail Overload
description: COMPANIES took time out last Wednesday to thank the people who answer the phone and sort through the mail. But perhaps everyone in the office should have received flowers on National Secretaries Day. As companies began taking a hatchet to costs, they often cut the number of secretaries, leaving workers to pick up the slack with help from E-mail and voice-mail systems.

title: Snubbing Human Rights
description: NOT so long ago, when the cold war was coldest, countries knew where they stood on the issue of human rights. With a few exceptions like the world's condemnation of apartheid, the rule was that the bad guys on the American side weren't really so bad, but the bad guys on the Soviet side were horrible.

title: IN THE KITCHEN;The Easiest Chocolates to Make
description: FOR candy companies, Mother's Day is one of the big three. Along with Valentine's Day and Easter, the biggest sales are racked up for the second Sunday in May, to honor Mother.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: April 28, 1996
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction

title: IN BRIEF: BAEDEKER;Tastes Just Like Chicken: Gator With Caviar on the Side
description: New Jersey has 21 counties and 567 cities, boroughs, villages, towns and townships, but that isn't the half of it. The State Department of Transportation's directory "New Jersey Local Names" lists more than 3,000 "locales, areas and municipalities," most of them unincorporated hamlets, neighborhoods, communities, nooks or crannies that someone, at some time, decided to call by a name. Here are three of them. CAVIAR Greenwich Township, Cumberland County

title: Drivers Fume as Gas Prices Rise Sharply
description: For about a month now, Madeline Becerra has been worried that her Town and Country mini-van was malfunctioning.

title: CULTURE ZONE;Second Childhood
description: A DISTURBING NOVEL ABOUT A middle-aged man's affair with a 12-year-old girl was hot. Batman, Bilko and Bond were big. "The King and I," "Inherit the Wind," "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum," "A Delicate Balance" and "The Night of the Iguana" were packing them in on Broadway. You could see "Sabrina," "Father of the Bride" or "Diabolique" at the movies. Coffeehouses were in, so were hip-hugger pants, cocktail dresses, sharkskin suits and shades. Women wanted to look like Audrey Hepburn. Men wanted to look like the Rat Pack. The Beatles topped the charts. Golf was hip.

title: ART;The Netherlands, Too, Cheers For a Cherished Native Son
description: VERMEER FEVER IS sweeping the Netherlands this spring, but there is a quiet spot not far from the painter's birthplace in Delft. It is a windmill called De Kat, and its mighty stones used to crush roots and rocks to make pigments for the Dutch masters. The mill, Europe's last to produce pigments this way, has opened its gates to show its samples.

title: As Time Goes By
description: Aging and Old Age By Richard A. Posner. 375 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $29.95.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: TOURS;Kayaks in Newport Harbor
description: Correction Appended

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: AIRLINES;Finnair Bans Smoking
description: Think of Finland, and the fresh, bracing air of pine forests and lakes might come to mind. That may be one reason Finnair, as of March 31, banned smoking on its flights to Helsinki from the United States and Canada. About 90 percent of Finnair's flights are smoke-free, the chief exceptions being flights to Japan.

title: They Payeth Much
description: When I read that the fake pearls that belonged to Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis were sold at Sotheby's auction for $211,500, I thought of the Gospel image of the pearl of great price. The merchant finds a pearl, sells everything he has and buys it. Then I thought of this sentence of Jesus's: "Where your treasure lies, there also doth your heart lie."

title: ON THE JOB;May They Have Your Attention -- Please!
description: When the workday ends and executives head home to the little white house with the green shutters and the picket fence, why are they lugging briefcases stuffed with work? Because they can't do the work during the day -- they're in meetings. Gather round, now, for a session on meetings.

title: Catholic Latins Embrace a Charismatic Mode
description: THE musicians in La Neuva Jerusalem warmed up with electric keyboard, bass and guitars for a crowd that had come together in the cavernous Patchogue church with the born again fervor of a Baptist big tent revival rally.

title: WEDDINGS;Sarah J. Jaffe, Richard S. Eisert
description: Sarah Jane Jaffe, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Jaffe of Providence, R.I., and Richard Searle Eisert, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Eisert of North Tarrytown, N.Y., pere married last evening in Newport, R.I. Rabbi Leslie Gutterman officiated at Rosecliff, one of Newport's summer "cottages."

title: Ideas & Trends;The Death of Some Salesmen
description: Correction Appended

title: WEDDINGS;Anne L. Wakefield and Ned Hoyt
description: Anne Lee Wakefield, the daughter of Ana Maria Murillo Guillen of Mexico City and Ted Wakefield of Whittier, Calif., was married yesterday to Edward Alexander Hoyt, a son of Sarnia Hayes Hoyt and Edward Lydig Hoyt of New York. The Rev. Jose Luis Heredia performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Iglesia de Santa Catarina in Coyoacan, Mexico.

title: RESTAURANTS;A Class Act
description: TWENTY years ago, the Manor probably served the finest food in New Jersey. It still serves excellent food, but so does the competition. And the sociology of restaurant dining has changed. People seem to eat more often in restaurants that are less formal and serve better food than informal restaurants served 20 years ago. (The glut of culinary institute graduates tumbling out of New York City, where it is more expensive to open a restaurant, is one reason.)

title: WHAT'S DOING IN;Vancouver
description: The new International Terminal at Vancouver Airport, which will open May 1, epitomizes the city's 10-year tourist boom that began during Expo '86. Since that world's fair, Vancouver has been transformed from a pleasant metropolitan area with the charms of a small town to a sophisticated, vibrant city dotted with innovative architecture.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION;The Art of Disintegration
description: Something has decomposed, and it is from that decomposition that hope comes again," the artist Louise Bourgeois says of her not-quite-abstract image of three maggots -- ovoids formed by bands of white pastel and blood-red gouache streaks on black paper. The artworks in LOUISE BOURGEOIS: Drawings & Observations (University Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive/Bulfinch/Little, Brown, $24.95) prove her point, demonstrating the possibilities of drawing today, after its "death" as a mandatory artistic skill. In contrast to Ms. Bourgeois's elegant, highly finished sculptures, her drawings are impromptu records of raw feeling registered in symbolic form. The artist's absorbing commentary (recorded during interviews with Lawrence Rinder, curator for 20th-century art at the University Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive at the University of California, Berkeley, who also contributes an excellent introduction) reveals the emotional and philosophical roots of her imagery. With an acute sensitivity to materials and form, she fuses elusive iconography with subtly inviting colors and textures. In these charged graphic works, the act of drawing weds decomposition and composition, providing release and "hope" -- for Louise Bourgeois, and for us. Siri Huntoon

title: Mayor Barry of Washington Plans Break for Rejuvenation
description: With this city's finances in shambles and his own health a matter of concern, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. announced today that he was beginning at least a week at a retreat in Maryland to rejuvenate himself mentally, physically and spiritually.

title: CHATTER;The Price of Pinstripes
description: George Steinbrenner is unhappy in the Bronx. What should New Jersey offer him -- if anything -- to move the Yankees here?

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS/DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN;Things Get Messier in Tug of War at Church of St. Ann
description: While the Episcopal Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity, an architectural treasure on Montague Street, continues to fall into disrepair, the bishop, the rector and the vestry remain locked in a struggle that has paralyzed the church.

title: WEDDINGS;Donna Benedek, Jason D. Levitz
description: Donna Sheryl Benedek, a daughter of Doris and Howard Benedek of New York, was married there last evening to Jason Drew Levitz, a son of Linda Weisbrod of Roslyn, L.I., and William Levitz of New York. Rabbi Joel S. Goor performed the ceremony at the 200 Fifth Avenue Club.

title: BOOK NOTES;Surviving the Holocaust in a Chinese Haven
description: Evelyn Pike Rubin paused to add up the years it took her to write "Ghetto Shanghai," a memoir about surviving the Holocaust among 18,000 stateless European Jews who were given succor in China in World War II.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;New Airline Routes To Iceland and China
description: Icelandair has just introduced routes to the United States, and Northwest Airlines is adding its first nonstop service to China.

title: The View From: Bridgeport;Downtown Bridgeport, Minus Casino, Builds Hopes on the Arts
description: LIKE a long-forgotten Rembrandt discovered in the attic that restores a family's fortunes, a remarkable, but little-seen, art collection is holding out hope for Bridgeport's downtown.

title: DIARY
description: GETTING AND SPENDING

title: How Could Hudson County Destroy Its Own Mountain?
description: To the Editor:

title: DINING OUT;Country Style, a New American Menu
description: ANYONE who remembers John's in Woodbury will be amazed at its transformation into John's Cafe.

title: Gifts of Largesse
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: More Food (and Lots of It) Arrives at Times Square

title: DANCE;Beyond the Days of Dancing Foot Soldiers
description: BALLET, FOR MANY PEOPLE, IS STILL AN art of swans, peasants and supernatural creatures, neat lines of dancers who frame and complement the stars of the performance in perfect synchrony without a leg or arm or wisp of hair astray. Whether the "boys and girls" of the present or the "ladies and gentlemen of the ensemble" of earlier times, the corps de ballet has been the motor of 19th-century works like "Swan Lake" with its fluttering birds and "Giselle" with its vengeful Wilis, the ghostly spirits who, mesmerized and mesmerizing, invariably draw applause as they travel en masse across the stage. The corps has been there to magnify atmosphere, plot and the architecture and spectacle of the choreography.

title: No Headline
description: I said, 'What should we do, put a sign up at the Charles River, saying, Boston closed for alterations, come back in 10 years?' "

title: Acres and Acres of Color
description: POISED where the piedmont meets the coastal plains, the pine-forested mountains of west central Georgia, formed from resilient Hollis quartzite, are scored by dramatic ravines and streaked with pink and white dogwoods in the spring; nearby farmlands, once fleecy with cotton, now are host to the full range of botanical specimens from the southeastern United States and an ever-blooming palette. This swatch of land is sometimes called the Chattahoochee Trace after the river that wanders down from the state's northern mountains to form the border with Alabama. It embraces 200 miles of scenic country roads and some of Georgia's most carefully preserved landscape and history -- all because of a rare native plant called the plumleaf azalea and a hot springs that simmers at 88 degrees year round.

title: At Naval Academy, Ethics Lapses Go Back Years
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE STREET;Children At Work
description: It was a heartening sight during Take Our Daughters to Work Day on Thursday to see children with their parents heading into the workplace. The event, which also included sons judging from the traffic on Manhattan streets, provided a look into fashion's future, and it's not too different from the past. Two themes dominated: the classics, and sportswear without the disheveled look. Dresses and skirts were the favorites among young girls, and boys wore suits or mixed separates. Clothes inspired by the music worlds of hip-hop and grunge were left at home.

title: April 21-27;Seeking Asylum From Genital Mutilation
description: Last week, after news accounts led to protests and the likelihood of continued notoriety, the Immigration and Naturalization Service freed Fauziya Kasinga, 19, who says she fled her homeland of Togo to escape the tribal rite of genital mutilation and seek asylum in this country.

title: World News Briefs;Zulu Princess Found Stabbed to Death
description: A Zulu princess believed to have been abducted during an attack on a royal residence this week has been found stabbed to death, the police said today.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: MIDTOWN Free Wheeling Through History

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;A Branch Library That Could Fit In a Closet
description: It's a sunny April weekday afternoon, but the Macombs Bridge Library is packed. That isn't unusual since the library, a branch of the New York Public Library at 152d Street and Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard since 1955, is housed in a space roughly the size of a small studio apartment in the midst of the Harlem River Houses.
