It takes all of 12 people to fill the tiny room.

title: MUSIC;Solo or Ensemble, A Vocal Theme
description: ALL manner of solo, choral, theatrical and operatic events are on the week's agenda. Indeed, the theme is vocal.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: How to Survive Welfare Cuts: Really Trying;A Family Has $1.60 Left for 30 Days
description: WITH four weeks until her next welfare check, Brenda Perez emptied her piggy bank to see how much money was left for the rest of the month. There was $1.60.

title: CLASSICAL VIEW;The Great Man Returns, With Soothing Truths
description: THE END OF THE EARLY music revolution is being noted not with speeches or plaques but with Leopold Stokowski records. Gut strings and wooden flutes were once the fresh, cold air that would sweep Stokowskian voluptuousness from our minds. Now the great man returns, saying no to harsh diets and soothing us with truths we had all but forgotten.

title: Do-It-Yourselfers Carve Out A Piece of the Publishing Pie
description: When Barbara Saltzman ventured from Southern California to offer her late son's lavishly illustrated manuscript for a children's book, the New York literati reacted in the cool manner of the book's grumpy king and queen: "Nobody giggled. Nobody yuckled. Nobody laughed and nobody chuckled."

title: POSTINGS: 23-Story Building to Go Up Near United Nations;$30 Million Office Tower For German Government
description: Construction is to begin within days on a 23-story office building near the United Nations that will be entirely occupied by the Federal Republic of Germany.

title: Did Thoughts of April 15 Influence Auction Bids?
description: Believe it or not, a few souls at the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis auction at Sotheby's might not have been possessed by mass hysteria. Some might have been bidding instead with an eye on next April 15.

title: SOAPBOX;Bitten, Then Banned
description: DOG Bite Sunday was the day I realized it was unsafe to hang out on my roof anymore. I resent giving up that pleasure.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;In Their Own Image
description: EVEN in the nation's publishing mecca, the glossies at the newsstands were silent about the scene that attracted Jorge Cano-Moreno and his friends, a hybrid of hip-hop and the Latin culture of their parents. Neither the Spanish-language publications nor the mainstream entertainment magazines had tapped into their experience. The artists and celebrities they favored were rarely profiled.

title: OLYMPICS;Savannah Sailing: A Change Of Worlds
description: Two former crew members of Mighty Mary, the 75-foot yacht that competed in the America's Cup trials last year, are finding out that campaigning Europe Class dinghies for the Summer Olympics is a contrast in extremes.

title: WEDDINGS;Marion Murray, Bernard Levine
description: Marion Murray and Dr. Bernard Levine are to be married today at the Rolling Hills Country Club in Wilton, Conn. Rabbi James Prosnit is to perform the ceremony.

title: Editorial Notebook;Mayor Giuliani Girds for Battle
description: One of Rudolph Giuliani's big advantages in running for re-election is the fact that not many other people actually want his job. More than a year before the New York mayoral campaign really begins, most of the city's top Democrats have already taken themselves out of the running, eyeing juicier prizes one more year down the line. Both Gov. George Pataki and Senator Alfonse D'Amato seem vulnerable when up for re-election in 1998, despite the fact that former Mayor Ed Koch, in a burst of advance planning, has already endorsed them both.

title: To Keep Yankees, Eminent Domain Makes Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: Goetz's Attackers Should Have Known Risks
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties;Cosmic Girl
description: I went to Cosmopolitan once, looking for freelance work. An editor gave me some red binders filled with story ideas. The ideas were oddly reversible.

title: Plan to Regulate Cheese Has Quebec Up in Arms
description: In Quebec they are calling it an insult to the French palate and suggesting that it is just another way federalism fails the province. In the rest of Canada people are asking what all the fuss is about.

title: Area on Way Up
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;A Disabled Group Grades the Airlines
description: The Paralysis Society of America, a nonprofit organization created by the Paralyzed Veterans of America, is gathering reports from passengers on how well airlines are complying with the Federal Air Carrier Access Act of 1986. The act prohibits discrimination against people with disabilities, visible or not.

title: Visions in Green
description: DURING the years between the two world wars, Weeks Hall, a south Louisiana gentleman living in his ancestral home, Shadows-on-the-Teche, would go into his garden in the dead of winter, gather a boxful of camellia blossoms, carefully arrange them on Spanish moss and send them by express freight to friends and relatives in the North.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLOYD BENNETT FIELD;Precision, Pride and Plastic
description: Eighteen years ago, the Japanese introduced a new line of warships. Larry Gertner had to build every last one of them.

title: April 21-27;Who's Calling Whom Weak?
description: Whoever coined the saying "When the going gets tough, the tough get going" probably didn't have women in mind. But according to an anthropologist, women appear to be far better equipped than men to withstand hardships like extreme cold and famine.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK

title: BOOKEND;Jane Jacobs: Still a Pioneer
description: There is something strangely pleasing about the fact that Jane Jacobs, who has spent her life writing books about cities and the virtues of urban disorder, has now, at 80, written one about a single woman who lived a life of extreme order in that most rural of places, Alaska. This book -- "A Schoolteacher in Old Alaska" -- is much more important than its self-consciously quaint title lets on. It is nothing like any of Jane Jacobs's other books, and in fact was written only partly by her; the body of it is the memoir of her great-aunt, Hannah Breece, who spent 14 years at the beginning of this century teaching children of Alaska natives. Breece died in 1940, leaving her great-niece a manuscript she hoped would be put into publishable form.

title: BASEBALL;Back Pain Sidelines Johnson
description: Randy Johnson's great start has hit a snag. Johnson, who entered Friday night's game at Milwaukee with a 4-0 record and a major league-leading 47 strikeouts, left in the fourth inning with sharp pains in his lower back.

title: John Lee Hubby, a Geneticist and Professor, 64
description: John Lee Hubby, a geneticist and retired professor of zoology and biology at the University of Chicago, died on March 28 at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 64.

title: Can Towns Control Gaming's Downside?
description: LEDYARD is a rural eastern Connecticut town where the churches easily outnumber the cocktail lounges. But it still worries about bad influences. Town Council member Cynthia S. Brewster is putting the finishing touches on a 15-page ordinance that would restrict adults-only book and video stores, massage parlors and nightclubs.

title: Point of Health Insurance Is to Spread Risks Around
description: To the Editor:

title: The Greening of Newt Gingrich
description: It is a pleasure to welcome House Speaker Newt Gingrich to the growing club of politicians who have come to believe that America's air, water, endangered species and what is left of its splendid natural resources deserve strong protection. His task now is to persuade some of his fellow Republicans to follow his lead.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ON EARLY INFANCY

title: EARNING IT;Personal Trainers to Buff the Boss's People Skills
description: THE boss, whip-smart and self-assured, had risen like a comet to become chief executive of a blue-chip entertainment company in his early 40's. On the way up, however, he had acquired certain blind spots. He was an armchair quarterback, signing off on every small decision. His meetings were a disaster: people wandered in every few minutes, with the boss doing nothing to fend off distractions.

title: Hospital Plans Unit for Children
description: COUNTY officials recently announced plans to build a $60 million children's hospital at the County Medical Center in Valhalla within five years. This 150-bed hospital would become the only hospital in the New York City area specializing entirely in providing tertiary care -- the highest level of care -- for seriously ill children.

title: JERSEY;He Could Pay the Bill. Did He Need the Care?
description: SEVENTEEN years old, recently jilted by a girlfriend, miserable in the gloom of adolescence and certain that all his roads were blocked, Larry Bresan decided to end it all one day in 1991. Or, at least, to make a statement.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Public Relief

title: IN PERSON;Paterfamilias
description: David Popenoe, a sociology professor at Rutgers University, has a radical idea. He thinks children should live with both their biological parents.

title: GOVERNMENT;What Budget Squeeze? There's Money to Borrow
description: The state government is facing lean times, and the Legislature, the Whitman administration and dozens of interest groups are furiously debating what expenses to cut to bring the $16 billion budget into balance. But lawmakers are still feeling generous when it comes to borrowing money to pay for future programs.

title: J. CARTER BROWN;Alternative To Propaganda
description: To the Editor:

title: Edward Gordon, 65, Pianist and Director Of Ravinia Festival
description: Edward Gordon, the director of the Ravinia Festival, summer home of the Chicago Symphany, from 1968 to 1990, and director emeritus since then, died on April 19 at Evanston Hospital in Evanston, Ill. He was 65 and lived in Chicago.

title: WINE;On the Shawangunk Trail: Samplings
description: A WAVE of wine-tasting events offers the novice and the connoisseur an opportunity to sample a wide range of domestic and international products at rather reasonable prices.

title: A Million Here, a Million There
description: GOVERNOR WHITMAN has finally had to take the budget ax out of the closet.

title: SOMETHING'S GOT TO GIVE
description: Frey's story on air traffic controllers at the New York Tracon portrayed them as a bunch of half-crazed adrenaline junkies. Having worked with them for the last 26 years (as a Kennedy-based pilot for 22, and, more recently, flying in and out of Newark), I would characterize them differently.

title: Norwich's Deer Now In Hunters' Sights
description: MOST of the deer from the Mohegan Park Zoo in Norwich, remainders of a herd that had served as town pets since 1936, were shipped out of town one night early this month, auctioned off in Ohio, and are now in Texas game farms where they will be hunted and killed for trophies.

title: Peter Haden-Guest, Ex-U.N. Editorial Director, 73
description: Peter Haden-Guest, a retired editorial director at the United Nations and a British peer, died on April 8 at U.C.L.A. Hospital in Westwood, Calif. He was 73 and lived in East Hampton, L.I., though he made frequent visits to London to attend sessions of the House of Lords.

title: DEADLY FLIGHT -- A special report.;In Crash That Killed Brown, Signs of Safety Shortcomings
description: Capt. Ashley Davis of the Air Force and his co-pilot, Capt. Tim Schafer, had good reasons to forget about trying to land in the pouring rain at Dubrovnik, Croatia, on the afternoon of April 3.

title: High Spirits
description: This spring, casual pants are lean and clean.

title: PERSPECTIVES;A Big Refinancing at a Middle-Income Co-op
description: WE came looking for a better way of life," said Philip Leblang, explaining what brought him and his family to the Amalgamated Warbasse Houses middle-income co-op in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn 32 years ago, when it was newly built. He and his wife, Hilda, are still in the two-bedroom apartment on the third floor that they bought then for $2,600.

title: Putting the Focus on the Family Business
description: WHEN Peter M. Deane, the founder of a kitchen design firm in Stamford, died five years ago at the age of 50, his wife, Ingrid Deane, hired an outsider to run the company until their children, then in their early 20's, could develop experience and grow into the family business.

title: For Amanda Plummer, It's Bring On The Eccentrics
description: Correction Appended

title: INVESTING IT;Will Japan's Success Soon Shine on Its U.S. Investors?
description: IT'S bad enough when a seemingly smart investment idea goes wrong and costs you money. But it's an even greater frustration when being right doesn't pay off.

title: Putative Damages;The Non-Cash Value of $43 Million
description: THE headlines last week after Bernhard Goetz was found liable in the 1984 subway shooting of a Bronx teen-ager extracted a straightforward meaning from the case: Mr. Goetz, the world was told, had been ordered by a Civil Court jury to pay Darrell Cabey $43 million.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;America's Most Notorious Team
description: On the football field, life could hardly be sweeter for the Dallas Cowboys.

title: OUTDOORS;Attention, Mudville: Madame Casey Is Now at Bat
description: This is the worst part of the year. Birds frolic in the (not-so) temperate sky, the baseball season has begun and I sit by the phone and wait for the coach to call. Why does coed softball start so late in April?

title: Bus Bomb Kills 12 Near New Delhi
description: A bomb ripped through a bus here today, killing 12 people and seriously wounding 20 as India began its general elections, officials said.

title: WOR Hires Bob Grant To Be Host Of Program
description: Bob Grant, the radio talk-show host taken off the air by WABC after a remark he made about the death of Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown, has been hired by a rival New York City station.

title: A Cold Heart in China
description: THE ATTIC Memoir of a Chinese Landlord's Son. By Guanlong Cao. Translated by Guanlong Cao and Nancy Moskin. 245 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $24.95.

title: With Partners Like These, Who Needs Rivals?
description: FOR people whose knowledge of Government securities is limited to a beach-towel session with Tom Wolfe's "Bonfire of the Vanities," B. Gerald Cantor is not a household name. If they know Mr. Cantor at all, it is as a generous art patron whose private collection of Rodin sculpture is unsurpassed.

title: VIEWPOINT;A Handshake Unwise for Europe
description: NOTWITHSTANDING negative forecasts, European monetary unification is likely to happen on schedule on Jan. 1, 1999. But while there are clear potential economic benefits, unification is being carried out in a way that is likely to produce unfortunate effects for Europe and its trading partners, including the United States.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 3/ The Whitman Corporation: It's known for chocolates, it sells mufflers, and it's acting more and more like a Pepsi bottling company. By Barry Rehfeld.

title: TRACK AND FIELD;Arkansas Gets Revenge On Final Day of Relays
description: This one, Arkansas said, was for pride. As Jason Bunston, the only senior on the Razorback men's 4x1,500-meter relay team, said: "We didn't talk about it. I think it was understood."

title: Add a Dome?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THEATER;In 'Buried Child,' Lois Smith Plays to America's Gothic Side
description: THE VOICE COMES FROM offstage a shrill, grating, endless rant that rises and falls with the randomness and fury of a storm wind. Lois Smith, playing Halie, the matriarch of a Gothic farm family with a terrible secret, has the opening speech in Sam Shepard's play "Buried Child." It sounds like a monologue because the character is talking at, not to, her grizzled husband, Dodge (James Gammon), who squirms and grimaces on a battered sofa on stage. As he swigs from liquor bottles stashed under the couch cushions and wheezes over his cigarettes, she nags from upstairs about his drinking, his smoking and his health. His one-liner replies, laden with sarcasm, she claims not to hear, inducing him to shout. The effect is unnerving and comic at the same time.

title: AS TRUCE BEGINS, LEBANESE RETURN TO THEIR HOMES
description: Tens of thousands of Lebanese piled their possessions into almost anything that could move and returned today to villages like this one to survey what they had fled when Israeli forces attacking Hezbollah guerrillas laid siege to southern Lebanon.

title: QUICK BITE;A Corn Bread That Is Alive With Flavor
description: If the mention of cornbread stirs unpleasant memories of sweet, yellow cafeteria fare, the Butterflake Bake Shop in Teaneck offers a welcome surprise. Its rough, round loaves are brown and thick-crusted with an old-world flavor that gives only the slightest hint of copn.

title: CHOOSING MY RELIGION
description: Dubner's article was poignant and memorable. I admire his courage in coming to terms with his religious conflict and, even more, his ability to speak openly to his mother about his feelings.

title: The Soul of a School Board Race
description: IT was time to talk about contingency plans. The race for School Board 3 was just beginning, and a group of candidates were huddling around a dining room table in an Upper West Side apartment and, between crackerfuls of blue cheese and cups of seltzer, discussing what to do if things turned ugly.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: TIMES SQUARE;Subway Plan For Times Sq. Reduces Exits
description: Unlike the labyrinth of Greek myth, which had one entrance, the maze that is the Times Square subway station has 11 exits and entrances. But under a proposal by the Transit Authority, Times Square, the busiest station in the system, would have only one large street-level entrance open around the clock and just four additional entrances from 6 A.M. until midnight.

title: AUTHENTICITY IN FILM;Wrong!
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: MILLIONAIRES ROW By Norman Katkov. Dutton, $23.95.

title: Brent Williams, 85, a Tenor And Officer of The Bohemians
description: Brent Williams, a sure-fielding tenor who gave up baseball for singing and ended up glad-handing his way through the New York music world as a longtime officer of The Bohemians and its Musicians Foundation, died on April 18 at his home in Rowayton, Conn. He was 85.

title: Opera Garnier
description: To the Editor: It is indeed uplifting that old architectural-cultural masterpieces of the world, like the Opera Garnier in Paris, are properly renovated and once again made functional and beautiful, as Daphne Angles tells us in "A Step Forward Into the Past in Paris" (Travel Advisory, Feb. 25).

title: WEDDINGS;Laura C. Riegel, Patrick D. Curry
description: Laura Cushing Riegel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Eveland Riegel Jr. of Montchanin, Del., was married yesterday to Patrick Daniel Curry, a son of Joan M. Devigili of Hazleton, Pa., and the late Daniel J. Curry. The Rev. John Martiner performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church, Christiana Hundred in Greenville, Del.

title: A Good Year for Running;More Women, Fewer Causes
description: BY all appearances, circumstances have not been so bright for women running for office since 1992, and perhaps ever. There will probably be more women candidates for state and Federal office this November then ever before. A Democrat is leading in the Presidential race, and there is thought that Democrats might even regain control of Congress -- again boding well for women candidates, who are likely to be Democrats.

title: MUSIC;One-Stop Shopping on the Cultural Circuit
description: TALK about mixed media! Next Sunday's concert in the Capital Music Festival XI begins with an art lecture and slide show; continues with performances by the New Jersey Percussion Ensemble, assisted by a marimba-violin duo and a dance troupe, and is followed by a dance workshop for children. Not for nothing is it called "Feast for the Senses."

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: How to Survive Welfare Cuts: Really Trying;Just $12 Remains For All Of April
description: IN the last eight years, Darlene Davis, a 38-year-old grandmother and recovering drug addict, has lost almost everything: her job as a computer programmer, her health, her apartment, her family ties and custody of her five children. The clothes on her back and a monthly welfare check for $285 she received from the County of Los Angeles are "about the only thing I have left," she said.

title: WEDDINGS;Jane Katz, Herbert Erlanger
description: Dr. Jane Katz, a professor of health, physical education and athletics at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice in New York, is to be married this evening to Dr. Herbert L. Erlanger, an attending anesthesiologist at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. Rabbi Bonita Taylor is to officiate at Tavern on the Green in New York.

title: Let George Do It
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IN THE GARDEN;Dividing Perennials Multiplies Neighborliness
description: TRADITION holds that spring-blooming perennials are divided in the fall, while fall-blooming perennials are divided in the spring. This theory is essentially correct, but sometimes gardens do not work out this way.

title: POSTINGS: New Office-Residential Building Planned;$4 Million Paid For E. 64th Site
description: The foundation headed by Theodore W. Kheel, the noted labor negotiator and philanthropist, has bought the pair of dilapidated two-story brick buildings at 7 1/2 and 9 East 64th Street and plans to tear them down to build a headquarters for three foundations, with rental apartments above.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the parody of Minnesotans' speech in the film "Fargo" described a scene incorrectly. The Brainerd police chief, Marge Gunderson, does not actually throw up at the murder scene; she only thinks she will.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;Of Star Worship And Flame Wars
description: THE INTERNET HAS BEEN praised as the most useful invention since the carburetor and denounced as the biggest waste of time since network television. There is some justice in both counts, as many opera lovers can attest.

title: Q and A
description: Roommate Living in A Co-op

title: Sports of The Times;For Playoffs, A Veteran Perspective
description: IF you happened to follow the fortunes of the Knicks this season, you had to be disappointed in their victory over the Cavaliers here yesterday afternoon as they went up by 2-0 in their first-round playoff series. Now they are just one game short of taking the series, which they will attempt to do Wednesday back in their own lair. But the 84-80 triumph was achieved without any of the players berating each other, traducing the coach or even attacking a courtside chair with a karate kick.

title: COVER STORY;Going Back Into That Scary Water
description: A man and woman are having a romantic interlude on a boat. Ominous music on the soundtriack. They're just about to make love when suddenly ... the waves thrash, the woman is pulled overboard, the boat sinks. "Elizabeth! Elizabeth!" the man cries. It's a - squid!

title: Contemplating Sin, Salvation and Her Success
description: FABIO was staring at Joan Osborne. Perhaps the romance-novel cover model was jealous of her curly blond tresses or taken by her dimples; he might have been curious about her nose ring. Or maybe he recognized her from the video clip for her hit song, "One of Us." She'll never know; he only stared in silence as Ms. Osborne tucked into a salad at the Source, a vegetarian restaurant on Sunset Boulevard.

title: Loneliness of Gay Elderly Holds a Vision of Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE;G.O.P. Club Evicts Children
description: In the language of jurisprudence, the relationship between the Metropolitan Republican Club and the After School Workshop centered on a balancing of interests. But in the language of business, the bottom line is that on June 30 the Republicans are evicting, and possibly closing, a popular children's program.

title: ROAD AND RAIL;Trolley Urged for a Limping Old Freight Line
description: Once, the railroad connected the blue-collar towns along the Delaware River from Camden to Trenton. As many as 50 passenger trains a day shuttled students, commuters and shoppers. Freight cars hauled raw materials to dozens of factories, including the Roebling Steel plant here, which built the cables for the Brooklyn and Golden Gate bridges.

title: Big-Screen Violence: Do Sensibilities Matter?
description: To the Editor:

title: On Language;May Day! Might Day!
description: EXHUMING A REport from a law firm that cast a benign light on the Clintons' Whitewater actions, Mortimer Zuckerman, editor in chief of U.S. News & World Report, opined, "This report may well have been written in invisible ink for all the attention it has had."

title: Austin Art Scene
description: To the Editor: Austin provides the perfect mixture of art and music for the frugal traveler -- art during the day and music at night. Before you follow Susan Spano's excellent directions ("Club Hopping Around Hip Austin," Feb. 18) to the clubs, climb aboard the city bus and get off in front of the University of Texas campus. This is a short distance from the Archer M. Huntington Art Gallery at 23d and San Jacinto. There is no admission fee to the exhibition of 20th-century American paintings that constitutes the James Michener Collection. Here are paintings rarely been seen in New York City, by Arshile Gorky, Milton Avery and other artists.

title: Briton Scores With a Multi-Cultural Novel
description: CAN an Englishman living in Huntington write a novel with a narrator who was a Red Guard in the Cultural Revolution but now lives on Long Island and is influenced by an obscure American President?

title: Abuse of the Mentally Ill In Prison Has Deep Roots
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting a Car
description: To the Editor: So the car rental companies want you to pay a penalty if you reserve a car but don't show up. Now what happens if you show up and they don't? On Feb. 17, we had to wait three hours in the Phoenix Airport for a Hertz car we had reserved several months earlier.

title: Picassos Reclaim Their Patrimony
description: FIRST the Walt Disney Company cracked down on phony Mickeys. Then Chanel started going after knockoffs. Now, it's pay-back time for Pablo Picasso.

title: What Military Buildup?
description: To the Editor:

title: New Releases
description: CRANBERRIES: 'TO THE FAITHFUL DEPARTED' Island

title: Profiting From Four-Season Landscaping
description: HOWARD K. FREILICH, owner of Blondie's Treehouse, an interior horticultural concern here, knows how to grow a business.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: SOAPBOX;Pension 3-Card Monte
description: IF you've ever refinanced a mortgage, no doubt you wished that the lower rate had been available when you bought the house -- that the bank would roll back the date of the new rate and return the extra cash, or perhaps give you a year's grace on your house payments.

title: JERSEYANA;Just an Old-Fashioned Town, Filled With Music, Art and Fish This Weekend
description: Fish and people are pouring into Lambertville and its Pennsylvania neighbor New Hope this weekend for the 15th annual Shad Fest, a popular showcase not only for art and music, but also for the town of Lambertville itself.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;1922 Hawaii Theater To Reopen, Revamped
description: The historic Hawaii Theater in Honolulu is scheduled to open on May 10 after a 10-year, $21 million restoration.

title: WEDDINGS;Susan C. Gold, William H. Groner
description: Susan C. Gold, a marketing director at Bilous-DiBucci Music in New York, was married last evening to William H. Groner, a partner in Worby Borowick & Groner, a law firm in White Plains. Rabbi Gary Bretton-Granitoor officiated at the Essex House in New York.

title: MANUAL LABOR
description: Your writer apparently does not understand that instruction manuals are superfluous. Real men understand how to operate all things, mechanical and electrical, intuitively. Onlywimps resort to reading instruction manuals.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;F.A.A. Proposing Freer Flight Routes
description: AIRLINE passengers who are flying over familiar territory sometimes puzzle over what they can identify below -- Stamford, Conn., say, northeast of New York, on a trip from La Guardia to Washington National, which lies to the southwest.

title: Edinburgh
description: To the Editor: What a pleasure it was to open the Travel section and read about Martins and the Vintners Rooms, two of my favorite restaurants in Edinburgh ("Where the Food is New in Scotland." March 24). The article brought back pleasant memories of a Scottish holiday my partner and I took in September 1993. Martins food and ambiance were so special that we returned a second time, a week later.

title: Streetscapes/The Montauk Club in Brooklyn;A Venetian Palace With a Native American Motif
description: WE have become culture of clubs -- fitness clubs, book clubs, video clubs, frequent-flier clubs -- so one would think that a Venetian palace built for Brooklyn's elite should be prospering.

title: Pig Noises Put Man in Jail
description: A man who oinked at his former wife and played "Old MacDonald Had a Farm" when he saw her walking past his house began serving a 30-day prison sentence this week for harassment. His lawyer, however, said he had arranged for his client to be freed on $1,000 bail next week pending appeals.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: AUDREY HEPBURN'S NECK By Alan Brown. Pocket Books, $21.

title: The Stuff of Dreams
description: Private Myths Dreams and Dreaming. By Anthony Stevens. 385 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $27.95.

title: April 21-27;Celebrity for Sale
description: Judging by Sotheby's $34.5 million auction of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis' estate last week, a virulent strain of historiphilia has swept the land. Bidders who paid dearly -- $33,350 for a footstool daughter Caroline used, for example -- said they were clamoring for "a piece of history."

title: Joseph Churba, Intelligence Aide Who Criticized General, Is Dead
description: Joseph Churba, who was the Air Force's top Middle East intelligence expert in 1976 when he publicly criticized comments by the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. George S. Brown, about Israel's being a military burden for the United States, died on April 18 at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 62 and moved to midtown Manhattan from Washington in January.

title: Opportunity Comes to Those Who Take Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: What Is the Answer to Free, Odious Speech?
description: To the Editor:

title: Land of the Pharaoh
description: ThE PYRAMID By Ismail Kadare. Translated from the French of Jusuf Vrioni by David Bellos, in consultation with the author. 161 pp. New York: Arcade Publishing. $21.95.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a chart last Sunday with an article about the Nicholas mutual funds misstated a performance figure for Nicholas Limited Edition, a leader among diversified domestic equity funds. Through the first quarter of this year, it gained 15.04 percent, not 9.67.

title: APPEARANCES;Blue Heaven
description: Correction Appended

title: Sunday April 28, 1996: THE ROAD TO CHINA;Porsche Undressed
description: Traveling by car in Bei jing can make a visitor long for an eastbound lane on the Long Island Expressway on a Friday afternoon in August. Soon this joy of a ride will be available to citizens throughout China, as the country closes in on its goal of putting a million cars a year on the road by 2010. Toward that end, the People's Republic has asked manufacturers around the world to submit designs to kick-start its own auto industry. Among those who have is Porsche, but what the venerable German company is offering is a horsepower of a different color from the low-down, zillion-dollar road eaters that the Hamptons lovers drive. No airfoils, ostrich-skin seats and radar detectors on these babies. The potential Chinese model is a sedate $6,000 sedan, code-named C88 and intended as much for cargo as passengers.

title: BEST SELLERS: April 28, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction

title: WEDDINGS;Thomas H. Hipp, Elizabeth Griffith
description: Elizabeth Amalie Griffith, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan R. Griffith of Lawrenceville, N.J., was married there yesterday to Thomas Herbert Hipp, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert R. Hipp of Findlay, Ohio. The Rev. Dr. H. Dana Fearon performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of Lawrenceville.

title: ON POLITICS;State Knows a Thing or Two About the Minimum Wage
description: For $5.50 an hour, Sal Risalvato will put a willing and able person to work -- pumping gasoline, cleaning windshields and mopping the restroom floors at his service station in Riverdale, Morris County.

title: Melancholy Memoirs
description: To the Editor:

title: WEDDINGS;Robin B. Biggs, Cyrus B. Noble
description: Dr. Robin Bolton Biggs and Dr. Cyrus Bartol Noble, medical residents, were married yesterday in New York. The Very Rev. Dr. James Annand performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church.

title: What Makes an Indian?
description: KILLING THE WHITE MAN'S INDIAN Reinventing Native Americans at the End of the Twentieth Century. By Fergus M. Bordewich. 400 pp. New York: Doubleday. $27.50.

title: BASEBALL;Yankee Bullpen Fails to Support A Decent Gooden
description: He can never be what he once was. But with a new, downsized delivery, Dwight Gooden finally demonstrated yesterday, in his fourth and finest start as a Yankee, that he can be what he is -- less powerful, but more precise than ever.

title: Habitats/46 West 83d Street;Lawyers' Apartments of the 1st Part and the 2d Part
description: AT the nadir of the real-estate recession of the early 1990's, Barbara Peabody couldn't sell her one-bedroom apartment on the Upper West Side.

title: G.O.P. Is Preparing Budget Plan With Political Traps for Clinton
description: Bloodied but only partly bowed after a 16-month battle over the 1996 Federal budget, Republicans in Congress are finishing plans to shave at least an additional $600 billion from spending by 2002 and, they hope, to seize the political high ground on the deficit issue from President Clinton in this election year.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Fancy and Free

title: Three R's of Habitat Are Raising Houses
description: CAROLYN DeROSA, a senior at West Islip High School, had never even hammered a nail before she joined Habitat for Humanity's campus chapter at her school as a volunteer two years ago.

title: Actors Rate Students' Hands-On Diagnoses
description: THE patient, a 52-year-old woman, complained of fatigue. Not only did she lack energy but she was also constantly thirsty. The patient was then given a complete physical exam, which lasted an hour.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CENTRAL QUEENS;Wrangling Over Open Jobs In District 24
description: Top administrative positions remain unfilled at eight schools in District 24 and school board members and parents have accused one another of playing politics and delaying the process.

title: A Hope to End Standoff Is Seen
description: Federal agents maintaining their 34-day standoff with the anti-government Freemen were told today by former Green Beret Col. James (Bo) Gritz that the group might be persuaded to surrender.

title: INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3 What do New Yorkers dream about? Ask Theatre of Dreams, where the dreams are the drama.

title: FOOD;A Balanced Blowout
description: MARY ELLEN TENDS TO BE PRAGMATIC, UNsentimental and very, very clear. She knows that the image she has of herself as a hostess -- the graciousness nurtured by her mother and grandmother and the competence acquired through assiduous study of life-style magazines -- has about as much value as her appendix.

title: ART;Picasso: Love Him? Hate Him? A Bit of Both?
description: IT IS DIFFICULT TO IMAGINE modern art -- and especially modern portraiture -- without Pablo Picasso. Today the Museum of Modern Art opens its third blockbuster Picasso exhibition since his death in 1973 at the age of 91. The show, "Picasso and Portraiture," presents seven decades of his portrait paintings and prints.

title: WEDDINGS;Gita van Heerden and Eckart Forster
description: Dr. Gita Satterlee van Heerden and Dr. Eckart Forster were married yesterday in New York. Judge Rena Uviller of State Supreme Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony at the House of the Redeemer, an Episcopal Church retreat house.

title: Past Imperfect
description: CELESTINE Voices From a French Village. By Gillian Tindall. 292 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $25.

title: CAPITOL SKETCHBOOK;Promoting the Black Conservative Cause
description: Of all the proteges of Lee Atwater, the late Republican master of Machiavellian campaigning, few are so dedicated as Alvin Williams, a boyish-looking political operative who has stepped up to the fund-raising table to promote the rara avis cause of black conservative candidates.

title: THEATER;'Closer Than Ever' in Mount Vernon
description: WHATEVER becomes of "Big," a $10 million-plus musical opening on Broadway tonight, let it be known that theater songs by the mega-musical's composer David Shire and the lyricist Richard Maltby Jr. are being sung and acted live, unmiked and technologically impaired, at Fleetwood Stage, a very small theater company here.

title: Iraqi Oil Impasse Hits Gulf War Victims
description: The suspension of talks between Iraq and the United Nations this week was especially bitter news for Carlos Alzamora.

title: An Alternative to Jail Time for the Young
description: IT was a year ago that Nelida, an 18-year-old from Bridgeport, says she was "at the wrong place at the wrong time" during the attempted robbery of a cab driver by a group of teen-agers.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MADISON SQUARE;La Goulue. 1 P.M. Table Talk.
description: It's 1 P.M. at La Goulue. Francois Latapie, a dapper gentleman with dark, wavy hair stands beside a mahogany wall in the Madison Avenue bistro, greeting his clientele. A light kiss on the cheek for the fabulous blonde in a pale blue Chanel suit. A gentle hug for the European baroness clad in 18-karat gold jewels over her taupe knit dress and black patent leather pumps.

title: SPENDING IT;Booking a Room for Less Without Calling the Hotel
description: IF you don't trust yourself to negotiate with a hotel for the best rate, a discount booking service offers an alternative.

title: Man Is Killed Trying to Protect Friend
description: A retired principal of a Queens elementary school was stabbed to death late Friday by a group of teen-agers who terrorized the occupants of two Queens Village homes while attempting to steal a new car from a driveway, the police said.

title: ART REVIEW;Sometimes, Meaning Is Where You Find It
description: I LIKE how my work has one meaning if you know about it and another if you don't," Jonathan Weinberg is quoted at saying in a news release for his current show, one of three solos at the Jersey City Museum. The remark would look good printed on a T-shirt, but it is unlikely to do more than prompt readers to wonder what else is new.

title: Bermuda Escape
description: To the Editor: We were interested in Susan Spano's "Gambling With the Thermometer in Bermuda" (March 3) because we too decided to escape from winter by traveling to a place that "guaranteed" 68 degrees -- the perfect temperature for what we like to do: play tennis, walk the beaches, tour museums, forts and old towns.

title: TECHNOLOGY VIEW;Things That Go Bump and Crash, Night and Day
description: THE LASER DISK, THOUGH never embraced by the mass market and now threatened by the promise of the digital video disk, remains the medium of choice for enjoying movies at home. What's more, its end is not necessarily at hand. The CD-size digital video disk isn't even a real-world product yet. Perhaps one day the new format will gain ascendancy, but first the players must be brought to market, and then a catalogue of titles must be created. And not incidentally, this medium of wondrous promise must live up to its billing.

title: Closing Argument
description: IN CONTEMPT By Christopher A. Darden with Jess Walter. Illustrated. 387 pp. New York: Regan Books/ HarperCollins Publishers. $26. SOME historical controversies seem baffling. In the great Russian Orthodox schism of the 1600's, for example, people were burned at the stake over such questions as whether you should extend two or three fingers when making the sign of the cross. A few hundred years from now, students may be similarly puzzled by our national obsession with the trial of O. J. Simpson. But like those old Russian autos-da-fe, the trial was about more than one person's innocence or guilt.

title: Sports of The Times;That 'Playoff Stuff' Stirs the Rangers
description: THEY might be worth their weight in silver -- Stanley Cup silver.

title: WEDDINGS;Michele L. Tuck, Rhinold Ponder
description: Michele Lois Tuck, the Mayor of Princeton Township, N.J., was married yesterday to Rhinold Lamar Ponder, a lawyer in New Brunswick, N.J. The Rev. Reginald T. Jackson, an African Methodist Episcopal minister, officiated at Prospect House on the Princeton University campus.

title: Parchman's Plantation
description: 'WORSE THAN SLAVERY" Parchman Farm and the Ordeal of Jim Crow Justice. By David M. Oshinsky. Illustrated. 306 pp. New York: The Free Press. $25.

title: Foreign Affairs;The Envelope, Please
description: Last week's round of Mideast diplomacy produced both winners and losers. Here's how the judges scored it.

title: Zoe Caldwell Strides in Footsteps of Strong Women
description: IN her cozy dressing room at the Golden Theater where she is making audiences weep and laugh as the diva Maria Callas, the actress Zoe Caldwell stared at a picture of the opera star and Aristotle Onassis. "Maria never got over his marriage to Jackie Kennedy," she said. "But he loved Maria and, I think, would have gone back to her."

title: WORKS IN PROGRESS;New Home for the Arts (and Hope) Takes Shape in Newark
description: It may sound incongruous: suburbanites driving into downtown Newark for a show or a concert, and maybe a walk by the river.

description: A RUSSIAN MOTHER By Alain Bosquet. Holmes & Meier, $26.

description: 'GISELLE' IN HARTFORD

description: LIFE OF A POET Rainer Maria Rilke. By Ralph Freedman. Lyric verse translated by Helen Sword in collaboration with the author. Illustrated. 640 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $35.

title: Policy Findings
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Cypress Hills;An Evolving Northeast Brooklyn Enclave
description: TRAVELING along an elevated line with a birds-eye view of the industrial and inner-city streetscapes, housetops and church spires of North Brooklyn, the J train passes over Williamsburg and Bushwick before arriving at once-rural Cypress Hills on its way to Jamaica Center.

title: WEDDINGS;Gail Harris, John A. Finger
description: Gail Harris, the daughter of Ritalou and Robert Harris of Chevy Chase, Md., is to be married today to John Avram Finger, the son of Ellen Fox of Palo Alto, Calif., and Dr. Avram Finger of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Rabbi Debra Newman Kamin is to officiate at the Four Seasons Hotel in Chicago.

title: State Education Chief: A Zealot for Higher Standards for All
description: Last fall, when Richard Mills decided to leave Vermont and come to New York as Education Commissioner, a staffer roasted him with a headline about the move:

title: WEDDINGS;Michele M. Parisi, Robert J. Banach
description: Michele Marie Parisi and Robert John Banach are to be married today in Ramsey, N.J. The Rev. Joseph G. Moffo is to perform the ceremony at St. Paul Roman Catholic Church.

title: WEDDINGS: VOWS;Heather Simpson, Kevin Hanson
description: KEVIN HANSON, 34, is the director of advertising sales research in New York for E! Entertainment Television, the cable network. In his free time, he can sometimes be found surfing in rough ocean conditions or skiing in blizzards with Myles Kleinfeld, one of his closest friends. "We're storm-chasers, if you will," said Mr. Kleinfeld, who lives in San Francisco. "We love a good snowstorm and a good hurricane."

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;William Morris Centenary Celebrations
description: The eminent Victorian William Morris, poet, businessman and a progenitor of the Arts and Crafts movement, is probably most familiar to Americans today for the Morris chair, for the floral fabrics he designed for Liberty of London and for fancy gift wrappings made from his wallpaper designs. Morris had an intimate relationship with the Victoria and Albert Museum, both as an adviser on acquisitions and as one who used the collection "more than any living man," as he once said. To commemorate the centenary of his death, the museum will celebrate his work from May 9 to Sept. 1.

title: UP AND COMING: Ying Huang;A 'Butterfly' By Way Of Shanghai
description: WEARING A TRIM black suit and high heels, Ying Huang could have passed for a young Chinese business executive arriving for a sales meeting at a fashionable Paris hotel. Indeed, when she sat down for a cup of tea, she needed little prompting to demonstrate what she had to offer. She lowered her eyes demurely, performed a little Japanese dance with her hands and improvised a couple of bars from Puccini's "Madame Butterfly." She then burst out laughing.

title: Will 'TLC' Transform 'Cinderella'?
description: JACK PRINCE bridles when anyone suggests his penthouse apartment near Sutton Place is a wreck.

title: Drawing Rooms
description: MARK HAMPTON, A NATURAL ARISTOCRAT IN THE WORLD OF decorating, carries himself with an otherworldly mien that somehow brings everything around him into harmonious accord. His interior designs are impeccably polite, classic in the most usable sense of the word. Rooms by Hampton sit serenely, arms folded just so, ready for their portrait. And that is precisely how Hampton likes to render them. It's frankly startling, then, to imagine that this elegantly demure apartment, belonging to the head of a prominent French fashion company, was once a 50's period piece with wall-to-wall shag rugs. As far as Hampton was concerned, eyes closed against the memory, "it was a totally blank page." And so he stripped it back to its Georgian Revival bones, adding enough molding and paneling to make a bolder stage set for the owner's eclectic antiques. From Louis XIV purebreds to Chinese lacquer, the furniture was collected over many years, each piece the object of a long-term, if serial, infatuation. "They don't buy furniture," Hampton says of his clients. "They fall in love with it." That passion, wedded to Hampton's regal restraint, makes for rooms brimming with subtle sensuality, much like a beautiful watercolor.

title: Big Election in India Starts Out Smoothly
description: As India has turned away from decades of socialism and toward free-market economic policies, its vast bureaucracy has been blamed for inertia and obstructionism. But at running elections, there can hardly be a more efficient operation.

title: A LA CARTE;Wide Opportunities for Tasting Island's Wines
description: MAY is a milestone month for Long Island wines. More than 1,000 people are expected to sample Island wines in Manhattan, a leading Island hotel is introducing a largely Long Island wine list and free tastes of most local wines are being offered by a Bridgehampton restaurant.

title: ROAD AND RAIL;A Runway to Come Home To
description: The families of Alexandria Field all six of them -- share the same dream: they want to be able to walk outside their front doors, hop into their planes, taxi about 100 feet and take off into the wild blue yonder.

title: FOOD;Truffles, Chilled and Rolled: the Easiest Chocolates to Make
description: FOR candy companies, Mother's Day is one of the big three. Along with Valentine's Day and Easter, the biggest sales are racked up for the second Sunday in May -- to honor mother.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: A DIVING ROCK ON THE HUDSON: Volume 2 of "Mercy of a Rude Stream" By Henry Roth. Picador USA, $14.

title: The Significant Vs. the Pretty
description: To the Editor:

title: EARNING IT;The Forgotten Offspring of Bankruptcy
description: DISCOVERY ZONE was quite the cash machine when Doug Fyffe, an electrician in Dayton, Ohio, read about the company in a magazine five years ago. A line on the cover announced, "Franchising Surge." Inside was the story of an Illinois man whose franchise on a new indoor-playground business was pulling in $18,000 a week.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-14

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: POWER TO HURT Inside a Judge's Chambers: Sexual Assault, Corruption, and the Ultimate Reversal of Justice for Women. By Darcy O'Brien. HarperCollins, $24.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHINATOWN;How Charles Pei Wang Lost a Civil Rights Job
description: The nomination of a Chinatown civic leader to head the staff of the United States Commission on Civil Rights was scuttled this month, and he says he was unfairly rejected because of his role in a labor dispute.

title: Broadway Is Bursting With Energy And Youth
description: FOR the six days every week that 11-year-old Larissa Auble is on Broadway in "Show Boat," her mother, Louise Auble, must make the 70-mile round-trip commute from their Livingston, N.J., home to get her daughter to and from the Gershwin Theater on West 51st Street.

title: Another Use for That Trusty Broom
description: The would-be robber had a knife. The motel clerk had a broom. It was clearly not an equal fight.

title: A Man From Radio Land
description: Media Marathon A Twentieth-Century Memoir. By Erik Barnouw. Illustrated. 264 pp. Durham, N.C.: Duke University Press. $22.95. MOST of us know Erik Barnouw as a professor of mass media or as the author of books on cinema and of a magisterial three-volume "History of Broadcasting in the United States," still definitive after almost 30 years. "Since the dawn of history," it begins, "each new medium has tended to undermine an old monopoly, shift the definitions of goodness and greatness, and alter the climate of men's lives." They certainly altered his life: Mr. Barnouw's soft-spoken, enjoyable memoir, shaped as a series of character sketches of interesting and distinguished people he has encountered, reveals a "white-collar vagabond" career that has lurched from theater to radio to teaching to television and film.

title: Israel to Investigate Death in Jersualem
description: The Israeli police said they were investigating the death of a Mexican priest whose body was discovered today in his room in the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, the holiest Christian site in Jerusalem.

title: Dispute on Ex-Police Officer Ties East Hampton in Suits
description: WITH all of East Hampton's notoriety for drawing Hollywood celebrities to the quaintness of small town life, no one could have dreamed up a script more dramatic than the unfolding scenes that have been played out by local residents over the past two years, pitting the town board and the police department against a former member of both.

title: Melancholy Memoirs
description: To the Editor:

title: MARKET TIMING
description: Monday

title: Thai Shrimp Farmers Facing Ecologists' Fury
description: Like thousands of other shrimp farmers in Asia and Latin America, all Maitri Visetsak wanted was to get rich quick.

title: After Years of Conflict, Jay Sites Are Opening to the Public
description: A PRESERVATION struggle that began along Route 1 here 17 years ago officially ended in 1992 when Westchester County bought 21 1/2 acres of the former John Jay property from a developer for $11.5 million. Some of the ongoing restoration has been open to the public, but now one phase of the project is complete. Next Sunday at 3 P.M., weekly walking tours will begin in the Boston Post Road Historic District -- a National Historic Landmark.

title: SIGNOFF;An Idea, A Camera; Viewers Go On the Air
description: ON the dusty plains of Dilley, Tex., a herd of 600 monkeys gallops past tumbleweeds and barbed wire, while their caretaker rails agianst hunters who have declared open season on the animals. In Riverside, Calif., the teacher of an S.A.T. preparatory course exhorts his students to beat the test. Halfway around the world, an Indonesian tribe struggles with civilization as its members smoke their tobacco of choice members smoke their tobacco of choice - Marlboros - and mug for the camera.

title: Frustrations, Lack of Power: Behind the Board 3 Exodus
description: SEVEN of the nine members of School Board 3 are not running for reelection. Most of them cited their frustrations.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HUNTS POINT;So, Just What Is The Point?
description: When Belinda Arroyo first heard that a vacant building in her Hunts Point neighborhood was being turned into a theater that would present rap concerts, she was less than pleased.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MUSEUM MILE;Say Wright Lloyd Frank Would What
description: Jens Reusch, a 31-year-old German tourist, took the elevator up at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum last Wednesday. He was following the directions in his guidebook ("Man folgt der Spiralformigen Rampe von der Kuppel nach unten"), and the wishes of the museum's architect, Frank Lloyd Wright. But he was going the wrong way.

He had rebuilt the party after the defeat of George Bush, helped engineer a Republican landslide in the 1994 Congressional elections and euphorically celebrated House action on the Contract With America.

title: BASEBALL;Roberson, and Pep Talk, Give Mets a Needed Edge
description: Carl Everett was ready. So was Butch Huskey. But it was Kevin Roberson who got to start in right field tonight. Mets Manager Dallas Green played down the move before the game, but it seemed like pure genius afterward.

title: Correction
description: The introduction to the centennial issue on April 14, titled "5,000 Sundays," incorrectly described the anniversary that was celebrated in Britain's royal jubilee in 1897 (and was photographed for the Magazine). The occasion was Queen Victoria's 60th year on the throne, not her 50th.

title: When It Comes to Health, Remember the Children
description: To the Editor:

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;Pesky Parasites And Nasty Bites
description: THREE diseases you may never have heard of -- and your doctor may not recognize -- are among those that can lay you low in the aftermath of a trip to the tropics, or even to a United States national park. There are no vaccinations or pills that prevent these three: schistosomiasis, a parasite disease also known as bilharzia, or snail fever; giardiasis, frequently called giardia, for the parasite that causes it, and dengue, or breakbone fever.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS/DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN: DINING;Gage & Tollner: The Same, but Different
description: Gage & Tollner, the 117-year-old landmark restaurant in Downtown Brooklyn that has been under renovation since last fall, will debut its new look starting with private parties this week and will offically open to the public on May 8. Joseph Chirico, the new owner, said he has tried to retain the historic flavor of the restaurant while providing modern amenities.

title: SOMETHING'S GOT TO GIVE
description: Darcy Frey's article "Something's Got to Give" (March 24), on air traffic controllers, dis-turbed me. Images of warfare came to mind: men giving their all to safeguard countless strangers, bonding in the face of terror.

description: There are purists who say that the only blueberries worth eating are the small, intensely flavored fruits that grow on low bushes in the famous blueberry barrens of New England and maritime Canada. It's a good thing the purists are wrong.

title: New Releases
description: STEVE DAVIS: 'THE JAUNT' Criss Cross

title: THEATER;Faithful to the French Moderns, Like Moliere
description: IT WAS FOUNDED BY LOUIS XIV IN 1680, its lavish Salle Richelieu dates back to the late 18th century and its repertory leans heavily on the great classics of French theater, yet the Comedie-Francaise bristles at the suggestion that it is a monument to past French glory. Nowadays, the company regularly puts on works by living playwrights. Even more crucially, it believes that, if presented properly, plays written centuries ago offer acute commentaries on the issues of our day.

title: Mental Health Coverage Won't Break the Bank
description: To the Editor:

title: A PEACE PLAN FOR THE CIGARETTE WARS
description: Kluger makes sense. A binding pragmatic approach for both parties is the only answer. Government regulators have to learn from previous "prohibition" fiascoes that banning smoking is not the answer. In exchange, cigarette manufacturers should submit to new rules of realistic marketing.

title: Sports of The Times;Atlanta Is Suddenly Quivering From Early Olympic Experience
description: THE specter of the Summer Games arrived with a roar this past week -- all five rings of it: The torch was on its way. The bulldozers were rumbling. The sponsors were promoting. The athletes were emoting. And rumors of fear and trembling were flying around town.

title: IN THE GARDEN;Dividing Perennials Multiplies Beauty and Neighborliness
description: TRADITION holds that spring-blooming perennials are divided in the fall, while fall-blooming perennials are divided in the spring. This theory is essentially correct, but sometimes gardens do not work out this way.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Three Funny Women, Joking Through Pain
description: SOPHIE was the biggest star. Next came Totie, whose real name, curiously enough, was Sophie. But at the Forum Theater Group, Belle is the top.

title: Crash at a Border Checkpoint Kills 2 in Van and Injures 19
description: A van crammed with nearly two dozen people crashed near an immigration checkpoint on Friday, sending people flying as it shot across a freeway and overturned. Two people died and 19 were injured.

title: THEATER;Divas in Metaphor, Divas in Crisis, Divas in Life
description: IF ever a word signifying distinctiveness has been worked to death, the word is diva. For many, the diva emanates from opera, surpassing the prima donna. An impresario, Matthew Epstein, once wrote of the diva as a thrilling woman "who faces a whole house of people and by her bravura, her virtuosity, makes them submit to her. In a funny way, the emergence of the diva was a beginning of women's liberation."

title: FILM;The Bouquets For a Late Bloomer Are All Hard Won
description: Irma P. Hall is cruising the South Side at the wheel of her late mother's 1978 Cadillac. The rusty heap chugs along at barely 30 miles an hour. But the actress -- who has won raves for her portrayal of an old blind woman in "A Family Thing" -- isn't in a hurry to get home, or anywhere else.

title: Dangerous Inheritance
description: MASON'S RETREAT By Christopher Tilghman. 290 pp. New York: Random House. $22.

title: A PEACE PLAN FOR THE CIGARETTE WARS
description: After we depolarize long enough to adopt something as remarkably well balanced as Kluger's approach to cigarettes, I suggest we turn him loose on gun control -- and maybe follow that up with some common-sense accommodation on abortion, capital punishment and assisted suicide. Issues like these might start to sort themselves out when we become willing, even if a little afraid, to "dance with the devil."

title: MARKET WATCH;When Chiefs Fear Disclosure
description: There was a time in this country when the figures that companies released about themselves bore a disturbing resemblance to the speeches of Lewis Carroll's Queen of Hearts: the numbers said whatever the company wanted them to say. Relying on them was hazardous to your wealth.

title: AT THE GATE;Communicating Not Just Over the Phone
description: WHEN Excel Communications Inc. makes its expected debut next month as a public company, many investors may be be swept off their feet, only to land right on their backsides.

title: Eating Disorders Strike Younger Girls and Men
description: EATING disorders on Long Island are increasing, as well as crossing age, sex and class lines, experts in the field say.

title: DINING OUT;In Pelham, Warm Welcome Is Reflected
description: THOUGH the space here is hardly expansive, the welcome certainly is. Walk in the door and either a staff member or the owner, Primo Maestri, appears immediately, clearly wanting to please.

title: Inside the Meritocracy Machine
description: THINGS HAVE CHANGED AT VAN Nuys High School since its most famous alumnus, Robert Redford, graduated in 1956. Indeed, inside the sprawling, campuslike complex of sandstone-colored buildings and temporary trailers, there is something futuristic about the place. With its earnestly beleaguered faculty, teeming hallways and stew pot of cultures, with its tension between classes and colors and between homeboys (and girls) and newcomers, it looks and feels the way public high schools everywhere in the country are likely to in the next century as our cities continue to expand into the suburbs.

title: YOUR HOME;Lowering Taxes on A Mortgage
description: CAN you imagine buying a home and passing up an easy opportunity to save thousands of dollars?" asked Douglas F. Wasser, a Manhattan real estate lawyer. "All it takes is the application of a simple but well-known technique and the savings will automatically flow."

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Feb. 4 with an article about dealing with children who break the law misstated the name and mission of a residential treatment center in Hackensack. It is the Holley Child Care and Development Center, not Holly House, and it treats children with emotional handicaps, not youthful offenders. A letter dated Feb. 9 from the Youth Consultation Service, which operates the center, was misrouted at The Times, delaying this correction.

title: In Israel, a Ghost Town Stirs Back to Life
description: Minutes before a 4 A.M. cease-fire went into effect this morning, a last Katyusha rocket fired by Hezbollah guerrillas smashed into an apartment building in the heart of this border town, shaking an underground shelter where Aviva Ohion was sleeping with her family.

title: Face Lifts for Monuments
description: Visitors to the nation's capital might have to dodge scaffolding, construction crews and jackhammers as they tour historic sites for the next several summers.

title: EVENING HOURS;Venerations, Generations
description: Raising glasses to children's health, a cable arts network, Shakespeare and Picasso, Picasso, Picasso.

title: Hero Worship;Longing for a New Lone Genius
description: ONE of the most surprising literary sensations this spring is a tiny volume, "Longitude," by Dava Sobel, about an obscure 18th-century inventor. Subtitled "The True Story of a Lone Genius Who Solved the Greatest Scientific Problem of His Time," Ms. Sobel's book has people in the publishing industry puzzling over the secret of its success. Is it the bite-size format? The book's handsome appearance? Simple nostalgia?

title: Art in Fiber: Off the Bed and Onto the Wall
description: DON'T call it a quilting bee. It's a modern adaptation -- an intellectual exercise of three artists with like interests getting together to critique each other's work. For the past two years they have met monthly, alternating at each other's studios from Greenwich to Brookfield.

title: In Search of El Dorado
description: THE CREATURE IN THE MAP A Journey to El Dorado. By Charles Nicholl. Illustrated. 398 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $25.

title: John Flanagan, 90, Psychologist Who Devised Pilot Aptitude Test
description: Dr. John C. Flanagan, a psychologist who devised the aptitude tests that helped select American pilots in World War II and then adapted the technique to education, died on April 15 at his home in Menlo Park, Calif. He was 90.

description: THEY love city slickers here in the Finger Lakes. They really do.

title: INVESTING WITH: John L. Wallace;Robertson Stephens Growth and Income Fund
description: WHEN the broad stock market is treading water, a gifted stock picker rises to the occasion. So if you're part of the legion of market watchers who are convinced that prices are topping out for the year, you might want to direct your money to such a fund manager.

description: IT was 9 P.M. on a Saturday midway into a performance of the musical "Big" in Detroit. Part of the scenery, a huge house, which was meant to pivot, got jammed. "Call Neil at home," the producer shouted. "Quickly."

title: Corrections
description: A notice last Sunday inviting readers to submit anecdotes about business meetings carried an outdated reference to the magazine that publishes a pseudonymous humor column under the byline Stanley Bing. Since July, the column has appeared in Fortune, no longer in Esquire.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;Smits Steps In, in Overtime, To Defeat Fumbling Hawks
description: Rik Smits, sore feet and all, showed that the Indiana Pacers can win in the playoffs without Reggie Miller.

title: World News Briefs;Chechen Chief's Widow Plans Peace Mission
description: The widow of the slain Chechen rebel leader, Dzhokhar M. Dudayev, is planning a peace mission to Moscow to try to stop fighting in the secessionist region.

title: Q and A
description: Crossing to France

title: Weird and Weirder
description: KANGAROO NOTEBOOK By Kobo Abe. Translated by Maryellen Toman Mori. 183 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.

title: THE NIGHT;2 Chances To Tell Life From Art
description: AT the opening-night party for the Virgin Megastore in Times Square on Monday, only the shrink-wrapped compact disks that would go on sale the next day seemed even remotely virginal. Everything and everybody else -- music-industry honchos, publicity flacks, gossip purveyors, Robin Leach and others with something to sell -- seemed far less innocent.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: THE ONLY WORLD Poems. By Lynda Hull. Edited by David Wojahn. HarperCollins, cloth, $22; paper, $12.

title: HOME REPAIR;With Plastic Laminates, Start Simply Because There's No Turning Back
description: PLASTIC laminate is the tough surfacing material widely used as a cover for kitchen countertops. Laminates are made of thin sheets of kraft paper impregnated with phenolic resin. A plastic veneer, melanin, is added to the resin-paper sandwich, followed by a layer of colored or patterned plastic, then topped with another layer of melanin. The multilayered sandwich is fused under heat and pressure. The result is a thin, heat-resistant veneer that makes a durable and decorative work surface. Two copyrighted trade names for this product are Formica and Micarta.

title: Sojourn in an Antebellum Garden
description: WHEN Genevieve and Morrell Trimble cast their eyes on 250 acres of rubble and overgrown landscape -- the remains of Afton Villa, a Louisiana ante bellum mansion with lavish gardens -- they decided to pre-empt its inevitable takeover by real estate developers by buying it themselves. Since the main house had burned to the ground in 1963, their architect, Barry Fox, helped turn the pool house into charming living quarters for the Trimbles, who in 1972 embarked on their huge, 20-year project to restore the lost gardens. Thanks to their dedication, their gardening skills, and the quality of the original landscape architecture, Afton Villa again offers visitors to Louisiana a taste of the golden age of Southern living.

title: Freemen Farm Attracts the Fringe
description: A girl pedaling a red bicycle, children enjoying an Easter Sunday horseback ride, and two men brandishing rifles with banana Clips -- for one month, telephoto images like those have provided the nation fuzzy snapshots of life inside the Freemen compound.

title: World News Briefs;South Korea to Invest $19 Million in North
description: South Korea today authorized a $19 million investment package for its impoverished Communist rival, North Korea.

title: Vietnam Ousts Official
description: The Communist Party has purged a high-ranking official who apparently fell from favor after opposing the quick pace of Vietnam's move toward a more open economy.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the F.Y.I. column on April 14, to a reader's question about the origin of a small unused church on Roosevelt Island, included a misstatement from the Roosevelt Island Operating Corporation about records of the building's history, and misstated the date of its construction. Records indeed exist, showing that the church was built in 1923 by the Episcopal New York Altar Guild as the Chapel of the Holy Spirit, for the use of Protestant patients of Metropolitan Hospital, then on the island. The church closed in the 50's, and was used briefly by a Greek Orthodox group in the 60's, when it was known for a time as the Chapel of St. Dennis.

title: April 21-27;A Super Hacker Enters A Plea Bargain, in Person
description: Is he a criminal genius who stole millions of dollars worth of data and services from hundreds of telephone andcomputer networks? Or is he simply a lonely electronics whiz who never hurt anyone and never sought to profit from his electronic break-ins?

title: Group Opposes Managed Care
description: CODE BLUE" -- in medicine, the words indicate a patient has gone into cardio-pulmonary arrest and must receive immediate emergency resuscitation.

title: MUSIC;Out of the Depths, On to a Festival
description: IN February of 1994 the South Shore Music Festival hit bottom. It looked as though the club, founded in 1933 in the depths of the Great Depression to encourage and employ young musicians could not survive in the 1990's.

title: April 21-27;The President and Congress Finally Agree on a Budget
description: Seven months after the 1996 fiscal year began and more than three months after the longest Government shutdown ever, President Clinton and the Republicans who control Congress finally agreed last week on spending levels for the departments and agencies.

title: INVESTING IT;In Whatever Guise, Whitman Looks Sweet
description: THE Whitman Corporation may finally be getting down to business: its soft-drink business.

title: Westchester Q&A: Dr. Rameshwar Bhargava;Taking Fear Out of High Tech's Future
description: SOMEDAY perhaps "nanocrystals" will be a part of the everyday vocabulary of Americans, just as megabytes, cathode ray tubes, lasers and other once vague terms and high-tech inventions are today.

title: BROADWAY PRODUCERS;The Costs Say It All
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting a Pickwick Cart Before the Horse
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: THE BATTLE FOR HISTORY Re-fighting World War II. By John Keegan. Vintage, paper, $10.

title: Theft on Cruise
description: To the Editor: On Dec. 15, the last night of a Caribbean cruise on the Noordam of the Holland America line, passengers put their luggage out in the passageway to be picked up and transferred to dockside in Tampa. A camera bag full of equipment (a 35-millimeter camera, four lenses, etc. worth over $1,500) was stolen out of the larger piece of luggage that we had placed it in. Whoever took it more than likely didn't single out our luggage but probably unzipped others also.

title: Pasadena School Stops Jamaicans
description: John Muir High School of Pasadena, Calif., showed how good its 1,600-meter relay team is and proved it could beat the Jamaican schools that have dominated the event at the Penn Relays for more than a decade.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;Olajuwon Fouls Out As Lakers Get Even
description: Hakeem Olajuwon made only a cameo appearance.

title: THEATER;Nerd Girl, Yo-Yo Guys, At 'The Library'
description: LISTEN to the grunts of the four-member Mortimer Adler High School marching band, the guys who also fill in as dim students in "The Library," which Stamford Theater Works delusionally bills as a musical.

title: Reality Bites
description: The World on Blood By Jonathan Nasaw. 341 pp. New York: Dutton. $22.95. Stainless By Todd Grimson. 265 pp. New York: Harper Prism. Paper, $12.

title: WEDDINGS;Susan B. Rebell, Peter J. Solomon
description: Susan Barach Rebell, a management consultant in New York, is to be married today to Peter Jay Solomon, an investment banker and a former Deputy Mayor of New York. Dr. Ronald B. Sobel, the senior rabbi at Temple Emanu-El, is to officiate at the apartment of Jeannette R. Solomon, the bridegroom's mother.

title: End of 53d St. Transfer Shows M.T.A.'s Contempt
description: To the Editor:

title: Three People Are Involved In 'Domino' Liver Transplant
description: In the first "domino" liver transplant in the United States, a 17-year-old Pennsylvania girl has received a liver and a large and small intestine from a young donor, and her own healthy liver has been donated to a third patient.

title: IN BRIEF;Downtown Renewal Includes Pieces of History
description: Englewood's historic Monument section is about to undergo a face lift.

title: HORSE RACING;Derby Favorite's Front Foot Draws Trainer's Attention
description: Unbridled's Song, the favorite for next Saturday's Kentucky Derby, galloped a mile and three-quarters this morning wearing a bar shoe and an acrylic patch on his left front foot.

title: Daughters of the Revolution
description: FOUNDING MOTHERS & FATHERS Gendered Power and the Forming of American Society. By Mary Beth Norton. 496 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

title: Savage Spite
description: AMELA FAKO FOUND ONLY ONE FAMILY PHOTO when she returned to her home in the Sarajevo suburb of Ilidza last month. The picture, taken in the 1970's in front of the Hotel Serbia in Ilidza, showed her with her family; now, their faces were obliterated by a drill bit. "The picture was a primitive message, part of the other war, one not done with guns," Fako said. "It was the war of fear, the war on the mind. They wanted to make it difficult for us to come home."

title: PLAYOFFS;United Knicks Slam, Bump and Strut to a 2-0 Lead
description: Charles Oakley, face mask and all, went stumbling into the crowd late in the third quarter for a loose ball, which he deftly flicked back to Patrick Ewing for an uncontested and disheartening dunk.

title: Long Island Q&A: Daniel A. Lehner;Making Sure You Have Something to Read While In-Flight
description: DANIEL A. LEHNER is president of three corporations: Inflight Newspapers, a multimillion dollar business that distributes newspapers and magazines to airlines and hotels; Inflight Advertising, which manages the advertising and manufacturing of the plastic binders that hold the magazines distributed by Inflight Newspapers, and Lehner International, which oversees Mr. Lehner's various business investments, like the Great American Cafe, a Valley Stream restaurant.

title: In the Region/Westchester;A Below-Market Rental for Village Employees
description: THIS small, affluent village, known for its riverfront mansions and quaint downtown, has agreed to sell a vacant waterfront building to an affordable-housing organization that plans to build 24 rental units on the top two floors and a new library for the village on the first floor.

title: Commercial Property/One Broadway;Tenants That Felt They Were in Not-So-Good Hands
description: NEW YORK has long been a place where landlords and tenants seem to haggle over everything and where a lease's fine print can run to dozens of pages. But even in New York, the legacy of ill will left by lease -- and eventually, sale -- negotiations between tenants of One Broadway, that landmarked building opposite Bowling Green Park, and Allstate Insurance, its former owner, seems extreme.

title: Sunday April 28, 1996: YUMMY ALGAE IS NETTED;Skimming The Pond
description: You can't buy Super Blue Green Algae in stores. It and related pond harvests produced by a company called Cell Tech in Klamath Falls, Ore., are sold only by 300,000 independent distributors, much the way Amway sells soap. But you can find the algae that is fished out of Upper Klamath Lake and hawked as a nutritional supplement on the Internet.

title: HOME CLINIC;How to Prepare Plastic Laminate
description: PLASTIC laminate is the tough surfacing material widely used as a cover for kitchen countertops.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Judith Krauss;Nurses on the Front Lines of Health Care
description: WHEN Judith Krauss is asked her occupation she says simply "nurse." But as conversation unfolds, she discloses more: She is the dean of the Yale School of Nursing and her husband, Robert L. Krauss, whom she met while both were studying at Yale, is a nurse-midwife.

title: N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;For Rangers, a Glint of Daylight Peers Through Clouds
description: Nine hours before losing Game 1 to Montreal at Madison Square Garden almost two weeks ago, the Rangers held their usual game-day practice in suburban Rye, N.Y. But several of their Manhattan-based players, including the captain, Mark Messier, missed it because heavy rains had flooded the roads.

title: April 21-27;Charges of Sexual Harassment On the Automobile Line
description: The only Mitsubishi workers in Normal, Ill., who haven't been wrenched by charges of widespread sexual harassment are the 610 robots that labor alongside about 800 women and 3,200 men producing cars at Mitsubishi Motor Manufacturing of America.

title: The Good Mother
description: THE WOMAN WHO WALKED INTO DOORS By Roddy Doyle. 226 pp. New York: Viking. $22.95.

title: TELEVISION;A Bold Old Hand Reshapes CBS News
description: O.K., HERE WE GO," whispers Andrew Heyward as the moment of truth arrives promptly at 6:30, with Dan Rather beginning his delivery of "The CBS Evening News." Mr. Heyward is in the program's main control room at CBS's broadcast center on West 57th Street in Manhattan, just a few feet from the command post where the executive producer, Jeffrey Fager, is cuing Mr. Rather.

title: SUNDAY VIEW;Culture Clashes Still Intrigue In 'King and I'
description: WHENEVER YOU return to something -- to a play, a song, a scene -- you bring your past with you. And not just what you've been through and figured out, but what your culture has been through and figured out too, and what you are both still going through.

title: The World;A Baffling Endgame in the Mideast
description: BECAUSE this is the Middle East," goes the old punch line to a long series of anecdotes that purport to explain situations that defy common logic. If there was any need to illustrate the genesis of the format, last week had it all.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Hess Shares His Excitement
description: Something special must be happening with the Jets: Leon Hess, who has waved off all requests for impromptu interviews in his 15 years as principal owner, gave a brief news conference today after watching his $60 million-plus off-season investment at minicamp.

title: Asking Better Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: SPOTLIGHT;Road Warriors
