description: Ryan O'Neal and his daughter, Tatum, make an unlikely and winning pair of schemers in Peter Bogdanovich's amusingly raffish PAPER MOON (1973). The picture skips across the Bible Belt of the Depression era, flavored with an appealing edge of sentimentality. The best and funniest chapter finds the jealous youngster nimbly separating her smitten partner from the clutches of a pretty temptress, one Trixie Delight. Madeline Kahn handles this role nicely, and John Hillerman does well in a double characterization. The film became a short-lived television series that couldn't touch the original. No wonder - not with a double does of O'Neals. Young Tatum copped a supporting Oscar - MONDAY at 4 P.M. and TUESDAY at NOON on BRV.

title: Old Demons Are Roused On a Street In Berlin
description: For more than a century, Wilhelmstrasse was a seat of world power, as well known as Downing Street, the Quai d'Orsay and the Kremlin. Nearly all of its imposing government buildings are gone, but this week city officials began a new effort to remind Berliners of the street's extraordinary history.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: STRANGE THINGS The Malevolent North in Canadian Literature. By Margaret Atwood. Clarendon/Oxford University, $19.95.

title: WEDDINGS;Ann E. Meyerholz, Kevin M. Garrity
description: Ann Elizabeth Meyerholz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Meyerholz of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Kevin Michael Garrity, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Garrity of Chatham, N.J. The Rev. Warren Bouton officiated at the Community Congregational Church with the Rev. Patrick O'Donovan, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Witnesses to an Execution
description: A man who raped and stabbed a 20-year-old neighbor, then sat on her sofa and watched her die, was executed on Friday while her family watched on closed-circuit television.

title: WEDDINGS;Alina Garcia, Carlos Lapuerta
description: Alina Rosa Garcia, a senior analyst at the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, was married on Friday evening to Carlos Lapuerta, a partner in the Brattle Group, an economic and financial consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Xavier Morras, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Little Flower in Coral Gables, Fla.

title: Medically Uninsured Increasing On Island
description: AN increase in Long Islanders without health insurance is generating concern that many people are not receiving adequate medical care.

title: Sunday April 28, 1996;A QUESTION FOR: Lola Pashalinski
description: A two-time Obie winner, she is a founding member of Charles Ludlam's Ridiculous Theatrical Company and the 60-year-old namesake of the Lola, an award to be given for the first time tomorrow night by the Lesbian Exchange for New Drama.

title: Correction
description: An article on April 14 about how directors adjust their films for release on video referred incorrectly to the video version of Oliver Stone's film "Natural Born Killers." After the killing of 16 children and a teacher in March at a school in Dunblane, Scotland, Warner Home Video stopped distributing "Natural Born Killers" in Britain; the video was not banned there.

title: WEDDINGS;Miss O'Brien, Mr. Chrysler
description: Ana Maria O'Brien, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. O'Brien of Arlington, Va., was married last evening to Jack F. Chrysler 3d, the son of Mrs. K. Peter Knudsen of Perrysburg, Ohio, and Mr. Chrysler Jr. of Malibu, Calif. Msgr. Jude O'Doherty performed the ceremony in the Dahlgren Chapel at Georgetown University in Washington.

title: Word for Word/Dumbed Down Shakespeare;Translations of the Bard: Perorations Devoutly to Be Missed
description: WE live in an age that strives for easy digestion, an age of gel caps and sound bites. Some things, though, are not improved in the quest for convenience. Consider this:

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 7 about cellular telephones misstated the location of AT&T Wireless Services. It is in Paramus, N.J., not Parsippany. The article also referred incorrectly to the number of AT&T Wireless Services customers in the New York City area. The figure given, two million, is the number of wireless customers of all companies in the area, not just of AT&T, which declined to provide the number of its customers.

title: CHOOSING MY RELIGION
description: I view Dubner's personal story as more of a "search for his roots" than choosing his religion. His tale made me think of adopted children who embark on a search for their natural parents.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;FUNDS WATCH
description: Shooting Stars In Minnesota

title: Reporter's Notebook;The Auction Aftermath: Was It Worth the Price?
description: The television crews have packed up their equipment. The bidders who lost out in the volleying for ever-higher prices have gone home empty-handed. And the buyers who shelled out megabucks at the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis estate auction at Sotheby's last week are facing the morning-after question: Did I pay too much?

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WATERFRONT;Blazing a Path Alongside The Hudson
description: Imagine being able to bicycle all the way from 72d Street to the George Washington Bridge without ever crossing traffic. With nearly $3 million in Federal money now in place, and $2 million coming from the state, the plan for an uninterrupted promenade along the Hudson River's edge known as Riverside Walk is finally in its design stages. Construction is expected to begin in 1999.

title: The Nation;Dole's Foreign Policy Record: It's Hard to Read
description: BOB DOLE'S pitch for himself as the next commander-in-chief is that he deserves the job because he's a tough guy who knows what he's doing.

title: Passengers Are Frustrated by Slower Commutes on Subways
description: A young man looked up from his newspaper Friday morning, briefly noted the cityscape trundling by outside the F train, and returned to his paper. He looked up again a couple of minutes later, wrinkled his brow, sighed, and said, to no one in particular, "We're still not at Church Avenue? I hate this train."

title: A.H. Howell, 83, Book-Loving Banker
description: Alfred Hunt Howell, a retired banker and philanthropist, died on Tuesday at his home in Riverdale, the Bronx. He was 83.

title: WORKS IN PROGRESS;Filling In the Blanks to Make a Waterfront Park for the Ages
description: For years, the future of Liberty State Park seemed to be stuck in neutral, held up by an interminable dispute over whether an 18-hole golf course would be built in its barren interior. Park planners loved the idea, saying the greens fees and cart rentals generated by the 7,000-yard course would provide a vital source of revenue. Open-space advocates hated it, saying the park would be best developed like Central Park in Manhattan, full of lawns and meadows and playgrounds.

title: World News Briefs;Andreotti Judge Quits, Bringing Trial to Halt
description: A murder trial involving a former Italian Prime Minister, Giulio Andreotti, was halted today when the judge and his assistant withdrew.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the budget bill signed by the President misstated the size of the cut in domestic government spending in some editions. The cuts total $24 billion, not $24 million.

title: On Shanghai Visit, Yeltsin Finds It Is Russia's Turn to Be Envious
description: The last time a Russian leader came to this city, in May 1989, the streets were clogged with student protesters demanding democracy and China seemed to be on the brink of cataclysmic political change.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;A Draftee Is Eager To Take The Plunge
description: If Danny Kanell is anything, he is smart. And you get the feeling that the quarterback from Florida State knows what kind of situation he has walked into with the Giants.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;For the Brave, an Open-End Russia Fund
description: ABOUT the time that the people of Russia elect a president in June, Americans are expected to get their first chance to buy an open-end mutual fund invested there. Neither is without substantial risk.

title: WEDDINGS;Marilyn N. Ling, Leway Chen
description: Dr. Marilyn Ning Ling, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William S. M. Ling of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Leway Chen, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Terry H. Chen of Dexter, Mo. The Rev. Dr. J. Barrie Shepherd performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: WEDDINGS;Elish V. Hickey, Mark E. Telling
description: Elish Veronica Hickey and Mark Edward Telling, account managers in New York for Cigna, the insurance company, were married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Michael R. Moynihan performed the ceremony at St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;The Padres Discover a New Winning Formula
description: For part of last week, the list of National League leaders showed Tony Gwynn and Wally Joyner as the top two hitters with averages in the high .400's, but they weren't even playing and the San Diego Padres kept winning. Are the Padres that good? "Earl Weaver said you have to have deep depth," said Kevin Towers, the team's rookie general manager, who then cited two examples of the Padres' deep depth.

title: Florida G.O.P. Reproves Clinton on Judgeship
description: When President Clinton travels to Florida on Monday to underscore his efforts to fight illegal drugs, the state Republican Party will greet him with a newspaper advertisement accusing him of offering Federal judgeships "for sale" to top fund-raisers.

title: Millions for Defense
description: The Search for Justice A Defense Attorney's Brief on the O. J. Simpson Case. By Robert L. Shapiro with Larkin Warren. 363 pp. New York: Warner Books. $24.95.

title: Spring's Hopes, Eternal
description: MENTION baseball, and I think of long, languid evenings spent under a clear night sky, T-shirts and shorts, freshly shorn grass, hot dogs and cold beer. But in Minneapolis, where I live, nights don't get languid until July, and my Minnesota Twins play indoors on a field that is painted, not mowed.

title: In Greenwich, the Hard Work of Democracy
description: MORE than two hours into its meeting last March, Connecticut's largest legislative body was still on its first item of business: Reviewing a $275,000 contingency fund for maintenance work at two elementary schools. The air of the cavernous auditorium seemed to crackle with tension, and persistent chatter coursed through the back rows.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: SOME welcome old film friends are bowing in on television this week. The no-longer-youthful Irene Dunne and Charles Boyer imbued Leo McCarey's LOVE AFFAIR (1939) with a seasoned charm that somehow eluded the director's worthy 1957 remake (with Deborah Kerr and Cary Grant). It also missed the Warren Beatty-Amette Bening "Love Affair" (1994) by a country mile. Dunne and Boyer portray two smitten worldings with easy grace and expertise, seamlessly lacing comedy and drama - plain suds. The early shipboard scenes and a Madeira interlude are a joy. The last line - "If you can paint, I can walk" - lingers. It's on Saturday at midnight on Channel 21.

title: MANHATTAN PROJECTS
description: As one of the "less affluent residents" on the north end of Central Park, I joined the original voices of protest against the proposed Christo and Jeanne-Claude publicity stunt in the early 1980's. Central Park does not need Christo to attract more visitors.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS;Ready to Stir Up St. Francis
description: Wearing a crisp tailored suit, Frank J. Macchiarola seemed like the last person who would be able to get along with the cluster of college students hanging out on the steps of St. Francis College.

title: WEDDINGS;Elliott W. Sparkman, Sloan Walker
description: Elliott Ward Sparkman was married last evening in Bryn Mawr, Pa., to Samuel Sloan Walker 3d. The Rev. Timothy Dobbins performed the ceremony with Bishop Frank T. Griswold 3d of Chicago, at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer.

title: CHOOSING MY RELIGION
description: Stephen J. Dubner's "Choosing My Religion" (March 31) was the Passover table talk of choice, the buzz of Brooklyn, and has become the latest addition to our "clip 'n' save" pile.

title: F.B.I. Is Investigating Dole Campaign Gifts
description: Federal law-enforcement officials are investigating accusations that people associated with a sporting goods company made illegal contributions to Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign, a newspaper reported today.

title: Man Accused of Posing as Physician Faces a Federal Indictment
description: Gerald Barnes, who the authorities say has been masquerading as a doctor on and off since the 1970's, was indicted by a Federal grand jury on Friday on charges of prescribing drugs illegally and engaging in mail and wire fraud.

title: Rocky Path for U.S. Admiral in Bosnia
description: Adm. Leighton W. Smith Jr. strode through the underground passage beneath Sarajevo's soccer stadium, flanked by bodyguards, to a waiting helicopter kicking up dust in the dirt field.

title: INSIDE
description: A Token Buys Impatience

title: MANHATTAN PROJECTS
description: John Tierney's "Manhattan Projects" (The Big City, March 31), supporting Christo's effort to gain approval to construct a gigantic artwork in Central Park, brings to mind a time not so long ago when I had the good fortune to watch Christo's team carefully wrap the Pont Neuf in Paris.

title: MAKING IT WORK;Let the Sleepers Awake
description: MARIO CUOMO, the former governor of New York, is sitting on the comfortable couch in the living room. On his lap is a little girl. They are laughing and playing a game of shadow puppets. ("He's paying attention to his child, unlike my father," explains Jeff, whose recurring dream this is.) Jeff begins to cry. Standing behind him is his mother. Jeff asks her why she isn't crying. "You know I'm not going to cry for you anymore," she says. Jeff wakes up, weeping.

title: Point of Health Insurance Is to Spread Risks Around
description: To the Editor:

title: Where the Games Began
description: Correction Appended

title: The Logic of Peace in Chechnya
description: The savage war in Chechnya has so far outlasted every effort to end it. The death last week of the Chechen rebel leader, Dzhokhar Dudayev, in a Russian rocket attack ought to bring both sides to their senses. They should at last commence serious discussions on a cease-fire and peace agreement.

title: Sunday April 28, 1996: BRINGING UP BABY;Sample Sale
description: The National Institute of Standards and Technology produces some 1,300 Standard Reference Materials -- known as S.R.M.'s -- that the Federal agency sells as basic quality controls for science and industry. It does this for everything from whale blubber to peach leaves. Until now, though, there has never been an S.R.M. for a staple as common as baby formula. According to Thomas E. Gills, chief of the S.R.M. program, the new formula sample has assigned values for calories, protein, fat, carbohydrates and other nutrients.

title: Unjustified Raid
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: What the Constitution Requires
description: In 1956, Dwight D. Eisenhower appointed me to the Supreme Court. Now, at 90, I am frequently asked to identify the Court's greatest achievements in my 34-year tenure. High on my list is the protection of individual rights and human dignity.

title: Paper Says G.O.P. Is Set on Platform Job
description: Representative Henry J. Hyde, a staunch abortion foe, is to be named chairman of the Republican National Convention's party platform committee, The Chicago Tribune reported.

title: Trial Turns To Statements About Death On Videotape
description: Once again last week, as in all of Dr. Jack Kevorkian's other assisted-suicide trials, the focus came down to a dramatic videotape. Except this time not one, but two, patients appeared on the television screen with the retired pathologist and their family members, just hours before they died.

title: How Could Hudson County Destroy Its Own Mountain?
description: To the Editor:

title: DRIVING SMART;The Search for Smarter, Safer Air Bags
description: AIR bags obviously make cars safer, but they can have deadly consequences: since October they have been responsible for the deaths of at least 15 children who were sitting in front passenger seats during accidents. Air bag suppliers have responded with technology to make their systems safer, by shutting off the passenger-side bag if a child-safety seat is in use.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: THE SECRETS OF THE HOPEWELL BOX Stolen Elections, Southern Politics, and a City's Coming of Age. By James D. Squires. Times Books/Random House, $25.

title: LIVES;Old Dad
description: Recently, a friend of my grown daughter, Amy, was surprised to learn that she had a sister and asked:

title: Harbor Is a Natural Asset, Not Just an Economic One
description: To the Editor:

title: EARNING IT;Away at Management Camp and Feeling Alone
description: HERE at leadership boot camp, the recruits rise with the dawn, only to give blood for a cholesterol count before they have their continental breakfasts. They are subjected to a "60 Minutes"-style interview in front of TV cameras, and are snooped on by note-taking psychologists peering through one-way windows.

title: SOCCER;Despite Two Talented Additions, Another MetroStars Loss
description: The presence of Tab Ramos and Ruben Dario Hernandez, who made their Major League Soccer debuts, elevated the MetroStars' level of play considerably tonight. But the home team was still unable to post its first victory, losing to the Columbus Crew by 2-0 before a Giants Stadium crowd of 26,416 and falling to 0-3 on the season.

title: FILM VIEW;Adrift, Fleetingly, in Warhol's World
description: GAZING DESPERATELY INTO the gloom, scrunching my 23-year-old features into an expression I hoped would convey the essence of tormented poetic melancholy, I chain-smoked Benson & Hedges cigarettes, took dramatic little gulps of bourbon from a paper cup and fought back imaginary tears.

title: BROADWAY PRODUCERS;Challenging A Newer Breed
description: To the Editor:

title: ATLANTIC CITY;At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week. Tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;A Floundering Community Board Re-Invents Itself
description: Last fall, Community Board 10 in Central Harlem seemed to be approaching meltdown. Absenteeism was rampant. Committees went without a chairman. An important budget meeting failed to draw a quorum. Members were voting on measures they had not read, then changing their minds. Meetings were degenerating into free-for-alls. Finally fed up, the board's chairman, Barbara Askins, resigned.

title: THEATER;Addicted to the Hard Life
description: ANYONE WHO HATES Sir Peter Hall should invite him to spend two weeks beside some idyllic swimming pool, doing nothing but sunbathe and sip champagne. Such a regimen, he says with a shudder, would make him miserable.

title: PLAYING AROUND THE NEIGHBORHOOD: EAST HARLEM;Assembling a Collage of Art Forms
description: ARTISTIC traditions from around the world will come together in the courtyard of El Museo del Barrio in East Harlem next Saturday for Family Day as professional artists lead hands-on workshops for children.

title: New Refugee Conflict Points Up Flaw in Bosnia Pact
description: Hundreds of Muslims were expected to return today to their homes in this shelled-out village, where hundreds of Bosnian Serbs were expected to try to keep them away. Fearing bloodshed, American troops barred cars and buses from entering the area.

title: The Elevator Probe's Downside
description: An investigation into the New York City elevator inspection program has uncovered widespread bribe-taking. This will come as little surprise to most New Yorkers, who have seen similar corruption revealed in the past, involving inspectors who check everything from restaurants to plumbing.

title: Clinton Tapes His Testimony In Fraud Trial of Ex-Partners
description: Sitting in a room in the White House, President Clinton gave videotaped testimony today in a criminal trial involving his former Whitewater business partners, James B. and Susan McDougal.

title: Priest's Death Explained
description: The police said today that an autopsy on a Mexican priest found dead in Jerusalem's holiest church showed that he had died of overeating.

title: In the Capital Of Cyberspace, But Far From Capital Politics
description: He is a "content provider" now, dressed in Microsoft Corporation camouflage of plaid shirt and hiking shoes. The Michael Kinsley who was the leftward half of "Crossfire" on CNN and the mischievous editor of The New Republic seems to have been left to the archives of the East Coast.

title: Essay;Same-Sex Marriage Nears
description: As the legislative session headed toward a midnight close Friday night, opponents of homosexual marriage insisted on a recorded vote. Supporters of gay rights won. Hawaii's state senators voted 15 to 10 against the more conservative House's bill to ban the licensing of marital unions of persons of the same sex.

title: A Civil Servant Guides Congress on the Path to Safety
description: After decades of passing laws governing safety in the workplace, Congress now finds that the shoe is on the other foot.

title: Man Is Charged With Shooting on Campus
description: A 29-year-old New Haven man was charged today with shooting a student at Central Connecticut State University.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12

title: Sports of The Times;What If Superman Falls?
description: THE winningest team in the history of the National Basketball Association is dependent on the well-being of Superman. Or so it often seems. And yesterday there was a great gasp from Chicago Bulls adherents when Michael Jordan, who has aroused suspicions that he is actually from another planet, fell to the floor, grimacing.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Feeling of Spacious Grandeur In a Seldom-Played Symphony New York Philharmonic Avery Fisher Hall

title: Claiming Power To Lead Justice
description: The man from Albany has been pulling rank recently on two guys from New York City, a Brooklyn Criminal Court judge and the Bronx District Attorney. The issues are legal and political, but the stakes go beyond the rewards of victory in a court or an election.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Cranky, Feisty and Addl'd At a Post-Punk Dance Party
description: It's easy to understand what made Shaun Ryder one of England's biggest stars in the late 1980's and early 90's. His band, Happy Mondays, led a wave of post-punk party music from Manchester, simultaneously jolly and cranky. Mr. Ryder personified the English working-class dropout -- idle, resentful, often drug-addled but still feisty -- while the band played every danceable groove it could swipe. Mr. Ryder railed in a bleary, tuneless voice with a thick Manchester accent, barely comprehensible to Americans; the music blithely ignored his recitations of bummers.

title: Trust Is a Casualty of Israeli Attacks
description: Lebanon's Prime Minister said tonight that Israel's 16-day assault on his country had done deep damage to prospects for normal relations between the countries once they reach a peace accord.

title: Patents;For an avid fisherman without the use of his legs, a pontoon boat designed to hold a wheelchair.
description: MIKE HAGGERTY, a farmer in Spalding, Neb., is an avid fisherman who lost the use of his legs after a farm accident 13 years ago. "I fish out of the window of my pickup truck a lot," Mr. Haggerty said. "But there are a lot of good fishing places along the shoreline that you can't get to in a wheelchair."

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Innovations on Internet Deliver News and the Mail
description: Two companies plan to introduce technologies on Monday that demonstrate how rapidly the Internet is evolving and transforming the uses of traditional broadcasting and telecommunications services.

title: Hong Kong Governor, Due in U.S., Is Warily Bullish
description: As Christopher Patten prepares to begin his final year as the territory's last Governor, he will visit the United States this week both to trumpet Hong Kong's successes and future and to outline his concerns about China's takeover of Hong Kong on July 1, 1997.

title: The Little Light Light That Could
description: Light-emitting diodes play a ubiquitous if humble role in today's electronic world. They are the little dots of red or pale green light that indicate that the disk drive is spinning, the VCR is recording or a particular line of a multiline phone is in use.

title: Forest Fire Threatens Los Alamos and Indian Sites
description: A forest fire whipped by wind continued to blacken acre after acre today, threatening ancient Indian artifacts and inching toward Los Alamos National Laboratory property.

title: Freeze in U.S. Aid Hampers New Haitian President's Recovery Effort
description: The final American combat unit withdrew last week, leaving a reduced United Nations presence here. Now the United States has frozen most of its economic aid to Haiti, which until recently was being hailed as one of the Clinton Administration's shining foreign policy triumphs.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : Korean War's Legacy of Frostbite
description: Bitter cold has been a relentless foe to armies throughout the ages  at Valley Forge, at Stalingrad in World War II, in the cold bogs of the Falkland Islands and in the battle of the Chosin Reservoir during the Korean War.

title: Markets Closed in Japan
description: Financial markets were closed here today in observance of a national holiday, Greenery Day. On Friday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 4.93 points, to 22,235.03.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: POP
description: Affairs of the Heart In the French Style Michel Legrand Hunter College Assembly Hall

title: For Union Chief, Tough Challenges
description: From the way he used to rail against "the tired old men" of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the way he once backed Jesse Jackson for President, Jan Pierce always seemed to relish a good fight.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:

title: Boy Held in Sex Attack
description: A 14-year-old boy was arrested yesterday for abducting a 12-year-old girl from her school at gunpoint on Friday and taking her to his house in Brooklyn where he forced her to perform a sex act, the police said.

title: AUTO RACING;A Funny Thing Happened on Way to Andretti's Victory
description: All those drivers who tormented Michael Andretti should have driven by his house here first. Those two big lion statues standing guard at the gate would have sent a warning: Don't try to mess with Andretti's mind, especially when you are about to race at a track in his hometown.

title: San Francisco Papers Said to Be Near Deal
description: The San Francisco Chronicle and The San Francisco Examiner are close to an agreement to shut The Examiner and run a jointly owned morning paper, The San Jose Mercury News has reported.

title: Xerox Is Offering a New Category of Color Printer
description: Hoping to find a color-printing niche with machines that sell for about $200,000 each, the Xerox Corporation has introduced its Docu-color printer, which can transform electronic files into full color pages at a rate of 40 sheets a minute.

title: When 2 Speakers Are Not Enough
description: The idea of bringing the spectacle of cinema into the living room has transformed the consumer electronics industry. High fidelity, as a marketing concept, has substantially given way to home theater. And the magnitude of that shift, several industry managers agree, can be read in the dominating influence of home theater on loudspeaker sales.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;After a Theft, a Sale
description: For two years, Alice Artzt, the classical guitarist, was happy to have Naah Allotey as a live-in nurse for her 85-year-old mother, Harriet, who was bedridden after breaking her neck. Then the family discovered that Ms. Allotey had bilked the elderly woman out of $54,000 in car and credit card payments, run up about $4,000 in overseas phone calls and filled a rented storage locker with appliances, furniture and clothing, much of it illicitly charged, Lieut. Charles Davall, a police spokesman, said last week.

title: Working Class Forages for Cans, Too
description: They start arriving before there is even a suggestion of light in the sky, some rolling their bloated shopping carts west across the spit of bridge that crosses the Harlem River from the Bronx, others hauling swollen garbage bags east along 207th Street from the subway.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Rebels With a Cause And a Video Camera
description: Authority Sucks" is the elegant title of this week's editions of "MTV News Unfiltered," a daily half-hour program made by high schoolers with cameras supplied by MTV and then edited in the famous music-video slash-and-dash style for the benefit of viewers whose attention span could not last through this sentence.

title: Finding Ways to Entice Readers
description: The New York Post began printing a blazing red toll-free number on its front page last week to advertise an ambitious home delivery service that the newspaper hopes will find upscale suburban readers for the urban tabloid newspaper.

title: Technology: CONNECTIONS;On the Web, tuning in to Timothy Leary's last trip, live from his deathbed.
description: BETWEEN April 14 and April 21, according to Timothy Leary's home page on the World Wide Web, his "average daily input of neuro-active drugs" included 50 cigarettes, a joint of marijuana, two lines of cocaine, 12 balloons of nitrous oxide, 0.45 of a cubic centimeter of ketamine and assorted other intoxicants. For Mr. Leary, whose 1960's motto was "tune in, turn on, drop out," this might seem business as usual, except for the sobering "health summary" that precedes the chronicle of his daily drug intake.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Slaves Not in Name But in Horror's Reality
description: WORSE THAN SLAVERY Parchman Farm and the Ordeal of Jim Crow Justice By David M. Oshinsky 306 pages. Free Press. $25.

title: Papers Spend Heavily In a Battle for Readers
description: The New York Post has started putting out a new Sunday edition. The Daily News will soon start full-color printing, with The New York Times following suit next year. Less than a year after the death of New York Newsday, the local newspaper market remains a fiercely competitive battleground for increasingly scarce readers, forcing the papers to spend heavily to maintain, and perhaps increase, circulation.

title: Congressmen Going to Bat For U.S. Computer Maker
description: Congressmen in two districts where the supercomputer maker Cray Research is a major employer have asked the White House and the National Science Foundation to help persuade a Federal weather research laboratory not to purchase a multimillion-dollar Japanese supercomputer.

title: Teacher Broke Rules: Condemn or Hail Her?
description: To the Editor:

title: More in G.O.P. Say Dole's Senate Role Hinders Campaign
description: A small but growing number of influential Republicans, some close to Bob Dole's Presidential campaign, believe that Mr. Dole should distance himself from the Senate -- perhaps even step down as majority leader -- and focus on broader themes that engage the public.

title: Men Accused of Having Sex With Minors
description: The police arrested two Harlem men on Saturday on charges of having sex with two 12-year-old girls the night before, the police said.

title: Wife of Suharto Is Dead
description: Siti Hartinah Suharto, the wife of President Suharto of Indonesia, died today of a heart attack, a spokesman for the President said. She was 72.

title: INSIDE
description: New Data on Sperm Count

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;No, It's Not the Waltons, It's the Knicks
description: Your basketball team, the one held in high regard by, well, you and the coach, is one game away from a potential Eastern Conference semifinal showdown with America's Basketball Team, the Chicago Bulls.

title: Advertising;Advertising agencies make a pitch to politicians and consultants, urging them to clean up their act.
description: IN an innovative initiative to reduce the personal attack and invective in political advertising, the nation's advertising agencies will urge broadcast and print media to assume watchdog duties during this year's election campaign season.

title: Goose and Gander
description: To the Editor:

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Muslim holiday Eid al-Adha, the feast of sacrifice, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today and tomorrow.

title: BASEBALL;Franco Saves Face With Save No. 299
description: It had all the makings of a disaster. A five-run Mets lead entering the bottom of the ninth inning was down to two. The Pirates had the winning run at the plate, and a crowd of 27,706 was rocking Three Rivers Stadium, roaring for the Mets to fold.

title: Libraries Ponder Role In the Digital Age
description: With the turn of the century looming, one of the oldest and most cherished cultural institutions, the library, stands at a crossroads. Librarians all over the world are struggling to cope with new technology that has revolutionized the storing, preserving and disseminating of information and changed the very notion of what a library is.

title: Metro Matters;Old Schools Are Unfixed, New Unbuilt
description: EARLIER this month, Public School 109 in East Harlem had to be evacuated because it shook to its foundations, as if it sat on the San Andreas fault instead of East 99th Street. It trembled because a playground was under construction next door, and that can be a problem for a school 97 years old.

title: Pledged to Mideast Peace and Willing to Fight;Burning the Haystack
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Separate Worlds, Linked Electronically
description: The latest high-tech, on-line concert at the Kitchen took as its point of departure the distant, quiet music of Morton Feldman. It was a strange meeting of minds. Feldman was a composer who looked askance on most forms of technology. He thought the modern world had become far too noisy and complicated, and he lonaed for the lost world of Schubert. "My music is handmade," he once declared. "I'm like a tailor. I make my buttonholes by hand."

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Child Who Exuberantly Finds His Inner Man
description: Forget about watershed musicals for the moment and consider "Big," the bright, shiny, larger-than-life toy of a show that opened last night at the Shubert Theater. It doesn't have a solemn thought in its head, although the thoughts it does have are sometimes primal. It's like the nine-foot teddy bear that participates in one of its glitzy production numbers: a bit awkward at first, but endearingly familiar and, when it dances, so exuberantly gifted that it gives you the helium high of a balloon flight.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;8 Hours Honoring 25 Years Of Artistry
description: The music started at 6 P.M. and stopped at 2 in the morning. In length, that adds up to "Tristan und Isolde" with the first act of "Parsifal" thrown in. James Levine was celebrating his 25th anniversary of conducting at the Metropolitan Opera, and so Saturday night (and Sunday morning) became an operatic party of extravagant proportions. I counted 57 performers, 43 numbers and 3 sets. Cecilia Bartoli, Marilyn Horne, Luciano Pavarotti and a few others didn't make it, but almost everyone else did.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Jordan's Back Is Aching But Bulls Steam Ahead
description: Nothing slowed the Chicago Bulls today. Not a back injury to Michael Jordan, who scored 26 of his 29 points in the first half. Not the ejection of Dennis Rodman, who had to leave the game in the third quarter with two technical fouls. And certainly not the Miami Heat, a team that looked dreadfully overmatched.

title: A Very Small Computer's Big Numbers
description: It might seem to take hubris to enter a new technology market and compete against the likes of Hewlett-Packard, Apple Computer, Sharp Electronics and Motorola. But with little fanfare, Psion P.L.C., a company based in London that specializes in hand-held computers, has grabbed a lead in the $1 billion worldwide market for these $200-to-$600 electronic organizers in the last few years.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about a retired banker in the Bronx omitted his first name. He was Alfred Hunt Howell.

title: Bay of Pigs Report Contains No Dark Secret
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;6 to Join Cycling Hall of Fame
description: The United States Bicycling Hall of Fame was incorporated a decade ago in the home of the Tour of Somerville, the country's oldest road race for cyclists, which will take place Memorial Day for the 52d time. Last week, the Hall of Fame announced its six 1996 inductees, led by Greg Lemond, the three-time winner of the Tour de France and the first American to win cycling's most prestigious event.

title: Regents' Plan Will Hurt Advanced Students
description: To the Editor: The plan by the New York State Board of Regents to raise standards for high school graduation (news article, April 24) continues a double standard.

title: A Little Experiment for David Letterman
description: Starting in June, the Monday showings of "Late Show With David Letterman" will be taped the previous week rather than earlier the same evening.

title: World News Briefs;2 Wounded by Bombs At an Athens Square
description: Two bombs exploded within 10 minutes of each other at a popular Athens square today, slightly wounding two policemen and causing panic among hundreds of people seated at outdoor cafes, the police said.

title: Teacher Broke Rules: Condemn or Hail Her?
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Lifts Ban on Alaskan Oil Exports
description: President Clinton gave formal clearance today for exporting Alaska's North Slope oil, ending a 23-year-old ban. The President also imposed additional safety requirements on tankers hauling the oil.

title: Abroad at Home;Cynics at Work
description: In the spring of 1994 President Clinton was told that President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia planned to get arms from Iran, in violation of the U.N. embargo on the former Yugoslavia, and send most of them on to beleaguered Bosnia. Mr. Clinton decided to express no view on the plan. The arms shipments went forward.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LARAINE PACHECO's phone has been ringing constantly since the indictment on Wednesday of LORRAINE PACHECO, the principal of Public School 192, along with four other district officials, on charges of conspiring to file fraudulent absentee ballots in a 1993 school board election.

title: HORSE RACING;Run Like the Wind and Inherit the Roses
description: Like father, like son.

title: Intentions of Syria's Leader Remain a Big Question Mark
description: The latest fracas in Lebanon found Syria's longtime leader, Hafez al-Assad, back in his familiar role at the center of the Middle East peace equation. But it is a measure of the uncertainty that surrounds him even after a quarter century in power that no one could agree whether he joined in the cease-fire to make peace or to flaunt his veto power.

title: Tokyo Journal;Young Japan Is Dyeing (It's Anything but Natural)
description: If a few space aliens landed in Japan and conducted some scientific research, they might conclude that elderly Japanese have gray hair, middle-aged Japanese have black hair and young Japanese have brown hair.

title: Pledged to Mideast Peace and Willing to Fight;On Embracing Turkey
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Groundbreaker for Toy Store
description: A groundbreaking ceremony is to be held today for what is being billed as the largest Toys 'R' Us store in the country. The 98,000-square-foot store, to be situated next to Ikea, will add 100 year-round jobs to the economically depressed Elizabeth area and 150 more seasonal openings at Christmas, said Michael Paul Miller, the executive vice president of the Paramus-based company. The store will be combined with a Kids 'R' Us and a Babies 'R' Us.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Memorial Day for Workers
description: The state's A.F.L.-C.I.O. will remember those who died in New Jersey workplaces during a Workers Memorial Day rally on the State House steps today. A total of 114 workers died on the job in 1994, the latest year for which totals have been compiled, said Charles Wowkanech, the secretary and treasurer for the state's A.F.L.-C.I.O., which has 980,000 members in the construction, manufacturing and service industries and government.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Marketers Expand Current Agency Ties
description: The Walt Disney Company and Bertelsmann A.G. have expanded their relationships with agencies on their rosters. And a third marketer, British Airways, said it would continue its relationship with its agency for the last year.

title: Scouting Trip Brings Drug Czar No Easy Answers
description: In one of Miami's shabbier neighborhoods, Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey stood talking with a group of women in a treatment program for cocaine addiction at a family health clinic.

title: Joseph Judge, 68, Writer and Editor
description: Joseph Judge, a writer and editor who spent 25 years at National Geographic magazine, died on April 20 at his home in Potomac, Md. He was 68.

title: Find Creative Ways To Counsel Students
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Hearing Set on Tax Bill
description: A proposal that would allow homeowners to deduct their property taxes from their income taxes will receive its first legislative hearing on Wednesday before the Senate's State Government Committee. The hearing will be held in Scotch Plains, the home of Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco, the measure's main sponsor.

title: Seeking to Delay Seizure of Assets, Goetz Is to File for Bankruptcy
description: Enraged by last week's jury award of $43 million against him and terrified that he might lose all his possessions, down to the pet guinea pig and chinchilla he considers his closest companions, Bernhard H. Goetz will file for bankruptcy today, according to his lawyer, Darnay Hoffman.

title: Bond Offerings Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page caption yesterday about a highway construction project in Boston misidentified a thoroughfare in the picture. It was Congress Street, not the Central Artery; the artery, which the project will replace, was not shown.

title: Pledged to Mideast Peace and Willing to Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: Use of the Flag At an Art Show Causes Outrage
description: An estimated 2,500 demonstrators gathered today outside the Phoenix Art Museum to call for the removal of a controversial exhibit that includes an American flag stitched from human flesh and another draped in a toilet.

title: BASEBALL;The Manager as Alchemist: Alou Turns Young Players Into Gold for Expos
description: For the better part of a dozen years, the diamond lay ignored in the corner while less sparkling gems were put in the spotlight. But ultimately that diamond would be salvaged from its obscure location, and now it shines so brightly that others cannot understand what took so long.

title: No Headline
description: When we started, they were nothing but street people. Today, they are borderline poor, working poor, the almost-about-to-be homeless, families in temporary housing. It's amazing that people are relying on cans for things such as rent, electric bills, food." GUY POLHEMUS, who runs a can redemption center in Upper Manhattan. [B1:3.]

title: Mali's Democracy
description: While hardly anybody was watching, the people of Mali were burning some 3,000 firearms in a March ceremony meant to mark the end of a five-year conflict between Tuareg nomad rebels and the Malian Army. These "flames of peace" are a salutary augury for Africa, and a pointed reminder for Washington. Mali has moved without fanfare from 35 years of single-party rule and 23 years of military dictatorship to a multi-party democracy. This feat might be better known if a single high-level American official had troubled in recent years to visit Bamako, Mali's capital.

title: At the Helm of a Media Giant as Spain's Political Wind Shifts toStarboard
description: From his three-story penthouse apartment, complete with swimming pool and just three blocks from the Prado museum, Jesus de Polanco keeps a close watch over his $1 billion media empire.

title: Another Round in Court For a Charismatic Mayor
description: Sitting among members of the City Council at a night meeting last week, Mayor Raul L. Martinez tangled with residents over zoning variances, presented commendations to police officers, and otherwise presided over Hialeah business as he has for most of the last 15 years.

title: India Separatists Say They Killed 15 on Bus
description: Two separatist groups from the violence-torn areas of Kashmir and Punjab took responsibility today for an election-day bus bombing that killed 15 people.

title: World News Briefs;Kidnappers in Germany Escape With $20 Million
description: Using a tape-recording of one abductor's voice and a partial license plate number, the police worked today to track down kidnappers who made off with a $20 million ransom after holding a millionaire captive for a month.

title: Media: PUBLIC RELATIONS;When cutting jobs, don't let the workers read about it in the paper first.
description: THE barrage of criticism that has rained down on executive suites at companies that have laid off workers has led a growing number of corporations to seek public relations help in developing their messages.

title: History in the Air, Nostalgia on the Block
description: To the Editor:

title: Are U.S. Men Less Fertile? Latest Research Says No
description: The news was dire, the possibilities catastrophic. Men the world over, several widely publicized studies reported, are losing sperm, with counts declining drastically over the past few decades. If the trend continues, some researchers warned, there will be no human population in a couple of centuries.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Scoring Spree Overwhelms Thibault
description: Push did come to shove this afternoon at the Molson Center, where the Rangers ended their playoff series against the Canadiens on a killing note by treating Montreal's wisp of a goalie, Jocelyn Thibault, like a slice of Swiss cheese.

title: Go-Between Continues Negotiations to Halt the Freemen Standoff inMontana
description: James (Bo) Gritz, a popular figure in far right circles, returned to the Freemen's compound in Jordan, Mont., today to continue the talks he began on Saturday that he hopes will end the 35-day standoff with Federal agents peacefully.

title: New Pact for Kazak-Russian Oil Pipeline
description: Moving to tap the vast oil resources near the Caspian Sea, Russia, Kazakstan and Oman have agreed on a new accord to build a major oil pipeline.

title: In America;Oasis of Optimism
description: To get to the East Village apartment of Sharon and Ofer Levy you have to climb four flights of stairs so steep they seem to lean backward. The tiny apartment, at the end of a shoulder-width hall, is spotless and cool. The Levys are all welcoming smiles.

title: Conservative School Board Gains Turned Out to Be No Revolution
description: School board elections in New York City had never caused such a ruckus.

title: 2 Shot in Subway
description: Two people were shot in a Manhattan subway station at 8th Avenue and 34th Street last night, the police said.

title: BASEBALL;Rivera Completes 'No-Hitter' In Victory
description: The Yankees' Mariano Rivera has pitched nine hitless innings. But he has stretched them over the course of seven days and three games, so he will not be credited with a no-hitter.

title: HOCKEY;Blue Is the Primary Color as the Rangers Win Series
description: For entertainment and excitement, this was the worst game of a good series, the closest thing to a rout in almost two weeks of tense meetings between two very different teams.

title: Bosnia Hit-Squad Reports Chided as Effort to Halt Aid for Army
description: Opponents of a United States effort to equip and train the Bosnian Army are conspiring to block the program by spreading stories about assassination teams and Iranian troops, Bosnia's delegate to the United Nations said here today.

title: AUSTRALIA GUNMAN KILLS AT LEAST 32
description: A gunman methodically killed at least 32 people at and near a popular tourist site on Sunday. The police captured him today when he bolted in flames from a guest cottage, which he had set afire with three hostages inside.

title: Pledged to Mideast Peace and Willing to Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: Rig Count Rises by 10
description: The number of oil and gas rigs operating nationwide rose by 10 last week, to 757, Baker Hughes Inc. said. The rig count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil and natural gas.

title: BASEBALL;Next Start Schedulad For a Relieved Cone
description: David Cone's degree of concern went up and down like a roller coaster late last week when, in the course of two days, the right-hander went from the precaution of skipping a start to lying in a hospital bed wondering if he would be baseball's next J. R. Richard.

title: Spaniard Wins Pritzker Prize
description: Rafael Moneo, a Spanish architect who has fashioned a richly diverse body of work from the basic principles of modern design, has been awarded the Pritzker Architecture Prize for 1996.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When they were children in the 1930's, the grandnephews and grandnieces of Gov. Herbert H. Lehman of New York would often get together at his home in Purchase. "We all lived nearby and saw him frequently," JOHN L. LOEB JR., the former ambassador to Denmark, said the other day. "He was our hero and we were a tremendously close family."

title: Arson Fire Guts a Church
description: A fire that gutted a 114-year-old predominantly black church has been ruled an arson, the authorities said this weekend.

title: J. J. O'Connor, 65, Founder Of Marketing Academy, Dies
description: James Joseph O'Connor, who created the nation's first Academy of Food Marketing in 1960 and helped to develop nutrition programs in Latin America and India, died on April 19 at Arlington Hospital in Virginia. He was 65 and lived in Arlington.

title: Up From Affirmative Action
description: The debate over affirmative action gained momentum last week when the United States Supreme Court refused to block a Mississippi mandate that all of the state's universities, including its three traditionally black institutions, must have the same admission standards. Coming on the heels of a Federal appeals court ruling against race-based preferences at the University of Texas Law School, the decision has led some to fear that blacks will be shut out of higher education.

title: POP REVIEW;With Long False Fingernails, Sharp, Realistic and Strong
description: In recent years, there have been many concerts at the Beacon Theater at which long lines at the ticket pickup window have kept fans waiting outside as the performance began. There have also been many shows at which ushers too proud to whisper have disrupted songs as they've moved people in and out of seats. But before this weekend, there hadn't been a show at the Beacon that this critic has seen, not even those of Bob Dylan or Bruce Springsteen, at which nearly every person stood through the entire concert, hanging on to the singer's every word and cheering loudly for almost every other lyric and line of dialogue. That was the case, however, when Ani DiFranco performed on Friday night at the theater, demonstrating the power of music to bring a community together and mobilize it to thought and, perhaps in some cases, action.

title: Equity and Debt Offerings Set This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: A Local Mirror of the Big-Government Debate;Democrats Hope to Reclaim New Jersey Seat Lost in the 1994 Gingrich Wave
description: As he drove his long, blue, four-door sedan to an urgent news conference recently, Mayor William J. Pascrell Jr. took a moment to boast of his lean approach to government.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Luring Back the Tourists
description: After years of decline as a seashore destination, Wildwood and its barrier-island neighbors, North Wildwood and Wildwood Crest, are trying to win back visitors with a $600,000 regional television advertising campaign whose musical motif is a calypsolike jingle called "Welcome to Our Island."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;A Vote on School Standards
description: The State Board of Education is scheduled to vote on Wednesday on basic standards for what New Jersey schoolchildren should be taught. The Whitman administration has said that the core curriculum standards would enable the state to establish per-pupil costs for every district as it sought to comply with an order from the New Jersey Supreme Court requiring parity between poor districts and richer ones.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week.

title: Justice Dept. Vows Scrutiny Of Bell Deals
description: Confronted by two giant telephone mergers, including the $22.1 billion deal proposed by the Nynex Corporation and the Bell Atlantic Corporation, the Justice Department plans to push for tough new rules aimed at insuring vigorous competition in local telephone markets.

title: World News Briefs;U.S. to Fight Ebola In Philippine Monkeys
description: American scientists say they will set up a laboratory to survey primates in the Philippines to help prevent monkeys infected with the deadly Ebola virus from being exported to the United States.

title: Jesus Revisionists Draw the Ire of 'a Jolly Elf'
description: He is an unlikely polemicist, this round-faced man with curly white hair who admits that former students sometimes recall him as "a jolly elf" and whose office wall bears the sign "I keep trying to lose weight, but it keeps finding me."

title: Kenneth Stark, 68; Lawyer Supported Community Services
description: Kenneth M. Stark, a Manhattan real estate lawyer who was active in community services on the Lower East Side, particularly those for the homeless and mentally disturbed, died on Wednesday at his second home, in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 68 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Sports of The Times;For Messier, the Cup Turns Into a Crusade
description: PUT him in armor and on a horse, give him a lance, and his baldish chiseled head would belong on a medieval tapestry of the crusades. And for Mark Messier, the Stanley Cup is his crusade.

title: Mr. Clinton's Economic Scorecard
description: The week after the White House settled its budget squabbles with Congress is a good time to assess President Clinton's stewardship of the economy. He came into office promising to bring a consensus style of policy-making to the White House -- no longer would a budget director like Richard Darman, who served under President Bush, bully everyone in sight. He also promised to direct Federal spending away from wasteful programs and toward future-looking investments in training people.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Every Style and Emotion A Joy, but Finally Sadness
description: Just about evepy kind of dance was represented in "Keeping Dance Alive," a fast-paced and enjoyable program on Saturday night at the Steps Studio on the Upper West Side of Manhattan to raise money for Dancers Responding to AIDS. The evening, produced by the studio, got off to a sultry start with a staging by Ann Reinking of the "All That Jazz" number by Bob Fosse from "Chicago," performed by Bebe Neuwirth and students from Steps. Laurie Kanyok tossed hersalf and her blond curls in Michele Assaf's "You Put a Move on My Heart." And Christian Holder sizzled his way through "Contrabajissimo," a tightly coiled tango solo by Margo Sappington.

title: AUTO RACING;Crashes Mar Winston Select
description: Bill Elliott fractured his left thigh bone in one of several crashes today during the Winston Select 500 at Talladega Superspeedway. Elliott's Ford Thunderbird went airborne twice after spinning coming out of Turn 2 on Lap 78. Elliott was conscious when airlifted from the infield care center to Birmingham for surgery.

title: BASEBALL;Schott Sent Recycled Flowers
description: A basket of flowers that the Cincinnati Reds' owner, Marge Schott, sent to umpires in sympathy over John McSherry's death was recycled, The Dayton Daily News reported today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A.A.R.P. Plans to License Managed-Care Health Plans In a move expected to prompt millions of elderly Americans to join managed health plans, the American Association of Retired Persons will begin licensing its name to health-maintenance organizations across the country later this year.

title: Lynn O'Donnell, 43, Producer Of the Documentary 'Crumb'
description: Lynn O'Donnell, the producer of the documentary film "Crumb," died in San Francisco on April 17. She was 43. The cause was ovarian cancer, said her husband, Lawrence Wilkinson.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Fathers and Sons As Partners in Music
description: Fathers, sons and reflections on romance held the stage at two concerts over the weekend. On Friday night at Town Hall, the pianist Ellis Marsalis played gentle duets with his son Branford on saxophones. And on Saturday night at the Beacon Theater, the rhythm-and-blues singer Gerald Levert teamed up with his father, Eddie Levert Sr. of the O'Jays.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Jets Have Elected to Receive Some New Talent
description: The quarterback today used words like "very powerful, huge stride," and the coach described "an exciting kid -- you get the ball to him and he explodes."

title: IN PERFORMANCE: THEATER
description: Another Charming Irishman Who Happened to Write Well 'Bein' With Behan' Irish Repertory Theater

title: Regents' Plan Will Hurt Advanced Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about the creator of the nation's first Academy of Food Marketing misstated his first name. He was James Joseph O'Connor. It also misspelled his wife's maiden name. She is Barbara Abell O'Connor. And it omitted one of Mr. O'Connor's sons, Kevin J. O'Connor of Houston. A corrected obituary appears on page B7.

title: A.A.R.P. Will License Its Name To Managed Health Care Plans
description: In a move that could prompt millions of older Americans to join managed health plans, the American Association of Retired Persons will begin licensing its name to health maintenance organizations across the country later this year.

title: CHRONICLE
description: All over town this month, awards for meritorious accomplishment are being given out. At tonight's 20th anniversary celebration of the Brookdale Center on Aging of Hunter College, some 380 people will gather at Tavern on the Green to see BEVERLY SILLS give JACOB REINGOLD, the former executive vice president of the Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale, the Hunter College President's Award.

title: U.S. TO AID ISRAEL WITH TECHNOLOGY AGAINST ATTACKS
description: The Clinton Administration announced today that it would help Israel develop a weapons-defense system to shield the country both from ballistic missiles and from the types of small rockets that Lebanese guerrillas have rained down on northern Israel in recent weeks.

title: Bridge
description: There is an obscure symmetry about the diagramed deal, and readers should see if they can spot it before reading on.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Wall Street Journal Bets Internet Readers Will Pay a Fee
description: The Wall Street Journal will begin publishing on the World Wide Web today, joining hundreds of newspapers that have already made the jump on line. But The Journal is nearly alone in betting that Internet users will pay an annual subscription fee for access.

title: Pledged to Mideast Peace and Willing to Fight;On Embracing Turkey
description: To the Editor:

title: HORSE RACING;Caution for Unbridled's Song
description: Although the handlers of Unbridled's Song believe the bruise to the inside heel of his left front foot will not compromise his performance in Saturday's Kentucky Derby, they will continue to treat the foot cautiously.

title: Taking In the Sites;Dining Out in Manhattan: How to See and Be Seen
description: Train a camcorder on just about anything, feed the contents into a Web server and shovel the results onto a site on the World Wide Web. Computer literates in droves have decided that this is a cool idea and have acted on the impulse. So now there are thousands of sites displaying video images that range from street corners to sunsets, from fishbowls to toilet bowls.

title: Companies Convicted of Negligence in Puerto Rico Oil Spill
description: A Federal jury in Puerto Rico has found three companies controlled by a family once accused of being the worst polluter of New York Harbor guilty of criminal negligence in a 1994 barge accident that caused a spill of heavy oil on a three-mile stretch of beach in the heart of the island's tourist area.

title: Antiterrorism Law Gives Immigrants No Second Chances
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: In recent weeks KITTY CARLISLE HART has been showered with one tribute after another to mark the end of her 25 years with the New York State Council on the Arts, 20 of them as its chairwoman. But none will have quite the permanence of the honor that will be bestowed on her today. The theater in the futuristic structure in Albany known as The Egg ip being formally named for her by Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: Microsoft Offering News Without Charge on Internet
description: The Microsoft Corporation has made headlines countless times in the last 20 years, but now it wants to make headlines in a different way -- as a global news provider on the World Wide Web.

title: BASKETBALL;High School Star Outjumps Camby Into the N.B.A.
description: Marcus Camby, the consensus national college player of the year, and Kobe Bryant, one of the most highly recruited high school players in the nation, today joined the lengthening list of underclassmen to announce their intentions to play in the National Basketball Association.

title: Pipe Bomb Explodes at City Hall in Spokane
description: A pipe bomb packed with three-inch nails exploded in a doorway of Spokane City Hall before dawn this morning, the police said. The building was unoccupied, and no one was injured.

title: Paris Journal;Land of Descartes Under the Spell of Druids?
description: The French see themselves as a people who appreciate method and logic. Their teen-agers are taught logic and philosophy in school. Intricate discourse fills as much television time as any national sport. And this year the country is making a fuss over Rene Descartes, France's emblem of rational thought, who was born 400 years ago.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Pakistan Premier Blames 'Foreigners' for Bombing
description: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto blamed foreigners for a bombing that killed 40 people on a crowded bus on Sunday and promised that those responsible would not go unpunished.

title: California's Governor Joins G.O.P. Abortion-Plank Foes
description: In a new threat to party unity, Gov. Pete Wilson of California today joined his counterparts from New York and New Jersey in vowing to work to remove an anti-abortion plank in the party's platform at the Republican convention this summer.

title: Dance Notes
description: Tapping in Harlem

title: Trump's Blinding Light
description: To the Editor:

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Absence of Buying by Japan Weakens Dollar Against Yen
description: The dollar fell against the yen yesterday, hurt by speculation that the Bank of Japan might soon raise interest rates.

title: POLITICS: HOUSING;Dole Calls Public Housing One of 'Last Bastions of Socialism'
description: Senator Bob Dole called today for an end to Government-assisted housing programs, terming public housing "one of the last bastions of socialism in the world" and attacking the Clinton Administration for regulatory excess that he likened to the "thought police."

title: U.S. Defeated In Its Appeal Of Trade Case
description: The United States lost its final appeal today in the first major case brought before the newly created World Trade Organization. A three-judge panel ruled that regulations issued under the Clean Air Act discriminated against foreign oil refiners.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Eritrea: African Success Story Being Written
description: On the outskirts of this lovely Italianate capital, the Government recently built an unusual steel plant. There is no iron ore nearby. Instead, former rebel soldiers are melting down the Ethiopian tanks once used to crush them and turning them into construction girders.

title: Censorship in Cyberspace
description: Congress acted without thinking when it decided three months ago to censor the growing web of computer networks in the name of protecting children. It held no hearings and made no effort to learn how the Internet actually works. Had it done so, it would have discovered that the Communications Decency Act was an unconstitutional and wholly unnecessary infringement on free speech.

title: Man Is Held in S.I. Girl's Death
description: For two weeks, relatives and friends of a high school freshman on Staten Island had been mystified by her death, wondering who would break into her home to kill the girl, who was known as a teen-ager active in church activities.

title: Top Court Hears Arguments On Confinement of Rapist
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether the state overstepped its authority in committing a rapist to a psychiatric hospital months after he finished his prison term.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BOYD GAMING TO ACQUIRE PAR-A-DICE GAMING
description: The Boyd Gaming Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the Par-a-Dice Gaming Corporation for $163 million in cash and the assumption of $12 million of debt. Par-A-Dice owns the Par-A-Dice riverboat casino in East Peoria, Ill. Boyd Gaming said it valued the riverboat and land-based assets and operation at $155 million. Boyd is also acquiring an adjacent 204-room hotel and a vacant potential gaming site in Missouri, which the company valued at $20 million. Shares of Boyd Gaming, based in Las Vegas, Nev., rose 50 cents, to $14.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Louisiana's Best-Kept Folk Secret
description: It's the Other Festival, the David to the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival's Goliath. The Festival International de Louisiane here is exactly what the Jazz and Heritage Festival was 00 years ago: adventurous, comfy and barely known outside its boundaries. It is perhaps the best unknown folk music festival in the United States, and one with an international mandate. It comes with lots of dance drive and a bit of ideology. And it's all free, every drop of it.

title: Ledger for Liberia's War: Profit(eering) and Loss
description: In the arctic cold of the Liberian faction leader Charles Taylor's air-conditioned living room, a senior aide sought to counter the depictions of bloodshed and anarchy that engulfed this city recently.

title: POLITICAL BRIEFS;THE CAMPAIGNS FOR CONGRESS
description: Texas Newcomer Intends To Keep it Simple

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Jordan Is Fine; Rodman Is a Worry
description: Fifteen hours after being bent over in pain from back spasms during the Bulls-Heat game on Sunday, MICHAEL JORDAN walked into the Chicago Bulls' headquarters in Deerfield, Ill., yesterday with confidence that he'll be ready for the next game.

title: Executive Changes
description: FUJITSU LTD., Milpitas, Calif., named George Everhart president of its new U.S. personal computer unit.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Banner Days for Ink-Jet Printers
description: COLOR ink-jet printers keep getting better and better. Just when you think they have run out of tricks, a new model comes along and pulls a banner out of its paper tray. Not to mention a mouse.

title: Chess
description: If you want to win one of the big Swiss-system tournaments, you have to press like crazy to win games because the field is sure to be stocked with grandmasters hungry for prize money.

title: Affirmative Action as Long as We Need It
description: To the Editor:

title: Fine-Tuning Images of Brain Activity
description: Scientists studying the activity of the living brain with widely used new imaging techniques have been missing some of the earliest steps in brain activity because those changes are subtle and are masked by reactions that happen seconds later, Israeli scientists say.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Source Media Inc., Dallas, to Wunderman Cato Johnson, New York, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., to handle marketing communications for a new interactive cable television channel. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $20 million. Fetzer Vineyards, Hopland, Calif., a unit of the Brown-Forman Corp., to Gardner, Geary, Coll & Young, San Francisco, to handle advertising for the wine marketer, previously at Carmichael Lynch, Minneapolis, which continues to handle other Brown-Forman wine brands like Korbel champagne. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million.

title: Peres and Arafat, Closer Peace Partners, May Meet in U.S. Today
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, is following the Israeli Prime Minister, Shimon Peres, to Washington, and the two men, more than ever partners in a fragile peace effort, are expected to meet here on Tuesday, Israeli officials said today.

title: Sports of The Times;Van Gundy and His Trap Defense
description: A MAN who has "interim" stamped onto the little white paper sticking out of his fortune cookie, if not in the actual print of his coach's contract, must operate from the position that nothing is over until it's over. Thus Jeff Van Gundy, one victory away from steering the Knicks to their rightful destiny, the second round, isn't about to let himself fall into the 2-0 complacency trap, especially after having once experienced a great playoff escape from 0-2.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Time Warner Purchase
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that its Southern Progress Corporation unit had bought Weight Watchers magazine from the H. J. Heinz Company. The price was not disclosed. Southern Progress will not be involved with the Weight Watchers weight-loss centers or with other operations of Weight Watchers International. Nor will it be involved with the Weight Watchers Food Company, another Heinz unit. Weight Watchers magazine has a circulation of one million and readership of five million. It has editions for North America, Italy, Australia and Britain.

title: David Petersen, 54, Pioneer Of Financial Plans for the Ill
description: David D. Petersen, one of the country's leading experts on financial planning for the seriously ill, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. Mr. Petersen, who lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, was 54.

title: Jordan Defendant Could Face Death
description: A man who pleaded guilty in the slaying of Michael Jordan's father could still face the death penalty despite his testimony that sent his lifelong friend to prison for the crime, a judge ruled today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NATIONSBANK AGREES TO BUY TAC BANCSHARES
description: The Nationsbank Corporation agreed yesterday to buy TAC Bancshares Inc., parent of Chase Federal Bank, for $280 million in cash. Nationsbank, based in Charlotte, N.C., said the acquisition would increase its presence in Florida with the addition of $2.8 billion in assets and $2 billion in deposits. Chase Federal, based in Miami, has 34 branches in southern Florida. The deal values Chase Federal stock at $5.24 a share, below its closing price Friday of $7.25 a share. Chase Federal's stock was down $2.25, to $5 yesterday. Nationsbank stock was down 75 cents, to $79 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Cal Releases Fowlkes
description: The sophomore forward Tremaine Fowlkes has been released from his basketball scholarship by the University of California, the school announced yesterday. Cal's athletic department earlier this month denied Fowlkes's request to be released and he appealed the ruling.

title: BASEBALL;300th Save For Franco Is a Beauty
description: Twelve years to the day from his first major league save, John Franco reached another milestone last night, becoming the first left-hander in major league history to notch his 300th. With his third save in three nights, the 35-year-old closer also helped the Mets to some milestones: a 3-2 victory over the first-place Montreal Expos, and their first three-game winning streak of the season.

title: ON PRO FOOTBALL;Tried, but Not True: How Jets Failed
description: This was the 1992 draft book on Johnny Mitchell: great athlete, a ton of talent, only 20, a junior, immature, may need time to develop maturity.

title: U.S. Loses Trade Case
description: The United States has lost a case brought before the World Trade Organization in a decision that is expected to fuel a politcal debate.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Visions of the Alumni, Brought to Life by Their Successors
description: The dance division of the State University College here has much to celebrate. Last May, the 20th class of dance majors graduated from the college. This fall, the entire college will celebrate its 25th anniversary.

title: A Zeffirelli 'Carmen'
description: The Metropolitan Opera has engaged Franco Zeffirelli to direct and design its new production of Bizet's "Carmen," which is to open on Oct. 31. The team that had been announced -- Liliana Cavani, director, and Dante Ferretti, set designer -- has withdrawn from the production because of artistic differences with the Met. The casting for the production is unaffected by the change. It includes Waltraud Meier in the title role, Angela Gheorghiu as Micaela, Placido Domingo as Don Jose and Sergei Leiferkus as Escamillo.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BWAY CORPORATION TO ADD DAVIES CAN UNIT
description: The BWAY Corporation agreed yesterday to purchase most of the assets of the Crown Cork and Seal Company's Davies paint and can division for $43.7 million. BWAY, an Atlanta-based maker of steel containers, also agreed to form an alliance with the Philadelphia-based Crown Cork to distribute paint and cans in Canada. The addition of Davies will increase BWAY's revenue of $250 million by about 20 percent, the company said. Shares of BWAY rose $1.75, to $16.125, and Crown Cork and Seal edged up 25 cents, to $46.625.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;MCA Sues Viacom, Saying New Channel Violates Their USA Network Partnership
description: After months of haggling over their joint ownership of the USA Network on cable, MCA Inc. sued Viacom Inc. yesterday, accusing it of violating their contract by starting a new cable channel, Nick at Nite's TV Land.

title: Findings on Breast Cancer Have Only Complicated the Puzzle
description: SIX years ago, when researchers first reported the existence of a gene that could predispose a woman to breast cancer, the hope among the public and perhaps even some scientists was that the discovery would provide answers that would be black and white. A woman would be able to take a test and find out that either she had the bad gene or she didn't. She would get cancer or she wouldn't. Granted, there would not be much she could do about it, but surely some new means of prevention or treatment could not be far behind the discovery of the gene.

title: Bob Grant Returns
description: Bob Grant, the outspoken radio talk show host dismissed by WABC-AM, returned to the airwaves yesterday, this time on WOR-AM. While Mr. Grant did not temper his commentary, there were signs that he would find himself watched more closely: one advertiser canceled its ads on the station, and the Rev. Al Sharpton protested outside WOR's studios.

title: 3 Muslims In Bosnia Die Going Home
description: Three Muslim refugees were killed today and dozens were wounded in several angry confrontations with mobs of Serbs. The Muslims were trying to return to homes they had not seen since the war.

title: On Abortion, Will Dole Respect Rule of Law?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;LLOYD'S TO DELAY BEFORE SEIZING U.S. ASSETS
description: Lloyd's of London agreed yesterday to wait another month before attempting to seize assets from 2,700 United States investors, some of whom face financial ruin after huge losses at the British insurance market. Lloyd's also won greater protection from state regulators for its $20 billion bank accounts, used to pay claims in the United States. Several states have attempted to seize some of those funds to repay investors. Nine states have sued Lloyd's, contending that it defrauded the investors by recruiting them to invest in Lloyd's without adequately informing them of the risks. Lloyd's, which denies the charges, has accused some state regulators of bringing lawsuits that would tie up crucial bank accounts and threaten the insurance market.

title: Rowland Increases The Salaries Of Top Aides
description: Gov. John G. Rowland has given raises to three top aides while opposing an arbitrated pay increase for state court workers and threatening to veto a proposed increase in the state's minimum wage.

title: With Sharp Exchange, Supreme Court Refuses to Hear Case ReopeningAbortion Issue
description: Although nearly four years have passed since the Supreme Court narrowly reaffirmed the status of abortion as a constitutional right, an action -- or, more accurately, a nonaction -- by the Court in an abortion case today demonstrated how highly charged the issue remains for the Justices.

title: ON HOCKEY;Rangers' Next Act Stars Penguins
description: The Rangers' six-game triumph over Montreal was the glamour match of the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs. Their second-round meeting with the Pitttsburgh Penguins offers even better marquee value, with mega-stars, major themes and intriguing subplots at all roster levels.

title: Australia Gunman Called a Loner With a Mental History
description: Neighbors say he slept by day, prowled by night, threatened visitors with guns and nonchalantly cut the grass minutes after being told of his father's drowning.

title: Court Overturns Damage Award In Downing of Korean Airliner
description: A Federal appeals court in Ohio today overturned a judgment that had awarded about $15 million to the relatives of five people who were killed in the 1983 downing of a Korean Airlines jetliner, and experts said the decision might be applied to about two dozen cases still pending 13 years after the incident.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Boeing Reports Earnings Drop After 1995 Machinists' Strike
