description: The Boeing Company reported a 34 percent drop in earnings yesterday for the first quarter, reflecting fewer commercial aircraft deliveries as a result of the 10-week machinists' strike in late 1995.

title: BASEBALL;The Labor Talks Go Quietly And Slowly
description: Baseball's labor representatives can have an equally difficult time making progress in their effort to negotiate a new collective bargaining agreement whether they are in the public eye or in private offices. Negotiators proved that again yesterday in the latest sessions of the low-profile phase of their talks.

title: India's Epic Election
description: India reaffirms its faith in democracy with national elections that began over the weekend. It is an occasion to celebrate. No other democracy is so large and so diverse. Despite the Government's suspension of liberties in the mid-1970's, India retains a belief that politics and government can overcome violence and factionalism.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: AUTO RACING;Elliott Undergoes Surgery
description: BILL ELLIOTT underwent successful surgery in Birmingham, Ala., yesterday to repair a broken left femur he suffered in a crash-marred Winston Select 500 Nascar race Sunday at Talladega, Ala. "Elliott's leg should heal satisfactorily without any problems," Dr. JAMES ANDREWS said. (AP)

title: INSIDE
description: Sperm Protein Dispute

title: Mother Fatally Beat Girl, 3
description: A 26-year-old Brooklyn woman pleaded guilty yesterday to second-degree murder in the beating death of her 3-year-old daughter.

title: 3 Big California Utilities to Buy Power Competitively
description: California electricity customers would benefit from the institution of a pool that would buy low-cost power from utilities throughout the West, under a proposal announced yesterday by the state's utilities.

title: Resolved: To Be a Network, Not a Channel
description: Asked to name a popular cable network, most viewers would tick off CNN, ESPN or Nickelodeon. Their very specific types of programming -- news, sports and children's shows, respectively -- give each a clear public identity.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Holloway Chooses Seton Hall
description: SHAHEEN HOLLOWAY of St. Patrick's in Elizabeth, N.J., one of the nation's most highly recruited point guards, announced last night that he had made a verbal commitment to attend Seton Hall next season.

title: Freeman Depended on Subsidies
description: Striding to the edge of Ralph E. Clark's ranch here recently, a Freeman in a cowboy hat nailed to a fence post a manifesto denouncing the Federal Government as a "corporate prostitute."

title: Girls Aren't Goldfish
description: To the Editor:

title: Bob Grant Is Back on the Air, Picking Up Where He Left Off
description: At 4:02 P.M., he put on his half-frame reading glasses. At 4:03, he sipped some coffee. At 4:04, he fiddled with his earphone. At 4:06, he leaned toward the microphone, practically shouting his signature opening line, "And let's be heard."

title: Where Men's Wear Strikes a Fearless Pose
description: A regular ritual at men's fashion magazines is the tense moment when the editorial director tells the staff he dislikes a hyper-edgy fashion shoot.

title: Detroit Man Guilty of Murder In Death After Bridge Dispute
description: Eight months ago, Martell Welch Jr. stood on a bridge over the Detroit River before a crowd of late-night revelers and beat a woman so severely that she jumped into the dark waters to escape him. She could not swim. Today, a jury found him guilty of second-degree murder in her drowning death.

title: Eerie Quiet of Frogs and Toads Isn't Part of a Normal Cycle, StudySays
description: EIGHTY years ago, the wilderness in and around Yosemite National Park was rife with the trilling, croaking songs of frogs and toads, but no longer, according to a new study.

title: PRESIDENT DECIDES U.S. WILL SOON SELL OIL FROM RESERVES
description: In an effort to stem an election-year surge in gasoline prices, President Clinton announced today that the Government would seek to bring them down by selling about 12 million barrels of oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve.

title: Barnard College Clerical Workers' Strike Goes On Despite FlaggingSupport
description: As 150 clerical workers reach the 20-day mark in their strike against Barnard College, the exuberance they once showed is clearly flagging.

title: Thousands of Christian Youths Gather in Washington to Celebrate Their Faith
description: Wearing T-shirts and buttons proclaiming their faith, carrying backpacks of cookies and blankets, thousands of evangelical Christian young people spread over the Mall today to celebrate Jesus.

title: New Era Is Promised For Optical Telescopes
description: MIGHT it be possible for an observer on Earth to discern something no thicker than a pencil on the surface of the Moon? Astronomers specializing in a burgeoning field of physics called optical interferometry believe so.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Major League Soccer

title: They're Not Just 'Secretaries' Anymore
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;ICO Global Selects WPP Group
description: ICO Global Communications Ltd., a telecommunications company in London, said yesterday that it had named the WPP Group in London to handle all aspects of its marketing communications. The billings were not disclosed. One WPP unit, the J. Walter Thompson Company, will handle advertising, while a second, Hill & Knowlton, will handle public relations. Further details about WPP's work for ICO, which will also involve units like G Force Communications, Research International and Sampson Tyrrell, are to be discussed at a news conference on Thursday. ICO, which was started by Inmarsat, the international organization that offers marine telephone service, plans to offer voice, data, fax and paging services by 2000.

title: Two Child Welfare Employees Are Suspended in Abuse Death
description: Five months after Elisa Izquierdo's beating death created a flurry of headlines and finger-pointing, the Giuliani administration yesterday moved to dismiss the caseworker and supervisor in charge of the 6-year-old girl's case, the first such disciplinary action ever against city child welfare employees.

title: Company Hid Data In City Contract Bid
description: A company in line for a $31 million city contract to maintain firehouses concealed from New York City officials its history of underpaying workers, and did not let on that a major subcontractor for the job is barred from operating in the state, records show. Either problem could have disqualified the company.

title: U.S. Strains With China: 1 Exception
description: Despite their strained relations, the United States and China have embarked on a program of environmental cooperation to address problems like rapid urbanization, pollution from energy consumption and the changing agricultural patterns of an increasingly prosperous population.

title: In Sperm Race, 2 of 3 Proteins Are Ringers
description: FOR decades, biologists have been searching for a crucial protein on the heads of sperm that allows them to fertilize eggs. The protein is of more than academic interest because researchers believe that its discovery could lead to new contraceptives and, not incidentally, great riches for themselves and their universities.

title: Reforming New York City Schools
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has urged that school principals be stripped of their tenured job security and that local school boards lose their power to hire and fire. Both reforms are vital to the improvement of New York City's schools. Principals are the crucial force in determining whether a school succeeds or fails. Those who perform poorly must be ousted, not held in place by an outmoded tenure system. School boards, meanwhile, have too often used their hiring powers for patronage and, in some cases, graft. They must be reined in and refocused on education issues. Gov. George Pataki and legislative leaders need to work hard to make both reforms happen.

title: Market Place;Rockwell wants to shed military businesses, but only at top prices.
description: THE cold war is over, Pentagon spending on new weapons is tumbling -- and the military contractors are rolling in money. How's that?

title: Federal Charges for Suspects in Officer's Death
description: Three men facing state charges in the March killing of a police officer in the Bronx were indicted yesterday on Federal charges that they conducted a series of armed robberies as part of a violent gang known as the Park Avenue Boys.

title: Two Rivals Negotiating Slate In an Effort to Defeat Yeltsin
description: In a bid to compete with the rebounding re-election campaign of President Boris N. Yeltsin, two major rival candidates, a Harvard-trained economist and a nationalist general, said today that they were negotiating an improbable political alliance.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Quarterly Profit Down At Rhone-Poulenc
description: Rhone-Poulenc S.A., France's biggest chemical company, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit fell 13.5 percent, because of higher interest payments and charges related to the integration of the British drug company Fisons P.L.C. Net income fell to 633 million French francs, or $123 million, from 732 million francs in the corresponding period last year. Operating income fell to 1.8 billion francs from 2.1 billion francs.

title: At Kennedy Auction, Profane, Not Sacred
description: To the Editor:

title: Illuminating How Bodies Are Built for Sociability
description: THE most vicious and mulish winter in memory finally behind us, let us now praise gentleness, in temperature and temperament alike. For as much as people must compete for status or global markets, they need sociability, affection, love. These are not options in life, or sentimental trimmings; they are part of the species survival kit.

title: Much Bluster Over 90 Cents
description: As a political matter, the issue of raising the minimum wage is relatively straightforward, like mathematics. As an economics question, it is much more subjective, like, say, religion.

title: POP REVIEW;Borrowed Songs, With Exuberance
description: It isn't always easy to separate Van Morrison the artist from Van Morrison the crank. But on Sunday night at the Supper Club, the first of three nights of a rare club engagement, the division was clear. The artist sang two sets; the crank arrived for a set of encores.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Book parties are usually homages to the author, but LETTY COTTIN POGREBIN likes to turn the tables. On Sunday, at a party given for her by PHYLLIS WENDER, her literary agent, she paid tribute to each of the 45 women in the room.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Two Die in Plane Crash
description: A man and woman from East Windsor, N.J., were killed yesterday afternoon when their single-engine plane crashed in a rural area of New York, authorities said.

title: HORSE RACING;The Trainer Who Came in From the Cold
description: As he came charging out of the mist this morning at Churchill Downs, the gray colt Skip Away looked like a ghost, which figures, considering he is trained by someone who is used to working in the shadows.

title: Gore Urges Cable Industry to Take On the Bells
description: The cable television industry is picking up some friends in high places, just when it needs them most.

title: Ex-Director of C.I.A. Disappears While Canoeing on Choppy River
description: William E. Colby, the spymaster who led the Central Intelligence Agency through its worst days in the mid-1970's, was missing and presumed dead today after disappearing while on a solo canoe trip in rough waters, the authorities said.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;State Park Funds Restored
description: Following a public outcry, the State Department of Environmental Protection has restored almost all the $800,000 in budget cuts that would have led to reduced hours at state parks and historic sites, Commissioner Robert W. Shinn told a legislative committee yesterday.

title: For Kohl, British Beef Is Edible, but Not Worth a Political Stew
description: The German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, wouldn't touch the British beef controversy with a 10-foot pole, but he didn't mind digging in with a fork and knife today.

title: Winds Strengthen Forest Fire in New Mexico
description: Formed from the hardened ash of ancient volcanoes, the Pajarito Plateau in northwestern New Mexico is a land forged by fire. This week ashes rained down on the area again as firefighters fought flames that were touched off by a smoldering campfire and that are threatening the Los Alamos National Laboratory and Bandelier National Monument, home of some of New Mexico's most impressive Anasazi ruins.

title: Kansan Drove Woman to Bronx After Killing Her, the Police Say
description: After driving all the way from Kansas with his girlfriend's corpse by his side, a man surrendered at a Bronx police station house Sunday night and confessed to stabbing the woman to death, the police said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;METROMEDIA CANCELS ALLIANCE ACQUISITION
description: Metromedia International Group Inc. called off its $360 million purchase of Alliance Entertainment Inc. yesterday, one month after Alliance warned that its first-quarter revenue would not meet expectations. Alliance had said that it expected first-quarter revenue of $175 million, less than estimates of $191 million. Metromedia, the media company controlled by investor John W. Kluge, agreed in November to acquire Alliance, a New York-based distributor of compact disks and cassettes, for $12 worth of its stock for each Alliance share, plus warrants. It revised the stock portion to seven-tenths share of Metromedia for each Alliance share in December.

title: G.E. Seen in Talks To Purchase Space In Rockefeller Center
description: The General Electric Corporation is in talks with an investment group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company to buy the 1.3 million square feet of space that G.E. leases in Rockefeller Center, people familiar with the discussions said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Daily Briefing column in New Jersey copies on Saturday about money-laundering charges against Stephen McClintock, a former employee of the TropWorld casino in Atlantic City, included an incorrect title given for him in the indictment. He was a table-games sales executive in the casino marketing division, not a vice president for marketing.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Cold May De-Corn Fourth
description: What's the Fourth of July without sweet corn? Whether the state's crop will be available for the holiday weekend, when demand and prices are highest, will depend on how warm it gets in May, Joann Russo, an owner of Russo's Fruit and Vegetable Farm, said yesterday. Farmers were late by a few days getting corn into the ground because of the wet, cool weather in early April. Yesterday's rain should not hurt the crop, unless the fields flood, preventing the next round of planting, she said.

title: Obesity Drug Approved That Fools Appetite
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved the first new anti-obesity drug in 22 years, a controversial medicine that essentially fools patients into feeling full.

title: Observer;Don't They Phone?
description: Look, I'm as tired as you are of reading about the Kennedy auction. All it proved was that my mother wasn't just whistling Dixie when she bent over my cradle and said, "A fool and his money are soon parted."

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS INC., Dallas, will exercise an option to raise its stake in T.I.-Acer, its Taiwan memory chip joint venture with Acer Inc., a Taiwan personal computer maker, to 33 percent from 26 percent.

title: The Decline And Fall Of a Roman Emperor
description: For centuries, a gilded bronze statue of Emperor Marcus Aurelius gazed calmly down from the heights of the Campidoglio, Rome's town hall square, as dictators rose and fell and Prime Ministers came and went.

title: Goetz Files for Bankruptcy, Citing Judgment in Shooting
description: Bernhard H. Goetz moved to protect his meager assets yesterday, filing for bankruptcy under Chapter 7 of the United States Bankruptcy Code.

title: McCall Is Balancing Books and Ambition
description: H. Carl McCall, New York State's chief fiscal monitor and one of its most prominent Democrats, often couches criticism in the numbingly dull language of an auditor: a mix of statistics and bureaucratic minutiae.

title: Richard Morris, Film, TV and Stage Writer, 72
description: Richard Morris, who wrote the book for the musical "The Unsinkable Molly Brown" and the screenplay for the film "Thoroughly Modern Millie," died on Saturday at the Encino-Tarzana Regional Medical Center. He was 72 and lived in Sherman Oaks, Calif.

title: Revco's Next Step Is Big Expansion
description: Revco D.S. Inc. said today that it plans to add 100 new stores next year and 150 annually after that, reviving an aggressive expansion the drugstore chain halted during the Rite Aid Corporation's unsuccessful bid for the company.

title: Children Testify in Murder Trial of Mother
description: Two children went to State Supreme Court in the Bronx yesterday to describe how their mother and father killed their younger sister Shayna, who was 4 at the time of her death two years ago.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;It's account decision time for a number of companies both big and small.
description: ADVERTISERS old and new, big and small -- including Coca-Cola, Sears, Novell and Wired magazine -- have made decisions involving accounts.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Enter Singing: Young, Hopeful And Taking On The Big Time
description: Two months, one Pulitzer Prize and acres of magazine and newspaper pages later, the waiflike hopes of the American musical are living in fancier digs. Uprooted by a cyclone of critical ecstasy and a hunger for theatrical novelty, they have posed for fashion layouts, inspired a Bloomingdale's ad campaign and will record their songs about life on the edge for David Geffen's Dreamworks label. They even have a producer who is comparing their spirit to that of -- oh, dear -- the movie "Forrest Gump."

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Nets Owners Still Plotting Future
description: Talks are continuing among the Nets' seven owners to create what is expected to be a new internal structure, with some of those who want to stay buying the shares of those who want to leave. But the prospect of selling the team to the Devils' owner, JOHN McMULLEN, or Bally Entertainment Corporation seems to be fading.

title: No Headline
description: He used to sleep all day, and walk around his property and other people's properties at night. He was pretty scary. He fired a gun off at night."

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about the producer of the documentary film "Crumb" misspelled her surname in some references. She was Lynn O'Donnell, not O'Connell

title: On My Mind;Yes, Do It, Do It
description: This column was supposed to start with the following paragraph:

title: NYC;We're No. 1: Get the Angelenos Back to the Gym
description: YOU might have noticed New York men walking with an extra bounce in their step yesterday, and the most likely reason was that they'd heard the good news: fresh scientific studies show that they may be proud carriers of the highest sperm counts in the country.

title: History Deleted
description: Some authors who use the Kennedy Library have emerged with less than warm feelings toward it. Nigel Hamilton, Stephen E. Ambrose and John H. Davis have complained that it is a captive of the Kennedy family. But it is rare to catch the library improperly censoring material because it detracts from the Kennedy image.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Brewers Agree to Defer Pay
description: Several players who were asked by the Milwaukee Brewers to defer part of their salaries until after the season said yesterday they were surprised but not troubled by the request. "If I can help them out in any way that I can, I'll be glad to do it," said BEN McDONALD, who will earn $2.5 million this season. The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel reported yesterday the team was seeking $1.5 million in deferments and sought assistance from six of its eight players who are earning more than $1 million this year.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Express PATH Service Begins
description: Express PATH service from Newark to the World Trade Center got off to a smooth start yesterday, officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said. The three express trains, which run mornings only at 7:30, 8 and 8:43 A.M., reduced the 22-minute ride by an average of 3 minutes 34 seconds, half a minute more than anticipated, said Michael DePallo, director and general manager of PATH.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Iran Building Tunnels For Missiles, U.S. Says
description: Iran is building tunnels along its Persian Gulf coast, apparently as protective storage sites for ballistic missiles, a United States official said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Government to Sell Oil From Strategic Reserve President Clinton said the Government would begin to sell about 12 million barrels of oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, in an effort to head off a surge in gasoline prices during an election year. The move was authorized in the Federal budget agreement reached last week and was envisioned as a way to cut the deficit. But the President attributed his decision to concern about the higher prices at the pump. They have risen to a national average of $1.27 for a gallon of regular from $1.16 a few weeks ago. [Page A1.] A Plan to Pool Power Purchases Electricity customers in California would benefit from a plan to form a pool to buy power competitively throughout the West. [D4.]

title: Patterns
description: Designer Boutiques in SoHo

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;The Burdens of High (and Low) Birth
description: THE LAST OF THE SAVAGES By Jay McInerney 271 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.

title: POLITICS: ADVERTISING;Business Groups Hope Ads in Pivotal Electoral States Sway Clinton on Product Liability Bill
description: In a coordinated advertising campaign running in states critical to the Presidential race, several groups financed by business are accusing President Clinton of carrying water for greedy trial lawyers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;7 Agencies Compete For Sega Account
description: Sega of America, the video game marketer owned by Sega Enterprises, said yesterday that it had named seven agencies to compete for the creative portion of its national broadcast account, with billings estimated at $20 million to $30 million. That assignment had been handled for the last five years by Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, a unit of the Omnicom Group, until that agency and Sega mutually agreed to part company this month over creative differences.

title: PERIPHERALS;A Bountiful Grab Bag of Programs
description: FOR about $30, you can get a pair of CD-ROM's with 3,062 Windows programs to try out. Yes, 3,062. Or, if you are so inclined, there's another CD-ROM for about $40 with some 2,000 scientific and technical programs. Finally, for about $15, there is a CD-ROM with a mere 1,600 Windows and DOS programs. Let's see. If you try out eight programs a day, you can get through all of the above in almost 833 days.

title: Russia Given a Deal to Repay $40 Billion Debt
description: Russia got up to seven years' more breathing space today on repaying more than $40 billion of the accumulated debt it owes to foreign governments, possibly giving another lift to President Boris N. Yeltsin's prospects for re-election this summer.

title: Contractor Set to Fix Firehouses Hid Damaging History
description: A Brooklyn construction company in line for a $31 million city contract to maintain firehouses concealed from city officials a history of underpaying workers and the fact that a major subcontractor for the job is not allowed to operate in New York State, city and state records show.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday with a front-page article about plans of the American Association of Retired Persons to license its name to health maintenance organizations misstated the organization's 1994 revenue from insurance fees and related interest income. It was $146.1 million, not $164.9 million.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Left-Handed Concertos Are a Match
description: While showing welcome interest in new music, the classical music business seems to be trying to eliminate the composer from the process. We've had operas by rock stars, oratorios by committee, even an opera ostensibly composed by a librettist. So it is good to report that when the Baltimore Symphony played three works by William Bolcom at Carnegie Hall on Sunday, the composer took center stage. Thanks to a highly irregular commissioning request, Mr. Bolcom was able to show off the true virtuosity of the art of composition, and received a virtuoso's applause.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FUNDS OF SOROS ACQUIRE STAKE IN USAIR
description: Investment funds run by the billionaire George Soros have acquired a 5.13 percent stake in the series B cumulative convertible preferred stock of USAir Group Inc. The investors paid $8.44 million to acquire 218,600 series B shares as an investment, according to a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The most recent transactions of the investment funds include the purchase of 160,000 shares at $52.61 to $53.25 each between April 10 and 18, the S.E.C. filing said. The preferred shares were unchanged yesterday at $49.25. USAir, based in Arlington, Va., is the nation's fifth-largest airline. A share of the class B stock is convertible into 2.49 common shares.

title: Home Sweet Hotel;A Cheap Room With a Kitchen for Long Stays
description: After he was appointed regional manager for the McInnes Steel Company in January, Daryl K. Boe planned on staying in a motel while he looked for an apartment. "But I was driving by here and saw a sign on a new building saying $189 a week," the 29-year-old Mr. Boe said recently, "so I stopped to check it out and here I am."

title: Sports of The Times;A Course In History, Not Econ
description: THIS season marks the 20th anniversary of Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's decision to pull up stakes in Milwaukee and move west to Los Angeles. Abdul-Jabbar embarked on a 14-year run that included five National Basketball Association championships, one of the great legacies for winning in professional sports.

title: Stocks Lowerin Tokyo
description: Stocks traded lower here today. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 193.73 points, or more than eight-tenths of 1 percent, at 22,041.30. There was no trading on Monday because of a holiday, Greenery Day. On Friday, the Nikkei finished up 4.93.

title: Off-Duty Officer Arrested on Harrassment Count in Dispute
description: An off-duty New York City police officer was arrested on Saturday night on a harassment charge after a dispute on the block where he lives in Roslyn Heights, the Nassau County police said today.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;New Chechen Leader Is Now Reported Dead
description: Just a week after Russian forces killed the separatist Chechen leader, Dzhokhar M. Dudayev, Russian news reports said that the rebel chief's successor had died at the hands of his comrades.

title: Four Months Into Its Budget Year, the U.N. Says It Is Broke
description: Only four months into its budget year, the United Nations is out of money for daily operating expenses and will have to borrow from cash set aside for peacekeeping, the organization's chief financial officer said today.

title: Barenboim's Other Musical Roots Pack Parisians In: The Tango
description: While learning the piano as a child in Buenos Aires in the late 1940's, Daniel Barenboim naturally played classical music. Yet the music he often heard on records and on the radio was the tango, especially the haunting tales of love, betrayal, mischief and nostalgia sung by Carlos Gardel. And when the family moved to Israel in 1952, young Daniel carried this music with him.

title: POLITICS: THE DRUG WAR;In Florida, Clinton Says He'll Widen The Battle
description: Moving once more to head off any Republican attempt to tar him as soft on crime, President Clinton came to South Florida today to highlight his Administration's renewed drug control efforts, with a particular emphasis on discouraging young people from using illegal drugs.

title: MCI Offers a Set of Communications Services on One Bill
description: The MCI Communications Corporation announced yesterday that it would offer consumers a bundle of communications services, from long distance to paging to Internet access, on a single bill.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Last year, it was Windows 95 for BILL GATES; this year it's Baby 96. MELINDA FRENCH GATES, 31, the wife of the founder and chairman of the Microsoft Corporation and a Microsoft executive herself, gave birth to an 8-pound, 6-ounce girl on Friday at Overlake Hospital in Bellevue, Wash., The Associated Press reported. The baby has been named Jennifer Katherine.

title: Q&A
description: Tree Roots

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Growth Forecast Is Cut By German Institutes
description: Germany's six leading economic research institutes slashed their forecasts yesterday for economic growth in 1996 to three-quarters of 1 percent from the 2.5 percent they predicted six months ago. The institutes also criticized the Bonn Government, saying its drive to cut spending and qualify for the single European currency could limit any recovery. (Reuters)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: Provident Agrees to Acquire Paul Revere for $1.2 Billion
description: The Provident Companies, the No. 2 seller of individual disability insurance policies, agreed yesterday to buy the No. 1 insurer in the field in a deal that would give it more than one-third of the market.

title: By Design;Dressing for a Hole-in-One
description: Back in the 1920's and 30's, dressing to play golf was a fashionable activity. Then it became a matter of plaid pants and polo shirts. But things are looking up. Both Ralph Lauren and Giorgio Armani have designed golf wear that is chic while adhering to the dress regulations of many country clubs: no T-shirts or short shorts, for example, and no patterns other than plaids or stripes.

title: S.E.C. Charges 3 At Kendall Square
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a formal complaint today against the Kendall Square Research Corporation and three of its former top executives, charging them with fraud.

title: Trojan Gold's Fate
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Chinese Fair Showcases An Old Taboo: Lingerie
description: Beneath China," an international exhibition that opened here last week with a name suggesting archeology or history, was actually a showcase for underwear.

title: ON BASEBALL;Cone Finds a Comfort Zone
description: David Cone is living proof that timing is everything. In a less perfect world, the Yankee right-hander would have been petrified this past weekend to learn he had circulatory problems in his pitching hand. Yet Cone was strangely serene, as if a protective shield about him assured everything would be all right.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MERCK-MEDCO MANAGED CARE TO BUY SYSTEMED
description: Merck-Medco Managed Care Inc., a unit of Merck & Company, said yesterday that it would acquire Systemed Inc. for about $67 million, or $3 a share. Systemed, based in Torrance, Calif., manages pharmacy benefit programs for employers, insurers and government agencies. The company also operates a mail-order pharmacy in Des Moines and a claims-processing business in Cleveland. Systemed had sales of $152 million and net income of $4.3 million last year. Systemed shares fell 31.25 cents, to $2.8125, in Nasdaq trading. Merck-Medco is based in Whitehouse Station, N.J.

title: COMPANY NEWS;RHODES CONSIDERS SALE OF COMPANY AND HIRES SALOMON
description: Rhodes Inc. said yesterday that it was considering a sale of the company, a move that comes after it recently purchased two rival furniture retailers. Rhodes, an Atlanta-based home furnishings retailer, said it had hired the investment firm Salomon Brothers Inc. to advise the company in looking for a buyer or to consider other strategies. Shares of Rhodes rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $10.75, giving the company an indicated current value of just under $100 million. The company operates 109 furniture retail stores in 15 states. Late last year, Rhodes acquired 21 furniture stores and two distribution centers from Weberg Enterprises Inc. for $32 million. It also purchased the Glick Furniture Company for an undisclosed price.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;China Is Buying Into Hong Kong Airlines
description: Companies controlled by the Government of China said yesterday that they would pay $8.27 billion (Hong Kong), or $1.07 billion (United States), for stakes in both Hong Kong airlines, breaking a 48-year hold on the industry by the British-run Swire Pacific Ltd. A little more than a year before the British colony reverts to Chinese rule, Citic Pacific Ltd., the Hong Kong arm of China's biggest overseas investment company, will increase its stake in Cathay Pacific Airways to 25 percent from 10 percent. At the same time, China National Aviation, a branch of China's aviation regulator, will acquire a controlling stake in Hong Kong Dragon Airlines Ltd., now largely owned by Swire, Cathay and Citic Pacific.

title: Ex-New Jersey Prosecutor Is Called Cheat and Bully
description: The Federal Government portrayed a former prosecutor of Somerset County today as a cheat and a bully who defrauded his partner in a gasoline station and the Internal Revenue Service, and once threatened to plant cocaine in a gasoline wholesaler's car.

title: TV SPORTS;Fox Is Playing It Safe With N.H.L.
description: Don't puzzle long over why NBC aired a tripleheader of National Basketball Association playoff games from 12:30 P.M. to 8 P.M. Sunday, while Fox split the nation in three to show regional National Hockey League playoff action at 3 P.M.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;ABB Posts 19% Rise In First-Quarter Profit
description: Asea Brown Boveri said yesterday that its profit rose 19 percent in the first quarter, to $219 million, compared with $184 million in the first quarter of 1995. ABB, the Swiss-Swedish engineering company whose products include industrial robots and power stations, said it expected cost-cutting and "good growth" in emerging markets to continue to have a positive impact on earnings this year, even as overall order growth slows.

title: The Pro-Immigration Lobby
description: The forces in favor of reducing legal as well as illegal immigration roared into Washington like a speeding train last year. The momentum appeared to be unstoppable. Polls showed that Americans overwhelmingly favored reductions in the number of legal migrants. Support came from a bipartisan reform commission led by the late Barbara Jordan, from President Clinton and from Republican and Democratic lawmakers, who introduced bills to change the current policy, which brought in 720,000 legal immigrants last year.

title: 3 Big Funds for '98 Governor's Race
description: H. Carl McCall, the New York State Comptroller, is not the only politician gearing up for a possible gubernatorial candidacy in 1998.

title: HORSE RACING;Stable Upbeat Despite Favorite's Injury
description: For the first time in 12 years, a full field of 20 horses is considered likely for the Kentucky Derby, which will be run here Saturday with Unbridled's Song still the favorite despite what his trainer conceded today to be a quarter-crack of the left front hoof.

title: Bombing Suspects Lose Bid for Secret Files
description: The judge in the Oklahoma City bombing case refused today to order American intelligence agencies to turn over classified information that the suspects' lawyers say might link the bombing to international terrorism and help their defense.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Big Newspapers Report Circulation Losses Are Slowing
description: Most of the country's biggest daily newspapers lost circulation in the six months ended March 31 compared with the similar period a year earlier, according to nationwide figures released yesterday. But the declines were smaller than in the past for many and were offset by impressive gains by The Wall Street Journal, USA Today and The Daily News in New York.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Seles Sues Over Stabbing Incident
description: One day before the three-year statute of limitations was to expire, MONICA SELES filed a $16 million claim yesterday for lost earnings against the organizers of the Citizens Cup tournament in Hamburg, Germany, where she was stabbed.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FORD MOTOR PLANS PILOT PROGRAM FOR LINCOLNS
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it planned to begin a pilot plan for its Lincoln luxury car division in four areas of the United States. Called Lincoln Assured, the program would put Lincoln Town Cars, Continentals and Mark VIII's that are less than two years old and have fewer than 36,000 miles through a 150-point inspection process. Cars that qualify for the program will be resold with a minimum bumper-to-bumper warranty of two years, or 24,000 miles -- or the balance of the original factory warranty, whichever is longer. The six-month program, to be started in late May or early June, will be available to Lincoln dealers in Atlanta, Dallas-Fort Worth, St. Louis and the Tampa, Clearwater, St. Petersburg area of Florida.

title: China Boosts Cathay Pacific Stake
description: Responding to growing pressure from business interests on the Chinese mainland, Swire Pacific Ltd. said Monday that it would sell more of Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific Airways to a partner who is ultimately answerable to Beijing's ruling State Council.

title: BASKETBALL;Manhattan Picks Leonard
description: For the third time in his basketball career, John Leonard is packing his duffel bags and heading to Manhattan College. Leonard, a former player and assistant coach at Manhattan, today will return to the Riverdale campus, where he will officially be named the new head coach.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;Loves, Lost And Never Tasted
description: Richard Thompson

title: Orville Prescott, Times Book Critic for 24 Years, Dies at 89
description: Orville Prescott, principal daily book critic for The New York Times for 24 years and a considerable force in the literary world, died on Sunday at his home in New Canaan, Conn. He was 89.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Two's a Crowd for Ritter As a Violent Husband
description: Family abuse gets still another television-movie treatment in tonight's "Unforgivable" on CBS. One underlying purpose: perhaps what "The Burning Bed" did for the stalled career of Farrah Fawcett back in 1984, "Unforgivable" can do for the currently unfocused screen image of John Ritter. Not quite. Mr. Ritter, still best known for his comic finesse in "Three's Company," does indeed turn in a powerfully impressive performance, but the film itself, based on a true story, is far too schematic, preachy and predictable.

title: California Measure Could Trump U.S. Law on Securities Suits
description: A small cadre of the nation's leading trial lawyers have mounted a bold effort to use a California ballot initiative to make an end run around a law enacted by Congress last year that restricts their ability to bring lawsuits when a company's share prices drop suddenly.

title: A Campus Appetite for a la Carte;Student Tastes Lead Yale to Consider Menus of Other Colleges
description: Fifty years ago, Yale students, dressed in jackets and ties, were served dinner on fine china by waiters and waitresses in majestic Gothic dining halls. A typical menu in 1937 featured broiled loin lamb chops and tenderloin steak.

title: Computer Deal Would Create No. 3 Company For Services
description: Battling to keep up with the big boys in computer services, the Computer Sciences Corporation has agreed to pay a generous $1.4 billion in stock for the Continuum Company, which handles such chores for banks and insurers, the companies said today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Cabby Held in Fare's Death
description: Prosecutors have become accustomed to the sad fact that driving a cab is a hazardous occupation. But Edward M. Neafsey, Acting Prosecutor for Union County, said yesterday that he had never before charged a cabdriver with killing his fare. The cabby, Sylvester McDaniel Jr. of Rahway, was accused of fatally stabbing Stephen Roseberry of Linden on Sunday morning after he refused to pay for the ride in advance, Mr. Neafsey said.

title: Eating Less May Bring Longer Life
description: Reducing calories by 30 percent appears to slow the rate of aging in monkeys, providing new evidence that humans might live longer by eating less.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Volvo Profits Lower On Reduced Sales
description: The Swedish automotive company A.B. Volvo said yesterday that its profits were down in the first quarter but slightly better than expected. The car and truck maker's first-quarter profit of 1.92 billion kronor, or $284.9 million, was barely half of the 3.67 billion kronor reported for the corresponding period last year, but better than the market forecast of 1.8 billion kronor.

title: BASEBALL;Yanks and Orioles: Two Teams Much Too Close for Comfort
description: Both teams have payrolls close to $50 million. Both have outspoken owners who want the players on those fat payrolls to produce a championship. Both have new managers who once made out the lineup card for the Mets. The Yankees and the Orioles are shadows, but, more important, they are adversaries who should hound each other all season.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DISCOVERY TO ACQUIRE THE NATURE COMPANY
description: Discovery Communications Inc., which operates the Discovery Channel on cable television, plans to buy the Nature Company from CML Group Inc. for $40 million in cash, the companies said yesterday. The Nature Company, in Berkeley, Calif., is a specialty retail chain and mail-order business selling nature-related books, toys and games. The deal includes 114 Nature Company stores and three Scientific Revolution stores. Discovery, a privately held company based in Bethesda, Md., is owned by the Liberty Media Corporation, Cox Communications Inc., Advance/Newhouse Communications and John S. Hendricks, founder, chairman and chief executive of Discovery.

title: Reynolds Expands Test of Smokeless Cigarette
description: The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company said yesterday that it had begun inviting smokers in Chattanooga, Tenn., to try Eclipse, its nearly smokeless cigarette.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Expansion Is Slow In Quarter in Britain
description: The British economy expanded by 2 percent in the first quarter compared with the corresponding quarter last year. It was the slowest rate of growth since the third quarter of 1993. Compared with the previous quarter, the expansion was four-tenths of 1 percent. Analysts had expected quarterly growth of five-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Richard Granelli, 90, Designer Of Major Architectural Project1
description: Richard H. Granelli, an architectural designer who helped draft prestigious projects like Rockefeller Center and the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, died on Sunday at his home in Brewster, N.Y. He was 90.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Bill Reignites A Debate On Lead Risk
description: After a decade of failed attempts to modify laws protecting children from lead-paint poisoning, the City Council began wrestling with the difficult issue again yesterday, debating a bill that would drastically scale back a city program for removing lead-based paint from thousands of apartments.

title: Abb Rejoins Holocaust Battle
description: PARIS  The Roman Catholic hierarchy dissociated itself Monday from France's most popular defender of the poor, the Abbe Pierre, after he reiterated his support for a book questioning the Holocaust.

title: Sales of New Homes Fell 7.6% in March
description: Rising interest rates bit substantially into sales of new homes in March, driving them down by 7.6 percent, to an annual rate of 672,000, the slowest since last May, the Departments of Commerce and Housing and Urban Development reported today.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about newspaper competition in the New York area misstated the latest circulation figures for Newsday and The New York Times. Corrected figures appear today in an article about circulation trends at the country's largest dailies. (Business Day, page D8.)

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;A Victim's Taped Prediction
description: Opening statements began yesterday in a murder trial in which the victim's taped conversation with the murder suspects is expected to play a part. "If I don't come back, they know who to look for," a laughing Debra Smith-Davis of Hackettstown tells her fiance, Frank Zollo, on a tape that prosecutors say was made weeks before her death. "You'll drag me into the woods and kill me."

title: ON GOLF;Seeking a Sport's No. 1 Moment
description: Since we're between major championships, and since golf clubs and grill rooms across the frozen north are thawing out and preparing for the busy season, the timing is right to examine a topic sure to generate a little more heat.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Why Jackson Keeps On Stumping
description: Why can't Jesse stop running? Tonight's 90-minute "Frontline" biography -- drawn from Marshall Frady's book, "Jesse: His Life and Pilgrimage," to be published in June by Random House -- tries to answer that question. But finally you're left to decide whether the politician-preacher-performer is driven more by his mission or by his ego.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bond Prices End Lower in Dull Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell in dull trading yesterday, despite a report that showed rising interest rates severely hampering housing sales.
